column2: NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 27 -- Indian friends of the United States are hoping Washington will seize the exceptional opportunity presented at the forthcoming United Nations General Assembly session in New York to increase goodwill between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A new type of Government study designed to give the first official breakdown of how the consumer's dollar goes for labor, materials, distribution costs and profits on things bought at retail was ordered today by President Truman.

A river in the hill-lands is a beautiful thing at any time of year, but in late September it is a stream of wonder, changing day by day and even hour by hour. That is the wonder of it, the change, the moods reflected and even magnified; and beyond that is the freight, large and small, that it brings from the distant hills and carries silently past to deposit in the lower valleys.
" Vigorous" is the word for Prof. Gregory Dexter Walcott, chairman of the Philosophy Department at Long Island University.

Frank Sauchelli, a workhorse of a back from Newark, booted a 27yard field goal with 17 seconds remaining to enable Hugh Devore's New York University football team to gain a thrilling 10-to-7 triumph over the Lehigh Engineers at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 -- Navy won its opening football game of the season today, conquering Yale, 31 to 0, at Memorial Stadium before a crowd of 25,000, including 3,800 midshipmen.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Federal and state inspectors are at work across the Cotton Belt with a machine that can help head off losses for thousands of farmers.

More than 1,000 teachers of Catholic elementary parochial schools attended curriculum courses given during the summer by staff members of accredited representatives of the Commission on American Citizenship.

IT takes something, maybe just character, to become a legend while still on the sunny side of the wheel chair and the cane. Tallulah Bankhead is such. She could drop the last part of her name and go along on the Tallulah, with banks duly honoring that signature, and the law prepared to stop patent infringement.

VERONA, Italy -- In this small, highly developed city set deep in a rich countryside on the main road to Venice, the fall harvest season is at hand. It is the best time of year here, with a climate much like the American Indian summer -- a time when the traveler will find the field clear after the dust of many touring feet has settled.

Both as a Professor of Law and a citizen I was deeply shocked by the televised Nixon apologia. The spectacle of a young man, confronted with what even the most charitable among us would call the product of bad judgment, resorting to demagoguery was a sordid and shameful experience.

ALBANY, Sept. 27 -- The State Army and Air National Guard and Naval Militia Association urged Congress today to require that draftees who have served two years outside combat areas be inducted into National Guard units after their discharge.

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 27 -- After surprising a highly favored St. Lawrence University eleven by scoring a pair of first-period touchdowns, Union College lost, 20 -- 19, to the Larries today in the opening game for both teams.

THE settlers at Plymouth in 1620 were fortunate in having in their number a historian who could do justice to their heroic enterprise. William Bradford's history of the "Plantation," now edited by Professor Morison, is by common consent not only a historical document of the first importance but the first "classic" in our literature. Bradford was an English farmer's son and had little formal education, but he loved books and knew his Bible well.

MUCH information has been crammed into this volume. Will Oursler, author and former police reporter, and Laurence Dwight Smith, who has worked closely with the Secret Service, have pushed aside many dusty curtains to lay bare sordid-operations in the United States.
The financial news headlines last week told of how the nation's investors responded with unprecedented interest to the offering of $170,719,000 of new public housing bonds.

BRISK and provocative, this study of bureaucratic and farm organization politics deals mainly with three divergent campaigns for soil conservation. The Extension Service operates through the land-grant colleges, a method stoutly supported by the powerful American Farm Bureau Federation.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Tony Rados outpassed Purdue's vaunted Dale Samuels to enable Penn State to come from behind in the final five minutes today and tie the Boilermakers, 20 -- 20.

MISS HALSEY has written this book on behalf of her child, and by moral social definition all children, "the most important group of people bar none, in the United States." In it she examines the structure of American business society, whose values, she feels, have created the neurotic personality, the American schizophrenia and anxiety, a heritage she is anxious not to pass on.
DENVER, Sept. 27 -- The problem of the United States Mint's Denver branch really would not perturb most of us. It simply has got too much gold.
DETROIT, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Barring a last minute change in plans, at least two and possibly three of next year's passenger automobiles will boast engines developing more than 200 horsepower.

AROUND Sarasota, Fla., where the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus goes into winter quarters, Fred Bradna is an imposing and beloved sight. Now 80, he is nevertheless keen and erect, his thinning brown hair is close-trimmed in the German military way, his attire is eye-catching and starchy.

LIKE many another man, outwardly upstanding, John Steinbeck carries around with him a wide streak of self-confessed madness. In his case, this takes the form of wanting to write plays. Since his normal trade is that of being a serious novelist, it is only natural that the plays to which he aspires would be comedies.

WASHINGTON -- A special term for one of the more dangerous types of motorist was coined by Thomas W. Ryan, New York State's Director of Safety, in an address before the New York State Automobile Association, meeting here last week in joint assembly with the American Automobile Association.

AS a novelist, Clyde Brion Davis always savors his materials; he likes the people he writes about. This is precisely the strength of "Thudbury," a sprawling, ironical study of a medium-sized American city and the people who made it go during the past fifty years.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Following is a list of those who donated, and the amounts they gave, to the 1948 Gubernatorial campaign fund of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois -- the fund whose balance was used for gifts to supplement the pay of eight top state officials -- (addresses are Chicago unless otherwise indicated):

LONDON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- The United States Embassy reported today that George F. Kennan, American Ambassador to Moscow, would leave London tomorrow for "about two weeks" of conferences in Bonn, Paris and Geneva. Dispatches from Moscow said Mr. Kennan originally had planned to return Oct. 7.

WHEN Pablo Casals and his cohorts engaged in music-making two summers ago at Perpignan, a group of engineers from Columbia Records were standing by with microphones, tape recorders and the other paraphernalia so dear to their hearts.

" I don't think I've ever ridden a better horse." That's what Eric Guerin said yesterday after Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's great 2-year-old colt Native Dancer, in a superlative performance that equaled the world record for six and a half furlongs over a straight course, had carried him to a two-and-a-quarterlength victory in the $107,545 Futurity at sunny, windy Belmont Park.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Spray trees and shrubs susceptible to various scale insects. An application of nicotine sulfate now will kill scale insects while they are feeding on leaves and twigs and reduce the number that crawl into crevices of trees and shrubs to hibernate. Larch, maple, lilac, camellia are prime targets.

WHEN Pablo Casals and his cohorts engaged in music-making two summers ago at Perpignan, a group of engineers from Columbia Records were standing by with microphones, tape recorders and the other paraphernalia so dear to their hearts.

" I don't think I've ever ridden a better horse." That's what Eric Guerin said yesterday after Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's great 2-year-old colt Native Dancer, in a superlative performance that equaled the world record for six and a half furlongs over a straight course, had carried him to a two-and-a-quarterlength victory in the $107,545 Futurity at sunny, windy Belmont Park.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Spray trees and shrubs susceptible to various scale insects. An application of nicotine sulfate now will kill scale insects while they are feeding on leaves and twigs and reduce the number that crawl into crevices of trees and shrubs to hibernate. Larch, maple, lilac, camellia are prime targets.
DETROIT, Sept. 27 (AP) -- With the championship race pressure off, the Indians romped to victory over the Tigers, 11 to 6, today in the first of a two-game series.

ONE test to determine if the fictional barrier between the ordinary mystery and the suspense novel has been crossed is: How many bodies -- dead and/or nude -- has the author strewn about? Mark Derby, the pseudonymous credit on "Element of Risk," has leaped the hurdles nicely.

THIS violent tale bears a striking surface resemblance to "Mutiny on the Bounty." Like the Nordhoff and Hall classic, it is based on an actual Pacific mutiny, and the subsequent, well-documented trial of the renegades.
SEATTLE, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Brawny Bill Earley and an unexpectedly potent defensive platoon carried Washington to a 19-13 intersectional football victory today over Minnesota before a crowd of 49,000.

Godfrey Macdonald, vice president of the Grace Line in charge of passenger traffic, received the company's thirty-year service medal in a ceremony held last week at which officials of the line and of W. R. Grace Co. were present. J. Peter Grace Jr., president of W. R. Grace, presented the medal.
STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe today strongly demanded a pledge of "equal security" for all members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Last week more than 10,000 surgeons, other physicians, and technical experts met in New York at the thirty-eighth annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons to hear reports on recent advances in all phases of surgery.

A STUDY of metropolitan waterfront crime, "A Funeral for Sabella" is done very much in the manner of the sort of movie "documentary" that includes an element of fiction. Although the city of the story is not identified, it resembles New York in many ways, especially in that its more sinister minor characters call to mind some of the faces that flitted across the television screen during the Kefauver hearings last year.
Baseball, having moved itself more or less to the sidelines for one brief week-end, sweeps back on the sports scene this week with its last grand flourish of the year -the annual world series.

ONE of the fall garden chores is the division of perennials which have grown into large clumps. Not every perennial needs division every year, but now is a good time to look over the border and decide which ones do.

THERE is no doubt that Mr. Hoover always has had a case in defense of his ill-starred administration; but when he comes to make it it turns out too good a one. This is the third -- and we hope not the final -- volume of a fascinating series of memoirs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A coffin containing the body of a dead United States airman was dropped into the ocean yesterday to prevent a giant stratofreighter plane from crashing into the Atlantic with thirty-seven persons, the Air Force announced tonight.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- There are a lot of beef cattle coming to market these days. Farmers are getting less money for them, too. But that doesn't mean meat on the consumer's table is going to be much cheaper.

GENEVA, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Brooklyn College's football team was routed by Hobart , 48-12, in the season's opener for both teams today. The victory was Hobart's first in an opening game since 1941 when they beat Union, 14-0.

A partly dear veteran who suffered a 60 per cent hearing disability in World War II was shot twice early yesterday on a Brooklyn street when an enraged hold-up man mistook his failure to heed a command as unwillingness to comply.

PARENTS always face a problem when a teen-age son takes up speed as a hobby. Pete Elliot's parents, in this book, are more understanding than most. With relief they watch their son tire of irresponsible hot-rod racing.

The "Nixon affair," which culminated last week in the unprecedented television and radio broadcast in which the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee made his accounting and defense of the $18,235 private expense fund contributed by a group of Californians, has become the news high-light of this hard-fought and uncertain Presidential campaign.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 27 -- Ideal fall weather today brought out one of the largest opening-day crowds at the Danbury Fair in its eighty-nine-year history. A crowd estimated at 25,000 visited the grounds at mid-afternoon and more persons were still passing through the turnstiles.
SEATTLE, Sept. 27 -- More than 1,000 recreation leaders of the United States and Canada were gathering here today for the week-long National Recreation Congress, which opens Monday night.

WHEN a packed moving van lumbers to a stop before an empty house, it is like a Pied Piper, calling out the neighborhood children to supervise the unloading. It happens on any street, in any town, and is cause for much comment and excitement -- except, perhaps, for the child whose furniture is being unloaded.

VERY likely the most disturbing element in this first novel, at once an elementary investigation into misceability and the darkling subconconscious of a young man, is a painful sincerity of an author wrestling with what look like two mutually exclusive themes.

HARTFORD, Sept. 27 -- Republican leaders in Connecticut declare they have discovered "overwhelming irregularities" in petitions filed by Miss Vivien Kellems for a place on the Nov. 4 election ballot as an independent candidate for the United States Senate.

This country would like to be self-sufficient in such a commodity as wax -- used in polishes, carbon paper, shoe dressings, textiles, fruit protection, castings and the like -- and has pushed research in new sources with considerable success in recent years.

A large variety of attractive furniture, silver, enamels and other art objects will be auctioned in two sales this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. Another sale, of American and other books collected by the late George Bird Grinell, will begin the series of sales on Tuesday and Wednesday.

MUNSAN, Korea, Sunday, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of three proposals handed to Communist truce negotiators in Korea by Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr., senior United Nations armistice delegate:

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Sept. 27 -- A North Korean Army lieutenant who deserted three weeks ago from his job as chief of Communist security forces at Panmunjom said today that he had seen Russians on anti-aircraft positions in North Korea and had heard that the Katusha multiple-rocket gun, used by the Russians against the Germans in World War II, was on its way to the Korean front.

At Cornell University experiments in the freshman and sophomore physics courses are to be televised. Students cannot stay home, however; they will have to be present in the classroom. Where the television will come into play is in projecting experiments from the instructor's desk to viewing screens visible from all corners of the room.

THE most difficult problem in cleaning Rembrandt paintings is the psychological one," says Murray Pease, associate curator in conservation and technical research at the Metropolitan. He means, of course, that the public has been conditioned for so many years to seeing Rembrandts submerged in the golden glow of tinted and darkened varnish that they ofter fear a painting which has simply been freed of this obscuring veil has been "over-cleaned."
The first complete revision of the King James Version of the Holy Bible in fifty-one years will be published on Tuesday.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson on his political funds:

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Kansas City Blues of the American Association got off to a winning start in the Little World Series tonight, hitting effectively behind their ace pitcher, Ed Erautt, to down the Rochester Red Wings of the International League, 5 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Government's plans to challenge Charles Chaplin when he returns from a trip abroad show every promise of providing dramatic chapters both for the actor's not uneventful career story, and for the history of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service.

DORTMUND, Germany, Sept. 27 -- Erich Ollenhauer, considered the shrewdest political strategist of the West German Social Democratic party, was elected today as chairman of the party and confidently predicted that he would lead it to victory in next year's general election.

TO a generation used to publications on sex which ignore both esthetic and philosophical considerations, the scope and grace of Havelock Ellis' posthumous essays should seem like a magical re-creation of the dignity of the Victorian Age without the restricting narrowness Ellis so vigorously battled.

AN author with both poetry and prose to his credit and a physician (German-born and German-trained) who has been both a general practitioner and a specialist (dermatology and geriatrics), Dr. Martin Gumpert shows every indication in "You and Your Doctor" that he has pride and respect for his calling and those who call on him.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Sept. 27 -- Wesleyan University continued its domination over Middlebury College by downing the Panthers, 33 to 6, before a homecoming crowd of 3,000 at Porter Field today.

T. Lamar Caudle came to prominence last year when the corruption scandals in Washington were at their hottest. As Assistant District Attorney in charge of the Tax Division of the Justice Department Mr. Caudle had figured in a number of cases where prosecution was allegedly lax.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 -- U. C. L. A.'s Paul Cameron provided the spark today to spur the Bruins to a 14-to-0 victory over Texas Christian.

EVERY four years, about this time, the word "apathy" enjoys a widespread popularity. Political apathy, so called, is everywhere deplored; everywhere the effort is made to overcome it. Streetcar posters and the back covers of magazines, paid for by irreproachably nonpartisan organization, sound the call for a heightened interest in polities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Theron Lamar Caudle came to Washington from North Carolina in July, 1945. If he had stayed in North Carolina, where he was born June 22, 1904, he undoubtedly would have been a prosperous lawyer and he might have become a judge, or the Governor of his state.

DESCRIBING his book on James Russell Lowell as an experiment, Leon Howard says he has used "the life and works of a man who is not particularly fascinating to anybody's first glance" to shed a light on human nature and society.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 -- Although steel operations were off slightly this week, employment continued to register new highs for the year in this area. Claims for unemployment compensation totaled 4,816, a decline of 150 from the previous 1952 high established one week earlier.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 27 (UP) -- Tennessee, its flashing offensive backs of 1951 departed, went back to its old game of waiting for breaks today and finally got one in the fourth period to take a hard-earned 14-to-7 victory over Mississippi State.

OSLO, Sept. 27 -- The largest and most powerful fleet that has cruised in the North Sea since World War I dispersed this week after participating for twelve days in the NATO Exercise Mainbrace, the first training exercise of its kind and the first in which the new Atlantic Command of NATO has participated.
From the University of Chicago last week came the report of an astronomer who has developed a new and possibly superior method for studying the interior of the human head and abdomen with X-rays.

PEOPLE seem hard put to find the right term to describe Hemingway's "The Old Man and the Sea." Your reviewer inaccurately characterizes it as a novella. We have larded our critical vocabulary with several cognates: novela, Novelle, novella, nouvelle, novel and novelette, and our standard authorities (Webster and New English Dictionary) have not caught up with our cosmopolitanism.

THERE was a time when the "teachers' convention" was one of the events of the bridge year. There were six thousand professional bridge teachers in the United States, and two or three times each year they assembled to hear the latest dicta of auction bridge authorities, like Milton Work and Wilbur Whitehead, and later of contract bridge authorities like Ely Culbertson and Hal Sims.

ABOARD THE EISENHOWER SPECIAL, Sept. 27 -- The Nixon story has changed many things, but it hasn't changed the date of the month, and it probably hasn't changed the basic issues of the Presidential campaign.

ABOARD SPARKMAN PLANE, Sept. 27 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, voluntarily set forth his personal financial condition today as "an act of good faith" with the American people.

George Wilson, an outfielder, made his debut as a Giant first baseman yesterday at the Polo Grounds, and the experiment will always be recalled with a shudder by those who saw it. For, it was an easy pop foul that George overran and muffed that influenced a victory for the Philllies over Leo Durocher's team. The count was 7 to 3.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 27 -- The body of Mrs. Margaret Ellis, 42 years old, of 91 Ivy Way, this place, wife of Samuel Ellis, who is president of the Port Washington Board of Education, was found drowned today at 10:30 A. M. in reeds near Manhasset Bay Estates Beach.

OSLO, Norway, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway and Admiral Lynde D. McCormick, ranking Atlantic Pact officers, said today Operation Mainbrace had disclosed several weaknesses in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

We call to the attention of our readers and of the concerned city officials a letter published on this page today from Miss Dorris Clarke, chief probation officer of the Magistrates' Courts. We subscribe heartily to the views expressed. On a number of occasions we have made appeals for the probation officers, and it is a source of regret that, although there has been some improvement in salaries, justice has not been done.

Senator Richard M. Nixon's explanation of his privately contributed $18,235 expense fund, made last Tuesday night in a television and radio speech, gave impetus to the Republican campaign, reports from correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in forty-eight states indicate.

DORTMUND, Germany, Sept. 28 -- West Germany's Socialist party, the Social Democrats, today agreed to a proposal by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer that the Bundestag debate on the Saar's future, scheduled for Wednesday, be postponed until after the Federal Government has tried to sell new proposals on the Saar's future to the French Government.

Yom Kippur, or the Day of Atonement, the most solemn occasion of the Jewish year, began at sundown last night with the reverent strains of the Kol Nidre chant and will end at sundown tonight with the blowing of the shofar, or ram's horn.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Sept. 28 (AP) -- A special faculty committee was named today to study loyalty review procedures at the Pennsylvania State College which resulted in the dismissal of one faculty member.

In an effort to help the drug trade and related industries plan their advertising for markets during periods offering greatest sales opportunities, the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, has developed a novel program.
Major league baseball attendance declined nearly 9 per cent in 1952 over 1951, a United Press survey showed yesterday.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 29 -- The Communists in effect rejected yesterday new United Nations proposals for an exchange of prisoners to end a deadlock in the long-drawn-out negotiations at Panmunjom and to achieve an armistice in the Korean war.
Seven new films, including importations from France and Italy, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 28 -- Throughout India today 320,000,000 Hindus celebrated the traditional season of the end of the monsoon rains in festivals marked by the parading of the garishly painted effigies of such deities as the ten-armed goddess Durga, Mother Earth, and the forty-foot tall Ravana, demon king of Lanka.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 29 -- Britain's most famous Liberal daily newspaper, The Manchester Guardian, turned over a new leaf this morning by appearing with news instead of advertising on its front page for the first time since its foundation in 1821.

As the Yankees and Dodgers prepare for their fourth world series meeting in othe last twelve years, starting Wednesday at Ebbets Field, that advantage in pitching which more than anything else enabled the Bombers to make off with the winners' share in the first three seems more pronounced than ever.

Statements of Senator Taft in his speech at Springfield, Ohio, on Sept. 17 are shocking. They show either woeful ignorance on the part of the Senator or a perversion of the truth, to me incredible in a man of his character. His campaigning ardor for General Eisenhower has certainly swept him off his feet.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 25 (delayed by censor) -- Venezuela's two opposition parties have started, in spite of restrictions on activity, to take part in campaigning for the elections Nov. 30 for a Constituent Assembly. It will be the opposition's first chance in five years to test its voting strength.

OLD STURBRIDGE VILLAGE, Mass., Sept. 28 -- In this re-created eighteenth century village a two-day town meeting was ended today at which nine articles dealing with a present-day warrant were discussed by delegates from six New England states and representatives of Federal departments and agencies.

A 12 1/2-cent subway fare, plus imposition of special assessments on real estate to be collected with the regular realty tax, has been proposed as a method of wiping out the huge annual operating deficits of the municipal transit system.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The fall in Government securities has completely dominated and depressed the stock markets in the last few days. Practically half of a very substantial rise which had occurred in the preceding three months was lost and on one day the decline was one of the sharpest which has occurred this year.

Yesterday was certainly Alicia Alonso's day in the Ballet Theatre's season at the Metropolitan Opera House. In the afternoon she gave an enormously winning and skillful performance of the soubrettish heroine of "La Fille Mal Gardee"; in the evening she stepped from a coruscating presentation of "Swan Lake" directly into the morbid melodramatics of Agnes de Mille's "Fall River Legend" and left the audience shouting both times.
Discussions of books and films that tell the story of America will begin at branches of the New York Public Library on Wednesday.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 28 -Ch. Toplight Template of Twin Ponds, a 3-year-old imported Welsh terrier owned by Mrs. E. P. Alker of Great Neck, repeated his best-in-show victory of a year ago in the thirtieth event of the Westbury Kennel Association today.

CAIRO, Sept. 28 -- In a broadcast Fathy Radwan, Minister of State and leader of the Nationalist party, lashed out today at the Wafd and its leader, former Premier Nahas, for defying thte present regime.

EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 28 -- Henry Crown, chairman of Material Service Corporation said tonight that any inference that his $5,000 contribution to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's 1948 Gubernatorial fund had "any business significance is definitely unfair."

PITTSBURGH Sept. 28 (UP) -- Adrian Burk's aerial repertory and Bob Walston's artful toe led the Philadelphia Eaggles to a 31-25 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers today in a National Football League opener before 24,501 fans.

LOS ANGELES, Sept 28 (UP) -- Thirteen thousand striking machinists today heeded an urgent back-to-work plea by President Truman and agreed to resume vital fighter plane production at the Douglas Aircraft Company's El Segundo plant during new negotiations in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A House Appropriations subcommittee today reported a "tremendous amount of good work" has gone into African airfields and took to task investigating Senators and others for "unfair" and "false" criticism.

Using deductive techniques, United States Government officials have finally obtained what they regard as confirmation from official sources of the long prevalent rumors that the Soviet Union's major Volga-Don Canal, opened last summer, was largely built by forced labor working under secret police direction.

Just before the start of the 1951 season, a Kent School student told an inquiring reporter that grooming a gridiron required the same careful attention as a manicure. "You have to cut the grass just so," he explained, "and then you apply the polish. The polish," he continued, "is the white lime used to line the field."

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower spent a quiet Sunday working on campaign speeches at his home, 60 Morningside Drive, after attending 11 o'clock services with his wife in St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University campus.

OLSO, Norway, Sept. 28 -- Black ties at dinner and an issue of rum each noon still are among the distinguishing hallmarks of the British Navy. But the tradition, pomp and custom important in all navies, particularly so the British, have not hobbled technical progress.

A showdown between General Naguib, Egyptian Premier, and Mustafa Nahas, the leader of the Wafd for many years, was inevitable. If Egypt is to introduce true reforms, attack corruption and inefficiency and punish those guilty for past abuses, the power of the Wafd, and of Nahas in particular, must be broken.
YONKERS, Sept. 28 -- Dr. Charles Robbins of the New York Pioneer Club won the senior Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union 25-kilometer run today and led the Pioneer squad to a sweep of team honors.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Cleveland's magnificent Browns overshadowed the Los Angeles Rams in all departments today as they routed the National League champions, 37 -- 7, before an opening day crowd of 57,832.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Sept. 28 -- It costs $10,000,000 to $12,000,000 -- on top of an original outlay of $9,000,000 -- to build a typical European air base up to the standards required by jet combat units of the United States Air Force.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28 -- Yugoslav reports from Turkey and Greece indicate that the Yugoslav military mission that visited those countries this month succeeded in preparing the ground for further conversations that may result eventually in a Balkan entente to neutralize Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary, the principal Soviet satellites in Southeastern Europe.

Eleanor Holm Rose, arriving here from Florida last night, tried unsuccessfully to gain admittance to the five-story town house at 33 Beekman Place, which she formerly shared with her now-estranged husband, Billy Rose.

The forty-two night fall session of the Yonkers Raceway harness racing season, featuring the $25,000 Gotham Trot on Oct. 16, will start tonight. Included in the meeting is the Grand Circuit's final stop of the year, Oct. 13 to Nov. 1.

Vice Admiral Renato Guillobel, Minister of Marine of Brazil, and a party of officials of the Brazilian Navy attended solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. With them were Rear Admiral Milton Miles, chief of the Pan-American Division of the United States Navy, and Rear Admiral R. F. Whitehead, chief of the United States Naval Mission to Brazil.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The text of the identical Soviet notes to the Allied powers on a proposed Austrian treaty, as broadcast by the Moscow radio, follows:
Publication of the new Revised Standard Version of the Holy Bible was hailed yesterday in New York pulpits as a major event in the history of American Protestanism.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 28 -- The nation may expect "good business,'' at least for the next six months," the president of the American Bankers Association declared here today.

ELMONT, L. I., Sept. 28 -- A young woman walked into a police booth here this morning and told Patrolman John Jones that she had just killed her husband, a Nassau County policeman. She handed Patrolman Jones an empty revolver.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Jim Greenglass drove in the winning run with a fly to Gus Bell with one out and the bases loaded in the last of the ninth today as in the Reds closed their season with a 3-2 victory over the Pirates.

The national board of Americans for Democratic Action asserted yesterday that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had abandoned the liberal elements of the Republican party responsible for his nomination for the Presidency and had become the official spokesman for the "G. O. P.-Dixiecrat alliance."
Hold-ups in two uptown Broadway hotels were carried out early yesterday in the space of twenty minutes by a stick-up band that included a blond girl wearing a red coat, the police reported.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin said today that unemployment was probably at a post-war low. He based the estimate on the number of workers claiming unemployment compensation benefits.

The Fund for the Advancement of Education announced yesterday that it had awarded fellowships valued at a total of $1,017,600 to 193 high school teachers over the country for self-education in the present academic year.

Two policemen in uniform, responding to a telephoned complaint of extortion, were manhandled, punched and kicked and threatened with death by members of the Tiger gang in Brooklyn before they were able to effect arrests, according to the policemen's story told yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court.

Reports from correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES indicated great popular interest in the expense fund of Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican candidate for Vice President, after his explanation of it last Tuesday and somewhat less interest in the special fund of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic nominee for President.

A woman named Dora died in a New York hospital a few years ago without being interviewed by anyone to find out what had happened to her over the years. Thus the history of psychology was deprived of priceless information, for she was the famous Dora described by Dr. Sigmund Freud, founder of psychoanalysis, in "Fragments of an Analysis of Hysteria," one of his most important cases.

" Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" supplied yesterday's matinee performance by the New York City Opera Company, both works making their first appearances of the new season. The casts, however, were largely familiar, with one exception.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Stan (The Man) Musial got a hit and Hank Sauer didn't today as the Cardinals lost a 3-0 decision to the Cubs.

DALLAS, Sept. 28 (UP) -- The New York Giants wore down the Dallas Texans with a mixture of Charley Conerly's passing and Eddie Price's running today to spoil the Texans' National Football League debut, 24 to 6.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 28 -A powerful, coordinated attack by the Meadow Brook Club poloists overwhelmed the Milwaukee Shamrocks, 12 -- 1, in the final game of the National 20-goal championship on Bostwick Field today.

Luckily for the jet age a barrel of crude petroleum is internally elastic. For the jet engine, foreseeably the only power for military aircraft, is already powering the planes of one airline -- the Comets of British Overseas Air- ways Corporation on the London-Johannesburg run --and its appetite for fuel is voracious compared with the piston engine.

NEW MARTINSVILLE, W. Va., Sept. 28 -- New names supplanted some of the old in the annals of speed boat daredeviltry today in one of the most spectacular regattas of the season on a smooth, sunny, almost ripple-less Ohio River.

Harry Quigley, who learned his soccer in Ireland, played at center forward for the New York Americans and stole the spotlight in the match with the Brooklyn Hispanos at Sterling Oval yesterday. The newcomer, who helped his side to a 3-2 lead in the first half, scored the first four talllies credited to the home team, which won, 6 -- 3. In the opening game of the doubleheader, Brookhatten-Galicia and Hakoah tied, 2 -- 2.

Two museum shows are on this week's list of art exhibitions. On Wednesday the Whitney Museum will show the collection of Edith and Milton Lowenthal; and on Thursday the Jewish Museum will offer Biblical and Jewish themes in contemporary American sculpture.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A small group clustered in the rear of a chartered transport plane descending for a landing at the Washington National Airport early today held the first meeting of a new fraternity entitled "The Order of the Hound's Tooth."

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- On his return from a fortnight in Strasbourg, Yugoslavia and Austria Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said tonight that our "policy of peace is understood and the community of Western nations is growing in unity and strength."
DETROIT, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Tigers finished the season in familiar fashion today, dropping an 8-to-2 decision to the Indians.

The National Association of Manufacturers announced yesterday it had asked the United Nations Ad Hoc Committee on Restrictive , Business Practices to investigate trade unions that "hamper international trade and interfere with raising living standards throughout the world."

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, State Education Commissioner, declared tonight that the State Board of Regents, acting under the Feinberg Law, would begin next month to carry out the mandate of the law to establish a list of subversive organizations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The committee that sets policy for Republicans in the United States Senate charged today that Federal censorship had grown in the last twenty years until "the right of a free people to know what their Government is doing was stolen away."

THE NEW YORK TIMES has conducted a splendid editorial campaign in an effort to obtain more police officers to meet the current crisis in the City of New York. I note from your editorial of Sept. 25 "The Mayor Acts" that you close by congratulating the Mayor. I for one feel that you and your paper should be heartily congratulated for having conducted a forceful, worthwhile and constructive campaign in this very serious matter.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company has promoted three assistant vice presidents to vice presidents, N. Baxter Jackson, chairman, announced over the week-end. They include Francis P. Beattie and Walter M. Ross, members of the National Division, and Pierce Onthank, in charge of the 100 Park Avenue office.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 -- The champion Yankees, with a sort of junior varsity line-up that helped pile up five errors, closed their American League season today by taking an inelegant pasting from the Athletics by a score of 9 to 4.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 -- Twentieth Century-Fox cut all ties at midnight last night with its vast theatre empire, which stretched from the Pacific Coast to the Atlantic and at one time numbered 700 houses.
Princeton kept its winning streak intact through twenty-three games on college football's first big Saturday.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 28 (UP) -- Quarterback Bob Williams fired two touchdown passes today to lead the Chicago Bears to a 24-to-14 victory over the Green Bay Packers in the National Football League season opener at City Stadium.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 -- It may be, as many observers believe, that steel demand will taper off after the turn of the year, but there was no advance sign of this in the steel market last week. Demand exceeded actual production because of previous losses in output.
Carl Milles, chairman of the National Arts Foundation's advisory committee on sculpture, arrived yesterday morning at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from Stockholm, Sweden.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 28 -- One of the largest single-day crowds in the eighty-nine-year history of the Danbury Fair turned out today. Fair officials estimated the throng at 40,000. It was believed that only once before -- the opening day in 1946 when the fair was resumed after a World War II suspension of several years -- had today's crowd been surpassed.

" I am delighted to contribute these charming ribbon headdresses to Patterns of The Times," said Emme, when she showed us these enchanting creations. They were especially created for our readers by the well-known milliner.

Cotton futures prices moved higher at the start of last week but turned reactionary and closed Friday with small and irregular changes. Net changes on the week on the New York Cotton Exchange were 9 points lower to 19 points higher.

The future of "It's a Problem," a truly superb program that has brought rare insight and understanding to the manifold problems of contemporary family life, is uncertain. As matters stand at the moment the presentation is scheduled to go off the air in two weeks and the National Broadcasting Company is disconcertingly vague about when and if it will return. Its permanent loss would be most grievous.
A 13-year-old boy was burned critically last night when he brushed a wire carrying 11,000 volts of electricity atop a forty-foot tower of the Long Island Rail Road in Elmhurst, Queens.

While the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was conducting "Exercise Mainbrace" in the North Sea, Sweden was staging large-scale naval and air force maneuvers in the waters surrounding the Baltic island of Gotland. The two operations, though simultaneous, were completely separate, the Swedes are careful to explain.

ABOARD THE TRUMAN TRAIN, Sept. 28 -- President Truman spent Sunday without any speeches as he rolled westward today but he was winding up to begin a "give-'em-hell" whistle stop campaign early tomorrow at Breckenridge, Minn. Wherever he stopped today he received a hearty welcome from Midwest crowds.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Sept. 29 -- Four United States jets accidentally bombed a newly won Allied hill on the Korean western front yesterday and helped counter-attacking Chinese Communists drive Greek infantrymen from the position.

WESTFIELD, N. J., Sept. 28 -- Here for a visit with her mother, Mrs. Elanore Young of 503 Carlton Read, Mrs. William O'Dwyer laughed at rumors today that she plans to divorce the Ambassador to Mexieo.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives asserted in a report made public today that it was "well justified" in surmising that J. Howard McGrath, former Attorney General, sought "a man who might be susceptible to pressure" when he appointed Newbold Morris as a special Assistant Attorney General to investigate corruption in the Federal Government.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Benefited by a ten-knot southerly breeze, forty-three sailing craft were out today in another postseason regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Orders for nearly 400,000 deadweight tons of tankers have been placed with Italian shipyards as a result of that country's new construction subsidy program to interest its nationals in enlarging the Italian-flag fleet of oil carriers.

MORECAMBE, England, Sept. 28 -- The area of possible conflict between the right and left wings of the British Labor party was reduced by executive action today on the eve of the party's annual conference at this Lancashire seaside resort.

The temptation of "subtle communism'' lies in its attack upon the weak point of our social life, the lack of fellowship between employers and employes, the Right Rev. Michael Hinsuke Yashiro, Presiding Bishop of the Nippon Seikokwai (Holy Catholic Church in Japan), declared in a sermon yesterday morning at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

As a site for improvement with a one-story taxpayer building, a plot of vacant land at the southeast corner of Westchester and Metcalf Avenues, the Bronx, has been purchased by Land Properties, Inc., represented by Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, from the City of New York.

A New York pediatrician, speaking before a Michigan medical group in Detroit last week, called on the doctors he was addressing to cut down to an absolute minimum the hospitalization of young children because of the detrimental emotional effect upon them as a result of being separated from their mothers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama said today he did not want to pass judgment on the supplementary expenditures fund used by Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican opposing him for the Vice Presidency, but that he would not have accepted such a fund.

For a long, long time Theodore H. Silbert of Standard Factors Corporation seemed to be just about the only person in the United States who realized that specialized finance companies, as he called them, had become an immense and vital factor in the American economy.
Queens Borough President James A. Lundy announced yesterday that he had exonerated Bernard F. Fox, an engineer, of all charges of incompetence and misconduct in the Queens sewer scandal.

" The Woman With The Whip: Eva Peron," a biography by Maria Flores, will be published on Oct. 16 by Doubleday. Finished just before Eva Peron's death, about which an epilogue was written, the book presents a life of the fabulous woman who influenced the economy and prospects of contemporary Argentina.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 28 -- Adolf Van Glabeke, a member of the Liberal opposition in Belgium's Chamber of Deputies, charged tonight that Adrien Van Coppenolle had had access to "important documents involving security of the state" while he served a prison sentence for collaboration with the Nazis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The State Department has just issued a circular urging its employes, in the interest of saving working man-hours, to fly to and from foreign assignments and conferences. It does not, however, make air travel obligatory.

Although gross operating revenues of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company in the first eight months of 1952 dropped 3 per cent below the level attained a year earlier, net income for the 1952 period surpassed that recorded in 1951 by 136 per cent.

ROME, Sept. 28 -- The Church of Christ, United States Protestant sect that has been carrying on missionary activities in Italy since 1949, was allowed by Italian authorities to hold its regular Sunday service this morning. On two previous Sundays the police had prevented it from holding religious services for its congregation in Rome on the ground that its pastors had not obtained permits as required by Italian law.

CHARLES WALTER DRESSEN, the Shakespeare of the dugout, called the turn with uncanny exactitude in his most recent literary masterpiece. That Pulitizer Prize gem was titled, "The Dodgers Won't Blow It Again!" Charlie had to squirm uncomfortably and sweat a little blood immediately after publication date because it did appear then as though the Brooks might blow the pennant.

Two new links in the Long Island state parkway system will be opened without fanfare today. One will be the last three-mile section of the Northern State Parkway and the other the entire six-mile length of Sagtikos State Parkway, which connects the Northern and Southern State Parkways at their eastern ends.
Mary Ryback sold the new home on plot 43 by 154 feet at 145-31 Twentieth Avenue, Whitestone, Queens, to Joseph De Fino, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

DUBLIN, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Cavan, with 2 goals and 4 points, and Meath, with 1 goal and 7 points, battled to a 10-10 tie today in the final of the all-Ireland senior football championship on a field soaked by eight hours of continuous rain.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 28 (UP) -Louise Suggs of Carrollton, Ga., rallied today to win the first Betty Jameson open golf tournament with a 54-hole score of 212, four under women's par, at Brackenridge Park.

The decision of the United States to put the Korean case forward in the forthcoming meeting of the General Assembly of the United Nations has its good and bad aspects. Last year the United States specifically opposed an Assembly debate on the ground that truce negotiations were in progress and might be hampered by the inevitable clash of opinion in an Assembly debate.

If the nominal age of a science could be taken as a rough measure of its state of development, then economics should today be in the vanguard of all the sciences in terms of refinement and systematization. For we know that economics, which stems from the Greek word oikos, literally antedates Christendom itself.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 29 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,387 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

For the fourth consecutive year the Dodgers ended the regular season in an overtime game yesterday. While the three previous finales were highly important, yesterday's twelve-inning affair with the Braves at Ebbets Field carried no significance.

There may be a slight trace of political guile in President Truman's request to Chairman James M, Mead of the Federal Trade Commission for a study of where the consumer's dollar goes. In fact, Mr. Truman said that "powerful interests are at work trying to convince the consumer that it is the farmer who is responsible for the high cost of living."

CAIRO, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib's Government today declared war on Mustafa Nahas' Wafd party. Unless something unexpected happens, the showdown is expected to have only one end -- victory for the soldier over the politician.

Robert Aura Smith, Far East specialist and member of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, cautioned yesterday that the United States would have to maintain a position of strength in Korea "for the rest of our natural lives -- and we might as well be prepared for it."
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Browns cut loose with an 18-hit barrage today to whip the White Sox, 12 -- 1, at Comiskey Park.
Japan has proposed to settle dollar for dollar and pound for pound her outstanding bonds floated in Britain and the United States.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 28 -- The first International Conference of Artists sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization ended today under the presidency of the Italian composer, Ildebrando Pizzetti.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28 -- A 19-year-old Yale junior varsity football player, Demetre Homer of White Plains, N. Y., died this morning in Grace-New Haven Community Hospital from a brain hemorrhage.
BOSTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -The Senators today scored a 5-4 victory over the Red Sox and finished in fifth place in the American League.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 28 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh described today in an interview his plans for the distribution of land to the Iranian peasants and for providing credit to free them from heavy debt and high interest rates under the decree he issued in August providing that 20 per cent of the landlords' share of the harvest go to the villages and the peasants.

BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 28 -- Oregon and Idaho, neighboring Pacific Northwest states loosely termed Republican despite their frequent flirtations with the New Deal and Fair Deal in the last two decades, have one thing in common in this Presidential campaign.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 28 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, made public tonight his Federal income tax returns for the last ten years.

The Giants closed the 1952 championship season at the Polo Grounds yesterday by serving as the victim of Robin Roberts' twenty-eighth triumph of the campaign. This gave the right-handed stalwart of the Phillies the distinction of being the first National League pitcher to count so many successes since Dizzy Dean won twenty-eight and lost twelve for the Cards in 1935. The score was 7 to 4.

The Army Engineers' small-boat fleet, since the early Nineteen Hundreds a homeless unit subject to the whims of other government agencies or private pier owners for a base of operations, finally has found a haven of its own at Caven Point in Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Labor Committee on National Policy of the National Planning Association warned today that free labor unions abroad must be strengthened lest the basic goals of American foreign aid programs "be seriously imperiled."

The winter drama season at the New York City Center this year may include lesser-known Shakespeare works such as "Measure for Measure," "Troilus and Cressida" and "Love's Labour's Lost," or George Bernard Shaw's "Major Barbara."
A request by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley, to let a contract for 13,000 new parking meters to other than the low bidder, has been snagged at least temporarily by the Board of Estimate.
A request by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley, to let a contract for 13,000 new parking meters to other than the low bidder, has been snagged at least temporarily by the Board of Estimate.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- A sharp decline in wheat late in the week with the near delivery establishing a new low for the season featured the trade in grain, but during the week many cross currents of speculation reflected various influences.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- The United Nations was told today that the four-year-old problem of the 880,000 Arab refugees of the Palestine war had placed a huge social and economic blight on the entire Middle East.

A five-story apartment house on lot 55 by 100 feet at 705 West 179th Street, near Broadway, has been sold by the Estate of Samuel Herzog to Hugh K. McGovern, operator. It is assessed at $56,000 and was sold subject to a ten-year mortgage of $42,500.

Renewed unrest on the waterfront here and at other Atlantic coast ports was threatened last night as a small but important segment of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., unable to reach agreement on a new contract, warned that its members would not report to work after tomorrow.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Dick Savitt, Orange (N. J.) player, had his all-court game in top working order today as he defeated Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., 10 -- 8, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, for the Pacific Coast men's singles tennis title.

On Seventy-first Avenue in Forest Hills, in a recently built apartment as American as a baseball game, is the exotic little household of Basri Haznam, consul of Indonesia. His petite young wife, who presides over it, wears the kabaja kain, the long narrow skirt and bright blouse that are the dress of her native Sumatra.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 28 -- A prominent Dutch rubber expert said this week that there is still a fairly good chance for the January meeting of the Rubber Study Group in London to arrive at a preliminary agreement. He strongly denied reports after the group's July-August meeting that the conference had been a failure.

Cardinal Spellman dedicated yesterday the Bary Manning Walsh Home, 420 East Fifty-ninth Street, where 300 aged men and women of all faiths the cared for in an atmosphere that embraces a "dynamic approach" to solving the problems of the homeless aged.
The Amato Opera Theatre, which offers week-end performances at 159 Bleecker Street, presented "La Boheme" Saturday evening.

Alexander Kotov of Russia, after having-won seven straight, played to an adjournment with Herman Pilnik of Argentina after forty-one moves and Gideon Stahlberg of Sweden, the runner-up in the tourney, defeated A. Matonovic of Yugoslavia in twenty-three moves yesterday in the ninth round of the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, Sweden, according to a report from Stockholm.

Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for re-election, will begin today a two-week campaign of upstate counties, during which he will speak at scores of communities seldom visited by candidates for national office.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 -- Charging that the United States is preparing a new world war directed against the Soviet Union, Nikita S. Khrushchev, a member of the Politburo, and who will play a leading role in the Communist party's nineteenth congress, has called on the Moscow party organization to display heightened vigilance against foreign espionage.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Army, it is indicated, is letting a new mandatory retirement order operate to drop from its active rolls three colonels about whom there has been controversy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Frankie Albert, the wizard of the T-formation, guided the San Francisco Forty-Niners to a 17-3 victory over the Detroit Lions in a National Football League game today before 54,761 fans in fog-banked Kezar Stadium.
MOSCOW, Sept. 28 -- For all practical purposes, it appeared today that any prospects of East- West agreement on a state treaty for Austria some time in the foreseeable future are dead.

Perhaps it is the change in the season, the end of oppressive heat; perhaps it is some subtle change, in this young person hurrying in to dinner, that defies analysis. Whatever is the cause, something new and welcome has occurred that no one had expected.

DORTMUND, Germany, Sept. 28 -- The German Social Democrats will fight next year's general election on a platform whose principles are unchanged, but whose language is more moderate than the violent terms fostered by the late chairman, Kurt Schumacher.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 28 (UP) -Rochester's Red Wings evened the little world series at one game each today with a seventh inning-scoring burst against the Kansas City Blues for four runs and a 5-3 victory before 13,011.

Ten counties throughout the country that are reported never to have guessed wrong in a national election in fifty-six years may lose their reputation as political beacons if present trends are any criterion. There has been a serious split in the bloc.

ZURICH, Sept. 28 -- At the annual rally of the Swiss Bankers Association held at Basle over the week-end two pronouncements of great international significance were made at the chief session yesterday.

VIENNA, Sept. 28 -- The Soviet refusal to attend a proposed London conference of Big Four foreign ministers' deputies came as no surprise here, since the organ of the Austrian Communist party, Die Volkstimme, had already dismissed the West's proposal as histrionics intended to conceal from the Austrian people a determination of Western powers, as the Reds claimed to see it, to stay in this land.

The mock atomic air raid on the five boroughs tomorrow evening will set in motion the city's most elaborate civilian defense effort, with emergency crews rehearsing not only their ability to take command of disaster areas but taking steps to provide for every contingency that might result from the "enemy" attack.

The wide selection of colors in this fall's fashions demand a more careful selection of hosiery shades. Light camel tones, olive greens, ruby red, various blues, graduations of gray and, of course, black and brown all require, harmonizing hosiery. The many colors presented by hosiery manufacturers have been carefully coordinated to meet this demand. Although they are not pale, there is a definite softening of tones from the gray taupes to pink beiges.

The dime subway and bus fare came under pressure from a new but not unfamiliar direction yesterday when Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., announced plans for a new wage drive on both public and private lines.

TOKYO, Sept. 28 -- Japan's textile industry blossomed out today in rich brocades and silks at a mass fashion show in the Imperial Theatre here. Sixteen Japanese fabric manufactures provided silk, cotton, nylon, artificial silk, staple wool fiber and mixed materials for more than a hundred creations designed by Mme. Chiyo Tanaka.

The Warren Petroleum Corporation, Oklahoma manufacturer and marketer of natural gasoline and liquefied petroleum gas, had the second highest net income in its history with the total for the fiscal year ended with last June of $8,163,717.

" This Is Cinerama," initial production in the newly developed Cinerama process, will have its premiere tonight at 8:15 o'clock at the Broadway Theatre for an invited audience. Regular showings will begin tomorrow on a two-a-day, reserved seat basis.

The seventy-member General Electric conference board of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., voted yesterday to empower union negotiators to call a strike of 71,000 workers in sixty General Electric plants "when and if" they deemed it necessary.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Government announced tonight that it had crushed an attempted rebellion early today in which five persons were killed and ten wounded.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Dr. Paul B. Magnuson, chairman of the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, told the District of Columbia Medical Society today that his fifteen-member group had had an absolutely free hand and soon would submit an unbiased report.
Dr. Samuel S. Kistler, chemical engineer and abrasives authority, has been made research associate by the Peninsular Grinding Wheel Company of Detroit. He recently resigned from the Norton Company.

On Sept. 5 you ran an article by Anthony Leviero, your Washington correspondent, describing the special commission which President Truman has called into existence in order to study further the immigration and naturalization policies of the United States.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 29 -- British proposals designed to give Britain and other non-member states an observer role in the affairs of the six-nation European Coal and Steel Community appeared tonight to be assured of approval by the Consulative Assembly of the Council of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The United States agreed today to buy 6,000 to 7,000 long tons of tin from the Bolivian government. The short-term deal covers Bolivian tin now stockpiled at Peruvian and Chilean ports.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- The Mortgage Bankers Association of America today accused the Veterans Administration of failing the war veteran in his search for funds to buy a home by refusing to recognize that the V. A. guaranteed mortgage interest rate is too low in today's market.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Publication of the Japanese debt settlement terms created a record demand for Japanese issues on the stock market here today, with some gaining as much as fifteen points.

New York University's opening triumph over Lehigh put the 1952 football Violets one up on their records of the last two years. Their upset of the Engineers marked the first important success for the Heightsmen under Hughie Devore, who took over in 1950 what is perhaps the most unenviable coaching situation in the East.

The four-story building containing forty apartments at 39-21 Sixty-fifth Place in Woodside, Queens, has been sold by Rudolph Pesek to Raphael Reader. The Advance Realty Company was the broker in the transaction. Albert W. Sibek was attorney for the seller and Harry Deutsch acted for the buyer.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon's campaign headquarters said today the Republican Vice Presidential candidate planned to make no further statement on his personal finances.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Already running behind schedule and threatened by a general cut-back in rearmament outlays by member countries, the defense goals of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have encountered a new snag in the form of mounting costs of airfields and other installations needed for the projected European army.
YONKERS, Sept. 29 -- Ankaway raced away with the Armonk pace that headed the opening program tonight of what appeared likely to be a prosperous fall season at the Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- Federal rent controls expire tomorrow except in critical defense areas and areas in which local governing bodies, by votes before midnight tonight, ask their continuance to April 30.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The belief that Communists have wormed their way into the highly secret Central Intelligence Agency and every other security organization of the Federal Government was expressed today by Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, head of the intelligence agency.

Parents of 400 youngsters registered and waiting to be seen at the Morris J. Solomon Clinic for the Rehabilitation of Retarded Children are being organized into active neighborhood groups throughout Brooklyn under a new program the clinic is conducting. The program has been planned as an answer to a real need for some form of interim help and guidance to meet some of the problems and difficulties of immediate concern to these parents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- The Board of Immigration Appeals refused today to halt the deportation to Yugoslavia of Antonia Sentner, wife of William Sentner, recently arrested Missouri Communist leader.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Robert A. Collier, chief counsel for the Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives that is investigating the Justice Department, said today that the second part of the group's report would be issued on Wednesday. Part one of the report was published today.

We are currently approaching the height of the book season. And when the year is past, about ten thousand titles will have been published in the United States. That is an amazingly small number when one considers that perhaps a majority of the country's one hundred and fifty million people plan or have planned to write a book some day.
Your recent editorial on the League of Women Voters was in keeping with THE TIMES policy of public service and of printing all the news that's fit to print.
The United States Government's "long-term borrowing rate" rose beyond 2 3/4 per cent yesterday for the first time since the late thirties.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson told the American people tonight that the difficult task of ridding the world of communism and assuring freedom and prosperity was all theirs, and he warned them not to be distracted by phony issues in the Presidential campaign.
With a moderate volume of business, prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange finished 5 to 26 points net lower yesterday, with the near months showing the most weakness.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A 1929-type depression after the defense boom is extremely unlikely, Robert C. Turner, Presidential advisor, said today.

Prices of most commodity futures on the local markets yesterday showed an irregular to lower tendency in a moderate volume of trading. Hides, rubber, tin, cottonseed oil and soybean oil futures drifted lower. Potatoes, coffee, cocoa, wool and wool tops were firm, while lead, zinc and sugar were irregular.

Twenty-five-year-old well-dressed twins from East Northport, L. I., were arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn on charges of draft evasion. They waived examination and were released in $1,000 bail each for Federal grand jury action.

Scientists are reportedly investigating the peculiar reactions registered by chimpanzees, monkeys and pigeons whenever a British Overseas Airways Corporation Comet jet liner approaches Johannesburg, South Africa.

Lee Sala of Donora, Pa., left-hooked his way to a unanimous ten-round decision last night over Norman Hayes of Boston, seventh ranking middleweight, before 1,500 fans at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.
FARGO, N. D., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of President Truman's first speech today on his whistle stop campaign trip:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The final report of the Bipartisan Commission on the Renovation of the White House, a handsome document just off the Government presses, strongly recommends that steps be taken toward constructing a new office building for the President of the United States.

SHERIDAN, Wyo., Sept. 29 -- After three hours with the members of the Sheridan County Sportsmen's Club last night, and after looking over the trophies that adorn the peeled log walls of the clubhouse, we are satisfied that Wyoming must be the place where the "deer and the antelope play."

New York, despite almost continuous drives by the Department of Sanitation to educate the public and to penalize, litterers, still presented a grimy face yesterday. Persons entering the city by trains on the uncovered tracks on upper Park Avenue found the view of the streets especially unprepossessing.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 29 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, charged today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee, had adopted "the Old Guard prescription that the way to win an election is by noise, name-calling and emotionalism."

LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- United States, British and French officials arranged today for an early conference of their deputy foreign ministers here to map the next move in the quest for an Austrian independence pact.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28 -- Lebanon's reform movement which caused the resignation of Bechara el-Khoury who had been President for nine years, reached a stalemate in its efforts to form a Cabinet. Abdullah Yafi apparently was asked again today to try to form a Cabinet. He had made a vain effort last week.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 29 -- Senator Irving M. Ives called today for the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as "the one man who really knows the requirements of defense" and who is equipped by experience to rout "waste and slipshod management" out of the present Democratic defense program.

TORONTO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A settlement, affecting 12,000 workers in Ontario's newsprint and pulp mills, has been reached between twelve pulp and paper companies and nine American Federation of Labor unions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 29 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today that he is "becoming realistic about interest rates." Here as a principal speaker at the seventy-eighth annual convention of the American Bankers' Association, he added that he has been "very pleased" with the Treasury's recent financing operations.

It has seemed to me that until quite recently General Eisenhower's attack upon the Truman Administration was directed more at how, rather than what, things are done by the Fair Deal. This indicated that he tacitly approved in principle much for which the Democrats claim the patent.

POCONO MANOR, Pa., Sept. 29 (UP) -- A project to provide new sources of water for millions of residents in the Delaware River watershed has been slowed down by "reckless and ill-founded statements" that it is only for the benefit of New York City, Francis A. Pitkin, chairman of the Interstate Commission on the Delaware River Basin (Incodel), said today.
" When you hear bombers passing overhead and air raid sirens sounding at 7:45 o'clock this evening do not become unduly alarmed. This is a New York City civil defense test."

DALLAS, Sept. 29 -- The Dallas Texans today placed four players on the National Football League waiver list and at the same time announced the signing of two rookies and another player on waivers from Detroit, Cleveland and San Francisco.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- With wholesale meat prices all well below ceilings -- they have been skidding downward for five weeks -- good buys for consumers now are appearing in retail stores, the American Meat Institute said here today.

Every now and then in some part of the city a single siren wails out and as suddenly dies away. But for the duration of the iron moan people within earshot on the street stop and turn to look at each other, everyone hoping his neighbor may know something he doesn't.

Most of the members of the Association of National Advertisers anticipate that by the end of this year their percentage of net sales spent for advertising will exceed that of 1951 by 0.3 per cent -- 2.55 per cent compared with 2.25 per cent last year.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Tonight was a red-letter one for London music lovers as Arturo Toscanini, after a thirteen-year absence, conducted the Philharmonia Orchestra at the Royal Festival Hall. The program was all Brahms -- the tragic "Overture" Symphony No. 1 in C and the Second Symphony in D.

A 43-year-old pregnant woman reported to the police yesterday that she was kidnapped by two men in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn late Sunday night, kept prisoner for seven hours in their car and raped before she escaped at 6:15 A. M.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Imposition of import fees to raise the price of foreign wool to that which the Government guarantees American sheep raisers was urged today before the Tariff Commission. C. J. Fawcett of the National Wool Marketing Corporation, Boston, joined with spokesmen for the National Wool Growers Association in asking an import fee to supplement the present 25 1/2 cents a pound tariff.

A spectacular five-alarm fire, visible for miles in Brooklyn and along the Manhattan shore of the East River, last night burned a $1,000,000 pier in Brooklyn to its pilings. Flames shot from the blazing wood and corrugated metal structure to a height of fifty feet before the walls of the pier caved in.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Congressmen should have the courage to vote themselves salaries large enough to meet their needs, Vice President Alben W. Barkley said today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 29 -- Many more import licenses will be issued soon, Coroliano Goes, new head of the Export-Import Control Board, announced today.
GRAND FORKS, N. D., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of a transcribed interview President Truman today gave to Jack French, a newsman for radio station KNOX, Grand Forks:
We turn attention today to a homely topic -- dishwashing. No one likes it, but few of us, including even the men in the family these maidless days, can escape doing it at one time or another.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The relief of Gen. James A. Van Fleet after seventeen months of grueling command of the Eighth Army in Korea has been decided upon at the Pentagon. There will be no formal announcement, however, until his successor has been selected.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Certain Fair Deal Democrats in Congress said today that, while they were convinced that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson had made real headway with independent voters, they were now urging that he "switch his attack from the head to the belly."

The report from Jakarta, Indonesia, in which Sultan Hamengku Buwono, Indonesia's Minister of Defense -- as published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 19 -- was quoted as saying that "The Ceram revolt, which sought to set up a Moluccas Republic, was virtually over," needs correction.

PANAMA, Sept. 29 -- President-elect Jose A. Remon in announcing his Cabinet at a press conference here today said that the present ambassador Roberto Huertematte would remain in Washington as the representative of his Government.
Comparing the Yankees and Dodgers on the offense, that wide disparity which so clearly manifests itself between the two clubs in pitching seems to vanish completely.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Winter sports enthusiasts and Florida resort proprietors will welcome the winter weather forecast for this area announced today by William Ken nedy, chief meteorologist at the Federal Weather Station on top of Bear Mountain. He predicted the "lowest temperature in years and more snow than usual."

A convincing practical demonstration of management and labor working together harmoniously was given yesterday in the Astor Hotel. A head of a union substituted for an ailing company executive at the latter's own request to deliver an address on successful operation of an employe incentive plan at the plant with which both are connected.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- The new management group at R. K. O. Radio Pictures has sounded out Jerry Wald about assuming the post of production chief and the producer has signified his willingness provided a satisfactory agreement can be worked out.

Tenants of Parkway Village will vote today on acceptance of rent increases demanded by the bank-owners of the international community in Queens. This action was decided upon last night at a long meeting of the Parkway Village Community Association in Grace Memorial House, 155-24 Ninetieth Avenue, Jamaica.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 30 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters communique 1,388, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Sept. 29 -- Lawrenceville School's football squad, numbering fifty-seven, "appears stronger than last year, despite our one-sided opening game victory last Saturday." That's how coach Larry Tiihonen described his team today as he sent his charges through a light drill in preparation for Saturday's game with Trenton High.
Following is the text of a nation-wide radio and television address made last night by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson at the Student-baker Theatre in Chicago, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson has decided to present United States proposals regarding Korea to the United Nations General Assembly as soon as possible after it opens its 1952 session here Oct. 14.

Vincent Hallinan, Progressive party-American Labor party candidate for President, in a radio broadcast speech here, vigorously attacked yesterday the Democrats and Republicans for their "bipartisan" war in Korea and their "reactionary" programs "in Congress, the Government and courts."
LOUVAIN, Belgium, Sept. 24 -- The American College, founded here in 1857, reopens Sept. 30 with an American as rector, the first non-European to be appointed to that post.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will make a full disclosure of his financial situation in response to public interest in his financial affairs, James C. Hagerty, his press secretary, said yesterday. At Eisenhower temporary headquarters in the Commodore Hotel, Mr. Hagerty said he was sure the Republican Presidential nominee would make his financial statement "later on."
MOSCOW, Sept. 29 -- The network of railroad lines in eastern Kazakstan will be materially extended and strengthened according to Communist party officials in Kazakstan.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -- Under terms of a new agreement signed with the Ministry of Communications, the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation will invest $12,000,000 in its subsidiary Compania Standard Electric Argentina, it was learned today.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Sept. 29 (AP) -- France is responsible for defects in newly built runways on three airbases in France assigned to the United States Air Force, a Supreme Allied Headquarters communique said tonight.

One of the outstanding social events of the autumn season will be the Junior League Ball to be held in the ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 26.
