Guests of honor will be some of the provisional members of the Junior League who will make their debuts this season. The proceeds will be contributed to the Welfare Fund of the league.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- James M. Mead, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, assured President Truman today his agency would soon conduct a series of public hearings to seek information on the division of the consumer's dollar among the various producing and distributing functions of the nation's economy.

Japanese dollar bonds of fourteen different issues soared in price to new high record levels yesterday following the formal announcement that Japan had agreed to recognize in full the claims of external bondholders for back interest and to resume paying current interest on the bonds on Dec. 22 at the original contractual rates.

ABOARD THE TRUMAN TRAIN, in North Dakota, Sept. 29 -- President Truman ridiculed Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential candidate, today, as the inept tool of the "unholy crew" that dominated the Republican party.

Eolus, a 5-year-old that competes on the flat as well as over the jumps, won the Rouge Dragon hurdle handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Skillfully handled by Pat Smithwick, the son of Battleship carried the colors of Lawrence Jennings to a clear victory over Rigan McKinney's Sundowner, the favorite with the crowd of 33,580.

GENEVA, Sept. 29 -- A United Nations Committee of Experts, charged with drafting an international agreement on the elimination or regulation of restrictive business practices, has finished its third session here after making what members regard as highly satisfactory progress.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 29 -- An 11-year-old boy is to be parted from his German foster parents and returned to his Yugoslav mother at the order of the Court of Appeals of the United States High Commissioner's office.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A screen writer who said he had dropped out of the Communist party in 1947 today named a score of Hollywood figures he claimed were members with him.

The National Cash Register Company has entered into a stock purchase agreement with the Computer Research Corporation of Hawthorne, Calif., under which it will acquire a controlling interest in that company, Stanley C. Allyn, president of National, announced yesterday in Dayton, Ohio.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- In its report for the year ended last March, the British Broadcasting Corporation emphasized today the importance of its news broadcasts to nations behind the Iron Curtain. Noting a marked increase in Soviet jamming, the report cited the explanation given by a former Soviet political commissar who fled to the West: "What is chiefly feared is a source of objective news not colored by Moscow."

If the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod were dispensed with on the ground that his services were not essential, the news would be hardly less upsetting than is the announcement that The Manchester Guardian is about to put its front page inside and one of its inside pages outside.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Premier Antoine Pinay's efforts to keep prices down in France failed in September for the second successive month, according to official figures issued today.

The Coast Guard's newest and most modern lightship, the Ambrose (WAL-613), arrived at St. George, S. I., from Baltimore yesterday to take on stores for the vital but lonely vigil off Ambrose Channel -- the major seaway to the Port of New York.

Among the many cruel tragedies of war there is one that is especially grievous to all concerned, and that is the accidental bombardment of friendly troops. The tragedy is all the more painful if, in a coalition war, the injury is inflicted by the troops of one nation on the troops of a gallant ally.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- John Rhodes Cobb, holder of the world's automobile speed record, was killed today when his jet-propelled boat Crusader was halfway to a new world mark of more than 200 miles an hour on the waters of Loch Ness in Scotland.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Dissension brewing for months between head coach Joe Stydahar and his backfield coach. Hampton Pool, blew to the surface today in the defending champion Los Angeles Rams of the National Football League.

The opening hearing into the controversy over the new dual rate exclusive patronage contract proposed by the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference will be held here on Oct. 28, it was announced yesterday by the Federal Maritime Board.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Jim Rivera, Chicago White Sox rookie outfielder, today was ordered booked on a charge of raping the 22-year-old wife of a soldier, a statistician at Fifth Army headquarters, who was working part time as an usher at the time of the incident.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Mutual Security Agency stoutly defended today the sending of a former Iowa corn husking champion overseas to help increase production of hybrid corn in Western Europe.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 29 -- The nation's chief scientists should have an effective voice in defense planning at policy-making levels, Dr. Lloyd Berkner declared here today. He is president of Associated Universities, Inc., which operates Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island for the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Governor Stevenson at Louisville Saturday night wholly subscribed to the charge made by Secretary of State Acheson that, in connecting Acheson's speech of Jan. 12, 1950, with the attack of North Korea against South Korea June 25 of the same year, General Eisenhower "distorted" history and to serve that purpose omitted a salient passage in Acheson's speech.

Although Western Europe is far from being a political or economic entity it is beginning to draw together as never before in modern times. The approach is functional. It began with an effort to restore normal economic life, to break down trade barriers, and to promote the common defense.

The country's steel mills set a new production record last week. Operating at 104 per cent of theoretical capacity, or 1.7 points better than they had expected, the mills poured 2,160,000 net tons of raw steel during the seven-day period ending Sept. 27, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

HONG KONG, Sept. 29 -- A special ten-day "friendship period" has been proclaimed in Ulan Bator, capital of Outer Mongolia, to highlight the importance of the "cultural and economic cooperation" between the Soviet-oriented republic and Communist China, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Grain futures were again under pressure of long liquidation today, wheat, corn and oats showing substantial recessions at times. December wheat again made a new low for the crop. Buying appeared to be largely by shorts, taking profits but there was enough commission buying to cause moderate recoveries from the low spots.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Supplementing pay increases that were adopted Aug. 4 for most of the 3,000 Westchester County employes, the Board of Supervisors approved today an upward revision in the salary scales for twenty-nine job classifications and held a public hearing on pay increases for supervisors.

One way to describe the troubled times in which we live is to call this the age of the displaced person. Slave labor in Russia, refugees crossing into West Germany, countless millions in Korea, China, India and Pakistan -- these for one reason or another have been compelled to leave their old homes and find a precarious existence elsewhere.

Ireland, which recently embarked on an intensive drive to increase exports to the dollar market, is taking steps to promote greater trade with Canada. A trade adviser representing Coras Trachtala Teoranta (Irish Dollar Export Corporation) will arrive in Canada soon for a three-month promotion tour, it was announced here yesterday by the Consulate General of Ireland.
ALBANY, Sept. 29 (UP) -- The fabulous painting, "Genius of America," that hung in the Grand Union Hotel in Saratoga Springs for 75 years may be given to Albany.
The Columbia football team went through two hours of defensive drills yesterday as Coach Lou Little opened practice for Saturday's game against Harvard.

Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, in his first appearance in New York since he became the Democratic candidate for Vice President, accused the Republicans last night of using catchy phrases and glib slogans. He cited the phrase "creeping socialism" as an example of "counterfeit rhetoric passing as legal tender."

A small but important segment of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., yesterday postponed for one week a previous order to its rank-and-file members not to report to work after midnight tonight. The work stoppage had been decided upon following the inability of this group to reach agreement with employers on a new contract. The present pact expires tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Fellow workers said today that Senator John J. Sparkman's wife, Ivo, puts in a six-day, sixty-hour week to earn the $4,500 a year base pay she gets as one of his staff.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Greater emphasis on guidance as a means of cutting down the "alarming" number of pupils who drop out of school was urged here today at the annual meeting of the Council of City and Village School Superintendents.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the Department of Agriculture said today that it may be some time before the ban on imports of livestock, meat and game animals from Canada is lifted.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- Two views, diametrically opposed, were expressed here today at a Pacific Coast meeting of the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- An all-electronic color television set that requires no spinning disk and will automatically receive either color or black and white transmission pictures was described here today. Kenneth E. Farr, Westinghouse Electric Corporation engineer, said picture quality of the forty-two tube laboratory model color set developed by his company is "comparable to black and white in every respect."

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 30 -- The Chinese Communists seized and held for more than six hours yesterday three United States soldiers who unwittingly had wandered across the line around the 1,000-yard neutral zone set aside at Panmunjom for the negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war.

Two more large stores announced yesterday an additional night opening on Mondays. Previously, several leading stores here and elsewhere had adopted the Monday evening opening supplementing that on Thursday night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Government earmarked an additional 25,000 tons of casing and tubing today for delivery to oil and gas operators during December.

The city is holding $59,110 in money earned by Victor Clemente, contractor on fourteen Queens sewer jobs, and in deposits on three others, it was learned yesterday. Various municipal agencies, meanwhile, are studying how much of this sum might be attached to pay for repairs to alleged faults in his projects.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (UP) -- Slingin' Sam Baugh, ejected from a football game for the first time in his sixteen years as a pro player, still passed for two touchdowns tonight as Curly Lambeau's Washington Redskins won a revenge 23-to-7 victory over the Chicago Cardinals in a National League contest before 17,837 fans.
Praise for Princeton formed the major part of the message Harvy Harman, Rutgers coach, brought to the Football Writers Association luncheon yesterday at Toots Shor's.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 30 -- The Chinese Communists, using tanks, infantrymen and artillery, launched heavier attacks yesterday along a ten-mile sector of the east-central front in Korea and scored local penetrations against hard fighting South Korean defenders.

The slight progress made last week by the stock market was arrested yesterday due mainly to reduced trading in the pivotal issues. Despite the extra half hour of business on the Big Board which extended trading hours to 3:30 o'clock, interest was restricted in good measure by the Jewish holiday.

Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal party candidate for the United States Senate, urged construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway yesterday. He asserted that railroads and power interests had blocked the development "for narrow and selfish" reasons.
TERRY MOORE was wearing a worried frown when he walked over to talk to Bill Dickey.

TOKYO, Sept 23 -- Almost all of the air and armored forces of the Chinese Communist regime, more than one-third of its field armies and a large proportion of its Soviet-made artillery have been pinned down in Korea by the United Nations forces, despite the lag in recent action occasioned by the truce talks at Panmunjom, Japanese sources state.

Production of machine tools, the giant machines that make machines, is continuing to increase. As a result, the backlog of orders is dropping steadily. The National Association of Machine Tool Builders, a Cleveland group, reported yesterday that cancellations of tools ordered for national defense were still heavy in proportion to new orders.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 29 -- Bob Watson and Pete Cassella of Brookville scored an 8-under-par 33, 29 -- 62 for victory in the Long Island Professional Golfers Association amateur-pro tourney at the Huntington Crescent Club today.

A water main burst early this morning under Broadway between White and Lispenard Streets, flooding the Canal Street station of the B. M. T. subway and disrupting service on all of its express and local lines. Vehicular traffic on the busy Canal Street link between the Manhattan Bridge and the Holland Tunnel also was tied up.

The growing emphasis on cooking and serving in the same container is pointed up by the opening of a department at Georg Jensen called "Design in Use." Here are collected several new and many old designs of the kind and quality that would encourage the homemaker to continue this practice.

Station WOR-TV will discontinue nine programs at the end of this week, including its "All Night Show," and reduce its weekday on-the-air hours approximately 35 per cent. The changes are being made for reasons of economy.

Mayor Impelliteri's program to increase the number of policemen to or beyond the authorized strength of 19,847 by July 1 will go into high gear tomorrow when 800 recruits will be sworn in at 10:30 A. M. at City Hall.

MEHALLA EL KOBRA, Egypt, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Egypt's strong man, Premier Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, making a triumphal tour of northern Egypt, promised thousands of wildly cheering Egyptians today that the British would be forced out of the Nile Valley.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, and Harry M. Moses, bargaining agent for the Northern coal operators, signed a one-year contract today that will affect more than half of the country's miners.

Baseballs, propelled first by the Dodgers, then by the Yankees, flew in all directions at spacious Yankee Stadium yesterday as the National and American League pennant winners prepared to clash at Ebbets Field tomorrow at 1 P. M. in the first game of the 1952 world series.

The first volume of an American edition of the memoirs of Edouard Herriot, President of the French National Assembly, will be published Oct. 14 by the Old and New World Publishing Corporation. "In Those Days," the first of three volumes, describes M. Herriot's early life and his first steps in French politics.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, declared here today that there has been a "positive and definite" increase in the morale of the armed forces of the North Atlantic Treaty countries from Norway on the western flank of the alliance to Turkey on the east."

MORECAMBE, England, Sept. 29 -- Aneurin Bevan, who wants to inject more old-fashioned socialism into the British Labor party's program, had his say today on the first day of the annual party conference at Morecambe.

Hugh Gibson, director of the Provisional Intergovernmental Committee for the Movement of Migrants from Europe, said yesterday in an interview that several South American countries were definitely interested in absorbing as much as they could of Europe's surplus population of 5,000,000. Mr. Gibson cited Venezuela, Brazil, Chile, Paraguay, Uruguay and "possibly Argentina."

Arrangements for the presentation in New York, London and Paris of the dramatic version of Pierre La Mure's novel, "Moulin Rouge," practically have been completed, according to Arthur Lesser, sponsor of the multiple offerings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Republican National Committee issued today a series of bulletins replying to what it said were "misrepresentations" by President Truman in back-of-the-train speeches as he headed west.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson tonight portrayed the Bible, which appears in a new version tomorrow, as having had a predominating role in shaping the national life of this country.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Kansas City staged a four-run rally in the eighth inning to break a tie and defeat Rochester, 6 -- 2, in the third game of the little world series tonight. The American Association club took a 2-1 lead in the four-out-of-seven series.

The only news by which those in the business of raising, wholesaling or retailing flowers can obtain their proper share of the consumer's dollar is through cooperation in national advertising and promotional programs, according to John Henry Dudley, Lansing, Mich., president of the Society of American Florists.

August bookings by furniture manufacturers were sufficient to place cumulative 1952 business ahead of the first eight months of last year, according to the monthly report yesterday of Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading producers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The White House announced today that President Truman had directed a study "of the skilled manpower requirements which would be placed upon the watchmaking industry in event of full mobilization."

MADRID, Sept. 29 -- A nationwide project designed to cope with one of Spain's gravest social and economic problems -- the extreme subdivision of land holdings -- is quietly being drafted by the Spanish Government, well-informed sources said today.

Travel is broadening, and John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn and Democratic candidate for United States Senator, proved it when he went far north to Watertown for a campaign speech under the sponsorship of the Jefferson County Democratic Committee. In that part of the country, apparently, it is not politically discreet to oppose the St. Lawrence Seaway project.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Air raid sirens, horns and whistles will be sounded at 7:45 P. M. tomorrow throughout Westchester County for a public test of civil defense facilities. Traffic will be halted from 7:55 P. M. to 8 P. M. on the three Post Roads -- Routes 1, 9, and 22 -- but no interruptions in other activities will take place.

ABOARD THE TRUMAN TRAIN, in North Dakota, Sept. 29 -- President Truman declared today that the Republican party was split four ways on farm policy and that its Presidential candidate, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, had stepped off the party's farm plank right "into the deep water."

MOSCOW, Sept. 27 -- The Literary Gazette today published a letter from the wife of a mining engineer describing the "hysterics" of her husband's bosses and working conditions so disorganized that her husband and other mine technicians never have any days off, seldom get more than a couple of hours of sleep a night and receive a tongue lashing if they go to the movies with their wives.
The growing importance of trade unions in the international scheme of things is pointed up by two separate proposals, widely different in origin, publicized on the same day.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- President Truman has approved a plan for the Government to insure air lies against the hazards of war abroad.

The most solemn occasion in the Jewish year -- Yom Kippur, or the Day of Atonement -- ended at sundown last night as Jews the world over brought to a close a twenty-four-hour period of prayer, penitence, meditation and fasting.

Having helped to find foster parents for 7,500 children in the last forty-four years, Miss Sophie van Senden Theis will retire today from the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.
Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, Commanding General of the First Army, announced yesterday he would retire from active military service at the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, Republican National Chairman, declared today that President Truman's whistle stop tour through the West had "lowered the great office of the President to the level of the cheapest politics."
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Commodore George Edward Cove, commander of the liner Queen Elizabeth and commodore of the Cunard fleet, retired today from a sea career that lasted nearly forty-eight years.
Alicia Markova last night made her second guest appearance with Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House, this time in "Swan Lake." Again it was a performance of exquisite artistry.

" Son of Paleface," which arrives at the Paramount, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Paramount Technicolor comedy stars Bob Hope, Jane Russell and Roy Rogers. Frank Tashlin directed and Robert L. Welch produced from a script written by the Messrs. Tashlin, Welch and Joseph Quillan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, announced today that he had asked the Department of Justice not to institute deportation proceedings against Frank Costello, New York gambler and racketeer, until it had been determined whether Costello would be needed as a witness "at trials of some of our former key Government officials."

Senator Herbert H. Lehman proposed yesterday to the President's special Commission on Immigration and Naturalization that this country open its doors to more than double the number of immigrants now being admitted and eliminate country-of-origin quotas and racial discrimination.
MOSCOW, Sept. 30 -- Shaburov's wedding party will be famous for some time to come in Baku. Or perhaps infamous would be a better word to use.
JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., Sept. 30 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft tonight accused the Truman Administration of following a "demagogic" policy of "spend and spend and tax and tax and elect and elect."

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Sept. 30 -- Settlement of the Saar's future on terms favorable to France was presented as the price of French ratification of the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community Treaty today by Gilbert Grandval, French Ambassador to the territory.

Harry Gross said yesterday that in 1947 he took over operation of two horse rooms in the Garment District that had been run by George Scalise, former president of the Building Service Employes International Union.

Bonds called for payment in September before maturity were fewer than in the preceding month, but the total was the largest for any corresponding period since 1950. The month's total of $40,313,000, which was the smallest figure since June, compared with $40,908,000 in August and $18,229,000 in September, 1951.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 30 -- The Khedivial Mail Line steamer Mohamed Ali El Kebir docked at Pier 1, here, this morning with sixty-two passengers from Mediterranean ports. Among them was Prof. Mohammed Mustafa Giada, 52-year-old head of the Department of History at Fuad I University, Cairo, and one of the four international winners of John Hay Whitney Foundation World Scholarship s.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified 122 battle casualties today in a new Korean war list that included 17 killed, 103 wounded, 1 missing and 1 injured. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):
Brooklyn's pets, once inelegantly described as "them bums," to which Branch Rickey some time later gave the more refined touch of "ferocious gentlemen," are about to try it again.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 30 -- A dispatch from Kuala Lumpur today gave details of the murder of R. E. Bogle, assistant manager of the European-owned Frazer estate in the Kulai district of the southern Malaya state of Johore.

ABOARD THE TRUMAN TRAIN, in Montana, Sept. 30 -- Continuing his hammering offensive against Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President Truman today accused the Republican Presidential candidate personally of underestimating the Soviet menace and thereby doing "a great deal of harm."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Donald C. Cook, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced today that his agency has adopted new rules dealing with the registration and prospectus requirements of the Securities Act of 1933.

An appeal to "the next President of the -- United States" to assist government and business in eliminating "road-blocks in the path of the continued prosperity of our country" was made yesterday by H. E. Humphreys Jr., president of the United States Rubber Company, in a speech that he called "a Father's Message to the Next President of the United States."
TORONTO, Sept. 30 -- The Toronto Symphony Orchestra today announced that all playing personnel will be screened for Communist connections.

The Italian whole wheat bread in a little Italain restaurant on Mulberry Street is crusty, flavorful, with lots of chew and none of the sweetening that makes American whole wheat bread unsuitable to eat with many main dishes. Having munched our way through what must be several loaves, we finally asked the proprietor the other day where he got his bread.

GENEVA, Sept. 30 -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, one-time president of the German Reichsbank and current adviser of numerous governments in the more turbulent parts of the world, has conclusively demonstrated to the Swiss that whatever he may have lost during and since World War II, he retains his talent for rubbing people the wrong way.

A method to use the facilities of small machine shops in the event big ones are "knocked out" by sabotage or a "sneak" attack was outlined yesterday by Russell S. Rymer, special programs coordinator in the Office of Inspector of Naval Material.

Millions of voters are turning to the Republican Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates because "they know the safety of every man, woman and child in America depends on rooting the traitors out of our Government," former Representative from Connecticut Clare Boothe Luce said last night.

A meeting of the committee of the Benedicts, a subscription dance for young married couples, post debutantes and single men, was held yesterday afternoon at the office of Chapin Palmer, 50 East Seventy-second Street. The dance will take place on Nov. 28 in the ballroom of the Pierre.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Office of Price Stabilization dropped price controls today on a number of additional items that the agency decided came within restrictions of the new National Production Act. Under an amendment to the law, which includes provisions for economic controls, price curbs on fruits and vegetables, both fresh and processed, were ordered dropped.

Determined to prevent a repetition of the carnival atmosphere that marked the 1952 Easter Parade on Fifth Avenue the police have pledged that next year they will, if necessary, "forcibly" exclude from the area those "characters" intent on making a mockery of the holy day.

Hawaii is the land of the latest progress in personnel administration as well as grass-skirted romanticism, Ralph O. Beck Jr., vice president of the Mutual Telephone Company, Ltd., of Honolulu, declared yesterday. In an address before second-day sessions of the American Management Association's personnel conference in the Astor Hotel, he said the island territory has far outstripped the mainland in many personnel administration techniques since the end of World War II.

Some that is familiar and much that is new is to be seen in an exhibit of the works of sixteen Italian artisans at Bonniers, 605 Madison Avenue. The display which includes glass, ceramics, brass, lamps and, lacquered trays, offers a timely opportunity to revaluate the modern design movement in Italy.
Two threats to peace on the waterfront, here and in other Atlantic Coast ports, were dissipated yesterday, at least temporarily.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Benjamin Dorfman, one of four New York men accused of first-degree murder in the slaying of a Reader's Digest guard at New Castle in a robbery on April 3, 1950, pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter in County Court today before Judge Eugene F. Sullivan.

An announcement last night by Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet that Engine Company 326 at 2929 West Eighth Street, Coney Island, was being discontinued immediately brought quick protests from the Uniformed Firemen's Association and from civic groups of the Coney Island area.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Mortgage bankers today were warned that the present prosperity can't go on forever and were urged-to set their house in order to meet bad times when they come. This caution was sounded by L. Douglas Meredith, executive vice president of the National Life Insurance Company, Montpelier, Vt., at the annual convention of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America in the Conrad Hilton Hotel.

A new joint procurement agency for the Army, Navy and Air Force, which is expected to purchase nearly $2,000,000,000 worth of clothing and equippage this fiscal year, starts operations today at 111 East Sixteenth Street. The agency, built on a reorganization of the New York Army and Navy Purchasing Offices, will be commanded by Brig. Gen. R. P. Hollis, formerly in command of the New York Procurement Agency.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Jubilation still reigned today on Colgate's picturesque Chenango Valley campus over the first defeat of Cornell since 1944, which launched the coaching regime of Hal Lahar in spectacular fashion last Saturday.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The principal activity in the stock markets centered again today in the foreign bond section, although the turnover was much smaller than yesterday. With profit-taking in progress, the advance in Japanese bonds was only moderate and early gains were not fully held.

The defense in the conspiracy trial of thirteen secondary Communist party leaders, charged with teaching and advocating the violent overthrow of the Government, produced its first witness yesterday. He proceeded to give a point-by-point contradiction of testimony by the Government's first witness, Louis F. Budenz.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Federal Reserve Board's index of industrial production climbed 30 points above the July average this month, according to preliminary estimates for September released today.
HAVRE, Mont., Sept 30 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of President Truman's address here today:

The Department of Sanitation, which will institute a forty-four-hour week for its uniformed force today, announced yesterday that it had called up 900 reinforcements from the Civil Service lists to maintain adequate street cleaning services.

New fall clothing from the Budget Shops of Lord Taylor were shown yesterday on the second floor of the store. New fashion highlights that had been modified expressly for less expensive clothes were noted throughout the collection of suits, coats, daytime and evening dresses.

A renewed tendency on the part of some members of the cosmetics industry to resort to exaggerated advertising claims for products, particularly new ones, has been noted by the Toilet Goods Association, Inc. This is unfortunate, the association maintains, because if one company, by using these methods obtains a large part of a certain market, its competitors are tempted to follow suit.
Contracts are being drawn for Sam and Bella Spewack to convert "Angels Cooking" as a welcome addition to Broadway's bill of fare, it became known yesterday.
Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, yesterday accused the Liberal party of reneging on its commitment to endorse him.

Commissioner of Investigation James H. Sheils yesterday subpoenaed books and records of fifteen leading contractors in the Queens sewer field, as the widening Queens sewer investigations caused the hold-over summer grand jury to be extended for two more months -- from Oct. 6 to Dec. 8.

At 1 o'clock this afternoon the teams will square away. The world series will begin. Come to think of it, New Yorkers are lucky dogs. For four years running now at least part of the championship struggle has been played within local precincts. Indeed, during three of these years the championships were subway affairs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon publicly voiced his gratitude today to those who supported him in the recent controversy over his acceptance of a privately financed expense fund of $18,235.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that it has arranged with fourteen New York banks for a $75,000,000 credit, effective on Oct. 14. A credit for the same amount with the same group of banks expires that day.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- The De Havilland Aircraft Company announced tonight it had completed delivery of nine Comet jetliners to the British Overseas Airways Corporation fifteen months ahead of schedule and soon would fulfill foreign orders.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Anita R. Colt's Jack Jr. sped to a length and one-half victory in the Stetson Purse today before a crowd of 11,004. The 3-year-old gelding turned back seven others in his age group and was the third favorite in the first five races to reach the winner's circle.
The market for Treasury securities scored net gains for the day ranging up to about 1/8 of a point for long-term bonds following a confusing trading session yesterday.
George A. Cornish, managing editor of The New York Herald Tribune for the last eleven years, has been named executive editor of the paper, it was announced last night by Whitelaw Reid, editor.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 30 (AP) -- President Truman said today American newspapers had "an unsurpassed opportunity" to serve their country in giving the facts of this year's political campaign.

SANTA MARIA, The Azores, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Church bells rang and bands played in the port city of Figueira da Foz today in rejoicing for the rescue of all seventy-four men aboard the Portuguese fishing vessel Joao Costa, which sank in the Atlantic after an explosion a week ago.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 30 -- Mrs. William Stockhausen of The Creek Club turned in a score of 80 -- 6 -- 74 to win the low net honors during the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Garden City Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Although the Treasury has refinanced most of an $11,000,000,000 issue of certificates of indebtedness, there were signs tonight that even an exceptionally high interest rate failed to keep all commercial holders of the issue interested.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 80 -- All school boards in the state must take steps before the end of the year to remove subversive teachers and must report their action against the teachers to the State Education Department, the department's counsel said today.

Tom Fool made it look easy again. The Greentree Stable's 3-year-old just appeared to romp to victory in the Sysonby Handicap, the one-mile race that served as the feature on the program at Belmont Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Army released today the details on a massive but maneuverable atomic gun. The eighty-five-ton weapon, which shoots an eleven-inch projectile for at least twenty miles, is designed to put down an atomic barrage in support of ground troops.

Dean Alfange, one of the founders of the Liberal party, which is now backing Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for President, announced last night his own support of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican choice. He also said he would support Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for re-election.

Your lead editorial of Sept. 26 dealing with inflation gives an impression which is at variance with the facts, and I am sure you will wish to correct or clarify it. I refer to the statement that "inflation was mounting rapidly long before June, 1950."

A preliminary count of ballots cast by 353 residents of Parkway Village in Queens in a referendum vote last night indicated early today that the 685 tenants there would refuse to sign new leases that would increase their rent. Today is the deadline for acceptance of the rent increase.

WATERTOWN ARSENAL, Mass., Sept. 15 (Delayed) -- Midnight stragglers in Boston's Scollay Square were among the first unauthorized and unsuspecting civilians to see the atomic artillery piece on Labor Day, 1950.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -- Helen Deutsch and Joseph Pasternak, M-G-M writer and producer, are plotting a romantic drama about the international set that has been entered on the studio's future production schedule as "Nina."

Although trading on the New York Stock Exchange in September expanded slightly compared with that in August, the volume of business was the smallest in three years for a September. This was also true of the 241,069,131 share turnover for the first nine months of this year.

The Health Department's orthopedic consultation service, which has been called one of the weak links in the agency's chain of services for physically handicapped children, has been strengthened as a result of recommendations in a study by the American Public Health Association.

One of the most baffling mysteries of the current Presidential campaign is the apparently steadfast determination of General Eisenhower and his advisers not to take the Taft-Hartley bull by the horns and defend, and in defending explain, that legislation before the electorate.

Thousands of fans in the metropolitan area, disappointed in their quest for tickets and not otherwise able to keep in touch with the progress of the world series, will be kept informed of developments in each game merely by dialing the New York Telephone Company's time bureau, MEridian 7-1212.

ALBANY, Sept. 30 -- Enlistments in New York National Guard anti-aircraft artillery units will be open to men from 35 to 44 years of age under authorization by the Department of the Army, Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, commanding officer of the guard, announced today.

MORECAMBE, England, Sept. 30 -- Aneurin Bevan and his leftist bloc in the British Labor party won a great victory today at the party's national conference, a victory that surely will influence party policy, although it has by no means delivered the party into Mr. Bevan's hands.

HONG KONG, Sept 30 -- Foreign Roman Catholic missionaries arriving from China said today that a number of Chinese had been taught how and when to "kneel, genuflect, bow and fold their hands" for the "progressive" Catholic ceremonies accompanying the coming "Asian and Pacific Peace Conference" in Peiping.

The inability of the railroad issues to maintain the basic price structure sent the stock market yesterday into a moderate recession. Pressure was fairly general and produced even wider inroads than were sustained Monday, when the extra half hour was added to the daily trading schedule on the Stock Exchange.
Larger flotations of local government and public utility bonds than in recent months and a smaller volume of stock offerings marked the new financing here in September.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 1 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,389, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Wednesday, Korean time:

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 1 -- Communist troops, in another of the series of sharp probes that they have thrown along a wide front in Korea, captured another hill yesterday, their third this week. In bitter though still small-scale fighting, Chinese units, backed by tanks, dislodged United Nations forces from high ground east of Kumsong.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (UP) -Hampton Pool was named head coach of the pro football champion Los Angeles Rams today after Joe Stydahar resigned or was "fired," as the result of coaching staff dissension and the team's poor showing.

Morning shopping will be a thing of the past within five years, with most retail establishments open from noon to 9 P. M., Robert _. Whitney, president of the National Sales Executives, Inc., predicted yesterday at the opening of a three-day sales conference of the Frank H. Lee Company, hat manufacturer at the St. Regis Hotel.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Sept. 30 -- Maj. Gen. Alvan C. Kincaid, vice commander of the Continental Air Command, reviewed marching Air Force squadrons for the last time here today as he ended thirty-five years of military service.

A paper-bound edition of "Speeches of Adlai Stevenson" is scheduled for Oct. 16 publication by Random House. The speeches begin with Mr. Stevenson's welcoming address to the Chicago Democratic Convention and continue through to his Baltimore address on inflation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- A penchant for tackling knotty human problems at their roots appears to be the chief characteristic of Mrs. Elizabeth Healy Ross, noted psychiatric social worker to be sworn in tomorrow as deputy chief of the Children's Bureau.

An extra dividend of $1.25 a share and a quarterly dividend of $1.25 a share on the common stock, both payable on Dec. 8 to stockholders of record Oct. 31, have been authorized by directors of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway System. An extra dividend of 50 cents a share was distributed a year earlier.

The contract between the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., and almost one hundred dry cargo ship and tanker companies, which expired at midnight last night, has been extended on a "day-today" basis.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Mrs. E. B. Coxe 3d of Haverford, Pa., and Mrs. J. Stewart Brown of Sewickley, Pa., won the United States Senior Women's Golf Association Scotch foursome tournament with 41, 39-80 over the South course of the Westchester Country Club today.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 30 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin opened his own campaign in support of the Republican national ticket here this afternoon by assuring Fairfield County residents attending the Danbury Fair that "you ain't seen nothing yet" in the fight on communism. That fight, he added, is going to get "rougher and rougher and rougher."
Travel on the B. M. T. subway was returning to normal late yesterday afternoon as crews from various city agencies succeeded in restoring the inundated Canal Street station at Broadway to full use.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 30 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, after receiving a hero's welcome from approximately 35,000 South Carolinians and their Governor, James F. Byrnes, charged today that the Democrats had produced "treadmill prosperity" and an Administration marked by "a scandal a day."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 30 -- The national protest movement that drove President Bechara el-Khoury from power less than two weeks ago and made Camille Chamoun President brought forth tonight a trusteeship Cabinet of four neutral functionaries headed by diplomat Khalid Shehab, Lebanon's Minister to Jordan, as Premier, Minister of the Interior and of Justice and Information.
LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 1 -- According to the seventeenth edition of Burke's Landed Gentry, published today, ownership of a country estate is no longer the main qualification for recognition

The need for an over-all body to cope with the transportation problems in and around New York City was emphasized yesterday by David Rockefeller, vice president of the Chase National Bank, in a speech to 500 experts and others interested in regional planning.

Reports that Brazil would increase the number of import licenses covering goods from the hard currency area rated as essential came as a surprise yesterday to exporters here. The reason: Brazil has been following a policy of curtailed dollar imports as part of its program to reduce the present backlog of unpaid commercial outstandings due United States exporters.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 30 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, commenting on Gen. Walter Bedell Smith's statement that Communists possibly had infiltrated the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that the nonpolitical agency "must never become a political football."
The Revised Standard Version of the Holy Bible, a new and authorized revision by American Protestant scholars, was published yesterday by Thomas Nelson Sons with an advance sale of 1,000,000 copies.

A two-story building at 550 Bergen Avenue, at the corner of East 149th Street, the Bronx, leased to Hearn Department Stores, Inc. has been sold by Irving Fishman, Nathan Weinberg and Jack Stonenblick to Abe Schoenbaum.

There was something dramatic yesterday in the appearance of the Republican nominee for President pleading his cause in front of the Capitol of the State of South Carolina -- and it was something new in American politics. Of all the states of the "Solid South," South Carolina is among the most "solid," which means most solidly anti-Republican.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Long Island Rail Road Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to abandon the operation of about twelve miles of its Rockaway and Far Rockaway Beach branches.

MEXICO CITY, Sept 30 -- A former Mexican opera singer and a one-time explosives engineer were under arrest today as the main conspirators in the recent plot to blow up a Mexican Airways DC-3 and collect $208,000 insurance on six of the twenty persons aboard the plane.
Michigan State's mighty Spartans, who have established a pattern of winning their football games with rallies are the nation's No. 1 football team.
Except for potatoes on the New York Mercantile Exchange, trading in commodities here was light yesterday. Tin, wool, wool tops and world sugar made gains. The mothers were lower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- The United States has drawn up a resolution asking the United Nations General Assembly to call on the Chinese Communists and the North Koreans to end the war in Korea on the basis of the truce terms submitted by Gen. Mark W. Clark's Unified Command in Tokyo.
" No, I haven't been losing my rest in thinking about tomorrow," said Joe Black yesterday, just before he went out to join his mates in the final workout at the Yankee Stadium.

EAST PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 30 (AP) -- A mental hospital fugitive robbed a Providence bank of $51,239 today, killed a policeman, wounded another and held two women as hostages in their home before the police subdued him with tear gas.

It is all over now, make no mistake about that. It has gone, and no amount of self-delusion can either persuade to the contrary or can get it back. It went swiftly. It seems no more than an hour ago, perhaps even less, that the rising sun of an early dawn proclaimed the summer as here.

ATLANTA, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Capt. Walter J. Shaffer, who began flying in 1915, retired today as an airline pilot at the age of 65. His last turn at plane controls was on an Eastern Air Lines flight from Indianapolis to Atlanta.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 30 -- The Duchess of Kent, 46-year-old aunt of Queen Elizabeth of Britain, arrived here this afternoon for a month of ceremonial functions in British Far Eastern territories. Her visit is the first made here by a member of the British royal family since the tour by the late King George VI, when he was Duke of York in 1929.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 30 -- The Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe voted with near unanimity today a proposal that would establish close organic links between the six continental nations now moving toward economic and political federation and Britain and seven other nonparticipating council states.
Nearly 4,000,000 Americans -- a proportionate number of them from New York -- are in uni form. They are in combat, on occupation duty in hospitals, in training camps, and in key defense bases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Southern Coal Producers Association signed the national soft coal wage agreement today but an undisclosed number of companies whose tonnage was described by John L. Lewis as "nominal" have not accepted the terms.

Woven palmetto strips are one of the textured designs reproduced in a group of plastic wall coverings available through decorators at the Gilford Leather Company, 515 Madison Avenue. Backed with fabric, these materials might also be suitable for upholstery coverings.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Sept. 30 -- The frustrated Army plot in Venezuela, announced yesterday by the Government in Caracas, may end the Venezuelan Opposition's hopes of getting at least a strong minority in the Nov. 30 elections for a constituent assembly.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 (AP) Penn announced its 1953 football schedule in a hot-dog napkin.
The Yankees got their last look at "soft" pitching yesterday until after the world series. And they were hitting the ball into the seats.

The number of Negroes in the seventeen-county New York-North-eastern New Jersey standard metropolitan area of the United States Bureau of the Census has passed the million mark for the first time. This has been shown by the 1950 census.

OSSINING, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Commuters here have banded together to promote the No-Vote No-Gripe Club and reports tonight indicated it was expanding into many parts of the metropolitan area, with 11,000 "N-V N-G" lapel buttons already distributed to adherents of all political parties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The remark President Truman quoted General Eisenhower as uttering about the friendship policy of the Soviet Union toward the United States was made Nov. 15, 1945, in the course of testimony before the Military Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives. General Eisenhower was testifying in support of Universal Military Training.

The Whitney Museum will open to the public today an exhibition of work by contemporary American artists in the collection of Edith and Milton Lowenthal. One hundred and eleven examples are included and thirty-two artists are represented by paintings, sculpture or drawings.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 30 Maurice (Mickey) Shuman, Peddie Prep School head football coach, doesn't have much depth, but his current Old Gold and Blue has the potential to better the showing of the 1951 eleven.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Gen. Waiter Bedell Smith, head of the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that he had furnished the two Presidential candidates, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, and President Truman as well, with an amplification of his statement about Communist spies at a court hearing yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Paul V. McNutt, former Federal Security Administrator, accepted membership today on the Veterans Advisory Committee just set up by the Democratic National Committee. Mr. McNutt was at one time United States High Commissioner in the Philippines and was the first United States Ambassador to the islands when they became independent.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 30 -- A purported letter from Ambassador Chester Bowles to the editor of a pro-Communist publication in Bombay was disavowed by the Ambassador and also by the editor in question today immediately upon publication in another Bombay weekly of a photostat of the alleged letter.
The Beatrice Foods Company had a net profit of $1,387,279 in the six months ended on Aug. 31 on sales of $118,011,243, William G. Karnes, president, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Grain futures showed quite a little strength following initial weakness today, but buyers are still chary of following rallies, and prices settled back after the early run-up. As has been the case for some time, weather conditions that are perfect for corn and soybeans, are the reverse in regard to winter wheat seeding, and there is also concern now regarding late pasturage conditions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Truman placed an additional import duty of five cents a pound on shelled almonds, including those blanched, roasted or preserved, but not including almond paste, by proclamation today.
PARIS, Sept. 30 -- France's deficit with the European Payments Union for September will be between $50,000,000 and $60,000,000, the highest registered in six months, it was learned today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 -- "Gutter politics" was the term put on President Truman's criticism of General Eisenhower by Gov. John Lodge of Connecticut on his arrival here today to speek at an Eisenhower-Nixon rally in Beverly Hills.

The relative positions of the leaders in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden were virtually unchanged yesterday, by the results recorded in the tenth round, according to a report from Stockholm.

Earl Browder, former head of the Communist party in this country who was ousted from the party in 1946, and his wife, Raissa Irene Berkman Browder, were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of making false statements in connection with her petition for naturalization.

New issues of corporate securities valued at more than $74,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings-include twenty-five-year debentures of Anheuser-Busch, Inc., reflecting the first public financing of this 100- year-old brewing company.

Aneurin Bevan, leader of the leftwing Laborites in Britain, won a handsome personal victory at the annual Labor party conference in Morecambe yesterday. Two of his followers -- R. H. S. Crossman and Harold Wilson -- supplanted two old-time stalwarts -- Herbert Morrison and Hugh Dalton -- on the party executive.

BINGHAMTON, Sept. 30 -- Lieut. Gov. Frank Moore came here today to attempt to remove opposition to the State University of New York's plan to have local communities pay their share of costs for permanent state Institutes of Applied Arts and Sciences.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 30 -- The United States Embassy has made inquiries at the Foreign Ministry about an anti-American play performed at the Royal Theatre to inaugurate The Hague's fifth annual "Month of Arts."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices of farm products as a whole decreased 2 per cent during the month ending Sept. 15.

The Regional Plan Association has given expert attention to the problems of transportation. The theme of the major session of its seventh annual Regional Plan Conference yesterday was transportation and its relation to metropolitan living. The speaker was chosen not because he was an expert, but because he was not.
A new collection of mirrors designed by Edmond J. Spence for the Carolina Mirror Corporation are now available through decorators at the designer's showroom, 40 East Seventy-third Street.

CAIRO, Sept. 30 -- The Egyptian army moved today to tighten its control over the civil administration of the country by assigning staff officers to every Government department. An announcement from general headquarters said:

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30 -- Several thousand students at the University of Buenos Aires went on strike today to regain privileges that they believe are part of a democratic regime. Early tonight approximately one thousand engineering students gathered in the courtyard of the School of Engineering and denounced a Government decision to abolish the Centro de Estudiantes de Ingenieria (Engineering Students Center), which has been critical of the faculty.

CLYDE BRION DAVIS' new novel, "Thudbury,"* is an ironic comedy about a wealthy, conservative and powerful American business man. It might have been a maliciously entertaining satire, for Mr. Davis is a clever and skillful writer with a gift for parody; but it is a tiresome and flat novel instead, because Mr. Davis has chosen to use a technical narrative device that sadly damages his story's effectiveness.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Politics and a constitutional amendment are playing havoc with White House social life.

The State of Maryland announced yesterday that it will receive bids Oct. 8 on two bond issues. One will consist of $17,000,000 of obligations dated Nov. 1, 1952, and due Nov. 1, from 1955 to 1967. The other will be $1,500,000 of Johns Hopkins University bonds dated Nov. 1, 1952, and due Nov. 1, 1955 to 1967.

Elsewhere on this page we carry a letter from a correspondent referring to our editorial of Sept. 26 "Mr. Stevenson on Inflation." The passage to which our correspondent refers was a commentary directed at Governor Stevenson's attempt to dismiss the inflation issue with the observation that "the Kremlin" had "dumped a barrel of yeast in our economy."

The appointment of William T. Kirk as international director of International Social Service was announced yesterday. In his new post he will direct the organization's world-wide social service program while continuing to head its American branch at 425 Fourth Avenue.

Elsewhere on this page we carry a letter from a correspondent referring to our editorial of Sept. 26 "Mr. Stevenson on Inflation." The passage to which our correspondent refers was a commentary directed at Governor Stevenson's attempt to dismiss the inflation issue with the observation that "the Kremlin" had "dumped a barrel of yeast in our economy."

As Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower left here by airplane yesterday to begin an 8,000-mile Western swing, his aides expressed the belief that President Truman's personal attacks on the general would backfire against the Democratic cause.

Four years ago the American electorate could not have guessed that Korea would be the paramount issue in the next election. Yet, as the debate between the candidates warms up, it is increasingly apparent that this subject stirs up more dust and heat than any other.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Tallulah Bankhead today assured Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois and his running mate, Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama that her heart still belonged to the Democrats.

Lou Little added a short passing drill to yesterday's regularly scheduled defensive workout as the Columbia football team held a three-hour practice session at Baker Field in preparation for Saturday's game with Harvard.

A 23 - year - old student was charged with felonious assault last night in an attack on a patrolman who was trying to break up an attempt by a dozen persons in Times Square during the civil defense test to distribute leaflets objecting to the city's air raid defense forces.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's first national "fireside chat" on television, carried Monday evening over the National Broadcasting Company's network, was the other side of the coin to Senator Richard M. Nixon's recent studio defense of his personal trust fund.

William L. Pfeiffer, Republican state chairman, predicted last night on the basis of a one-week survey of political conditions in upstate New York that more voters would go to the polls this year than ever before in the state's history.

The appointment of William T. Kirk as international director of International Social Service was announced yesterday. In his new post he will direct the organization's world-wide social service program while continuing to head its American branch at 425 Fourth Avenue.

Assignment of 2,000 firemen to patrol duty at school and church crossings, relieving policemen of such duties, was proposed yesterday by John E. Carton, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

Terence F. Kennedy, a resident of London, England, has bought for investment from Justin C. O'Brien the five-story apartment house at 60 East Eightieth Street in a deal negotiated by cable and telephone by Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., brokers.

PLATTSBURG, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Senator Irving M. Ives warned tonight that the nation could not afford to entrust its defense mobilization program for the next four years to a Democratic party that had demonstrated an "astonishing talent for getting nothing done."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -President Truman has issued an executive Order extending until next April 1 the appointments of all Army and Air Force Reserve Officers that are due to expire Oct. 28.
VIENNA, Sept. 30 -- The United States special mission for economic cooperation announced here today that $35,000,000 of American aid would be granted Austria for six months ending Dec. 31.

By a vote of 85 per cent of outstanding stock and 99.8 per cent of that voting, stockholders of Colonial Airlines at a special meeting in Wilmington voted yesterday to accept the offer of Eastern Air Lines to acquire Colonial through an exchange of two Eastern shares for three of Colonial.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 30 -- Former President Otilio Ulate sharply criticized today those of his political enemies who forced his resignation in a surprise crisis last week-end.

THE experts are not completely in agreement as to the precise figure that should be placed on pitching in determining relative baseball values. Some say that pitching accounts for 75 per cent of a team's strength. Others rate it at 90 per cent. Whichever is correct, however, it's overwhelmingly high. Pitching is the predominant factor whether it be over the course of a full season or over a shorter stretch such as the world series.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of an address today by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, at Columbia, S. C.:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Small Defense Plants Administration will begin negotiations with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation soon to speed up loans for small plants by permitting regional offices to recommend loans up to $50,000 where there is no private bank participation and up to $100,000 where banks participate.

The liberation policy of encouraging passive resistance, slowdowns and non-cooperation, as outlined recently by John Foster Dulles, appears to many people in Western Europe as too bold. To most Eastern European exiles, on the other hand, it appears as too moderate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau said today that Federal tax collections in July and August ran about $1,500,000,000 ahead of the first two months of the previous fiscal year. Collections totaled $9,240,000,000 compared with $7,7,38,000,000 a year ago, the bureau added.

Countless citizens of our city will agree that the Fifth Avenue Coach Company is the most indifferently and inconsiderately operated bus line in New York. The conditions surpass almost anything a person can take.
K. T. Keller, chairman of the board of the Chrysler Corporation, has been chosen to receive the national award of the Society of Industrial Realtors as "industrialist of the year."

It was not only a very beautiful, but an illuminating showing of furs that Gunther Jaeckel put on yesterday morning for the press. The story told was not so much one of details in design as it was of color.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 30 -- The current tight money market may provide all the restraint necessary to prevent further unwarranted inflation of real estate values and the "top heavy mortgage situation which might become dangerous when the tide of inflation turns," bankers were told here today.
Consolidation of Miles Shoes, Inc., into the Melville Shoe Corporation was approved by stockholders of both companies at meetings here yesterday.

Thirteen artists have been selected for grants aggregating $18,000 in the 1952 Competition for Scholarships in Painting, Sculpture and Graphic Arts sponsored by the Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation. The winners, announced yesterday by Hobart Nichols, director of the foundation, included three New Yorkers -- Peter Todd Mitchell, painter, who received $2,000; Cleade Enders, painter, who received $500, and Clare Romano, graphic artist, who received $1,500.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau said today that Federal tax collections in July and August ran about $1,500,000,000 ahead of the first two months of the previous fiscal year. Collections totaled $9,240,000,000 compared with $7,7,38,000,000 a year ago, the bureau added.

Countless citizens of our city will agree that the Fifth Avenue Coach Company is the most indifferently and inconsiderately operated bus line in New York. The conditions surpass almost anything a person can take.
New York's fourth city-wide Civil Defense exercise was carried out last night under a luminous moon and in clear night skies, which helped to pinpoint the objective of two flights of "enemy" bombers.

ECHETA, Wyo., Sept. 30 -Shortly after we closed our eyes last night, with a large, uneven portion of Wyoming landscape boring between our shoulders through the sleeping bag, we were rudely awakened by George Grunkemeyer, who doubles as guide and cook, and who holds a theory that no hunter should eat breakfast later than 4:30 A. M.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 5 to 10 points net yesterday, with a moderate volume of business.

Warehouse supplies of steel in; most sections of the country are "far from adequate to meet demands," L. B. Worthington, president of the United States Steel Supply Division of the United States Steel Company, reported yesterday.
An automobile firm has agreed to sponsor the coast-to-coast radio broadcasts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society Orchestra this fall and winter at a cost of $1,100,000.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 1 -- The Japanese turned out today in heavy numbers for the first general election since the end of the Pacific war, voting as a sovereign and independent power under the San Francisco Peace Treaty.

ROME, Sept. 30 -- The Italian part of the offshore procurement program, by which the United States finances the manufacture in Europe of military end items, began to show its first results today in Brescia, where the Fiat Company delivered to United States Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker 100 three-quarter-ton trucks produced by its local factory in that city.

GILLETTE, Wyo., Oct. 1 - This small cow town seems to be the center for the Northern Wyoming hunters, and you see cars from a dozen states, most of them decorated by an antelope or a mule deer, parked in front of the Stockmen's Cafe, and both entrances to the town are marked by long banners shouting "Welcome, Hunters."

Herman B. Delman's How won the Ladies Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Aided by Nick Shuk's nicely gauged ride. How moved fast in the stretch of the mile and a half race to win by a length and a quarter over the Woodvale Farm's Marta.

Six public school teachers who refused recently on grounds of possible self-incrimination to answer questions of the Senate subcommittee investigating communism in the nation's schools will be dismissed from their jobs today, it was announced yesterday at the Board of Education.
Arthur W. Wallander will retire next Monday as city Civil Defense Director, to be succeeded by Deputy Chief Police Inspector Herbert R. O'Brien, according to reliable reports yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Republicans here, apparently nettled by President Truman's continuing attacks on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the party's Presidential nominee, during his whistle stop tour of the Far West, today dispatched a flying "truth squad" of Republican Senators that will play leap frog with the President for the remainder of his two-week schedule.

It has become almost traditional that a naval officer should head the federal shipping agencies that keep watch over the nation's maritime policy and over its many-sided merchant marine activities. Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, who brought a high level of intelligence and energy to his work as chairman of the Federal Maritime Board and as Maritime Administrator, retired yesterday, well deserving the gratitude of both industry and labor.

Hereafter, when you call them "Bums," you had better smile. For they opened the 1952 world series in Flatbush yesterday and out popped an explosion that all but touched off full-scale hysteria in this hotbed of baseball enthusiasm.

As 812 recruits were added to the Police Department at public induction ceremonies in City Hall Plaza yesterday, Mayor Impellitteri told New Yorkers that "no race, color or religion" had a monopoly on crime. At the ceremonies, witnessed by several hundred persons, ninety-eight police officers were promoted.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia. Oct: 1 -- The State Economic Council announced today a six-month ban on the import of approximately 100 articles in an effort to deal with the serious economic and financial situation in which the Government finds itself as a result of the losses suffered during last summer's drought.

MALONE, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Senator Irving M. Ives took his re-election campaign into this stronghold of sentiment for the St. Lawrence Seaway today with the frank admission that he still could not "in good conscience" endorse the proposed waterway.

A former $20,000-a-year Wall Street customer's man, who had been the subject of a nine-month investigation by the office of Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, was held without bail yesterday in General Sessions on a charge of misappropriating $120,000 of foreign investors' funds.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (UP) -- Willie Pep punched his way tonight to a ten-round decision over the Canadian lightweight champion, Armand Savoie, in Chicago Stadium to strengthen his campaign to win back the world featherweight title he held twice previously.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of a recorded broadcast tonight by President Truman over the American Broadcasting Company network on a program sponsored by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union:

Two big producers of chlorophyll -- American Chlorophyll and Archer-Daniels-Midland Company -- announced price reductions yesterday. Henceforth, a standard preferred grade of chlorophyllin, 100 per cent pure, which is the substance known as chlorophyll, will cost $60 a pound. The reduction on various grades ranges from 20 per cent to 33 1/3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UP) -- The Veterans Administration announced today that it would drop 2,250 of its hospital employes and cut other veterans' medical services to meet money cuts ordered by Congress.

As one who has served as adviser in a half dozen agencies concerned with mobilization and inflation problems and as one who has written many books on these subjects I was very much disturbed by your editorial of Sept. 16 on Governor Stevenson on inflation.

ALBANY, Oct. 1 -- The importance of teamwork between a number of professions in achieving total rehabilitation of the handicapped was stressed today by Leonard W. Mayo, director of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, at the annual meeting of the State Association for Crippled Children here.

The other day I received a letter from my kid brother (19 years of age) who is in a hospital in Japan, thanks to wounds received in Korea. Enclosed was a small blood donor's card. True, he had volunteered the blood donation, but also true that he had very serious wounds and the need for blood must have been very great for his donation to have been accepted.
George Heller has been named national executive secretary of the newly created American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, A. F. L.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Oct. 1 -- "The man over there in a raincoat is a French agent who watches my house," Kurt Conrad, Socialist leader in the Saar said. "Whenever I have visitors he is there and, of course, the French also watch all my friends."

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Oct. 1 -- In his first month in office, completed today, President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra has pitted himself against senior officers of the armed forces and appears to have carried the day. Forty-nine senior officers of all three services whom

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- British Government securities were upset today by reports that a big refunding operation was imminent. Details of the new loan were not released until after the market had closed, but uncertainties caused small reaction in gilt edges, as well as further diminution of business generally.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Truman told American voters tonight in a nation-wide radio broadcast that the Republicans would take a victory to mean "that they had a blank check to tear down the things that have been built up in spite of their opposition during the last twenty years."

The open season is on for cook books. We saw few new ones last summer, but now we learn from Helmut Ripperger, who untiringly digs into them one by one for Publishers' Weekly, that at least forty are scheduled for fall and winter issue.

URAVAN, Colo., Oct. 1 -- The vast arid tableland known as the Colorado Plateau is bustling with activity these days. Today will mark another milestone in this mineral - rich 65,000 - square - mile area when the nation's largest uranium refining mill here goes into operation.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 1 -- A rapid and tremendous personnel turnover, too many exercises, maneuvers and demonstrations and too little attention to morale are reducing the efficiency and effectiveness of the United State Navy, in the opinion of many of its officers and men.

Forty-second Street between First and Second Avenues was formally reopened to traffic yesterday morning by Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. The block had been closed since February, 1951, because of construction.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 1 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon accused President Truman tonight of playing "gutter politics at its worst" by criticizing Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's judgment on foreign policies.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- After two days of rehearsals, the novel conductors' symposium being held here this week had not unearthed a new Eugene Ormandy; but that did not prevent it from being one of the brightest ideas ever hatched in American orchestral circles.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1 -- Jack L. Warner, vice president in charge of production for Warner Brothers and a founder of the company, disclosed today that he had resigned from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
ABOARD THE EISENHOWER TRAIN, in Michigan, Oct. 1 -- It was "just one of those days" for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in Michigan today.
Volunteer workers for the Travelers Aid Society began their solicitation yesterday for $406,000 with which to help immigrants and other persons who may become stranded in this city during the year.

Attorneys for Bennett E. Meyers, former Air Force major general who served jail sentences for income tax evasion and subornation of perjury, appealed to the United States Tax Court yesterday to set aside a tax claim of about $450,000 made by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.
Our town takes pride in being the country's No. 1 host to service men and women. This tradi tion goes back to the time when George Washington led our first armed forces.

Five thousand Fordham students were warned yesterday by the Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, university president, against "those pale men who have no values; the liberals in education, in journalism and in government." The occasion was the annual Mass of the Holy Ghost yesterday morning in the campus gymnasium, which is the formal opening of the school year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- A settlement plan involving claims ranging well over $100,000,000 was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the program aimed at ultimate liquidation of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, New York holding company.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 1 -- A new film-industry law that requires every Mexican movie house to devote at least half of its annual screen time to Mexican-made films, was passed by congress today and was immediately described as "discriminatory" by spokesmen for American movie interests in Mexico.

How one of the seventeen defendants in the investment banking anti-trust suit with two partners on the directorate of a big New England textile business lost a top underwriting position in such business to another defendant banking house was described by defense counsel yesterday in the trial at the Federal District Court here.
With Charles Paul conducting, eighty-five members of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony were heard in a Carnegie Hall concert last evening that featured as soloist Margaret Roy, soprano.

REGGIO EMILIA, Italy, Oct. 1 (UP) -Four persons were killed and a dozen injured today when the Rome - Milan express passenger train plowed into a standing freight train. The dead were three members of the express and one passengers. 'Vhe accident occurred when the first two coaches of the express slipped off the rails while crossing a switch on enter-I 'ing the local station.
WASHINGTON, Oct 1 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 119,3 379 today, an increase of 810 since last week.

The election of Lincoln Kirstein, dance authority, to the newly created post of managing director of the New York City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., was announced yesterday by Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of directors.

Agnes de Mille's "The Harvest According," set to music by Virgil Thomson and with scenery and costumes by Lemuel Ayers, was presented last night by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House, as the first of the two scheduled premieres of its current season.

India today will celebrate the eighty-third anniversary of the birth of Mohandas K. Gandhi. The celebration will take one form that would be dearest to Gandhi's heart. It will initiate the large-scale village improvement program that has been in the planning stage for some time and in which the United States will share.

Secretary of the Treasury Snyder is not, he told newspaper men this week, "enthusiastic" about continuing the excess profits tax, which expires on June 30 next. Administratively, said the Secretary of the Treasury, the problems raised are "the most difficult ever conceived."

Coach Hugh Devore concentrated on his second-stringers during yesterday's New York University football practice at Ohio Field. He is convinced N. Y. U. must develop more dependable reserves if the Violets are to be successful this year.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan and three of his inspectors appeared yesterday before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury in what was believed to be a renewed crackdown by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office of police-protected gambling operations.

At a City Hall press conference yesterday, the American Biblical Encyclopedia Society announced the publication of the first volume in English of the Biblical Encyclopedia, or Torah Shelemah, on Oct. 22. The volume will be presented to President Truman on the publication date.

Plainclothes men on his payroll tried to help him in 1950 when he was being shadowed by investigators for District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Brooklyn, Harry Gross testified yesterday at the departmental trial of thirty-one suspended policemen charged with taking his graft.

ABOARD EISENHOWER TRAIN, in Michigan, Oct. 1 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower bid today for Michigan's twenty electoral votes, describing himself as a "Vandenberg Republican" willing, as President, to revive and extend the bipartisan foreign policy approach fostered by the late Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg.

Leonard S. Hobbs, vice president for engineering and a director of the United Aircraft Corporation, has been named a member of the corporation's executive committee. William R.
