Robbins, vice president and controller, was elected a director. The changes were caused by the death of Raycroft Walsh, who was a director, member of the executive committee and vice chairman.
I settled an old score with Allie Reynolds.

A debut violin recital was given last night in Town Hall by Jean Spitzer who, with Leon Pommers at the piano, built a program around a Handel sonata, Brahms' D minor Sonata and the Prokofieff First Concerto. Pieces by Dohnanyi, Debussy, Castelnuovo-Tedesco and Szymanowski also were played.

The Yankees disclosed yesterday that center fielder Mickey Mantle, under orders to report to his Miami (Okla.) draft board for a physical examination on Monday, had applied for permission to have the tests made here.

Selecting a candidate in the Presidential election may be easy for most voters, but thousands of them are beset with questions on how to record their choice. Many of these citizens are calling the New York League of Women Voters, where a staff of volunteers is on a constant hunt for the answers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The retail food price index dropped 0.8 per cent in the three weeks between Aug. 25 and Sept. 15, chiefly because of lower prices for fresh fruits and vegetables, eggs and pork. This will be reflected in the monthly Consumers' Price Index, which will be published in about three weeks.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 -- Senator Robert A. Taft predicted today that "the kind of name-calling campaign President Truman has started" would hurt the Democrats and help to elect Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President.
Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal candidate for United States Senator, issued a statement yesterday denouncing "Republican obstruction aimed repeatedly at weakening our armed forces."

ABOARD TRUMAN TRAIN, in Montana, Oct. 1 -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, reported to President Truman today that he had called on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to put a stop to political use of his statement that he believed communists might have infiltrated Government security agencies.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Pravda announced today that the magazine Bolshevik soon will publish an "important statement" on economic questions by Soviet Premier Joseph Stalin.
BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, Soviet commander in Germany, demanded today that the Western powers dissolve all anti-Communist underground organizations with headquarters in West Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UP) -- The United Stages Tax Court has ruled that penalties paid by a manufacturer for "willful" price ceiling violations cannot be deducted as "necessary business expense" for income tax purposes.
In a statesmanlike speech yesterday at Flint, Mich., General Eisenhower defined what he considers to be the essential basis and the paramount goal of American foreign policy.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 1 -- Win or lose against Temple, Cornell, Michigan State, Holy Cross, Penn State, Colgate and Fordham, its remaining foes on a rugged nine-game schedule, Syracuse is convinced that it has its strongest football team m year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Contributions totaling "several thousand dollars" have been made to the Nixon family -- but not accepted -- since the Republican nominee for Vice President gave an account of his personal finances a week ago.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The newspaper publishers of America, whose papers this day will reach 150,000,000 Americans, paid tribute today to a tiny 7 by 11-inch single sheet printed in a Boston print shop in 1704.

I was distressed to see that I have been reported as intending to "go over the head of" Eugene Black, the Director of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, in my efforts to persuade the bank to help in the matter of providing funds for the assimilation of refugees.

The Mayor's Committee on Management Survey made public yesterday the 551-page final report by Prof. Robert M. Haig and Prof. Carl S. Shoup of Columbia University on the city's fiscal problems and methods of solving them.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents and teachers in public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
A large number of reservations have already been made for the Thanksgiving tea dance to be held for the benefit of the Judson Health Center on Nov. 20 in the ballroom of the Plaza.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 2 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida's conservative Liberal party, proponent of alliance with the Western democracies and of the progressive rearmament of Japan against communism in Asia, has swept the nation in the first general election since the restoration of Japanese sovereignty.

SHERMAN, Tex., Oct. 1 -- A certificate recording Dwight D. Eisenhower's birth in near-by Denison on Oct. 14, 1890, was filed today in the Grayson County Clerk's office. Nobody had bothered to make out a certificate when the Republican Presidential candidate was born.

The stock market was overshadowed yesterday by the opening game of the World Series. The list continued to follow an easier course as trading shrank. Price changes in either direction were small, but the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index eased 0.55 point.

Ninety-five Columbia University faculty members -- many of them full professors -- organized a committee yesterday afternoon for the election of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential nominee, in his campaign against Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate and president-on-leave of the university.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Because of a building elevator strike here, trading operations on the Board of Trade were halted at 12:30 P. M. today.
I am amazed at the naive views being expressed in editorial columns attacking Senator Nixon for the fact that he has the support of people paying for his political activities.

New issues of public utility mortgage bonds and railroad equipment trust certificates aggregating $35,250,000 will be offered to investors today by investment banking syndicates, following purchase at public sealed bidding. The offerings are as follows:

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 1 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, told state employes under his jurisdiction today that they could take an extra hour for lunch tomorrow "if they wish" to see and hear his Republican opponent, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

The Government sought to pick holes yesterday in the testimony of the first defense witness in the trial of thirteen secondary Communist party leaders charged with conspiracy to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the Government. The witness was Abraham B. Magil, a former editor of The Daily Worker and an admitted Communist.
So far as Casey Stengel is concerned, the Dodgers for the first time in their history won the opening game of a world series because they had power and pitching.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Munitions Board today issued regulations requiring the military services to buy domestic wool unless the price is more than 10 per cent higher than the loan support level established by the Department of Agriculture.

Hundreds of hand delivery carts worming their way through heavy traffic were designated yesterday as an important factor in midtown congestion. Furthermore, by ignoring stop-and-go lights they create added perils for motorists and pedestrians, N. Peter McLean, executive secretary, Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association, said.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue reported today that gamblers had been found using tax-exempt, nonprofit organizations as a "front" to evade the Federal wagering tax. They operate money-raising lotteries for the organizations and pocket most of the proceeds, the bureau said.
LONDON, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- Tumbling prices of lead today on the London Metal Exchange may hit the British Treasury for a loss of 2,500,000 ($7,000,000).

A chair, a furniture collection, fabrics, carpets, window shades bathroom linens and an electric fan captured the seven awards made by the Home Fashions League at a luncheon yesterday. The prizes, called Trail Blazers, are presented in recognition of significant advances in design in the American homefurnishings field in the last year.
A three-pound steak became involved last Friday in a "sizzling" international issue between an American air traveler and some stern British customs officials at London Airport.

" An Evening With Beatrice Lillie," billed as an intimate cavalcade of songs and sketches, brings Miss Lillie back to the local stage tonight at the Booth Theatre after an absence of more than four years. The curtain will rise at 8 o'clock.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 1 -- Textron, Inc., is making plans to close three plants in this area recently purchased from Lonsdale Company.

The Columbia football team was pitted against its freshman counterpart yesterday in a full-scale contact scrimmage as Lou Little continued to drill his offensive and defensive alignments for Saturday's game with Harvard.

HUNGRY HORSE DAM, Mont., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of President Truman's address today at the dedication of the Hungry Horse Dam, near Kalispell, Mont.:

HONG KONG, Oct. 1 -- Communist China celebrated its third anniversary today with a mammoth Peiping parade featuring slogans of "peace" and a military order of the day calling for strengthening of its armed forces to combat an alleged twin "menace" in the Far East.

A letter to one of the grand jurors investigating the Queens sewer situation caused County Judge William B. Groat to summon the grand jury to Long Island City yesterday and direct it to investigate the sending of the document as a possible misdemeanor.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 1 -- Editorial brickbats flying between two Bombay weeklies, one pro-Communist and the other anti-Communist, are falling around the United States Ambassador, Chester Bowles, who apparently is paying the price of trying to treat Communists like ordinary persons.
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 2 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,390 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Thursday, Korea time:

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Mike Turnesa of Knollwood and William Kuntz of Bonnie Briar captured the Westchester County Golf Association's best-ball pro-amateur tournament that attracted seventy-seven teams to the Pelham Country Club today.

The final book of Dutton's centennial year will be "The Worm Ouroborus," by E. R. Eddison. Scheduled for Dec. 29 publication, the work is a commentary on our times in the form of an allegory. It will have an introduction by Orville Prescott, daily book critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

An institutional advertising campaign designed to answer the questions most frequently asked by the public about life insurance will start the week of Oct. 13. Holgar J. Johnson, president of the Institute of Life Insurance, sponsor of the campaign, said the ads will appear in 475 daily newspapers for a series of fifteen 1,000-line messages.

" Monsoon," a drama in Technicolor, filmed entirely in India, has been acquired by United Artists for release in the United States, the Western Hemisphere and Europe. The offering, directed by Rodney Amateau and produced by Forrest Judd for The Film Group from a play by Jean Anouilh, features Ursula Thiess, Diana Douglas, George Nader, Ellen Corby and Philip Stainton.
Ralph Kiner, seven-time home run king of the National League, has been placed on the market to the highest bidder, The Associated Press learned yesterday.
The cotton futures market opened with gains of 9 to 13 points on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed 14 to 35 points higher on the day.

Hope springs eternal in the breasts of parents on a good many subjects, and one of them is the matter of child-to-parent communication. Each autumn about this time parents hope that this year things will be different, that this year the child will come home when the school day is over to discuss freely and at length news of the classroom.

KENT, Conn., Oct. 1 -- At the end of the 1951 season Jim Draper, the former Bowdoin center who now is head football coach at Kent School, anticipated a noteworthy campaign this year. Ten letter men were due to return and Draper felt the Blue and Gray might enjoy one of its most successful seasons sons in years.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 1 -- Mrs. Caryl H. Sayre of the Creek Club scored 80 -- 6 -- 74 to win the low net prize during a one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at Meadow Brook today.

Bergdorf Goodman made its bow yesterday with one of the most elegant fur collections of the season. In each design, shown at the Fifth Avenue shop, was that same restraint and flawless good taste that characterize its custom models.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Valerian A. Zorin made his first appearance as the Soviet delegate to the United Nations today and lost an attempt to have the disarmament commission discuss the Kremlin's report to the General Assembly in an open meeting.
BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Rocky Marciano returns to his home town tomorrow, and a rousing civic welcome has been planned by the folks who knew him as a boy.
Small apartment buildings on the East Side formed the bulk of realty figuring in Manhattan transactions reported yesterday.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct 2 -- The ground fighting subsided yesterday along the Korean front, although there were sporadic small but intense engagements-as the Chinese Communists continued their efforts to seize high ground from the United Nations troops.

There was more than one hero in the Dodger clubhouse yesterday, despite the fact that Joe Black, the 227-pound, strong-armed Negro right-hander, became television's darling immediately after he had beaten the mighty Yankees at Ebbets Field in his first start in a world series and his third start in the major leagues.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Official Navy spokesmen said today that they knew of no extraordinary development in construction or commissioning of guided missile craft beyond those already announced.

United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., suffered a sharp setback in earnings in the fiscal year ended last June 30, despite sales which reached the second highest level in its twenty-four-year history.
I would like to answer the letter from Elise Rhades which appeared in your paper.
The city of Miami, Fla., received no bids yesterday for an issue of $3,330,000 of incinerator revenue bonds slated to mature from 1953 to 1981.

WHITEVILLE, N. C., Oct. 1 (UP) -- Thomas L. Hamilton, Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, went to prison today to begin serving a four-year sentence for directing a wave of floggings that terrorized this rural area for more than a year.
The New York quota in the Red Cross regional blood collection program has been increased to 22,000 pints for October, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William M. Markel, program director.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Cordell Hull, former Secretary of State, will observe his eighty- first birthday tomorrow, after making a remarkable recovery from a critical illness he suffered at the end of August.
FLINT, Mich., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's address here today:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UP) -- Defense Mobilizer Henry H. Fowler told Congress today the Government's authority to allocate major defense materials should be continued at least until July 1, 1953.

The 18,000-ton transport LaGuardia will end her duties as a dependent carrier for the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service in two weeks and is slated to be laid up in the James River, Va., reserve fleet.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Pleasant Surprise was a straight-heat winner in the Hanover Filly Stake for 2-year-old pacers today, setting a season's record for age and gait. The race was worth $15,049.

It was a relief to note that the Italian authorities permitted the Church of Christ, an American Protestant missionary organization, to hold religious services in Rome last Sunday. One hopes that this means the whole unhappy dispute will soon be settled with friendliness and understanding.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 6 per cent during September, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. If the figures of Frederick Loeser Co., which closed last spring, are not included in the comparison, the decline would have been cut to 2 per cent.
Sharp increases in resources, deposits and capital funds were reported by the Manufacturers Trust Company in its statement as of Sept. 30, issued for publication today.

ATLANTA, Oct. 1 -- Southern Democratic leaders, nettled by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's personally led political invasion of Dixie, met here today and started an angry-worded counter-attack raking the Republican Presidential nominee as a "decoy" for the South's "traditional enemies."

The National Hockey League's board of governors yesterday decided not to approve no-recall arrangements proposed by the minor American Hockey League to govern the transfer of players between the two loops.

CHICAGO, Oct 1 -- Mortgages on our liberty are being taken by the Federal Government for every favor it gives the public in the shape of subsidies, doles and grants, Laurence F. Lee, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, warned the nation today. Every Government boon is purchased with the coin of freedom and the American taxpayer "picks up the check," he said.

The final report of the Haig-Shoup study of New York City's finances, made for the Mayor's Management Survey and delivered to City Hall yesterday, is a ponderous volume of 551 pages. Much of its content has already become known to the public. It is a generous, perhaps even diffuse, canvass of facts as to revenues, taxation and other governmental problems.

The "new" Waldorf-Astoria Hotel achieved its twenty-first anniversary yesterday, and though the everyday activity of serving more than 8,000 meals and housing the occupants of 2,000 rooms and suites kept everyone busy, a few had time for reminiscence.

IT has been a mighty long campaign for Joe Black. He pitched twenty-seven games in Cuba last winter and then in fifty-six more during the course of the regular season. But the rubber-armed heavyweight seemingly gets better and better with practice. Yesterday he whirled through No. 84 with confident ease, at his supreme best in the most important game of them all.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Truman has designated Albert W. Gatov, West Coast shipping man, as chairman of the Federal Maritime Board.

Build-up of industrial strength is our best guarantee against future aggression and the start of World War III, Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., asserted last night. But such strength, he pointed out, comes from a cumulative effort in peacetime, particularly in the fields of technology and training of manpower.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- The campaign against the French Government's foreign policy on Germany and North Africa has turned, as the reconvening of the National Assembly draws near, into a threat against Foreign Minister Robert Schuman himself.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Mrs. Richard Hellmann of Scarsdale, N. Y., took a two-stroke lead in the twenty - seventh annual United States women's senior championship with a round of 39, 39 -- 78 over the south course of the Westchester Country Club today.

Retailers and other business men opposed to fair trade are preparing an all-out fight to upset or nulify the McGuire Act in the courts, Representative John A. McGuire, Democrat, of Connecticut, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that the United States had not "crystallized" its position for introducing Korean truce proposals in the United Nations General Assembly, but he did not deny that a State Department draft resolution for that purpose had been circulated among other United Nations' members.
PARIS, Oct 1 -- The Soviet Union now has about 300 submarines, according to an estimate made today at a press conference here by Dan A. Kimball, United States Secretary of the Navy.

Brazilian Government officials reaffirmed here yesterday that there will be no recourse to devaluation or a moratorium in order to speed liquidation of the present high backlog of commercial debts owing to United States exporters. The backlog is estimated to be well above $200,000,00O.
Volume decreased noticeably in the New York commodity futures markets yesterday and prices were markedly irregular.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer, the Wheeler Cup champion from the Century Country Club, scored a 42, 38 -- 80 today at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club and won low gross honors by six strokes in the final Westchester Class A tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association season.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- A survey conducted by the International Press Institute, an organization of editors in the free countries of the world, warned today that the absence of straight news reporting in Russia was a factor that might affect the whole course of war or peace.

The nation's supplies of gasoline, light fuel oil and heavy fuel oil increased sharply last week, according to the report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline stocks totaled 120,276,000 barrels at the weekend, an increase of 1,961,000 barrels over the previous week's 118,315,000, but below the 122,468,000 barrels of a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Federal Trade Commission moved against two major liquor corporations today in an attempt to establish the principle that price agreements among subsidiaries of a parent corporation violate the anti-trust laws just as much as a conspiracy between independent competitors.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 2 -- Fifty-two Chinese Communists were killed yesterday morning and 113 others were wounded by two platoons of United States soldiers sent into a prison compound on Cheju Island, off the south coast of Korea, to quell one of the most serious prisoner of war uprisings of the Korean war.
Money for the payment of interest on the 6 per cent external dollar bonds of the Republic of Czechoslovakia was not made available to bondholders on the Oct. 1 due date yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 1 -- An intensive three-week television and radio campaign will be put on by the Republicans in an effort to sell Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to the voters in the same manner as "soap, ammoniated toothpaste, hair tonic or bubble gum," a leader of the Volunteers for Stevenson declared today.

SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 1 -- Intensifying, his political attack on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President Truman denounced the Republican Presidential candidate today as a pliable mouthpiece of "the private power monopolies."

GENEVA, Oct, 1 -- Greece and Turkey have filed complaints with the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade against recent United States action affecting important exports from those two countries.

The commission appointed by President Truman to study the whole question of our immigration and naturalization laws has opened its inquiry with two days of public hearings in New York. It moves on to Boston today and will subsequently travel around the country receiving expressions of opinion on American immigration policy from qualified citizens.

Several hundred persons scattered for safety shortly before noon yesterday when an explosion in a three-story water tower atop the ten-floor building at 156-160 West Thirty-fourth Street, in the heart of the shopping district, de molished an adjoining brick chimney and cascaded concrete, bricks and tons of water on the sidewalk below.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- The German Federal Republic will be allowed to mine uranium and build its own atomic pile once its pending treaties with the Western powers have been ratified, it was reported today.

There are four major reasons for the fact that the index of consumer prices currently is turning upward. The National Industrial Conference Board made this statement yesterday and listed the factors as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Government today set for small business its share of the iron ore expansion goal for 1955. It said small companies should provide 24 per cent of the 147,000,000 gross tons of ore scheduled for that year.

An unusual dramatization of fashion took place yesterday noon at the Brooklyn Museum. The occasion was a luncheon given for the representatives of twenty-five nations who are attending an international seminar on museums sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 24:

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 1 (AP) Eddie Erautt hurled a two-hit shut-out and hit a homer as the Kansas City Blues defeated the Rochester Red Wings tonight, 9 -- 0, in a five-inning little world series game abbreviated by rain.
UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, tonight attributed the blame for inflation to "the high price boys of the Republican party."

Alexander Kotov of Russia, still undefeated after ten rounds, yesterday widened his lead over the field in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, when he won his adjourned ninth-round game from Herman Pilnik of Argentina in seventy-three moves, according to a report from Stockholm.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 -- Dollar expenditures, however vast, will not create the peaceful world desired by all, Joseph M. Dodge, former president of the American Bankers Association, told the closing session of the group's annual convention today.

A continuation by all segments of the advertising business of their efforts toward public service was urged yesterday by speakers at the closing of the three-day forty-third annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers in the Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce announced today that export licenses for shipments of iron and steel scrap will be granted for the balance of this year but that stringent qualifications must be met to obtain such licenses.

NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, Oct. 2 (AP) -- India inaugurated fifty-five development projects, organized and financed with United States help, on this birthday of the late Mohandas K. Gandhi, father of the Indian nation.

Opposing the sentiments expressed in a referendum, the executive committee of the Parkway Village Community Association recommended yesterday that the 600 tenants of the village, a housing project in central Queens, abandon their fight against proposed rent increases there. Most of the tenants are employed by or identified with the United Nations.

It was hardly the time to confront the fellow, who was just about to take infield practice yesterday at Ebbets Field, but a rumor that called for immediate tracking down made it necessary. After all, if, as the grapevine had it, Pee Wee Reese soon is to be named playing-manager of the Pirates, who better than the shortstop would know it?

Early reports from district captains of the city-wide air raid drill on Tuesday night indicated yesterday that the 50,000 participating civil defense workers operated competently. Arthur W. Wallander, city director of civil defense, said he probably would have a detailed report next Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- A strike of 1,500 elevator operators and starters employed in more than 100 buildings early today slowed the activities of an estimated 500,000 office workers and their employers in Chicago's downtown Loop business and financial district.

Marine patrol observations of smoke offenders by inspectors of the Bureau of Smoke Control will be resumed today through an arrangement between Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan and William G. Christy, director of the smoke bureau. From now on a smoke inspector will be taken along daily on the regular police harbor patrol.
MORECAMBE, England, Oct. 1 -- Forces of the Right and Center made a strong counter - attack against the Left today in the British Labor party's annual conference here.

THE one unmistakable new accent in World War II was Bill Mauldin's. None of the novelists was able to produce a better novel than the novels of World War I; none of the poets got anywhere in particular. But Mauldin's immortal characters, Willie and Joe, sardonic and savage and implacable, expressed a tremendously influential point of view in a cartooned chronicle that will outlast marble and the gilded monuments.

WASHINGTON, Oct 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Leon Keyserling, wife of President Truman's top economic adviser, is on extended leave from her Commerce Department job, but officials refused comment today on published reports that she was the subject of a check-up by the Loyalty Security Board.

CAIRO, Oct. 1 -- Egyptian Army headquarters revealed today that, according to the findings of its intelligence service, former King Farouk had organized an "iron guard," the function of which was to liquidate hostile elements among Egyptian nationalists.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Oct. 1 -- Gen. Matthew W. Ridgway, Supreme Commander of Allied forces in Europe, found himself today in the midst of what best can be described as a grade A "hassle" in public relations. To cap the day, French Defense Minister Rene Pleven sent a French general to protest at what has widely and mistakenly -- been interpreted as General Ridgway's criticism of the French defense effort.
Representative Jacob K. Javits told a special Presidential commission yesterday that he believed the new Congress might repeal the controversial McCarran - Walter Immigration Law.

A tract of 237 acres in Hampton Bays, L. I., owned by the Pratt family for more than 100 years, has been purchased by a development company for sub-division into housing plots of one-half and one acre. Arthur Miles, broker in the sale will handle the development.

For the fourth consecutive week wholesale food prices declined and averaged lower than in any week since June 24, according to the Dun Bradstreet index. The index for the week ended on Tuesday stood at $6.43, compared with $6.45 a week earlier. The figure was 5.3 per cent lower than the $6.79 level of a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- J. Howard McGrath, the former Attorney General, displayed a "deplorable lack of knowledge" of the Department of Justice while he was its head, and "showed no enthusiasm for purging his department of wrongdoers or incompetents," a judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives reported today.

Four new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. At the Globe is "Lure of the Wilderness," a Technicolor romantic adventure from Twentieth Century-Fox starring Jean Peters, Jeffrey Hunter, Constance Smith and Walter Brennan. Louis Lantz wrote the screen play from a story by Vereen Bell. Jean Negulesco was the director and Robert L. Jacks the producer.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 2 -- Responsible quarters here predicted today that Denmark would reject the Soviet Union's protest against planned North Atlantic Treaty Organization air bases in this country, which would include some United States personnel. In a note delivered to the Danish Ambassador in Moscow the project was scored as a threat to the security of the Soviet Union and other Baltic nations "for which the Danish Government will have to bear the consequences."

The New York City Opera offered a double bill last night in the City Center of Music and Drama, consisting of the first stage performance in America of Bela Bartok's opera, "Bluebeard's Castle" and the first performance by this company of Ravel's capital farce -- a masterpiece in every line and note of it -- "L'Heure Espagnole".

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 -- Premier Stalin, in a statement published today, said he believed that war between capitalist countries continued to be inevitable under the present circumstances; that experience had shown that conflict among capitalist countries over markets was a stronger force than the "contradictions between the camp of capitalism and the camp of socialism."

The surface as well as the shape of the furniture is an important note in a series of traditional room settings just installed at Altman's. The emphasis is achieved in several ways: by combining several figures and finishes of mahogany on a single piece, by painting -- and decorating -- other pieces, by topping tables, chests and desks with either hand-tooled leather in unusual shades or marble with a distinctive and unexpectedly colorful grain.

A three-act melodrama, which might have been entitled "Eddie Durham's Dilemma" or "What to Do?" was enacted at Ebbets Field yesterday, but only a few persons were in the audience. Fifteen years of manicuring and protecting baseball diamonds have made Durham a weather-wise expert, who needs only to glance skyward for a clue.

IN 1634, in the city of Loudun, Urbain Grandier was burned at the stake before an enthusiastic audience of 6,000 persons for the crime of sorcery. Grandier, who was an exceedingly sinful man as well as a brilliant one, was innocent of the crime of consorting with devils and of afflicting the seventeen nuns of the local Ursuline convent with demoniac possession.

TACOMA, Oct. 2 -- President Truman accused Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower tonight of destroying the Army's centralized purchasing system of World War II and of reverting to the more wasteful practice of letting each branch do its buying.

Julius G. Forstmann, president of the Forstmann Woolen Company, took issue yesterday with the stand of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers that duties on raw wool should be removed. In telegrams to the Unied States Tariff Commission and to Ames Stevens, president of the wool manufacturers' association, Mr. Forstmann said that wool is a vital basic raw material and therefore must be kept domestically available.

THE HAGUE, Oct. 2 -- After waiting more than a year for the United States to do something about Congressionally imposed restrictions on imports of cheese and other dairy products, the Netherlands is preparing to take direct retaliatory action.

There were many eye-catching styles in Sophie's collection of originals shown yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. The "originals" are distinguished from the custom-made fashions displayed recently by this designer in that they are ready-to-wear. However, they have the same carefully detailed and soigne look that Salon Modern clothes have.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- President Truman wrote from his whistle stop tour today to congratulate Cordell Hull on his eighty-first birthday and to pay tribute to the former Secretary of State for his "many years of service to your country and to humanity."

Jack Hyatt, Fordham football captain-elect, who suffered an attack of polio over a month ago, last night made a surprise appearance at a rally in the Rose Hill gymnasium for the Rams' game with Holy Cross at Worcester, Mass., tomorrow.

Beef steaks and lamb chops dropped in price this week, the consumers' service division of the city Department of Markets reported yesterday. Porterhouse, sirloin and chuck steaks reached the lowest levels since the spring of 1951 and round steak the lowest since last fall.

The half-away mark was passed yesterday in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, as Alexander Kotov of Russia continued his winning streak by defeating R. G. Wade of New Zealand, according to a report from Stockholm.
HONG KONG, Oct. 2 -- A man without a passport today began his third week as an unwilling passenger on a Hong Kong-Macao ferry. And the end is not in sight.

A large number of newly imported antiques as well as a group of reproductions have been used against basically contemporary backgrounds for the annual refurbishing of the elaborate apartment that W. and J. Sloane calls "A House in Town."

Another entry in the 125,000,000 market for laxative products was announced yesterday by the Harrower Laboratory, Inc., pharmaceuticals manufacturing company with headquarters in Jersey City, N. J. The new ethical drug product is called "Prulose Complex" and will be backed by a $500,000 promotional campaign aimed principally at the medical profession.

Asserting that residents of the West Side from Fifty-ninth to 125th Streets fear to leave their homes at night because of the prevalence of crime, three prominent clergymen appealed yesterday to Mayor Impellitteri to bring the Police Department up to full strength at once and to make uniformed men now engaged in clerical work available for active patrol duty.

At a dramatic, tension-filled public meeting, the Board of Education voted unanimously yesterday to ratify the dismissals of six teachers who recently refused to answer questions of the Senate subcommittee investigating communism in the nation's schools.

THE TIMES is so scrupulously fair that the editorial on the President's speech seems at variance with your customary comments. It was made in reply to the General's criticism of the failure to see the Russian threat. Mr. Truman said that Ike, who was in Europe and in close contact, did not see it either and cited Ike's testimony.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Office of Price Stabilization granted a price increase of 20 cents a ton to anthracite mine owners tonight to compensate them for the like increase in owners' contributions to the United Mine Workers Health and Welfare Fund.

Regardless of how the factional intra-party struggles are resolved in Japan the outcome of the first free and unsupervised election must be regarded as encouraging. The victory of Premier Yoshida and his conservative Liberal party is no surprise, but their showing was stronger than many supposed it would be, while the Communists suffered a devastating defeat.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 14 to 25 points net lower than on Wednesday.
Ingus Naruns, Latvian 'cellist who made his debut in Town Hall last season, gave his second recital there last evening.

A new line of British walking shoes, called Lillibets, will be made available to the public for the first time next Monday in Macy's recently remodeled second-floor Little Shop, where the designs will be carried exclusively. The collection has been made on American lasts and the styling has been geared to the youthful tastes and modes of the American woman.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 2 (UP) -- A former German general who originally was sentenced to death for ordering the massacre of 335 Italians in Rome in 1944, has been released from prison, British officials announced today.

HONG KONG, Oct. 2 -- The "Asian and Pacific Peace Conference'' opened today in Peiping after a long propaganda build-up, as spokesmen for Red China, the host country, sounded a background theme of "peaceful coexistence" and declared the Peiping regime wanted to trade with the West to promote China's industrial development.

Columbia University explained yesterday its "official position" in regard to an editorial in The Columbia Daily Spectator, an undergraduate newspaper, supporting Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential candidate against Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate who is the university president on leave.

Waterfront operations afloat were resumed yesterday by smoke inspectors. In a police launch they patrolled part of New York's harbor and shouted warnings through a megaphone to skippers of smoke-producing craft.
William Carolla has been pro-rooted to assistant manager of the industrial division of the R. M. Hollingshead Corporation in Camden, N. J.

Fire in an electric locomotive stalled a ten-car Pennsylvania Railroad commuter train in the eastbound tunnel under the Hudson River yesterday morning, pouring choking smoke through the narrow area and injuring ten of the 300 passengers and crew. One of the injured was hospitalized.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's demand today that South Koreans, rather than Americans and other United Nations forces, defend their own front lines was received with amazement and incredulity by a number of United Nations delegates.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- The strike of 1,600 Chicago elevator operators and starters, called during the rush hour yesterday morning, spread today to more office buildings and caused new hardships.
There was no depression in the Dodger dressing room after yesterday's emphatic loss of the second game of the world series to the Yankees.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 2 -- The National League of Masonic Clubs voted unanimously here today to award its second meritorious service medal to Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, vice president and general manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in recognition of "his great contribution to public information and public education."

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Mrs. Richard Hellmann of Scarsdale, N. Y., became the new champion of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association by adding an 86 to her first round 78 for 164, over the south course of the Westchester Country Club today.

The managers of the veterans hospitals in the Bronx and Brooklyn expressed grave concern yesterday over the effect of a Veterans Administration order for a nation-wide reduction of 2,250 in hospital staffs, excluding medical.

PINE TREE, Wyoming, Oct. 2 -- The county lines in this wild and still somewhat woolly area run in straight lines and right angles, but like the antelope and muledeer, the towns wander all over the place.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 2 -- The Syrian Cabinet, meeting in Damascus today, discussed the question of confiscating Jewish property for the benefit of Palestine Arab refugees.

" The Rebel Prince: Memoirs of Prince Louis Ferdinand of Prussia" will be issued Oct. 15 by Henry Regnery. The author, who would be emperor today if Germany were still a monarchy, describes the rigors of a princely education, of his rebellion against court snobbishness, militarism and narrow nationalism. He also tells of his work on the Ford assembly line in the nineteen-thirties.

A five-alarm fire that was discovered soon after midnight last night destroyed the Concord Baptist Church of Christ, 847 Marcy Avenue, reputed to be the oldest Negro Baptist church in Brooklyn. The flames cremated the body of a woman for whom funeral services had been held earlier last night in the church.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 2 -- This was Eisenhower Day in the Lincoln country.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- The United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency, which thus far has been restricted to minor preparatory operations, announced today that it would embark at once on a large-scale relief and reconstruction program.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund must raise $20,000,000 for next year's operations or face curtailment of its welfare services, which already have helped 60,000,000 needy children.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- Taxpayers in the United States paid a record $65,009,585,000 into the Federal Treasury the last fiscal year, which ended June 30, an average of more than $415 for every man, woman and child in the country.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 (AP) -- East Germany's rubber-stamp Parliament today voted unanimous approval of a series of laws reorganizing justice along Russian lines. It was a further step toward making the East zone a full-fledged "peoples democracy."

Rosser Reeves, an executive of the Ted Bates advertising agency, denied yesterday that the Citizens for Eisenhower organization planned a $2,000,000 radio-television campaign. Such a plan had been suggested but rejected, he said.

Fall and winter fashions worn by prominent New York women from 1821 to 1921 comprise an interesting exhibit that will be opened to the public today in the Costume Gallery at the Museum of the City of New York. From this collection also come many of the fashion notes found in today's women's apparel.
SEATTLE, Oct. 2 -- President Truman revealed tonight that guided missiles were "now in assembly-line production" and were expected to be in the hands of American troops soon.

ALBANY, Oct. 2 -- A State University spokesman said today it was "highly likely" that William S. Carlson, president, would recommend over-all regulations to govern fraternities and other social organizations on State University campuses on such matters as discrimination.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Results of the first large scale clinical trials here of isonicotinic acid hydrazide on patients suffering from various forms of pulmonary tuberculosis show that the drug "is very effective" but in general should not be given alone because of the emergence of drug-resistant bacilli.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Real progress has been made toward a clean-up of college athletics, but the nation's sports editors are ignoring it, Dr. John A. Hannah, president of Michigan State College, said today.

EDMONTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Eugene Holman, president of the Standard Oil Co. (New Jersey), said today the chances of Alberta oil finding a market in California will be good after the $82,000,000 trans-mountain pipeline to British Columbia is completed.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman informed the United States Ambassador James C. Dunn, who called at the Foreign Office today, that France, in view of the decision of the International Court of Justice at The Hague, would authorize imports in Morocco without requiring accompanying purchases of exchange from the French Control Office to pay for these imports.

Beginning celebration of its 100th anniversary as one of the oldest Jewish socialg roups in the country, the Harmonie Club last night held a dinner-dance at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel which was attended by 1,000 persons.
There are at least five candidates for minority leader of the State Assembly, a post left vacant as a result of the death last month of Assemblyman Irwin Steingut.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman today received the proposals of the West German Federal Republic for the settlement of the future status of the autonomous Saar territory claimed politically by Germany and economically by France.
Columbia expects to face a hard-driving line when it meets the Harvard eleven at Cambridge tomorrow.

John Foster Dulles, the Republican foreign-policy adviser, charged last night that fears of an "unholy deal like Yalta" between the Democratic Administration and Russia were paralyzing the efforts of captive countries behind the Iron Curtain to try to free themselves.

A design for the largest single tapestry in the world has been accepted by the United Nations Planning Committee. The tapestry will hang on the enormous wall of the delegates' entrance lobby of the General Assembly building.
CLARKSVILLE, Va., Oct. 2 -- The John H. Kerr Dam, $87,000,000 Federal flood control and power project on the Roanoke River, will be dedicated near here tomorrow.

THE victory of the Dodgers on opening day shocked Casey Stengel into a state of complete coherency yesterday. For the first time in ages his conversation was entirely intelligible, with honest-to-goodness nouns and verbs in their proper places. Listeners actually could understand what he was talking about, not that they necessarily learned anything more.

A modest sales gain and a slight improvement in net profits marked department store operations for the six months ended July 31, according to the report issued yesterday by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter dismissed yesterday the petition in a suit to declare unconstitutional the city's $10 use tax on trucking concerns engaged in interstate commerce.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Grain futures displayed a stronger tone today but prices held within fractional limits and demand inclined to wane on the bulges. Wheat buying continued due to dry weather in most sections and prospects of liberal export clearances this month

ALBANY, Oct. 2 -- The "protection of youth against subversive propaganda" was listed today by State Education Commissioner Lewis A. Wilson as one of the major problems faced by the Education Department.

The Long Island Transit Authority accused William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, yesterday of joining forces with the Pennsylvania Railroad in an effort to delay the road's reorganization.
City and Queens borough officials adopted a new procedure yesterday for achieving a speedy reconstruction of the faulty two-mile sewer built in Laurelton by Victor Clemente for $185,679.

DALLAS, Oct. 2 ((AP)) -- Officials of the National Outboard Association said today that five world records were established in the N. O. A.'s one-mile straightaway event at Lake Dallas Monday. Claude Fox of Knoxville, Tenn., executive director, also said four association records were chalked up.
QUEBEC CITY, Oct. 2 -- An off-beat scene of the "listening in" fans for the first world series game:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- During the week ended Oct. 1, member bank reserves decreased $483,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it will support this year's corn crop at a national average price of $1.60, three cents a bushel more than last year's average.
The nation's largest liner, the United States, became the home of the Naval Reserve's first shipboard unit yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Mrs. Marion W. O'Connor's La Corredora, winner of the Monmouth Oaks, had an easy time in taking the $6,000 Assembly Purse at six furlongs today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer, who is publisher and owner of a daily and a weekly newspaper in Ohio, said that Department of Commerce investigations had proved that satisfactory newsprint can be produced from bagasse, sugar cane waste material.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- British government securities made little response today to the announcement of the Government's big refunding operation or the figures of the sterling area's gold and dollar reserves in September. Prices of short-term gilt-edged securities rose fractionally to adjust to the terms of the new issue but other stocks closed with only small alterations after keeping fairly steady all day.

Anchor Man lasted just long enough to repulse a bid for victory by Risque Rouge in the mile race that served as the feature attraction at Belmont Park yesterday. With Con Errico urging the 3-year-old son of Amphitheatre into a big lead rounding into the stretch, Anchor Man found his margin persistently reduced by the hard-charging Risque Rouge.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 3 -- Communism in the Far East received probably its worst setback since World War II yesterday when the count of votes in the Japanese general election, now virtually complete, returned not a single candidate of the Japanese Communist party to the all-powerful lower house of the Diet.

One of the many difficulties arising from the estrangement between Billy Rose and his wife, Eleanor Holm, appeared to have been ironed out yesterday when Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally announced that an agreement had been reached between their counsel whereby Mr. Rose would vacate his home at 33 Beekman Place this afternoon and Mrs. Rose might move in tomorrow.

Butternut squash, perhaps the most versatile member of the winter squash clan, is generally available in all produce stalls for the first time in its history. It is a relatively new variety that has taken time to catch on.

Coming Glass Works announced yesterday that major stockholders of the company are planning to dispose of 104,104 shares of common stock through a public offering to be managed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Lazard Freres Co.
Your editorial on "Cheap, Mr. President," appears to miss completely the point made by Mr. Truman when he recalled the friendship which General Eisenhower expressed for Russia in 1945.

A serious lack of facilities to cope with the problems of the aged was found by the Community Service Society in the most intensive study yet undertaken into the needs of New York's older population, it was announced yesterday.

The happiest fellow in the Yankee clubhouse yesterday was Billy Martin. Demonstratively, that is. Less demonstrative, but happy and relieved in his own quiet way, was the husky righthander, Vic Raschi.

For the first time in a metropolitan area as large as Washington, D. C.,, a central charge account service is being offered covering several hundred stores in that city. The plan is being sponsored by the Central Charge Service, just formed by Washington business men, professional men and bankers.

The forty-three-family apartment house at 1387 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, has been sold by Ditbro Realty Corporation to an investing client of Samuel Goldberg, lawyer, for cash over tow mortgages of $132,275. The property is assessed at $130,000. Austin Hermann and Taylor Co., were the brokers in the sale.

YONKERS, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Hy Klas scored a nose victory in a driving downpour over a sloppy strip in the feature at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Hedgewood Fingo was second, with Royal King third, a neck back.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Howland Sargent, Assistant Secretary of State for public affairs, today told the United States National Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization that with its programs well firmed in six years, UNESCO now should turn to combatting "ideological racketeering."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced proposed marketing quotas and acreage allotments for cigar filler and binder tobacco for 1953.
Following are the texts of addresses by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower yesterday in Illinois, as sent by The Associated Press:

ROME, OCT 2 -- Moscow's campaign of vilification against Americans has prompted the Italian Communist party to issue a secret circular detailing how the "perfect Communist activist" should show his contempt for American military personnel and civilians by being rude to them on every possible occasion.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 3 -- The Communist riot staged Wednesday in the prisoner-of-war compound on Cheju Isand, off the south coast of Korea, was to have been the signal for a mass break-out of nearly 6,000 Chinese prisoners on the island, a United States general declared yesterday.
LONDON, Friday, Oct. 3 -- The Admiralty announced early today on the authority of Prime Minister Churchill that a British atomic weapon has been successfully exploded in the Monte Bello Islands.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Prime Minister Churchill's Government gave the British people today the best piece of news they have had since it came to power nearly twelve months ago. Beginning next week, tea will be on sale freely after twelve years of rationing.

Much to the relief of the harassed sponsors, the financial troubles of "Buttrio Square" are happily over and done with, they hope. The opening is now set for Oct. 14 at the Century, vows Gen Genovese, co-sponsor. All this was made possible yesterday when Eugene Loring, choreographer and over-all director of the musical, formed a syndicate composed of fifty enthusiastic members of the company who will become stockholders to the extent of $200 each.

CAMP ATTERBURY, Ind., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Five overseas Army veterans, two of them wounded in Korea, have been sentenced to long terms at hard labor for a mutiny in the Camp Atterbury post stockade the night of Sept. 11. The men were convicted Wednesday after a general court martial that started last Friday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (UP) -- Premier Stalin declared world market conditions for capitalist countries were getting worse, and to cover up such difficulties the West undertook an armaments race, the Korean war, the Marshall plan and the militarization of industry.

We share the impatience of the members of the Long Island Transit Authority, George E. Roosevelt and Tracy S. Voorhees, with any proposals to delay further the reorganization of the Long Island Rail Road. The Authority makes public this morning a memorandum sharply eritical of William Wyer, trustee in bankruptcy, on the grounds that he seeks "non-reorganization."

GENEVA, Oct. 2 -- The Western world needs a determination to face "painful adjustments" and not new organizations to cope with its pressing trade and monetary problems, the chairman of the contracting nations to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said in opening the seventh session of that group here today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 -- A new roster of alleged Communist party members in the radio industry was given to the House Committee on Un-American Activities today by Owen Vinson, radio program director and admitted former member of the party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon's campaign manager conceded tonight that the Republican Vice Presidential candidate used the Senate franking (free postage) privilege to determine whom Californians wanted the Republicans to nominate for President.

Nashville, Tenn., sold $2,305,000 of bonds due from 1954 to 1992 to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., yesterday, at a bid of 100.0004 for 2 1/2s and 2 1/4s, an interest cost of 2.397 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields ranging from 1.15 per cent to 2.6 per cent. At the close, all but $393,000 of the issue was placed by the syndicate.

MORECAMBE, England, Oct. 2 -- Rearmament, the original cause of the present controversy in the British Labor party, looked like a dead or dying issue today at the party's annual conference in Morecambe.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 2 -- Two prominent physicians who led last year's opposition by Danbury Hospital staff members to certain acts by the hospital's board of managers have been suspended in what staff members call reprisal.

SEATTLE, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A tearful Harry A. Jarvinen, who waited seven hours for the verdict, was declared innocent last night by a Federal court jury of giving false information to two Government agencies.
The Pirates confirmed yesterday that their slugging outfielder, Ralph-Kiner, was on the block.

John Cashmore, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, defended last night his position on the St. Lawrence Seaway and indicated he resented editorial criticism of a speech he made on the question at Watertown last Saturday.
SEATTLE, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's talk here tonight:

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Four innings of no-hit, no-run relief pitching by Jack Crimian tonight carried Rochester to a 10-5 victory over Kansas City in the fifth game of their little world series. Kansas City still leads in games, 3 -- 2.

At least one foreign visitor found New York's legendary hustle a blessing yesterday. For if, in driving a bus down Broadway he had stopped to chat on a first-name basis with each of his 150 passengers -- as he does regularly in his native Amersfoort, the Netherlands -- Jan van Gent would not have survived his first day on the job.

I was much amused by the letter of Eugene Burr in THE TIMES of Sept. 20 explaining why Eisenhower could not be expected to "repudiate" McCarthy. Mr. Burr explains that by the Constitution, as amended, the power of electing Senators is given to the people of the state concerned and that it would be interfering in someone else's affairs to give an opinion on the fitness of a Senatorial candidate.

In your editorial "Probation and Crime," in which you comment upon Dorris Clarke's letter eloquently pleading for an increased probation staff at higher salaries, you end on a highly provocative note when you write, "* * * the real test of wisdom and civilization's progress is what we do with the offender when caught."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 862,061 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,498 cars, or 1.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 2,514 cars, or 0.3 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 18,125 cars, or 2.1 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

CAIRO, Oct. 2 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier and Commander in Chief, back from his triumphal tour of lower Egypt, threw himself today into the task of reshaping Egyptian policy toward the Sudan.

A call to business men to get into politics in their home communities was issued yesterday by Laurence F. Lee, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. Leadership is needed at the "precinct level," he said, as part of the fight to meet the issue of continuing freedom, which is "the challenge of the Twentieth Century."

New York bank loans to business rose $59,000,000 last week to within $35,000,000 of the year's peak reached on March 19. The total was $7,932,000,000. The advance, according to data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was the eighth gain to be registered in the past nine weeks, and was largely the result of seasonal influences.
Another policeman accused of taking bribes to protect Harry Gross' bookmaking business was dismissed from the force yesterday.

As of yesterday an unhappy gentleman listed as M. P. O'Brien, which his friends say is a contraction of a longer Hungarian name, was fluctuating between the Portuguese-owned port of Macao and Hong Kong. For two weeks he has been aboard the ferry which covers the fifty miles between these two cities.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 2 -- Dr. Lewis Webster Jones, president of Rutgers University, announced today the appointment of a committee to review the cases of two professors who refused to answer questions before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

ABOARD THE EISENHOWER TRAIN in Illinois, Oct. 2 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower campaigned across isolationist-minded Illinois today and declared in a speech at Champaign that if there must be a war in the Far East "let it be Asians against Asians, with our support on the side of freedom."

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Oct. 2 -- M. Grandval, French Ambassador to the Saar, and high Saar officials declared here today that no provisional solution to the question of this territory's future status, such as is thought to have been proposed by the West German Government today, would be acceptable.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Losing to Colgate for the first time since 1944 in its opening game last Saturday came as somewhat of a shock to Cornell, which anticipated a reasonably successful football season despite the loss of twenty-six 1951 letter men, including most of its ranking backs.

Giving a new twist to fundamental Communist doctrine for immediate propaganda purposes, Premier Stalin again expounds the thesis that war is inevitable. He declares, however, that the next war is more likely to be fought between the "capitalistic" nations rather than between the "capitalistic" or free world and the Communist world.

The Grand Union Company, which operates a chain of about 290 "super market" retail grocery and food stores, reported yesterday, for the quarter ended Aug. 30 net profit of $374,730, equal to 50 cents a share on 621,045 shares of common stock outstanding.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Bugle-blowing Chinese Communists hurled fourteen separate attacks at United Nations forces in Western Korea last night and seized four outpost hills in bloody hand-to-hand fighting.
Cocoa, coffee, hides and lead lost ground in futures trading yesterday. Movements in other New York commodities were mixed or inconsiderable.

William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman, announced yesterday that the state and county committees of the party would make an intensive drive for a large registration. He declared that nearly 9,500,000 New York State residents were eligible to register and vote in the Nov. 4 election. This, he said, is 3,000,000 more than the total New York State vote in the 1948 Presidential election.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Council will send a special team to conduct on the spot examinations of at least two of three Allied airbases in France to which United States air wings have been assigned. This decision followed widespread reports that these fields have been poorly constructed by French engineers and that as a result American units cannot operate from them until pending repairs are completed.

Along about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon a gripping fear began to envelop Brooklyn. It spread as the day wore on and by nightfall folks were going from door to door speaking in whispers. The first world series championship for Flat-bush, which only the previous day loomed so invitingly just around the corner, may turn out to be just another figment of an overwrought imagination.

While showing gains over a year ago, deposits, loans and total resources of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York on Sept. 30 were below the levels of June 30, according to the bank's quarterly condition statement to be published today.

The British Labor party's annual conference at Morecambe defeated a resolution yesterday to reduce the defense program -- but only by a vote of 3 to 2. This result, which came near the close of an exciting conference, can be taken two ways. The Bevanites showed surprising strength and won what might almost be called a moral victory.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 2 -- A new declaration by Gen. Miguel Henriquez Guzman that he is "at the will of the people" has served the Mexicans as a sharp reminder that although the vote counting of last July's election is over there still may be serious trouble before Dec. 1.

There were 212,895 calls made for inning scores during the first game of the world series between the Yanks and Dodgers Wednesday at Ebbets Field. According to the New York Telephone Company, this total was 34,234 under the total for the series opener a year ago between the Giants and Yanks.

A slim improvement was shows yesterday by the stock market, but it was one of those negative sessions with no proof that the pattern had changed. The scattering of interest among a variety of unrelated divisions indicated that traders were "shopping around."

It is a waste of investment bankers' time to serve on the directorates of companies other than their own, defense counsel in the investment banking anti-trust trial declared in Federal Court here yesterday.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 2 -- Dick Gurney and Tom Stearns, assistant football coaches at the Hotchkiss School, were twitting the head coach, Delaney Kiphuth, in the dressing room just before practice today.
AUSTIN, Tex, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Gov. Allan Shivers announced tonight he would vote in November for the Republican candidate, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

ABOARD TRUMAN TRAIN, Oct. 2 -- President Truman, it now is apparent, has undertaken the toughest mission in his career. He is throwing all his prestige and political experience into a no-quarter effort to destroy Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential candidate.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Oct. 3 -- Britain's first atomic weapon was successfully exploded at 8 A. M. today, West Australia time [7 P. M. Thursday, Eastern Standard time] in the Monte Bello Islands, fifty miles off the Northwest Australian coast.

There is now a "remarkable unanimity" of prophecy regarding good business prospects during the early months of next year, the National City Bank of New York points out in ts monthly Letter, published today. Business observers, the bank notes, are counting on Government spending and on the construction and industrial plant and equipment programs which are largely influenced by Government spending.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 2 -- Senator Robert A. Taft told an audience of 1,200 Franklin County Republicans tonight that "President Truman and his friends don't seem to understand the distinction between honesty and dishonesty."
BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Rocky Marciano, world heavyweight boxing champion, came home to a hero's welcome today while a crowd of 60,000 persons roared its approval.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 2 (UP) -- The University of North Carolina today canceled its football games with Georgia and North Carolina State College when four students, including Fullback Harold (Bull) Davidson came down with polio.

MADRID, Oct. 2 -- The National Board of Catholic Bishops complained today that the Spanish Government had granted to the Roman Catholic Church in Spain only "minimum rights" in the field of high school education. The criticism was contained in statement entitled "The Right of the Church on the Apostolate of Education" and signed by the Spanish Primate, Enrique Cardinal Pla y Deniel.
Governor Dewey declared last night that "the Democratic party has just made the most monumental blunder in bringing to this state its Jim Crow candidate for Vice President of the United States."

An intense squall and thunderstorm, accompanied by hail, high winds and heavy rain, struck the city at the rush hour last night. It caused injuries to at least fifteen persons, did considerable property damage and sent the mercury plunging 11 degrees in five minutes.
TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 3 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,391, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M Friday, Korea time:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Sharp Note, a swift bay colt with the power to move on the outside, came on with a final burst in the third heat to win the rich Kentucky Futurity and the 1952 3-year-old trotting championship today.
Succoth, or the Feast of Tabernacles, the last of the major Jewish holidays of the autumn, will begin tonight.
A flash strike halted hundreds of New York taxicabs late yesterday afternoon and union leaders warned that one-third of the city's cabs might be tied up by this morning.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh today made a new gesture threatening to break relations with Britain.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, whose 116 affiliated member hospitals and social service agencies care for 480,000 men, women and children of all races and creeds annually, started its thirty-fifth annual campaign for $20,000,000 yesterday for support and maintenance of its institutions.

Directors of R. K. O. Radio Pictures, Inc., yesterday elected Ralph Stolkin as president to succeed Ned E. Depinet, and Arnold M. Grant as board chairman in place of Noah, Dietrich. Mr. Grant was also elected general counsel.

Beatrice Lillie is the funniest woman in the world and her program of songs and sketches is admirable and hilarious. "An Evening With Beatrice Lillie," she calls it, adding "with Reginald Gardiner" to observe all the program amenities, and it opened with a series of loud reports at the Booth last evening.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- With indications before them that the volume of surface passenger travel across the Atlantic may reach the highest level in two decades, major shipping companies today agreed to defer any increase in rates at least until next March.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Instructed to disregard the Presidential campaign and the probable make-up of the new Congress and concentrate on the economic control measures that they believe will be needed next year, specialists of the various agencies concerned with economic controls have begun drafting suggestions for legislative action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Government agencies and the private shipping industry are extending themselves in planning a high-powered symposium on defense transportation for this year's annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A Government anti-trust prosecutor said today a world-wide conspiracy to control oil prices began in 1928 in London and continues to the present day.

Two old favorites turned up on television Wednesday evening and, tentatively at least, the. scorecard must read one hit and one error. The hit was "Cavalcade of America" at 8:30 P. M. on N. B. C.; the error, "The March of Time" at 9:30 on A. B. C.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Undeterred by Department of Defense efforts to eliminate special observance "days" for the armed services in favor of a single and unified "Armed Forces Day," the Navy League of the United States is preparing for a full-scale Navy Day.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- James P. McGranery, Attorney General, announced today a drive to take United States citizenship from naturalized racketeers and criminals, then eject them from this country.

We do not believe that the effort to get rid of the few subversives who may still exist within the public school system will be helped by a ruling that has just been announced by the State Department of Education. On the contrary, we think that an already complicated situation will be further confused to a point where the whole procedure may well be reduced to chaos.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 2 -- Suit was filed today in Federal District Court by Eli Lilly Co., a drug manufacturing concern, asking that an injunction be issued restraining Schwegmann Brothers, super market of New Orleans, from selling Lilly drugs at prices below those called for in fair trade contracts.

Joseph Stalin's latest major policy statement, in effect, gives notice to the world that he regards his rule as still far from finished and that, in his opinion, any speculation about the succession to him is still premature.

AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Senator Irving M. Ives today accused Senator John J. Sparkman, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, of "deliberate misrepresentation" in presenting campaign issues to the voters of upstate New York.

A peaceful solution of a contract dispute between the American Weighmasters Association and three small but important locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., appeared closer yesterday.

Samuel Platzer has purchased the new one-story taxpayer at 18-24 South Main Street in Pleasantville, N. J., from the Braler Realty Corporation for cash above a mortgage of $48,500. The building, 50 by 80 feet, is on a plot 155 by 50 feet and contains four stores. Albert M. Greenfield Co. were the brokers.
Helicopters will begin regularly scheduled flights over the New York-New Jersey port area in less than two weeks.

FORT DIX, N. J., Oct. 2 -- Thirteen soldiers escaped early today from the prison stockade here through a twenty-five-foot tunnel they had been digging for weeks with tin cans, a broken knife and a basting spoon taken from the camp kitchen.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Premier Stalin in his message said the only way war among the capitalist countries could be averted was to destroy "imperialism." The capitalist countries, he added, are not likely to make war against the Soviet Union because they realize this would mean the destruction of capitalism.

The American Geographical Society is accused in the official periodical of the Soviet Academy of Sciences of preparing its "World Atlas of Disease" as a basis for world-wide bacteriological warfare, "which is not only projected by the U. S. A., but is already being carried out by them in Korea."

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- "My play, 'Evangeline,' has nothing to do with the work by the same name of the American poet Longfellow," Henri Bernstein, noted French dramatist, warned the press here before the premiere of the production.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday the appointment of Deputy Chief Inspector Herbert R. O'Brien to succeed Arthur W. Wallander as city Civil Defense Director and at the same time named a three-man commission to act in an advisory capacity.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 2 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon coupled an appeal for the votes of Virginia Democrats with a demand for Federal action to outlaw poll taxes today as he stumped this normally Democratic state in behalf of the Republican national ticket.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- R. A. McDonald, head of the National Production Authority, said the N. P. A. has issued regulations to go into effect when construction controls are relaxed. The agency announced these rules now to give builders an opportunity to plan ahead. The new regulations will:

Charles Gilman, who came to the Board of Education in 1908 as a $300-a-year office boy and had to complete his high school education at night, was elected yesterday to the new post of Administrator of Business Affairs at an annual salary of $22,500.

Total resources of The National City Bank of New York, amounting to $5,888,906,767 on Sept. 30, compare with $6,025,683,556 on June 30 and $5,556,379,159 a year ago. The bank's latest quarterly condition statement, to be issued today, shows deposits at the end of last month amounting to $5,402,085,923, against $5,541,640,663 and $5,070,367,108 on the earlier dates.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 2 -- Herbert J. Biberman, film writer-director and a member of the "unfriendly ten" who served jail sentences for refusing to tell a Congressional committee in 1947 whether or not they were or had been members of the Communist party, has applied for reinstatement in the Screen Directors Guild.

Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal party candidate for the United States Senate, told a meeting of the party's trade union council last night that a Republican victory next month would result in a depression "in the not distant future."

BOSTON, Oct. 2 -- Strong criticism of the national-origins restrictions of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act of 1952 was voiced here today at a hearing by President Truman's special Commission on Immigration and Naturalization.

Alicia Alonso gave her first performance this season of "Giselle" with the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and a fine performance it was. This has long been one of Miss Alonso's best roles, and it continues to grow in finish and in perfection of detail from year to year.

A lone bandit fled with $10,000 from a Brooklyn branch of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company yesterday after handing a note to a woman teller that read: "Don't shout -- this is a hold-up -- you won't get hurt."

Tonight the moon will be full; scattered across the United States, and in Mexico, Canada and Puerto Rico, bird watchers at some two hundred stations -- local weather conditions permitting -- will be on the lookout for birds on the wing.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 3: (UP) -- Polio struck another member of the University of North Carolina football team today as health authorities kept a close watch and hoped the mild outbreak on this crowded campus would run its course.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 3 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today coupled a call for the re-election of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican, with a fierce attack upon Democratic Administrations for tolerating Communist penetration of the Government and "treason itself."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today set final 1952 price support floors for burley cigarette tobacco and four types of chewing, snuff, cigar, and pipe tobacco.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of an address here today by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois:
