WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Conservationists were delighted to learn today that a Federal District Court had upheld the Government's right to prevent airplane travel in and out of primeval forest areas set apart as recreational regions on the Northern Minnesota border.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Soviet Union demanded today the immediate recall of George F. Kennan as United States Ambassador to Moscow, charging him with having made "slanderous attacks" against the Soviet Government in violation of established diplomatic behavior.
Taxicabs were back on the streets in their full numbers yesterday afternoon after a one-day "quickie" strike that had halted hundreds of them.
LONDON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Britain's sartorial bible, the trade journal Tailor and Cutter, tried America's two men of the hour on for style today and raised a glad cry of "Stevenson for President."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 3 -- Lebanon is scheduled next week to join the growing list of nations in this area where Government is carried on by Cabinet and legislative decrees issued entirely or largely without the participation of parliament.

The victim's background of opposition to the Trujillo regime in the Dominican Republic imparted mystery yesterday to the slaying of Andres Requena, 44 years old, of 601 Vest 110th Street. Mr. Requena was a former diplomatic or consular employe of the Dominican Republic, a former Army private first class, and the co-publisher of a pamphlet that periodically attacked the Trujillo Administration.

Events today: "The Love for Three Oranges," City Center, 2:15 P. M.; Mu Phi Epsilon musicale, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street, 2:30; "Faust," City Center, 8:15; Ruggiero Ricci, violinist, Charles Paul conducting members of New York Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45;. "La Boheme," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30; Saidenberg Chamber Players, Washington Irving High School, 8:80; American Lyric Theatre, 133 Macdougal Street, 8:40.
ATHENS, Oct. 3 -- A bill by which future general elections will be held under the majority system was adopted in Parliament tonight by acclamation.

MIAMI, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Alabama's hard-charging backs -- Bobby Marlow, Tommy Lewis and Bobby Luna -- carried the Crimson Tide to a 21-7 victory over the youthful but highly regarded Miami Hurricanes in the Orange Bowl tonight.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 -- Close study by Western diplomats of Premier Stalin's new statement on Communist policy led them to conclude tonight that the Soviet leader did not envisage any immediate prospect of armed conflict between the United States and Russia, nor on the other hand any immediate prospect of warmer or more cordial relations between East and West.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 3 -- John Ford plans to spend about three months in Ireland next summer helping a group of "prominent people" to establish a native film producing organization that will bring the Irish as much recognition in the movie field as that enjoyed by the Abbe Theatre.

The soviet Government has forced the withdrawal of George F. Kennan from his post as Ambassador to the Soviet Union by declaring him persona non grata. Its pretext for this move was the charge that he had violated the norms of diplomatic usage by his recent remarks about the position of diplomats in Moscow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce announced today that Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer was leaving on a two-week trip through the West and Midwest.

Vincent A. Flynn of Bayonne, N. J., supervisor of industrial engineering with Sylvania Electric Products Corporation, has been made research director in the national office of the Society for Advancement of Management.

ABOARD EISENHOWER SPECIAL TRAIN in Wisconsin, Oct. 3 -- Asserting that the United States had been caught "flat-footed" in two world wars because of an insufficient merchant marine of its own, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower named a four-member congressional committee today to advise him on programs to expand American-flag shipping.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today analyzed the current attacks on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization as "a great final effort being made for isolationism in this country."

The series of "Pop" concerts in Carnegie Hall continued last night with Charles Paul and a group of New York Philharmonic-Symphony musicians. Mr. Paul conducted Prokofieff's "Classical Symphony," Mozart's "Haffner" Symphony and Harl McDonald's "Little Symphony on Themes from Childhood," while Ruggiero Ricci was violin soloist in Ravel's "Tzigane" and the American premiere of Joaquin Rodrigo's "Concerto d'Ete."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Internal Security subcommittee of the Senate asked the Department of Justice today what it intended to do about the group's recommendation that Prof. Owen Lattimore be prosecuted for perjury.
TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command Communique 1,391 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday Korea time:

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Merger of E Z Paintr Corporation of Milwaukee, largest manufacturer of paint rollers, and Nu-Enamel Corporation, Chicago, was approved today by the United States District Court.

Arbitration of the wage dispute between East Coast longshoremen and their employers will commence on Oct. 14 and continue on a daily basis until completed, Prof. Paul R. Hays, the arbitrator, announced yesterday. The scene of the proceedings has not yet been chosen, he said.
" It will be Joe Black tomorrow," said the gleeful Chuck Dressen after the victorious Dodgers romped into their dressing room at Yankee Stadium.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Smoking a big cigar and obviously pleased but silent about the successful testing of Britain's atomic weapon, Prime Minister Churchill returned to his country home in Kent today by air after a visit to Queen Elizabeth at Balmoral in Scotland.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended to that body today that it permit the railroads in the South and North to hold in abeyance joint rates published in connection with the former service of the Ocean Steamship Company of Savannah on traffic between New York and the Georgia city.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Jack Crimian's brilliant relief pitching for the second straight night helped the Rochester Red Wings to an 8-4 victory over the Kansas City Blues tonight to tie the little world series at three games apiece.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and closing prices were somewhat irregular, points higher to 9 points lower than on Thursday.

Approximately four million persons who had not previously been "citizens" of any country have now acquired nationality and citizenship. They are Malayans. More than a million are not Malays; they are ethnically Chinese. Something under 200,000 are Indian in origin.
Armed robbers in Manhattan yesterday perpetrated without hindrance five brazen daylight holdups that netted more than $14,000 in cash.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Senator Russell B. Long complained today that the armed services were "stationing too many men" in the European theatre.

The New York office of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation disclosed details yesterday of the plastic "Lockfoam" which its Burbank, Calif., engineers are squirting into complex hollow spaces in airplane structural members to strengthen and stiffen them and hold the skins in true aerodynamic form under pressures of high speed.

Protestant congregations here will hold special celebrations of the Lord's Supper tomorrow morning, thus joining in a World-Wide Communion Sunday observance that is held annually among non-Roman Catholics.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 3 -- An extensive gift from the estate of Dr. Henry Drysdale Dakin, British-born biochemist, who developed Dakin Solution in World War I, has been received by Adelphi College. Included are Dr. Dakin's scientific library, the laboratory equipment used during his fifty years of research in America and a collection of rare chemicals.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 3 Senator John J. Sparkman, the Democratic Vice President nominee, declared today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had made "an unbelievable and complete surrender to the Republican isolationist group."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today ordered two subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., to supply natural gas to three utility companies serving areas in Pennsylvania and New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $2,500,000,000 of tax anticipation series 161-day Treasury bills to be dated Oct. 8, 1952, and to mature on March 18, 1953, which were offered on Sept. 26, were opened to the Federal Reserve banks today.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- The State Federation of Labor announced today its support of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic Presidential candidate, and John Cashmore, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate.

In addition to the $822,000,000 that West Germany agreed last month to pay to Israel and the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, between $750,000,000 and $900,000,000 is expected to be paid to about 500,000 other victims of the Nazi regime, Dr. Nahum Goldmann, chairman of the conference, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- A nonstriking employe of the International Harvester Company was fatally slugged today, a day after he crossed a picket line to go to work at the Forge Plant of the McCormick Works.

All royalties derived from the sale of a newly published biography of President Benjamin Harrison, entitled, "Hoosier Warrior," will be applied toward the Jesuit Seminary Building Fund, it was announced yesterday by the Very Rev. John J. McMahon, Provincial of the New York Province of the Society of Jesus.

Chief Judge Robert A. Inch reserved decision in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday on two motions to pave the way for an appeal by Martin James Monti, a former Amy lieutenant who is serving a twenty-five-year treason sentence.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Frank Small Jr., chairman of the Maryland Racing Commission; five tracks and a horseman's association have contributed $4,000 for a silver punch bowl for the Maryland Governor's mansion.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- A new schedule of charges for the purchase and sale of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange is expected to be presented at a hearing on the proposal to members of the Exchange within a month, Walter Maynard of New York City, president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, told members of the Chicago financial fraternity at a meeting today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3 -- Republicans and Democrats were at close quarters today, exchanging frosty compliments at a range of four city blocks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Western and Southeastern railroads today rejected the union shop demand of seventeen non-operating unions.

A former member of the Police Commissioner's confidential squad, who resigned last year after receiving a subpoena to appear before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury, faced prosecution on a contempt citation yesterday after refusing to appear before the panel to answer questions on his financial affairs.

Did formation of the United Corporation by Morgan financial interests in 1929 further an alleged conspiracy of investment bankers to freeze "traditional relationships" with issuing companies, or was it rather a development that led certain defendant bankers in the current anti-trust suit to lose underwriting managements to J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., an alleged conspirator ?

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Cornell, toppled by Colgate last Saturday to its first opening game defeat since 1935, and Navy, off on the right foot for the first time since 1946 with an impressive triumph over Yale, will clash tomorrow at Schoellkopf Field in one of the East's significant early-season football games.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Dr. Edward T. Wentworth of Rochester, president of the State Medical Society, officially opened and dedicated today a 123-year-old doctor's office that has been restored here as part of the early American village exhibit at the Farmers' Museum, affiliate of the New York State Historical Society.

Gazing back over the tense and crowded period since 1945, and the profound fluctuations that have taken place in the world outlook, the war years seem as long ago and far away as some remote epoch in history. It is hard to recapture the mood or those days, and still harder to fit the judgments we made then into the very different context of today.

OTTAWA, Oct. 3 (Canadian Press) -- A big world demand for Canadian dollars has boosted Canada's official exchange reserves to a new high of $1,856,000,000 -- more than the exchange reserves of the entire sterling area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Romance touched this week's list of new patents. Among the hundreds of useful but prosaic valves, chemicals and electric circuits appeared a mitten, invented by Mark Neider of New York to help young couples hold hands in cold weather.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 3 -- Princeton and Rutgers square off in the forty-fourth renewal of the nation's oldest college football rivalry in Palmer Stadium tomorrow.
Only potatoes showed important volume in New York commodity futures trading yesterday. Changes were generally unimportant.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3 -- Lloyd Jordan recently told a meeting of the class of '28 that Harvard football had gained respect and was now in search of prestige, and tonight, on the eve of the Columbia game at the Stadium, the Harvard coach remained optimistic about the Crimson's chances of subduing the favored Lions.

WITH GOVERNOR STEVENSON IN OHIO, Oct. 3 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, campaigning in Taft country for the first time, charged today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had sold out to the Republican Old Guard.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Herbert C. Gerlach, County Executive of Westchester, and Dr. William A. Holla, County Health Commission, said the time schedule set by the Interstate Sanitation Commission for modernization of Westchester sewage disposal plants would be met.

Alicia Markova packed the Metropolitan Opera House to the guards again last night in another guest appearance with the Ballet Theatre, in which she danced in "Les Sylphides" and the 'Nutcracker" pas de deux.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended Sept. 30, 1952, to 111 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- After a 9,000-mile tour of fifteen defense bases across the country, a subcommittee of the House of Representatives reported today gratification over construction progress at the bases, but expressed concern that the military was not as economy-minded as it could be.

Belgium's trade position, representing a heavy surplus in relation to the rest of Western Europe and its associated currency areas and a substantial deficit with the dollar area, shows the need for suitable means of converting earnings in soft currencies into dollars.
Following are the texts of speeches by President Truman today in his campaign on the West Coast, as reported by The Associated Press:

The growth of the air freight industry since its establishment in 1945 indicates that such traffic will surpass passenger business within the next decade, Robert W. Prescott, president of the Flying Tiger Line, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Burbank, Calif.

TOKYO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The strength of the United States Far East Air Forces is being increased by 50 per cent for the United Nations unrelenting air war on Red Korean targets, the United States Secretary for Air, Thomas K. Finletter, said here today.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams lost to the Detroit Lions tonight, 17 to 14, but redeemed themselves in the eyes of their fans.
The New York University football team will be aiming for its second consecutive victory when it meets Kings Point in Great Neck, L. I., today. No Violet team has won two straight games since 1946.

Max Brendler, a former plain-clothesman and the only policeman who has turned state's witness in the Harry Gross police bribery scandal, refused to do it again yesterday at the departmental trial of thirty suspended members of the force.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 3 -- General Sir Gerald Templer, High Commissioner for Malaya, said in Kuala Lumpur today he was receiving regular "fan mail" from people with information about Communist terrorists. Yesterday he received information from people of three new villages in the federation in eighteen sealed boxes that reached him under armed escort and accompanied by headmen from the three villages.

In a letter printed in another column on this page Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. takes the stand that this newspaper endorsed the provisions of the secret protocol of Yalta regarding China and Manchuria and is therefore in no position to criticize it. We did nothing of the sort.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -Despite a 15 per cent increase in taxes, earnings of Philadelphia banks in the first nine months of 1952 were 8 per cent above those of the corresponding period last year.

Bus stops on the far side of the street, as now are the rule on Central Park West, are shortsighted traffic regulations, Joseph F. Addonizio, managing director of the West of Central Park Association, said yesterday. The new system lead to confusion and increases the possibility of accidents, he added.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 3 -- A United States business man and three of his Argentine associates were attacked by strikers yesterday in one of the most pointed recent manifestations of growing labor and student unrest in this country.

James B. Cahill bought the two-family house at 116-27 207th Street, St. Albans, Queens, from Thomas H. O'Brien Sr. and insured title with the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company. The sale was negotiated by A. D'Arienzo as broker.

Efforts on behalf of children by both public and private welfare agencies in this city will be coordinated on a broader scale than ever before through the new child welfare division of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City, Raymond M. Hilliard, executive director of the council, reported yesterday.

The stock market followed yesterday the indecisive pattern set earlier this week. Prices churned about, with the general drift to the lower side, while the volume on the Stock Exchange slumped to the smallest since Monday as transfers contracted to 980,000 shares, against 1,040,000 shares on Thursday.

The word snoop has a most unfortunate connotation, as do such of its cousins as the snooper who does it and the snooping which finds him at work. In fact, it has so bad a connotation that even the dictionary, which usually is reserved in judgment, defines it as "to pry into others' affairs in a sneaking way."
ROME, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Roman Catholic Italy lifted a police ban against the Protestant Church of Christ today after United States diplomatic intervention.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- A career diplomat with an American-born wife has been chosen by the British Government to succeed Sir Oliver Franks as its Ambassador in Washington.

Stanley Steingut, son of the late Irwin Steingut, has been selected as the Democratic candidate to succeed his father as a member of the State Assembly from the Eighteenth Assembly District, Kings County, it was disclosed yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Crosley Motors, Inc., which has discontinued making automobiles, today reported a net loss of $1,981,486 for the fiscal year ending July 31.

SAN FRANCISCO, Saturday, Oct. 4 -- President Truman softened up his "anti-Ike, crusade" yesterday. As he entered the fertile paradise of the Central Valley of California, however, he declared that the Republicans would end the development of natural resources if they "succeed in grabbing off the White House and the Congress next November."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, took his stand tonight beside Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee, in proposing that the United States "should arm the South Koreans as rapidly as possible and, when they are in a condition to defend themselves, we should withdraw American troops."
The State of Rhode Island announced yesterday that it will receive bids Oct. 22 on $5,000,000 of state highway improvement bonds dated Nov. 1, 1952, and due Nov. 1, 1953 to 1972.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 3 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift, 21-year-old Glen Oaks ace, captured her sixth tournament of the season today when she led a field of forty-four in the semi-monthly competition of the Women's Cross County Golf Association.

The construction and rehabilitation next year of seven schools in congested sections of Manhattan were urged upon the City Planning Commission yesterday by Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan. The commission is now preparing the proposed capital budget for 1953.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A short-lived, but bitter, controversy over the makeup of committees to welcome Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower here was settled amicably today when two Negroes were named to the welcoming party.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

SILVER CITY, N. M., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Senator Everett Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, last night attacked President Truman's campaign practices and declared his intention of answering the President "at every stop."

This has been an unusually busy year for crank letter-writers who specialize in threatening baseball players. Bobby Shantz of the Athletics, Ralph Kiner of the Pirates and Joe Black of the Dodgers, among others, were warned by poison-pen notes during the regular season.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 3 -The Government announced today an investigation of the publication of a purported letter from United States Ambassador Chester Boles to a Bombay pro-Communist editor, which Mr. Bowles has denounced as a forgery.

Yesterday could not have been a happy day for General Eisenhower, despite the size of the crowds that turned out to greet him in Wisconsin, nor was it a happy day for many of his supporters. Weeks ago, when he used the strong word "un-American," General Eisenhower made it clear that he detests the methods and the tactics of Senator Joseph McCarthy.

SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Three Republican Senators, covering President Truman's tracks "with the facts," flew in today "to refute the big lie that the G. O. P. would kill reclamation and power projects."

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 4 -- United Nations infantry paced by low-flying fighter-bombers, recaptured yesterday one of four outpost hills on the Western Korean front near Panmunjom, seized over Thursday night by the Chinese Communists in a series of attacks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Allahyar Saleh, Iranian Ambassador, said today he saw "no alternative" to severance of diplomatic relations between his country and Britain if the British should reject Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's latest proposal for settling the Iranian-British oil dispute.

Two men were held in bail yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court after their arraignment on charges of conspiring to defraud the United States Government. They were accused of selling information on sealed bids for the Government's purchase of $17,000 worth of medical supplies.
BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- Berlin's Soviet-controlled elevated railway system today announced a winter schedule that drastically cuts service between West Berlin and the Soviet zone of Germany.

The Long Island Rail Road's trustee and the Pennsylvania Railroad, both accused on Thursday by the Long Island Transit Authority of trying to delay reorganization of the bankrupt commuter line, last night gave partial answer to the charge.
Sales of properties in downtown Manhattan featured realty activity in the city yesterday.

Prayers of thanksgiving were offered by Jews last night opening their annual celebration of Succoth, or Feast of the Tabernacles. The celebration of their harvest festival will be continued nine days by Orthodox and Conservative congregations and eight by Reform Jews.

Westchester County was ordered yesterday by the Interstate Sanitation Commission to end pollution of the Hudson River on or before Dec. 31, 1958. The commission represents New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut.
The major leagues probably will restore the old bonus rule this winter, with a few extra teeth.

PARIS, Saturday, Oct. 4 -- The Communist official journal L'Humanite published today a document giving further details of the dispute that resulted in the demotion of two French Communists, Andre Marty, longtime strongman, and Charles Tillon, wartime Communist resistance chief.
Ralph Olson, Giles St. Clair and Carlos Lopez have been elected vice presidents of S. B. Penick Co., according to S. B. Penick Jr., president.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey accused the Democratic party last night of practicing "political hypocrisy" in its approach toward civil rights legislation. He told a Harlem audience of 1,000 persons that the record of the last twenty years indicated clearly the Democrats had no intention of making good on election promises.
FORT DIX, N., J., Oct. 3 -- Nine of thirteen soldiers who escaped from the prison stockade here on Thursday were still at large today.

PREACHER Roe is a lethargic gentleman from the Arkansas hills. He speaks softly. He pitches softly. Old Preach lazily wheeled in his "nothing ball" at the Stadium yesterday and proved to the consternation of a vast pro-Yankee gathering that when the Dodgers get slick pitching they can be tough, mighty tough.

Utica Knitting Company shareholders will vote on Oct. 30 on a proposal to buy the J. T. Flagg Knitting Company, Inc., of Alabama, for Utica stock, to change the name of the company to the Flagg-Utica Corporation and to make certain changes in the capitalization.

Mayor Impellitteri was asked yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. to call a special executive meeting of the Board of Estimate to discuss the city's financial outlook for the fiscal year beginning next July 1.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct 3 (AP) -- The government of President Victor Paz Estenssoro issued a decree today setting up a government mining corporation, presumably to operate the country's tin mines after nationalization.

Johnny Saxton, Brooklyn welterweight, extended his winning string to 'thirty-two by gaining' a split decision over Ralph (Tiger) Jones in the main ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Each weighed 150 1/4 pounds.

In your editorial of Sept. 17 "Soviet Grip on China" you say that new developments in the Far East "make it necessary to consider again events which are in part the consequence of a secret protocol which the United States approved at Yalta.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, announced today that the anti-trust subcommittee of the House Committee on the Judiciary will hold hearings soon to determine whether the Creole Petroleum Corporation and the Shell Caribbean Petroleum Company have violated the anti-trust laws. Mr. Celler is chairman of the Judiciary Committee and the anti-trust subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Staff experts at the Federal Communications Commission today recommended that the proposed merger of United Paramount Theatres, Inc. and the American Broadcasting Company should not be approved by F. C. C.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 3 -- When Choate opens its football season against Wilbraham on the latter's gridiron tomorrow, the Blue and Gold will be sporting new white jerseys. The old ones were ruined in the Lawrenceville game during a terrible storm last year and school officials gave the battle-scarred shirts to the players as mementos after the last 1951 contest.

The recent disclosure of the horrifying frequency of assaults should no occasion too much astonishment on the part of New York City's newspaper and citizenry. Outrage, yes -- but surely not astonishment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Securities and Exchange commission announced that it has issued an order extending until Nov. 30 the time in which holders of the $5 series and $2.80 preferred stocks of Pennsylvania Edison Company, as well as holders of "over-printed'' certificates for such stocks, may surrender them for final payment.

The fifty-second running of Belmont Park's Grand National steeplechase was won yesterday by Montpelier's 6-year-old gelding Sea Legs, whose sire, Battleship, led 'em home in the event in 1934 and four years later, as a 6-to-1 shot, won the Aintree Grand National.

The New York Telephone Company yesterday disclosed that 291,065 calls were made for inning scores during the second game of the world series between the Dodgers and the Yankees on Thursday at Ebbets Field.

Of the ten games scheduled for the twelfth round of the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, Sweden, only four were decided yesterday and all were drawn, according to a report from Stockholm.

HONG KONG, Oct. 3 -- Deputy Premier Kuo Mo-jo, the chief of Communist China's delegation to the Asian and Pacific Peace Conference in Peiping, charged today that the United States was seeking to revive "Japanese militarism" under a plan to establish a "Pacific Pact Bloc" based on Japan as a nucleus.
PURCHASE, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis won the low gross award in the Women's Tri-County Golf Association one-day tournament at the Century Country Club course today with an 84.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- President Truman marked "Democratic Women's Day" today with the suggestion that "women can best work toward the goals they seek by voting for Adlai E. Stevenson.''

HISTORY repeats itself; foreign correspondents repeat one another. Then, of course, John Gunther comes along and repeats them both. Outside Gunther, however, there are still many amazing or amusing stories of horror or hilarity that foreign correspondents like to tell. You will find a great collection of these in "Off the Record,"* a sort of limitless, sociable session of the Overseas Press Club of America.

Although the drama uptown is full of aches and pains, it flourishes in Greenwich Village. In addition to "Summer and Smoke" and "Widowers' Houses," already celebrated in these columns, the current Village drama includes Anita Grannis' "Love In Our Time" at the Originals Only Playhouse off Sheridan Square.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Oct. 3 -- Concentration on Government and military projects by many colleges is menacing the future of scientific research in this country, a leading atomic scientist asserted here today.

SHERIDAN, Wyo., Oct. 3 -- Although the antelope season will be over by mid-October, mule deer, elk, moose and mountain sheep will be legal game in several parts of Wyoming until early November, and there is plenty of time for those planning a hunt here.
WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 3 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon followed a day of campaigning through Maryland tonight with a "throw-the-rascals-out" brand of speech tonight in this Delaware industrial center.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 -- The trustees of the Boston Public Library voted tonight, 3 to 2, to keep Communist newspapers and other Communist material on the library shelves. The action followed an editorial exchange between The Boston Post and The Boston Herald.
Following is the text of an address given last night by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower at Milwaukee as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Normal week-end restraint and a tendency to await the result of the Government's refunding operation kept business in British funds at a low level on the Stock Exchange today. However, prices held and this steadiness helped other markets to end the week on a quietly firm note.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Quarterback Pete Stark scored two touchdowns and, passed to Halfback Ray Perkins for two more tonight as Syracuse humbled Temple, 27 -- 0.
MORECAMBE, England, Oct 3 -- The fifty-first annual conference of the British Labor party, the most dramatic political convention in this country since World War II, ended here today.

Fall and winter selections from the misses' sportswear department of Altman's were presented recently at a showing on the store's third floor. The group included styles appropriate for town or country in one-piece dresses, separates and ensembles.
TRENTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- New Jersey's Department of Education is teaching itself how to run a television station.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Six medical men declined before the House Committee on Un-American Activities today to answer questions regarding Communist affiliation.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- The New York State Conservation Council, meeting here for its annual convention, today adopted a resolution reaffirming its opposition to the proposed Panther Mountain Reservoir and Dam, on the South Branch of the Moose River, Herkimer County.

" The Infirmities of Genius," by Dr. W. R. Bett, has been scheduled for Oct. 28 publication by the Philosophical Library. Dr. Bett examines the work of fifteen literary figures in connection with their particular illnesses. Among those considered are Thomas Carlyle, Walt Whitman, Edgar Allan Poe, Lafcadio Hearn and Charles Baudelaire.

The "E" in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, known for short as UNESCO, is perhaps the key letter for that agency. Certainly episodes like the recent one in which a UNESCO pamphlet was withdrawn from the Los Angeles public schools because somebody was under the impression that it was trying to "undermine patriotism and replace it with loyalty to world government" suggest that a lot of people do need educating.

There was a bit of confusion mingled with the gloom in the Yankee clubhouse yesterday after the second Brooklyn victory in the world series. The players were wondering what move Casey Stengel could make today in an effort to stem the Flatbush tide.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 3 -- Aroused by the suspension of two of its members from the staff of Danbury Hospital, the Danbury Medical Society at a meeting tonight voted to investigate hospital facilities in neighboring towns in the event of "further ruptures," and demanded the immediate reinstatement of the suspended doctors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today ordered Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, Syracuse, N. Y., to charge off to earned surplus a $1,500,000 expenditure made as a payment to the Aluminum Company of America in 1949.

The flowers and vegetables, arrangements and gardens on display at the County Center in White Plains this week-end offer a cheerful salute to the waning garden year. Nurserymen and professional gardeners have joined amateurs from fifty-three garden clubs to present "Our Premier Flower Show," sponsored by the Ninth District of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State.

ABOARD THE EISENHOWER SPECIAL IN WISCONSIN, Oct. 3 -- A quirk in Wisconsin law caused the Eisenhower special train to speed over, without touching, the body of an 18-month-old baby girl lying between the railroad tracks between Appleton and Neenah, Wis., today.
Five current art exhibitions proclaim the artist's right to paint as he pleases.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Continued dry conditions in the Southwest inspired considerable buying of wheat today, with the support of a more impressive character than recently. July wheat was especially strong, reflecting the unfavorable conditions in the Southwest, but there was also more active support of the other futures.

Beatrice Lillie has scored the first hit of the new season in her intimate "cavalcade of songs and sketches," appropriately dubbed "An Evening With Beatrice Lillie." Without exception, New York's drama appraisers yesterday unrestrainedly hailed the return to the local scene of the British comedienne.

To release 500 policemen "for full-time police duty to fight crime," Fire Department line organizations renewed yesterday their offer to carry out emergency services that they performed before 1930, but that have since been shared with the police.

At 12,922,045 lines, total advertising in the seven New York dailies in September was 2.21 per cent below September last year, according to figures made public yesterday. Financial and general advertising showed gains of 16.15 and 2.67 per cent respectively while classified, hitherto a monthly gainer, showed a loss of 2.32 per cent.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Another step in the process of ending controls and reintroducing competition into British life was taken by the Conservative Government today immediately after yesterday's announcement of the end of tea rationing.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 3 -Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, vice president and general manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, received the meritorious service medal here tonight from the National League of Masonic Clubs at its annual convention. It was given in recognition of his contribution to public information and education.

Except in the East, where three Ivy League games and meetings between Navy and Cornell, Princeton and Rutgers and Fordham and Holy Cross head the card, today's college football program is notable for its many intersectional pairings.

Local retail trade showed a sharper decline this week, according to estimates yesterday. Department-store sales were put at about 9 per cent less than in the corresponding period of last year. Shopping had to meet the competition of the world series games and also suffered because of the rainstorm on Thursday night, which cut store traffic.

When a distinguished citizen, such as Dwight D. Eisenhower, visits a state capital, such as Springfield, Ill., it is natural for the Governor to offer to show the visitor around and set him up something to eat. If the visitor is to make a speech in which the citizens of Springfield might be interested it is natural for the Governor to do what he can to assist him to do so.

HAVANA, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Kid Gavilan, defending the welterweight title in his home land for the first time, was a 3-to-2 favorite today to defeat challenger Billy Graham of New York in their fifteen-rounder at the Gran Stadium tomorrow night.
Admiral Oscar C. Badger, who retired only a few months ago after 45 years of active service with the Navy, has made the U. S. O. his first order of civilian business.

An encouraging increase in the volume of Austria's exports to the United States during the first half of this year was reported yesterday at a meeting of the United States Austrian Chamber of Commerce in the Town Hall Club.

An interesting series of "show-you-hows" in good cookery got under way this week in the French Provincial kitchen that has been planned for Bloomingdale's new Au Gourmet shop by its director of store design, Miss Helen Wells.

The appointment of William T. Kirk as international director of International Social Service is welcome news. His record is a distinguished one. Appointed by the Allied Military Government during the war as relief director for Naples, Italy, he was later put in charge of repatriation of Allied displaced persons and refugees in the European Theatre of Operations.

AMONG the more popular time-killers is a conversational game called "Who's the Greatest Pitcher (or Fielder or Batter) in Baseball?" This, properly pursued in an ill-lighted place, can, of course, lead to violence.

MIXING rather than matching appears to be the current fashion for home furnishings. How well this system works may be judged by the collection pictured here. Designed by Edward Wormley and available through decorators from the Dunbar showroom, it relies on several themes rather than developing a single one as might have been the case a year ago. Materials as well as motifs are varied.

JOHN STEINBECK, an author who obviously enjoys movie making too, has a pair of picture projects on tap, which should keep him occupied well into next year. First on the docket, it became known last week, is "East of Eden," his ambitious and widely praised novel published last month, set in his native Salinas, Calif., Valley and dealing with two families from the end of the Civil War to the Nineteen Twenties.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- A 56-yard scoring pass play late in the third quarter gave Pennsylvania a 7-0 victory over Dartmouth on Franklin Field today in what threatened to stand as the season's battle of futility. With both teams attacking operations overwhelmed by the virulence of the defensive lines, and the crowd of 35,000 in a state of apathy bordering on boredom in midsummer heat, the Red and Blue struck suddenly for the winning touchdown.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Southern California's versatile tailback, Jim Sears, passed to two touchdowns and ran for another today as the Trojans defeated an outweighed but not an outfought Army team, 22 to 0.

A LOW-PRICED 8mm movie projector that incorporates advanced design features was announced last week by Bell Howell Company. It is the No. 221, weighs only twelve pounds and costs $99.95. The 500-watt AC unit has an optical system consisting of a condenser and coated f/1.6 lens.

THE operators of the country's airlines have been assured that the inevitable aerial bus service, via large dependable helicopters, can be expected before 1960. This "whirlibird" transportation is considered essential in most of the cities in the United States because of the distance between the airports and the metropolitan centers.

When rockets are sent up from White Sands, N. M., in efforts to explore the atmosphere at heights that cannot be reached by unmanned balloons, instruments record what they see, feel or otherwise experience. Cameras take pictures of the sun's spectrum, thermometers measure temperatures and barometers pressures, Geiger counters record the intensity of cosmic rays.

CAIRO, Oct. 4 -- One after another the symbols of the old regime have crumbled and toppled under the impact of the Egyptian Army's revolutionary movement. First there was the King, then the feudal landlords and now, inevitably, former Premier Mustafa Nahas and the Wafd party, for thirty-four years the very expression of Egyptian nationalism, not to say patriotism.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4 -- President Truman today charged Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower with blameworthiness and irresponsibility for the precarious situation of United States forces in Berlin and for making political capital gain of the Korean war.

THE prevailing trade winds appear to be favorable for the motion picture industry. The dark pall cast by the shadow of television is slowly lifting, giving rise to the belief that the two industries can go on living and prospering side by side, for the time being at least.

IF, as the publishers say on the jacket, this cloak-and-dagger story of Charles-Henri Sanson, the hangman of Paris, has been a best seller in Sweden, Denmark and Holland, it only proves that audiences abroad can be as lowbrow as those at home.

Throughout the United States the week, posters bearing the slogan, "Ready, Willing and Able," will call attention to the eighth National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week. These posters, which stress the physically disabled as a potential source of skilled, reliable workers, will be found on public conveyances, billboards, store windows and in industrial plants.

The salesman has been the butt of many jokes and, as pictured in fiction and the theatre, is a character not likely to get ahead in his chosen field. Oddly enough, the cream of the crop among corporate executives have risen from the ranks, many having started as salesmen.

IN showing the Edith and Milton Lowenthal Collection of contemporary American art, the Whitney Museum is at once following the main line of its own activities and providing a provocative event on other grounds. For it is obvious that the functions of a private collection differ from those of a public collection, each having certain advantages and disadvantages from the standpoint of the visitor.

BOSLEY CROWTHER has a naive and mistaken view of many Americans' attitude toward Charlie Chaplin's politics if, as he claims, "Mr. Chaplin has expressed in recent years some slightly unorthodox notions about society and social mores.

IN one of the gloom-drenched scenes of this novel the heroine, a pregnant young wife, says wistfully to her husband: "We could make each other happy." and he answers: "How can anyone be happy nowadays?"
WHEN George Abbott was a young man just out of Prof. George Pierce Baker's class at Harvard, he was fired from a vaudeville act.

TALLULAH BANKHEAD, as fearless a woman as ever throttled a metaphor, is coddling a qualm. She will coddle it up to and through next Saturday night, at which time she will know whether she's been harboring a hand grenade or caressing the Kohinoor diamond.

A STRIKING feature of our symphonic programs in late seasons, and especially those of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, has been the number of performances of opera in concert form. This recent trend may not be comforting to those disciples of the pure and the absolute in music who deem the forms of symphonic composition finer, more distinctive, more exalted than those other forms which derive more or less directly from the practices of the lyric theatre.

TELEVISION in Britain has taken its biggest forward step since the war's end with the recent completion of a main national network and extension of service to Scotland and Wales. The smallness of the British Isles is for once an advantage and, it is claimed, Britain now has the best national coverage in the world, as programs are available to 80 per cent of the population, or 40,000,000 people.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 4 -- Holding off the home forces in the final minutes of action, the Milwaukee Shamrocks nipped Meadow Brook, 7 -- 6, for the Monty Waterbury handicap championship before 6,000 fans in the Boy Scout polo benefit game on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.
A recent statement that fire losses in the United States are approaching $3,000,000 a day, around a billion dollars a year, met a mixed reception among authorities here during the week.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Pilloried by its own mistakes, Cornell was an easy victim of Navy today. With three of their four touchdowns coming on the follow-up of errors, the alert Midshipmen routed the Big Red, 31 -- 7, at Schoellkopf Field. It was Navy's second straight victory and Cornell's second straight defeat, a sharp reversal of recent precedent for the teams.

THE starry, white blossoms are open on the sweet autumn clematis (C. paniculata). Soon after their last vestige of perfume has been dissipated in the crisp October fair, the plumy fruits will cover the plant as completely as did the starry blossoms. They will persist until early in the winter.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 4 -- Williams College suffered its second straight loss of the football season today, bowing to the University of Rochester, 12 -- 7, before 3,000 at Weston Field.

SINCE opera is almost as much of an exotic to the Japanese as their No-Drama would be to Americans. the career of impresario is undoubtedly one of the rarest in Japan. Yoshie Fujiwara, who is visiting in this city, wears the rarity of his occupation -- opera impresario in Japan -- with grace.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The State Department began work today on a tough, uncompromising note, scheduled for delivery in Moscow early next week, that would reject as rude and unjustified the Soviet Union's demand for the recall of United States Ambassador George F. Kennan.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Routine repairs to the Cunard liners Queen Elizabeth and Queen Mary will be done in New York if Britain's shipbuilding and engineering unions ban all overtime from Oct. 20.
The Yankees, behind the four-hit pitching of Allie Reynolds, defeated the Dodgers, 2 -- 0, before 71,787 fans at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, tying the world series at two games each.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 4 -- The longest current winning streak in college football was continued through the twenty-fourth game by Princeton today to the general edification of 25,000 spectators at Palmer Stadium.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Britain's reply to Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's proposals for settling the dispute between Britain and Iran over the expropriation of the property of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company was sent to Teheran today for delivery by George Middleton, British Charge d'Affaires.

SECOND Kings does not tell us whether the scoffing children of Bethel were digestible, but we have good evidence about the scoffing children of Britain. Thomas Carlyle was one of many in his age who took up the mantle of prophecy; he was, however, the only Elisha in nineteenth-century England who tried to act as his own bear.

In National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week, which will start on a state-wide scale today, the New York State Employment Service will seek placement of 9,000 registered partly disabled job-seekers as its immediate goal.

ROME, Oct. 4 -- "Premeditated murder" was the judgment passed by the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano today on the recent trial in Sofia, Bulgaria, of forty Roman Catholics accused by the Bulgarian Government of spying.

TOKYO, Oct. 4 -- Top United Nations military leaders in Korea and Tokyo studied carefully this week detailed official reports on the flare-up of fighting in Korea in an effort to determine whether the hill battles there were isolated enemy thrusts or first feelers of an all-out Communist offensive.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 4 -- This shoreline community of 50,000 persons is involved in one of the most controversial issues that have arisen in recent years -- whether to permit the construction of a $15,000,000 generating plant on property owned by the Society of Jesus, which adjoins several exclusive shore developments.

DEVON, Pa., Oct. 4 -- Ch. Toplight Template of Twin Ponds, the 3-year-old imported Welsh terrier that has been showing in top form recently, scored again today. He became best in show of the fortieth event of the Devon Dog Show Association, repeating his victory of a year ago.

IN AS MUCH as a certain lady reporter was in Culver City at the time, documenting the appetite and habits of a dog, the script of "Son of Paleface," Paramount production 10104, Revised, Final, White, came out of the Paramount mimeographing department unheralded. It consisted of a blue cover, 112 pages, weighing less than a pound.

NO season passes without some gardeners bemoaning their losses from seed that failed to germinate. They ought to straighten their backs, if possible, and take a look at the horticulturists at the Kenilworth Aquatic Gardens in Washington, D. C.

SOMEWHAT the same sensations that the audience in Koster Bial's Music Hall must have felt on that night, years ago, when motion pictures were first publicly flashed on a large screen were probably felt by the people who witnessed the first public showing of Cinerama the other night at the opening performance of this new system of film projection at the Broadway Theatre.

VIENNA, Oct. 4 -- The prospects for settling the claims of former Austrian Jews against the Austrian Government for wrongs inflicted on them by the Nazis seem to be brighter. Austrian Finance Minister Reinhard Kamitz, who discussed the question with Jewish organizations during his recent visit to New York, has taken up the matter with his Government and Jewish representatives here and so far negotiations are going well.

THE old, standard themes permit infinite variation; and when the variation is fresh and alive the old, standard theme comes all alive and bright and new. The theme of "The Tender Age" is the one of a boy's growing up.
Frantic cries for the police -- or any other kind of help -- from a man in an apartment at 181 Ellery Street, Brooklyn, brought a police radio car speeding to the Williamsburg section last night.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 4 -- New York University and Kings Point played to a 20-20 tie at Tomb Memorial Field today. A seventeen-yard touchdown pass from the Violet quarterback, Frank Sauchelli, to left half-back Bill Burney deadlocked the game at 2:30 of the fourth period.
MOSCOW, Oct. 4 -- Moscow awaited tonight with no little anticipation and considerable excitement the opening tomorrow night of the nineteenth congress of the Communist party.

Wesleyan University has instituted a new graduate program in letters, social studies and the sciences, in which evening seminars in eighteen courses ranging from art to philosophy will be given. The program is part of Wesleyan's new Division of School and Teacher Services, which this fall also initiated a two-year graduate program leading to the Master of Arts degree in teaching.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 4 -- Though the struggle goes on behind a facade of the grave courtesy characteristic of the region, the upper South, for all its Democratic party tradition, is yet another great battleground in the Presidential race.

Registration for this year's Presidential election starts tomorrow in Near York City and Westchester. Many partisan and non-partisan groups, seeking a record vote, are making coordinated drives to persuade every eligible citizen to qualify by registering.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- King Ranch's To Market galloped to a three-length victory over Dr. Ole Nelson in the $57,900 Dollar Gold Cup at Hawthorne race track today.
TRENTON, Oct. 4 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon carried his campaign for the Vice Presidency into New Jersey today by urging voters to reject "bossism and Trumanism" in Washington.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 4 -- A new hindrance has developed here to the Federal Government's plan for early parliamentary ratification of the West German-Israeli restitutions agreement signed in Luxembourg last month. A condition made by the Jewish signers was that payment of the $822,000,000 reparations in goods and services was to begin immediately after ratification to alleviate Israel's current economic problems.

FONTAINEBLEAU, France. Oct. 4 -- A Western Europe which was largely destroyed and overcome by air power during World War II is never going to regain confidence in its ability to stand upon its own feet until it sees above it a protective aerial "umbrella."

ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 4 (Reuters) -- Huge crowds welcomed Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia today when he made a triumphal entry into the former Italian colony of Eritrea, newly federated with Ethiopia.

TOKYO, Sunday, Oct. 5 -- United States Sabre jets, in three dogfights over northwest Korea yesterday, shot down two enemy MIG jet fighters and damaged five others, bringing their score for October to six Communist planes destroyed and twelve put out of action.

LATE in the seventeenth century all London was agog over what the Rev. Mr. Titus Oates had lately revealed of a Popish Plot. Mr. Oates was an Anglican clergyman who had temporarily turned papist, had lived in Catholic seminaries abroad, and then, turning his coat another time, had come back to England with improbable tales of a monstrous conspiracy to kill the king, burn London, and murder all English Protestants.

Ludek Pachmann of Czechoslovakia played a draw in his adjourned twelfth-round game with Alexander Kotov of Russia in sixty-three moves yesterday in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, Sweden, to share a distinction with Y. Auerbach of Russia, who had drawn with the leader earlier, but in twenty moves.
I read Lillian Smith's "A Declaration of Faith in America" (Sept. 21) with the greatest delight.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 4 -- The pace of the Presidential campaign has now reached such a pitch that it is at least reasonable to ask whether all the activity is clarifying or confusing the central issues before the people.

LAST week in our discussion of what parents might do to help their youngsters toward understanding the current political campaign and the deeper meaning of responsible citizenship, we made brief mention of the varied citizenship training activities going on in many schools today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Evidence concerning the bombings and other outrages last year in the Miami district will be presented to a Federal grand jury in the Florida city on Monday, James P. McGranery, Attorney General, announced today.

MADELEINE RENAUD and I were members of the Comedie Francaise. We believed that our futures were inextricably bound to that company and, indeed, our names were attached to long-term contracts. But in 1946, that great institution was subjected to decrees which were not satisfactory to all the actor-members of the Societe des Comediens Francais.

In many ways printers consider themselves a class apart. One might deduce this from the habit printers have of calling the less skilled practitioners of their trade "shoemakers" or "plumbers." And in a newspaper, where a vast number of editorial employes are concerned with duties which, compared to type-setting and page-composing, seem quite intangible, printers tend to have an I-make-the-ship-go attitude about their own part in the production of the paper.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 4 (UP) -- The Rochester Red Wings completed one of the greatest comebacks in the history of the little world series tonight by defeating the Kansas City Blues, 6 to 4, in the seventh and final game.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 4 -- Most of the students of Peru's four national universities are on strike and the others are threatening to strike on Monday. The Governor of the Department of Arequipa, where the strikes began, has resigned supposedly because of his inability to end the movement and his replacement by an active army officer was announced today.

BECAUSE the peaks of perfection so often reached in the exquisite art of Edouard Vuillard (1868-1940) have never been comprehensively viewed in this country, no new gallery could open more auspiciously than with a selection of his work.

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- A formal reorganization of all the Communist parties in the world may well begin shortly after the Soviet Union initiates administrative changes in the Bolshevik hierarchy next week. Just how drastic the forthcoming reforms may be remains to be seen both in Soviet and international Communist terms.

TOKYO, Sunday, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Col. Aubrey D. Smith, chief of the Far East command's plans and operations supply section, died Saturday of a knife wound that Gen. Mark Clark's headquarters said was "allegedly inflicted by his wife, Mrs. Dorothy Smith."
A ten-year, $102,105,000 development plan for New York University was announced yesterday by George E. Roosevelt, president of the university's governing council, and Dr. Henry T. Heald, chancellor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4 (UP) -- The Republican "Truth Team" said today that President Truman had made "false" statements regarding the Republican stand on social legislation while remaining silent on "major" issues of "communism, corruption and confusion" in his Administration.

OTTAWA, Canada, Oct. 4 -- Using two helicopters, five Canadian geologists during the past season made an aerial geological survey of 57,000 square miles of territory in the Northwest and accomplished as much at the same cost as it would have taken a ground party twenty-five years to do, according to a statement by Minister of Mines George Prudham.

ABOUT six months ago Howard Hanson, in these pages, appealed to readers for suggestions about a recording program devoted to American music. Part of the returns are now in. Dr. Hanson, director of the Eastman School of Music, expresses astonishment at the number of replies received in response to his letter.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 4 -- Holy Cross showed enough daring and imagination to defeat the Fordham football team in a stirring battle today. With all the scoring taking place in the first half, the Crusaders held off the eager Rams' closing bid to register the triumph by 12 to 7.

IS honesty the best political policy? Yes, said General Eisenhower on Sept. 21 in St. Louis. This copybook maxim, is one of the "standards by which, in those days [when the general was in grade school], greatness was judged; the standards by which those great Americans actually lived."

THE planks of the Democratic and Republican platforms touching conservation matters were quoted and briefly commented on in our August column. In the two months that have elapsed, the two candidates have expressed views of their own about conservation.

AN American-educated Chinese on the faculty of the University of Hawaii, C. K. Cheng approaches the question of United States policy in respect to China in a manner refreshingly different from some recent diatribes.

MOST gardeners are usually on the lookout for new and pleasing plant combinations, since it is not as simple as it may seem to put plants together properly. Factors to be considered are form, vigor, foliage, texture, time of bloom and color.

BERLIN, Oct. 4 -- The repatriation of the remaining German war prisoners in the Soviet Union was held out today by the East German Government as further bait for the reunification of Germany.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 4 -- They measure natural gas in trillions of cubic feet -- in Texas, of course. And though Texas exports it to as far away as New England, it keeps 2,036,800,000,000 cubic feet of its 4,673,500,000,000 annual production for its own uses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- The Veterans Administration's chief medical advisers have unanimously recommended that it close "some" of its hospitals unless Congress restores $31,000,000 cut from its appropriation.

The uneasy stalemate that has prevailed since July between "fair trade" proponents and their most dogged and formidable adversary was shattered last week. Eli Lilly Co. sued Schwegmann Brothers in Federal Court in New Orleans.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 4 (AP) -- A hard-driving Penn State football team today thwarted what appeared to be inevitable defeat for the third straight week as the Nittany Lions took advantage of a blocked kick and a fumble to outscore William and Mary, 35 to 23, before 25,000.
SHERMAN, Conn., Oct. 4 -- The 546 year-round residents and many summer visitors of this Yankee town in the foothills of western Connecticut celebrated today the 150th anniversary of its settlement.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 4 -- An aroused Notre Dame eleven staged a brilliant second-half comeback, sparked by Quarterback R. V. Guglielmi, to upset Texas, 14 -- 3, today before a record 66,390 fans in Memorial Stadium. The Longhorns were ranked third in the United Press national roll.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Representative Frank L. Chelf said today that Supreme Court Justice Tom C. Clark had used "improper judgment" in the 1946 Kansas City vote fraud case but he had found no new evidence reflecting on Justice Clark's integrity.

WHEN the epicure thinks of honey, he recalls the taste of many good things. He remembers the firm, sweet honey cookies of Germany, the lebkuchen, that are perhaps the most famous Christmas cookies of a country that can boast many famous Christmas cookies.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Plant small-flowering spring bulbs, daffodils and hyacinths. Crocus and other small bulbs are set about three inches deep and apart. Holes for daffodils should be deep enough so that at least six inches of soil can go over the bulbs, and five inches on top of hyacinths. Hyacinths and daffodils should be spaced a minimum of six inches apart.
The author, a 19-year-old resident of London, has just returned to England to enter the Royal Air Force or Oxford University, depending on his draft board.
CLINTON, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Piling on 33 points in the second quarter, Hamilton College handed Brooklyn College its second trouncing of the season by a score of 52 -- 0 today.

A publicity campaign by the New Jersey Highway Authority to persuade the voters next month to pledge state credit for a $285,000,000 bond issue has stirred a controversy in the state. Yesterday the New Jersey Taxpayers Association condemned the drive and a Ridgewood publisher said he would start a taxpayer's suit to halt the campaign spending.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 4 -- The town of Wonosobo in central Java is to become a Southeast Asian "Middletown" for a searching eighteen-month study, financed by the Ford Foundation and carried out by a team of nine Americans in cooperation with Indonesia's national university of Gadjah Mada.

The first act from Franz Lehar's popular operetta, "The Merry Widow," will open the New York Public Library's recorded concert between noon and 2 P. M. on Wednesday in the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building. The two principal roles in the recording, an October release, are sung by Dorothy Kirsten and Robert Rounseville.
The Opportunity Shop, whose board of managers is headed by Mrs. Charles King Morrison, has recruited debutantes to assist in sales at the shop, located at 46 West Forty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- The canning industry will honor "the man behind the tin can" on his 200th birthday anniversary on Oct. 23. That man was Nicolas Appert, who was born in 1752.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- John Foster Dulles, chief foreign policy adviser of the Republican party, echoed here today the suggestion made this week by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, that South Koreans replace United States troops on the front lines in the Korean war.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 4 -- The Democrats face today the problem of getting farm policy back into the campaign.
DULUTH, Oct. 4 -- Following are excerpts of General Eisenhower's speech here today as recorded by The Duluth Herald:

The photograph of the Duncan Dancers in the Long Island garden, published in the letters column of THE TIMES Magazine on Sept. 21, evoked memories of a lovely summer afternoon. The iris were in bloom around the pool, and George Barrere's silver flute accompanying the dancers completed a scene that remains in memory one of mystic enchantment.

With a fanfare of publicity Broadway last week witnessed the debut of Cinerama, a new and impressive method of imparting depth to picture. The inventor, Fred Waller, has not solved the problem of presenting stereoscopic pictures on the screen, nor does he claim to have done so.

A large number of tickets have been sold for the evening performance of "My Darlin' Aida" at the Winter Garden on Oct. 28, which has been taken over as a benefit for St. Barnabas House, a temporary shelter for children.

IN a move to make it easier for tourists to plan their trips to Israel, the Israel National Tourist Center in Jerusalem has taken steps to guarantee that all hotel rates throughout that country will remain fixed at the recently adopted schedule for a full year, through Oct. 1, 1953.
The National Machine Tool Builders Association, an organization of companies that make the machines responsible for mass production, is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary this month.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 4 (UP) -- California showed a record opening-day crowd of 56,708 Minnesota football fans today why it is rated the nation's second-best team as it scored a 49-to-13 victory with a powerful running attack.

The campaign is at the halfway mark. It is a political axiom that the voters are ready to vote at the end of September, and that October is nothing but words and vexation of spirit. But not this year, evidently. A national poll last week reported half the voters still undecided.

IN Dun Laoghaire, Ireland, Torca Cottage, the former home of George Bernard Shaw, is up for sale. It's described as an "Old World type residence, of charm and character, completely modernized without disturbing its Shavian associations." Phone Dun Laoghaire 86177.

DETROIT, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Villanova, rated fifteenth in the nation in the weekly United Press poll, turned two intercepted passes and a fumble into touchdowns tonight to defeat a stubborn University of Detroit, 21 to 7, before 19,312 fans.

QUITO, Ecuador -- This city, almost astride the Equator, is 2,840 miles, or twelve hours' flying time, from New York. To be in Quito is to step back to another time, that of sixteenth-century Spanish colonial greatness in the New World.

The board of governors of the Woman's Hospital has taken over the evening performance on Dec. 12 of "Two's Company," the new musical by Vernon Duke and Ogden Nash, starring Bette Davis, at the Alvin Theatre. It will be the first theatre benefit given by the hospital in many years, and the proceeds will go toward the purchase of additional X-ray equipment for the treatment of cancer patients.

The Great Pyramid of Cheops with its 3,000,000 cubic yards of masonry was the biggest single block in the world until the Grand Coulee Dam was built. The pyramid was built about 2,700 B. C. by some 100,000 laborers in the course of twenty years at a labor cost of about 400 man-hours per cubic yard.

ON the day after Gertrude Lawrence's funeral I happened to be walking through Forty-fourth Street. At the St. James Theatre the electricians were taking down her name from the marquee. Her name had already been removed from the houseboards, and the huge photographs of her had been put away.

WE make our friends; we make our enemies; but God makes our next-door neighbor. Hence he comes to us clad in all the careless terrors of nature; he is as strange as the stars, as reckless and indifferent as the rain.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4 -- It used to be that Columbia could not win a football game from Harvard but things have changed drastically. Today Lou Little's Lions continued their domination over the Crimson by registering a 16 to 7 triumph before a crowd of 14,000 at Harvard Stadium. It was the fourth straight year that Columbia had turned the trick.

FORT MONTGOMERY, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Residents from this village and near-by areas will participate in a parade and ceremonies here tomorrow to observe the fall of the twin forts, Montgomery and Clinton, 175 years ago next Monday. Parts of the forts are preserved and will be visited by thousands of school children next week.

IT is refreshing to read a sober, balanced, scholarly discussion of such an emotional issue as the Sudan by someone who is not only expert but who has been involved in the developments. Mekki Abbas shows no bias in favor of the British or the Egyptians, and he has no extremism about the aspirations of his native Sudan.

THERE is nothing that gives the average person greater satisfaction than planting a tree or shrub. It may be a black alder dug out of the swamp and moved into moist soil in the back yard. Or it might hold the promise of sparkling McIntosh apples, luscious Bartlett pears, wonderful Redhaven peaches, or Kendaia grapes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Seven veteran career men in the Government's tax service were named today to top posts in the newly established Internal Revenue District comprising six New England States. Secretary John W. Snyder announced that Thomas E. Doyle, who entered the revenue service in 1922, has been appointed District Internal Revenue Commissioner for the six-state area.

In northeastern Minnesota, on the Canadian border, lies one of the few unspoiled forest and water areas of the United States. The final quarter of the year and the first week of longer trading hours for many security and commodity exchanges was ushered in on a note of greater optimism than had been prevalent of late. With peace assured in the soft coal industry and predictions for business more favorable, the outlook indicated a decided improvement.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 4 -- With Ed Molloy, junior quaterback, and Ed Woodsum pairing beautifully, Yale rebounded from its setback at the hands of Navy last Saturday with a 28-0 triumph over Brown in the Bowl today.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 4 (UP) -- Indiana's undermanned Hoosiers, sparked by the passing of Lou D'Achille, rallied twice today to whip Iowa, 20 to 13, in a Big Ten game before 20,000 fans in Memorial Stadium.
