WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau, a report showed today, has discovered 428 cases of "pay-offs" and graft in its drive all over the nation against income tax evasion by racketeers and crooks.
Bennett E. Meyers, former major general in the Air Force, who already has served a sentence for tax evasion and subornation of perjury, was accused yesterday of trying to bribe a witness to lie.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Oct. 4 -- Although no details on West Germany's latest proposals for reaching an agreement with the French on the future of the Saar were given out here by either French or Saar officials, the impression created in the Saar's capital today was that no great progress had been made.

IF you visit the loan exhibition which opens at the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday you will see, among many others of the same style, the paintings reproduced on these pages. You will be struck by their blatant, carnival color -- burning yellows, searing oranges, hot reds, pinks like raspberry sherbet, vehement greens and gentle lilacs -- colors which clash, vibrate and resolve themselves into bright sunshiny harmonies.

The Propeller Club of the United States, meeting on the West Coast for the first time in eleven years, will open in Los Angeles tomorrow its twenty-sixth annual convention. In conjunction with the meeting, the club will convene the American Merchant Marine Conference, which will include technical papers and panel discussions.

Along about now, when there is a briskness in the autumn winds, Santa Claus takes time off to confer with business executives throughout the country. (Later on he will be talking busily with mothers, fathers and uncles.)

INADEQUATE roads, "inequitable" taxation and other factors that contribute to increased commercial-carrier costs will be discussed at the nineteenth annual convention of the American Trucking Associations, which will start today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and continues through Friday.

AS the Nineteenth Congress of the Soviet Union's Communist party opens in Moscow today, the key question is: Will this Congress mark the beginning of the transfer of power from Stalin to his successor? For the first time in a quarter of a century Stalin will not give the report of the Central Committee, the key Congress document, but Georgi M. Malenkov, long Stalin's protege, will deliver it.
The weekly Itawamba County Times in Fulton, Miss., recently adopted this slogan: "The only newspaper in the world that cares anything about Itawamba County."

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 4 (AP) -- The arm, heart and feet of a hulking Vanderbilt freshman quarterback bewildered a big Northwestern defense today and forced the favored Big Ten Wildcats to settle for a 20-20 tie in an intersectional football battle.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, today warned students who expected to attend college next fall that they faced much stiffer deferment regulations.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- United States and Canadian Air Force units stationed in Britain joined the Royal Air Force and the French, Belgian and Netherlands air forces today in the largest air maneuvers over Britain since the war.

The role of hormones in health and disease is the subject of the twenty-fifth annual Graduate Fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine, which will begin tomorrow a comprehensive series of hospital clinics, morning panels and evening lectures. It will continue through Oct. 17.

Under the auspices of the board of directors of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club, the annual Futurity Ball, a dinner dance, will be held at the Plaza on Oct. 30. The entire proceeds of the party, which is being underwritten by Belmont Park, will be used for the maintenance of the club and its philanthropic work in the interest of the members of the uniformed services.

The role of former Attorney General J. Howard McGrath in the corruption picture has always been hazy. The Justice Department, which McGrath then headed, entered the picture last fall with disclosures of malpractice in the Tax Division. One result was that President Truman fired T. Lamar Caudle, head of the Tax Division.

TOKYO, Oct. 4 -- Japanese and foreign analysts here busied themselves this week with attempts to interpret more fully the results of Japan's first general election since restoration of national independence.
STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 4 -- The U.S.S. Aggressive 422, a naval minesweeper of unusual construction, was launched here today.

WICHITA FALLS, Tex., Oct. 4 -- Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated Department Stores, was widely acclaimed here this week for his tribute to the expanded and stable economy of Texas and the Southwest. He spoke at the opening of a new Fedway store here.

OPERA LOVERS this week may have their choice of four new full-length opera recordings, all made in Europe. The new disks offer the familiar splendors of La Boheme, recorded in Rome (Remington), La Traviata, also made in Rome (Remington), Cilea's L'Arlesiana, recorded in Milan (Colosseum) and Tchaikovsky's Pique-Dame, with soloists, orchestra and chorus of the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow (Colosseum).

THIS Tuesday will mark the 175th anniversary of the Battle of Saratoga, the turning point of the Revolutionary War and one of Sir Edward Creasy's "Fifteen Decisive Battles of the World." The occasion seemed appropriate for a pilgrimage to the Saratoga battlefield, so on a recent afternoon I visited the consecrated fields along the Hudson where the independence of the United States was insured.

Adult education in this country is now at an all-time high. Throughout the United States schools and community colleges are putting greater emphasis than ever before upon study programs for adults. Nearly 5,000,000 are enrolled in such classes -- an increase of almost 2,000,000 in four years.

HAMBURG, Pa. -- Of all the months to visit Hawk Mountain Sanctuary, that vast expanse of trees and shrubs which makes up the wildlife refuge a few miles north of here, October is probably the best and most rewarding, for it marks a high point in the annual eagle and hawk migration to the South at a time when the fall foliage is at its best.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Oklahoma, plagued by fumbles in its opener a week ago, regained composure and a measure of its reputation today by walloping Pittsburgh, 49 -- 20, in an intersectional football game played before 38,000 approving fans.

New slums are being created in many parts of the city faster than modern housing can be constructed to replace them, James Marshall, recently retired member of the Board of Education, declared yesterday.
DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Duke, holding Tennessee to two first downs and 25 yards gained rushing, uncorked a vicious ground game today to defeat the Vols, 7 -- 0, before a crowd of 35,000.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, their physicians said today, are in good health.

The identity of the assassin of Andres Requena, formerly active in Dominican Republic politics, and the political loyalties of the victim remained a mystery yesterday. Senor Requena, former editor of De Patria, a pamphlet critical of the regime of President Hector Trujillo was shot dead Thursday night on the lower East Side.

THE oceans speak to us in riddles. We have learned that life began in the sea, that it contains every element, that it influences climate, the growth of vegetation on land, even the destiny of peoples and nations. But the oceans hold many secrets and pose knotty questions to those engaged in oceanography -- a relatively new science. Only by persistent research can the pieces of the oceanic puzzle be assembled.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Oct. 4 -- No amount of food and technical aid from the United States will save Asia from communism unless this country also offers spiritual and intellectual leadership, Minoo R. Masani, statesman and industrialist of India, declared here today.

SHOW business, especially for one lone seal, can be a dull grind even up at the top. Othello, with his mirror to give the illusion of company and kind Mister Higgins for his trainer, was toiling along bravely, though, until an invitation came from King Willie of Sealskin Island.
BERLIN, Oct. 4 (UP) -- An order of the day called on the East German police today for the "broad organization of defense" and made it plain that the East German Communists were building up an army.

EACH year dozens, even hundreds, of new daylilies enter the garden picture to contend for top honors. Some of them show the merit of champions; others fail to surpass the old favorites. In taking stock of the new varieties, it is difficult to resist giving credit to a few older ones that still lead the race in their color classes.

FOR some reason which has always puzzled me, a volume of poems or essays is more likely to come out of the printing plant looking like a classic than almost any other kind of book. It is as though designer, pressman and binder, realizing that they are dealing with a form of literature that is in exceedingly precarious health, were doing their best to make up in appearances for what is lacking in appreciation.

DARK tulips are accents and, therefore, should be used with restraint and subtlety. They may be planted to bring depth and substance to an otherwise pale combination of pink, lavender and yellow tulips. Or they may be used to blend an otherwise too bright combination of yellow and orange tulips. Again, they might be the strong point among early-flowering perennials.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- With a fine fall breeze that rose from seven knots out of the west to ten, the post-season racing of the Larchmont Yacht Club was carried on today out on Long Island Sound.
Following are the prepared texts of addresses by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson yesterday afternoon at Fort Dodge, Iowa, and last night in St. Paul, Minn., as carried by The Associated Press:
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie put before United Nations delegates today a set of suggestions for saving time by speeding the work of the General Assembly.
ABOARD THE TRUMAN TRAIN ON THE WEST COAST, Oct. 4 -- President Truman has engaged General Eisenhower in an epic political conflict, and before the Nov. 4 finale one of them is going to get hurt.

Americans will be sorry to see the forthcoming departure of their good friend British Ambassador Sir Oliver Franks. His great scholarship has entitled him to warm respect; his engaging personality has helped to win the affectionate esteem in which he is held. He has been, moreover, an excellent symbol of the close ties of understanding that bind together the people whom he represents and those to whom he came.

Samuel J. Montgomery, who has spent thirty-nine years in the Customs Service, will retire as chief assistant appraiser on Oct. 30, it was announced yesterday by John H. Flynn, Appraiser. Mr. Montgomery will be succeeded by Theodore Bishop, a veteran of thirty-eight years in the service.

AN editorial writer and book editor for a Midwestern newspaper has written the story of a family venture (and adventure) in adoption that should interest all parents who enjoy reading accounts of family life that are honest, warm and happy.

I HEAR that a suggestion was made to Queen Elizabeth not long ago that the office of court jester should be taken out of abeyance. One wonders at first how this ancient office ever came to be discontinued. It must have died away before the advance of constitutional government.

Elements in the zipper manufacturing industry responsible for about 10 per cent of the industry's annual volume of $115,000,000 acted last week to form the Zipper Industry Association, with the announced purpose of setting up standards for the manufacturers.
An Army captain waiting with a family group for a traffic light to change was killed yesterday at 2 A. M. when a nine-ton trailer truck went out of control at Madison Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 4 -- Wesleyan took to the air to defeat Bowdoin, 27 to 7, today as the Redmen's passing duo, John Brigham and Dave Nixon, passed to Bob Backman and Bob Lavin with great effectiveness.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People demanded today an end of segregation in schools on Army posts.

TO do the author of "Rhymes of a Rebel," justice, he calls his verses rhymes, not poems. If we say he is not a poet, he will retort, probably in rhyme, that he does not claim any such high dignity. He does not rub shoulders with Mr. Eliot or Mr. Pound.

" THIS study," says the author, "is concerned with the literary and biographical background, the genesis, writing and meaning of Herman Melville's 'Mardi'" -- and those who have read "Mardi" will appreciate the complexity of Mr. Davis' task.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- According to a report that reached official Washington this week, a wave of disillusionment about the present Greek Government appears to be widening, and the Greeks must look to King Paul for non-partisan leadership that "alone can prevent them from being lost in a maze of left [Communist] turns."

The tabernacle, or booth, that is built at Jewish homes and synagogues for the celebration of Succoth, the Feast of Tabernacles, was described as "a canopy of peace, a symbol of the impermanence of the home," in a Succoth sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Samuel M. Segal, rabbi of Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street.

THE world lost a doctor and gained an essayist and moralist when Aldous Huxley, grandson of Thomas Henry Huxley, contracted keratitis at Eton. Plunged into almost total blindness, he knew that he would never recover his sight sufficiently for the microscope and anatomy laboratory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, made public today his income tax returns for the last eight years, showing a gross income of $89,497.71, on which he paid Federal taxes amounting to $18,441.51.
Following are the prepared texts of President Truman's speeches at a luncheon in San Francisco yesterday and in Oakland last night, as carried by The Associated Press:

MARTHA FULTON is a wonderful lady who has been through the mill. With a discerning and witty pen she fashioned a play, seen last Tuesday evening on Armstrong's Circle Theatre over N. B. C. video, about a young mother who decided to do something about a school problem. It would have won the approval of any father who has been tempted to sue the P. T. A. for alienation of affections.
AS an ardent adherent of the Great Books idea which has been so vigorously attacked by Gilbert Highet, I feel I have to come to its defense. * * *

Store sales in the metropolitan area did not do so well last week. A bad rainstorm on Thursday evening, when many stores were open, and the World Series baseball games served to cut down traffic, and volume diminished as a consequence.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- A dispute over whether the conductor shall be American or British threatens to put an early end to the London run of "Porgy and Bess." The American folk musical by George Gershwin, last presented in Berlin, is scheduled to open at the Stoll Theater on Thursday.

EVEN while New York and New Jersey officials were swinging shovels last week at the breaking of ground by the Port of New York Authority for the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel, Authority engineers were working on plans for a brand new $200,000,000 tunnel under the Hudson River connecting West Fourteenth Street and Hoboken.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 4 -- Wisconsin shattered Illinois' string of eleven games without defeat, 20 to 6, today with crunching running by Alan (The Horse) Ameche, dancing dashes by Harland Carl and pinpoint passing by a sophomore, Jim Haluska.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Oct. 4 -- Spurred by fears that Western Europe is falling behind in the peaceful exploitation of nuclear energy, scientists of ten countries met here today to consider plans for a jointly operated atomic research center.

THE story is told that in the old Indian Civil Service a wise old Briton whose job was to brief recruits coming out to India always gave the following advice: "Do not try to understand the Indian mind; just be sure the Indian understands yours." This was sound advice, for if there is any people in the world of whom it can be said that they are "different," it is the Indians.
" I threw that long ball," was Joe Black's rejoinder to the first writer who offered a sympathetic remark that it was tough to lose on three hits. "I'm always failing."

NEWARK, Oct. 4 -- The first of two public forums under the auspies of the New Jersey League of Women Voters will be held Tuesday at Collingswood High School. The second forum is scheduled for Hillside Junior High School, Montclair, on Oct. 14.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 4 -- One of the two physicians suspended from the Danbury Hospital here has received special permission to use the hospital for an obstetrical case expected in about two weeks.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Quarterback Jack Scarbath's passing and running ripped the scoring bonds off undefeated Maryland in a four-touchdown burst and then the Terrapins retired into their shell for the last quarter of the game in trouncing Clemson, 28 to 0.

Gen. Lucius D. Clay said last night he took full responsibility for arranging American access to Berlin, that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had had nothing directly to do with it, and that he himself still did not think he had made any mistake.

LOCKPORT, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Senator Irving M. Ives charged today that President Truman was behaving like a "ward heeler" in a "vicious and utterly unworthy aspiration to annihilate the character" of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- John Cashmore, Brooklyn Borough President, said here tonight that "the Dewey, Ives, Taft, Eisenhower team" was spending millions "in a desperate effort to sell the American people a bill of goods and sell American labor down the Ohio River."

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 4 -- Except for the Presidential battle, no contest in the Pacific Northwest is drawing greater interest this fall than the vigorous fight between Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican of Washington, and Representative Henry M. Jackson, Democrat, for Mr. Cain's seat.
Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein outlined yesterday some aspects of the state's plan to combat irregularities at polling places here during registration week and on Election Day.
The New York City Opera Company staged Prokofieff's "The Love for Three Oranges" yesterday afternoon at the City Center of Music and Drama. It was the troupe's thirty-fourth performance of this work.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Vice President, it has been said, is only a heartbeat removed from the Presidency and therein lies the real importance of the job.

A PROVEN master of the picture-book technique, Stefan Lorant turns again to the life of Abraham Lincoln. (His is first venture in the field, "Lincoln: His Life in Photographs," came out in 1941.) This time there will be no need for a revision and no place, at least in the foreseeable future, for a comparable book by anyone else.

The long awaited "procedure" for Quartermaster purchasing of wool products under the "Buy American" provision, released last week by the Munitions Board, should open the road for substantial wool purchases in the immediate future.

We sincerely join with the keynote objective set forth at the end of your Sept. 30 editorial on labor cartelization -- that Americans in all fields of endeavor may join hands abroad in the common objective of increasing production for the purpose of raising living standards.

Harry Hershfield in "The Ad Lib -- Quip That Stings" (Sept. 21) writes that: "a number of the television-radio political panels are now tossing in hoary retorts as if they were original and spontaneous. For a few of the following originals, we give credit where credit is overdue.

Twenty-five dance-minded small fry from the Lower East Side had their first look at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon, when they attended the Ballet Theatre's production of "Billy the Kid." They expressed unanimous approval of the performance.

MUCH of the economic news last week made encouraging reading for the business man. Even the retailer, who is not experiencing any sharp upturn in fall sales, was cheered by predictions that Christmas trade is likely to set a new record in both dollar and unit volume.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- An Army study disputed today Senate investigators' charges that too many United States infantrymen were in noncombat jobs.

First frost is one of the major landmarks of the year. It is the turning point, the boundary between the green and growing season and the season of rest for the leafy world. True, the time of rest comes gradually. Leaves color and begin to fall and the active juices of life are withdrawn to the roots, even before frost strikes.

SMALLEST of the litter, the little black fox was chosen by his father to stand watch while father robbed a henhouse. Forgetting caution, the little fox had a rough time of it, what with breaking his leg and having to spend days and days caged under the lilac bush on a farm.

AS one who has constantly advocated greater freedom of expression for the screen, I feel some hesitancy in taking issue with Jean Delannoy's remarks concerning censorship in your paper last Sunday. If, however, I read this French director's article correctly, he would readily grant admission to any motion picture to anyone, regardless of age, desiring to see it.

BEETHOVEN: Overture to Coriolanus and Egmont; Leonore Overture No. 3; Josef Keilberth, conducting the Berlin Philharmonic and Bamberg Symphony (Capitol). Sound, energetic readings by a fine conductor, especially in the "Leonore" No. 3.

WITH that strange perversity of the human race, the more we become urbanized as a people, the more our interest seems to rise in the natural surroundings we have given up. Increasingly the ordinary city dweller feels the need occasionally to "get out into the country"; increasingly his curiosity is aroused about the simple forms of nature that excite even the least trained eye.

WHEN a girl is 17 she is usually more concerned with her future than with her past. Sylvia, however, worried about both. An orphan, happy with her adopted family, she had never given much thought to her origin until dashing Brooke Lowry came along.

LONDON, Oct. 4 (Reuters) -- Arsenal, London glamor team, upheld a fifty-six-year record today by scoring a 3-1 victory over Blackpool, knocking the northerners off the top spot in the English Soccer League.
JULE Styne, the song writer and co-sponsor of "Pal Joey," has just completed his score for "Hazel Flagg," the musical he plans to present here early next year in association with Anthony B. Farrell.

NO matter what kind of a dog Sally Scott describes -- a frisky spaniel, a serious-minded collie or just a plain mutt -- he is always a distinct personality. Benjie was plain mutt, a huge, cheerful, walloping stray, with a love for all mankind, and when he bumbled into the Smith household he changed the outlook of the whole family.

Trailing three youths who were believed to have stolen $450 of automobile and television accessories from a store last Monday, Brooklyn detectives discovered, upon arresting the three yesterday, that the loot had been increased by $700 of additional material taken from the same store early on Friday.

A bit of squeeze play was worked on Eddie Arcaro by David Gorman on Belmont Park's far turn yesterday, and it helped in the scoring of a two-length victory by Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' One Count over Calumet Farm's Mark-Ye-Well in the $79,200 Jockey Club Gold Cup race.

MOST of us have a difficult enough time in life with two normal legs. Henry Viscardi Jr. was born with his legs deformed, two gnarled stumps folded across the abdomen. He spent the first six years of his life in a hospital, enduring the pain of operations as well as the psychological pain of knowing he was different from other people.

The U. S. and the U.S.S.R. established diplomatic relations only nineteen years ago by the calendar but eons ago in terms of the swiftly changing chronicle of world struggle. Relations between the two countries were never more strained than they were last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- In an unusual appeal for campaign funds the Democratic National Committee will have 250,000 volunteer workers throughout the nation making a week-long door-to-door canvass starting Wednesday seeking $5 contributions for the Stevenson-Sparkman ticket.
J. J. Singh in his "How to Win Friends in Asia" (Sept. 28) raises a question as to the exclusion of Asians from the Anzus Pacific Council.

ON EISENHOWER TRAIN, Oct. 4 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower ridiculed tonight President Truman's attacks upon him as "noisy but harmless blanks" fired by an old artillery man who symbolized a Democratic campaign based on "sound without substance, promises without performance, howls without harming."

NOKOMIS, Sask., Oct. 4 -- Despite the similarity of names, this prairie village was not the birthplace of Hiawatha's grandmother, nor, so far as can be determined, did Longfellow ever sleep here, but it is a happy hunting ground for those seeking prairie chicken, Hungarian partridge and assorted waterfowl.

Professor Highet's review is a laudable and incisive criticism of what has involuntarily become a vested interest in the cultural field. For he is attacking not merely the new set of fifty-four volumes, but the reading program of the far-flung network of Great Books discussion groups. * * *
The Yankees sang the praises of two old pros in the clubhouse yesterday following the 2-to-0 shutout of the Dodgers with which they squared the series at 2 -- all.

Theft prevention measures have been a factor in keeping down both truck cargo and individual package thefts in the last three years, according to Jack Seide, president of Babaco Alarm Systems of New York.

One hundred thousand persons are expected to march today in the sixteenth annual Pulaski Memorial Day Parade on Fifth Avenue from Twenty-sixth to Fifty-second Street in honor of Brig. Gen. Casimir Pulaski, Polish aristocrat, who was killed in the American Revolution while aiding the colonists.

IN "The West Pier" Patrick Hamilton tells of the formative years and early manhood of Ernest Ralph Gorse, born in 1903 in Hove, England, and introduced to us as, practically from that year, a member of "the criminal class."

A FRESH variation on the cowboy theme, this picture-story has something of the quality of a streamlined folktale. Nanda Ward, daughter of the artist, writes of the cowboy Johnson who sets out from the Western foothills to find his prized sombrero, whooshed away in a high wind.

COLOR is the film for fall, and for the next two or three weeks, when the countryside is at its best in the annual display of brightly hued foliage, amateurs will use more of it than ever. For the ranks of fall color devotees grow each season as new photographers are attracted to the picture possibilities of nature's most brilliant show.

Puerto Rico is entering a period of greatly stepped-up industrial and economic development, with a minimum of 100 new plants expected to be established during 1953. This will be the highest number for any year since the island's economic development program -- tabbed "Operation Bootstrap" -- was started in 1947.

ONCE again Mitchell Wilson makes science and invention fiction readable and believable. He makes real people out of the miracle men who are pushing us into a push-button world. In so doing, he ignores several successful formulas for popular fiction.

AS a television viewer, I long maintained an open mind on the question of "live" versus film programs in relation to providing the viewer with maximum satisfaction. In listening to the radio, it never made any difference to me whether the show was "live" or recorded, so why should I react any differently to television programs?
ALBANY, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Upstate voters are registering early and in record-threatening numbers for the Nov. 4 Presidential election.

" THE Southern railways," Douglas Southall Freeman has observed, "meant more than mountain ranges and scarcely less than the great rivers in determining the lines of advance and defense" in the war of the Eighteen Sixties.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4 -- Soviet confidence in the system of life that Russia leads and, in particular, Moscow's confidence that this system is quite capable of an economic existence independent of the capitalist countries and of a political existence despite hostility and antagonism from the United States and America's supporters in the world arena, have been powerfully demonstrated this week.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The Russians announced tonight that they would send an all-star delegation, including Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky, and their Ambassador to Britain, Andrei A. Gromyko, to the United Nations General Assembly in New York this month.

THE construction of a space station, an artificial moon pursuing a carefully computed orbit around the earth, can no longer be regarded as a theme for science-fiction writers only. The station would be a practical launching site for interplanetary rockets and a base for the building of substations, such as a satellite observatory from which astronomers could obtain pictures of the universe unblurred by an intervening atmosphere.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4 -- Discarding all pretense of opposition to the Peronista Government, Communist student groups have come out openly in support of the regime and its policies in universities.

HONG KONG, Oct. 4 -- A report calling for the establishment of a permanent organization to promote "cultural exchanges" among "Asian-Pacific peoples" was submitted to the Peiping "peace conference" today by Saifuddin Kitchlew, head of the Indian delegation.

" THE Living Blackboard," educational TV project offered by WPIX in cooperation with the New York City Board of Education, will open its fall season tomorrow. The series will be telecast on Monday, Wednesday and Friday during the school year from 11:30 A. M. until 12 noon, and will be supplemented by radio instruction over WNYE and home visits by accredited instructors.
FRUIT trees and small fruits can be planted in the fall. Since there may be certain hazards in this practice, the decision should be based on the site and the soil.
The Brooklyn Eagle is announcing today its support of Gen. Dwight E. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President of the United States.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 4 (UP) -- An alert Purdue team with plenty of power and speed turned its breaks into touchdowns today to knock Ohio State out of the still-young Big Ten leadership, 21 -- 14, before 75,417 fans.

A preview of the new melodrama "Dial 'M' for Murder," starring, Maurice Evans, at the Plymouth Theatre on Oct. 27 has been taken over by the board of trustees of the Manhattan School of Music as benefit for that institution.

One of the most productive salesmen in the country does not act the part, and probably would have trouble passing one of "them thar new-fangled" aptitude tests that are so widely used on those wishing to enter the selling field.

TORONTO -- Canada's decision to build the St. Lawrence Seaway alone means there will soon be large changes in the landscape along the northern bank of the river between Cornwall and Iroquois, Ont. Within the next few years river communities will disappear under water and stretches of the highway and railroad along the banks will be moved.

IF the flower border seemed a little dull this year, some of the plants in it could be rearranged now to make it more colorful next season. The addition of tulips to dramatize the usual complement of spring bloom is also a good idea. So is the planting of a few lesser-known but worth-while perennials.
For the time being Japan is in excellent shape to resume service on its dollar and sterling bonds, as it proposes to do on Dec. 22.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Oregon State slowed vaunted Michigan State to a walk here today and the Spartans had to kick a last second field goal to pull out a 17-14 victory.

VICTORY of the Swedish team in the European Bridge League's championships, which ended last week, was a triumph for the principle of strength in numbers. Contract bridge is as well developed in Sweden as chess in the Soviet Union. The Swedish National Bridge Association has 50,000 members; the American Contract Bridge League, drawing on twenty-six times the population, has 40,000.

HAVANA, Oct. 4 -- The welterweight championship fight between Kid Gavilan and Billy Graham, scheduled for tonight, was postponed because of a tropical rainstorm. It will be held tomorrow night, weather permitting.

HAMBURG, Germany, Oct. 4 -- (Reuters) -- A sea-loving German shipowner and his tough crew of salt-water captains are watching their life's dream, a revival of the windjammer era, fail because of falling freight rates.

When listeners tuned in to radio stations of the Columbia Broadcasting System at 10:35 o'clock last night to hear a recording of a speech given by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson earlier at Fort Dodge, Iowa, they heard instead a rebroadcast of a speech he had given Sept. 27 in Louisville, Ky.

ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- Governor Dewey today named Douglas M. Moffat, a lawyer, of New York City, to head the temporary State Commission on the use of television for educational purposes. The Governor also appointed Young B. Smith, dean of Columbia Law School, vice chairman, and five other commission members.

The marked changes in the nation's economy in recent years have been responsible for much of the activity in the pension field so far in 1952, informed sources declare. Pension plans have been revised and new ones adopted on the basis of these changed conditions.

America's post-war policy in the Far East -- particularly Secretary Acheson's policy pronouncement of January, 1950, regarding our "defensive perimeter" -- has become a hot issue in the Presidential campaign. What follows is an attempt to set out chronologically the background of events, the indictment being made by Administration critics and the Administration's answer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Individuals in the United States saved $1,700,000,000 in liquid form in the second quarter of 1952, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

THE value of pygmy perennials should not be discounted because of their diminutive size, for they include some of the showiest plants in the garden. Many are delightful for their minute perfection, and all make significant contributions.
The first in the new series of the Five Enchanted Musical Evenings, under the auspices of the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service, will be a dinner on Oct. 31 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

HARTFORD, Oct. 4 -- The petitions of three Connecticut candidates for Congress and the State Legislature, including that of Mrs. Paul Robeson, wife of the singer, were rejected today by Mrs. Alice K. Leopold, Secretary of State. Their names will not be on the Nov. 4 election ballot.

SOMERSET, Pa., Oct. 4 (AP) -- A Greyhound Line bus bound from New York to Chicago rammed the rear of a large steel-laden truck on the Pennsylvania Turnpike near Somerset today, killing four passengers and injuring thirteen other persons.

OCCASIONALLY a first story is purely dazzling, better than anything the unhappy author may achieve later: but the average professional writer is apt to prefer that his published sins of twenty years ago should remain forgotten forever.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Additional winners were announced this afternoon on the second day of the annual flower show held by the ninth district of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State at the Westchester County Center. The show will be open to the public again tomorrow from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.

BALLET Theatre begins its final week at the Metropolitan on Tuesday, with an American Composers' Night on Thursday as its chief "specialty." There will also be "Giselles" by both Markova and Alonso, and on Saturday night Gemze de Lappe will do the central role in "Fall River Legend" for the first time.

BORDENTOWN, N. J., Oct. 4 -- The two oldest boys of the eleven-member Conger family, orphaned on Sept. 20 when their parents were killed in an auto accident, said today that $5,000 in cash and pledges and many offers of adoption had been received from well-wishers in forty-eight states and Canada.

F only for "Porgy and Bess," the second annual Berlin Cultural Festival would have been a success. However, there were many other excellent contributions by the United States and nine other participating nations, and the people of Berlin had good reason to be grateful.

ROUGH railed walls, an old sail fastened to some trees, logs for pews and a plank for a pulpit -- such was the first Anglican church in America, at Jamestown in 1607. The development from this beginning to the architectural splendors of King's Chapel, Boston, and St. Paul's, New York, forms the theme of this handsome book.

VIENNA, Oct. 4 -- Russia's recent refusal to continue negotiation of an Austrian state treaty, either on the original basis or the new one proposed not long ago by the West, ended a long chapter in Austria's history as a nation half alive, half free.

NINE years after the death in 1460 of Portugal's Prince Henry the Navigator, under whose egis many adventurers engaged in maritime exploration and geographic study, the Portuguese sovereign Alfonso V gave to a new group of intrepid seamen the royal rights to trade along Western Africa's new-found "Coast of the Negroes" south of Liberia.

Bankers now seem agreed that they have a responsibility to assert their "leadership" in the nation s economic affairs. This was made clear last week at the annual convention of the American Bankers Association in Atlantic City, N. J.
An institute for advanced study in business management and industrial organization is soon to be established in Italy, emphasizing American methods and with instruction by American educators.

LE GRAND has his own individual approach to American history as anyone knows who has read his "Cats for Kansas" and other adaptations from our folklore. In his newest tall tale he explains how Mike Fink helped open up the West by making it possible for pioneers to cross the Mississippi.

Beginning tomorrow housewives in New York and seven surrounding counties in this state and nine counties in New Jersey will find dollar-and-cents ceiling prices for 360 "market basket" food items posted in 28,000 grocery stores and supermarkets.

I saw the new M. G. M. version of "The Merry Widow" here in Philadelphia last week and was greatly surprised today to see that you gave it such a good review. The beautiful music that Franz Lehar wrote for it was shoved into the background by M. G. M. and substituted for it was a series of the mort ridiculous love scenes I've ever had the sad misfortune to watch.

WHILE legislators in Western Germany are busy "decartelizing" the film industry, the East German regime has organized a State Committee for the Film Industry whose duty it will be to supervise all film production and distribution, control all movie houses and propose film legislation for approval by the Communist - controlled Parliament.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Results of a survey of accounts receivable of members of the Chicago Association of Credit Men took a disappointing turn in August, the association reported. However, the last quarter of the year and the first of next year are expected to show better results.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- The United States National Commission of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today renewed its opposition to the admission of Spain to the organization.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 4 -- President Vargas, in his speech last night, appealed for national unity to save Brazil. He asked for the collaboration of all political parties as a means to attain that end.

I am gratified to learn from an article in a recent issue of THE TIMES that our representatives in Congress are doing some serious stewing about the effects of radio and television on the American public. And high time, too, that this important problem should receive such attention.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Hampton Stables' Alerted, with Peter Anderson in the saddle, won his fifth big race of the season today when he came from behind to out-game Combat Boots, Armageddon and General Staff in the $30,000 added Olympic Stakes, closing-day feature at the Atlantic City race track, before a crowd of 16,587 fans.

Eisenhower on the "murderers row" of Republican chairmen who would dominate the committees of the United States Senate if the Republicans won in November.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Senator Joseph McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, denied today published reports that he had persuaded Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to omit a defense of General of the Army George C. Marshall from General Eisenhower's speech here last night.

Three sales offering decorative accessories for the home and many items of collector interest will be held this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

SOMETHING is rotten in the state of Denmark. That observation, this time, is provoked by certain manifestations surrounding the appearance of Hemingway's "The Old Man and the Sea." As I remarked two weeks ago, this was one of the happy instances in which a great piece of writing received instant recognition.

DESPITE the fever - pitch excitement prevailing in Brooklyn these days over the Dodgers, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden is going full steam ahead on plans for the twenty-fifth anniversary celebration of the Cranford Rose Garden, Oct. 14. At that time rose lovers from six states are expected to converge on the garden, which will flaunt a beautiful burst of fall bloom for the occasion.

How much truth is there in the constantly reiterated European charge that we are a nation of materialists? Fenton B. Turck examines the charge in an article which he entitles the "American Explosion" and which appears in the Scientific Monthly. From his statistics emerges a picture of the extraordinary cultural change that has occurred in the last ten years.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Premier Stalin was expected generally to day to be elected president of the proposed Presidium of the Communist party, which will take the place of the Politburo. Other members of the Politburo seemed slated to become members of the Presidium.

THE well-known Toscanini attributes of leanness coupled to a consecutive musical thought are concretely demonstrated in the new Victor recording of Brahms' Fourth Symphony. No sentimentality, no lingering over phrases, no "expression"; instead, a forthright, strongly rhythmic, sinewy interpretation that, on the surface of things, should be possible of duplication by almost any qualified conductor.

SO complex are the mechanics of opera-house management that in order to play a single week in Detroit during its post-season tour, the New York City Opera Company was forced to rearrange its entire fall schedule at the City Center.

MUCH in this record of Count Folke Bernadotte's mission to Palestine is headline history: his negotiations for truce, cease-fire and peace in the 1948 Arab-Israel war. Dictated without literary artifice in airplanes and hotel rooms, the memoirs of the assassinated United Nations Mediator are chiefly notable for what they reveal of the robust Bernadotte mind, method and personality.

The new constitution of the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., will become effective on Oct. 15 after having been approved by a thirty-day referendum of its 22,000 members, with more than 95 per cent voting for adoption.
WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Oct. 4 (UP) -- An air-minded Boston College squad battled Wake Forest to a 7-7 tie tonight as the Deacons missed three scoring opportunities.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 4 -- High on Holmenkollen Hill overlooking Oslo and its beautiful fjords stands the headquarters of the Atlantic Pact's Commander in Chief North, visible symbol of Scandinavia's determination to resist aggression.

More and more the problems related to the United Nations action in Korea are being discussed as a part of the political campaign. Some of the statements have been confusing, just as some of the facts in the case have often seemed confusing. Korea is probably the biggest campaign issue in the minds of many persons and it is important, therefore, that we keep our thinking as straight as we can.

IN many of his books Rear Admiral Edward Ellsberg has given evidence that he is a good man to have around in an emergency. In "Passport for Jennifer" nobody is lying trapped in a submarine at the bottom of the sea, but Admiral Ellsberg's gallantry and resourcefulness are further revealed.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Hampton Stables' Alerted, with Peter Anderson in the saddle, won his fifth big race of the season today when he came from behind to out-game Combat Boots, Armageddon and General Staff in the $30,000 added Olympic Stakes, closing-day feature at the Atlantic City race track, before a crowd of 16,587 fans.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 4 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois wound up a flying visit to Iowa and Minnesota tonight by offering to "educate" Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on the "murderers row" of Republican chairmen who would dominate the committees of the United States Senate if the Republicans won in November.

ZURICH, Oct. 5 -- Since Sept. 19 the Swiss National Bank has been obliged to intervene frequently to keep the dollar-franc rate exchange in Zurich above the lower statutory gold point of 4.28. At the present official price of gold of $35 an ounce mean dollar parity in Switzerland is 4.3728 francs, the higher gold point being 4.46.

News of the death of Sir Keith Arthur Murdoch in Melbourne, Australia, yesterday brings sadness to his numerous friends here. He began his career as a newspaper reporter and ended it as Australia's leading newspaper publisher, but his outstanding quality was not ambition for personal success. It was friendliness.

Chancellor Henry T. Heald of New York University, remarking that New York City is faced with a "multitude of political, social and economic problems," extends a hand of cooperation to the community which serves and is served by the university. The university should not remain aloof from these problems, he says in his annual report.

If there are any super teams in college football this year no one would suspect it from the returns thus far. For three weeks now the Knock-the-Favorite-Down Club has been deflating the heavyweights of the gridiron something scandalous.

The Samaritan Home for the Aged, 440 East Eighty-eighth Street, will be the beneficiary of the performance of "An Evening With Beatrice Lillie," on Dec. 4 in the Booth Theatre. Proceeds will be used to purchase new equipment for the home.

Yesterday afternoon's "La Traviata" at the City Center disclosed a new leading tenor in Jon Crain, who sang the role of Alfredo. The other principals in the New York City Opera cast -- Ann Ayars, Richard Bonelli, Luigi Vellucci, Richard Wentworth -- had been seen previously in their parts. Julius Rudel conducted.

DEER PARK, Tex., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Stella Walsh, dean of America's track women, gave ten younger disciples a lesson in durability today in the first national women's pentathlon ever held south of the Mason-Dixon line.

The fourteenth annual Maria Moors Cabot Prizes for "the advancement of international friendship in the Americas" will be presented Thursday afternoon by Columbia University to four journalists from Latin America and one from the United States.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Third-seeded Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., was the only ranked player to experience any trouble as the favorites stroked their way through the second round in the Pan-American tennis tournament today.

BERLIN, Oct. 5 -- To celebrate the third anniversary of its founding, the East German Government announced today an amnesty or reduction of sentence for 2,612 former Nazis and welcomed as its guest Nikolai M. Shvernik, the president of the Soviet Union.

Documentary and contemporary prints, delicate gauzes, textures and damasks are among an extensive group of a hundred curtain and drapery fabrics presented by Greeff Fabrics for their fall collection. These are available through decorators from the showroom at 4 East Fifty-third Street.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Leon Jouhaux, Nobel Peace Prize winner last year and patriarch of the French labor movement, who returned recently from a visit to North America, said today that organized labor in the United States might soon be ready to form a political labor party.

Ten close contests for seats in the House of Representatives are in prospect in New York this year, in the opinion of both Democratic and Republican officials. Seven are in the metropolitan area and three upstate. They involve six districts now represented by Democrats and four represented by Republicans.

According to the prepared text of Governor Stevenson's Baltimore speech as published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 24 the Governor said: "In the last six years since the end of the Second World War financing the Government's net receipts have been $4,000,000,000 more than its expenditures.
