WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, declared tonight that the Federal Communications Commission was "duty bound by law to look into the Republicans' secret 'blitz' radio and television program."

The Bowater Corporation of North America, Ltd., a recently formed subsidiary of the Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd., of London, has just acquired from the parent company all the common stock of the Bowater's Newfoundland Pulp and Paper Mills, Ltd.; the Bowater Paper Company, Inc., of New York, and the Bowater Southern Paper Corporation, the $65,000,000 enterprise now building newsprint and pulp mills in East Tennessee.

With Cardinal Spellman presiding, Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, offered pontifical mass there yesterday to mark the forty-second anniversary of the consecration of the church. There was a congregation of 3,500 and the ceremony was televised by WPIX.

The formula for making the ink previously used exclusively by the Paper Mate Company in its ball point pen, has been purchased by Scripto, Inc., the world's largest maker of mechanical pencils of Atlanta, Ga., it was reported over the week-end by James V. Carmichael, president of Scripto.

Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Democratic Finance Committee, broadcast instructions last night to volunteer workers throughout the country who will begin on Wednesday an eight-day, door-to-door drive for $5 contributions to the Democratic campaign fund.

While Alexander Kotov of Russia, leading with a score of 10 -- 1, adjourned his thirteenth-round game yesterday at Saltsjobaden in Sweden, E. Geller of Moscow made a major gain by winning from Gideon Stahlberg of Sweden in the world chess championship zonal tournament, according to a report from Stockholm.

For anyone who has been following Argentine developments it is no shock that the Communist student groups are openly coming out in favor of the Peron regime against the independent striking college students.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The stock markets and financial world generally last week was treated to a succession of events giving much food for thought if not always for prompt or vigorous action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The International Cotton Advisory Committee said today that 1952-53 cotton production probably will exceed consumption if consumption "again reaches or even exceeds last season's 25,000,000 bales."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- The draft rejection rate has increased to almost 42 per cent during the Korean war -- 6 per cent above World War II levels -- although physical standards are about the same.
THE NEW YORK TIMES having such a wide coverage, we feel that you could help us a great deal in trying to collect data for the Jacksonville Historical Society.

Mayor Impellitteri's call on the New York public to observe Fire Prevention Week from Oct. 5 to 11 serves to call attention again to the vast destruction in lives and property caused each year by preventable fires. Last year New York's fire apparatus responded to 62,728 alarms and put out 44,040 fires.

SECAUCUS, N. J., Oct. 5 -- Braving rough water, which meant spills and accidents, and with a racing program so long it carried the late heats into the poor visibility of twilight, the New Jersey Outboard Association held its season's-end regatta today on the Hackensack River at Snipes Beach.
On Sept. 23 you printed a letter from Pierce T. Wetter of New York in a column "Nixon Fund Discussed."

Eleven luxury liners will take temporary leave of their normal Atlantic routes to enter the special cruise field from New York this winter. They will offer thirty-one cruises to scores of ports in the Caribbean, South America and the Mediterranean.

One of the more popular pastimes among the economists at the moment would be considered by some to be a little on the ghoulish side. It consists in burying and jumping on the grave of a corpse that most of us had thought was dead and buried these many months, if not years. This is the corpse of the so-called "25 per cent" tax formula, authored by the Australian economist, Colin Clark.

HAVANA, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Cuban Kid Gavilan, flashing a speedy attack, successfully defended his welterweight championship tonight with a one-sided fifteen-round decision over Billy Graham of New York. Each fighter weighed 146 1/2 pounds.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 5 -- A vast new ocean canyon, linked to a system of undersea channels comparable in extent to the Mississippi River and its tributaries, has been discovered in the Western Atlantic by a scientific expedition that returned here today aboard the sea-going tug Kevin Moran.

The formation of a 120-member memorial committee to advance the principles of former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson, who was killed in a plane crash Jan. 22, was announced yesterday by the board of trustees of Freedom House.

AVON, Conn., Oct. 5 -- The annual fixture of the Bushey Hill Spaniel Field Trial Club ended today on the Old Farms school grounds, with Berol Lodge Kennels' Berol Lodge Black Velvet, handled by Luke Medlin, winning the open-all-age cocker stake.

SCHENECTADY, Oct. 5 -- Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, tonight accused Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower of resorting to a "campaign of smear and falsehood" either through "ignorance or a desire to be President, regardless."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 5 -- John Blandford, director of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees, will inform the United Nations General Assembly opening Oct. 14 in New York that his organization can solve the refugee problem only by heavy United Nations investment in large-scale development projects.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Poetry, A Magazine of Verse, will observe its fortieth birthday tomorrow with the publication of its largest single issue, containing the latest poems of foremost living poets, Karl Shapiro, the editor, announced today.
Senator Richard M. Nixon called yesterday for repudiation of those parts of the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin Yalta Agreement "which abet the Communist slavery of free nations."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- After racing nine miles around a triangle in Long Island Sound today after a real southerly breeze, four Atlantic Class sloops were clocked nine seconds apart. The yachts sailed in another of the post-season regattas at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

City Council President Rudolph Halley, criticizing the Democratic party for having nominated "a machine-picked candidate" for the Senate, announced yesterday his endorsement of Dr. George S. Counts, the candidate of the Liberal party.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5 -- At the rate steel was being turned out last week the steel industry this month will chalk up one of the greatest monthly tonnage records in its history. The month of October is usually a peak month and compares quite favorably with a similar tonnage pattern in the month of March.

The six-story loft building at 657-59 Broadway, between Third and Bleecker Streets, occupied for the last twenty-five years by the Adam Hat Company, is under contract of sale to Alexander Hirsch. The property, held at $225,000, is being sold by the Adam 659 Corporation, a subsidiary of Adam Hat Stores, Inc. Tankoos Co., brokers, are negotiating the deal.
Commissioner Ford C. Frick urged a be-kind-to-umpires attitude on team leaders at their traditional meeting before this world series started.

Reaction of the man in the street and the woman in the home and the office appears to be somewhat unfavorable to President Truman's attacks on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, according to reports received by THE TIMES from correspondents in the forty-eight states.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 5 -- The prison riots in the nation this last year reflect the neglect of the public to give enough financial support to the penal system, as well as public failure to back more constructive programs of rehabilitation, it was agreed today by a group of wardens at whose prisons riots have occurred.

The current "peace" conference in Peiping is an obvious and outrageous fraud, of course. High on the agenda is the item of "promoting better understanding" between peoples, while the whole purpose of the meeting is to foster as much misunderstanding between East and West as is possible.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 5 -- Dr. Nelson Glueck, whose archaeological survey of Jordan between 1932 and 1947 put 1,000 ancient sites on the map, will begin a similar exploration of western Palestine, he told a conference of Israeli scholars and archeologists today.
A pay-adjustment plan affecting teachers taking days off to observe religious holidays was announced yesterday by the Board of Education.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Oct. 5 -- The dry season has arrived in Tongking, main theatre of the Indo-China war, and French headquarters here expects an early renewal of major hostilities. French, Vietnamese and Vietminh forces are preparing for heavy winter battles.

HONG KONG, Oct. 5 -- The running propaganda assault of the "Asian-Pacific Peace Conference" in Peiping took the form yesterday of platform attacks on the alleged United States policy of economic "blockade and embargo."

DUKE SNIDER lunged viciously at a ball in batting practice before yesterday's game and Master Mickey Mantle, showing a surprising perceptiveness for one so young, nodded his head as though he was agreeing with himself.
TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 6 -- Communist and United Nations troops fought stubborn local battles on the western and east-central fronts in Korea yesterday.
I always had pretty good luck batting against Johnny Sain but this time I hit the jackpot.

The 1953 spring line of Arrow shirts will be offered to the trade today, it was announced by Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., the first major manufacturer to present its new line. Prices are generally unchanged. The line stresses sports shirts, all of which will have matching pockets and a predetermined fold line in the collars.
A church must reach out into the community and express itself in life, as well as in creed and liturgy, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken declared yesterday in a sermon at Riverside Church.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5 -- Look for Joan Crawford and Joseph Kaufman, the independent producer, who have a box-office hit in "Sudden Fear," to continue their association. The star is much interested in making the film version of "Promised Land," the Joan Lowell book.

" R. Hoe Co., New York, manufacturer of printing equipment, supplies the recoil mechanism," reported Elie Abel of this newspaper in his account of the gun which fires an atomic projectile. The well-known firm of printing-press builders is not the only one that played its part in producing the weapon.

Modern science, viewing "life shattered like a broken glass," needs to return to the teachings of Christ to find more than mere "sludge and mud" in its interpretation of man, Godfrey Schmidt, Professor of Law at Fordham University, said yesterday.
His intimate friends in and out of business call him Tony, but less informally he is known as Anthony Blotta, one of the true artists in the ready-to-wear couture. His tailoring is of the best.

Rabbi J. Howard Ralbag of Congregation Ohav Sholom Orthodox), 270 West Eighty-fourth Street, in a Succoth sermon yesterday morning, called for "an early harmonious, basic understanding" among men in the fields of religion and politics.

Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway declared last night that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's "military strength in being remains dangerously inadequate," and held that to operate on the idea that a potential aggressor might not want war was "unjustified and dangerous."

ABOARD THE EISENHOWER TRAIN, Oct. 5 (AP) -- One of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's closest advisers denied today that the Republican Presidential candidate altered his Milwaukee speech Friday night at the request of Senator Joseph McCarthy of Wisconsin.
The new lightship Ambrose (WAL-613), which will take up her station today at the approach to New York Harbor, stands in sharp contrast to her frail forebears of a century ago.

The bitter attacks against the United States voiced by the Politburo members, Vyacheslav M. Molotov and Georgi M. Malenkov, in Moscow yesterday dashed the reassurance seemingly given last week by Premier Stalin's major statement on domestic and foreign affairs.

The critical shortage of nurses in this country will not be solved without drastic changes in nurses' education, discriminatory employment practices and low salary scales, four leading nursing organizations declared yesterday.

DETROIT, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Maurice Richard of Montreal and Marty Pavelich of Detroit scored goals tonight as hockey's finest, the first and second All-Star teams of the National Hockey League, battled to a 1-1 tie before 10,680 fans at Olympia.

When a presentation of the one-act version of "Swan Lake" can sell out the Metropolitan Opera House to the last inch of standing room at a Sunday matinee, that is news. Exactly that happened yesterday when Alicia Markova appeared for the second time in the role as guest artist with Ballet Theatre.

WINOOSKI PARK, Vt., Oct. 5 (UP) -- Halfback Ralph Consiglio of Suffern, N. Y., scored two second-half touchdowns today to bring Arnold College from behind for a 13-to-9 victory over St. Michael's College before about 2,000 rain-drenched fans at St. Michael's Field.
DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 5 -- Dogs belonging to Margrit V. Fischer of Newtown, Pa., were the main winners tonight in the thirty-ninth annual specialty of the German Shepherd Dog Club of America.

CAIRO, Oct. 5 -- Adly Seleh Lamloum, 23-year-old scion of a wealthy land-owning family, who as a protest against the Government's land reform program led an armed foray against the police station at Maghagha in Upper Egypt Sept. 12, was sentenced to life imprisonment at hard labor by a special military tribunal at Meineh today.

FORT MONTGOMERY, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Several thousand persons attended ceremonies here this afternoon commemorating the 175th anniversary of the fall of Fort Montgomery and Fort Clinton on Oct. 6, 1777. It was then that an American defeat delayed the British in an attempt to join General Burgoyne's forces, which were defeated a few days later in a decisive battle of the Revolutionary War.

The view that consumer credit has been over-extended and constitutes a threat to the welfare of consumers and retailers was challenged over the-week-end by the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The organization declared "no economic yardstick has been developed which establishes the limits of such credit extension."

With six weeks to go in New York's horse-racing season, the Metropolitan Jockey Club opens a twelve-day meeting at the Jamaica track today. For the last twenty-four days of the campaign, which ends on Nov. 15, the Empire City Racing Association will stage the shows at the Jamaica oval.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- The Supreme Court starts its new term tomorrow with a history-making decision pending on racial segregation in southern public schools.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Heart disease, various types of paralysis, arthritis and congenital defects account for about 58 per cent of the 150,000 cases in the Federally aided programs for the permanently disabled. Heart ailments alone account for 25 per cent.

Five six-story apartment buildings at the southwest corner of Joralemon Street and Columbia Place, in the Columbia Heights section of Brooklyn, have been sold by Nathan Wilson, operator, after an ownership of four years, to an investing client of Di Lorenzo $ Di Lorenzo, attorneys, for cash over a first mortgage of $177,750. They were modernized in 1939 at a cost of $400,000.

ABOARD THE TRUMAN TRAIN, Oct. 5 -- President Truman turned his railroad battlewagon eastward from San Francisco today to continue his attacks on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and the Republican party clear across the middle tier of states for a climax in New York next week-end.

Cotton prices in the domestic market backed and filled within a relatively narrow trading range last week and closed the week with small, irregular net changes. At the close of trading on Friday on the New York Cotton Exchange prices were 11 points higher to 10 points lower from the close of the previous week.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Fred Annon and Daniel Cohen, who played the last three holes in darkness as 140 teams competed, took top honors today in the Ryewood Country Club's first pro-member tournament with best-ball card of 31, 32 -- 63.

This is the first day of registration in New York City and Westchester County. Every evening, today through Friday, the polls will be open from 5 to 10:30 o'clock. Next Saturday the hours will be 7 A. M. to 10:30 P. M.

It would be pleasant to record that "The Sterling Area" by A. R. Conan* was the complete as well as the last word on the economic affairs of that troubled part of the world and that it belonged in the library of every economist. The latter part of that statement is probably true, for the tables it contains are valuable.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Senate Republican "truth" spokesmen assailed President Truman today for what they termed an effort "to load some of his tragic errors" in Berlin, Korea and China on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 5 -- If Al Parsells, eight-goal star, doesn't get an increase in rating from the United States Polo Association, it will not be the fault of the Tallmans (N. Y.) rider. Playing one of his finest games, Parsells hit four goals to lead Brookville to an 11-6 triumph over Pete Bostwick's quartet today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Expression of concern for the day when present controls over the economy may lapse dominated the quarterly report submitted to President Truman yesterday by Henry H. Fowler, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization.

Loans of the Chase National Bank outstanding on Sept. 30 totaled $2,200,120,840, a new high, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition published today. The figure compares with $2,196,947,098 on June 30 and $1,953,537,210 a year ago.
British sterling developed a firm undertone last week, moving from a low of $2.78 3/8 on Wednesday to close on Friday at $2.78 3/4, a gain of 1/4 cent over the preceding week.

Prior to the debut of championship soccer at the Yankee Stadium next Sunday, four of the metropolitan clubs appeared in a double-header at Sterling Oval in the Bronx yesterday. In the first game Hakoah defeated the Brooklyn Hispanos, 3 to 1, and then Brookhattan-Galicia routed the New York Americans, 4 to 0.

Joseph C. Grew, American Ambassador to Japan at the time of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, has written an account of his diplomatic career that Houghton Mifflin will publish on Nov. 17. "Turbulent Era" covers forty years in which Mr. Grew held posts at Cairo, Mexico City, St. Petersburg, Berlin, Vienna, Paris and Ankara.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 5 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's campaign headquarters said today a former Republican Mayor of Senator Richard M. Nixon's home town of Whittier, Calif., plus a man who helped with Mr. Nixon's 1950 Senatorial campaign, have enlisted in the Stevenson cause.
ABOARD EISENHOWER SPECIAL in Montana, Oct. 5 -- The tension on this political campaign train, as it rolled through the majestic Rocky Mountains, was almost unbearable today.

The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. announced yesterday the appointment of the Rev. Dr. J. Edward Dirks as associate general director of its Commission on Christian Higher Education.

Twenty-three full professors at Columbia University issued yesterday an analysis of the funds of Senator Richard M. Nixon and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, which purported to show that there were clear differences in the moral implication of the two funds.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Jimmy (Bud) Taylor, a promising 21-year-old Negro welterweight from Miami, Fla., died in Charity Hospital today from injuries suffered when he was knocked out in a boxing event here Friday night.

For the first time since this forty-ninth world series began, the Dodgers really let go their pent-up emotions when they reached the Yankee Stadium clubhouse after Carl Erskine's magnificent pitching yesterday. Erskine's hurling, plus Duke Snider's seventh-inning scoring single and his winning double in the eleventh, put the Dodgers one game away from winning the series.
A panel of six school children appearing on the New York Times Youth Forum over the Du Mont television channel agreed last evening that as much learning was carried on outside of schools as inside.

Olinville Gardens, Inc., bought from the Schulte Real Estate Company a vacant lot of land measuring 100 by 250 feet at the southeast corner of Olinville Avenue and Britton Street, the Bronx, for improvement with apartments. Harold L. Rockmore was the broker.

HANOI, Indo-China, Oct. 5 (AP) -- French Union troops moved outside their key defense bastion in the Red River delta today and struck into Communist-led Vietminh territory for the first time in nearly a year. They failed to encounter any important enemy resistance.

Mrs. Hans Riesser, whose husband has just been made observer to the United Nations from the Federal Republic of Germany, looked like a Westchester hostess as she presided at the tea table on a recent afternoon in her apartment in the East Sixties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson has sent Premier Mohammed Mossadegh of Iran a note saying the United States is sorry, but the Premier must have "misunderstood" the recent joint proposal of this country and Britain to settle the Iranian oil dispute.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today the road to socialization of industry can be reversed.
TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 6 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,394, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:
Brooklyn's first world series championship may be lurking just around the next corner.

It's football that gets the most attention in the fall, but in recent years a movement has been under way to put more emphasis on soccer. The result is that today, at most schools, soccer occupies an important place on athletic programs. In fact, at several schools soccer is challenging football for student interest.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Lard prices were forced down to a succession of new lows for the season last week, but late in the period there was better demand with a modest rally from the low points of the week. Deliveries on October contracts were large, houses that took delivery on September contracts apparently passing the burden along.

The Associated Merchandising Corporation, representing twenty-three large stores over the country, has announced that its directors have voted to make available its A. M. C. expense-accounting manual to the National Retail Dry Goods Association and the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Grain futures displayed a stronger price trend the latter part of the week, following several days of long liquidation which carried the markets to lower levels. Strength developed in wheat, which influenced the coarse grains, and there was late week firmness in soybean futures, which also checked selling of the grains.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 5 -- The forthcoming Benelux ministers conference at Knocke, Belgium, will, according to well-informed quarters here, be friendly despite the fact delegates will be faced with almost insurmountable difficulties.

BRIGHTWATERS, L. I., Oct. 5 -- The last of the bells from sixty-three steam locomotives scrapped by the Long Island Rail Road when it replaced them with Diesel engines, was installed here today in the steeple of the nearly completed edifice of the Church of the Nazarene.

ABOARD THE EISENHOWER TRAIN, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, announced tonight that he had demanded that Secretary of State Dean Acheson send the Soviet Ambassador to the United States home.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman went to the unusual length of issuing a public denial today "in the name of the French Government" of allegations that France had engaged in secret negotiations with the Russians to block German rearmament.
The annual Staten Island two-day horse show held on the grounds of the Clove Lakes Stables, Sunny-side, ended last night as title contests were decided. The fixture drew a total of 200 entries.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Joseph R. McCarthy said today he believed he could end his "one-man" crusade against Communists in government if Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was elected President.

Lloyd Wiseman, 46 years old, vice president of the Crocker First National Bank of San Francisco, and a woman found with him in his room on the twenty-ninth floor of the Warwick Hotel, 65 West Fifty-fourth Street, were burned fatally yesterday.

Both lean men and men whose ages and waistlines are beginning to have in common a good, round number -- perhaps in the forties -- may be expected to receive with pleasure advice from abroad that the vest is coming back.
Four new films, including an importation from Italy, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 5 -- The Daily Princetonian, student newspaper at Princeton University, will endorse Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican candidate for President in a front-page editorial tomorrow morning.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Vito Parilli, the former Kentucky star, earned his professional spurs with a sparkling performance today, leading the Green Bay Packers to a 35-20 victory over the Washington Redskins in a National Football League game.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told a rally in Harlem yesterday that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson was well equipped for the Presidency as result of his experience in foreign and domestic affairs. Mrs. Roosevelt also voiced "sadness" and disillusionment over the campaign conducted by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican candidate.

A bright new hit has come to television: "The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet" at 8 o'clock on Friday evenings over the American Broadcasting Company network. The pleasures and trials that go with raising a couple of boys are related on the program with an unusually warm and understanding relish.

There are major issues and there are minor issues in every campaign. The former are those that involve the welfare of the entire country, and the latter are those that deal with groups of Americans or sections of America. The truly patriotic voter considers first the major issues, and only in the event that there are none to contend with does he base his decision on the minor issues.

William Wyer, trustee of the Long Island Rail Road, issued yesterday a denial of charges by the Long Island Transit Authority that he had recommended a delay in hearings by the Interstate Commerce Commission on the proposed reorganization of the railroad. Hearings can begin at any time if the commission does not require results of current studies, he said.

Once again the calendar brings us around to the annual Latin-American awards of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation. There are twenty-eight fellowships this year totaling more than $100,000 -- a tidy sum, but the good which will come of it will far outweigh the money.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 5 -- Governor Stevenson has strengthened his staff for the closing months of the Presidential campaign.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, founded in 1827 on Canal Street, celebrated its 125th anniversary yesterday morning with a communion service in the present building at Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street.
Television viewers here missed two programs on the National Broadcasting Company network last night as the result of walkouts by the company's engineers in Washington, D. C., and Hollywood, Calif.

Opening on Wednesday, the Museum of Modern Art's exhibition of paintings and drawings by the Fauves, the avant garde of French painting in the early twentieth cenutry, is the major event of the week. Later paintings by one of the group's leading members,
TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Many debutantes from the metropolitan area will be present at the sixty-fourth annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball to be held on Oct. 25 at the Tuxedo Club.
Governor Dewey predicted yesterday that within a year after the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to the Presidency nine-tenths of the Korean battlefront would be manned by Koreans.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The rumpus arising from the Berlin airport interview of George F. Kennan, United States Ambassador in Moscow, which resulted in the demand for his recall by the Soviet Union, must surely represent a sad disillusionment to America's foremost expert on things Russian.
Following are typical comments of persons interviewed by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES on President Truman's first week of whistle-stop speeches:

Harold E. Stassen told a television audience last night that, although he was "not happy" about Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, he would rather see Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower spend a few minutes on a train with Senator McCarthy "than ten years in bed with Alger Hiss."

DALLAS, Oct. 5 (UP) -- The San Francisco Forty-Niners displayed both an opening and closing scoring sprint today as they defeated the punchless Dallas Texans, 37 to 14, for their second straight National Football League victory.

Protection from traffic hazards for persons seated along the malls on Broadway between Sixtieth Street and 168th Street was promised by James A. Sherry, executive officer of the Department of Parks, in a letter released last night by the recipient, a young man who had conducted a month's campaign to remedy the condition.

Commissioner Ford Frick, once a baseball writer himself, forgot to bring his ticket to the stadium yesterday but figured he would not be denied admittance as he strode to the gate and explained what had happened.

With the passing of title to the land to Briar Oaks, Inc., work is ready to start on a $12,500,000 apartment house development on a tract of eighteen and one-half acres in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. The property occupies the west side of the Henry Hudson Parkway from West 242d to 246th Streets, including the former Arrowhead Inn.

A project for developing a pattern to enable United States industry to play a decisive part in aiding economic progress of less-developed countries, with consequent benefits to the entire free world, was announced over the week-end by the National Planning Association.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- In the preparation of fabrics for the coronation year, a race has developed between synthetic and natural fibers to produce interesting materials. Heading the synthetics is terylene, the test tube yarn that promises to rival nylon in popularity.

For the first time, civilians will have a chance to see what G. I.'s at the front look forward to most -- a U. S. O.-Camp Show. In a simulated Korean battlefront setting, the New York United Service Organizations Defense Fund will present a thirty-minute U. S. O.-Camp Show performance Thursday on the steps of the Sub-Treasury building at Nassau and Wall Streets. The curtain goes up at noon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The record of the Department of Justice in handling war-contract settlement cases referred to it by the General Accounting Office was described as "shameful" in a report issued today. A House Judiciary subcommittee which was appointed to investigate the Department prepared the document.

Paul R. Hays, who is to act as arbitrator in the current dispute between the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and the New York Shipping Association, announced yesterday that the proceedings, scheduled to begin Oct. 14, would be open to the public.

Americans of Polish background marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday in the sixteenth annual parade in honor of Brig. Gen. Casimir Pulaski, hero of the American Revolution, and to proclaim their hope that Poland may one day be free from the domination of the Soviet Union.

ABOARD THE EISENHOWER TRAIN, Oct. 5 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower rolled across Montana today promising to rout out "the pinks" as well as "the Communists" from government, and deploring the "errors" that caused the United States to fall "into two world wars in the last seven years."

High interest aroused by the Presidential race, together with intensive campaigning by political, civic, labor and business organizations to get out the largest possible vote this year, is expected by election officials to result in a record registration here and upstate this week.
HONG KONG, Oct. 5 -- Communist China has concluded a ten-year economic and cultural agreement with Outer Mongolia, the Peiping radio announced today.

MOSCOW, Monday, Oct. 6 -- Georgi M. Malenkov, Premier Stalin's comrade-at-arms, told the nineteenth congress of the Soviet Communist party, in its opening session in the Great Hall of the Kremlin last night that the United States had assumed Hitler's mantle, had launched a drive for world domination and planned to achieve this end by means of a third world war.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- In its reply today to the Iranian Premier's counter-proposals for a settlement of the oil dispute, the British Government utterly ignored the conditions laid down by Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 5 -- Amid a welter of rumors of art impending Cabinet crisis, the Indonesian armed forces put on their greatest display of military power today in a huge parade to honor the seventh anniversary of the founding of the Indonesian National Army.
A new collection of upholstered pieces, most of which have foam rubber construction, is available through decorators at the Mansfield Furniture Company, 203 East Eighteenth Street.

Reginald Denham, the playwright and director, whose schedule for the next year already is crowded with assignments, may be assigned to stage "The Man Upstairs," the Patrick Hamilton thriller due in New York late this season under the sponsorship of Alexander H. Cohen and Rita Allen.

" NO one who conceives him as only a potential servant to man can apprehend the mustang. The true conceiver must be a true lover of freedom -- a person who yearns to extend freedom to all life. Halted in animated expectancy or running in abandoned freedom, the mustang was the most beautiful, the most spirited and the most inspiriting creature ever to print
ANDERSON, Ind., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Home-town friends began making plans today for a city-wide celebration Oct. 21 for Carl Erskine, the Dodger pitcher who won the fifth game of the world series.

WEST NYACK, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- A robust moon, just a shade past fullness, and the promise of a calm, windless night inspired nine bird lovers to undertake a ten-hour vigil last night in the Rockland County Audubon Society's first fall count-study of the nocturnal migration of birds.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Six Swiss mountaineers braved the chill, bleak sides of Mount Everest today for a direct assault on the unconquered peak of the world's highest mountain. No man has ever reached the summit, five and a half miles up, and returned to tell about it.

The Ford Foundation Board on Overseas Training and Research announced yesterday that it had awarded foreign study fellowships to eighty-three American college graduates for work on the problems of Asia and the Middle East.

Department of Agriculture estimates of the 1952-53 world cocoa crop are now for "a slightly higher level than the 1951-52 estimate." This is a reversal of the report made in mid-September, which expected an 8 to 10 per cent reduction in the crop.

Present and former members of the Police Department are scheduled to appear today before the Richmond County special grand jury, which has been investigating gambling and official corruption on Staten Island. It is the first session of the jurors since they took a three-and-a-half-month summer recess last June.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Hugh Gaitskell, a supporter of the present moderate leadership of the British Labor party, declared today that it was time to end the attempt at "mob rule" by Aneurin Bevan and his leftist cohorts and "to restore the authority and leadership of the solid, sound, sensible majority of the movement."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Maurice Pate, executive director of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, warned today that lagging financial help from governments threatened to delay the shipment of relief supplies to needy children overseas.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Business that is served by perpendicular transit returned to normal in downtown Chicago today as 1,500 elevator operators ended a five-day strike. The tie-up had halted or drastically curtailed elevator service in more than 100 buildings.

Add to the list of films arriving this week, "Gods of Bali," a feature-length documentary of the dances and festivals of Bali, which will open at the Guild Theatre on Saturday Nikola Draculic produced and directed for Nederland Film.

Replies and counter-replies are shuttling back and forth between Teheran, London and Washington without the Anglo-Iranian oil dispute getting any closer to settlement. Both Britain and the United States have now answered Premier Mossadegh's note of Aug. 30 with the somewhat bland, but not unjustified, assertion that he must have misunderstood their previous note.

NEWARK, Oct. 6 -- Six Essex County marines today cast their votes for President of the United States at the Essex County Clerk's office, where they marked absentee ballots, which normally are mailed thirty days before an election.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 6 -- There are some jails in this country "so filled with corruption" that even if a person were not a criminal when he was put in, the chances are he would be one when he came out, E. W. Biscailuz, Sheriff of Los Angeles County, California, declared today.

NEWARK, Oct 6 -- The Appellate Division of the New Jersey superior Court was asked today by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company to reverse the State Public Utility Commission's denial of the company's twenty-nine-month-old request for a $9,800,000 rate increase.

Domestic steel making furnaces poured more steel last week than ever before in a similar period. It was the second successive week that the mills established a production record. Operating at 105.7 per cent of theoretical capacity, or 2 points better than they had expected, the mills turned out 2,195,000 net tons of raw steel during the seven day period ending on Oct. 4, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

The importance of site selection was stressed by Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, at the opening session yesterday of the lecture course sponsored by the Real Estate Board of New York. The sessions of the course on "Planning for Profit" will be held on alternate Monday afternoons at the Biltmore Hotel.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The latest exchange between France and Germany on the future of the autonomous Saar territory, claimed politically by Germany and linked economically with France, has failed to produce an agreement but at least has kept open the negotiations, and the possibility of settlement.
DETROIT, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Nash Motors disclosed today it plans to put its foreign-built "NXI" (Nash Experimental International) model car into production late next year.

Spurred by retail sales which show a marked improvement over a year ago, production of women's coats and suits for fall is running well ahead of the average for the last three years, according to Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, Inc.

Harold Riegelman, until recently a vice president of Montgomery Ward Co. and merchandising manager for its soft lines department, has been appointed manager of marketing for the receiver department of the General Electric Company.

Football takes over the center of the stage this week as baseball makes its exit, just in time for the game the East has been waiting for. Princeton and Pennsylvania have a date in Palmer Stadium Saturday and most people have figured it out that this is it, so far as the race for the Ivy is concerned.

Duke Snider, Dodger center fielder, tied a record held by Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig when he came up with two successive home runs in the Dodgers' losing game at Ebbets Field yesterday to bring his total to four for the series.

I would like to add a long-festering observation to those expressed in the letter signed "Citizen," relative to the apathy of the public on blood donations. I write feelingly, as the veteran of two wars.

Former Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander and August W. Flath, former Chief Inspector, were witnesses yesterday as a Staten Island special grand jury resumed its investigation into gambling and official corruption on the island. The session was held at the Richmond County Courthouse, St. George, S. I.

An invitation to the Italian film producers, directors and actors now visiting in New York for Salute to Italian Films Week to return here to make motion pictures was extended last night by Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri. The Mayor's suggestion was made at ceremonies inaugurating the first preview presentation of one of the seven Italian films that will be shown nightly through the remainder of this week at the Little Carnegie Theatre.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis, the Tri-County champion, closed out the Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's season by winning the low gross honors with a 1 over par 39, 35 -- 74 over the Westchester Country Club's South Course today.

A biography of Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential candidate, is being rushed by the John C. Winston Company of Philadelphia for publication Friday. "This Man Nixon," by Phillip Andrews, presents the "inside" story of the Senator's life and includes his speech in defense of his use of private funds.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 -- Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, disclaiming any personal political ambitions, predicted today a Democratic party victory in November because of the number of voters who have become disgusted with the Republican campaign and the way in which Senator Taft had "taken over."

The Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation, organized four years ago to fight the affliction that affects 7,500,000 persons throughout the nation, set a fund-raising goal of $5,000,000 at its annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.

PASSAIC, N. J., Oct. 6 -- An inter-racial group of youngsters between the ages of 2 1/2 and 5, representing several nationalities, played today in the new headquarters of the Guidance Guild Nursery School here at 526 Paulison Street. Their mothers were working at various jobs.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Grain futures showed considerable strength in the early part of the Board of Trade session today, but the buying demand waned later. Increased offerings of corn in the pit tended to unsettle all grains. Widespread frosts were reported through most of the Corn Belt, but this was regarded as a favorable development in the case of corn, and other crops are well out of the way of any frost damage.

A three-alarm fire in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn at 11 A. M. yesterday destroyed the Beth Israel Synagogue at 349 Christopher Avenue and the upper floors of two adjoining tenements. No one was injured in the blaze, which raged out of control for ninety minutes, but nine families were made homeless.

City officials joined leaders of the United Hospital Fund yesterday at a noontime gathering of 1,500 persons on the steps of the Subtreasury Building at Broad and Wall Streets to mark the opening of the fund's 1952 drive for $3,326,000.

With a unique record, including nine drawn games in twelve rounds, Y. Auerbach, one of the five Russians competing in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, yesterday gained his second victory when he won his adjourned match with Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, according to a report from Stockholm.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 -- radio actor tossed two military medals at an un-American Activities subcommittee of the House of Representatives today and told Representative Clyde Doyle, its chairman, to "give them back to President Truman."

BOSTON, Oct. 6 -- Reporters and photographers from a score of newspapers were among the prize winners announced today in the annual photography and news writing contest sponsored by the New England Associated Press News Executive Association.

Soviet industrial production in 1952 will be only about 40 per cent of that of the United States in 1951, analysis of the production data announced by Georgi M. Malenkov, Politburo member, indicates. The Soviet Union has a population of about 210,000,000 compared with 155,000,000 in this country.

A funeral service was held yesterday for Andres Requena, co-publisher of a pamphlet opposed to the present Trujillo Government in the Dominican Republic, who was killed Thursday night in the hallway at 243 Madison Street.

An extensive exhibition of crystal from the Leerdam glassworks of Holland opens today at Black, Starr Gorham. The display, which includes such examples as decorative one-of-a-kind vases and art objects, fine tableware and architectural glass panels, will continue through Oct. 18.

John L. Lewis' recent settlement with the bituminous coal operators added 10 cents a ton to the 30 cents already being paid by the industry into the United Mine Workers of America Welfare and Retirement Fund. This means that for pensions and other purposes this fund will probably have approximately $160,000,000 within the next year, as compared with $126,000,000 last year.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 6 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon barnstormed through industrial Southern New England today, hammering away at President Truman for "playing cheap, dirty politics" at a critical moment in the nation's relations with Russia.

The dollar value of television to the electric power and light industry as a sales medium and power-load builder is steadily on the increase. This was emphasized yesterday by Dr. Charles B. Jolliffe, vice president and technical director of the Radio Corporation of America, in an address before a conference of more than 100 utility executives at the Roosevelt Hotel.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 6 -- The Harvard Graduate School of Education has attracted eight Eastern colleges to join the twenty-one now cooperating to develop more qualified public school teachers, it was announced today.

John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy adviser, said last night that "the question of [diplomatic] retaliation in kind ought to be seriously considered" as an answer to the Soviet Union's action in declaring Ambassador George F. Kennan "persona non grata."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange lacked a trend yesterday and closing prices were unchanged to 9 points higher than last Friday.
The Woodward Iron Company, producer of pig iron, has announced results of operations for the first nine months this year. The company sells 90 per cent of its production in Southern states.

The Girl Scout movement is a popular one in Greater New York. There are now 46,324 Scouts here, 3,000 more than a year ago and nearly 10,000 more than three years ago. In addition, many more girls wish to join the organization as soon as it can expand its resources and increase its facilities enough to take care of them.
" We thought we'd wrap it up today."
RYE, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Al Salamone, assistant at Ridgeway, and David Ratner of the home club, posted the winning best-ball card
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines reported today that world production of crude petroleum totaled 4,282,977,000 barrels in 1951, a 12.8 per cent increase over 1950 output.

BERLIN, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Nikolai M. Shvernik, Soviet President, on a visit here for ceremonies marking East Germany's third anniversary, said today the Soviet zone state had won "an honorable place" in the Communist world, and had obtained its "trust."

An impressive first-day record registration was set yesterday when 549,974 persons crowded the city's 4,394 polling places to qualify for the election on Nov. 4. The previous record was 436,321, established in the 1944 Presidential race.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein called upon the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to schedule immediate public hearings on proposed reorganization plans for the Long Island Rail Road. The plans have been filed by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and the state-created Long Island Transit Authority.

The delivery of essential materials in this country over inadequate highways has already become a national problem, James A. Farley, former United States Postmaster General and now president of the Farley - GMC Truck Company here, said yesterday.
A Red Cross bloodmobile crew working yesterday in the Roosevelt Hotel ballroom collected 408 pints of blood from employes of seven business groups.

Today's recipes are prompted by the bulletin last Friday from the City Department of Markets that popular lamb cuts are from 6 to 15 cents a pound less than they were a year ago. Shoulder chops show the biggest drop; they now average 95 cents a pound as compared with $1.10 last October. Shoulder roast, at 59 cents a pound, is down 10 cents.

Rockefeller Center believes it has found a tree that will survive in the botanically bleak region of midtown Manhattan. Last night a crew from a New Jersey nursery planted a fifty-foot honey locust in front of the International Building near the corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

The Board of Higher Education dismissed three municipal college professors yesterday for their refusal to answer questions about alleged Communist party membership before the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee.

Pat Marcune, 127 3/4 pounds, Coney Island, hammered out a split-decision victory over Bill Bossio, 127 1/2, Pittsburgh, in the ten-round feature bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn before 1,100 fans last night. The meeting was the seventh between the pair and Marcune now holds the advantage, three triumphs to two, with two bouts drawn.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The Council of Ministers representing the fourteen North Atlantic Treaty allies will be asked at its mid-December meeting here to approve steps for an Allied defense force in Europe of seventy-five divisions and 6,500 combat aircraft by the end of 1953.
Brooklyn missed the boat yesterday on that long-awaited cruise that was to bring its first world series championship to the shores of the Gowanus. But it will get another chance today.

MADRID, Oct. 6 -- Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, the Archbishop of Seville, sharply criticized today both the Jesuit magazine America of New York and Archbishop Paul Schulte of Indianapolis for having expressed opinions different from his own on the Protestant question in Spain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Puerto Rico accounted for 138 of 301 American battle casualties in Korea identified by the Defense Department today. A new list reported totals of 25 killed, 210 wounded, 46 missing and 20 injured. The following were listed form New Jersey and Connecticut (none from New York):

The Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association voiced opposition yesterday to the economy reduction set for Nov. 4 of 2,250 employes of Veterans Administration Hospitals, including forty in the Bronx and twenty-five in Brooklyn, and labeled the moves as "false economy."

SEATTLE, Oct. 6 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower charged tonight that the "sly apostles of Fair Dealism" believed in "whole-hog Federal Government." He promised that a Republican Administration would expand the Western reclamation program by uniting the resources of private enterprise with those of the local, state and Federal Governments.

Squared Away, Mrs. Jan Burke's steady sprinter, won the Interborough Handicap on the Metropolitan Jockey Club's opening-day program at Jamaica yesterday. Favored at 5-2 by the crowd of 20,952, Squared Away justified the calculations by turning in a good performance under the guidance of Eddie Arcaro to score by a half-length over F. Ambrose Clark's Tea-Maker.
A "Gaston and Alphonse" battle for control of the American Federation of Labor's largest union came to light yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Trading was on a small scale in most sections of the London stock markets today, with price movements generally narrow.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 6 -- The ten-nation European Council for Nuclear Research decided here today to recommend to their Governments the establishment of a $25,000,000 atomic study center near Geneva.

Mrs. Caroline Potts, who is 72 years old and weighs about, 115 pounds, was mugged on the street near a Brooklyn subway station last night by a youth described by the police as 6 feet 4 inches tall and weighing 190 pounds.
SALAMANCA, N. Y., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican seeking re-election. retorted tonight to remarks made by one of his opponents.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 6 (AP) -- A Yale University economist today proposed that the United States reduce its debt by selling off Government-owned power plants and tide water oil lands if they aren't turned over to the states.

The Community Service Society has taken a closer look at what is coming to be known as the "old-age problem." From the most intensive study of its kind ever undertaken the Society has gathered a wealth of information which adds up to a pretty discouraging picture.
Appointment of Wendell W. Lang as general attorney was announced yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation, whose law department he joined in 1936.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 6 -- For the first time since John L. Lewis broke with the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1940, the head of the United Mine Workers is leaning toward support of the Democratic ticket in a Presidential election.

The seventh annual National Hardware Show got off yesterday to an opening that marked new highs in participation and attendance. The five-day trade exhibit is being held at Grand Central Palace, where the displays of more than 700 manufacturers have filled every inch of 192,000 square feet available for show purposes.

The stock market found little reason yesterday to change its indecisive attitude. Prices found it difficult to establish any set pattern, first drifting to an easier level, then firming and finally closing mixed. Selling was never of a pressing nature and by the same token no response came from the buying side.

A rising crime problem in Queens was noted yesterday as County Judge Peter T. Farrell reported that the September grand jury had handled 65 per cent more cases than that for September, 1951. A check-up showed that the County Court had been falling steadily behind in its work.

When Haensel and Gretel's father, Peter by name, a besom-maker, came home the afternoon his wife had shooed the children out into the witch's forest, he was exhilarated. His pockets were loaded with sausages and other food, he carried a bottle in hand (from which he obviously had been sipping) and he sang, "Tra-la-la-la, tra-la-la-la -- Hunger is the best cook!" because he had sold all his brooms.

ROME, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Delegates from thirty-two countries today signed a new international air law convention fixing the liability of airlines at a maximum of just over $77,000 for death or damage caused in foreign countries.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Following is the itinerary of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois for the remaining four weeks of the Presidential campaign, as announced today by his campaign headquarters (all times Eastern standard):

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn, today invaded predominantly Republican upstate New York with the prediction that the Democratic party could achieve "a terrific landslide" in the state this November if the local candidates and workers got out the vote.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Peyton Ford, former Deputy Attorney General, was defended by an associate today in the face of criticism by a House subcommittee for the way he handled cases of alleged fraud in settling World War II contracts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Democratic National Committee its fire today on the "truth squad" the Republican National Committee has assigned to follow President Truman on his tour of the West.

It is a shameful fact that less than 50 per cent of the American citizens eligible to vote bothered to go to the polls and vote in the national election of 1948. This year the American Heritage Foundation and 200 other organizations are cooperating to remedy a shameful condition.
Everyone says my hit won the game but I sure don't feel like any hero.

EMOTIONALLY exhausted from their nerve-wracking experiences of the day before, the customers sat in numbed immobility for most of yesterday's world series game at Ebbets Field. Then as excitement began to grow late in the fray, pulses started to quicken and once more it was a rip-snorter, brittle with thrills until the final out.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Brannan announced today there will be no marketing quotas or acreage allotments on upland or extra long staple cotton produced in 1953.

Double-breasted closings, variations of the over-blouse, and deftly draped treatments highlighted the collection of forty-six French and Italian blouses shown yesterday by the National Associattion of Blouse Manufacturers at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel. Purchased for inspirational and adaptation purposes, the presentation included such names as Dior, Desses, Fath, Givenchy, Capucci and Viscounti.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 6 -- Despite her strategic vulnerability and the exposure of her northern frontier to the Soviet Union, Norway is creating a small but effective delaying force that would stand a good chance of checking an enemy invasion until help could arrive.
Yale's football coach, Jordan Olivar, a newcomer at the helm in New Haven this season, expressed his respect yesterday for the Columbia team that will meet the Elis in the Bowl on Saturday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- State legislation designed to speed the resettlement of home owners and tenants displaced by the construction of new parkways and thruways was proposed unanimously today by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors. Three bills were forwarded to the Legislature for early action.

WASHINGTON, Oct 6 (UP) -- Federal Judge Henry A. Schweinhaut ruled today that two witnesses before the Senate Crime Investing Committee were within their rights in refusing to testify in the presence of television, radio and photographic apparatus.

Four sportily dressed youths, captured last night in the Bronx after a liquor store hold-up, were identified by the police as among the thirteen soldiers who had tunneled their way out of a stockade at Fort Dix, N. J., last Thursday, with tin cans, a broken knife and a basting spoon.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of Secretary of State Acheson's address here today to the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C. I. O.:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Amy disclosed today that it would soon organize anti-aircraft battalions equipped with guided missiles that would automatically seek out and destroy attacking aircraft.

Plans have been completed for the annual luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the American Women's Voluntary Services, Inc., to be held next Tuesday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The complete cast for its "Boris Godunoff" excerpts and several program changes have been announced by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society for its first concerts of the season at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 16, 17 and 19. Dimitri Mitropoulos, musical director, also has made known program revisions for the second week.

The overwhelming victory of Senator McCarthy in the recent Wisconsin primary seems to have aroused the ire and amazement of those to whom his name is anathema. Might it occur to these misguided individuals that the people of his own state, as well as thousands of others throughout the nation, might "love the Senator for the enemies he has made"?

May I compliment you on the complete fairness of your news columns in the current campaign and on the abundant space allotted on your editorial page to critics of your policy? I myself can hardly criticize it, for I made at that time the same choice that you made.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6 -- Four actors today had their bread-and-butter problem solved for periods of time ranging from one year to ten by being signed to new work agreements.
HAVANA, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Cuban newspapers today blasted Welterweight Champion Kid Gavilan for his slow, cautious tactics last night in successfully defending his crown against Billy Graham of New York.

Somerset Maugham's "The Sacred Flame," originally produced on Broadway by Gilbert Miller in 1928, opens a limited engagement this evening at 8 o'clock at the President Theatre. The revival is the first in a series of attractions planned for this season by Anthony Parella.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Supreme Court started its new eight-month term with a thirty-minute session today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of Class I rail systems during August at $79,000,000, compared with $58,000,000 in the same month last year.

LONDON, Oct 6 -- A distinguished group of British experts on foreign affairs declared today that the chief immediate aim of Soviet policy in Europe was to "secure the withdrawal of American forces and the liquidation of American bases on the Continent."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 5 -- The Economic Council of Serbia has decided to suspend its powers to force university graduates with skills to take assignments in the provinces where such skills are required in industries, local government and social welfare.

Young people whose interests include collecting may want to acquire a leaflet about seal and label collecting, a new hobby that was rated first in popularity in a recent nation-wide survey. The leaflet has been prepared by the American Hobby Federation, the organization that conducted the survey.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 7 (UP) -- Senate Republican "truth" spokesmen declared today that President Truman had "falsified the facts" by saying that Republicans did not understand "what it takes to meet the menace of Communist aggression and subversion."

Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman of the Liberal party, declared last night that the 1952 Presidential election was "a clear turning point in the life of the country" and would determine the question whether "we are going back to the age of Hoover, or forward to the world of the Twentieth Century."

Five medium-size landing ships that have been converted into coastal minelayers were turned over to the Norwegian and Turkish Navies yesterday under the provisions of the Mutual Defense Assistance Pact.

Edward C. Maguire, chairman of the New York Volunteers for Stevenson, said yesterday that 10,000 workers now were engaged in a registration and voting drive and that their efforts to carry the state for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson would be aided by an intensive state-wide radio campaign.

WYNYARD, Sask., Oct. 6 -- On a prairie that is dotted with autumn-dry pot holes, the sparkling Ducks Unlimited projects constitute a waterfowl oasis. Without them much of this prairie would be a duck factory out of production.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 7 -- Examination of the fresh and specific statistics on the Soviet economy presented to the nineteenth party congress by Georgi M. Malenkov, Politburo member, disclosed today that Soviet production, particularly on the basic sinews of modern industrial might, was advancing undeviatingly toward the massive goals set for it by Premier Stalin.

Walter Reade Jr., motion-picture theatre executive, announced yesterday that the Atlantic Video Corporation, of which he is president, will build an ultra-high frequency television station in Asbury Park, N. J., to operate on Channel 58.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 6 -- Six persons were injured when nine automobiles and two trucks were involved in a crash early today on the Elizabeth Meadows stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike. The state police attributed the accident to a combination of fog and high-speed driving.
The first U. S. O.-Camp Show to be seen by a civilian audience at a special performance Thursday here in New York will leave the same day for Korea as U. S. O.-Camp Shows Unit No. 1,075.
LONDON, Oct. 7 (Reuters) -- British steel production last month was at a new high record rate for September, the British Iron and Steel Federation said today.

The chance to tie Joe McCarthy's record of winning four straight world series beckons Casey Stengel today. But the Yankee skipper, though elated by the 3-to-2 victory that pulled him even with the Dodgers at Ebbets Field, approached the "big one" in something of a quandary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A contract to build the nation's first all-jet seaplane was awarded by the Navy today to the Glenn L. Martin Company of Baltimore on the basis of its winning design in a Navy-sponsored competition.

By order of the State Civil Defense Commission, New Yorkers will participate on Dec. 13 in a second city-wide "incident," Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday at the swearing-in of new defense officials at City Hall. The first public participation test was held last November.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 6 -- Referee Ashton Donza died of a heart attack during the sixth round of a welterweight fight between Ross Virgo and Jack O'Brien at the Coliseum tonight.

ROSLYN, L. I., Oct. 6 -- Ted Burger and Henry Brancato of Bethpage tied with Milton Glass, Engineers, and Arthur Stuhler, unattached, at 66 in the weekly amateur-pro event of the Long Island P. G. A. at the Engineers Golf Club today. Each team carded a 34, 32.

DENVER, Oct. 6 -- James T. Hill Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Air Force, told members of the National Guard Association here today that "political second guessers from the brush" were taking liberties with the country's recent military history.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 6 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson will start out tomorrow on a 4,350-mile campaign tour of eight states in the Middle West and South, and indications are that he will take along a new and somewhat fiercer look.

There was a stiff fight for the top spot in the United Press college football ratings yesterday. Michigan State retained first place for the third straight week, but California and Wisconsin were close behind.

The Elevator Industries Association, Inc., has filed with Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Control Administrator, a report asserting that automatic elevator service in residential buildings is five times as safe as manually operated service.

The sale of tickets for today's finale at Ebbets Field began shortly after the final out yesterday. Several thousand fans, six abreast, were on a lane extending from Montgomery Street to McKeever Place, waiting for the box offices to open.

A new technique in fabric selling was introduced yesterday by M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., one of the country's largest textile manufacturers. A year ago this month, there was opened, in Framingham, Mass., a new type of shopping center, "Shoppers World," which some felt was too much of an innovation to be a success. It shunned many old-time theories of successful marketing, was "too big," and would result in traffic jams, it was held.

Predictions by steamship passenger traffic officials that 1952 would be a record travel year have been more than borne out by the tremendous volume of passengers who crossed the Atlantic on surface ships from Jan. 1 to mid-September.

The switching of management in Dayton Power and Light Company underwritings from the former E. B. Smith Co. to Morgan Stanley Co. came under discussion in the investment banking anti-trust trial here yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 7 -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who investigated possible civil rights violations in last winter's bombings of Carver Village, a Negro apartment project in Miami, and the home of a Negro couple in Mims, Fla., were questioned here today by a Federal grand jury.

VIENNA, Oct. 7 -- Foreign Minister Karl Gruber protested today against what he described as "the often impatient and unjustified interference of subordinate organs" of the United States occupation authorities in Austrian affairs. He voiced his protest in a speech to the Industrial League in Linz.

RIO DE JANEIRO Oct. 7 -- The dollar attained a new high exchange rate of 36 cruzeiros in the black market here today, while reports are that some transactions have taken place at 37 cruzeiros for large amounts.

OMAHA, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Independent Natural Gas Association of America, concluding a one-day convention yesterday, asked the Federal Power Commission to "promptly re-examine the basis of its new rate return formula."

Edwin L. Tice has purchased the 138-acre Topanemus Farms on the Lafayette Mills-Marlboro Road in Marlboro Township, N. J., from Charles R. Nash, executive vice president of the Wall Street insurance firm of Johnson Higgins.

It is wrong to call what is happening in the marketing field today a "retail revolution," because what affects the retailer must affect the manufacturer, according to E. B. Weiss, director of merchandising for the Grey Advertising Agency.

CHICAGO, Oct 7 -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, asserted today that if a shortage in pork develops this winter, as has been predicted, it will be the result of an error of judgment by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan and not because of inadequacy of existing price-support law.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 7 -- European scientists hope the "super-synchroton" to be erected in their projected Geneva research center will unlock some hidden secrets of the universe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Defense Materials Procurement Agency today completed its network of buying offices to acquire strategic materials from friendly foreign nations with the appointment of Rear Admiral Paul L. Mather, U. S. Navy, retired.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- The stock markets were brighter today on optimistic interpretation of Britain's trade balance for the last half-year and record steel production in September.

In the old days, they say, the Yankees used to win a world series simply by strolling out on the field before the opening game. Just the sight of titans like Ruth nonchalantly knocking ball after ball into the bleacher seats in batting practice would demoralize the opposition.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Success of the first semester of an experimental project, designed to help parents of pre-school children prepare their youngsters for school experience, "justifies a forecast of definite gains during the new school year," according to a report on the project released today by the Chicago Board of Education.

Sustained demand from buyers and forecasts that tool kits, handicraft hobby sets and packaged hardware items would achieve a new high in Christmas gift sales this year highlighted trade optimism yesterday at the seventh annual National Hardware Show.

The number of collective farms in the Soviet Union has been reduced 60 per cent since 1949, Georgi M. Malenkov revealed in his address to the nineteenth Congress of the Communist party in Moscow on Sunday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- The three-man crew of a C-47 Air Force plane was killed and three service men hitchhikers were injured today when the twin-engined transport crashed into a wooded section on the outskirts of North Philadelphia Airport.

Distribution of 300,000 new shares as a stock dividend in the ratio of one share for each twenty-four outstanding is planned by The National City Bank of New York, under the terms of a proposal announced yesterday.
The report of Northrop Aircraft, Inc., for the eleven months to June 30, shows a net profit of $2,068,502, equal to $3.60 a share on sales and billings totaling $167,721,854.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, the United States' No. 1 ranking player from Philadelphia, needed the full five sets today before he eliminated the Chilean ace, Luis Ayala, in the third round of the Pan-American tennis championships. The scores were 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.

GENEVA, Oct. 7 -- The six countries forming the European Coal and Steel Community have asked for and expect to get all the legal authority they need under existing international agreements to proceed with the formation of a free trade area among themselves. spokesman for the community said here today.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- Army, which gave a good account of itself, all things considered, against Southern California, would feel happier over its prospects against Dartmouth at Michie Stadium on Saturday if it were able to put its full strength on the field.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 7 -- A suspended policeman accused of having committed two burglaries while on night patrol duty and also of having accepted bribes from motorists was indicted today by the October Suffolk County grand jury here.

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons are aiding in the plans for the annual Post-Debutante Tiara Ball for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service to be held on Dec. 29 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Kelley Keresey and Mrs. Donald Perkins are co-chairmen of the event and Mrs. Robert G. Shaw 2d and Miss Jean Tanburn are co-chairman of the executive committee.

William L. Kleitz, president, Guaranty Trust Company, was elected chairman of the Clearing House Committee at the ninety-ninth annual meeting of the New York Clearing House Association yesterday. Alexander C. Nagle, president, First National Bank, was re-elected president of the association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- With the national political campaign moving into its closing weeks, the farmers, small merchants, teachers, laborers and others who comprise the bulk of the population of the ten central and northeastern Illinois counties are perturbed by several major questions.

" Just for You," the Paramount romantic musical in Technicolor, starring Bing Crosby, Jane Wyman and Ethel Barrymore, which arrives at the Capitol, is thin morning's lone film newcomer. Elliott Nugent directed and Pat Duggan produced from a script by Robert Carson and the story, "Famous," by Stephen Vincent Benet.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 7 -- An indication that interest in good design has invaded farm areas was the enthusiasm with which a group of rural homemakers received yesterday the opening lecture of a series at the museum here. The course is called "Art for Homemaker."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Israel Industrial and Mineral Development Corporation of New York filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for sale of 30,000 shares of Class A stock, $100 par.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- In the absence of any important outside buying, both wheat and corn futures declined sharply today on the Board of Trade, professional selling being in evidence, along with some scattered liquidation. Not much attention was paid to the weather news during the session, although the five-day forecast predicted another long period of arid conditions, with not much change in temperature.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines reported today that marketed production of natural gas in this country totaled 7,457,359,000,000 cubic feet in 1951, compared with 6,282,060,000,000 cubic feet in 1950.
A scrimmage, with the emphasis on ground offense, featured Columbia's practice session yesterday in preparation for Saturday's game with Yale at New Haven.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Statements in New Zealand by Sir John Cockcroft, director of Britain's Atomic Energy Establishment at Harwell, disclosed that Britain has made more progress toward the industrial exploitation of atomic power than had been thought.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 7 -- James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. L O., disclosed this afternoon that he had resigned from three Government security groups in protest against the award of defense contracts to the General Electric Company.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 8 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet said today that his Eighth Army had stopped the biggest enemy assault in twelve months short of the main Allied lines in Korea, but that the Communist forces were capable of continuing "limited" attacks through November.

Many parties will be given at the luncheon and fashion show to be held today in the Empire Room of the Waldrof-Astoria under the auspices of the Virginia Day Nursery. Guests have been requested to bring packages of rummage suitable for resale later at Everybody's Thrift Shop at 922 Third Avenue for the benefit of the nursery.

Luxury passenger vessels of the United States Lines will carry 5.300 passengers traveling abroad as Army dependents in the next five months under a contract arrangement with the Military Sea Transportation Service.
The State Public Service Commission was asked last night to stay electric rate increases granted last summer to the Consolidated Edison Company and to order a rehearing of the entire rate case.

Military and civilian personnel of the Army are scheduled to give more than 1,300 points of blood this week to Red Cross bloodmobile units that will visit three installations in the area, the Red Cross announced yesterday.

More American men and women qualified to vote hold political opinions than will actually vote this November. Why is this the case? The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will be the beneficiary of a luncheon and fashion show to be held tomorrow in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. The benefit will precede the opening dinner dance for this season to be held later in the day in the Trianon Room.

The four-story building containing about 20,000 square feet of space at 324-334 Ellery Street in Brooklyn has been sold by I. Engelhardt and R. Wexlin to E. Kessler, who will use it for the sorting, distributing and selling of wool stock.

The small silhouette for festive wear and to complement furs, shimmering with jewels or fashioned of flowers, provided the main theme for the Millinery Stabilization Commission's showing last night at the Astor Hotel.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 8 -- The armistice talks at Panmunjom were recessed indefinitely today at the request of the United Nations. In one of the strongest statements made during the negotiations, Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr. called for a recess until such time as the Communists were willing to accept an Allied solution of the prisoner-of-war problem or else present an alternate proposal in writing.

Two thousand patients made a figurative and wholly delightful hour's escape from their beds at Bellevue Hospital yesterday.
