Jacobs, medical superintendent, put on a ten-gallon hat and cowboy boots for the occasion and dressed his 3-year-old-son, Bill, Jr., in Western style.

Leading custom smelters here yesterday cut the price of lead 1 cent to 15 cents a pound, New York, reflecting readjustment to the lower level of prices named for the metal last week in London for November-December delivery. The former 16-cent price has been in effect since June 24.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -- American Airlines told the Civil Aeronautics Board today that it planned to double its transcontinental air coach service by next spring.

James Madison Blackwell, president of the Association of Alumni of Columbia College, yesterday criticized faculty and student groups for using the name of Columbia University last week in endorsing Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential nominee. The college is a part of the university.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles, who at 31 still hopes to regain the world heavyweight championship, will resume his ring career here tomorrow night against Bernie Reynolds of Fairfield, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Republican National Committee, in the face of a new Democratic attack on the finances of its campaign and candidates, today booked Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, to make another country - wide radio - television broadcast next Monday.

John M. Redding, assistant postmaster general, declared here yesterday that a Republican Presidential victory would bring a blight on the trucking industry. He spoke at the annual convention of the American Trucking Associations at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ABOARD TRUMAN TRAIN, In Colorado. Oct. 7 -- President Truman declared today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had betrayed personal and political principles, had surrendered to a "moral scoundrel" and "moral pygmies" in the persons of Senators William E. Jenner of Indiana and Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, and therefore as President could not be trusted with the "awful responsibility" of controlling the atomic bomb.

A shortage of best-selling carpet items is causing retailers to move from one manufacturer or distributor to another seeking to get sufficient quantities to keep up with consumer demands, store executives and mill representatives reported yesterday.
WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 7 (AP) Fisticuffs stole the show last night when rival candidates for state political offices -- from Governor down -- met on the same platform to debate issues.

A dinner honoring Samuel D. Leidesdorf, business man and philanthropist, for fifty years of service to local and national causes marked the first major fund-raising event last night of the 1952 campaign for $20,000,000 sought by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

Miss Lillian Johnson, a frontier-minded veteran of the nursing service, is scheduled to leave soon for Trivandrum, in the State of Travancore, on the southernmost tip of India, as the first foreign public health consultant, for her field in that region.

A new work by Frederick L. Schuman, Woodrow Wilson Professor of Government at Williams College, will be issued Oct. 20 by Knopf, entitled "The Commonwealth of Man: An Inquiry Into Power Politics and World Government."

Wallace H. Benton has been promoted to general sales manager of the Selby Shoe Company. He succeeds William F. Hooley Sr., who will continue with the Selby organization as vice president and will supervise style improvement and merchandising coordination.

Frances Redmond, giant 23-year-old man released last March from Creedmoor State Hospital, was returned to the hospital in a strait jacket yesterday after he had caused a disturbance in Special Sessions Court in Long Island City, Queens.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 8 -- Hard-driving Chinese Communist troops flung new attacks last night and today against United Nations positions along two-thirds of the Korean battle line. A growing concern for what appears to be a large undecided vote in New York City was evident yesterday among both Democratic and Republican leaders as the national campaign entered the home-stretch. W. Alton Jones, president of the vast Cities Service Company, is burning the midnight oil preparing his special report to Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, Iran's Premier, on his findings resulting from his recent one-month visit to that country.

The City of Philadelphia yesterday borrowed $28,220,000 in the public market on serial bonds maturing from 1954 to 1983 at an interest cost of 2.815 per cent. The bonds were sold at sealed bidding to a syndicate headed by National City Bank at a bid of 100.03 for 2 1/2s and 2 3/4s. A syndicate headed by Drexel Co. and Chase National Bank bid a cost of 2.87 per cent.

Professor Olin Glenn Saxon, Yale economist, speaking before the National Consumer Finance Corporation this week, urged what amounted to a program of turning the clock back about twenty-five years in terms of Government fiscal and currency policy. He urged a debt retirement plan which would have the effect of eliminating the federal debt completely in thirty years; and he urged a return to a currency system featured by full convertibility into gold.

A Cuban maritime commission, spurred on by President Fulgencio Batista, is now nearing the completion of a study designed to give the island republic a merchant marine that will eventually carry the Cuban flag to all parts of the world.

In a cash deal, the Varick Building Corporation has sold the big factory-type building at 34-50 Varick Street, through to St. Johns Lane, to a purchaser who expects to use all the space. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal party candidate for the United States Senate, proposed last night a natoinal agency -- governmental or private to inform foreign policymakers on the nature of the Communist threat He told the Men's Club of Riverside Church there had been much talk in the campaign of past mistakes in foreign policy.

PENN YAN, N. Y., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives of New York tonight called on President Truman, when touring this state, to discuss campaign issues soberly and to "respect our intelligence and our sincerity with intelligence land sincerity of his own."

The Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York opened a drive yesterday to raise $285,000 of the $2,000,000 it will spend to operate thirteen centers in the Bronx and Manhattan in the coming year.

Although Alexander Kotov of Russia failed to finish his fourteenth-round game with Luis A. Sanchez of Colombia, his commanding position in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden was not endangered yesterday, according to a report from Stockholm.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed slightly irregular yesterday, 4 points lower to 5 points higher than on Monday.

LINDEN, N. J., Oct. 7 -- Something new in the elimination of industrial plant smoke was demonstrated today with a ground-type safety flare, featuring the use of an atomized water spray, at the Bayway refinery of the Esso Standard Oil Company here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Government's forty - six civilian agencies bought $3,087,200,000 of supplies and services last year, and gave 53 per cent of the business to concerns with less than 500 employes.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 7 (AP) -- The resignation of Dr. George H. Whipple, Nobel prize winner in medicine, as dean of the School of Medicine and Dentistry at the University of Rochester, effective June 30, was announced today by the university.

DENVER, Oct. 7 -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, a Congressional opponent of Universal Military Training, proposed today a new plan under which all physically qualified young men would receive basic military training near their homes in units of the National Guard.

The extraordinary success of "I Love Lucy" may prove too much for television. Every new show that comes along this season seems bent on trying to duplicate the elusive nonsense of Lucille Ball's vehicle. So far lightning hasn't struck the second time.

The unbeaten football Giants, preparing for their first meeting of the season with the undefeated Browns at Cleveland, yesterday were heartened by the news that John Rapacz, offensive center, would be available for Sunday's game.

The ancient Biblical ritual of Hakhel, performed in the days of the Hebrew Kingdom after every sabbatical year, was presented yesterday at Yeshiva University by 1,000 children from metropolitan Jewish schools marking the first time the ritual had been performed in the United States.

Stevenson of Illinois charged tonight that it was the Republicans who really created the Communist menace in this country by stumbling into the economic depression of the early Nineteen Thirties. The Federal Maritime Board will hear on Oct. 16 arguments in connection with two proposed rule changes affecting the conduct of steamship conference affairs, it was announced yesterday.

Fullback Bobby Boettcher ground out consistent gains during the New York University football practice at Ohio Field yesterday. Boettcher has averaged 5 yards a carry in N. Y. U's two games this season.

Diana Steiner, the first of this season's Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Award winners to collect her prize of a New York recital debut, played the violin at Town Hall yesterday afternoon with the poise and address of a veteran. A Concord grape crop high in quality and big in tonnage now being pressed will accelerate the purchase of the Welch Grape Juice Company by the National Grape Co-Operative Association, Inc., under a contract entered into by them last June, it was learned here yesterday.

As the big clock atop of the scoreboard in Ebbets Field turned 3:55 yesterday afternoon a dramatic baseball season came to a close with a grizzled 62-year-old campaigner cheering himself hoarse at the very moment an entire borough found itself plunged deep in gloom.

Abel, president of the Central National Bank of Mineola, disqualified himself today as a prospective member of Nassau County's October grand jury because the panel is scheduled to hear the case in which he has accused Mrs. Lillian Robinson of swindling $475,000 from his bank through a long-range home improvement loan scheme.

ABOARD NIXON TRAIN, Oct. 7 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, rolling across Ohio on a campaign tour, charged tonight that four more years of Democratic rule would yield the American people no hope of peace but "more Alger Hisses, more atomic spies, more crises."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Certificates of necessity for accelerated tax amortization for ninety-two new defense facilities were certified by the Defense Production Administration between Sept. 25 and Oct. 1, the Government agency announced today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, reported ill, handed fresh notes to the United States and British envoys tonight after a day of consultations on the British-Iranian oil dispute.

MOSCOW, Oct. 7 -- Deputy Premier Lavrenti P. Beria told the nineteenth Congress of the Communist party today that "only hopeless fools" thought that the Soviet Union could be frightened by any "provocations." He said the Soviet people would deal a cashing blow to any group that attacked them.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 7 (UP) -- Crafty Admiral, Greek Ship and Rube were named today as the three American horses selected by a panel of racing writers to run in the $50,000 Washington, D. C., International here on Oct. 18.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development put out its seventh issue of American dollar bonds in this market yesterday. The offering consisted of $60,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent obligations due on Oct. 15, 1971, priced at 98, to yield 3.65 per cent to maturity.
SHENANDOAH, Iowa, Oct. 8 -President Truman and Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, called signals on a Midwest farm belt football field today.

VICEROY, Sask., Oct. 8 -- This morning we made another trip to that "secret" duck shooting paradise known as Channel Lake and after a vain effort to locate a shooting point on either side of the neck that separates the two stretches of water we decided the secret was shared only by the duck hunters of Southern and Central Saskatchewan.

Regardless of inflation, a cent is still something to be reckoned with in the financial world. Even 7/100 of a cent. That was the difference (per $1,000 bond) between the two best bids offered yesterday by banking syndicates for $16,005,000 of serial construction bonds of the State of Maryland.

An important entry into the petrochemical field was revealed yesterday with the announcement by J. Peter Grace Jr., president of W. R. Grace Co., of the formation of a wholly owned subsidiary, which he will also head, to be known as Grace Chemical Company.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 8 -- Narcotics addiction over the country has decreased in the last year, M. L. Harney, a top national official in this field, reported today.

The four - story apartment house accommodating twenty-one families at 489 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Lorrae Real Estate Corporation to a client of Samuel M. Halperin, attorney, for investment. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The property is assessed at $42,000.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 8 (AP) -Averell Harriman said today that Senator Robert A. Taft's "philosophy is based on the freedom to sell apples."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The heaviest penalty assessed to date by the Office of Price Stabilization will be collected from the Barium Steel Company of New York City; its wholly owned subsidiary, the Central Iron and Steel Company of Harrisburg, and Central's wholly owned subsidiary, the Phoenix Iron and Steel Company, Phoenixville, Pa.

Despite long delays and confusion at some polling places, there was no let-up yesterday in the unprecedented pace of voters registering for the election on Nov. 4. When the books closed at 10:30 P. M. the tally for the third day was 561,597, making the total for the first three days 1,676,846.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 8 -- The struggle between the Roman Catholic Bishops on one side and the Yugoslav Communist party and Government on the other has been renewed with increased violence. The reactivation of the struggle was precipitated by a decision of the Bishops who met in Zagreb, Croatia, Sept. 23-25 to prohibit their clergy from joining the Government-sponsored priests associations.

Walter A. Lynch, acting Democratic State Chairman, was in touch yesterday with President Truman's special train and arranged for an additional stop at Yonkers tomorrow night. The special train, scheduled to leave Hudson at 6:20 P. M., will arrive at Yonkers at 8:50.
MOSCOW, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Russia's planning chief declared today that dispersal of Soviet industry, making it less vulnerable to air attack, would be a key feature of the nation's latest five-year plan.

SHENANDOAH, Iowa, Oct. 8 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, followed President Truman on the same farm country platform today to describe the President as "a master of the art of demagogy."

ROME, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- John Cashmore, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, attacked the McCarran-Walter, Immigration Act today as "hateful" and "un-American" and promised to work for its repeal if the voters send him to Washington.

Governor Dewey charged last night that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois and Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, Democratic candidates for President and Vice President, were running in Alabama under a "white supremacy'' label, and presented evidence to prove it.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 8 -- Chips, the Dalmatian mascot of this city's Fire Department for thirteen years, died in its headquarters today. He had responded to 3,000 alarms before being "retired from active duty" in January.

The nation's supply of gasoline stocks declined last week to 119,793,000 barrels from 120,276,000 in the previous week and 122,919,000 a year ago, according to yesterday's report of the American Petroleum Institute.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Billy Talbert of New York and Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, four-time United States national doubles champions, were upset today in the Pan American tennis tournament by Straight Clark of Los Angeles and Harold Burrows of Charlottesville, Va., 6 -- 4, 12 -- 10, 6 -- 4.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Net personal income in the United States during August was placed by the Department of Commerce today at an annual rate of $267,000,000,000, which was $3,000,000,000 higher than in July.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 -- Fresh from his latest bargaining victory over the nation's coal operators, John L. Lewis assured the United Mine Workers in convention here today that the union had not reached the end of the road in its plans for a more ambitious union pension and welfare fund.

Harold R. Harris, it was announced yesterday, will leave his post as vice president and manager of Atlantic operations for Pan American World Airways to become, on Jan. 1, president of Northwest Airlines.

PARAMUS, N. J., Oct. 8 -- In the closet of a little white room in the men's quarters of Bergen Pines County Hospital, stored away in suitcases and cardboard boxes, are photographs, newspaper clippings and letters that help Charles Grieder to relive the days when he was New Jersey's only airplane pilot.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Department of Justice balked the attempts of the Food and Drug Administration to seize a carload of contaminated corn grits that had been shipped by the Pabst Brewing Company from its grits mill in Peoria, Ill., to its brewery in Milwaukee, Wis., witnesses said at a Congressional hearing today.

WATERTOWN, Mass., Oct. 8 -- The kick-off of an intensive campaign to broaden consumer knowledge of the new wonder metal, titanium, so that consumption may be raised, production expanded and prices driven down, was staged here today by military officials and industrial experts.

Prompt placing of orders for resort wear lines points to early production and a substantial increase in business for New York manufacturers of women's sportswear. Members of the Sportswear Guild opening lines this week reported showings to capacity crowds, good immediate response and considerable willingness on the part of retailers to depart from their conservative buying practices of the last several seasons.

The Government and Civic Employes Organizing Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations yesterday chartered its first teachers' local in this city. The new organization was designated as Local 378 and named, by vote of the executive board, the United Teachers, C. I. O.

The shouts of the victor, following a night of tumultuous revelry, having duly subsided along with the moans of the vanquished, the late 1952 world series moved hastily into the shadows yesterday to become just another notation in the record books.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- At least seventy-eight persons were killed and more than 200 injured today in a railwayman's nightmare of a wreck just outside of London.
The State of Maryland borrowed $18,505,000 yesterday on issues of bonds maturing from 1955 to 1967 at an interest cost of about 1.715 per cent.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Wheat and corn futures scored a good rally early, but the demand faded and the market receded sharply from the high spots. Oats demand was curbed by fears of further imports of Canadian grain. The Korean news which appeared to be of a potentially bullish character had little effect.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter signed an order yesterday calling upon Victor Clemente, Queens sewer contractor, to show cause why he should not comply with a subpoena that directed him to produce his records for the last six years or go to jail until they were submitted.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, retorted bluntly last night to detractors of his administration, particularly City Council President Rudolph Halley. He urged Mr. Halley to moderate his criticism in the interest of maintaining public confidence in the thirty-five municipal institutions.

The purchase by the city of the Tottenville branch of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad for $1, leaving the company to operate the fourteen-mile line as the city's agent at a fee of 5 cents a passenger, was recommended yesterday in a report submitted to Mayor Impellitteri.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The main interest on the Stock Exchange was transferred today to the industrial shares. Although business was quiet, leaders closed at the day's best. Oils also improved, mainly on hopes of an agreement with Premier Mossadegh of Iran.

The young season's most ambitious piano program so far was attempted last night in Town Hall by George Walker, who included on his program no less than the Schumann Fantasy in C, the Chopin B minor Sonata, the Prokofieff Toccata and Haydn's familiar Sonata in E flat.
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 9 -- The Chinese Reds and South Korean infantrymen fought a fierce seesaw battle today for "White Horse Hill" on the central Korean front, scene of the year's heaviest fighting.

More than $1,500,000,000 in time and space devoted to public service advertising has been contributed by American business during the last decade, it is reported in the Advertising Councils annual report, released yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Recent communications from Washington to the French Government regarding defense questions and Tunisia were offensive to French dignity, Premier Antoine Pinay told parliamentarians of his own Independent party today, according to those present at a caucus of that group.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The President has made his record the paramount issue in the campaign, subordinating the Democratic candidate in the process, and, if the Republican nominee for President is elected, the inescapable conclusion will be that Mr. Truman's record has been repudiated by the American people.

CHARLES DILLON STENGEL always needs room when he talks. He needs gesturing room and he needs conversational room. If a fellow listens to him often enough, he'll discover that Casey rarely fails to complete a story though it might take him two hours of rambling discourse as he wanders away on a detour and then a detour of a detour et sic ad infinitum.

The verbal assaults against the United States launched at the Moscow party congress by Stalin, Molotov and Malenkov continue unabated and have just been reinforced by salvos from two particularly representative Soviet figures. They are Deputy Premier Beria, who is the Himmler of Soviet Russia, and Marshal Vasilevsky, its Minister of War.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Hi Billee won the $10,000 added Laurel Sprint Handicap today, defeating Jouett Shouse's Cinda.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of General Eisenhower's address tonight at the San Francisco Cow Palace:

George G. Walker, president of the Electric Bond and Share Company, and Kinsey M. Robinson, president of the Washington Water Power Company, saw their efforts to keep the Washington utility out of the hands of public ownership become successful yesterday.
May I add my comments to those of other readers on your editorials of Sept. 26 and Oct. 1 regarding the Truman Administration's alleged responsibility for inflation.

Ralph Ilowite, who did what few men would dare -- he tore up a traffic summons and threw the pieces on the ground in front of the policeman who had just given the sommons to him -- paid a lighter penalty yesterday -- a suspended $2 fine for littering -- than a man would dare hope for.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 8 -- Senator John J. Sparkman replied here tonight to Governor Dewey's charge that he was a "Jim Crow" candidate and was running on a ballot that spelled out "white supremacy."
Three hold-ups netted robbers a total of $3,673 in the Bronx and Washington Heights yesterday, the police reported.

The men who preside at the cutting tables in the garment industry pursue an honorable vocation pre-eminent among all the occupations of their craft. In the women's garment industry they are members of Cutters Union Local Ten, affiliated to the International Ladies Garment Workers Union (A. F. L.), and they are now celebrating the fiftieth birthday of their union.

Those cotton traders who commented rudely on the earlier estimates of the 1952 cotton crop received a measure of vindication yesterday. They had pointed out, when everybody was screaming about the drought, that all the reports of great damage were coming from areas that grow little cotton and that conditions had been better than fair in two of the three most important cotton-growing states -- Texas, California and Mississippi -- and in other important areas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson, expressing more hope than has been heard from official quarters for some time, declared today that the United States still believed that a "humanitarian solution" to the Korean prisoner - of - war problem could be reached with the Communist negotiators at Panmunjom.

With the exception of one game, adjourned a second time, fourteen rounds were completed yesterday, in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, leaving Alexander Kotov of Russia 2 1/2 points ahead of the field, according to a report from Stockholm.
SHENANDOAH, Iowa, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from an address today by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, at the Shenandoah Harvest Jubilee:

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Yildiz, owned by Mrs. W. M. Jeffords with Glen Lasswell up, staged a thrilling stretch duel with W. G. Helis Jr.'s Evicted in the Audubon purse at Garden State Park today, winning by half a length in the mile and a sixteenth event.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 -- Two Soviet jet fighters harassed a United States hospital plane en route to Berlin today, firing several bursts of machine-gun fire in its vicinity. Within a few hours the United States had protested the action as "uncivilized."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared tonight that the United Nations had fallen into a "Soviet trap" that was "perfectly conceived, perfectly timed and perfectly sprung" when it entered into Korean peace talks with the Communists.

ABOARD NIXON TRAIN, Oct. 8 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon continued today to hammer away at the Truman Administration's foreign policy, asserting that "nothing would please the Kremlin more" than the election of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois as President of the United States.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 9 -- A B-29 Superfort, carrying a crew of eight, disappeared Tuesday shortly after radar equipment had picked up an unidentified plane approaching it from the direction of the Russian-held Kurile Islands, the Far East Air Forces said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Leon H. Keyserling, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, predicted today that the country's annual productive capacity would increase by $100,000,000000 by 1962, and he suggested that "several billion" of it might well be spent for more medical care.

Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, R. A. Butler, apparently has achieved the first of the financial targets he set for himself when he took office a year ago. In the first half of 1952, according to the most recent figures, Britain had a favorable trade balance of $67,200,000, excluding U. S. defense aid.
I write as a former supporter of General Eisenhower, though a Democrat.

Influenced by the unexpectedly high cotton crop estimate, cottonseed oil futures slumped yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange, dropping 16 to 23 points. Other allied markets were weak and crude oil was softer in the South.

Despite a 14.7 per cent rise in revenues, earnings of the Meredith Publishing Company and its subsidiaries were barely changed in the fiscal year ended on June 30, the annual report revealed yesterday.

ALBANY, Oct. 8 -- Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, commanding general of the New York National Guard, reported today that seventeen New York Army and Air National Guardsmen had qualified in the designating examination to take the competitive examination in March for entrance to the United States Military Academy at West Point.

DENVER, Oct. 8 -- Lieut. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Deputy Chief of Staff of the Army, told the National Guard Association here today that the ground forces' general reserve would have to help train the 650,000 replacements the Army must have in the coming year.

Mayor Impellitteri and Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan would be requested to permit the playing of bingo when conducted by and for the benefit of religious institutions or veteran or charitable organizations under a resolution introduced yesterday into the City Council.

Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., political adviser on the staff of General Dwight D. Eisenhower, announced today from Eisenhower headquarters at the Commodore Hotel that John A. Roosevelt of 895 Park Avenue, youngest son of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, had volunteered his services for the Eisenhower campaign and would make several speeches for the general in New York and New England.

The eightieth anniversary of the founding of the McAuley Water Street Mission was celebrated last night at its present address, at 124-126 Water Street. Hooker Talcott, president of the mission, gave an address of welcome.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Brannan Plan has been the object of intense controversy among farmers and politicians alike since it was first advanced in April, 1949, by the Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan.

A gift of $1,500,000 from Frank Jay Gould for a student building was announced yesterday by Chancellor Henry T. Heald of New York University. Twenty-five hundred students gathered to hear the announcement, which Dr. Heald made from the steps of Gould Memorial Library on the University Heights campus, where the new building will stand.

The Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, despite its problems in Iran, is on the comeback trail. The largest British-owned operating oil company will place in operation today its new oil refinery at Dunkirk, France, to replace that which was virtually destroyed during the spectacular rescue of the British Expeditionary Force in May, 1940.
The United Fruit Company's dry cargo service on the west coast of Central America soon will be improved by the addition of two new foreign-built diesel-powered vessels, the Leon and the Lempa.

PARIS, Oct. 8 (UP) -- An American stockbrokers firm in Paris protested to the United States Embassy today that "extremely unmannerly" French policemen had carried out a mysterious search of their offices.

Seventy - five policemen were continuing last night an investigation into the "suspicious" death early yesterday of a 36-year-old patrolman, whose mangled body was found in a subway tunnel near the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 1:

" HEMINGWAY: THE WRITER AS ARTIST"* is a scholarly critique by Carlos Baker, Professor of English at Princeton University and author of "Shelley's Major Poetry." Here, Hemingway's works are carefully examined, sympathetically expounded, gravely weighed. In compiling his literary appraisal Professor Baker was aided by Hemingway's publishers, letters from Hemingway, friends, and the full scale of earlier critical studies.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, the Iranian Premier, declared in a message that reached London today that he was willing to discuss and settle Iran's dispute with Britain over the Iranian oil industry but he still demanded money from Britain before entering negotiations.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York opened a fund drive for $650,000 with a reception yesterday in the Plaza Hotel for seventeen campaign and cookie sale committees. Mrs. Howard Phipps, the president, announced that $43,000 had been received in advance gifts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today fixed Oct. 28 as the date for a hearing on a plan filed by the American Power and Light Company, New York holding company, for dissolving the company and distributing all of its net assets to its stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast the nation's 1952 cotton crop would be 524,000 bales more than it had estimated a month ago. Nearly ideal weather conditions as the crop came to harvest were the main factor.

He could not have operated as a bookmaker without permission of the police, Harry Gross declared yesterday at the departmental trial of thirty suspended plain-clothes men accused of taking graft from him.

Sharp criticism was leveled yesterday by Meyer Davis, prominent orchestra leader and Broadway "angel," against the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802, an A. F. and L. group of which he is a member, because the union is barring members from being stockholders in shows for which they recruit the orchestra personnel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Army chief of staff, said today he favored telling other North Atlantic Treaty nations what atomic weapons could do.

CINCINNATI, Oct., 8 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles, former heavyweight champion, tonight knocked out Bernie Reynolds of Cliffside, N. J., in 1 minute 40 seconds of the second round of a scheduled twelve-round bout.

BONN, Oct. 8 -- Following talks with Government officials and political party leaders, Dr. Nahum Goldman, chairman of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, expressed the view today that the Arabs would fail to thwart ratification of the $822,000,000 restitutions agreement recently concluded between the West German Government and Israel.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Oct. 8 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Allied Supreme Commander in Europe, will fly to London next Tuesday to attend the annual dinner of the Pilgrims Society, at which he will be the guest of honor, Supreme Allied Headquarters here announced today.

The six-story building with forty-five apartments at 3343 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Alisandrew Realty Corporation, client of Harold Kohn, lawyer, to David Green. The property is assessed at $152,000. Hyman Leff was the broker in the sale, and the buyer was represented by Green Selzer lawyers.

We don't hear so much about the Welsh rabbit these days except as it may appear on the Friday-lunch menus of tea rooms, where it more usually is billed as a Welsh rarebit. John C. Bruno, tall gray-haired restaurateur, thinks it is as such.

Democratic Senators Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, J. William Fulbright of Arkansas and Paul H. Douglas of Illinois sent out telegraphic appeals last night, under their joint signatures, for "huge sums" of money to defray the cost of television and radio broadcasts to insure a Presidential election victory for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois and "challenge Republican broadcasts."
There is a festive air about the table-setting exhibition now on view at Georg Jensen. There are fifteen settings in all, and each has been dedicated to a special holiday or event.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8 -- The Movietime U. S. A. Tours sponsored by the Council of Motion Picture Organizations this week is rounding out one year of activities aimed at stimulating interest in the movies. Although no specific claims are made percentagewise in regard to the effect the tours by stars and other personalities may have had on business receipts, the general belief in the industry is that the campaign has been beneficial

A complete reversal occurred yesterday in the stock market as prices, led by the rails and televisions, scored the widest daily gains in two weeks. The two favored divisions previously had given indication of breaking out of the narrow pattern, especially the electronics.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 8 -- Prime Minister Daniel Malan opened South Africa's first uranium plant at the West Rand Consolidated Mines, near Krugersdorp. He announced that as well as producing uranium, several gold mines would manufacture sulphuric acid, largely used in uranium extraction plants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department predicted today slightly higher poultry prices for consumers next year, with increases for eggs and turkeys more than offsetting declines for chicken.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 8 -- Another attempt will be made to write a civil aviation treaty between the United States and Mexico. The Government has agreed to a Washington request to reopen negotiations, and new talks are expected to begin here soon.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 120,269 today, an increase of 890 since last week.

Armed with soap, scrub brushes and a sound truck, the Columbia University chapter of Youth for Eisenhower urged 400 students yesterday to clean up the "mess in Washington" by electing Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, who is president on leave from the university.

A strangely subdued Michael J. Quill announced yesterday a program of demands for 8,000 workers on nine private bus lines and 45,000 employes of the Board of Transportation but said not a word about strike.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Oct. 8 -- A sparkling round of 40, 37 -- 77 enabled Mrs. Allan Ryan of The Creek Club to score 36 points and win the point-par tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Nassau C. C. today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 8 -- With Palmer Stadium sold out to its capacity of 49,000 seats and the tickt office flooded with requests for reservations for the game, Charley Caldwell said today that Princeton would line up against Pennsylvania here Saturday exactly as it did against Rutgers, both offensively and defensively.

Liberty Music Shops, Inc. was accused yesterday of moving to end price cutting of classical phonograph records in city stores and acting to increase generally the present retail price level of these records. The accusation was made by Abraham M. Lowenthal of 55 Liberty Street, attorney for Sam Goody.

There was a bit of suspense after the running of the $17.475 Frizette Stakes for 2-year-old fillies at Jamaica yesterday. Mrs. E. E. Dale Shaffer's Sweet Patootie finished first, but "official" wasn't flashed on the result board till the stewards had taken a quick look at the movies.

After months of virtual parliamentary deadlock, due largely to the weakness of the governing coalition, the King of Greece has issued a decree dissolving the legislative body and calling for a general election next month.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 8 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois stumped across Wisconsin today, praising the state's political tradition of free inquiry and free debate and calling for the defeat of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, minister of the Marble Collegiate Church, said yesterday that the Democrats had "feasted on power" long enough. He spoke before the New York State meeting of the Daughters of the American Revolution
LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 8 (UP) -- The Kansas University football schedule will not be canceled because Morris Kay, defensive end, has polio, university officials said tonight.

Your valued editorial, "An Unhappy Day," about General Eisenhower's backing of Senator McCarthy, reflects your considered opinion, with which all thoughtful people must agree. Although many believed that General Eisenhower, judging from his military experience, had the stamina to become a leader of our civilian Government, this is today highly doubtful.

A subpoena to appear before the Senate subcommittee investigating communism in the nation's schools was served yesterday on Cyril Graze, 41-year-old public school mathematics teacher, immediately after he had finished making a statement at his departmental trial for insubordination and unbecoming conduct.

JAMESBURG N. J. Oct. 8 -Milton (Babe) Lichardus, assistant to Johnny Farrell at Baltusrol, took a three-stroke lead in the first round of the New Jersey section of the Professional Golfers' Association 72-hole championship with a three-under-par 35, 33 -- 68 over the Forsgate course today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 ---FoHowi;g is t teat of the introductior, to Secretary Gereral Trygvi Li8 anTual report to the United Natio General Assembly:

" The World in His Arms," a romantic period adventure in Technicolor, produced by Universal-International and starring Gregory Peck and Ann Blyth, is the film attraction opening today at the Mayfair. Raoul Walsh directed and Aaron Rosenberg produced from a script by Borden Chase, additional dialogue by Horace McCoy and the novel by Rex Beach.

The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, will be the beneficiary of the forty-fifth annual exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York, to be held on Nov. 6 through 8 in the Colonnades Ballroom of Essex House. Mrs. W. Redmond Cross is president of the Horticultural Society.

" The Consul," Gian-Carlo Menotti's opera which ran on Broadway for seven months in 1950, entered the repertoire of the New York City Opera Company at the City Center last night. Once again its sincerity and compassion moved an audience to spontaneous demonstrations of enthusiasm.

Permit me to add my voice to the clamor for action toward the Fifth Avenue Coach Company. E. Frank's letter expresses very well the anger which many of us feel over the indifferent inefficiency of this favored company.

Teen-agers in hundreds of schools throughout the country will be asked this year to consider just what part they play financially in their families and perhaps to estimate, in dollars and cents, just how much they cost their parents. The calculating will be part of a study of money management included in home economics classes using material prepared by the Institute of Life Insurance, 488 Madison Avenue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Twenty-three witnesses were called today to testify before President Truman's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization. All but three assailed the McCarran-Walter Immigration Law.
Each member of the Yankees received $6,176.51 for his share in winning the world series.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 9 -- The Korean armistice talks have gone into an indefinite recess without the slightest indication that either the United Nations or the Communists have any plan for ending the deadlock on the repatriation of war prisoners, which both sides say is the only issue blocking peace.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 8 -- Members of The Hill School's varsity football squad sprinted the length of Dell Field at the close of today's practice, howling at the tops of their lungs. The demonstration was unexpected but it caused Ned Hall, the school's new headmaster, to chuckle. "
Postal officials have begun preparations to assure Christmas "mail call" for the men and women of the armed forces on or before the holiday.

Marine Midland Corporation and its constituent banks and affiliate in the third quarter of this year had consolidated net operating earnings of $1,632,243, or 28 cents a share on 5,848,953 common shares outstanding on Sept. 30. The figures compare with $1,527,028, or 27 cents a share on 5,583,800 shares outstanding, for the similar quarter of 1951.

I have been a resident of New York City for the past five years. I live in Manhattan, and I voted in the last national election. Within the past few days I was notified by the firm which employs me that I was being sent to Los Angeles on a business trip which would require my presence there during the entire registration period.

In connection with your special dispatch of Oct. 3 from Washington based on a report released by the Department of Commerce regarding the "feasibility" of producing newsprint from sugar cane bagasse, it may interest you to know that the Mexican daily Ultimas Noticias printed its issue of June 24 entirely with paper from sugar cane waste material produced in the paper factory of Catalan-born Antonio Bayarte of Mexico City.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie reported to the United Nations General Assembly today that "no one can be sure today that we can succeed in preventing a third world war." He added that the very dangers with which the world was faced "make the United Nations more important than ever in the struggle for peace and security."
Retailers, who are now opening their stores more than one night a week are hurting themselves and are returning the retail business to the "dark ages."

With the engagement of Morton Da Costa as director, Albert Selden plans to go into "immediate production" with "The Grey Eyed People," the new comedy by John Hess, former magazine, television and fiction writer.

Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois described Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio yesterday, as Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "political mother-in-law." He gave his opinion of the Ohio Senator's relationship to the Republican Presidential candidate on his arrival at La Guardia Airport, en route to Connecticut, khere he will campaign for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Oct. 8 -- The Americanism of the management of General Electric Company was questioned today by the executive vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in an attack on the company's labor policies before the recent convention of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O.
OSWEGO, N. Y., Oct 8 (AP) -Senator Irving M. Ives said tonight that in foreign policy "it is high time we had someone in the White House who knows what is going on."
Brooklyn-born Tommy Holmes, who got into his second world series this year as a result of being fired as manager of the Braves, returned to the Boston organization and to managing yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 8 -- On orders of the Paris military tribunal the police raided the offices of Communist party newspapers and allied organizations today in Paris and eight other major cities.
DENVER, Oct. 8 (UP) -- Senate Republican "truth" spokesmen said today that President Truman had "taken over Adlai Stevenson, lock, stock, and barrel."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- A 92 per cent block of the voting stock of American President Lines will be advertised tomorrow for public sale, it was announced here today at a joint press conference held by Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce; George Killion, president of the Government-operated company, and R. Stanley Dollar, shipping official.
Following are the texts of addresses by President Truman in Shenandoah, Iowa, yesterday afternoon and in Jefferson City, Mo., last night, as carried by The Associated Press:

HONG KONG, Oct. 8 -- A Supreme Court decision, handed down here today by Chief Justice Sir Gerald L. Howe, stripped Red China of title to thirty-one more former Chinese Nationalist aircraft parked at Hong Kong's Kaitak Airfield.

The Lehman Corporation's net ordinary income for the three months ended Sept. 30, first quarter of its fiscal year, amounted to $1,049,395, against $999,465 in the corresponding quarter of 1951, Robert Lehman, president, disclosed yesterday in an interim report to stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UP) -- The first of America's new Mariner class cargo ships, described as the fastest and largest in the world, was delivered today to the United States Maritime Administration.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 8 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama accused Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower here tonight of parading "from one state to the next warmly embracing the arch-isolationists and reactionaries."
PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Lord Ismay, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's first Secretary General, has asked the members of that democratic alliance to devise for it an emblem and a flag.

When the United Nations General Assembly opens its deliberations here in New York on Oct. 14 the delegates and officials will find nearly all of the work completed on United Nations Plaza, the refurbished street arrangement, costing $10,505,000, from Forty-second to Forty-eighth Street on Manhattan's East Side adjacent to the United Nations home.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 8 -- L. R. Boulware, vice president of employe relations for the General Electric Company, said tonight that "the greatest danger to defense production at General Electric right now" was a strike threat by James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O."

FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Minister President August Zinn of Hesse said today that United States authorities had sponsored, but later had ordered dissolved, a secret German sabotage group trained to go into action should the Russians overrun Germany.

It has long been a complaint of practitioners of the art -- or craft -- compendiously treated by Vitruvius, that the most neglected item of information about a building in this city is the name of the architect.

SHENANDOAH, Iowa, Oct. 8 -- President Truman accused Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today of "the baldest attempt to steal" the Democratic party's record of price support policies, which, the President said, had assured the farmers prosperity for twenty years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The United States rejected today as invalid a demand by the Soviet Union for the recall of George F. Kennan as United States Ambassador to Moscow.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Massachusetts Republican, set forth today before the twenty-sixth annual convention of the Propeller Club a four-point program to end what he called the nation's "feast-or-famine maritime policy."

DETROIT, Oct. 8 (UP) -- The National Hockey League and Stanley Cup champions, the Detroit Red Wings, with a newcomer leading the big production line, will open the 1952-53 season tomorrow night against the New York Rangers.
A change in regulations since World War II now permits service men and women to wear civilian clothes in off-duty hours. This has brought about a kind of "invisible army"

Following are the texts of addresses by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois in the Field House at the University of Wisconsin in Madison, Wis., yesterday afternoon and in the Milwaukee Arena last night, as carried by The Associated Press:
BONN, Germany, Oct. 8 -- Life has been made easier for the seven top Nazis serving war crimes sentences in Spandau Prison in Berlin, the Western Allies announced tonight.

A banking syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation, Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Goldman, Sachs Co. will offer to investors today a new issue of $60,000,000 of 4 3/8 per cent sinking fund debentures of United Gas Corporation due Oct. 1, 1972, at 102.35 to yield about 4.2 per cent to maturity.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- For a few minutes this afternoon a four-block stretch of Montgomery Street, the "Wall Street of the West" looked about as it did on a mid-April day of 1951 When a blizzard of ticker tape, confetti and torn telephone books enveloped General of the Army Douglas MacArthur on his way to Washington, after having been dismissed from his Far Eastern commands.

Registration of voters for the Nov. 4 election seems to be booming everywhere. Whether this means that the nation is going Republican or staying Democratic, or is abnormally aroused by a heated Presidential campaign, this showing of a record-breaking interest of the people in taking part in the governmental process is healthy and inspiring.

Forty sailors from the Naval Supply Depot at Bayonne, N. J., will make a mass donation today at 10 A. M. at the Red Cross Blood Donor Center, 70 West Fortieth Street, for two young victims of hemophilia.

The City planning Commission made public yesterday a proposed capital budget for 1953 of $478,920,523 that allocated no funds for the proposed Second Avenue subway project or extensions of the Utica and Nostrand Avenue subway lines in Brooklyn.

The United States -- and what might be called American opinion -- are coming in for some sharp criticism from sensitive friends with whom we disagree. Our Paris correspondent tells us that the French Cabinet. "severely criticized" United States policy in North African affairs, when Tunisia and Morocco were discussed in Paris on Tuesday.
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 9 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,397, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (UP) -- Athletic Director Ed (Moose) Krause of Notre Dame predicted today that the National Collegiate Athletic Association would be "killed," if a plan to "share the wealth" from football television were approved at the next convention.

The elegance of brass and woods handcrafted in sculptural and structural forms characterizes a new collection of lamps available through decorators at the Heifetz Company. 16 East Fifty-third Street. Contemporary in appearance, the lamps are designed by Yasha Heifetz, some jointly with Bernard Fischer, who also molds and curves the brass rods used for several of the bases.
CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 8 (AP) -The State Supreme Court today cleared Hugh Gregg, Republican nominee for Governor, of charges that he had made excess expenditures in his primary campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Democratic National Committee dubbed the Republican opposition today "the kerosene lamp party" as it quoted from the record to attack an assertion that the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress had done more for rural electrification "than all other Congresses put together."

MERCERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 9 -- There seemed to be something strange about the goings-on at Mercersburg Academy this afternoon. The football squad was practicing on the jayvee field while the school band was working out on the varsity gridiron. Had the band been playing football, it would have presented quite a problem to opponents. No two boys were dressed alike.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Friday, Oct. 10 -- President Chiang Kai-shek, in a broadcast on the eve of Nationalist China's "Double Tenth" anniversary, told his countrymen last night both in Formosa and on the China mainland that the Nationalists had made a successful comeback since the dark days of 1949.

BONN Germany, Oct. 9 -- Authoritative officials here privately confirmed today that the United States had sponsored and helped finance the secret training of young Germans, including many former soldiers, to become guerrilla fighters in the event of a war with the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- It was suggested today that President Truman grant full pardon and amnesty to all persons who violated the immigration laws prior to June, 1952, to protect them against retroactive provisions of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act, which becomes effective Dec. 24.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 10 -- South Korean infantrymen early today fought their way back to the crest of "White Horse Hill" on the central Korean front, after four days of see-saw combat, in which the position had changed hands sixteen times.

Politics took a new turn yesterday at the state Citizens for Eisenhower-Nixon headquarters. There was a unanimity of judgment and confident appreciation of events probably unparalleled in campaign annals and it was expressed in a new idiom.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 9 -- Deploring the failure of Congress to follow up the exposures and recommendations of the Senate Crime Investigation Committee, the American Prison Association today called for legislation that will "effectively control the operation of gangsters and racketeers in all of their nefarious activities."
The continued success in Paris of "Sur la Terre Comme au Ciel," (On Earth As It Is in Heaven) has forced Margaret Webster to defer its local unveiling until the season of 1953-54.

Adele Simpson commentated at a presentation of her fall designs from Bonwit Teller at a luncheon yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. "Direct" was a word used frequently by this designer in describing her creations, which ranged from coordinated ensembles of brushed wool to elegant evening gowns of soft peau d'ange.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- The National Boxing Association noted today that foreign fighters dominated at least four of the eight weight divisions and blamed television for having curbed the development of young boxers in the United States.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower tonight proposed limited programs of Federal aid to help Americans meet emergency medical bills and properly educate their children. In a major speech outlining his idea of the economic opportunities that beckon to the American people, the Republican Presidential nominee declared that an essential step was to make "equality of opportunity a living fact for every American regardless of race, color or creed."
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama praised the Democratic formula for prosperity tonight and said the Republican Presidential candidate failed to understand it.

Aside from reddening a few noses and sending shivers along brightly costumed spines, the chill breezes that blew through Wall Street yesterday noon did no damage at all to the sprightly and unusual United Service Organizations-Camp Shows performance there. Augmented by Ezio Pinza, Lucy Monroe, Noble Sissle, Eubie Blake and Bert Lytell, a Europe-bound camp show unit entertained a crowd of nearly 7,000 persons for an hour and a quarter.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- A draft Convention on the Political Rights of Women, which has been under discussion in various units of the United Nations since 1946, was issued today in its final form, as a memorandum from the office of Secretary General Trygve Lie.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- Representatives of twelve major New York department stores told the Public Service Commission today they were considering a return to private generating plants because of the increases in commercial and industrial electric rates granted the Consolidated Edison Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 4 were 5 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

Net retail sales of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 2 were 5 per cent below the record volume attained in the preceding year, while net earnings declined to $2,792,554 from $5,265,924.

Following are the prepared text of an address by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson yesterday afternoon at Kansas City, as reported by The Associated Press, and the text of his address last night at St. Louis, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

BONN, Germany, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. George F. Kennan flew from Moscow to Bonn with her two small children today and rejoined her husband, the United States Ambassador Russia said was persona non grata (unwelcome) last week.
Buyers and jobbers continued yesterday to keep order-writing at a high level at the seventh annual National Hardware Show at Grand Central Palace.

Harry Gross, imprisoned bookmaker, lost his self-control on the second day of cross-examination and ranted for nearly ten minutes on the witness stand yesterday against the thirty suspended policemen who are being tried for allegedly taking graft from him.

Plans for a complete shake-up and change in the way of doing business by the New York Stock Exchange were revealed yesterday by Richard M. Crooks, chairman of the board, in an address given in Pasadena, Calif., sponsored by the Los Angeles Stock Exchange.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 9 -- The Parliament of Lebanon voted today, by an overwhelming majority, dictatorial decree-making powers for six months to Premier Khaled Shehab.

A request to include Harlem in the list of proposed areas for extension of the alternate-side-of-the-street parking plan early next year was made yesterday by Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain in a letter to Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.
Straight lines for day and more flowing lines for evening were shown in the Christian Dior fashions presented by Saks Fifth Avenue at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

A resolution "deploring" the President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization as "a usurpation of the legislative powers of Congress" was adopted yesterday by the New York State conference of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

DETROIT, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay, the new Red Wing captain, scored his 188th goal in the National Hockey League for a new team record as the champion Detroit team opened the 1952-53 season with a 5-3 victory tonight over the New York Rangers before 11,039 fans.

The resignation of James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers (C. I. O.), from three Government security groups in protest against the award of defense contracts to the General Electric Company focuses attention on the vital problem of what to do about Communist-dominated unions in security-sensitive defense plants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The United States has promised France a total of $525,000,000 of "defense support" and other economic aid this fiscal year. It has suggested that the amount could be increased somewhat if France stepped up her relative contribution to the European defense effort.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 -- Frank Wilkinson, City Housing Authority official suspected of Communist ties, will be questioned "in private" when the California Senate Committee on Un-American Activities continues its investigation of the C. H. A. here soon.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- William G. (Big Bill) Lias' accountant swore today that he knew of no instance in which the 400-pound West Virginia gambler had "falsified" his income tax returns.

LIVERPOOL, England, Friday, Oct. 10 (UP) -- A teen-age footman at the Earl of Derby's country home "went berserk" with a submachine gun last night, killing two other servants and wounding the countess and a third servant, police announced early today.

President Truman will arrive here on his special train tonight to end his two-week whistle-stop tour of the nation with four speeches in the metropolitan area. He will deliver a major address on civil rights tomorrow afternoon in Harlem, and another speech tomorrow night at a Columbus Day celebration in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, called today for a general labor boycott of the processes of the Taft-Hartley Act as the best means of forcing repeal of the law.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday adoption of a new type consolidated bond as the basis for a simplified ten-year financing program estimated to cost $500,000,000, including a proposed $200,000,000 two-way trans-Hudson tunnel, as well as the authorized third tube for the Lincoln Tunnel.

Fifty-two local housing authorities offering $116,354,000 of notes to finance projects backed by the Public Housing Administration received only a scattering of bids for the notes yesterday because acceptable offers were limited by the P. H. A. to an interest cost of 1.2 per cent.

Alexander Kotov of Russia met with another semi-reverse at the hands of Gideon Stahlberg of Sweden in the fifteenth round of the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, yesterday, according to a report from Sweden.

Coach Steve Owen pronounced the New York Football Giants 'a's fit as they can be" for Sunday's big game with the Browns at Cleveland after his squad's final hard workout of the week at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
Randolph Hokanson, pianist, gave a recital in Town Hall last evening, playing a new sonata by James Beale and works of Bach, Chopin and Bartok.

A profile of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin will be published Monday by Beacon Press, entitled "l%cCarthy: The Man, The Senator. The 'Ism'." The authors, Jack Northman Anderson and Ronald W. May, analyze Senator McCarthy's political life and his methods and supply answers to 'some questions' about his activities.

A false alarm turned in by a mischievous boy gave Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet an unexpected opportunity yesterday to study at first hand the operations of his department in Coney Island, where strong protests have been lodged against the recent discontinuance of an engine company.

The years have not dealt kindly with "Mr. and Mrs. North," the vivacious couple who back in the Nineteen Thirties made their first appearance in the pages of The New Yorker. They've been adapted and re-adapted for stage, screen and radio. Now they're going through the television wringer.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 9 -- The Long Island Rail Road reorganization committee of the Long Island Association requested the Interstate Commerce Commission today to postpone until next year proposed hearings on reorganization plans for the bankrupt line. All other interested groups had asked immediate hearings.

Rayon and acetate yarn and staple shipments in September totaled 108,900,000 pounds, a decline of 4 1/2 per cent compared to the previous month, but 32 per cent greater than shipments in September, 1951, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. Shipments in the first nine months of the year totaled 860,600,000 pounds, a loss of 9 per cent compared to the January-September period of 1951.

BUFFALO, Oct. 9 -- President Truman asserted tonight that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential candidate, and his running mate, Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, favored immigration laws that discriminated against the people of Eastern and Southern Europe.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 10 -- South Korean troops recaptured the bloody crest of White Horse Hill today for the tenth time in less than four days with a ten-minute bayonet charge that sent a Chinese battalion streaming back down the mountain's northern slope.

SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 9 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told an enthusiastic audience here today that the changes in the Moscow line noticeable in statements by Premier Stalin and other Soviet leaders at the Soviet Communist party congress were the direct result of the gathering strength of the Western world.

An exhibition that should prove as interesting to local residents as to those of the foreign countries for which it was prepared opens today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Called "Handcrafts in the United States," it is one of four displays arranged under the auspices of the United States Department of State by the American Craftsmen's Educational Council to be sent on tour through Europe, the Middle and Far East and South America.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 9 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio admonished Republicans today not to "underestimate" President Truman even though he was an "expert in demagoguery."
Sergeants generally have not been noted for handing out bouquets. But this word of appreciation for the United Service Organizatians from a staff sergeant stationed in the South came as no surprise.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois ridiculed and scorned Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower all the way across Missouri today and ended up here tonight by promising the American people a rosier future than anything they had known in the past.

Walter Hoving, president of Bonwit Teller and chairman of the board of the Fifth Avenue Association, cited Federal Reserve figures yesterday to show that department store sales here between January and Sept. 27 were 9 per cent lower than in the corresponding period last year.

The Protestant Council of the City of New York expressed "amazement" yesterday at a resolution introduced into the City Council on Wednesday that would sanction the playing of bingo for the benefit of religious, charitable or veterans organizations. The proposal was referred to the committee on general welfare of the city body.

The chair situation in 1952 was discussed and dramatized at a luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group in the Astor Hotel yesterday. Dedicated to the proposition that position is everything in life, the program was introduced by Alfred Auerbach, home furnishings consultant, who outlined the development of the chair, and was brought to a climax with a "fashion show" of thirty-one available seating designs.

There was much more of Japan than a Japanese locale in last night's performance of "Madame Butterfly" at the City Center. The Japanese roles were taken by Japanese members of the visiting Fujiwara Opera Company of Tokyo, and they had with them their own costumes, props and ideas about acting.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9 -- Three Harvard University professors today undertook a nation-wide campaign to raise funds among faculty members of United States colleges and universities for the defeat of Senators Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin and William E. Jenner of Indiana in the coming elections.

In Joppa, Ill., across the Ohio River from Paducah, Ky., the first unit of one of the nation's largest electric generating plants is scheduled to begin turning out vital power by the end of this year for the Atomic Energy Commission.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Domestic shares responded with selected small rises on the Stock Exchange today to the lifting of a threat of a ban on overtime and piece work in the engineering industry. Engineering shares rose a few pence, as did British Government securities and industrial shares generally on the strength of the staving-off of the risk of dislocation of defense and export programs.

One new film opens at a first-run theatre this morning. At the Palace is "My Wife's Best Friend," a romantic comedy starring Anne Baxter and Macdonald Carey, from Twentieth Century-Fox. Featured in the cast are Cecil Kellaway, Casey Adams, Catherine McLeod, Leif Erickson, Frances Bavier, Mary Sullivan and Martin Milner. Isobel Lennart wrote the screen play, based on a story by John Briard Harding. Richard Sale was the director and Robert Bassler produced.

THIRTY-ONE years ago, when Lytton Strachey's "Queen Victoria" was published, many delighted readers were so startled and impressed by Strachey's point of view that they often overlooked the masterly grace of his prose. Here was an attitude which expressed to perfection that yearning for sophistication, for worldly poise and ironic mockery, for cultivated rejection of all things conventional, respectable and Victorian, which swept fashionable and intellectual circles after the first World War.

Completion of the $573,970 combination storm and sanitary sewer in Bayside Hills, Queens, will cost the taxpayers $28,569 more than the original contract, it developed yesterday when bids were opened by I. Robert Bassin, assistant to Borough President James A. Lundy

The board of the Port of New York Authority awarded yesterday the first contract for materials for the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel. The contract, amounting to $10,620,971, went to the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the low bidder, and provides for the delivery of 46,275 tons of cast iron and steel for the tunnel segments.

Paris in the spring, Parris Island in the fall. That was the talk last evening aboard a Baltimore and Ohio train that carried a 20-year-old Frenchman and forty other Marine Corps recruits to their training station in South Carolina.

CAIRO, Oct. 8 -- The Rev. Dr. Etienne Drioton, an Egyptologist of world repute, was dismissed tonight by the Egyptian Cabinet from his post as director general of the Department of Egyptian Antiquities in the Ministry of Education. He was the last remaining foreign director general in the Egyptian Government.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- Delegates to the annual convention of the American Humane Association called on the organization's board of directors today to censure the New York City branch of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals for "tacit approval" of a law that permitted the seizure of unclaimed animals for research purposes.

Ever since seven persons were killed in a tenement-house fire on Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, last June, the city has recoiled with horror at the thought of the possibility of any repetition of this holocaust. A special Mayor's committee headed by Robert Moses has recommended both short-range and long-range steps toward improving the old tenement-building situation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- John M. Redding, Assistant Postmaster General and a former publicity chief of the Democratic National Committee, told the Women's National Club today that newspapers, magazines, radio and other communication media were preponderantly Republican-"angled" by editors and advertisers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- The Army issued a call today for 47,000 more draftees in December but ordered them processed during the first two weeks of the month in order not to dampen the Christmas spirit.

In an effort to stem the flood of off-quality natural rubber which has inundated the United States market since World War II, two hundred rubber manufacturers will meet at the Statler Hotel for a two-day seminar beginning Tuesday. They plan to examine critically their buying and inspection practices.

DENVER, Oct. 9 -- The New York National Guard delegation was defeated here today by 501 to 219 in a move to endorse involuntary assignment of returning selectees to military units for the remaining six years of obligatory Reserve service they must perform under the law.

The cost of electric current for all city agencies and services, now $14,000,000 a year, will be increased by $1,900,000 a year under a contract with the utilities approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Federal Communications Commission told the Volunteers for Stevenson today that, lacking "specific information," it could not act on a charge that the Republicans planned a country-wide radio and television "blitz" in the closing days of the election campaign.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The death toll in yesterday's triple train wreck at Harrow and Wealdstone station, a few miles northwest of London, mounted to at least ninety-eight tonight. Ninety more persons lie in hospital seriously injured.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 -- The Great Hall of the Kremlin echoed Thursday with a stormy ovation tendered by the Communist party's Nineteenth Congress in response to a pledge by a North Korean spokesman of that country's full determination "to achieve final victory over the hated enemy -- the American interventionists."
Governor Dewey said last night that a revolt within Communist China was "entirely possible," and he expressed the hope that if a revolt occurred the United States would "do nothing to discourage it."

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 9 (AP) The Dairymen's League Cooperative Association renewed an old battle today with vegetable oil manufacturers and called for a united front by dairymen to fight the sale of imitation milk products.

There was little in the way of class at the Jamaica race track yesterday, but that small fact was overlooked by the 17,691 fans who attended. Despite the paucity of quality there was interesting competition, and those who refused to abide by the book in their selecting had a little the better of it in their jousts with the mutuel machines.

The Queens asphalt plant in Flushing is "one of the worst violators of smoke regulations in the city." William G. Christy, director of the Bureau of Smoke Control, charged yesterday in a letter to Borough President James A. Lundy, whose office operates the facility.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Kentucky's football coach, Paul Bryant, underwent an appendectomy tonight at Good Samaritan Hospital.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Israel has agreed to the release of all blocked bank accounts belonging to Palestinean Arab refugess, a sum estimated at $14,000,000 to $15,000,000.

THE first report on coastal waterfowl shooting comes from Maine, which opened for duck and goose shooting on Oct. 1, and although local black ducks provided excellent shooting during the first three days, there seems to be something of a lull in wildfowling right now.

Sister Joan Marie Ryan, 38-year-old Bronx-born missionary of the Maryknoll Sisters, who had been held prisoner by the Chinese Communists for twenty months, arrived yesterday at La Guardia Airport on her way to the order's mother house at Maryknoll, N. Y.

A method that makes it possible to produce cortisone out of simple, readily available chemicals, assuring an abundant supply of this wonder-working hormone of the adrenal gland, is announced in the current issue of The Journal of the American Chemical Society.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Successful human use of pills as a method of birth control was reported today by Dr. Benjamin Sieve, who, while asserting he had preliminary success with them, declared further extensive studies must be made "before the general use of this anti-fertility factor is warranted."

Production of raw steel by domestic mills during September amounted to 9,034,000 net tons, the highest output ever achieved for a thirty-day month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Following is the text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's address in Los Angeles last night as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- John Cashmore, Democratic candidate for the Senate, today attacked his Republican opponent, Senator Irving M. Ives as an "undercover man for reactionary, private gain interests" and a "Taft in sheep's clothing."

Preferred stockholders of Gar Wood Industries, Inc., will receive a sizable dividend on Nov. 13 when the company will pay $2.81 1/4 cents a share, covering four quarterly dividends which had been in arrears as well as with the current quarterly payment. E. F. Fisher, president, reported following yesterday's board meeting that sales for the fiscal year ending on Oct. 31 are expected to exceed $53,000,000.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 9 -- With the agreement of the Mexican Government, the Rockefeller Foundation will try to do for livestock and poultry production here what its agricultural program has already achieved in Mexico for production and the improvement of grains and vegetables.
Eighty-eight singers, nine of them new to the company, will be heard in Metropolitan Opera performances during the coming season, Rudolf Bing, general manager, announced yesterday.

Following is a summary of the New York City registration, by Assembly Districts, as compared with the four days' registration in 1950, when a Governor, Senator and Mayor were elected, and in the 1948 and 1944 Presidential years:

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 9 -- Buoyed by an enthusiastic welcome to Senator Richard M. Nixon Monday night, Rhode Island Republicans are demonstrating an optimism they have not shown since the party last carried this state in a national election, for Calvin Coolidge, in 1924.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 9 -- An investigation by the Connecticut Medical Society into conditions at Danbury Hospital surrounding the suspension from its staff of two prominent Danbury physicians. Dr. John D. Booth and Dr. Nathaniel B. Selleck, was recommended late today by the board of censors of the Fairfield County Medical Society.

ATLANTA, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Atlanta Journal, the South's largest newspaper, announced today its support of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic nominee for President. It said that he was not its choice for the nomination, but added:
