The New York County Lawyers Association was told yesterday that the proposed Constitutional amendment to limit the President's power to make treaties and executive agreements would seriously hamper the work of the United Nations and imperil the historic method by which this country has grown great.
Pan American-Grace Airways reported yesterday that $50,000 in cash had been stolen from a big four-engined passenger airliner, apparently as it winged its way from Miami to Lima, Peru.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 9 -- The Cinerama Corporation, sponsors of the new motion-picture projection system that is thrilling New York audiences, is going into production of story pictures on its own and is completing arrangements for filming a program of four features. Merian C. Cooper, who helped the company put together its experimental entertainment program, has been signed to a five-year contract as general manager in charge of production.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Three horses reached the wire only necks apart in the $5,000 Bethesda Purse today, and it was Brookfield Farms' Iswas who gained the decision. The 4-year-old gelding returned $7.80 for $2 after running the mile in 1.38 1/5.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 -- The famed Pripet marshes, whose tangled bogs and desolate depths have trapped more than one invader of Russia from the west, are to be replaced by fertile grainfields in the next few years.
A large exhibition of work by contemporary American sculptors illustrating Jewish and biblical themes is now on view at the Jewish Museum, where it will continue through November.

The stock market lost most of Wednesday's rallying power yesterday but, encouraged by the railroads, managed to maintain a strong position. In terms of stock movements the emphasis was on those with gains, yet the composite rate slipped back 0.18 points on the day.

It is customary and good politics for candidates for election to local office to visit all of the polling places they possibly can during Registration Week. Monday night I visited 36 election district polling places in my own Ninth Assembly District. I was thrilled with the determination of our citizens to qualify themselves to vote, evidenced by the tremendous numbers that came out to register.
Housewives may have to shuffle menus and buying habits this week to keep within their budget limits on meat and eggs.

While wool blends have made some progress in the men's suit field, there has been a decline in the percentage of regular weight suits made of rayon and other synthetic fibers this fall, according to a survey released yesterday by the Wool Bureau, Inc.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- The Pennsylvania Motor Truck Association charged today that railroads in Pennsylvania do not pay their fair share of taxes.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, the new president of City College, and 1,200 members of the uptown student body engaged in an unusual first meeting yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday, and lost 13 to 32 points on the day.

A new four-day registration record was set in the city yesterday, but enrollment lagged materially on the fourth day and the over-all increase over the previous record of 1944 was only 212,175. The registration for four days was 2,186,062, compared with 1,973,887 for the Presidential contest of eight years ago.

CAIRO, Oct. 9 -- British military authorities announced today that custody of the El Firdan bridge across the Suez Canal was being returned to the Egyptian Army. The bridge is eight miles north of Ismailia.
LONDON, Oct. 9 -- After waiting seventeen years, Londoners saw George Gershwin's "Porgy and Bess' tonight and they loved it.

Earl Browder, formerly this nation's chief Communist, and his Russian-born wife, Mrs. Raissa Irene Berkman Browder, were released on bail yesterday after nine days in jail. They previously had been unable to raise the $2,500 bail set for each after a Federal indictment charging perjury.

It is the height of inconsistency for those who favored Ike's nomination as one who could unite the various elements in the country now to cry out because he has given some support to McCarthy and Jenner.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- During the week ended Oct. 8 member bank reserves increased $141,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- The International Harvester Company and officials of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., reached an agreement today for ending a ten-week strike at the company's plant in suburban Melrose Park. The strike made 4,900 workers idle and delayed shipment of finished Army equipment to Korea.

The Board of Estimate authorized yesterday a $400,000 transfer of funds within the Police Department budget to provide 200 civilian employes to replace a like number of policemen now performing clerical and other non-police duties.

For the first time in medical history a human patient has been supplied with an artificial heart-valve made of plastic. The patient, a 30-year-old housewife, who three weeks ago was in constant danger of sudden death, is now back home reportedly doing "very well," according to information received here yesterday.
Following are the prepared texts of addresses by President Truman in Cleveland yesterday afternoon and Buffalo last night, as prepared by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Howard L. Doyle, United-States Attorney for the Southern District of Illinois, told a House of Representatives subcommittee today that his income tax returns should be referred to the Bureau of Internal Revenue and the Department of Justice for investigation,
The Republicans have their McCarthy. The Democrats have their Truman.
Angry charges were exchanged yesterday in the examination of two witnesses at a departmental trial of a teacher suspected of being a member of the Communist party.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- More than 1,500 persons will attend a dinner for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican nominee for re-election, to be held here Oct. 27. This was announced today by the "McCarthy Broadcast D i n n e r" committee.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 9 -- The Pakistan Moslem League, the country's ruling political party, will open a four-day conference in Dacca, East Pakistan, tomorrow. It will deal with problems facing the nation and especially with just what to do about Kashmir if the Security Council is unable to solve the situation.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- The United States Government has told Premier Pinay that it cannot now promise that France will receive in the fiscal year ending next June the approximately $650,000,000 of budget-supporting aid upon which the French have counted for 1953.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The installation of Diesel locomotives has brought about the most rapid changeover in a type of motive power in the history of transportation, the president of the Association of American Railroads said here today.
Steve (Ike) Eisenhauer, Navy guard, is the lineman of the week. -4. husky 200-pounder from Sheffield, P, Eisenhauer yesterday easily wonne Associated Press first llnems_ poll of the football season.

Loans to business by New York banks reached a new high level last week, advancing $54,000,000 to reach a total of $7,986,000,000. The increase, which reflected seasonal influences, lifted commercial credits outstanding $19,000,000 above the previous peak of last March 19.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- A sixteen-story building, whose design is something between that of the United Nations headquarters in New York and Le Corbusier's Radiant City in Marseille, has been approved by an internation architects panel as the central edifice for the permanent headquarters of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in Paris.

A smiling, 17-year-old blue-eyed blonde was seized yesterday as the alleged leader of a gang that in the last three weeks had stolen $10,000 in a series of hold-ups of hotels and an A. P. grocery store.

Milgrim's "Flair for Fashion Club," which will be devoted to helping the career girl select her wardrobe, opened last evening with a fall fashion show on the store's third floor. Membership cards were made available on which to list name, business address, phone number, size, style and color preference.
TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,398 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The board of directors of Interlake Iron Corporation voted today to purchase Mather Iron Company's 30 per cent interest in the Dalton Ore Company. This would give Interlake sole ownership of Dalton, its principal iron ore supplier.
Montreal, Canada, announced yesterday that it will receive bids Oct. 21 on $5,170,000 of local improvement bonds dated Oct. 1, 1952, and due Oct. 1, 1953 to 1971.

JAMESBURG, N. J., Oct. 9 -- Milton (Babe) Lichardus, assistant pro at Baltusrol, added an even-par 71 to his first round of 68 for a 36-hole total of 139 to retain the lead by a stroke as the halfway mark was reached in the New Jersey Professional Golf Association's championship over the Forsgate course today.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 9 -- Federal Judge Albert Bryan held today that the Government might repossess the surplus oil tanker Meacham on the ground the vessel had been unlawfully transferred to a corporation financed by Chinese aliens.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Net working capital of American corporations had climbed to a new high level of $85,700,000,000 by the end of June, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The figure represents a rise of $1,600,000,000 compared with the end of the first quarter of this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Supreme Court will not rule on the constitutionality of segregating Negroes from white students in public schools until after the Presidential election. This was made certain today when it issued an order postponing arguments on the issues to Dec. 8.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission announced today that it had accepted as correct the audit submitted by Herman Taylor, boxing promoter, on the number of tickets and receipts for the Joe Walcott-Rocky Marciano heavyweight title fight here Sept. 23.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 9 (AP) -- W. E. Brown's Bank Coal, a 3-year-old Apache colt, won the Executives Purse at Garden State Park today, defeating Allison Prestridge's Dark Count by a head. Censorship was third.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Wheat futures showed a fairly strong tone today, but corn and oats worked lower because of selling pressure. Soybeans declined under increasing hedge pressure. Wheat's strength was attributed to the dry weather in the West and Southwest and on the report that 262,000,000 bushels had been placed under loan through Sept. 15, the largest impounding on record for that date.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, if elected President, would not face the same opposition from Congress as has President Truman, Vice President Alben W. Barkley said last night on the Columbia Broadcasting System's television program, "Pick the Winner."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 851,866 cars, the Association of American Railroads reported today. This was 10,195 cars, or 1.2 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 6,891 cars, or 0.8 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 12,037 cars, or 1.4 per cent, less than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Potato traders settled down yesterday to wait for the Oct. 1 crop estimate of the Department of Agriculture, due to be published after the close of the market today, but the effects of the "potato shortage" reported by news agencies on Tuesday and Wednesday continued to be noticeable.
Yale concedes that Columbia will be the favorite in their thirtieth football meeting at the Bowl in New Haven tomorrow.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- The police raids on Communist newspapers and front organizations, including the Union of French Republican Youth, yesterday were reported today to have produced important documents showing Communist propaganda plans for demoralizing the French Army in France and in Indo-China.

Now is the time in New York's Italian neighborhoods when sidewalk wine grape "shops" spring up overnight. For the next two months or so thirty-six-pound boxes of Concords and forty-two-pound boxes of Tokays and other wine grapes will be offered the home wine-makers.

Walter A. Lynch, acting Democratic State Chairman, charged yesterday that Governor Dewey had attempted to raise a false racial and religious issue in attacking the Democratic Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates for running under a "white supremacy" label in Alabama.

On several occasions recently you have taken the position that the Thirtieth Street Overhead Expressway should be built promptly. I find it difficult to understand what seems to me to be a very dogmatic attitude on your part on this question.

Walter A. Lynch, acting Democratic State Chairman, charged yesterday that Governor Dewey had attempted to raise a false racial and religious issue in attacking the Democratic Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates for running under a "white supremacy" label in Alabama.

On several occasions recently you have taken the position that the Thirtieth Street Overhead Expressway should be built promptly. I find it difficult to understand what seems to me to be a very dogmatic attitude on your part on this question.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- World industrial production in mining and manufacturing fields has ceased to expand and has begun a slightly downward trend, the United Nations Monthly Bulletin of Statistics reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Peiping radio said today the Communists "will continue to persist in negotiations" for a Korean armistice "despite the Allied decision Wednesday calling an indefinite recess." A broadcast, recorded here by The Associated Press, was somewhat milder in tone than outpourings by the Pyongyang and Peiping radio yesterday, which spoke of "the failure" of the negotiations.

MONTREAL, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Cal Gardner whipped his second goal of the game into the net at 12:21 of the third period tonight to lift the revamped Chicago Black Hawks to a 3-to-2 triumph over the Montreal Canadiens in the opening game of the National Hockey League season at the Forum.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 9 -- Richard E. Meier, president of Interstate Finance Corporation, Evansville, Ind., was elected president of the National Consumer Finance Association today, succeeding M. L. Goeglein of Los Angeles.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 -- The biggest "ticker tape" welcome in the memory of Los Angelenos greeted Gen. Dwight. D. Eisenhower as his motorcade cruised through the downtown area this afternoon.

WHEN Notre Dame was the mightiest gridiron power in the land a few years ago, Frank Leahy, a perfectionist, became slightly irked at a particular play that fell a bit below his own rigid standards of perfection. So he assembled his squad about him on the practice field and transfixed them with a chilly stare.

The American-flag tramp fleet, which has developed in the last six years into an important segment of the American Merchant Marine and a potentially valuable emergency auxiliary to this nation's defense forces, must receive Government assistance and consideration, F. Riker Clark, president of the American Foreign Steamship Corporation, asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve an 1,800-for-1 split of its common stock. The road, chartered in Illinois, also requested permission to re-incorporate in Delaware.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 -- "A vigorous and independent coordinated system of transportation under private ownership and not a dominated spoon-fed industry dependent on a paternalistic government" is the goal of the Commerce Department, Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer said here tonight in an address at the twenty-sixth annual convention of the Propeller Club.

Today is the day of national celebration for all the Chinese who are still free. It marks the forty-first anniversary of the proclamation of the Republic of China, the culmination of the successful revolt of Dr. Sun Yatsen against the Manchu dynasty. It is called the Double Ten because it falls on the tenth day of the tenth month.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Republican and Democratic nominees for President, will speak on Oct. 24 on a radio program marking the seventh anniversary of the ratification of the United Nations Charter.

Bertram D. Tallamy, superintendent of the State Department of Public Works, estimated yesterday that $3,750,000,000 would be required to meet state highway system needs for the next twenty years. He based expenditures on $200,000,000 a year for the first decade and $175,000,000 a year thereafter.
BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 9 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. tonight urged President Truman to return to Washington and leave off political campaigning because of the increased tempo of the Korean War.

It is now the turn of the British Conservative party to hold its annual conference. There is much less excitement and no such rift in the ranks as the Bevanites disclosed when the Labor party met at Morecambe two weeks ago. The Tories are in the sobering position of being in power and, anyway, the weighty figure of Winston Churchill is still there to overpower dissidents.

Unless the trade implications of negotiated underwriting and competitive bidding can be related to anti-trust concepts of conspiracy, they have no place in an anti-trust trial but should be studied by Congress, Judge Harold R. Medina said yesterday during the course of the investment banking anit-trust trial here.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 9 (UP) -- The Republican "truth team," barnstorming in Missouri and right in President Truman's home county, today accused Mr. Truman of using "garbage pile" tactics to elect his "captive candidate," Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, to the Presidency.

ABOARD NIXON TRAIN, in Pennsylvania, Oct. 9 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California urged Pennsylvania voters today to lead the way to "a change from the mess in Washington" as he denounced the "spineless" Stevenson-Truman-Acheson team.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Wallace K. Harrison, Director of Planning for the $68,000,000 permanent headquarters of the United Nations, announced its completion this afternoon. He told members of the Secretariat that "I hope it will prove worthy of the job you are doing."

The largest bauxite mining operation in Africa has just been brought into operation by Aluminum Limited of Canada on the verdant tropical island of Kassa in the Los archipelago, five miles off the coast of French Guinea, near Conakry, French West Africa.

SEATTLE, Oct. 9 (AP) -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's name on the Washington election ballot is being viewed seriously by Republican leaders as a handicap in Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's bid for the state's nine electoral votes.

Directors of the Washington Water Power Company surprised financial circles yesterday by offering to take over the assets and operations of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company. Both of these Pacific Northwest utilities have been fighting off public power ownership in that territory for many years.

PARIS, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Bache Co. (France), S. A., subsidiary of the Wall Street concern, whose Paris offices underwent a mysterious police raid last Monday, reported they were operating normally today.

The fact that stores, catering exclusively to men, are now setting aside special shopping days for women reveals the late recognition by such establishments that a very large share of sales of men's wear is made to women.

The emphasis was on pass defense in New York University football practice at Ohio Field yesterday. Coach Hugh Devore said he was not satisfied with the team's attempts at stopping the patterns he expected Holy Cross passer Charlie Maloy to use tomorrow at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

Former Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien appeared by invitation yesterday afternoon before the special grand jury investigating charges of organized gambling and official corruption on Staten Island. He said he had been questioned "simply on police regulations and procedures."
AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Rocky Jones of Philadelphia scored an upset victory tonight by winning a unanimous decision over Roland La Starza in a ten-round bout.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 9 -- The Ohio Secretary of State, Ted W. Brown, said today that the vote in the state Nov. 4 might be close to 3,900,000. He based his estimate on complete unofficial reports of registration in thirty-five counties. Special registration is not required in fifty-three counties.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- President Truman today named George Wadsworth, a career diplomat, to be United States Ambassador to Czechoslovakia.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 9 -- A fusillade of shots fired tonight through a closed venetian blind into the home of a family at dinner here wounded a 24-year-old woman.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 10 -With the introduction of the passport system between India and Pakistan that comes into force Wednesday, West Bengal is suddenly facing the problem of handling a large number of Hindus coming from Pakistan's East Bengal Province to take up permanent residence in India.

F. William Lacey's letter in your issue of Oct. 9 protests his being "cheated out of his right to vote" by our methods of registration. This seems a good time to call the attention of Mr. Lacey and the patient citizens who have been standing in line at the polls to the fact that last year there was introduced in the New York Legislature a bill for Permanent Personal Registration.

Borough President James A. Laundry Queen staged a one-session course in the rudiments of sewer construction in his office in Kew Gardens yesterday for the benefit of residents in the vicinity of Laurelton Parkway and 130th Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Five oil companies asked the United States Court of Appeals today to set side the refusal of Judge James R. Kirkland in United States District Court to discharge a grand jury impaneled to investigate an alleged international oil cartel.
MOSCOW, Oct. 10 (UP) -- Reorganization of the Russian Communist party was the principal business before today's session of the nineteenth party Congress in the Kremlin.
Two thugs held up the assistant manager and a woman employe of the Walgreen Drug Store at Forty-fourth Street and Broadway at 4:15 P. M. yesterday and escaped with $2,000 payroll.

ABOARD NIXON'S TRAIN, in Pennsylvania, Oct. 10 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon blasted away today at President Truman's "war prosperity" and linked him with the "rest of these crooks and these incompetents" in the national Government.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 10 -Princeton's winning streak, the longest in major collegiate football, will be at stake tomorrow in Palmer Stadium when the Tigers meet Pennsylvania.

A spiritual crusade with the objective of having more families of all faiths over the world institute the practice of daily family prayers, which was started a decade ago by an Albany Roman Catholic priest, was reported yesterday to have become "the greatest crusade of its kind."

James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, charged in a radio broadcast last night that the Republicans, were attempting to befuddle and confuse the voters with slogans and catchwords that "mean exactly nothing."

Senator Irving M. Ires, who is seeking re-election on the Republican ticket, will concentrate his campaigning in the metropolitan area for the next week. He is completing a two-week bus tour upstate today.
ALBANY, N. Y., Oct 10 (AP) -- Excerpts from President Truman's speech here follow:

Maj. Gen. Withers A. Burress, commander of the Seventh Corps of the Army now serving with North Atlantic Treaty Organization military units in Europe, was named yesterday as the next commanding general of the First Army to succeed Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, who retires on Dec. 31.
UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- The text of rear-platform remarks by President Truman this afternoon follows:

MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 11 -Marshal Nikolai Bulganin told the All-Union Communist party's Nineteenth Congress that "it is no secret" the Soviet economy can be switched from peaceful production "to the war rails" within a very short time.

Lumber production for the week ended Oct. 4 was 13.2 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were up 12.1 per cent and orders 7.8 per cent.

The Dutch tug Zwarte Zee, said to be the most powerful ocean going towboat in the world, is en route here from Genoa, Italy, with the American cargo ship Newberry Victory, it was announced here yesterday by Phs. van Ommeren, N. Y., Inc., general agents in this country for L. Smit Towing Company of Rotterdam.

Two more former plainclothes men have been indicted by the Brooklyn rackets grand jury on perjury charges in the borough's investigation of the financial affairs of present and former members of the department.

UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal party candidate for the United States Senate, said tonight that Gov. Adlai Stevenson was a "new political star, who understands the issues of "war and peace and prevention of depressions."
Following are the prepared texts of addresses by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson in Oklahoma City yesterday afternoon and New Orleans last night, as carried by The Associated Press:

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 10 -The Incodel plan for a joint project by Pennsylvania, New York and New Jersey to develop and use the Upper Delaware River was assailed here today by Andrew J. Sordoni, Pennsylvania Secretary of Commerce.
Service men and civilian personnel at the Army Port of Embarkation Base at Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, watched a simulated rescue at a mid-day Fire Prevention Week demonstration there yesterday.

Many manufacturers of lower price bedroom and dining room furniture will increase prices about 5 per cent before the end of the year, retailers predicted yesterday. Some increases already have been made by leaders in th field, they said.
The routes President Truman will follow in the city today on speaking engagements and to Pennsylvania Station were announced last night by the Police Department as follows:

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- France has renewed proposals to her Allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that the military commitments of the alliance and the costs of meeting them be considered on a global rather than a regional basis.

Columbus Day is ordinarily a big sales day in stores here. Last year it fell in the week corresponding to the one just closing. This year Columbus Day sales will be thrown into next week's figures. This is the major reason why sales of local department stores will show a decline this week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- One of the patents issued last week in the electrical category covers a hearing aid disguised as a pair of spectacles. The microphone is over the spectacle bridge, and is automatically focused as the wearer turns his head toward a speaker.

In keeping with its three-yearold product diversification program, the Pressed Steel Car Company yesterday acquired the 60-year old Axelson Manufacturing Company, Los Angeles, producer of petroleum pumping and aircraft equipment.

" The Human Frontier," presented by Blue Shield Medical Service to acquaint the TV audience with latest developments in scientific study and research, will be televised by WNBT on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 7 to 7:15 P. M., beginning Oct. 14. Dr. Robert M. Goldenson of Hunter College will be the commentator. The new series will be produced by Phyllis Adams.

VIENNA, Oct. 10 -- Should a judge be removed from a court case on the ground of partiality because, as a former orchestra director, he gives an expert opinion on an issue in the case -- the quality of a baritone's performance?

Representatives of various local water districts in Nassau County have agreed not to object to a proposed $15 annual increase in charges for each hydrant serviced by the Long Island Water Corporation, it was announced yesterday at the Public Service Commission, 233 Broadway.

JAMESBURG, N. J., Oct. 10 -Lou Barbaro of Hollywood, playing at a one-under-par clip, came from behind to win the seventy-two-hole New Jersey Professional Golfers' Association championship over the Forsgate Country Club course today with a 283.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Francis Biddle, former Attorney General, considers the action of his successor, Tom C. Clark, in limiting the investigation into the Kansas City, Mo., vote frauds of 1946 to have been "inappropriate, improper and unheard of," according to testimony released today by a Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives.

One who is comfortably settled in front of a television set, hoping to confirm predictions about today's football game, is in no mood to give much thought to the lawn, either front or back. The summer is gone, taking with it the necessity of periodic grass cutting, and that, one feels, is that.

The New York State organization of the Daughters of the American Revolution ended its fifty-sixth annual conference at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday, and then visited the Jumel Mansion on Washington Heights, once the headquarters of Gen. George Washington.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of the address in Salt Lake City tonight by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower at the Latter Day Saints (Mormon) Church Tabernacle:

ROME, Oct. 10 -- In a "notification" addressed to parish priests and the faithful of his diocese, Ildefonso Cardinal Schuster, Archbishop of Milan, called upon the Government to check the activities of Protestant pastors and "emissaries" who try to lure Italians from their traditional Roman Catholic faith.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 10 (AP) -Hygrade Food Products Corporation, in a $7,000,000 cash deal, today acquired control of the 100year-old, $25,000,000 meat packing firm of Kingan Co., Inc. of Indianapolis.

Flags flapped gaily in the narrow streets of Chinatown yesterday and the dragon pranced as ever, but for the fourth straight year Chinese-Americans could find no cause for celebration on the Chinese National Independence Day.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 10 -Asserting that education in the United States "cannot remain neutral or indifferent on the issue of liberty versus tyranny," Dr. William F. Russell, president of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared here today that schools an colleges must emphasize citizenship programs teaching democratic deals and principles.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Boston University's Terriers upset the Miami University Hurricanes, 9 -- 7, tonight. The hard-charging Boston line smeared Miami's Bob Mosketti for the clinching safety late in the final period at Fenway Park.

Now that the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations have endorsed Adlaf Stevenson for President, victory for the Democrats seems apparent to the undiscerning eye. Nothing, however, could be more misleading from a realistic point of view.

A long-term venture in interfaith goodwill and community brotherhood will begin on Friday in the Riverdale section of the West Bronx when a temporarily "dispossessed" Jewish congregation will start holding regular Friday services in the parish house of a near-by Protestant Episcopal Church.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 10 (UP) -The fast-traveling Republican "truth team" came to a halt in Indiana today to join in an all-out G. O. P. party effort to help Senator William E. Jenner, Republican, of Indiana, to keep his seat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Office of Price Stabilization has announced that after Oct. 15 it will discontinue the requirement that wholesale meat distributors note the class of buyer and seller on each record or receipt of a wholesale meat transaction.

Uncertainties of nationalization hang over the Bolivian properties of Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated, Inc., Joseph C. Rovensky, chairman, said yesterday in transmitting the six-month report to stockholders.

A new $1,400,000 unit of the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases will be dedicated Tuesday afternoon, it was announced yesterday by Laurance S. Rockefeller, president of the center's board of managers.

Dealers from sixteen states and one each from Denmark and Italy will take part in the eighteenth edition of the New York Antiques Fair, which opens Monday for six days at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 10 -- The city of Peoria finally served a summons on the Canal Barge Company of New Orleans yesterday -- but only after a two-year watch on the Illinois River.

Registration in the city slumped sharply yesterday as compared with the fifth day of 1948, when 492,946 men and women enrolled. Only 452,915 persons registered yesterday, but the heavy registration earlier in the week was sufficient to continue the record-breaking pace, and enrollment for the five days set a mark of 2,638,977, compared with the 2,416,614 voters who qualified in five days for the Presidential contest eight years ago.

BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- East Allied Germany's Communist - controlled press jumped today with what one official described as "unholy glee" on reports of a United States-supported sabotage organization that was subsequently directed against both the Social Democrats and the Communists.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 10 -Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish representatives today urged modification of the McCarran Immigration Act at a hearing here by the President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization. Special objections were made to the quota system of regulating immigration, and to what were described as racial discriminations and the lack of adequate provision for hearings and appeals by rejected persons.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 -Tom Hanbock, head of the Min San Trading Company, surrendered at the Federal Building today. He posted bail of $2,000 for a court appearance on Oct. 21 to answer to the charges of violating the foreign assets control regulations by sending $161,448 to persons in Communist China by way of Hong Kong.

The M. A. Hanna Company, engaged as principal or agent in producing and marketing coal and iron ore and in operating Lake vessels and docks in connection with these activities, reported yesterday a net profit of $8,745,234 from operations during the first nine months this year.

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A German court heard testimony today that Admiral Wilhelm Canaris, German espionage chief in World War II, was hanged twice for conspiring against Hitler -once to show him what death "tasted like."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Wage Stabilization Board took preliminary steps today toward consideration of a contract between Southern and Northern coal operators and the United Mine Workers of America allowing the miners an increase of $1.90 a day and a ten-cent-a-ton increase of royalties to be paid by operators into the miners' welfare fund.
LONDON, Oct. 10 (Reuters) -The British Commonwealth is still the world's largest market, transacting 29 per cent of the selling and 33 per cent of the buying, statistics showed today.

The danger of a serious rift between the United States and France looms on the horizon. It may he said at once that if it is aggravated, and with it the other irritations that ruffle the surface of the Atlantic alliance, Mr. Stalin and the comrades now hanging on his words in Moscow will be confirmed in their belief in Stalin's revised view of the future.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Unless an armistice is reached before the question arises in the United Nations General Assembly, the United States is expected to ask the General Assembly to confine its discussion of Korea to the prisoner of war issue.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 -- Lit Brothers Department Store obtained a court injunction today barring about 1,700 of its employes from going on strike Monday.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10 (UP) -- A former United States champion, Art Larsen, and Army Sgt. Bernard Bartzen made the Pan American singles championships an all-American affair today in their advance to the semi-finals.

Columbus Day, the 460th anniversary of the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus, will be widely celebrated here today, tomorrow, the actual anniversary, and on Monday, the legal holiday. The biggest event will be the parade up Fifth Avenue from Forty-fourth Street to Eighty-fourth Street, starting at 1:30 P. M. tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan told farmers today they can "avoid the danger of temporary declines" in cotton prices if they follow the rules of orderly marketing in the coming weeks.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 -- All the blues of the heavens, the waters and the distant mountains opened the Los Angeles fashion group's "Hemisphere Highlights" fashion extravaganza here tonight, and all the flowers, confections and sunsets were a delight in the closing scene.

SEATTLE, Oct. 10 -- The eighteenth biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America began debate late today on whether to accept or reject the new revised standard version of the Bible, but a vote is not expected until next week.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 10 -Nine hundred delegates attending the third annual convention of the National Association for Retarded Children, who close their sessions tomorrow, heard Dr. Clemens Benda say today that "so-called mentally deficient children often are the victims of unfair and unjust discrimination -- yet their condition may be due to an injury from an automobile accident."

GENEVA, Oct. 10 -- The contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade hesitantly and rather reluctantly decided today to start the process whereby Japan will eventually be included in the western network of commercial agreements.

George Araujo, 21-year-old Providence fighter, spoiled the New York debut of Joey Brown, New Orleans lightweight, by knocking him out with a left hook to the jaw in 1:24 of the seventh round in the listed ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

HONG KONG, Oct 10 -- About twenty persons were injured and thirty-five more were reported under arrest tonight following a series of clashes between pro-Nationalist and pro-Communist Chinese as the former celebrated the Chinese Republic's "Double Ten" national anniversary on the tenth day of the tenth month amid a remarkable display of Nationalist flags.

A tangled legal situation has developed at the Board of Education's trial of a teacher who has denied being a member of the Communist party but who refused yesterday to take the witness stand and testify about possible past membership.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Treasury said today that a San Francisco trading company had been indicted on charges of slipping United States money through Hong Kong to Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- A possibly serious threat to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's candidacy for President in at least two key states came to the attention of Republican national headquarters today, but little concern was evident.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 10 (UP) -- Michigan State goes after its eighteenth straight victory tomorrow at the expense of Texas A. and M.

Differences in profit experience of various segments of an industry are an important factor in renegotiation of Government contracts, according to a survey of William J. Casey, New York attorney, and C. Richard Gunzer, Certified Public Accountant.

The American Prison Association adopted this week a resolution deploring the failure of Congress to follow through "on the exposures and recommendations" of the Kefauver Committee. It called on Congress to enact legislation that will "effectively control the operations of gangsters and racketeers in all of their nefarious activities."

It seems strange that modern science, financed by a New York benevolent agency, could tell Mexico how to improve her breeds of corn and wheat. Yet something like this has happened. The Rockefeller Foundation, working in cordial cooperation with Mexican scientists, has succeeded in developing new or improved varieties of both corn and wheat for Mexico.
The mercurial Harry Gross, in jovial mood yesterday, amused a full courtroom with a monologue concerning his famous "day at the races" on Sept. 13, 1951.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -John P. Davies Jr., career diplomat, accused of recommending that the Central Intelligence Agency enlist the advice of persons described as Communists, has told Senators he could not give them details because the incident was "only slightly less sensitive than that of atomic energy."

Facing the extended week-end holiday, the stock market yesterday idled along to a mixed closing. With the major markets shut down today and also on Monday, Columbus Day, preferences were held to the recent favorites, including the railroad and television issues. In contrast there was weakness in the industrial sections, particularly among the coppers.
Brooklyn Prep preserved its unbeaten slate but had to settle for a 6-6 tie with Xavier High last night in the twenty-third meeting of the teams at Ebbets Field, Brokolyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -Harold D. Cooley, Democrat of North Carolina and chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, advised cotton growers today to hold their crop off the market until prices bounce up again.
The Ivy League and the Big Ten offer the two games that may have the most far-reaching results of any on today's intercollegiate football card.

The desperation and dishonesty of the Republican campaign are becoming more evident every day. I hope you will permit me to cite the recent charge by Senator Francis Case (Republican) of South Dakota that I have been a member of certain Communist-front organizations, a charge supposedly documented by references to reports of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Jimmy Kane tossed two touchdown passes and set up the third marker by air in Boston College's 20-14 victory over a scrappy Drake University team. Joe Bevere, from near-by Chelsea, was threatening to pass Drake to victory when Joe Cote saved the Eagles with a last-minute interception.

WAYNE, Pa., Oct. 10 -- Having seen his Valley Forge Military Academy football squad lose its opening two games this season, Coach L. Maitland Blank was sitting in the locker room today with his assistants, Maj. John S. Olson and Stuart Smith, wondering how to stop Pennington in tomorrow's contest here.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer expressed doubt tonight that diverting the nation's foreign trade to foreign ships would help much to ease the foreign shortage of dollar credits.

SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 10 -- While awaiting an address tomorrow by Prime Minister Churchill, the conference of Conservative party workers today devoted the second day of its annual meeting to discussing domestic issues.

Billy Rose, theatrical producer, was directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally to produce at an examination next Wednesday all books, documents and records relevant to his financial background and his mode of living during his marriage to his now estranged wife, Eleanor Holm.

Churchmen's Week opens tomorrow and ends on Laymen's Sunday, Oct. 19, which was organized eleven years ago as a project of the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World. Churchmen's Week, a new observance, has been planned under the auspices of the United Church Men of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A., who will also join in observing Laymen's Sunday.
ABOARD THE EISENHOWER TRAIN, Oct. 10 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced personally today that he would make before Election Day a disclosure of his financial returns...
CINCINNATI, Oct. 10 -- The first walkout in what may become a silent strike of all the country's 375,000 soft coal miners began today.

Textile mills and suppliers were urged yesterday to give closer design cooperation to the blouse manufacturing industry. B. H. Lerner, executive director of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, appealed to textile men for fabric ideas that will aid the trade to hold the gains it has made in the apparel field in the last several years.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The weekend restraint and Chancellor R. A. Butler's warning that hard times were ahead led to dullness on the stock exchange today.

NEWARK, Oct. 9 -- Twenty-one-year-old Margie Jason swore off televised crime programs tonight after precipitating a hold-up scare that brought more than a dozen pistol - brandishing detectives and patrolmen to the Lido Restaurant at 60 Branford Place just before 4 P. M.

Little effort was expended in the sixteenth-round game between Alexander Kotov of Russia and his counterman, T. Petrosian, in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden yesterday as they agreed to draw in fifteen moves, according to a report from Stockholm.

Highway perils created by negligence in shipping munitions were outlined yesterday at the closing session of the nineteenth annual meeting of the American Trucking Associations at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Delegates were told that regulations of the Interstate Commerce Commission and other governmental agencies must be obeyed strictly to avert "catastrophe and loss of life."
More babies were born in this city in September than during any single month since April, 1947, Department of Health statistics showed yesterday.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 10 -Andante, a mare owned by the Wee-3 Stables of New Rochelle, and Peg's Pride, a gelding belonging to T. F. Gussenhoven of Closter, N. J., began their quests of the open jumper championship with victories tonight as the twenty-third Montclair horse show opened.
TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 11 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,399 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Rev. Edward Bernard Bunn, regent of the Georgetown University Dental School and the School for Nursing, was appointed president of the university today. He succeeds the Rev. Hunter Guthrie, who held the post from early 1949 until last July when he went on leave.
Roy Campanella, Brooklyn catcher, may become the first Negro coach in major league baseball when his playing days are over.

Grover B., a 3-year-old gelding owned and trained by T. P. Morgan, did what a plurality of the crowd of 17,661 expected of him at the Jamaica track yesterday. He won easily in the main event in the role of 17-to-20 favorite. It was the third successive time that he had managed to make the grade after having been bet down to odds-on.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 10 -Still unable to field his strongest team, Coach Earl Blaik will send a crippled Army squad against Dartmouth before an estimated crowd of 22,000 at Michie Stadium tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The State Department agreed today that the question of the size of the French budget was something for France, and not the United States, to decide.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10 -- The fourth convention of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., closed today with the re-election of James E. Carey as president and Al Hartnett as secretary-treasurer.

What would be the public reaction, one wonders, if a leader of American industry should deliver a public address urging that businesses not only work for repeal of the anti-monopoly laws but openly defy these laws as a means of defeating their purpose? He would, we suggest, be the object of public condemnation from one end of the country to the other; and he would be sweepingly repudiated by responsible industrial and business leaders everywhere.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- A committee supporting North African nationalism appealed to the United States today to consider the disputes between France and Tunisia and Morocco on "their merits" and to suspend aid to France until the North African conflicts are settled.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 10 -- Success for the first time in growing in chicken eggs a virus that causes poliomyelitis was reported here today. The accomplishment led scientists to hope that it might point the way to the development of a potent vaccine against polio that could be produced on a large scale and at low cost.

CONRAD AIKEN, forever panting and forever young, is one of modern poetry's oldest traditions. He was born in 1889. He won Joseph Pulitzer's poetry prize in 1930. He is still going strong. T. S. Eliot attended Harvard (and, in a way, Ezra Pound's classes) with him. Others around Harvard Yard in 1910, or thereabouts, were briskly busy heading sheets of foolscap paper "Nocturne" or "Portrait of a Lady" and writing ancient thoughts in new measures.
The British Ministry of Labor has refused to grant a working permit to Jose Ferrer to appear in a production of Chekhov's "The Seagull" at the Old Vic Theatre, according to word received here.
ATLANTA, Oct. 10 (UP) -- Bob Jones has suffered a heart attack but is in "fairly good condition" in Emory Hospital, it was disclosed today.
ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, announced today distribution of a new booklet describing health services for children in the state and outlining needs in the field.

Nobody laughed, yesterday noon, when Marcelino Romany was reelected regional vice president of the Associated University of Pennsylvania Clubs. Nobody laughed, but everybody grinned, because everybody remembered how Mr. Romany broke the tension at the Republican National Convention in Chicago last July and set television viewers all across the country laughing.

Robert Buron, former Minister of Economic Affairs in France, told the French Chamber of Commerce of the United States yesterday that French producers must become more "export-minded" and employ modern selling techniques to capture more of the United States market.

One new film opens at a first run theatre this morning. "Gods of Bali," a feature-length documentary on the dances and festivals native to the Island of Bali, arrives at the Guild Theatre. Nikola Oraculic produced and directed the offering for Nederland Film.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 (UP) -- Brad Myers, running 84 yards for the longest touchdown run in the twenty-six game series, provided the winning margin tonight as Bucknell topped Temple, 19 -- 12, for its sixteenth straight victory before 12,000 fans.

President Truman came charging into New York last night for the ninety-eighth stop on his two-week whistle-stop tour of the country by special train, continuing his appeal for the election of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois Democratic candidate for President, and his attack on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican nominee.

Last night's performance by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House had as its feature Alicia Markova in her most famous role, "Giselle," with Igor Youskevitch as her partner. It was Miss Markova's final guest appearance of the local season, and the house was packed and enthusiastic.

The return of "Carmen" last night to the City Center presented a cast that was for the most part familiar, with the exception of Gloria Lane, who made her first appearance in the title role. She had made her debut with the New York City Opera Company only a few days ago in "The Consul."

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct 10 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson and Al Brosch of the Cherry Valley Club scored 34, 37 -- 71 in the first Long Island P. G. A. pro-woman's tournament at the Hempstead Golf Club today to win the gross prize with a 1-under-par performance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 10 -Humphrey Bogart is casting a longing eye on Ernest Hemingway's "The Old Man and the Sea" and already has outlined a proposition to the author's representative here, Al Horwits. No decision will be made on this and other pending offers for at least two months, Horwits said.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The Voice of America is telling its overseas listeners that the United States political campaign is being conducted on a "relatively high level," but is warning of trouble ahead.

TRENTON, Oct. 10 -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced a new second series issue of $28,000,000 of revenue bonds today to cover required interest reserves and finance improvements on the cross-state toll highway.
Among this week's art shows are three one-man appearances and a group of all whose merits can be enjoyed in different ways.

ROME, Oct. 10 -- Mario Scelba, Minister of the Interior, promised the Senate today to take swift action against a large group of neo-Fascists who five days ago staged a military parade on the estate of former Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, who was the last Commander in Chief of Mussolini's armies.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 10 (AP) -- The prepared text of President Truman's speech here follows:

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois said tonight that Joseph Stalin had made an accurate assessment of the foreign trade policy of the Republican party and warned that if the United States followed the ideas of the Republican Old Guard on international trade "we may condemn this nation to isolation and destruction."

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, commanding general of the First Army, will speak tonight at the annual reunion dinner of the Forty-fifth Infantry Division Association in the New Yorker Hotel. He will discuss the relation of the nation's military strength to its leadership in industrial and technological developments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged at 111.0 per cent of the 1947-49 average over the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products advanced 0.1 per cent, mainly because of higher prices for eggs, fresh fruits, some fresh vegetables, cotton, lambs, calves and steers.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 10 -- The board of managers of Danbury, Hospital has accepted the resignation of Dr. Francis Conway of West Redding, Conn., and New York as chief of the medical and surgical staff, it was confirmed here today by Bernard J. Dolan Sr., the board chairman.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Pressure of hedge selling increased in corn futures trading today, and there was also scattered long liquidation, with new low prices registered in the yellow cereal. This weakness induced scattered selling of oats also, and prices were heavy at times.

A new work by Evan Esar, author of several reference books in the field of comedy, will be issued Wednesday by Horizon Press, entitled "The Humor of Humor." Mr. Esar describes the evolution of humor from Aristotle to the present, classifying popular comedy into ninety-six basic types and illustrating each with examples of witticisms and stories.

Thomas Luchese, 52-year-old vice president of a prosperous garment manufacturing concern, speaks softly and dresses in well-cut conservatism that reflects the quiet dignity of the Malba residential district in Queens, where he lived for ten years until he and his family recently quit their unpretentious home at 106 Parsons Boulevard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 264 Korean war battle casualties in a new list that included thirty-eight killed, 205 wounded, seven missing and fourteen injured. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut).

In the first of what probably will be a series of moves to strengthen their roster for 1953, the Dodgers yesterday disposed of two more of the lesser lights among the eligibles in the recent world series.

The men's clothing industry will celebrate the twentieth anniversary of its organization on a national basis at the three-day convention of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. which opens on Monday at the Statler Hotel.

EVERY surfcaster that has ever looked out over white water knows the impulse that pushes him to make "just one more cast," and it was this last, reluctant cast that brought Al Doyle a 46-pound striper in the Martha's Vineyard Derby.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Eugene Constantin Jr.'s Nimble Fox took the Carvel Hall purse today and returned $27 for $2 after racing six furlongs in 1:12 4-5.

GENEVA, Oct. 10 -- The United Nations World Health Organization, in the most complete compilation of vital statistics ever assembled, reportedtoday more persons were marrying, having babies and living longer than ever before in history.
New York University will take on an undefeated Holy Cross football team today at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. The kickoff time is 2 o'clock.

EL PASO, Tex., Oct. 10 (UP) -The United States Department of Justice today ordered immigration agents to check on Paulette Goddard's divorce from Charlie Chaplin to determine whether any moral turpitude was involved in either their marriage or divorce.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 10 -Man is conquering the invisible With a new high-speed camera, Dr. Clyde Williams, director of the Battelle Institute here, said today.

MENLO PARK, N. J., Oct. 10 -Because of the intensive work being done at the state's new diagnostic center here, the courts of New Jersey are now able to send many boys and girls back to their homes instead of to institutions for juvenile delinquents, Judge David A. Nimmo of the Juvenile Court of Hudson County reported today.

Clarification of the Department of Agriculture's Oct. 7 release on the potato crop outlook was credited with bringing about liquidation of futures contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. Distant months were under early pressure, relieved by Maine buying at the low points.

Mayor Impellitteri and Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet commended yesterday 230 elementary school pupils for their contribution to fire prevention by submitting prize-winning essays on "The Fire-Safe Home."

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman charged tonight that the history of Republican votes in Congress on the whole price support question proved that the Republicans had a deep-seated horror of a really effective support program."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -The second largest harvest on record for the United States was predicted by the Department of Agriculture today.

Does anybody recall when it was thought the headquarters of the United Nations might be in Westchester or Connecticut? Or in Boston, Philadelphia or San Francisco? Or on Flushing Meadow? Does anybody remember an embattled minority in Westchester that did not wish to see its cherished serenity marred by the invasion of a passel of foreigners?

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10 -A passing duel is anticipated when Yale engages Columbia in the Bowl tomorrow for the thirtieth time in a gridiron rivalry which began in 1872. A crowd of more than 30,000 is expected.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 -- The United States Court of Appeals set aside today the conviction of Denis W. Delaney, ousted Collector of Internal Revenue for Massachusetts, on charges of having accepted bribes and falsifying tax liens.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Oct. 10 -John Foster Dulles asserted here tonight that the Democrats were conducting their campaign at "a low level" and charged that President Truman and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois had no hesitation about falsifying the Republican record and exploiting the fear of atomic warfare to "gain a few votes."

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- In the comedy of errors in French-United States diplomacy, which caused some emotion here this week and has now come fully to light, the two sides were about even in terms of fumbles and of maladroit efforts to cover them up.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was active again yesterday and the active months closed barely steady, 13 to 31 points net lower than on Thursday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 -- United States-Soviet relations have entered a period of acute strain as a result of the Kennan case, in the opinion of Western diplomats in Moscow but they generally doubted that the situation would deteriorate to the point of any formal rupture.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund approved tonight a $7,154,000 welfare program for maternal and child-care projects in thirty-one countries.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The majority opinion among representative newspaper critics was uncomplimentary about "Letter From Paris," a dramatization by the English playwright, Miss Dodie Smith, of Henry James' novel, "The Reverberator."

Asa S. Bushnell, director of the 1952 National Collegiate Athletic Association television program, said through The United Press yesterday that his group definitely had not presented any "share the wealth" program whereby all member colleges would share in receipts that are telecast.

Elsewhere on this page today we publish a letter from a distinguished group of friends which clearly calls for an answer on our part. The letter deals with the question of whether General Eisenhower has surrendered to Mr. Taft in the matter of foreign policy.

ELKHART, Ind., Oct. 10 (AP) -Senator Robert A. Taft said tonight his unsuccessful campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination had "succeeded in outlining the issues which are going to determine this November campaign."

LONDON, Oct. 10 (Reuters) -The re-opening of the London lead market has brought Britain a step nearer to regaining her pre-war position as the world's pricing center for the big four non-ferrous metals -- lead, zinc, copper and tin.

The millions of New Yorkers who have pushed registration figures to new highs this week are giving a good example of perseverance in the face of obstacles. The obstacles are the time, energy and annoyances of personal registration as it is practiced in this otherwise progressive state.

A young designer of theatrical sets was found murdered early yesterday in his burning apartment at 200 West Ninety-third Street at Amsterdam Avenue. Badly beaten, his hands and feet bound with an electric cord ripped from a bedroom light fixture, he had been placed beneath an overturned studio couch to which he was lashed.

In this can-minded country, a new can-opener is always interesting. A model now being introduced at Gimbels and Abraham Straus by the Rival Manufacturing Company is called Vac-O-Mat. Attachable by means of a powerful suction disk that creates a vacuum, it may be put anywhere -- wall, side of an automobile (during a stop for lunch on a journey), range top, portion of kitchen tiling or glass brick.
Directors of the Fire Association of Philadelphia and its affiliate, Reliance Insurance Company of Philadelphia, yesterday elected Kenneth B. Hatch president to succeced the late Frank H. Thomas.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 11 -- Fighting swayed back and forth throughout yesterday and early today for battle-scarred "White Horse" Mountain on the Central Korean front, key to the valley corridor through the Chorwon mountains to Seoul, the South Korean capital, fifty miles to the south.

John A. Roosevelt, youngest son of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, will make campaign speeches in seven states for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President, national headquarters of the Citizens for Eisenhower-Nixon announced last night. Mr. Roosevelt had announced on Wednesday that he intended to vote for the Republican nominee.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- Dr. Frank Graham, United Nations mediator for Kashmir, said today that the people of India and Pakistan must guard against stumbling into a dangerous situation as a result of their quarrel over control of Kashmir.

Dr. Wayne T. Barrett has been made manager of the research department of the Davison Chemical Corporation. He was formerly with the Phillips Petroleum Company and the Mellon Institute where he was a junior fellow in catalytic research.

The romance of a newly wed couple had hard going yesterday in Manhattan Traffic Court, where the bridegroom was brought before Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh to answer twenty-two traffic summonses he had ignored. For a brief spell it appeared that a honeymoon in the South would have to be postponed when a $750 fine was imposed with the alternative of 237 days in the workhouse.

Because there has been no concentrated nation-wide selling job done on frozen foods only a few purchasers of such items buy by brand name, according to Leslie Anderson, vice president and assistant to the publisher of Quick Frozen Foods magazine.

BINGHAMTON, Oct. 10 -- Louis Waldman, New York labor attorney, tonight called for a new national labor law and the establishment of national labor courts to replace judicial functions of the National Labor Relations Board.

FOR the fourth consecutive week. "A Man Called Peter" is in first place among the nonfiction best sellers. This in itself is not so important a the fact that it took forty-eight weeks for the book to get there, which is something of a record for persistence.

Princess Sibylia, mother of Crown Prince Carl Gustaf, heir to the Swedish throne, will break a bottle of champagne across the sharp, flaring bow of the second new liner built by the Swedish American Line since the end of the war in a ceremony Saturday at De Schelde shipyard, Holland.

THIS reviewer of Clinton Crane's thoroughly readable "Yachting Memories" recalls returning from a dove shoot in Georgia with Mr. Crane, at the conclusion of which Mr. Crane decided that the tension needed to discharge each barrel of his single-trigger gun was not the same. His solution was simple.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 11 -- Here at this lakefront city, where the good citizens have not yet forgiven the baseball Indians for their failure in the late American League pennant race, the stage is set for tomorrow's "big" football game.

THE subject of "Riot at Gravesend" is Wat Tyler's 1381 rebellion, when the Kentish commons, 50,000 strong, marched on London and after executing the Lord Chancellor, Simon of Sudbury, forced Richard II, the boy king, to treat with them.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Southern California's defensive platoon again stepped in where the offense feared to tread and presented the Trojans with a 20-6 triumph over the strong San Diego Naval Training Center last night.

ABOARD TRUMAN TRAIN, Oct. 11 -- Last Sunday in San Francisco some correspondents from the Truman train encountered the President's physician at breakfast in a hotel. The day before, he said, Mr. Truman had grumbled all day. Mr. Truman said he did not want to do it but it had to be done. When a boy misbehaves he needs to be spanked.
