WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Balloting in the Nov. 4 Presidential election already is under way among service men in this country and overseas.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Business in the Chicago area chalked up substantial gains in September, the third successive month of business improvement, the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago said following analysis of its monthly survey among its members.

TROY, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Kings Point scored its first football victory in three starts with a 32-20 triumph over victoryless Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute today. The Mariners, who had to come from behind twice for a 13-all deadlock at half-time, tallied three touchdowns in the final two periods.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Washington and Lee and the University of Richmond swapped touchdowns tonight but Bob Lafferty made good on all three of his extra-point kicks for Washington and Lee. That gave the Generals a 21-20 Southern Conference football victory before 5,000 in City Stadium.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Bob Dispirito, Rhode Island's brilliant captain, kicked a point after touchdown with three minutes to play and gave the Rams a 7-6 victory over Brown before 12,000 fans today.

OPEN public hunting, except in areas well removed from large metropolitan centers, is showing more of a decrease this year than at any time in the past, and it should be quite apparent to the city man that his only hope of finding reasonably good hunting lies in membership in an active rod and gun club.

The foundation of British foreign policy, Winston Churchill declared yesterday in concluding the annual Conservative party conference, is a true and honorable comradeship with the United States in defense of the life of a free world against "immense aggression and infiltration of Communist imperialism."

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Capt. Johnny Giusti was was carried off the field in the third period, came back in the final minute today to score a touchdown and give National Agricultural College a 20-20 tie with Brooklyn College.

THE collected works of Stephen Potter are now available for the first time in three volumes, the whole of which might be entitled "Selfhelpmanship," but is not. The newest, "One-upmanship," is described by Mr. Potter as "an account of the activities and teaching of the Lifemanship correspondence college of One-upness and Gameslifemastery."

Four of the five Russian players competing in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden in Sweden now hold the top places in consequence of the defeat of Laszlo Szabo of Hungary yesterday by T. Petrosian, Soviet grandmaster, in their adjourned game from the fifteenth round, according to a report from Stockholm.

MANY people who want to grow blueberries hesitate to do so because they've been told that this fruit will only grow in bogs, on mountain sides or waste land. They are also told that blueberries need an acid soil and other conditions which are definitely not present in the highly fertilized soil of the well-kept garden.

ATTESTING to the continuing popularity of the Postoffice Department's first-day sales and cover-cancellation service, collectors and dealers have spent more than $580,000 and mailed approximately 4,700,000 covers thus far this year in connection with the issuing of thirteen new stamps -- twelve commemoratives and one airmail item.

The terrain just north of Parallel 38 in Korea, where the Communist and U. N. forces are deadlocked, is broken by jagged hills and narrow, twisting valleys. It is a treacherous region in which to fight. When snow and ice, or spring mud, choke the area, infantry movement becomes a nightmare.

HERE is a bird book that is written especially for the general reader -- the suburbanite who maintains a feeding station for winter visitants, the youngster (or oldster), who is learning the difference between a house sparrow and a song sparrow and anyone who wants to acquire some elementary bird information in capsule form.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Sparked by the speed and power of Gene Filipski, the ex-Army star from Sacramento, Calif., and the power and drive of big Bob Haner, a fullback from Louisville. Villanova rolled to its fourth straight triumph today by thumping Wake Forest, 20 to 0.
In an effort to meet their financial difficulties, many independent liberal arts colleges have banded together on a cooperative basis to seek funds from business and industry.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Gov. Adlai Stevenson in a Columbus Day statement today pledged a continuation of United States efforts to have Italy admitted to the United Nations.

ALL three of these writers, two South Africans and one American, pose the same question: whither South Africa? And all of them agree more or less on the answer: South Africa is marching defiantly to the abyss. They differ sharply, however, on how the disaster can be averted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A secret "green book" of ideas on future aid to foreign countries is being compiled by officials of the Mutual Security Agency for the benefit of the next President, whoever he may be.
IN a country where most men and many women would rather eat a steak than a pheasant, it is welcome news to learn that a bumper herd of cattle is thundering to market this fall.

An enormous library of film that has been accumulating at the American Museum of Natural History for thirty years, a treasury of 2,000,000 feet in color and in black and white documenting expeditions to many parts of the world, will be prepared for public showings, the museum announced yesterday.
Soccer will take over at the Yankee Stadium today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 11 -- Princeton's twenty-four game winning streak, the longest currently boasted by any major college football team, came to an end today with 40,000 spectators limp from the excitement of the Tiger's repeated threats and failures to score the tying toughdown in a madcap second half.

A comprehensive new system to make "information as to the fitness of the contractors available to and binding upon all city departments, agencies and bureaus" is one aim of the current sewer inquiry, Commissioner of Investigation James H. Sheils said in an affidavit filed in Supreme Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The United States Office of Education said today early indications were that freshman enrollment in the nation's colleges was about 15 per cent greater than it was last year.
With whistle-stopping and video, with torch-light and tuba, the great American quadrennial exercise in democracy takes its course. Out of it will come the choice of a President.

The recommendation of the Board of Regents that the state's public schools start each day with a prayer has met with only limited success. Although it is now ten months since the board made the proposal, the majority of school districts in the state have failed to program the prayer, according to reports from state education officials and district school administrators.
This country's imports are moving by air in increasing volume.

CHESTER, Calif., Oct. 11 (AP) -- The bodies of a grocer and three small children who went with him on his weekly trip to the bank were found today in the trunk of his carf on a lonely logging road six miles east of here. They had been beaten to death by robbers.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Duke cut down South Carolina, 33 to 7, today before 25,000 fans, collecting on fumbles and the pass combination of Worth Lutz and Howard Pitt.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart (R.-Ind.) said tonight that a Korean truce could have been made if the United Nations and the Truman Administration had "agreed to the return of all Communist prisoners in exchange for all American prisoners."

Huge registration increases in New York City and upstate areas were recorded during the past week. Similar gains had been reported previously in New Jersey, Ohio, Indiana and several other states. Together they indicate an interest in the outcome of this year's Presidential election exceeding anything known in the last twenty years.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 11 -- Maryland's awesome Terrapins, springing little Chester Hanulak loose as if he were shot from a gun and using passer Jack Scarbath mainly for headwork, crushed previously unbeaten Georgia, 37 to 0, today before 35,000 fans.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Gardnar Mulloy upset Vic Seixas, top United States player, today to advance to the final of the Pan-American tennis championships.

ONE of the pleasant things about living in New York is that nearly every one of any consequence as a performer eventually gets here. Since most of us will never be able to visit Bali and see its dancers and hear its music, we are fortunate to have had authentic interpreters of these arts in our midst for a while.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The effects of a 32,000-pound tandemaxle truckload are about six times as destructive to pavement as those of an 18,000-pound single- axle load, a report by the Highway Research Board asserts.

This fall the nation's public high schools enrolled more than 6,000,000 pupils. Within four decades high school enrollment has doubled and then re-doubled. By 1960, it is estimated, more than 8,000,000 boys and girls will be attending United States secondary schools.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Minnesota snatched a spinetingling 27-to-26 victory from Northwestern today by driving 42 yards to the winning touchdown with less than two minutes to play.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- New York's skiing industry got its first good look at itself in the form of a comprehensive survey reported last week. The report was made at the seventh annual winter sports forum sponsored here by the New York State Winter Sports Council and the state Department of Commerce.
I WOULD like to refer to the letter of Murdock Pemberton published in your section on Sept. 28.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- John Foster Dulles asserted tonight that the Democrats had become "the silent partners of the Kremlin despots" by refusing to make it clear that they never would compromise with Soviet Premier Stalin at the expense of captive nations.

AN interesting fact about the author is made clear in this collection of nine s-f stories: he writes lucidly of robots, humanoid calculators, and extraterrestrials. But when he attempts the psychology of a human protagonist or antagonist, he fails dismally.

American religious leaders have a responsibility to uproot nationalistic barriers among nations and to guide mankind into a world society, Rabbi David B. Kahane declared in a sermin yesterday morning in the East Fifty-first Street Synagogue, at No. 221.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11 -- Evidence supporting Soviet newspaper claims, made six weeks ago, that Y. V. Knorozov, Soviet ethnologist of Leningrad, had established principles that should lead to a solution of the mystery of Mayan hieroglyphics has been set forth in an eighteen-page article in the Journal of Soviet Ethnology.

ATLANTA, Oct. 11 -- Programs for defense against biological warcare and for disaster and epidemic aid will be discussed in a three-day meeting at the United States Public Health Service Communicable Disease Center here. The meeting will open Monday.

DENVER, Oct. 11 -- The Republican high command now is so confident of victory on Nov. 4 that it is convinced it makes little or no difference what General Dwight D. Eisenhower says or does between now and Election Day.

J. J. Singh's article, "How to Win Friends in Asia" (Sept. 28) is well taken and points out the dangers that confront us if we do not keep a strong Asia policy. However, Mr. Singh, in his anxiety to pin blame on the United States, neglects to look for reasons behind our actions in the Pacific.

SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill pledged today continued British support of the Anglo-American alliance in defense of a free world against Communist imperialism. The Prime Minister, who looked fit and cheerful despite a head cold, was speaking as leader of the Conservative party to about 4,500 delegates to its annual conference which ended here this afternoon.

LATE flowers and brilliant fall coloring help make sourwood or sorrel tree an unusually interesting specimen. Its general appearance is almost that of a miniature tree. It is slender, little and dainty, and is beautiful at any time of year.

WHILE the film world cocks an eye at Cinerama and wonders whither and/or whether it will go, it being as yet a one-shot technique for throwing panoramic pictures on a screen, it is well to remember that regular movies are still doing business at the old stands and to note that, indeed, thy are hustling some technical improvements of their own.
MOUNT PLEASANT, Iowa, Oct. 11 -- Iowa Wesleyan today received a 1-0 forfeit when Dubuque football coach Moco Mercer apparently protested an official decision too vigorously.

MADRID, Oct. 11 -- A group of United States geologists began explorations in northern Spain this week for a location for seismographic tests preliminary to wildcatting in a major effort by United States interests to ascertain the existence of oil deposits in Spain.
Liberia's bountiful iron ore deposits are now assured as a leading foreign supply source for United States iron and steel mills for a long time.

PAN AMERICAN World Airways and Colonial Airlines, which raised tourist fares to Bermuda on Oct. 1, will be followed on Nov. 1 by British Overseas Airways. The round trip coach rate, formerly $85, plus tax, is now $90, plus tax, or $103.50.

A news story from France stirs memories. A few days ago Dunkirk formally dedicated its new oil refinery, the only one in Northern France, taking special pride that it had been rebuilt on the site, and with four times the capacity, of the plant that had been gutted by war.

Early in 1951 a Japanese merchant ship steamed into New York harbor with a load of Philippine sugar. The first Japanese vessel to appear in this area since the war, she attracted considerable attention. In July of that year regular Japanese-flag berth service was restored between here and the Far East.

MISSOULA, Mont.-- With snow starting to cap the higher peaks, Montanans have begun to shake out their sleeping bags and sight in their rifles -- certain indications that another hunting season is closing in.

" Chessie" the cat, the well-known trade symbol of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company, is straying into other fields. Its likeness is appearing or will soon appear on such articles as neckties, scarves, lamps and slippers under a licensing arrangement by C. O. with manufacturers in those fields.

DENVER, Oct. 11 -- Gen! Dwight D. Eisenhower today called for formal repudiation by the United States of the 1945 Yalta agreement with the Soviet Union to give the people of Poland hope that we "will work continually, yet peacefully, until the courageous patriots of Poland are again masters of their own destiny."

ALL this to-do about Texas is getting mighty tiresome. For many weeks now the literary arena has been reverberant with reports of a threatened secession from the Union; one would suppose, from all the uproar, that Miss Ferber's new novel had laid bare an astonishing and deeply disturbing new manifestation of American materialism.
DETROIT, Oct. 11 -- Bill Mihalo walked his way to two world records today to make a clean sweep of the world walking championships in Detroit.

VIENNA, Oct. 11 -- Jovan Gligor, Yugoslav baritone who was engaged by Vienna State Opera and then dismissed on the ground of inferior performance, emerged with flying colors and soaring notes from a second voice test in open court here today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 11 -- An all-day conference on labor arbitration will be held on the campus of Rutgers University here Thursday. It will be under the sponsorship of the New Jersey State Board of Mediation, New Jersey State Bar Association, American Arbitration Association and the Rutgers Institute of Management and Labor Relations.

Ted Atkinson popped down in front with four successive winners at the Jamaica cavalry post yesterday, but he had to settle for second money with the 3-to-4 favorite in a race he dearly wanted to win -- for reasons that were (a) financial, and (b) sentimental.

AFTER all these years, Alicia Markova has worked another miracle. She came to New York first in 1938 with Massine's newly formed Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, and during the war years in this country, with this company and later with Ballet Theatre, we saw her reach such a point of perfection that she was justifiably declared to be the greatest of all classic ballerinas.

BY Remy de Gourmont's standard -- that the only real books are those in which a writer, using himself, spells out the customs of his contemporaries, their dreams, vanities, loves and follies -- "Daughter of Confucius" is a real book.
TWO timely disks from London Records are currently available to indicate to interested music-lovers what Swiss composers are up to at the moment.

THE big problem facing Ralph Stolkin, new president of R. K. O. Radio Pictures and head of the five-man syndicate which purchased operating control of the company from Howard Hughes, is the selection of a first-class production executive to get the studio back on its feet in the shortest possible time.
One has to agree with J. J. Singh's conclusions in "How to Win Friends m Asia" (Sept. 28) even though the -arguments set forth are bound to cause some skepticism.

FANTASIES, when they have point and grace, besides achieving a sense of reality and naturalness beyond the merely quaint conceit, can be an enthralling form of literary entertainment. Almet Jenks' short novel belongs in this infrequent category.

THE quality of these annual anthologies may be plotted as an ascending curve. This, the fourth of the series, demonstrates the effect two new magazines, Galaxy Science Fiction, and The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction, have had upon the field.

Herschel E. Fowler, manager of the Northeast Airlines ticket office at La Guardia Airport, was arrested yesterday at his home, 42-64 Saul Street, Flushing, Queens, and charged with embezzling $17,500 of the company's ticket money. He waived a hearing in Queens Felony Court and was held in $20,000 bail for the grand jury.

President Truman brought his trainside whistle-stop technique into the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, delivering a Columbus Day dinner speech in which he heaped scorn on the Republican party and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, its candidate for President.

Paul A. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, accused the Republican State Committee yesterday of hiring teenagers to boo President Truman on Friday when the President toured New York State on his way here.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Colgate's opportunistic football team capitalized on a couple of Rutgers errors to down the Scarlet, 13 -- 7, today before 6,000 fans.

FROM the Philippines comes the design of 5-centavos brown and 6c blue stamps to be issued for the fourth meeting of the Indo-Pacific Fisheries Council at Manila on Oct. 23 through Nov. 7 for "the study of the various fish problems of each member nation with a view to providing remedies and solutions through exchange of technical information"; the design is a "bangus" fish with a map as background.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 -- The public welfare services of this nation and Canada, far from being "in jeopardy," have the support of all political parties -- "even at election time," George F. Davidson, Canada's Deputy Minister of Welfare, declared today.

THIS, surely, is one of the best-timed books of the year or any year. Last winter when Senator Douglas, casting himself rather more in the role of Professor Douglas, gave a series of lectures at Harvard on the ethical standards for public officials, he doubtless knew that they would be published during an election campaign in which public morality would be an issue.
Patrolman William Pawelko of the East 126th Street Station balked an attempted hold-up in Harlem yesterday noon by capturing an armed thug who was carrying $1,300 he allegedly had stolen.

THE psychology of religion is, in principle, a joint inquiry. The scientist may not have all the facts or the saint all the insight. Fortunately, L. W. Grensted combines a knowledge of both the essentials of religion and the methods of psychology.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Tony Branoff, a freshman, and Ted Kress, a sophomore, ran and passed Michigan to a 28-to-13 victory over Indiana today before 58,200 fans at Michigan Stadium.

THE only predictable thing about that dynamic monkey, Curious George, is his unpredictability. Giving him a bicycle is just an invitation to trouble -- one which George accepts enthusiastically. First thing you know George is delivering papers for a trusting newsboy who ought to have known better.
DENVER, Oct. 11 (AP) -- General Eisenhower is opposed to suggestions that the United States break off diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

THERE are many reasons why the newly opened exhibition of work by the fauve painters at the Museum of Modern Art is important. It is intrinsically a fascinating show. It reveals so many cross currents in the art of the time.
THE TIMES Magazine for Sept. 28 printed an "In October" list of scheduled events. The only international holiday might well have been included, under the date of Oct. 24.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 11 -- The Middlesex County Sewerage Authority, at a special meeting here today, rejected a request from the Somerset County Citizens Committee on Water Supply and Pollution for an additional six to nine months to study methods to end pollution of the Raritan River and voted to build a trunk sewer costing $22,500,000.

The 1953 schedule of the Italian Line will offer twenty-nine express sailings from this country to the Mediterranean, an increase of three over this year, and its vessels will call at Greek ports for the first time since 1939, W. H. McConnell, vice president in charge of passenger traffic of American Export Lines, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The explosion of Britain's first atomic weapon off the coast of Australia last week is almost certain to speed up a review of the strict United States curb on the exchange of atomic information, officials here believe.

OCCASIONALLY a first novel appears which, without any fanfare, and by a special kind of set-apartness, an unmistakable fusion of integrity and passion, indicates the arrival of a new writer who must inevitably attract the attention of the discerning.

THE television season is now in full swing; hardly a day goes by without its quota of premieres and returning attractions. It will be a little time yet before an over-all appraisal of the medium's efforts can be made. Meanwhile, herewith is an interim report on some of the personalities who have been seen of late:

The Child Study Association will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Millionairess," by George Bernard Shaw, with Katharine Hepburn, Cyril Ritchard and Robert Helpmann in the leading roles, on the night of Nov. 14 at the Shubert Theatre. Mrs. Nelson Doubleday, Mrs. Frank J. Karelsen Jr. and Mrs. Jacques C. Nordeman are co-chairmen of the committee in charge.

A NOT so major aspect of today's insistence on obtaining the secret of life in a capsule is the demand that the theme of a play be expressed in one sentence of less than ten words, if possible. This may be why we so often read that a play is the study of the struggle between good and evil.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 11 -- Democratic leaders from ten Southern states -- who heard Gov. Adlai R. Stevenson touch on the civil rights issue during a major address -- expressed confidence that the Democratic Presidential nominee would carry the South.

The framers of the United Nations Charter, this country's spokesmen included, intended the United Nations General Assembly to be, first, a forum where opinions might be expressed and, second, a supervisor of the relatively non-controversial activities of the United Nations.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 11 -- Indonesia's smoldering Cabinet crisis over reorganization of the Indonesian National Army appeared to resolve itself today when the leading Government party, the Moslem party, annulled an earlier decision to introduce a motion to change the army's high command.

THE basic theme of Mrs. Craig's new junior novel is very similar to that of her popular "Irish": a girl's assertion of her integrity despite social pressures and the confusions of first love. Julie, however, is older than Trish was and her problems are more complicated.
NEWARK, Oct. 11 -- Registration in Northern New Jersey reached a record total today. Expectations are that figures from the rest of the state will disclose a similar condition.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 11 -Polling takes place in Belgium tomorrow to elect new local councils in the 2,666 communes -- cities, suburbs, villages and hamlets -- into which the country is divided for local government purposes.

LONDON has just staged what was surely the most ironical comedy of contrasts in recent musical history. Last week Arturo Toscanini conducted the Philharmonia Orchestra in two Brahms programs at the Royal Festival Hall and evoked a veritable fireworks display of superlatives from press and public.

ONE of the best plants in the garden is the rose. What is more no other flower adds so much beauty or has so many uses. Naturally, then, more has been written about the rose than any other single group of plants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The United States has under consideration a request for a United Nations "vote of confidence" on the firm stand being taken by the United Nations truce negotiators in Korea on the question of repatriation of war prisoners.

SCIENTIFIC methods are putting the tipsy driver in a spot where it will require much more than the ability to walk a straight line to escape a charge of drunkenness behind the wheel. Tests showing the percentage of alcohol in the blood of accused motorists are being accepted as evidence of guilt in courts throughout the country.

Allow me to express my appreciation, as a stranger, to one of America's "goodwill ambassadors" -- the American National Theatre and Academy. It is regrettable that little of the activities and development of the American theatre is presented to the audiences abroad.

Plans are under way for the annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association to be held on Nov. 14 at the Ambassador. Mrs. Ruth McCullough Young, president of the beneficiary, will give a tea and cocktail party on the afternoon of Oct. 21 in her home at 950 Park Avenue for members of the executive committee and patrons and patronesses, who are active in furthering the success of the forthcoming fete.

AMERICAN movie interests in this country and Mexicans both in and out of the industry are profoundly disturbed by a new film law that establishes Federal Government control of every phase of the industry -- movie making, distribution and exhibition.
The seventeenth annual Tip Top Ball, under the auspices of Auxiliary No. 5 of Stony Wold Sanatorium, will be held on the night of Nov. 7 at the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the institution.

NEWARK, Oct. 11 -- A twenty-four-foot aluminum dome of a planetarium donated by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Dreyfuss to the Newark Museum was set in place yesterday in a newly built room, completing one of the last phases of construction.

Roger W. Eddy, an author and a former ski trooper, is the developer of a gadget that has been known to make the rose-breasted grosbeak rush in where robins did not bother to tread. With the help of the National Audubon Society, the gadget is becoming a favorite item in the bird watcher's equipment, which heretofore has consisted principally of a pair of binoculars.

PLANNING the landscape around the new home or small property presents the problem of making a wise choice of plant material. So many kinds of shrubs, evergreens and perennials are available that confusion rather than satisfaction is likely to result.
It is hard to understand why those who control the destiny of the legitimate theatre are so determined on its complete destruction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The deep silence of more than half the voters who have been asked their Presidential preference has spread to the political oracles and reduced the 1952 crop of electoral predictions to an all-time low. In fact, this silence of the citizenry is one of the principal causes of the prophetic crop failure that many, who have feared that advance polling would lead to "government by Gallup," hail as a blessing.

Five physicians of the Departments of Psychiatry and Neurology and Surgery of Tulane University have reported to the American Physiological Society that it is possible to plant electrodes deep within the human brain and leave them in place in the unanesthetized patients for weeks without untoward effects.

IN 1948 I attended a writers' conference on the culture and heritage of the Pacific Northwest at Reed College in Oregon. Present were many learned individuals from the region's great centers of population.

Members of the recently organized women's board of the Kips Bay Boys Club, of which Mrs. Colley E. Williams is chairman, will direct special fund-raising events in behalf of more than 2,000 boys in a crowded district of the city.

Four auction sales for varying tastes and interests will be held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, this week when a collection of books, another of prints, a third of rugs and a fourth of French provincial furniture and decorations will be put on the block.
IN all the chief productions of the past month in London's West End, America has had an important or a predominating share.

Lord Dunsany in "Wanted: A Minister of Mirth and Mockery" (Oct. 5) laments the dearth of humorists in the world today and urges the appointment of international jesters to find something "funny in the trend of world affairs."

RENO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Firing a record-smashing 9 under par, Smiley Quick of Los Angeles today took over leadership of the Northern California-Reno open golf tournament with a fifty-four-hole total of 199.

WRITTEN in a style of love and happiness, this novel tells a story of Mennonite farmers who brought hard winter wheat to the Kansas prairies. The Palevskys came over from the Crimea in the summer of 1874 along with a number of other families from their village.

THIS may well be, in magazine parlance, the neatest meet-cute of the week -- the story of a ghost-writer who falls in love with a ghost. In this instance, Elizabeth Deveny, a shy, sensitive, drab poetess, is engaged by Harry Mellett, a publisher, to ghost-write the memoirs of Baroness Von Schillar, a once - famous beauty, whose spectacular adventures had outraged her native Boston.

TORONTO, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks unleashed a barrage of shots at their former goalie, Harry Lumley, tonight as they skated to a 6-to-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the first game of the National Hockey League season at the Gardens.
The police yesterday presented to Magistrate Ludwig Gloa in Brooklyn Felony Court a suspect whom they said operated a gambling palace and counting house on wheels.

MONTREAL, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Little Billy Reay, a balding sharpshooter of 34 years, slid a shot into the goal from a sharp angle in the final period to give the Montreal Canadiens a 2-1 victory over the champion Detroit Red Wings tonight.

IN the past six years I've spent many pleasant hours reading catalogues, and devoted countless other hours to experiments in my New York City apartment with plants from near and far. It's been a liberal education, and certainly not expensive when I consider all the fun I've had and all I've learned about house plants and how to make them grow under difficult city conditions.

TOKYO, Sunday, Oct. 12 -- The Communists charged yesterday that the United Nations Command had attempted to put pressure on the General Assembly of the world organization to approve a break-off of the negotiations for an armistice in Korea and an extension of the Korean war.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Oct 11 -- Eleven hundred New York National Guardsmen from six New York City Guard groups, encamped this morning at Camp Smith for a two-day target practice session. The contingents began practice firing with rifles, carbines, pistols and machine guns.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Oct. 12 -- The Nineteenth Congress of the All-Union Communist party approached its conclusion last night after a week of speeches in which two major theses emerged -- the invincible might of the Soviet Union and the world bloc that it heads, and the implacable determination of the United States and its allies to launch a third World War against the Soviet bloc.

Estimates put department store sales here last week at about 11 per cent under the corresponding week of last year if the figures of Frederick Loeser Co., which closed last spring, are included, and a drop of 7 per cent without these figures.

NEW YORK in the near future may have a new opera company headed by Laszlo Halasz, founder and former musical director of the New York City Opera Company. It is known that when Mr. Halasz left the company last December, he was approached by a film company with a view to producing opera in a Broadway theatre owned by the film company.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Penn State remained among the dwindling ranks of the nation's undefeated teams with a 35-21 victory over West Virginia today in a game in which interceptions, blocked punts and fumbles marked the scoring.

Although the United States Supreme Court has ruled that motion pictures are entitled to full guarantees of freedom of speech as outlined in the Constitution, censors throughout the country continue their pestiferous activities.
The Main Reading Room of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will be open as usual tomorrow, from 9 A. M. to 10 P. M.

ALTHOUGH Beatrice Lillie is wonderful as head mountebank in a big musical show, she is great when she is on her own. She is great, in fact, in a tenuous series of sketches and songs that is casually entitled "An Evening With Beatrice Lillie, With Reginald Gardiner."
EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 11 -- Michigan State, its football steamroller in high gear, flattened Texas A. M., 48 to 6, today to roll on to its eighteenth straight victory.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 11 -- Navy carved out a 14-to-0 victory over William and Mary today, to the complete satisfaction of the homecoming spectators in the crowd of 19,000. The undefeated Middies are now riding high on a streak of three victories.

The United States steel industry set a new production record last month, producing 9,034,000 tons, the highest output in our history for a 30-day month. Yet so far this year, from January through September, American steel production is about 14,200,000 tons below last year's.

WITH the partition of Germany and the dissolution of the State of Prussia, Berlin suddenly ceased to be the capital of the Reich and of its largest state. Though it has never regained either position it has become important to more people today than ever before in its stormy history -- despite the terrific destruction still in gaping evidence and the loss of its dominance as a manufacturing and transportation center.

SCHNECKSVILLE, Pa. -- Here at the Trexler-Lehigh Game Preserve, about ten miles northwest of Allentown, Sunday visitors can see one of the few herds of buffalo roaming at large in the United States. The preserve, on which is maintained one of the largest collections of hoofed wild animals in the country, is part of the Lehigh County park system.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The leaders of the Democratic and Republican campaigns for Congress seats are avoiding flat predictions. They remember how predictions were upset in 1948.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Senator James H. Duff, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today that the Democrats were putting out propaganda that he was out of the Eisenhower campaign but declared there was nothing to it. "I've traveled 12,000 miles in the last eighteen days, part of that time with Ike," he told a reporter.

RUFINO TAMAYO is finally painting a mural in the Palacio de Bellas Artes, the Government-owned national museum and the high sanctum of Mexican fine arts. This is an event of major importance here for it represents the first major shift in position between the two rival camps in Mexican art since Diego Rivera, David Alfaro Siqueiros and the late Jose Clemente Orozco "captured" recognition as the official school.

GREYBULL, Wyo., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Senator John Sparkman, Democratic candidate for Vice President, said tonight "the power lobby was trying to make the people believe that this whole great reclamation program is nothing but socialism."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 11 -- In this Presidential election year the predicted bumper crop of corn could figure in the outcome on Nov. 4 just as the peak crop of 1948 affected the balloting in that year. The pattern of 1952 follows that of 1948 in a number of respects.

WHEN Mexicans, who are both pessimists and humorists, get on good terms with a visitor, they are likely to say. "You must send your grandchildren here. This road (or building or whatever) will be finished then."

THE world championship contract bridge match, played annually between teams representing the American Contract Bridge League and the European Bridge League, will not fall within the appropriate calendar year when it is next played.

FOR Katharine Hepburn to have been in danger of losing her voice during the run of George Bernard Shaw's "The Millionairess" must have seemed to her and to all concerned with the production about as crippling a catastrophe as if Rocky Marciano had been threatened with losing the use of his right hand on the eve of his engagement with Joe Walcott.

THE gentle art of horsemanship is presented in text and photographs in this attractive volume. The writer, a teacher of riding, makes it plain that it is a gentle art, as applied to the horse, but one that takes a lot of learning, and she uses a very firm hand with the beginner who aspires to master it.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 11 -- Ridicule and denunciation have been poured on the United States from many quarters in Germany during the last few days as a result of the disclosure that United States officials here sponsored and financed a group of Germans to be trained for partisan warfare in the event that Soviet forces overran Western Germany.

MIDDLETOWN, N. J., Oct. 11 -- Costumed church members portraying early settlers, pirates and Indians presented here today a pageant that brought to life many of the colorful episodes in the long service of Old Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, which is observing the 250th anniversary of its founding in 1702.

Georgi M. Malenkov, Politburo member and one of the leading contenders for the succession to Premier Stalin's power, was probably a supporter originally of Leon Trotsky against Mr. Stalin during the early Nineteen-twenties when the two men struggled for the right to succeed Lenin, according to evidence in a detailed study of Mr. Malenkov's life published by the research staff of the Voice of America.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, said tonight he had dismissed American employes of the United Nations for anti-American activities when he had received official and convincing information against them by United States sources.

THERE are now two Grand Old Men of music -- Sibelius, who will be 87 next December, and Ralph Vaughan Williams, who celebrates his eightieth birthday today, Oct. 12. It is a long time since Sibelius gratified us with a new work; but the Sixth Symphony of Vaughan Williams, performed for the first time in 1948, showed him at the summit of his intellectual and imaginative powers.

Most great men of history are commemorated on their birthdays. Christopher Columbus has the distinction of being remembered on the day when his greatest deed was achieved, the landing in the Bahama Islands. Ironies followed him all his life. There were, and are, uncertainties as to where he was actually born and precisely when.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Two administrative officials of the world champion New York Yankees baseball team were seriously hurt a few minutes after midnight today in a three-car crash here on the Hutchinson River Parkway at Mamaroneck Avenue. A Philadelphia woman also was injured.

IN the Nineteen Twenties, while his own career was still in sunlight, Gen. Maxime Weygand of France wrote a first book on his hero, Turenne. The opening line was a quotation from Lacordaire: "It is the nature of noble hearts to discover the essential necessity of the times in which they live and to devote themselves to meeting it."

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 11 -- Henry A. Gerry and Mrs. Robert Millen of the Piping Rock Club shot 31, 35 -- 66 to deadlock with Edward H. Gerry and Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr., Piping Rock, 34, 32 -- 66, in the first round of the Meadow Brook mixed foursomes tournament today.

The loan operation of the Small Defense Plants Administration has grown to the size of a city bank. Since April the agency has approved 189 loans for a total of $22,393,258, it was made known last week by John Horne, national administrator.

Well-known women of society are advancing the plans for the exhibition of paintings and drawings by Ingres, lent by the Museum of Montauban in France, to be held here from Nov. 11 through Nov. 29 at the Knoedler Galleries for the benefit of the Museum of Montauban.

A NUMBER of fine critical appraisals and histories of the Japanese theatre have been published in France and Germany, but few in America. Zoe Kincaid wrote a book on this subject back in 1925, entitled "Kabuki, The Popular Stage of Japan." And in 1928 F. A.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 11 -- India has decided to take a firm but peaceful action for an early "integration" of French and Portuguese settlements with the Indian Union, authoritative sources indicated today.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 11 (AP) -- One of Governor Stevenson's advisers asserted today that Senator [Karl lV[undt, Republican 'of South Dakota and chairman of the Republican Campaign Speakers' Bureau, had told "another Rpublican lie."

New York University has named Dr. John H. Prime associate dean of its School of Commerce, Dean G. Rowland Collins announced yesterday. The promotion of Dr. Prime, Professor of Finance and formerly assistant dean of the school, was coupled with the appointment of three other administrative appointments for Commerce faculty members.

SHRUBS that will flower in shade are in ever-increasing demand. A number, fortunately, are a fine source of foliage and flowers when planted in medium to light shade. The quantity and quality of bloom will, of course, depend on the amount of light the shrub receives.
Members of civic, church and service groups in West Harlem joined yesterday in a Civil Defense parade, which marked also the culmination of Fire Prevention Week.

An artificial lung which can breathe for an anesthetized patient on the operating table and which automatically takes over when breathing becomes irregular and inefficient comes from the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, Boston. The lung has been used in more than 800 cases.

In an article prominent on the first page of your issue of Oct. 5 Harold B. Hinton described the situation in Greece in terms liable to disturb American public opinion. This is unfortunate, as the money spent by the United States in Greece has produced splendid results, to the common advantage of both countries.
Two New York veterans organizations attacked yesterday the proposed reductions in existing medical facilities in veterans hospitals.

LIGONIER, Pa., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Monkey Wrench, 7-year-old gelding that had won the opening day feature last Wednesday at the Rolling Rock Hunt Racing Association's fifteenth annual meet, today took the $5,000 added International Gold Handicap.
MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 11 (UP) -- The United States is "in serious danger" because of the "faulty" organization of military planning, Dr. Bush said here today at the Tufts centennial.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- In the past eighteen months Mohammed Mossadegh, the lachrymose Premier of Iran, has been able to squeeze out of Britain everything he ever wanted for his country -- except money and its concomitants, financial stability and political security.

IF anybody around here wants to read another story about pore white trash shanty-boat people down on the Lower Mississippi, here is a good story. There's nothing the matter here except that the author, while living the life of a shanty-boater to gather material for his book, must have been reading too much pulp fiction in the evenings beside the old kerosene lamp.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 11 -- Larry MacPhail's General Staff outran nine others today in winning the Quaker City Handicap by two and a half lengths at Garden State Park. Hampton Stables' consistent Alerted was second and Mrs. H. P. Christiansen's speedy Mandingo third.

In re-examining the case of and for "modern music" -- as has been done lately in your columns with reference to Aaron Copland's "An Indictment of the Fourth B" (Sept. 21) -- I might suggest your readers avail themselves of Aline Louchheim's fine article, "From Wild Beasts to Old Masters" ( Oct. 5 ).

BEETHOVEN: Sonata in A, Op. 12, No. 2; Walter Schneiderhan, violinist and Erich Berg, pianist; Sonata in G, Op. 30, No. 3; Helen Airoff, violinist, and Celiny Chailley-Richez, pianist (Remington). Very well-recorded versions and straightforward interpretations that are musical but not very imaginative.

A PERSUASIVE writer, Margaret Baker packs her stories full of extraordinary events and manages to make them sound almost as probable as they are diverting. This latest of her stories to come from England might be termed her most realistic, even though the children experience more adventures in a few months than more humdrum youngsters have in a whole childhood.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Louisiana State used a band of hard-running backs and Norm Stevens' highly effective passing to rout Kentucky, 34 to 7, in what had been forecast as a close Southeastern Conference football game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Henry W. Fowler, head of defense mobilization, said today it might be possible to speed up the military production program next year with only a moderate increase in appropriations and without restricting civilian production.

DR. BROCK CHISHOLM might well be called first Surgeon General of the Human Race. As the director general of the United Nations World Health Organization (W. H. O.) the Canadian physician administers from his headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland, a global campaign against disease that is saving hundreds of thousands of lives.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The name of Col. Jacob Arvey. Chicago Democratic leader, was linked today with efforts in 1951 to dissuade the Federal Government from pressing legal proceedings against the Pabst Brewing Company.

The American Chemical Society announces that a method of synthesizing cortisone from simple, readily available chemicals composed of carbon, oxygen, and hydrogen has been devised by Dr. Lewis H. Sarett and a team of chemists in the Merck Laboratories.

THE social historian of the future may well be grateful to Decca for inaugurating a 78 r.p.m. series of reissues called Curtain Calls. These records, intended to present the top popular performers of the past three decades doing the songs which helped to make them famous, should be a helpful and time-saving guide to the historian who might wish to examine popular taste during this period.

How to treat branch stores in the reporting of retail sales figures is receiving the attention of the Federal Reserve Board and Reserve banks. A proposed change, it is understood, may mean the publication of department store sales figures for a metropolitan area instead of being limited to a city as such.

A state-wide poll of 700,000 independent voters by members of Eisenhower-Nixon clubs shows 50 per cent of the independents for Eisenhower, 35 per cent for Stevenson and 15 per cent undecided, Frederick v. P. Bryan, state chairman of the Citizens for Eisenhower-Nixon Clubs, announced yesterday.

MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 11 -- Charges by Governor Dewey of New York in a speech this week that the "white supremacy" slogan of Alabama's Democratic ballot convicts the party's top nominees of "rankest hypocrisy" created little excitement in this state.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Southern Methodist University, with hard-charging backs making long gains off tricky double wing and Y formations, beat Missouri, 25 to 7, today for its first victory of the season.

UNDERLYING business sentiment last week continued favorable, despite the tendency in some quarters to anticipate a setback in the not-distant future. It appeared the consensus that the outlook until the middle of 1953 is reasonably well assured.
MOSCOW, Oct. 11 -- Moscow newspapers devoted themselves almost exclusively this week to the Communist Party Congress.

Bob Lippemeier of Forest Hills and Herb Hinman of Roosevelt repeated their victories of last Saturday when each triumphed in his own section yesterday in the second and last group runs sponsored by the Public Schools Athletic League. The runs were held over the two and one-half mile course at Van Cortlandt Park.

THIS sturdy book, built to resist a good deal of wear and tear, is just the thing for children who have outgrown cloth books and want simple, bright picture books. Garth Williams' portraits of twenty-six baby animals include such domestic creatures as a rabbit, woodchuck and raccoon and such exotic ones as an orang-utan and a giraffe.

THE framers of our Constitution gave more, and more elaborate, consideration to the executive office than to any other feature of our Federal Government. Yet we look in vain through all the prolonged debates in the Convention, and through the eleven Federalist papers on the executive, for any suggestion that there is any relation between the election of a President and political principles or issues.

Following is an incomplete summary of the New York registration, by Assembly Districts, as compared with the registration in 1950, when a Governor, Senator and Mayor were elected, and in the 1948 and 1944 Presidential years. The Assembly Districts with no 1952 totals had not reported as of 3 A. M. today.

Dr. Eddie Anderson's rugged Holy Cross eleven carried on unchecked in its bid for Eastern gridiron honors yesterday by drubbing Hugh Devore's undermanned New York University outfit, 35 to 0, at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

I think THE TIMES Magazine used poor discrimination in making its Sept. 28 cover a picture of the citizenry of Newton, Iowa, sitting and standing on the railroad tracks. For the past few years I have industriously spent time teaching my youngsters to keep off the local railroad tracks and stand only on the platform while waiting for or watching the train.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 11 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois told the South tonight that its prosperity and political power lay in the Democratic party and not "in following those embittered apostates who proclaim themselves Democrats while supporting the nominees of the Republican party."
Milton Katims was the conductor at yesterday's N. B. C. Symphony concert, broadcast, as usual, from the stage of the Belasco Theatre.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 11 (UP) -- California's powerful ground attack, led by All-America Candidate Johnnie Olszewski, overcame a pass-happy Oregon team, 41 to 7, today as the Golden Bears opened their Pacific Coast Conference season before a slim crowd of 17,739.

I would like to see you lend your good offices toward supporting legislation to allow those qualified citizens, disfranchised now because of a change in residence too close to election time, the privilege of voting a restricted ballot.

NOW that Cinerama has emerged as a public attraction, attested to by the daily queues of ticket seekers outside the Broadway Theatre, the question of what a forthcoming offering in the new process might be was answered last week by Merian C. Cooper, general manager in charge of production.

AS Americans, we have a heritage which is not only ancient and glorious but which is also -- what is more to the point -psychologically and emotionally suited to the needs of warmth-seeking human beings. We do not have to invent, explore or pioneer.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Corny Shields showed the way today with his Aileen in the Larchmont Yacht Club regatta on Long Island Sound. He led Bill John, in Dodger, by 3 minutes and 41 seconds over 7 3/4 miles in a north-northeast breeze that came at 12 miles an hour.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 11 -- In the last eight seconds of a thrilling game, Yale conquered Columbia, 35 to 28, before a highly excited gathering of 23,000 in the Bowl this gray afternoon.

The 1952 John H. Finley Award will go to Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer for "significant services rendered to the City of New York," Dr. Gabriel Mason, president of the City College Alumni Association, announced yesterday.

With about three weeks remaining before the Presidential election, financial markets are as indifferent to the political campaign as they have been to recent favorable business forecasts. They have adopted a "wait-and-see" attitude.

TWO of this week's exhibitions, that of Ibram Lassaw's recent sculpture at the Kootz Gallery and a large group of welded pieces at the Sculpture Center, show how resourcefully metal is being exploited as a medium by contemporary artists.

PADUCAH, Ky., Oct. 11 -- This city on the Ohio River is booming with the construction of an atomic plant and other new industry, but it is bewildered by an unusual volume of labor unrest and baffled in the search for solutions.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 11 (AP) -- With only one previous race to her record, the Brookmeade Stable's Tritium vaulted from the ranks of the unknown to account for one of the nation's richest 2-year-old filly races when she won the Selima Stakes today by a length and a quarter over Ogden Phipps' His Duchess before 14,678 fans.
BLOOMFIELD, Conn., Oct. 11 (AP) -- One woman and two men died and two other men were wounded as gunfire and an explosion rocked the quiet streets and lonely roads of Bloomfield tonight.

OPERATING on the celebrated national thesis that you can't kill a man for trying, George Schaefer, who has been guiding the theatre fortunes of the City Center since Maurice Evans withdrew behind the scenes, is now embarked upon attempting to set up a permanent acting company for his Fifty-fifth Street haven.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Before real frost strikes, bring indoors any house plants still in the garden or on the porch, and move to their winter resting place such tender plants as oleander or camellias in tubs. Take cuttings of fuchsias, geraniums, begonias, coleus and similar plants which are too large to be potted up and brought inside. Cut ivy for bowls of water.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Stanford Indians scored three times in the first twelve minutes and then stood off a bad case of their own fumblitis in the last quarter to trounce Oregon State, 41 -- 28, in a Pacific Coast Conference clash today before 28,000 fans.

ROME, Oct. 11 -- A strong plea for intensified Italian-Soviet relations and for the conclusion of a nonaggression pact between the two nations was made to Premier Alcide De Gasperi today by Pietro Nenni, leader of the left-wing Socialists.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Agreements have been reached by the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for the standardization of many basic military weapons, officials of the Mutual Security Agency, the over-all United States bureau seeking to coordinate dollar aid and its implementation, disclosed today.

AT long last my chance has arrived to air a pet literary "peeve." Fowler's "Modern English Usage" looks with its severest censure on a phrase such as "this kind of man" -- stigmatized as "the least criticized and the least excusable of the three misuses" of the word "kind."

A torrent of words came out of Moscow last week as the long-awaited Nineteenth Congress of the Soviet Union's Communist party finally opened. Although Premier Stalin was present, the spotlight was focused on his closest "comrades-in-arms," the Politburo members Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Georgi M. Malenkov, Lavrenti P. Beria and Anastas I. Mikoyan, all of whom, along with a host of lesser figures, delivered lengthy speeches.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Purdue's bruising Boilermakers, led by the stellar quarterbacking and passing of Dale Samuels, smothered Iowa today, 41 to 14, before 34,000 homecoming fans to take the lead in Big Ten Conference play.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Republican party's self-named "truth team" charged today that President Truman started his coast-to-coast tour "on the crony express but ended up on the phony express."

TOKYO, Sunday, Oct. 12 -- Vicious fighting continued today for "White Horse Hill," on the central Korean front. After six days of swaying battles neither side this morning held the shell-scarred crest.

HONG KONG, Oct 11 -- While delegates to the "Asian-Pacific peace conference" in Peiping were condemning war and embracing one another in periodic demonstrations of a "united front" brotherhood, the People's Daily, leading Chinese Communist organ, published an editorial this week analyzing the world situation in terms of a post-war political box-score.

ALTHOUGH the experts have been preaching for years that fall is the preferred time for planting roses, many home gardeners are either fearful or less than enthusiastic. The big sale of rose bushes always occurs in the spring.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Syracuse finally turned the tide against Cornell today. Unable to beat the Big Red in gridiron warfare for five successive years, the Orange humbled the Ithacans 26 to 6.

District Attorney Miles F McDonald, chairman of the Brooklyn Red Cross building campaign, has urged volunteer campaign workers to "take advantage of the generous support we know is available with a speedy effort to put the drive over its $500,000 goal this month."

ANOTHER engaging saga of the extraordinary development of the automobile has been added to the growing list of recent books which describe, from one viewpoint or another, how America has been set awheel.

AS Election Day draws near, garden clubs seem determined to have their political innings. "America Votes" is the theme of the fall flower show to be held by the Garden Circle of New Rochelle on Wednesday, at the Temple Israel Community House.

The U. S. farm belt is a twelvestate area which has more than one-fourth of the nation's 531 electoral votes. This week attention was focused on this region because of "whistle-stop" visits by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois and President Truman for the Democrats and by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the Republicans.

PORT JERVIS, N. Y., -- Only about two hours from the George Washington Bridge runs a foliage trail frequently overlooked by the metropolitan motorist. Hawk's Nest Road, or State Route 97, cut out of the Shawangunk Mountains and traversing Orange, Sullivan and Delaware Counties, is now bright with color -- fiery reds and brilliant yellows contrasting with dark green of pines and cedars.
NORTHPORT, L. I., Oct. 11 -- Sand and gravel has this normally quiet North Shore community in the midst of its biggest battle.

VLADIMIR HOROWITZ has not been represented by too many concerto disks. His new interpretation of Beethoven's Emperor Concerto, with Fritz Reiner and the Victor Symphony, is therefore going to arouse more interest than it normally would, and is also going to get the aficionados in a dither making comparisons with Messrs.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Bob Reynolds swirled around Kansas State's end to put the ball in position for Nebraska's second touchdown today, then walked off the field with a shoulder injury.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The George Bernard Shaw Memorial Appeal is to be discontinued, the fund-raising committee announced today, because of the lack of public support.

ONE could easily review the new exhibition "Sculpture of the Twentieth Century" at the museum here in an orderly, chronological fashion simply by following the logical plan of Andrew C. Ritchie of our Modern Museum, who selected the show.

Banks, among the first employers in this country to establish formal pension plans, are again on the move, overhauling and liberalizing their programs in the light of the current tax regulations and personnel scarcity.

ABOARD NIXON TRAIN in New York, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon lashed at President Truman's foreign policies today in his first swing through upstate New York. He charged that thieves and "second-raters" were helping to run the Federal Government.
AMES, Iowa, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Kansas Jayhawks overwhelmed Iowa State College, 40 to 0, to hold their tie with Nebraska for the lead in the Big Seven football race.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 12 (UP) -- The North Korean premier, Kim II Sung, has sent a message to Premier Stalin saying the Soviet Union's "friendly support" to the North Korean Communists has strengthened relations between the two states, the Moscow radio reported today.
DALLAS, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Oklahoma shocked Texas with four touchdowns in the first period and went to win, 49 -- 20, today in one of the outstanding offensive shows in Cotton Bowl history.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee, under the chairmanship of Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, again has asked the Department of Justice to study the testimony of John Paton Davies Jr., career diplomat, ostensibly to ascertain if perjury had been committed.
Heading Eric Larrabee's "Not the Number. But the Quality of Voters" (Sept. 28) I found myself left somewhere behind when the author took up the "competence" and "affect" of voters.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Vanderbilt, trailing favored Mississippi by two touchdowns at the half, surged back with a pair of last-half scoring drives on the passing arm of Freshman Bill Krietemeyer, but had to settle for a 21-21 tie today when a blocked kick gave Mississippi a fourth-period safety.

Plans are now formulated for the fourth annual dinner dance of the Ballet Associates in America, Inc., to be held on Nov. 28 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Alice Pleydell-Bouverie and Mrs. Norbert McKenna are co-chairmen of the executive committee in charge of the arrangements for the event.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Arkansas, sparked by the ball-handling magic of Ralph Troillett, blazed its way to a 20-to-17 victory over previously undefeated Baylor University tonight.
PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Beneath the shadow of the Kremlin walls stand two symbols of former Russian power -- Czar Kolokol, "King of the Bells," and Czar Pushka, "Sovereign of the Guns."

Attendance at ceremonies marking Columbus Day will occupy most of the time today for Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, the Republican State Committee announced yesterday.

A group of seventy-five persons, many of whom identified themselves as college students, gathered in front of the United States Court House in Foley Square yesterday morning to protest hearings by a Senate subcommittee into Communist activities and beliefs attributed to certain New York City teachers.

FOR the first time in twenty-seven years Herman Hickman, who walked away recently from a ten-year contract as football coach at Yale to become a television personality, is not to be found in some football stadium on Saturday afternoon.

Transamerica Corporation, the Far West's "little Federal Reserve Bank," is about to make its final bow-out from the affairs of a financial institution that a Nineteenth Century Italian immigrant, the late A. P. Giannini, fashioned into the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, now the nation's largest bank.

WE have watched with interest for the past six months the ups and downs here in New York City of a proposed law that would make parents liable to $25 fine for willful destruction of city property by a child under 16 years of age.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Halfback Earl Hersh scored three times tonight as West Chester (Pa.) State Teachers of Pennsylvania topped Delaware, 24 -- 20, for the first time since their seven-game series.

You might think that a subsidized orchestra, playing a fifty-two week season, free from economic pressure, under the interested and participating patronage of one of Europe's few remaining monarchs, would be a happy, contented group. And you would be entirely correct in your belief.

Young matrons headed by Mrs. Herbert T. Mundin and Mrs. William C. T. Gaynor are active in planning for the annual entertainment known as the Fan Ball, to be held on the night of Nov. 21 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Children's Memorial Cancer Fund, Inc.

The contract dispute between three locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and the American Weighmasters Association has served to emphasize that the union is composed of diverse groups in addition to longshoremen and cargo checkers.

MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 11 (AP) -- The man who helped organize America's scientific effort for World War II said today this nation had no pushbutton weapons that accorded to it an overwhelming military eupremacy.

The Bull Lines has signed a contract with the Staff Officers Association of America, A. F. L., providing a basic monthly wage of $390 for pursers on the liner Puerto Rico and several of the company's cargo ships.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Six blocks in the Forties along the East River will become the diplomatic center of the world on Tuesday when the United Nations General Assembly opens its seventh session, the first in its new home -- a low, sweeping building with a dome open to the light.

FOR all its thin veneer of civilization, Liberia's hinterland is still primeval Africa, matted by dense forests and laced by impassable rivers. Some areas have never been trodden by human foot or even seen by human eyes.

ONE of the most powerful arguments against taking the extra-point out of football is that it would put Francis Wallace out of business. Out of the novel-writing business that is. To Mr. Wallace, a game won by more than a point is a runaway and no fit climax.

ONE of the toughest problems a reviewer can face is that posed by the book whose greatest charm is that the author has deliberately underplayed or even concealed his central point. Remember H. F. Heard's "A Taste for Honey"?
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Illinois baffled Washington with the deadeye passing of Tommy O'Connell and a tight pass defensive today to defeat the Huskies, 48 to 14, before a crowd of 38,248.

Extending southwest from Anchorage, Alaska, the stepping stones of the Aleutian Islands lie out across the Bering Sea toward Soviet Russia just a short bombing distance away. WITH the opening of the United Nations General Assembly in its new home this Tuesday the main structures of U. N. Permanent Headquarters in Manhattan stand completed. The sloping, domed Assembly building was designed as a "workshop for peace," in the words of chief architect Wallace K. Harrison. He added, however, that the "real symbol of a building comes out of what is done in it, not what is done to the outside of it."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A new "Combat Development Agency" is being set up by the Army to decide the place and use of such new weapons as guided missiles and atomic artillery in tactical units.

THE Lady apple, used extensively in making up gift packages of fruit, combines a romantic history with modern problems of apple growing and merchandising. Found centuries ago in the forest of Api in Brittany, it was first propagated by monks.

ROME, Oct. 11 -- All non-Catholic religions in Italy are subject to the "vigilance and tutelage of the state" and this means among other things that their ministers must obtain authorization from the Italian authorities before they can exercise their ministry, according to a four-column article that appeared today in the Vatican newspaper the Osservatore Romano.

Heavy pressures are being exerted for resumption of trade between Japan and Communist China. Most Japanese pressure is through diplomatic channels. Most Chinese pressure is taking the form of publicity propaganda.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Taking full advantage of fumbles and intercepted passes, Muhlenberg tonight scored its first victory of the season and at the expense of its old Lehigh Valley rival, Lafayette, defeating the Leopards by 37 to 0.

Registration for next month's Presidential election, which ended last night throughout New York State, set a record in New York City but failed to reach the peak indicated by the heavy outpouring of voters during the early part of the week.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman probably has more popularity and prestige almost everywhere else in the free world than he has in France. This week M. Anadale, Staten Island, was held yesterday in $500 bail for hearing Oct. 22 by Magistrate Abraham M. Bloch in Felony Court.

LEADERS of all factions seem to agree that Dwight D. Eisenhower has an excellent chance to carry Texas this November. Straw votes, though probably highly unreliable, show him ahead so far. The most influential newspapers are for him. The people like him.

THE resumption of Leica camera and accessory imports was announced last week by E. Leitz, Inc., exclusive American importer, following acquisition of the company by Henry Mann, of New York. A continuous flow of these products, which was interrupted during recent sale negotiations, was assured by the Wetzlar, Germany firm.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Clement Attlee, who headed the last Labor Government and hopes to be Prime Minister of Britain again appealed tonight for an end of the factional strife within his party.

MANHASSET, L. I., Oct. 11 -- A blistering condemnation of the appointment of four "outsiders" as department heads of the $3,000,000 general hospital nearing completion here was made today by Dr. Harold A. Butman, past president of the Nassau County Medical Society.

ON a limited basis, WNBT is preparing to explore the feasibility of all-night TV programming. WDTV, in Pittsburgh, has done it successfully, but WOR-TV, locally, found the going a little rough and abandoned its all-night program some weeks ago.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 11 -- Pittsburgh struck from far downfield for a two-touchdown lead on Notre Dame today and then hung grimly on to post a 22-to-19 triumph over the Irish on an insurance safety scored in the final seconds before 45,503 fans.

LONDON, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers scored a 2-0 victory over Newcastle United, holder of the Football Association Cup, to take over the lead in the first division of English soccer today with 18 points.

AS in his previous science-fiction novel, "The City in the Sea," Wilson Tucker concentrates on human beings caught in a strange environment, the aftermath of a disaster. Corporal Russell Gary awakes from a monumental binge to discover that the eastern United States has been bombed with atomic and bacterial missiles.
President Truman delivered two major addresses here yesterday in his campaign to elect Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic candidate for President, and a Democratic Congress.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- With as devastating an attack as ever was mounted by any of its peerless teams of the Forties, Army ripped Dartmouth to shreds in the first half of their football game at Michie Stadium today.
I have been reading THE NEW YORK TIMES for fifty years. It seems to be a very reliable source of information and to permit the reader to use his own judgment.

Always a season's-end event of great importance, this year's national outboard championships, beginning Saturday morning on Lake Alfred, one of Florida's inland bodies have unusual prominence because of the John Ward Trophy test for Class C hydroplanes.

Campaign managers for the election of John Cashmore, Brooklyn Borough President, to the United States Senate announced yesterday that Mrs. A. L. Marks of Brooklyn had accepted the chairmanship of the Women's Independent Campaign Committee for Mr. Cashmore.

Shipwreck Kelly, the redoubtable flagpole sitter and stunt man of the Roaring Twenties, collapsed on a sidewalk and died at 7 o'clock last night with a scrapbook full of old newspaper clippings under his arm. His death came a few doors from the furnished flat at 332 West Fifty-first Street where he had been living alone on home relief.

WENDELL WILLKIE was the creation of a terrible national and world crisis; its creation in the sense that his special gifts of idealism, courage, thrust, and acuteness were called into effective action by the cataclysmic events following the fall of France, which gave him a stage on which to move.

Intent on exhausting every avenue that might lead to the slayer of Sanford L. Tillis, 26-year-old scenic designer, a score of detectives and five superior officers yesterday continued the round-the-clock questioning of his friends and business acquaintances.

CAIRO, Oct. 11 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier and commander in chief, told a special meeting of the Egyptian Chamber of Comerce today that his Government was eager to encourage investment of foreign capital in Egypt and would "for the sake of the country's prosperity provide all necessary guarantees."

Earnings of nearly all leading New York City banks were higher in the third quarter of 1952 than a year ago, despite higher taxes and other operating expenses in the period. Condition statements of the banks for Sept. 30, just published, also indicate that net profits for the nine months ended with September were substantially larger than in the corresponding period of 1951.
DESPITE her nineteen years in show business, Ann Blyth has taken on none of the outward characteristics which often distinguish theatrical folk from those in more prosaic walks of life.

NEWARK, Oct. 11 -- Resumption of full-scale commercial operations at Newark Airport within several months appeared probable today as work on the new $9,000,000 instrument landing runway approached completion.

HAROLD NICOLSON speaks somewhere of a schoolmate of his of whom a schoolmaster said, "You have only to look at him to see that he has never had a mean or dirty thought in his life." Then adds, "It was not till years afterward that I realized you had only to look at him to see that he had never a thought of any kind in his life."

Obviously, the higher the standard of our civilization rises, the higher our tax rates and the more diversified the sources of our taxes become. Taxation does more than raise revenue for government. The power to tax involves the ability to destroy but also the authority to develop our national welfare.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 11 -- Dr. Alfred P. Upshur, manager of the new Veterans Administration Hospital here, built at a cost of $23,000,000, was host at a luncheon today to Carl R. Gray Jr., Administrator of Veterans Affairs, and Admiral Joel T. Boone, Chief Medical Director of the V. A.

An unusual experiment in college curricula will begin this fall at Harding College (Arkansas) with the opening of a new School of American Studies. The new project will attempt, in a four-year degree program, to blend history, social science, political science, economics and government into all its courses so as to give a "solid grounding in American and Christian principles."

From the east side of the world to the west side and from its top to its bottom, the sidewalks of New York have been celebrated in song and story. As the greatest municipal magnet in the world, New York has to measure up to its famous reputation. For this reason, New York hospitality has to be tops, not only for visitors but for the G.I.

STOUT STEVE OWEN bristled noticeably in the old days when the experts persisted in referring to him as a "defensive coach." His heroes kept winning game after game and championship after championship. They didn't win them by playing scoreless ties. Hence, reasoned Steve, he must have had some sort of offense. But the label stuck until one afternoon in 1948 when Jimmy Conzelman came to town with his high-flying Chicago Cardinals.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Oct. 12 -- The South Korean Ninth Division twice battled to the crest of war-battered "White Horse" Mountain today in five hours of vicious see-saw fighting.

AN amateur color photographer who represents the "rebel" element in local pictorial circles last week told the Carroll Camera Club to 'let nature work for you; photograph your world as you find it." The speaker was Herbert Jerome Flatow, one of the most militant of a small number of amateurs in various clubs in this area who are trying to break through the traditions to a contemporary attitude toward photography.

CONRAD AIKEN is now in his sixty-third year. He is the author of more than twenty volumes of verse, more than a half dozen volumes of fiction, both novels and short stories, and of several volumes of criticism.
New York gave President Truman a cordial but hardly an overwhelming welcome yesterday as he made in mid-Manhattan the last stand of his nation-wide whistle-stop campaign tour.

Aides of Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens said yesterday they hoped to do something soon about excessive smoke created by the borough asphalt plant in Flushing, but that efforts so far had bogged down in a maze of uncertainties over how to proceed.
New York gave President Truman a cordial but hardly an overwhelming welcome yesterday as he made in mid-Manhattan the last stand of his nation-wide whistle-stop campaign tour.

Aides of Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens said yesterday they hoped to do something soon about excessive smoke created by the borough asphalt plant in Flushing, but that efforts so far had bogged down in a maze of uncertainties over how to proceed.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- The diplomatic flurry this week over United Sates economic aid to France is not likely to have any lasting consequences, except possibly as an example of how not to conduct diplomacy, in the opinion of expert observers here.

AN event of special and unprecedented importance to the future of symphonic performance in America, we thought, was witnessed recently at the Philadelphia Academy of Music. This was the symposium for conductors of community and non-professional orchestras sponsored by the Philadelphia Orchestra and the American Symphony Orchestra League, lasting through the week from Sept. 30 to Oct. 4.

PRAISE for Ernest Hemingway's "The Old Man and the Sea" has obscured, I fear, the praise which should be credited to Jan de Hartog's "The Distant Shore." Whether or not this latter work is to be counted among the great novels, * * * the scenes with the sharks and the sea surpass, I believe, comparable scenes in the Hemingway story for varied interest, excitement and tension.
