CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Harvard routed Washington University today by 42 -- 0 for its biggest shut-out victory in five years.

DESPITE the criticism that the de Havilland Comet Jetliner is not suitable for use in the United States because its use would not prove to be profitable, its current sole operator, British Overseas Airways Corporation, reports that the four-jet plane is a money-maker.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 11 -- The latest word from the hound's tooth and clay feet circuit is that rough tactics are paying off in the Presidential campaign.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Florida exploded Clemson's hopes of scoring an upset on the buzz-saw passing of Billy Hair today, with a fleet of backs that rolled up a 54-to-13 victory and the Gators' third triumph in four starts.

AMERICA'S program to help India solve her ancient problems of poverty, disease and ignorance has resulted in an astonishing encounter: Twentieth-century Hollywood coming to grips with customs and prejudices older than the Bible. Happily, the outcome has been mutually educational to the young Hollywood technicians here, on an unpublicized but highly effective State Department mission, and to millions of Indian villagers who are now seeing the films the Americans helped make.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 11 -- Preparations for a pressure strike of 375,000 soft-coal miners against the Wage Stabilization Board went forward here today.

These longer evenings are a good time to look for the answers. Why are so many barns painted red? Who thought up the superstition that fish bite better when the wind is in the south? Why do robins scold in October in exactly the same tone of voice they use in May?

More Sarah Lawrence College students will participate actively in the present political campaigns than in previous years, the college officials announce. They see in this a reversal of the trend of the past few years of apathy toward political action among college groups.

IT was May, 1914. Through Harvard Square wound a procession of artillery caissons bearing flag-covered coffins of Marines killed while landing at Vera Cruz. It was an emotional day, for these were among the first American war dead of the twentieth century.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 11 -- Ohio State rallied with three ninety-yard drives to topple previously unbeaten Wisconsin, 23 -- 14, today before 80,345 fans for a major upset and one of Ohio State's most brilliant victories in years. The Buckeyes knocked the Badgers from the Big Ten lead.

THE East and the Midwest are among the few regions in the world where the foliage of many trees and shrubs turns brilliant yellows and scarlets in fall. It is a popular misconception that frost is necessary to produce this conspicuous and beautiful phenomenon.

A new approach to the study of American cultural history, which uses a famous nineteenth-century appraisal of our democracy as a starting point for an intensive study, is under way at the Cooper Union School of Engineering this fall.

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, Commanding General of First Army, scored public apathy toward the need for military strength in a speech last night before 1,000 members of the Forty-fifth Infantry Division Association at their reunion at the New Yorker Hotel.

A new approach to the study of American cultural history, which uses a famous nineteenth-century appraisal of our democracy as a starting point for an intensive study, is under way at the Cooper Union School of Engineering this fall.

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, Commanding General of First Army, scored public apathy toward the need for military strength in a speech last night before 1,000 members of the Forty-fifth Infantry Division Association at their reunion at the New Yorker Hotel.
A manual of interest to those whose responsibility is balancing the family budget has recently been revised:

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 12 -Israeli Government officials explained today that the agreement the Government had made with the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission to pay Arab refugees an initial 1,000,000 ($2,800,000) out of accounts frozen in Israel was intended as a gesture of conciliation that might pave the way toward peace negotiations with the Arab states.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 12 -- The rapid industrialization of the South for the most part is being accompanied by an unparalleled technological advance that "substitutes brain for brawn" and increases the earning power of skilled workers, the Southern Association of Science and Industry reported today.
Attractions are diversified in the many art exhibitions opening this week. The sole historical show is that of Pre-Columbian art, which is on view at the Carlebach Gallery.

Hotel bookings here over the Columbus Day week-end were reported yesterday as heavier than they were over Labor Day, the Fourth of July or any other weekend since the World War II bed shortage, when transients slept on lobby settees.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 -- Buried under the avalanche of steel demand estimates supposed to cover the middle or latter half of next year is the fact that steel production and the volume of steel orders are currently at peak levels.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Since the resumption of free dealings in lead started eleven days ago in London on the Metal Exchange, the price has experienced something like collapse. At one time the spot price was 44 a ton below the Ministry of Supply's fixed price before control was removed, and only a modest recovery has since occurred.

Since the State of Israel was established the congestion at Haifa, its only major port, caused it to be rated as one of the most inefficient ports in the world. Now all that is changed. Its productivity in handling cargo has gone up 35 per cent in a single month as compared with last year's average.

The new Sixtieth Street rapid transit tunnel connection under Queens Plaza in Long Island City, Queens, which will provide means for an interchange of trains between the B.M.T. and IND subways, is 71 per cent completed and should be finished by the end of next year, according to Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the Board of Transportation.
Reports received by THE TIMES from its correspondents in forty-eight states indicate that voters currently regard the following as the leading issues in the national campaign for the Presidency:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 12 -- Milovan Djilas of the Yugoslav Politburo, one of the leading Marxist theoreticians of this country, published this week-end a critique of Premier Stalin's recent article in the magazine Bolshevik and concluded that the Soviet leader's work reflected that "a hidden and invisible crisis in the Soviet system has already begun."
PARIS, Oct. 12 -- The trade deficit of France during the first eight months of 1952 with the dollar zone was almost double that of a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Washington music critic who once dared to call Margaret Truman's singing flat -- and was promised a punch in the nose by her father -- proved today he held no grudge. Paul Hume, critic for The Washington Post, bowed gracefully toward 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue in his Sunday afternoon radio broadcast, which he devoted to a sort of musical history of the Executive mansion and its occupants.

In its ninety-two years of existence, the Cooper Union Forum has had many different types of free programs but even long memories could not recall anything similar to what was tried last night -- an event that was a cross between a public orchestra rehearsal and a program of contemporary music.
Major features of their spring, 1953, lines of men's shirts were announced over the week-end by two leading producers.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 12 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for the Presidency, was reassured today by the Grand Engineer of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers that mishaps on the trains that the General had used in his campaign had had no political significance whatsoever.

AMSTERDAM, Oct., 12 -- After one and a half years during which the Netherlands has succeeded in restoring external, monetary equilibrium she now has introduced a number of measures to counter her extreme creditor position with the European Payments Union.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -- The reorganization of R. K. O. Radio Pictures by the new management group was stepped up over the week-end with a series of dismissals and replacements of key personnel at the studio here and in the company's home office in New York.
President Truman will make a major campaign speech in Brooklyn next Saturday night after a two-hour motor tour of the borough, the Kings County Democratic Committee announced yesterday.

The influence on world-wide shipping now exerted by countries considered relatively unimportant in the maritime field prior to World War II was emphasized yesterday in a special study made public by the National Federation of American Shipping.

The textile manufacturing industry has emerged from its recent slump and the glut of inventories which bogged down the industry have been well liquidated, according to Robert L. Huffines, president of Burlington Mills Corporation of New York.

Prideful man has "put a moratorium on God," causing "practical materialism" to become "America's Enemy No. 1," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Columbus discovered America 460 years ago, and Election Day is three weeks from tomorrow. These facts were inseparably impressed yesterday upon "close to 1,000,000" persons who, according to the police, watched 50,000 marchers in the annual Columbus Day parade up Fifth Avenue.
DETROIT, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Ted Kennedy ripped home three goals tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Detroit Red Wings battled to a 4-4 tie in the roughest game in 1National Hockey League history.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Total trade in grain futures last week was larger than a year ago, but business in the pits was not evenly divided, soybean future purchases being about as large as wheat, corn and oats combined. Soybean future purchases for the week were 86,035,000 bushels, compared with 52,228,000 a year ago.
There is an interesting feature connected with Mr. Truman's "whistlestop" campaigning that I have not seen commented upon.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 12 -- The noisy battle over newly imposed movie and television censorship is being fought out in the Mexican press. In the tumult no one has sided with the censors except the Government, but this has been enough to bring the censor out on top in the first skirmishes.

PADUCAH, Ky., Oct. 12 -- A Citizens Committee for Industrial Harmony has been established here to seek out the cause and a cure for the unrest that has led to sixty work stoppages on the $1,000,000,000 atomic plant, at a cost of 2,775,000 man-hours, as well as numerous other strikes in the area.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- The 1952 session of the General Assembly will open Tuesday amid indications that it will be the most tempestuous in the history of the organization.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 12 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer emphasized today that negotiations between France and West Germany on the settlement of the Saar dispute had not been ended and that the keystone of his policy "as always," was to seek good relations with France.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 12 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin predicted today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's support of Senators Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin and William E. Jenner of Indiana would lose the election for the Republican Presidential nominee.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -The Navy has ordered a limited number of new jet seaplane fighters which could operate independently of aircraft carriers, industry and military sources reported today.
BOSTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Boston's rebuilt Bruins and the Montreal Canadiens battled to a 1-1 deadlock tonight in a National Hockey League game before 11,194 fans at the Boston Garden.

Typical comments of persons interviewed by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES on the issues and progress of the national campaign follow. Political affiliations are given for the persons who volunteered the information.
Five new film, including an importation from Italy, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

A Pakistani who arrived here only four months ago, on her first trip beyond the borders of her own country and those of India, told us the other day how much she liked muffin mixes, how she made meat pie out of hamburger and American pastry and how she fried doughnuts.
Pakistan, among the youngest of modern nations and also, with its 80,000,000 among the largest in population, comes close to being an ideal example of the importance of international

Theodore W. Kheel, in an arbitration ruling, has held that a linotype operator who was a member of a labor delegation on a Soviet-backed propaganda mission was properly discharged for "neglect of duty" even though the offense charged to him was committed off the employer's premises.

GENEVA, Oct. 12 -- As a result of strong United States support, the first experiment in the cooperative international administration of the program of large-scale migration from Europe to under-populated areas is to be continued for at least one more year.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 (AP) -The Philadelphia Eagles, with Bob Walston kicking four field goals, rallied in the final nine minutes of play to score 13 points and beat the victoryless Pittsburgh Steelers 26 -- 21 in a National Football League game at Shibe Park today.

SIEMREAP, Cambodia, Oct. 12 Young King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, one of the associated states of Indo-China, joined his troops here in the shadow of Angkor Wat today to lead them personally against pro-Communist rebels for a second time in the north.

SOUTH BOSTON, Va., Oct. 12 -- Clarence Mitchell, director of the Washington bureau of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, demanded today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower state whether he had a "secret understanding" with Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina regarding civil rights.
MIAMI SHORES, Fla., O 2 (UP) -- Ronald Hoatson nursed a $5,000 hangover today after a two-day spree in which he played "sugar-daddy to eight or ten girls."
A record registration in New York City for this year's Presidential election was in sight last night despite the failure of the usual closing-day rush to materialize on Saturday.

In your editorial "Korea and the Campaign," published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Oct. 5, you have made a brilliant analysis of our unwise and tragically costly pre-war Korean policy. You conclude that we have tried, and are still trying, to find an honorable way to put an end to the killing; that we have made many concessions to the Communists but will not compromise on the issue of an involuntary return of prisoners.

New York City's oldest program of free public lectures at night begins this autumn its ninety-third year in the historic Great Hall of Cooper Union, so cavernous a place and so deeply bedded in the city's rock that sounds of the Third Avenue "El" are scarcely audible.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- If a present costs more than $2.50, Senator Paul H. Douglas does not keep it. The Illinois Democrat discloses his arbitrary rule in a book, "Ethics in Government," to be published tomorrow by the Harvard University Press.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 12 -- Twelve-year-old Mike Murphy, running for secretary of the student body at Madison School, decided that making a clean breast of his financial status was the best way to clear up his difficulties with school authorities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- The professional men and women of the United States were called upon today by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, to join a crusade "to save our great, free nation from the reckless policies which are leading America straight down the road to bankruptcy, socialism -- and possibly even World War III."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson paid tribute to the country's schools and the men and women who conduct them in special messages read here today.

Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore, Democratic nominee for United States Senator, told a Columbus Day dinner last night that Americans of Italian extraction particularly had a right to be resentful of the McCarran Immigration Act.
King Ranch's To Market was being considered yesterday as a substitute starter for Crafty Admiral in next Saturday's inaugural running of the $50,000 Washington International at Laurel.

A group of teen-agers from East Harlem, deeply concerned over narcotics addiction in that district, has started a campaign against the menace. The distribution tomorrow of 30,000 leaflets, "How to Stop the Use of Narcotics in Our Neighborhood," marks the beginning of the drive.

Rubbernecks who are wont to gaze enthralled at advertising messages written in the sky will have their artistic sensibilities titillated today. Color will be used for the first time in commercial skywriting.
A majority of American citizen have "only the haziest notion" of what the Holy Bible teaches, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, pastor of Riverside Church, said yesterday in his sermon.

DALLAS, Oct. 12 (AP) -- John Nance Garner of Uvalde, Tex., Vice President during the first and second Administrations of Franklin D. Roosevelt, revealed today he would vote for Gov. Adlai Stevenson for President and for Senator John Sparkman for Vice President.

Veterans for Eisenhower will celebrate the Republican candidate's sixty-second birthday tomorrow with a luncheon at the Astor Hotel, at which Governor Dewey, Senator Irving M. Ives and Mrs. Doris Corwith of Rockville Centre, L. I., will speak.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, the Politburo's trade expert, told the All-Union Communist party congress that Soviet trade with capitalist countries had fallen off sharply "as a result of the aggressive course of the United States."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 12 -Wilson W. Wyatt, the Presidential campaign manager for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, said tonight that he had considerable evidence that many voters were switching from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican candidate, to the Governor.

Oct. 19 this year falls on a Sunday, so the Stock Exchange will be closed. But there was an Oct. 19, not too many years ago, when the stock market was not closed and when many people, perhaps, were wishing that it had been. When the final gong sounded that day the market was on the verge of demoralization.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 12 (UP) -Gardnar Mulloy added another success to an amazing year today by winning the Pan-American men's singles tennis championship, defeating the former United States champion, Art Larsen, in the final round, 7 -- 9, 8 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5.

The American Jewish Committee charged yesterday that the Socialist Reich party, labeled as neo-Nazi by the West German Government, had not dissolved last month, as its leaders announced, but had gone underground in Germany and was still represented in the United States by a registered agent.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 12 -- The British High Commissioner in Malaya, Gen. Sir Gerald Templer, said today that his security forces were beginning to get the shooting under control in the war against the bandits and predicted that Malaya would attain self-government.

Issuance on Wednesday of the Government's cotton crop report proved the dominant market factor last week. Monday and Tuesday found trading in narrow ranges. The report, however, gave figures somewhat higher than the trade had expected and by Friday net losses on the New York Cotton Exchange had been extended to 41 to 123 points.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Thirty-four of the world's leading scientists today directed a concerted and vigorous attack at the visa and passport policies of the United States Government.

I have read with great interest your editorial entitled "Rehabilitation Pays Off," in which you "congratulate medicine, industry and Government on a job well done, and look forward to further advances in the field of rehabilitation" (of handicapped persons).
Separates, once considered a fad and now a very important and apparently permanent part of the fashion scene, are brought to you today by Patterns of The Times.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- The price trend for grain and soybean futures on the Board of Trade was downward last week. Liquidation of long lines was not counteracted by any great volume of new buying. This technical situation encouraged pressure by local professionals which accentuated the weakness at intervals.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- The American Association for the United Nations urged the United States delegation today to take the lead in mobilizing "world-wide pressure" for a successful conclusion of Korean truce negotiations "based on United Nations principles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- President Truman came home today from a coast-to-coast stumping tour for a three-day rest before hitting the campaign trail again Wednesday for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.

ROME, Oct. 12 -- Amid scenes of enthusiasm and religious fervor such as have seldom been seen in Rome, Pope Pius today urged Catholics to lead the vanguard in the crusade against "the enemy" that is threatening the whole world.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 13 -South Korean infrantrymen dug in last night on the crest of battered "White Horse Hill" on the central Korean front, while new fighting broke out three miles to the east on high ground overlooking Chorwon, on the invasion corridor toward Seoul.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 -- The Communist party's Nineteenth Congress has added another great hydroelectric power development -- a big dam on the River Ob at Novosibirsk in western Siberia -- to the new Five-Year-Plan, it was made known today.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 12 -- Although the regular season does not end until mid-December, it may be that the New York Giants won the American Conference championship of the National Football League today. On the strength of a convincing 17-9 victory over the Cleveland Browns, Steve Owen's squad took a big step forward while the Browns, like their baseball counterparts, the Indians, let the "big one" get away.

DENVER, Colo., Oct. 12 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower mapped political strategy this week-end for his fourth and final thrust into the South in a bid to take the thirty-four electoral votes of Texas and Louisiana away from the Democrats. He will campaign on the issues of civil rights and ownership of offshore oil properties.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie has prepared, for the guidance of any United States citizen employed by the United Nations who may be summoned to testify before a Senate committee, a memorandum outlining the privileges and immunities of representatives of an international organization and their lack of immunity with respect to unofficial actions.

The McCarran Immigration Act was passed, over a Presidential veto, with what we must assume was the noblest of motives: to admit some good foreigners into the United States and to protect the United States against bad and dangerous foreigners. The wisdom of many features of the act was not so evident.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, charged today that the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, Richard M. Nixon, had introduced a bill to prevent the deportation of a Californian who "had very, vary questionable relations with Communists."
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The past week has brought a flow of good economic news.

Percival S. Howe Jr., president of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, said yesterday that training and job placement of blind persons through organizations like the Lighthouse could cut considerably the $60,000,000 spent annually by Federal, state and local government in aid-to-the-blind payments.

BAYTOWN, Tex., Oct. 12 -Ground has been broken here by Consolidated Chemical Industries for the construction of a sulphuric acid manufacturing plant that will use materials obtained from the refinery of the Humble Oil and Refining Company.
LONDON, Monday, Oct. 13 -- The Russians said today that their fighters fired on the United States B-29 bomber that disappeared over the northern tip of Japan last Tuesday with a crew of eight.

The first spadeful of earth for the new parish house and chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, was turned yesterday by Mrs. Albert Henry Wiggin, who has donated the structure, after morning services.

TRENTON, Oct. 12 -- Quick and courageous action by the acting warden and a handful of guards tonight quelled the third major outbreak of violence this year by convicts at the Trenton State Prison here.

New York City voters' registrations last week, plus applications for war ballots, which are still to be counted, appear likely to exceed the record set in 1944. In general, in city, state and nation, more people than usual seem to want to vote this year. The more a commentator knows about politics the less inclined he may be to offer a simple explanation -- for instance, that civic virtue has suddenly expanded.

Austin Scott, former N. Y. U. harrier now representing the Pioneer Club, won the Metropolitan A. A. U. twenty-kilometer road championship yesterday. Twenty-one runners started in the 12 miles 752 yards race and all but one finished.

Customs receipts here in September reversed the downward trend in evidence throughout most of the year, with a net gain of $4,784,927 over the corresponding month in 1951, Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs, said yesterday.

A petition protesting the paucity of Protestant judges in Brooklyn is being circulated among the borough's churches by the Protestant Lawyers Association and the Brooklyn Division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.
A "Family Rosary Crusade" rally at the Polo Grounds under auspices of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York yesterday afternoon brought out 75,000 persons.

The eagerness with which this department leaped upon A. C. Pigou's "Essays in Economics"* has been tempered. The fire behind the bright eye is quenched, for Professor Pigou has included among his essays a disquisition on newspaper reviewers of economic works.

The scepter of eastern football supremacy passed from Army to Princeton in 1950. In the wake of the astonishing massacre that was perpetrated on the Plain of West Point while the Tiger's twenty-four-game winning streak was being snapped by Penn, it becomes pertinent to ask whether the Black Knights of the Hudson are on the march back to the top.
Venetian and German glass objects, together with a group of Italian leather-desk accoutrements, make up a small collection of new accessories on view at Alfred Orlik, 745 Fifth Avenue.

RENO, Oct. 12 (UP) -- For the second straight year Smiley Quick failed today under pressure and E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Ardmore, Okla., carded a 69 to win the $7,500 Northern California-Reno open with a 72-hole total of 271.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 12 -Incomplete results of local elections held all over Belgium today indicated that the Socialists had gained at the expense of Communist candidates, especially in the industrial areas of Liege nad Hainaut.

Our European allies do not appear to be greatly worried over the outcome of the American election. When Mr. Churchill told the Conservative conference at Scarborough that whichever candidate won, "the United States will not abandon the mission of leading the free nations in resistance to Communist aggression," he expressed a conviction held by the governments and the majority of the people in the Atlantic alliance.

John Haynes Holmes, in a sermon yesterday at the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, analyzed the fears that occupy the minds and hearts of Americans in what he termed "The Age of Terror."
TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 13 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,401, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday Korea time:

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Lard prices showed more stability for the nearby deliveries, but free selling of deferred positions were relatively weak. The cotton report for October, which was more bearish than expected, had a depressing effect on all lard futures for a time, and the easier tendency in vegetable oils also curtailed buying.
WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 12 (UP) -- Quarterback Jim Stehlin passed for three touchdowns today as unbeaten Brandeis University defeated Arnold College, 41 -- 25, before 5,000 fans at Marcus Field.

Plans for the "permanent" reconstruction of two traffic-clogged sections of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive will be submitted to the Board of Estimate next month by Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge Authority, and Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 12 -- The spring remaining in the 10-year-old heels of Peg's Pride carried T. F. Gussenhoven's campaigner to the open jumper championship of the Montclair horse show today.

FOOTBALL is a singularly silly sport that follows no intelligible pattern, makes no sense and can be predicted accurately only by idiots. If baseball were to behave in the same untidy fashion, Preacher Roe would be a homerun slugger, Yogi Berra would pitch no-hitters and the Pittsburgh Pirates would beat the Yankees four straight in the world series.
DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Seven automobile race drivers were injured, one seriously, in a series of accidents on three race tracks in the west central Ohio area today.

In your editorial of Oct. 8 you state that France is opposed to a discussion of the Tunisian and Moroccan issues by the United Nations Assembly on the ground that such action would be interference in France's internal affairs.
OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 12 -- George H. (Pete) Bostwick set the pace with three goals as the Bostwick Field Poloists downed Westbury, 7 -- 4, on Bostwick Field today.

" The Gambler," a play by the Italian author Ugo Betti, adapted by Alfred Drake and Edward Eager, will open this evening at 8 o'clock at the Lyceum Theatre, with Mr. Drake starred in the title role. Thomas Hammond and Wayne Harriss are sponsoring the offering.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Peiping radio said the Chinese Communists' "Asian and Pacific Peace Conference in Peiping closed early today after having called on the United Nations to "bring about an immediate armistice in Korea" on Communist terms.

Alabama's amazing daughter frolicked through song, dance and sketch on Saturday night, and Channel 4 never may be quite the same again. For sheer force of personality on TV let there be no quibble: Miss Bankhead is the distaff Durante.

Joseph Stalin is the subject of two books scheduled for publication ten days apart. Next Monday Henry Regnery will issue "I Dreamt Revolution," by William Reswick, former correspondent of The International News Service in Russia and chief of the Moscow bureau of The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Sixteen hundred of the nation's leading hospitals will participate in perhaps the most comprehensive study of hospital financing ever undertaken in this country, it was announced today by Harry Becker, associate director of the Commission on Financing of Hospital Care.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Skippers of the Larchmont Yacht Club with their Class S racing sloops today won their match from those from Narragansett Bay, where a fleet of sister craft sail forth.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Al Rollins registered the first shut-out of the season tonight as the rejuvenated Chicago Black Hawks downed the New York Rangers, 2 -- 0.

Changes of the last twenty years, economic, political and social, rule out the possibility of a recession or major depression, according to Melvin H. Baker, chairman of the board of the National Gypsum Company.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- Premier Antoine Pinay made it clear today that, although he might quarrel with Washington as he did last week, France would remain faithful to "the Atlantic nations" and "the American alliance," of whose benefits she "forgets nothing." At the same time he insisted that France must be treated as a great power.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Bob Williams, completing thirteen of fifteen passes, pitched for three touchdowns today to lead the Chicago Bears to a 38-to-20 triumph over the Dallas Texans before 35,429 fans at Wrigley Field.

BLOOMFIELD, Conn. Oct. 12 (AP) -- The state police today were investigating the possibility that an unemployed electrical worker had been running down a list of persons he had wanted to kill when an expolsion in his automobile took his own life here last night.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 12 -- With a "silent strike" spreading slowly over the nation's soft-coal fields, leaders of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers sought today to dispel any notion that their members were engaged in a "strike against the Government."
Every New Yorker can appreciate the sentiments of Pvt. Joe Costanzo Jr. who wanted nothing more than "a real Italian dinner with all the trimmings."

Casey Stengel and his Yankees having long since departed, soccer took over at Yankee Stadium yesterday. The champion Philadelphia Americans topped the New York Americans, 4 -- 3, and the Brookhattan-Galicia booters beat Brooklyn Hispano, 7 -- 3, as competition opened in the American Soccer League.

The family budget, particularly the cost of food, was discussed by a panel of six high school students at the New York Times Youth Forum in the Du Mont Adelphi Teletheatre yesterday. Jane Nickerson, food editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was the guest on the hour-long program that began at 6 P. M. Dorothy Gordon, founder of the forum, was the moderator.
Swiss cheese and red hair figured prominently in week-end arrests by alert policemen in Brooklyn and the Bronx.

Ralston Young, "the Bishop of Grand Central," delivered the sermon yesterday morning at Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street. He discussed what it means to carry people's burdens as well as their luggage.

Whitford A. Baldwin has been made manager of the unit-load department of the Acme Steel Products Division of Acme Steel Company of Chicago. The division makes heavy-duty steel strapping for carload bracing.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 12 -- Although the national fraternity's constitution presently forbids such action, the Williams College chapter of Phi Delta Theta intends to pledge a Jewish student as a member, according to a story in The Williams Record today.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, and Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, attacked the controversial McCarranWalter Immigration Act in speeches here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP)--Chicago's improving Cardinals rode to a 17-6 victory over the Washington Redskins today on Charlie Trippi's passing and a rugged defensive line that kept the Tribe stalled almost all day.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Frank Pace Jr., Secretary of the Army, told the meeting that the Russians had made "tremendous strides" in scientific research.

The opening-night "La Forza del Destino" at the Metropolitan Opera on Nov. 10 will offer ticket prices scaled from $30 (orchestra) to $2.25 (family circle), it was announced yesterday at the opera house.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 12 (AP) -Iran's new Foreign Minister, former Deputy Premier Hossein Fatemi, announced today he was altering the nation's foreign policy by assigning top diplomats to Asian and neighboring countries rather than to Western nations as formerly.

MONTREAL, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Canada's production of aluminum in the next two years will be stepped up nearly one-third and is expected ultimately to approach figures that will be more than one-half of the present world output.
The way for this country to overcome "foreign leadership in the jet transport field" is to produce water-based jet airliners, a United States seaplane expert contends.

" I never opened it up, but I hope it won't get away from me." That's the answer offered the other day by Charley Donovan. The Hill School's cross-country coach, when asked how fast his royal-blue, war-surplus scooter could travel. Donovan uses the machine to trail his harriers as they plod over the picturesque Schuylkill Valley hills, and apparently it's just the thing for bumpy terrain.

An appeal to the Board of Estimate to make a complete investigation of the $9,000,000 Laurelton sewer network -- bidding, construc-and assessment levies -- was made public yesterday by the Eastern Queens Civic Council, representing twenty member organizations in the drainage area.

JOYCE CARY has done it again. His new novel, "Prisoner of Grace,"* is an extraordinarily brilliant tour de force. Only a consummate virtuoso in the art of fiction could have conceived this original, powerful and macabre study in character, politics and morality. Only Mr. Cary could carry it through to successful completion. But, breath-taking as it is, "Prisoner of Grace" is by no means an attractive or enjoyable reading experience.

Easy-to-care-for materials, such as stainless steel, ceramic, and laminated Strata-wood, are combined with simple design for many of the new flatware sets and cutlery pieces that are now in the stores.
BALBOA, C. Z., Oct. 12 -- Panama Canal pilots have been granted salary increases ranging from $868 to $1,200 yearly, under an agreement with Gov. John S. Seybold, representing the Canal company.

American clothing manufacturers will celebrate twenty years of strike-free labor-management relations and industrial progress with the opening today of the twentieth anniversary convention of the Clothing Manufacturers Association, U. S. A.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -The nation's Economic Stabilizer, Roger L. Putnam, today proposed a stand-by price and wage control law for Presidential use in the event of an emergency. Written into it, however, is veto authority for Congress.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Undefeated San Francisco ground out its third straight National Football League victory today with a convincing 28-to-0 rout of the Detroit Lions before a record crowd of 56,822 at Briggs Stadium.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 12 (UP) -The Los Angeles Rams were outplayed for three periods today, but came to life with three touchdowns and a field goal in the final period to defeat the Green Bay Packers, 30 to 28.
ZURICH, Oct. 12 -- At the invitation of the Brazilian Government five leading Swiss bankers left Zurich last Friday by air for Rio de Janeiro on a tour of inspection lasting until Oct. 28.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Directors of the Export-Import Bank announced today they had authorized credits to borrowers in Brazil totaling nearly $20,000,000.
WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 12 -Edward H. Gerry and Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr., Piping Rock, scored 66, 64 -- 130 to win the 36-hole mixed foursomes tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -The public is going to eat more and pay less for beef and veal next year. Supplies of lamb and mutton will be little changed and supplies of pork will decline. The price of these meats will not change much.
Alexander Kotov of Russia played to a fifteen-move draw in yesterday's seventh round of the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, Sweden, according to a report from Stockholm.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York criticized yesterday the proposal of the City Planning Commission to finance, by "adjusting" the present sewer rent charge against real estate, the expected rise in the cost of work on eight sewage treatment plants in 1953.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 12 -- Vice Admiral Joel T. Boone, chief medical director of the Veterans Administration, declared here today that he would ask Congress when it convened in January to restore the $31,000,000 cut that was imposed for the fiscal year 1951-1952 in the administration's medical budget.

It is, of course, quite obvious that the "peace" aspect of Peiping's just-concluded "peace" conference is another example of the typical Communist reversal of meanings, in which one says "black" to indicate "white." The tone of the proceedings was anything but peaceful and speech after speech bristled with hatred and belligerence.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is "the one man" recognized internationally as able to unite the free world, Senator Richard M. Nixon, his running mate, declared yesterday.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York criticized yesterday the proposal of the City Planning Commission to finance, by "adjusting" the present sewer rent charge against real estate, the expected rise in the cost of work on eight sewage treatment plants in 1953.

A concert of music by Baltic composers was presented yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Estonia was represented by Eduard Tubin's Symphony No. 5. Latvian scores were Jazeps Wihtols' "Jewel Suite," "Rhapsody for Violin and Orchestra" and "Dramatic Overture."

Industrial expansion in the United States has proceeded at a pace "unparalleled in history" since the close of World War II, according to a study on trends in industrial locations issued over week-end by the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Dr. Karel Petrzelka, the new Ambassador from Czechoslovakia, was told on his first visit to the State Department today that relations between his country and the United States could not improve until William N. Otis has received his freedom.

OMAHA, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said today President Truman's whistle stop campaign against Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower did the Republican Presidential nominee "more good than harm."
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of the address by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower here tonight:

BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Eight-year-old Pearl Simon from Louisiana's bayou country, will go back to the Children's Medical Center here tomorrow for a heart operation that, she insists, God told her would kill her. Heart specialists say that without the surgery she will die in four years.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 14 (AP) -Far East Air Forces headquarters Monday denied Soviet charges that a United States B-29 bomber fired at Soviet fighters before it disappeared last Tuesday off northern Japan.
Army and Navy both step out in the van of the football parade this week, figuring in two of the top pairings listed for Saturday the country over.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 -- Charles R. Devine, Spokane, Wash., advertising agency executive, was elected chairman of the Pacific council, American Association of Advertising Agencies, today.

One of the nation's top horticulturists returned yesterday from what was one of the most extensive plant-hunting expeditions -- if not the first -- to the British Isles. T. H. Everett of the New York Botanical Garden arrived aboard the Queen Elizabeth, carefully shepherding a group of portable greenhouses and crates containing 900 plants of 300 varieties -- all strangers to America.

ATLANTA, Oct. 13 -- Two million communicable disease cases occur yearly in the United States despite strides made in battling such diseases, it was asserted here today by Harry G. Hanson, Assistant Chief Sanitary Engineering Officer of the United States Public Health Service in Washington.

In the opinion of Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, the need for price controls on food has passed. Supplies are adequate, the current harvest is the third largest in our history and, according to Mr. Willis, there should not be any bidding for scarce products, a condition that sends prices up.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, charged last night that the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to the Presidency would result in a return to isolationism and the repeal of the New Deal.

CENTRAL CITY, Ky., Oct. 13 -- The picket lines and the tumult have left this little community, but bitterness and the remnants of boycott hang on after one of the strangest labor organizing episodes on record.

Active opposition to any effort to remove the citizenship requirement from the State Nurse Practice Act was promised yesterday by members of the New York State Nurses Association and the New York State League of Nursing Education, meeting in annual convention at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- The Government's Bureau of Land Management, which handles mineral leases on public domain land, is doing a booming business in the new Williston Basin oil country of the Northern Great Plains.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- William George Carr, newly inaugurated Executive Secretary of the National Education Association, told a press conference today that attacks on the public schools by vociferous minorities were slowing down efforts to meet the economic crisis in education.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Jubilant University of Pittsburgh students turned the quiet of the campus into a roaring celebration today in the wake of Saturday's 22-19 football triumph over Notre Dame.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 13 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois prepared to make his final swing into the West and South tomorrow with California and Texas as his main objectives.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 13 (UP) -- Governor Stevenson said today that the issues facing voters this Presidential election were freedom, economic stability and "perhaps whether civilization is to survive.'' He said he would meet these issues squarely and devote "every effort to finding the right answers."

Schools can no longer educate for "simple literacy and manual skills" but must offer a positive program to meet the needs of the nation's young people in these complex times, educators attending the seventh National Conference of County and Rural Area School Superintendents were told yesterday.
A number of years ago, and for a not very long period, a wonderful organization flourished in this city, and perhaps elsewhere in our broad land, attracting hundreds of members.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it was ready to begin purchasing an estimated total of seventy buildings to be demolished to provide new connections with the Lincoln Tunnel made necessary by the building of the $90,000,000 third tube.
SALEM, N. H., Oct. 13 (AP) -- A crowd of 32,132 set a New England thoroughbred racing betting mark today by wagering $2,176,650 on Rockingham Park's 14-race "double-header" program.

For all that antiques have steadily grown in favor in recent years, the turnout yesterday for the opening of the annual fall edition of the New York Antiques Fair at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory came as a pleasant surprise to the 200 dealers taking part.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 13 -- Four men lost their lives and one was at least seriously wounded in a battle between partisans of former President Bechara el Khoury and those of the present regime.

NEWARK, Oct. 13 -- Twenty thousand copies of an illustrated folder, designed to eliminate the "hit-or-miss" element from baby-sitting, have been mailed within the last week to Parent-Teacher Associations, women's organizations, home economics teachers, maternity wards and clinics throughout the state by the women's division of the New Jersey State Safety Council.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The United States has decided to support a move to place the Tunisian and Moroccan disputes on the agenda of the General Assembly, thus reversing the position taken when the issues were previously before the United Nations.
A 16-year-old Bronx high school boy accidentally shot his 14-year-old girl friend yesterday while displaying a .32 caliber revolver and then, full of remorse, shot himself, the police reported.

After a conference with Mayor Impellitteri and other officials at City Hall yesterday, three clergymen representing civic groups on the upper West Side of Manhattan decided that law violations in their area could not justifiably be called a "crime wave."
C. W. White has been appointed sales manager of the Eastern region for Talon, Inc., and Robert M. Evans sales manager of the Western region.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 13 -- It begins to look now as though 1953 will be a big year for screen biographies about prizefighters. Sugar Ray Robinson's triumph and the story behind the punching power and boxing craft that won him the championship belt in the welterweight and middleweight classes will be filmed by Abner J. Greshler, independent producer, in association with Larry Rumans Robinson will play himself in the picture.

Mrs. Julia Brown of Glen Cove, Long Island, will not be able to vote next month for the simple reason that she was in bed with bronchitis during the two weeks of registration. Her case came to our attention through her efforts to hold on to her franchise, which she has exercised faithfully in every election since she was 21 years old.

WHETHER it is influenced by the moon, low temperature, or a desire to check on the color of the grass on the other side of the fence, the woodcock migration is moving this way, and reports from several upstate areas indicate that the alders and birches have a much better timberdoodle population than last year.

Assemblyman John Brook blocked the efforts of Democratic Assemblymen to pass his own bill for permanent personal registration in the 1952 session of our State Legislature, hence his advocacy of permanent personal registration in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES is belated.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 13 -- The United States, British and French Governments announced today that an agreement had been concluded with the Yugoslav Government concerning the basis on which three-power economic aid would be continued during the fiscal year 1952-53.

Cardinal Hayes High's football team scored a 27-7 triumph over St. John's Prep of Brooklyn at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. The victory extended the Hayes team's unbeaten skein to thirteen over a two-season span.
BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- A message from President Truman was read today to delegates at the annual convention of the National Federation of Licensed Practical Nurses.

The Columbia Broadcasting System reported yesterday that it had received special permission from the Mayor's office to use a 4-year-old boy tonight in the cast of Eddie Albert's "Leave It to Larry," which makes its debut over Channel 2 at 8 o'clock.
BERLIN, Tuesday, Oct. 14 -- Erich Ollenhauer, West Germany's Social Democratic leader, named last night a new foreign-supported organization he said was trying to undermine his party.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -Voters already have "elected" eighty-two Representatives and five Senators to the new Eighty-third Congress although the results will not be official for three weeks.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 13 -- A three-goal surge in the final chukker enabled the Piping Rock poloists to gain a 12-9 victory over Meadow Brook at the Piping Rock Club today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- It took the Government more than three years and cost an estimated $500,000 or more in legal fees to dismiss a $4,900-a-year printer. The Supreme Court ended the battle today.

HONG KONG, Oct. 13 -- The United Nations was accused of having failed to live up to its Charter by waging war in Korea and "countenancing the oppression of national liberation movements in many countries" in a resolution adopted by the "Asian and Pacific Peace Conference" in Peiping, the Peiping radio reported today.

Last night's performance before a full house of Mozart's "La Clemenza di Tito" -- "Titus," for short -- was claimed by the Little Orchestra Society to be a first public performance in this city. The chances are that performances of the score will be far between, and as many people as Town Hall could hold took the opportunity to hear it.
YONKERS, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A record daily-double pay-off here was made and the track pacing record equaled at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

TRENTON, Oct. 13 -- The Trenton State Prison was quiet today after last night's outbreak in which twenty-five long-term prisoners locked up three guards and barricaded themselves in Wing 7 for ninety minutes until they were brought to bay by machine gun fire.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 13 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois sent the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund today $100 in currency that had been sent to him by eight employes of THE NEW YORK TIMES as a campaign contribution.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on whether the demand of the International Typographical Union that printers be paid for setting "bogus" type constituted a violation of the Taft-Hartley Act.

There were indications last week that the oft bemoaned condition of air economy of the United States has taken a turn distinctly for the better. It has been unexpected by all but close students of the industry.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 13 -- Students at the University at Eva Peron (formerly La Plata) declared a general strike today as student unrest unexpectedly continued to make itself manifest in a clash with the police. Four students, including two who had been injured, were arrested.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York will mark its thirty-fifth anniversary by staging a festival of music at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 17. It will utilize the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, with Hilde Gueden, Yehudi Menuhin and Alicia Markova, the ballerina, as soloists.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Nearly 43 per cent of the goods and services included in the average family budget now are under full price control, the Government reported today.

Diametrically opposed views on the potentialities of space travel and the building of a so-called artificial satellite that would travel in a fixed orbit around the earth were expressed yesterday at the second symposium on space travel held under the auspices of the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum af Natural History.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Coach Curly Lambeau of the Redskins today said too many of his players had a defeatist, "second division attitude."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Federal law compelling gamblers to purchase a $50 tax stamp will be tested before the Supreme Court, which consented today to hear arguments on the constitutionality of the statute.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The French-bred horse Worden II, was withdrawn today, leaving a prospective field of eight for Saturday's International horse race at Laurel.
In view of her geographical vulnerability to enemy attack, Great Britain is completing a vast program for feeding her 48,000,000 subjects in an emergency.

AN AIR BASE, in Northern Japan, Tuesday, Oct. 14 -- Seventy-five United States F-84 Thunder-jets flew here from Midway Island yesterday and today in the longest over-water flight ever made by single-engined jet fighter aircraft.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today opened a gift center, comprised of a series of shops in the basement of the General Assembly building, in which arts and crafts of forty member states of the United Nations went on sale on normal commercial lines.

Add to the list of films arriving this week, "Trip to America," a French-made comedy, starring Pierre Fresnay and Yvonne Printemps, which will open at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse on Saturday. Henri Lavorel directed and produced from a script he wrote in collaboration with Roland Laudenbach. Martin J. Lewis Productions is releasing the import here.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 13 -- India rejected today a Pakistani Government request for postponement of the passport system of travel between the two countries scheduled to go into force Wednesday, the Ministry of External Affairs said today. India will enforce the new travel regulations from the Indian side of the border, he added.

A program aimed at establishment of a national medical foundation financed by life insurance companies to provide medical care lacking in rural areas was outlined yesterday by John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn and Democratic candidate for Senator.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd, commandant of the Marine Corps, said today that a new method of cutting off Chinese Communist supplies in Korea by air attack was proving effective and had replaced Operation Strangle.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (UP) -- C. Wayland Brooks, Republican National Committeeman from Illinois, said today he had received money from a special fund to help pay office expenses during his entire eight years in the United States Senate.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Milwaukee's public transportation system has changed hands but about all the public will notice is a change of name.

PAWLING, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Trinity-Pawling School's football team has exceptional promise. Coach Jack Karpoe's Blue and Gold eleven, the fastest Jack has had since he came here in 1949, is small and light in comparison with teams of the past three years, and it lacks experience.

Oxford Paper Company announced private placement yesterday of $7,000,000 of its 20-year 4 per cent serial sinking fund debentures and an agreement for sale of an additional $3,000,000 to the same interests by Oct. 1, 1954. Hugh J. Chisholm, president, said the loan will be repaid through semi-annual instalments of $250,000 beginning April 1, 1958, with the unpaid balance due Oct. 1, 1972.

The old question as to how the waters of the Colorado River shall be divided between the states of California and Arizona appeared yesterday on a Supreme Court docket. The Court, acting under Article III, Section 2, of the Constitution, directed California to reply within sixty days to an Arizona complaint.

After a conference yesterday with Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic national chairman, Tammany Leader Carmine G. DeSapio reported that Mr. Mitchell was well satisfied with the progress of the Democratic campaign here.

LARCHMONT. N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Under about as perfect conditions as one could imagine out on the water, the annual lay-up regatta, the curtain lowerer for summer racing craft, was held out on Long Island Sound today from the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Detectives began a search yesterday for a five-day-old infant who apparently was kidnapped from Bellevue Hospital. The baby, who weighed five pounds, six ounces, was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raphael Hernandez of 366 West Twenty-third Street.

DES MOINES, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The nation's 9,580 state supervised banking institutions gained $6,500,000,000 in resources in the 12 months ended June 30, 1952, President Newton P. Black of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks reported today.

Net assets of the Wellington Fund rose $32,871,039 during the first nine months of this year to $226,801,761 on Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday in the quarterly report to shareholders. Net assets were equal to $20.41 a share, compared with net assets of $193,930,722, or $20.02 a share on Dec. 31, 1951.

Radio stations are losing millions of dollars each year by broadcasting commercial copy masquerading as news in the public interest, John F. Hardesty, director of local promotion of the Broadcast Advertising Bureau, Inc., charged yesterday. In an address to the Kentucky Association of Broadcasters in Ashland, Ky., Mr. Hardesty said the condition could not be remedied until broadcasters police all incoming items of questionable news value intended for air use.

OSSINING, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who have been held in Sing Sing Prison's death house for eighteen months, retained their adopted cool manner today after hearing that the Supreme Court had rejected their appeals.
SEATTLE, Wash., Oct 13 -- Churchmen at the convention of the United Lutheran Church in America were urged tonight to expand their programs for children's religious training.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 13 -- The Great Lakes ore fleet is battling reduced drafts, heavy fog and skidding temperatures in its late drive to increase stocks at lower lake docks and furnace yards.

Young women headed by Miss Nancy Ludington and including Mrs. Wayne Johnson Jr. are serving on the junior committee for the performance of Terrance Rattigan's new play "The Deep Blue Sea," with Margaret Sullavan in the leading role, on the night of Nov. 24 at the Morosco Theatre for the benefit of the Scholarship Fund of the Smith College Club of New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that domestic wool production in 1953 will be about the same as this year but that world production will increase.
CAIRO, Tuesday, Oct. 14 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib announced early today that Col. Mohammed Rashad Mehanna had been dismissed as the member of the regency council representing the army.

Casey Stengel will continue to guide the Yankees through the next two seasons. The 62-year-old pilot yesterday signed a new contract and while club policy kept the figures a secret, his earnings may top $90,000 and possibly reach $100,000 for each of the two years.

There were 103 more fatal accidents in this city in the first eight months of 1952 than in the corresponding period last year, the Greater New York Safety Council reported yesterday. The total number of accidental deaths up to Sept. 1, 1952, was 1,946.

OTTAWA, Oct. 13 (Canadian Press) -- One of the significant features of Canada's current industrial growth is the development of a rapidly expanding and varied aircraft industry which has become an important link in Canada's defense planning.

TRENTON, Oct. 13 -- The New Jersey Republican leadership proceeded today with preparations for the state-wide tour Thursday and Friday of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower despite the complaint of one organization group that it was being "left out" of the program.

Anyone with fortitude enough to visit "The Gambler" two or three times, might come away with some understanding of the circumlocutions of Ugo Betti's thought. He is an Italian lawyer who speculates about good and evil -- a little of Pirandello in his method, a little of Freud in his thinking, with perhaps a touch of Sartre in his knack of rationalizing life.

Two incidents on Sunday had political implications and yet achieved the miracle of being genial and kindly. One was the publication by James P. Shields, head of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, of an interchange of messages between himself and General Eisenhower.

Robert Friedenthal, 54-year-old special patrolman, was held without bail yesterday on a felonious assault charge by Magistrate Vernon C. Riddick in Brooklyn Felony Court in the shooting early yesterday morning of a 17-year-old youth. A hearing in the case was set for Oct. 27 in the same court.

Waterfront leaders optimistically awaited last night the opening this morning of arbitration proceedings in the dispute between the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and the New York Shipping Association. Although the union has been split into rival factions since the long dock strike of last fall, leaders expressed confidence that unrest this year would be held to a minimum.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Supreme Court refused today to consider the validity of a Texas law under which a striker had been convicted of a felony and imprisoned for physically interfering with a nonstriker during a labor dispute.

Boys and girls interested in devoting some leisure out of school time to participation in special art, drama, music or dance classes can register now at one of several centers offering these activities for children.

Customs, immigration and public health officers were kept busy from early morning to evening yesterday clearing 6,148 steamship passengers -- one of the heaviest concentrations of travelers to arrive here this year.
MASTER MELVIN OTT had been a member of the Giants for four years when he walked in, shiny-eyed, on John McGraw at breakfast on March 2, 1930.

Few seasons have offered as much news in blouses designed to complement suits as the current one. All the old conventional ideas, the jewelry necklines and such, can be discarded at the outset. The approach this season has been a fresh, fashion-alert one, echoing closely trends glimpsed in other ready-to-wear.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court indicated today it might step in to decide a thirty-year-old dispute between Arizona and California over their rights to waters of the Colorado River.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct 14 -Memo to the delegates of the United Nations General Assembly, meeting in New York tomorrow:

A thief who stole a suitcase from an automobile parked at 168th Street and Haven Avenue on Sunday got a good deal more than he expected, because in the bag were two ampules, each containing 1,000,000,000 contagious bacteria.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 13 -- John L. Lewis came back to the Democratic party today after an absence of sixteen years.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 14 -- The Soviet Foreign Ministry delivered a rebuttal last night to the State Department's defense of United States Ambassador George F. Kennan, charging in a note to the United States Embassy here that the American position was "in gross contradiction to the facts."

The Shipbuilders Council of America yesterday reported that fewer merchant ships were now under construction in American shipyards than at any time since January and the deadweight tonnage laid down was less than at any time in the last eight months.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Dr. Geoffrey Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of the Church of England, was under attack today from two sides in a dispute over angels - specifically angels of Italian marble.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Publicly reported cash dividends by corporations in the first nine months of this year were 4 per cent above the same period last year, the Department of Commerce said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Truman will make more than thirty speeches in three days as he heads into New England early Thursday morning to resume his hard-hitting campaign against the Republicans and their Presidential candidate, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 13 -- Following are abstracts from the resolution adopted today by the United Mine Workers, endorsing the Presidential candidacy of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson:

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- The "Schlieffen Plan" -- the classic turning movement employed by invaders of Western Europe from the East -- may take to the sea if war comes again, according to Vice Admiral Pierre Barjot, French commander-designate of the Indian Ocean strategic zone A new effort to get behind the defenders might be carried out by flotillas of Russian submarines instead of by massed armies, he said.

Senator Richard M. Nixon told a nation-wide television and radio audience last night that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson had disqualified himself for the Presidency by giving Alger Hiss a good character deposition at the first Hiss perjury trial in 1949.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether an alien may live indefinitely at liberty in this country under bond simply because the United States has been unable to deport him.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Apart from some selected industrials, prices declined in most sections of the stock market here today in dull trading. British Government securities finished around two shillings six pence (35c) lower, while most foreign bonds were dull.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- British automobile production for the first eight months of 1952 was 280,000, which was 30,000, or 9.6 per cent, lower than for same period last year. Of this total, 224,000 were exported -- a drop of 6.6 per cent.
A day-long conference will be held tomorrow in the Commodore Hotel to begin the women's part of the $20,000,000 campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

Robert Montgomery, screen star and television producer, has been appointed a member of the board of directors of the Committee of Public Understanding of Epilepsy, Frederick F. Greenman, president of the committee, announced yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 13 (AP) -- General Manager Gabe Paul of the Cincinnati Reds today announced the signing of Buster Mills and Ford Garrison as Redleg coaches for the 1953 season.

FORT SMITH, ARK., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Barbara Romack of Sacramento, Calif., and Marilyn Smith of Wichita, Kan., shared the medal with low qualifying scores of 76 today in the eighth annual Hardscrabble invitation golf tourney.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Tuesday, Oct. 14 -- A dispute among broadcasting engineers led to the cancellation early this morning of the television coverage scheduled for the opening of the seventh session of the General Assembly at 11 A. M. today.

Two brothers made separate trips yesterday to the Federal Courthouse to face technically separate United States Senate subcommittees. Each brother, on the ground of possible self-incrimination, refused to say whether he had ever been a Communist.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The new Sam S. Shubert Memorial Theatre opened here tonight with a pre-Broadway presentation of Maurice Evans in "Dial 'M' For Murder."
A former Communist official who was expelled from the party in 1950 as an informer testified here yesterday before a Senate Internal Security subcommittee that:
PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman tonight said he doubted the American people would follow Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower "blindly in future crusades."
Over on the Jersey Meadows on thirty-nine acres of silt one of the biggest and most successful experiments in food distribution is beginning to bear fruit.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 13 -- Republican hopes of carrying Louisiana and its ten electoral votes soared tonight as tens of thousands of New Orleans residents gave Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower an uproarious welcome. He arrived here to proclaim himself a believer in states' rights in general and, specifically, in the rights of the states to the coastal oil lands.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Odds based on economic conditions that may affect the behavior of voters appear to favor the election of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson as the next President of the United States, three farm economists said today.

I am replying to Will Durant's letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 7. He endorses the assertion of the New and Fair Dealers that their policies cured our economy of unemployment and that we "never had it so good."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review the appeals of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who are awaiting death in the electric chair in Sing Sing Prison for giving atomic bomb secrets to the Soviet Union.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 14 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,402, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. today, Korean time:

HANOI, Indo-China, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The French high command said today French Union forces had killed 300 Vietminh troops and captured 325 in their first winter offensive. The attack was mounted sixty-five miles southeast of Hanoi.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Oct. 13 -- Laura Gregor, a Mount Holly High School senior, woke up in her third-floor bedroom in her home at 42 Union Street here just before noon today, puzzled that her parents had not awakened her at 8 o'clock in time for school.

GENEVA, Oct. 13 -- Population pressures in Italy and Greece must receive more attention from non-European members of the Western community, Hugh Gibson, director of the Provisional International Committee for Migration from Europe, said here today.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 13 -- The Iranian Government announced today it had quashed a foreign-aided plot against Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's regime with the arrest of four men, one a retired general.

" Buttrio Square," a new musical play starring Billy Gilbert and featuring Lawrence Brooks, Lois Hunt and Susan Johnson, opens tonight at 8 o'clock at the Century Theatre under the auspices of Gen Genovese and Edward Woods.

The Clothing Manufacturers Association, now holding its annual convention in this city, has good cause for rejoicing. The relations between the Association and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers have been marked by such harmony and maturity of viewpoint that no strikes have been reported in the shops of Association members for twenty years.
Senator Richard M. Nixon gave a return performance last night; there can be no question of his versatility as a television artist.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Doubtless as a means of aggravating relations between the United States and its European allies in conformity with Communist strategy, Russia is squeezing Britain over grain supplies in obvious retaliation against the Battle Act, which is designed to limit East-West trade between the Soviet bloc and the recipients of United States aid.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 14 -- United Nations forces jumped off this morning in an attack on the central Korean front, on the eastern face of the enemy's old "Iron Triangle."

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 14 -- The Nineteenth Congress of the All-Union Communist party Monday named a special eleven-man committee, headed by Premier Stalin, to draft a new basic program for the Communist party, to be founded on Mr. Stalin's new economic theses.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- The Federal Government today was accused of jeopardizing Europe's oil supply by making charges that the international oil industry is largely controlled by five large American companies and two big British concerns.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- The National Production Authority today announced plans to survey the nation's steel-producing capacity to see if the steel industry is capable of producing certain critical items.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, head of the Central Intelligence Agency, declared here today that this country would "have little to worry about" in fighting Communist infiltration if the next President cooperated with security agencies "as well as President Truman."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -The Defense Department today identified 117 Korean war casualties. Of the total, 35 are dead, 67 wounded, 11 missing and 4 injured in battle zone accidents. The following were listed from New York (none from New Jersey or Connecticut):

The new report put before Mayor Impellitteri by Transportation Board Chairman Bingham on the progress of all subway construction shows that despite the indefinite hold-up on the $500,000,000 Second Avenue subway and extensions in Brooklyn the transportation agency is pushing rapidly ahead with smaller, but still important and in most cases vitally needed, construction projects.

Rights to subscribe for $1,973,000 of 4 per cent convertible subordinate sinking fund debentures will be offered today to stockholders of Foote Mineral Company. Due to mature on Oct. 1, 1967, the debentures are being offered at the rate of $500 of debentures for each 66 shares of common stock held plus in each case accrued interest from Oct. 1, 1952 to Oct. 23, 1952.

TRENTON, Oct. 13 -- Estimates by the New Jersey Highway Authority that the Garden State Parkway could be self-supporting from tolls if built with state-guaranteed construction bonds were reinforced today by engineering studies.

Sunny skies and balmy October weather brought thousands of Columbus Day shoppers to New York retail stores yesterday. Cold weather apparel was their main concern, merchants reported, and volume for the day was a record breaker for many stores, with gains ranging from 5 to 25 per cent for the day.

Four Americans now employed by the United Nations and one who is appealing discharge from a United Nations job refused yesterday to tell a Senate Internal Security subcommittee whether they were now, or ever had been, Communists.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- France's fiscal system, said to have been criticized in the recent "unacceptable" United States note, is the subject of an extensive program of reform that is to be submitted to a special Cabinet council to be held tomorrow.

Bert Bell, the Commissioner of the National Football League, speaking at the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's yesterday, conceded that professional football "is no longer a sport -- it's big business."

The men's clothing industry should start a concentrated drive to make the public more clothes conscious in order to increase the industry's share of the consumer dollar, I. M. Cohen, executive vice president of Joseph H. Cohen Sons, said yesterday.

A collection of accounts of true escapes of many kinds of people from many kinds of disaster, entitled "Great Escapes," will be issued by William Sloane Associates on Oct. 29. Compiled and edited by Basil Davenport, the volume's twenty-eight stories range in time from the days of Xenophon to the present.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13--The 1952 session of the United Nations General Assembly will open tomorrow at 11 A. M. with a forecast of diplomatic storms before the end of the week.

The Brand Chatillon Corporation, one of Fifth Avenue's best known retail jewelry concerns, put the entire stock of its store at 703 Fifth Avenue, items worth $3,000,000, on sale yesterday. Founded in 1916 by George A. Brand and Alfred Chatillon, the concern will go out of business next January.

COPENHAGEN, Oct. 13 -- Tommy Kono, the American Olympic weight-lifting champion, broke a couple of world records and got mixed in the middle of an unscheduled strip act before a delighted crowd, reports disclosed today.

A few days ago John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers signed a new contract with the Northern and Southern mine operators calling for a pay increase of $1.90 a day, as well as an addition of 10 cents a ton to the 30-cent royalty the union has been receiving from the operators, but ultimately, of course, from the coal consumers of the country.

Quiz song, owned by John Howard Clark and ridden by Willie Lester, made a bold closing rush to win the Correction Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The six-fur-long race, for fillies and mares of all ages, attracted twelve contestants, and of these Quiz Song was one of the least regarded, as indicated by her across-the-board pay-off of $42.30, $18.60 and $7.40.

WHEN war came in 1939 Guy Crouchback was almost relieved. Now he could no longer idle in an Italian villa and brood upon his personal humiliations and sickness of soul. In the army, fighting for king and country and justice, he hoped to experience some kind of a spiritual rebirth, a transformation which would wipe out his sense of frustration and unhappiness and restore his self-respect.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Abraham Lincoln's son obtained a $3,555.94 income tax refund that the Treasury decided was illegally deducted from the Civil War President's Federal salary, according to records made available to newspaper men today at their request.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Louis Weber, a New York numbers operator, failed today to get a Supreme Court review of his conviction for lying to the Senate Crime Investigating Committee. This order was one of the more than 300 handed down by the tribunal.

Independent voters like myself might well consider the implications of the following question: How can Mr. Truman reconcile all the slurring, mendacious, gutter-politicking remarks he is now making about General Eisenhower (and will continue to make) with the many kind, courteous and complimentary things he said about our great General a year ago when he, Mr. Truman, was trying so hard to entice Ike to accept the Democratic candidacy?

The Better Business Bureau of New York City has become so well established as a guardian of the public welfare that it will surprise some people to learn that it is only thirty years old.
