At a luncheon today the bureau will be honored, on its anniversary, by civic and business leaders from all walks of life, and by Mayor Impellitteri, representing the city government.

A fire fighter that remains stable in the presence of alcohol has been developed and demonstrated by the Pyrene Manufacturing Company of Newark, N. J. Pyrene engineers say no other foam can lie over a fire as much as twelve hours resisting the attacks of the alcohols ,ethers, esters, ketones and other water-soluble agents more and more used in industry and in petro-chemistry.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 13 -- Dr. James Stacy Coles was installed here today as ninth president of Bowdoin College.

Ivan R. Kraskin, 23-year-old student, agreed yesterday to return to Los Angeles to face a charge of draft evasion. He was arraigned before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, pressed Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, today to proceed with a proposed study by outside experts of how the military forces could make more efficient use of their personnel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- By and large, according to Profs. F. A. Pearson and W. I. Myers of Cornell University, the economic factors that in our political history have seemed to control the decision of voters in Presidential elections are about as favorable for the Democrats in 1952 as they were in 1948.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins of the National Football League today released Guard Ed Bagdon and Fullback Sam Venuto.

Mrs. Walter V. Cranford cut into a huge cake yesterday in the sun-swept Cranford Rose Garden at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Thus the twenty-fifth anniversary of the garden was celebrated in the presence of 250 members of the Botanic Garden and of the American Rose Society.

SEATTLE, Oct. 14 -- The Lutheran convention received today, but did not act upon, a report from its Board of Social Missions, which noted that the number of marriages between Lutherans and non-Lutherans was increasing.
Education should be made a separate area of government, to free the schools from possible political interference, Prof. John K. Norton of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday.

John Foster Dulles Republican foreign policy adviser, asserted last night that we were losing the cold war for lack of leadership at Washington. This will continue until the Russians have the balance of power, he predicted, unless Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is elected to put into effect his plan for a high-ranking central body to plan and direct strategy and tactics.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 14 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois called on the American people tonight to reject Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "crusade" and, in effect, offered them a substitute crusade of his own.

The Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations was told yesterday that opposition by some groups in the United States to the United Nations convention on genocide "is one of the great scandals of our time."
HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of an address by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said today that it would set up a group to plan for speedy militarization of the country's airlines in a national emergency.

Testifying at a Board of Education departmental trial of a suspended teacher, an assistant superintendent of schools declared yesterday that it might be proper for a teacher to attend a meeting of the Communist party to gain information but that becoming a party member was an entirely different matter.

HONG KONG, Oct. 14 -- A permanent "peace liaison committee," headed by Mme. Sun Yat-sen, one of Red China's six vice chairmen, has been established in Peiping to extend the work of the "Asian-Pacific Peace Conference" just concluded there.

The appointment of James Johnson Sweeney as director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, to take effect immediately, was announced yesterday by Harry F. Guggenheim, chairman of the board of trustees of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 14 -- In a belligerent resolution the Pakistan Moslem League, the country's ruling political party, has demanded that the United Nations Security Council take prompt action on the Kashmir problem. It also asked that the Government liberate the people of Kashmir "by all possible means" and that Pakistan "be prepared for an all-out struggle."

With six more American employes of the United Nations refusing to say whether they had been Communists, Senator Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat of Maryland, demanded yesterday that the United States delegation and Secretary-General Trygve Lie dismiss such individuals. He charged that Communists aimed "to overthrow the United States Government."

ATLANTA, Oct. 14 -- Dr. Alexander D. Langmuir, Chief of Epidemiology for the Communicable Disease Center of the United States Health Service, said here today that staying inside a house or building would afford little protection in the event of biological warfare attacks.

Only three horses showed up for the feature race at Jamaica yesterday, and even then the favorite couldn't win. Through scratches and declaring, the main race, a classified handicap called the On Watch, attracted only F. H. Stark's Assignment, the Lazy F Ranch's Out Point and the Phantom Farm's Press.

The Republican party may disappear on a national scale if it does not win the Presidential election this year, Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for re-election, said in a speech here yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The United States delegation was winding up its "home work" today for what may become primarily a role of mediator on many of the issues confronting the new session of the United Nations General Assembly.
Following are the texts of documents made public yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in connection with his financial statement:

The long week-end did little to benefit the stock market. The general price structure eased yesterday with plus signs in only a few of the major pivotal divisions. Stepped-up activity in scattered issues accounted for a slight increase in volume but the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES slipped back 0.34 point.

BOSTON, Oct. 14 -- Former Postmaster General James A. Farley said tonight that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's disclosure of his income had made it incumbent upon his running mate, Senator Richard M. Nixon, to give a similar financial accounting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A 30 per cent share of the $50,000,000 expansion goal assigned to the industrial valves and fittings industry has been allocated to small business, the Small Defense Plants Administration announced today. The expansion goal, established by the Defense Production Administration, calls for the $50,000,000 of added productive capacity by July 1, 1955.

To judge by the results of the Philadelphia Orchestra's first New York concert of the season last night in Carnegie Hall, this orchestra is now the most beautiful, finished and polite orchestra in the land; therefore in the world.

A steel production record is in prospect for October. If the industry maintains its current operating rate (106.6 per cent of capacity last week and an estimated 105.8 per cent this week), the month's output should reach 9,750,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings.

Original Italian designs, purchased not for adaptation but for direct sales, provided a colorful collection yesterday at Milgrim. Models from Veneziani, Vanna and Bartoli were supplemented by designs from Visconti, Fabiani, Polinober, Ferdinandi and Schuberth as well as by others from the Italian ateliers of Fontana and Mme. E. Garnett.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The state told a story today of a man "hopelessly in love" with another woman and offered it as the motive in the killing of Mrs. Dorothy May Grammer.
A "big blue flame" that reportedly passed over New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 7:33 o'clock last night mystified airport personnel.
Michigan State, the pre-season favorite, was back on top of the Associated Press football poll yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 -- President Truman's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization will open a hearing here tomorrow on the new immigration bill passed over the President's veto in June.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 14 (UP) -- Following is the text of the address by General Eisenhower here today:

" Seminar," a new program presented by Columbia University and the American Broadcasting Company, should not be missed by any viewer who is weary of the average run of entertainment pap and yearns for some intellectually meaty TV.

Former Mayor William O'Dwyer, now Ambassador to Mexico, was alleged yesterday to have attended a meeting with "seven or eight" of the city's leading bookmakers in 1949, the year he was elected to his second term as Mayor.
The press has estimated that some 60,000,000 persons heard or saw the Nixon defense on Sept. 23.

An increase in the authorized common stock from 2,650,000 shares to 3,250,000 shares was approved yesterday by stockholders of Segal Lock and Hardware Company, Inc. Stockholders also approved the granting of an option to Meade Johnson, president, to purchase 50,000 shares of stock at prices ranging from $2 to $6 a share.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, announced today that all states had entered agreements with his department to act as agents in the payment of unemployment compensation to veterans discharged from the services since the Korean fighting began.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The late President Franklin D. Roosevelt was quoted in a book published today as saying that persons should not go into politics unless they were financially independent.

HARRISBURG, Oct. 14 -- The Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission will start a research project Thursday into the causes of mounting accidents on the 327-mile superhighway. The project is expected to lead to the installation of a system of traffic controls along the entire roadway.

A nation-wide syndicate of investment houses headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and Blyth Co., Inc., placed on the market yesterday a block of 1,341,085 shares of common stock of Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association.

Buttering a pie pan, sprinkling coconut on top of it and baking the two until golden brown is the newest way to make a pie crust. Newspaper food editors yesterday learned of this easy innovation in home cookery, on the second day of their ninth annual conference, at a dinner given by General Foods.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. M. W. O'Connor's filly, La Corredora, caused a crowd of 18,342 much apprehension today in winning the Vineland Trial, a prep for Saturday's Vineland Handicap. La Corredora lasted by a nose to defeat My Celeste at Garden State.

Your editorial of Oct. 4 on "The E in UNESCO" shows clearly how very much UNESCO's program and activities accord with the hopes and values of the American people. United States support of UNESCO is in the national interest because, like the other United Nations agencies, UNESCO makes possible the pooling of resources and energies toward the attainment of common goals on a world-wide basis.

The greatest threat to the oil industry lies in the "consistent and persistent trend toward more and more Government control and regulation of the industry," P. C. Spencer, president of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, declared yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The new permanent headquarters of the United Nations, gleaming with glass and marble, won warm praise today at the opening of the 1952 session of the General Assembly.
YONKERS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Lady's Leon set the pace all the way to win the Kensico Pace before a crowd of 16,175 at the Yonkers Raceway tonight.

Importers of Italian-type cheeses still remaining under quota controls are hopeful of early action by the Department of Agriculture to make more equitable adjustments in country-of-origin allocations, it was learned yesterday.
The importance of developing in children the initiative to assume responsibility was emphasized last night at a panel discussion conducted by the Child Study Association of America.
FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 14 (AP) -- All eight favorites won handily today in the first round of match play at the Hardscrabble women's invitation golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Millard F. Caldwell, Civil Defense Administrator, complained today that the country's military authorities had only a dim understanding of the importance to them of keeping the basic industries running even though under enemy atomic attack.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Two Negro newspaper syndicates that backed the Democratic Presidential nominees of 1948 and 1944 were split today on this year's candidates.

Twenty-two prominent lawyers -- including Republicans and Democrats, supporters of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower a well as of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois -- put their stamp of approval yesterday on the Illinois Governor's deposition for Alger Hiss.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, declared today that the forces under his command were still below the "minimum military requirements" for the safety of Western Europe and cautioned against any slackening in the rearmament program through false confidence in the Kremlin's intentions or underestimating the Russians' economic capabilities.

Increased excise taxes are making sales departments mere tax collectors, "passing the hat for Uncle Sam," said Robert M. Ganger, president of P. Lorillard Company. Mr. Ganger spoke yesterday at the luncheon of the Sales Executives Club at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Trim city suits with fitted jackets and slim but easy skirts, worn with little jewel-toned velvet hats, opened Elizabeth Arden's fall collection of custom-made and ready-to-wear fashions. The presentation was made yesterday at luncheon in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The stock market was quiet today and prices moved narrowly and irregularly. Most markets weakened at first but strengthened later after it became known that the Government's loans had been fully subscribed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Corn and Soybean futures were under heavy selling pressure much of the session today, and the weakness in these commodities induced rather free selling of wheat. Long liquidation in December wheat forced the price down to a new low on the crop, but there was a rally from the low spots.

Lawrence V. Farnham, a valuation engineer for the Public Service Commission, presented yesterday at a public hearing an estimate of railroad improvement costs involved in the grade crossing elimination project on the Rockaway divisions of the Long Island Rail Road, which he termed "improvements not essential to grade crossing elimination."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Office of Price Stabilization, in the first such action since decontrol procedures started more than a year ago, today ordered ceiling price regulations restored on radio, television and phonograph parts, including aerials and boosters, but not cabinets.

I am one of the many million "independent voters" who although they may be enrolled in one party change their allegiance to follow the outstanding leaders whom they believe most clearly understand the problems facing America and who seem to them to have the courage and ability to solve them.

Don G. Mitchell, head of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., accused both Presidential candidates yesterday of failing to give any recognition in their campaigns to the problems of business and industry. He listed specific charges in present policy that business men hope the next President will bring about.

CAIRO, Oct. 14 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier and Commander in Chief of the Egyptian Army, left an emergency Cabinet meeting briefly today to announce that the provisional Regency Council had been dissolved and that one of its three members Prince Mohammed Abdel Moneim, had been sworn in as the sole temporary regent.

A speedy end of arbitration proceedings in the wage dispute between the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and the New York Shipping Association was indicated yesterday as the union completed the presentation of its case at the initial session.

The basic link between mankind's efforts to understand and harness atomic energy and the manifold problems of cancer control was stressed yesterday as the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases dedicated its new betatron unit and physiology laboratory at 410 East Sixty-eighth Street.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 14 -- General Eisenhower, in a speech here tonight, charged Washington waste and interference in personal life and recalled that in an earlier speech he had said that "unless there is a change Washington will be telling the housewife how to wash her dishes." The candidate said:

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 14 -- The Cabinet in an extraordinary meeting in Jerusalem approved today an import program and foreign currency budget of $305,000,000 for the next fiscal year. The adoption of foreign currency estimates, the first made public since the creation of the four-year-old state, marks a Government decision to balance all foreign currency payments and to peg all commitments abroad to actual income.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced plans for revising its quarterly reporting requirements and its proxy rules under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The commission has invited comments upon the proposals up to Nov. 10.

Western public utility companies borrowed $17,000,000 in the public market yesterday on issues of first mortgage bonds due in 1982. Both issues were sold at public sealed bidding to syndicates headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 14 -- Rabbi Irving Miller, new president of the Zionist Organization of America, said today that he had persuaded Israeli Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion to support a strengthening of the functions of the American Zionist Council instead of the formation of an overall Zionist federation in the United States.

Nota Camberos soprano, made her appearance at Town Hall last evening in a recital that indicated the materials of fine vocalism were at hand even though the artist did not always make skillful use of them.
A letter from Cpl. Eugene Fuller, Twenty-fifth Infantry Division, Korea, and a report by Betty Hutton on her United Service Organizations tour serve to show that morale is often a two-way street.
Michigan State, which last weekend stormed instead of squeaked to victory, improved its position yesterday atop the ratings of the United Press board of coaches.
American Can Company has appointed George F. Henschel sales manager of the Atlantic division.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Two Illinois men attacked today in Federal District Court, the Government's right to draft men for the Korean war. They asserted that President Truman acted unconstitutionally by putting United States soldiers into action there without a declaration of war by Congress.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Military and economic aid shipments overseas climbed sharply in August, the Department of Commerce said today.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- Pat Circelli of Ridgeway, the former Westchester open champion, and Milton Freedman of High Ridge won the Westchester County Golf Association's pro - amateur best-ball tournament over the Siwanoy Country Club course today with a 6-under par 32, 33 -- 65.

" Buttrio Square," which opened at the New Century last evening, is the sort of busy musical play that asks an impertinent question: How did so many competent people ever get into such a jam? From the minute the curtain goes up on an Italian village, the stage is squirming with activity.
TRENTON, Oct. 14 -- Lehman Brothers, New York investment banking concern, was named today as financial adviser to the New Jersey Highway Authority for completion of Garden State Parkway.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Following are the texts of speeches at the opening of the 1952 session of the General Assembly by Mayor Impellitteri of New York and Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, who was elected president, together with excerpts of speeches by Secretary General Trygve Lie, Warren R. Austin, United States Representative, and Dr. Luis Padilla Nervo of Mexico, who was president of the 1951 session:

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks battled from behind tonight to tie the National Hockey League champion Detroit Red Wings, 1 to 1, and break a twelve-game Red Wing winning streak on the Chicago Stadium ice.

The role of the Better Business Bureau in providing a medium through which responsible business seeks to regulate itself in the public interest was hailed yesterday by the city's business and civic leaders on the agency's thirtieth anniversary.

DETROIT, Oct. 14 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California speaking tonight in this labor center with its Negro population of 355,000, asserted that the Democratic party's civil rights pledges would not be fulfilled if Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama were elected Vice President.

A jungle of iron and steel just across the Hudson River in Edgewater became an open house yesterday for a small army of artists who, by invitation, invaded what was to them a strange aspect of the American scene -- an automobile assembly plant.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The de Havilland Aircraft Company said tonight it intended to have the most advanced version of its Comet jet airliner flying in 1954 and coming in production late in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- The Supreme Court has agreed to examine the damage claims of a Danish seaman who signed on a Danish vessel in New York and was injured in a foreign port.

Following is the deposition of Adlai Stevenson, Governor of Illinois, before William B. Chittenden, United States Commissioner in and for the Southern District of Illinois, taken at Springfield, Ill., on June 2, 1949:

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama carried his attack on Gov. Thomas E. Dewey into the Governor's home state tonight and named the two-time Republican Presidential candidate as "the twice-repudiated and embittered Mr. Dewey."

Senator Irving M. Ives, a veteran of World War I, declared yesterday that "we are in World War III, no doubt about it." HE spoke to 100 New York State leaders of Veterans for Eisenhower groups at a luncheon at the Astor Hotel marking the General's sixty-second birthday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and prices eased 16 to 45 points net, with old October showing the most weakness.

With the dedication yesterday of its Physiology Laboratory and Betatron Unit the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases has done much more than expand one of the greatest medical institutions of the world and certainly the greatest that is devoted specifically to cancer.

The State of Louisiana yesterday posted Nov. 10 as the date of sale of an issue of $46,500,000 of veterans' bonus refunding bonds. Among the bonds to be refunded are 3 1/2s sold in 1949. The new bonds will be dated Jan. 15, 1953 and will come due on Jan. 15, from 1954 to 1963.

VIENNA, Oct. 14 -- Josef Kresse, president of the trade section of the Austrian Chamber of Commerce, declared at a meeting in Bregenz today that Austrian business men would not accept United States productivity loans on American conditions.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 15 -- Premier Stalin, in his closing address to the nineteenth Congress of the All-Union Communist Party last night, pledged the Soviet party's support to foreign Communist and "liberation" movements and declared that the interests of the Soviet Union in general were "indivisible from the cause of peace in all the world."

Until Messrs. Truman and Stevenson summed up the deeds of the New and Fair Deals I had no conception of the magnitude of their accomplishments. I had thought that American industry, American labor, American ingenuity and, above all, the American people had contributed in some slight degree to the national progress of the last twenty years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Department State has arranged for thousands of readers abroad, from London to Singapore, to learn about the two major candidates for President in the United States election.

" Crowd Culture: An Examination of the American Way of Life," by Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell, is published today by Harper. The author, formerly professor at Columbia University and former president of St. Stephens College, analyzes the indexes of culture such as the press, radio and television, advertising, sports, music, education and religion, emphasizing the need for individualism.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 -- President Truman's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization, established to survey United States immigration policies and recommend changes, heard unfavorable testimony on the new McCarran-Walter Act from San Franciscans in its one-day session here today.

The Bellmore Shopping Center on the Bedford Avenue blockfront between Oak Street and Wilson Avenue in Bellmore, L. I., has been sold by the builders, Irving Berger and Gilbert Tilles, to a syndicate of New York investors represented by Herbert Einhorn of the law firm of Aronow, Brodsky, Einhorn Dann.

ALBANY, Oct. 14 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey said today the State Health Department was undertaking a $50,000-a-year program aimed at cutting down the death rate from heart disease among state employes through early detection of the disease.

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres this morning. At the Victoria and Sutton Theatres , the attraction is "The Four Poster," the Stanley Kramer adaptation of the Jan de Hartog comedy-drama. The husband and wife team of Rex Harrison and Lilli Palmer portray a married couple in the two-character offering, which was directed by Irving Reis from a script by Allan Scott and is being presented by Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Frank Costello, New York gambler who was convicted of contempt of Congress, has been removed from the Federal Penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa., to the Government's prison at Atlanta.

The price of the 1953 Henry J. series has been cut about $20, the Kaiser - Frazer Corporation announced today. The cars will go on display in dealer showrooms here Friday. City delivered prices exclusive of city sales tax in comparison with 1952 rates were given as $1,602, against $1,622 for the Corsair and $1,790, against $1,810 for the Corsair de luxe sedan.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., Oct. 14 -- Despite defeat in its first two games this season. Canterbury School's eleven is determined to finish the campaign on a winning note. "It's a good club and should develop into the best one since I've been hire." Coach Roger Desroches said today.

The Giants' first football luncheon of the season at the Polo Grounds yesterday supplied the information that one -- and possibly two -- of the three chief casualties in last Sunday's victory over the Browns at Cleveland would be available for duty in Sunday's home opener with the Chicago Cardinals.

There are many doors into the United Nations headquarters, and on the opening day of the Seventh General Assembly considerable confusion as to who was entitled to enter which. Once the right door opened, however, the uncluttered lobbies and vast, high corridors of the new Assembly Hall enveloped delegates and visitors in a soothing atmosphere of order, spaciousness and peace.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America celebrated the seventy-seventh anniversary of its founding yesterday. In honor of the occasion, more than 600 guests attended a reception and luncheon at the concern's home office in Newark, N. J.
SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 14 (AP) -- United States District Judge Albert L. Watson today voided the 1937 sale of the Williamsport Wire Rope Company to Bethlehem Steel Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A welfare fund supported by an employer violates the Taft-Hartley Law if its benefits are restricted to union members, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,403, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. today, Korean time:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- The Government announced approval today of tax benefits for an additional 101 industrial expansion projects estimated to cost $133,154,137.
Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University announced yesterday his support of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson for the Presidency.

For those who would like to add a contemporary flavor to their traditional Christmas trimming of the home, a collection of decorations and accessories newly arrived at the Penthouse Galleries, 15 West Fifty-fifth Street, should prove interesting.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- The House Un-American Activities Committee made slow progress today in its investigation of alleged Communist subversion in this area as five witnesses refused to answer questions on the ground of self-incrimination.

The places of eight of the leaders in the world chess championship zonal tournament remained unchanged at Saltsjobaden, yesterday, after results in five games of the eighteenth round were recorded, according to a report from Stockholm.

All agencies must register and file quarterly returns in connection with the sales tax whether a tax is due to the city or not, according to I. R. Sachar, fiscal adviser of the League of Advertising Agencies, Inc. Mr. Sachar also points out that:

Industrial Rayon Corporation had a net income of $6,469,744, equal to $3.68 a common share for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $6,686,592, or $3.80 a share, for the first nine months of 1951.

" Faith and Prudence." Lottie Michelson's comedy, offered last night by the Blackfriars' Guild, must be classified also as inferior stage material. This opinion is set forth with the knowledge that it represents a minority viewpoint. Most of the patrons indicated convincingly that they found "Faith and Prudence" a highly entertaining presentation.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan accused India tonight of endangering the United Nations by interfering in the domestic affairs of other countries.

Chrystal shapes and the sculptural manner in which they are ornamented show off to special advantage the brilliance of new designs introduced yesterday by Steuben Glass, 718 Fifth Avenue. The fourteen designs include bowls, vases, covered urns and table centerpieces, all made entirely by hand.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 14 -- Clayton Fritchey, public relations director to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's campaign manager, said last night that the Democratic Presidential nominee had telephoned John L. Lewis last week to thank him personally for his support in the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today it had ordered "initial production" of this country's first supersonic delta wing fighter plane, the F-102. The new aircraft will be built by Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation at San Diego, Calif.

Tax levies are having a sharp impact upon the cash position and earnings of many companies and is markedly affecting their financing programs, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Howard L. Doyle, United States Attorney for the Southern District of Illinois, was relieved of his official duties today by Attorney General James P. McGranery pending completion of an investigation of his income tax returns and financial affairs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The State Department began today a "thorough study" of charges by leading atomic scientists that the Government's visa and passport policies endangered liberty.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Secretary of the Air Force Thomas K. Finletter declared today that Operation Strangle, the large-scale air attacks on Communist supply lines in Korea, was draining Soviet production and making the Communist world "bleed at its most vulnerable point."
Ultra-modern facsimile transmission entered the conservative banking field yesterday.

CAIRO, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Egypt and the Sudan were reported today to have agreed on two extensive plans to make better use of the silty headwaters of the Nile -- so vital to their economy -- for irrigation and flood control.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 14 -- Assignment of pupils to public schools "cannot be limited by considerations of race, creed or color," C. Watson Hover, Hamilton County prosecutor, ruled today. He held that the practice must be stopped.

The Harmonie Club, second oldest social club in New York, will celebrate its centennial tomorrow with a reception in a special room constructed and furnished in the style of 1852 within the clubhouse at 4 East Sixtieth Street.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower disclosed yesterday that he had received total income in the last ten years of $888,303.99 -- including $635,000 for all rights to his book "Crusade in Europe" -- and had paid $217,082.71 in income and capital gains taxes.

The Algonquin Gas Transmission Company, which has been winning skirmishes with property owners along more than 2,000 miles of the natural gas pipeline it is laying from Texas to New England, may face a defeat because of a United States Supreme Court decision that could strip the company of its rights of eminent domain.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 14 (UP) -- The 250 delegates to the sixteenth national convention of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., unanimously approved today a three-point program aimed to promote this country's merchant marine.

Net income of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $31,624.000, equal to $3.95 a common share, it was announced yesterday. This represents an increase of 15 per cent above the $27,457,000, or $3.45 a share, earned in the nine months ended Sept. 30, 1951.

Elsewhere in THE TIMES today we publish, as a matter of news interest to our readers, the text of the deposition made by Governor Stevenson as a character witness for Alger Hiss during the first Hiss trial. Mr. Stevenson had been asked by the Hiss defense to appear in person.

The words "juvenile delinquency" are harsh, bitter ones used to sum up carelessly the crimes perpetrated by the younger element of our society. But a deeper meaning to the reasons for lawlessness in our youth exists. The streets of a big city are heartless playgrounds.

An honest regard for the facts is to be expected from the President of the United States even in the heat of a political campaign, but unfortunately the incumbent is so anxious to defend his own record that he seems willing to stoop to distortion to accomplish his purposes.

A ten-year career at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, N. Y., in which he played an important role in the education of officers for the merchant marine, ends this afternoon for Capt. John K. Galleher, administrative officer.

The time when atomic energy will be an economical source of electrical power is much nearer than was predicted a few years ago, according to Paul C. Aebersold, director of the isotopes division of the Atomic Energy Commission, Oak Ridge, Tenn.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Business at the Procter Gamble Company continued active and strong during the last year, with "real progress" being made R. R. Deupree, board chairman, told shareholders at their annual meeting they "can feel sure the company is being operated in a safe, secure and vigorous manner."

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The United States Bureau of Mines reported today that successful tests with a new German coal planer in a West Virginia mine may increase the amount of coal recoverable in thin beds of fuel.

Cake was served up with the campaign yesterday as Republican women celebrated the sixty-second birthday of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, their candidate for President. In all there were three huge confections sliced up and passed around in the course of the day at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 14 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower campaigned by air today across 855 miles of his native Texas to the massed singing of "Happy Birthday" and the cheers of thousands of rebel Democrats and hopeful Republicans who liked his advocacy of states rights.

While America's orchestras have produced "more and greater music every year than all the rest of the world has heard," the problem of financial support has become increasingly urgent, it was stated yesterday afternoon by Floyd G. Blair, president of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Society, at the society's annual meeting in Steinway Hall.
The police and hospital authorities continued yesterday a fruitless search for Gloria Hernandez, who was kidnapped from Bellevue Hospital pediatric ward last Sunday when she was only four days old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The State Department has no present intention of answering last night's note from Moscow restating its demand for the recall of George F. Kennan, United States Ambassador to Russia, who had criticized Soviet restrictions on diplomats.
Fifteen thousand handicapped and underprivileged children were guests of Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon at a free performance of the Rodeo staged for them.

Sales of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., for its fiscal year ended Sept. 30 should prove to be one-third greater than last year's total of $219,861,553, which was the company's record high, George W. Ritter, executive vice president, reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The Asian-Arab bloc, preparing for major political battles, today won four of the fifteen seats on the General Assembly's important General, or Steering, Committee.

Relations between the United States and Soviet Russia have reached a new low as a result of the Kremlin's renewed demand for the recall of Ambassador Kennan, which coincides with two new Soviet attacks on unarmed American planes in which more American lives have been lost.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 15 -- The Chinese poured heavy reinforcements into the battle for "Triangle Hill" on the Central Korean front early today and forced United Nations troops to make some withdrawal f rom advance positions seized yesterday.
VIENNA, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Gen. Alexei Cepicka, Czechoslovakia's Defense Minister, announced today that nation-wide military training would receive "top priority."

HANOI, Indo-China, Oct. 14 (UP) -- France's first big military offensive of the "dry" season fizzled today as Communist-led Vietminh rebel forces, almost trapped by a French striking force, fled under cover of bad weather.
The 1952 major league All-Star team, announced yesterday, is almost brand new everywhere except the infield.

A new administrative arm of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York was officially constituted yesterday at a special diocesan convention in the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

SEOUL, Wednesday, Oct. 15 -- United States Seventh Division troops, attacking through mist and fog, stormed to the top of "Triangle Hill" in Central Korea today. To the West, South Koreans won complete control of "White Horse Mountain" after engineers blasted the last Chinese red defenders to death.

William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman, yesterday characterized as "outright lies and weird charges" the week-end accusation by Paul A. Fitzpatrick, his Democratic counterpart, that the Republican State Committee had hired teen-agers to boo President Truman here last Friday.

Charging that the Democratic campaign was "one of the rankest political frauds in history," Governor Dewey said last night that its spokesmen pretended to be of the extreme left when they spoke in New York and of the extreme right when they spoke elsewhere.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The great dishpan discussion of 1952 is causing extra work at the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics of the Department of Agriculture.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 -- Delegates to the Teamsters Union convention here today increased from $30,000 to $50,000 the annual salary of the union's president, Daniel J. Tobin, and of John F. English, its secretary-treasurer.

An auction sale that is a kind of farewell to an occupation that has absorbed a well-known dealer and collector for fifty years will be held tomorrow at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Lauro Salas, the only Mexican ever to hold an undisputed boxing title, is bursting with confidence that he will hang on to his lightweight crown tomorrow night against the swarming attack of Jimmy Carter.

As one of the estimated half million citizens in New York City who, through no fault of their own, do not get to register, I am officially objecting to being penalized on my voting franchise because a plaster cast on my leg does not permit me to get to register. This, despite the fact that I have been registered for ten consecutive years at the same registration district.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Experts drawn from the military field are holding a three-day meeting at the Pentagon to discuss how to put into operation the new Armed Forces Reserve Act. The participants include representatives of the three armed services and the Defense Department as well as leaders in the National Guard and Army, Navy and Air Force Reserves.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The State Department disputed today a Soviet contention that Yuri Island, where a United States bomber was shot down last week, was Soviet territory.

From a school for young ladies there recently went out a bulletin on matters deemed of interest to parents. Most of these were routine by nature, concerning such trivialities as health, the proper marking for clothing, the listing of sundry school activities.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 14 -- A project to provide homes and livelihoods for all Palestinian Arab refugees in Syria, amounting to approximately 18,000 families or nearly 80,000 persons, either has been signed or is in the last stages of negotiation between the Syrian Government and the United Nations Palestine Arab Refugee Organization, which has its headquarters in Beirut.

Dr. Hans Rosenwald announced in a press release yesterday that he had resigned as chairman of the board of directors of the New Friends of Music, a post he has held since last May. "The pressure of other work" was the reason cited for his action.

Following is the prepared text of an address by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson yesterday at Casper, Wyo., as carried by The Associated Press, and last night in the Mormon Tabernacle at Salt Lake City, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Attempting to solve the "enigmatic situation" of the high number of licensed nurses in the statee as against the shortage of nurse power for patient care and teaching staffs, the New York State Board of Examiners of Nurses is conducting a survey of the field.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 14. -- John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers decided today to collect $8,000,000 in assessments from its members to fortify the union's treasury against "future contingencies."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14 -- A little more than a month ago when Jordan Olivar first greeted a squad of Yale football players, the new coach was not certain how quickly he could do a satisfactory job of molding them into a representative team.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Vice President Albert W. Barkley will start a speaking tour for the Democratic ticket Oct. 15.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 -Smog is more of a nuisance than a serious menace to life and health, Dr. Ralph E. Copeland of San Marino declared today at the annual convention of the American College of Osteopathic Internists.

General of the Army George C. Marshall, former Secretary of State, shied away from political questions when he returned yesterday on the liner United States after a tour of American military cemeteries in Europe and North Africa as chairman of the American Battle Monuments Commission.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Christmas catalogues for the big mail order houses have gone into the mails this week with bigger- than-ever ranges of gift ideas.

VIENNA, Oct. 14 -- The Czechoslovak Government yesterday handed the United States Embassy in Prague a third note of protest against the "sending of spies and terrorists from West Germany and the United States zone of Austria into Czechoslovakia," the Prague radio said tonight.

The extension of voluntary protection against medical expenses and disability in the last three years was characterized as "phenomenal" in a report filed by the National Association of Manufacturers with the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, it was announced yesterday by the association.

All bishops and clergy of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States were urged yesterday by the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop, to observe Sunday, Nov. 2, as a "special day of prayer and intercession for our country, that in this time of decision it may truly be a nation under God."

SANTA FE, N. M., Oct. 14 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, said tonight Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower favored cutting Government expenses, including military expenditures, enough to reduce taxes in 1954.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Bucky Harris today signed a new two-year contract to manage the Senators. His salary wasn't announced officially, but it was reliably reported to be around $35,000 a year. That would be an increase of $10,000 a year over what he made for the past three seasons.
Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, last night called his Republican opponent a "phony liberal."
Many parties were given at the annual luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the American Women's Voluntary Services held yesterday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

A king-sized American-built plane that weighs almost a third of a million pounds when fully loaded has been making successful flights for more than three years. The huge six-engined transport has completed trips with 100,000 pounds of materiel in its cargo compartment.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Parliament returned to Westminster today after its summer holiday to complete routine unfinished business. The current session closes Oct. 31 and the new one will be opened formally by Queen Elizabeth Nov. 4 when she will make her first speech from the throne.

Twelve young women will be presented formally at the Grosvenor Ball to be held on the night of Nov. 29 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of Grosvenor Neighborhood House. Among them are Miss Elizabeth Haight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everest D. Haight, and Miss Helen Ogden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Ogden.

A period of relative stability in the burlap market was predicted yesterday by W. B. Moncur, chairman of the Indian Jute Mills Association. Prices, he said, are more favorable for American users of burlap than in any period since the end of the war, and all conditions point to an ample supply in the foreseeable future.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- In the face of a Republican request that he stay "at his post of duty in Washington," President Truman today planned a third campaign tour that will take him into Pennsylvania, Delaware and possibly New Jersey next week.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 14. -- Good Time, a pacer, and Sharp Note, a trotter, boosted their season's winnings over the $100,000 mark for the first time in harness racing history, the United States Trotting Association announced today.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- A project on the site of one of the worst slum areas in this country's history -- a two-block district -- was officially dedicated here today as this sprawling city's first state-aided housing development for low-income families.

IT'S quite possible that the name of Casey Stengel has appeared in this space on previous occasions. There's a vaguely familiar sound to it. Just in case he's a complete stranger to you it had better be stated hastily that he's the chap who just signed a two-year contract to manage the Yankees at an annual stipend of some $80,000 or $90,000.

Traffic on the B. M. T. line between Manhattan and Brooklyn was halted for half an hour between 1:20 and 1:50 o'clock this morning by a small but smoky fire that broke out after a short circuit occurred in a feeder cable in the Canal Street station.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 (UP) -- A conference of 2,000 insurance executives was told today that a record crime rate could be expected if runaway inflation produced another "1929-type crash."
Two former Soviet Army soldiers, who risked their lives escaping last year through the Iron Curtain, had a chance to let off steam yesterday as soldiers of the United States Army.

" The Time of the Cuckoo," opening at 8 o'clock tonight at the Empire, will mark the 279th presentation at that house. And, according to the handwriting on the wall, it is apt to be the final attraction there before wreckers tear down the famous theatre to make way for an 18-story office building.
Prices of most commodity future on the local exchanges drifted irregularly lower in moderate trading yesterday.

THE Eastern big game season will get under way next Tuesday with the opening of the deer and bear season in Maine's five northern counties, and although the weather will probably be balmy and the cover rather heavy, the opening promises to be the largest in the history of the Pine Tree State.
Right-handers Allie Reynolds of the Yankees and Hoyt Wilhelm, Giants' relief specialist, took the Major League earned-run honors for the 1952 season.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -For the second time, the Supreme Court heard arguments today over the possession of the St. Nicholas Cathedral of the Russian Orthodox Church in North America, in New York City.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 14 -- The fitness of two Rutgers professors to teach has been questioned by a seven-man university committee because the two refused to answer questions put by the United States Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14 -- The Rip Van Winkle legend will be brought to the screen by Gabriel Pascal, possibly late next year. The producer, who now has "Androcles and the Lion" ready for R. K. O. release, has purchased from Gene Fowler a screen play about the marathon sleeper of the Catskill Mountains and has made an arrangement with Edward H. Griffith to be the director.

Israel "is a democratic outpost in the Middle East," Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, said in a telegram that was read last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel arranged by the Greater New York Committee for State of Israel Bonds.

Although the city is being compelled by circumstances to pay $1,900,000 a year more for its electricity than the $14,000,000 it now pays, there are other aspects of the "package" deal between the city and the electrical utilities that make the transaction a favorable one from the municipality's point of view.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Tax fraud investigators reported today that they had filed assessments totaling $23,831 against fifteen New York State residents for money alleged to have been received from pay-offs on graft.

DENVER, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Two men and a woman burned to death today in the crash of a rented single-engine plane a half mile east of Stapleton Airfield. A third man, taken to Fitzsimons Army Hospital, was identified as Beldon A. Wright of Lansdowne, Pa.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 15 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today coupled high praise for the accomplishments of the Tennessee Valley Authority with a promise not to impair its future "effective working out," while asserting that new projects should be developed under a system of Federal-state cooperation.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 16 (UP) -- The United Nations armistice delegation told the Communists at Panmunjom today it was willing to resume talks when the Reds presented a "constructive" proposal and reminded them that the talks were merely recessed, not ended.

Resort and cruise-wear lines shown this week by twenty-one members of the Miami Fashion Council at the New Yorker Hotel are being well received, according to Ben Silverstein, vice president of the organization. Most of the women's apparel makers, he said, will book larger orders than they did a year ago.

Delicacy marked the new designs in diamonds shown yesterday at the "Diamond U. S. A." luncheon in the Plaza Hotel. About $5,000,000 worth of diamond jewelry, representing designs from fourteen jewelers over the country, glittered in necklace, bracelet, clip, pin, ring and headpiece settings.

The newborn baby that was kidnapped on Sunday from Bellevue Hospital was found by the police last night in the shabby furnished room of a woman whose own infant, born last month, is critically ill at the hospital.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Americans will get a break on seats at the inauguration of the next President, compared with what the British will have to pay to see their new Queen crowned.

John R. Kimberly, vice president in charge of sales of the Kimberly- Clark Corporation, has been elected executive vice president, according to Cola G. Parker, president. Mr. Kimberly succeeds Ernst Mahler, who has retired after 38 years but will continue as a director.

Arthur Laurents has written a lovely play for Shirley Booth, and that makes it fine for all of us. "The Time of the Cuckoo" he calls it ironically. It was tenderly acted last evening at the Empire, where it ought to keep open house for a long time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The free nations' refusal to ship strategic war materials to the Soviet bloc has created bottlenecks in the Communists' war industries and slowed down their arms production, Congress was informed today by Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security.

As far as it can be anchored by stone, steel, cement and the will of man the United Nations is now settled, in Ambassador Austin's phrase, "on the rock of Manhattan." In taking possession of its permanent headquarters the General Assembly becomes as regular a feature of the life of New York as the striking group of buildings on the East River is already an integral part of the city skyline.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Lawyers for five oil companies argued in the Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today that the Government's grand jury investigation here of an alleged international oil cartel should he dismissed, or that it should be transferred to the Southern District of New York.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Britain declared today that Iran's counter-proposal for settlement of the British-Iranian oil dispute was "unreasonable and unacceptable."

Improved methods in the administration of cortisone that may reduce and possibly prevent its undesirable side-effects and make its benefits available to a greater number of sufferers from rheumatoid arthritis and other crippling diseases were described yesterday at the annual graduate fortnight or the New York Academy of Medicine.

Directors and officers of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States will mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of Thomas I. Parkinson as president of the company with a dinner in his honor tonight at the Union League Club. Mr. Parkinson was elected president of Equitable on Oct. 20, 1927, succeeding the late William A. Day.

Proposed new local government bond issues totaling $1,420,620,030 will be submitted to voters throughout the nation on Nov. 4 for approval at Election Day referendums, according to a survey by The Bond Buyer, trade newspaper.

New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have the opportunity to return three excellent Senators to Washington on Nov. 4. Connecticut, because of the death of Senator Brien McMahon in July, will be voting for two Senators, and has an excellent candidate for that seat also.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 -- The Chinese Nationalist Government has recovered or "frozen" in the United States by court procedure more than two-thirds of the $5,593,899 allegedly embezzled by Lieut. Gen. P. T. Mow, the former director of the Chinese Air Force Procurement Office in Washington.
Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., is ready with answers to President Truman's inquiry as to where the consumer's dollar goes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Peiping Radio today for the first time talked as if the Korean armistice negotiations at Panmunjom had blown up and accused the United States of trying to rally United Nations support "to continue and extend the Korean War."
A glimpse into his boyhood days was provided yesterday by Harry Gross at the departmental trial of thirty suspended policemen accused of protecting his former gambling places.

After hearing its present name twenty-four years and a name somewhat like it for forty-five, the New York Curb Exchange has taken steps to change its name. If the members approve the recommendation of their governors, it will become the American Stock Exchange on Jan. 5, 1953.
There is a critical shortage of nurses in our nation. This disturbing fact not only menaces

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 15 -- A record field of sixty-six members appeared at the Piping Rock Club today for the women's Long Island Golf Association final one-day tournament and meeting to elect officers for the 1953 season.

Two men staged a quiet hold-up in the heart of the Times Square area yesterday and escaped with $5,500 from Zimmerman's Hungarian Restaurant, 163 West Forty-sixth Street, only a hundred feet east of lunch-hour crowds on Seventh Avenue.
I have read in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 21 a story on the forthcoming elections in Venezuela, which the ruling Junta de Gobierno has set for Nov. 30.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 15 -- The Prudential Insurance Company of America made a $110,000,000 loan to the Lone Star Gas Company here today in what was termed one of the largest financial transactions in Texas history.

Revision of first year training for nurses to teach methods based on experience rather than on unapplied science is producing more confident and more interested students who learn more quickly, the New York State Nurses Association was told yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 (UP) -Executors of the estate of the late William Randolph Hearst filed a petition in Superior Court today seeking permission to distribute to the publisher's five sons quarterly dividends of $37,500 from a trust he left them.

Confidence that Western European producers of machinery and machine tools have attained a lasting as well as greater market in this country was expressed yesterday by members of the American Association of Machinery Importers, Inc.

Investment banking syndicates headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will place on the market today $17,000,000 of new first mortgage thirty-year bonds of Utah Power and Light Company and California Oregon Power Company.

When Mohammed Nasir was a boy in Iraq, he walked each day four dusty miles from his father's date palm grove to the tiny rural schoolhouse in Abu Khasib, near Basra, then four miles back. Now 42 years old, father of one daughter and three sons, including 6year-old twins, he commutes 500 miles in a single day to complete his studies for a doctorate in education.
A weary Phil Rizzuto plagued by nightmares and low blood pressure during the past six weeks, insisted yesterday that he will conclude his active career at the close of the 1953 season.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- A Paris military tribunal asked today that five leading Communist deputies, including Jacques Duclos, acting party head, be stripped of their parliamentary immunity to be prosecuted on charges of endangering the "external security of state" and of demoralizing the armed forces.

Two current art exhibitions are group shows, made up of work by what may be termed middle of the road moderns -- which is to say that a semi-abstract approach is evident but not far enough to the esthettic left to include non-objective paintings.

The versatility of rattan, a trait cleverly demonstrated in a collection of furniture by Tommi Parzinger introduced last year, is emphasized in this designer's latest treatment of the same material. The new collection, available -- as was the last one -- through decorators from the Willow Reed Art Company, 1 Park Avenue, seems even better adapted to indoor use.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois hit the Republicans here tonight with everything but the Golden Gate Bridge.

MOSCOW, Oct. 14 -- According to a Soviet official, the nation's machine-tool industry is prepared to convert at a moment's notice from a peace to a war basis and to supply the Soviet Army and Navy with every type of weapon needed.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 15 (AP) -United States High Commissioner Walter J. Donnelly today announced the appointment of Samuel Reber as Deputy High Commissioner.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- The Soviet Union moved tonight to force a debate on the Korean question in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly before the United States Presidential election. Although the suggestion was made informally and got nowhere, it apparently foreshadowed the tactics to be followed in the next few days.

Joseph Fisher, president of the Pharmacists Guild Local Union 668, in a suit filed in Supreme Court yesterday charged that the city authorities permitted untrained relief recipients and laborers, "most of whom can hardly read and write English" to fill, package and label drugs and medication intended for patients.
CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Its policy-making council today decided to have the National Collegiate Athletic Association share enforcement of its code with individual schools and conferences.

The Pennsylvania Railroad announced yesterday it had appealed to the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington to raise commuting fares on the Long Island Rail Road. It did not specify any amount. but asked the commission to fix a rate high enough to "cover the costs of providing commuter service."
The world series player pool of $500,003.28 yielded checks ranging from $6,026.32 for each full Yankee share to $66.13 for some Phillies' clubhouse help.

Careful self-scrutiny of public education to protect the schools against "unwarranted" criticism was urged yesterday at the seventh National Conference of County and Rural Area School Superintendents at the closing session at the New Yorker Hotel.

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons, headed by Miss Barbara Park and Miss Louise Wheeler as co-chairmen, are serving on the junior committee for the Dec. 11 performance of "Two's Company," with Bette Davis, at the Alvin Theatre for the benefit of the West Side Day Nursery. Mrs. Morton J. Curran Jr. is chairman of the executive committee in charge of the plans for the event.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 15 -- A group of Oregon business men disclosed today that they had gathered a special fund of approximately $13,000 in 1945 to erase the deficit Wayne Morse incurred in his first campaign for the United State Senate. Now, most of them are reported to have said they wished they had not picked up the check.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 15 -- Sweden, the determined neutral, is constructing the most extensive underground works in the world.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Sweden's last words on the June incident when two unarmed Swedish aircraft were shot down over the Baltic are being addressed to the nations of the free world in the form of a Blue Book and a speech.

MOSCOW, Oct. 15 -- Premier Stalin, laying down a new policy line that directs Communist parties to join democratic parties in popular fronts, told Communists abroad that the road to success lay in raising the banner of "bourgeois democratic freedoms" and in defending the national rights and interests of their own countries.
A new exhibit called "Why Toys?" opens today at America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street. The show displays toys designed by adults and examples of the use of creative materials by children.

BERLIN, Oct. 15 -- Dissatisfaction with the leadership of West Germany's labor movement erupted today with sufficient force at the Congress of the German Federation of Trade Unions to threaten Christian Fette's position as its chairman.

A pattern of more efficient selling has been developed by manufacturers during the last few months, according to W. L. Stensgaard, president of the Chicago point-of-purchase advertising displays organization bearing his name.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The second reduced supply of hogs in succession today turned prices higher over a broad section of the livestock market. Sales were steady to 25 cents higher. Cattle anti sheep slid downward, however, In many sales. Department of Agriculture reports on today's trading follow:

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 - Grains in futures displayed considerable strength during the forepart of the Board of Trade session today, but selling increased in the late trade with the market developing a reactionary trend. Corn was particularly strong for a time and this encouraged some buying of other grains, but oats, which were unexpectedly strong yesterday, were inclined to lag.
The delivery of mail by helicopter in the New York metropolitan area was started yesterday afternoon but an uncooperative Weather Man made it a start without the scheduled finish.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- President Truman headed toward New England by train tonight for three days of intensive campaigning in behalf of the Democratic ticket in an area that could well be pivotal, both in the Presidential and Congressional elections.

Yesterday, on the eighth anniversary of its introduction of air freight service, American Airlines announced that its business had risen from 1,900,000-ton miles for the first full year to a current 50,000,000-ton miles producing a healthy $10,000,000 in the line's gross annual revenues.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, which declared yesterday an extra dividend of 75 cents along with the regular 75-cent quarterly dividend, attained a new peacetime sales record of $342,722,873 for the nine- month period ended last Aug. 31, an increase of $189,351,059 over the corresponding period last year. The dividends, payable Nov. 19, bring the year's disbursements to $3.75 against $3.50 in the prior year.

Judge Harold R. Medina, whose accession to the United States Court of Appeals must await his adjudication of the long drawn out investment banking anti-trust suit here, was accused by Government counsel yesterday Of being "hostile" to the Government's "point of view" in the action brought against seventeen major under-writing houses.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 -- Thirteen scientists from this country and abroad were honored tonight with awards by the Franklin Institute at its annual Medal Day dinner.

ALBANY, Oct. 15 -- Thomas J. Curran, Secretary of State, dissolved today 54,000 nonprofit corporations listed on the state's records, including the National Association of Manufacturers, the American Legion, the New York Red Cross and the Salvation Army.

James J. Breslin, a former plain-clothes man attached to the Police Commissioner's confidential squad, was indicted yesterday on a charge of criminal contempt for refusing to testify before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury about his financial affairs.

Staffed by attractive hostesses, the Lincoln Canteen, which is operated under the auspices of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, New York District, was opened to service men at 7 o'clock last night by Mayor Impellitteri.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 15 (UP) -- G. Edward Grammer will be his own star witness in his fight to escape the death penalty for the "almost perfect" murder of his wife.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 15 -- An attorney general's ruling today gave rebellious Texas Democrats a chance to vote for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Richard M. Nixon and still stay in the party by writing in their names in place of the Democratic candidates.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The deadline for a report from the Department of Commerce on the cost of ending tax benefits for Government-subsidized ships has been extended to Nov. 1.

A 51-year-old American woman employed by the United Nations, facing a Senate Internal Security subcommittee with no lawyer beside her, said yesterday that she had been a Communist party member for a little more than a year "around in 1935."

West Hartford, Conn., sold yesterday $3,200,000 of school bonds due from 193 to 1972 to a syndicate headed by Estabrook Co. at a bid of 00.299 for interest of! 1.8 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields ranging from 1,05 per cent to 1.9 per cent.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Oct. 15 -- Admiral Robert B. Carney, United States Navy, who is Commander in Chief, Southern Commander under Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, will confer Monday on Malta with British military commanders regarding the coordination of the European and Middle East defenses in the event of war.

The nation's supply of gasoline stocks increased last week to 120,910,000 barrels from 119,793,000 barrels a week earlier, according to the report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. A year earlier gasoline stocks were listed at 121,895,000 barrels.

Sales of the Johns-Manville Corporation and its subsidiaries exceeded those for the same three and nine-month periods of last year, but earnings were lower, L. M. Cassidy, board chairman, reported yesterday.

The question of how far a teacher must go in disclosing past activities and associations after he denies present membership in the Communist party gave rise to sharp and often bitter argument yesterday at a Board of Education departmental trial.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- John Haderlein, former Chicago Postmaster who resigned effective Sept 1 as a Federal grand jury began investigation of the sale of job promotions in the Chicago Post Office, was one of eleven persons indicted today.

A collection of new furniture designed by Jens Risom is being presented concurrently with the opening of the designer's new showroom at 49 East Fifty-third Street. The furniture is available through decorators.

An experimental program that will furnish daytime care in foster families to children whose mothers must work or for other reasons are temporarily unable to care for them has been set up in New York for the first time. Known as the Foster Family Day Care Service, it has headquarters at 150 Court Street, Brooklyn.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
Jacob A. Malik, smiling, relaxed and in a determinedly non-political mood, left the United States yesterday and wound up a four-year tour of duty as chief Soviet delegate to the United Nations.
BOSTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- The last of baseball's DiMaggio brothers says he has "one year, maybe two" left before he quits.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- President Truman emphasized today the temporary nature of "escape clause" relief granted domestic industries under the Trade Agreements Act.

GENEVA, Oct. 14 -- A real crisis is developing in British-United States commercial relations. The British Government, according to a statement made by Oliver Lyttelton, Secretary of State for Colonies, at the recent Conservative party conference, has decided to ask for revision of existing international agreements that restrict the freedom of countries within the British Commonwealth to increase the amount of tariff preference they grant to one another.

WITH A TASK FORCE, off Korea, Oct. 15 -- Destruction and deception today were the mission of an unusual operation in which the United States used a large aggregation of combat ships to play a gigantic hoax on the Communist troops in North Korea.
" Bernardine," a new comedy written by Mary Chase, author of the Pulitzer Prize "Harvey" and the current fantasy, "Mrs. McThing," opens tonight at the Playhouse at 8 o'clock.

Net income of the United Corporation for the three months ended Sept. 30 was $1,454,619, of which $651,927 was a special credit representing part of the profit realized on the sale last July of all of the company's holdings of South Jersey Gas Company common stock, William M. Hickey, president of United, reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson was tentatively scheduled this evening to be the eighth and last speaker in the order of addresses planned for the United Nations General Assembly session tomorrow.

Interesting additions to the furniture collection made by Industria Mueblera in Mexico and designed by Edmond J. Spence are now on view at Modernage, 16 East Thirty-fourth Street. Made of materials native to Mexico -- mahogany, silver and palm matting -- this furniture is part of a large collection first introduced last April.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- The opening of bids in Albany on Oct. 30 for a $4,726,000 remodeling of the southern part of the Bronx River Parkway in Westchester will mark the beginning of a new tempo for road construction that has not been equaled in the county since the Nineteen Twenties. The work will be financed by the state.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio departed from his prepared text repeatedly tonight and accused President Truman of telling a "big lie" in his statements on "corruption in government."
ABERDEEN PROVING GROUND, Md., Oct. 15 -- The Army showed off its atomic gun today in a series of thunderous, precision-aimed long-distance shots with nonatomic ammunition.

Following are transcriptions of addresses by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower yesterday in Fort Worth, Tex., and Shreveport, La., and the prepared text of his speech in Memphis, Tenn., as carried by The Associated Press:

JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Alaskans apparently voted yesterday to return their Democratic Delegate to Congress by a narrow margin, but first-day returns indicated the probability of a sharp turn toward a Republican Legislature.

In his article, "New York City Teachers on Trial," which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Oct. 5, your education editor, Benjamin Fine, incorrectly assumes that there is no legal doubt about the validity of last week's dismissal of six teachers by the Board of Education under Section 903 of the City Charter.

Warning of a new competitive era to come, Dr. Robert A. Love, director of the evening and extension division of the City College School of Business, declared yesterday that department stores had not been getting their share of dollars spent for goods and services in this country in the last two years.

A 52-year-old man, the father of a girl complainant in a statutory rape case. slashed the defendant about the face with a knife early yesterday in a corridor outside the courtroom in Special Sessions where the case just had been adjourned.

The Juilliard String Quartet, which played the six quartets of Bela Bartok in a two-concert cycle during the 1948-49 season, began a repeat cycle last night at Town Hall devoted to the same six works.

A determination to keep Jews from becoming public charges motivates the aid that the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York gives the entire community. Mrs. Justine Wise Polier, Justice of the Domestic Relations Court, said yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 15 -- Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, tonight accused Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower of abandoning programs and principles he formerly had supported and offering "cheap and easy solutions to the problem of war and peace."

The wild ride of a 20-year-old veteran of the Korean War in a stolen Army truck ended at 9:15 o'clock last night when the two- and-a-half-ton vehicle crashed into the front of the Cortelyou Cleaners at 2103 Cortelyou Road, Brooklyn, almost seven miles from its start at Fort Tilden, Rockaway Point, Queens.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 -- The Tobin-Beck control of the Teamsters Union, A. F. L., ran into a boisterous collision with its New York and Chicago-led opposition today for the first time in the union's sixteenth national convention in session here.

The Danish National Orchestra of the State Radio, now touring the United States under the patronage of King Frederick IX of Denmark and the sponsorship of the American Scandinavian Foundation, gave its first concert in New York last night at Carnegie Hall.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 15 -- In a strong defense of the United Nations, Paul Ginsberg, national commander of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, emphasized tonight that it was the "only instrument in which free men can band together for collective security."

Following are the prepared texts of addresses by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson yesterday afternoon at Spokane, Wash., and Pendleton, Ore., and last night at San Francisco, as carried by The Associated Press:

Coach Lou Little devoted the greater part of yesterday's two-hour scrimmage to a defensive work-out, as the Columbia football team continued its preparation for Saturday's game with Pennsylvania at Baker Field.

Cardinal Spellman blessed the cornerstone of the John J.Raskob Memorial at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday and expressed his gratitude to the Raskob family for this addition to the institution. On the completion of the twelve-story structure it will have facilities for 700 patients.
New Yorkers may be looking as through a glass darkly after midnight Saturday.
COMMERCE, Okla., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Mickey Mantle, one of major league baseball's newest and brightest stars, is going to get all the plaudits his home town can bestow at an all-day celebration Friday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Atomic Energy Commission today approved agreements with two groups of private power companies to supply the electricity for the new atomic energy production plants at Pike County, Ohio, and Paducah, Ky.

SEATTLE, Oct. 15 -- The eighteenth biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America ended its seven-day meeting today. The delegates accepted an invitation to hold the 1954 convention in Toronto. This will be the first time the largest Lutheran body in the United States has met in Canada.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived here last night to make the first Republican Presidential campaign tour in New Jersey in twelve years. He will make nine speeches in the state today and tomorrow.

Governor Dewey received a citation from the Brooklyn Division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies last night for the "encouragement and support" he has given in his administration toward maintaining the agency's 116 institutions.

Jerome Melniker, 55 years old, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, committed suicide yesterday morning by taking gas and an overdose of sleeping pills in his home at 205 West Eighty-ninth Street, the police reported. A member of the family said Mr. Melniker had been in poor health for months and had suffered a nervous breakdown.
The New York City Opera Company last evening presented a restaged version of Alban Berg's "Wozzeck" at the City Center, with James Pease in the title role and Joseph Rosenstock conducting.
