CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Jimmy Carter of New York regained the world lightweight title tonight by outpointing Mexican Lauro Salas of Los Angeles in a fifteen-round bout before one of the smallest crowds for a modern championship boxing match, 5,283, at the Chicago Stadium.

In a near-record session on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, potatoes broke the limit in some deliveries but rallied later on short covering, some profit- taking and new buying, and closed unchanged to 12 points lower. Volume was 1,310 car lots.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- The meat packing industry has protested to the Federal Government the action of the Cuban Government in authorizing a tax-free, import duty-free monopoly to compete with United States lard and fats, the American Meat Institute announced today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 15 -- David M. Sisler, captain of the Princeton baseball team and son of the Browns' hall of fame first baseman, George Sisler, announced today that he had signed a contract with the Red Sox for "between $35,000 and $45,000."

CALCUTTA, India, Oct. 15 -- The introduction by the Indian Government from midnight last night of a passport system brought to a virtual standstill today refugee traffic across the India-Pakistan border, which had been running into the thousands.

The proposed $25,000,000 improvement of Bruckner Boulevard in the Bronx, which would include a new two-mile elevated expressway, was assailed yesterday before the City Planning Commission by Bronx civic spokesmen as something that would depress property values and drive business out of the Bronx.

Kyle Rote, who appears to have made a complete recovery from his knee operation, was groomed for relief service at both halfback posts and at fullback yesterday as the New York Football Giants bore down hard in practice for their 1952 home opener against the Chicago Cardinals at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

The three-week standby underwriting of 3,180,188 shares of Socony-Vacuum Oil Company's common stock resulted in nearly one- third of the big issue being distributed by the underwriters, most of it before the subscription period expired Tuesday.

Eight of the ten adjourned games from the seventeenth and eighteenth rounds in the world chess championship zonal tournament were played off at Saltsjobaden yesterday and, at the close of the sessions, Alexander Kotov of Russia maintained his lead by 2 1/2 points, according to a report from Stockholm.

GENEVA, Oct. 15 -- There is an "immediate and paramount need" for the settlement of emigrants from Europe in potential food-producing regions of Latin America, Hugh Gibson, director of the Provisional Intergovernmental Committee for Migration from Europe, said here today.

September sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an increase of 7.5 per cent over the same month last year, according to a compilation of forty-three companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Roger L. Putnam, Economic Stabilization Administrator, issued a general wage regulation today to carry out the purpose of Congress in exempting from wage controls hourly wages of $1 or less.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's 2-year-old colt Social Outcast was nosed out at the wire in the $26,850 Remsen Handicap at Jamaica yesterday -- but first money of $19,600 went to him (and an $11.40-for-$2 mutuel was posted) following a movie-room decision by the stewards.
LONDON. Oct. 15 -- The start of a new bookkeeping account brought scarcely any improvement in business to the Stock Exchange today and prices remained quietly firm.

HANOI, Indo-China, Oct. 15 -- French Union forces abandoned a string of six outposts about ninety miles northwest of here tonight as Communist-led Vietminh rebel forces began their first big attacks of the new dry season.

TOKYO, Oct. 15 -- Japanese officials said today the government was preparing a stiff demand on South Korea for "clarification" of the republic's recent policy, in effect expelling Japanese shipping from waters far beyond the Korean coastline.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, called upon, the country's coal miners today to prevent anyone from taking away the wage and welfare gains the union won in its new contracts with the major coal producers.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, after active trading. Prices at the finish were 4 to 18 points net lower than on Tuesday.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Timely reinforcements have come up to the Army football team for Saturday's game here with Pittsburgh with the return to action of three, first-string players who have been on the injured list.

The power to change the Port of New York for the better -- power to drive out the gamblers, shylocks and racketeers and to correct the abuses that have contributed to the port's present low estate -- rests almost completely with this city's maritime industry, Miles F. McDonald, Kings County district attorney, asserted last night.

Because the required minimum of nine affirmative votes could not be mustered, the Board of Estimate was forced yesterday to postpone until Nov. 20 action on the pending proposal for the city's purchase of the fourteen-mile Tottenville line of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad Company.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association television committee yesterday granted permission to station WNBW of Washington to televise Saturday's Maryland-Navy football game.

The weakness evident in the stock market in the last week culminated yesterday in a general decline which pushed quotations back for the widest losses of the year. Selling entered all the major sections of the list although many of the steels resisted the pressure

Charles Dickens is the subject of two books by Edgar Johnson, chairman of the English Department at the College of the City of New York, that are scheduled for publication by two concerns. Mr. Johnson has edited the extensive correspondence between the famous author and Burdett Coutts, whose adviser on her many charities Dickens was for more than thirty years.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 15, -A visiting United States official reminded the Indonesians today that they also had a responsibility in the matter of establishing good relations between Indonesia and the United States.

Blood donations to five bloodmobile units and in the three centers brought Tuesday's total to 837 pints, the Red Cross announced yesterday. The highest amount, 245 pints, was given by personnel at Stewart Air Forces Base at Newburgh, N. Y.

The discussion on inflation recently occurring in these columns has confused responsibility for the Federal Government deficits with responsibility for inflation. Inflation and Government deficits are far from equivalents. Prices began a rapid rise at the end of the war.

Airline operators flying jet-powered transports will have to be satisfied with 500 to 600-mile-an-hour speeds for the next twelve and possibly twenty years, according to Admiral Dewitt C. Ramsey, U. S. N., retired, president of the Aircraft Industries Association.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Oct. 15 -- Security provisions of the new McCarran Immigration Act should be retained, but national and racial restrictions on immigration should be liberalized, witnesses declared today at a hearing before the President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization.
HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Oct. 15 -- The amphibious task force that paraded through enemy waters today in a mock invasion steamed back tonight into a first-class storm.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The peacemakers in the British Labor party ran into fresh trouble today when the ascendant Bevanite wing played hard to get.

LONDON, Oct. 15 (Reuters) -- British imports of softwood timber from North American, European and other sources in 1953 will be more than twice as large as this year's, the Ministry of Materials said here today.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal operating subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $386,627,568 in the twelve months to Aug. 31. This compared with a consolidated net of $366,540,094 in the year to Aug. 31, 1951.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 -- A former Communist told the House Un-American Activities Committee today that the Reds had set up a plan for underground activity in this area in the event of war with the Soviet Union.

Dr. Axel Wenner-Gren, the distinguished Swedish financier, philanthropist and supporter of scientific research, is promoting a high-speed electric railway with a car that runs on a single track. The other day a half-size, three-car "Alweg," as the monorailway is called, carried passengers at a speed of over ninety miles an hour on a short experimental track outside of Cologne, Germany.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 16 -- Fiercely fighting Chinese Communists launched counter-attacks last night against South Korean troops inching along the crest of "Sniper Ridge" on the Central Korean front. The Reds also forced American troops back from one of their newly captured positions on nearby "Triangle Hill."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 15 -- Clarence Brown will direct and produce for Metro "A Bullet in the Ballet," based on the novel by the English writers Caryl Brahms and S. J. Simon. Although production plans remain to be worked out, the studio contemplates making the film in England and will endeavor to engage Moira Shearer for the starring role.

Much attention is due to be paid, this musical year, to Modest Petrovich Mussorgsky. The Philharmonic Society is leading off its season tonight with a cantata rendition of some stupendous scenes from his opera "Boris Godunoff."

Still another to join the crusade against overweight is Dr. Robert S. Harris, professor of biochemistry of nutrition at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Yesterday, addressing newspaper food editors attending their ninth annual conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, he offered them simplest reducing diet yet -- simply eat smaller portions.

Congress and a number of the State Legislatures must be under the impression that American soldiers are good enough to fight but not good enough to vote. That is the only conclusion that can be drawn from the deplorable state of our absentee voting laws. It is estimated that at least a million soldiers and many of their dependents will be disfranchised this election because of legislation that is too complicated, inadequate or nonexistent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Justices of the Supreme Court granted a stay of execution today to Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the New Yorkers sentenced to die in the electric chair for transmitting secrets of the atomic bomb to the Soviet Union.
Honors keep piling up on Casey Stengel. The grizzled pilot of the world champion Yankees yesterday was named Manager of the Year for the second time by baseball writers in an Associated Press poll.

The appointment of Theodore A. Heinrich as Associate Curator of Paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was announced yesterday by Francis Henry Taylor, director of the museum. Mr. Heinrich, now Curator of the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery at San Marino, Calif., will assume his new post on April 1, 1953.

THE Connecticut scoter, that illustrious bird misnamed "coot," will be fair game beginning at noon tomorrow, and although the birds are not present in the Sound in real numbers, the reef and breakwater shooters should be able to pick up a few limits.
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 211, for Wednesday's activities:

When the Good Neighbor Ship Brazil of the Moore-McCormack Lines sailed this week for Rio de Janeiro, Captain Harry N. Sadler was on the bridge beginning his thirty-second year as a shipmaster. The Brazilian Government has just awarded him its highest honor, the Order of the Southern Cross, for his outstanding service to Brazil.

" OCTOBER ISLAND,"* by William March, is a novel of salt and savor -- a comedy, as someone said on another occasion, to those who think, a tragedy to those who feel. It is all told in the tale of an immensely proper American lady who got herself enjoyably embroiled in the improbable mythology of a Gauguinesque atoll in the South Seas.

Radio and television render their greatest public service through the broadcasting of religious programs, Dr Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, told a dinner honoring radio and television officials at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- In the ten counties of New York State known collectively as the Southern Tier and constituting a Republican citadel as strong as Maine or Vermont, registration has risen so sharply and with so little help from party organizations this year that politicians of all stripes are puzzled as to its meaning.

BUFFALO, Oct. 15 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, Democratic candidate for Vice President, charged today that his Republican opponent, Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, had voted "consistently and vigorously" to scuttle low-rent housing.

ABOARD NIXON TRAIN, in Michigan, Oct. 15 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California stood fast today on his accusation that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois had disqualified himself for the Presidency by his deposition for Alger Hiss.
Even the best of Democrats could not "clean up the mess" in Washington now, Senator Irving M. Ives declared yesterday.

Black bordered cards bearing the caption "I Am a Jaywalker" will be handed to pedestrians who cross streets into lanes of moving vehicular traffic if a city-wide street safety plan is adopted, it was announced yesterday by the Broadway Association, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The academic quiet of Columbia University was roiled again yesterday by political rivalry as contending groups among the faculty and staff came to the support of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President, or of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, his Democratic opponent.

Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn, Democratic candidate for Senator, declared last night that the last two decades had seen greater social advancement than any other twenty years in the country's history. He said the people should thank the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt and President Truman for these advances.

SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 15 -- Since Coach Benny Howarth first came to St. Mark's School eight years ago, football here has had an Orange and Black tinge. Howarth, a former football and baseball star at Wesleyan, always has been partial to the school of thought represented by Coach Charlie Caldwell of Princeton and has built St. Mark's offenses around the single wing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Mastin G. White, solicitor of the Interior Department, said today the Supreme Court had held that Texas relinquished to the Federal Government any rights the Republic of Texas might have held in the submerged lands of the continental shelf.

The first Communist party congress to be held in Moscow in thirteen years has come to an end with a speech by Stalin in which the Soviet dictator in effect proclaims intensified warfare against the "capitalist" countries, to be waged by Communist Fifth Columns posing as national patriots and peace partisans but pledged first of all to support Soviet Russia and receiving Soviet support in return.

A sharp slump in ocean freight rates and failure of longshoremen to increase productivity were among the factors cited yesterday by waterfront employers in their effort to prove that the wage rise they have offered the dock workers was a generous one.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Office of Price Stabilization ordered today a delay until Oct. 27 in the effective date of its regulation restoring price ceilings on radio, television and phonograph parts. The regulation was issued yesterday and intended to go into force at once, but the agency ruled today that added time was necessary to allow the industry to adjust itself to the change.

For the first time in many months peace on the waterfront appears assured, for the present at least. The wage dispute between the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association is now in the hands of an arbiter. The union, as is usual in arbitration cases, has agreed to abide by his decision.

The National Broadcasting Company has resolved a problem with its engineering union and will begin regular weekday telecasts of the United Nations General Assembly meeting this morning from 11 to 12 o'clock.

The world's first transcontinental oil transport system is taking shape in Canada, John R. White, executive vice president of Imperial Oil, Ltd., told a meeting of the Canadian Club of New York last night.
With price decreases here ranging from $20 to $25, the 1953 Kaiser line of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation will go on display tomorrow in showrooms throughout the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety- four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 8, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Flush Royal, a 33-to-1 shot owned by a bookmaker, George MacLean, and ridden by Billy Nevett, provided one of the most thrilling renewals of the 113-year-old Cesarewitch Stakes today when he came from behind to win the grueling, two-and-a-quarter mile race by a neck.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, tonight picked an "all Truman" Democratic football squad, in reply to the Republican team named by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson at San Francisco.

The natural gas pipeline war flared anew yesterday when six Westchester County property owners obtained an order in Supreme Court at White Plains requiring the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company to show cause why lines already in should not be removed and damages paid.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 15 -- The Democratic State Committee announced tonight the itineraries of the tours to be made in this state later this month by President Truman and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic candidate for President.

Helen Keller, 72 years old, gazed yesterday with sightless blue eyes on an audience whose loud applause she did not hear. Holding Thomas J. Watson's right hand, Miss Keller handed him the Migel Medal, given in honor of M. C. Migel, chairman of the American Foundation for the Blind.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, told Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today that he was not one bit funny when he ridiculed a department pamphlet on dishwashing.

A SERIES of upsets on the gridiron last week had the experts wringing their hands in red-faced embarrassment. None of them came even close to calling the turn on any of the monumental upheavals. But all those upsets never fazed one 9-year-old schoolgirl. She entered the weekly contest conducted by one of our local gazettes and merely picked fifteen right out of fifteen tries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 6 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

CINCINNATI, Oct. 16 (UP) -- An increase in college freshmen this fall has checked the downward trend of total enrollments, according to reports from 567 institutions, Dr. Raymond Walters, University of Cincinnati president, said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 16 -- The Screen Actors Guild, after four months of negotiations, has concluded collective bargaining contracts with two big film producing companies that recognize the principle of additional payment to performers for repeat showings on television of pictures made specifically for the TV market.

Rare books and manuscripts by famous scientists in Greek, Roman, Arab and medieval European civilizations will be on exhibition today at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 33 East Thirty-sixth Street. The exhibition, arranged in honor of the 500th anniversary of the birth of Leonardo da Vinci, is titled "2,000 Years of Science."

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 16 -- Vice President Albert W. Barkley shrugged off questions on the subject of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. Republican of Wisconsin, but ripped into Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, with obvious relish here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today cotton consumption for the period of Aug. 31 to Sept. 27 averaged 37,756 bales for each working day.
A strong plea for the discontinuance of "heavy-handed" bargaining tactics has been made to the Military Sea .Transportation Service by the Committee for the Promotion of Tramp Shipping.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- After quarreling for eighteen months, Iran and Britain were no longer on speaking terms tonight.

The Gracie Square Boys Club and Girls Club of the Home Thrift Association, Inc., Will be aided by the performance of the Rodeo this afternoon in the Madison Square Garden, where sections of seats have been taken over to raise funds for the organization.

YONKERS, Oct. 16 -- A handsome bay gelding, whose trotting career, appeared finished two years ago, won the $25,000 Gotham Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight Chris Spencer, Dunbar W. Bostwick's 10-year-old ace, triumphed by six lengths in 3:09, accounting for a track record for a mile and a half and returning $12, $6.50 and $5.30 across-the-board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Labor members of the Wage Stabilization Board resisted a suggestion today that further consideration of the coal miners' wage increase be postponed until the middle of next week. The board will go ahead with the case tomorrow.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16 -- A tense situation has developed in Mexico's isolated jungle state of Yucatan because the market for the state's single crop, henequen, has collapsed.

ABOARD TRUMAN TRAIN in New England, Oct. 16 -- President Truman declared today that if Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower knew a solution for settling the Korean War he should come forward, as a long-time military adviser, and reveal it in order to save American lives.

The modern equivalent of the famous American vessels of the Clipper Ship Era, the new, fast cargo carrier Keystone Mariner, arrived in New York waters yesterday from her builder's yard at Chester, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The State Department was cautious today in official comment regarding the reports from Teheran of Premier Mossadegh's intention of severing diplomatic relations with Britain.

Two more teachers who have refused because of possible self-incrimination to answer questions of the Senate subcommittee investigating communism in the nation's schools will be dismissed from their jobs next week, it was learned yesterday at the Board of Education.

The clothing sent by voluntary agencies to Korea last year has been distributed and a fresh supply will be needed to provide for "hundreds of thousands of persons" dependent on relief this winter, Msgr. Edward E. Swanstrom, a vice chairman of American Relief for Korea, said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- The calculatedly moderate tone of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's address to the United Nations General Assembly brought swift praise this evening from governments reflecting a variety of individual and regional viewpoints.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Labor's "Shadow Cabinet" reportedly decided tonight that the party's members in Parliament should be asked to issue an ultimatum to the bloc headed by Aneurin Bevan calling on it to disband immediately and cease attacking other party members.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Jewish Welfare Board is experiencing increasing difficulty supplying mounting demands for more technical, field, program, building, administrative and consultative services from more than 300 Jewish community centers, Mrs. Walter E. Heller, chairman of the board's Jewish Center Division, said today.

On record sales of $1,813,490,000 for the first nine months this year, the General Electric Company earned $94,750,000, an increase of 10 per cent over earnings for the like 1951 period when they totaled $85,936.000.

HANOI, Indo-China, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Vietminh rebel troops equipped with mortars and artillery have surrounded a French Union force in the Nghialo rice basin ninety miles northwest of here, it was reported tonight as darkness closed over the battle area.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- Otto Nuschke, head of East Germany's Christian Democratic Union, said at a convention of his party today that it was now "unreservedly Socialist," and announced that it would perform a new role in regulating relations between the church and the state.
DETROIT, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Goalie Terry Sawchuk of the Detroit Red Wings turned in his first shutout of the season as his team-mates routed the Chicago Black Hawks by 7 -- 0 tonight before 11,600 fans.

Addressing a series of rallies in Queens, Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal party candidate for United States Senator, declared last night that the appeal of Senator Irving M. Ives, his Republican opponent, for votes to preserve the two-party system was "obviously an appeal of despair and a confession of weakness."

President Truman's order to the Federal Trade Commission for regular reviews of limitations placed on imported goods previously covered by trade-treaty concessions was seen by foreign trade officials yesterday as designed chiefly to provide some sort of "answer" to foreign criticisms of the trade curbs.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Delegations from the underdeveloped countries opened a drive today for more technical aid and financial assistance for fostering their economic development in the face of a disposition by the industrially advanced countries to concentrate their budgets upon rearmament.

The first Philharmonic - Symphony Society concert of the season under Dimitri Mitropoulos last night in Carnegie Hall offered a program of exceptional possibilities: the Beethoven "Fidelio" overture; Richard Strauss' tone-poem "Also Sprach Zarathustra," which is in some respects his most exceptional score, and excerpts from Mussorgsky's opera "Boris Godunoff," done with the assistance of the Schola Cantorum chorus and soloists of distinction in concert form.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- William Frederick Hoppe, the master among three-cushion billiard players, racked up his cue today in the Sportsman's Room of the Illinois Athletic Club.

MANILA, Oct. 16 -- President Elpidio Quirino, publicly quarreling with the Opposition-controlled Senate, took control today of the Senate-inspired investigation of the Philippine charity sweepstakes officials accused of malfeasance.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- The United States Court of Appeals brought an end today to a two-year fight for control of the Air Line Pilots Association, A. F. L., by ruling, in effect, that Clarence N. Sayen is president of the organization. The action clarifies union control in time for the union's national convention, which open Monday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 16 -- An 18-year-old freshman, son of a New York advertising executive, disappeared from his Harvard College dormitory early today after leaving four notes.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 16 (UP) -- Gov. James F. Byrnes urged today passage of an amendment to the state constitution that might by-pass any future Supreme Court decision ordering an end to segregation in South Carolina's public schools.

After last week's scarcity because of strikes in western packing plants, meat again is in good supply. The City Department of Markets reported yesterday that current receipts have amounted to 32,000,000 pounds, approximately 2,000,000 pounds more than the weekly average so far this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- H. D. Emery, attorney for seven ousted Oklahoma teachers, argued before the Supreme Court today that the state's loyalty oath was unconstitutional. It inflicted punishment without judicial trial, he declared, being applied retroactively to employes who might innocently have joined a subversive organization.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it would ask the Interstate Commerce Commission to dismiss the application of the Pennsylvania Railroad for higher commutation fares on the Long Island Rail Road.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower spoke last night at the eighth annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, appearing at the personal invitation of Cardinal Spellman.

Fifty-seven smartly dressed members of the aviation cadet drill team from the Pensacola Navy Flight Training School will donate a pint of blood each at the Brooklyn Red Cross Blood Center today at 5 P. M. shortly after they arrive at Floyd Bennett Field from Florida.
numerous other wise and dispassionate comments may be found, for this is a grave, lucid, learned and carefully organized book.

Aggregate value of all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange fell $1,873,155,517 between Aug. 31 and Sept. 30, the Exchange reported yesterday. Average value of a share fell $1.17, from $41.85 to $40.68. The average price was the lowest since April 30, when it was $40.53.

Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn, Democratic candidate for Senator, described the Taft-Hartley Act yesterday as an atomic bomb set "to destroy the hard-won security of American labor and to blast away the structure of sound labor relations."

Newspaper food editors in conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday learned, on the basis of a study of 700 women, how food figures in the psychology of a middle-class housewife. The report was made by Mrs. Harriett Bruce Moore, director of psychological services for Social Research, Inc., Chicago, at a breakfast given by Ralston Purina.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Delegates to the United Nations heard a warning from New Zealand's Minister for External Affairs today that talk and votes were not enough to fight aggression and that every country must stand ready to carry its share of military and economic sacrifices.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (UP) -- Jimmy Carter, again the world lightweight boxing champion after fifteen rounds of battling with Lauro Salas, left for his New York home today, seeking only a little time to rest.

Declaring that the Truman Administration had conditioned the American people to the inevitability of failure in foreign relations, John Foster Dulles asserted last night that the Republican party symbolized the possibility of throwing off "this mood of defeatism."

Wider knowledge of the atomic structure of steel may make it possible to increase the metal's strength "perhaps ten times over," H. G. Batcheller, chairman of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, declared yesterday at a regional technical meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute in Pittsburgh.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Navy reported today that it had completed one phase of a cosmic ray research project in which it had shot balloon-launched rockets as high as forty miles above the Arctic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- United States Government agencies have put priority tags on orders for equipment to help Japan modernize her steel-making industry, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Farmers themselves have stated why they will vote for the Eisenhower-Nixon ticket. Their views are summed up by the Republican Farm Council Organizing Committee, after a careful canvass of dirt farmer opinion, in a release entitled, "Why Farmers Like Ike."

Herman Methfessel, former District Attorney of Richmond, and Irving Rivkin, one of his assistants, were cleared yesterday by an official referee of the Supreme Court of charges of professional misconduct.
The North Hempstead, L. I., Union Free School District No. 11 sold yesterday $1,250,000 of bonds due from 1953 to 1981 to Kidder, Peabody Co., at an interest cost of 2.9 per cent.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 -- Ben Nicholson of St. Ives, England, with his painting, "December 5, 1949," has won the first prize at $2,000 in the 1952 Pittsburgh International, it was announced tonight at Carnegie Institute Founder's Day exercises.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and closing prices were steady unchanged to 22 points higher than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- "Unsubstantiated estimates of savings" called possible by proponents of the Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government were decried by a Senate committee today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- The less developed regions of the world have made substantial advances in the commercial production of energy since 1929, the United Nations Statistical Office reported today.

ST. MARGARETHEN, Germany, Oct. 16 (UP) -- German engineers have completed a 550-yard stretch of experimental highway they belive will be snow-proof and ice-proof in temperatures as low as 78 degrees below zero.

Opposing counsel in the anti-trust investment banking trial expressed agreement with Judge Harold R. Medina yesterday as to the desirability of shortening the investment banking anti-trust trial after the judge declared he could not understand why the Government counsel had charged him Wednesday with "hostility" to the Government's point of view.

PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 16 -- Delegates attending the Music Olympiad Conference here today have agreed upon four locations for three International Music Olympiad Festivals, but the site for a fourth -- proposed for Southern California in 1954 -- has not been determined.
TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 17 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,405, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

The stock market was forced again yesterday to absorb a good amount of selling but when the pressure subsided prices made a partial recovery. Strength in the rails inspired some bidding from the professional contingent and this was based mainly on chartist reasons. In general, however, the market was weak on the day.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- The Soviet Union's distaste for arbitration procedures was denounced today by Foreign Minister Osten Unden of Sweden, speaking before the United Nations' General Assembly. He found "this imperialistic Great-Power mentality" reminiscent of Germany's policy under Kaiser Wilhelm and something as "depressing and regrettable" as it was "antiquated" in the world today.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 17 -- United Nations troops beat back dusk-to-dawn attacks by the Communists on the central Korean front and this morning held most of hotly disputed "Triangle Hill" and "Sniper Ridge" in the mountains north of Kumhwa.
BOSTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Youthful Davey Creighton, bidding to become one of hockey's all-star centers, notched the tie-breaking goal tonight as Boston beat Toronto, 2 -- 1, before 6,248 Garden fans.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- British Government securities and tramp shipping shares provided bright features in otherwise dull stock markets today. Undated and longer term British funds gained up to three-eighths of 1 per cent. Tramp shipping shares improved sharply on the rise shown by the September freight index and to the cut in the price of bunker fuel oil.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 16 -- Indonesia verged on a Cabinet crisis today when Parliament approved a Nationalist party motion calling upon the Government to reorganize the country's Defense Ministry and make changes in the Army leadership.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 -- Three attempts to bring the top command of the Teamsters Union, A. F. L., under what was described as more democratic principles were blocked at the union s convention here today.
A Westchester doctor was "trying to get off the hook" yesterday, after advance publicity about his wife's book criticizing the medical profession had brought him a flood of criticism.

HASTINGS, Neb., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft said tonight that as a result of his campaign travels, "I am convinced he [Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower] will be elected President of the United States."

Mr. Kutcher, in a statement yesterday at the Socialist Workers party headquarters, 116 University Place, hailed the Appellate Court's decision as a "great victory, not only for myself, but for the liberties of all Americans."
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Strikes spread through the soft-coal fields today as about 113,000 United Mine Workers quit work to protest the Wage Board's delay in acting on their pay increase.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Department of Justice is "dealing a new blow" to the prestige of the United States abroad by its charges that American oil companies are participants in an international cartel, Frank M. Porter, president of the American Petroleum Institute, asserted in an address here tonight.

GROTON, Mass., Oct. 16 -- Jack Davison, the fullback who did so well at Princeton in 1949 and 1950 and who is the new head football coach at Groton School, was at home working over his practice schedule today when he received a phone call from one of the masters. It appeared Davison had forgotten to come to the Hundred House steps where the faculty was about to be photographed.

The presidents of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the Legal Aid Society, the New York County Lawyers Association and the Harlem Lawyers Association teamed together yesterday to ask the City Planning Commission to advance the building of a new courthouse for city and municipal courts in Foley Square.

With interest and feeling running high in the Presidential election, and to a somewhat lesser extent in the political composition of the new Congress, there is danger that voters will not give the attention deserved to their choice of candidates for the New York Legislature.

HONG KONG, Oct. 16 -- The Apostolic Internunciature in China announced today that the Roman Catholic hierarchy had been officially established in Nationalist Formosa and that Msgr. Joseph Kuo had been designated the first Archbishop of Taipei.

Although Mary Chase has considerable trouble with her drama exercises, she knows a lot about human beings and she is not discouraged. Leave her alone and she will make peace yet between the young and the old. "Bernardine," which opened at the Playhouse last evening. portrays the horrible problem of being adolescent. Maybe it's more than a problem; maybe it's a crime.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- The United Nations General Assembly approved today seventy items for inclusion on its agenda -- among them the controversial Tunisian and Moroccan questions. France allowed both issues to pass by unchallenged.

A proposed bill that would empower the Board of Estimate to assign to any municipal agency the authority to construct and maintain parking facilities, including meters, throughout the city was opposed by civic, planning and automobile groups at a hearing yesterday at City Hall.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct 16 -- Dr. Daniel Blain, medical director of the American Psychiatric Association, sharply criticized today the recent cuts in appropriations for the Veterans Administration medical department, contending that this move would result "in complete deterioration" of V. A. medical services within five years.
Pronounced movements on small volume and deliberate movements on larger volume were the rule yesterday in New York commodity trading.

MONTREAL, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Elmer Lach fired two third-period goals past Rookie Lorne Worsley within 43 seconds tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens a 3-1 victory over the New York Rangers before a crowd of 13,882.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 16 -- The mysterious disappearance, in a roomful of people, of a money bag containing $7,600 in small bills has added to the woes of the Central National Bank of Mineola, which was the victim two months ago of a $475,000 loan swindle.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 16 (AP) -- George Edward Grammer testified today he made up the story that the state says is proof he killed his wife and tried to make it look as if she had died in an automobile smashup.
Mrs. Beatrice C. Kinney of Albany was elected the first president of the newly formed New York State League for Nursing at its first business meeting last night at the Roosevelt Hotel.

CLINTON, Mass., Oct. 16 -- In one of the most impassioned speeches he has ever delivered President Truman, his anger aroused by a few booing and noisy youngsters here, defended his Cabinet, his White House staff and many others of his appointees. He did this before a crowd of more than 5,009 persons, pegging his speech on the fact that his appointments secretary, Mathew J. Connelly, came from this town.

Following are the texts of a "fireside" address made in Los Angeles lost night by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, and an earlier prepared address by him in the Shrine Auditorium there, as carried by The Associated Press:

Glamorization of non-medical hospital positions to attract competent help rather than the concentration of all the glamour on the nursing profession was urged yesterday by Harvey Schoenfeld, assistant director of Montefiore Hospital.
Charles E. Souders has been named general sales manager of International Cellucotton Products Company of Chicago.

Deflationary trends still failed to show up during the past week as measured by banking statistics. New York City banks, reporting to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for the week ended on Wednesday, showed an increase in loans to business of $148,000,000 which carried the outstanding total of borrowings to a record of $8,134,000,000.

Plans for razing the former Pulitzer mansion at 7 to 15 East Seventy-third Street, near Fifth Avenue, and improvement of the site with a modern apartment building were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the landmark by the William Waldorf Astor Estate to a builder.

If competing with Milton Berle is not the problem it once was, the Columbia Broadcasting System still is experimenting with assorted formats and personalities to dent the comedian's popularity on N. B. C. between 8 and 9 o'clock on Tuesday evenings.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- Grain futures held in a narrow price range today on moderate volume. The market was devoid of special feature. Wheat selling increased on small rallies, with commission support induced by increasingly critical weather conditions over the hard winter wheat belt in the West and Southwest.

A painter and a potter working in close collaboration have produced an original ceramic collection of one hundred pieces which will be on exhibition at the Associated American Artists, 711 Fifth Avenue, Oct. 20 through Nov. 8.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The television committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association reported today it was not ready to propose a football video program for 1953, but indicated this year's plan of restricted viewing might be repeated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Plans to get Army enlisted men out of their traditional olive drab uniforms and into smartly styled outfits of different color have apparently stalled again. Experiments with a gray-green uniform, which also had some new tailoring features, have been dropped.

BERLIN Oct. 16 -- Maj. Gen. Lemuel Mathewson, United States commander in Berlin, tonight reaffirmed his protest of Oct. 8 concerning the use of machineguns by Soviet jet fighters that day to try to force an American hospital plane to the ground.

The Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers has selected Nov. 10 as the opening date for co-ordinated spring 1953 showings, it was announced yesterday. The date was set by a special committee of the association, according to Samuel L. Deitsch, council president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The accountings of personal income that the national candidates have made public have served to obscure the origin of the pressure that produced them. This was the revelation that a group in California collected and disbursed a fund to cover the cost of the purely political activities of Richard M. Nixon, now the Republican nominee for Vice President, after he was elected to the Senate.

Establishment of a state-wide minimum wage rate that would cover 164,000 building service employes was recommended yesterday to State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi by the New York State Building Service Minimum Wage Board.

Carmine Gallone, the Italian director and producer who specializes in almost literal film transcriptions of Verdi operas, now has had a go at "La Forza del Destino." Prospective patrons of the Cinema Verdi, certainly an apt showcase for last evening's premiere, can rest assured that the Gallone formula still neither enhances nor betrays the composer.

Joe Scott, who suffered a concussion in the game against the Browns at Cleveland last Sunday, yesterday was placed on the inactive list by the New York Football Giants. He will be out for thirty days.

Judging from the terrific advance sale rolled up by "The Millionairess," opening at 8 o'clock this evening at the Shubert with Katharine Hepburn in the title role, theatregoers, whose watchword is caution, aren't interested in tomorrow's reviews of Bernard Shaw's fanciful satire.

Alexander Kotov of Russia, Gideon Stahlberg of Sweden and R. G. Wade of New Zealand were winners in the nineteenth round yesterday in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, according to a report from Stockholm.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson urged members of the United Nations today to sustain the "crucial test" of staying power and to fight on "as long as is necessary to stop the aggression and to restore peace and security in Korea."

An investment syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. and Watling, Lerchen Co. will place on the market today 195,000 shares of common stock of Aeroquip Corporation, manufacturer of flexible hose lines and related equipment. The stock is priced at $7 a share.

The City Planning Commission was told yesterday at the first of two public hearings on its proposed 1953 capital outlay budget of $478,920,523 that the city "has probably reached the limit of its capacity to borrow without impairing its credit."

Today's new film is "The Golden Hawk," a sea adventure in Technicolor, produced by Columbia, with Rhonda Fleming, Sterling Hayden, Helena Carter and John Sutton heading the cast, at the Palace. Sidney Salkow directed and Sam Katzman produced from a script by Robert E. Kent and the novel by Frank Yerby.

In its first change of ownership since 1928, the five-store store and apartment building at 1136 Madison Avenue, near Eighty-fourth Street, has been sold by M. Durant, F. Solley and S. F. Solley to David S. Meister, the realty operator, for cash over a first mortgage of $41,000.

DETROIT, Oct. 16 -- John A. Roosevelt, youngest son of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, said here tonight that he had broken with his family's traditional Democratic background and had become a supporter of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, because he thought he "can offer us the kind of leadership we need in these critical times."

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 16 -- Tighe E. Woods, director of the Office of Price Stabilization, said today that the Government agency was investigating "the reasons for a simultaneous drop in the price of livestock on the range level and price increases of meat on the retail level."
The New York City Ballet, recently returned from a five-month tour of Europe, will open its eleventh season at the City Center on Nov. 4. The engagement will run through Dec. 14.
Maryland's 235-pound tackle, Dick (Little Mo) Modzelewski, won lineman of the week honors yesterday in the weekly Associated Press poll.
NEWARK, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Ruppert Stadium, the once-proud home of the Newark Bears and the jump-off point for many of the major league's greatest stars, is headed for the scrap heap.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 16 -- Sweden, almost landlocked in the Baltto, geographically isolated and politically neutral, puts her faith in God, clever diplomacy and rapid-firing guns.
A tapering off was prescribed for the Fordham football squad yesterday as it prepared for its home debut against the Quantico Marines tomorrow at Randalls Island.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 16 -- Import restrictions placed by Latin American countries against the Irish linen trade will be discussed in London on Oct. 28 when the Council of the Linen Industry, accompanied by the Minister of Commerce, will meet the president of the Board of Trade.

Premier Mossadegh's announcement that he is breaking off diplomatic relations with Britain came within twenty-four hours after the British Government had rejected as unreasonable, unacceptable and contrary to international usage his time-limited ultimatums.

Eddie Arcaro proved to be the "difference" in the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. The "old pro" among the jockeys came home first on W. G. Williams' Sagittarius in the Pilate Handicap, a classified event of six furlongs, scoring by a head over Danny Shea's Jazerant.

BERLIN, N. H., Oct. 16 -- If New Hampshire's two barometer counties, Coos and Stafford, maintain their record this year of supporting the winning Presidential candidate, it apparently will be a matter of hindsight rather than foresight.
Fall and winter fashions by American and French designers were presented by Mimi Tuthill, 50 East Fiftieth Street, at luncheon at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

ST. CLOUD, Minn., Oct. 16 -- There was posted in the Sheriff's office at Austin, Minn., recently a notice of a chattel mortgage foreclosure against a tenant farmer. It was a small matter in that rich farming area, involving only a few head of cattle, hens, baled hay and farm machinery but not the farm itself.

A Greenwich Village property housing eighty-one families passed to new control when Phillip P. Zipes, operator, bought the six- story apartment building on plot 100 by 100 feet at 26-30 Charlton Street through Pearce, Mayer Greer, brokers.

A selection of sixty-three writings showing the importance of the Nineteen Twenties in American literature has been edited by John K. Hutchens, book news columnist and reviewer for The New York Herald Tribune. Scheduled for Oct. 29 publication by Lippincott, "The American Twenties: A Literary Panorama" contains the work of forty-three authors chosen as representative of the writers who gave that period its characteristic flavor.

Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for re-election, charged yesterday that the Democratic national administration, accustomed to the centralized power it had gained during the war, now was seeking to extend that power and insisting that it be made permanent.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The failure of the United States to give all the information requested from North Atlantic Treaty members regarding the state of their rearmament and plans for 1953 has resulted in protests by Europeans in the Atlantic Council here.

MUCH has been written of the enthusiasms of the wildfowler, the grouse specialist, the fox hunter and the quail expert, but these have a mere wisp of substance compared with the quiet but intense fervor displayed by the woodcock addict.

The Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, which comprises the Brooklyn Museum, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the Brooklyn Children's Museum and the Academy of Music, received in the fiscal year ended June 30 twenty-two gifts of $1,000 or more.
Following are the prepared texts of addresses by President Truman yesterday afternoon at Hartford, Conn., and last night at Manchester, N. H., as carried by The Associated Press:

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe won his first world title on Jan. 15, 1906, at Paris, as a lad of 18. He defeated the 18.1 balk-line king, Maurice Vignaux, and established a new world record average of 20.83 points per inning to win 500 -- 323.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Occupational therapy was presented as a field with a large demand for women technicians in a pamphlet issued today by the Federal Women's Bureau.
Dan Bucceroni, 24-year old Philadelphian, will oppose Dave Davey of Cliffside Park, N. J., in the feature ten round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena tonight.

In the case of the wage agreement between the coal operators and John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers, now awaiting action by the new Wage Stabilization Board, we are witnessing a singularly dramatic example of the consequences that were certain to flow from the Administration's mishandling of the steel strike earlier this year.

A dispatch from the United Nations bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES published in Tuesday's edition of this newspaper said Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in a speech on Oct. 2 had "demanded" that American forces be withdrawn from the Korean battle line to the reserve or outside of Korea, and that South Korean troops be trained to replace them.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- During the week ended Oct. 15, member bank reserves increased $374,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Port of New York Authority announced last night that the new $9,000,000 instrument runway at Newark Airport, which is expected to allow airliners to arrive and depart at the facility without having to fly over adjacent cities, would be put into use on Nov. 15.

United States retailers are losing "untold millions" of dollars each year in sales and profits because of faulty timing of advertising, according to Edward H. Burgeson, director of the Retail Department. Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower blueprinted the Soviet pattern for world domination in an address here last night and declared that the threat could be met successfully through faith and unity -- "unity of our own people" and "unity with our allies in the free world."

LONDON, Oct. 16 (Reuters) -- Viscount Runciman, president of the Council of the Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom, criticized today "artificially inflated'' freight rates prevailing for American ships bringing to Europe commodities purchased with United States Mutual Security funds.

Former Defense Mobilizer Charles E. Wilson said here yesterday that the outcome of the election will have little effect on the nation's march "down the road to socialism" unless sweeping measures are taken to broaden the direct ownership of the American industrial plant among the masses of the people.

Not since the days of Sid Luekman and the 1937 team has a Columbia football team vanquished Penn. And the Quakers, who arrive for a workout at Baker Field this afternoon, are favored again in their game tomorrow.

From his lonely station at distant, bleak Bear Mountain a Weather Bureau researcher recently gave out the news that the coming winter is to be a bad one. It will begin early and will last long, he said, with a little Indian summer to cushion the initial shock, but with what might be called Indian autumn leading only to the snows.

The completely automatic office is still far in the future, Professor Howard H. Aiken, director of the computation laboratory of Harvard University, declared yesterday. He told more than 600 office executives attending the American Management Association's office management conference in the New Yorker Hotel that much of the "unbounded optimism" concerning imminent dominance of office operations by electronic devices is premature.
LONDON, Oct. 16 (Reuters) -- The Court of Appeal here today ruled unanimously that a New York District Court order under the Sherman Anti-Trust Law could not be regarded as effective in England.

CHICAGO. Oct 16 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped to a new low since May 2 today. A supply of 12,000 head ran fully a third higher than forecasts. It broke effects of the two preceding sessions to stabilize the downward trend of prices
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- All American Airways, a local service company operating in seven eastern states, will separate into two companies, it was announced today.

The Pepsi-Cola Company showed a substantial improvement in its earnings for nine months, and yesterday declared an annual dividend of 25 cents plus an extra of 10 cents on its stock. The total of 35 cents, to be paid Nov. 14, marks the first disbursement since Dec. 15, 1949, when 10 cents was distributed.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 15 I read with interest your news account of the twenty-two lawyers who are supporting Governor Stevenson's deposition regarding Alger Hiss and also your editorial on the same subject.

There was just enough nip in the air yesterday, at the Kinder- berg in Central Park, to make today's event especially timely. This is the day the Department of Parks is to open there its first building designed and built exclusively for chess and checker players.

Judging from the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, the common denominators in the paintings by children, parents and teachers done in the first two weeks of classes at the People's Art Center are freedom of expression and enjoyment of materials.

DELMONT, Pa., Oct. 16 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama tonight completed a two-day series of appearances in steel and coal mining towns in Western Pennsylvania where he told enthusiastic crowds that the Democratic party had brought prosperity and "removed fear of the future from the hearts of Americans."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The executive committee of the General Federation of Women's Clubs voted today to ask intensified efforts to attain the release of William Oatis, Associated Press correspondent imprisoned in Communist-controlled Czechoslovakia.

A shopping center recently completed at Queens Boulevard and Sixty-ninth Road in Forest Hills, Queens, has been sold by Sol G. Atlas, builder to Baltimore Realties, Inc., represented by Richard Hull, attorney. Farber-Wittman, Inc., was the broker.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 16 -- A 20-year-old cattle and cotton farmer from Bonita, La., was elected president of the Future Farmers of America this afternoon at the closing session of the group's national convention. He was Jimmie Dillon, who succeeds Don Staheli of Hurricane, Utah.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, in his second fireside chat of the Presidential campaign, tonight backed the Truman Administration's policy in Korea and declared that the sacrifices in Korea were helping avoid a world atomic war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Within hours after Henry H. Fowler, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, called upon Government agencies to try and increase available supplies of critical short metals, particularly nickel, the Defense Materials Procurement Administration announced it had signed contracts assuring an added 4,104,000 pounds of nickel for this country.

A new group of upholstered units designed by Barney Flagg was introduced to New Yorkers for the first time yesterday. These units, which may be combined in innumerable variations to make a sofa of any shape, even one version that resembles a hair pin curve, may be seen at the new showroom of Erwin-Lambeth, 136 East Fortieth Street.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- The National Association of Housing Officials has not abandoned the hope that financing of Public Housing Administration-supported projects will continue by the sale of tax exempt temporary notes bearing a low interest rate.

Harry Gross, the cocky Brooklyn bookmaker, was shaken in his testimony yesterday for the first time in six days of cross-examination on the witness stand at the departmental trial of thirty suspended policemen accused of taking his bribes.
PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The nineteenth Communist party congress in Moscow made it clear that a new Soviet effort to split the Western Allies could be expected.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's speech today in the United Nations General Assembly:
JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Late election returns today assured the Republicans of dominance of the territorial legislature in the party's biggest Alaskan revival since the New Deal's advent.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct 16 -- David L. Cole, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, proposed here today a plan for retroactive restoration of wage cuts voluntarily negotiated by labor and management in "sick" industries.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 17 -- The Communist High Command proposed yesterday resumption of negotiations for an armistice in Korea but insisted that no concession would be made to the Allied view that no war prisoner should be repatriated without his own consent.

The selection of a twenty-five-man Presidium of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party named to succeed the Politburo seems to represent a major unification of power in the Soviet State and in the Communist party in the hands of a single group.
Mrs. Carmen Rodriguez, arrested for the kidnapping of a newborn baby from Bellevue Hospital, was cast in contrasting roles yesterday at her arraignment in Felony Court.

The cake pictured today is an adaptation of one served last night by Thomas J. Lipton, Inc., at its dinner at the Pierre Hotel for newspaper food editors. The dessert was made with the company's packaged frozen-dessert mix. As adapted by THE NEW YORK TIMES' home economist, Mrs. Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, the cake uses either that mix or regular ice cream.

President Truman, who is continuing his campaign for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic nominee for President, in New England, will arrive here tomorrow evening and make two speeches in Manhattan and one in Brooklyn.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman charged last night that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, by his recent endorsement of former Senator Chapman Revercomb of West Virginia and by his endorsements of Senators William E. Jenner of Indiana and Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, had disqualified himself to "lead the American people in the ways of equality, tolerance and brotherhood."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The single fact of membership in an organization listed as subversive by the Attorney General is not sufficient ground for the discharge of a Government worker under loyalty regulations, the Federal Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic Presidential candidate, will get a helping hand next week in his radio-television campaigning from President Truman, Vice President Alben W. Barkley and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's address at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation dinner, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, and his address at the Paterson (N. J.) Armory, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follow:

A letter by David Newhall in today's TIMES states a criticism of President Truman which one hears far too often. It charges that the President is deserting more important matters to campaign and is campaigning for only half the people "whose paid servant he is supposed to be."

Contributions by a group of Marines stationed near the United States Embassy in London made it possible for Rodger C. Bates, an 18-year-old British youth, to be sworn in yesterday as a member of the corps.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 16 -- The editors of two prominent, sensational weekly newspapers were arrested in Bombay today on police charges of forgery and willful publication in one of these periodicals of a forged photographic reproduction of a pro-Communist letter over a signature purported to be that of United States Ambassador Chester Bowles.

ABOARD NIXON TRAIN, in Indiana, Oct. 16 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, rolling across the flat farmlands of Indiana, gave his enthusiastic endorsement today to Senator William E. Jenner and asserted that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois was an appeaser of communism.

MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 17 -- A group of thirty-six prominent party and Government leaders was elected yesterday by the new Communist party Central Committee as members and candidates of the new Central Committee Presidium, which replaces the former twelve-man Politburo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 842,713 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,153 cars, or 1.1 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 25,970 cars, or 3.0 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 46,176 cars, or 5.2 per cent fewer than in the same week two years ago.
Stan Musial, the National League batting champion, and Larry Doby, the American League home run king, also compiled the highest slugging averages in their respective circuits for the 1952 campaign.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct 16 -- An official tabulation today of last week's registrations in Westchester County showed a total of 374,438. In addition, the Board of Elections said, 2,000 or more would be added from persons in military forces after the Oct. 24 deadline. Hitherto the record was the 320,407 of 1948.

ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- Neither the Salvation Army nor the American Legion was any the worse off today for having been listed yesterday by the Secretary of State as among 54,000 nonprofit organizations whose New York charters had been forfeited for failure to file notice of their continued existence.

Until Prime Minister Churchill himself confirms the story we may not be absolutely sure that he proposes to come to this country next March. This is not to disparage the good faith of Edwin H. Leather, cited by one of our contemporaries as authority for the statement that Mr. Churchill has a definite program in mind, beginning with conferences with European Premiers and winding up with a bill of particulars presented in Washington.

ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- Enforcement of this state's Feinberg Law willl not be affected by the Federal Court of Appeals ruling that a Government worker could not be dismissed solely because he belonged to an organization listed as subversive by the United States Attorney General, Wendell P. Brown, State Solicitor General, said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- Representative John S. Wood, chairman of the House Un-American Activities Committee, said today that Communists could paralyze key defense industries in the Philadelphia district within twenty-four hours in the event of war with Russia.

BUFFALO, Oct. 16 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, promised tonight that his party would make good its platform pledges for a "constructive" housing program.

MILAN, Italy, Oct. 16 -- A strong stand against the Soviet Union and its attempt to use satellite countries in its maneuvers against the West was taken today by the Socialist Union of Central and Western Europe, which includes among its members all Socialist parties in exile from the Iron Curtain countries.

Claims by management of staggering costs and inability to pay were countered by union charges of prosperity in the industry and unreasonableness on the part of employers, as arbitration proceedings in the wage dispute between dock workers and their employers came to an end here yesterday.

Philip Sporn, president of the American Gas and Electric Company, urged last night that measures be devised to bring the entire electric utility industry into closer contact with what is going on in the field of atomic energy. He addressed the evening dinner session, at the Biltmore Hotel of the special conference on atomic energy in industry, sponsored by the National Industrial Conference Board, Inc.
GENEVA, Oct. 16 -- The United States has agreed to reconsider some aspects of its international trade policy that have caused particular damage to the commerce of Greece and Turkey.

The ten young Puerto Ricans who are the winners of the first scholarship given by the New York Puerto Rican Scholarship Fund, Inc., were guests of honor yesterday at a reception at the Grand Street Boys Association clubhouse, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.

When the Cardinals fought their way into third place in the second half of the National League season, it became almost a certainty that Enos (Country) Slaughter would be acclaimed for making baseball's "comeback of the year."

The police of the Old Slip Station reported yesterday that they were investigating the story of an accountant who said he had been seized at gunpoint during his lunch hour on Thursday by two men, forced into an automobile, bound and robbed.

In naming Charles Gilman as Administrator of Business Affairs for the New York City school system the Board of Education has taken an important step in the right direction. As auditor of the school board Mr. Gilman, who started as an office boy at the board forty-four years ago, has made an outstanding contribution to the school program of this city.

WINCHESTER, Va., Oct. 17 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, a leading opponent of the New Deal and the Fair Deal, announced tonight that he could not endorse the Democratic national ticket of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson and Senator John J. Sparkman because that ticket supported "Trumanism," which the Virginia Senator called the dominant issue of the campaign.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- A nine-member credentials committee voted today to seat Nationalist China in the United Nations General Assembly and bar any attempt to recognize Communist China for the rest of the 1952 session.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Week-end considerations further restricted business on the Stock Exchange today and price movements generally were narrow and irregular.

Fordham will make its 1952 home debut today against the Quantico Marines in Triborough Stadium on Randall's Island. The opening kick-off is scheduled for 2 P. M. Advance ticket sales point to a crowd of 10,000 as the Rams begin their second year in the East River park.

MILAN, Italy, Oct. 17 -- Representatives of the British Labor party and of the French and West German Socialist parties have agreed to differ on the German problem in general and on the problem of German rearmament in particular, at the end of numerous private conversations that have been going on in this city for the last two days.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- The United Nations General Assembly, in the first closely contested debate of the present session, defeated today South Africa's attempt to bar debate on the race-segregation policies of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Government.

A factory-new television set with one defective tube, planted in the home of a detective attached to the Queens District Attorney's office, led yesterday to the arraignment of two employes of a television repair service concern on charges of conspiracy and petit larcency.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 -- The University of California's special loyalty oath was outlawed today by the California State Supreme Court in a unanimous decision written by Chief Justice Phil S. Gibson.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 17 (AP) -- California's Gov. Earl Warren said here today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was the nation's and the world's one best hope for peace.

Enlistments in the United States Navy are slated for an increase. That arm of the defense establishment now promises winter underwear without the itch. According to Commander H. R. Fahlbusch, Clothing Supply Officer at the U. S. Naval Supply Depot, Brooklyn, the new underwear made of cotton is much warmer than the traditional wool product.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- The builder of Philadelphia's first non-segregated rental housing declared here today that the venture was an outstanding success.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Construction of the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company's natural gas pipeline on the lands of six northern Westchester property owners was halted abruptly late today when counsel for the owners served a temporary injunction order upon the contractor.

Prices of cotton futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 13 points higher than on Thursday. The market started 5 to 34 points higher, on heavy trade buying in December and also in May and July. The advance, however, attracted hedge selling and profit-taking.
Major crime complaints in the calendar year 1951 were 254 per cent more numerous than those recorded in 1950, according to the annual report of the Police Department made public yesterday.

Members of the judiciary, political leaders, prominent attorneys and business men were among the 500 persons who attended the funeral yesterday, in St. Patrick's Cathedral, of George W. Olvany, former leader of Tammany Hall and one-time General Sessions judge.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The number of cattle being fed for market in the three most important feeding states -- Illinois, Iowa and Nebraska -- totaled 1,258,000 -- 14 per cent above the total of a year ago, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

W. R. Grace Co., international industrial and trading concern, announced yesterday purchase of the common stock of the Foster Kleiser Company, largest outdoor advertising concern on the Pacific Coast and second largest in the country. The transaction involved approximately $7,500,000.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 17 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, Democratic nominee for Vice President, accused Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower tonight of endorsing for public office candidates "who have bitterly fought everything he ever stood for."

Four and one-half years ago, Haifa was a port without longshoremen, "straw bosses," harbor police, tugboatmen, customs and immigration officials or any of the thousands of skilled men needed to operate a large, modern harbor. Today, however, the port employs 7,000 "first generation" workers and is considered by many as one of the best in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered an inquiry into rates maintained by motor carriers, both common and contract carriers, on canned goods moving in Official Territory between points named in railroad tariffs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UP) -The Atomic Energy Commission acted today to bring some of the electrical industry's best brains into the drive to develop a nuclear reactor capable of producing electric power.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- A mass X-ray survey of nearly 20,000 coal miners and their wives in the famous Welsh mining valley of Rhondda Fash, or the Little Rhondda, has revealed that more than 5 per cent of the women between the ages of 20 and 24 are tuberculous.

ORANGEBURG, S. C., Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Citadel surprised to gain a 7-7 football tie with Furman today and barely missed victory in the final period. A crowd of about 7,000 saw the southern conference game.

The successful use of a mechanical substitute for one of the four chambers of the heart in a human patient is announced in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association by a team of three Detroit physicians.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Senator Herbert R. O'Conor said today that he felt the nation's security was endangered unless "Americans of questionable loyalty" were immediately driven out of United Nations employment.
The Eaton Manufacturing Company, manufacturer of automotive and aircraft parts, had a consolidated net profit of $6,873,255 in the first nine months this year, the report disclosed yesterday.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 17 -- Dr. Donald F. Gibson of Danbury today won a second preliminary legal skirmish in his fight to retain his right to practice medicine in Connecticut.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, declared last night that the Republican program for labor legislation called for "the prevention of strikes by court injunction and the destruction of labor unions by prohibiting industry-wide bargaining."
Yonkers, N. Y., has appointed Oct. 20 for the sale of bond issues totaling $1,918,000. Dated Oct. 1, 1952, the obligations will come due Oct. 1 from 1953 to 1972.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic candidate for the Presidency, tonight was labeled a "dupe" of Alger Hiss and disqualified to hold the high position to which he aspires.
Following are the prepared texts of addresses by President Truman yesterday afternoon at Lawrence, Mass., and last night at Boston, as carried by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Port of New York Authority, among others, today filed briefs with the Interstate Commerce Commission opposing a grant of authority to Isbrandtsen Company, Incorporated, a round-the-world steamship operator, for service from ports on the Pacific Coast to ports on the Atlantic Coast north of Cape Henry, Va.

More holes were torn in Harry Gross' testimony yesterday during his seventh day under cross-examination at the trial of thirty suspended policemen charged with taking bribes to protect his $20,000,000-a-year bookmaking business.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 17 -- Scores of persons in Alabama, Mississippi and Louisiana reported today that they saw a brilliant ball of fire flash across the sky last night and felt a jolt as the object apparently exploded on contact with the earth's atmosphere.

Signing of a contract covering 13,000 employes of the eastern division of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company was announced yesterday by Max Block, president of the District Council of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen, A. F. L.

The impasse in the Wage Stabilization Board over coal wages is, as we observed here yesterday, an impasse purely of the Administration's making. The Administration joined hands with Philip Murray of the Steel Union to crack the price-wage line irreparably. With the precedent of the steel settlement hung around its neck the newly created (third) Board was handicapped from the very outset in any effort to deal realistically with new wage demands.

Adherents of many religious faiths will take part during the coming week in programs honoring the United Nations. Tomorrow will be United Nations Sunday as well as Laymen's Sunday. The day will bring to a close Churchmen's Week, which was inaugurated this year, and it will also open United Nations Week.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -The report of a study of the domestic help situation in the United States showed today only one servant for every twenty-five families with the shortage increasing.

DETROIT, Oct. 17 (UP) -- A New York investment banking concern has agreed to arrange the underwriting of revenue bonds for construction of a five-mile suspension bridge across of the Straits of Mackinac, it was announced today.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Oct. 17 -- Roslyn Swift of Glen Oaks and Mrs. Saul Weinsier of Fresh Meadow captured the low gross prize as the 1952 Women's Cross County Golf Association tournament program ended at the Nassau Country Club today.

The fact that the present overwhelming interest in the ceramic arts is not something new but a continuation of a taste many centuries old is indicted in an exhibit scheduled to open at the Newark Museum on Monday. Composed of European and American ceramics, it presents examples of pottery and porcelain and an explanatory text that is virtually a capsule history of this art as it has been practiced in the Western world.
NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 17 (AP) -- A Superior Court judge has dismissed a suit of Kings Super Markets to have a 1952 state law setting minimum prices for cigarettes declared unconstitutional.

A Teachers Union attorney has asked the Board of Education to await a State Supreme Court ruling on the applicability of the City Charter's self-incrimination provision before dismissing two teachers who were uncooperative witnesses recently before the Senate subcommittee investigating communism in the country's schools.
