Pennsylvania's undefeated football team will be heavily favored to defeat Columbia for the thirteenth straight time today as the Quakers invade Baker Field for an Ivy League contest. The game will start at 2 P. M.

The unionization of office employes is almost inevitable in the future, C. Wright Mills, Associate Professor of Sociology, Columbia University, declared yesterday. He spoke before concluding sessions of the American Management Association's two-day office management conference in the New Yorker Hotel.

A return by retail advertising people to the practice of relating the facts about a product in their ads instead of plugging "gimmicks" was urged yesterday by Mrs. Lucille Goold, vice president of Hewitt, Ogilvy, Benson Mather, Inc., ad agency. She spoke at the Ohio State Advertising Conference in Columbus, Ohio.
Paul Saxl proposes to retire from Frankenbush Co., Henry Grote from David A. Noyes Co. and Paul N. Shaskan from Shaskan Co., all on Oct. 31.
Following are the texts of addresses by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson yesterday at Fort Worth and last night at Dallas, Tex., as carried by The United Press:

CLINTON, Conn., Oct. 17 -- The bluebird weather was an effective conservation measure for the opening of the Connecticut scoter season at noon today, and although a few of the big sea ducks moved on the ebb tide, the shooting was generally poor.

Lumber production for the week ended last Saturday was 9.7 per cent above the comparable week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were up 6.1 per cent and orders 3 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet.
A large group of ceramics and tiles from France, Italy, Switzerland, Sweden and the United States is on display at Living Today, Inc., at 1398 Lexington Avenue.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 17 -- Hofstra College has refused permission for a speech on the campus next Wednesday by Vice President Alben W. Barkley on the ground that the college facilities are not available for partisan political activities.

DETROIT, Oct. 17 -- Price reductions ranging from fifty cents to $257.85 on some models, and increases from $72.52 to $84.42 on others in the 1953 Dodge line of automobiles were announced today by the Dodge division, Chrysler Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The State Department demanded from the Soviet Union today monetary compensation for the United States B-29 bomber shot down off Japan Oct. 7, as well as repatriation of any survivors of the crew of eight who might have fallen into Soviet hands.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 17 -Arthur Lubin, the director, has bought screen rights to "The Wisdom of the Serpent," a forthcoming novelette by Adela Rogers St. Johns, to be published in three installments in Cosmopolitan magazine, starting with the December issue.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 17 -- A Roman Catholic theologian was quoted today as suggesting that failure to vote is, under certain circumstances, a mortal sin.
TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 18 -- American troops this morning stormed "Pike's Peak," the last Communist stronghold on "Triangle Hill" on the central Korean front north of Kumhwa.

WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Prospects for the 1953 wheat crop are the poorest in 30 to 40 years in western Kansas, R. I. Throckmorton, dean emeritus of agriculture of Kansas State College, said last night.

Since Bernard Shaw's "The Millionairess" is a senile play, the plan seems to be for Katharine Hepburn to supply the youth and the vitality. England is now slowly recovering from the shock of this boisterous performance. Last evening Miss Hepburn transferred it to the Shubert Theatre to open the Theatre Guild's new season.
PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 17 -- Two armed men staged a daring daylight hold-up today and escaped with an $11,000 construction company payroll.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Scrolls and gold medals in recognition of outstanding community service were presented in the new Economic and Social Council Chamber here today to five civic leaders by Mayor Impellitteri under the auspices of New York City's Board of Education, the Sachs Foundation and the United Nations.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 17 -- President Truman and Governor Stevenson are waging a campaign of desperation and are waving a bogey man in the hope of frightening Americans into voting the Democratic ticket, Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, said here tonight in a radio broadcast.

The New York City Opera Company last evening presented its first "Tosca" of the season, with Wilma Spence in the title role, Walter Cassel as Scarpia and Jon Crain as Cavaradossi. Tullio Serafin conducted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UP) -Larry Knohl and Jacob Freidus, both of New York, were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of making "false, fictitious and fraudulent statements" to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17 (UP) -- G. Edward Grammer, New York business man, told authorities he had beaten his wife with a piece of pipe after drinking "five or six" Scotch and waters on the night of her "almost perfect" murder, a Baltimore policeman testified today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Truman denounced in unusually bitter terms today the Republican party and its Presidential candidate, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, in relation to what he termed "cruel and repellent" immigration legislation. Mr. Truman's attack drew immediate Republican criticism.

Both praise and criticism were heaped upon the City Planning Commission yesterday by the Board of Education at a public hearing on the proposed 1953 allowance of $115,348,135 for school construction and modernization, including site acquisitions. The hearing was the second of two held by the commission on its proposed 1953 total capital budget of $478,920,523 for all city purposes.

LAUREL, Md, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Seven horses from four countries will meet tomorrow at Laurel Park in the $50,000 Washington International, most ambitious race of its kind in the history of the United States racing.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Grain futures, led by wheat, had the best upturn in several weeks, the trade finally taking cognizance of the critical drought situation which has developed in the Southwest. Advances in wheat were 3 cents or more, and there were also good gains registered in the feed grains and in soy beans.

Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder yesterday granted a motion to Bond Stores, Inc., for a preliminary injunction against S. Klein on the Square from selling merchandise under the name of "Bond" or "Bond Fifth Avenue," The suit seeks an accounting and $250,000 damages.

Paul Crabtree, actor director, and Frank J. Hale, president of the National Yeast Corporation, have formed a partnership for the Broadway production of Vina Delmar's latest playwriting effort, "Lily."

Marking an end to twenty-eight consecutive weeks of declines in department store sales in this city, retail trade here turned upward this week. Store executives here, encouraged by the reversal, showed more optimism than in a long while. The upswing bolstered confidence in prospects for fall and Christmas selling.

No one, to our knowledge, has made a more skillful and penetrating analysis of recent Soviet maneuvers than the account of such doings which General Eisenhower gave to his audience at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation dinner on Thursday evening. Here was a sharp look behind the Iron Curtain, a careful judgment of Soviet intentions.
The first Federal civil service examination solely for blind persons to be held in the New York area was given yesterday at the Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.
Five of this week's exhibitions, work by four painters and a sculptor, should provide interest for those who keep up with the rapidly, changing art scene.

President Truman will spend four and three-quarter hours here tonight, touring lower Manhattan and Brooklyn by automobile, delivering a major campaign address at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn and attending a Democratic rally at Williamsburg Bridge Plaza, Manhattan.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 17 -- Federal troops were reported today to have sealed off all roads leading into Yucatan, the capital of Merida State, as mounting tension over the collapse of the henequen market threatened to explode into violence.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct 17 -- The Jewish War Veterans of the United States voted unanimously today a strong condemnation of the Soviet Union's demand for the recall of United States Ambassador George F. Kennan. The resolution stressed that the attack on Mr. Kennan was "part of a persistent campaign of hatred and vilification directed against the United States by the Soviet Union."

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 17 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois accused both Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, and Gov. Allan Shivers of Texas of confusing the offshore oil issue for political purposes.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's address last night at Newark, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, and his earlier speech at Wilmington, a carried by The Associated Press, follow:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Defense Materials Procurement Agency today signed a contract with the Bagdad Copper Corporation, Bagdad, Ariz., for an expansion of that company's facilities to insure the delivery of at least 27,000,000 pounds of copper a year and of 940,000 pounds of molybdenite. The company will spend about $14,000,000 on an expansion program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia denied today the petition of five oil companies that a Federal grand jury investigating an alleged international oil cartel be discharged.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- The Secretary of Commerce, Charles Sawyer, today described the nation's traffic accident problem as "America's public enemy No. 1" and predicted that by the end of the year 40,000 persons would be killed and 1,500,000 injured in accidents on American highways.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:
John A. Murray has sold the two-story dwelling at 6 LeBritton Street, Locust Valley, L. I., to Harold Joseph Byrnes. The title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today appealed to party leaders in every state to intensify the drive for small contributions, a campaign organized by Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the party's finance committee.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Ratification by France of the treaty to create a European Defense Community with a single armed force under the command of North Atlantic Treaty officers became more doubtful than ever tonight when Edouard Herriot, leader of the Radical party and Speaker of the National Assembly, came out against it.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 -- President Truman declared today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was now supporting Republican isolationists who had raised "a grave and terrible danger" of appeasing Russia and denounced the General's "Cromwellian" crusade as a "reign of terror by slander."

Less than an hour after their plane let down at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday afternoon, a fifty-seven-man cadet drill team from the Pensacola (Fla.) Navy Flight Training School gave a pint of blood each at the Brooklyn Red Cross Blood Center, 57 Willoughby Street.
TOKYO., Saturday, Oct. 18 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,406, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Korea time:
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Pittsburgh's vastly improved football squad moves into Michie Stadium tomorrow to meet Army's revivified forces before a crowd of 20,000.

Tilden High scored a major upset in scholastic football by defeating Boys High, 21 -- 12, at Boys High Field yesterday. The East Flatbush eleven rallied to score touchdowns in the third and fourth periods to annex their second triumph in four starts. It was Boys' first setback after a victory and a tie.

The thin strains of a flute echoing across upper Broadway today will signal the third appearance of the Pied Piper in Morningside Heights. The Pied Piper Carnival, annual children's fair held by the students, faculty and alumnae of Barnard College, will take place this afternoon on the campus.

With 189 games decided and only one adjourned, the competitors in the world chess championship zonal tournament were ready for the twentieth and semi-final round, scheduled for today at Saltsjobaden, according to a report from Stockholm.
Eddie Arcaro, in his last ride of the year on the New York circuit, did a superlative job to win the main event with Woodvale Farm's Jimminy Baxter at the Jamaica track yesterday.
Five high school students were captured in a stolen automobile by a radio car patrolman yesterday morning after a three-mile chase through Bronx streets at seventy-five miles an hour.

Events today: "Madame Butterfly," City Center, 2:30 P. M.; Concert Artists Guild Musicale, Steinway Hall, 4; Virginia Chorale, Town Hall Club, 5:15; "La Traviata," City Center, 8:15; Hazel Dell Nordsieck, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Suzanne Bloch, lutenist, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:45; Saidenberg Little Symphony, Washington Irving High School, 8:30.

Chester Bowles, our energetic and effective Ambassador to India, has earned the hatred of the Communists for many reasons, notably for his success in presenting the American case to the people of Southern Asia. The lengths to which pro-Communists will go in their efforts to destroy him are illustrated in a story from New Delhi that has its amusing aspects.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 17 -- Maurrie O'Connor of Branch Brook and Willie Goggin of Upper Montclair easily won their first match as the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association pro-pro championship got under way over the hilly Essex County course today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Cornell and Yale will meet in the Bowl tomorrow in a nationally televised Ivy League clash that could be the second wide-open football contest here in two weeks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.4 per cent during the week ended on Tuesday to 110.7 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products declined 1.9 per cent because of sizable decreases in the prices of most livestock, live poultry, and some fresh fruits and vegetables.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- When the Marshall Plan Council meets here Monday it will consider a draft report by which European nations would propose the early end of economic aid by the United States. They would urge, instead, that the United States greatly extend its investments abroad to help Europe overcome the dollar gap.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 17 -- Princeton's football team will attempt to get back into the victory column tomorrow afternoon when it meets Lafayette in Palmer Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set Oct. 27 as the date for hearing applications of nine utility corporations, including three from New York, for approval of plans for the operation of two electric generating stations for power for the Atomic Energy Commission's plant to be erected in the vicinity of Portsmouth, Ohio.

The Jo-Nel Realty Corporation, an investing client of Harry Grayer, attorney, has purchased from Murray Lipton and Morton Goldberg the ten-story apartment house for eighty-nine families on plot 150 by 100 feet at 107-23 West Ninety-third Street. The property is assessed at $500,000 and was sold for cash over two mortgages amounting to $402,000. Austin Hermann was the broker, and Herman I. Weiss was the attorney for the sellers.
MANILA, Oct. 17 -- Filipino officials attach great importance to the Philippine-United States security talks scheduled to be held here in the latter part of this month.

TOKYO, Oct. 18 -- The Chinese Communists this morning pressed for acceptance of the Communist proposals to the United Nations commander, Gen. Mark Clark for resumption of negotiations for an armistice in Korea. The Reds turned big propaganda guns on the American call at the United Nations General Assembly session for additional troop support from member nations.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

CLEVELAND, Oct. 17 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations shipbuilding workers closed its annual convention today after returning its three chief leaders to office and approving a sheaf of resolutions on American shipping.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Oct. 17 -- Mrs. Renee Oakman Bradbury, 41-year-old former model and a descendant of Nathan Hale, was in serious condition tonight in North Country Community Hospital after having been stabbed in the neck with a steak knife at her home, 14 Bay Avenue, Sea Cliff, by a 25-year-old male companion.
For the majority, the most eagerly awaited sight in New York, especially for those from abroad is the torch held aloft by the Statue of Liberty.

In a complete reversal of pattern of earlier sessions of the week, the stock market rallied substantially yesterday and eliminated its Thursday losses. Climbing back almost three points in a few issues, with recovery in the composite rate at 1.84 points in terms of THE NEW YORK TIMES index, it was indicated that technical factors still dominated.

The delay in the completion of a special steamship subsidy and tax report was attributed yesterday by local shipping industry leaders to "complications" created by representatives of the trampship operators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Dr. Lin Yutang of New York, author and educator, received a patent this week for a Chinese typewriter that represents a triumph of simplification -- it has only seventy-two keys and fewer than 1,400 pieces of type. Prior efforts to achieve a machine suited to oriental languages involved, he says, a drum with 4,000 or 5,000 characters whose position the hapless stenoggrapher would have had to memorize.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 17 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower made his first reply tonight to Democratic declarations that he had remained silent in the face of attacks on General of the Army George C. Marshall by describing his wartime superior as one of a group of "great American patriots."
WINCHESTER, Va., Oct. 17 (AP) Following is the prepared text of the address by Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia in a state-wide radio broadcast tonight:

Three important statements made almost simultaneously on Thursday by the Democratic and Republican candidates for the Presidency and the Secretary of State in the present Administration will not give much comfort to the men in the Kremlin or much discomfort to allied Governments scanning the electoral campaign for omens of change in American foreign policy.

Today's new film is "Trip to America," a French-made comedy, starring Pierre Fresnay and Yvonne Printemps, at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. Henri Lavorel directed and produced from a script he wrote in collaboration with Roland Laudenbach.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Dave Beck of Seattle was elected by acclamation today as general president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., one of the nation's largest unions. He succeeds Daniel J. Tobin, who stepepd aside, after heading the union of 1,250,000 members for forty-five years.
Phil Rizzuto quit?

Millard E. Tydings, former Democratic Senator of Maryland, predicted yesterday that his state would go Democratic by 30,000 votes in the Presidential election. He said he based his opinion on reports and a survey that indicated "a decided dip away from the Eisenhower camp in the last three weeks."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Lawyer and engineers representing motion-picture industry discussed at a news conference today the presentation the will make before the Federal Communications Commission in support of the industry's application for a channel in the stratosphere to be used to carry televised entertainment to motion-picture theatres.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 17 -- Disorderly crowds, demonstrating against yesterday's Parliament vote demanding changes in the Defense Ministry and the Army leadership, broke into the Parliament Building and the Foreign Office today and tore down Dutch flags in front of the office of the High Commissioner of the Netherlands.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 17 -- President Juan D. Peron today announced the creation of a new social welfare institution, the Fundacion Evita, to complement the work of the Fundacion Eva Peron. The new institution will be capitalized with the earnings of his late wife's writing, the book "La Razon De Mi Vida" and the unpublished "My Message," he said.

Victor Clemente, Queens sewer contractor, said yesterday he was not thwarting any broad municipal inquiry of Queens sewer construction, and that he was "the only contractor" who had been examined by the Queens District Attorney and Borough President and the Commissioner of Investigation.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 -- Christian Fette, moderate pro-Western head of the German Federation of Trade Unions, was replaced today by Walter Freitag, head of the Metal Industries Union, who promised a more radical domestic policy and a passive attitude toward rearmament.

The undersigned members of the New York Bar, most of whom have been independent in politics and have voted from time to time for candidates of different parties, have decided to support Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson in this election. They have come to this conclusion for reasons which include the following:
COMMERCE, Okla., Oct. 17 (AP) -- The neighbors who knew Mickey Mantle as high school athlete and minor league baseball player belatedly welcomed him home today from his success in the world series.

Alaskans, including Ernest Gruenling, Governor since the end of 1939, like to say that whatever may be the case with Maine it is a proven fact that "as Alaska goes so goes the nation.'' Alaska has just "gone." Since it is still a territory its citizens, however wise and good, are not allowed to vote for President.
BOSTON, Oct. 17 -- An 8-year- old Louisiana girl was operated on successfully today at the Children's Medical Center despite a dream in which she said God warned her that surgery would be fatal.
The following books of a religious and inspirational nature have been issued recently:

ELMSFORD, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- The women's Tri-County Golf Association today ended its second year of formal activity at the Fairview Country Club by combining a tournament with its annual business meeting.

ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- A new long-term research program into mental disorders and their possible prevention and cure will be conducted at Rockland State Hospital, Dr. Newton J. T. Bigelow, State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, announced today.

Gracie Mansion was the scene of an unusual fashion show yesterday morning. The occasion was the celebration of Pennsylvania Week and the honoring of Mrs. Vincent Impellitteri, a native of the Keystone State, whose interest in fashion is widely recognized.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Oct. 17 -- Alexander Pellizon, a 55-year-old fireman, of 47 Fourth Street, this city, was arrested on a charge of first-degree manslaughter tonight in the fatal stabbing of William L. Mallory, 46, of Lindbergh Street, chief engineer at the North Country Hospital, under whom Pellizon had been working since 1927.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Dr. Henry F. Grady blames his former boss, Secretary of State Dean Acheson, for the ruptured British - Iranian diplomatic relations, The Call-Bulletin said in a copyrighted interview today.

MADRID, Oct. 17 -- In an interview appearing in the Spanish magazine Destino tomorrow Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin, Allied land commander in chief in Central Europe, is quoted as having said that France should withdraw from the United Nations if that body should try to interfere with the administration of the protectorates of Morocco and Tunis.

" Paul Klee," an interpretative biography of the painter-poet by Carola Giedion-Welcker, will be published on Monday by Viking Press. The volume is illustrated with 128 reproductions of his work and thirty-six reproductions of paintings by Klee's contemporaries.

HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 17 -- With an anonymous gift of $1,000,000, Dartmouth College will award twenty scholarships annually to outstanding youths throughout the country beginning with next fall's entering class.

Dan Bucceroni, Philadelphia heavyweight, gained the decision over Dave Davey, Cliffside Park, N. J., in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The decision in Bucceroni's favor was unanimous but close.

Sugar prices set a new high level for 1952 yesterday. The spot price rose to 6.65 cents a pound, duty paid, and the ex-duty price for November futures in the No. 6 domestic contract on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange closed the day at a new high of 6.12 cents.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Archibald Cox, chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board, said today the board "hopes to reach a decision" on the soft coal wage case tomorrow.

The unification of Soviet state and Communist party power in the new twenty-five-man Presidium of the Party's Central Committee appears to be more symbolic than real, as it seemed at first, and the Presidium actually is a decorative facade concealing the fact that real Soviet power is still in the hands of Premier Stalin and his closest confidantes.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 17 -- Three developments seemed likely today to restore Premier David Ben-Gurion's control of the Knesset (Parliament).

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Simplification of the New York statute on trust investments "to eliminate all conflict or cross reference between various portions of our laws" was urged here today by Bascom H. Torrance, vice president, City Bank Farmers Trust Company of New York.
Army, Navy and the Marines all figure prominently in the action offered on today's intercollegiate football program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 178 casualties of the war in Korea. The new list included 34 killed in action, 134 wounded, 4 injured in accidents and 6 missing in action. The following casualties were listed for New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for re-election from New York, told a television audience last night that a Republican Administration could take the "quicksand" out of the nation's prosperity.

The woes of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road were compounded yesterday when inspectors of the Bureau of Smoke Control cracked down on the carrier for persistent excessive smoking by two of its steam locomotives.

The Baird Management Corporation, an investment group, has purchased the six-story building containing two stores and twenty-eight apartments at 914 Longwood Avenue, the Bronx, from the Estate Securities Company, operators. The property is assessed at $74,000. Jacobs, Leibowitz Kahn were attorneys for the seller and Hyman Greenberg acted for the buyer.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 17 (AP) -- The unbeaten Maryland and Navy football teams knock heads tomorrow in a charged atmosphere surpassed only by the Army-Navy classic.
Output of newsprint in North America last month exceeded that for any September on record, according to a report issued yesterday by the Newsprint Service Bureau.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Construction of huge concrete "sofa pillows" on the soft bottom of the Hudson River between South Nyack and Tarrytown, as a base for a bridge that will carry the projected New York-Buffalo Thruway across the Tappan Zee there, will cost $11,772,520, the State Department of Public Works informed Westchester County officials today.

The newspaper food editors' conference, in session since Monday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, concluded yesterday on an international note which in consideration of the opening here earlier this week of the General Assembly of the United Nations, was well timed.

Much has been written about the clear, brisk air of the autumn. Although poets, essayists and mystic philosophers do not necessarily agree on everything, they do agree upon the virtues of the autumn air. Agreeing with them too are non-professional letter writers, diarists and even the most fortunate of all writers, those who think good thoughts without ever troubling to place them on paper.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a Soviet note, sent last week, and another by the United States on the disappearance Oct. 12 of an American B-29 plane near Yuri Island. The texts were made public today.
Five firemen were overcome by smoke late yesterday afternoon while battling a smoky fire in the sub-basement of the thirty-two story Salmon Tower, at 20 West Forty-third Street.

HONG KONG, Oct. 17 -- Hong Kong recovered its Roman Catholic prelate from Communist China tonight when Coadjutor Bishop Lawrence Bianchi crossed the border after fourteen months' confinement in Waichow in neighboring Kwangtung.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- A novel form of agreement on aid for economic development was signed today by the United Nations. Norway and India, providing for technical assistance to India with Norway and India sharing the costs, and contemplating capital assistance provided directly by Norway.

There is a need for an industry-wide campaign to promote men's clothing and most industry members want such a drive, according to opinions expressed at the convention of the Clothing Manufacturers Association this week.

The city survey of sidewalk newsstands in the midtown area with a view to relieving pedestrian congestion was urged yesterday by the Thirty-fourth Street Midtown Association. The purpose is to determine where hazards and obstructions have been created so that remedies can be applied, according to N. Peter McLean, executive secretary of the organization.
LONDON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A Nobel Peace Prize winner, Lord Boyd Orr, heads a new company formed, to promote trade between British concerns and Iron Curtain countries, it was announced tonight.

The local towboat industry yesterday morning honored the Morania Oil Tanker Corporation's tugboat Bill Endter for her participation last January in the East River rescue of passengers from a crashed Northeast Airlines plane.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- General Assembly delegates studied today a new forty-one page report from the United Nations Commission for the Unification and Rehabilitation of Korea, the world organization's political liaison body in Korea.

For his Town Hall recital last night, Claude Frank, the young pianist, followed the program patterns he previously had set. Only three works figured, all of considerable weight. After completing Schubert's posthumous A major Sonata and Artur Schnabel's Piece in Seven Movements, Mr. Frank assembled a small orchestra on the stage and played Mozart's Concerto in E flat (K. 271).
With the idea of impressing safety on New Yorkers and the entire nation, the National Safety Council and the Greater New York Safety Council are presenting today a New York Green Cross Safety Parade.

An international Gaelic football game involving County Cork, champion of Ireland's National League, and a selected New York team will be played tonight at the Polo Grounds. The contest is set at 9 o'clock after a hurling match between Tipperary and Galway, both of New York. A crowd of 30,000 is expected.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 -- Led by its flashy running back, Gene Filipski, the former West Pointer, Villanova kept its unbeaten and untied record intact tonight. The Wildcats swept to a 28-to-7 triumph over a previously undefeated Boston College eleven.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Mediation Conciliation Service announced today settlement -- subject to ratification by union members -- of a two-month wage dispute between the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., and the Douglas Aircraft Company's plant at El Segundo, Calif.

LONDON. Oct. 17 -- The Economist, one of Britain's most influential weeklies, which prior to the nominating conventions showed a slight preference for Eisenhower the General, voiced some grave misgivings today about Eisenhower the candidate, and held these misgivings to be shared by many Europeans.

CAIRO, Oct. 17 -- Beginning yesterday and continuing today plainclothes operatives of the public prosecutor's office raided homes and offices of a number of Egyptian and foreign journalists and newspaper executives. Several persons were taken into custody, although no charges were preferred.
GENEVA, Oct. 17 -- The forced labor camps in the Soviet Union are not a profitable operation for the Russian economy, an expert on them said here today.

Presidents of twenty organizations affiliated with the National Council of Women of the United States voted yesterday to move the council office from 501 Madison Avenue to the Carnegie Building for International Activities, which will be built early next year in the area of the United Nations.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 17 -The job outlook in social work and business and the opportunities in the military services for graduates next June are bright, nine women experts told New Jersey College for Women students at the second session of a three-day Vocational Information Conference today.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 17 -- Texas' oil allowable flow for November was set today at 3,372,252 barrels daily, a record high.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 -- The United States Olympic Association, sponsoring agent for the International Olympic Games, sued a music association today in a move to prevent the group from using the name "Olympic" or "Olympiad" in promoting its activities.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Details of a gigantic protective sphere that will make possible the first experiments with a highpowered atomic reactor for submarines were made public today by the Atomic Energy Commission and the General Electric Company.

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES published Oct. 14 Democrat Assemblyman Ludwig Teller accuses me of blocking the passage of permanent personal registration in the 1952 session of the Legislature. That is a serious charge -- serious because the legislation is of such tremendous importance to the people of the state, is such a vital and necessary election reform, and serious because it is not the truth.

Unless their pace slackens in the fourth quarter, the year's final lap, the nation's major metal industries in general will make 1952 one of their best production years. Output of aluminum and zinc is running at a rate which promises either a new record this year or a figure slightly under the all-time peaks for both industries.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 18 (UP) -- John L. Lewis tonight delivered a strong speech urging the election of Democratic candidates in November, but he avoided mention of the Wage Stabilization Board's action in cutting his union's negotiated pay rise.

SHRIMP fishermen, oil well riggers, waitresses, bartenders and even the haute monde at City Hall in this Louisiana bayou town turned movie actors this week when a motion-picture location unit moved into town to film a fictional account of strife between fishermen and tidelands oil drillers.

CUBA'S national lottery will pay off a new kind of dividend this year. The little island republic, straining for cultural advancement, has hit on a formula to stimulate interest in serious music and develop talented artists.
This is United Nations Week. Today through Friday will mark the seventh annual nation-wide observance of the birth of the world organization. Oct. 24, 1945.

EVER since Plato political societies have wrestled with the problem of how to bring to the fore those most fit to lead. Formulas for one age frequently prove unsuitable to another. Eighteenth-century Virginia boasted a formula which succeeded in elevating an exceptional group of statesmen who played a leading role in winning colonial independence, setting up the Federal Government, and directing the destinies of the new nation for its first thirty years.

Applauding William Wyer, trustee of the Long Island Rail Road, for "doing an excellent job of putting the railroad back on its feet," the Queens Chamber of Commerce asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to postpone proposed hearings on the line's reorganization "for at least six months."

At the top of the National Football League's American Conference standings as the result of impressive victories in Dallas, Philadelphia and Cleveland, the New York Giants today will open their home season at the Polo Grounds.

THIS is the country of the can-opener; we are, so it contemptuously is said, "tin can cooks." And yet it was not an American with an eye on the quick lunch that invented canning, but rather one whose nation stands high in culinary achievement.

THERE'S still time to plant daffodils. So long as the bulbs are in the ground before it freezes, they will flower next spring. This fall an abundance of new varieties is recommended for large flowers with fine substance and resistance to weather.

In a four-page letter starting with the words "Dear Tom," Robert Moses, president of the Long Island, State Park Commission, has made a personal appeal to Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, to adopt the commission's "alternative proposal" for a new runway at the Farmingdale, L. I., plant of the Republican Aviation Corporation.

EVERYONE has a right to pick the memories he wants to carry with him into old age. If the colloids of the past which lie suspended between the covers of Robert J. Casey's "Chicago Medium Rare" are of the pleasant variety. isn't it about time? Few authors have had a good word for Chicago in years.

DESPITE its many virtues the chinquapin (a small cousin of the chestnut) appears to be little known outside of southwest Missouri, Arkansas and Texas. When blight virtually eliminated the American chestnut, the chinquapin might have been expected to fill the breach.

BONN, Oct. 18 -- Although the Saar is rich industrially, the importance of its ultimate disposition is to most Germans not based on economics but on politics, domestic and international. The resources of the Saar are not vital to the German economy.

ANY impression that TV facilities automatically intrude physically on a forum discussion must be revised in the light of video paraphernalia installed in the United Nations' new $68,000,000 headquarters along the East River in Manhattan.

THE American tourists have not yet gone home from London, a report from the British capital notes happily. British tourist officials say the crowds now jamming the hotels, theatres and historic sites of England are not late-departing summer visitors but rather a new crop of arrivals, in Europe for the fall touring season when American travelers theoretically are fewer in number, accommodations are easier to obtain and prices are lower.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Camden Police reported tonight that an anonymous phone call from a man who said he took 250 milligrams of radium worth $8,000 from the New York Shipbuilding Corporation here to treat his sock mother has led to the recovery of the capsule.

FOR many years we thought l that tulips, narcissus, hya: cinths and the smaller early bulbs would not do well in the Rocky Mountain-Plains area. low we find that wonderful displays of these flowers can be had ff the culture given them compensates for differences in climate and soil.

SHORTLY after World War II ended the Vienna State Opera began a new phase of its career. Under the leadership of Egon Hilbert, it began giving "guest performances" in different opera houses throughout Europe. The practice started with appearances at London's Covent Garden in the fall of 1947, and since then the company has visited an increasing number of continental capitals.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- While most of the standing committees of Congress have been officially idle since the Eighty-second Congress adjourned early last summer, the House Committee on Un-American Activities has gone more or less quietly along, digging up the hidden membership of the Communist party in this country.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Oct. 18 -- The north shore of Long Island -- from Glen Head to Cold Spring Harbor -- had a mystery on its hands today that stumped everybody, including the Coast Guard and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Top business management came to grips with reality last week. Management representatives conceded that "miracle" electronic office devices will be "just around the corner" for a long time to come. Others responsible in management admitted that some company executives chosen during and just after World War II leave much to be desired.

" FIRST LOVE" is a novel as frankly sentimental as its title, as romantic as the name of its heroine, Alys Monterey. When we first meet Lyssie she is a lively, sensitive 17-year-old, whose life centers on her mother, once a famous actress, and Anne-Justine, her old governess and friend.

EARLY October is the best time for planting daffodils and tulip bulbs in the Middle Atlantic States, but they can go into the ground any time up to frost. This is also generally true throughout the AIidwest. Since these bulbs produce their root systems in fail, however, the sooner they are planted the stronger the roots qll be.

TO THE EDITOR: There was an error in Chad Walsh's review of "The Devils of Loudun." He says: "The narrative centers around three main characters, the Jesuit priests Urbain Grandier, Jean- Joseph Surin * * * etc." Mr. Walsh misread; Grandier was not a Jesuit.

THE annual report of Floyd G. Blair, president of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, delivered last Tuesday to his board of directors, is more than a summary of the present status of the society. It is a significant reflection of problems, which confront all American orchestras in different ways and degrees of complexity, and upon the solution of which their future is largely dependent.

NEWARK, Oct. 18 -- General merchandise on six of the seven floors of the Essex Warehouse Company at 950 McCarter Highway was damaged in a spectacular three-alarm fire that broke out on the adjacent dock on the Passaic River this afternoon.

It is a commonplace these days to point out that our Presidential election is casting all other news developments into darkness. Things are happening which would receive due attention in normal times but are largely ignored nowadays. One such event was the annual conference of the Inter-American Press Association in Chicago this last week, a meeting which accomplished much of importance and interest to hemispheric relations.

MONTREAL, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Floyd (Busher) Curry, a hard-working but unspectacular seasoned player, fired a loose rebound past Goalie Sugar Jim Henry in the third period tonight to enable the Montreal Canadiens to beat the Boston Bruins, 2 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game.
Retail business improved considerably last week in all sections of the country, causing considerable activity in the wholesale clothing markets here.

MARY DEASY'S fourth novel, broader in scope and more ambitious in conception than her first three, is about politics and passions in the American heartland. More particularly, it is about a man who lived to build a bridge across a river joining two expanding cities.

The Atlantic Community Conference held recently at the University of Oxford set a precedent which might be usefully followed in this country. The object of the conference was to acquaint the British public with the structure and progress of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and dispel widespread misapprehensions regarding its scope and purposes.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 18 (UP) -- The defense in G. Edward Grammer's murder trial, trying to weaken the charge that love for a pretty United Nations secretary drove him to kill his wife, today introduced a "third woman" in the New York business man's private life.

Traditional divertissements will be features of the Halloween Ball for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery to be held on the night of Oct. 31 at the Plaza. Miss Louise Marock is chairman of the benefit committee and serving with her as co-chairmen are Mrs. Arthur Cowan, Mrs. Theodore W. Stemmler and Mrs. Carlton Sawyer.

CONTEMPLATING his career as novelist critic, political pamphleteer, philosopher, editor, sculptor, and avant-garde painter, Wyndham Lewis once referred to himself a "Renaissance portmanteau man" An apt label which sets him apart from D. B. Wyndham Lewis, the humorous essayist, and for that matter, from other writers on either side of the Atlantic

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 18 (UP) -- Texas Christian's favored Southwest Conference champions pushed Texas A. M. around handily today, but gained no better than a 7-to-7 tie before 20,500 spectators.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 18 -- The Benelux economic union, projected nine years ago by Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, now seems in the view of many observers impossible of attainment unless the three countries federate or surrender part of their sovereignty.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 18 -- A majority of the employes in a collective bargaining unit may invalidate a union shop during the term of a contract and need not wait until the contract expires, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today. The board split, three to two on the issue.

Greenwich House will be the beneficiary of the performance Nov. 3 of "The Deep Blue Sea," a new play by Terence Rattigan with Margaret Sullavan, at the Morosco Theatre. Herbert Scheftel is chairman of the committee that is in charge of the sale of tickets for the event, and serving as co-chairmen are Mrs. William C. T. Gaynor and Mrs. Francis T. P. Plimpton.

THERE is one thing about Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's campaign for the Presidency on which most observere agree: that it is extraordinary among political campaigns in that its appeal has been and still is -- despite some recent deviations -- to the mind rather than to the emotions.

HARRY ALAN TOWERS, of London, England, has taken an institution as American as the hot dog -- the radio transcription business -- and built from it an organization which handles an estimated 80 per cent of all American radio programs sold outside North America.
Following are the prepared texts of addresses by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson yesterday at San Antonio, Tex., and last night at Houston, as carried by The Associated Press:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The semi-official news agency Yugopress reported today a batch of Yugoslav World War II prisoners had been released by the Russians from Siberian camps and returned home.

Lord Dunsahy, in "Wanted: A Minister of Mirth and Mockery" (Oct. 5), overlooks the role of court jester as training ground for higher office. In this country, for example, an elective term as opposition White House jester should be prerequisite for all Congress - bound junior politicos.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- The new $14,000,000 center of Manhattanville College, established for women by the Roman Catholic religious order of the Sacred Heart in New York 112 years ago, was dedicated here this afternoon on the 250-acre estate of the late Whitelaw Reid at Anderson Hill Road and Purchase Street.

Former President Herbert Hoover came out of self-imposed political retirement last night to reply to "the misrepresentations" that have been hurled against the Republican party since he left the White House twenty years ago.

NOW that the head man and parliamentary spokesman of the biggest film workers' union, Tom O'Brien, M. P., is chairman of the massively powerful Trades Union Congress for the coming year, the struggle to increase British film production may be expected to grow more clamant.

" MORE creative effort has been expended in the past twenty-five years toward engineering truly comfortable chairs than in any comparable period in the world's history." Alfred Auerbach, home furnishings consultant told an audience at a luncheon sponsored by the Fashion Group earlier this month.

THERE are two books here, one the novel that "October Island" nearly was, and one the novel it is. The first is a cheerful, clever book about the biological contours of religion. The second is indifferent and obvious.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, gave his full support today to the stand taken by Communist negotiators in Panmunjom for the repatriation of all prisoners of the Korean war, whether they want to go back or not.

COMEDY, in brief, is criticism. If through laughing at others we purge ourselves of certain spiteful and ungenerous instincts -- as through tragedy we achieve a higher and more publicized catharsis -- that is not quite the whole of it.

BUENOS AIRES is a far piece from New York, and travel between the two is more commonly thought of as being by glamorous cruise ship or high-speed airliner than by bus. Actually, the long trip between hemispheres can be made almost completely by bus, truck, station wagon and vehicles less easy to define.

The first of a series of articles on the principles of stereophotography as they relate to stereo movies appears in the fall issue of Bolex Reporter, quarterly consumer magazine published by Paillard Products, Inc., sole American importers of Bolex motion-picture cameras.

The ink was scarcely dry on Wage Stabilization Regulation No. 1 -- the basic wage freeze order of January, 1951 -- when the Wage Stabilization Board ran up against John L. Lewis. Mr. Lewis had just negotiated a wage hike for the miners, to take effect on Feb. 1.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 18 -- Yugoslavs have become faintly aware of the fact that survival of United States policy toward their country in its present form may somehow be connected with the result of the Presidential election.
ABOARD THE TRUMAN TRAIN IN CONNECTICUT, Oct. 18 -- President Truman today expressed his regret at the death of Mr. Matthews in following statement:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Senator Wayne Morse, Republican of Oregon, today endorsed the Democratic candidate for President, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.
AS a boy of 6, S. M. Chartock "conducted" an orchestra of older boys and girls at an elementary school graduation in Brooklyn and managed to survive his first crisis in the field of music.

AN English novelist and miscellaneous writer, T. H. White, has previously made it clear that he holds a very low opinion of the manners, morals and ideals of the twentieth century. Perhaps he idealizes some other, but if so it is certainly not the eighteenth, whose worst foot he puts pretty consistently forward in this odd little volume of scandalous or horrendous anecdotes.

ATLANTA, Oct. 18 -- Business in most major fields is continuing at high level in the Southeast, cooler temperatures and special fall sales increasing the number of buyers in the stores. In many centers a substantial rise in demand for goods also reflected the recent improvements in employment and payrolls in textile mill towns.

ATLANTA, Oct. 18 (UP) -- A defensive play sent Georgia Tech into scoring action today and after Bobby Moorhead had run for a touchdown with an interception, the Engineers rolled over Auburn, 33 to 0, before 37,000 fans.

The cosmic rays consist of primary and secondary components. The primary components are heavy particles -- hydrogen nuclei; the secondary components are mesons. The meson was predicted by the Japanese physicist Hideki Yukawa, who won the Nobel Prize for his achievement.

THE place of the Mafia in the annals of American crime has never been satisfactorily assessed. An earlier generation knew this dread society of Sicilian origin as the Black Hand, infamous for its extortion methods.

AFTER all these years in which people have been doing everything they possibly could to make bigger and better motion pictures, more lavish, more populous and more endowed with all the finest accessories of advanced mechanical techniques, it is startling -- but just a bit delightful -- to have a couple of producers come along and throw a couple of pictures at us in which size is deliberately reduced.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18 -- Harvard hit high C thrice today -- Clasby, Crowley and Culver -- to topple valiant Colgate from the unbeaten ranks by the margin of a single point in an Eastern gridiron upset that was fought right down to the wire. The score was Harvard 21, Colgate 20.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 18 -- Military Security Agency represents tires here have recommended that the United States give further financial aid to Western Germany in the coming fiscal year, a senior United States official stated today.

DURBAN, South Africa, Sunday, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The worst race rioting in South Africa since 1949 broke out yesterday in Port Elizabeth, killing six persons or more and injuring a dozen, at the suburban New Brighton railway station. Considerable property was burned or smashed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The clash between the chief Republican and Democratic campaign points -- "Time for a Change" and "You've Never Had It So Good" -- is perhaps nowhere more evident than in Maryland and West Virginia.

The international sculpture competition, which was announced last winter by its sponsor, the London Institute of Contemporary Arts, will be conducted for the United States by the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, the museum announced yesterday.

John Cashmore, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, told the Women's Democratic Club of New York yesterday that the Republican party "has done everything possible to encourage crippling inflation."

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Oct. 18 (UP) -- A campaign to throw the striking left-wing Farm Equipment United Electrical Workers Union out of the International Harvester's Farmall tractor works was under way here today.

BALBOA, C. Z., Oct. 18 -- A record of $2,635,980 for Panama Canal tolls collections in a month was set in the thirty operating days of September, according to a report released by the canal company here. The company also received a credit of $412,301 for government-owned or operated vessels.

THE famed cafes of St. Germain des Pres held nothing but disappointment last summer for all the American, Scandinavian and German tourists who poured into the Left Bank on the trail of existentialists. The existentialists were on holiday, like everybody else in Paris.

Dr. Robert C. Cook, acting director of the Population Reference Bureau, cites in its bulletin Ceylon's experience to show how easily and cheaply modern epidemic control measures can lower death rates. The decline in the death rate is a blessing, but it also upsets the balance between birth and deaths and often precipitates economic and political crises.

CAIRO, Oct. 18 -- A statement issued tonight from Egyptian Army headquarters said that, on Thursday, the authorities had uncovered "an espionage network" in which some members of certain publishing houses were implicated.
The Jews of the world number 11,672,000, distributed among ninety-seven countries, according to a survey of world Jewish population made public yesterday by the World Jewish Congress.

THE one thing she cannot stand, says Beatrice Lillie, who has stood a lot, is the person who arrives breathless with "some material I've written with you in mind, it'll be simply perfect for you." Miss Lillie says it would not be perfect for her.

Now burn the twin fires of autumn, the smokeless fires of color in the woodland and the leaping flames on the hearth. By day and by night, for a brief span, body and soul are doubly warmed, maple and birch on the hillside, hickory and oak on the fire dogs. And it is one of the season's compensations that as the one fire dies the other brightens.

Plans are being advanced by members of the women's committee for the varied social events to be held in connection with the sixty-fourth National Horse Show which will open on Nov. 4 at the Madison Square Garden and will continue here throughout Nov. 11. Mrs. Herbert C. Chase is chairman and Mrs. Clarence C. Pell Jr. and Miss Patricia Alexandre, vice chairmen of the women's committee.

A lecture by Ambassador Abba Eban, Israeli envoy to the United States, will open New York University's first annual Brith Abraham Lectures Series on Tuesday. Establishment of the series, devoted to the cultural relations between the United States and Israel, was announced today by Henry T. Heald, chancellor of N. Y. U., who accepted a $1,000 grant from Brith Abraham, national American Jewish fraternal order.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 260 battle casualties in Korea. The new list included forty-seven killed, 197 wounded, nine missing and seven injured. The following casualties were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Leslie Biffle, secretary of the Senate, will head for the farm belt next week to find out what the ordinary voter thinks about the Presidential race.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 18 (UP) -- Penn State retained its unbeaten status by tumbling Nebraska from the undefeated ranks today but the losers turned back the Lions three times within the 10-yard line before going down to a 10-0 setback.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Two Lea, the pride of the Calumet Farm, took command in the stretch to win the $25,000 Children's handicap at Bay Meadows today and smash the track record for a mile and one-sixteenth.

FOR many years those of us engaged in research in the history of the motion picture have held Terry Ramsaye in the highest esteem and respect for his scholarship, as evidenced in his book, "A Million and One Nights: A History of the Motion Picture."

AT this time of year the city child scuffs through the fallen leaves of the plane tree and the country child walks through a world aflame. Now, more than ever, children want to know what tree is that one? They will find about 130 answers in "Trees." by Herbert Zim and Alexander Martin, a handy-sized volume in The Golden Nature Guides Series.

NOT even such laureates of Philadelphia as Christopher Morley, Struthers Burt and Carl Bridenbaugh are as enthusiastic about its historical virtues as Baltimore's Mr. Johnson. Nor is his delightful essay simply an antiquarian spree.

ONE thing that's as plain as a pikestaff is that Adlai Stevenson is out to get the literary vote. As sturdily as he has resisted the temptation to give in to other pressure groups, the Governor, we feel, has capitulated 100 per cent to the men and women in this country who read and write books.

Philip W. Lennen, one of the leading copy writers in the advertising field and creator of the famous slogan, "Not a Cough in a Carload," is a tough man to interview. It is not that the six-foot plus, genial advertising executive is unavailable but because after fifty years in the business he is chock full of interesting anecdotes which he can rattle off almost. endlessly.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 18 -- Take a player who can throw with accuracy, add a receiver who can catch his passes and mix with an outside running threat when the occasion demands. That was the formula that paid big dividends today as Yale registered a 13-to-0 triumph over Cornell's football squad in the Yale Bowl.

The New York Public Library will open its fall series of free art lectures on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Simon Lissim, head of the library's Art Education Project and an artist and designer, will begin the series of ten weekly lectures with the topic, "Art in Industry." No advance registration is required for attendance.

THIS eleventh anthology by the fecund Mr. Derleth is also his third collection planned to illustrate a specific phase of science fiction. Eleven has not proved to be a lucky number for the veteran editor; his latest effort is probably his poorest.

TOKYO, Sunday, Oct. 19 -- Communist troops increased their pressure along the western front in Korea today, but apparently, at least for the time, they had abandoned attempts to drive United Nations forces from positions in the central mountains that the Allies captured last week in a limited offensive by the United States Seventh and the Republic of Korea (R. O. K.) Second Divisions.

IN one of his early essays, Somerset Maugham took note of the fact that most of Ibsen's plots are, in essence, the same: A number of people sit glumly in a stuffy room; a stranger enters and opens a window; everyone catches cold and the curtain falls.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 18 -- Abraham Lincoln returned to the National Cemetery here today to repeat a false prophecy born of deep humility in a trying hour eighty-nine years ago -- "the world will little note nor long remember what we say here. * * *"

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The possibility that 10,000,000 young Americans will see service in the armed forces in the foreseeable future was stressed tonight by Frank Pace Jr., Secretary of the Army. Such a figure, he said, would mean that 30,000,000 persons in the United States would be directly or indirectly affected.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18 (UP) -- A crippled but brilliant halfback, Paul Cameron, playing only half the game, threw three touchdown passes today to lead U. C. L. A. to a 24-14 victory over Stanford before 80,617 football fans.

In Ernest Newman's article, "An English and Universal Music" (Oct. 12) the respective roles of nationalism and universality, as related to listener appreciation, enter rather prominently. So far as most concertgoers in our own country are concerned, the fact that a work is a product of a native composer's imagination has but slight bearing upon its acceptance.
It is more important to preserve honor in a crisis than material possessions, Rabbi Louis I. Newman declared in a sermon yesterday morning at Temple Rodeph Sholem, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

In a message released for publication in Washington on Friday President Truman made the startling statement that General Eisenhower was "willing to accept the very practices that identified the 'master race,'" although he had had a prominent part in the liberation of Europe from Nazi domination.

As a daily reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES, esteeming it above every other source of light on contemporary history, and as one who has frequently and gratefully enjoyed the hospitality of its pages, I hope I may qualify as a friendly critic.

LIKE Robert MOSES himself, who scorns any easy task, Cleveland Rodgers, former newspaper man and long-time member of the City Planning Commission, undertook a heavy assignment in writing a biography of New York's man of many jobs.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 18 (UP) -- The Mississippi Republican Executive Committee voted tonight to withdraw its Presidential electors from the general election ballot in favor of an independent slate sponsored by pro-Eisenhower Democrats.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 18 The brilliant running attack of Michigan State's first-string backfield, the speed of the second-string backs and the pin-point passing of a third backfield combination combined to outclass Syracuse University today, 48 to 7.

IN his major pronouncement just before the recent Communist Party Congress in Moscow Joseph Stalin held out an appealing prospect before Soviet workers. In the future, he told them, there will be the five-hour work day along with doubled real wages. He neglected, however, to say just when these happy conditions would prevail.

Once-tied Pennsylvania, rated the top team in the Ivy League, conquered Columbia, 27 -- 17, before 20,000 fans at Baker Field yesterday. It was a keenly waged gridiron struggle, in which the favored eleven lived up to its pre-game billing, even though the margin of victory was not up to the calculations of the experts.

Two hundred Chinese greeted Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of Nationalist China's head of state, when she arrived yesterday at La Guardia Airport. She was en route to the home of her brother-in-law, Dr. H. H. Kung, in Locust Valley, L. I., to convalesce from a nervous skin disorder.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- In many smaller cities and large villages of upstate New York women voters will outnumber men this year by substantial margins for the first time. Political leaders of both parties and representatives of women's organizations are not sure which candidate will benefit but they agree it is a significant development.

WRITING his autobiography at the age of 70, Dr. William Sharpe arrives at a wholesome philosophy of life: "We should always make the supreme effort to control our destiny. Far better to go dawn fighting than to resign.

STARKVILLE, Miss., Oct. 18 (UP) -- Quarterback Jack Parker, who never played in a T-formation until last month, passed for two touchdowns, ran for two more and kicked three extra points today to give Mississippi State a 27-to-14 victory over Kentucky today.

STORRS, Oct. 18 -- The University of Connecticut repelled the University of Maine's bid for its second straight Yankee Conference championship today, winning, 13 to 7. It was Maine's first defeat since 1950. The Black Bears had won twelve and tied two.
MORRISVILLE, Pa., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Little more than nineteen months from the day Benjamin F. Fairless turned the first shovelful of dirt a giant new steel mill is about ready to come to life.
Following is the text of the address by President Truman in Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
DALLAS, Oct. 18 (UP) -- The Green Bay Packers defeated the Dallas Texans, 24 -- 14, tonight in a National Football League game.

WEST NEW YORK, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Passaic High School's football team walked off the field at the beginning of the fourth period of its game with Memorial High School and under National Federation rules the West New York eleven was officially credited with having won the game by the 33-0 score compiled over the first three periods.

Department store trade here last week went into the black for the first time in twenty-eight weeks. Sales were favorably affected by substantial Columbus Day trade, additional night openings, and the start of special promotions by a leading store.

THE background is still the same -- of sky and blue water. And men -- although of a different breed -- still conn the ships and fly the planes. But the Navy, in less than a decade, has changed forever.

National College of Education, Evanston, Ill., is to present a course for future teachers on the child's emotional needs. The college has brought together in the classroom an analytical psychiatrist, a psychologist and experienced teachers to study their roles in the emotional adjustment of the school child, and to gain greater knowledge of how emotional needs can be satisfied.

Tom Fool earned vindication yesterday and also earned $42,200. The Greentree Stable's famed 3-year-old, waging a savage stretch duel with George D. Widener's Battlefield in the $50,000 added Grey Lag Handicap at Jamaica, gained the victory by a nose.

ALTHOUGH the 1951-52 season went into the books last May as one of the worst in the theatre's local history, it could yet achieve some measure of redemption as the one which turned up Jan de Hartog's "The Fourposter." Now no one in this department is pretending that "The Fourposter" is going to become anything of a classic, but it does boast a distinction all its own.

Speeches by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Republican and Democratic candidates, respectively, for President, will feature the closing session of the twenty-first annual Herald Tribune Forum Tuesday night. The forum, which 2,000 persons are expected to attend, will open this evening.

DURING the past ten years ranunculus have led the fall planting parade in southern California and most parts of the Southwest. Brilliant color tones ease of culture and remarkabl keeping qualities combine tomak the ranunculus the most want butb for fal! and winter planting.

Manual Training High School of Brooklyn and Mont Pleasant High of Schenectady took varsity first-place honors yesterday in the sixteenth annual New York University Interscholastic Cross Country Race at Van Cortlandt Park.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 17 -- The chronic concern here over foreign exchange problems has become acute with the German and Dutch moves to cut valuation of the Brazilian cruzeiro in trade operations.

MILAN, Italy, Oct 18 -- After discussing means to promote socialism in Asia and in Central and South America the Socialist International, which is holding it's second congress in this city, began the discussion today of its relations with the United Nations on the basis of a report that, if approved in its present form, would commit international socialism to advocating some profound structural changes in the United Nations as at present organized.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 18 -- Leaders of Minnesota's Democratic-Farmer-Labor party have moved to head off any attempt by Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, the Republican Vice Presidential candidate, to capitalize on the Communist issue.

Calliope, flute and children's shouts mingled harmoniously on the Barnard College campus yesterday afternoon as 1,500 youngsters and their parents responded to the call of the Pied Piper. Entertainment of all kinds and the customary carnival food were offered at the third annual Pied Piper Carnival presented by the undergraduate organizations and alumnae of Barnard.
" AMERICAN INVENTORY." the TV educational series that is a joint venture of the National Broadcasting Company and the Sloan Foundation, hopes to come up with a major programming "scoop" next January.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Wisconsin smashed to a 42-13 victory over Iowa today and again raced toward the front in the Big Ten football scramble.

THERE is a brief pause in a photographer's appraisal of his subject which he has learned to recognize as the one point at which interest is at its peak. It is frequently referred to as "the split second" and "the exact instant," a small frame of time in which the picture "jells"; the photographer shoots then or never.

President Truman, through a message to the thirtieth anniversary convention of the American Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training, known as O. R. T., joined with 700 delegates last night in honoring Senator Herbert H. Lehman.

PUTNAM VALLEY, N, Y., Oct. 18 -- Louis Waldman, New York attorney, said tonight that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1949 had accepted full personal responsibility for the decision to allow Russian troops to occupy Berlin and Prague during World War II.

LAKE ALFRED, Fla., Oct. 18 -- A graying, middle-aged dentist and pharmaceutical manufacturer from the Pittsburgh district, Dr. R. D. Frawley, who is also a seaplane enthusiast in his home town of Dravosburg, Pa., became the country's Class M outboard champion this afternoon, winning the title for the first time.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 18 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois ended his 6,000-mile trip into the West and South tonight with an appeal for a foreign policy based on expanded trade and armed resistance to Communist aggression.

THOUGH cartoonist John Held Jr. gets first billing in this happy-go-lucky excursion to yesterday, such novelty as it exhibits should really he credited to Frank B. Gilbreth Jr., who supplies the book-length text. "Held's Angels" is far more than an extended blurb to a grab-bag of nostalgic drawings.

A SURPRISING number of "tourists" visited Texas during the years of the republic and early statehood. Starry-eyed, most of them; they came anticipating wonders and usually found them. All were vocal and returned to their homes to write their impressions of the land of the Alamo and San Jacinto; the vast, unknown, fascinating land which Houston and Crockett and Bowie had wrested from foreign tyrants.

Gov. Earl Warren of California arrived in New York yesterday to begin an eastern speaking tour for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, whom he described as the man who "has done more to organize the free world for its own defense than any other person on earth."

IN an etiquette book written for American use in the early part of the nineteenth century, gentlemen of the cloth are admonished not to spit on the floor when visiting parishioners. Nowhere in the 700 pages of her "Complete Book of Etiquette: A Guide to Gracious Living" does Amy Vanderbilt forbid the clergy to expectorate upon the floors of their flock.

LET'S face It: television is getting pretty bad. The high hopes for video which were held by so many are vanishing before our eyes. The medium is heading hell-bent for the rut of innocuity, mediocrity and sameness that made a drab if blatant jukebox of radio.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- Army met more than its match in a fast, hard-hitting Pittsburgh eleven today but came on in a blazing fourth-period rally to score two touchdowns before yielding by 22 -- 14 in Michie Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A rising tide of registrations prompted state officials and other qualified sources today to predict a turnout of 55,669,850 voters on Nov. 4.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 18 -- An "audacious and cunning" offer by a Soviet motion picture distributing agency to have Russian films presented in Roman Catholic schools and parish halls was disclosed today by the newspaper El Pueblo.

Silk, a material which steadily has been losing ground to the newer man-made fibers, is due for a partial comeback in the fashion field, it was predicted last week. American weavers have been blending the fiber with synthetics for unusual and novel effects, and now Italian mills have come up with a pure silk shantung which will not water-stain or come apart at the seams.

THE idea of war as a corrective for moral stagnation has periodically engaged the exceptional gifts of Evelyn Waugh. In the measure of tradition and discipline that battle and training for battle make accessible to the rootless, footloose modern individual, and the degree of separation it affords from the vulgarities, shams and short views of present-day society, Mr. Waugh sees distinct advantages.

There is a lot to be learned in the Big City. Even in Times Square, a-glitter with electric diamonds and neons competing with the sun and moon, study is offered in areas of life remote from Broadway. High atop the Astor Hotel, at the world's crossroads, management executives, forty strong, currently are studying the tools, the techniques and the skills of their top-level jobs.

FOR most gardeners the autumn mood is reflected by the chrysanthemums. Richness of color and wealth of bloom are combined, in this perennial of the harvest season. Here in the Northeast, wherever there's a flower show the mums are sure to make a bid for the center of attention.

TORONTO, Oct. 18 (UP) -- A broadside of third period goals -- by Sid Smith, Max Bentley and Rudy Migay -- all within two minutes enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to gain their first victory of the National Hockey League season tonight as they whipped the New York Rangers, 4 -- 3.

The Presidential campaign arguments over Federal aid to education have led many to believe that proponents of aid are favoring something brand new. Actually, as a report issued last week by the United States Office of Education showed, we already have Federal aid to education to the extent of about $2.5 billion annually.

The performance of "The Millionairess," with Katharine Hepburn in the leading role, on the night of Dec. 11 at the Shubert Theatre has been taken over in behalf of the Near East College Association. Mrs. Walter Hines Page 2d heads the benefit committee.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 18 (UP) -- Sonny George kicked a 22-yard field goal in the last 75 seconds today to give Wake Forest a 9-to-7 victory over a North Carolina team playing its first game after a three-weeks' polio quarantine.

A pair of touchdowns each by Bob Hazzard and Frank Lloyd sparked the Riverdale School football team to a 41-14 rout of St. Paul's of Garden City, L. I., on the victor's field in Riverdale yesterday. It was the second straight triumph for Riverdale and St. Paul's second defeat in three games.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 18 -- In as exciting a horse race as any race track fan could ask for, the 4-year-old colt Wilwyn, English-bred and English-owned, won the $50,000 Washington, D. C., International at the jam-packed Laurel Race Track today.

LIBERTY CORNER, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Natural gas -- colorless but suffocating and flammable -- is boiling out of the ground near this tiny pre-Revolution village from a break in the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company's pipeline.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Never has a political campaign been brought to the American people as fully as General Eisenhower and Governor Stevenson are doing it this year. No section of the country has been ignored. No medium of reaching the people has been overlooked.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 18 -- The defending champions, the state P. G. A. king and the state open titleholder were beaten today in the second round of the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association pro-pro best-ball title event.

IF there were any way of analyzing comedies objectively, "In Any Language" might turn out to be about as competent as "Room Service," "Boy Meets Girl" and "Three Men on a Horse," give or take a few merits in either direction. "In Any Language" is the knockabout comedy by Edmund Beloin and Henry Garson that George Abbott has recently put on the stage.
Darlington Hoopes, Socialist candidate for President, announced last night that he would nationalize the banks, railroads, coal mines and steel if he were elected.

Extensive use of aluminum in the superstructure will permit the Norwegian-America Line to increase the passenger capacity of its proposed luxury liner from 780 to 900 persons, Hans Christian Henriksen, president of the company, announced yesterday.
TOKYO, Oct. 18 -- New South Korean divisions had a baptism of heavy fire last week and emerged christened by their United Nations comrades as a sound and solid, though fledgling, fighting force.

IN the days when the West was much wilder but less woolly the erection of a fence often started a range war that had wide repercussions. The erection of sheep fences on public lands is stirring up another war today, between the stockmen and the sportsmen.

GARDENERS in search of ways to extend the blooming season might take a tip from the common witch hazel (Hamamelis virginiana), which is now in flower. This shrub and its relatives are stalwart cohorts in the campaign to provide garden color during the dull fall and winter months.
VIENNA, Oct. 18 -- The nineteenth Congress of the Communist party of the Soviet Union seems likely to have fateful effects for "people's democracies" as well as the Soviet Union itself.

In "Our Capitalists -- Soviet View and the Reality" (Sept. 21) Adolf A. Berle Jr. emphasizes the broadly based ownership of American corporations. He underemphasizes the concentration of control of American economic activity.
BIDDING methods among the leading players change so slowly that differences are hardly perceptible from one year to the next, but they do change.

--ld, E Northwest has long been known for its prominence in production of narcissus bulbs., But when it comes to tulips and 'hyacinths, the gardener out here always orders imported Dutch varieties. In any case, our bulb planting seaon extends from late i August through October.

BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor asserted today that the uncertainty as to whether the Bonn treaty system with the Western powers would be ratified had brought about a situation of suspense that was an acute danger to the West.
