LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 18 -- Oklahoma's magnificent Sooners, with football magician Eddie Crowder faking and passing brilliantly, moved a notch nearer their fifth successive Big Seven Conference championship today by blasting the Kansas Jayhawks, 42 to 20.

HOW and why do nations rise to economic power and prominence? Adam Smith tried to answer this question in his classic "An Inquiry Into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations" at a time when England was well launched on her great period of economic supremacy.
The number of British merchant seamen increased by 1,544 between June 30, 1951, and the same date this year, the International Transportworkers Federation reports.
The productive capacity of the chemical industry has almost quadrupled since 1939. And the total of chemists and chemical engineers available to man it has little more than doubled.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 18 -- The Iron Curtain around Russia's vast frontiers has been strengthened greatly in the past two years by radar, jet fighters and other measures. This is one of several conclusions drawn by European observers this week, partially as a result of such recent incidents as the loss of a U. S. B-29 near the Kurile Islands.

The letter by Ross W. Woollett of Australia in your columns of Oct. 5, answering J. J. Singh's article, "How to Win Friends in Asia" (Sept. 28) was an eye-opener on his dated ideas that "the present-day practicalities suggest that the council be molded from nations which have demonstrated their ability to uphold a stable system of government."

SHOULD a President of the United States be held responsible for obnoxious laws passed during his administration? What did Lincoln do when his carnivorous Congress roared for traitors' blood? J. G. Randall, in this third volume of "Lincoln the President," explains the Emancipator's technique, including one device never used before or since.

If the Fordham Rams could have called it quits at the half yesterday they would have had a modest triumph at Randall's Island Stadium. Unfortunately, the Quantico Marines had to be battled for two more periods, so the Rose Hill boys were beaten, 21 -- 8, before 8,000 fans, most of them disappointed.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Bucknell's Bisons gained their seventeenth straight football victory today with a 22-0 decision over an unexpectedly resistant University of Buffalo, before a crowd of about 1,000 in Civic Stadium.

FLUSHING, the Netherlands, Oct. 18 -- Scandinavia's largest luxury liner, the 22,000-ton, 800-passenger Kungsholm of the Swedish American Line, was christened today by Princess Sibylla, mother of Crown Prince Carl Gustav of Sweden, at the Royal De Schelde Shipyards here.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- British and Turkish ministers held highlevel talks on Middle East defense here today but there was no evidence that they had reached any definite conclusions.

A NOVEL print - sale party which costs $10 to attend, the ticket including the purchase of a print, is announced by the American Society of Magazine Photographers, Inc. The event is a combination exhibition, print sale and party to be held from 8 P. M. to midnight Friday at Charles Kerlee's Studio, 149 West Fifty-fourth Street.

WRITTEN in the grand tradition of the nineteenth century, this novel is as texture-rich as a good Yorkshire pudding. The author has an excellent narrative sense. The hero and villain are of almost Gargantuan proportions.

Greater recognition is being given by corporations to the importance of presenting welfare plans to their employes in attractive and interesting literary form. The improvement in such presentation has been in keeping with the rise in greatly diversified employe benefit planning in recent years.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 18 -- Cash from a bountiful harvest is beginning to flow into the business stream. Volume of activity, as measured by bank debits, was 11 per cent higher than last September, the Minneapolis Reserve Bank reported.
In reply to Mr. Tepper's letter, allow me to relate an experience of mine that was in direct contrast to his.

WASHINGTON, Oct., 18 -- The sharp attack by thirty-four leading scientists this week on the Government's visa and passport policies was another painful blow to an already very sore spot in the State Department.

THAT pastel charmer, Miss Flora McFlimsey, the old-time doll of whose Christmas. New Year and Easter Mariana has already written, has had a birthday. No one in the doll house (not Pookoo Cat nor even the Little Girl herself) seemed to remember the occasion.

Department of Health officials, fed up with unsanitary food handling conditions in "a great many" of New York's 22,000 restaurants, announced yesterday a program designed to keep utensils sparkling and food uncontaminated -- or else.

The four black ponies pulling little yellow carts continued their plodding rounds of the pony ride in Brooklyn's Prospect Park yesterday, but the interest of the younger set centered on fifty-five more spirited-looking steeds near by.

Last August, shortly after the Olympic Games in Finland, another international sports event was held in the village of Stoke Mandeville just outside of London. The competition was as keen as that in Helsinki, but the times were not as fast nor the crowds as great, for all of the 150 participants were paralyzed and competed from their wheel chairs.

HELICOPTER service came to New York last week. It came after several years of waiting and one false start. The years of waiting passed while the Civil Aeronautics Board and the Post Office Department pondered and weighed and wondered whether the New York area should experiment with the delivery of mail by helicopter as Los Angeles and Chicago had been doing.

BEATING out Marilyn Monroe and Martin and Lewis in a storm of rhinoceros dust as the most surprising money-making development of the year, equatorial Africa, long taboo as a movie location, suddenly finds itself in the middle of a boom.

LAST week's column ended on the note that in our literature, explaining ourselves to ourselves or to anybody else isn't easy. The difficulty is one, it seems to me, which grows with the passage of time. In the beginning, when we were colonials, first in fact and then in attitude, the picture was uncomplicated and clear Irving, Cooper.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Mounts belonging to Fred Blum of Brooklyn held the spotlight in the open jumper division today when the New Brunswick horse show began.
WASHINGTON, D. C., Oct. 18 -- The Wage Stabilization Board today cut to $1.50 the $1.90-a-day pay increase negotiated by John L. Lewis for his 375,000 soft coal miners.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct 18 (UP) -- Minnesota, rated a 20-point underdog at game time, swept Illinois aside, 13 -- 7, today to move into a tie for first place with Purdue in the Big Ten title race.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 18 -- The civil rights platforms of the Republican and Democratic parties were debated here today by Senator H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey, Republican candidate for re-election, and Archibald S. Alexander, Democratic nominee. Both appeared on a special panel, "Civil Rights in Our Times," at the convention of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Europe was first surprised, then concerned to discover that foreign policy had become an important issue in the United States elections. When the Republicans nominated General Eisenhower it was immediately assumed over here that international affairs would not figure in the campaign.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- Most United Nations delegates who left the General Assembly Hall after Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky's seventy-five-minute speech today told anybody who asked that they had not heard a thing that they had not been hearing for the last six years.

NATURALIZING is a popular and rewarding way to use spring-flowering bulbs, and most of them are well adapted for the purpose. This type of planting, however, takes skill and knowledge to achieve an unstudied effect.

Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, American Zionist leader, expressed "shock" yesterday over the "irresponsible" statement by President Truman last Friday imputing to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower the condoning of anti-Semitic and anti-Catholic immigration policies.

PARIS. Oct. 18 -- The 1,000- square-mile territory of the Saar has created a problem out of all proportion to its size because it has become the major obstacle to French-German cooperation in the interests of the North Atlantic alliance.
After 136 years of operation under state supervision, savings banks are now eyeing the desirability of operating under a Federal charter.

JOSEPH L. TEPPER'S letter in your section on Oct. 12 would be insulting if it were not so ridiculous in its extravagant language and fancied grievances. Doesn't he know that the theatre management assigns the house treasurer himself, and not any hireling clerk, to wait on the customers at the window.

AARON COPLAND is in a pleasant position when, as sometimes happens, his works are discussed in these pages rather than upon those given over to music. He regards himself here as only a visitor. He is not a professional writer, makes no pretense at being a writer, and considers his literary output as being no more than a by-product of his own trade.

A recent opportunity to browse through the columns of The Weekly Connecticut Courant -- today The Hartford Daily Courant -- for the decade 1814-1824, produced some curious parallels with certain preoccupations of the American press today.

were announced during September, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. Additions announced in August totaled $37,280,000, while in September of last year figures were $14,889,000.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Three masked and armed bandits tonight crashed a football party in Nashville's fashionable Belle Meade section and robbed forty guests of about $100,000 worth of cash, jewelry, fur coats and other valuables.

SUNDAY, Nov. 16, will be a red-letter day on the Northern Pacific. On that date its crack train, the streamlined North Coast Limited, will move out of the Union Station in Chicago on the inaugural run of the fastest schedule in its history -- forty-six and one-half hours between Chicago and Seattle, which means a reduction of twelve hours in the westbound trip and nine and one-quarter hours on the east- bound run.

Lafayette High registered its second straight one-sided football victory by overwhelming Abraham Lincoln High, 54 -- 0, at Lincoln Field yesterday. This was the second defeat in three games for the Honest Abes.

GARDENERS in the northern-most states who would enjoy the gay colors of tulips might well take a leaf from the notebook of the Dutch growers. These experts grow their tulips in pure sand, liberally enriched with rotted manure.

HANOI, Indo-China, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Pro-Communist Vietminh rebels, attacking in waves of screaming "human sea" assaults, overran today the French Union bastion of Nghialo, gateway to the Red River valley leading to this capital city.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Four young followers of a Boston priest who asserts that salvation is impossible outside the Roman Catholic Church won their fight today to sell a book explaining their views in Pittsburgh. They had been fined $25 each for peddling books without a city permit.

Permanently fixed in the vocabulary of every literate person are certain pairs of proper names so firmly joined that no mental exercise or operation of the will can separate them. Like Chang and Eng, the original Siamese twins, these coupled names are never apart in our thinking -- Lewis and Clark, David and Jonathan, Gilbert and Sullivan, Barnum and Bailey, Sears and Roebuck, Abercrombie and Fitch, Wells and Fargo, Weber and Fields.

GENOA, Italy, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Panama's Consul-General here filed suit today charging the twenty-six-man crew of the 5,925-ton freighter Makiki with "insubordination, rebellion, appropriation of funds and extortion."

IT was that magic chocolate which started all the trouble -- that and the strange man in the strange chocolate shop popping up out of nowhere! So said Johnny Midas, but he knew in his heart that he had really been very greedy.

CETRA-SORIA has spared no pains to make its new full-length recording of Verdi's Don Carlo a notable event. The four disks are technically excellent and the cast of performers presumably the most star-studded ensemble available.

Carnegie Institute of Technology this fall dedicated the new million - dollar building of its Graduate School of Industrial Administration. The nation's first school in this area of graduate work was founded with the aid of a 36,000,000 grant from the Carnegie and Mellon Foundation.

THIS is the third volume in a trilogy of novels about the Stecher family, which William Carlos Williams, a New Jersey pediatrician and one of America's best-known poets, began writing as far back as 1927. Joe Stecher, an honest, quiet, resourceful Silesian immigrant, works his way up to the ownership of a big printing business in this country in the twenty years before the United States entered the first World War.

Women headed by Mrs. Averell Harriman and including Mrs. Harold E. Talbott are assisting the sale of tickets for the performance of "Dial 'M' for Murder," with Maurice Evans in the leading role, on the night of Nov. 19 at the Plymouth Theatre for the benefit of the Women's Trade Union League. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is honorary chairman of the benefit committee.
There is a father and son combination in the industrial world today that outdoes many of the fabulous stories in the history of American industry.

A NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS highway - needs study shows what many New York drivers have been well aware of -- widespread deterioration in 14,321 miles of state roads. The survey found 5,996 miles of highway more than twenty years old, 6,827 only eighteen feet wide or less, 7,164 structurally deficient, 5,405 miles deficient in service, 6,224 miles considered unsafe, 1,459 miles unimproved and 780 bridges requiring reconstruction.

Refusing to be awed by the visitors' prowess, the New York All-Stars upset the County Cork fifteen, champion of Ireland's National League, 13 to 12, in a thrill-packed Gaelic football match at the Polo Grounds last night.

A strong Syracuse cross-country team captured a significant victory from St. John's, Navy, and Manhattan in a quadrangular meet held at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday afternoon. The Orange compiled 26 points as St. John's, Navy, and Manhattan finished next in that order with 56, 67 and 93 points respectively.

IN a day when the "stream of consciousness" technique plays such a large part in the literature of personal portrayal, it is interesting to see at work a method which is quite opposite. Here John Henry Newman is delineated primarily in terms of his relationships to others.

THE preface of Lodge's "George Washington" describes a celebration in Paris. Feb. 9, 1800, in honor of Napoleon's Egyptian campaign. "There were," says Lodge, "two features in all this pomp * * * which seemed strangely out of keeping with the glittering pageant.

The maritime industry of this port will be honored on Wednesday at the twenty-eighth anniversary dinner of the West Side Assocation of Commerce to be held in the Statler Hotel. On this occasion the organization's West Side Award for 1952 will be given to John M. Franklin, president of United States Lines, and to Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks.

THE classic flamboyant figure of the poet, "mad, bad and dangerous to know," was revived in our own time in the person of Hart Crane. The legend of his tortured life was established in Philip Horton's brilliant 1937 biography and revived in a study of the poetry eleven years later by Brom Weber, who now edits these letters.

FAMOUS detective characters have, on all too rare occasions, managed to meet with or without the consent of their respective authors -- usually with highly pleasing results. Surely no one can forget the classic encounters of Arsene Lupin with the Spoonerized Herlock Sholmes, or the more recent collaborations of Stuart Palmer's Hildegarde Withers with Craig Rice's John J. Malone.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Lou (Little Poison) D'Achille, a snappy southpaw passer and nimble runner, stoked up Indiana for a 33-0 romp over Temple today as the Hoosiers hoisted their biggest winning margin in three years and shut out their first foe in thirty-eight consecutive games.
HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 18 -- Darthmouth's Indians finally developed an offense, and scalped a cold Rutgers team. 29 -20, before 8,000 chilled spectators at Memorial Field.

A PHOTOGRAPHIC project whose goal is to document the contemporary scene in Hempstead, L. I., for future historians, has been undertaken by members of the Meroke Camera Club of Merrick with the collaboration of Charles Hewlett, historian of the Town of Hempstead.

WITH THE CANDIDATES IN DREAMLAND, Oct. 18 -- Ever since General Eisenhower went through Springfield, Ill., the other day and Governor Stevenson invited him to drop into the Governor's Mansion for a talk, I keep dreaming that they actually met and that I was there.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 18 -- After a morning of high tension in which army units in full battle dress cordoned off Parliament and the Presidential Palace, Premier Wilopo said this afternoon that the "situation is slowly reverting to normal."

NAPLES -- Tourist officials from forty-six countries, meeting here last week, applauded the continuing trend toward low-cost travel and urged its extension as the best hope of solving Europe's dollar shortage.

Having worked himself through the heaps of verbiage in Joseph V. Stalin's recent pronunciamento on Soviet economic theory the reader comes upon a statement which is so typical of Communist "upside-down" thinking and talking and at the same time so easily understood by the layman that it deserves to be lifted out of the mass of words and to be presented standing alone.
THREE familiar names appear on this list of cookbooks -- Marian Tracy. Elizabeth David and Maria Lo Pinto. Irene King is a new but welcome addition to the ranks.

JOHN MASON BROWN is not yet the Dean of American drama critics. Critics seldom retire, so Mr. Brown must await his turn. But few of them, few indeed of even the novitiates of criticism, can match him in the intensity of his love affair with the theatre, his exuberance in a romance now flaming through its third decade.

Two Columbia University students and their Hunter College companions were the victims of six hoodlums who robbed them of a wrist watch and an identification bracelet as the four sat on a bench on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, off East Sixty-third Street, at 1 A. M. yesterday.

IT was a gigantic hoax from the start. When the late Charlie Bidwill was the owner of the Chicago Cardinals, he regarded his football team as a plaything designed to amuse him whenever he couldn't watch the Chicago Bears in action. Bidwill, you see, had been a Bear fan all his life. But when the All-America Conference sprang into being, Bidwill got mad.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 18 -- Mighty Maryland scored the first three times it had possession of the ball and went on to rout Navy, 38 -- 7, before a record Capital district football crowd of 44,716 spectators at Byrd Stadium today.

A number of letters which have appeared in your column have criticized General Eisenhower for having worked out what appears to be a modus vivendi with Senator Taft and the wing of the Republican party which Taft represents. There are some who even go so far as to question his integrity in this respect.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Oct. 18 -- The United States Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean, backed by the naval and naval air forces of five Allied countries, will begin an eight-day exercise Nov. 10, designed to maintain the sea link between French North Africa and Europe in the event of war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The two groups of voters who, according to the Democratic and Republican campaign committees, are "switching" from one Presidential candidate to the other have been joined this week, though very cautiously, by a third. This is composed of reporters who, after having made a second pilgrimage to Southern states, are now inclined to think that one or more of these Democratic strongholds will be carried by General Eisenhower.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Responding to a speech made yesterday by its leader, Edouard Herriot, the Radical party congress meeting in Bordeaux adopted unanimously tonight a resolution accepting "the principle of a European army" but drawing the attention of Parliament and the Government to the reservations defined by M. Herriot, Edouard Daladier and Edgar Faure in the debate at the congress.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 18 -- Wesleyan scored a 27-to-14 triumph over a hard-fighting Worcester Polytechnic team on Andrus Field today. The game was marred by fumble and ragged play.

President Truman drew impressively large, enthusiastic crowds at three stops for political talks in a motor tour of lower Manhattan and Brooklyn last night. It was his second campaign visit to New York in eight days.
FIVE or six months ago we took up on this page the matter of the child who is "different from the group" -- and happy to be. The article occasioned considerable comment from our readers.

" DRY WALL" gardening is gaining more recognition than formerly, but it took the present building boom to give it popularity. A dry wall has no cement; it is built loosely with rammed-down soil. It is in the ramming process that the wall gets its strength.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 18 (UP) -- The University of Mississippi defeated Tulane, 20 to 14, today before 38,000 fans in 80-degree weather.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Republicans and Democrats both claimed an edge today in the election campaign battle for control of the Senate. But the strategists in both parties keyed their claims to the outcome of the Presidential race.

THE publishers announce that Norman Beasley is a "non-Scientist," but assuredly this impressionistic and enthusiastic account of the Christian Science movement from 1866 to about 1909 presents a point of view which must be termed, for lack of a better phrase, pro-Scientist.
The text of former President Herbert Hoover's speech over the Columbia Broadcasting System's radio and television networks last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follows:

A scientific guessing game, with millions of dollars at stake, is about to pay off. There was hardly a competent industrialist or financier a scant decade ago who believed that liquid gold would ever flow across the Canadian Rockies to United States ports in the Pacific Northwest.

IN the Nineteen-Thirties Henri Cartier-Bresson, an extremely intelligent young French photographer-at-large, was discovered and discovered by this and that local esthete of influence. He was relatively unharmed by the experience.

COLOGNE, Germany -- A super- speed train that runs on a single track at speeds as fast as many airplanes and which could revolutionize rail transportation was shown to reporters recently outside this city. Officials of the development company said that it would be introduced commercially within a year.
One must agree with Lord Dunsany in "Wanted: A Minister of Mirth and Mockery" (Oct. 5) that our times do need a "Fool" very badly.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 17 -- Premier Stalin's closing speech at the Moscow Communist party congress dealt one more damaging blow in a series of reverses suffered in recent months by the Reds in India, a key country in the Kremlin's program for bringing Asia under Soviet domination.

THE theme of the fourth annual National Postage Stamp Show here next month will be "The Story of the Red Cross in Stamps." This was announced by Peter G. Keller, executive officer of the exhibition's sponsoring group, the American Stamp Dealers' Association, upon his return last week from Washington, where he conferred with Red Cross and Post- office Department officials on phases of their participation.

President Truman came to New York last night for the second time in eight days and in a Brooklyn speech charged Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President, with heading "one of the lowest gutter campaigns I have ever seen."

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 18 -- Andy Kozar, a coal miner's son who once thought he'd never walk, and a stand-in tailback with a bad knee propelled Tennessee to a 20-0 victory over Alabama today in Dixie's "bowl-maker classic" before 50,000 fans.

The "loyalty" controversy at the University of California has been at least temporarily ended by a unanimous decision of the California Supreme Court. The court held that all state employes could be required to take a prescribed oath, but it also held that a special oath or declaration could not be required of college professors.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Princeton hoped its victory at Palmer Stadium today against Lafayette would be the beginning of another long winning streak. The Tigers stopped the Leopards, 48 to 0, before 10,000 on the same field where Penn last week ended Princeton's twenty-four game streak.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 18 (UP) -- Michigan unleashed a powerful running attack sparked by Ted Kress and Dick Balzhiser to humble Northwestern, 48 to 14, today for the Wolverines' second straight Big Ten victory. The setback was the Wildcat's third of the season without a victory. They have only a tie to their credit.

More than $1,000,000 of the latest office machinery and equipment will be unveiled at the Grand Central Palace tomorrow when the National Business Show begins a week's run. Gen. Douglas MacArthur, chairman of the board of Remington Rand, Inc., will officially open the exposition at 1 P. M. in a tape-cutting ceremony.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 18 -- In almost unbelievable bitterness the Stevenson and Eisenhower leaders are fighting it out down to the last ballot in what probably will be a Presidential vote of 1,500,000 in Texas on Nov. 4.
Home decorators and collectors with varying tastes will have a wide choice this week in the many offerings of the New York auction galleries.

THREE years ago one of the Bible's great prophecies seemingly took life before our eyes in Israel. The entire community of Jews of the Yemen -- some 40,000 -- which had been living in literal bondage for centuries, was being flown into the world's newest republic.

Further evidence of traditional cooperation at sea was presented yesterday as a 25-year-old seaman, previously stricken with stomach ulcers aboard a United States freighter, walked down the gangplank of the Swedish American liner Stockholm.

Whether carbon monoxide gas or food poisoning caused the death of a 2 1/2-year-old girl and the serious illness of her three small brothers in a West Side tenement at 151 West Sixty-fourth Street yesterday was being investigated early today by police and Health Department officials.

The situation in American Indian affairs has entered a crisis phase. The facts should be known before, not after, the coming election. A directive from Commissioner Dillon S. Myer to all Indian Bureau officials, dated Aug. 5, occasions the crisis and also describes it.

Democrats and Republicans are in general agreement that control of the next Senate hinges on the outcome of fifteen key contests in fourteen states. Eleven of the seats involved are now held by Republicans and four by Democrats. To gain control of the Senate, the Republicans must hold all the seats they now have and win two of the four "doubtful" seats held by Democrats.

OTTAWA, Oct. 18 -- A complaint that Canadian rearmament is losing momentum because of lack of interest by a section of industry was made this week by R. E. Brophy, Deputy Minister of Defense Production, at the annual meeting of the Canadian Industrial Preparedness Association.
Common stock issues of twenty-four Japanese companies are now attracting Wall Street attention.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, asserted today that the country's "anti-labor experts are busy conferring on new anti-labor laws" in the hope of Republican victory at the polls next month.

LEOPOLD STOKOWSKI has offered his services to conduct two concerts of contemporary American music at the Museum of Modern Art on Oct. 26 and 28. They should be provocative programs with works by Henry Cowell, Ulysses Kay, John Lessard, Wallingford Riegger, Alan Hovhaness, Elliott Carter, Lou Harrison, Ben Weber, Vladimir Ussachevsky and Otto Luening (the last two will be represented by pieces for, of all things, tape recorder) spread out over the two evenings.

NOW that the evidence is all in on the recent season of Ballet Theatre, the conclusion is inescapable that it was the company's best season in many a year. And that is about as welcome a development as could be dreamed up at the moment.

A three-reel documentary motion picture, "The Greater Glory," which depicts the training and activities of Jesuit priests, had its first showing last week at the Biltmore Hotel at a meeting of the special gifts committees of the Jesuit Seminary Building Fund.
TOKYO, Sunday, Oct. 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,407, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:

The annual card party in behalf of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service will be held on the afternoon of Nov. 10 in the ballroom of the Colony Club. Mrs. Bedell Holmes Harned is president of the league, other officers of which are Mrs. Ernest V. Hubbard, vice president; Mrs. Rudolph Fluegge, secretary, and Mrs. Malcolm E. Smith, treasurer.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Do not burn leaves, but rake them up for a compost pile. The several rakings necessary before the ground freezes amass a tall stack. A three-foot pile of leaves ends up as six inches or so of compost. Build the pile in a hidden corner, leaving a depression in the center to catch water, which will hasten decomposition of the leaves in winter.

THE early gold seeker in Oregon did not have the easy time of a California Forty-Niner. While panning gold, an Oregon man had to keep one hand on his rifle, for the Rogue River Indians fought without mercy to defend their streams and forests.

TO THE EDITOR: IN a recent issue there appeared a review which announced a "popularly priced edition" of Georges Rouault's "Miserere" at $3.75. The article does not state clearly that this edition contains merely reproductions of the original prints.

The will of William Howard Gardiner, former president of the Navy League of the United States, who died last June 21 at the age of 77, is being contested, it was learned yesterday. The probate petition listed the estate as "over $20,000."

THE fascinating phenomenon that was Dorothy Dix was born Elizabeth Meriwether in November, 1861, seven months after the guns fired on Fort Sumter. She lived to be 90; and considering that her pen-name was a household word for fifty years, it is quite possible that more Americans were familiar with it than any other, even Franklin D. Roosevelt's.

A LITTLE more than two weeks now remain before the people of the United States must choose a new president. The candidates have traveled thousands of miles and discussed many issues. In the early stages of the campaign it appeared that business and the conditions necessary to its health might be given considerable attention by the Presidential aspirants.

THE island of Haiti, looking so dreamy and idyllic in the blue of the Caribbean, has had a serious problem for some time -- malnutrition among its inhabitants. They don't get enough of those prosaic things called proteins.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Abba S. Eban, Israeli Ambassador to the United States, declared tonight that continued antagonism of the Arab world to his country "remains an element of regional tension."
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Clarence Hartwick's Sickle's Image streaked off to win the $40,000 Vineland Handicap at Garden State Park today, defeating sixteen fillies and mates.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (Reuters) -- Manchester United, English League soccer champion last season, slammed home five goals today against Preston without reply, crowning a team shuffle to regain winning form. The United, foundering near the bottom of the first division, made nine changes in team positions before today's game.

THIRTY-SIX brief nature essays, plus "a message from the author" are comprised in this little book, which is illustrated with some pleasing photography of animals, flowers, lakes, clouds, trees, each with its own caption.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- General Assembly delegates share the contradictory feelings of lesser mortals about what is good for them and for the United Nations. They know that constructive proposals, put forward in moderate language, are what everybody needs; but when they get them they find them just a trifle boring.

THE last brandy ad soda has been sipped and the click of billiard balls is heard no more in a row of stately vine-clad buildings across the greensward of Lafayette Square from the White House. The Cosmos Club has departed, after three-quarters of a century.

Despite all the work that has been done with them, cortisone and ACTH are still mysteries. The moon-faces, the mental confusion, the symptoms of diabetes that frequently follow the administration of either hormone in arthritis, in some skin diseases and in about a score of other afflictions have been a source of concern.
Capitalizing on a Brooklyn fumble and an intercepted pass, Adelphi tallied twice in the second quarter to down the Kingsmen, 14 -- 0, at Brooklyn College Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Organized labor will have a voice in discussions of whether to suspend price controls on items of major interest to consumers, Tighe E. Woods, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, said today.

WHEN a young female writer we know switched her contributions from a monthly magazine to a weekly, her husband wearily complained: "What a bore -- I used to not read you once a month, now I'll have to not read you once a week.

THE Beethoven Symphony No. 9 has not been so much in the news since that fabled week, a few seasons past, when New York had five live performances. Three companies -- Victor, Westminster, London -- have just issued the score, in what possibly is a test of the free enterprise system.

A new antibiotic, magnamycin, apparently effective against bacteria that are immune to such antibiotics as penicillin and streptomycin, has been discovered in the Pfizer biochemical research laboratories. The new antibiotic destroys most gram-positive bacteria, such as the pneumonia germ and streptococci, and is said to affect large viruses and Rickettsia such as the organisms that cause psittacosis and Rocky Mountain spotted fever, respectively.

The withering and arrogant response of Randolph of Roanoke to the dozen members of the House who had attacked him has a longer history than Gerald W. Johnson reports. It goes back at least to Edmund Burke, to May 6, 1791, the date of his final break with Fox.

FOR many years Langdon Warner has been the outstanding Occidental student of Japanese sculpture, painting and folk-art in all their varied forms. The word "student" is used advisedly, because it expresses Mr. Warner's attitude better than "expert," "scholar," or "authority" -- designations to which Mr. Warner is entitled, but to which he himself objects.

A VERSATILE artist, Marcia Brown adapts her illustrative style to her material, ranging freely from crisp, modern patterns as in "Henry -- Fisherman" to the manner of early wood engravers as in "Dick Whittington and His Cat."

The San Francisco public schools have undertaken a long-range study and analysis of democracy. The major purpose, according to a report on "Politics and Democracy" prepared by the high school division, is to define democracy in such a way that it will be better understood by the nation's youth.

ANYONE who lived in Argentina through even a part of the reign of Eva Peron inevitably returns after any discussion of the lady to two questions: "How?" "Why?" And after the explanations and reasons have been summed up, the most convincing answer to question No. 1, all the impressive rationalization of this admirable book notwithstanding, seems to be, "Fate."

WHAT! And also Ho! For the master of the neatly turned out unexpected cliche as well as the labyrinthine plot has turned out yet another tale of eccentric behavior in the foamy, feathery world of the Wodehousians.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department said in a special report today that next year's supplies of food and other farm products would probably be near this year's record levels. It declared that there should be "slight change" in retail food prices.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman declared here tonight that the Republicans were waging a "phony crusade" based on "the philosophy of fear -- the fear of old-thinking men who have no vision of their country's future."

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of "The Time of the Cuckoo," with Shirley Booth, on the night of Nov. 12 at the Empire Theatre for the benefit of the Riverdale Children's Association. Mrs. Stephens Wiman heads the committee that has in charge the sale of tickets for the event.

WHEN Vasco Pratolini's "A Hero of Our Time" was published here last spring, a friend of mine, a warm admirer of Mr. Pratolini's previous novel ("A Tale of Poor Lovers"), volunteered the following: "An Italian, if he has any talent and follows his own nature, is a born story teller.

NOT in twenty years has there been such a slashing, hard-hitting campaign by a Republican nominee for President as that which Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is conducting, nor has there been in this period a candidate to whom this style of attack was better suited.
UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Oct. 18 -- Following are extracts from the speech of Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, today in the United Nations General Assembly (interpretation from Russian):

" IF art has its periods of decadence and revival, it is proper that a historical record should show this fairly." These were the words of Andrew Carnegie in 1896, the year of the first of the famous international exhibitions which, with a few interruptions during periods of war or museum reconstruction, have been held annually at the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh.

MADRID, Oct. 18 -- Egiz, clandestine nationalist periodical, edited and published by Basque priests, announced in its latest issue reaching Madrid today that it was suspending publication in conformity with a stern order issued jointly by the Roman Catholic Bishops of the Bilbao Vitoria and San Sebastian Dioceses.

The most important issue in the financing of hospitals today is the voluntary prepayment plan and to what extent it can be developed throughout the country, Dr. George Baehr, president and medical director of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, told a group of the nation's health leaders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- One of the greatest struggles in the official career of Mr. Matthews occurred in the fall of 1949 when as Secretary of the Navy he sought to quell the "revolt of the admirals" and dismissed Admiral Denfeld.

THE most loved American who ever came to the tropics was James Norman Hall, the Iowa small-town boy who arrived in Tahiti in 1920. He had a gentle humor, an abiding concern for people, and a ready franc for anyone in need. When he was working on a novel Chinese merchants, American beachcombers and broken-down European counts would report dally to the local bars on Jimmy's progress, certain thereby to cadge a free drink.

RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 18 (UP) -- Duke's unbeaten powerhouse rolled to a 57-0 victory over a helpless North Carolina State team today as Quarterback Worth (A Million) Lutz pitched three touchdown passes in the first quarter to begin the slaughter. A crowd of 11,500 saw the game.

Although there was trading in security markets on only four days last week, the stock market developed the sharpest break in prices for the year to date. There was no particular news development to account for the decline. Among the reasons advanced were the strained foreign situation, the pending soft coal wage rulings and the indecisive action of the market itself in recent weeks.
Three thousand marchers joined yesterday in an hour-long parade down Fifth Avenue in an effort to impress New Yorkers with the importance of safety at home, on the job and in public.

The political experts were deeply immersed last week in their quadrennial scrutiny of the great question -- Who will be the next President? They were probing it, turning it, measuring it, remarking on how it looked from one angle or another -- doing everything but answering it.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 18 -- After one of the most successful weeks in the anti-bandit war, official sources revealed in Kuala Lumpur tonight that for the first time since the beginning of the emergency in the middle of 1948 the number of terrorist incidents had dropped below the number of "contacts'' made by the security forces.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 -- The Secretary of the Army, Frank Pace Jr., praised the helicopter today as an aircraft instrumental in reducing casualties among United States fighting men.

HERE in the South and Southeastern states we have to put our bulbs in cold storage when they arrive so they'll keep until the weather gets colder in November. Yet our planting period for bulbs is fairly long. We can set them out any time from November to January.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 18 -- Notre Dame upset unbeaten Purdue, 26 to 14, today in a battle of butter-fingered backs and hard-hitting linemen in which 21 fumbles occurred before 49,000 fans.

THE Cagney Brothers, James and William, the producer, will go into a huddle this week-end over their next production for Warner Brothers -- "A Lion Is in the Streets." After many false starts during the last seven years, the screenplay of the Adria Locke Langley novel now is in shooting shape.

I. Sy Seidman is a man to whom music is just spots before the eyes. He is also the possessor of a collection of 300 pieces of music turned out to further the campaigns of Presidents and would-be Presidents, from the time of Andrew Jackson up to and including the Republican "We Want Eisenhower" and the Democratic "Don't Let Them Take It Away."

UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican candidate for Vice President, charged tonight that President Truman's attacks on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower were "a frantic effort to gloss over the Administration's tragically sorry record in combating communism."

THIS seventh novel -- and, according to Rose Franken, the last in the Claudia series -- takes up the story of Claudia and David five weeks after the death of their eldest son, when they are marking time in the Manhattan home of David's wealthy brother.

THE question of leadership is today very much in the public consciousness. This is so not only in the United States, where the Presidential campaign is focusing sharp attention on the problem, but throughout the world, which has become a battleground for conflicting ideologies and opposed theories of government.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 18 (UP) -- John Borton, sophomore quarterback, fired five touchdown passes, four of them to End Bob Grimes, to lead Ohio State to a 35-7 triumph over Washington State today before 72,000.

Alexander Kotov of Russia, paired in the twentieth round yesterday with S. Taimanov, another Soviet player, drew for the sixth time in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, according to a report from Stockholm.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Charlie Maloy was in action only about half the time while the undefeated Holy Cross eleven rolled up a 46-0 victory over Brown today, but he enhanced his reputation by scoring two touchdowns and passing 22 yards to Lou Hettinger for another marker.

The temporary financing of the $500,000,000-a-year low-rent housing program backed by the Public Housing Administration has run into a snag because the Washington housing administrators believe the public market for the notes of the participating local housing authorities is out of line with P. H. A. ideas of their true value.

The Viewpoint School Scholarship Fund will be augmented by the proceeds from the performance of "The Time of the Cuckoo," with Shirley Booth, on the night of Nov. 13 at the Empire Theatre. Tickets for the event may be obtained at the Burden Littell Bureau, 114 East Sixty-second Street.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Unbeaten Southern California gained its fifth victory of the season today with a 28-6 decision over Oregon State.

Methods by which private business could play a decisive part in helping solve problems of financing development of under-developed countries and expansion of world trade appear to have been effectively blocked off from consideration at the current session of the United Nations General Assembly.

FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT sought public office ten times. On eight of these occasions he was successful. Of those two times at bat when he struck out, one was in a party primary and the other during a year when it was unlikely that any Democrat could have won.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Someday, when it suits their purpose, the leaders in the Kremlin probably will proclaim that it was the Russians who invented the atomic bomb. This will ignore the recorded facts of history, of course, but Soviet leaders have not been deterred in the past from claiming for Russians the credit for great inventions simply because history listed nationals of other countries as the inventors.

" HOW many Congressmen can ride into office on the President's coattails?" That, Mr. Louis Bean has said, is the modern political counterpart to the medieval "How many angels can dance on the point of a needle?" In a timely and fascinating book, Malcolm Moos, Professor of Political Science at Johns Hopkins University, has a go at this question.

TO the naked natives he was "The Great One" -- as potent and ageless as Africa. To the local Portuguese administrator, he was one huge, vicious headache haunting Mozambique. To Maniero, the hunter, he was the challenge of a lifetime, a leviathan among elephants.

Navy and Marine air reservists who have served in the Korean war have made a "wonderful record," and their experience has counted heavily in combat, even though younger men have quicker reflexes, Rear Admiral Lucien A. Moebus, chief of Naval Air Reserve Training, said here yesterday.

For many weeks U. N. delegates have been predicting that the seventh session of the General Assembly would be the most tempestuous in U. N. history. The vortex, everyone knew, would be Korea. The storm warnings included the deadlocked truce negotiations in Korea; the sudden outbreak of fighting there; the new international party line expounded by the Russian Communist Congress in the past two weeks; the rumbles of the American election campaign.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 19 -- Denmark, guardian of the entrances to the Baltic and with some of the flattest and best tank terrain in Europe, does not possess today a single modern tank.
WHEN Sleepy Jim Crowley advanced to the coaching ranks after having been one of the Four Horsemen at Notre Dame, he took keen delight in describing his exploits to listeners on the banquet circuit.
Officials and rank and file of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., settled back over the week-end to await the outcome of two separate disputes with management.

ZURICH, Oct. 19 -- Publication last week of the official statement explaining the purpose of the legislation now before Parliament to give the Swiss franc parity in gold has given rise to misunderstandings among businessmen in other countries who ask what is the immediate object and practical significance of the change.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The trade of France with Argentina is going through a serious stage. In 1951 French exports to Argentina had reached a total monthly average of three billion francs. Since the beginning of 1952 they have declined to half of that amount.

Cotton prices last week rallied from early losses but closed the period with moderate net losses, down 3 to 41 points, the nearer deliveries showing the biggest drops. The near October delivery, which went off the board on Wednesday, closed out 18 points below the close on the previous Friday.

Rene Pleven, French Minister of Defense, warned the members of his party yesterday that there is no alternative to the policy of the Atlantic Pact. "We do no think isolationism would be any better for Western Europe than for America," he said in a speech defending the Pleven plan for a European army.

The work of eight potters is represented in the opening exhibition of the Davis Gallery, 231 East Sixtieth Street. The pieces on display, mostly bowls and vases in many shapes and sizes and some decanter sets, are pleasantly arranged in the gallery, which has a black and white decorative color theme.
Opposition to a further increase in Long Island Rail Road commuter fares at this time was expressed yesterday by George E. Roosevelt, chairman of the Long Island Transit Authority.

Rawn Spearman, the young tenor who sang here and later in Paris in the revival of Virgil Thomson's "Four Saints in Three Acts," brought his career a long step forward yesterday afternoon. He gave a song recital at Town Hall that had the sort of beautiful quality that is achieved only three or four times a season.

LAKE ALFRED, Fla., Oct. 19 -- A Muncie monument manufacturer, Paul Wearly, who earned part of his expenses through Indiana University as a professional speedboat driver, today added a Class B American crown to the Class C title he captured yesterday to become the only double winner in the National outboard championships. Wearly put two consecutive heat victories together for the maximum winning total of 800 points.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- This Catskill Mountains colonial city and its historic environs became a giant classroom this weekend for thirteen wide-eyed New York City pupils and their teachers.

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, commander of the First Army, called yesterday for a spiritual regeneration in America to meet the twin threats of aggression from without and moral degeneration within.

MILAN, Italy, Oct. 19 -- The second congress of the Socialist International was thrown into confusion today when Finn Moe of Norway suggested that the United Nations should admit Spain under Generalissimo Francisco Franco and all the nations that have thus far applied for membership and whose candidacy is supported either by the Western democracies or the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Council of State Chambers of Commerce asserted today that "the existence of creeping socialism in the United States is no myth."
Typical comments of persons interviewed by correspondents and reporters of THE NEW YORK TIMES follow, with political affiliations given for those who gave that information:

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 19 -- The office of the Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces issued an announcement tonight that may foreshadow a housecleaning within the Indonesian Army. The announcement said the General Staff had "decided upon a number of steps to overcome the present situation" -- of unrest in this capital and in the country.

Plans for building a large one-family home were announced in connection with the sale of a plot 100 by 121 feet at the northwest corner of Coralyn and Wilmont Roads, in the Rocky Dell section of White Plains, N. Y., by the Gramatan Improvement Company to David L. Hensle, who insured title with the Security Title and Guaranty Company.
An astonishing thing happened yesterday afternoon with the N. B. C. Opera Theatre's television production of Benjamin Britten's "Billy Budd" operas, after the famous tale of Herman Melville.

Angered by alleged lack of patronage and recognition from the Democratic party, the New York Council of Polish Democratic Clubs voted yesterday to withhold endorsement of Gov. Adlai Stevenson for President and Senator John Sparkman for Vice President.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Oct. 19 (Reuters) -- At least eleven persons were killed in riots which broke out in a Negro reserve last night after native crowds helped two arrested Negroes escape from police.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- The New York Rangers and the Boston Bruins crowded a full game's hockey action into twelve minutes of play tonight, each team scoring twice late in the final period for a 2-2 deadlock before 7,467 fans at the Garden.

Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for re-election in New York, attacked yesterday pronouncements on immigration policies "by certain Administration spokesmen," who, he asserted, "employ the very appeals to bigotry they purportedly condemn."

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Oct. 19 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery suggested today that it might be a good idea if the next ministerial meeting of the North Atlantic Council would look into the matter of creating an over-all Allied directorate to coordinate all propaganda and psychological warfare.

The first plan by any American maritime union to subsidize college educations for its members and their children was announced here yesterday by the Atlantic and Gulf district of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L.

Total toy sales volume for 1952 is estimated at between $370,000,000 and $400,000,000 at the manufacturers' level, an increase of more than 10 per cent over last year, Norman G. Wintermantel, president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., said.

CAIRO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Army announced today that a former commander of Egypt's Frontier Corps and his assistant would face a court martial Wednesday on charges of desertion and inciting soldiers to rebel. The Prosecutor has asked the death penalty for the two officers, Maj. Gen. Hussein Sirry Amer and Col. El Sayed Farah.

A "mere" nominal Christianity is no safeguard against Communist ideology, Bishop Raymond A. Lane, Superior General of the Maryknoll Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America, said yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The consistory of the New Utrecht Reformed Church, Eighteenth Avenue at Eighty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, looked back 275 years yesterday to its origin as a hardy group of Dutch settlers organized in October, 1677, under the Rev. Casparus Van Zuuren.

Preferred and common shareholders of the Southern Railway Company have been summoned to a meeting in Richmond, Va., on Nov. 21 to authorize issuance of new bonds aggregating more than $89,643,000 to refund three issues maturing before the end of 1956.

ATHENS, Oct. 19 -- Speaking today in the tobacco center of Kavalla in northern Greece, Charles W. Yost, United States Charge d'Affaires in Athens, touched upon points of paramount interest to the Greeks, who recently have appeared somewhat confused concerning the attitude of the United States toward a nation it has been helping since passage of the Greek-Turkish aid bill in 1947.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Americans for Democratic Action today repudiated such labels as "leftist" and "radical," which it said were pinned on it almost daily during the political campaign.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Sayed Sir Abdel Rahman el Mahdi, the picturesque patron of the pro-British independence movement in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, departed from London today, leaving the political future of his native land still unsettled.

SWITZ CITY, Ind., Oct. 19 -- Henry F. Schricker, Democratic Governor of Indiana and a candidate for the United States Senate against Senator William E. Jenner, Republican, said last night he thought it was a "regrettable incident" that President Truman had asserted that the Republicans embrace a program of "anti-Semitism, anti-Catholicism and anti-foreignism."

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Rookie Hugh McElhenny slammed a total of 103 yards from scrimmage and tallied on a 95-yard punt return today in leading the undefeated, untied San Francisco Forty-niners to a victory over the Chicago Bears, 40 -- 16.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Britain, already beset with worries on many fronts, has cause for further concern in the reign of terror being waged by the secret Mau Mau society against natives and Europeans alike in the territories of the Kikuyu tribe in Kenya.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A House Appropriations subcommittee today charged the military had been "less than candid" in outlining to Congress plans for construction in all parts of the world. The subcommittee contended at least $72,000,000 had been saved in this field by putting into effect reforms it had advocated but it said "a satisfactory situation still does not exist."

John Foster Dulles, speaking yesterday on Laymen's Sunday at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Ninety-first Street, outlined the basic principles that he said should guide the American people in their struggle against the tyranny of international communism.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Hermon Dunlap Smith and Mrs. Edison Dick, co-chairmen of the National Volunteers for Stevenson, deplored in a statement today the recent attacks upon Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson for the deposition he had made during the first trial of Alger Hiss, former State Department official who later was convicted of perjury.

AS long as Americans remain the free citizens of a free country they will cherish the memory of their greatest hero, Abraham Lincoln, and continue to read and write new books interpreting his career and character. The Lincoln literature is already so enormous that only scholars who devote much of their lives to it can master it.

The country's 375,000 soft coal miners were set last night for a strike in protest against what they considered the Wage Stabilization Board's "nullification" of the contracts negotiated three weeks ago by John L. Lewis and the major coal producers.

If a conciliator is a man who gets hit on both sides of the head, Edward Peters has come through the ordeal mighty well. After being the man in the middle in more than 300 California labor dispute he has left the lion and the lamb under one pink quilt and has written a book.
The Rev. G. Clare Backhurst was instituted yesterday as thirteenth rector of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Twenty - first Street and Fourth Avenue, by Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan.

A week ago the newspapers carried a story about three professors associated with the Department of Agricultural Economics at Cornell and of a formula they had worked out for predicting the outcome of Presidential elections.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 (AP) -- With the brilliant Washington, D. C., International out of the way, attention turned today to the famed Pimlico Special here next Saturday. But it will be a long time before racing fans forget the English colt Wilwyn and his thrilling victory in the international classic yesterday at Laurel Park.
New York is sinking ever deeper in the "muck" of moral "degradation," the Rev. Ira W. Langston said yesterday in his sermon at the Park Avenue Christian Church, 1010 Park Avenue.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 19 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Hossein Fatemi's semi-official newspaper indicated today that United States intervention could delay the promised diplomatic break between Britain and Iran.
Two ladies of totally dissimilar talents -- Joan Davis and Jane Froman -- are the latest additions to television's roster, and each in her own way should find herself at home in the medium.
A music-loving Coast Guardsman recently presented an unusual problem to the director of the club of tlo United Smwice Organizations in Cape May, N. J.

Sometimes toward the end of a recital a singer will suddenly become so much better that one almost wonders how the same person could seem so different. This happened last night at Town Hall, when Else Fink, German soprano, gave her second New York recital.

On the program Suzanne Bloch's recital at Carl Fischer Concert Hall Saturday night was listed only as the sixty-third concert to be presented by the Society of the Classic Guitar. With justice, though, it could have been billed as "Music in Shakespeare's Time."

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 19 -- The outcome of the Benelux ministers' conference at Knocke, Belgium, has been received with moderate satisfaction here. Although all problems have been referred to committees, there is no doubt that the conference was held in a friendly atmosphere and that all parties agreed Benelux should be saved and economic union reached despite manifold difficulties.

Perhaps the men's shop of the Fifth Avenue emporium which not long ago announced a "revival" of the pearl stickpin has detected a trend toward elegance in gentlemen's dress that has escaped general attention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The nation's forty-one largest cities collected $2,125,000,000 in taxes from their people in the 1951 fiscal year, or an average of $61 per head, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- Niven Busch didn't idle away the summer months at Hollister his ranch in Northern California. Besides turning over to Simon Schuster the manuscript of a new novel, "The Hate Merchant," scheduled for December publication, Mr. Busch wrote a screen play entitled "The Moonlighter," which has been purchased by Joseph Bernhard, the independent producer.
The Community Service Society would like to express its sadness at the passing of Leeds Johnson -- a friend to our families in trouble.

Two important achievement awards were announced here yesterday by judges of the contest run by the American Public Relations Association. The first, for a national campaigns in the transportation field, went to the Goodyear Tire Rubber Company for the campaign for better roads which it announced in big newspaper space and followed in spectacular copy in the national magazines through the Kudner Agency, Inc.

For reasons peculiar to his industry or to himself, or both, John L. Lewis seems to be more often at odds with the Government than he is with the coal mine owners. Last month he made a new soft coal contract calling for an increase of $1.90 a day in wages, plus a 10-cent increase in the 30-cent-a-ton royalty for the union's pension and welfare funds.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 19 -- Faced with mounting costs and dwindling supplies in the field of farm labor, some eight hundred representatives of various phases of the cotton industry will gather this week in California, where mechanized cotton production has made its greatest strides.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The attitude of reserve amounting to almost indifference that the City and particularly the stock markets have shown toward the encouraging economic news that has recently been showered upon it has persisted in the past week.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Otto Graham pitched four touchdown passes to lead a resurgent squad of Cleveland Browns to a 49-to-7 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles before 27,874 fans at Shibe Park today. The defeat was the worst for the Eagles since 1933.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Trade volume in grain and soybean futures last week was about the same as the previous week, allowing for the fact there were only four days of open markets. Purchases of grain and soybean futures averaged about 45,000,000 bushels daily, compared with 55,000,000 daily for the corresponding period in 1951.

Mayor Impellitteri has ordered the creation of a new and expanded classification bureau within the Municipal Civil Service Commission to tackle as soon as possible the job of reorganizing the entire pay and classification status of the city's army of 200,000 employes.
The account of the game read "Michigan State scored on the opening kick-off when Bob Leberman was mobbed by a mass of Spartan tacklers in his end zone for a safety."

Cities, like people, go through subtle and unstable transition. New Yorkers, though, seem less aware than other urbanites of physical change in the city's appearance. Most of the recent city change has taken place on the river margins and down at the island's tip. Battery Park, long furrowed and marred by work on the Brooklyn Vehicular Tunnel, is green again, like an emerald set in Manhattan's toe.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- The American Labor party here reported today that its constitutional rights might have been violated when the use of a room in the Onondaga County War Memorial Building was denied to it for a political rally and speech last night by Corliss Lamont, the party's candidate for United States Senator.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 18 -- Roughly one-half of Point Four funds allocated to the Arab states has been earmarked this fiscal year for use in Syria. Today, in an interview, the Syrian Foreign Minister, Zafir Rifai, indicated he was not sure Syria could afford to accept the gift.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Editors of some of the nation's leading newspapers agreed today that the press was under more pressure from both sides and subject to more criticism from partisan readers in its coverage of the 1952 Presidential campaign than in any other one in memory.

DETROIT, Oct. 19 (UP) -- Cloyce Box caught two touchdown passes today to spark a comeback drive that carried the Detroit Lions to a 24-16 victory over the Los Angeles Rams before 40,152 fans at Briggs Stadium.

HANOI, Indo China, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The French Army imposed a tight censorship tonight on all news of troop movements under way to counter the Communist-led Vietminh offensive in the Nghia Lo sector, 100 miles northwest of Hanoi.

PENN YAN, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Recognizing that family life in the United States showed a high rate of failure and instability, 500 participants in the Family Life Conference at Keuka College, Oct. 17 to 18, decided that the home in our culture need not surrender to decadence.
Five thousand followers of many religious faiths attended the annual rally of the Interfaith Movement, Inc., yesterday afternoon on the Mall in Central Park.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 19 --Psychiatry under the British Health Insurance System has acquired a new respectability because the psychiatrist now receives as much money as other medical specialists, Dr. Thomas Main, medical director of Cassell Hospital, just outside of London, reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Five of the seven major committees of the General Assembly will move tomorrow into the organizational phase of their work, against the precedent set in previous sessions of waiting for the close of the opening debate.

Slim, neat lines and practical materials give a light, airy look to numerous chair and table designs by J. Cecil Witty. Pieces from this furniture group, intended for indoor and outdoor use and introduced today by the Troy Sunshade Company, may be ordered through the Mayhew Shop, 603 Madison Avenue.

Benny McLaughlin, Philadelphia-born booter, drove two goals as the Philadelphia Nationals remained undefeated in American Soccer League play by blanking the Brookhattan-Galicia eleven, 2 -- 0, in the feature match of a double-header at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

This week's art program is a crowded one, including many one-man and group exhibitions, as well as a special show of eighteenth and early nineteenth century American landscape painting that will go on view Friday in the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum, with loans from a number of public and private collections.

Bernard M. Baruch, 82-year-old adviser to Presidents, expressed his admiration for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "abhorrence of intolerance'' in a letter to the Republican candidate made public yesterday at temporary Eisenhower headquarters in the Commodore Hotel.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Mr. Nicholson's newspapers were in the fore of the fight against the political dictatorship of the late Huey P. Long. Their success in uncovering the 1932 election frauds, however, was not enough to dislodge the Long machine.

Reports received by THE TIMES from its correspondents throughout the country indicate that the result of the contest for the Presidency between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican, and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democrat, continues to be uncertain and that the election may be very close.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Three Senators, one of the nation's leading labor leaders and a former woman Representative voiced their views today in the Chicago area in support of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential candidate, and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic nominee.

Would it be unseemly for just a plain American to criticize adversely the views of one so eminent as Will Durant, and (worse yet) do so on the ground that these views -- as expressed in his letter published in THE TIMES on Oct. 7 -- are unreasoned?
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Cash proceeds of $18,150,000 for the United Jewish Appeal were announced here today at the final session of its National Leadership Conference.

The results of four adjourned games from the twentieth round of the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, completed yesterday, failed to dislodge any of the Soviet competitors from the first five places in the standing, according to a report from Stockholm.

Mr. Vishinsky has now made his opening address at the current session of the United Nations General Assembly, and the delegates, it is reported, are still going through his text with the fine-tooth comb to see if he could possibly have said anything new. If he did, it wasn't apparent at the first hearing or reading.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A 1953 budget of $2,759 883 to provide for world-wide religious, welfare and morale services to 150,000 Jewish men and women in the American armed forces and to strengthen home front morale through support of Jewish community centers was recommended today to the National Jewish Welfare Board by the Leadership Mobilization for G. I. and Community Services.

The Most Rev. Michael Hinsuke Yashiro, Presiding Bishop of the Holy Catholic Church in Japan (Anglican), received his episcopal ring, one of the symbols of his office, at a service yesterday morning at St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church-in-the-Bouwerie.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Admiral Sir Roderick McGrigor, Britain's First Sea Lord and Chief of the Royal Naval Staff, said here today that Communist coastal gunnery in Korea had become "very accurate" and that the enemy's mines "still constitute a risk" for Allied ships.
A union business agent was held in $7,500 bail yesterday on charges of pistol-whipping the wife of a Bronx factory owner with whom his union had been in conflict for two and one-half years.

Things are slowing down perceptibly this week along Broadway after a crowded week of five premieres. The only event on this week's calendar is the belated arrival at 8 o'clock this evening of S. M. Chartock's Gilbert Sullivan company, directed by Mr. Chartock, at the Hellinger.

France is proving a reluctant bride as the time approaches to link herself to her tough and unattractive neighbor across the Rhine. With the Schuman Plan well and miraculously launched in August and September, she is now balking at the need for accepting the European Army, which will pool military power as the other plan does the coal and steel industries.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- United States Custom agents seized ninety-six pounds of opium -- valued at more than $1,000,000 on the narcotics black market -- in a raid aboard a British oil tanker when the vessel docked here today.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh made public yesterday a list of 347 drivers with out-of-state license plates who since Jan. 1 had ignored five or more traffic summonses they had received on New York City streets.
Five new films are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The discussion of Europe's dollar gap, when the Marshall Plan Council meets tomorrow under the chairmanship of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, will be regarded as the first step toward an economic conference between the United States and Europe early next year to seek long-term solutions to take the place of American economic aid.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 19 -- Buoyed by a rousing reception from the "home folks" when he returned here last night, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, worked on his plans today for a final campaign swing through the Midwest and the vital eastern industrial states.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Aneurin Bevan, faced with the possibility that his colleagues in Parliament might call upon him this week to disband his bloc in the Labor party, was notably nonprovocative when he addressed about 2,000 enthusiastic party members at Wall-send-on-Tyne tonight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- The National Negro Council, with a claimed membership of 300,000 in thirty-two states, announced today support of the Republican Presidential ticket and asked 20,000 Negro ministers to preach special sermons on Nov. 2, the Sunday before the election.
TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 20 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,408, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

Two thousand members of the Fire Department paid tribute yesterday to six of their colleagues and a Fire Patrol member who died in the line of duty in the last year and fifty-one others who died of natural causes.

An unusual food exhibition in which all products bear the label "Made in Canada" has just opened here. The first of its kind, the show is presented by Canada's Department of Trade and Commerce to interest importers and wholesale buyers, and also to inform Americans on the wide range of edibles being produced by their neighbors to the north.

Benny Howarth, head football coach at St. Mark's, is a 145-pounder who stands 5 feet 6 inches. He's a little man with a big work schedule. In addition to teaching Latin and mathematics, he coaches (a) football, (b) baseball and (c) basketball.

The trend of population to the suburbs is compelling department stores to establish branches or fall behind in dollar volume. Despite the difficulties of getting working capital, those that established branches have been able to finance the larger number of charge and installment accounts evident in suburbia.

MILLBROOK, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Running one of the best races seen in a Cocker Spaniel event in many months, Ru-Char's Bess Again, bred, owned and handled by Mrs. Charles K. Greening of Mahwah, N. J., took top honors in the Cocker Spaniel open all-age stake of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America today.

ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan, is under heavy attack in the farm areas of New York from both Republicans and Democrats as the battle to win the agrarian vote enters its final stages.

The Ludwig Hektoen gold medal, given annually by the American Medical Association for "originality of investigation and excellence of presentation" of an exhibit at its annual scientific assembly, will be presented on behalf of the association this afternoon by Cardinal Spellman to a team of three physicians on the staff of St. Clare's Hospital, 415 West Fifty-first Street.
LITTLETON, Colo., Oct. 19 (UP) -- An explosion ripped a freight train locomotive off its undercarriage today and sent it hurtling into the air, killing four men.
The General Foods Corporation achieved a record in sales for the six months ended with September and increased net earnings to $11,032,097 from $8,613,071 a year ago.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Another dry week in the hard winter wheat states of the West and Southwest finally forced substantial buying support. At the same time corn and soybeans futures appeared to have been oversold and free short profit-taking caused a reversal of the price trend, following sharp declines early in the week.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 19 -- Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican-Liberal of New York and a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, emphasized here today that true bipartisanship in foreign policy was the key solution to the problem of West Germany, which, he added, "could become another Korea if we vacillate or let down our guard."

President Truman was accused yesterday by Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican nominee for Vice President, of "engaging in the lowest type of gutter politics." The junior Senator from California called upon Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic candidate for President, to "immediately disassociate himself" from Mr. Truman's criticism of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, as a man willing to condone racial discrimination.

The United States will "press hard" in the General Assembly of the United Nations to get as many members as possible who have not yet done so to face up to their tangible responsibilities in Korea, Assistant Secretary of State John D. Hickerson said yesterday.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 20 -- The police investigating cases of alleged bribery and corruption in Japan's national election Oct. 1 issued a summons Sunday for Foreign Minister Katsuo Okazaki, to explain his campaign expenses. He acknowledged the summons and agreed to report to police headquarters today.

Good little afternoon-in-town fashions are brought to you today by Patterns of The Times. Variations of three designs, all in misses' sizes and made from Advance patterns, are shown in the accompanying illustration.

In its first change of ownership since 1867, the five-story store and apartment building at 1332 Third Avenue, adjoining the north-west corner of East Seventy-sixth Street, has been sold by the Dillon Estate to Hugh K. McGovern, operator, for cash over a mortgage of $20,000.

Up in the Eighteenth Congressional District, East Side Manhattan, where Vito Marcantonio used to reign for a decade, James G. Donovan is running for re-election to the House of Representatives. Once more Mr. Donovan, a Democrat, has Republican and Liberal endorsement as well, the completely unified coalition treatment that turned Mr. Marcantonio out of Congress in the 1950 election after past efforts had failed.

Read superficially, Georgi M. Malenkov's recent address to the Nineteenth Communist Party Congress was a boastful recital of great accomplishments on the home front. Soviet industry, he claimed, has increased its production thirteen times since 1929; both absolute and per capita production of heavy industrial and consumer goods are well above 1940; this year's grain crop is likely to be the highest in Soviet history, and so on.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 19 -- Fred Blum of Brooklyn had the championship and reserve winners in the open jumper competition of the New Brunswick horse show today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 19 -- A reported decision of Moscow to disband the Cominform quietly was published this week-end in several of Yugoslavia's leading newspapers. The report could not be confirmed from other sources.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Little Eddie Le Baron, capably filling the shoes of Sammy Baugh, flipped a 43-yard touchdown pass to End Hugh Taylor in the final period to give the Washington Redskins a 28-24 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in a National Football League game today at Forbes Field.

GENEVA, Oct. 19 -- It is clear from discussions here during the last week that many governments are beginning to think that an organized international program of large-scale migration from Europe may be a kind of missing link in a number of great world problems.
