SEOUL, Korea, 19 (AP) -- Gen John Howe, Chief of United States Army Field Forces, today praised the performance of United States-trained South Korean troops but declined comment on how soon they would be ready to replace all United Nation troops at the front.
A gridiron thriller between the Giants and Chicago Cardinals was wrapped up in the final fifteen seconds at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 19 -- Connecticut's first mock atomic attack -- a simulated bombing affecting seven towns and cities in this section of Fairfield County -- was held today without previous warning to 2,000 volunteer participants.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 -- Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault (ret.) of Flying Tiger fame today celebrated what he termed "the first defeat the Communists have suffered in the Far East."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 19 -- An analysis of the results of local government elections held throughout Belgium last Sunday show that Socialists obtained the largest number of votes and made the biggest gains. The Socialists polled 38.85 per cent of the votes cast, and the Social Christian (Catholic party) 36.49 per cent.

" The Age of Paradox: A Biography of England, 1541-1551," by John W. Dodds, will be published on Oct. 30 by Rinehart. The 200 illustrations have been arranged to present a picture of mid-nineteenth century English life and of events, trivial and important.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Commenting on reports that he agreed with the criticism of the pending European Army treaty made by Edouard Herriot, Speaker of the National Assembly to the Radical party congress, Premier Antoine Pinay said tonight that the Government had taken its stand in favor of the treaty and he would propose no change in that attitude.

The amazing success of Dr. Boris Stern, a United States Department of Labor specialist, in increasing the productivity of Haifa harbor has elicited deserved praise in your editorial columns on Oct. 13. You rightly state: "We may well be proud of the economic and social contributions toward such programs by our own experts, whose services we share gladly with the peoples of other nations."

For sixteen years the Catholic Youth Organization has provided an outstanding, expertly directed and carefully coordinated program for the youth of all colors, races and creeds here in New York City. This agency's leadership has given and continues to give sound guidance and sympathetic counsel to the young people of our times who face tough problems and who need the best direction it is possible to give them.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 -- A 1,200-mile motor trip through some of this state's major agricultural valleys and metropolitan areas has provided at least two possible answers to the question:

Ever since he made a spectacular debut three years ago, Sigi Weissenberg's talent has been questioned by none. The point at issue, judging from his last two concerts, is the direction his talents are taking.

NEWARK, Oct. 19 -- Extensively rebuilt for its third century of service, Trinity Cathedral held its reopening ceremony today. Since last April, when reconstruction began, services have been held in the diocesan house at 24 Rector Street.

MADRID, Oct. 19 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco today urged the stronger Western nations to give material, military and economic aid to those that were weaker so as to enable not some but all Christian powers to defend themselves against communism.
LACKAWANNA, N. Y., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Steel production at the Bethlehem Steel Company plant here, the largest in the state, was halted late today by the walkout of 1,200 rolling mill workers.

Louis B. Mayer, former production chief of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, will become chairman of the board of directors of the Cinerama Productions Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Dudley Roberts Jr., president. Mr. Mayer will succeed Lowell Thomas, who will continue in active participation in the company as vice chairman.

Two brothers were among 234 policemen cited yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan for meritorious conduct in the line of duty. They were Patrolmen Andrew K. and Walter C. Bentley, both of the West 100th Street station.
A crowd of 10,000 persons overflowed Straus Square along East Broadway on the lower East Side to participate yesterday in a rally to promote the sale of State of Israel Bonds.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 20 -- American and South Korean troops recaptured this morning "Pike's Peak" and "Sniper Ridge," north of Kumhwa on the central front in Korea, lost last night to the heaviest Chinese counter-attacks against the United Nations limited objective offensive launched last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- President Truman appeared to exude high confidence of Democratic success in the election as he returned to Washington today for a forty-eight-hour rest before setting forth again on his campaign for the Democratic ticket.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 20 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander, refused today to resume negotiations for an armistice in Korea on the basis of Communist proposals made last week for a total exchange of war prisoners.

About 2,000,000 people in the United States, mostly transient defense workers and service men and their families, will be living in 815,000 trailers by the end of 1952. They will have raised the trailer construction business from $1,300,000 in 1930, the year it was born, to about $142,000,000, divided among 150 concerns.

Hazel Dell Nordsieck, soprano, gave a debut recital at Town Hall Saturday evening. Mrs. Nordsieck, 1952 winner of the National Career Award Contest of the National Society of Arts and Letters, is a graduate of Indiana University. where she studied with Dorothee Manski.

Three teen-age girls were Democrats and three boys were Republicans in a panel discussion yesterday entitled "Will a Democratic Victory Secure Our Future?" at the New York Times Youth Forum, which was televised by WABD and will be broadcast by radio station WQXR at 10:15 A. M. on Saturday.

The world's industrialized countries will need to supply steady financial aid to the underdeveloped nations for many years to come, Eugene Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, declared here last night.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 -- Last week the steel operating rate was 106.5 per cent of rated capacity -- unchanged from a revised rate in the week before. It must again be pointed out that current percentage of operations are based on a now obsolete steel capacity figure which runs to Jan. 1, 1952.

The Board of Education's trial examiner, in the cases of eight teachers who had refused to say whether they had ever been Communist party members, declared yesterday that they had been "ill-advised" not to answer any question short of becoming informers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Northern soft coal operators notified John L. Lew/s ^today. that they day requested..hini .tourge - t/e'::mmersI to retdrn:b'wor.:?':. .(,!.r" .... ;. ;!.'[;
The recent activities of New York City department heads to improve housing conditions in our city deserve praise.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation today was denied a Supreme Court hearing on an appeal which sought reinstatement of a $3,120,743 damage award against Otis Co., investment banking concern.

GENEVA, Oct. 20 -- The countries of Eastern Europe under Russian domination are using forced labor to an increasing extent in response to Russian demands for stepped-up production, the Federation of Free Journalist said here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Higher prices for all grains and soybeans were the rule on the Board of Trade today in the forepart of the session, but selling pressure increased substantially on the upturns and prices receded from early tops.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -Following is the text of the conclusions of a two-member panel of the Subversive Activities Control Board in a proceeding to require the Communist party to register as Moscow-controlled:

General Douglas MacArthur, chairman of the board of Remington Rand, Inc., played the leading role yesterday in a dramatic demonstration of the speed with which modern office machines operate. He made a brief address in Grand Central Palace at 1:10 P. M. and then cut the tape to open the forty-fourth annual National Business Show.
SALEM, N. H., Oct. 20 (UP) -Tony De Spirito, the nation's leading rider, neared the 300-victory mark today by winning four of Rockingham Park's eight races to boost his 1952 victory list to 292.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 20 -- Denmark, a tiny country with a pacifist and neutralist tradition and a highly important strategic location, has undergone in the last two years a "military revolution."

Paired with Herman Steiner of Los Angeles in the twenty-first and final round of the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, yesterday, Alexander Kotov of Russia wound up his schedule in first place with a score of 16 1/2 -- 3 1/2., comprising thirteen games won and seven drawn, according to a report from Stockholm.
ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 20 (UP) -Vice President Albert Barkley tonight said Democrats who became rich since 1933 and now said they would vote Republican were "throwing the crutch at the doctor."

OGDENSBURG, N. Y., Oct. 20 -The influence of "narrow, special interests" upon Republicans has prevented the construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway and power project. Averell Harriman, Mutual Security Director, told the St. Lawrence County Democratic Committee here tonight.

YONKERS, Oct. 20 (AP) -- David Caudle won the Grand Circuit feature at Yonkers Raceway tonight, gaining a nose decision over Derby Day. Peg Jones was third, a length back, before 9,664 spectators who braved the chilly weather.
Cardinal Spellman presented the Ludwig Hektoen gold medal to a team of three physicians yesterday at the chancery office of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, 451 Madison Ave.

The official whose ruling changed the complexion of the game and put Pennsylvania in position for the winning touchdown last Saturday at Baker Field was technically correct, it was conceded yesterday by Lou Little, Columbia coach. However, Little told the Football Writers Association at the weekly luncheon-meeting at Toots Shor's that he was not sure the official used "good judgment" in making the call.

Surgical cures of cancer have often had seriously damaging psychological effects on patients, according to two papers read yesterday at the opening session of the annual meeting of the American Cancer Society.

Building trends were outlined yesterday by Richard Roth, a partner in the architectural firm of Emery Roth Sons, at the second in a series of realty lecture courses sponsored by the Real Estate Board of New York. "Designing for Profit" was the subject of the address, which was given at the Biltmore Hotel.

The dishes Ike likes to eat were sampled by food editors yesterday at a luncheon previewing the foods to be served to 2,000 guests tomorrow night at the Eisenhower-Nixon Touchdown Dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens made public yesterday the results of a new investigation in which his office reported that nearly half of the concrete being delivered to borough highway and sewer jobs had been "deficient." The five companies involved supply concrete for work throughout the city.

Atomic fission poses a major problem for package designers, speakers said yesterday at the opening meeting of the Packaging Institute in the Commodore Hotel. Industrial utilization of the atom, it was pointed out, may not be able to progress faster than the methods devised for handling fissionable materials.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Establishment of a threefold memorial at Union College to Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War and Union graduate, was announced today by Thomas J. Watson, chairman of the sponsors committee for the memorial. Mr. Watson is chairman of International Business Machines Corporation.
The Atlantic Refining Company and its subsidiaries had a net income of $31,149,000 in the first nine months of this year against $31,988,000 earned in the corresponding period last rear.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Can a Federal employe put a political campaign picture in the window of his home? Can he use his car to take voters to the polls next month?
Michigan State made the strongest showing of the season yesterday as it headed the United Press football ratings for the fifth consecutive week.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 20 -- A circular distributed to the Indonesian press today on behalf of the demonstrators who demanded the dissolution of Parliament last Friday indicated that Marxist splinter groups were responsible.

Trailing the field for almost half of the six furlongs, Delegate of the Woolford Farm closed with a great burst to win the $20,000 added New Rochelle Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The event featured the opening day's program of the Empire City Racing Association, and was witnessed by a chilled turnout of 18.658.

GEVARAM, Israel, Oct. 20 -- More and more American Zionists must realize that giving money is not enough, Dr. Nahum Goldmann, chairman of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, last night told a group of forty-two young people, most of them from English-speaking countries, who came here to learn Hebrew and thereby qualify for temporary jobs in Israel.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 20 -- President Syngman Rhee firmly insisted today that the South Korean Army was not yet strong enough to fight alone against the Communist forces. He made his statement a few hours after Government officials had declared the President would make no statement that could have a bearing on the Presidential elections in the United States.

The development of a device that measures the variations of electrical current in the stomach and that some day may be useful in helping to diagnose stomach ailments was described yesterday at the opening sessions of the seventeenth annual convention of the National Gastroenterological Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Army officials said today that the number of points needed for a soldier to complete a tour of duty in Korea had been increased, but the basic point system had not been changed.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 21 -- The Chinese Communists broke off attacks yesterday on "Triangle Hill" and "Sniper Ridge," main objectives on the central front in Korea seized last week in a United Nations limited offensive and the scene of bitter fighting for the last eight days.

Holders of common stock of Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company will receive a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share, a year-end dividend of 50 cents and a 2 1/2 per cent stock dividend on Dec. 15, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- Leaders of the Popular Republican Movement, the party of Robert Schuman, Foreign Minister, decided today that if the Government did not agree by Wednesday to submit the European army treaty to the National Assembly, M. Schuman should resign.

Leo A. Bercow and Walter Berger, operators, bought the six-story apartment house at 3301 Steuben Avenue, the Bronx, through E. Osborne Smith, Inc., broker and insured title with the Metropolitan Title Company. Charles H. Kelman was the attorney for the seller of the property, which is assessed at $215,000.

DETROIT, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Birmingham Country Club, which will be host next summer to the National Professional Golfers Association championship, has requested a change in the set-up of the annual classic.

Virtually all the country's unionized soft coal mines shut down yesterday as irate members of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers struck against a Government order cutting 40 cents from a Lewis negotiated pay increase of $1.90 a day.

ALBANY, Oct. 20 -- Counsel for Harry Gross argued before the Court of Appeals today that the twelve-year sentence given the bookmaker more than a year ago had, in effect, been a punishment for crimes of which the defendant had not been convicted.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- The Political and Security Committee, in which Korea and other outstanding issues before the United Nations General Assembly will be debated, will hold it first meeting Wednesday.
PARIS, Oct. 20 (AP) -- One of the scantiest groups of midseason style collections in Paris fashion history will get under way this week, with Lanvin-Castillo's opening tomorrow morning.

HANOI, Indo-China, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Communist-led Vietminh troops captured a second French outpost in northwestern Indo-China today !m their stepped-up offensive aimed at Thai territory near the Chinese border.

The Fordham University football squad loosened up in a light workout yesterday after Saturday's bruising battle with the Quantico Marines. The defensive backfield spent the entire afternoon working on the pass-defense patterns that will be used against Boston College's Jim Kane, when the teams meet Friday night at Braves Field in Boston.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 20 -- South African police today attributed Saturday's rioting in New Brighton, Port Elizabeth, in which eleven persons were killed, to "possible misrepresentation'' of their arrest by two Negroes who escaped from the police after being arrested for theft.
Following are the texts of addresses by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower yesterday at Bridgeport, Conn., and last night at Worcester, Mass., as carried by The Associated Press:

Twenty-three drivers on a list of 347 motorists with out-of-state license plates who were being sought by the police for running up five or more traffic violations since Jan. 1 came in to Manhattan Traffic Court voluntarily yesterday to pay fines totaling $2,115.

Borough President John Cash-more of Brooklyn, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, told member of the Civil Service Forum last night that he would do all in his power to help bring about an adequate salary plan for "automobile enginemen and all other groups, including educational and Uniformed forces and transit employes."

The story of Santa Claus and his sleigh propelled by reindeer does not change, but the toys he delivers keep abreast of the times. The doll industry, source of many of the favorite play items, watches fashions to be able to supply the children with the things their parents use and wear.

CAIRO, Oct. 20 -- The efforts of Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt, to find a new basis for understanding and cooperation between Egypt and the Sudan, which has been jointly ruled by Britain and Egypt, entered a possibly decisive phase today with the arrival in Cairo of Abdel Rahman el Mahdi, religious leader and patron of Umma, the pro-independence party.

WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 20 -- If you play football for Ralph Erickson at Loomis School you don't take it easy. You have to move, and move fast. The former Vermonter, in his seventh year at the helm of Maroon and Gray football believes in working his boys hard.

Predicting that the Republicans would carry Upstate New York with a plurality of at leas 800,000 votes, Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for re-election, said yesterday that this should be more than enough to overcome any Democratic advantage in this city.

A scroll commemorating the golden anniversary of the founding of Saks Co. in New York City was presented yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri to Bernard F. Gimbel at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Saks Co. is a subsidiary of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., of which Mr. Gimbel is president.
MUROC, Calif., Oct. 20 -- The "highly sector" Douglas X-3 research plane, reported as the successor to the world's fastest aircraft, was flown for the first time today and described as a "success."

Raw steel production is scheduled to fall only 1,000 tons shy of the record this week. Output is estimated at 2,214,000 net tons, with operations scheduled to run at 106.6 per cent of theoretical capacity. However, a new record could be established during the current week, if the trend of the last five weeks is continued.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- The New England Electric System, largest electric utility in this area, announced tonight that it was one of eleven electric utility companies working with a chemical concern to determine the commercial feasibility of using the heat from nuclear fission for the generation of electric power.

Two events of recent weeks caused men's thoughts to turn -- briefly, to be sure, the world being what it is -- from matters political to the art of conscious cerebration. One was the publication of the remarkable wartime journal of Bernard Berenson entitled "Rumor and Reflection."

The long-awaited Bruce Smith report on the New York Police Department, prepared for the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, is made public this morning. As expected, it is sharply critical. At the same time, and this is most important, it makes clear that major improvements and reforms are already under way.

As a citizen I should like to note my disagreement with the conclusion in your editorial entitled "The Hiss Deposition," which is based upon the opinion of twenty-two of my legal brethren. As a lawyer I should like to file my dissent from this legalistic opinion.
IF you have never taken a small boy hunting, we can recommend it as an experience that will be remembered, and even treasured, but it will do nothing to weigh down the game pocket on your coat.

" IT was a strange feeling," said Lou Little musingly, "but when that pass interference penalty was called against us in the Penn game on Saturday, I asked myself, 'Where did I ever see that before?' But I knew the answer. It was in that identical spot, in the identical situation, against the identical team and with the identical result."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Dr. Robert L. Johnson, former chairman of the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report, accused the Senate Committee on Government Operations today of an "unfair attack" on the work of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Australia's Minister of State for External Affairs, Richard G. Casey, reiterated today before the General Assembly his country's firm determination to continue endorsement of present United Nations negotiators at Panmunjom and to resist any attempt to transfer the truce talks to New York to be dealt with in the Assembly.
An intensified effort to crack down on violators of salary stabilization regulations was announced here yesterday by Justin Miller, chairman of the Salary Stabilization Board.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 20 -- An appeal for "economic unity of the non-Soviet orbit" to win "a possible hot war or a long cold war" was sounded today by George A. Sloan, chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The principal feature in quiet stock markets here today was the weakness of South African gold mining shares. Reaction to racial disturbances over the week-end in South Africa, plus the Anglo American Corporation Groups' quarterly reports, depressed leading gold issues by more than two shillings (28 cents) in some cases.
Snow surprised the city yesterday morning and continued to tease it with sharp flurries in the afternoon and evening.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 20 (UP) -Three letters addressed by Grammer to Miss Mizibrocky as "My Darling Tillie" were admitted as evidence at the trial today. In them Grammer repeatedly professed his devotion to her and started off one by writing:

Teddy (Red Top) Davis, 129 1/2 pounds, Hartford, Conn., last night gained a split decision over the favored Percy Bassett, 129. Philadelphia, in the ten-round bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.

The stock market found a good excuse yesterday to back away from the recovery effort of late last week. It was the spreading strike in the coal mining industry. Here again, however, this economic factor may prove the excuse rather than the reason in terms of technical market operations.

An Associated Press dispatch from Washington, published yesterday, reported that "editors of some of the nation's leading newspapers agreed that the press was under more pressure from both sides and subject to more criticism from partisan readers in its coverage of the 1952 campaign than in any other one in memory." These opinions came out at a meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.
A rare copy of the "Bug and Treacle" Bible was placed on display yesterday in the lobby of the Vanderbilt Hotel to mark the beginning of National Bible Week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The State Department charged in a formal statement today that the Bulgarian Government had effectively destroyed the Roman Catholic Church within its borders through a series of "trials" of church leaders that started three weeks ago.
HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 20 -A gift of historical documents pertaining to Samuel Morey, a steamboat pioneer, has been made to Dartmouth College by Dr. Herbert B. Wilcox of New York and Orford, N. H.

Virtually no change took place in the aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange between Sept. 15 and Oct. 15. On the former date it was 1,715,635 shares and on the latter 1,716,974 shares. Neither total included short positions carried in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers. These were 62,796 shares on Oct. 15 and 82,675 shares a month earlier.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 20--Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, tonight taunted his Republican opponent, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, for carrying on a campaign of political expediency -- a campaign of "no policy, no program and no real faith in the future of America."
WINNIPEG, Oct. 20 (Canadian Press) -- The biggest harvest in western Canada's history is practically over after what grain men term a miracle season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, denied today a charge that the military establishment was deliberately blocking an impartial examination of the armed services' utilization of manpower.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Communist party of the United States is "a puppet of the Soviet Union" and "lives for the day when it can install a dictatorship of the proletariat" in this country, a two-member panel of the Subversive Activities Control Board asserted today.

ABOARD THE EISENHOWER TRAIN, in New England, Oct. 20 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower opened the last lap of his Republican campaign for the Presidency in industrial New England today by expressing his indignation over the campaign "lies" told about him and by stressing the two themes of peace and prosperity.

Santos Ojeda, Cuban-born pianist, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Brahms' Variations and Fugue on a Theme of Handel was the major work of his program and his final group included Comparsa, by the Cuban composer, Alejandro G. Caturla, and three Argentinian Dances by Alberto Ginastera.

PARIS, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Eighteen West European nations discussed today their chronic shortage of United States dollars, but failed to arrive at any definite solution for the problem. They will try again tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review two cases where labor unions were accused of violating the Taft-Hartley Law by causing members to lose their jobs or work assignments for breaking union rules.

Cocoa took heavy losses in New York futures trading yesterday, dropping 64 to 37 points on Cocoa Exchange volume of 146 lots. The principal influence appeared to be the weakness on the London Terminal Market, where cocoa opened 2 to 5 shillings below Friday's close, recovered and then lost ground to close 2 to 6 shillings lower.

Speculating on the possibility of future helicopter travel from suburbia to the Manhattan metropolis, McCreery's selected fifteen fashions appropriate for this mode of travel and presented them yesterday to the press. The majority of the designs were in misses' sizes and available on the fourth floor, where customers also may view a model of the new Doman "air taxi" helicopter.
In time for fall refurbishing, a small group of conventional wallpapers and a larger collection, precision trimmed so the paper is ready for hanging, have become available here.

TOKYO, Oct. 20 -- (AP) -- Takeo Kurusu, Japan's Finance Minister in 1948, was convicted today of taking bribes and sentenced to eighteen months in prison in the first verdict of the nation's biggest postwar scandal.
ALBANY, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower would capture New York if the Presidential election were held today, newspaper editors in the state believe.

Negotiations are under way for sale of the equipment manufacturing portion of the Eastman Kodak Company's distillation products industries division to the Consolidated Engineering Corporation of Pasadena, Cal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -The motion picture industry said today that theatre television was "here to stay" and urged the Federal Communications Commission to assign a number of channels for the exclusive use of theatres.

A collection of character sketches and other writings by Sir Joshua Reynolds, discovered at Malahide Castle and Fettercairn House along with the Boswell papers, will be issued Nov. 17 by McGraw-Hill under the title "Portraits." The material is believed to have been the basis of a projected biography of Reynolds by Boswell.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Jesse W. Randall, president of the Travelers Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn., called today for a national safety campaign "to save America from danger to its freedom."

The five-story building containing four apartments and a studio at 46 Commerce Street, in the Greenwich Village section, has been purchased by the Truckee Holding Company, of which Thomas M. Graham is president, from the estate of Carlton A. Shively.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -The colonel who died as a hero on "Triangle Hill" in Korea last week was identified today as Lieut. Col. William H. Isbell Jr., a 45-year-old West Point graduate.

The old plant of the Morristown Memorial Hospital at the corner of Morris and Spring Streets in Morristown, N. J., is under contract of sale to a group of New York investors, according to Horace G. Jeffers, attorney for the hospital, which moved to new buildings on Madison Avenue in Morristown last July.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 20 -- A vaccine designed to provide immunity against all the three types of virus causing infantile paralysis has produced "favorable responses" in its first controlled tests on six Baltimore children, it was disclosed today at the opening of the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.

President Truman condemned yesterday what he termed a "campaign of smear and slander against Government employes by certain self-seeking persons and interests" and urged persons interested in good government to fight all attempts to reduce the Federal employe to the status of a "second-class citizens."

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Preconceived ideas about what the "happy, healthy family" must be like are no more conducive to good family life than preconceived notions about the ideal child are to a youngster's good personality development, members of the American Academy of Pediatrics were told last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- A demand that both Presidential candidates "unequivocally declare" their position on the Veterans Administration medical program before Election Day has been made by Marshall E. Miller, national commander of Amvets.

The members of the Subversive Activities Control Board who held yesterday that the Communist party of the United States is "a foreign-dominated revolutionary movement" could reasonably have come to no other conclusion. The subversive and alien nature of Communist policy is apparent; and now an official determination to this effect has been made after long hearings by a panel of the fact-finding body set up by Congress two years ago under the Internal Security Act.

GENEVA, Oct. 20 -- The Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration decided unanimously today to enlarge its activities to include assistance in the settlement of immigrants in areas where more population can be absorbed only as part of general economic development.

MILAN, Italy, Oct. 20 -- International socialism will pledge to do everything in its power to bring about a conference between the the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union together to discuss the unification of Germany of a resolution on European problems that will be submitted to the second congress of the Socalist International tomorrow is adopted.

" Captain Black Jack," which opens at the Holiday Theatre, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The British-made melodrama was produced and directed by Julien Duvivier, with George Sanders, Herbert Marshall, Patricia Roc and Agnes Moorhead heading the cast. The Classic-Goodman and Kaufman production is being presented here by Walter Gould.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -The Government has made substantial progress in its drive to enable business men to obtain Federal contracts without resorting to "5 percenters," officials said today.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Surprising wintry weather and the equally surprising par-72 score made by John Sierge in the face of the unfavorable conditions marked the start of the New York Herald Tribune tournament of golf club champions at the Westchester Country Club today.

LONDON, Oct. 20 (UP) -- The leader of Britain's second largest labor union today joined the attack on left-winger Aneurin Bevan and said the unions may be called on to save the Labor party from disaster at Mr. Bevan's hands.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of the address by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson here tonight:
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- In years past, stores that ordered rattan, wrought iron an dsimilar casual furniture did not want delivery until warm weather or spring.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, unchanged to 6 points higher than on Friday.

ABOARD NIXON CAMPAIGN TRAIN, Oct. 20 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, the Republican Vice Presidential candidate, today attacked the administrative record of Illinois' Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, on the latter's home ground.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 20 (AP) -Miss Mathilda Mizibrocky, a secretary at the United Nations headquarters in New York, testified in a crowded courtroom here today that she loved G. Edward Grammer before his wife was killed and was planning to many him. The 28-year-old Canadian said that she did not know Grammer was married and had three children.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 21 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,409 for twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -The Government announced today allocation of materials for construction to start before July on 599 commercial, religious, municipal and entertainment projects costing almost $100,000,000.

A sudden week-end recovery in market sentiment for new issues of high-grade corporate bonds was seen yesterday in the keen bidding by investment banking syndicates for $20,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of Carolina Power and Light Company, a standard A-rated public utility credit.
Governor Dewey charged last night that President Truman had injected race and religion into the campaign and thereby had sunk to the lowest level in American history.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- A television program that was to have included Lester B. Pearson, president of the United Nations General Assembly, was canceled tonight as a result of a labor jurisdiction dispute. The same dispute caused the cancellation last week of a program on which Secretary General Trygve Lie was to have appeared.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 20 -Gov. Earl Warren of California, beginning his Eastern speaking tour in behalf of the Republican Presidential ticket at rallies here and in Belleville tonight, hit out at the "weird campaign" that he declared the Administration had conducted to retain its power.
We think that some of our readers may be interested in an accounting of our letter columns during the course of this year's Presidential campaign.

EVER since Charles Kingsley and Nathaniel Hawthorne tried their hands at refashioning the classic tales of ancient Greece to the tastes of their own era other writers have been attracted by the same project. The old stories are so simple as well as so familiar that they seem to offer endless possibilities for elaboration according to taste. John Erskine wrote

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 -- The sale for $39,508,364 of all remaining shares of Bank of America stock owned by Transamerica Corporation and its subsidiaries was announced today by Sam H. Husbands, president of Transamerica. This, he said, represented a book profit of $20,038,513. The purchaser was a nation-wide underwriting group headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and Blyth Co., Inc. The stock has since been placed by the underwriters with investors.

Three out of every five persons applying for home relief are being rejected by Welfare Department screening. Department veterans said yesterday that this was the highest rejection rate in years, perhaps a record.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) -- More than 1,200 Government purchasing agents were advised today on how to stretch the dollar to get greater value for the taxpayers.

CHATHAM, N. J., Oct. 20 -The Committee for International Justice declared today through its executive secretary, H. Keith Thompson Jr., who is also the registered agent in this country of the Socialist Reich party of West Germany, that immediate release and restoration of the property and rights of the 1,045 Germans imprisoned as war criminals would be in the best interests of the United States.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 20 -- The British sent a battalion of troops and a cruiser to Kenya and declared a state of emergency tonight in this East African colony in an effort to control the fanatic, secret, anti-white society known as Mau Mau.

The new Socialist International is holding its second congress in Milan, Italy, and it is a lively and interesting meeting, well attended by delegates from all parts of the world. This International was formed in Frankfurt on July 1, 1951. It considers itself the heir of the historic Second International, created in 1889, which petered away between the wars under the impact of nationalism and the Communists' Third International.

Richard S. Perkins has been appointed to the boards of directors here of the Royal Insurance Company, Ltd., the Liverpool and London and Globe Insurance Company, Ltd., the British and Foreign Marine Insurance Company, Ltd., and Thames and Mersey Marine Insurance Company, Ltd., all member companies of the Royal-Liverpool Insurance Group.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service has started a school here to familiarize personnel with the myriad provisions of the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act, which is scheduled to become law Dec. 24. The school is being held at 70 Columbus Avenue.

LAKE ALFRED, Fla., Oct. 20 -- The same regatta-savvy Hoosier driver who romped off with the national Class B and C outboard championships last Saturday and yesterday to become the only double-winner added a third major honor today.

TRENTON, Oct. 20 -- The two convicted defendants among the so-called "Trenton Six," accused of the murder of a Trenton shopkeeper, sought reversals of their convictions today before the State Supreme Court. The court reserved decision.
The Dodgers and the Reds in the National League and the Yankees and the Senators in the American took the 1952 individual fielding honors.

LONDON, Oct. 20 (Reuters) -- An atomic war would probably be over in a few weeks with an "overwhelming victory" for one side, according to Brassey's Annual, unofficial but authoritative armed forces yearbook.

Gross operating revenues and net income of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on last Sept. 30 increased 5 per cent and 4 per cent, respectively, above the results attained a year earlier, according to the report released yesterday.
The Red Cross announced yesterday that 1,200 pints of blood had been collected over the week-end, with the hightest amount, 472 pints, donated by the community of Levittown, L. I.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -Business activity "quickened" last month as the nation recovered from the steel strike and a normal summertime slump, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Although no players' contracts have been signed yet, the chances are excellent for Steve Hill, who played the role of the young director in "The Country Girl,' and Pier Angeli, Italian movie actress now under contract to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, to undertake the principal parts in "Masquerade," the comedy-romance by L. S. Birchard and Jeroam Stagg.

An "exhaustive investigation" by the state's Election Frauds Bureau has uncovered the names of scores of persons suspected of having registered here illegally for the November election, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday.

Extensive changes in the organization and operation of the Police Department to eliminate serious and long-standing defects were recommended yesterday by the Institute of Public Administration in a report to the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 20 -- The first showing of the forecast of the British Coronation Collection from seven of the top London couturiers and from a number of the British wholesale collection took place here today in the United Funds Fashion showing.
Lou Little allowed his regulars to take a day off from contact work as the Columbia football team held a two-hour defensive drill yesterday in preparation for Saturday's game with Army.

Gov. John S. Fine of Pennsylvania advised the heads of the Republican national ticket yesterday not to be sidetracked by the Democrats' "deliberately low-grade" campaign and called on them "to talk straight and to the point" on the issues confronting the voters.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 20 -- A robust former trades union leader representing the State of Israel and an ascetic Talmudic sage who is an authority on the interpretation of Jewish law for a religious group conferred today on problems of state and religion.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 20 -John Roosevelt, the youngest son of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, praised his father's Administration tonight, excoriated President Truman's Administration and urged the voters "to let Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower lead us out of the wilderness."

Before the season is over, we may have a capital Gilbert and Sullivan company on the premises. S. M. Chartock, who has had a long experience with this form of madness, has assembled a promising company which began with "The Mikado" at the Mark Hellinger last evening.
AMERSFOORT, the Netherlands, Oct. 20 (UP) -- There's a whale of a difference between driving a bus in New York and driving one through the narrow, winding streets of this old Dutch town.

AUBURN, N. Y., Oct. 20 (UP) -James A. Farley said tonight the Republicans "illustrated what they meant by corruption in the undignified and disgraceful" fight between General Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft for the G. O. P. Presidential nomination.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 20 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and the Government of West Germany are deeply disturbed by the growth of French opposition to this country's rearmament and sovereignty and by the desire of French politicians to tie ratification of the German treaty system to a favorable settlement of France's claims on the Saar.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Truman accused the Republican leadership tonight of "deliberately distorting" his words to create the false impression that he had charged Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, with being anti-Jewish and anti-Catholic.

The Coast Guard has advised the operators and owners of twenty piers in the Port of New York that it proposes to place the properties on a restricted area list as of Nov. 1. It has asked the owners and operators to file prior to that date any objections they may have.
Crucial is the word for the day for many of the big fellows of the college gridiron as the season reaches the halfway mark Saturday.
" It Pays to Be a Yankee."

Ambassador William H. Draper Jr., United States special representative to Europe, warned last night that the countries of Western Europe would have to increase industrial production greatly and the United States would have to buy much more from Europe in order to ruin Premier Stalin's blueprint of waiting for the Western countries to attack and destroy one another.

A Bronx father whose 15-year-old son attempted three times to shoot him with a homemade "zip gun" Sept. 23 was found guilty yesterday of contributing to the delinquency of a minor. The verdict was given by Justice Jacob Panken of the Domestic Relations Court.

The supply and the quality of cultured pearls should be controlled at the source in Japan by an organization similar to the Diamond Syndicate, Ernest Heller president of Heller Deltah Company, said in an interview yesterday.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Oct. 20 -- Long Island State Park Commissioner Robert Moses proposed today to give up a strip of state park property for the construction of a mixed-traffic highway from the North Shore to the South Shore of Long Island in Nassau County.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 20 -- The National University's Law School is a place of special importance in Mexico because generals have been replaced by lawyers as the almost universal recipients of high Government jobs.

More than 300,000 of the nation's 375,000 soft coal miners were reported idle yesterday in what is politely referred to as an "unauthorized" walkout "in protest against the decision of the Wage Stabilization Board" on Saturday in allowing only $1.50 of the $1.90 a day wage increase agreed to between themselves by the union and the operators.

Four men, including a convicted narcotics peddler and a former assistant United States Attorney from New Jersey, were named yesterday in six indictments by a Federal grand jury for income-tax evasion and for concealment of assets from huge profits collected in the sale of sugar and corn syrup during sugar rationing.
Pan American World Airways became yesterday the first commercial airline in this country to buy jet passenger transports.

The beginning of an extensive housing survey in Harlem by city officials yesterday brought from Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh expressions of "shock" and incredulity that "a condition like this exists in New York City."
I was much interested in your recent Topics of The Times about Greenland. It was quite correct in saying that Greenland was not a "forbidding land."

Amos Culbert has resigned as vice president for sales of Northwest Airlines. His duties will be assumed by Malcolm S. Mackay, executive vice president, with James Mariner promoted from general sales manager to assistant vice president for sales.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, said today that a few Communists in key union positions could disrupt defense production and called on every labor union to oust any Communist or pro-Communist from its official staff.

A new plan of organization of the Mathieson Chemical Corporation as a result of its recent expansion and acquisition on Oct. 1 of E. R. Squibb Sons was announced yesterday by Thomas S. Nichols, president.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 20 -- The Syrian Government has announced that it is free to accept any bid for developing Latakia as a modern national port, despite the fact that the bidding closed officially last month.

Support for restoration by Brazil of a guarantee system designed to protect foreign traders against loss in event of currency devaluation is growing among business groups here as well as in the Latin-American country.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The United States today brought a treble-damage action against the Syracuse Professional Basketball Club, Inc., for allegedly charging more than ceiling prices for the Syracuse National's games last season.

A "selective selling" policy should be used where possible to reduce distribution costs, Henry Bach Associates, Inc., ad agency, advises in the latest issue of its house organ "The Bach Letter." For many businesses, the publication says, the sales curve and not the profit figure remains the chief measure of success.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- When the President accused General Eisenhower of adopting the "Nazi philosophy," of "accepting the very practices that identify the so-called 'master race,' though he took a leading part in liberating Europe from their domination," Mr. Truman again was borrowing from the spirit land one of his favorite ghosts to terrify the American people.

The two-story taxpayer at 116-32 Queens Boulevard in Kew Gardens, Queens, has been sold by Charles B. and Robert Benenson to clients of Benjamin Stein of Schiff, Dorfman, Stein Broff, attorneys. Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., was the broker and the Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Oct. 20 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Commander of the United States Pacific Fleet, denied today that his present tour of Formosa was connected with any move to deneutralize this Chinese Nationalist stronghold.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 -- The thirty-fourth annual National Metal Congress and Exposition opened for five days in Convention Hall today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 21 -- Darkness had enveloped University Field tonight before Coach Charley Caldwell blew the final whistle on a rock-and-sock scrimmage that kept Princeton's football squad moving at top speed for more than an hour. More of the same is in store for the Tigers tomorrow.

EN ROUTE WITH NIXON IN MISSOURI, Oct. 21 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, campaigned across President Truman's home state today and raised the possibility that Representative Dewey Short, Missouri's perennial Republican member of Congress, might be the next chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Several models designed especially for the American market, now the world's second largest buyer of British automobiles, were unveiled today at the press preview of the 1952 motor show in London. The show will be formally opened tomorrow by Field Marshal Earl Alexander, the Minister of Defense.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Dry weather was the dominant factor in wheat today, the market turning strong after early easiness. The firmer tone helped other grains, with commission buying developing in all pits on the early reactions.

Speakers at yesterday's sessions of the annual New York Herald Tribune Forum at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel covered a wide range of topics, from young people in politics, to freedom, to keeping the peace and to politics.

Cocoa traders have never passed through a more confusing period with less hysteria than in the last year, Samuel Y. Coyne, president of the New York Cocoa Exchange, asserted yesterday at the annual meeting of the Exchange. He gave the credit to the operations of manufacturers, merchants and traders on the Exchange, which were "the greatest single factor in stabilizing the cocoa market during this trying year."

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- The Illinois Volunteers for Stevenson Committee here announced today that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for President, had been solicited for a $2 to $25 contribution to aid the campaigns of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Presidential and Vice Presidential nominees.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Reports that the defense budget for the coming year might be lowered to about $41,000,000,000 and at the outside not exceed $45,000,000,000 gained support today.

Another drop in the city's public assistance case load was recorded in September, with 277,603 persons receiving aid, 3,243 fewer than in August, Henry L. McCarthy, Commissioner of Welfare, reported yesterday to Mayor Impellitteri. September grants totaled $11,890,517, a decline of $95,000 since August, or a saving at an annual rate of $1,140,000.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 21 -- Prof. Gaylord W. Anderson, president of the American Public Health Association, declared here tonight that recent efforts of the American Medical Association to restrict the field of public health activity "would turn back, the pages of public health half a century."
A thirty-day workhouse term and $1,440 in fines were imposed yesterday in Traffic Court on an accountant who admitted ignoring fifty-three parking summonses since 1950.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UP) -- Eight Republican Senators called on Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential nominee, to "disassociate" himself from "President Truman's action in raising the religious and racial issue in this election."

Soviet chess players made a clean sweep of the five top places in the world championship zonal tournament in Saltsjobaden, Sweden, after all results of adjourned games from the twenty-first and final round had been recorded yesterday, according to a report from Stockholm.

Earnings of state-chartered commercial banks in New York City during the first half of this year surpassed those of similar institutions in other parts of the state for the first time in almost a decade, according to figures issued yesterday by William A. Lyon, superintendent of banks.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 21 -- Against the background of a growing countrywide demand for general elections, Premier Wilopo called upon the Indonesian people tonight to maintain their national unity and said his Cabinet would continue to carry out its program, including general elections.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 21 -- Three Chicago physicians said today that more bacteria were developing more resistance to, "wonder drugs."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 12 points lower to 4 points higher.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson plans to introduce a resolution in the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly under which the Assembly would endorse the stand taken by the United States, as the agent of the United Nations, in conducting the Korean armistice negotiations. The resolution will be introduced Thursday or Friday if the committee has taken up the Korean question by that time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced an increase today of 100,000 tons in the quantity of quota sugar that may be made available in 1952 -- bringing the year's total of sugar quotas for all domestic and foreign areas to 7,800,000 short tons.

Rabbi Irving Miller, president of the Zionist Organization of America, predicted yesterday that "sooner or later" Israel would have a coalition government that would bring a "new spirit of unity within the country." He held that the majority of the Israeli people desired a broader Government.

TAIPEI. Formosa, Oct 21 -- President Chiang Kai-shek of Nationalist China called on the "Overseas Chinese" communities throughout the world today to unite in applying economic sanctions against Communist China. He also urged Chinese living abroad to boycott Communist elements and "fellow travelers" in their own midst.
Can Native Dancer win over a distance?

Henry W. Grunewald, Washington "mystery figure," moved in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday to have the special Brooklyn grand jury restrained from questioning him further because, he charged, the panel was seeking to find out if he had made any financial contribution to Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential candidate, when he was seeking his Senatorial seat in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- A demand that Paul R. Porter, a Mutual Security Agency official at Paris, return to Washington for questioning concerning his alleged pro-Soviet writings as a Socialist during his younger years was disclosed today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21 -- The Pittsburgh Courier, one of the largest weekly Negro newspapers in the country, has endorsed Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Richard M. Nixon for President and Vice President, respectively.

VIENNA, Oct. 21 -- The heads of Austria's coalition Government are hurrying back tonight from three spots in Europe to cope with the situation caused by the failure of the People's party and the Socialist parties in that administration to agree on next year's budget.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, ripped into the Wage Stabilization Board today for cutting 40 cents off the $1.90 a day increase for his soft coal miners and declared the men would go back to work when the operators honored their contract in full.

The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., yesterday charged the Port of New York Authority wth "prejudicial and biased conduct" in its opposition last week to the steamship company's application to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to operate an eastbound intercoastal service.
The Government's campaign to interest industry in a vast expansion program for titanium, a light but strong metal needed for the defense effort, is beginning to achieve results.

Another biographical study of Premier Joseph Stalin is scheduled for publication Oct. 30 by Dutton under the simple title "Stalin." The author is Nikolaus Basseches, an Austrian journalist who, before he was expelled from the Soviet Union, spent many years in Russia as a correspondent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today a study of manufacturing companies showed profit rates after taxes mostly higher in 1951 than in 1940 but lower than in 1950.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 21 (UP) -- The defense rested unexpectedly in the G. Edward Grammer murder trial today after the defendant had decided not to testify in his own behalf.
LONDON, Oct. 21 (UP) -- Randy Turpin outpointed George Angelo of South Africa in a fifteen-round bout tonight to win the vacant British Empire middleweight championship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- A report issued today by a subcommittee of the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives drew the inference that there was a connection between political contributions and the "tapering-off" of a Department of Justice anti-trust investigation in 1949 of four large liquor distilling companies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Miss Ruth Elizabeth Crawford, the United Nations staff member who last week told a Senate subcommittee that she had been a Communist party member in 1935, has offered her resignation as a publications officer of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

A man doomed to die next week in the electric chair asked through his attorney at a clemency hearing before Governor Dewey yesterday that he be "permitted to meet with dignity the death that the courts have decreed."

James F. (Jay) O'Connor, business agent of Local 791, International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., was indicted yesterday on charges that since 1946 he had extorted nearly $18,000 from a stevedoring concern on threats of labor trouble.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Lanvin-Castillo inaugurates the midseason in a collection developing the trumpet or low-released flare silhouette, a collection diffused with Castillo red, brilliant sapphire blue, heliotrope violet and a soft dark green that is almost gray.

The alertness of the driver of an armored truck carrying "at least $1,000,000" in deposits for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York led to the arrest yesterday of two ex-convicts, who allegedly had been following the truck for twenty-five minutes in the Bronx.

The crucial issue of the Sudan is approaching one of its periodic crises, but this time with better hopes of a solution than ever before. The new Sudanese Government Statute is to go into effect on Nov. 9 unless a substitute understanding is reached, and it is up to Premier Naguib to take a stand.
Seven past presidents of the National Gastroenterological Association were honored last night at the twentieth anniversary dinner at the Statler Hotel.

Today's new film is "Springfield Rifle," a Warner Brothers period action drama in WarnerColor, starring Gary Cooper, at the Paramount. Andre De Toth directed and Louis F. Edelman produced from a script by Charles Marquis Warren and Frank Davis and a story by Sloan Nibley. Paul Kelly, Phyllis Thaxter, Lon Chaney and Philip Carey are among the featured players.
YONKERS, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Ogden Hanover, a 9-to-1 shot, staged a stretch rush for a two-length victory in the Grand Circuit pacing feature at Yonkers Raceway tonight before 12,005 fans.

Radiation treatment of certain forms of cancer of the larynx has proved as effective as surgical removal of the voice box but also has saved the patient's voice, the American Cancer Society was told yesterday.

World merchant shipbuilding reached a post-war peak last month when 5,864,873 gross tons were under construction. Although the volume of tonnage was a record for this period, the number of individual ships involved was slightly less than at the start of the year, according to a quarterly report released yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping.
RYE, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Towering Tommy Goodwin today captured the first tournament of golf club champions sponsored by the New York Herald Tribune.

CAIRO, Oct. 21 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib told the British Ambassador today that he could not take up the Sudan question with Britain until he had completed his current talks with Sudanese leaders in about a week.

THE hop had gone from his fast ball and he was fading toward the end of a notable career when Hal Schumacher of the Giants made a statement of eloquent simplicity. It summed up the entire sports situation in one graphic sentence.

Delegates from eighteen states attended the opening yesterday of the twelfth biennial convention of Women's American O. R. T. (Organization for Rehabilitation through Training) at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
BOSTON, Oct. 21 -- A sharply-worded attack on Big Government's restrictions on business as a form of "cancer" came today from a self-described bureaucrat.
OSWEGO, N. Y., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Averell Harriman contended today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was compromising his principles.
The cold snap of the last two days has brought about discontent in the ranks of the volunteer ground observers of the Aircraft Warning Service in the midtown area, officials reported yesterday.

The New York City school system is operating under a serious handicap. The office of Associate Superintendent in charge of the elementary division has been vacant. This is an important position, directly concerned with more than half a million young boys and girls attending the city's public schools.

Commissioner of Investigation James H. Sheils asserted yesterday that the Queens Borough laboratory had been reporting defective concrete for "more than five or six years," with no apparent record of corrective action by other borough officials.

One the eve of departure to join Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower upstate, Senator Irving M. Ives declared last night that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson was the "tail" of the Democratic "donkey" and that he should be defeated in repudiation of the "gutter techniques" of President Truman.

New handmade rugs designed by Count Sigvard Bernadotte of Sweden, a large collection of whose floor coverings was introduced in New York two and a half years ago, emphasize this designer's versatility. The additions, all of which are available through decorators from Schumacher, utilize four different techniques of weaving and display rather than four different types of design.
Registrations in New York State for the election next month reached a high of 7,825,456, or 780,782 more than the 1948 record of 7,044,676, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -An average of 25,000 G. I. home financing applications was granted each' month during the first half of 1952, the Veterans Admhuistration announced today. More than 28,000 veterans received G. I. home loans at 4 per cent from private lenders during the month of September, the announcement stated.

An exotic fruit cup of mangoes, papaya and fresh pineapple, a rare, sweet-fleshed fish caught only in tropical waters and such vegetables as fried plantains and the squash-like chayote -- these were highlights of a typically Panamanian luncheon served yesterday to food editors at the Gotham Hotel.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 21 -- The Metropolitan pro-pro championship, serving as a tune-up for the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association championship to be staged here tomorrow, finished in a three-way tie today after a field of fifty-six, forming twenty-eight teams by blind draw, had completed the par-71 route at the Innis Arden Golf Club.

Vera Franceschi, pianist, gave a recital at Town Hall last evening. A native of San Francisco, Miss Franceschi is a graduate of the St. Cecelia Conservatory in Rome, the Paris Conservatory and the Manhattan School of Music, at which she now teaches.

More than 25,000 separate items of light electrical equipment and supplies for industrial and commercial purposes were shown yesterday at opening of the National Electrical Industries Show in the 165th Infantry Regiment Armory.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- A supply of cobalt 60 equal to twice the world's supply of radium is being used here to test the effect of radiation on materials to be used in developing an atomic power plant for submarines.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- An extraordinary amount of interest in the United States Presidential campaign is being shown by the British people, who, having begun by favoring Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, now are showing signs of disenchantment with him.

Back from Amersfoort, the Netherlands, yesterday came George E. Brennan, a Third Avenue bus driver, firmly convinced that he would rather maneuver between elevated pillars, and dodge taxicabs and jaywalkers than have his vision beclouded by banks of flowers at Dutch intersection.s

No one has been quicker or louder in blasting Senator McCarthy as a slime-slinger than have President Truman and Governor Stevenson -- and many of us agreed with them. But now both of those campaigners have embraced the McCarthy strategy for their own rabble-rousing oratory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- A charge that Eastern Airlines was illegally in control of Colonial Airlines at the time a merger of the two was under consideration was made today in a petition filed by National Airlines with the Civil Aeronautics Board.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 22 (AP) United Nations Command communique 1410 for the twenty-four-hour period ended 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korea time:

The marathon departmental police graft trial enters its fourth month today, with no early end in sight. Harry Gross, whose bookmaking graft the thirty defendants are alleged to have accepted, came back on the stand yesterday afternoon to continue his story of payoffs.

BOSTON, Oct. 21 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower addressed the largest crowd of his campaign here today when an outpouring estimated by the police at 100,000 gathered on historic Boston Common to hear him pound communism and stress the virtues of "truthful campaigning."

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Britain's Colonial Secretary, Oliver Lyttelton, will leave for Kenya next week for a personal survey of events there and to discuss with the Kenya Government plans for the future development of the colony.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Convinced that 1955 will prove the testing period for both domestic and foreign business men because defense spending will have died off by then, Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer will have reports ready on both domestic and foreign trade possibilities before he leaves office on Jan. 20, next.

Big-time hockey makes its seasonal bow in New York tonight, with the Rangers, Gotham's representatives in the National Hockey League, squaring off against the Lynn Patrick-coached Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden.

ST. PAUL, MINN., Oct. 21 (AP) -- The establishment of a Federal transportation commission to take over the functions of agencies such as the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Federal Power Commission and the Civil Aeronautics Commission was proposed here today.

Milton Weill, president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, announced yesterday that three business men would be general chairmen of the federation's $20,000,000 maintenance appeal. They are Saul Horowitz, president of the H. R. H. Construction Corporation; Salim L. Lewis, a partner in Bear, Stearns Co., investment brokers, and David K. Rosenthal, president of the R. K. Dress Corporation.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Communist China is attempting to buy from Britain certain kinds of machinery and equipment that are forbidden to it by the Allied ban on exports of strategic goods.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Aneurin Bevan and his minority group in the parliamentary Labor party held their first open-house meeting today in the House of Commons. They had few guests.

Dr. Louis Berger, in his initial address as president of the Kings County Medical Society, proposed last night the development of a "temporary" group unit that would include all members of the society and in which patients would be required to contribute some of the funds.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 21 -- The Venezuelan Government announced that national security officers tonight surprised and shot to death Leonardo Ruiz Pineda, leader of the underground Accion Democratica party.

Housing projects were hailed yesterday by city officials as a means of eliminating slums and also developing planned communities within the city limits. Addressing several hundred residents and school children at the cornerstone laying of Cooper Park Houses at Kingsland Avenue and Frost Street in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, Borough President Cashmore and other officials stressed the value of the $8,100,000 development. It will provide low-rent apartments for 700 families by next spring.

Tom Campbell dropped in on New York yesterday and paused long enough during two days of tub-thumping for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to mention that he could solve India's food problem in comparatively short order. All he would need is some Point Four money to apply his own methods of mechanized agriculture.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 21 -- West Germany's 80,000 policemen will be supplemented by armed forces of about 458,000 men next year if the European army is organized.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 21 -- Non-white defiance of the segregation laws is gaining momentum and it verged on violence in at least two centers today and yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Permits to begin construction on 311 school and college building projects throughout the United States were granted in September by the Division of Civilian Education Requirements, Earl James McGrath, Commissioner of Education, announced today.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 21 (UP) -- Leo Durocher tonight said that he hoped eventually to find a position in motion picture production work but added he would return to the Giants in 1953 as manager.

A no-holds-barred battle against the Institute of Public Administration report on the Police Department by police line organizations was presaged yesterday when the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association called the document "a malicious smear against every member of the uniformed force."

The stock market proved a point yesterday -- that strikes can be anticipated, and cessation of work in any industry need not cause a price upset. The share list drifted yesterday with price changes limited in both directions and trading at a slow pace.

In Indo-China the expected Communist offensive of the Vietminh has been launched. French Union troops, including the growing forces of Vietnam, are faced with hard fighting. A significant factor in the early clashes has been the use of modern heavy weapons by the Communists.

An energetic program for pushing economic development of Latin-American countries with private United States investment was advocated yesterday at a meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Statler Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The United States has lent or given more than a tenth of its national revenue in the last seven years as foreign aid to friends and former friends.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The State Department in an analysis of the situation made public today, supported the recess in the armistice negotiations in Korea declared on Oct. 8 by the United Nations command, pending the receipt of written proposals from the Communist forces on the question of prisoner repatriation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Allotments of steel for civilian goods in the first quarter of next year will amount to only 33 per cent of the average amount used in the first six months of 1950, the National Production Authority announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The City of Chicago is reaping a little fortune out of the rags, the paper and the metal which formerly went from municipal departments to the scrap heap. Other purchasing departments should do the same, Richard B. Berry, deputy chief purchasing agent of Chicago, told the 1,200 delegates attending the annual conference of the National Institute of Governmental Purchasing here today.
In the strongest language he has yet employed, Governor Dewey yesterday lashed out at the Democrats with the assertion that they were relying solely on "bloodstained prosperity" to win the election.

Vic Seixas, playing captain, Hamilton Richardson and Straight Clark were named last night by the United States Lawn Tennis Association to represent the United States in the Davis Cup interzone final in Australia, Dec. 18-20.
MIAMI, Okla., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Mickey Mantle is scheduled to receive his third Army induction examination in less than two years at Oklahoma City tomorrow.
BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's speech on Boston Common today:

The purchase of British jet airliners by Pan American World Airways makes it certain that American-flag commercial aviation on world routes will be at least as speedy and modern as its strongest competitor for the next five or six years. Airline operators and airplane manufacturers the world over agree that it is unlikely that a commercial jet airliner better than the deHavilland Comet Mark III will be in operation before 1956.

Dr. Max Y. Seaton has been named senior vice president and technical coordinator of the chemical divisions of Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation. Dr. Seaton formerly was executive vice president of the company's Westvaco chemical division.

Third-quarter earnings of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company more than doubled those of the corresponding period a year ago, but the net for the nine months of 1952 was somewhat lower, John D. Biggers, president, disclosed yesterday.

A musical version of their newly published book, "Spindletop," dealing with the Texas oil boom, is the goal of James A. Clark and Michael T. Halbouty. And the collaborators already have set the wheels in motion.

The appointment of Edgar Brinkmann, operating manager of National Bulk Carriers, Inc., for the last five years, to the newly created post of director of technical research, was announced yesterday. He was succeeded as operating manager last week by John K. Galleher.

Packers of frozen foods have organized a country-wide cooperative selling agency with headquarters in Miami through which they will sell their packs under the single brand name of He-Man Foods, Inc. Bob White, widely known for food promotion and merchandising in Chicago, has been made manager of the company.

TOKYO, Oct. 21 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida served notice on the nation today that he intended to succeed himself as head of the new administration to be formed as a result of the general election that returned the conservative Liberal party to power.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- The accident prevention campaign being carried on by a special committee of the American Academy of Pediatrics was highlighted today with the presentation of an award of merit to that committee by Dr. Walter B. Stewart of the National Safety Council.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Laryngitis sent Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, to the hospital today. He probably will be unable to campaign for several days at least.

New Jersey residents will have an opportunity on Election Day to do themselves a material service. Proposition Number 1 on the ballot would empower the state to back with its credit the issue of bonds for the construction of the Garden State Parkway.

Life insurance purchases throughout the United States in September showed an increase of 30 per cent over the volume in the same month last year. The total in September, the Life Insurance Agency Management Association reported yesterday, amounted to $2,504,000,000, compared with $1,923,000,000 in September, 1951.
Mayor Impellitteri switched on the porch light of Gracie Mansion last night in a ceremony to demonstrate how the American Legion's program of "Lights On -- Votes Out" will operate on election eve.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Oct. 21 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina tonight urged the voters of his state to stop being "slaves" to the Democratic party label and to make Election Day "our Emancipation Day" by supporting the Republican Presidential nominee, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Caution was the keynote on the stock markets today. Most sections opened with slight drops, but recovered a greater part of the losses and closed on a firm note. The recovery was particularly marked for South African gold mining and Rhodesian copper shares.
A pistol-toting female bandit directed the looting of a Brooklyn home yesterday of $7,600 after letting in two male confederates who tied up the woman of the house, her 8-year-old son and a maid.

The prepared texts of Gov. Adlai Stevenson' address, made last night in Chicago and carried by radio and television, and that by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, both made to the Herald Tribune Forum at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, follow:
LONDON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Georgina Brown, 14-month-old quadruplet, went home this week able to see, although doctors had declared her incurably blind at birth.

The use of some of the manmade "miracle" fibers in a fabric does not guarantee that all of the characteristics claimed for that fiber will be found in the fabric that finally reaches the consumer, Dr. W. E. Coughlin, director of the textile laboratory at the Good-housekeeping Institute, said yesterday.

FORT WORTH, Oct. 21 (UP) -- The defending champion, Mrs. Babe Didrickson Zaharias, and the medalist, Betsy Rawls, won their first-round matches easily today in the seventeenth annual Texas women's open golf tournament.
New issues of public utility and industrial securities valued at more than $24,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The public offerings are:

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Government circles indicated tonight that the Cabinet would set a date tomorrow for submission of the European army treaty to Parliament, and that Premier Antoine Pinay would make a public statement clarifying his position regarding foreign policy.

Views From Overseas The decreasing turnover on stock exchanges both in the United States and Great Britain is due to high taxation.
