This was the opinion expressed here yesterday by John Braithwaite, chairman of the London Stock Exchange, who will be the guest of the New York Stock Exchange today prior to his departure for Canada to attend the centennial celebration of the Toronto Stock Exchange on Friday.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Army's football forces were dealt a blow today when it was learned Bob Guidera and George Kovacik, tackles, were lost to the squad.

A New York premiere of selected designs from The Chicago Tribune's American Fashions Competition was presented yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The event marked the thirteenth year of nation-wide competitions to discover talent in the field of fashion design.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Briefs were filed in the United States Court of Appeals today in suits of two men attacking the constitutionality of the reserve clause in baseball player's contracts.

Events today: Leslie Frick, mezzo-soprano, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 5:30 P. M.; "Bluebeard's Castle" and "L'Heure Espagnole," City Center, 8:15; Witold Malcuzynski, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Juilliard String Quartet, Town Hall, 8:30; Manhattan Trio, Hubbard Auditorium, Manhattan School of Music, 8:30; The Tyroliers, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30; American Lyric Theatre, 133 Macdougal Street, 8:40.

A new effort to enact a child-vandalism bill was begun yesterday when Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey, Brooklyn Democrat, introduced in the City Council a local law that would hold a parent of any child under 16 years old responsible for "willful destruction" of city property by the child.

May I call to the attention of your readers a bill now being considered in committee of the New York City Council. This is the Quinn-Isaacs bill, designed to modernize labor relations in New York City.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- The Government charged five leading Communist Deputies today with ordering and encouraging physical and moral sabotage against France and her military effort and asked the National Assembly to strip them of their parliamentary immunity so they could be prosecuted.
Directors of the Roosevelt Hotel, Inc., have entered into a rearrangement of a previous plan to transfer the company's assets to the Hilton Hotel interests.

The Presidential candidates of the two major parties expressed the common view last night, in a half hour they shared before a nation-wide television and radio audience, that United States leadership would eventually bring about an enduring peace in the world.
NEWARK, Oct. 21 -- The public reception given here today to President Truman was interpreted by Democratic officials as an augury of victory in New Jersey for Governor Stevenson.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Only half of the country's eligible teen agers are being taught how to drive automobiles in properly conducted high school classes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- The United Nations General Assembly voted today emphatic approval of a United States request to consider the establishment of an impartial commission to look into the Communist world's charges that the United States had dropped germ weapons in Korea and China.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Foreign Minister Paul van Zeeland of Belgium urged the Marshall Plan Council today to prepare Europe's concrete proposals for bridging the dollar gap, to be presented at a conference between European countries and the United States.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 21 -- Jerry Wald has requested that the contract between Wald - Krasna Productions and R. K. O.-Radio Pictures be canceled immediately and that the termination date be made retroactive to the close of business last Saturday.
Following is one of a series of articles on the present political situation by The Associated Press, based on a nation-wide survey it made on estimates by newspaper editors and political writers.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on $33,491,000 of state-guaranteed loan notes for the temporary financing of low-rent and slum clearance projects. The bids slated for acceptance ranged in interest cost from 1.29 per cent to 1.33 per cent.

Our peripatetic city scout tells us that the best way to recover the rich mixed-grill flavor of New York of fifty years ago is to explore the region lying east of Astor Place. Start from St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie and follow Tenth Street to the river -- or as far as it goes until, at Avenue D, it is stopped by an assembly of high brick walls and green spaces.

Police of West Hempstead, L. I., have taken away the revolver of Frank P. Walsh, electrician and night industrial guard, who on Sunday evening fired a bullet into the picture tube of his receiver because he couldn't stand the noise any longer. They should give him back his gun; his work has barely started.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 22 -- Chinese Communist troops, in a series of attacks and counter-attacks, today drove to the top of "Pinpoint Hill," a dominating position on "Sniper Ridge" and an important advance post captured by the United Nations in a limited offensive last week, north of Kumhwa on the central Korean front. The Chinese controlled the position as of noon today, with the swaying battle still continuing.

A long step toward solving the problem of proper communications between a manufacturer and retailers will be taken next month by James Lees Sons Company, carpet and yarn manufacturers of Bridgeport, Pa. It may well serve as a pattern for other manufacturers in varied fields, according to Joseph L. Eastwick, president of Lees.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Foreign Minister Paul van Zeeland of Belgium urged the Marshall Plan Council today to prepare Europe's concrete proposals for bridging the dollar gap, to be presented at a conference between European countries and the United States.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 21 -- Jerry Wald has requested that the contract between Wald - Krasna Productions and R. K. O.-Radio Pictures be canceled immediately and that the termination date be made retroactive to the close of business last Saturday.
Following is one of a series of articles on the present political situation by The Associated Press, based on a nation-wide survey it made on estimates by newspaper editors and political writers.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on $33,491,000 of state-guaranteed loan notes for the temporary financing of low-rent and slum clearance projects. The bids slated for acceptance ranged in interest cost from 1.29 per cent to 1.33 per cent.

Our peripatetic city scout tells us that the best way to recover the rich mixed-grill flavor of New York of fifty years ago is to explore the region lying east of Astor Place. Start from St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie and follow Tenth Street to the river -- or as far as it goes until, at Avenue D, it is stopped by an assembly of high brick walls and green spaces.

Borough President John Cashmore, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, told the members of the Brooklyn Junior Chamber of Commerce yesterday that they must become active in politics if they were fundamentally interested in better government.

Laurence C. Tombs of Montreal, a travel-industry official for a quarter of a century who has been particularly active in the promotion of air transportation, was elected president of the American Society of Travel Agents yesterday at the organization's twenty-second convention in Miami.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Oct. 21 -- Vice President Albert W. Barkley appeared the likely choice today to deliver any Democratic answer to an address by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, who is scheduled to speak on Oct. 27 in Chicago.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois declared tonight that the Democrats had led the United States through "a humane revolution, without hatred or bloodshed" and asserted that repetitions of that "miracle" throughout the free world offered the best answer to the challenge of Communist imperialism.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The nation's 327,000 striking soft coal miners indicated today that they would stick it out until they got the full $1.90 a day wage increase that John L. Lewis negotiated with the coal industry.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Capt. Charles L. Melson, Chief of Staff of the Severn River Naval Command and administrative aide to the Superintendent of the Naval Academy since July, 1950, relieved Capt. Francis D. McCorkle yesterday as commanding officers of the 45,000-ton battleship New Jersey.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 21 -- Forty-nine members of the Brown University faculty, who emphasized that they were speaking not as representatives of the institution but as individual citizens, announced in a statement tonight their "enthusiastic support" of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for President.
Mayor Impellitteri presented prizes yesterday to teen-age winners of the fourth annual Police Athletic League photography contest at a ceremony held in City Hall.

The Admiral Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed for commercial sponsorship of Bishop Fulton J. Sheen's television program of religious talks, "Life Is Worth Living," which resumes over the Du Mont-network on Tuesday, Nov. 18, from 8 to 8:30 P. M.

National Golf Day, sponsored by the Professional Golfers Association and Life, will be held again in 1953, Andrew Heiskell, pulisher of the magazine, declared yesterday at a luncheon at the University Club.

A member of the Board of Education proposed yesterday that the city's children start each school day by singing the first and fourth stanzas of the patriotic hymn "America" instead of reciting the prayer suggested by the State Board of Regents.
The Association of The Bar of The City of New York announced last night its recommendations on candidates for judiciary posts in the coming election.
Following are the prepared texts of addresses by President Truman yesterday at Jersey City and Philadelphia, as carried by The Associated Press:
Following is the text of an address by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson last night in Chicago as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia cleared the way today for a grand jury investigation here of an alleged international oil cartel. It dissolved a stay of proceedings it had imposed upon the Federal District Court and refused a request of five oil companies for a further stay.

ABOARD TRUMAN TRAIN, in Pennsylvania, Oct. 21 -- President Truman barnstormed into Pennsylvania tonight and declared that if Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and the Republican party won the election with their "fraudulent campaign," their "reactionary" policies would endanger world peace and domestic prosperity.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, placed before a United Nations committee today a United States appeal for greater economy in the United Nations.

RIO DE JANIERO, Oct. 21 -- Twenty soldiers and officers of the military police in the State of Minas Gerais are to be tried by court martial on charges of subversive activities in the armed forces, it was announced today. It is the latest of several indications that Brazilian authorities are pushing their drive against wide Communist infiltration of the Brazilian services.

Harold C. Peterson, superintendent of transportation for the IND subway division, testified yesterday at a Public Service Commission hearing that if the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company's station at Nineteenth Street and Avenue of the Americas was discontinued, the passengers using it could "easily be accommodated" at the Twenty-third Street or Fourteenth Street stations of the IND on the Avenue of the Americas.

Pacific Mills omitted the quarterly dividend usually paid at this time, it was announced yesterday. The company said that "in view of the fact that the dividends of $1.50 per share this year have not been earned, the directors decided not to take action on payment of the dividend."

WASHINGTON, Oct 21 -- David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, is expected to be named soon as the head of the Defense Department's sweeping investigation into how the armed services use the manpower assigned to them.

MONROE, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- According to Bart Allen, who takes all forms of hunting seriously, if a beagle "only lived longer and could cook" he would postpone indefinitely his half-hearted search for a wife, for it is a recognized fact that a beagle neither scolds nor talks back.
WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 21 -- Although injuries and early season illness have beset Coach Ed Douglas' Taft School football squad, the morale of the Red and Blue "has remained exceptionally high."

i After a brief ownership, Nathan Wilson, the operator, has resold the sixt%en-story and penthouse apartment hotel on lot 30 by 100 feet at 25. East Sixty-seventh Street to an investor in a deal negotiated by Louis Nowikas, broker. Assessed at $410,000, the property consists of six stores and sixty-one apartment~ and was bought by th~ seller from the Knott Corporation.

The next session of the Atlantic Council is scheduled for December. By that time it will be ten months since the top Ministers of the Western alliance met in Lisbon. It is obvious that the interval between meetings is too long. Left to themselves, without the prodding, encouragement and sense of partnership that comes from batting things out around a table, the member nations tend to pull apart and go off on their own tangents.

In contrast to the reduced incomes reported by many other industries, the airlines this year have generally turned in better profit results. In keeping with this trend, the operating statements of three airlines yesterday announced substantially higher earnings than a year ago.

Jacob K. Javits is now completing his third term as member of the House of Representatives from the Twenty-first Congressional District, on the upper West Side of Manhattan. The early enthusiasm of Republican leaders over his energy and his lively mind, coupled with a humanitarian outlook, has proved to be well justified.

James C. Petrillo, head of the American Federation of Musicians, has decided to place before the international executive board of the union a heated dispute between Meyer Davis, band leader and a prominent Broadway "angel," and Local 802, an affiliate of the A. F. M. Mr. Davis had requested that Mr. Petrillo act on his own initiative and issue a stay of enforcement, pending an appeal.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Moscow is telling the Russian people to expect the worst no matter who wins the United States election. To a Communist either candidate is just about as bad as the other.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Oct. 23 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet said today that the Republic of Korea never would be strong enough to man alone the fighting line now held by his Eighth Army.

Walter C. Heck, 53-year-old former operator of the Carnegie Hall box office concession, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey to eighteen months in prison for defrauding the Government of $147,000 in admission taxes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Post Office Department is investigating a complaint that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, abused his Congressional franking privilege by mailing, post-free, pamphlets advertising his book "McCarthyism -- the Fight for America."
TROY, N. Y., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of an address by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower here tonight:
PARIS, Oct. 22 -- The French Cabinet decided today to submit the European army treaty and the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies to Parliament by the middle of November.

The Second World War left behind a tragic multitude of homeless and jobless human beings. For the last four or five years various agencies have been nibbling at this problem. The United States Displaced Persons Commission had brought in nearly 400,000 individuals when it went out of business on Aug. 31 after four years of work.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney of Oklahoma, predicting national victory for the Democrats Nov. 4, declared today it would "take a political miracle for the Republicans to break through to get a single electoral vote in the South."

On Jan. 7 of this year THE NEW YORK TIMES expressed its hope that General Eisenhower would be nominated by the Republican party and declared its readiness to support him in the event that he became a candidate. We would make the same choice today, even in the absence of this prior commitment.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The name of Britain's new jet engine, the Rolls Royce Conway, was taken off the secret list today. This action by the Ministry of Supply followed the publication last week in American Aviation Daily, a United States publication, of details of the engine.

United Air Lines, Inc., achieved record revenues and earnings in the first nine months this year and yesterday declared an extra dividend of 50 cents along with the regular quarterly of 25 cents. The dividends, payable on 15, Dec. 15, put 1952 disbursements equal to the $1.50 distribution last year.
ROME, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Italian Ministry of Industry and Commerce is going to ask Parliament to give limited protection to manufacturers of medicinal products.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, declared yesterday that "Governor Dewey's recent statements are the most shameful political plays on the emotions of our people ever stooped to by an official of government."

Because two brothers were operating a thriving concern with 125 employes, Judge Clarence G. Galston in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday permitted one of them to wait until next March 30 before beginning a penitentiary term of a year and a day for income-tax evasion.

The late George Bernard Shaw is represented on publishers' lists this season with two collections of his writings. Dodd, Mead will issue on Oct. 31 "The Selected Prose of Bernard Shaw," edited by Diarmuid Russell. The volume contains passages of autobiography, sections of his novels, selections from Shaw's ."Music Criticism" and "Drama Criticism" and from "Pen Portraits."
TORONTO, Thursday, Oct. 23 (Canadian Press) -- The Telegram, Toronto evening newspaper, is offered for sale in an advertisement published in this morning's Globe and Mail.

For those who love old houses, as well as for the student of early American art, an exhibition opening tomorrow in the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art will furnish an absorbing chapter in eighteenth century history.

Two nine-man crews from the city schoolship John W. Brown lustily pulled oars yesterday afternoon in a lifeboat race in the East River from Thirty-fourth Street past the ship's stern to Twenty-fourth Street. One crew represented the John W. Brown's deck force, the other the ship's engineers. The engineers flashed past the finish line about a boat's length ahead to cheers from Board of Education guests on the training ship and from watchers ashore.
HANOI, Indo-China, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Black River town of Vanyen fell today before a Vietminh offensive, straining French Union lifelines in northwest Indo-China.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Jimmy Bivins of Cleveland added to his reputation as a power puncher tonight as he won a split decision over young Wes Bascom in a ten-round heavyweight bout at the St. Louis Arena.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Charles Oliphant, former chief counsel of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, has received temporary permission to represent clients in cases before units of the Treasury Department.

A deluge of soot showered down upon luckless passers-by at the rush hour yesterday morning around Kent Avenue in the Williamsburg district of Brooklyn. By afternoon it had brought a flood of protests and lawsuit threats by irate citizens to the Bureau of Smoke Control and other city officers.

The Government moved yesterday to strip Frank Costello of his United States citizenship. The 61-year-old gambler is now serving an eighteen-month sentence for contempt of the Senate. The Department of Justice filed a petition in Federal Court to cancel Costello's naturalization on the grounds that he had not been of good moral character in the five years preceding his citizenship application.

The third double-bill performance of Bartok's "Bluebeard's Castle" and Ravel's "L'Heure Espagnole" was given last night by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center. Norman Kelley, as Gonzalve, and Richard Wentworth, as Don Inigo, made their first appearances in those roles during the latter.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Oct. 22 -- Henry Witte, suspended police chief of Lodi, was found guilty today on all five counts of an indictment for failing to suppress gambling in his town. The jury, which had heard seventeen days of testimony before Judge J. Wallace Leyden in Superior Court here, was out for eight hours.

BUFFALO, Oct. 22 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois charged tonight that the Republican "economic reactionaries" and "isolationists" were allies of communism at home and abroad "even if they don't know it."
Four women testified yesterday that they were afraid to walk along the Avenue of the Americas between Fourtenth and Eighteenth Streets at night, because the neighborhood was "dangerous."

Two workmen were killed by smoke poisoning in a fire on the 6,645-ton Norwegian freighter Fernfield early yesterday at her dock at Pioneer Street, Brooklyn, and the Erie Basin. The victims were Konrad Stromme, 50 years old, of 946 Fifty-ninth Street, and William McEwan, 55, of 116 Astor Court, both Brooklyn and both employed by the Golten Sigurd Machine Corporation, 455 Carroll Street, Brooklyn.

Teachers who are members of the Communist party are required by party tenets to indoctrinate their students with subversive doctrines, it was charged yesterday by the city attorney who presented the cases against eight suspended teachers in departmental trials that started Oct. 1.
A group of 714 Columbia University professors and staff members declared their support yesterday of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Columbia's president, for President of the United States.

The American Federation of Labor's Free Trade Union Committee charged yesterday that the Chinese Communist regime had executed or caused the death of more than 14,000,000 persons in the last five years, including more than 500 United States prisoners of war captured in Korea.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Arab and Asian members of the United Nations scored a victory today in getting their joint complaint against South Africa's policy of apartheid, or race separation, high on the agenda of the General Assembly's special Political Committee.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 22 (UP) -- Towns and jungle roads were placed under tight military control today as the Government pressed its emergency drive against the secret Mau Mau terror society.

A statement in which ninety-two leading authors accused newspapers and magazines of "nationwide abuse of the written word" in covering the Presidential campaigns was made public yesterday by John Steinbeck, Herman Wouk, John Hersey and Cleveland Amory.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Spring suits on middy lines form an interesting part of Manguin's midseason collection. In smooth two-tone tweeds, black and white or slate and brown or two tones of beige, the middy jackets are often open right down to hemline which clings about the hips.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Bayard Sharp's Judge M. defeated nine other fleet Jersey homebreds to account for the $10,000 added New Jersey Breeders Stakes before 17,102 fans today. The fleet 2-year-old, ridden by William J. Passmore, beat Mrs. Sara Chait's Brother Friar by a length, with Bernadette Stable's Dandolo third.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) --A St. Louis clothing manufacturer proposed a standardization of specifications in the textile industry today.

Countries represented at the recent International Cotton Textile Conference in England have responded quickly to the American suggestion to increase home consumption of fabrics, according to Robert T. Stevens, chairman of the American mission.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., is offering today a new issue of $20,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds of Virginia Electric and Power Company due on Oct. 1, 1982, at 101.541 to yield 3.17 per cent. The bankers acquired the issue at competitive sale Tuesday on a bid of 100.961.

LONDON, Oct. 22 (Reuters) -- Commonwealth Prime Ministers may consider a suggestion for partial convertibility of sterling into dollars at their conference here next month, reliable sources said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 22 -- A jurisdictional struggle for control of technical workers in television, which is expected to assume national proportions and may lead to repercussions in the motion picture studios as well, was under way today between two American Federation of Labor internationals, the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 22 -- Relatively larger numbers of men in the Navy and the Marine Corps are being kept in combat today than in World War II because more and better psychiatric care is being given at the front, Dr. George N. Raines said today. He is chief of psychiatric services for the Navy and marines.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 10 to 42 points lower than on Tuesday, with the near months relatively weaker than the distant ones.

The decision of the National Labor Relations Board reported in THE TIMES on Oct. 15, that a union could not restrict welfare fund benefits to its members, is of significant import in the field of industrial relations. It marks a substantial advancement under the Taft-Hartley Act in the protection of the individual worker's rights.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Defense Department announced today the highest weekly United States casualty toll in the Korean war since the week ended last July 2. The total for the week ended last Friday was 963.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A Federal judge freed George S. May of contempt-of-Congress charges today with the comment that "compulsory self-incrimination is characteristic of totalitarian governments.''

The question is put by someone who is seen rushing into and out of the house from time to time, and who occasionally even appears at the dinner table. She is, this someone, a tall, lanky child, and now she pauses with pencil and notebook in hand.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Grain futures developed a reactionary trend today following the brisk rally of late yesterday, the pronounced weakness of cash corn being the main unsettling influence.

A team of scientists returned from the South Pacific a few weeks ago full of facts and figures about the life and times of an atoll, and yesterday one of them reported on the expedition at the American Museum of Natural History.

Today's new film is "Limelight," Charlie Chaplin's first film in five years, which the comedian wrote, directed and produced and in which he stars with Claire Bloom, English newcomer to the screen, at both the Astor and Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux Theatres.

ALBANY, Oct. 22 -- The eighty-sixth convocation of the University of the State of New York will be held here Friday. Former Chief Judge Learned Hand of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals will speak on "Education for a Free People" at the evening session.

The board of directors of R. K. O. Radio Pictures, Inc., announced yesterday the acceptance of the resignations of A. L. Koolish and William Gorman as directors and the resignation of Ralph E. Stoklin as president of the corporation and also as a director.

Two luxurious passenger liners to operate under the American flag between New York and East Coast ports of South America have entered the planning stage, Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of Moore - McCormack Lines, announced yestreday.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 22 -- Al Brosch of Cherry Valley gained the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship for the fifth time as he won the event today at the Innis Arden Golf Club with a 36-hole score of 137, five under par.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Three steps to rid the United States of Communists were taken by James P. McGranery, Attorney General, in a program announced at the Department of Justice tonight.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 22 -- A Brazilian deputy has launched a campaign in Congress to add Brazil to the roll of Latin-American countries that have rejected, or protested, against military aid agreements with the United States.

Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, announced last night plans, "ready to begin" in a few weeks, for redevelopment of the Columbus Circle neighborhood by private builders and the construction of a $20,000,000 coliseum by the authority.
YONKERS, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Claude Hanover scored an upset over the odds-on favorite, Signal P. Direct, in the feature race at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 22 -- A suit for $232,296 was instituted here late yesterday by twenty-one members of an insurgent longshoremen's group against Dade Brothers, contracting stevedores at the Army Engineers pier facility at the Claremont Terminal, and Local 1478, Marine Warehousemen's Union, the International Longshoremen's Association.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 22 -- In an experiment on the use of the New Jersey Turnpike for transporting huge anti-aircraft guns, First Army officials maneuvered today a thirty-one-ton, 120-millimeter weapon, towed by an M-20 prime mover, onto the toll road through the Elizabeth interchange with only a slight scraping of tires.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today an increased production and use of synthetic fibers during the next two years and a corresponding drop in demand for American cotton.

Five models powered by eight-cylinder engines were shown in the 1953 line presented yesterday by the Dodge division of the Chrysler Corporation. This was a new departure, for all of the 1952 series were equipped with six-cylinder engines.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, with the acquiescence of the United States, decided unexpectedly tonight to give the Korean question top place on its agenda. The vote, after three and a half hours of procedural wrangling, was unanimous.

ON THE NIXON TRAIN, Oct. 22 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, today charged that the Truman Administration was using "a form of political blackmail" to scare farmers into voting Democratic.
The five-story apartment house at 276 East 199th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Mary Campbell to Milton Janoff through Nehring Brothers, Inc., brokers.

WILTON, Conn., Oct. 22 -- Senator Estes Kefauver began his Eastern speaking campaign tonight in behalf of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for President, by accusing Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower of "vacillation and indecision" in his Republican campaign for the Presidency.

Plans for erecting a fifteen-story apartment house at 52-54 Park Avenue, adjoining the northwest corner of East Thirty-seventh Street, were announced yesterday by Shampan Shampan, Brooklyn architects, who have purchased for the purpose a plot 34 by 100 feet from the Emerald Estates.

UNION, N. J., Oct. 22 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio was warmly received at Republican meetings as he toured New Jersey today to urge all members of his party, and particularly those who supported him before and during the Republican convention, to get out and work for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Presidential nominee, and Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, the Vice Presidential nominee.

THOSE who have been delaying their fall surf-casting excursion to the Outer Banks of North Carolina can head south any day now, for the channel bass are moving inshore in numbers, and the large fish are due to make an appearance any day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Eight small companies in the New York metropolitan area have formed a new production pool for the handling of defense orders, the Small Defense Plants Administration disclosed today.

TROY, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower blasted the Democratic party as the party of stand-patters today as he wound up three days of campaigning for the twenty-eight electoral votes of Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island, and struck in New York for this state's crucial forty-five votes.

John W. Davis, Democratic candidate for President in 1924, announced yesterday his support of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower. Mr. Davis, a resident of Locust Valley, L. I., was Ambassador to Great Britain from 1918 to 1921 and president of the American Bar Association in 1922.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- British Government securities made the best showing in stock markets today when a moderate expansion in business enabled giltedge to make widespread gains of about one-eighth of 1 per cent.

UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- The state conference of probation officers adopted a resolution today declaring that pre-sentence reports on convicted persons made by parole and probation officers should be kept confidential between the judge and probation officers.

We heard the chairman of the board of a large food corporation remark the other evening that "everyone is competing for the cake-mix business." The newest development in this kind of product, which takes everything but the fun out of home baking, is a fruit-cake mix that supplies all the necessaries except the kitchen stove for its completion. Well, practically all.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 22 (UP) -- A Navy plane discovered the sixth tropical hurricane of the season today about 650 miles southwest of here. The hurricane, with winds of eighty-five miles an hour, was only 400 miles south of Havana, Cuba.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Mickey Mantle, World Series hero for the Yankees, who underwent his third draft physical here today, was ordered to report at Fort Sill tomorrow for further examination to determine if he could be called into service.

Robert T. Dunlap and Hal A. Kroeger have been elected directors of Gerity-Michigan Corporation, it was announced yesterday by James Gerity Jr., president Mr. Dunlap is president of Great American Industries, Inc., and Mr. Kroeger is a founder of A. H. Kroeger Organization, management consultants.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared tonight that the Republicans were trying to "buy the election with $100,000,000 worth of lies, slanders and treacherous appeals to the emotions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie today dismissed one United Nations employe who had balked at answering questions about Communist activity put by a Senate subcommittee, suspended another and placed ten on compulsory leave. All twelve were United States citizens.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama tonight accused Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York of a "desperate effort to re-establish his standing" by "smearing" Mr. Sparkman with charges of favoring white supremacy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Postal officials said today they were trying to find ways to check an extortion racket in which Chinese Communists seek to swindle the families of American service men held as prisoners of war in Korea.

Sales of 20,000 tons of cocoa by the British Cocoa Marketing Board were reported here yesterday, reversing price directions on the Cocoa Exchange. The officially announced sale, at 230 a ton, brought sales by the board for this crop year above the total 1951-52 distribution.
DANVILLE, Va., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Former Gov. William M. Tuck said here tonight he could not endorse the Democratic national ticket or associate himself with the Democratic campaign.

Bond prices on the New York Stock Exchange dropped last month to the lowest level since December, 1951. At the end of September the average price was $97.46, down 68 cents from the end of August, when it was $98.14. The December, 1951, level was $97.43.

Witold Malcuzynski, pianist playing last night in Carnegie Hall, addressed himself to a program of more than ordinary substance, devoted to the works of three composers who all can be called masters of the romantic school.

The Music Division of the New York Public Library announced yesterday that it had acquired what is believed to be the only complete set in existence of the Columbia Phonograph Company's 1903 output of "celebrity" disks, the first issue of its kind in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The loud and enduring silence that has invested the faculty houses and other resorts of "true liberals" since the President said that General Eisenhower has "accepted" the Nazi philosophy of a "master [Nordic] race" enforces a certain conclusion about their way of thinking.

James J. Breslin, former plainclothes man assigned to the Police Commissioner's confidential squad, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court to a criminal-contempt indictment that resulted from his refusal to answer questions on his finances before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury.

Attempts to balance this country's aid-bolstered export surplus by encouraging additional volume of imports present a threat to domestic production, members of the American Tariff League were told yesterday at the annual meeting.
Five City College alumni will receive Townsend Harris Medals for "outstanding post-graduate achievement," Dr. Gabriel R. Mason, president of the alumni association, announced yesterday.

The one-story taxpayer building at 56-07 Myrtle Avenue in Ridgewood, Queens, has been sold by Anthony Menninger to the Greenel Realty Corporation, represented by Samuel Skoller, attorney. David Nurmberg was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

SINGAPORE, Thursday, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Indonesian Foreign Minister Mukarto Notewidigdo predicted today that Indonesia would sever the last ties linking her to the Netherlands "in the not too distant future."

The Pennsylvania Railroad charged the Long Island Transit Authority yesterday with "misrepresentation" of the road's handling of the Long Island Rail Road situation. According to the Pennsylvania, the authority's attitude is "more likely to hinder than help an orderly reorganization" of the bankrupt Long Island.

Net profit of the Reynolds Metals Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries for the first nine months of 1952 amounted to $9,304,914 after a provision of $18,566,381 for income taxes, the company reported yesterday. The earnings were equal to $5.50 each on the 1,677,118 shares of common stock outstanding at the end of last month.

A plea for reinstatement to the force for the remainder of the current departmental police trial was made yesterday by spokesmen for the thirty suspended plain-clothes men charged with complicity in the bookmaking business of Harry Gross.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Mrs. Frank Goldthwaite, a Fort Worth amateur who captained the 1952 Curtis Cup team, scored the first major upset of the seventeenth Texas women's open golf tournament today when she ousted the medalist, Betsy Rawls.

It is estimated that a saving of $80,000,000 in the cost of New Jersey's Garden State Parkway would be affected if the improvement were financed by the state's full- faith-and-credit bonds, as against bonds secured only by revenues. The issue is to be decided at referendum on election day and civic interests are at odds over the question.

The stock market decline gained momentum yesterday and left prices at their lowest since June, The fresh setback was on a par with the two serious declines of last week but trading was not sufficient to prove the reversal anything more than a continuation of the technical movements of the last week.
Subway, elevated and city-owned surface transit service has been cut down gradually during non-rush-hour periods in the last ten months in an economy move, it was learned yesterday.

Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company announced yesterday that it had contracted to acquire certain assets of Weston Dodson Co., a century-old firm of coal operators in Bethlehem, Pa., in exchange for 273,000 shares of Lehigh stock.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Emanuel Shinwell, who was Minister of Defense in the late Labor Government, asked the Conservative Administration today to consider the desirability of "adopting some new diplomatic device" to terminate the Korean war.

Lew Mauser of New Rochelle, N. Y., operator and builder, has purchased a tract of land bordering on the Cross County Parkway near the intersection of the Hutchinson River Parkway in East Chester, on which he will build a six-story apartment house for spring occupancy.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 -- President Truman declared tonight that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President, using "cheap campaign tactics" based on isolationism, had endangered national security and the cause of world peace.
Following is the text of President Truman's address at Syria Mosque, Pittsburgh, last night as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

EASTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 22 -- Last season, Williston Academy's varsity football squad lost its first three games and then came on to sweep the last half of its six-game schedule. So far, the 1952 campaign has followed the same pattern, the Blue and Gold having dropped its opening three tests.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Britain gave her approval today to a new constitution providing, for self-government in the internal affairs for the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, whose future has long been in dispute between this country and Egypt, the joint rulers of the territory.

TORONTO, Oct. 22 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored three goals in the third period to defeat the Detroit Red Wings, 5 -- 4, tonight and crowd into a three-way tie for second place with Montreal and Chicago in the National Hockey League.

Furnishings from a number of periods have been combined to give a fresh uncluttered appearance to a five-room model apartment at Riverview North, 605 East Eighty-second Street. The apartment, planned by John Abbate of Park East Decorators, opens for inspection tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Capt. George Wauchope, executive vice president of Farrell Lines, was elected general chairman of the marine section, National Safety Council, at the council's fortieth annual convention and exposition here today.

A hundred original paintings and miniatures by the late Arthur Szyk, illustrator and cartoonist, will be on view today in a memorial exhibition at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
A blueprint for action when defense spending begins to taper off and the country returns to a consumer- demand economy will be shaped by the nation's department stores.

ROME, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- In this industrial city of central New York, which has been on the winning side in most national and state elections dining the last thirty years, the Democrats regard themselves as the underdogs this year but sense a trend in their direction that they hope will mean the election of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Late this afternoon fifteen girls of varying national backgrounds nursed their aching feet in their own small lounge in the basement of the General Assembly building as they doffed brand new uniforms and hung up chic blue overseas caps.

The G. O. P. is now blaming the Democrats for inflation, despite the fact that the most inflationary single act in recent years was the killing of the O. P. A., which was done by Republicans and Dixiecrats over the protests of President Truman.

Towns and individual property owners in New York and Connecticut took additional legal action yesterday in attempts to halt construction and operation of natural gas pipelines by the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 22 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley jibed at Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as the inept captive of Senator Robert A. Taft during a campaign tour today of outlying and suburban districts of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, was named today head of a Department of Defense citizens' advisory commission to investigate military manpower.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Mrs. Harry S. Truman, taking time out today to see a style show, heard a French designer and dressmaker declare that so far as Paris fashions were concerned, the United States was lagging far behind in furnishing the trade to build a free world economy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 15, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 22 -- As goes New Orleans, it is said here on every side, so probably will go Louisiana in the Presidential election. And New Orleans is a poser, with perhaps the majority opinion for the Democrats to carry the city by a slight margin.
Following is one of a series of articles on the present political situation by The Associated Press, based on a nation-wide survey it made of estimates by newspaper editors and political writers.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 22 -- An army of 55,000 children scored the greatest victory won so far in the relentless war against polio. The story is one of the great epics of modern medicine.

Mrs. Mary Bain of New York, women's chess champion of the United States, made an auspicious start yesterday in the world championship challengers' tournament, the first round of which was contested at the Soviet Army Clubhouse in Moscow, according to a report from the Soviet capital.

It was with great satisfaction that I read the recent news articles and editorials in THE TIMES commending the efforts of the teen-age members of the James Weldon Johnson Community Center at 173 East 112th Street for their efforts to cope with the narcotics menace among their age group.

Another easy triumph was scored by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's grand 2-year-old colt Native Dancer in the $56,700 East View Stakes at the Jamaica track yesterday, and now the champion of his division has (1) a nine-for-nine record.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 22 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer defended today the presence of former Nazi party members in Germany's Foreign Ministry, who add up to 66 per cent of the senior officials with the contention that the Foreign Ministry could not be build up without persons who knew something about the past.

Operations of the Chromium Mining and Smelting Corporation, Ltd., Ontario, Canada, and its American subsidiaries, in the fiscal year ended on April 30, resulted in a profit of $450,763 compared with $275,565 for the preceding fiscal year, Leo H. Timmins, president, reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, and Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, clashed today on the issue of how many limousines the United Nations can afford to own.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Labor members of the Wage Stabilization Board assailed the public and industry members today for cutting 40 cents from the $1.90 a day wage increase negotiated by John L. Lewis for his soft coal miners.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 22 -- Ed (Porky) Oliver of Lemont, Ill., playing his first tournament golf in Australia, equaled the course record with a 67 today to lead after the first round of the 7,000 Australian ($15,680) Ampol tournament.

Little Murry Dickson of the Pirates, whose only deficiency as a pitcher seems to be serving home-run balls, and Cleveland's big-winning Early Wynn were the 1952 leaders in allowing enemy batsmen to reach the fences.

Union leaders, management aides and welfare agents joined hands yesterday to initiate a drive to acquaint workers with the health and welfare services available to them through the 423 agencies affiliated with the Greater New York Fund.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved the plan for the merger of Alabama Power Company and its subsidiary, Birmingham Electric Company, with Alabama to continue as the surviving company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22 -- Lana Turner is going to have a new leading man in her next Metro picture, "Latin Lovers," and his name is Ricardo Montalban. Originally Fernando Lamas, who was co-starred with her in "The Merry Widow," was assigned to the picture, which will get under way next month with Mervyn LeRoy as director.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- Pennsylvania has one fervent wish concerning its game with Navy at Franklin Field on Saturday. It hopes the issue its settled, one way or another, at a reasonable early Stage in the contest. In their team's tie with Notre Dame and its subsequent victories over Dartmouth, Princeton and Columbia. Red and Blue supporters have been kept on tenterhooks until each game's final minute.

The nation's supply of gasoline totaled 122,002,000 barrels last week, according to the report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. This represents an increase of 1,092,000 barrels above the previous week's stock and compares with a supply of 121,450,000 barrels last year.
Larry Parks and his wife, Betty Garrett, are set to tour in Vernon Sylvaine's four-character domestic comedy, "Anonymous Lover," preliminary to appearing in it on Broadway late this season.

Although much effort is being expended to promote advertising, there is a considerable need for more, according to Leonard W. Trester, director of public policy for the General Outdoor Advertising Company, Washington, D. C. He spoke at a meeting of the Cincinnati Advertising Club yesterday in the Sinton Hotel there.
A United Nations committee visited the State Motor Vehicle Bureau at 80 Centre Street yesterday to study procedures under which New Yorkers are tested for driver's licenses.

Denying the Republican charge that the Democratic national administration was leading the country toward socialism, Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal candidate for United States Senator, declared last night that the American people were not going back to the depression days of 1932.

Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., will place on the market late in 1954 a few color television receivers if the Federal Communications Commission permits, John K. McDonough, general manager of the company's radio and television division, declared yesterday.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 23 -- South Korean troops won back yesterday the crest of "Sniper Ridge" on Korea's central front after the Communists, for nine hours, had held the dominating position north of Kumhwa.

THE last boat trip taken by Eddie Arcaro was on the Island Queen, a wheezing paddle-wheeler, which crossed the Ohio River from the Maestro's native Kentucky to a resort known as Coney Island, somewhere on the Ohio bank. It took place so long ago that Eddie's recollection of the journey is vague and misty.

Wally Hergesheimer saw to it that the opening of the New York Rangers' home season was at least a partial success. The sharp-shooting little right wing scored all three goals credited to his team in its contest against the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night.
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,411, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:
The Football Giants were chased through a forty-five-minute session of hard scrimmaging by Coach Steve Owen at the Polo Ground yesterday.

The letter of Abraham Lederman, president of the Teachers Union, which appears in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 16, should not go unchallenged. It presents an incomplete and incorrect view concerning the termination of employment of teachers by the Board of Education under Section 903 of the Charter.

Two ex-convicts suspected of planning the theft of about $1,000,000 from an armored truck in the Bronx on Tuesday were held without bail in Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday for a hearing tomorrow on charges of attempted robbery and possession of burglars' tools.

TRENTON, Oct. 22 -- Ransford J. Abbott, chairman of the New Jersey Highway Authority, said today the Garden State Parkway would be constructed on high-level bridges over three inland waterways to avoid interference with water traffic.
BUFFALO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's address here tonight:

Because of the size and complexity of their city, it is natural for New Yorkers to be confused sometimes by their civic life. That's why the straight forward and sensible plan adopted by city leaders to aid vital defense-related agencies is welcome news.

VIENNA, Thursday, Oct. 23 -- The People's party-Socialist coalition that had governed Austria ever since her liberation seven years ago broke apart at midnight last night when the Government resigned because of the inability of its two wings to agree on a 1953 budget.
Three governors and a retired general participated last night in a dinner arranged by the Citizens Committee for Eisenhower-Nixon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

With only sixty-five days left until Christmas, Henry Mamm, 49 years old, a boss pressman for The New York Daily News at its Brooklyn plant, found himself yesterday faced with a problem -- an $8,500 deficit in the pressmen's Christmas fund.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl, former Governor of Minnesota, tonight called the drunken driver "as great a menace to the dignity of human life as is communism."
The following political speeches are scheduled for radio and television today:

The enterprising Brooklyn Society of Artists is holding its thirty-sixth annual exhibition a long way from home -- at the hospitable Riverside Museum, 103d Street and Riverside Drive. A half hundred oil paintings, a score of water-colors and caseins and small groups of graphic work and of sculpture are included in the current showing that will continue through Nov. 9.
A leading radiologist reported yesterday that a severe shortage of competent radiologists in this country was hampering good treatment of cancer.

A banking syndicate headed by B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., will offer a new issue of $12,500,000 of Savannah River Crossing 3 3/4 per cent bridge revenue anticipation certificates of the Georgia Coastal Highway District today.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Oct. 22 -- The Bloomington Daily Pantagraph, a newspaper partly owned by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, announced today it would not endorse either Mr. Stevenson or his opponent, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, for President.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22 -- The Screen Actors Guild today posed the threat of a strike action that would put an end to the filming of television advertising spot announcements.
New York University will probably field a varsity football team next season, but there seems to be some doubt about the sport being continued in 1954, N. Y. U. officials admitted yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 22 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was accused today of selling Germany's birthright in the Saar for a mess of "Europeanized" pottage, as the Government answered the opposition criticism aroused by the issue of the Saar's future and directed as much at the French Government as at the coalition regime in this country.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 22 (UP) -- Iran broke diplomatic relations with Britain today.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 22 -- To assuage Arab displeasure with the West German-Israeli restitutions agreement the Federal Government offered today to consider requests for economic aid from Arab nations.

Two city officials who were reported last Monday by Dr. Luther H. Gulick, executive director of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, as having approved the new consultants' survey report on the Police Department "with reservations" insisted yesterday that they had opposed the report.

Station WNEW, one of the country's leading independent radio stations, filed application yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission for a commercial television station to operate here on Channel 31.

KATHERINE ANNE PORTER, who is more famous for having written few books than other authors are for having written many has now gathered a fine thirty years' profile of her best critical sketches in "The Days Before."* The pieces are alive with the vigor of strong opinions expressed in a style of singing clarity. Miss Porter is not a Texan for nothing.

DETROIT, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The nation's automobile companies hope to be able to build 5,000,000 passenger cars next year despite the confusion about the availability of materials, according to L. L. Colbert, president of the Chrysler Corporation.

Hook-and-eye machines thundered and pounded behind the walls in Louis Rabinowitz's eleventh-floor office at 120 East Sixteenth Street the other day as he traced the path that led him to devote a good part of his fortune to scholarly research.
Excellent spring bookings were reported yesterday by members of the Guild of Better Shoe Manufacturers, Inc., following the opening of their lines early this week.

Fur merchants who bid up the price of Alaska fur seal at the United States Government auction in St. Louis last week have rendered the fur industry a disservice, according to Eugene K. Denton, president of The Tailored Woman. He said he hoped that these merchants would not attend other fur auctions to repeat their performance.
Following is one of a series of articles on the present political situation by The Associated Press, based on a nation-wide survey it made of estimates by newspaper editors and political writers.

Advancing for the seventh successive time, New York bank loans to business rose $46,000,000 last week to reach another new high of $8,180,000,000. The seasonal increase brought the expansion since mid-year to $510,000,000, against $685,000,000 in the similar period a year ago.
A Brooklyn bookmaker who was convicted twenty-four times but served a jail term only once, was exposed yesterday in Kings County Court by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz.

The climax of the Philharmonic-Symphony concert last night in Carnegie Hall came with the playing of the five movements from "Romeo and Juliet," the "dramatic symphony" of Hector Berlioz. This was the most sensitive and poetical playing of the orchestra -- which, indeed, could not have found in the other scores of the evening the opportunity to interpret music with such fineness, intensity and exquisiteness of feeling.

Greenwich House, an old hand at opening its heart to one more, has done it again. It has found room for, and enrichment from, the Inwood Pottery, which faced extinction because of the death of the woman who founded it in the woods at the northern tip of Manhattan thirty years ago and made it a mecca for people, young and old, aspiring and accomplished.

A $200,000 verdict was awarded yesterday to Dr. John E. Silson, 38-year-old former Air Force surgeon, for injuries suffered two years ago in a subway accident. The verdict was given by a jury of men after a week's trial of a suit against the city before Supreme Court Justice Bertram Newman, an upstate jurist assigned here.

Steadiness in the Australian auctions for the last week and the manner in which the market has absorbed tenders of October delivery, which expires today, were responsible for two active trading days for wool on the New York Cotton Exchange, prices holding well.

The Board of Estimate authorized Queens Borough President James A. Lundy yesterday to accept bids for repairs to a faulty $185,679 sewer laid in Laurelton by Victor Clemente or, as an alternative, for construction of a new sewer.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will visit Harlem again tomorrow afternoon and will make a major speech from a platform in front of the Theresa Hotel, Seventh Avenue and West 125th Street, at 1 o'clock.

The Board of Education unanimously ratified the dismissal of two more public school teachers yesterday, bringing to eight the number dismissed for refusing to answer questions about alleged Communist party membership before a Senate investigating subcommittee last month.

To many of us on this side of the line the celebration today of the one hundredth birthday of the Toronto Stock Exchange may come as a bit of a surprise. It has only been in the past few years that Canada has burst dramatically into the economic spotlight as a country with perhaps the fastest growth and richest potential of any in the world.

TORONTO, Oct. 23 -- More than 1,000 leading industrialists and bankers will attend the centenary dinner of the Toronto Stock Exchange tomorrow night at the Royal York Hotel at which the Hon. Leslie M. Frost, Premier of the Province of Ontario, will be the principal speaker. Among those who will be present are the presidents of many companies whose shares are listed on the Exchange which began operations 100 years ago.
Anticipating an aerial barrage by the Philadelphia Eagles at the Polo Grounds on Sunday, Coach Steve Owen emphasized pass defense in yesterday's two-hour workout of the New York Football Giants.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 23 -- The big question marks in any attempt to appraise voting sentiment in Central New York this year are the reasons for the phenomenal increase in women registrants and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's appeal to young voters whose memories of the depression are vague and impersonal.
A plea to defend the nation's public school system against attack was made yesterday by Mrs. Edwin Troland, public education chairman of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- A denial that the American public was apathetic on the traffic safety problem was voiced today by Harold P. Jackson of Newark, N. J., chairman of the safety organization of the President's Highway Safety Conference.

A former Police Commissioner, four high-ranking police officials and a former chief inspector appeared yesterday before the special Richmond County Grand Jury investigating gambling and corruption on Staten Island. Each witness declined to comment on the testimony he had given.

Marcus S. Siegel, 53-year-old Brooklyn attorney convicted last July of participating in a black market ring in babies, was sentenced yesterday in Kings County Court to an indeterminate penitentiary term up to three years.

Optimism over recent strengthening of the economy in free countries of Southeast Asia, both as a check to communism and preparation for greater stability in trade and investment relations with the West, keynoted the opening yesterday of the Far East Conference.

OTTAWA, Oct. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's new cost-of-living yardstick, the consumer price index which went into operation today, climbed 1/10 of a point during August to 116.1 from 116.0, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.

FORT SILL, Okla., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Army doctors completed a medical examination of Mickey Mantle today and then announced that any report on the Yankee star's fitness for military service must come later from the Oklahoma City recruiting office.

The result of twenty years of Democratic administration is a 50-cent dollar on its way to becoming a 10-cent dollar, with galloping inflation "just around the corner," Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr. told members of the Women's National Republican Club yesterday. He urged the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and a Republican Congress because of "Democratic failure all down the line in both foreign and domestic policies."

The island of Raroia in the South Pacific has a population of 127 persons and twenty-five pigs, or did have them when a delegation from this country, headed by Dr. Norman D. Newell of Columbia University, left it recently. From our reporter's account of what Dr. Newell has to say we cull the following:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- In the select semicircle of chairs reserved for full delegates to the United Nations, women are moving up only gradually. They have, however, managed to claim nine seats at the green tables in this seventh session of the General Assembly, compared with seven in Paris in 1951, and five in 1947.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 23 -- The present policy of controlled distribution of food grains will be abolished throughout the country by successive stages. Food Minister Rafi Ahmad Kidwai said in Bombay yesterday that the decision had been taken because of the substantial improvement of the food situation.

Your editorial of Oct. 15 "Looking at the Record," concerning the remarks of President Truman on civil rights, seemed to us rather unfair. On the record, as you presented it, the Administration fought hard for civil rights legislation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- If the United States again becomes involved in a global war, the chance of winning it will be determined largely by whether the nation employs its manpower at the highest point of efficiency and at a cost that will not bring about a collapse of our economy.

THE NEW YORK TIMES is scheduled to start printing its International Air Edition in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, with the issue of Saturday, Nov. 1. Printing operations are now centered in Paris, except for copies of the International Air Edition that go to Central and South America, which are printed in New York.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Quarterback Johnny Gramling passed South Carolina to a touchdown on the opening series of plays for a 6-0 football victory against an offensively weak Clemson before 35,000 today.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 23 (UP) -- The defending champion, Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias, seeking her fifth title in the Texas women's open golf tournament, won her toughest match of the meet today by going two extra holes to beat Barbara Romack, of Sacramento, Calif., on the twentieth.

Nearly everything on the program that Leslie Chabay sang last night in Town Hall was unusual, and all of it was of interest. He avoided the obvious items, making a careful selection of Bach and lieder composers and introducing a novelty of worth.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 23 -- "The Glass Web," a murder mystery novel written by Max Ehrlich, has been acquired by Universal-International and will be filmed under the title of "Spin the Glass Web." Lee Leonard will write the screen play.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 24 -- South Korean troops jumped off this morning in a strong attack on Chinese Communist positions on "Sniper Ridge" on the central Korean front. At noon the Republic of Korea Second Division troops were reported fighting forward toward the last enemy outposts on the high ground.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Henry W. Grunewald, Washington mystery man, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of contempt of Congress for refusing to answer questions of a House subcommittee investigating tax frauds last winter.
ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- For the first time since woman's suffrage was enacted in 1920, more women than men will be eligible to vote in New York state in the Presidential election Nov. 4.

PARIS, Friday, Oct. 24 -- Andre Marty, French Communist leader who has been in public disgrace for a month, has been suspended from the party's Politburo because of his "obstinate refusal" to make a full public confession of his "political errors" and deviationism.
BUFFALO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of General Dwight D. Eisenhower's speech here tonight:

In his address at Troy on Wednesday, on the subject of inflation, General Eisenhower was attacking the Administration on a sector that was not merely inadequately defended but which fully warrants the description completely indefensible.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Assets of American farmers are still going up, but at a slower rate than during the last two years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson made public today the text of the resolution in which the United States, together with nineteen or twenty other states, will propose that the General Assembly endorse the stand taken by the United States, as the agent of the United Nations, in the Korean armistice negotiations.
President Truman's recent whistle-stop tour, whatever its purpose in partisan domestic politics, has had a disastrous effect upon foreign public opinion of the United States and its foreign policies.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Following is the text of a draft resolution on Korea released today by the United States delegation to the General Assembly:

The American Federation of Labor's Free Trade Union Committee reported yesterday that forced labor was the common plight of all classes in Communist China, from prisoners to peasants and wage-earners. The statement was said to have been based on smuggled information from Red Chinese sources.

BUFFALO, Oct. 23 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower capped a day of campaigning for New York State's crucial forty-five electoral votes when he accused the Truman Administration of injecting racial and religious bigotry into the election contest. He spoke before an audience of 14,000 in Memorial Auditorium here tonight.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of an address by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson here tonight:

A small and thoroughly satisfactory collection of suits and coats was presented yesterday afternoon at the New Weston Hotel by Digby Morton, the English designer who is in the United States for a short visit. While the major portion of the showing consisted of custom-made clothes, a few were ready-to-wear and can be shipped on order from London.

The $6,534,000 of 3% per cent debentures of Equitable Gas Company which Philadelphia Company, parent enterprise, has wanted to sell for months, remained unsold yesterday even after the staging of public sealed bidding formalities.

Ferris Fain, the American League batting king, and Sid Gordon, who hit only .289 in National League competition, were the most productive night-game batters in the major leagues during the 1952 campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio charged here tonight that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential candidate, "is falling right in with the Communist program" on the issue of inflation.

HEADQUARTERS Eighth Army in Korea, Oct. 23 -- William C. Foster, Deputy Secretary of Defense, said here tonight considerable progress was being made toward replacing front-line units with South Korean divisions but that there was no possibility that Korean forces would man the entire front within the foreseeable future.

ABSECON, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Mrs. Michael Higgins of Upper Montclair and Mrs. George Kretzschmar of Arcola finished in a tie for the opening-day low net honors in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's Adele Ubelacker Memorial tournament at the Seaview Country Club today.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- British importers of South African diamonds lost their exemption from control measures applying to other countries under regulations issued here today.

Heavily outnumbered sophomores won the traditional annual pole rush on South Field at Columbia University yesterday. Panting freshmen charged again and again, only to be thrown back. Both sides were shirtless and otherwise shopworn when the final whistle blew at twilight.

EASTVIEW, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, which recently bought the Butler estate here for development into a national headquarters, said today in newspaper advertisements that it did not "at this time plan any mass transfer of our offices to Westchester."

CAIRO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Egypt's strong-man Premier promised wildly cheering crowds today that Egypt would become a great power in the world and pledged himself to "complete independence of the Nile Valley."

A tract of about three acres on Park Place East, near Route 17, in Woodridge, N. J., has been purchased by Julius Blum Co. for improvement with a one-story industrial building to contain 50,000 square feet. The company, headed by William Thurnauer, will use the property for the fabrication and distribution of steel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks rallied for two final-period goals tonight to balance two first-period markers by Maurice (Rocket) Richard and tie the Montreal Canadiens, 2 to 2, before 7,186 fans.

The International Business Machine Corporation and subsidiaries increased net income in the first nine months this year to $21,251,233 after taxes and all deductions, from $20,070,493 earned in the corresponding period last year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- High-level Western diplomats were reported today to have suggested to India that New Delhi take an active role diplomatically in the Korean situation and use its contacts in Peiping to see whether the Chinese Communists wished to make any new overtures.

Bank clearings of the twenty-five leading cities of the nation for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $20,476,965,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represents an increase of 20.4 per cent above the $17,004,210,000 cleared in the corresponding 1951 week and 36.9 per cent above the $14,950,778,000 recorded in the previous holiday week.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Winding up a two-day speaking tour in the suburbs of New York, Vice President Alben W. Barkley heaped praise upon Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson tonight as a man with the most "profound grasp" of the country's "tragic problems" and as the man best qualified to solve them.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23 -- Yale University School of Engineering will celebrate its centennial tomorrow and Saturday. T. Keith Glennan, president of the Case Institute of Technology and a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, will speak on "Washington Challenges the Engineer" at the anniversary dinner tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $166,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Sixteen lawyers yesterday called "inaccurate and unsound" a recent defense by twenty-two lawyers of the deposition for Alger Hiss made in 1949, by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic candidate for President.

The Long Island Transit Authority insisted yesterday that the Pennsylvania Railroad had in effect rejected an authority plan for reorganization of the Long Island Rail Road by demanding freedom from regulation of rates and services by the Public Service Commission.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Two Senate rivals told the Audit Bureau of Circulation's thirty-eighth annual luncheon today why they believed their respective parties could do more for the nation.

Standard Brands, Inc., and United States subsidiaries had a net income of $5,935,720, or $1.69 a share for the first nine months of this year, against $6,320,951, or $1.81, a year ago, based on 3,175,527 and 3,174,527 common shares, respectively.

A new production by Herbert Graf of "La Forza del Destino," debuts of Laura Castellano, soprano, Sigurd Bjoerling, baritone, and Josef Greindl, bass, and the return to the repertoire of "Tosca" and "Lohengrin" will be features of the opening week of the Metropolitan Opera's 1952-53 season.

Walter M. Weismann, chairman of the board of the Aetna Industrial Corporation of New York, has purchased financial control of the Kaynee Company, manufacturer of boys' shirts, sportswear and pajamas, it was announced yesterday by Robert L. Hays, president and general manager.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Prime Minister Churchill's Government surmounted tonight the first hurdle along the legislative road leading to the denationalization of the iron and steel industry. The policy of the Conservative Government, as set out in a White Paper, was approved by the House of Commons by 303 votes to 269.

Customs authorities of New York soon may be seeking a safe dumping place for more than 10,000 gallons of spiritous liquors, the largest batch of unwanted drinking alcohol they have ever had to throw away.

Now is the time to venture into business, members of the Exchange Club of New York were told yesterday by Joseph M. Katz, president of the Papercraft Corporation, Pittsburgh, and a member of the Young Presidents Organization. He said 86 per cent of all new business enterprises succeed during the first five years.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 23 -- Mrs. Samuel Trepner of Glen Head and Mal Galletta of North Hills won the play-off for low-gross honors in the Long Island Golf Association's mixed foursome championship at the Piping Rock Club today.

One of the most exciting football seasons Columbia has experienced appears to be building up to a climax in tomorrow's meeting with Army at Baker Field. Both teams have suffered setbacks and neither is to be rated among the superior creations of Lou Little and Earl Blaik, but all the signs point to a sparkling offensive display between two evenly matched foes in a renewal of a rivalry that has provided so many spectacular episodes.

Phil Rizzuto, who has been in Lenox Hill Hospital for the past week, is under treatment for a duodenal ulcer, the Yankees revealed yesterday. This ailment came to light in the course of a thorough examination of the star shortstop by Dr. Jacques Fischl of the Yankee medical staff.

A dramatic demonstration of fire-fighting techniques and equipment that have made possible the saving of hundreds of lives in airplane crashes was put on yesterday at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn. Members of the fire department at the Naval Air Station, New York, finishing a two-week refresher course in fire fighting, manned crash trucks and repeatedly rescued a dummy "pilot" from the cockpit of a plane engulfed in gasoline flames.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- The United Nations Convention on Freedom of Information, an international draft pact started five years ago but still unfinished, came in for new criticisms today in the General Assembly's Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23 -- There will be no political rallies in Harvard Square, Police Chief Patrick F. Ready today told a group of Harvard College students who had been planning a Stevenson-for-President meeting before the Harvard-Dartmouth football game Saturday.
PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Jacques Heim's fur separates and fur trims are destined to delight the young winter sports enthusiast as much as they bewitched the audience at his midseason opening.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, said today that he was "always willing" to talk to Secretary of State Dean Acheson about the Korean situation.

Further indication that a mixture of materials in furniture is the order of the day may be seen in a new collection introduced here by Modernage. Called "design-a-group" and planned by Marc Berge, the many variations possible for the surface materials add interest to what might otherwise be monotonous box-like shapes.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 23 -- The Yugoslav Government has requested the Mutual Security Agency to accelerate the release of the American funds provided in the United States, British and French economic trade agreement signed only ten days ago.

Harry Howell, defenseman, and Andy Bathgate, a center, rookies brought up from the Guelph (Ont.) farm club to fill in for injured players, will remain with the New York Rangers, it was disclosed yesterday by Manager Frank Boucher.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A memorandum to members, issued today by the Board of the National League of Women Voters, sharply challenges the present appropriations system in Congress.
