WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture may hold an area-wide meeting of cotton producers to tell them how they can get better prices by orderly marketing of their crop, a spokesman said today.

The men and women responsible for the planning and construction of the permanent United Nations headquarters on the East River, were honored last night by the American Association for the United Nations at a dinner in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on the eve of United Nations Day.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Both Democrats and Republicans are wooing the Negro vote in some of the hardest-hitting literature ever featured in a national political campaign.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan rejected yesterday the plea of thirty suspended plain-clothes policemen that they be given work in the department pending the outcome of their long trial on charges of complicity in the bookmaking affairs of Harry Gross.

A junior high school girl who asked, "How can one human being be perfectly content, knowing that another person suffers?" was the winner yesterday of a 100-word essay contest on "Why I Am For the United Nations."

An eighty-five-foot-high electric election indicator, which will enable visitors to Times Square on the night of Nov. 4 to tell at a glance which of the candidates for President is leading in electoral votes and which has won, was under construction on the north side of the Times Tower yesterday.

The American Basketball League last night voted to disband rather than accept the players involved in college court scandals. The decision, disclosed by John J. O'Brien, who has been president of the oldest basketball circuit in the country since he revived it in 1928, was made at a meeting here of the members of the A. B. L.
TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 24 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,412, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, took over today as chairman of the Defense Department's Citizens Advisory Commission on Manpower Utilization in the Armed Services.

NORTH ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 3 -- Members of the Brooks School's football squad displayed a great deal of sparkle and enthusiasm as they went through their workout today and Coach Leo Cronan, a former Notre Dame performer, came off the field smiling.

A man who fell from the platform of the B. M. T. station at Fourteenth Street to the tracks and a suitcase dropped from a train to the I. R. T. tracks just south of the Vernon-Jackson station in Long Island City delayed thousands of homeward-bound subway passengers in Manhattan and Queens during last night's rush hour.

HANOI, Indo-China, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Communist-led Vietminh forces broadened their offensive tonight to include attacks against the French in the Red River Delta as well as drive on French posts along the Black River.

Dr. Charles S. Cameron, medical and scientific director of the American Cancer Society, predicted yesterday that 75,000 to 100,000 persons could be saved annually if physicians and clinics gave each of their patients a six-point cancer check-up.

The stock market yesterday made its first recovery since last Friday, with most of the help provided by the railroad division. The comeback, though, followed establishment of a new low level since June and was accompanied by only a moderate increase in volume.

We are near the close of one of those weeks so dear to our American culture, this one being National Rice Week. That United Nations Day -- which is today -- should come within it is a curious, and very happy, accident. For of all foods, rice is perhaps the most international in use.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Europe's constitution makers decided today to ask a representative of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community -- the continent's first operating venture in pooled sovereignty -- to assist in drafting plans for a European parliament.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 23 -- The increase in the rate of release of schizophrenic patients during their first year in mental hospitals has resulted in an estimated saving of $1,500,000 annually, but this is being used to provide additional care for aged patients admitted to the hospitals with mental diseases, their lives prolonged by medical advances.

Two new films will open at first-run houses this morning. "The Lusty Men," an R. K. O. Western drama, with Robert Mitchum, Arthur Kennedy, Susan Hayward and Arthur Hunnicutt, is at the Criterion. Nicholas Ray directed and Jerry Wald produced the Wald-Krasna production from a script by Horace McCoy and David Dortort.

Plans for the Democratic rally in Madison Square Garden next Tuesday evening, at which Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, candidate for President, will be the principal speaker, were announced yesterday by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, state chairman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, confirmed tonight that his party's fund drive was lagging so badly that the Democratic National Committee would be unable to give any financial assistance whatsoever to party candidates for the House of Representatives or Senate.

Two of the three and one-half bars of silver bullion that disappeared from a Brooklyn pier early yesterday were recovered a few hours later by city detectives. The shipment, valued at $3.200, was part of a consignment of seventeen 250-pound cases of silver consigned to the American Smelting Company, Perth Amboy, N. J.

RENO, Nev., Oct. 23 -- What may be the largest private land transaction in United States history, as far as area is concerned, was completed here today with the sale of the 1,000,000-acre Gerlach Ranch for more than $3,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- President Truman today accused Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, of conducting a "fancy version" of the unsavory Senatorial election campaign that shook Maryland in 1950 and in which Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, played a leading role.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada and chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, praised today two Republican colleagues now engaged in touch-and-go contests for re-election.

British Equity isn't bound by any hard and fast rule to bar American performers. This observation comes from Hugh Beaumont, a prominent London producer. MANILA, Oct. 23 -- The Government and Red Cross relief workers realized today they had a major disaster problem in the death-strewn areas of the Central Philippines.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Prime Minister Churchill disclosed today in the House of Commons that Britain's first atomic bomb, tested Oct. 3 in the Monte Bello Islands, off Australia, was exploded in a naval vessel. The heat of nearly 1,000,000 degrees generated by the blast vaporized the vessel.

Despite depressed freight rates and a sharp decline in available cargoes over the last six months, merchant ship tonnage under construction throughout the world will increase the size of the world's merchant fleets to record proportions.

Stephen Messana's Harlem Maid overtook the front-running Duke Fanelli in the last few yards to take the Glen Island at Jamaica yesterday. The race, a mile-and-a-sixteenth event, attracted seven competitors, and even in that relatively short field the favorite failed to get on the board.

WESTKILL, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Hunting the ruffed grouse in these rocky, tangled hills has much in common with bird-dog training. In order to be successful, you must know more than the grouse, and we ran into a lot of well-educated grouse today.

OTTAWA, Oct. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's total foreign trade swelled during September, but for the second month this year, imports outpaced exports resulting in a $7,900,000 deficit, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Consolidated Feldspar Corporation has agreed to sell substantially all of its assets to the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation in exchange for 108,534 shares of International's common stock. FOOTBALL players have been fumbling at such a furious rate this season that a bit of fumbling by a stabber after scores might go unnoticed. Last week, for instance, Notre Dame pounced on fifteen fumbles against Purdue, seven of its own and eight belonging to the Boilermakers. If that isn't a new Olympic record, it should be.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 23 -- The lower house of Iran's Parliament voted the upper house out of office today.

LITERARY criticism, sometimes an art and more often only a trade, consists in its essentials of two elements: information about books and writers and opinions about them. Differences between critics appear in the information they think worth imparting and in the nature of their opinions. And these differences, of course, reflect the personalities of the individual critics: their most fervently held convictions, their unformulated prejudices and their own ability and stincLive mannerisms as writers.

After ruling the country for seven years, and making it a bulwark against Communist penetration even under partial Soviet occupation, the Austrian coalition Government has fallen apart and Austria faces a new election on issues which may determine its viability.

Meats are in abundant supply, with lower retail prices for pork, veal and one cut of lamb, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday. Meat receipts for the preceding week were the second largest this year.

Ezzard Charles, determined to re-establish himself at the top of the heavyweight ladder, will level fire at durable Cesar Brion of Argentina over the ten-round route tonight in the feature attraction of Madison Square Garden's first boxing show since Sept. 5.

Steven Runciman, British historian and author, who is now visiting America, will have the second volume of his "A History of the Crusades" published next month by Cambridge University Press. The volume will cover the story of the Frankish state of Outremer from the accession of King Baldwin I to the reconquest of Jerusalem by Saladin.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 24 -- Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon announced tonight that he was resigning from the Republican party because the tenets of Abraham Lincoln no longer held in a party "dominated by reactionaries running a captive general for the Presidency of the United States."

Events today: Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman conducting, Hunter College Auditorium, 11 A. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Young People's Concert, Igor Buketoff conducting, Town Hall. 3 P. M.; Myna Fremont, soprano, Peabody Home, 1000 Pelham Parkway, The Bronx, 3; "Carmen," City Center, 2:30; Nemone Balfour, ballad singer, Town Hall, 5:30; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," City Center, 8:15; Vera Bell, soprano, and Helen Prieto, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

The Brooklyn College eleven will play the tenth game in its football series with Wagner at Brooklyn College Field today. The Kingsmen, who won by 20 -- 0 the last time the teams met in 1948, hold a 6-3 edge in the rivalry.

Harry Grossman, candidate of the Democratic and Liberal parties for Congress from the Seventeenth Congressional District, charged yesterday that Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., his Republican opponent, had an absentee record that was approximately three times that of the over-all Congressional average.

The current study by banking authorities to improve methods of processing checks was started none too soon, it appears, for the flood of checks handled in this area continues unabated and is even rising. According to figures compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, during the last Columbus Day week, the bank handled 8,079,000 checks in the four-day period.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- France addressed a supreme appeal to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in Bonn tonight, requesting him to alter the stand that he has taken on the question of the Saar. It was hoped here that the West German Chancellor would do this so that a joint statement might be issued Monday giving hope of a definitive agreement on the French "Europeanization" plan.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 24 (AP) Vice President Alben W. Barkley swung through the Carolinas today, denying that the Democratic party ever had considered the South "in the bag," but predicting that it would "vote right" Nov. 4.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- In the presence of the former King and Queen of Yugoslavia, Jacques Fath presented his midseason collection. Handsome early spring redingotes in black, mole and light golden, brown broadcloth expressed the new feeling for natural lines with flare springing from smooth unpadded hips.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Oct. 24 -- Fred Gronauer of Sands Point, former Indianapolis amateur, won the Long Island Professional Golfers Association championship at his home club today with a 36-hole score of 141.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- Pennsylvania's once-tied football team ruled a slight favorite to maintain its undefeated record tomorrow when it opposes Navy (3-1) at Franklin Field.

Great news comes from Cleveland, where the American Public Health Association is meeting. Dr. Harold A. Howe of Johns Hopkins reports that with a killed vaccine composed of the three known viruses of poliomyelitis obtained from the brains of infected monkeys he has protected six children.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Yale and Lafayette concluded preparations in the Bowl this afternoon for their fourth gridiron meeting tomorrow. The Elis, a heavy favorite to gain their fifth triumph in six games, never have lost to a Lafayette eleven.

Protestant churches in many communities tomorrow will celebrate the 435th anniversary of the Protestant Reformation by conducting union services. One such service will be held at 8 P. M. at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, under the auspices of the St. George Association.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 24 -- Nevada, with three electoral votes, is hardly likely to play a decisive role in the selection of the next President.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Government has settled a $42,426 back income tax claim against Charlie Spivak, a band leader, for $10,000 because "his future is dubious," the Internal Revenue Bureau disclosed today.

SCHEVENINGEN, the Netherlands, Oct. 24 -- The Petroleum Committee of the International Labor Organization decided unanimously tonight to recommend the fixing of minimum wages for all workers in countries lacking collective bargaining machinery. It appeared to be aimed at such countries as Burma and Saudi Arabia.
DETROIT, Oct. 24 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower gave the nation his pledge tonight that if elected President he would go to Korea to seek an early and honorable end of the war there.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended Oct. 21 to 110.6 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. All commodities other than farm products and foods declined 0.1 per cent. Lower prices were reported for crude rubber, cow hides, linseed oil, inedible tallow and some manufactured animal feeds.

The California Bears and the Southern California Trojans, playing to a full house of 100,000 in the Los Angeles Coliseum, and Duke and Virginia at Charlottes-villare, are the top pairings among the gridiron elite today, but New Yorkers need journey no farther than the subway ride to 218th Street for one of the best college scraps of the year.

It must seem startlingly clear to all of us now that a vote for Stevenson is in truth a vote for John L. Lewis, Philip Murray and William Green. Many incidents throughout the past twenty years have pointed to the increasing threat of the power of these men over our Government.
It's fun for a child to eat when he's hungry, and the youngster whose unregulated food habits deprive him of this pleasure is, in one respect at least, "underprivileged."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 24 -- Following are excerpts from the statement on Korea made today by Secretary of State Dean Acheson before the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee:

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- A debate today in the constitutional commission, laying the foundations for the political unification of the six European states united in the coal and steel pool, and the proposed defense structure recalled a division between those who would build a highly centralized federal system and others who seek a loose confederation of sovereign states.

In the bright dawn of peace, just seven years ago, the leaders of the free world constructed for their mutual security a new organization -- the United Nations. It was inspired by faith in freedom's future and dedicated to the proposition that all nations enjoy equal and inviolable right to peace and independence.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were again active, and prices at the close were barely steady 10 to 36 points lower than on Thursday, with the most pronounced weakness in near months.

Every now and then something happens in this world to remind us that civilization is but a thin and desperately held veneer over the dark and primitive abysses of the human soul. In East Africa the secret terrorist society of the Mau Mau has mushroomed in recent months to the point where drastic measures are being taken to save Kenya from distress.

Ezzard Charles, former heavyweight champion of the world, pounded away at Cesar Brion of Cordoba, Argentina, for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night, and these tactics earned the unanimous decision for the former heavyweight champion of the world.

Russel Tochterman, formerly of Beau Brummel Ties, Inc., of Cincinnati has succeeded Allan Weiss as merchandise manager for neckwear for Cluet, Peabody Co., Inc. Mr. Weiss has been made general merchandise manager for all Arrow products.

Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for re-election, declared yesterday that it was "repugnant to me" that the issue of civil rights had been injected into the present political campaigns. He said it was an issue, like international affairs, that should be treated only from a bipartisan point of view.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 24 -- American investors can buy steel mills at bargain-counter rates -- about 20 cents on the dollar, although the industry has just spent $5,000,000,000 on expansion, J. L. Mauthe, president of Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, declared here today.

Veronica Lake, film player, is a likely candidate for the leading feminine role in "Masquerade," the comedy by L. S. Birchard and Jeroam Stagg, that the team of Ben Tomkins and Alvin Cooper-man is producing.

WASHINGTON, Oct 24 -- The Government's retail price index dropped 0.2 per cent between mid-August and mid-September, the first decline since last February. The index had been rising steadily since then. A drop of 1 per cent in food prices was responsible for the decline. Prices for all other major groups went up.

For nine days he was a burglary suspect. Yesterday he was told it was a case of mistaken identity. And so today, Pfc. Emil Luttecke's interrupted honeymoon will start again. On Oct. 3 a man broke into the apartment of Mrs. Channa Malinowski at 265 East Burnside Avenue, the Bronx, and fled with a purse containing $14.
TRENTON, Oct. 24 -- Registration figures released today by the Secretary of State indicated that New Jersey's vote in the Presidential election would be the heaviest in the state's history.
The Chicago Board of Education has designated Nov. 24 for the sale of $9,500,000 of building bonds maturing from 1953 to 1972.
The illustration accompanying your Oct. 19 article on the safety parade in New York City showed two grown women and one small girl wearing kilts, sporrans, doublets and Highland bonnets.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, unanimously adopting a series of resolutions here today, called on Congress and State Legislatures to safeguard civil liberties by the adoption of remedial legislation "in the fundamental fields of employment, education, housing and public accommodations."

A Federal court referree has authorized the Bethlehem Textile Mills, Inc., of Bethlehem, Pa., to continue in operation while arrangements are studied for it to pay its debts, court papers showed yesterday. The action by Irwin Kurtz, referee in bankruptcy, was on the basis of a company petition saying continued operation of the 2-million-a-year business done by the company was "in the best interests" of its creditors.

LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Fort William Henry, scene of one of the greatest massacres during the French and Indian War, will be rebuilt as a museum at Lake George, it was disclosed today with the filing of incorporation papers for the Fort William Henry Corporation in the Warren County clerk's office here.

Mrs. Mary Bain of New York, women's chess champion of the United States who was a winner in the first round, lost yesterday in the second round of the world championship challengers' tournament at Moscow, according to Soviet news sources.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Oct. 24 -- A resolution calling for the establishment of a Chinese Overseas National Salvation Association was adopted today with the aim of mobilizing Chinese communities abroad behind Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist Government.

An ambitious program of medical education, in which closed-circuit color television will bring developments in cancer therapy to a third of the nation's doctors simultaneously, was announced yesterday by the American Cancer Society and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

ROME, Oct. 24 -- Communists and left-wing Socialists joined Christian Democrats, independents and the Government itself in the Senate today in deploring the freeing by British authorities in West Germany of former Field Marshal Albert Kesselring.
DETROIT, Oct. 24 -- Mrs. Mamie Eisenhower, who admits to being "a pretty friendly fellow," expressed regret today that her husband's cross-country campaign for the Presidency was drawing to a close.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 24 -- India will welcome assistance of American business interests in launching an extensive propaganda campaign to popularize Indian tea in the United States, a market spokesman of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry said today.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson declared their support of the United Nations last night and called upon the people of the nation to back the world organization.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 24 (UP) -- The twentieth victim of three hit-and-run highwaymen who have operated through three states, told the police today he drove the bandits to the Atlanta area where they apparently separated.
Catholic Youth Organization Week will end tomorrow with a series of special events emphasizing the importance of religion for the young people of today.
Two young women carrying payroll cash totaling $1,791 were robbed in lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon
Two hundred New York children joined Mayor Impellitteri yesterday in celebrating United Nations Day at City Hall. They participated through essay, pantomime, song and some earnest cake-eating.

James A. Farley, former Postmaster General and ex-chairman of the Democratic National Committee, charged last night that the Republicans had raised the false issue of communism in the Presidential campaign to hide the fact that they had no real issues.

SALEM, N. H., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Tony DeSpirito, the 17-year-old jockey who was grounded for incompetency after each of his first two races, today became the eighth American rider to bring home 300 winners in a year.

The top weight of 164 pounds has been assigned to F. Ambrose Clark's The Creek in the Monmouth County Gold Cup, main event of five jumping and flat traces to be held at Red Bank, N. J., today by the Monmouth County Hunt Racing Association.

Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee and his wife, Nancy, will be the guests on "Junior Press Conference," when the program has its premiere over Channel 7 on Saturday, Nov. 1, at 6 P. M. The panel will comprise Richard J. Murphy of the University of North Carolina, Austin Dilworth of St. Joseph's College, Pat Maguire of Northwestern University and Nell Gayley of Beaver College. "Corruption" will be the discussion topic.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Following is a stenographic report of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's speech here today:
British horseplayers, as well as Empire City - at - Jamaica horseplayers, will be interested in the running of the $75,000 added Gold Cup race at the Empire-on-the L. I. R. R. horse park today.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 24 -- With a mixture of determination for the grim task at hand and a rising hope for the future, United Nations Day was celebrated in this war-shattered capital today.
ALBANY, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Big-game hunters will invade the Adirondack region of northern New York tomorrow when the state's deer and bear season opens.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Found guilty of using scarce metals in violation of National Production Authority regulations, Star Fastener, Inc., of 201 Front Street, Brooklyn, was ordered to repay in allocations the quantities of metals misused.

WESTKILL, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- No one is more deserving of success, on the basis of concentrated effort and muscular exercise, than the grouse hunter, who probably is rewarded with more pleasure and less game than any seeker of upland game.

ALBANY, Oct. 24 -- Unfounded denunciations are spreading fears and suspicions that may lead to the destruction of the country's political institutions, Learned Hand, retired chief judge of the Second Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, asserted here tonight.
Governor Dewey said last night that even with all the good-will in the world Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic nominee for President, could not clean up corruption in Washington.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, former Republican Representative in Congress from Connecticut, told an audience of 1,400 today at the Executives Club luncheon that "Achesonism," and not "McCarthyism" was the real menace to America.
Eight active alien Communists involved in deportation proceedings surrendered yesterday at Ellis Island after the Department of Justice had revoked their bail.

ABOARD STEVENSON TRAIN, in New York, Oct. 24 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois told upstate New York audiences today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "proposal of a quick and a slick way out of Korea" would risk a "Munich in the Far East, with the probability of a third World War not far behind."

Plans for consolidating offices of the Ford Foundation and affiliates under one roof were disclosed yesterday with the announcement that the philanthropic organization had leased space in the twenty-three story office building rising at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Fifty-first Street.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 24 -- The puppet characters originated by Bob Clampett for the "Time for Beany" television show will appear in a feature-length motion picture.

Mrs. George S. Patton Jr., widow the wartime commander of the United States Third Army, was located at sea last night after a widespread search by wireless and shore-to-ship radio telephone. The search was started by relatives who had been unable to find Mrs. Patton's auxiliary schooner When and If, to notify her of the death of her daughter, Mrs. John K. Waters, at Highland Falls, N. Y.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- This was Bob Hope day today at a Federal Communications Commission hearing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Industrial expansion goals adequate to the needs of part mobilization and for five years of all out war have already been set and announced for 176 industries and products, the Defense Production Administration disclosed today. Similar plans are being drafted for an additional seventy-eight industries.

WOODSTOCK, Conn., Oct. 24 -- The campaign to save the 204-year-old little red school house of Quasset Hill, built in 1748, believed the oldest one-room school in the country in continuous use, goes on apace.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 24 -- Amendment of the immigration laws was asked by the American Society of Travel Agents at the closing session of its World Travel Congress here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 269 Korean war casualties in a new list that reported seventy-one killed; 181 wounded; nine missing in action and eight injured. Casualties from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut follow:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 (UP) -- Harvard collides with Dartmouth for the fifty-sixth time tomorrow in one of the nation's oldest football rivalries, with the Crimson favored by a point to snap the Indians' five-year gridiron supremacy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- The General Assembly paid tribute today at a special session celebrating the United Nations seventh birthday to the memory of "those who have died in support of United Nations' principles," including "brave men who have laid down their lives in Korea."

BONN, Germany, Oct. 24 -- West Germany's relations with France, delicate for more than two months, received a sharp shock tonight with receipt of the French reply to Chancellor Adenauer's proposal for a joint statement on the future of the Saar.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 24 -- Larry MacPhail expects the two jockeys to have a great deal to do with winning tomorrow's $25,000 winner-take-all Pimlico Special between his General Staff and Greentree's One Hitter.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson will make heavy use of radio and television in next week's wind-up of the Presidential campaign.
Work by established artists and newcomers figure in five of this week's exhibitions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Government has just exposed one of the secrets of the magician's art. Merville A. Taylor, a north Hollywood (Calif.) conjurer, told all to the United States Patent Office, and the details came out this week in Patent 2,614,838, granted him for his bird cage that folds up, complete with bird.

SEATTLE, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Complimented and condemned for its action last night that kept Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, off the air, Television Station KING stood its ground tonight and said it felt it "had every legal authority to back it up."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 24 -- Col. Adib Shishakly. Syria's "strong man" in a thunderous demonstration in Aleppo, Syria's largest city, finally launched today his Arab Liberation Movement as the sole Syrian political organization, taking the place of the political parties he abolished this summer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Tonight's commitment by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to go to Korea, if he is elected, to try to bring about an end to the war there has created some disquiet in Democratic political circles.

The end of the first week of the city's firetrap survey in Harlem brought a crackdown yesterday by Frederick S. Weaver, Deputy Commissioner of Housing, on the Klahr Realty Corporation, owner of a five-story tenement building at 1 West 118th Street.

The Barnacles, an organization of 400 government and transportation company representatives who expedite the arrival and departure of travelers at the city's piers, airports and terminals, will select on Nov. 3 the "Waterfront Man of the Year."
MANCHESTER, N. H., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, urged New Hampshire voters today to help elect Governor Stevenson so as "not to repeal the twentieth century."

A Democratic Senator acting as chairman of a Senate subcommittee strongly criticized Trygve Lie, United Nations Secretary General, yesterday for giving leaves of absence with pay to ten American United Nations employes suspected of Communist affiliations.

Steady recent declines in the free markets for privately minted gold coins were underlined this week, according to Pick's World Currency Report, by Saudi Arabia's refusal of delivery on 60,000 "British" sovereigns, worth $675,000.
ALBANY, Oct. 24 -- The Court of Appeals today upheld unanimously the twelve-year bookmaking sentence given to Harry Gross more than a year ago. There was no opinion.
Robert Anderson, bass, made his debut as The Commandant in last night's "Don Giovanni" presented by the New York City Opera Company.

DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP) -- State Democrats charged today that Republican fund raisers had asked Michigan auto dealers to put up $100 each to a $75,000 fund to pay for the telecast of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's speech here tonight.
The Texas Company declared an increased quarterly dividend of 75 cents yesterday plus an extra of 30 cents, despite its report of reduced earnings for the first nine months of this year.

MANILA, Oct. 24 -- Filipino and foreign officials here believe the Communist Hukbalahap revolt may be reduced within the next six or eight months to small-scale displays of violence and lawlessness if the present rate of progress in suppressing the uprising continues.

A small explosion and fire in a manhole outside a powerhouse serving the B. M. T. and I. R. T. subway lines caused one of the city's worst delays in transportation last night at the height of the rush hour.

The unsold balance of the recent issue of $170,719,000 of local housing authority bonds secured by Public Housing Administration assistance contracts declined yesterday to $11,516,000 as watchful-waiting investors decided that the time was ripe for purchases. More than $3,000,000 were placed in one day, bond distributors said.
Apparently half the stocks bought at present on the New York Stock Exchange are bought with capital gains considerations in mind, Keith Funston, president of the Exchange, reported yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 24 (UP) -- G. Edward Grammer's attorney filed a motion today for a new trial for the New York business man who was convicted of slaying his wife because of his love for Miss Mathilda Mizibrocky, 28 years old, an employe of the United Nations in New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- A debate on procedure erupted today into a Soviet-bloc charge that proposals for checking the length of United Nations General Assembly sessions were an infringement of the rights of the minority by a United Nations secretariat controlled by the United States.

A young married couple, who moved into their new apartment Oct. 17 and were visited by robbers a day later, had hopes for a happy ending yesterday when detectives of the West Sixty-eighth Street station arrested two men on burglary charges.

Over 10,000 visitors are expected at the National Shoe Fair in Chicago which opens tomorrow and continues through Thursday. The show, sponsored by the National Shoe Retailers Association and the National Shoe Manufacturers Association, will open the "New in Shoes" promotional campaign. About 125,000 spring styles will be shown in exhibits at the Palmer House, Congress, Morrison and Conrad Hilton hotels.
The fourth annual nonsectarian drive by American business men to promote larger congregations in church and synagogues will be conducted all next month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Dr. Kerel Petrzelka, the new Czechoslovak Ambassador, had an eight-minute meeting with President Truman today. He refused to say what they discussed, but he echoed some of Premier Stalin's views when reporters asked him about the imprisonment of William N. Oatis, Associated Press correspondent.

As much a part of October as the turning of the leaves are shows that feature chrysanthemums. For the eighth successive year, the annual show created around this flower opened yesterday at the New York Botanical Garden, with the cooperation of the North Jersey, Westchester and Long Island chapters of the National Chrysanthemum Society.
The deadline for avoiding jail sentences was extended yesterday until next Friday for drivers with out-of-state license plates who have received five or more traffic summonses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon, who has bolted the Republican party as well as its Presidential nominee, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, stepped tonight into a position where he might be able to dictate whether the United States Senate should be Republican or Democratic in the next Congress.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- The United States Embassy's informal explanation to the French Foreign Office of the United States vote for early consideration of the Tunisian and Moroccan issues in the United Nations was presented to the French public today as a "demarche," with implications of a United States apology for the action.

The forty-fourth annual National Business Show will end its six-day run in Grand Central Palace at 6 P. M. today with most exhibitors satisfied that the event was the most successful ever staged. Several leading manufacturers reported late yesterday that orders written at the show exceeded those at last year's event by 25 to 100 per cent.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson told United Nations delegates today that the United States was ready and eager to end the Korean war but that peace could not be "purchased at the price of honor."

Somewhat on the early side, basketball breaks into the local sports picture tonight at Madison Square Garden, where a benefit exhibition double-header will be staged. The New York Knickerbockers will face the College All-Stars in the main attraction, following an encounter between the Rochester Royals and the Boston Celtics.

TOKYO, Oct. 24 -- Japan's Diet [Parliament] selected Shigeru Yoshida, 74-year-old pro - Western Premier, tonight to succeed himself as the leader of this nation's first Government since it regained sovereignty, lost by defeat in World War II.

Despite the urgent warnings of General Ridgway that the defenses of Western Europe are still inadequate the European nations primarily concerned continue to take their time in remedying the situation. There are, of course, many elements that enter into this situation, but most of these elements find a crystallization point in the issue of the Saar, that tiny but industrially important region now bound to France economically but claimed by Germany.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 -- The latest studies on the prevalence of tuberculosis in this country lead to the "educated guess" that there are 1,200,000 victims of the disease in the United States. Results of the studies were presented at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association by Dr. R. J. Anderson, chief of the division of chronic diseases and tuberculosis, United States Public Health Service.
Following is one of a series of articles on the present political situation by The Associated Press, based on a nation-wide survey it made of estimates by newspaper editors and political writers.

Those who worry about youngsters eating too many sweets will be interested in orange-juice-on-a-stick, a frozen product introduced in Florida school lunch rooms and now spreading north. It is becoming available in Detroit, Pittsburgh, Columbus, Ohio, and Norfolk, Va. Test marketings also are being made in other cities.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Anthony Valenti, labor union leader, was found guilty today by a jury in United States District Court on charges of falsely denying he was a Communist in an affidavit filed in October, 1949, under the Taft-Hartley Act, with the National Labor Relations Board.

The long and short of it won out at the Hunter College freshmen hazing yesterday when 6-foot Evelyn Cherry and 5-foot-1-inch Mary Esther Connors won prizes for the best costumes in the traditional fete, which was, based this year on a circus theme.

BELLPORT, L. I., Oct. 24 -- The three-man crew of a Navy fighter-bomber was fished out of Great South Bay near here today after the plane made a forced landing a mile north of Fire Island. The men were flown by Coast Guard helicopter to Floyd Bennett Field, where they were reported to be uninjured and only "a little shaky and cold from the dunking."

TORONTO, Oct. 24 -- Canada's position as the fourth largest trading nation in the world and the largest on a per capita basis underscores the need for trade with other countries, but it also emphasizes that to export a nation must import, according to L. M. Frost, QC.

FONTAINEBLEAU, France, Oct. 24 -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Chief of Staff of the United States Air Force, who flew today to make an on the spot inspection of two United States-occupied air-bases in France and one in West Germany, expressed high satisfaction at the progress in converting air personnel quarters for the winter, in building recreational facilities and developing roads and other vital installations.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Bolivian Government handed the nation's three big tin mines a bill today for more than $485,000,000.

GREENVILLE, N. C., Oct. 24 (UP) -- Four convicts, two serving time as accessories to murder, kidnapped their guard and four other prisoners today in a break from the Pitt County prison farm. The State Highway patrol said the convicts were armed and dangerous.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- The demoralized cash corn situation was again the main feature of the grain trade today, with more corn coming in than the warehouse people and processors could handle. This meant another drop in cash prices with new No. 2 yellow corn selling as low as 13 cents under the December price.

As the debate on Korea began yesterday in the General Assembly of the United Nations preparations were under way for the opening of an extremely significant conference tomorrow in Manila. On the invitation of President Quirino the United States has sent a group of high-ranking officials, civilian and military, to meet with the Filipinos in a comprehensive study of the problem of mutual security and the relation of the Philippine defense establishment to it.

ALBANY, Oct. 24 -- The State Court of Appeals upheld today, four to two, the first-degree murder sentence of Camilo Leyra Jr., twice convicted of having slain his aged parents with a hammer in their Brooklyn home in January, 1950. The Court set the date of his execution for the week of Dec. 1 at Sing Sing.

HANOI, Indo-China, Oct. 24 (UP) -- The State of Vietnam, fighting desperately to stem an offensive by three divisions of Chinese-equipped Vietminh Communist troops, today appealed for stepped-up United States aid.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- The reaction of many delegates to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's remarks about going to Korea was summed up tonight by the wife of one Western diplomat.

John Foster Dulles, Republican party foreign affairs adviser, declared yesterday that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic nominee for President, had tried to give the impression "that he and I stood alike on the Hiss matter" but that this was not true.

The wise men who sat down in Philadelphia 165 years ago last May to draw up a Constitution for "the people of the United States" couldn't foresee the technology of a Presidential campaign in the year 1952. Anybody who thinks they should be blamed for this might like to tell us what a campaign in the year 2116 will be like.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker.
HOUSTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A report that a Houston group had made an offer to transfer the St. Louis Cardinals to Houston drew a "no comment now from Fred Saigh, president of the National League club.
MIAMI. Fla., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Miami's Hurricanes, beginning to roll after a poor start this football season, scampered through the mud of the Orange Bowl tonight to a 20-6 victory over Marquette.
TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 25 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,413, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

John L. Lewis with his usual restraint has now accused Economic Stabilization Administrator Roger L. Putnam of stealing milk from babies, and from miners' babies at that. What Mr. Putnam does with the milk Mr. Lewis did not say.

Squirrel hunters found Ramsey Conklin dead and buried under autumn leaves at noon yesterday in deep brush on a slope of the Ramapo Mountains in Rockland County 300 feet south of the Ramapo-Dunderberg trail. Ramsey's sons climbed up to identify their patriarchal dad.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 25 -- Suffolk County had its first all-out air raid alert today since World War II. An estimated total of 20,000 of the 25,000 Civil Defense volunteers in the ten towns participated. Sheriff William McCollom, Suffolk Civil Defense Director, called the results "highly successful.''

MORROW is undertaking the surprising experiment of republishing, one by one, the entire canon of Erie Stanley Gardner's Perry Mason stories at today's regular trade prices (which means a 25 per cent mark-up from their original cost).

BONN, Germany, Oct. 25 -- The French - German negotiations on the Saar's future are deadlocked and prospects for a rapprochement between the two nations, which is regarded as a key to Europe's unity, have seriously worsened.

THE appointment of Lincoln Kirstein, director of the New York City Ballet, to the new post of Managing Director of all the producing activities of the City Center is the happiest idea anybody has had for the theatre in many a long day.

The main truth of the campaign -- the key of the conflict, and the key to the vote which we think is going to overwhelm the Republican party on Election Day -- lies in the contrast between the candidates. Men are more dramatic, and more symbolic, than parties.
Now that the Dodgers have left, the Bronx has a new problem.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- With near unanimity parliamentary delegates from six European countries today approved the work plan for drafting a treaty to form a supranational European Parliament and political authority. Reservations came only from the French Socialist and de Gaullist spokesmen who argued that the plan was too ambitious and tended too much toward a centralized federal authority.
GENEVA, Oct. 25 -- The United States is in trouble with some of its best allies because, they say, the United States is not keeping its trade agreements.

The mile-and-five-furlong ride on Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' One Count in the $79,700 Empire Gold Cup Race was strictly a pleasure trip for Dave Gorman at the Jamaica track yesterday. "It was so easy it was ridiculous,'' Gorman said on his return to the jockey room after the 3-year-old colt had carried him to a nine-length victory.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Oct. 25 -- Delegates to the Nationalist sponsored Overseas Chinese Affairs Conference here called today on Chinese communities abroad to launch economic warfare against the Peiping regime by suspending remittances of "ransom money" and refusing either to trade with or invest in Red China.

" CULTURE," wrote T. S. Eliot, "is the one thing that we cannot deliberately aim at. It is the product of a variety of more or less harmonious activities, each pursued for its own sake." Especially during the Forties, however, business in America got a conscience about culture.

The recorded voice of Mayor Impellitteri, speaking at 3 o'clock this afternoon over WNYC, will open the station's third annual art festival programs. The festival will be presented through next Saturday.

News comes from Manila that Philippine President Quirino has instructed his executive departments to go ahead at full speed with the rebuilding of Manila's Metropolitan Theatre, so that the city's famous symphony orchestra can once more have a home. Dr. Herbert Zipper, its pre-war and post-war conductor and its recent guest, played his Beethoven Festival in Manila this year in inadequate auditoriums.

I am an independent voter and feel no party responsibility, and unlike THE NEW YORK TIMES, I waited to judge the measurements of the other candidate before making up my mind. I happened to prefer Stevenson from the first, but have taken the trouble to study both men through their speeches, and certainly if my first choice had been the other candidate I would now be running, not walking, to join up with the I-Used-to-Like-Ike-Brigade.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 25 (UP) -- Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, challenged General Eisenhower tonight to tell the nation what he intended to do on his projected personal visit to Korea.

Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee who is president on leave of Columbia University, brought 3,100 alumni and their families to the northern tip of Manhattan yesterday for the fifth annual homecoming reunion at Baker Field.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The Chicago Tribune, whose editor and publisher, Col. Robert R. McCormick, in August advised voters not to cast their Presidential ballots for either Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican, or Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democrat, said tonight its "advice to the voters, if they wish it, is to vote for General Eisenhower."

The war in Korea -- now two years and four months old -- emerged fully last week as a central issue in the struggle for the American Presidency. The issue revolves about the question of how to end that stalemated war -- a question that is perplexing world diplomats in what is expected to be one of the most tumultuous United Nations General Assembly sessions in history.

READING, Pa., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, today called upon General Eisenhower to end his campaign for the Presidency and "concentrate immediately on solution of the Korean war."
ATLANTA, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Leon Hardeman and Billy Teas teamed with Georgia Tech's powerful defense today to give the unbeaten, untied Engineers a 30-to-0 victory over Vanderhilt.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 25 -- If Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is to break into the Solid South anywhere, Virginia seems to be one of the likeliest places.

BUFFALO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- An investigation was ordered today into reports that three members of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's campaign entourage had been "roughed up" by policemen who had arrested them Thursday night when the Republican candidate appeared here.

IN the normal course of events a professional team doesn't engage in a full-dress, rock-'em-and-sock-'em scrimmage after pre-season training has ended. During daily practice the boys merely run through plays in a dummy scrimmage. It's a neat and effective package. Half the squad goes on the offense against the other half, first with enemy formations and then with its own.

HONG KONG, Oct. 25 -- Although the snarled prisoner exchange issue looms as the last technical obstacle to a Korean armistice, it is doubtful that the Chinese Communist leaders regard this knotty problem as the sole bar to peace in Korea.

Both major Presidential candidates and their managers appear to be in agreement that the decisive battleground in this year's election is located in nine Northeastern states which have 137 electoral votes, just over one-quarter of the national total of 531. Here they have been concentrating their energies for the past week and here they will spend most of the time remaining to them before the polls open a week from Tuesday.

WHEN his doctor told him that he would have to seek a quieter life than that of a radio script writer, and a home less stimulating than New York, Richard Morenus would have nothing to do with half-measures. He went to live in the Canadian bush, a thousand miles north of Chicago.

Time was when nearly all great professional athletes, although well paid during their active careers, found themselves penniless and friendless when their playing days were over. MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The once-dangerous Hurricane Fox, which raked Cuba yesterday with 165-mile-an-hour winds, broke up into harmless wind squalls tonight as it spun through the British-owned Bahama Islands, east of the Florida coast.

DETROIT, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The nation's new car retailers are hearing it said they may have 6,000,000 passenger vehicles to sell next year. They also hear that steel allocations to the auto makers will be only enough to make about 600,000 cars in next year's first quarter.

DURING the harvest season a number of questions arises concerning dooryard fruit trees -- particularly the apple. The quantity and quality of yield, and whether they are up to standard, may point up some of the cultural needs that have been neglected.

OPENING with sixty pages of reproductions from the highly popular "French show" held recently at the Museum of Modern Art. "U. S. Camera 1953" (New York: U. S. Camera Publishing Corp. $6.95) maintains this excellent standard throughout an unusually attractive annual, to be published tomorrow.

LAST week's announcement that Bishop Fulton J. Sheen's television program will be presented this season under commercial sponsorship represents a new departure in broadcasting. It will be the first program of a dominantly religious character to be financed by an advertiser who intends to use a portion of the time on the air for direct selling of his product.

BLUFF KING HAL ruled England and Anne Boleyn was queen when small Tamsyn moved to London to grow up in the household of a famous armor-maker. She would rather have stayed in Devon, watching the comings and goings of her uncle's ships, and she was homesick among her city cousins until she discovered that one of them, Piers, shared her feeling for the sea.

THE outlook for fall and winter cruises this year is good for everyone concerned -- for both the ship operators and the cruise passengers. Cruise offerings scheduled from New York by regular trans-Atlantic tonnage diverted to winter vacation assignments are already larger than last season, with thirty-one voyages scheduled against twenty-three last year.

An electronic moisture-measuring device which previously had been used on cotton yarn conditioners or slashers has been successfully applied to rayon, acetate and synthetic yarn slashers, according to John D. MacNamara, textile industry sales manager of Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- Debutantes from New York, Long Island, New Jersey and nearby places assembled here tonight at the Tuxedo Club for the sixty-fourth annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball to make the largest turnout of young people since before the war.

The mounting demands for services and the effects of inflation are sharply increasing budgets of the nation's colleges and universities, according to a recently published study by the Council of State Governments. Titled "Higher Education in the Forty-Eight States," it points up the impact that higher enrollments, added courses and new classrooms have had on the operating costs of the institutions of higher learning in the United States.

As your editorial of Oct. 19 points out, the loyalty controversy at the University of California has been ended. But the principal issue has never been touched, for it is still assumed that one of the requirements of teaching at an institution supported by the community should be loyalty to that community.

ROME, Oct. 25 -- Representatives of 62,000,000 European Socialist voters, meeting in Milan this week for the Second Congress of the Socialist International, confirmed their strongly anti - Communist position by voting resolutions in support of rearmament, of European unity, and in general, of all institutions and initiatives designed to raise a dam against the further spread of communism.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Republican National Committee replied quickly and angrily to Mr. Mitchell's statement.

BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Nebraska battled favored Colorado to a 16-16 tie today before 30,500 fans in a Big Seven football game marked by Carroll Hardy's 86-yard kick-off return for the Buffaloes and the brilliant defensive play of the Cornhuskers.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- One of the cardinal points of American foreign policy is the effort to promote what is called the integration of Europe. By integration, an awkward word, is meant the joining together into a whole, by means of economic and political federation, the free portion of the Continent.

THE Metropolitan Opera is in the principal business of producing performances of opera just as a hospital is concerned largely with ministering to the sick. But just as nearly every hospital is also involved with a concurrent effort in education, so the Metropolitan has increasingly assumed the subsidiary function of training a few people in operatic traditions and techniques.

EXPERIMENTAL research in cancer, research that deserves to be called scientific, began only fifty years ago. Despite all the work done with hormones, nitrogen mustards, cortisone, urethane, antibiotics, folic acid antagonists, colchicine and radio-isotopes, there is still no cure for cancer nothing but the surgical removal of malignant growths or their destruction by radiation.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 25 -- As part of a movement for good grooming, students of Thomas A. Edison Vocational and Technical High School here will be sent home to change to standard clothing when they report for classes in dungarees, Samuel J. Martin, principal, warned today.

DETROIT, Oct. 25 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, charged here tonight that the "bipartisanship of reaction" had produced the McCarran-Walters immigration law and the Taft-Hartley labor law.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 25 -- India's peculiar veneration of the cow will be dramatized on ancient Hindu Cow Worship Day tomorrow by the opening of two nation-wide campaigns, one by the government to improve the quality of this country's remarkably low-grade cattle, the other by a powerful Hindu religious group to rally public opinion against the killing of cows for beef.
Groups believing that Zionism has outlived its usefulness and should be dissolved were criticized last night by Rabbi James G. Heller, national president of the Labor Zionist Organization of America.

JOHN H. GRIFFIN has written a long, intimate novel about a man who is obviously himself, but who is also every other male; a man who is young and interested in music, who goes to a Benedictine monastery somewhere in France to examine manuscripts of Gregorian chants, and who becomes enchanted with the idea of turning himself into a saint.

SCHEVENINGEN, the Netherlands, Oct. 25 -- Oil company representatives succeeded today in slowing down but not in stalling a determined trade union drive for action by the International Labor Organization on a forty-hour week for the petroleum industry the world over.

Their statement, which stressed that the signers spoke for themselves alone included the names of two deans and eleven department chairmen.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (UP) -- Drought and forest fires marred the nation's Indian-summer weather today.

Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal party nominee for United States Senator, said yesterday that civil rights, which he termed the "number one domestic task facing American democracy today," were being violated in the North and West as well as in the South.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 25 -- A heavy Rutgers football team, led by a fine end, Russ Sandblom, broke a victory drought at Brown Field today, scoring two touchdowns in the second half to beat Brown University, 19 to 7.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- One day last week Gov. Luis Mu+/-oz Marin received a letter from the States enclosing two 25- cent chances on that week's lottery and asking him to please check with the official lists and let the writer know if she had won.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 25 -Thinly manned Iowa fighting like the iron men of thirteen year ago, ripped to an upset 8-to-0 triumph over Ohio State today in a Big Ten football battle before 44,659 homecoming fans.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Britain's swollen American colony is showing an extraordinary interest in the election and this year's absentee vote -- expected to amount to around 11,000 -- will probably set a record.

IN 1834 a young pharmacist from the French wine country arrived in Paris with the manuscript of his neo-Shakespearean play, "Arthur of Brittany." MAMARONECK, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- Fullback Foey Datino paced Mamaroneck High School's 32-20 victory over Gorton High of Yonkers today in a Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association game before 3,000 at Mamaroneck's Memorial Field.

YOUR reviewer of "Hear the Train Blow'' refers twice to the woodcuts Charles Clegg and I are supposed to have employed to illustrate our book and hence I infer he does indeed mean woodcuts. Now among the 870 illustrations in our book there are many kinds of pictorial reproductions: engravings, lithographs, letterpress, wash drawings and a variety of other art forms.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct 25 -- A group of eighteen Texas geologists and engineers has estimated the value of minerals under the disputed submerged lands off the Gulf Coast of the Lone Star State at up to $80,000,000,000.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 26 (UP) -The Moscow radio said today that Secretary of State Dean Acheson's United Nations speech on Korea Friday "abounded in prevarications" and tried to absolve the United States of responsibility for delay in reaching a truce.

NEWARK, Oct. 25 -- An application will be made Monday before the United States Supreme Court for a rehearing in the Burlington-Bristol bridge case. On Oct. 13 the court had denied an application for a writ of certiorari, aimed at a review of the New Jersey Supreme Court's decision last March 11, in which the sellers of the two Delaware River toll bridges to Burlington County were assessed $3,000,000.

TOKYO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The national commander of the American Legion said tonight the United Nations should give the Communists in Korea an ultimatum and if the Reds failed to make peace "we should use every weapon available."

City College's soccer team moved a step closer to its second consecutive Metropolitan Collegiate Soccer Conference title yesterday by routing the Kings Point Merchant Marine Academy, 5 to 1, at Lewisohn Stadium. The victory enabled the Lavender to gain at least a tie for first place with three victories and no defeats in conference competition.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 25 -Bucknell's seventeen-game winning streak came to an end today as Colgate ran at will to triumph 26 to 0, before 13,000 homecoming fans in Bucknell Memorial Stadium.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 -- Strikes in the steel, maritime and construction industries have not slowed the expansion of non-agricultural employment in the district during recent months. Non-agricultural employment is well ahead of 1951. This g level of lernployment h. occurred ,principlly because of gains in defense industies, at military establishmerits, and in trade and service industries.

There were signs, even before last week's snow flurries, that unseasonable chill was on its way. The gabbling of geese was one of them. Geese no longer come over these parts in the vast numbers seen in the past, but when the migration begins, early or late, one will occasionally hear that thin, high, chattery note of the flock in flight.

The Reading Clinic at Smith College, now beginning its fifth year, gives the students an opportunity to learn more efficient techniques of reading. Last year, as a result of the project, the average student's reading speed increased from 248 words per minute to 602, with an accompanying 13 per cent increase in comprehension. One freshman increased her reading speed from 325 to 1,440 words per minute, with 100 per cent comprehension.

IT was a long way to go to see a chrysanthemum. First to Hoboken via the Hudson Tubes and thence to Madison, N. J., on a resolute Lackawanna local. But the out-of-town tryout of chrysanthemum Orloma was worth the trip.

Persons active in behalf of the Play Schools Association have taken over the performance of the new musical production, "My Darlin' Aida" on the night of Nov. 5 at the Winter Garden Theatre. Mrs. George W. Naumburg and Mrs. Ruth R. Goddard are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UP) -- Leading radio and television news men believe that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson will win the Presidency by one of the narrowest margins in history, a poll by Broadcasting-Telecasting magazine showed today.

M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-Second Street. Ralph Fabri, artist and typographer and president of the Audubon Artists, will be the lecturer.

We would like your readers to know that the cover picture of THE TIMES Magazine for October 19 showed the hardworking members of the New York City League of Women Voters. The scene depicted League headquarters during Registration Week, in which six days we received and answered 7,000 inquiries from voters throughout New York's five boroughs and adjoining states.

A 14-year-old boy strolled into the Eighth Annual Chrysanthemum Show at the New York Botanical Garden yesterday and without benefit of background materials or any formal training swept away the honors in a flower-arrangement contest.

MIAMI BEACH -- The picture along Florida's Gold Coast from Palm Beach down to Miami Beach continues to be expansive, with more new hotels and more new motels being added every season. Miami Beach will present four new hotels to its guests this winter, totaling 700 new hotel rooms, plus an equal number of newly built apartment units.

LINCOLNDALE N. Y., Oct. 25 -- Recent criticism of child welfare agencies in New York City on grounds of "substandard" work and purported unconstitutional practices was attacked here today by Judge John Warren Hill, Presiding Judge of the Children's Court of the City of New York.

THE filmed history of naval operations in World War II, which has cost the National Broadcasting Company $500,000 to produce in cooperation with the Navy Department, will begin a twenty-six-week run over Channel 4 this afternoon from 3 to 3:30 o'clock.

At Barnard College a course, "The Practice of Politics," puts students in working contact with basic units that affect political action: the precinct club, the campaign headquarters and the private pressure group.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Oct. 25 -- The United States Deputy Defense Secretary, William C. Foster, told the press today that an attack on Formosa "would automatically change the policy of neutralization" of the Nationalist stronghold. Mr. Foster added, however, that as far as he knew, the United States policy on the neutralization of Formosa "still stands" at the present moment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The final Washington hearings of the President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization, due to start Monday, will carry into the final week of the Presidential campaign a phase of one of its major controversies.

BOSTON, Oct. 25 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois tonight answered Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's dramatic proposal to go to Korea to seek a settlement of that war if elected President by saying that the "root of the Korean problem does not lie in Korea -- it lies in Moscow."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Truman was making preparations today to set out at 4:30 A. M. Monday on his fifth and final campaign swing. He will make about forty speeches in seven Midwestern states, including six major night speeches.

" TOP BANANA," the musical which recently completed a successful stand at the Winter Garden and is currently on tour with Phil Silvers in the starring role he created, may wind up on the Hollywood sound stages as an independent production.

Eisenhower will not do as well as Governor Dewey did in 1948, Louis Hollander, president of the million-member labor group, announced yesterday after a personal scouting trip.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 25 -- Opposition to the military aid agreement with the United States has become so strong in committees of the Brazilian Congress that it is reported that the whole matter is being referred to President Getulio Vargas to see if he can reconcile opinions.

VENICE, Fla. -- This is a pleasant community to visit if one does not crave formal entertainment or organized excitement. Fishing and swimming are excellent, casual clothes are in order and sun glasses are essential rather than affectation here.

Erasmus Hall subdued Boys High by 28 -- 0 yesterday in the forty-seventh game of their fifty-four-year-old series at Boys High Field. The victory enabled Erasmus Hall to increase its lead in the series, 23-20, four games having ended in deadlocks.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- In Africa, darkest and most isolated of continents, a giant that has slumbered through many millenniums of history has lately begun to stir and flex its muscles. All over the continent there have recently been signs of awakenings and unrest.

The contribution of Chesapeake Bay to the life of the State of Maryland and to the nation as a whole, its history, commerce, industry and social effects, will be demonstrated in an exhibition opening in Baltimore Thursday. The exhibition is arranged by the Maryland Historical Society as an activity of its newly organized Maritime Museum.

In this book Phyllis Fenner has assembled an unusual group of sixteen spooky stories -- not the most horrific specimens I have ever come across, but a varied and unhackneyed crew.

GEOLOGY and paleontology are difficult subjects for poetry, even prose-poetry, but in California anything is possible. "Earth Song" is a prehistory of California, starting with the lifeless earth and ending with some cautioning words on the modern erosion problem.
EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 25 (UP) -- Northwestern's football team scored its first victory this season by defeating Indiana, 23 -- 13, today.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- With the heaviest winter calendar of events in history for Arizona and with the addition of important new winter sports facilities in New Mexico, visitors to the Southwest this season can expect a busier and more comfortable vacation.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 25 -Danbury's "grand old lady" and Connecticut's eldest citizen, Mrs. Sarah Frances Rockwell, today observed her 108th birthday. To those who would emulate her longevity, she urged, "take things easy and never worry."

IN spite of its title, this book deals only with "Germany in power." It bears as subtitle: "The Background of German Development," but the reader who expects a historical survey of the growth of Germany from early times to 1939, will be disappointed.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, in his first major appearance in Harlem since the start of his campaign, challenged yesterday the sincerity of the Truman Administration's civil rights program and promised that there would be no discrimination "wherever I can help it."

IF a historical novel is based on accurate research and written with a lively eloquence, it fulfills the dual function of throwing light on the past while it entertains as fiction. This is doubly true when it deals with a relatively unknown yet important period.

Still smarting from the sting of their upset 1-point defeat by the Chicago Cardinals last Sunday, the New York Football Giants will attempt to rebound today against the Philadelphia Eagles. Kick-off time is 2:05 P. M. for this Polo Grounds contest, which is expected to draw upward of 25,000 spectators.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- The Southern California Trojans punctured the myth of California's invincible backfield today by bottling up Johnny Olszewski and scoring a 10-to-0 upset victory before 94,677 football fans.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Oklahoma's Sooners defeated Kansas State, 49 -- 6, after a sputtering start today and moved one step nearer a successful defense of their Big Seven Conference championship before a crowd of 42,000 that included 100 high school bands.

Waterborne traffic through New York harbor in 1951 exceeded by 7,000,000 tons the twenty-six-year record set in 1950, according to a preliminary survey released here last week by the Army Corps of Engineers.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Evergreen and deciduous shrubs and trees set out any time this year need thorough watering and mulching before winter. It is also important that established evergreen shrubs such as rhododendrons and daphne do not lack water now. Soak soil deeply around the roots once a week until the ground freezes hard, and then spread a mulch.

SINCE Katharine Hepburn is a fabulously popular actress, the limited engagement of Shaw's "The Millionairess," in which she is now appearing, will be one of the town's big successes. On the day when the Theatre Guild first put the tickets on sale, hundreds of patient theatregoers lined up in Forty-fourth Street outside the Shubert Theatre, where a battery of ticket sellers was trying to cope with the first big business of the season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Truman said today that the Communist-dominated Czechoslovaks were being made aware that the Western nations were in the midst of a great effort to build a common front against Soviet expansion.

Bernard F. Gimbel, president and chairman of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc., said yesterday New York would benefit by millions of dollars when the new Columbus Circle Coliseum was completed.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 25 -- Billy Talbert and Gardnar Mulloy will meet tomorrow in the championship final of the Greenbrier Hotel's first autumn invitation tennis tournament.

NOTE on the creative ferment of our times: The Doubleday book clubs -- all eight of 'em -- will soon start selling Christmas gift items, by mail order, to their members. Book ends, reading lamps, scrapbooks, games and plant holders will be among the merchandise offered, but there will be no novelties manufactured out of unsold books.

The Presidential campaign is now nearing its Election Day climax, and for that we think most Americans will be grateful. The two major candidates and their hosts of satellites have been battering at each other almost daily for many weeks; they have crisscrossed the country by plane and train and car; they have spoken from rear platforms and state Capitols, television studios and open fields; they have exhausted their audiences and they have exhausted themselves.

GREENWICH VILLAGE may have seen everything; but if it ever saw William de Lys before, it has forgotten all about him, and is about to be loudly reminded. For out of Pittsburgh, by way of Denver and nearly everywhere in between, has come Mr. de Lys and the Theater de Lys, which will open at 121 Christopher Street tomorrow with a production of John Huston's "Frankie and Johnny."

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 25 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican candidate for re-election from New Jersey said here today that "during the past several months the country has been shocked by the realization that there is no practical and effective way to avert work stoppages even where there may be a national emergency."

GIVE WJZ-TV and its Public Affairs Department full credit for that old college try. Mrs. Devereux C. Josephs heads the committee for the performance of "Dial 'M' for Murder," with Maurice Evans in the leading role on the night of Nov. 6 at the Plymouth Theatre for the benefit of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service.

Hard on the heels of the nationwide observance of Fire Prevention Week come stiff figures of ever-rising loss from fire. The National Board of Fire Underwriters estimates September fire losses at $58,949,000, a jump of 10.4 per cent over September 1951.

WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Quarterback Jimmy Stehlin of Allentown, Pa., today led undefeated, untied Brandeis University to a 31-19 upset victory over Wayne University. The triumph was the fourth of the season for the Judges.

One hundred and forty-four physicians on the staff of the Veterans Administration Hospital in the Bronx signed yesterday a protest against recent budget cuts by Congress in the Department of Medicine and Surgery of the Federal agency.

Home furnishings and decorations of every description continue to flow through the auction channels in a steady and voluminous stream. Most galleries will have sales this week, offering the public a rich and varied choice.

Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein of Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, 117 East Eighty-fifth Street preaching on "Religion and Election Campaigns" yesterday morning, declared that "religion has an important contribution to make to political life" but that "a pulpit must never degenerate into a soapbox."

Some carriers in this area already commenced a lay-off which at week-end involved several thousand trainmen and others. ON page one of this story young Jonathan Tucker is a shy, hesitant, city-bred boy, forced by his mother's illness to go West to Live for a while with Big Matt Tucker, an uncle whom he had never seen. The rugged life at Tucker Ranch, a pack station in the High Sierras, lying under the shadowing peaks of Thunderbird Pass, gradually instills in the boy a deep love for the mountains.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25 -- Yale enjoyed its expected romp over Lafayette today. Advancing with almost measured steadiness after a scoreless first period, the Bulldogs set down the overmatched platoons from Easton, Pa., by the score of 47 to 0.

John Mangiante sparked the Seahawks, scoring twice, intercepting two Brooklyn passes, recovering three opposition fumbles and running for one extra point.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 25 -- Duke's power-packed football machine, with Sophomore Worth Lutz in the driver's seat, reduced the vaunted Virginia defense to a rubble in two periods today. The final score, as Duke remained undefeated and untied, was 21 to 7.

The coal controversy cast some clouds on the economic horizon last week, but otherwise the business and industrial scene remained serene. Industrial production and business activity in general cruised along at a high level and, in the opinion of the economic forecasters, promised to hold this pace well into 1953.

TALLAHASSEE -- An important link in the new $50,000,000 Jacksonville expressway project will be open to motoring tourists in January. This is the $11,000,000 John E. Matthews (or Arlington) Bridge, spanning the St. Johns River a few miles east of Jacksonville, which will enable motorists to by-pass downtown Jacksonville.

THE fruits of the 1951 Casals Festival at Perpignan are now beginning to enter the phonograph catalogues. Putnam, head of the Economic Stabilization Agency.

The article lists no scientist who disagrees with the protest.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 25 -- Dr. Willem Rudolfs, consultant on water supply and sewage treatment, is retiring soon as chairman of the Department of Sanitation at Rutgers University's Agricultural Experiment Station, a post he has held for thirty years.

He wrote: "Through humor, his only alternative to madness, Lincoln saved himself from both sadism and suicide to become the most compassionate of all the historic bearers of great power."

Provisional members of the New York Junior League who will make their debuts this season will be the guests of honor at the New York Junior League Ball to be held on the night of Nov. 26 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the organization's Welfare Fund.
