We have just had two strong statements on the Korean problem. They should hearten our friends and allies and help to convince our adversaries that there is and will be in this country a real steadfastness on the Korean issues. Secretary of State Acheson, in an admirable address to the General Assembly, made a clear and cogent moral case for the position maintained by the United Nations and the United States.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 25 -- Syracuse tumbled Holy Cross from the ranks of the unbeaten before 18,000 at Archbold Stadium today after a thrilling uphill fight. With only forty seconds to play, the Orange tallied the decisive touchdown as Pat Stark tossed to Don Ronan in the end zone to seal a 20-19 verdict.

AS its title indicates, "The Boy Who Stole the Elephant'' is an unusual story, done in the bold black and whites that appeal to children of the middle years. With the kindest of motives, 12-year-old Gyp steals the royal elephant Queenie from Mr. Catfish Williams the villainous owner of a small one-ring circus.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Cain Hoy Stable's one-eyed Armageddon withstood a strong stretch challenge today to win the $25,000 added Benjamin Franklin Handicap by a half length before 30,594 spectators at Garden State Park. Belair Stud's Golden Gloves was second, with M. Kahlbaum's Jampol third.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon tonight asserted Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson was "color blind on the Red issue."

MOSCOW, Oct. 25 -- It can be stated with a good deal of certainty that there are few current questions that are regarded with milder interest on the part of the average Moscow newspaper reader than the progress of the United States election campaign.

THIS sixth volume of the Council on Foreign Relations' annual surveys of American foreign policy records the gratifying opinion that the immediate danger to the United States by the end of 1951 was far less than it had been a year earlier, when world war threatened to engulf a nation unsure of its allies and militarily unready itself.

The Bethlehem Steel Company's plant at Bethlehem, Pa., is now fashioning steamship rudderstocks on twin forgings, in filling an order for ten to be used on super-tankers of the 29,250-deadweight-ton class being built at the company's Quincy, Mass., shipyard.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- For the third straight year, the United Nations General Assembly refused today to allow Communist Chinese representatives to enter its hall and speak for the people of China.

ALTHOUGH the five little monkeys were "a trouble, trial and torment" to the animals of the jungle, they will give a great deal of pleasure to small humans. Their pranks are just the sort to charm the mischief-loving picture-book audience and their reform (brought about by the enraged jungle citizenry) will confirm that same audience's deep-seated belief in the triumph of virtue.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 25 (UP) -- Paced by the bull-like drives of Fullback Richard Ochoa, Texas knocked the Rice Owls out of the Southwest Conference contention today with a 20-to-7 victory before 66,000 spectators. Ocha plowed through a very respectable Rice line with the determination of a bulldozer, usually ending his drives by dragging two and three tacklers for an extra yard or two.

ONE of the current novels is being advertised by the catch-line, "Can a man love his wife -- and be unfaithful at the same time?" It is a silly question, of course, as the copy-writer is no doubt well aware, and belongs more properly to that form of huckstering designed to lure the customers into seeing a Grade-B movie.

IN the morning of our national existence the honest liberal knew pretty well the part that government should play in the ordering of our lives. It should govern as little as possible; if men were left reasonably free, Thomas Jefferson suggested in 1801, they would work out their own improvement.

THE latest "Mrs. Tim" story is a bubbling little tale with a smidgin of mystery and a generous amount of romance. Mrs. Tim, leaving her colonel-husband in Kenya, flies back to England to spend the summer with their son and daughter.

HAVING paid little attention to the startling photographic and projection process called Cinerama during its experimental development stage, the motion picture industry now appears to be working up a keen interest in this technical advancement which has broadened the pictorial scope of the screen.

NEXT to Sir Walter Raleigh, who admitted him to his acquaintance, perhaps the most romantic figure of Elizabethan England is Christopher Marlowe, a man of mystery, violence and poetical genius. Even before he left Cambridge, mystery, romance -- and slander -- touched his life.

NEWARK, Oct. 25 -- A three-and- three-quarter-hour exchange of questions and answers on television will be conducted by Archibald S. Alexander next Thursday night as an innovation in the closing phase of his campaign as Democratic candidate for United States Senator.

The Korean battle front is a winding line beginning about twenty miles south of Parallel Thirty-eight on the west coast of Korea and ending about fifty miles north of the parallel on the east coast. DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 25 -- Fairfield County's estimated 295, 000 voters in twenty-three cities and towns, besides casting ballots in the Presidential and state-wide contests Nov. 4, will choose one member of the United States House of Representatives, eight members of the Connecticut State Senate and thirty-nine representatives of the lower house of the General Assembly.

The retirement of Rear Admiral Edmund W. Burrough, U. S. N., at the statutory retirement age of 62 was announced yesterday. Admiral Burrough has been serving as deputy commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier and deputy commander of the Atlantic Reserve Fleet.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 25 (UP) -A suspected member of a hit-and-run bandit trio that robbed and kidnapped twenty persons in a week of crime was taken by Federal and state officers here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson will make a special bid for the women's vote next week with four afternoon radio broadcasts sponsored by the women's division of the Democratic National Committee.
BOSTON, Oct. 25 -- Plans for an exchange of information on distribution techniques and statistics on a global scale are being mapped by the International Chamber of Commerce.

HAVANA -- Visitors to Cuba this winter will benefit by the inauguration of a "new deal" for tourists, according to Martial Facio, president of the recently created Cuban Tourist Institute, who enthusiastically predicts that this will be the best season in many years.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 25 (AP) -- General Staff, pride of the racing stable of Larry S. MacPhail, bounced to a front-running victory over One Hitter today in a two-horse Pimlico Special and got back the $25,000 his owner paid for him three years ago.

Busy doctors of the New York Physicians Art Club have managed through the year to find time to make diverse and talented contributions for their annual art show, which opened to the public last week in the American Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 25 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee, appears to be within hailing distance of an upset victory in this Democratic party citadel, but late reports would yet indicate that a final election triumph might not be his.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois placed a wreath today upon the grave of Franklin D. Roosevelt and told an audience of 2,500 in nearby Poughkeepsie later that the Democrats would continue to strive "to achieve at last that America, free and friendly and strong and responsible, of which he always dreamed."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- If the election a week from Tuesday fails to draw to the polls the greatest number of voters in history, it won't be because the public has not been urged to do its democratic duty.

ANOTHER record - breaking winter-motoring season appears to be in the offing as Northern tourists prepare to set out for warm-weather resorts. Florida, as usual, heads the list in popularity with New York drivers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Jacob Blaustein, president of the American Jewish Committee, asserted here tonight that the gravest threat confronting the Jews in Europe, particularly in Eastern Europe, was the rising strength of extreme Fascist and Communist elements. He charged that the overwhelming majority of 400,000 Jews were being "held captive" in the Soviet satellite states.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- A gallant Navy team, pinned deep in its own territory for most of the contest, struck through the air on the end of a 94 yard march in the third period to gain a 7-7 tie with favored Pennsylvania before 65,000 spectators on Franklin Field today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 -- Freshman Fred Wyant, a left-handed tosser from Weston, W. Va., acted as if he never had read about the resurgent Pittsburgh Panthers as he paced West Virginia to a 16-0 upset before 28,524 fans today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- There is a vitality about St. Petersburg today that one does not readily associate with the city's famed green benches and sloping curb stones that have made life easier for the elderly and the ailing these many years past.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- Colombia, Lebanon and Denmark were elected today to vacancies on the United Nations Security Council, replacing Turkey, the Netherlands and Brazil.

TRENTON, Oct. 25 -- The Republican party in New Jersey, mindful of what happened country-wide in the 1948 Presidential election, is "running scared" for psychological reasons this year. The Democratic state organization is running the same way, but for a different reason. It really is scared.

The Kansas City "short cut," the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad's new line in Missouri, will open for freight service on Tuesday. This new Burlington-Kansas City line is the largest single railroad built since World War II. It cost $16,000,000 and took thirty-four months to construct.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Hugh McElhenny, Don White and Joe Perry reeled off long touchdown runs and Frankie Albert passed for three more as the San Francisco Forty-Niners scored an easy 48-21 victory over the Dallas Texans in a National Football League game today.

Investing simply must be a lot easier than understanding some of the books that are written about it. One such is "A Guide to Profitable Investment" by Harold R. Gruver. It seems expressly designed to keep investors out of the market most of the time.

Taking the lead in the early minutes of the game and never giving it up, the New York All-Stars defeated the County Cork Gaelic football team, 14-12, before an overflow crowd of 8,000 at Croke Park, the Bronx, yesterday. More than 1,000 persons were turned away at the gates.

James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, declared yesterday that, while he believed this was "the most crucial era of all time," it has become one in which a prodigal Christian faith has risen following years of backsliding.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 26 -- Iranian Communists shouting "Death to the Shah," battled military students in the presence of the Shah and the Queen today. Scores were injured and 147 were arrested.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (UP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers exploded against the Chicago Cardinals today for a 34-to-28 triumph. Quarterback Jim Finks threw three touchdown passes before 20,395 fans.

TRENTON, Oct. 26 -- Archibald S. Alexander, former Under Secretary of the Army and the 1952 Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, is facing an uphill fight in his race to unseat Senator H. Alexander Smith in New Jersey.

Traveling in a wheel chair he hopes to leave behind in this country when he returns home, Paul Francolon, internationally known French jockey whose riding career was terminated by an accident at Longchamps race track, arrived here yesterday for treatment.

Gloria Lane made her first appearance as Amneris at the City Center last night. The other singers in the New York City Opera Company's presentation of "Aida" were familiar. Leading roles were taken by Jon Geyans, Anne McKnight, James Pease and Lawrence Winters. Tullio Serafin conducted.

Iris de la Torre Bueno's 5-year-old Brussels Griffon, Ch. All-Celia's Beau Brummel, a sturdy and successful little dog show campaigner, became best yesterday in the twentieth annual event of the Progressive Dog Club at The Livingston in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement tonight on the soft coal strike:

Borough President John Cashmore, Democratic nominee for United States Senator, last night pledged his "complete energy and efforts" toward repeal of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act if elected. At the same time, he said, he would strive for enactment of the Lehman-Humphrey Bill.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- France has concluded a trade accord with Poland which, according to official sources, covers an exchange of goods comprising the export of 7,000,000,000 francs worth from Poland to France and 6,600,000,000 worth from France to Poland in the period up to June 30, 1953.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 26 -- Delegates representing the leading gas utility companies in the United States and Canada, including executives from the nation's top gas appliance manufacturing companies, arrived here today to attend the thirty-fourth annual convention and exhibition of the American Gas Association opening tomorrow. Included in the registration this morning was a delegation of gas utility men from France now touring this country and individual members from Great Britain and Australia.

Marjorie Schloss, Memphis, Tenn., soprano and voice teacher of a number of actors and actresses, gave her first New York recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Her brief program included Beethoven's "Ah! Perfido," five lieder by Hugo Wolf and four songs by Louie White.

PERFORMANCES by Syracuse and Navy last Saturday indicate with startling clarity the awesome power of Michigan State and Maryland. Or are we going a little too fast for you? All right. Let's spell it out slower.

Postwar geographic dispersion of Soviet heavy industry has made the Soviet Union far less vulnerable to land or air attack than ever before in that country's history, analysis of detailed data released at the recent Communist party congress in Moscow indicates.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Radio and television manufacturers charged today that Government officials went back on their word in restoring price ceilings on radio and television parts.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Oct, 26 -- Dr. E. Malcolm Stokes turned in a round of 37, 37 -- 74 to spark the Garden City Country Club "A" team to victory with 307 points in the Long Island Golf Association team championship tournament at the Brookville Country Club today.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 26 -- Police smashed an illegal tribal meeting on the outskirts of Nairobi today after firing directly at the main speaker.

Our French friends are grieved with us. Judging from what President Auriol said on Saturday and the hot blasts in the French press since our startling vote at the United Nations on Wednesday agreeing to place Tunisia and Morocco second and third on the agenda, there is a deep sense of anger and frustration.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 26 -- Shouts of "pig-dog Eisenhower" and accusations that the Americans are the real war criminals marred an attempt to lead veterans of Hitler's Waffen or armed S. S. divisions back into the political life of the Federal Republic.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 13, Dr. Benjamin Fine heralded what he termed as a "new movement" of cooperative college financing which he said is now "sweeping the country" in an article headed "U. S. Colleges Are United in Movement to Acquire Funds."

Reports received by THE TIMES from its correspondents throughout the country indicate that the outcome of the contest for the Presidency between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican, and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democrat, continues to be very uncertain.

The Right Rev. Horace W. E. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, in two sermons yesterday asked for a renewal of loyalty to the basic truths of Christianity to enable the Church to become "a worthier instrument for the realization on earth of the purposes of God."

In support of medical education in the United States, the National Fund for Medical Education, 2 West Forty-sixth Street, will conduct during the next twelve months a $5,000,000 industry-wide solicitation campaign, Colby M. Chester, chairman of the fund's committee of American industry, announced yesterday.

Mayor Impellitteri's fiscal advisers are offering a proposal to create an independent Transit Authority to take over the municipal transit system for operation on a "self-sustaining" basis with the aid of a special tax on business as well as real estate to augment revenues obtained from subway, bus and street car passengers.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 26 -- If efficient party organization were the sole criterion for winning elections, Ohio's twenty-five electoral votes could safely be counted for the Republicans.

The $2,500,000 study of city departments and agencies, to which the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey has already devoted nearly three years, was denounced and ridiculed yesterday by Construction Coordinator Robert Moses, himself a member of the group.
LONDON, Monday, Oct. 27 (Reuters) --The Socialist slanted Daily Mirror predicted in a New York dispatch today that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson would be the next President of the United States.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, this morning accused President Truman of political demagoguery and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic candidate for President, of hypocrisy.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns used their entire bag of tricks today to score a 19-15 victory over the Washington Redskins with a 10-point last-period surge in a thrilling National Football League contest.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- The nation's oldest child guidance clinic is ready to start some of the newest research in juvenile delinquency. While discussions continue all over the country on rising delinquency rates, the internationally famous Institute for Juvenile Research, here, is putting into action a new program aimed at understanding the individual child with a view toward the prevention of emotional illness.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 26 (Reuters) -- Oil companies, eager to avoid the danger of nationalization of expensive plants and machinery in less stable areas, plan to spend nearly $184,500,000 in the next four years expanding refinery capacity here.

There are numerous one-man and group exhibitions on this week's calendar and, opening next Saturday at James Graham and Sons is an important retrospective of paintings by the veteran American artist, Everett Shinn.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Scoring when and how they pleased, the Detroit Lions rolled up more points than they had tallied in four previous games today to crush the Green Bay Packers, 52 -- 17, in a National Football League game.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 26 -- The Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation has postponed a decision on the Dutch application to raise the European Payments Union credit maximum by $100,000,000 to $455,000,000, according to Telegraaf.

Jacob Arvey, Democratic national committeeman from Illinois, appearing here last night on a television program, said he did not think that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, if elected, would continue Secretary of State Dean Acheson in his Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast near-record world production of corn this year, which, if achieved, would put world output of the five principal cereal grains at an all-time high.

MANILA, Oct. 26 -- President Elpidio Quirino announced tonight he would ask more United States military aid for the Philippines at tomorrow's talks on mutual defense problems between American and Filipino leaders. In a press interview at Malacanan, President Quirino said:
Three bankers have discovered, by experience, that making money in business is easier than making hats for fun.

MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Soviet press said today there was mounting evidence of sharpening conflicts within the capitalist world that were driving a wedge between the United States and its Allies -- just as Premier Stalin predicted.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- The progress of European Jewish communities toward self-sufficiency has permitted the American Joint Distribution Committee to devote a major part of its aid to the needs of Jews in North Africa, Israel and the Near East, it was reported here today.

Your editorial of Oct. 18 which lauds the Board of Education for promoting Charles Gilman to the position of Administrator of Business Affairs raises the hopes of employes who look forward to recognition in a career of governmental service and it is indeed gratifying.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Police Commissioner Michael C. Noeppel, a Republican, denied tonight an allegation that three members of the entourage of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had been beaten by Buffalo policemen last Thursday.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- City interest last week switched from the stock to the commodity markets because of two events of importance. First came the reported decision of American rubber manufacturers to use less synthetic and more natural rubbers, followed by the Government' announcement here that from the beginning of next year free trading in zinc will be restored to the metal market.

It's Hat Week; a Neat Look campaign has been organized by "blue chip" makers of men's fashions for 1953; the liquor industry is well into its campaign to make its commodity the ideal gift; and men's wear retailers in New York are announcing plans for St. Valentine Day sales with election and Thanksgiving still in the offing.

Using the champions of the world as their foil, the New York Rangers registered their first victory in the current National Hockey League season last night. Bill Cook's young sextet swept into the Detroit Red Wings as if the holders of the Stanley Cup were just another bunch of skaters and beat the visitors, 3 to 2, in Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Although Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, the new Premier of Egypt, has not formally departed from the policy of his predecessors, there is evidence from Cairo that his attitude on the future of the Sudan is what the British would call more realistic and reasonable.

The designation of the Korean conflict by "Republican spokesmen" as "Truman's war" will have an adverse effect on the morale of United States troops in the field and on their families at home, Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal party nominee for United States Senator, said last night.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 26 -- Hostility to the United States military assistance agreement appears to be growing here, although the reasons behind the objections are obscure. Nearly all of these are aimed at alleged provisions that are not actually included in the agreement.

In its first change of ownership in thirty years, the four-family house with three stores at 500-502 East 183d Street and 2280 Bassford Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Abraham Mechanic to an investing client of Gescheidt Gillette, attorneys, in a deal negotiated by G. Satriale Son, brokers.

The city's Office of Civilian Defense, spurred by reports from Korea that more blood was needed to save the lives of wounded service men, will begin this week a city-wide drive for blood donations from the 500,000 persons affiliated with its organization.

WARSAW, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Polish voters elected today their first Sejm (Parliament) under the new constitution of the Polish People's Republic. All candidates represent the Communist-controlled National Front and there was no opposition.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- The surrounding Adirondack Mountain range was dusted with a light cover of powder snow and the temperature hovered around 11 above as the thirty-first annual United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association convention ended today.

A new deal, for better or for worse, in the all-important question of Government shipping subsidies, is expected in the merchant marine industry regardless of who wins the Presidential election next week, industry leaders said yesterday.

Walter Winchell, columnist and commentator, said last night in his weekly radio and television broadcast that he had evidence that President Truman was a member of the Ku-Klux Klan in Independence, Mo., in 1922.

A mere five feet tall, and a size 10, Mme. Biki of Milan, Italy, who is known for her handsome custom-made styles, is an excellent example of how the small woman should dress. Most interesting is the fact that this Italian woman designed her own wardrobe.

Weakness in the spot cotton market and in the nearer deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange, while distant months were relatively steady, characterized last week. When the market closed on Friday active futures were down 17 to 111 points. In the preceding week the market had shown net losses of 3 to 41 points.

At a recent meeting Clarence Francis, chairman of the board of General Foods, said that 30 per cent of all the coffee consumed in this area was of the instant or soluble variety. This is an indication of the tremendous increase in popularity of the quick-to-prepare beverage, for in 1948 it represented only about 14.5 per cent of the coffee used here.

MILAN, Italy, Monday, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A preacher of the American-led Church of Christ said today that the police had forcibly prevented members of the congregation from attending services yesterday in near-by Alessandria.

SLOATSBURG, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- The shotgun-riddled bodies of the Ramapo town clerk and his squirrel-hunting companion, a New Jersey banker, were found this morning on an upland forest path near the carcass of an illegally killed deer.

Placing five harriers in the first nine finishers, St. John's University captured the junior Metropolitan cross-country title at Tibbetts Brook Park yesterday. Jim Byrne of St. John's was the individual winner with a record clocking of 20:53.9 for the four-mile course.

The proposed visit to Korea by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, if he is elected President, could touch off World War III, Wilson Wyatt, campaign manager for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, declared on a television program here last night.

Philadelphia's Eagles dropped into the Polo Grounds yesterday with a fiery spirit, an old line and a new defense, designed to flatten the Giants on their own home grounds. The combination worked, too, the New Yorkers paying the penalty for a sluggish performance as the Eagles avenged an earlier setback by the Giants with a 14-10 upset victory before 21,458 fans.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Frank E. McKinney, former Democratic National Chairman, predicted today that his party would win the Presidency with at least 294 electoral votes -- 28 more than the minimum needed.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The state of Britain's shipbuilding industry is beginning to cause some concern, though this relates to the future rather than to the present. Figures just issued show that orders received in the first quarter of this year amounted to 500,000 gross tons, 350,000 tons for the second quarter and 150,000 tons for the third quarter.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Continuation of the debate on Korea in the main Political and Security Committee of the United Nations appears to hinge now upon the reply by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky to Friday's speech of Secretary of State Dean Acheson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A special nineteen-member policy committee to study ways to increase the effectiveness of the Executive Office of the President, was announced today by the National Planning Association so that future Presidents might best be able to carry out their duties.

Taxpayers need at least an extra month to fill out returns, according to the American Institute of Accountants. This is one of fifty-eight recommendations made by the institute to a Congressional committee making a general study of tax laws and tax administration, it was announced over the week-end.

While Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower spent yesterday in seclusion working on the speeches he hoped would clinch the election for him, the Republican candidate's campaign manager declared that the Democrats, led by President Truman, intended in wind up their drive for votes with a barrage of "below-the-belt" charges.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Norman Van Brocklin, Los Angeles flinging star, sparked his team in a fourth-quarter rally today and the Rams trounced the Chicago Bears, 31 to 7, before a crowd of 43,574 in Los Angeles' Memorial Coliseum.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 27 -- United Nations troops dug in yesterday on captured enemy positions on "Sniper Ridge," north of Kumhwa on the central front in Korea, and beat off light Chinese probing attacks last night and early this morning, possible preludes to a fresh mass assault.

Once more the General Assembly of the United Nations has settled, for the course of a session, the question of representation of the Chinese. Although some nations, especially those that have recognized the Peiping regime, abstained on the question of giving full authorization to the representatives of Nationalist China, there was an overwhelming vote to the effect that the question had been settled and should not be raised again.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Unless adequate compulsory automobile insurance rates are obtained casualty insurance companies serving Massachusetts are faced with disaster, the executive secretary of the companies' joint public relations organization said today.

Lowell B. Mason, who describes himself as a bureaucrat, is, to put it mildly, a unique example of the species. In his working hours Mr. Mason is a member of the Federal Trade Commission. When he is not celebrating as a member of that body, however, he likes to indulge in intellectual gym workouts.

EAST MORICHES, L. I., Oct. 26 -- Frostbite regattas, long an enthusiastic cold-weather program of sailormen who prolong their pleasure boat season into the icy and snowy week-ends of winter, today were copied as a device by powerboat skippers to extend their year of race meets.

MANHASSET, L. I., Oct. 26 -- The interim medical advisory committee to the board of trustees of the North Shore Hospital ended four years of service today when its twenty members resigned in protest against organizational activities and policies adopted by officials of the $3,500,000 community hospital scheduled to be completed here next spring.

The Bull Lines will start biweekly passenger and freight service between New York and the Virgin Islands with the departure from here on Nov. 13 of the liner Puerto Rico. The ship, which formerly called at San Juan, Puerto Rico, and Ciudad Trujillo, Dominican Republic, will drop the last-named port from her itinerary.

John L. Lewis casts such a bearlike shadow that it is easy to lose sight of some of the strange associates the United Mine Workers president has in his present effort to wreck the Government's wage-control program. Mr. Lewis' principal support in this endeavor comes from the Northern soft coal operators, a group in which the major steel producers play an important, if not a controlling, role.
Nine new films, including importations from England, France and Germany, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

SYRACUSE, Oct. 26 -- Faced with a serious financial crisis that is handicapping efforts to meet problems created by the increased post-war birth rate, the public schools must embark upon an all-out program to sell the community on the value of supporting education, speakers said here today.

The debut of the Newark Portuguese team at the Yankee Stadium yesterday was a successful one. The New Jersey eleven registered its second triumph in three outings by topping Hakoah, 2 -- 1, in the feature battle of an American Soccer League twin bill before 4,226 chilled onlookers.

ON a small far near Fort Worth lives a blinded war veteran named John H. Griffin who is an established musicologist and a recognized authority on Gregorian chants. For several months now rumors have been circulating through the literary world to the effect that he is more remarkable as a novelist than as a musicologist, that his first novel, "The Devil Rides Outside,"* is an altogether extraordinary work of fiction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- In a surprise move to end the week-old soft-coal strike before embarking on his final whistle-stop campaign tour, President Truman tonight called John L. Lewis, mine leader, and Harry M. Moses, president of the Bituminous Coal Operators Association, to a White House conference with Government officials.

NEWARK, Oct. 26 -- Senator Estes Kefauver made a swing through North Jersey today, attacking what he termed corruption in some local Republican administrations and declaring that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson would make a "great President" who would "always stand for honest government."

The hallmarks of one type of American ceramic, now being made in almost every section of the country, are present in another new collection of such objects on view at the Pottery Barn, 150 Tenth Avenue.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 26 (UP) -- A hurricane that seemingly had spent its main fury after pounding Cuba and skirting Nassau built up again, reaching eighty miles an hour as it swept northeastward into the Atlantic shipping lanes.
Both Presidential candidates will be in the New York City area this week in their final drives to capture the state's forty-five electoral votes.

The annual James J. Hoey awards for "outstanding contributions to the cause of interracial justice" by a Negro and a white person were presented yesterday to Joseph J. Yancey of this city and Charles F. Vatterott Jr. of St. Louis in the Carroll Club, 120 Madison Avenue. Msgr. John S. Middleton, representing Cardinal Spellman, made the awards, conferred annually by the Catholic Interracial Council of New York.
BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson said today that one of the great concerns of the times was "arresting the growth of Federal bureaucracy" in areas of state and local responsibility.

Senator Irving M. Ives, speaking yesterday at a mass meeting of Ukrainian-American organizations, declared that underground movements against the Soviet Union had become the strongest single deterrent to all-out war. He addressed 3,500 persons at Manhattan Center.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- About 232,000 taxpayers have been able to collect $8,900,000 in the past nine months as the result of a joint Government-newspaper-radio campaign to locate missing owner of unclaimed Federal tax refunds.

Governor Dewey declared last night that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's promised visit to Korea if he should be elected President would bring no immediate end to the fighting, but would result in a detailed and positive program designed to end the war as quickly as possible.
VIENNA, Oct. 26 -- Prague Radio reported that Czech Marathon runner Emil Zatopek broke three long distance world records today.
Girl Scout Sunday was observed yesterday afternoon with special services at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Temple Emanu-El and Riverside Church.

MUNSAN, Korea, Monday, Oct. 27 -- The last train out of Munsan left yesterday. It was a train that wasn't going anywhere, in a dual sense. It was the living quarters of the press corps that has covered the truce talks, first at Kaesong and then at Panmunjom.

Clarence Derwent, an actor for fifty years, was guest of honor at a dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria. The testimonial event was held under the auspices of the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy. Mr. Derwent is the newly elected president of ANTA, a non-profit group that holds a Congressional charter, and chairman of the chapter.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 26 -- Political momentum -- the edge which an incumbent, in the absence of any egregious blunders in his record, has against a challenger -- is a major element in the Arizona election picture.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, declared today that the Republic of Israel "both needs and deserves the continued help of our Government and our people."
TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 221, for Sunday's activities:
James T. Gavigan has been appointed vice president of Holliston Mills, Inc., Norwood, Mass., and sales manager of the book cloth divison, effective Dec. 1.

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 26 -- The Air Force indicated today that after one more test flight this week it would take over from the Boeing Airplane Company the first of two experimental models of the B-52 Stratofortress -- the eight-jet "intercontinental" bomber on which this country's military leaders apparently are banking so heavily.

JAMESTOWN, N. D., Oct. 26 -- Two high school girls stood at the entrance to the Jamestown Armory the other night and handed out party literature at a Democratic rally. One wore a Stevenson button and the other an Eisenhower emblem.

The defense finally caught up with the offense Saturday in a season that has seen Michigan State, Maryland and Oklahoma pour it on week after week in leading the intercollegiate football procession. The biggest victim was no less a team than California, which had been averaging thirty-five points a game in holding a place among the big four on the gridiron.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26 -- Kathryn Grayson, who obtained a release from her contract last August after a thirteen-year association with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, has been signed by the studio to star in its Technicolor version of the Cole Porter musical "Kiss Me, Kate."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Government economists said today all signs point toward a business recession late in 1953 and that a step-up in the arms program may be necessary to avoid it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, Republican leader of the House of Representatives, declared today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has within his grasp "a remarkable sweep that could carry as many as thirty to thirty-five states, including several in the South."

Consolidated net earnings of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation for the first nine months this year totaled $21,880,560 after providing $24,699,207 taxes. The earnings equaled $5.69 a common share and compare with $21,477,842, or $5.58 a common share for the 1951 period, according to the report to be published today.

Observers of the international scene have long been aware that the easy days of the Atlantic alliance are over. "Easy" is a comparative term, of course; every step in the organization of this great partnership has been made against enormous obstacles. Friction is inherent in the nature of the enterprise.

The height of the tourist season is over for most Americans, but there is word from Monte Carlo that the men who cater to the whims of guests the world over are going to avoid the usual pitfalls in the future.

Janice Mitchell, soprano, gave her third New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. With Gibner King providing accompaniments worthy of remark for skilled musicianship, Miss Mitchell presented an interestingly diversified and unconventionally arranged program.

ON THE CENTRAL FRONT, in Korea, Oct. 26 -- For the second time since the North Korean Army, armed with Russian weapons, smashed across the Thirty-eighth Parallel on June 25, 1950, United Nations troops here have begun to call this conflict a "new war."

Tom Lea's new novel, "The Wonderful Country," will be issued on Nov. 13 by Little, Brown. It is about the Southwest, where Texas and Mexico meet, beginning in the Eighteen-Eighties. As in his first work, "The Brave Bulls," Mr. Lea has done the illustrations.

The 1952 Metropolitan Contract Bridge Team of Four championship yesterday at the McAlpin Hotel went to Mrs. Edith Kemp, Harry Fishbein and Tobias Stone of New York, Alvin Roth of Washington and John R. Crawford of Philadelphia.

I have been asked by many of my friends in Bronx County to give expression to my thoughts regarding the contest for Surrogate of Bronx County. Bosses Knewitz and Flynn would like this to be a popularity contest. In so far as the residents of Bronx County are concerned this is the most important elective office in the entire county.

" Victory at Sea," an account of the Navy's role in the second World War, is a documentary film of rare power and poetry. With a superlative score by Richard Rodgers, the series of twenty-six chapters is not alone history but a drama told with moving simplicity and restrained majesty. It is a television program not to be missed (3 P. M. Sundays over Channel 4).

Strong opposition to fees or quotas on imported wools was expressed by two leading wool textile manufacturers in letters to President Truman, it was made known yesterday. Francis W. White, president of American Woolen Company, urged Mr. Truman to refuse to impose fees if the Tariff Commission should recommend such action, and to direct countervailing duties on South American wool tops.

Alyne Dumas Lee, Chicago soprano, made her New York debut last night at Town Hall. She proved to be an intelligent and sympathetic artist who sang with such sincerity and inwardness that nearly all her interpretations had a touching quality.

Mrs. Mary Bain, woman chess champion of the United States who made an even score in the first two rounds of the world championship challengers' tournament in Moscow, was defeated by Elizabeth Bykova of Russia after 32 mover in the third round, according to Soviet news sources.

The Walton Community Center, which sponsors events at the Walton High School, Jerome Avenue and 196th Street, the Bronx, launched its second opera season Saturday night. The opening presentation was an English version of Puccini's "La Boheme."

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman of New York sharply condemned "McCarthyites" and "McCarthyism" today as "Stalin's unconscious helpers" and asserted that "McCarthyism" presented as grave a danger to the nation as "those who carry cards of membership in the Communist party."

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, worked on his speech about Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois today. There were reports that it would not be shown to representatives of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower or top Republicans before its delivery.

CLINTON, N. J., Oct. 26 -- Bulldozers and earth movers have bitten forty-five feet deep into forested Jugtown Mountain, five miles west of this Hunterdon County community, to ease the grades and widen Route 28, which in former winters tended to become an icy death trap for trucks.

Leopold Stokowski appeared as the brilliant conductor and also protagonist of the five American composers whose works made the program of the concert given last night under the auspices of the American Composers Alliance, and Broadcast Music, Inc., in the Museum of Modern Art.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks and the Boston Bruins fought to a 1-1 tie before 13.412 National Hockey League fans in the Chicago Stadium tonight.

After a week of comparative quiet, with only one opening, there will be a rush of three tonight -- "My Darlin' Aida," Winter Garden; "Frankie and Johnny," Theatre de Lys (121 Christopher Street in Greenwich Village); "The Pirates of Penzance," Hellinger.

The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service, long a target from many quarters of the maritime industry, soon will come under the direct fire of the maritime committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations. Preparations are being made for the attack at the next session of Congress.

Church services and a parade of 3,000 marchers up Seventh Avenue marked the opening yesterday afternoon of the new buidlings of the Williams Institutional C. M. E. Church (Colored Methodist Episcopal) and its recreational and youth center at 2243 Seventh Avenue.

ZURICH, Oct. 26 -- The issuance last week of the statement of accounts by the European Payments Union for September furnished the facts for arriving at an impartial verdict about the feasibility of reviving trade between Europe and South America by extending the scope of E. P. U. to enable accounts between the two continents to be settled periodically on a multilateral basis.

House dress, town dress, spectator-sportswear dress -- all may be made from the single versatile dress pattern brought to you today by Patterns of The Times. In addition, there is a pattern from which can be made four fashionable waist styles to replace the conventional belt.

GENEVA, Oct. 26 -- Americans may be surprised when the smoke has cleared after the election campaign to discover how far Europe has moved toward acceptance and even rather strong advocacy of the idea that United States economic aid should end soon.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 -- Jonathan B. Bingham, assistant director of the Technical Cooperation Administration, held here tonight that the entire Middle East could achieve "enormous benefits" if Israel and the surrounding Arab states were able to arrive at a lasting peace.

Retailers of men's clothing should increase their profit through greater efficiency in distribution, Jerome I. Udell, chairman of the board of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., maker of Gramercy Park clothes, said yesterday.
The National Tuberculosis Association declared yesterday that, despite progress in control and treatment of tuberculosis, 265,000 persons might be spreading the disease in this country.

Two men and five boys were wounded slightly at 7:50 P. M. yesterday by the accidental firing of a hunter's shotgun at 171st Street and Brook Avenue, the Bronx. The police said that the gun was being carried with its muzzle pointed downward and that the charge of shot richocheted off the pavement.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Villanova's powerhouse proved too tough for plucky little Xavier today as the Wildcats from the East rushed to their sixth straight victory, 34 to 20.

State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi reported yesterday that the overwhelming majority of 116,000 displaced persons living in New York State in the last four years were contributing to the welfare and prosperity of the state and nation.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 -- General demand for steel was still building up last week as mills attempted to make a dent in the big tonnage of unfilled orders. It was clear that a new output record would be attained in October. The same can be confidently predicted for November despite the labor trouble at the coal mines.

BUFFALO, Oct. 26 -- Cheered by the receptions given to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower last week, Republican leaders in the counties of Monroe (Rochester) and Erie (Buffalo) are talking confidently this year of carrying both for the first time since 1932 or, at the very least, of substantially reducing the Democratic pluralities of 1948.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- Orthodox Communist dogma dismisses religion as an opiate and God as non-existent. But what is tantamount to a substitute for any human craving for a deity is being created by the Kremlin through the virtual apotheosis of Stalin.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 -- Senator John Sparkman, the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, stopped in Los Angeles today long enough to comment on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's promise of a trip to Korea in an effort to end the war.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic nominee for President, returns to the city late tonight for a rally in Harlem and a rigorous day of campaigning here and in New Jersey tomorrow that will be capped by a big Democratic rally in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 26 -- The probability that Iran will now offer oil at fantastically low dumping prices in an effort to break into the world oil market and attract anyone who can find a tanker and is looking for a quick profit is holding back an increase in the output of Middle Eastern oil fields.

Representatives of forty-four of the United Nations attended a solemn mass offered in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday to invoke "the blessing of Almighty God upon the deliberations" of the world organization.

The emotional welfare of children who have fathers in the armed services overseas is jeopardized when they are subjected to careless and belittling talk about the Korean effort, according to Dr. Elizabeth M. Fuller, associate professor and principal at the Institute of Child Welfare, University of Minnesota, Dr. Fuller discusses the impact of such talk on children in the latest issue of Book House magazine, a monthly publication issued by The Book House for Children.

Permit me to congratulate you for your impartial editorials and especially for "Mr. Truman's Mud." I have been in your God-given country for fifty-two years. I like it every year more and more, but when election year comes I dislike it because the leaders insult each other and accuse each other with false charges and countercharges for their selfish interests.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- A radical slump in cash corn prices following heavy receipts which glutted the terminal markets of the Midwest proved the dominating factor in the grain trade last week. Congestion of corn at warehouses, where storage room was extremely restricted, forced the biggest discounts ever known.
Stephen A. Mitchell, the Democratic National Chairman, said yesterday it was not up to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson to "decide or determine" the kind of campaign waged in his behalf by President Truman.

A plea for the creation of a national Protestant "pressure group" dedicated to "developing and strengthening the spiritual and moral qualities that are essential to American democracy" was voiced yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. L. Wendell Fifield in a Reformation Sunday address before 450 laymen and clergymen at the sixth annual communion breakfast of the Federation of Protestant Men in Brooklyn.
Three former high police officials named by Harry Gross as recipients of his gambling graft were challenged yesterday by the bookmaker to deny under oath that they had accepted his pay-offs.

STOCKTON, Calif., Oct. 27 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama summed up the twenty-year voting record of Republicans on leading agricultural issues and offered it today to California's Central Valley farmers as evidence that a Republican victory this fall would bring into operation a "boom or bust" philosophy.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 27 (UP) -- Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon read a "top secret" Government memorandum today that he said "proves" that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, as Army Chief of Staff, had recommended the withdrawal of American occupation troops from South Korea in September, 1947.
Columbia's football team began preparations yesterday for Saturday's game with Cornell as Lou Little directed an hour-long defensive drill. The regulars were excused from contact work.
MONTREAL, Oct. 27 -- Canadian football players from Westmount High School in Montreal taught a team of Americans a lesson at their own game this morning.

Changes were made last night in the itinerary of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's swing today through this city and northern New Jersey to permit a maximum number of voters to see the Democratic candidate for President.

I have just read your editorial on Hawsepipe Skipper in THE TIMES of Oct. 16. I congratulate Captain Sadler, as any sailor would who reads of a man who has spent so much time on the bridge. But I think this company of mine takes the record for length of service of its skippers.
I have long admired your newspaper for its completely unbiased news coverage and especially enjoy your coverage of the 1952 campaign for President of the United States.
The investment banking anti-trust trial, now nearing the end of its second year, will soon reach its half-way mark -- the wind-up of the presentation of the Government's case.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The Arab members of the United Nations launched today a full-scale attack on Israel during a debate on assistance to Palestine refugees that was not intended to be political.

BERLIN, Oct. 27 -- The Western Allies made today a new attempt to patrol the Autobahn linking Berlin with West Germany. A "courtesy patrol," revamped and disarmed to meet Soviet objections, sought to pass a Soviet check point, but was refused.

An effort is apparently under way to mobilize an impressive list of intellectuals and public figures to protest pending recommendations of the Subversive Activities Control Board that the Communist party register as, in effect, a foreign agent with the Attorney General under the Internal Security Act of 1950.

The Esso Standard Oil Company must pay the United States Government $432,084 as the result of an admiralty decision handed down last week by Judge J. Skelly Wright in Federal District Court here and made available yesterday. Judge Wright is a visiting jurist here from New Orleans.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- A perfume spray topping a long slim handle highlights the fall exhibit of French umbrella designers. When on your way about town, wherever your umbrella goes your favorite perfume is on hand, right under your thumb.

BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- A court order today dropped a curtain of secrecy around a special meeting of stockholders of Puget Sound Power and Light Company called to vote on proposed sale of the bulk of the company's holdings to six public utility districts in Washington State.

LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 27 -- The High Authority of the Schuman plan entered a new chapter today. It moved from the political field into the economic by assembling here about 150 industrialists, trade union leaders and economists from the six member countries for consultation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -- Immediate termination of the Wald-Krasna Producing Company's contract with R.K.O. Radio Pictures was worked out today under conditions that require Jerry Wald, the executive producer, to assist R.K.O. in an advisory capacity on the filming of "High Heels" and "Size Twelve."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- In a contest culminating in thirteen ballots, Yugoslavia won election today over Czechoslovakia, 40 votes to 18, to the sixth vacancy on the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

Increased operating costs are cutting into the earnings of oil companies. Of four major producers which announced results for the first nine months this year, only one showed a larger return over the similar period of 1951.

TOKYO, Oct. 21 -- Soviet armed forces have much increased their activities on the southern Kurile iselands, with sight of the coast of Japan, and on southern Sakhalin, repossessed by Russia under the Yalta agreement, according to reports reaching Tokyo from official and unofficial sources.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Douglas Wright, chief of the Southwestern Power Administration, said today he believes the agency has legal authority to buy steam power to mix with hydroelectric power and to lease transmission lines to serve Government customers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, accomplished a neat diplomatic trick today. He stayed away from the meeting of the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee -- and completely dominated it.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Sixty-eight thoroughbred horses worth about $250,000 were burned to death in a fire that destroyed Douglas Park's biggest barn last night.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Expansion of the American Joint Distribution Committee's aid program among the 500,000 Jews of North Africa and Iran was discussed today at the annual conference of the committee's field directors.

All boxes have been taken for the sixty-fourth National Horse Show, which will open next Tuesday at Madison Square Garden and continue there through Nov. 11. Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman is president of the National Horse Show Association.
CHESHIRE, Conn., Oct. 27 -- Cheshire Academy has some potentially good football players, but injuries to key men have handicapped the Blue and White this season.

A jury of seven women and five men, with four men as alternates, was picked from a special panel in Federal Court here yesterday to hear evidence against John David Provoo, 36-year-old former United States Army sergeant accused of treason.

One wonders sometimes what Latin-American politicians would do if they didn't have "Tio Sam" to bat over the head at frequent intervals. Certainly life would be much duller and demagoguery a harder trade to follow. If there is anything that is sure fire in Latin-American politics it is to berate the Colossus of the North and conjure up that worn-out ghost of "Yankee imperialism."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 27 -- The first European Assembly of Political Youth received a warning tonight that only close association with Britain could prevent a collapse of the European community that might push Germany or France into the arms of the Soviet Union.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 27 -- The natural gas industry -- the nation's sixth largest corporate enterprise -- has stored more than 500,000,000,000 cubic feet of gas in underground wells in anticipation of this winter's peak demands.
QUEBEC, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Pappy Gault of Spartanburg, S. C., won the North American bantamweight boxing championship tonight with a unanimous twelve-round decision over Fernand Gagnon of Quebec.

Plans have been completed for the River Park Regional Shopping Center in Philadelphia, Pa., on which work is to be started in the spring, it was announced here yesterday by spokesmen for the sponsors. The seventy-six-acre site on the Schuylkill Expressway and the City Line was acquired last May by John McShain, builder.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower paid tribute yesterday to the people of France on the anniversary of the dedication of the Statue of Liberty.

Waterfront veterans from laborer to steamship executive will gather on Nov. 13 at the Union Club in Hoboken, N. J., to pay tribute to Christian M. (Chris) Smith, who is retiring as a steamship passenger agent for the Erie Railroad after fifty-eight years of service.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, described as a "cruel and shameful fraud" last night Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's public announcement that, if elected President, he would go to Korea to seek an end of the war.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Delegates engaged in writing a constitution for a European federation received assurances today from a British spokesman that nothing they had decided thus far would bar Britain's cooperation with the proposed community, which she has declined to join.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was urged today to approve quickly a $20,000,000 stock issue so a combine of private power companies can begin construction of two huge new generating plants along the Ohio River before bad weather sets in.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, charged tonight that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic Presidential candidate, was unfit to serve in the nation's highest office because of his associations and advisers.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Armour Co. signed a contact today with the United Packinghouse Workers Union, C. I. O., granting a 4-cent hourly pay increase to 30,000 workers in twenty-eight plants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -Thomas K. Finletter, the Secretary of the Air Force said today a contract had been awarded to a group of three construction companies to speed and supervise construction of bases in France to be used by the Air Force.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Thomas C. Robbins of Larchmont, N. Y., winner of the United States senior golf championship this year and last, led a field of 230 in the qualifying round of the inaugural North and South senior tournament today.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 27 -- The independent kingdom of Bhutan, an isolated mountainous state between India's northeastern frontier and Communist-held Tibet, had a new ruler today.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will meet a daughter of President Theodore Roosevelt when he makes a ten-minute speech this morning on the steps of the Mineola Courthouse in Nassau County as part of his morning tour through Queens and Nassau Counties.

" The Promoter," a British-made comedy starring Alec Guinness, which arrives at the Fine Arts, is today's lone film newcomer. Glynis Johns, Valerie Hobson and Petula Clark head the featured cast of the import, which was directed by Ronald Neame and produced by John Bryan from a screen play by Eric Ambler and a novel by Arnold Bennett.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 27 -- Application for permission to operate a helicopter service carrying passengers, property and mail between Baltimore, Washington, Wilmington, Philadelphia and New York has been made to the Civil Aeronautics Board by the Baltimore and Annapolis Railroad Company.

Mayor Impellitteri, about to board a plane for Boston at 2:17 o'clock yesterday afternoon, told reporters that there was no ill-feeling or rift between him and the Democratic state or national committees.

YONKERS, Oct. 27 -- A strike of thirty-five drivers and mechanics of four bus lines in Westchester County started at daybreak today. It forced 15,000 daily riders in Yonkers, Tuckahoe, Eastchester, Bronxville and New Rochelle to find other means of transportation.

The widely advertised speech of Senator McCarthy has been delivered, and the Republic still stands. The junior Senator from Wisconsin, who has made his way to national fame and political fortune via the route of wild charges, gross distortions and assorted forms of demagoguery, said nothing last night to change this estimate of him, although he did couch his nationwide broadcast in milder terms than had been expected.

THE sport of wildfowling has two aspects; one involves the "hunting" of waterfowl, the other concerns the "shooting" of waterfowl, and as any seeker of these migrants can testify, these two aspects are not always present at any one given place at a particular time.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, delegate to the United Nations and a member and former chairman of its Human Rights Commission, received a special citation for her work in behalf of the humanities tonight at a county-wide United Nations rally arranged by the Westchester lodges and chapters of B'nai B'rith, Jewish fraternal organization, in the County Center here.

MONROE, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- District Attorney Abraham Isseks of Orange County said tonight that no clue had turned up as to the identity of the slayer of Town Clerk Robert W. Nugent of Ramapo and Charles E. Simpson, a Ridgewood, N. J., banker, while on a squirrel hunting trip on Saturday.

YONKERS, Oct. 27 -- A mystery involving the loss of a briefcase containing jewelry valued at $34,000 wholesale was solved tonight when an honest resident of New York City returned the case and gems to the police.

A survey to determine what young persons and adults working with them consider the biggest problems facing the youth of this country is now being carried on by the National Midcentury Committee for Children and Youth, it was announced yesterday.

Commissioner Robert Moses has reduced his multiplicity of jobs by one, resigning, in a final salvo of criticism, from the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey. Dr. Luther Gulick, director of the survey, remarks by way of reply to his letter that Mr. Moses "attended two out of forty-five committee meetings and took no part in the scores of subcommittee meetings held."

At first sight it is difficult to find a reason for the parody of a free election conducted in Poland last Sunday. Certainly the Polish people could not have been fooled. They must have known when they lined up alphabetically to "vote" for the one candidate named on their ballot that this was a travesty on free choice.
Georgia Tech and Duke, matched in the game of the year in Dixie, and U. C. L. A. and Michigan State face the strongest opposition this week of the nation's ranking college elevens.

CALCUTTA, India, Oct. 27 -- A weird, terrifying jungle tug of war between a giant python and a calf elephant drew villagers from miles around to a clearing in the Manchik Forest Reserve near here, tribesmen reported today.

BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- Archibald MacLeish, former Librarian of Congress, said tonight that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, had never previously mentioned his name "even in his wildest, most irresponsible charges." Mr. MacLeish said the [House] Committee on Un-American Activities had not mentioned it either.

The American Labor party, depicting itself as the peace party, rallied its forces in Madison Square Garden last night, with Vincent Hallinan, Progressive nominee for President, denouncing continuation of the Korean war as part of a long-range American business program of imperialism.

Twenty-five miles north of Philadelphia, in a vast region of the Delaware Valley around Morrisville, Pa., intensive activity is in progress these days as construction workers rush the erection of the country's largest single steel expansion project and one of the East's biggest housing developments.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Swift Co., the country's biggest meat packer, has decided to discontinue hog slaughtering in Chicago, the company announced today.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 28 -- United States Marines, in hand-to-hand fighting, threw the Chinese Communists back yesterday from a strategic ridgeline, known as "the Hook," on the western front in Korea, northeast of the old truce-conference site at Panmunjom.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Air Force spokesmen indicated today that fighter escorts were being provided at times for B-29's and other aircraft that were forced to approach "sensitive" areas and thus risk attack by Soviet fighter planes.
YONKERS, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Frisco Fancy registered a three-quarter length victory over Mr. Primrose in the Grand Circuit pace feature at Yorkers Raceway tonight, Wind Up was third.

High Dive of the King Ranch submitted a spanking performance in winning the Pebbles Handicap, a classified race of a mile and a furlong at Jamaica yesterday. Ably guided by Jockey Willie Boland, High Dive came from fourth in the stretch to first at the wire.

Directors of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company announced yesterday a quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share on the common stock and 2 cents a share on the Class B stock and extras of 40 cents and 2 cents, respectively, on the common and Class B stock.
YONKERS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -"Pass the sugar, please."

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- With the drought situation in the Southwest growing more critical daily, and complaints increasing from other sections of the winter Wheat Belt, there was a stronger undertone in wheat today. There was also a firmer market for cash corn which gave buyers of other grains more confidence.

The stock market followed the line of least resistance yesterday, barely moving most of the session. A lift of 0.05 point in the composite averages indicates the narrow price movement on the day. Volume dwindled as the session wore on and shrank to the smallest in a week, with transfers on the Stock Exchange only 1,000,000 shares against 1,060,000 shares on last Friday.

A new issue of $4,650,000 of 3.7 per cent revenue and refunding bonds of the Philadelphia Parking Authority will be placed on the market today by an investment banking syndicate headed by Alex. Brown Sons, Shields Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 27 -- A section of an improvised platform behind the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad station, from which Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson was scheduled to speak shortly before 5 P. M. today, collapsed a moment before the Democratic Presidential candidate was to appear. No one was injured.

Production of the Armco Steel Corporation was reduced during the strike this summer and sales and earnings for the first nine months this year were below those of a year ago. Facilities have operated at full capacity since the first of September, Charles R. Hook, chairman, reported yesterday, and third quarter results improved over the similar three months last year.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic nominee for President, received one of the most tumultuous receptions of his campaign late last night when he arrived in Harlem for an address in which he told cheering thousands that he would work for a world "where men can live as brothers under the laws of God."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- "I have summoned you representatives of the press," the "liberal" Professor began, "for a fuller exegesis -- or perhaps for this audience I should say explanation -- why the group of college educators of which I have the honor to be chairman feels that, by any test of morals, ethics, logic or intelligence, no citizen or newspaper can justify being for General Eisenhower for President and must switch at once.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, urged the 350,000 striking soft coal miners today to go back to work as he promised President Truman he would.

MANILA, Oct. 27 -- Measures to strengthen the internal and external security of the Philippines and the defense of Southeast Asia were decided on today at a conference between representatives of the United States and the Philippines. The conference was held at the Malacanan Palace, the home of the Philippines President.

We continue our discussion of candidates for judicial offices, presenting bar association recommendations as a trustworthy guide to voters on Nov. 4. Today we deal with the office of Surrogate in the Bronx, an important court requiring integrity and experience in specialized law having to do with administration of estates.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 28 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters communique 1,416 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. today:

The memory of America's twenty-sixth President, Theodore Roosevelt, was honored yesterday at wreath-laying ceremonies at the equestrian statue of the "Rough Rider" outside of the American Museum of Natural History on Central Park West at Seventy-ninth Street.

Retailers and clothing manufacturers who fail to point out in their advertising the exact performance characteristics of garments made with only a small percentage of man-made fibers face a gradual loss of customers. Dr. Robert C. Shook, president of Robert Shook Associates, a consulting organization in the textile and general economics field, gives this warning in a study: "Woven Apparel Blends -- Trends in Their Use."

Much has been said about the merits of Paris fashions vs. American, so let's take a look at what leading hair stylists from both sides of the Atlantic have to propose in new coiffures. It is interesting to note that both are agreed on the importance of short hair, yet their interpretations are entirely different.

Net income of the Philadelphia Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $28,145,649, equal to $2.28 a common share, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $25,151,356, or $2 a share, for the corresponding twelve months of 1951.

BUFFALO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A cold front began to move in from the west late today and started to push off a blanket of smoke that covered most of New York State. The United States Weather Bureau said the smoke haze had originated from forest fires to the south and west of here, particularly in Ohio.
Address given by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson at Quincy, Mass., yesterday morning, as reported by The Associated Press, follows:
Coach Lou Little of Columbia, whose team played a 14-14 deadlock with Army at Baker Field last Saturday, paid high compliment to the cadets and their coach yesterday.

The child does not always voice complaints or respond with a oral outburst to disturbing situations at home. They may leave a lasting impression upon him, however, and parents should not underestimate the child's keenness of perception nor his ability to react to such disturbances, Dr. Sidney L. Green advised last night.

Marks, it was agreed at the beginning of the school term, do not mean everything. It would be too much to say, it was observed to be pupil, that they do not mean anything, for they do indicate roughly a student's relative standing in his class, his general proficiency in a subject or, possibly, a deficiency.

Verdi's music in "My Darlin' Aida," put on the Winter Garden last evening, is romantically Italian. Charles Friedman's new libretto is American, with a strong dash of "Uncle Tom's Cabin" seasoning. Despite the beauty of the singing by Dorothy Sarnoff and Elaine Malbin, there is no way of avoiding the fact that the music and the libretto have nothing in common, except, perhaps, a certain shoddiness of style.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 -- Twenty-eight million handicapped Americans were represented here today as the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults opened its three-day convention.

Orlando Zulueta, 133 pounds, Cuba, registered an upset last night when he outpointed Paddy De Marco, 139, Brooklyn, in the ten-round feature bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn before 2,000 fans.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Pakistan plans to ask the United Nations Security Council to take a direct hand in clearing the way for the long-delayed plebiscite to determine whether the Princely State of Kashmir comes under Indian or Pakistani control.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The results of a draft physical examination of Mickey Mantle, New York Yankee outfielder, have been forwarded from Fort Sill to the Army's Surgeon General in Washington for review.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 27 (UP) -Influence, a Brookfield Farms gelding, defeated Mrs. R. H. Heighe's Seer by three-quarters of length at Pimlico today.
I am one who has switched after really profound study of the issues.

Dollar volume of new orders booked by furniture manufacturers in September exceeded the previous month by 11 per cent according to the monthly report yesterday of Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading factories.

NYERI, Kenya, Oct. 27 -- The main Kikuyu tribal areas of Kenya, which are administered from this town, have now been under a state of emergency for a week and it is possible to take stock of the situation.

The annual country fair of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest will be held today and tomorrow in Ninetieth Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues and in the parish house of the church. The entire block will be roped off between the hours of 2 and 11 P. M. on both days of the event to provide space for the horseback rides, ferris wheel and other amusements for children.

Tavern owners must fight for a better share of the take-home sales of beer and ale and meet the competition from grocery stores through aggressive promotions and realistic pricing, speakers at the annual convention of the New York State Wholesale Beer Distributors Association said yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel.

In many vegetable canneries throughout the country processing of this year's pack still is going on. But it is evident already that corn will be the only major item in good supply. Most other vegetables will be down by a considerable percentage, mainly because of last summer's drought.

WASHINGTON, Oct 27 -- President Truman accepted today the resignation of Joseph C. Duggan as Assistant Attorney General. Mr. Duggan will leave the Department of Justice as of Saturday to resume private law practice in New Bedford, Mass.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Five member states, led by France, demanded today that the United Nations revive a controversial news pact, approved in 1949, and ask Governments to adhere to one section under which they would be requested to circulate "corrections" to false or distorted news dispatches.
COLUMBUS, O., Oct. 27 -- Station WTVN tonight canceled the telecast of Senator Joseph McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, because the station had been unable to obtain an advance copy of the speech.

Governor Dewey appeared last evening on a fifteen-minute program over a state-wide National Broadcasting Company television and radio network with a fabricated "Truman Trojan Horse" which he said the President would like to leave in Washington for the next four years.

Senator Irving M. Ives and Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, debated the issues of the Presidential campaign last night at the annual open program meeting of the Brooklyn Section of the National Council of Jewish Women at the Brooklyn Jewish Center, 667 Eastern Parkway.

" The Letters of Edna St. Vincent Millay," a collection of correspondence covering fifty years, will be published tomorrow by Harper. Edited by Allan Ross Macdougall, the letters begin when the late poetess was in the fourth grade and end shortly before her death.

Although it is losing money at the rate of $100,000 a week, R. K. O. Radio Pictures, Inc., has a fair chance to pull through, Arnold Grant, chairman of the board, told a press conference at the Hotel Warwick yesterday.

TRENTON, Oct. 27 -- The Strategists in the campaign for the re-election of Senator H. Alexander Smith believe that their only problem is to remind the Republican voters that the senior New Jersey Senator is up for re-election.

William Z. Foster, chairman of the American Communist party, was ordered yesterday in Federal court to undergo a physical examination to see if he was fit to be tried on charges of conspiracy to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the Government.

THE NEW YORK TIMES received about 200 telephone calls and numerous telegrams within thirty minutes last night protesting the televised speech by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and objecting to the TIMES' editorial support of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for President.

LONDON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- The House of Commons approved tonight a bill allowing United States service men stationed in Britain to be tried by United States military courts instead of British courts for offenses committed while on duty.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active again yesterday and closing prices were unchanged to 18 points higher than on Friday.

In the coal miners' union, as most persons know by now, no strike is ever called -- not, at least, by that name. The basic rule of the union is: "No contract, no work." In other words, if Mr. Lewis says, for example: "The operators have honored their contract," that is the signal to continue, or return to, work.

Official indication that the Brazilian Government is considering proposals by United States exporters on the serious problem of the South American country's heavy backlog of unpaid dollar credits became known here yesterday when the American - Brazilian Trade Council released a letter from Walther Moreira Salles, Brazilian Ambassador to the United States.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's address here tonight:
The North Atlantic last week lived up to its reputation as the most turbulent of oceans.

A 200-year-old brass crown, from atop a gatepost in the shadow of Westminster Hall in London, changed hands in a ceremony in midtown Manhattan yesterday, symbolizing the link between the British Government and Columbia University.
