WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, retired, endorsed today the idea of having South Koreans take over the front lines in Korea, but said it was something that could not be accomplished before early 1954 at best.
CHESTER, Ill., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Convicts at Menard State Prison, scene of an uprising Sept. 22, seized a prison lieutenant and six guards as hostages in a new outbreak of rioting late today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- James McGranery, Attorney General, urged today that the new Immigration and Nationality Law, which was enacted over President Truman's veto last June, be largely rewritten by Congress.

Fears of a drastic readjustment for American business in 1953-1954 are unfounded, but the country can blunder its way into a recession if it fails to appreciate the expanded potential of producers, distributors and working capital. This was the keynote of several addresses yesterday at the eighth annual convention of the Commercial Finance Industry in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel which was attended by several hundred commercial finance company executives.

The dependence of the armed forces on civilian transport was described yesterday by Francis Shackleford, Assistant Secretary of the Army. Speaking at the opening session of the seventh annual convention of the National Defense Transportation Association at the Statler Hotel, he urged, as a national defense measure, the construction of more roads and the rehabilitation of existing routes.

Miss Josephine E. Kestler, an attorney who pleaded guilty June 18 to a first degree grand larceny indictment involving peculations totaling $48,000, was sentenced yesterday by General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen to serve from two and a half to five years in state prison.
An exchange program for Japanese and Anglo-American cultural leaders was announced yesterday by Columbia University with the arrival of Miss Fusae Ichikawa, champion of women's suffrage in Japan.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Encouraged by the continuing firmness of British Government securities, most industrials improved modestly on stock markets today. Among the best spots were textiles and selected brewery and colliery issues.

The Phonograph Manufacturers Association appealed to the National Production Authority yesterday for help in overcoming a serious shortage in electric phonograph motors. The association represents eleven independent phonograph producers who are unable to meet retail demand for their products during this heavy selling season.

The names of 2,376 persons suspected of having registered illegally for the November election have been listed thus far by the State Attorney General's Election Frauds Bureau. The suspects will be challenged on their residence qualifications if they appear at the voting polls here.
Following is the text of a speech by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in Chicago last night as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
Rise of the branch store does not mean the decline of the parent department store, nor is it yet clear that multiple night openings will result in sales volume to offset added expenses.

If signs mean anything in the eleven counties that brag a bit about picking all the Presidential winners since William McKinley in 1896, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower looks like the victor this time, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

Secretary of the Navy Dan A. Kimball charged here last night that some American politicians were as adept as the Soviet printing presses and the Kremlin loudspeaker in the exploitation of untruths for propaganda purposes.

GARY, Ind., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued here tonight by President Truman disputing Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's Detroit speech dealing with withdrawal of United States forces from Korea:

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Belatedly today British newspapers informed their readers of the pledge by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to go to Korea if elected in search of a way to bring the war to an honorable conclusion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused the Shell Oil Company of setting up a marketing plan which the commission said might weaken competition or create a monopoly n the kerosene and fuel oil business.

LONDON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Communist China joined North Korea today in demanding that Peiping and Pyongyang representatives take part in the United Nations debate on Communist charges the Allies used germ warfare in Korea.

Viscount Astor, American-born member of the House of Lords, who died in London on Sept. 30 at the age of 73, left one-half of his interest in his American trust estate, in equal shares, to his five children. This was disclosed yesterday when a will disposing of his American estate was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Oct. 27 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's top military directorate, the Standing Group, is expected to tell civilian leaders on the Atlantic Council here tomorrow that the military power of the Soviet Union is still as great a threat to Western safety as it was a year ago and that Allied rearmament cannot be allowed to falter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on whether a union truck driver might be dismissed for refusing to cross another union's picket lines to make deliveries for his employer.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 27 -- In an unexpected development, the State School Boards Association today shelved endorsement of a resolution urging the establishment of the United States Office of Education as an independent agency of the Federal Government under the direction of a National Lay Board of Education.
John Foster Dulles, chief foreign-policy adviser to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, declared last night that "war is the ultimate failure of statesmanship."

Trading was light in New York commodity futures markets yesterday. Rubber dropped 75 to 70 points on the New York Commodity Exchange following reports that the Government had ordered the final 7,000 tons of rubber under its contract with Siam. Rubber trading was limited to 230 tons.

Lee Tracy, currently portraying television's sleuth extraordinary, Martin Kane, may star on Broadway this season in Robert E. Sherwood's war comedy of the Thirties, "Idiot's Delight." He would undertake the role of Harry Van, the brassy song and dance man, a part he played last year in the New York City Center Theatre Company presentation.

ABOARD THE TRUMAN TRAIN, in Northern Ohio, Oct. 27 -- On election night, when politicians are eagerly watching the returns, President Truman will be aboard his train, rolling back to Washington. That was the announcement today from the railroading White House.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 27 -A twin-engine Air Force transport plane crashed and sank in the Hudson River about a mile north of this city today.

The large amount of new capacity being brought into operation by the domestic steel industry in its defense expansion program made possible the new weekly production record achieved by the mills last week -- 2,221,000 net tons of raw steel.
To introduce a little order into the chaos of the clothes closet, the homemaker might consider some of the new accessories available in stores here.

Urging that an equal voice be given to young physicians in the formation of policies of medical associations, Dr. Gervais W. McAuliffe was installed last night as the new president of the New York County Medical Society. He stressed that more and more service must be the first aim of modern physicians.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 27 -Now it turns out that Jack Scarbath, the brilliant split-T quarterback who led Maryland to three straight football victories over Navy, has done the midshipmen a favor.

The Propeller Club of the United States plans an all-out "selling" campaign throughout the nation in an effort to win understanding and support from people who are now luke-warm about their own merchant marine, Hugh Gallagher, president of the club, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Truman told Democratic party workers today that, if they did their job between now and Nov. 4, the Democrats could "lick" the big-money boys" just as "we licked them" four years ago.
Congratulations on your lead editorial of Thursday, Oct. 23, in which you reaffirmed your support of Dwight D. Eisenhower.
Two arguments, one used on each side, make many of us very sad in this Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Post Office Department, it is understood on good authority, has asked Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, to make a settlement on 9,542 pieces of mail sent post-free under his Congressional franking privilege that the department has adjudged to be not frankable.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- The Government today banned electric utilities in the Pacific Northwest from delivering power to large users if contracts for such delivery were signed after Sept. 1.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 27 (AP) -- The hard-riding Mexican Army team tonight won its second straight international jumping event at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show, beating the United States' civilian team by one and two-fifth seconds.
SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 27 (UP) -- The Federal Government will spend $10,000,000,000 on production of two classes of Boeing jet bombers, a company official said today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, campaigning across Pennsylvania today, promised a program of more housing, expanded Social Security, better medical care, a sounder dollar, and more education, without regimentation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear arguments on whether the provisions of the 1947 Portal-to-Portal Act imposed a two-year limit beyond which the Federal Government might not file lawsuits for violations of the child labor laws.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Sweden reversed her position today on the issue of a special fund for grants-in-aid and low-interest loans for economic development in under-developed countries.

THE valley lay between two low mountains in Nova Scotia. There was a village and, about sixteen miles away, a town. But the valley farmers lived comparatively isolated lives of strenuous and perpetual labor. Strong men and outwardly simple ones, they were as complex and troubled as men everywhere. But few of them were well educated in the bookish sense.
LONDON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Queen Elizabeth presided at her first royal film performance tonight.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 27 -- Howard Morton, Huntington, C. C. and Pete Burke, Cold Spring, combined to post a 33, 34 -- 67, three strokes under par, to win the weekly amateur-pro of the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association at the Fresh Meadow club today.

TEXARKANA, Ark., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon told a yelling Texas-Arkansas crowd today that President Truman and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson were "traitors to the high principles" of the Democratic party. He said they tolerated and defended Communists in the Government.

GARY, Ind., Oct. 27 -- President Truman issued a formal statement tonight accusing Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower of making a "thoroughly dishonest" effort to shift responsibility for the withdrawal of United States troops in Korea in 1949 from himself to the State Department.

S. M. Chartock's new Gilbert and Sullivan company, which seemed to be having some trouble last week in "The Mikado," appeared more comfortable in its offering of "The Pirates of Penzance" at the Mark Hellinger last night.

In sarcastic vein Dr. Luther H. Gulick, executive director of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, wrote City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses yesterday that the latter was "wise to resign" from the committee.
Dorothy Froehlich, coloratura soprano from Pittsburgh, made her recital debut last evening at Carnegie Recital Hall.

DETROIT, Oct. 27 -- A pioneer and comprehensive health plan that is termed a "revolutionary project" wil be introduced in a small Israeli town next month, it was reported here today. The plan eventually will embrace the entire country to help solve the fledgling nation's taxing medical needs of her record influx of immigrants.

The stage was cleared of musicians for a time last night at the Museum of Modern Art. The distinguished Leopold Stokowski, who was contributing his services to the cause of contemporary American music, departed temporarily with his soloists and small orchestra. But there was a series of sounds from a loudspeaker, and these in turn came from a tape recorder.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Tom Robbins, United States senior golf champion, continued his mastery of par, as well as the opposition, today to lead the championship flight safely through the first round of the North and South seniors invitation championship.

The appointment of Prof. Edward Davison as acting director of the Hunter College School of General Studies was announced at the college yesterday. Professor Davison succeeds Prof. Broderick Cohen who retired last month after serving as director twenty-eight years.
The text of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's address last night at Madison Square Garden, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follows:
The texts of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's addresses yesterday Queens Borough Hall in Kew Gardens, at Mineola, L. I., and at the Commodore Hotel follow:

MADRID, Oct. 28 -- Gen. Hoyt M. Vandenberg, Chief of Staff of the United States Air Force, arrived this evening with his wife for a two-day visit during which he will have talks with Spanish military leaders.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois was heard and seen by crowds officially estimated at 300,000 yesterday as he campaigned in Manhattan and northern New Jersey stressing Democratic gains in employment, housing, social welfare and the fight against communism.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- The long golf season in Westchester ended at the Knollwood Country Club today with a pro-amateur tournament staged by the Westchester County Golf Association. The campaign closed amid low temperatures and cold rain as eighty-four pairs competed.
Cotton trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices for active months were 19 to 37 points lower than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Officers of the United Mine Workers were reported today to have served notice on the anthracite operators that they expected an agreement by the end of this week. Negotiations were recessed today until Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The State Department disclosed today that Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, had an informal agreement with the United States Government that he would not employ on his staff United States citizens who were Communists.

Business men may put out the best annual reports and produce the most of many products but their relations with the public are all wrong, Charles Allen Thomas, president of Monsanto Company, declared last night.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 28 -- The need for improving school services in the rural and farm areas of the state and for providing an adequate program of health education for all school children was emphasized today at the closing session of the twentieth annual meeting of the State School Boards Association.

An eleven-man jury awarded Duane Jones $300,000 last night in his suit against nine of his former employes, the Manhattan Soap Company and Frank G. Burke, an official of Manhattan. The ruling, however, excepted the Manhattan Shirt Company and Donald Gill, a former vice president of the Jones agency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Present-day teaching of the "Three R's," which has been under sharp attack in recent years, was defended in a pamphlet issued today by the Association for Supervisors and Curriculum Development of the National Education Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Percy Bassett of Philadelphia won a split verdict over Charley Riley of St. Louis tonight in a closely fought featherweight boxing match at the Uline Arena.

RENO, Nev., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, rapped back today at recent criticism by President Truman and the Democratic Presidential candidate, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois. Mr. Stevenson, in a New England talk, referred to Senator McCarran as a man "who used to be a Democrat."

The Rev. Dr. Frederic Sutter, pastor of Trinity Lutheran Church of Stapleton, S. I., was re-elected president of the board of trustees of Wagner Lutheran College for his thirty-fifth consecutive term of one year at the annual meeting of the board yesterday afternoon at the college on Grymes Hill, S. I.

There is a new air of calm confidence among campaign advisers to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois that the political miracle of 1948, which kept President Truman in the White House, is going to be repeated in the polling booths next Tuesday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 29 -- United Nations troops recaptured at noon today the crest of "Sniper Ridge," north of Kumhwa on Korea's central front. The ridge was lost last night in a savage Chinese attack.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- For the next three months or so, Jose Vela Zanetti of Leon, Spain, and Delancey Street, Manhattan, will be spending eight to twelve hours a day, seven days a week, inside a long canvas tent set up smack in the middle of a United Nations public lobby.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson brought his campaign for New York's key block of forty-five electoral votes to a climax last night at a rousing, demonstrative rally in Madison Square Garden attended by 25,000 persons. At least as many others were turned away for lack of space.

VIENNA, Oct. 28 -- The crisis caused last week by the inability of the People's party and the Socialist wing of Austria's coalition Government to agree on next year's budget was resolved today by the Government's resignation and reappointment to conduct the nation's affairs until the general elections in February.

New York State voters who reject both the Republican eagle and the Democratic star on next Tuesday's ballot will have a choice of four minor party candidates for President, four for Vice President, of whom two are women, and five for United States Senator.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The question of a coordinated housing policy for the coal and steel workers of Western Europe, as a means of increasing production in those industries, was formally raised today by the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, or the Schuman plan.

Net income of the United States Steel Corporation for the strike-affected quarter ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $30,405,472, equal to 92 cents a common share, Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman, reported yesterday. He also announced that directors had declared a dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock, the same as had been paid in recent quarters.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 28 -- The West German Government is "determined" to speed ratification by the Bundestag of the European Defense Community Treaty and the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies, despite the rebuff by France over the Saar's future and the breakdown of negotiations on that issue.

KEARNY, N. J., Oct. 28 -- A teletype alarm was broadcast today for the arrest of 16-year-old Claus Eischen for questioning in the murder of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hans Eischen Sr. of 339 Schuyler Avenue, this city.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 28 -- Of all the Midwest Farm Belt states, Iowa is regarded as the assayed factors. One is, how far and how deep the persistent forward movement of Governor Stevenson has run among rank and file farmers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 -- Exposing children gradually to household dangers such as fire, water, electricity and "poison" was advocated today by Dr. Harry F. Dietrich, a Los Angeles pediatrician, as a means of protecting them from accidents.
Michigan State still leads, but Maryland is a fast-closing second in the battle for the No. 1 football rating in the nation.

Three more faculty members of city colleges were suspended without pay yesterday and face dismissal next week for refusing to answer questions by the Senate subcommittee investigating communism in schools.

Ann de Ceballos, soprano, made her debut in recital at Town Hall last evening, singing a program of works in English, French, German, Italian and Gaelic. (The soprano is a native of Aberdeen, married to a Venezuelan).

More than $14,000,000 of family stock holdings in two of the nation's major industrial enterprises -- the Anheuser-Busch Brewery of St. Louis and the Corning Glass Works of Corning, N. Y. -- will be placed on the market today by nationwide syndicates of investment houses.

A new chamber music ensemble, the Harpsichord Quartet, began its first season last night and presented the first of four concerts that it will give at Carnegie Recital Hall. The group featured early music, but as it will do in its future programs, it also included modern works.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 28 -- State Treasurer Walter T. Margetts announced today that Federal Social Security benefits had become available to public employes in New Jersey not otherwise covered by state or local pension systems.
The stock market was unable to break its stalemate yesterday. The approach of Election Day turned a damper on activity and prices were left slightly lower at the close.

Merlin Hall Aylesworth, first president of the National Broadcasting Company, former publisher of The New York World-Telegram, and one-time utilities executive, left an estate of less than $10,000, according to a petition for probate of his will filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

MANILA, Oct. 28 -- The American representatives at yesterday's United States-Philippines security talks made no specific new commitments with regard to aid to the Philippines, informed American quarters said today. It was stated, however, that sympathetic consideration was given a Philippine proposal for increasing the Filipino armed forces with American assistance and the matter has been referred to the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff for further study.
Opponents of three of the six Congressional incumbents in New York County have sought to make a major issue of absenteeism.

In this third and final installment of discussion of candidates for judicial office we take up the Municipal Court, four districts, and one City Court contest. As usual we record the recommendations of bar associations as a trustworthy guide to voters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- In the subdued luxury of the board room of the Riggs National Bank, which was filled with men who looked as if they belonged in board rooms, R. Stanley Dollar lost today the steamship line his father founded nearly fifty years ago.
WINNIPEG, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Major North American grain exchanges, including the Winnipeg Grain Exchange, are considering switching back to the old closing time of 2:15 P. M., Eastern standard time.

Today will mark the twenty-third anniversary of the "big break" in the stock market on Oct. 29, 1929. The stock market that memorable day was quite different from that on a current trading day. Then, it will be recalled, 16,410,030 shares, a record number, were transferred.

Appeals to THE NEW YORK TIMES to switch its editorial support from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for President to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois continued to roll in yesterday, heavily dominating a new tide of messages touched off by Monday night's television broadcast by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

The letter of Russell Lynes printed Oct. 21, charging that General Eisenhower has failed to pin-point corruption, completely misses the point that corruption under the present Democratic Administration is not of the pin-point variety. It is spread through almost every department of Government and involves many top officials.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The influential Manchester Guardian praised both American Presidential candidates today.

Living in New York is not always a bed of roses. There are the crowding, the frantic pace and a certain tension which the presence of multitudes always generates. But there are also advantages in intellectual and esthetic stimulation which no small city and many large ones cannot duplicate.

Henry W. Grunewald, Washington "mystery figure," testified yesterday for two hours before the special Brooklyn Federal grand jury. Later Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo delayed until Nov. 6 action on Mr. Grunewald's application for an order restraining the panel from asking him any further questions.

A hardwood floor on the third floor of the Museum of the City of New York became yesterday a cobbled street. Wagon wheels rumbled, horses' hooves clattered in a convincing illusion of a street scene laid a century ago in the heart of New York.

In the outline of the new structure of the United Nations; published yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES, Czechoslovakia should not have been listed as represented in the Economic and Social Council, having been defeated in yesterday's balloting by Yugoslavia, whose term expires in 1955.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, starting a three-day campaign tour of the metropolitan area, hit back yesterday at Democratic criticism of his announcement that he would, if elected President, go to Korea to seek an early and honorable end of the war.

A dividend of $2 a share has been authorized by directors of Boeing Airplane Company, it was announced yesterday by William M. Allen, president. The dividend will be distributed on Nov. 26 to holders of the 1,623,681 outstanding capital shares.
Prices of most commodity futures held firm in the New York markets yesterday with trading generally dull. Many of the commodities were influenced by buying and selling abroad.

POMFRET, Conn., Oct. 28 -- Wendell Mansfield is satisfied with his Pomfret School eleven's performances in its last two games, but he feels the Red and Black would move into high gear if more speed were generated in the team's attack.
HIBBING, Minn., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of President Truman's Speech here tonight:

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Stock market prices were less decided today. But apart from the motor shares the undertone remained firm. Motors were depressed by authoritative predictions that harder times were coming for the industry. Associated concerns also were lower.

Arnie Weinmeister, left tackle and co-captain of the Football Giants, yesterday served as an assistant to Coach Steve Owen in helping to explain the Giants' two straight defeats at the weekly luncheon in the Polo Grounds' press room.

Net income of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $43,313,353, against $38,579,175 in the preceding twelve months, it was announced yesterday.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower saved forty precious minutes from a day packed with political activity here yesterday afternoon for a locker-room talk about sports with thirty-seven coaches, promoters and players.

INTERVALE, N. H., Oct. 28 -- New England's skiing problems and the prospects for the 1952-53 winter season were discussed thoroughly today as the two-day annual winter activities conference of the New England Council ended. Not since these conventions came into being seven years ago has there been so productive a session as this year's.

When educators turn to parents and children for opinions on how school programs and practices might be modified, the answers are likely to be pointed and direct, an experiment recently conducted in California along these lines reveals.

The mishaps that marred the maiden arrival of the French liner Flandre July 30 were caused by the failure of the vessel's electrical and feed pump systems, Henri Chardon, director of the company's passenger and freight traffic, disclosed yesterday.
A "two-gun" man boasting about a couple of murders held up eight persons in a loan company office at 137 East Fifty-seventh Street yesterday morning and escaped with a few hundred dollars.

BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- United States Headquarters in Berlin reported tonight that a United States Army officer and his car were missing after having started out on the Autobahn that crosses the Soviet zone of Germany between Berlin and the British zone.

It is probable that by the end of work tomorrow all heat, and all heat-in-spired energy everywhere, will be created from natural gas, the rays of the sun or the byproducts brought about by stripping the atom of its former identity.

Plans are being advanced rapidly for the forty-fifth annual autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York to be held on Nov. 6, 7 and 8 at Essex House for the benefit of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind.

Quiz shows have been a stock staple of television ever since the scientists put a light in the home screen, but this season these divertisements seem to have hit a new high in artificiality. And the slips are showing.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Constance Morabito's My Celeste won the feature on today's Garden State card at a mile and one sixteenth. She defeated six other allowance horses in finishing two lengths ahead of J. Gavegnano's Pensava.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Two of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's campaign organizations reported today they had collected a total of $998,967 and spent $739,268.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 28 -- A retired deputy fire chief and his wife were suffocated by smoke early today in a fire that swept their home here at 3419 Ventnor Avenue.

Bond Issues totaling $15,000,000 of San Francisco City and County, Calif., were posted yesterday for public sale on Dec. 8. The offerings will consist of general obligations to finance various public improvements.
A ten-week-old wage battle between the General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., was settled yesterday on the company's terms.

The twilight of a bookmaking career was described yesterday at the departmental trial of thirty suspended plainclothes men accused of having received graft from Harry Gross, who has boasted that he used to handle bets totaling $20,000,000 a year.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- International and governmental action to lower immigration barriers was urged today at the annual conference of field directors of the American Joint Distribution Committee, which aids needy Jews abroad.

Most upstate Democratic county chairmen concede privately that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is a stronger candidate in their areas a week before election than was Gov. Thomas E. Dewey four years ago. Nevertheless they have strong hopes that the situation will change in their favor before Election Day, largely because of a trend they profess to see as the time for voting draws nearer.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 28 (AP) -- The second Wesleyan University fraternity in a month has seceded from the national body because it intended to accept a Negro.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will campagin by motorcade through parts of Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Westchester today, on the second day of his three-day tour of the metropolitan area.

DETROIT, Oct. 28 -- With the specific view of elevating agriculture and its allied fields to a professional status in Isreal and to correct the young state's "present occupational maldistribution," Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, will undertake before the end of this year a rural vocational education program.

Net income of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation for the first nine months this year declined to $70,739,620 from $76,953,965 earned in the 1951 period. However, an extra dividend of 50 cents was declared yesterday in addition to the regular quarterly of 50 cents, both payable on Dec. 1. No extra was paid a year ago.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The most serious and widespread forest and brush fires in years burned fiercely today throughout much of the Eastern half of the United States.

BOSTON, Oct. 28 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower lost an almost sure chance to insure victory in the Presidential election in one blow when he failed to drop Senator Richard M. Nixon of California as his running mate, W. H. Lawrence, a political reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said today.
Designs printed from photographs and some patterns made up of drawings of Japanese scenes appear in two new groups of Covington decorative fabrics.

LONDON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A field of forty-three of the best handicap horses in the country is expected to go to the post tomorrow for the 110th running of the Cambridgeshire Stakes, second leg of the autumn "double."

The city announced yesterday that it would bring suit tomorrow to prevent the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company, a subsidiary of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, from discontinuing passenger service pending court action.

It was Sir Stafford Cripps, while still Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, who first asserted that American aid would do Europe more harm than good if continued after the expiration of the Marshall Plan. "I hope no Government representative and no responsible journalist in the United States will suggest a continuation of, or a substitute for, Marshall aid when the program ends," he said to this correspondent in the spring of 1950.
A Columbia University law student who attempted to confound the New York State Attorney General had his dreams of glory rudely snuffed out yesterday. He also lost his right to vote.
Autumn's robustly flavored vegetables -- cauliflower, broccoli and Brussels sprouts -- and the ever-present spinach are the subjects for today's recipes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- An ambitious approach to a solution of Europe's recurring economic and financial emergencies, one designed to end massive annual appropriations for economic aid grants abroad, has been under discussion in conferences here on next year's Mutual Security program.

THE early reports on the Adirondack deer hunting are far from bright, but the majority of those who trained out for the opening over the past week-end indicated that the deer seemed quite plentiful but were difficult to find because of the heavy cover.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 28 -- The season's first rainclouds are rolling over Israel announcing coming winter storms and the Jewish Agency for Palestine and Israeli Government officials are working overtime to put sound roofs over the heads and dry floors under the feet of nearly 250,000 inhabitants of the country's immigrant camps.

Mounting opposition to higher duty payments on raw wool -- technically in the form of a fee on top of existing rates -- was cited by foreign trade sources yesterday as likely to bring modification of pending proposals for increased import levies on the commodity.
The Eisenhower campaign has changed materially in the last month.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 -- Jerry Wald today signed a long-term contract with Columbia Pictures under which he will function as the studio's executive producer with the title of vice president. Harry Cohn, president, announced the deal less than twenty-four hours after the producer had arranged the termination of the contract between Wald-Krasna Productions and R. K. O. Radio Pictures.
The Indians' Early Wynn and Robin Roberts of the Phils were the most effective night-game hurlers during the 1952 major league season.

James R. Macduff, Commissioner of the New York State Motor Vehicle Bureau, said yesterday that he was "very much in favor" of periodic inspection of automobiles by state-operated stations and periodic examination of persons holding licenses to drive.
GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- The United States received a little tit for tat today on its measures of agricultural protection. United States farmers will lose some markets as a result.

Expansion of private debt from $141,000,000,000 to $277,000,000,000 since the end of World War II warrants study by banks and factors because of a possible decline in national income in the years ahead, Dr. Jules Backman, Professor of Economics, New York University, pointed out yesterday.

David Colin, president of the Colin Pharmacal Company, Inc., 36-31 Thirty-third Street, Long Island City, Queens, began a suit in Supreme Court yesterday to compel Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein to return the company's books and records.

A conference of representatives of several of the city's retail chain stores with Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet in his Municipal Building office yesterday agreed to discontinue immediately the sale of cellulose-type masks, which department tests found to be flammable.

Ted Atkinson's triple highlighted yesterday's Empire - at - Jamaica racing card. For those among the 17,696 fans who followed Teddy, an otherwise dismal afternoon was indeed profitable. The popular pilot scored in the second, sixth and seventh events and was third in the eighth. He had no other mounts.
Southern California and Purdue made the biggest gains in The United Press football ratings yesterday as Michigan State held the No. 1 spot for the sixth consecutive week.

Unforeseen events must be met as circumstances dictate, but we certainly should make every effort to prepare adequately for those events we can foresee. May I use your columns to urge both of our Presidential candidates to consider thoughtfully the most important single foreseeable foreign policy question which the new President will face during his term of office.
Washington, D. C., continues to remain a high point of interest to the service man. And the ...
TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 29 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1,417 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

It was in a lyric, frequently impassioned, reading of the Brahms Sonata that Jeanne Mitchell last night really showed her mettle. Barring a few awkward bowings in the slow movement, this was a warm, temperamental example of violin playing from one of the most talented of the younger set of American instrumentalists.
The Rangers, who have improved steadily since they made their home debut a week ago, will oppose the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.
Two sharply different oral portraits of John David Provoo, treason trial defendant in Federal Court, were drawn by opposing counsel yesterday for jurors who listened, entranced.
The White Crest Company of Baltimore has been made local distributor for the entire line of home appliances by Universal Major Electric Appliances, Inc., of Lima, Ohio.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- A Four-Power recommendation calling for an increase in the United Nations relief budget for Arab refugees was supported today by a number of Latin-American and European countries.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Civilian leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were warned by their top military advisers here today not to relax in their current long-term defense build-up in the belief that "special weapons," such as atom bombs or guided missiles, could yet obviate the need for trained military manpower.

Medical care at Kings County Hospital is good in spite of city regulations that hamper its administration, Dr. Haven Emerson, director of a recent study of the Brooklyn institution, reported yesterday to the Women's City Club of New York.

Three steps for a media man to take if he is to become creative were suggested yesterday by Sherwood Dodge, vice president of Foote, Cone Belding, at the 1952 Eastern Annual Conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies in the Roosevelt Hotel. Mr. Dodge was a speaker at the opening sessions of the two-day meeting which has its theme, "Creative Progress is Our Responsibility."

HIBBING, Minn., Oct. 28 -- President Truman rolled through Minnesota today, attacking McCarthyism and the press and contending that a Republican election victory would reverse the revolution of the common man. He said this "peaceful revolution," achieved by the Democratic party, had brought prosperity to all Americans.

A 44-year-old longshoreman was under arrest yesterday on an indictment that alleged he had extorted $6,290 from a newsprint loading company by threatening the concern with labor trouble at its East River pier.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Graduate School of Journalism of Columbia University has angrily rejected a suggestion by a Columbia graduate that he resign. This was disclosed today in a letter written by Dean Ackerman to Maurice C. Hull, president of the Columbia University Club of Cleveland.

At Rikers Island workhouse, a number of "toughies" who have committed some of the lesser transgressions, have been cast in the roles of Santa's helpers. Fifty men, some old and discouraged, others young and just restless, are whiling away their thirty and sixty-day sentences, mending and renovating broken and discarded toys for 100 Police Athletic League Christmas parties.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- The General Assembly, which has been proceeding at slow speed since it convened two weeks ago, is slowing down to a virtual stop while delegates await the outcome of the United States election a week from now.
HOUSTON, Oct. 28 -- Jesse H. Jones, Houston financier and former Cabinet member, is contributing to both the Democratic and Republican parties, he disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board postponed today a ruling on the request of National Airlines for an investigation of the purported purchase of stock of Colonial Airlines by Eastern Airlines.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- The delivery of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's speech here last night in which the Wisconsin Republican attacked Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois as unfit to be President, marked the end of a bizarre undercover research program by both Republican and Democrats.

YONKERS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Direct Gal, a 25-1 outsider, scored a half-length victory in the feature Grand Circuit event at the Yonkers Raceway tonight, pacing the mile in 2:10 over a strip classed as "good" after an afternoon of rain, sleet and snow.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced the arrest of Charles Edward Hopkins, 21 years old, in Jacksonville today in connection with a wave of kidnapping assaults and armed robberies in Georgia, Alabama and Tennessee last week.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 28 (Reuters) -- Governor Sir Evelyn Baring announced today an economic and social new deal for this British colony. However, his reservation that it could not be carried out in an "atmosphere of unrest and anxiety" was underlined by reports of new terrorist slayings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Automobile manufacturers were assured by the National Production Authority today that they will receive an "equitable" share of whatever extra steel is found available for civilian uses for the first quarter of 1953.
Six hundred board members from voluntary health and welfare agencies met all day yesterday to discuss the barriers to their giving efficient citizen leadership to their agencies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Local price stabilization boards are to be set up in cities throughout the country in a move to decentralize the application of price regulations, Tighe E. Woods, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, announced today.

The election of the next President and Vice President of the United States is, of course, the Number One task for all of us on Tuesday, but hardly less important is the job of selecting the members of the Eighty-third Congress. More than one-third of the Senate and the entire House of Representatives will be chosen on Election Day.

New appointments to the Council of the Diocese of New York of the Protestant Episcopal Church and of the department heads of church agencies were announced yesterday by Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan at a luncheon marking his fifth anniversary as head of the diocese.

Senator McCarran of Nevada is best known in the East for his sponsorship of the wretchedly prejudiced Immigration Act of 1952 which bears his name. But this is not Mr. McCarran's only claim to a questionable fame. This Democratic chairman of the Senate's powerful Judiciary Committee fought long and hard against a humane and liberal Refugee bill.
If Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein has his way John Cacopardo, 42 years old, who in 1937 was convicted of murder and sentenced to thirty years to life, will soon be a free man.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- President Truman, campaigning for Governor Stevenson through Minnesota, assailed Senator McCarthy today. He said the Republicans were trying to win the election with tactics of "fear and smear" and "slander and character assassination."

The Federal Maritime Board hearing into the proposed dual rate structure of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference opened here yesterday morning. It is being held in the Department of Commerce offices at 2 West Forty-third Street, before Board Examiner C. W. Robinson.

As one who has nothing but admiration for the fair way in which THE TIMES has covered the present political campaign I am writing to you in the hope that though the views expressed in this letter differ materially from the position taken in your editorial columns you may feel that they are of sufficient interest to your readers to merit publication.

DURING the first half of the twentieth century the pace of history seems to have increased beyond human capacity to keep up with it. Never before have so many epochal changes crowded into so few years, changes that fundamentally alter the circumstances of human living and confront us all with dazzling new possibilities and frightful probabilities.

LONDON, Oct. 28 (Reuters) -- Communist China demanded today that Britain hand over seventy-one aircraft left by the Chinese at Hong Kong airport and legally recognized as American property, or "bear all the consequences."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28 -- Jordan Olivar, whose surprising Yale team has taken the measure of five of six opponents for one of the most impressive records in the East, has a tailor-made pep talk to keep his favored charges on edge for Saturday's contest with Dartmouth in the Bowl.
Three of the five oil companies which reported results of nine months' operations yesterday showed substantially improved earnings over a year ago, with two establishing new records for the period.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois today urged a four-point program to fight inflation and asked American women to back it up by voting for Democratic candidates.

Delivering a political speech at Minneapolis on Monday Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon read to his audience a hitherto unpublished memorandum dealing with a high policy question in the matter of Korea. The memorandum was dated Sept. 26, 1947. It was signed by the Secretary of Defense.

Paris, Oct. 28 (AP) -- France, Italy and Britain received the biggest shares of $729,000,000 the United States has split among European nations this year for defense weapons under its off-shore procurement program. The program seeks to bolster Europe's economy, build its productive capacity and furnish arms for the North Atlantic Treaty nations.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 28 (AP) -- The United States civilian team finally broke Mexico's domination of international competition at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show with a perfect ride to win the pair jumping event tonight.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 28 -- For the second time in two years, Connecticut is electing two United States Senators simultaneously, and the issue appears very much in doubt.

IT wasn't particularly dignified. In fact, it might not even qualify as "conduct becoming an officer and a gentleman." But Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman had not yet become the president of the National Horse Show Association, bringing to it his down-to-earth naturalness and utter distaste for stuffed-shirt pomposity. At that time, though, he was merely taking a few practice swings, running a horse show at the Squadron A Armory.

Assailing Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, for his speech of Monday night, Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal party candidate for Senator, said yesterday that it was time Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and other Republican leaders declared just where they stood on him and his methods.

William J. Grede, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, assailed President Truman yesterday for having said that business men favor unemployment. Mr. Grede, who also is president of the National Council of the Young Men's Christian Association, spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives of New York in the Roosevelt Hotel.

SEIGNIORY CLUB, Que., Oct. 28 (Canadian Press) -- The harmony which exists between Washington and Ottawa is highly prized in both capitals, Denis Harvey, director of the commodities branch of the Canadian Federal Trade Department, said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, was host last evening at a dinner attended by delegates from five Asian or Middle Eastern countries that have displayed neutralist tendencies in the East-West conflict, as well as by delegates from member nations of the Soviet bloc.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M. Oct. 28 -- Political analysts of hinterland counties regarded as election weathervanes generally have ignored an entire state that may prove to have staged a "dress rehearsal" of next week's general election two years ago.

Baseball's major-minor executive council drew up a new bonus rule here yesterday that would put a $6,000 limit on bonuses given to promising young players and make it hard for clubs to retain all players who received bonuses, The Associated Press reported.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Drought reports today indicated increasingly critical developments in winter wheat, but while the market for wheat showed strength early it lacked buying power to maintain rallies and prices receded from early tops.

An ex-convict, once accused of defrauding the Government of $692,269 in taxes, was indicted yesterday on charges of cheating a commercial credit house of $36,190, which he said he needed to save his brother from the electric chair.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 156 Korean war casualties in a new list that included 20 killed, 121 wounded and 15 missing in action. No casualties were reported from New Jersey or Connecticut. Those from New York were:

Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, was forced to abandon a campaign speech at last night's Democratic rally in Madison Square Garden to make room for an entertainment program arranged by Volunteers for Stevenson.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- Sixteen small nations opened a drive today to revive a controversial global pact on freedom of information that the United States and Britain have attacked as a threat to press liberty.

At last the Theatre de Lys has flung open its doors to culture and the public at 121 Christopher Street in the Village. "A club theatre for members only," the program announces with some finality. As a building, the Theatre de Lys is comfortable, neat and attractive, with a well-designed apron stage where interesting performances might conveniently be mounted.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Lord Elton declared in the House of Lords today that the United States Federal Bureau of Investigation had in its possession a recording of a statement by Donald D. MacLean, one of two missing Foreign Office diplomats, that he was not only a Communist, but "a proselytizing Communist."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, sentenced to die for giving atomic secrets to Russia, made another effort today to save themselves from electrocution at Sing Sing Prison. They petitioned the Supreme Court to reconsider their pleas for review of their sentence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Thirty-three witnesses speaking for church, welfare, citizenship, legal, labor, patriotic, farm and veterans' organizations filed before the President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization today to say what should be done about the McCarran-Walter Act.

Ten ships measuring 72,508 gross tons were added last month to the list of vessels under construction the world over to specifications of the American Bureau of Shipping. In the same period twenty ships of 71,460 tons were completed by various shipyards.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 28 (Reuters) -- Iraq's four political parties jointly demanded today abrogation of the British-Iraqi friendship treaty, which permits British troops to be stationed in this oil-rich kingdom.
CHESTER, Ill., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Rebellious prisoners at Menard State Prison tonight agreed to release three of their hostages and meet with prison and state officials.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 28 -- One of the nation's leading natural gas and oil research directors gazed in to a "hydrocarbon crystal ball" today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon, who recently resigned from the Republican party and announced his support of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic candidate for President, said today he ranked "yellow journalism" alongside communism as one of the "country's greatest internal dangers."

RACINE, Wis., Oct. 28 -- Wisconsin farmers favor Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for President by a margin of 2 to 1 despite a slow gain in popularity for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, according to a survey completed Oct. 15 and made public today by the Wisconsin Agriculturist and Farmer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Senator Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois stood alone today among Republican party leaders in publicly endorsing Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's sweeping attack upon Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- For the past three days the big English manufacturing city of Manchester has been out of bounds to United States Air Force men because of serious attacks by gangs of youths on Air Force police patrols in the city.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue is demanding $307,000 in retroactive income taxes from the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee. The taxes are on the more than $1,000,000 raised and distributed between 1942 and 1949 for aid and resettlement of Spanish Republican refugees.

The National Labor Relations Board has just made a three-to-two decision affecting the union shop, each side frankly admitting that its point of view may well injure collective bargaining relationships.
Obsolete regulatory laws are seriously hampering railroad development throughout the country, William White, president of the New York Central System, said yesterday.

A bill to grant increases up to $300 a year to pensioned city employes now receiving less than $1,200 annually was passed unanimously yesterday by the City Council. The measure, which has the approval of Mayor Impellitteri, now goes to the Board of Estimate.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Yugoslavia submitted to the Legal Committee of the General Assembly today a resolution asking priority for the codification of rules and regulations governing diplomatic immunity, "in the interest of confirming and restoring principles observed since the Middle Ages."

A decline last week of 1,235,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 120,767,000 barrels, compared with 122,002,000 a week earlier and 121,069,000 a year ago.
The Federal Maritime Board heard only one witness under cross-examination yesterday at its inquiry into the dual rate structure of a steamship conference.

Elimination of political influences and issues from Federal agencies responsible for regulation of transport in this country and immediate expansion of the merchant marine were urged yesterday by the National Defense Transportation Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, today urged a little walking and bus-riding upon military personnel and civilians assigned to the military establishment. The reason: a more economical use of Government-owned vehicles in the District of Columbia area.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- A Chicago teacher who earns $2,700 a year has sent a $1,000 contribution from her savings to the Citizens for Eisenhower headquarters in New York to help in the Republican Presidential nominee's campaign "to keep the country out of war."

CAMDEN, S. C., Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Camden Chronicle, a semi-weekly newspaper, said today it had received a two-column picture that purported to show Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower. Republican Presidential candidate, and his wife, dining with Negroes in Harlem.

TORONTO, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Maurice Richard of the Canadiens scored two goals tonight to tie the National Hockey League record at 324, but Montreal lost by 7 -- 5 to the Toronto Maple Leafs and dropped from first to second place.
Pro-election factors again held the stock market yesterday to a narrow channel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Britain and Canada have joined to ease a "pinch" in the United States in the supplies of aluminum result-from hydroelectric power shortages, the Defense Production Administration announced today.

Over the protest of Government counsel, the defense in the investment banking anti-trust trial succeeded yesterday in getting into the record documents relating to the compliance of defendants with the "blue-sky" regulations of certain states over the public issuance of securities.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 29 -- This normally Democratic state, which gave its Presidential elector votes to Republican nominees in 1920 and 1928, now appears, in the opinion of many observers, to warrant inclusion in the South's "doubtful" list as the national political campaign enters its final phase.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 -- Robert H. Wylie, manager of the port of San Francisco, said today on his return from the Far East that he had found there an undercurrent of fear that the Japanese were about to open a "devastating" shipping rate war.
The State Attorney General's office obtained warrants yesterday from Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh for the arrest of fourteen persons charged with "flagrant violations" of the Election Law.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 29 -- Wilhelm Schepmann, the last leader of Hitler's brown-shirted Storm Troopers, the S. A., is a candidate of the Refugee party in the communal elections in Gifhorn in Lower Saxony.
The threat of a strike of 3,500 newspaper delivery employes at midnight Friday was removed yesterday when union and management representatives reached agreement on terms of a new one- year contract.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Following are excerpts from an official translation of the speech on Korea delivered in Russian today by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky before the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:
Major league home-run production dropped almost 10 per cent during the 1952 baseball season.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A Korean war casualty list of 1,278 Americans killed, missing and wounded was issued by the Defense Department today for the week ending Oct. 24.
Twenty-five Republican Governors and three Democratic Governors of Southern states urged last night the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President.

OTHERS talk garrulously about our century's golden day -- John Hutchens lets it speak for itself, eloquently. In his excellent new book, "The American Twenties: A Literary Panorama,"* he has given us the tales and spoofs and plays, essays and poems and sketches that most truly represent a time of vigorously creative writing, unhazed by later clouds of gravely critical commentary.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The Standing Group of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, a body of experts, is thinking about the need for world-wide strategy instead of planning limited to the Atlantic pact area. This came to light today after the group's consultations with the treaty organization's council.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- President Truman tonight scorned Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's proposal to go to Korea, raising the question whether he could do better in ending that conflict than members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who already had been there.
NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Richer, a 3-year-old colt, won the 110th running of the Cambridgeshire Stakes today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct 29 -- The Soviet Union proposed tonight that the United Nations General Assembly create a new United Nations commission to take "immediate measures" for a peaceful settlement of the Korean question.

Roman Totenborg, violinist, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall with a program that had upon it not a single work designed for virtuoso display. It was a program of instrumental ensembles of various kinds and every piece a composition, classic or modern, of distinguished contents.

As is natural, election campaign news predominated in yesterday's newspaper. On an inside page, however, was a news story that bore the headline, "Kings County Care Is Termed 'Good.'" We hope our readers, including city officials, didn't stop with the headline.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 29 -- The Ministry of Finance announced today that a delegation of three senior officers of the Government would soon be leaving for the United States to negotiate a World Bank loan for expansion of the steel industry in India.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of President Truman's speech tonight at a dinner meeting of the Cook County Labor League for Political Education of the American Federation of Labor:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A length of the royal purple velvet being woven for Queen Elizabeth's coronation robes will be brought hero from London for a precoronation display.
Goblins, ghosts and witches were in the air in several sections of the city yesterday, two days ahead of Halloween.

In honor of the youngest chaplain serving in Korea -- 21-year-old Lieut. Henry Siegman -- seventy- five members of the Jerome Shary Post of the Jewish War Veterans, 36 West Forty-seventh Street, will donate a pint of blood each tonight at the Manhattan Blood Center of the American Red Cross.
R. C. Myers of the United States Steel Corporation has been elected a vice president of the Porcelain Enamel Institute.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- After twenty-four hours of uninterrupted work on water pipeline problems, William E. Thrasher, superintendent of Westchester Joint Water Works No. 1, returned at dawn this morning to his home here at 1185 Harrison Avenue and was killed an hour later in an accidental fall.

WATERLOO, Iowa, Oct. 29 (UP) -- The Republican "truth squad," following President Truman through rural Iowa, declared today that the Republican Eightieth Congress had enacted the present farm program.

Eight Congressional seats from Brooklyn and Staten Island will be at stake on Tuesday when voters go to the polls in the first test of a Republican plan to gain one and possibly two seats in the traditionally Democratic stronghold.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The President's Commission on Imigration and Naturalization, created to restudy alien policy in the light of controversies raised by the McCarran-Walter law that Congress passed over a White House veto, ended its hearings tentatively today after having heard more than 400 witnesses.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 -- Making handicapped persons self reliant was offered today to members of the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults as the goal toward which social workers and relatives of the disabled should work.

OSSINING, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Bishop Patrick J. Byrne, 65-year-old Apostolic Delegate to Korea, missing since the Communist invasion of Seoul where he was stationed, has been declared officially dead by the Vatican.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the general level of farm prices declined 2 per cent between mid-September and mid-October. This was the second consecutive month that farm prices declined by 2 per cent.

Much of the effectiveness of the country's school system is lost because the education program is not continuous, Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, vice president of the Fund for the Advancement of Education, declared yesterday.

The waiver purchase of valuable players from a National League club by an American League club or vice versa will be made more difficult if recommendations of baseball's executive council, announced yesterday by Commissioner Ford C. Frick, are followed.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers reserved decision in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday on a motion to have a provision in the Social Security Act declared unconstitutional because old-age insurance benefits were denied to a man when he balked at revealing his earnings after reaching the age of 65.

LADENTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Ramsey Conklin, Ramapo mountaineer who was found dead under an autumn leaf blanket in near-by woods last Friday, is to be buried tomorrow on the shore of Pine Meadow Lake in Palisades Interstate Park.
The cotton futures market closed quiet and barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and active months were unchanged to 11 points lower than on Tuesday.

We were thinking about doughnuts yesterday, a traditional Hallowe'en food. It seemed to us the little cake with the hole in the center has come far since New England housewives took a morning to fry a big batch for family and farm hands.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- The failure of nations able to make foreign investments to end taxation of such investments by their nationals was blamed today as an important, cause, of the shrinkage of foreign private investment.

Harry Gross offered yesterday to tell the Kings County rackets grand jury "anything they ask me." He made the offer at the departmental trial of thirty suspended policemen charged with taking his bookmaking graft.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, got himself all tangled up today in a treaty the United States signed with Spain in 1898.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Oct. 29 -- Twenty prominent Southern Californians, including both Republicans and Democrats, today demanded that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President, repudiate Senator Joseph McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
New York banking acquired a fully satisfied customer yesterday.

Young women who made their debuts in recent seasons, including Miss Pamela Straus and Mrs. Robert Gould Shaw 2d, are aiding in the plans for the Post Debutante Tiara Ball to be held on the night of Dec. 29 at the Plaza for the benefit of the Spence Chapin Adoption Service.

The two New York entries, Mrs. Mary Bain, United States champion, and Miss Mona M. Karff, met yesterday in the fifth round of the world chess championship challengers' tournament for women in Moscow and played to an adjournment after 41 moves, according to Soviet news sources.

THE woodcock shooting, which has been extremely spotty in most areas and very poor in others, seems to have shown considerable improvement during the past few days, and reports received yesterday from Maine, Vermont, northern Connecticut and upstate indicate that the late birds are moving south.

Judge Carmine J. Marasco in Kings County Court dismissed yesterday indictments against a Queens doctor and a registered nurse who had been charged with the illegal placement of children for adoption, a misdemeanor.

HONOLULU, Oct. 29 -- Federal Judge Jon Wiig denied today four defense pretrial motions in Hawaii's Smith Act case. This made it virtually certain that the seven indicted territorial residents would go to trial Nov. 5 as scheduled for alleged Communist affiliations.

A posthumous edition of Christopher Ward's two-volume "The War of the Revolution" will be issued Nov. 10 by Macmillan. Edited and prepared for publication by John R. Alden, Professor of History at the University of Nebraska, the work describes the personalities of the generals, colonial life, the technology of gunnery and the part played by the Indians.

SEOUL, Oct. 27 -- In the opinion of top-ranking officers in Korea, military victory can be won in Korea without necessarily going to the Yalu River -- if the United Nations have reinforcements of seven or eight more divisions and public readiness to accept high casualties during a three-week time of breaking through and amphibious landings.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 29 -- Bribes were offered to three members of the University of Maryland football team, including the star quarterback, Jack Scarbath, to hold down the score of last Saturday's game with Louisiana State University, the police disclosed today.

PARIS, Oct. 29 (UP) -- France welcomed Charlie Chaplin today on his first visit in twenty-one years by making him an officer of the Legion of Honor -- the highest distinction it can confer on an alien citizen in peacetime. He formerly was a chevalier of the Legion.

The basis of a voter's choice should not be the statements of the present campaign but the probable situation in Washington during the following years. For this reason it is largely irrelevant to charge Eisenhower with sacrificing principle to political expediency. It is even more irrelevant for THE TIMES to campaign against President Trumen, thus implying that Stevenson has become "Truman's captive."

ANDY LOTSHAW, the trainer for the Chicago Cubs and the Chicago Bears for some three decades, has finally retired, thus removing from the world of sport one of the most colorful figures ever to patrol its ever green pastures. Andy was the character with an affinity for the unusual in thought, word and deed. There almost was something Bunyanesque about him on occasions as he'd turn the constant ribbing of his athletes into stunned silence.

Sales of defense products by the General Motors Corporation in the first nine months of 1952 totaled $1,026,000,000, nearly two and one-half times the volume for the same period of last year, C. E. Wilson, president, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, reported yesterday in their quarterly financial statement.

Directors of American Gas and Electric Company yesterday declared an extra dividend in stock at the rate of one share for each forty shares held, in addition to the regular quarterly 75-cent cash dividend. The board also voted to recommend a split of the common stock on a two-for-one basis and called a special meeting of shareholders to be held on Jan. 27 to vote on the proposal.

Plans for the new $27,485,000 General Grant Houses to be built near Columbia University by the City Housing Authority with Federal aid were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The new houses, together with the adjacent Morningside-Manhattanville project approved by the Board of Estimate last May 8, will make up an integrated neighborhood development.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Lawyers for five major oil companies were in two courts here today fighting a Justice Department investigation of an alleged international oil cartel.

Record operating revenues and earnings were achieved by Trans World Airlines, Inc., in the third quarter this year, according to the report issued yesterday by Warren Lee Pierson, chairman and Ralph S. Damon, president.

Although unit volume is ahead of a year ago, shipment of women's nylon hosiery for Christmas appear to be lagging behind other types of apparel, acording to a survey of the market. Retailers have yet to bring to a peak their inventories of branded lines for holiday selling and their failure to order will bring a last-minute rush that could quickly exhaust existing stocks.

Columbia's football team continued to drill for Saturday's game here with Cornell with a two-hour contact scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field. The Lions' quarterback, Mitch Price, saw limited action in the session despite a bad knee, and is expected to be ready for the Big Red.

Reflecting record sales for the quarter and nine months ended last Sept. 30, net income of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation rose 54 per cent and 14 per cent, respectively, from a year ago, Gwilyn A. Price, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized the Columbia Gas System of New York City to borrow up to $25,000,000 from the Guaranty Trust Company and other banks. The company will issue its 3 per cent notes maturing on Oct. 31, 1953, in exchange for the loans.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Corn futures showed a much stronger tendency today, and there was a sharp relative advance in the spot corn basis, indicating a lessening of country selling pressure and some improvement in the congested warehouse conditions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, asked today why Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, had not demanded that his running mate, Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, make public his income tax returns.

In presenting a tentative defense budget for the next year of more than four billion dollars, French Defense Minister Pleven has raised again the issue of American aid. This issue is a direct result of the Congressional cut of nearly $1,500,000,000 made in the original $7,900,000,000 Mutual Security Program, on which the calculations of our European allies were based.

The Inland Steel Company reported a net profit yesterday of $4,794,694, equal to 97 cents a capital share, in the third quarter of 1952, compared with $7,748,751 or $1.58 a share for the similar period of last year. Net sales dropped to $98,308,564 in the latest quarter from $131,229,602 in the three months ended Sept. 30, 1951.
Blue pinpoints on a global map at the headquarters of the United Service Organizations describe the range of spiritual, welfare and recreational facilities offered by the U. S. O.

The three - story garden type apartment house accommodating sixteen families at 189-29 Thirty-seventh Avenue in Flushing, Queens, has been purchased by Charles Mantione from Ignatz and Paula Reiss. The sale was negotiated through Harrington Walters as broker and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The State Department, in reply to inquiries, confirmed today published reports that Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican of California and candidate for the Vice Presidency, had once asked the United States Embassy in Havana to assist Dana C. Smith, an attorney of Pasadena, in regard to an alleged gambling debt to a Cuban night club.
The State of California borrowed $25,000,000 in the public market yesterday to help finance school building.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Oct. 29 -- Marking an important milestone in the long slow search for a united Protestant Church in this country, thirty-five clergymen and laymen representing fifteen major denominations opened a three-day meeting here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The probability that the Consumers Price Index may be held to a standstill or show another drop in the September-October period was indicated today by a report on retail food prices, which showed an average decline of 0.3 per cent for that period.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 29 (Reuters) -- The Government announced today Kenya's new budget of $52,000,000, the biggest in the colony's history.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Twelve Federal prisoners, six of whom declared themselves to be Communists and pleaded for deportation to the Soviet Union, received two to five-year sentences today for rioting at the El Reno (Okla.) Reformatory.

Miss Clemence Dane, English novelist and playwright, is at work on the dramatization of her novel, "Broome Stages," for presentation on the London and Broadway stages under the auspices of Walter Chrysler Jr. and Michael Powell.
A frisky little filly named Grecian Queen, owned by Mrs. Ben F. Whitaker, gave Eric Guerin an all-the-way-in-front ride in the $51,500 Demoiselle Stakes at the Jamaica track yesterday.

NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 29 -- Jim Vermillion, senior master at St. George's School, was chuckling today about the "absence" of Pete Rothermel, coach of the football squad, two weeks ago Saturday. Because that day was an open date on the schedule, the varsity team was on Crocker Field engaging in an intra-squad game. There was no sign of the coach who played 150-pound football at Princeton ten years ago.

Fashions from Jane Engel were modeled by eight service women in a revue, "About Face," under the sponsorship of the First Army Recruiting Service last evening in the ballroom at the Henry Hudson Hotel.
The following political speeches are scheduled radio and television today:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The International Joint Commission granted authority today to the United States and Canada to build a power project in the St. Lawrence River, just downstream from Ogdensburg, N. Y., which would produce an estimated 12,600,000,000 kilowatt-hours of energy a year.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Aneurin Bevan and his supporters announced tonight their acceptance under protest of the majority decision of their Laborite colleagues in the House of Commons that the Bevanites disband.

Commodity futures in the New York markets closed irregularly yesterday with most items off slightly. Trading was generally light with potato dealers waiting for the Nov. 3 delivery date, wool traders delaying until the tariff situation clear and others postponing action until after Election Day.
The clay pipe industry is entering a buyers' market, manufacturers representing the nation's producers were told yesterday at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Neil P. Cullom, attorney for the defendants in the Duane Jones case, said yesterday that "it is our intention to press the issue to final legal conclusion, which necessarily is some time in the future. * * * Because we had expected complete exoneration, we are more than surprised by the verdict."

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 29 (AP) -- France's Pierre d'Oriola, riding Ali Baba, tonight finally showed his 1952 Olympic title form as he won the international individual jumping championship in a double jump-off at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

LONDON, Oct. 29 (Reuters) -- The European press -- Leftist, Center and Rightist -- joined today in condemning Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, for his attacks on Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential candidate.

With every season Central Park serves different tastes and different uses. It is always good -- and always a surprise -- to see in the center of the world's busiest city this convenient retreat where the vitality of nature has been subdued to the gratifying calm of a rich garden.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will bring to a climax tonight an arduous three-day campaign tour of the metropolitan area at a rally in Madison Square Garden. There his Republican and independent supporters hope to outdo in fervor and vote-appeal the big show put on at the Garden Tuesday night for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, his Democratic-Liberal opponent for the Presidency.

It is encouraging to note that the Commissioner of the New York State Motor Vehicle Bureau, James R. Macduff, has come out "very much in favor" of periodic inspection of automobiles by state-operated stations and periodic examinations of persons holding licenses to drive.

RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 29 -- The sixteenth annual convention of the National Home Demonstration Council ended here today after about 3,000 delegates heard an economist say that indirect controls were the only means by which inflation could be curbed.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 29 (AP) -- A band of Trappist monks from Rhode Island has purchased an isolated 8,700-acre tract known as Hidden Valley, nine miles west of Hot Springs, Va., for the site of a monastery.
