Mayor Impellitteri praised the work of the city Health Department at the dedication yesterday of the department's new $1,250,000 Jamaica Health Center, 90-37 Parsons Boulevard, near Jamaica Avenue, Queens, serving 300,000 residents of the area.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Wall Street economists assert that neither Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower nor Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson as President could materially reduce taxes or Government spending or make more than a feeble stab at balancing the budget for two or three years -- possibly until the 1955 fiscal year or later. Either successful candidate, they feel, would oppose renewing the excess profits tax when it expires in June.

Many parties will be given at the annual luncheon and bridge for the benefit of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children to be held today in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Peter McDonnell is chairman of the benefit committee.

Carrying their surprising resurgence into Madison Square Garden last night, the Chicago Black Hawks subdued the New York Rangers, 3 to 1. Chronic tail-enders in the National Hockey League for several seasons, the Black Hawks skated efficiently to the triumph, their fourth of the campaign, and gained the circuit leadership.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Bolivia's rich tin mines will be taken over formally by the revolutionary government Friday in a ceremony in Catavi, the nation's chief tin-producing center, the Government announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 22:

William Wyer, trustee of the Long Island Rail Road, filed an amended petition in the Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday seeking permission to have his own engineering firm, William Wyer Co., start six surveys designed to improve operation and reduce expenses of the bankrupt railroad.

Delegates from the many yacht clubs along Long Island Sound attended the Yacht Racing Association meetings yesterday afternoon and last night in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. At the annual gatherings of both the senior and junior groups, officers were elected for the coming year and awards were made to the class winners over the summer.
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 30 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,418, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The recording of a statement that Lord Elton ascribed to Donald D. MacLean, in which the former Foreign Office official was supposed to have set forth his political views, actually was made by Guy Francis de Moncy Burgess, another British diplomat, who disappeared with Mr. MacLean, the Foreign Office disclosed today.

The Department of Health took drastic and seldom-invoked measures yesterday to force fifteen families in a three-story rooming house at 10 Stuyvesant Avenue, in Brooklyn, to vacate the building within forty-eight hours because they were living under conditions "dangerous to life" and "unfit for human habitation." The agency said the average rent paid by the tenants was $16 a week.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Marion Hiskey, Texas collegian, shot a record-breaking 65 to win the medal today in the Mexican amateur golf championship.

A scout who eavesdropped during the Newspaper Food Editors' Conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel the other day reports sadly that the trend in cookery still seems to be toward what he calls the jiffy dinner.

Small plastic syringes sold in hobby shops for the lubrication of model airplane engines might possibly be used for the hypodermic injection of narcotics, the police warned here yesterday. At a hearing in the Flatbush Magistrate's Court, distributors and hobby-shop representatives agreed to discontinue sale of the syringes.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower made public last night part of a letter from Gen. James A. Van Fleet, Eighth Army commander in Korea, that said the South Korean Army was "in apple-pie order." According to General Van Fleet, if more Korean divisions could be used, more American divisions could be relieved.

After the Supreme Court had declared unconstitutional the Government's seizure of the steel industry Mr. Truman sought to have Congress get him off the spot in which he found himself. While he admitted that there was something to be said for using the Taft-Hartley Act, he was against the idea, he said.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Defense Minister Rene Pleven told the National Assembly's Defense Committee today that, rather than revise the whole budget, he would maintain the original French estimate of $650,000 in United States aid for 1953.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican of Washington, reported contributions today of $66,072 and expenditures of $18,116 in his re-election campaign, the biggest total of Congressional contributions filed so far.

A drop of $8,097,763 in the twelve months' earnings of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company was reported by J. P. Levis, chairman, at a directors' meeting in Toledo at which Hugh C. Laughlin was elected executive vice president and a director. George S. Babcock was made a vice president.

MOSCOW, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Collective farms of Uzbekistan are planning to invest their own money in a long-term program for irrigation of a vast area of Uzbek cotton growing land, the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia announced today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- The United States plans to ask the United Nations to give Secretary General Trygve Lie the power to oust all United States Communists from the staff of the world organization.

MONTREAL, Oct. 29 (Canadian Press) -- A spokesman for the Aluminum Company of Canada, Ltd., said today the company will double its ingot shipments to United States defense and consumer plants in the first quarter of 1953.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Stephen Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, tonight dismissed Col. Lawrence Westbrook, one of his assistants, after having received reports that, while employed by the committee, he had helped negotiate a Government contract for a Portuguese tungsten firm.

A new philosophy is developing in the management of international trade, it was asserted yesterday by Julian L. Watkins of the J. Walter Thompson Company. He spoke at the closing day's session of the eastern annual conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies in the Roosevelt Hotel.
The texts of speeches by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower yesterday in the Bronx and Westchester, and excerpts from his radio-television address follow:
TOKYO, Oct. 29 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida selected a sixteen-man man Cabinet today as the nucleus of the new National Government, the pro-American chief executive's fourth post-war Administration.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 29 -- Forty-one members of the Brown University faculty came out tonight for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican candidate for President, declaring that their announcement was in answer to the endorsement last Tuesday of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic nominee, by forty-nine other faculty members.

ABOARD TRUMAN TRAIN, Oct. 29 -- A tape recording taken by radio station KGLO of Mason City had President Truman starting his speech to a train-side crowd at Manly, Iowa, early today with the following words:

Rosemary Kuhlmann, who gained fame as the mother in Gian-Carlo Menotti's "Amahl and the Night Visitors," made a deep impression last night as a second Menotti heroine. This time it was Magda Sorel in the New York City Opera Company's third presentation of "The Consul."

DETROIT, Oct. 29 -- Hadassah, closing its annual convention here today, adopted a record 1953 budget of $9,000,000 -- the highest in the forty-year-old history of the organization -- for the maintenance of its comprehensive medical, social welfare, youth Aliyah (immigration) and vocational education programs in Israel.

The subject of dirt, as it is to most homemakers, was the main preoccupation of the day-long second annual National Home Vacuum Cleaning Conference held yesterday in the Commodore Hotel. The meetings were attended by home economists, representatives of newspapers and magazines and members of the conference.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Possible key facts bearing on the dispute between President Truman and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower over withdrawal of troops from Korea in 1949 were obscured today by official secrecy.
This has been a rather baffling football season for Fordham. Before the campaign opened, Ed Danowski labeled this as potentially his strongest squad in seven years in charge on Rose Hill.

ATLANTA, Oct. 29 (AP) -- More than 80 per cent of the top officeholders in the South have rallied behind Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois in his Democratic bid for the Presidency, an Associated Press survey showed today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -- Metro appears to be going in for period costume adventure tales, hoping, of course, to repeat the success now being enjoyed by its "Ivanhoe." Scheduled for filming next year in Technicolor is "The King's Thief," a newly purchased story written directly for the screen by Robert Hardy Andrews.
DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Senator Morse said here today that he would not have referred publicly to the 1947 Defense Department document on Korea "if I had not been authorized."

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 30 -- Reinforced Chinese Communist troops, for the second time in two days, today drove Allied defenders off the crest of "Sniper Ridge," north of Kumhwa on the central Korean front.

The American Cyanamid Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries suffered a sharp drop in earnings, with the net income for the first nine months this year totaling $16,931,763, in contrast to $30,231,096 made in the 1951 period, the report revealed yesterday.

On a blind couple's plea "in the name of mercy" to stay their eviction from a Bronx apartment, Justice Herman C. Stoute reserved decision in Ninth District Municipal Court at 8 Reade Street yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Orlando C. Mood, who received a letter from Gen. James A. Van Fleet on the training of South Korean troops, is a former Chief of Staff of the United States Eighth Army in Korea.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A battalion of Communist-led Vietminh troops, making the first strong attack in southern Indo-China in recent weeks, has wiped out the French defense post of Bensan, near Thudaumot, twelve miles north of Saigon, the French announced today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 -- Senator Nixon, in a nation-wide television broadcast tonight, branded the Democratic contention that things were "never so good" as false in the fields of both domestic and foreign affairs.

Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal party candidate for Senator, was honored yesterday by Adolf A. Berle Jr., Rudolph Halley and 750 others at a luncheon in the New Yorker Hotel. Dorothy Schiff, chairman of the Independent Citizens for the Election of George S. Counts, presided.

Evidence of "non-compliance" with the recently enacted local law restricting the burning of refuse in apartment house incinerators to the hours between 7 A. M. and 9 P. M. was reported yesterday by Rear Admiral William S. Maxwell, retired, deputy director of the Bureau of Smoke Control.

The market for Government securities sold off moderately yesterday, but declines were held short of 1/4 of a point. Two issues of bonds eligible for bank purchase this year for the first time -- the 2 1/4s of June 1962-59 and the 2 1/2s of 1967-62 -- each sold off 3/1s of a point. Losses of 1/8 of a point were most prevalent.

MANILA, Oct. 29 -- United States and Filipino officials here see little Prospect that a comprehensive Western Pacific or Southeast Asian mutual security pact can be arranged soon. Negative factors are regarded as too strong at the present time.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, today accused sixty-five faculty members of having "jeopardized the nonpartisan position of the university" by avowing their support of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic candidate.

The defense of Latin America is just as vital to us as the defense of Europe or Asia. This is a truism which may be well enough understood in the United States, although we do not hear much about it publicly. However, it is equally true that this defense means as much to each Latin-American nation as it does to us, and this does not seem to be well understood among all our neighbors.

The Ohio Valley Electric Corporation, recently formed by fifteen electric utility companies, announced yesterday that sites on the Ohio River at Madison, Ind., and near Gallipolis, Ohio, have been selected for construction of two steam-electric generating stations.

Colby M. Chester, lawyer and corporation executive, will retire today as chairman of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross. Mr. Chester's last act as chairman of the chapter for the last eight years will be to preside at the forty-sixth annual meeting of the organization in the Statler Hotel.

A dark, poker-faced former Nisei sergeant told a spellbound jury in Federal Court yesterday that John David Provoo, treason trial defendant, had expressed pro-Japanese sentiments in Manila three days after Pearl Harbor and had been the first United States soldier to offer his services to Japanese captors the day Corregidor fell.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Following is a stenographic report of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's address in Convention Hall tonight;

The six-story building with sixty apartments at 2401 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by David Green from I. A. Raff through Allan S. Feldman Sons, brokers. The property is assessed at $275,000.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman, reporting on his talks with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany concerning the "Europeanization" of the Saar, told the Cabinet today that sufficient progress had not been made to justify postponement of the Saar elections.

Two types of "binaural" sound systems and a newly developed record compensator among other high-fidelity equipment went on display yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker at the opening of the fourth annual Audio Fair, for which the Audio Engineering Society of America is sponsor.

A $250,000,000 project designed to provide an all-water route from the North Atlantic to the Black Sea, which is expected to prove a substantial economic asset to at last four European countries, is now being studied by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
Horace Stoneham, president of the Giants, has delivered an ultimatum to Manager Leo Durocher to make up his mind by next month between baseball and the movies, The Associated Press reports.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 29 -- Finance Minister Alfredo Hernandez told the press today that he had made satisfactory arrangements for settlement of Costa Rica's foreign debt during his recent visit to Washington.

In a talk yesterday to 101 new firemen, Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet attacked the finding of "a so-called expert," a consultant for the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, that Fire Department discipline was lax. On the contrary, he argued, departmental discipline was "good."

Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, told 600 students and faculty members yesterday that the recent dismissals of teachers by the Board of Higher Education were based on fitness and not on principles affecting academic freedom.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- A new bookkeeping account opened on an undecided mood in the stock markets today. Reiterated statements that the automobile industry faced difficulties unsettled sentiment and scared buyers, with the result that prices drifted lower.

We who have signed this letter are consulting engineers. It was drafted just before your heartening editorial, "A Choice Reaffirmed," appeared. It is therefore with increased pleasure that we address it to THE TIMES.

Thirty years of operation by the Alcoa Steamship Company, Inc., was observed yesterday as its ships, offices, agents and ports of call joined in a simultaneous birthday party that stretched from Canada to South America.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois asserted tonight that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's proposal to go to Korea originated not with the General but with "a speech writer from a slick magazine" in one "last desperate bid" for support from the voters in next Tuesday's election.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- European countries cannot be induced to spend more for defense in the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1953, whatever the amount of economic aid extended to them by the United States to alleviate balance of payments difficulties, according to a study by the Mutual Security Administration.

YONKERS, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Prince Eton, favored by the crowd of 10,064, scored a wire-to-wire victory in the Farragut pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight with a half length to spare over David Caudle. Claude Hanover was third.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Israel accused the Foreign Minister of Iraq today of bringing the "voice of Nazism" into the halls of the United Nations for the first time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Governor Stevenson has deplored that General Eisenhower "has made a vote-getting issue out of our ordeal" in Korea. This suggests that an opposition party should not seek votes on what throughout our history has been accepted as the most legitimate of issues: whether a war, however just, could have been avoided by an Administration and was brought on by its blunders of act and policy.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Senator Nixon, although stung by renewed Democratic demands for his income tax returns, declined today to give a year-by-year breakdown of his earnings.

In case the external world is not frightening enough, you are respectfully directed to Frederick Knott's "Dial M for Murder," which opened at the Plymouth last evening. It is a British thriller which Maurice Evans has had the wisdom to bring across the water and in which he gives a marvelously expert performance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has drafted tentative new safety regulations for the nation's airlines. One measure would require the use of a pilot warning device for each propeller on an airliner, to give an alarm when the propeller goes into reverse pitch.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, said yesterday that we must remove from our national life all contradictions that distort the idea of America in the eyes of the world.

The Radio Corporation of America and its subsidiaries achieved an all-time record in sales for the three and nine months ended on Sept. 30, according to the report issued yesterday by Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, board chairman.

Freshness marked the Jerry Parnis collection of holiday and resort designs presented yesterday by Best Co. at the Pierre Hotel. The silhouette that ran throughout the presentation of crisp, full skirt, slim waist and molded bodice possessed an appealing Dresden-like quality.
A novel exposition in which many of the new materials flowing from industrial laboratories will be displayed under one roof is in the planning stage.
BOSTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Algonquin Gas Transmission Company announced today completion of its main line from Lambertsville, N. J., to Boston.

CHESTER, Ill., Oct. 29 (UP) -- A band of thirty-eight psychiatric convicts released three guards held as hostages at Menard State Prison today, and officials began negotiating with 300 other rioting prisoners seeking the release of seven more guards.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Conditions fostered by the Soviet Union in its satellite countries "are even worse and more arbitrary than those against which we are protesting" in primitive colonial lands, Joseph Djerda of Yugoslavia told the Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations today. His charges brought angry denials from Soviet bloc spokesmen.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Unable to reach agreement on the amount of money the United Nations should spend for public information activities, the organization's Administrative and Budget Committee instructed Secretary General Trygve Lie and an advisory group today to try again for a compromise budget.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Restrictions on consumption and delivery of electric energy in the Pacific Northwest were announced today by the Defense Electric Power Administration.

A tract of approximately five acres in Clifton, N. J., has been purchased by the Brogan Cadillac Oldsmobile Company through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, as the site for a new showroom and service station. The property, on Passaic Avenue, was acquired from Gene Boyle, whose restaurant, at the corner of Alwood Road and Passaic Avenue, adjoins the site.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 29 -- The gas industry has spent billions of dollars during the last few years to develop the country's resources of natural gas and to bring the fuel to the large centers of consumption. Managements now are confronted with questions as to whether these expenditures were justified; whether the industry can obtain funds for further development, and at what rate of interest such funds could be obtained.
Governor Dewey accused the Truman Administration last night of allowing itself to be outwitted by the Russians abroad and duped by Communist-followers at home.

CAIRO, Oct. 29 -- Premier Mohammed Naguib of Egypt and the delegates of the Sudanese independence parties signed a final agreement tonight containing a joint program for the further political development of the Sudan. Presumably the same agreement was accepted by the groups favoring union with Egypt.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- Coming up to what the coaches figure will be the team's stiffest test thus far this season, unbeaten Pennsylvania will be reinforced by the return to action of two first-string linemen for Saturday's game with Penn State. Between 65,000 and 67,000 spectators are expected at Franklin Field for the renewal of the rivalry between the Keystone State elevens, which last met in 1948.

HARRISBURG. Pa., Oct. 30 (AP). -- Lieut. Pertrand du Breuil, on Ukase, tonight won the in-and-out event at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show for France, its second first-place as Mexico withdrew in a protest over the course.

The tonic and the subdominant of a Boccherini Symphony in A major and the Brahms Second Symphony in D enclosed the novelty, and an important one, of the program of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall.

The second of a pair of odds-on winners for Jockey Ted Atkinson on the Empire-at-Jamaica program yesterday was the gray roan 3-year-old gelding This Side, who raced six furlongs in 1:11 3-5 and won with three lengths to spare after having taken the lead high in the stretch.

DALLAS, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Colonel Westbrook said tonight that at the time he became involved in the tungsten deal he had no connection with the Government or the Democratic party and was not contemplating any.

E. G. Grace, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, predicted yesterday "full operations" for the company through the first quarter of next year and urged the removal of Government controls over steel by Jan. 1.
A lot of people are asking what is causing the great increase in registration so people can vote on Nov. 4. It is time someone pointed out the real answer to this important development.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 30 -- Gas utilities must maintain and improve earnings in every possible way in order to retain the support of investors. This advice was given here today by M. P. Walker, vice president of the Irving Trust Company of New York, at the closing session of the American Gas Association's annual convention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- More farmers will vote the Democratic ticket this year than in 1948, when they were a decisive factor in the election of President Truman, Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, said today.
The cotton-futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices on active months were 28 to 38 points net higher than on Wednesday.

A New York County grand jury is again investigating reports of a $10,000 payment in 1949 to former Mayor William O'Dwyer at Gracie Mansion by the one-time president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association.
READING, Pa., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Following is a stenographic report of remarks by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson here today:
In reference to General Eisenhower's proposed trip to Korea, I think that Governor Stevenson correctly stated that the trouble lies in Moscow, not in Korea.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Bolivian Army troops occupied tonight buildings and offices of three companies whose mines will be formally nationalized tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The National Production Authority today agreed to take under consideration urgent pleas by the construction industry that the agency advance by four months the date when it will permit a general relaxation of controls over construction.
DETROIT, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Metro Prystai, Ted Lindsay and Johnny Wilson scored third-period goals tonight to give Detroit a 4-to-1 victory over the Boston Bruins and snap a three-game losing streak.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Oct. 30 -- Delegates to the Nationalist-sponsored Overseas Chinese Affairs Conference pledged full support tonight to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Government and its "Recover the Mainland" campaign in a manifesto that brought the ten-day assembly to a close.

Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, reviewed last night the accomplishments of the Democratic Administrations over the last twenty years, declared that his party had substituted prosperity for bankruptcy and called for the wiping-out of the McCarran immigration law.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Direct investments by private United States investors and enterprises in the less developed countries abroad reached a record total in 1951 and seem headed for an even larger total this year, Dr. Isador Lubin of the United States reported today.

The $50,000,000 handkerchief industry in the United States will receive hand-made embroidered goods from several new sources next year to replace merchandise lost through stoppage of imports from Communist China, it was learned yesterday at the annual meeting of the Handkerchief Industry Association in the Advertising Club.

DETROIT, Oct. 30 -- President Truman told the people of Michigan today that the chance for world peace did not lie "in Republican isolationist policies of withdrawal, of feeble half-measures, of appeasement and surrender." He wound up the day with a denunciation of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee, whom he accused of condoning in effect the "big lie" technique of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

Henry H. Fowler, Director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, suggested last night that the Government create a civilian Reserve Corps of industrial leaders who have served the Government's mobilization program and have returned to their posts in business.
The Government served notice in Federal Court yesterday that it would call Gen. Jonathan Mayhew Wainwright as a witness in the treason trial of former Army Sgt. John David Provoo.

Farming in the United States seems on the way to becoming a full-time job, according to a survey just completed by the Institute of Life Insurance. The body declared that Department of Agriculture figures reveal that 78 cents from each dollar of agricultural income from all sources last year came from cash receipts from crops or livestock.

Colorful racing silks of many well-known stables were used in transforming the main ballroom of the Plaza into a miniature reproduction of Belmont Park for the Belmont Futurity Ball, a dinner dance given last night for the benefit of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club.

Brother Honeste Celestine, Professor of Biology at Manhattan College for forty-two years, will celebrate his golden jubilee as a member of the Brothers of the Christian Schools tomorrow. A pontifical mass of thanksgiving, celebrated by Bishop Bryan J. McEntegart of Ogdensburg, a former pupil of Brother Celestine, will be offered in De LaSalle Chapel on the Manhattan campus tomorrow.

Harry Gross, the bookmaker whose present embarrassments include a twelve-year prison term, conceded yesterday that he might well have been arrested nine times in a thirteen-month period of 1942 and 1943.

From the perspective of investors abroad, American enterprises stemming from the exploitation of natural resources offer the most attractive opportunities for investment, Sir Denys Lowson, former Lord Mayor of London and a specialist in the distribution of British investment company shares, said here yesterday.

It is of more than passing importance that the first international trade-union school in Asia is about to be opened in Calcutta by the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions. Institutions for the training of labor leadership in Asia and Africa were among the first projects discussed when the I. C. F. T. U. was formed three years ago to combat the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions.

Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal party candidate for United States Senator, charged last night at a series of Liberal party rallies that former President Herbert Hoover's reasoning still served as the basis for Republican policy. Because of this, he contended, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's election would bring on another depression.

A Public Service Commission hearing on the petition of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Company to discontinue its passenger service was halted dramatically yesterday when the city obtained an order temporarily restraining the railroad from continuing any further proceedings.

We have seen no representation of your Midwest readers in the debate in your letter columns over the Presidential campaign. We therefore feel that we are entitled to some space for the expression of our opinions. We also know that we express more than just the opinions of the undersigned.

Senator Irving M. Ives, campaigning for re-election to the United States Senate, told a television audience last night that no Democratic Administration since the Civil War had known peacetime prosperity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A Government attorney contended today that an alleged international oil cartel jeopardized national security. Leonard J. Emmerglick made the statement in court in opposing moves by major oil companies for dismissal of subpoenas for their records.

The stock market broke through yesterday to the higher side by a small margin as pre-election influences continued to dominate trading. A flurry of dealings in the oils and some of the automotives provided the only interesting spots in an otherwise dull session.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A University of Maryland junior, accused of trying unsuccessfully to "fix" his school's football game with Louisiana State University Saturday, appeared at a hearing here today and his lawyer indicated he would fight removal from the District of Columbia.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Britain and France addressed to the Soviet Union today an appeal that it accept, on humanitarian grounds, the principle of voluntary repatriation for the prisoners of war in Korea.
The National Basketball Association will open its 1952-3 season tonight with Minneapolis and Syracuse favored to win the divisional titles.
ROCKFORD, Ill., Oct. 30 -- Sale of The Rockford Register-Republic and The Rockford Morning Star to a new corporation headed by E. Kenneth Todd was announced today.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon called tonight on the Democratic Presidential nominee, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, to "quit hedging" and let the American people know if he intended to keep Dean Acheson as Secretary of State if he was elected.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Sen. Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, said tonight that he has been advised by a responsible source that President Truman is "contemplating an order imposing additional duties on imported wool."

The family is an important source of strengths and resources, it was asserted last night by Jean Schick Grossman, author and parent education director of the Play Schools Association. In the field of social work tapping this source and getting families to realize and use these strengths to help themselves is an important and recognized factor, she explained.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30 -- Demonstrating the efforts by a European country to fill its dollar gap with some of Mexico's freely convertible pesos, Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands today formally opened the "This Is Holland" exposition here.

This year's candidates for election are by far the most verbose in the history of the nation. With four days of campaigning still left they already have originated 35,000,000 words of telegraphed news.
ROME, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Italy has demanded that the Australian Government act promptly to provide work for 1,000-odd. Italian emigrants who are now idle, the Foreign Office announced today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Three Harvard professors who are seeking funds with which to fight the re-election bid of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, reported today that they had received $11,800 to date.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30 -- All's well again between the comedy team of Bud Abbott and Lou Costello and the Universal Pictures Company. The comedians announced today cancellation of the $5,000,000 suit for damages charging break of contract that they had started against the company last November in the United States District Court in New York.
On a high hill in Staten Island, reached by narrow roads winding through trees and over rocks, a blue and white flag waves a welcome to Girl Scouts of New York who yearn to know more of country life.
Between 1950 and 1952 more than 800 beds were added to the general care bed capacity of the hospitals in New York, the Hospital Council of Greater New York reported yesterday in its October Bulletin.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Dr. G. R. Love of Oconomowoc, Wis., scored the No. 1 upset of the North and South seniors invitation golf tournament today by eliminating favored Thomas C. Robbins of Larchmont, N. Y., 1 up, to gain the semi-finals.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, replied tonight to charges by Gen. James A. Van Fleet that he had lacked support in getting more Republic of Korea troops into the combat line.

Buying a quart of paint exactly like the yellow in an oil painting or the blue in a bit of fabric has never been an easy task. Now, as a result of a device demonstrated here yesterday, it not only will be easy, but it will be quick, inexpensive and labor saving with far less inventory required on the part of the dealer.

ROME, Oct. 30 -- A new approach to the Trieste question, consisting of submitting the controversy between Italy and Yugoslavia over the Free Territory to the judgment of the International Court of Justice at The Hague was proposed by the Italian Government in a note delivered today to the Yugoslav Government by the Italian Minister in Belgrade.

A three-acre tract with a new building on Route 17 in Lodi, N. J., has been leased by Ditto, Inc., manufacturer of duplicating machines, supplies and printed business forms. The property is owned by the Ironwood Realty Company, headed by Sol Entin, Passaic industrialist. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

The homemaker, no matter how good a washing she gives her laundry, will discover that "she can't get along for very long without the bleaching process," Miss Pamela Anderson of Good Housekeeping magazine said yesterday at the first of two day-long sessions of the Sixth National Home Laundry Conference in the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- General Van Fleet's letter to a former aide, supporting General Eisenhower's contention that more intensive training and more liberal equipment of the South Koreans could have taken and still could take United States soldiers out of the "front lines in Korea where they do not belong," accentuates Administration policy prior to and in direction of the Korean war as the central issue of this Presidential campaign.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Harry Brecheen, left-handed pitcher today signed a contract with the Browns after receiving his unconditional release earlier from the Cardinals.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- United States legal advisers initiated conferences today with staff experts of the United Nations on the problem of eliminating American Communists from the secretariat of the world organization.

The Public Service Commission rejected yesterday a plea by the Long Island Rail Road for permission to eliminate an island platform, for use by passengers of main line trains, from the design of the grade crossing elimination structure to be built at Floral Park, L. I.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Nearly a million acres of rich timberlands, brush and grasslands have been burned over this month in tinder-dry states in the Eastern half of the country, a survey showed today. Damage runs into millions of dollars, and the situation is more dangerous now than it was at the start of October.

GREAT hunters have rarely been even adequate writers. Men who spend their lives shooting big game in Indian jungles and the high veldt of Africa just aren't the type. Guns are their familiar tools, not words. Tracks, trophies, bushcraft and adventure are their interests, not subtleties of character (their own or others') and intangibles of emotional atmosphere.

THOSE planning a trip to Mattamuskeet Lake for the goose shooting next month should find more birds in this honker center than at any time in the history of the "made" lake, according to a call received yesterday from Axton Smith of Belhaven, N. C.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 760,741 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 77,636 cars, or 9.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 104,059 ears, or 12.0 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 127,194 cars, or 14.3 per cent fewer during the corresponding week two years ago.

More than 1,125,000 persons have taken Red Cross training courses at the New York Chapter, have received aid from its home service department, or have donated blood to its blood bank in the last eight years, it was reported yesterday by Colby M. Chester, retiring chairman of the chapter.

Lehman Brothers, financial adviser to the New Jersey Highway Authority, said yesterday that "there is no doubt that the proposed 180-mile Garden State Parkway will be self-supporting if state credit is placed behind the $285,000,000 revenue bond issue to complete the Parkway."
LONDON, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- Britain's export prospects have grown worse since last March and hopes for a rise in production have faded, the Minister of State for Economic Affairs acknowledged today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Murray L. (The Camel) Humphreys, reputed Chicago underworld figure, was acquitted today of contempt of Congress for refusal to answer questions of Senate crime investigators.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- The Tunisian nationalist movement was pledged today to cooperate with the West in building North African security if Tunisia won full sovereignty and independence from French rule.

Columbia is favored over a Cornell team that has yet to win a game. Nevertheless Lou Little views tomorrow's contest at Baker Field with considerable trepidation, in light of the fact that Bill Whelan, the Big Red's captain and best running back, will make his first start of the season against the Lions.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Mr. Pulvermann, said by The New York Herald Tribune to have shared in a "5 per cent" contract to sell tungsten to the United States, declared today the deal was a "mere business affair."
Anthony S. Gaccione of the Tioga Paper Stock Company, Inc., has been elected for the third time president of the New York Association of Dealers in Paper Mills' Supplies.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Again revealing his fondness for the Pimlico racing strip, H. C. Boorse's G. R. Petersen won the $5,000 Lafayette purse today by ten lengths over Knights Reward.
WINNIPEG, Oct. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Western Canada's record wheat crop not only has been harvested in good condition, but demand is excellent and export sales are being made in record volume.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Four former operators of a Saratoga Springs gambling casino who have pleaded guilty to bribery charges were among seven persons named today in tax liens totaling almost $400,000.

Mr. Vishinsky, in effect, has demanded the surrender of the United Nations on the issue of Korea and the abrogation of its function as an agency for the suppression of aggression. He has done this by advancing proposals which would end the truce negotiations at Panmunjom and bring the whole Korean question before a new United Nations commission comprising, among others, Communist China, North Korea and presumably Soviet Russia.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, who interrupted his Presidential campaign tour last night in an effort to settle the riot at Menard State Prison in Illinois, is still scheduled to speak from 9:30 to 10 o'clock tonight at the traditional Friday-before-election rally at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

A new surgical technique with which it may be possible to stimulate the growth of children's limbs that have been shortened by disease or injury was discussed here yesterday before a group of leading orthopedic surgeons at the fifth annual alumni conference of the Hospital for Joint Diseases.

Town Hall has been rocked by jazz and its audiences have hummed along with folk singers, but last night the 31-year-old citadel of classical music shivered and shook to something new -- gospel singing. It was strong, vibrant and exultant, and the listeners clapped their hands and shouted, "Yes, man."
American seamen, wherever they may be on Nov. 4, will cast a substantial number of votes in the Presidential election, labor unions and employers indicated yesterday.

CAIRO, Oct. 30 -- The Egyptian Cabinet, after a three-hour emergency meeting this afternoon, announced a decision to summon the Arab League Political Committee in special session to consider joint action against West Germany's intention to pay reparations to Israel for crimes committed against the Jews under the Nazis.

Firmness marked the prices of prime bonds yesterday as the market place, succumbing to the growing enchantment of the Presidential campaign, began to slow down for the last week-end before the big day. Most Treasury issues of longer term were marked up 1/8 of a point.

A warning that teachers and school and college administrators should not be blind to the faults of education was voiced yesterday by Dr. I. L. Kandel, editor of the educational journal, School and Society. He spoke at the annual educational conference sponsored by the Educational Records Bureau and the American Council on Education, held at the Roosevelt Hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Approval of a $23,000,000 relief program to assist 850,000 Arab refugees in the Middle East for the twelve-month period ending June 30, 1953, was voted today by the General Assembly's Special Political Committee.

A biographical study of Domingo Sarmiento the "South American Benjamin Franklin," will be issued Monday by the Princeton University Press entitled "The Life of Sarmiento." The author is the late Allison Williams Bunkley, who also edited "A Sarmiento Anthology."
HANOI, Indo-China, Oct. 30 (AP) -- French Union troops tackled the Vietminh's Black River offensive on its left flank today.

Both Republicans and Democrats claim chances for victory next Tuesday in Queens' four Congressional districts -- two now held by each major party. The election story, in a borough noted for independence and ticket-splitting has been complicated by re-mapping of districts, record registration and a heavy influx of new resident.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower campaigned by motorcade for eight hours yesterday through Manhattan, Brooklyn and Richmond, strongly attacking the Truman Administration in six speeches for assertedly failing to deal effectively with the Korean war, with Communist expansion generally, with "Red agents" in the Government, and with waste, extravagance and dishonesty.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- The Korean question, which is now, for the third successive year, a dominant issue in the United Nations General Assembly, has acquired a similar position in the United States Presidential campaign.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 31 -- United Nations troops lost and then in a fierce counter-attack regained today "Triangle Hill," north of Kumhwa on the central Korean front. The hill, one of the main objectives of the Allies' limited offensive launched eighteen days ago, has been hotly contested ever since by the Chinese Communists.

Net income of the Aluminum Company of America and subsidiaries for the first nine months of 1952 amounted to $30,102,916, equal to $5.77 each on the 4,893,313 shares of common stock outstanding, the company reported yesterday.

For fifteen years New York City has operated its government under a narrowly provincial law, promoted and perpetuated by Borough President Lyons of the Bronx, that with certain exceptions requires that the city can hire as employes only persons who have lived within the city limits for three years.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- For the first time in many years it looked today as if an understanding between Britain and Egypt on the future of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan might be possible.

The General Telephone Corporation and its subsidiaries increased net income in the nine months this year to $6,001,130, or $2.24 a share on 2,341,500 common shares outstanding, from $3,983,425, or $1.90 each on 1,920,400 shares outstanding in the 1951 period, the report disclosed yesterday.

A top novelist with an irresistible hankering to write for the stage is John Steinbeck. So far he has been involved in the writing of three dramas, "Of Mice and Men," "The Moon Is Down" and "Burning Bright." By all odds, the first was head and shoulders over the rest.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 30 -- A-Pacopep, owned by R. E. Cudahy, scored a nose victory in the Chester purse over six speedsters at Garden State Park today before 13,800 fans.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Price rallies proved hard to maintain on the board of trade today despite the fact that in the case of wheat there was no lack of extremely pessimistic crop and weather reports to stimulate bullish sentiment.

Activity in sugar featured commodities yesterday. With shippers anxious to take advantage of the recent quota increase and with buyers holding back, spot sugar dropped 12 cents on Wednesday and 10 cents more today, going to 5.9 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. - Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhow responded today to a request by the American Veterans of World War II. (AMVETS) for a pro-election statement on his stand on the Veterans Administration medical program. The General said that this and other V. A. controversies would be made a matter "of primary concern" by him if elected.
MENARD, Ill., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Three hundred rioting convicts, gaunt with hunger, held out defiantly against all peace attempts at Menard State Prison today with seven hostages still in their hands.

Despite a number of adverse factors, including a drought last spring, Mexico has entered a period of prosperity and is proving to be a very profitable market for United States companies. This was reported yesterday by William Miller, general manager of Walter Thompson de Mexico., Mexican office of the J. Walter Thompson Company.

BUFFALO, N .Y., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Details of a new synthetic rubber that won't lose its "bounce" in cold weather or its firmness under extreme heat were outlined today at the annual fall meeting of the American Chemical Society's division of rubber chemistry.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, the Oregon Republican who bolted his party to support Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, said today that he had expected his constituents to criticize him for his move but they "overwhelmingly" had backed his switch.
DETROIT, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A mother with film star ambitions for her daughter admitted today, police said, that she had embezzled thousands of dollars from her employer to futher the girl's career.

Employers in this city are faced with a developing manpower shortage which will grow worse if business continues at high levels, the New York State Employment Service reported yesterday following a survey of 3,345 business concerns employing 215,000 workers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer will sail from New York tomorrow on the S. S. United States for a European tour designed to find out from Europeans and from Americans abroad the outlook for trade and maximum production on both sides of the Atlantic.

No tax liability exists, under Indian law, on a non-resident who exports to or imports from India on a principal-to-principal basis. A statement to this effect was made yesterday by the Government of India Information Services in an effort to clear up what it termed "misapprehension" by American business men over the liability to income tax of foreign exporters or their agents doing business in India.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, said tonight that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was "as ideally fitted" to be this country's next President as George Washington was to be our first President.

The two-story taxpayer and office building at 11-19 Northern Boulevard in Great Neck, L. I., has been purchased by David Green from the Boundary Realty Corporation. Reiss Co. were the brokers and Green Selzer were attorneys for the buyer.

Arrangements have been all but completed for the appearance here in winter track meets of three outstanding German runners who scored in the Olympics, Daniel J. Ferris, National A. A. U. secretary-treasurer, said yesterday that he was momentarily expecting confirmation of indicated acceptances by Herbert Schade, Rolf Lamers and Heinz Ulzheimer.

Irwin Edman, chairman of the department of philosophy at Columbia University, said yesterday that organizers of the list of 714 names of supporters of General Dwight D. Eisenhower had "introduced questionable techniques of propaganda to our campus and to the academic world at large."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Orlando C. Mood said today that a letter read by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in a campaign speech last night was a "confidential and personal" communication to him from Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet.

Directors of the Trans World Airlines, Inc. at a meeting yesterday voted to offer to stockholders the right to subscribe to one share of additional capital stock for each seven shares held at a price to be determined later.

Milford, Conn., sold yesterday $1,250,000 of public improvement bonds due from 1953 to 1967 to a banking group headed by Glore, Forgan Company at a bid of 100.46 for interest of 1.9 per cent. On reoffering, the bonds were priced to yield from 1.1 to 2 per cent.
Many parties will be given at the Halloween Ball for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery tonight in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Miss Louise Marock heads the benefit committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Jess Larson, head of the Defense Materials Procurement Agency, said today he had ordered a "top-to-bottom" investigation into a canceled contract through which the Government would have paid upward of $9,000,000 for tungsten and the contract negotiators would have received about $450,000 in "five-percenter" contingency fees.
Following is the text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's address at Madison Square Garden last night as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Alarmed by the sales of British art treasures to the United States and other countries, a committee appointed by the Chancellor of the Exchequer has recently recommended that the British Government should establish a permanent system "to prevent the export of objects of high importance."

YONKERS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Good Time, greatest money winning harness horse with $318,792.86, tonight failed to establish a world record for the mile on a half-mile track as he bade farewell to racing before 15,754 fans at Yonkers Raceway.
Like most Americans, I believe in a democratic country with maximum opportunity for movement between social groups. I believe in a background of values always present in public and in personal life.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 25 were 8 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

SOUTH BYFIELD, Mass., Oct. 30 -- The bell in the belfry in the old schoolhouse built in 1763 has been ringing every Saturday at Governor Dummer Academy. The Big Red has been triumphant in all five of its football games and, in keeping with custom here, the ancient tocsin has been sounded to celebrate each victory.

Three of the five Russian players competing in the women's world chess championship challengers' tournament in Moscow were winners in the sixth round, last night, according to a report received from Soviet news sources.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's candidacy is being supported editorially by 933, or 67.34 per cent, of the 1,385 daily newspapers polled by Editor Publisher magazine. The total circulation of the papers backing the Republican candidate for President is 40,129,237.

Price declines on three meat cuts are about the only encouraging changes shoppers will note in buying fresh foods for this week-end. In its weekly survey, the City Department of Markets found 6-cents-a-pound reductions on two cuts of pork and leg and rump of veal down 4 cents to an average of 79 cents a pound.

LADENTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Golden light reflected from yellowed oak leaves bathed Pine Meadow Lake and the Conklin cemetery in a kind of autumnal glory today when Ramsey Conklin was put to sleep beside his ancestors.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 30 -- According to their own revised estimates, Yugoslav authorities are seeking to import approximately 1,200,000 tons of foodstuffs to neutralize the effects of last summer's drought. The estimates include 800,000 tons of wheat and 300,000 tons of corn.
Standard Oil Company of California increased its gross operating income for the quarter and nine months ended with September, but earnings were little changed, the report revealed yesterday.

Warning that the "danger" of the McCarran Immigration Act rested in the assumption that some national groups were inherently inferior to others, Dr. Dan Dodson, Professor of Education at the New York University School of Education, urged yesterday that welfare workers capitalize on the heritage that has made this city a melting pot.

Scenes reminiscent of the wholesale return of American troops from Europe in the summer of 1945 will be re-enacted tomorrow at Army Base piers in Brooklyn and Staten Island when 6,189 soldiers and military dependents will move down the gangplanks of six Navy transports arriving from North European, Mediterranean and Newfoundland ports.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois reported to a United States Government agency in February, 1944, that the Soviet Union had "evidenced an interest" in American and British policy toward Italy and that this interest might increase if Soviet influence were extended in the Balkans as a result of the war.

The Carnegie Foundation of The Hague has just announced that its 1951 Wateler Peace Prize has been awarded to Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, former Dutch Foreign Minister and now Ambassador to Great Britain. This award marks the counterpart to the announcement that the prize for this year will go to Jean Monnet, chairman of the Schuman Plan Coal and Steel Authority.

Outrageous delays in getting ambulances to the scene of illness or accident, which occur from time to time in New York, can only be matched or surpassed by the length of time it has taken the city administration to come to grips with the question and make up its mind about remedies of jurisdiction.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- In what was believed to be the first such action since the Berlin blockade of 1948-49, Soviet zone authorities have turned back two train-loads of United States military supplies bound for Berlin. One of the trains carried eight new Patton type tanks.
Scandinavian Airlines System has set Nov. 19 as the date for the first of two exploratory flights over the polar air route from Los Angeles to Europe.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 - Criticism for authorizing the use of "top secret" information in political addresses was leveled against the Administration today by two Republican Senators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Defense officials are ready to approve a military budget for next year $5,000,000,000 below that appropriated by Congress this year and $10,000,000,000 less than the total funds requested by the armed services a year ago.

The agreement between the Egyptian Government and the Sudanese which was reached on Wednesday appears at first sight to be sensible and fair. If the British feel that it is (and a Foreign Office spokesman called it "an encouraging advance"), we will be seeing the beginning of the end of one of the most vexing and dangerous disputes in the Middle East.

The Red Cross blood bank had its best daily collection of the month Wednesday when 1,230 pints of blood were received. Two groups, members of the Reserve Officers Training Corps of New York University and the Community of New Rochelle, donated the day's highest amounts, 332 pints each.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks, scoring four times in the first ten minutes, swamped the New York Rangers, 8 to 3, before 5,781 Chicago Stadium fans tonight to take a game-and-a-half lead in the National Hockey League race.
ALBANY, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Parents of pint-size "spooks" in training for tomorrow's Halloween high jinks were alerted today against purchase of inflammable masks and jack-o'-lanterns.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 30 -- A charge by City Commissioner Charles S. Witkowski that municipal employes were being called upon to make salary "kickback" contributions of 1 1/2 per cent of their annual salary to the local Democratic organization brought a quick denial today from Deputy Mayor William Flanagan at City Hall.

Some humorous sidelights on political registration here were given in Supreme Court yesterday as a result of the Attorney General's investigation into illegal registration, which resulted in the striking of forty-seven more names from the voting lists by Justice Carroll G. Walter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A subpoena calling for delivery to the House of Representatives subcommittee investigating tax scandals of much-sought data involving a claim for around $20,000,000 of refunds has been "dishonored" by John B. Dunlap, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, it was charged today by the two ranking members of the House group.

Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, declared last night that he had confidence in the American people and did not believe three months of "dirty campaigning" would make them believe that a patent falsehood was true.

Michael Pollock sang his first Captain in Berg's "Wozzeck," last night at the City Center, and Jeanne Grant made her first appearance with the New York City Opera as Marie. Miss Grant was replacing the indisposed Patricia Neway.
Designs for festive northern wear, to complement furs, cocktail or dinner frocks, vied with those for resort wear in the showing yesterday at Milgrim's of new custom millinery.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic nominee for President, won a straw poll of Harvard University students announced today by The Harvard Crimson, university daily newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- During the week ended Oct. 29 member bank reserves decreased $330,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The pettiness of the Federal Communications Commission in the case of WNYC is growing tiresome.

A statement that an atomic energy-electric power industry can not be put on a sound basis so long as it requires a government-supported market for atomic weapons to make it economically feasible was made yesterday by Harry A. Winne, vice president in charge of engineering of the General Electric Company.

PITTSBURGH, Friday, Oct. 31 -- Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois abruptly suspended his Presidential campaign tour early this morning and left by plane en route to Illinois in an effort to halt the riot at Menard State Prison, which began on Monday.
Unrestricted parking by United Nations personnel on crowded thoroughfares in the midtown area was described yesterday as a widespread factor in creating traffic congestion.

This election year being a particularly anxious one for public opinion pollsters (after 1948 and all that), it was a brave thing for three of the nation's top practitioners of political forecasting to speak publicly yesterday on "Why the 1952 Polls Won't Go Wrong."
ATLANTA, Oct. 30 (AP) -- One of the nation's top industrialists today assailed hidden taxes and declared that, unless unmasked, they "can -- and will -- destroy us."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The first peace award of the Catholic Association for International Peace has been bestowed on the late Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, and will be accepted by his 12-year-old daughter, Patricia, the association announced today.

Gimbels third-floor boutique is a most alluring spot. In it one finds those gay clothes than mean to a woman of European tastes what boullabaisse means to an epicure, a very special flavor. Responsible for picking out these clothes of the French and Italian fashion feasts is Elizabeth Appenizellar, buyer for the department.

Establishing the fourth successive new high in the last eight weeks of advances, New York bank loans to business rose $48,000,000 last week to reach a total of $8,228,000,000. The latest increase brought the expansion in such loans since midyear to $558,000,000, compared with $695,000,000 in the similar periods a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy adviser, charged here today that the Truman Administration's foreign policy-making was so "haphazard" as to be "little short of criminal, when we face deadly peril from powerful enemies."

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The Republican "truth squad" charged today that President Truman was trying to salve his "conscience" with a last-minute attempt to pin the blame for his own failures on the Republicans.
Rumors that THE NEW YORK TIMES would shift its support to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic candidate for President, have been circulated widely in recent days.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Marion Hiskey and his North Texas State College team-mates continued to dominate the Mexican amateur golf championship today as they advanced into the second round.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Parliament was prorogued today after the traditional speech from the sovereign. It was Queen Elizabeth's first message of this kind since she came to the throne and was read to both houses of Parliament by the Lord Chancellor, Lord Simonds.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The stock markets were uneven today. British Government securities improved slightly in recognition of a continued strength of the sterling-dollar exchange rate, and South African gold mining shares further strengthened slighlty.
