PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The nations of Western Europe are fascinated by any reports that the United States contemplates modifying its present year-to-year system of appropriating aid for their economy and defense.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Henry W. (The Dutchman) Grunewald, the mystery man of Washington, pleaded innocent to contempt of Congress charges today when he was arraigned before the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia.
Unrestricted parking by United Nations personnel on crowded thoroughfares in the midtown area was described yesterday as a widespread factor in creating traffic congestion.

This election year being a particularly anxious one for public opinion pollsters (after 1948 and all that), it was a brave thing for three of the nation's top practitioners of political forecasting to speak publicly yesterday on "Why the 1952 Polls Won't Go Wrong."
ATLANTA, Oct. 30 (AP) -- One of the nation's top industrialists today assailed hidden taxes and declared that, unless unmasked, they "can -- and will -- destroy us."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The first peace award of the Catholic Association for International Peace has been bestowed on the late Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, and will be accepted by his 12-year-old daughter, Patricia, the association announced today.

Gimbels third-floor boutique is a most alluring spot. In it one finds those gay clothes than mean to a woman of European tastes what boullabaisse means to an epicure, a very special flavor. Responsible for picking out these clothes of the French and Italian fashion feasts is Elizabeth Appenizellar, buyer for the department.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- The case of William N. Oatis, The Associated Press correspondent who has been imprisoned for eighteen months in Czechoslovakia on espionage charges, was brought before the legal committee of the United Nations General Assembly today by Senator Theodore F. Green of Rhode Island, as "a tragic illustration" of how the Soviet Union and its satellies hamstring practices and, ultimately, justice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Henry W. (The Dutchman) Grunewald, the mystery man of Washington, pleaded innocent to contempt of Congress charges today when he was arraigned before the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia.

AT THE KOREAN FRONT, Oct. 30 -- In an informal sampling of American soldiers of a division fighting in Korea it was revealed that with surprising unanimity they disapproved of any plan that would take United States troops off the front line and put Republic of Korea soldiers in their place.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Oct. 30 -- A "deep" and "fundamental" desire for a united American Protestantism is welling up across the entire United States, the Rev. Dr. E. Stanley Jones declared here today.

The semi-final and championship basketball games of the Public Schools Athletic League play-offs will be allowed to return to Madison Square Garden at the end of the forthcoming season. Dr. William Jansen, superintendent of schools, granted permission yesterday. The dates have not been set.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Battle Zone," an action drama produced by Walter Wanger, released by Allied Artists and starring John Hodiak, Linda Christian and Stephen McNally, is at the Palace. Lesley Selander directed from a script by Steve Fisher.
A plea for American business men to look to Australia as a profitable field for investment was voiced yesterday by Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister for External Affairs.

A 10 per cent contract rate differential for exclusive shippers was strongly defended as "reasonable" yesterday as the Federal Maritime Board hearing into the dual rate structure of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference went into its third day.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 -- United States Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, tonight dismissed as "a ghost writer's gimmick" Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's promise to go to Korea in an effort to end the conflict.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- Maurice Chevalier, now 64, is back in London for his first professional appearance here in four years, and is packing them in as he did four, fourteen and forty years ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The Coast Guard removed today some of the restrctions it imposed on ship transportation after the Texas City, Tex., disaster in 1947.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 30 -- Bernard M. Baruch inferentially accused President Truman of political hypocrisy and renewed his own testimonial to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's qualifications for President in a telegram to Gov. James F. Byrnes that was made public here today.

PUSAN, Korea, Friday, Oct. 31 (AP) -- One hundred and seventy-eight Communist prisoners of war were injured Tuesday in mass demonstrations at four compounds on Koje Island and one prisoner was killed by rifle fire on Cheju Island, Allied officials announced today.

Johnny Bratton, former National Boxing Association champion, will enter the ring a 6 1/2 to 5 favorite to defeat Joe Miceli of New York in a ten-round welterweight fight at Madison Square Garden tonight.

One of the truly depressing times of year is that period which can be summed up as the last week-end of the autumn. It is a farewell to the good things of the summer and fall, a salute as mournful as that given by the actor taking his bow on the last night of the run of his play.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 30 -- More than half the divorce cases called on the Domestic Relations Court calendar here today were passed or continued, apparently as a result of a diocesan edict that limits the part Roman Catholic lawyers may take in such proceedings.

Vincent Hallinan, Progressive party candidate for President, challenged Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower yesterday to make public the full text of a letter from Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet, parts of which General Eisenhower read Wednesday night.

Residents of the Seventeenth Congressional District, New York's "silk stocking" area, have been seeing a good deal in recent weeks of Harry Grossman, who would like to be their Representative in the Eighty-third Congress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Small Defense Plants Administration, in its fourth quarterly report, emphasized that the feud which developed with the Department of Commerce nearly a year ago over the jurisdiction of S. D. P. A. and the department's small business divisions has been resolved.

Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee will arrive this morning at La Guardia Airport from Miami to carry out a three-day program of campaigning, at meetings in this city and on Long Island and on television, for the Democratic ticket headed by Governor Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.

HILLSBORO, Mo., Oct. 31--A fire tonight swept through a three-story nursing home here and A. A. Hiffman, civil defense director for the area, said at least eighteen persons were burned to death. Mr. Hiffman said that about twenty-one persons were injured.

Events tonight: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; "Madame Butterfly," City Center, 8:15; Cecile Dulac, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Berkshire String Quartet, John Langstaff, baritone, Washington Irving High School, 8:30.
BALTIMORE, Oct, 31 (AP) -- Nine colts and the Brookmeade Stable's filly, Tritium, will try to produce some evidence of becoming stars by winning tomorrow's Pimlico Futurity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Air Force Secretary Thomas K. Finletter said tonight that General Van Fleet only recently was "all full of praise" for the United States training program for South Korean troops.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of President Truman's address here tonight:

Young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons, including Mrs. Ludlow Fowler Jr. and Miss Daphne Towne, are aiding in the sale of tickets for the performance of "Dial 'M' for Murder," the new mystery play, with Maurice Evans in the leading role, on the night of Nov. 13 at the Plymouth Theatre for the benefit of the Youth Consultation Service.

Senator Morse's indeed shocking disclosure of a "Top Secret" State Department memorandum has actually aided the Republican cause greatly, since it shows the responsibility for Korea should be placed squarely on the State Department.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter, who earlier in the week had ordered a number of Columbia University students stricken from the voting lists, expressed his regret yesterday for having to do so.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Mexico's Joaquin d'Harcourt on Cordoves won tonight's individual open jumping after the United States took its third straight low-score team championship at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Rallying behind their driving fullback, Capt. Bob Haner, Villanova College preserved its unbeaten record tonight by scoring three times in the final half for a 20-20 tie with the rugged Parris Island Marines.

Whatever its other shortcomings, the City Planning Commission has for years seen the transit problem more clearly and taken a position far more courageously than has the city administration. The commission's message accompanying the proposed 1953 capital budget, made public yesterday, is notable for the wise advice it offers to the Board of Estimate and the City Council.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, will make another nation - wide broadcast Monday night, election eve, about the "record" of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic nominee for President, on the subject of Communists in Government.

A documentary short, "One Plane, One Bomb, One City," originally a C. B. S. "See It Now" television program of the mock bombing attack on New York carried but last June by the Air Force and the Civil Defense Command, will open at the Victoria Theatre on Thursday, Nov. 6, with the feature, "Breaking Through the Sound Barrier."

SINGAPORE, Oct. 31 -- Six terrorists raided a shop in Pelangei village in the Kuala Pilai area of the state of Negri Sembilan last night and stole a shotgun and ammunition. On Wednesday night terrorists raided a village near Segamat in the state of Johore and left with a big haul of home guard and police arms.

The Police Athletic League, recreational and anti-delinquency program for New York City's boys and girls, has done so many fine things that any questions raised about it are bound to be viewed initially with a skeptical and possibly hostile eye. Yet they should not be allowed to go unnoticed amid the many other criticisms of the Police Department voiced in the Bruce Smith inquiry for the Mayor's Management Survey.

The New York Corrugated Box Company has leased the one-story building at 938-842 Grand Street, Brooklyn, from the Grand Marble Works, Inc., in a transaction negotiated by the Kalmon Dolgin Company as broker. The building, containing 5,500 square feet of space, will be used for processing and distributing corrugated boxes for the dress and clothing trade.

Rocky Marciano, heavyweight champion of the world, yesterday received a belt emblematic of his title from Nat Fleischer, publisher of Ring Magazine. The ceremony took place at a meeting of the New York Boxing Writers Association at Al and Dick's Restaurant.

John van Druten's latest play, "I've Got Sixpence," co-starring Edmond O'Brien and Viveca Lindfors, will hang up its banner at the Barrymore Theatre starting Dec. 2. Arrangements for the booking were completed yesterday by Gertrude Macy and Walter Starcke, producers of the drama that deals with the financial, sex and spiritual problems of a New York couple.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- On the basis of confidential information supplied by the United States Government, Secretary General Trygve Lie has dismissed three United Nations staff members who had refused to give testimony about alleged Communist activities.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 31 -- Twelve hundred convicts returned to their cells at the Ohio Penitentiary tonight after rioting and setting eight buildings afire in the downtown Columbus prison.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 31 -- In his defense against the Chinese Nationalist demand for his extradition, Lieut. Gen. P. T. Mow told a Mexican court that the "group headed by Chiang Kai-shek" had charged him with embezzlement as a pretext for reprisals against his "actions to fight corruption" in Formosa.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent over the week ended last Tuesday to 110.4 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products decreased 0.6 per cent, largely because of lower prices for fresh fruits, hogs, steers, cotton, eggs and some fresh vegetables. Sizable price increases were recorded for live poultry, copra and wool.

ABOARD STEVENSON TRAIN, Oct. 31 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson made his final bid for the twenty electoral votes of Maryland, West Virginia and Delaware "in absentia" today as an Arkansas Traveler named Senator J. William Fulbright took over the rear platform chores of the absent candidates.

As if Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson didn't have enough trouble yesterday helping to quell a prison riot and trying to pick up an interrupted campaign schedule, he broke a front tooth while dining on his plane returning to New York. Minutes before he delivered his speech at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night, a dentist off stage put an emergency cap on the upper left first bicuspid for the Governor's television appearance.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Oct. 31 -- An exhibition of forty paintings by the late Hamilton King will open tomorrow at East Hampton Guild Hall, where Mr. King had been an exhibiting member-artist since the hall's galleries opened in 1931 with an exhibit he arranged.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan elevated twenty - two police officers to higher ranks yesterday at promotion ceremonies at Police Headquarters. In announcing the promotions, he reiterated his belief that all advancements should be in accordance with the merit system, which, he said, he intended to follow in the case of all vacancies.

DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Reports that the rules might be eased to permit Maryland and Duke to play in bowl games buzzed throughout the Southern Conference today. But there was no substantiation in official quarters.

Installation of completely automatic facilities in industry often is not worth while, David A. Wallace, president of the Chrysler division, Chrysler Corporation, said yesterday. He spoke before concluding sessions of the Society for the Advancement of Management's annual conference in the Statler Hotel.

Fresh rumors concerning this newspaper's position in the campaign have again induced a flood of letters and telegrams. These rumors are that we shall make some dramatic last-minute witch from Eisenhower to Stevenson; that this decision was reached at a recent meeting of our editorial council, and that such a switch was adopted, or defeated, by a number of "votes" variously reported.

" Ten Operatic Masterpieces" have been put in book form through the cooperation of Broadcast Music, Inc., G. Ricordi Co. and Charles Scribner's Sons. The volume contains the operas "The Marriage of Figaro," "Tales of Hoffman," "The Mastersingers of Nuremberg," "Aida," "Carmen," "Boheme," "Tosca," "Rosenkavalier," 'Love of Three Oranges" and "Wozzeck."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- The Government's Renegotiation Board said today it expects to examine about 7,000 defense contracts signed in 1951 to determine whether there have been excessive profits.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- The drive of the underdeveloped countries for new international agencies to finance economic projects took a new course today that brought them closer to the positions of the great powers.
One of six boys playing a Halloween game atop Long Island freight cars yesterday afternoon had a narrow escape when he was left dangling from a Brooklyn overpass twenty feet above the tracks.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Army concludes its home season at Michie Stadium tomorrow when the cadets play host to Virginia Military Institute in the sixth game between the two institutions. A crowd of 15,000 is expected.

SALEM, Ore., Oct. 31 (UP) -- Sixteen convicts, including three condemned murderers, staged a "strike" and refused to return to their cells at the Oregon State Penitentiary today because they received macaroni and cheese instead of potatoes.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 31 -- The first European Assembly of Political Youth -- "Strasbourg Junior," as it is generally known -- concluded tonight a strenuous five-day session with ardent endorsement of all the projects of its elders in the field of European integration.

An embarrassed steamship industry is trying to work out a way to proffer a polite but firm "no" to a costly proposal made this week by the Department of Justice. The suggestion worked out by the department's Immigration and Naturalization Service is to send immigration inspectors abroad by air so they can examine passengers and crews on the return trans-Atlantic crossings.

Lafayette's high-scoring football team registered its fourth straight victory by turning back James Madison, 27 -- 7, at Abraham Lincoln Field yesterday. It was the second defeat in five games for the Highwaymen.
A poll of 448 undergraduates at the New York University School of Law on Presidential preferences showed 75.5 per cent favored Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic nominee.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson have sent statements to a Brazilian newspaper chain declaring that, whoever wins the election, the United States will continue its Good Neighbor policy.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in October expanded slightly over the previous month, but the volume of business droped to the smallest for a corresponding month since 1948, despite the increased trading hours.

Simon W. Gerson, People's Rights candidate for Congress in Brooklyn's Thirteenth Congressional District, will speak for fifteen minutes tomorrow night on television Station WABD (Channel 5). The nominee said it would be the first appearance of an acknowledged Communist on TV here.

The election, for once, poses only small problems for the liquor industry. Oregon and North Dakota are going to vote on whether they will permit sale of whisky by the drink. The town of Elko, Cattaraugus County, New York, population ninety-five, is going to act locally as to whether it should go dry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Anthracite operators and the United Mine Workers were reported close to agreement tonight on new contract terms that would provide a wage increase about as large as the one recently negotiated in the northern soft coal industry.

The congregations of Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, and of Judson Memorial Baptist Church on Washington Square will become affiliated formally with the New York City Congregational Church Association of the New York Congregational Christian Conference at 8 P. M. Thursday, it was announced yesterday.

New securities offered publicly by underwriters here in October showed a marked decline from those made a year ago. The combined total of $606,712,000 for bonds and stocks compared with $1,025,872,000 in October, 1951. Compared with September of this year, stock offerings in October were slightly larger and bond flotations smaller.

The dual rate system proposed by the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference was again supported yesterday, this time by Prof. Henry R. Trumbower of the University of Wisconsin's Department of Commerce and Economics.

Educational measures for traffic safety among children in Copenhagen, Denmark, were discussed recently in an interview with a keen observer from that city. Erik Groes-Petersen, assistant commissioner of police and chief of traffic in Copenhagen, is on a traffic inspection tour of this country's largest cities under the auspices of the American - Scandinavian Foundation.

The Air Force is determined to spread among small business men here and elsewhere its purchasing for the 143-wings authorized by the last Congress. A total of $7,000,000,000 is committed to the Eastern Procurement District with headquarters in New York, of which $4,500,000,000 is still "in work" and available for small subcontracts.
GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- A group of prominent American businessmen has participated this week that they hope and believe may be an important event in the history of European capitalism.

Charles Kibel has completed the assemblage of an apartment house site through the purchase of a plot fronting 200 feet on the north side of Beech Avenue, 250 feet east of Kissena Boulevard, in Flushing, Queens. Mrs. Frieda Brown was the seller and the Halleran Agency was the broker.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Oct. 31 -- Garish jack o'lanterns blazed on the store windows here tonight and witches glared through the glass in acrobatic stances on painted brooms. Outsized cats stalked silently through the chilly night and all manner of imagined hob-goblins joined the strictly two-dimensional display of Halloween's traditional characters.

Senator Estes Kefauver, speaking in behalf of the man who defeated him for the Democratic Presidential nomination, predicted yesterday victory for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson in the belief that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had forfeited his chances of winning the independent voters.
New York's voluntary hospitals grew out of the recognition by public-spirited men and women that medical care should be made available to those who could not afford to pay for it.
The annual Red Mass under the auspices of the New York Guild of Catholic Lawyers will be celebrated at 10 A. M. tomorrow at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman will preside.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Nov. 10 on $7,280,000 of loan notes to finance development of Douglas Houses in Manhattan and Marlboro Houses, Brooklyn, both low-rent state-aided projects. The notes will be dated Dec. 1, 1952, and will come due July 20, 1953.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Flashy Billy Hair harnessed enough of Clemson's great single-wing offensive power to spark the Tigers to a 13-0 football triumph over Boston College's sluggish Eagles tonight at Braves Field. The victory broke the Southerners' four-game losing streak.
The following is a list of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:
The riot at the Menard State Prison in Illinois was the latest of a series of disturbances that have struck fifteen prisons throughout the country this year, according to The Associated Press.
Futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange were active again yesterday and closing prices on active months were 3 to 25 points net higher than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service announced tonight that a settlement had been reached in a wage dispute involving Lockheed aircraft plants in California. Some 27,000 workers had been affected by the dispute.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, demanded of Representative Cecil R. King of California, a fellow Democrat today that he take back charges he made yesterday against the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- British government securities outstripped other sections on the stock markets today. Firmness of sterling led to a steady rise in gilt edged securities of as much as five-eighths of 1 per cent.

A few years ago a pilot flying a passenger plane from New York to England was forced by mechanical failure to turn back to La Guardia Airport shortly after the take-off. When he called the control tower for landing instructions the operator asked if he had a rough engine.

More than a year ago, Herman Wilensky, 31-year-old convicted bookmaker, heard of a "sure thing" in the sixth race at Narrangansett Park. So did a number of others in the gambling fraternity around the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn.

With the exception of two games, one of which was postponed because of the indisposition of Eileen Tranmer, one of the English players, the sixth round of the women's world chess championship challengers' tournament was completed yesterday, with two of the Soviet players tied for the lead, according to a report from Russian news sources.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 31 -- Three divisions of the new East German army have been activated and equipped with artillery and tanks.
WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY in Korea, Oct. 31 -- A poll among American soldiers here indicates that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson is favored over Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower by about 2 to 1.
The man's vest, which all but disappeared during World War II along with the suit with two pairs of pants, is making a strong comeback.

THE lack of rain and the resulting dry woods, which constitute a serious fire hazard, may cut down the open hunting seasons in several Eastern states, and in some areas it will take several hours of heavy rain to improve conditions.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Sales policies of the steel industry must be completely overhauled before defense business seeks a lower level. Tom C. Campbell, editor of The Iron Age, told 250 members of the National Tool and Die Manufacturers Association at its seventh national convention here today. Otherwise, he predicted, the three "suicidal" trends of higher wages, higher taxes and higher prices forced upon it by Government will wreck the industry.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's address in the Chicago Stadium tonight:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Department of Defense identified today 539 additional casualties of the Korean war. The list included forty-seven killed, 443 wounded, eleven missing and thirty-eight injured. No casualties were reported from Connecticut and New Jersey. Casualties from New York were:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Jess Larson, Administration of the Defense Materials Procurement Agency, said today he was "gravely concerned" over the number of lead and zinc mines that have closed down in recent weeks because of declines in prices offered for the two metals.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- United Nations officials disclaimed responsibility today for midtown traffic snarls that local merchants had laid at the door of the world organization yesterday.

Prompt action by the city to establish an independent Transit Authority "with suitable sources of revenue" to take over and operate the municipal transit system was recommended yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

KAOHIUNG, Formosa, Oct. 31 -- The first shipment of United States planes for the Chinese Nationalist Air Force since establishment of the Nationalist Government on Formosa arrived today aboard the United States Navy Escort Carrier Windham Bay.

The rice shortage in the Orient, producer and consumer of 95 per cent of the world's supply, has been the subject of grave concern in recent months. It is one of the most serious problems facing the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations.

The news columns carried word the other day of the progress being made in several Midwestern and Southern cities in the sale of synthetic ice cream. Early reports from Chicago, Kansas City, St. Louis and Dallas, for example, had it that the consumer response has been so satisfactory that lawyers were busy studying the various state laws to find out where the synthetic product could be sold.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 31 -- India's ancient and strongly entrenched countrywide system of caste distinctions in the Hindu religion, with its attendant institution of untouchability, offers the readiest avenue for the spread of communism here, Jagjivan Ram, Minister for Communications, and himself an Untouchable, declared today in opening a conference of Untouchable legislators and other leaders of this large and depressed community at Nagpur.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 13 appeared a comment on a statement made by Congressman E. Celler.

Many printers are now determined to keep out of the "shoemaker's shoeless children" category and are embarking on self advertising campaigns, it was brought out at the recent convention of the Printing Industry of America in St. Louis.
TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 1 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,420, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson brought his Presidential campaign in the East to a close last night with the charge that his Republican rival was playing politics with peace and war, raising false hopes and risking the loss of America's allies in Europe and Asia.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 31 -- Indonesia's two largest Government parties announced today they could not support the present movement for the dissolution of Parliament. They condemned the movement as undemocratic and unconstitutional.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 1 -- Battered United Nations troops withdrew last evening from the crest of "Triangle Hill," north of Kumhwa on the central Korean front, leaving the Chinese Communist foe in possession after twenty-four hours of continuous combat in one of the bloodiest engagements of the war.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, declared tonight Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has made "a belated attempt to maek the training of South Korean troops a partisan political question."

A local price stabilization board made up of business and consumer members will be set up for the New York metropolitan area, it was announced yesterday by James G. Lyons, regional director of the Office of Price Stabilization.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 -- Four thousand members of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., voted unanimously today, according to union officials, to go on strike at noon next Tuesday unless the Wage Stabilization Board acts by then on gains obtained by the union after a two-month strike last summer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Voice of America, the foreign broadcasting service of the State Department, will complete its daily election news coverage with a dusk-to-dawn report on election results in many languages Tuesday night.

The pensioners, alcoholics, drifters and derelicts who eke out an existence along the pavements of the Bowery have devised their own social structure with a strict code of honor, morality and manners.

Representative members of the social and music worlds attended the dinner and entertainment given last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to mark the twentieth anniversary of the founding of the Musicians Emergency Fund of which Mrs. Lytle Hull is president and Fritz Kreisler, chairman of the board.

The plans of Antenor Patino, Bolivian tinplate heir, for flying to France yesterday were interrupted when sheriff's deputies visited his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and informed him he was under arrest.

ALBANY, Oct 31 -- With above normal temperatures and high winds forecast for this week-end, officials of the State Conservation Department said today the forest fire hazard was still great in most of the state.
ALBANY, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Turkey growers in New York State are raising a record number of birds this year for holiday tables.

Three of Italy's well known contemporary artists are represented by work at the Heller Gallery. For most of his painting life, Giorgio Morandi has been attempting to wrest meaning from still-life and occasional landscape. His means, that is to say the narrow limits of his dovelike color, become increasingly economical but there is a strange attraction to these studies that is often termed "metaphysical."

Columbia and Cornell, football rivals since 1889, will meet for the fortieth time at Baker Field today. The Light Blue, victorious by one-point margins as underdog the last two years, is favored to win more substantially than that from a Big Red team that has lost all five starts.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 (UP) -- The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission cited today thirty-five persons from sixteen states and Alaska for outstanding acts of heroism. Three of those recognized died in attempts to save the lives of others.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Changes in Federal rent controls legislation, all designed to give the Office of Rent Stabilization more authority in imposing ceilings in various communities, will be asked of the incoming Congress in January.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 31 -- President Truman asserted tonight that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had visited Korea in 1946 and that if he was "wrong" in later recommending the withdrawal of United States forces from that country "there was no reason to suppose he would be right in 1953."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Republican National Committee reported to Congress today that as of last Wednesday it had received $2,680,083 in campaign contributions since Jan. 1 and had spent $2,214,087.

CHESTER, Ill., Oct. 31 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson personally led a show of force that put down a five-day riot at Menard State Prison. The Democratic Presidential candidate stood by as a surrender ultimatum he had written was read to the 339 rebellious convicts.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad is getting ready to meet the financing problem raised by the approaching maturity of $14,482,000 of 4 per cent bonds of the Harlem River and Port Chester Railroad. This issue, which covers New Haven lines leading into the New York area, comes due on May 1, 1954.

A football coach doing his own scouting -- that was the picture yesterday as Hackley opposed Horace Mann on the latter's gridiron. Watching the proceedings was Frank Bertino, Riverdale Country School's head coach. To make sure no tricks were missed, he had his assistant, Jim Karney, along. It was Karney who made notes.

Walter F. O'Malley, president of the Dodgers, is in favor of the major leagues adopting the proposed new rule that would extend the intra-league trading deadline to July 31 from the present date of June 15 and that would require also "top-to-bottom" waivers in both major leagues.

This country's economy will grow and improve so long as our research laboratories continue active in our universities and in our industry, Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., said last night at a dinner of the American section of the Society of Chemical Industry in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Danger signals are set today for most of the handful of major college football powers that remain unbeaten.

Brazen hold-up men, working in daylight in busy sections of Manhattan, took $6,900 in three payroll thefts, and last night in Elmhurst, Queens, the manager of a chain grocery store was forced at pistol-point to surrender $5,282 in cash and checks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- If anyone should see what looks like a floor lamp standing in an open field it may be an atomic air burst direction finder, patented this week by a Schenectady physicist. It will indicate not only the direction from which an explosion comes, but its elevation, and can be read by a layman, such as a civil defense volunteer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau said today that it expected November to reverse the October weather pattern. The bureau said:
ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S TRAIN IN OHIO, Oct. 31 -- An Ohio mother, who lost two sons from Korean battle wounds on the same day, received the "heartfelt sympathy" of President Truman today.

Operations of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company and its United States and Canadian subsidiaries in the first nine months this year resulted in a net profit of $5,764,172, equal to $1.15 a common share, the report disclosed yesterday.
PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 31 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, denied today that she had done "an about-face" on the question of replacing United States troops with South Koreans.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower took a stand before a roaring Chicago Stadium crowd here tonight against both isolationism and McCarthyism. In his first speech in Chicago since he won the Republican Presidential nomination from the Middle West's favorite Senator, Robert A. Taft of Ohio, the nominee asserted:

As three city departments moved yesterday against Mrs. Bessie Honig, alleged owner or agent for at least six "firetrap" apartment houses, the Department of Housing and Buildings announced that 1,914 violation notices had been served on Harlem landlords in the housing survey of that area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Nationalization of the Bolivian tin mines will not be followed by the taking over of other properties and resources by that Government, Victor Andrade, the Bolivian Ambassador, said today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (UP) -- The wife of Gen. James A. Van Fleet, Eighth Army Commander in Korea, said today she had turned over to General Eisenhower a copy of a letter her husband had sent from Korea at the request of the Republican Presidential nominee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Regional and district officials of the Office of Price Stabilization were advised today by Tighe E. Woods, price administrator, to "go slow" in nominating persons to serve on proposed local stabilization boards of the agency.

A psychological appeal for votes for the Socialist party was made last night by Darlington Hoopes, candidate for President, in a nation-wide National Broadcasting Company television and radio hook-up at 11:15 P. M.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 -- Senator Robert A. Taft charged here tonight that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for President, "was engaged in a surrender of principles."

QUEBEC CITY, Oct. 31 (UP) -- A Swedish sea captain beached his freighter today on the rocky bank of the St. Lawrence River, near here, to prevent it from sinking after a collision with another vessel in a fog.

A man who has traveled much in Manhattan to keep his finger on the political pulse of the nation announced yesterday that his personal opinion poll indicated that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson would be elected President of the United States next Tuesday.

Last night's performance of "The Marriage of Figaro" at the City Center offered a new Susanna in the person of Laurel Hurley, the young soprano now singing her first season with the New York City Opera Company.

A record world production of 14,000,000 carats of industrial diamonds was reached in 1951, with the United States importing about 86 per cent of the supply, A. E. Long, an official of the United States Bureau of Mines, said yesterday at a drilling symposium at the University of Minnesota.

In your issue of Oct. 15 you carry a full page advertisement headed "Socialism? Brother, You Don't Know the Half of It." It appears that this expensive advertisement is a reprint of what has already been published nationally by the Standard Steel Spring Company of Corapolis, Pa.

Savings deposits held by smaller commercial banks with assets of less than $7,500,000 account for 33.98 per cent of all deposits of these banks, according to a survey just completed by the American Bankers Association. The average number of savings accounts in each of the 2,208 participating banks was 1,329, with an average balance of $859.

Johnny Bratton, Chicago battler, stopped Joe Miceli of the East Side in the star bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Scheduled for ten rounds, the fight came to an end in 0:18 of the eighth when Referee Harry Kessler intervened to save the local boxer from further punishment.

UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 31 -- El Abed Bouhafa, Tunisian nationalist, said today that his denunciation of a statement made yesterday by Salah Ben Youssef was based on his belief that Mr. Ben Youssef had violated decisions taken by North African nationalist parties.

Gary Graffman, winner in past seasons of two Rachmaninoff Fund awards and the soloist, as winner of the Leventritt award, with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, presented a program that made immense tests of the interpreter's range of technique and imagination last night in Town Hall.

Utilizing the services of more than twenty-five entertainers, musicians and dancers, the Musicians Emergency Fund acted as sponsor for an elaborate program last night at the Waldorf-Astoria on the occasion of its twentieth anniversary dinner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The State Department said today that the controversial official document on Korea cited by Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon was still a "top secret" document in department files.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 31 -- With Wingback Dick Yaffa returning to the starting line-up, Princeton's once-beaten varsity football team will be at full strength for the first time in three weeks when it meets Brown in Palmer Stadium tomorrow.

Lafourche, claimed for $7,500 a little over a month ago and now running in the better race-track company, won the mile and a sixteenth Achievement purse that was the main event at Empire-at-Jamaica yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon said tonight that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson "apparently thinks first hand information about a problem concerning a local prison is important -- but that a first hand inspection and study of the battlefields of Korea, where 123,000 Americans are casualties is not important."

BONN, Germany, Oct. 31 -- A spokesman for the Federal Government stressed today that despite protests from the Arab nations the West German Parliament would be urged to ratify the $822,000,000 restitutions agreement with Israel and affiliated Jewish organizations.

Dr. Helen Montague, still alert and keen-eyed, her hair only partly graying, emptied her desk and bade good-by to her staff at Children's Court yesterday after thirty-five years as chief of the court's psychiatric services.

Reversing the October trend of recent years, when retirement of bonds before maturity usually was around the lowest level of the year, the prepayments last month rose to the highest total for any month since July and the largest for an October since 1946.

The New York Knickerbockers. who came within an eyelash of winning the National Basketball Association championship the past two seasons, will launch their 1952-53 loop campaign at Madison Square Garden tonight. Their opponents will be the Baltimore Bullets.

In sharp contrast to the spurious "peace" conference recently staged by the Chinese Communists in Peiping is the Overseas Chinese Affairs Conference that has been held in Taipei, Formosa. To this meeting came 262 delegates from twenty-eight Chinese communities throughout the world.

The virtues and shortcomings of the latest addition to the family of home laundry equipment, the dryer, were discussed yesterday at the second and final day's meeting of the Sixth National Home Laundry Conference at the Commodore Hotel.

ABOARD STEVENSON TRAIN in the East, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's campaign train -- without him aboard -- suddenly backed into a crowd at Silver Spring, Md., today and caused wild shouts and screams, but nobody was injured.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The National Committee for an Effective Congress endorsed today as "most eminently qualified" seventeen Senate candidates, thirteen Democrats and four Republicans.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and its wholly owned subsidiaries increased earnings in the third quarter by $13,351,294, but the nine months' result was $3,342,538 less than a year ago, according to the statement to be released today.

Calling many "alleged" programs for public improvement "carping criticism and baseless accusation," Mayor Impellitteri yesterday praised the New York Federation of Women's Clubs for its "affirmative and constructive spirit."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Roger L. Putnam, Economic Stabilization Administrator, laid down the rules today for employer-to-employe Christmas presents in the form of cash bonuses, gifts, or time off.

Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., candidate for re-election in the Seventeenth (Silk Stocking) Congressional District, is undismayed by the empty chair his Democratic opponent, Harry Grossman, is using to dramatize his charge of absenteeism.

Fordham's football forces hope to hit the highway to victory this afternoon when they meet Detroit University at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, in their fourth game of the season. The kick-off is scheduled for 1:30 P. M.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Oct. 31 -- The first "working agreement" between the two main streams of Protestant thought regarding church union was reached here today.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- Formal polls of Coos and Strafford Counties in New Hampshire, where voters traditionally have backed the "winning" Presidential candidates for more than half a century, give Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower the edge in 1952. Democratic leaders, however, insist that that "just isn't so."

The strongest price rise in almost two months lifted the stock market yesterday out of its stalemated condition, and immediately brought the comment from analysts that the action forecast a Republican victory on Tuesday. Followers of the Democratic party claimed it was a "staged" show.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- The importance of Asia as a market for motion pictures, both from the political and the economic standpoint, is being discussed by John Evans, British Government, Film Censorship officer for Singapore, Malaya and Sarawak, in a series of talks now being held with Hollywood studio production heads.

Harry Gross provided yesterday an explanation for one of the puzzling aspects of his behavior when, last September, he suddenly balked at testifying against eighteen policemen accused of conspiracy to accept graft payments. The manner of his refusal, which technically saved him from long jail terms for multiple offenses against the dignity of the court, was chosen simply on the advice of counsel, Gross asserted.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Oct. 31 -- Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe of Oyster Bay, exhibiting orchids, gardenias, camellias and rare tropical blooms and plants in a 250-square-foot setting in the former home of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, now the country seat of Long Island University, won a blue ribbon this afternoon in the first day's judging of the five-day benefit fall flower show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 31 -- The Bolivian Government nationalized the big three tin producing companies of Bolivia today under a decree implying there may be no payment for stockholders.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for President, won a harrowing race with time and the weather last night when he arrived in New York by plane for the traditional Friday-before-election rally in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Yale rules a favorite over Dartmouth in the thirty-sixth meeting between the rivals in the Bowl tomorrow. The kick-off is scheduled for 1:30 and a crowd of 40,000 is expected. The Elis, tied with Penn for first place in the Ivy League, will seek their fifth successive victory and their sixth in seven games this season.

The poll takers are cautious this year. What puzzles them, as Archibald M. Crossley, Elmo Roper and Dr. George Gallup admitted Thursday evening, is the "undecided category." Mr. Crossley put this item at about 10 per cent of the total. Now, 10 per cent is a large item in an election. Ten per cent can create a sweep in the Electoral College.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- India and Pakistan plan to ask other Asian and Arab states this week-end to support a proposed United Nations good offices commission to tackle the long-standing complaint against South Africa's treatment of Indian nationals.

OTTAWA, Oct. 31 (Canadian Press) -- A Federal engineer, examining a rock sample believed to contain graphite, has spotted kyanite, leading to the discovery of huge deposits of this scarce heat-resistant mineral used to coat jet engine exhausts.
One of the largest mergers ever negotiated in the work clothing field was concluded yesterday, according to an announcement of the Blue Ridge Manufacturers, Inc., of Lynchburg, Va.

HERRON, Mich., Oct. 31 (UP) -- Five uranium miners were killed when an explosion ripped through the shaft of an abandoned gold mine with such force that frightened residents streamed from their homes twelve miles away, the state police said today.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 31 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy football team will clash with Brooklyn College tomorrow afternoon at Tomb Memorial Field, the academy gridiron at Kings Point. It will be Homecoming Day for the academy.
WITH THE AIR FORCE, in French Morocco, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The newest bill for American atom bomber bases in this restive African land is $2,000,000 to repair sagging runways.
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- France's decision to permit Parliamentary elections in the Saar next month is bound to exacerbate relations between Paris and Bonn, which have been getting worse anyway.

Announcement of the extension for three months of the national average support price for wool shorn or pulled, and its continuation during 1953 at 90 per cent of parity, caused grease wool and wool top futures to stiffen yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Wool futures were up 1.2 to 2 cents and wool tops were up 1.5 to 2.5 cents.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Kentucky's great pass-catching end, 212-pound Steve Meilinger, moved into the quarterback role for the first time in a brilliant football career to lead the Wildcats to a 29-0 victory tonight over Miami's Hurricanes.

On the top of Mount Scopus, overlooking Jerusalem, stands a group of handsome stone buildings that belong to a university. But there are no students in the halls, no professors in the classrooms. The buildings stand empty except for a few guards. A new term begins on Monday, but there will be no faculty, no teaching, no learning atop Mount Scopus.

The former residence of George Ehret Jr., at 3 East Ninety-third Street, near Fifth Avenue, has been purchased by Mrs. Charlotte Rubenstein from Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, who bought it about six months ago. The house occupies a lot 22 by 100 feet and now contains a triplex suite of nine rooms and four baths and a garden duplex apartment of six rooms and three baths.
This has been the driest October since 1924, besides being below normal in temperature and above normal in total amount of sunshine, the Weather Bureau said yesterday.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Louis Mancinelli, 26 years old, who has been practicing medicine in near-by Highland for the last two and a half years, was arrested today by the state police on a charge of practicing without a license.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- The Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today a Yugoslav resolution requesting the International Law Commission to codify "diplomatic intercourse and immunities" within the body of international law and to regard it as a priority job.

Three of the Democratic incumbents in the four Bronx Congressional Districts are conceded a definite edge in their fight for re-election but the Republicans believe they have an excellent chance of capturing the fourth seat.

FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT voted Republican in his first Presidential election. "My father and grandfather were Democrats and I was born and brought up as a Democrat, but in 1904 * * * I voted for the Republican candidate, Theodore Roosevelt, because I thought he was a better Democrat than the Democratic candidate."

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 31 (UP) -- The defending champion, Frank Stranahan, and co-favorite Billy Maxwell were upset by two young Southwestern golf stars today in third round play of the Mexican amateur championship.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A Superior Court judge took under advisement today a petition for a temporary injunction which would prevent the Puget Sound Power and Light Company from selling most of its assets to six Washington State public utilities districts.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 31 -- Two officials of the East German Parliament delivered a letter today to the office of Hermann Ehlers, President of the West German Bundestag, that may contain new proposals on Germany's reunification.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire said today that the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and a Republican Congress would result in "an investigation of the defense effort that will open the eyes of the American people wider than anything that has broken yet."

Lou Cascino ran the fastest cross-country race in City College's history yesterday as Fordham defeated the Lavender, 23 to 34, in a dual meet at Van Cortlandt Park.

The "Tree of Hope," a Harlem landmark long associated with the late Bill Robinson and the old Lafayette Theatre, was rededicated yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri in an outdoor ceremony at Seventh Avenue and 131st Street.

Some of the nation's leading scientists met last week in Boston to participate in a special symposium on nutrition which was arranged by Harvard's School of Public Health and supported by the National Vitamin Foundation. The relation of obesity to health, the psychology of overeating, the formation of fat, the relation of fat to body type were the chief topics of discussion.

Many young women are aiding in the plans for the fashion show and cocktail dance for the benefit of the Rosemary Hall Scholarship Fund to be held on Nov. 20 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza. Mrs. Thomas Lewis is chairman, and Mrs. Donald Dunwody and Mrs. Charles McAdams, vice chairmen, of the benefit committee.

A CARTOONIST is supposed to speak volumes with his drawings, so no one worries very much about his talent with words. In fact, among the contemporary political cartoonists, the commentator who signs the name Herblock to his daily drawings in The Washington Post (and 150 other newspapers) sometimes uses no words at all to put across the punch in his pungent sketches.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- A new attempt to work out formula to bring about a ceasefire in Korea has been started by members of the Asian-Arab bloc in the United Nations.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 1 -Illinois came up off the Big Ten floor today to smack Michigan with a 22-13 upset that dimmed the Wolverines' Rose Bowl chances and gave the Illini their first victory in four Conference games this season.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Head bowed and in tears, Harry Agganis knelt on the sidelines for more than half the game today while Maryland's mightiest football team marched over game but mismatched Boston University, 34 -- 7.
The theatre benefit committee of the Union Settlement has taken over the performance of "The Climate of Eden," a play by Moss Hart, on the evening of Nov. 19 at the Martin Beck Theatre.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 1 -- Undefeated Michigan State, the nation's top-ranking football club, racked up two first-half touchdowns and staved off inspired Purdue for a 14-7 victory today before 49,500 to extend its winning streak to twenty-one.

YONKERS, Nev. 1 -- Scotch Spencer, a 4-year-old gelding by Scotland, owned by Donna Lee Owen of Omaha, . .eb., and driven by Neal Houslet, took control at the three-quarters and continued to a one-length victory over Mr. Dean in 2:04 in the Blue Mountain $4,500 pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Mexican Army team tonight won the final international jump at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show to record its sixth victory in eleven events.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 1 -- The New York University football squad today out-rushed Lafayette by a wide margin but had to struggle to gain a 14-7 triumph before a Lafayette Homecoming and Founders Day gathering of 6,000.

Under Frances Rodman's "Gallery Notes" ( Oct. 26 ), which presents a variety of comments on art by notables from different countries, President Truman is quoted as being of the opinion that "so-called modern art is merely the vaporings of half-baked, lazy people."

A curious belief appears to have gained widespread acceptance among younger filmgoers concerning the cinema's historic past. Fostered in part by such extravagant lampoons as "Dream Boat" provided, an erroneous concept of what films of the pre-talkie era were like is burgeoning.

" HYPERCLOSE - UP Photography With the Exakta" by George Berkowitz, just published at 25 cents a copy by Exakta Camera Company, 46 West Twenty-ninth Street, describes several methods of obtaining subject magnifications directly in the camera.

IN THREE of the newly opened exhibitions the stress is particularly strong on tradition or discipline or both. Tradition is emphasized in the selection of paintings from Ingres to Lautrec at Paul Rosenberg's; discipline, well within the modern movement, is to be found in the final painting by the late Niles Spencer at the Downtown Gallery and in a selection of work by Leger from 1913 to 1943 at the Perls Gallery.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 1 -- Scientific and cultural approaches to the Soviet Union by the United States offer a better chance for achieving new friendship between the two nations than the present restricted diplomatic and political activity, in the opinion of Dr. S. S. Bhatnagar, eminent Indian scientist who has just returned from a visit to both countries.

LAST March, a basic repertoire of classic records was published in these pages. Bringing it completely up to date without composing a listing almost as comprehensive is a near-impossibility. The last eight months have seen a bewildering variety of new releases -- duplications new works, needed disks, unnecessary disks.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 1 (UP) -- Texas stormed into undisputed possession of first place in the Southwest Conference today with furious line play that brought three opening-period touchdowns and a 31-14 victory over Southern Methodist before 55,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The border states of Maryland and West Virginia, between them, seem likely to give Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower a net of one electoral vote, at the most, of the 266 that he needs to win the presidency.

There are museums of natural history, botanical gardens and zoos but there is no permanent microvivarium, as one biologist calls a collection of living microorganisms. Microbes and other microscopic organisms are just as important as plants and animals in the study of the many forms that life assumes.

Debutantes of this season headed by Miss Audrey Wagstaff and including Miss Margaret Gerli, are aiding in the plans for the performance of "Rigoletto," with Lily Pons, Giacinto Prandelli and Leonard Warren in the leading roles, on the night of Dec. 18 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc. Mrs. William Randolph Hearst is the founder and president of the beneficiary.

An aroused Cornell squad, smarting from the sting of five successive defeats, came from two touchdowns behind to score three times in the last period and upset favored Columbia, 21 -- 14, before 22,000 onlookers at Baker Field yesterday.

IN his two seasons as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, Rudolf Bing has gained a reputation for giving new treatments to old operas. This being so, there has been curiosity about what he and his colleagues will do to a venerable warhorse like Verdi's "La Forza del Destino," which launches the season a week from tomorrow.
PARIS, Nov. 1 -- City authorities turned down today plans for a seventeen-story, sandwich shaped United Nations "skyscraper" in Paris because it would interfere with the view of the Arc de Triomphe.

THE film business likes and consequently abuses the word unique. This is an interim report on a film in production here which rates the word in its exact and literal sense: i. e., there never has been one such before. Now half-finished, "Animal Farm" will be the first feature-length cartoon film made in England; it will also be the first cartoon film ever made for politically conscious adults.

SOUND conservation practices, while concerned primarily with the protection, restoration and improvement of wildlife resources, must include the studied control of the harvest of these resources, and it is this phase of conservation that seems to be misunderstood by many sportsmen, landowners and rule- of-thumb conservationists.

THIS is the season for little bouquets. Lucky is the gardener who can gather armfuls of 'mums after the first black frost or cut branches of vivid berries to deck the house. The season when it is necessary to learn how to make much from little has opened.

Two prison riots on Friday attracted nation-wide attention: one because a Presidential candidate who is also a Governor had to break off his campaign for a few hours to go to the scene; the other because of the great destruction of public property which resulted. These riots were the fourteenth and fifteenth of a series of disturbances this year in the nation's prisons.

The maples have had their glory, and the birches, and the oaks have spread their russets and purples and browns; and now the evergreens, the pines and spruces and the lowly pasture cedars, come into their own. They stand in massed greens against the hillsides, brilliant against the white birch boles and the silvery trunks of the maples, greener it seems than at any other season.

APPROXIMATELY 150 outstanding artists representing many of the countries which are members of the United Nations have entered a prize contest for designs from which the world organization's Postal Administration may make selections for use on U. N. postage stamps in the years ahead. Several of the competitors are Americans.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 -- Notre Dame conquered Navy, 17 -- 6, before 61,927 spectators at Municipal Stadium today, but the score is deceptive. Aside from the Fighting Irish margin of victory, virtually everything else in the contest was top-heavy in Notre Dame's favor.

EARLY birds in the fall migration of trailer dwellers to Florida's west coast will catch a glimpse of things to come at the convention of the Trailercoach Dealers National Association in St. Petersburg from Nov. 10 to 16.

Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon, who resigned from the Republican party in criticism of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's campaign, declared yesterday that a Republican victory would "put the military mind in the White House" and increase the danger of an all-out war.

A GOOD many readers, one fears, will find Robie Macauley's excellent first novel either too subtle or too trite. Technically, "The Disguises of Love" involves the intricate interweavings of the streams of consciousness of a professor of psychology, his wife and his son who pretends he likes comic books and secretly reads the best literature he can find.

MADRID, Nov. 1 -- The Spanish Government ordered employers in many fields of industrial and commercial activity today to give employes double wages for this month only to ease hardship felt by working masses as a result of steadily climbing prices. The official bulletin will publish the decree tomorrow.

Little by little, the effect of currency depreciations on world price levels is beginning to be felt. Their pressure on prices is battling against the upward force of the remaining shortages in some areas. Expressed in dollars, the index of Swiss wholesale prices has fallen 5 1/2 per cent since 1948 and that of the United Kingdom has risen only 3 per cent.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 1 -- Archibald M. Mull Jr., past president of the State Bar of California and active supporter of Gov. Earl Warren, California's three-term Republican Governor, announced today his unqualified support of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic nominee for President.

An opportunity to buy a ferryboat, rowboats and catamarans was given amateur and professional boatmen yesterday, when the salvage division of the Department of Purchase put the floating equipment up for public bidding.

That ubiquitous philodendron can be picked up anywhere from the dime store to the corner grocer's, and will survive considerable neglect and mistreatment while the neophyte is learning the ABC's of indoor gardening.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Having soil tested in fall allows ample time to follow recommendations for timing or fertilizing before next year's planting. To avoid inconvenience and wet soil, take samples before the ground freezes. A pint is ample but it should be a cross-section, not just surface soil. If no local agencies test soil, query the state experiment station for service.

Ships may spend longer periods at sea without the need for dry-docking to scrape rust off their bottoms or make costly hull repairs, as the result of a year-long anti-corrosion experiment made last week by the Dow Chemical Corporation.

American private investment in less developed foreign countries will probably set a new record this year and amounted to almost $1,000,000,000 in the eighteen months ended last June 30, Dr. Isador Lubin has reported to the U. N. General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee.

AT the age of 75 Dr. Hjalmar Horace Greeley Schacht, a wily, elusive and frequently despised man, despite his considerable animation and charm, has lived to fulfill richly the prophecy made in doggerel about him in the German satirical magazine "Simplicissimus" twenty-one years ago.

ATHENS, Nov. 1 -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, head of the Greek Rally party, publicly repudiated today an article in Apogevmatini, an Athens newspaper, which under the heading, "We warn you," suggested that violence would result from a Papagos defeat in the Greek elections Nov. 16.

A RECENT survey of activities that occupy leisure time of teenagers in Maplewood and the Oranges in New Jersey showed that watching television headed the list. Of the 4,821 boys and girls enrolled in high schools 88 per cent answered the questionnaire, which was designed to reveal what changes, if any, our rapidly changing culture has wrought in the adolescent's use of out-of-school hours.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Missouri broke a fiercely fought football game with Nebraska open with startling suddenness in the third quarter today as the Tigers held their Big Seven Conference lead on a 10-to-6 victory.

THIS is a new story about the girl who in "Wait for Marcy" made her hesitant entrance into the world of dates and dances. Now at 17 Marcy is sure of her place in the high school crowd but puzzled and a little aggrieved because no one treats her like a grown-up.

GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- Belgium has agreed to start removing the discriminatory controls on United States and Canadian exports that have been plaguing American business in that small but lucrative market for the last twelve months.

THE Warner Theatre, which has been dark since June when "About Face" closed, may do an about face in the near future. Last week, negotiations were in progress between the management and Twentieth Century-Fox officials, who see the Warners' erstwhile Broadway showcase as another outlet for their product.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "The Millionairess," by George Bernard Shaw, with Katharine Hepburn in the leading role, on the night of Nov. 10 at the Shubert Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Children's Professional School.

OKLAHOMA CITY -- Autumn water-skiing in the plains state of Oklahoma is a neat trick if you can do it. Many people can in this prairie state, which has plenty of suitable water and weather. Other fall sports for Sooner state tourists include deer hunting with bow and arrow or rifle, gazing at pastured buffalo and Longhorn herds, squirrel, duck and quail shooting, sailing, fishing, stagecoach and horse riding, wolf and coyote hunting.

DALLAS, Nov. 1 -- Except for Texas' drought, business in recent weeks maintained a steady and relatively bright tone, the Federal Reserve Bank's monthly summary of business indicated. The bank reported that department store sales in September were 12 per cent above August levels, and 7 per cent over September last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -Representative John W. Byrnes, Republican of Wisconsin, today stood back of his statement accusing the Secretary of the Treasury, John W. Snyder, of "highly suspicious activities" in a Hollywood tax case, despite what he called the Cabinet officer's "pious denial and holier-than-thou attitude."

IT was spring in Tennessee. Deep in his goosefeather bed Jim Blake stirred to the shrill cry of the first whippoorwill, then set forth to feed the farm animals and his father's horse, which was now his horse, for his red-headed father had gone off with Andrew Jackson to fight the Creek Indians, somewhere far to the south.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 1 (UP) -- Twenty-five Shetland ponies and small saddle horses burned to death today in a blaze which swept through a barn housing fifty-five horses here. It was Kentucky's second horse barn fire in less than a week.

His heroes have been beaten before -- and good. The Bears once whomped the Giants, 57 to 7. The Cardinals once outraced them, 63 to 35, and the Eagles once rode roughly over them, 45 to 0.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Expenditures for new industrial plant facilities announced during October slipped to $10,501,000, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. Now a half-century old, the American Power Boat Association, ruling body of the sport of speed boating, will hold its fiftieth annual meeting and election at Cincinnati on Nov. 15 and 16. The results of the mail voting which has been in progress for several weeks will be made known then.

Rabbi Irving Miller, president of the Zionist Organization of America, asserted last night that a lasting peace between Israel and the Arab nations could be achieved only through direct negotiations. New recordings of Debussy's piano preludes will be a feature of the recorded concert on Wednesday between noon and 2 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. THE city dweller and suburban home owner are almost equally dependent on cut flowers for brilliance and cheer during the long drab winter. Much to their dismay, flowers are considerably more expensive during the very months when the need seems greatest.

FOUNDATION plantings that are left to their own devices may grow out of bounds and "swallow up a house," says George M. Codding of the Bartlett Tree Expert Company. Trees planted too close to a house may do much the same thing, he points out.

THE great political importance of conservation is underlined not only by the amount of space both party platforms gave this vital subject but also by the careful attention both Presidential candidates have paid it.
Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for President, was cut off the air on Friday night before he was able to finish his address at the Democratic rally in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

MONTREAL, Nov. 1 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens defeated the New York Rangers, 4 -- 1, tonight, but 14,787 fans wept home mildly disappointed because Maurice (Rocket) Richard failed to break the National Hockey League scoring record of 324 goals.
VIENNA, Nov. 1 -- Five American manufacturers held a "management seminar" in Vienna this week designed to demonstrate to Austrian industrialists the advantages of increasing productivity.

AMES, Iowa, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Powerful Oklahoma, led by the running of Haliback Billy Vessels and the "magic ball tricks" of Quarterback Eddie Crowder, smashed Iowa State, 41 to 0, today in a Big Seven football game.

IN 1947, at the peak of record production for children, I attempted an evaluation of the entire output and an assessment of significant trends. At that time commercial exploitation dominated the field. Little or no attention was given to the making of records that would bring to children the best entertainment that could be fashioned for them.

DURHAM, N. C., Nov 1 -- A trio of tornadic Georgia Tech backs and a tackle who blocked two punts trampled Duke's perfect record, 28 to 7, today as the effortless Engineers from Atlanta stormed through their twenty-first game without defeat.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 1 -- Ohio penitentiary was quiet today except for one flareup of disobedience, after last night's rioting of more than six hours in which 2,000 convicts set fires causing damage that may run to almost $1,000,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- The final irony of this astonishing and in some ways appalling political campaign is that after all those miles and all those speeches, General Eisenhower and Governor Stevenson were right back in Chicago this week-end, trying to prove things which almost everybody took for granted at the nominating conventions here three months ago.
Final "Get Out the Vote" appeals by four national agencies were accompanied yesterday by predictions that the voting on Tuesday would set a nation-wide record for the number of ballots cast.

INTERVALE, N. H. -- The biggest program of improvement in four years will be found in New England winter vacationlands this season. This was made clear during the seventh annual Winter Activities Conference of the New England Council attended by more than 100 resort and lift operators, hotel owners, representatives of state development and highway commissions, travel agents and affiliated organizations here last week-end.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 1 -- Bucknell returned to the victory column today by defeating Lehigh, 28 to 6, before 5,000 in the annual Dad's Day game in Memorial Stadium.

A 2-year-old child who was not only hard of hearing but also had been unwilling to wear a hearing aid or communicate with her parents was taught, within six months, to make and use a number of words by Prof. O. Hobart Mowrer, psychologist, of the University of Illinois. He treated the child much as he would a bird.

ANICHE was left empty a place left unfilled with loss to his friends, his colleagues and his art when Frederick Jacobi went to his rest after a heart collapse on the twenty-fourth of this month in this city.

Since the establishment of the National Health and Welfare Retirement Association seven years ago, $34,000,000 has been entrusted to its board of trustees by 2,300 health and welfare organizations to provide retirement benefits. This was announced last week by Henry Bruere, board chairman, at the group's annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, declared today that communism in the United States could be defeated only by the truth and not by "vigilante attacks, irrational tirades and forceful suppression."

The plastic surgeon can now make new noses, chins, foreheads or other parts out of damaged human features with cartilage taken from young cattle and specially treated for the purpose in the Amour Laboratories of Chicago, according to a method developed by Sir Harold K. Gillies, F. R. C. S., eminent British plastic surgeon.

The Norilsk and the Tobolsk, two modern passenger ships, built in Italy for Soviet Russia, have been delivered to that country and are now reported to be in Viadivostok harbor. Although relatively small -- each grosses 3,500 tons -- they have a combined passenger capacity of 692.

The United States Forest Service has begun a two-year program to determine accurately for the first time the country's total timber resources and arrive at methods for conserving them. A description of the program and the reaction of some lumber manufacturers to it was outlined last week by R. E. Broderick, executive secretary of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association.

IN the early part of the sixteenth century, Spain -- spilling out over colorful regions of historical incident -- was concerned, among other things, with the wars in Italy, the Inquisition at home, and the golden pathway of the Conquistadors through the Indies, Mexico and Central America.

Business in October remained at the high level reached after the steel strike, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reports in its monthly survey issued for publication today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 1 -Livingston Platt, chairman of the executive committee of the Westchester Republican organization, said today that he believed Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's county plurality in Tuesday's Presidential election would exceed 100,000. Harold T. Garrity, Democratic county chairman, declared it would be less than 60,000.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, who has been in Buckinghamshire making speeches for the Conservative candidate in a by-election for one seat in Parliament, had a brush with hecklers in the market town of High Wycombe today.

As probable factor in "the present low moral tone of society" Rabbi Julius Mark in his sermon yesterday cited the failure of supporters of religion to follow the examples of Biblical prophets and speak out on public issues at a proper time.

To bring the dramatic story of the election to the thousands of visitors that are expected to be in Times Square on Election night, THE NEW YORK TIMES will operate an electric election indicator eighty-five feet high on the north side of the Times Tower.

MR. ALLEN, author of "Only Yesterday," is widely known as a master of the surface pasticcio of the American Twenties. In his new book, "The Big Change," he takes up the years between 1900 and 1950 -- and proves that the genre of writing he represents is better suited to a decade than to a half century.

In Korea last week there was talk of the new war. At the U. N. General Assembly in New York there was talk of the new proposal. The full import of what was taking place in Korea and at the U. N. was not immediately clear. Either could have a decisive effect on the Korean conflict.

THIS book defies some elemetal conventions of literary description of life across the tracks. As is well-known, to borrow a moth-eaten phrase, the people who dwelt across the tracks lived drab, sodden lives. No sunshine warmed their hearts.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Regents of the University of California have unanimously decided not to seek a rehearing on a recent State Supreme Court decision outlawing the special loyalty oath thta the Regents had demanded of faculty members and university employes.

The National Horse Show, a blend of sport, society and fashion, begin an eight-day run in Madison Square Garden on Tuesday. The sports part of the sixty-fourth National will encompass all of the usual horse show divisions, embellished by jumping contests among the teams of five nations.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 1 -- A call for spiritual rearmament in the fight for the American way of life was made by Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker in a speech at Founder Day exercises at Lafayette College today marking the institution's 126th year.

THIS is a delightful and quite worthwhile book, even if you may already have read most of the syndicated newspaper columns that make it up. John Crosby's Herald Tribune column on radio and television is the most widely syndicated in the business.
