Although the Metropolitan Museum's most important recent accession, Valasquez' equestrian portrait of Don Gaspar de Guzman. Count-Duke of Olivares, is on display in the dwarfing vastness of the museum's Great Hall, more than thirty other new acquisitions have just been put on public view in the Room of Recent Accessions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- Dean Acheson and Andrei Y. Vishinsky are not only the foreign ministers of the two super-powers of the post-war world but able lawyers as well. Their legal qualifications lend additional significance to the current discussions of the Korean prisoner of war question in the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly.

BEGINNING in China after the Japanese occupation, this story takes a young Chinese couple from a village to Shanghai and, finally, to present-time Formosa. The author establishes with fine attention to detail the China of yesterday, with its illusory changelessness of customs.

IN the nine years since Jack Kapp, the late, venturesome founder of Decca Records, herded the cast of "Oklahoma" into a recording studio to cut the first complete score of a Broadway musical show, this new dimension which he brought to the entertainment field has burgeoned into one of the sturdiest branches of the record industry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- There is an air of high confidence in Republican national campaign headquarters during the closing stages of this campaign which is at once reminiscent and yet different from that of 1948. There is confidence too, but of a different sort, at Democratic national campaign headquarters.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- In sums ranging from 50 cents to $10, in addition to two large checks, gifts totaling $5,000 have trickled into United Nations headquarters during the last few months, testifying to public hope that delegates invoke divine guidance for their decisions and votes.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- In the British Foreign Office a dream has come true. The diplomats find it hard to believe that Egypt, of a sudden, could have found a Premier as sound, sensible and reasonable as Gen. Mohammed Naguib so far seems to be.

When reading William Brownell's interview with the lovely screen star Ann Blyth, one remark of hers about Mario Lanza struck me, "* * * if only we could help him some way, get to him and find out what it was, that happened * * *."

BONN, Germany, Nov. 1 -- Western Germany appears to be enjoying another spectacular post-war economic boom. This, it is believed here, is a factor in the renewed restlessness about the Bonn Government in Eastern and Western Europe.

The election of Mrs. Mary Q. Cassidy, principal of the Mabel Dean Bacon Vocational High School, as president of the New York City branch of the National Council of Administrative Women in Education was announced yesterday.

WRITTEN by a young Southern newspaper man out of a deep knowledge and obvious love for his material, this first novel about pioneering in the mountains of northwestern Georgia in the Eighteen Thirties is a refreshing experience from first to last.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- A fumble on its 6-yard mark and an interception on its 8 cost the University of Pennsylvania two touchdowns and its place among the undefeated football teams of the nation today as it lost to Pennsylvania State College, 14-7, before 67,000 at Franklin Field.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1 -Yale scored its fifth successive triumph by beating Dartmouth, 21 to 7, today before 40,000, the largest crowd to watch a football game in the Bowl this season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Democratic National Committee charged today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had used at least eighteen false statements, distortions or quotations out of context during his seventeen-page attack last Monday on Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic candidate for President.

All last week Harvey E. Sampson, president of the Harvey Radio Company, was a man out of this world -- he actually was wired for sound. Concealed under his left armpit was a pocket-size sound recorder, which took down every word uttered by everyone within several feet of him. The sound was caught through what appeared to be an ordinary wristwatch on his left arm.

An out-of-the ordinary event in the auction world, one that will make its strongest appeal to connoisseurs of French paintings and of masterly French eighteenth-century furniture. will be held Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

THOUSANDS of devoted Lloyd C. Douglas fans will welcome this intimate biography of the late preacher-novelist by his two daughters. Douglas himself had planned to tell his life story, but death cut him down in the midst of his labors.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 -- Ore supplies at lower lake docks and furnace yards will be at a dangerously low level when shipping is resumed next April, but stocks will be speedily replenished, vessel operators declared today.

Armed with slide-rules, past statistics, and comparative voting records for areas with and without TV, they will come up with judgments on the role of the new medium in its first big year in national politics.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 1 -- William M. Wickham's 3 - year- old White Skies, with Jimmy Stout up, hung on to defeat Larry S. MacPhail's General Staff by three-quarters of a length in the Princeton Handicap at Garden State Park today.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1 (UP) Henn de Lamaze of France and Al Mengert of Spokane, Wash., advanced to the final of the Mexican amateur golf championship today.

Last week, at the age of 76, Eugene G. Grace, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, shot a hole-in-one at the Saucon Valley Country Club in Bethlehem, Pa., where the National Amateur Golf Championship was held last year. It was a 159-yard drive -- the fourth ace of his career.

Two more days and the American voter will be able to express his choice for President. In all probability the decision has already been made. Actually, it is the essential part of the democratic process -- an attempt, with some technical reservations, to determine the majority will.

THE way classical LP disks have been arriving these days one virtually needs an electronic brain to remember them. Electronic brains are expensive. THAT indoor gardening now ranks as a major winter sport is evident from the number of manufacturers who are busily engaged in turning out all kinds of equipment created especially for the house-plant hobbyist. Although most of this equipment fills a definite need, a few of the items are strictly for the addict.

The Milky Way looks like a broad, flat band of light stretched across the sky. Actually it is a thin, disc-shaped, great cloud of stars with curved arms, the whole resembling a gigantic pinwheel. Astronomers have successfully photographed similar spiral galaxies but have not been highly successful in interpreting photographs of the Milky Way because the solar system is embedded in the middle of it.

Warburg is chairman of the beneficiary's board of directors, and Mrs. Max M. Warburg is chairman of the ladies committee.

MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 1 -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney of Greentree and Mrs. William S. Paley of Kiluna Farm, both in Manhasset, are joint chairmen of the North Shore Hospital Thanksgiving Ball to be held on Nov. 29 in O'Hara Hall, United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point. Admiral Gordon McLintock, superintendent of the academy, and Mrs. McLintock will be hosts.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1 (UP) -- Harvard was forced to fight like a pack of demons today to win a "breather" football game from tiny Davidson College, 35 -- 26, before a slim crowd of 6,500 fans at Harvard stadium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, Republican National Chairman, warned today of attempts to "steal" the election Tuesday and called on election officials to exercise "every possible precaution to prevent vote frauds."

YANKEE dollars are currently buying several parcels of Virginia soil -- scene of two Confederate victories -- to insure everlasting reminders of the gallantry of three New York regiments that were decimated at the second battle of Bull Run.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 1 (UP) -- Wisconsin turned loose Alan (the Horse) Ameche and Quarterback Jim Haluska for two quarters today and that was all it took to whip Rice Institute, 21 to 7, in an intersectional game before 36,000 homecoming fans.
NEW ORLEANS, NOV. 1 (UP) -- Quarterback Pete Clement sparked Tulane's Green Wave to a 34 to 21 victory over Mississippi State in a Southeastern Conference football game today.

THE letters of Edna St. Vincent Millay have been edited by Allan Ross Macdougall with so much skill and care that they may serve as her autobiography and self-portrait. She went through life as through a magic wood, ignorant of malice and immune to bitterness.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 1 -- The British High Commissioner, Gen. Sir Gerald Templer, who returned last Wednesday from a brief trip to Ceylon, imposed severe punishment today on Pekan Jabi, a "new village" two miles from Segamat, an important center in Johore State.

J., Nov. 1 -- With a record registration of 355,000 eligible voters in Bergen County, heretofore known as "the banner Republican county of New Jersey," a total vote of 290,000 is forecast for next Tuesday. FOR the first time in the sixty years of the record industry it is possible to buy any type of jazz disk, old or new. Previously, jazz -- what may be regarded as a permanent art -- had been available only through the combined sufferance of the store, distributor and company, since it was unable to compete in volume with popular, light and classical records.

GENEVA, Switzerland. SO MANY countries do not as yet enjoy long-playing records. Sooner or later, they will, I am sure, take full advantage of the new advances. In the meanwhile, I cannot help but feel there are several real compensations for those areas cut off from the steady flow of new recordings and therefore having to rely upon the old stock.

MOST reports agree that the election campaign has had little direct effect upon business. Short-run indications are that economic activity will be sustained well into the early part of next year, at least. Recent gains in retail trade have bolstered confidence in the outlook for Christmas trade and gains of 10 per cent or more over last year are held possible.

I HAVE wondered, as the deadline drew nearer for me to write this particular piece, what would happen if I were to do anything so foolhardy as to set down exactly what I felt about the play that I have written and its possible fate this coming Thursday night.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- During the past few weeks the world has been quietly storing up its troubles in a sort of Pandora's box for the next President of the United States. It is more than likely that either Mr. Stevenson or Mr. Eisenhower is going to have to peep into it even before he enters the White House.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 1 -Union County, long a Republican stronghold, will prove it "likes Ike" with a 35,000 plurality in Tuesday's general election, Charles F. Beardsley, chairman of the Union County Republican Committee, predicted today.

Three high officials of the Puerto Rican Government and Jaime Benetez, Chancellor of the University of Puerto Rico, have been invited to serve as members ex-officio of the Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs in New York City, Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 1 -- Nassau County Democratic leaders insist that Republican pluralities will be slashed at Tuesday's election, while Republican strategists, confident of their established stronghold here, predict a record-breaking vote that will help Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower sweep New York State.

Short-run indications are that economic activity will be sustained well into the early part of next year, at least. Recent gains in retail trade have bolstered confidence in the outlook for Christmas trade and gains of 10 per cent or more over last year are held possible.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 1 (UP) -- Tiny Thurlow Weed, a five-foot-five-inch 128-pounder whose only football talent is place kicking, booted a field goal from the 17-yard line with less than six minutes to go today to boost Ohio State to a 24-to-21 triumph over Northwestern before 35,000 fans.
HARRY COHN, founder, president and guiding spirit of Columbia Pictures, made an important policy decision last week in appointing Jerry Wald vice president and executive producer of the studio.
LEVITTOWN, L. I., Nov. 2 -- In a Sunday picnic atmosphere, Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee brought the campaign to Levittown Hall today at a rally of the Levittown Democratic Club.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 2 -- In the President's home state of Missouri, professional and amateur talk of politics usually comes down to a matter of cold mathematics. This is as true in this Presidential election year as in former years.

Wallpaper designs for every room in the house, whether furnished in a traditional or contemporary manner, are included in six new collections of papers made by the Birge Company. The scenic, Heritage and Colonial groups are available at the Lenox Wall Paper Corporation, 424 Madison Avenue.

A couple whose golden anniversary last night was the occasion for a personal note from President Truman celebrated fifty years of marriage by making gifts of $250,000 to charities, churches and educational institutions of the three major faiths.

Allen Wardwell, former president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, announced yesterday that he was renouncing his early support of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee, and would vote for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic candidate.

I read with interest your account of the life of Lieut. Gen. Alfredo Dallolio, whose death on Sept. 20 was reported in your columns. I was glad to see that you gave this prominence to a man who was one of the most respected figures in this country -- the person to whom, more than any other single man, Italy owed her recovery in the First World War, after the disaster of Caporetto.

Weakness in the cotton market continued into the early days of last week but prices rallied on the New York Cotton Exchange and by the close of trading on Friday there had been net gains ranging from 9 to 37 points over the close on Oct. 24. The preceding week had shown net losses of 17 to 111 points.

FOR nearly as long as I can remember I have been reading "Sironia, Texas,"* by Madison Cooper, the novel that has caused so much advance talk because it is said to be the longest ever written in America. For all I know it is the longest ever written anywhere at any time -- not counting serial novels which appeared in many volumes over many years, like Proust's.

Following a brief prayer at the morning service yesterday for God's guidance of whichever candidate is elected tomorrow, the Rev. Dr. Ralph Walker of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street, addressed his remarks to the major Presidential candidates.

Engineering reports on a project to pipe natural gas from the Middle East to Europe, a distance of 2,500 miles, at an initial cost of $425,000,000 have been released by S. D. Bechtel, president of the Bechtel Corporation.

COLOGNE, Germany, Nov. 2 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer completely rejected today negotiations between East and West Germany on this country's reunification but suggested France reopen the discussions on the future of the Saar.

VIENNA, Nov. 2 -- With the leaders of the shipping industry, banking and commerce of Holland assembled in Vienna to inaugurate a new public relations service for the port of Rotterdam, pioneers of the movement for the development of the navigability of European waterways seized the occasion to press discussion of the problem.

The eighth-round games in the women's world chess championship challengers' tournament were more closely contested last night than any previous ones in Moscow, and the leaders were unchanged, according to a report from Soviet news sources.

DETROIT, Nov. 2 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs snapped Detroit's long-standing home streak tonight with a 4-2 victory over the Red Wings, who had gone through eighteen previous games at Olympia without a loss.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -- Alan Ladd will do a second picture abroad for Irving Allen, the Independent producer, on a releasing arrangement with Columbia Pictures after completing "Red Beret," being made in England. The future project, titled "The White South," will deal with the adventures encountered on a whaling expedition into the Antarctic.

Rosalind Russell, who has been thinking of appearing for at least two years in a musical variation of "My Sister Eileen" (the Joseph Fields-Jerome Chodorov comedy hit of yesteryear, based on the Ruth McKenney stories from The New Yorker), finally made up her mind to do so.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers took an early lead on breaks today and then held on through a last-quarter rally by the Washington Redskins for a 24-23 victory in a National Football League game before 25,866 fans.

A new system of I. R. T. train departures at the Main Street station, Flushing, Queens, has been started by the Board of Transportation. Express trains will now leave from the center and south track, and passengers will use the south platform, which has been designated as the express platform.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,422, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Monday, Korean time:

Allan Sloane, a radio and television writer who is suing "Red Channels" on charges of libel and defamation of character, has been notified by the Columbia Broadcasting System that, pending further notice, it will not accept any of his new scripts.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Following are the texts of two documents declassified today by President Truman -- a memorandum by the State-War-Navy Coordinating Committee to the Joint Chiefs of Staff; a reply transmitted via the then Secretary of Defense, James Forrestal, and an accompanying statement by Mr. Truman:

The Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs in New York City will soon have four new members: Chancellor Jaime Benitez of the University of Puerto Rico; Mariano Villarenga, Secretary of Education for Puerto Rico; Fernando Sierra Berdocia, Secretary of Labor, and Teodore Moscoso, Administrator of Economic Development.

Public ethics can no longer be viewed in black and white terms, the Very Rev. Dr. James A. Pike, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, said yesterday in his sermon.

An up-state Republican plurality of 900,000 votes -- which would be a record -- was predicted yesterday by the party's state chairman, William L. Pfeiffer, as assuring New York State's forty-five electoral votes for the Eisenhower-Nixon ticket by a safety margin of more than 200,000 votes.

PUTNAM VALLEY, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Alfred Vellozzi, 13 years old, of 230 Bennett Avenue, Yonkers, a Boy Scout, was wounded fatally near here this afternoon when a .22-caliber rifle being carried by Howard F. Lee, 36, of 43 Lindsay Street, Yonkers, a former Scoutmaster, was discharged, the state police reported.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 2 -- This capital had a festive air tonight as the final preliminaries to tomorrow's inauguration of General Carlos Ibanez as President were completed.

A collection of stamps that included some of the most famous philatelic gems of the Reichspost Museum in Germany were missed and believed stolen for an hour yesterday after a Pan American World Airways plane had been unloaded at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 2 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's bid for reelection to the United States Senate on the Republican ticket was expected to overshadow the struggle between the Republican and Democratic candidates for Wisconsin's twelve electoral votes Tuesday.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer in effect accused President Truman today of uttering untruths about the United States' Far Eastern policy in two recent campaign speeches.

J. Donald Kingsley, the agent general of the United Nations reconstruction agency in Korea, has again called attention to the need for our continued help. Winter is settling over Korea and it will be a bitter winter of hunger and cold for multiplied thousands.

MADRID, Nov. 2 -- The major obstacles to the conclusion of United States-Spanish military and economic agreements were understood today to have been removed after nearly seven months of negotiations. The negotiators were a special United States military mission and representatives of the Spanish Government.

The major controversial issue of the exchange of prisoners of war has caused the truce talks at Panmunjom to reach and remain at a stalemate, rapidly leading toward the direction of unprecedented devastation of civilization and human lives.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, suggested today that a telegram he had sent to the Attorney General this morning must have prompted President Truman to declassify a top-secret document in order to protect Senator Wayne Morse.

The autobiography of Stanton Griffis, a business man turned diplomat, will be published on Nov. 20 by Doubleday under the title "Lying in State." Mr. Griffis, who is descended from scholars and preachers, considers himself the family's black sheep, since he left letters for business.

Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, charged yesterday that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, was seeking to build up a myth that he knew all about domestic and foreign affairs when by his own pronouncements he had shown just the opposite.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Although gilt-edged securities set a good example on the stock markets last week, it has not as rule been followed by other sections which generally speaking continue to lack investment attraction in view of uncertainties in the industrial outlook.
BOSTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- One hundred firemen and twenty-five policemen were overcome by smoke today battling what one officer called the city's worst waterfront fire in thirty-two years.

PITTSBURGH, Nov 2 -- When all the figures are in for last month steel production will have made a new all-time high for October. Estimates indicate that total steel ingots produced last month will exceed 9,700,000 tons. This was the industry's answer to the temporary steel shortage and evidence was plentiful that a similar outpouring of steel will take place this month.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game tonight before 13,422 fans. The victory, the fifth straight for the league-leading Hawks, increased their first-place margin to 2 full points over the Montreal Canadiens and the Toronto Maple Leafs.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 -- The Philadelphia Americans defeated the Philadelphia Nationals, 1 to 0, in an American Soccer League game today to head the standing with 7 points.
Former Representative Hamilton Fish, a die-hard of Republican isolationism, gave his belated endorsement yesterday to the party's Presidential candidate, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.
AMSTERDAM, Nov. 2 -- The Dutch average annual dollar dificit officially was estimated at $150,000,000 although this year it will be slightly lower.

November is here. The holiday season is upon us. These are the days when a busy woman enjoys her hours of relaxation after hectic periods of shopping and holiday planning, and when she likes to have a sense of leisure and luxury.

With juvenile delinquency as their theme six youths from secondary schools in the metropolitan area took part yesterday in the New York Times Youth Forum on television from the Du Mont Adelphi Teletheatre, Fifty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 2 -- A fair plebiscite in the French colonies in India as to whether the four small territories shall join the Indian Union or remain with France is "clearly quite impossible" under present conditions there, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today.

The Rev. Lillian S. Gregory, minister of the Congregational Parish at Jericho and Jericho Center, Vt., told the congregation at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street, yesterday morning that "the preaching of today must have more urgency than the preaching of yesterday."

As Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower prepared yesterday to wind up his campaign for the Presidency on a $250,000 nation-wide radio and television program in Boston tonight, his supporters accused the Truman Administration of a last-minute effort to rig farm prices to obtain votes.

Georgia Tech and U. C. L. A. did the prize jobs of last week in intercollegiate football and are closely bunched with Michigan State, Maryland, Oklahoma and Southern California as the Big Six of the gridiron.

LONDON, Nov 2 -- In the oak-paneled room of the judicial committee of the Privy Council in Downing Street, a court composed of august law lords and other peers met the other day to hear twenty-odd claims to perform services at the coming coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.

THE NEW YORK TIMES will furnish complete radio coverage of the election tomorrow night through the facilities of WQXR and WQXR-FM and twenty-one FM stations extending from Washington to the Canadian border.
Reports received by THE TIMES from its correspondents throughout the country indicate that the outcome of this year's contest for the Presidency is highly uncertain.
The "Garden Calendar" tells the season no less than does the sky of late autumn to which the gardener, tidying up around the place, raises his eyes now and then to watch the high, thin clouds pass.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 2 -- Warden Ralph W. Alvis tonight said that 1,600 convicts in four cell blocks were "out of control" and that guards shot and wounded one long-term convict trying to escape.
While all voting in New York City at tomorrow's general election will be done by machine, the heavy registration will compel some up-state communities to use paper ballots as well.

For the second consecutive year no single film has been deemed sufficiently outstanding to receive first prize in the Robert J. Flaherty Film Awards contest for "creative achievement" in the documentary field, the City College Institute of Film Techniques, sponsor of the awards, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Drastic declines in cash corn prices recently. with new No. 2 yellow selling as much as 13 cents below December, failed to exert as much pressure on futures as expected, and for the week corn futures showed sizable price gains.
PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The cumulative deficit of France with the European Payments Union, according to official estimates, may come close to or even exceed $520,000,000 in October.

John Forney Rudy, director of public relations for the National Federation of American Shipping, has received a citation from the National Merchant Marine Committee of the American Legion for his services to the group.
A man shot three time in the back died in the hallway of an East Harlem tenement last night just after two patrolmen had arrived and heard him gasp: "My name is Nick Peratto * * *, Bronx."

The International Bank for construction and Development, after disbursing more than $1,000,000,000 in foreign aid loans during the past seven years, is understandably proud of its record as successful business enterprise.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Signs of a fall in production at home and a recession in foreign trade are beginning to worry the British Government. One dock worker in five is now unemployed -- with pay -- because of the falling off of general cargoes.

NANGAL, India, Oct. 22 (By Airmail) -- More than two-score American construction experts employed by the Indian Government on the immense Bhakra-Nangal multi-purpose river valley project here have evolved for themselves and their families a life in which East meets West.

The death last week of Sir Francis Wylie has taken away a firm friend of a whole generation of young Americans. Sir Francis was the first Oxford Secretary of the Rhodes Trust and he filled that post for twenty-eight years, beginning in 1903. He was 87 years old when he died, and Lady Wylie and their five children survive.

FOOTBALL never has been noted for its sanity. That's why it also is known as the Great Autumnal Madness. By the time November rolls around, however, its daffiest tendencies usually are brought under control and it behaves with a reasonable amount of decorum, Perhaps that's why the Cornell-Columbia result was such a stunner.

The nationalization of their tin industry, which occurred formally on Friday, is Bolivia's business. To seek the prompt, adequate and effective compensation of American interests in the Bolivian tin industry is the duty of the United States State Department. These are clear principles, which are recognized by international law and by the policy of the "Good Neighbor," especially as it was formulated in the Bogota Charter of the Organization of the American States in 1948.

To bring the dramatic story of the election to the thousands of visitors that are expected to be in Times Square tomorrow night, THE NEW YORK TIMES will operate an electric election indicator eighty-five feet high on the north side of the Times Tower.

Six hundred Federal, state and city jurists, members of the New York bar and the law faculties and senior law students of five universities attended a solemn votive Mass of the Holy Ghost offered yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral to invoke "God's blessing on the courts at the opening of the judicial year."

Representatives Jacob K. Javits and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., received scrolls yesterday from the United Organizations for Histadrut, Israel's labor federation, in recognition of their "outstanding efforts on behalf of Israel and Histadrut and their "distinguished leadership in the battle for liberty, democracy and social justice."
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's statement tonight in connection with the Korean war and a message from a group of Korean war correspondents:

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 3 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, commander of the Eighth Army in Korea, said today United Nations forces remained "in complete control" of the central front area where South Korean attacks yesterday again failed to reconquer the lost position on "Triangle Hill," north of Kumhwa.

Mayor Impellitteri assured property owners of Bayside Hills, Queens, yesterday that there would be no increase in local assessments on a 9,000-foot storm and sanitary sewer, even though a new contractor would finish the $573,971 job taken away from the original builder because of excessive delays.

Prof. Irwin Edman, executive officer of the Philosophy Department of Columbia University and head of the Volunteers for Stevenson at Columbia, asserted yesterday that an ethical and not a political issue was involved in the dispute over advertisements signed by Columbia University employes on behalf of the Presidential candidates.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 2 -- A fawn 3 1/2-year-old Great Dane, Ch. Dion of Kent from Knoxville, Tenn., became the main winner tonight in the fourteenth annual dog show of the Union County Kennel Club.

Jack I. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., yesterday announced signing of an agreement under which the company will take over Albert's stores in San Rafael and Richmond, Calif. It will assume operation of the stores immediately with the Albert Corporation retaining the real estate which it leases to Macy's.
Voting for the forty-nine elective posts in the Atlantic and Gulf districts of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., will begin today and will continue through Dec. 31.

While millions of Americans stand in line tomorrow waiting to vote for candidates of their choice, they should "lift up their hearts in grateful salute to all those, known and unknown, who have prepared that privilege for them," the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers declared yesterday in a sermon at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 -- Senator Wayne Morse declared tonight it was a "myth" that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was an efficient and able administrator of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He further held that the United States would now be in a total war in Asia if there had been an Eisenhower Administration for the last eighteen months.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 2 -- President Truman declassified and made public this evening the controversial top secret document in which the Joint Chiefs of Staff in 1947 had recommended the withdrawal of United States occupation forces from Korea.

A haze that hung over the metropolitan area yesterday was smoke from forest fires down South. It should roll away this afternoon when the wind shifts from southwest to northwest and Election Day should be fair and cooler.

WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY, in Korea, Nov. 2 -- Although thousands of miles of rolling sea separate him from home, the United States soldier fighting on this mountainous peninsula is as interested in the results of the election as the grocery store owner in Council Bluffs, the insurance salesman in Topeka or the subway guard in Brooklyn.

Not often in television is there an instance where a program goes badly off the beam in the hopes of corraling a spectacular popularity rating and then quietly mends its ways to become one of the most worthwhile attractions on the air. Such a program, however, is "Author Meets the Critics" (10 P. M. Thursdays on the DuMont Network).

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Mexico's plan for solution of the crucial issue of repatriation of prisoners in the Korean truce talks was formally submitted to the United Nations today as a resolution. Members of the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee will have it before them for consideration as they resume debate tomorrow on the Korean question.

Two big annual exhibitions, that of contemporary American Painting at the Whitney Museum and the thirty-ninth annual of the Allied Artists of America at the National Academy, open on Thursday. The next day the Metropolitan Museum will show a selection of their European and Asiatic works of art that eventually will be permanently installed in the new galleries, now being reconstructed.
