Ralph Hewitt, the Columbia backfield star of two decades ago, has his troubles these days. Now the football coach at Portsmouth Priory, which is among the season's unbeaten, Hewitt has six children. Two of them, Tommy, 8, and Ralph, Jr., 12, can't wait until they play with a regular team.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- "Splinter" parties have twelve Presidential candidates this year, but none of these candidates will make much of a dent in Tuesday's total vote.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri of New York returned to the state where he had once lived today to tell Connecticut voters the election of Democrats on national and state levels would wipe out a "bigoted and narrow" McCarran-Walter Immigration Act.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Wilson W. Wyatt, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's campaign manager, said tonight that he had information that the Republicans planned an hour-long radio and television program tomorrow night on Election Eve that he called "an all-timed, all-timer -- the huckster' last gasp."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UP) -- The Republican "truth squad," which trailed President Truman across the country on his campaign trip, charged today that he had been "guilty of over 100 * * * lies, half-truths and distortions."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Senator McCarthy today termed the Democratic National Committee's reply to his speech about Governor Stevenson "the most frantic lying spree upon which a Presidential campaign has ever embarked."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Lewis A. Pick. who has directed $5,000,000,000 of military construction during three and a half years as Chief of the Army Engineers, will retire with formal ceremonies at Fort Belvoir, Va., on Nov. 18.

NAPLES, Italy, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Turkey and Greece participated in Atlantic pact maneuvers for the first time as naval, land and air units of six North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations tonight started ten-day exercises stretching into the Eastern Mediterranean.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Representative Ralph W. Gwinn, Republican candidate for re-election, called upon the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Westchester District Attorney George M. Fanelli today for an investigation into the authorship of 60,000 pamphlets attacking his voting record and purported association with "hate groups."
Controller Lazarus Joseph made public yesterday his complete annual report on the city's financial activities for the fiscal year ended June 30.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Delegates to the United Nations General Assembly, who have been following the United States Presidential campaign with almost as much attention as they have devoted to Assembly developments, are impatiently waiting for information on the foreign policy of the new President.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 2 -- Finance Minister Alfredo Hernandez disclosed the official text of his recent agreement with the United States foreign bondholders protective council for settlement of Costa Rica's defaulted foreign debts.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Nov. 2 -- The Sixth Congress of the Yugoslav Communist party opened this morning in a confident mood despite the serious economic and financial problems that are assailing this country. More than 2,000 delegates gave Premier Marshal Tito a triumphant welcome when he opened the proceedings and settled back for a brief session devoted to organizational matters.
Eight new films, including importations from France and England, are slated to arrive in first-run houses this week. The programs follow:

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Nov. 2 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson came home today to worship in the church of his youth and later asked the townfolk for their prayers if the Presidency "should be my destiny." As the wearing campaign neared an end, the Democratic nominee returned to the family home for a morning of relaxation.

The need for blood for the wounded in Korea has been so well advertised by the American Red Cross that our attention has been focused away from the need of blood donors in our municipal hospitals. It is difficult for the hospitals to use such mediums as the radio, newspapers and television because of medical ethics.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Nov. 2 -- As part of a new and deliberate policy, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces, will take with him tomorrow on his trip to inspect Greek and Turk ish defenses a mixed group of staff officers representing five of the fourteen treaty countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Many Americans have been astonished during this campaign to learn some of the facts about racial controversy in their nation's capital.

DETROIT, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Quarterback Bobby Layne tossed two scoring passes to End Leon Hart, and Pat Harder connected for a 43-yard field goal as the Detroit Lions upset the Cleveland Browns, 17 to 6, before 56,029 fans at Briggs Stadium today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Campaign officials agreed today the 1952 election campaign just ending has been one of the wordiest on record. In addition, the leading orators covered more ground than any of their predecessors.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 2 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, charged tonight that his Republican opponent, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, had "advanced proposals which might well increase the risk of a third World War."

If the United States continues to permit great concentrations of economic power resulting in monopoly or oligopoly (control by the few) it is playing the Marxist game, according to Henry A. Wells, a former assistant Attorney General who played around with such concentrations as chief of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice.

Police Commissioner Monaghan has decided that the plan to curb jaywalkers proposed by the Broadway Association is not practical, at least at this time. The Association suggested that police hand to jaywalkers small, black-bordered cards bearing the slogan: "I am a jaywalker."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- George Blanda, place-kicking specialist for the Chicago Bears, booted a 48-yard field goal late in the fourth period today to enable his team to score a stunning 20-17 upset victory over the previously unbeaten San Francisco Forty-niners before an overflow crowd of more than 61,000.

Despite lower prices for residual fuel oils in the third quarter of 1952, the adverse effects of the oil strike in May and the subsequent walkout in the steel industry, the Sinclair Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries achieved record gross operating income in the first nine months this year.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Deral Teteak blocked Adrian Burk's last-quarter punt and John Martinkovic bulled 9 yards into the end zone with the loose ball today to give the Green Bay Packers a 12-10 National Football League victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.

The Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association made public yesterday a letter sent to the Securities and Exchange Commission by its manager, Raymond F. Copes, in which he characterizes as productive of returns "grossly misleading, inaccurate and incomplete" the quarterly statements called for under the commission's proposed revision of its Form 9K and its rules X13A-13 and X15D-13.

Yesterday afternoon's concert by the New Friends of Music in Town Hall began the seventeenth season of the organization, which this year is concentrating on Italian classics, Mozart and contemporary composers. The Italians were absent from the first program, but a contemporary composer was very much on hand, with Aaron Copland playing the piano part to his cycle of songs set to poems by Emily Dickinson.

The world premiere of Louis Gesensway's "A Double Portrait" occupied part of the Saturday evening Philharmonic - Symphony program. Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto was played by Yehudi Menuhin, and Dimitri Mitropoulos conducted the Bach-Resphigi Prelude and Fugue in D.
Continued strength in the British pound sterling highlighted an otherwise dull session in the foreign exchange market during the past week.

A few days ago the writer was discussing the election campaign with a friend who had some professional experience in that field. Commented the latter dryly: "There have been some excellent Republican speeches in the past few weeks.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Rams handed Dallas its sixth straight National Football League loss today, humbling the Texans, 42 to 20, on the passing of Norman Van Brocklin and the powerhouse running of Deacon Dan Towler.

Scheideler, Beck Werner, Inc., the agency which, with seven of its executives, is defendant in a damage suit brought by Duane Jones and decided in Mr. Jones' favor by a jury in Supreme Court here last Tuesday, availed itself yesterday of the immemorial custom of if not "cussin' the court," at least "cussin'" the jury.

Although there are some changes in the list of parterre boxholders for the premiere performance of the sixty-eighth season of the Metropolitan Opera Association next Monday night, a number of the regular subscribers will be in their usual boxes on opening night.

The New York City Opera Company closed its ninth fall opera season last night at the City Center. The two final operas, the forty-third and forty-fourth performances of the stand, were "Carmen" in the afternoon and "La Boheme" in the evening.

St. Luke's Hospital marked the first major step in its second century of service yesterday with the laying of a cornerstone for a nine-story, $7,000,000 building on the east side of Amsterdam Avenue between 113th and 144th Streets.

Global exhibits at the twenty-ninth annual Women's International Exposition were put to music yesterday, with Irish ballads, Polish folksongs and hourly versions of the national anthem wafting impartially over colorful booths displaying wares of many lands.
The Socialist party ended its national campaign with a rally last night at Reading, Pa.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State chairman, expressed his thanks to party workers last night and stressed the importance of their manning every precinct throughout the state, particularly upstate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Between 330 and 400 of the latest type of United States jet fighters will be supplied to Britain's Royal Air Force through the cooperative efforts of the United States, Canada and Britain, the Defense Department announced today.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 3 -- The European press today gave up forecasting the outcome of the Presidential election and mostly confined itself to a report of the campaign, giving each candidate a 50-50 chance.

The proposal that public school children sing the first and fourth stanzas of the patriotic hymn "America" in lieu of a daily prayer suggested by the New York State Board of Regents was opposed yesterday by Jerome Nathanson, a leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture.
BERLIN, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A United States lieutenant released after six days of Soviet captivity said today the Russians had threatened him with permanent imprisonment.

HIGH WYCOMBE, England, Nov. 2 -- While the United States goes to the polls on Tuesday some 60,000 voters in this semirural, semi-industrial area on the edge of the Chiltern Hills will cast their ballots in a contest that has great political significance on this side of the Atlantic.
White predominated at Bonwit Teller's gala tea and cocktail showing of holiday evening wear held Friday at the store for the season's debutantes.
Fears of inflation apparently have disappeared, and inflationary influences have been discounted in the markets, according to the November letter of the National City Bank of New York.

As the climax to one of the most tumultuous and momentous political campaigns in the nation's history, nearly 7,000,000 men and women in New York State are expected to go to the polls tomorrow to register their choice for President.

Jane Hobson, mezzo-soprano, gave her second New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The youthful singer was heard in the same auditorium in 1946 as winner of the Naumburg Foundation Award, and since has appeared in opera and at symphonic concerts under important leadership.

The struggle was all uphill for the Rangers in their National Hockey League game against the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night, but the Broadway Blues just made it. Bill Cook's athlete's weren't fortunate enough to win the game, but they just managed to the Montreal when the situation indicated another New York defeat.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Leaders of both parties today predicted victory in the contest for the control of Congress. This will be decided Tuesday along with the Presidential race.

CAIRO, Nov. 2 -- United States diplomatic, technical cooperation and public relations missions in the Middle East beyond the Turkish frontier are looking forward to a somewhat easier time in carrying out their jobs after Tuesday's elections at home, and more so when the new Administration is installed in January.

ZAGREB, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Col. Gen. Koca Popovic, chief of the Yugoslav General Staff, told the congress of the Yugoslav Communist party today the Yugoslav Army was capable of resisting aggression despite its numerical inferiority.

Governor Dewey promised yesterday that if Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was elected President tomorrow, American troops would be withdrawn within six months from at least three-quarters of the front lines in Korea and replaced by South Koreans.

Paced by Pito Villalon and Marcial Gonzalez, the Brookhattan-Galicia eleven gained its second American Soccer League triumph in four starts yesterday by beating the New York Americans, 2-1, in the feature battle of a doubleheader at the Yankee Stadium.

There are no constitutional questions or amendments to be voted upon in New York State tomorrow. Only the names of candidates for federal, state and local office will be found on the ballot. We summarize here the recommendations which this newspaper has made to its readers.

In Burgundy, the visiting wine-lover sees the little plot of ground that gives what some connoisseurs claim to be the world's greatest white wine -- the Montrachet. Diagonally across the narrow dirt road is a second little plot, not quite so valuable, the wine not quite so noble; this is Batard-Montrachet.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- After six weeks of campaigning in the National Football League, the season virtually started anew today for the Giants, following a 28-6 victory over the Chicago Cardinals. The triumph before 27,195 fans at Comiskey Park, coupled with the Browns' setback at Detroit, brought about a New York-Cleveland deadlock for the American Conference lead.

Out of towners visiting New York often receive the mistaken impression that its citizens have collectively contracted vertigo and would certainly have no inclination to participate in more sedentary pleasures like the contemplation and study of the lowly flower. We can easily point out that the impression is one of the surface variety.

Production of passenger cars and trucks by the General Motors Corporation during October, 1952, showed a sharp gain over the same month's output last year, but the reverse was true in the case of the Chrysler Corporation, according to reports issued yesterday by the two companies.

With vacancies on the six-member Federal Tariff Commission recently increased to two, foreign-trade groups wondered yesterday whether President Truman should leave new appointments to his successor or fill at least one vacancy soon. Both vacancies are on the Republican side of the politically nonpartisan commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Civil Service Commission accepted today the resignation of a suspended employe after she had admitted she had "seen to it that pertinent information was made available" to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and other members of Congress.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Nov. 3 -- Jack Parker and Pete Burke of the home club clipped 10 strokes from par with 34, 28 -- 62, to win the weekly amateur-pro of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association at the Cold Spring Country Club today.

Former Representative Hamilton Fish, who announced on Sunday his endorsement of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, took issue yesterday with a statement in THE NEW YORK TIMES that Mr. Fish had been repudiated by the Republican state organization and by Governor Dewey, who was the Republican nominee for President in 1948.
There are a number of widespread misconceptions about voting which should be corrected.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association today doled out punishment to a couple of its better-known basketball playing members -- Kentucky and Bradley -- for rules violations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UP) -- The nation's 4,927 national banks had more than $102,000,000,000 in assets on Sept. 5, the Comptroller of the Currency announced today.

Eighteen buildings used as rooming houses in the neighborhood of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn have been sold by Mrs. Marie Bommer Frohlich to Murray Halpern, who plans to hold the properties for investment. The parcels have an assessed valuation in excess of $220,000. John F. James Sons were the brokers.

Stephen A. Mitchell, National Chairman of the Democratic party, accused the American Broadcasting Company last night of permitting Walter Winchell to deliver a "partisan political speech" in behalf of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican candidate for President, during the commentator's regular Sunday night broadcast.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Europeans will follow the returns from tomorrow's election in the United States with intense interest. European officials put off many decisions and suspended much diplomatic activity pending the outcome. The election has been recognized as having vital importance for the whole Western world.
Five hundred supporters of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson contributed $40,000 yesterday in a last-minute fund-raising drive that included a $53-plate luncheon at the Commodore Hotel.
Henry Hill, architect, has joined Gunnison Homes, Inc., housing subsidiary of United States Steel Corporation, as a consultant.

Rumors current in shipping circles that the world's two largest ocean liners -- the Queen Elizabeth and the Queen Mary -- would undergo major alterations in passenger quarters and would be fitted with stabilizing fins were denied here yesterday by spokesmen for the Cunard Line.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, said yesterday on a recorded television and radio program that his projected post-election trip to Korea was to get information, not to boss the military operations there. He added that he did not pretend to have any "patent medicine" to solve the Korean situation.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 3 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley, in a nation-wide telecast address directed primarily to women voters, declared today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower held out "a false hope" that there was "some quick and easy way out of Korea."

APPLETON, Wis., Nov. 3 -- Senator McCarthy, in an eleventh-hour plea for the election of the Republican national ticket in tomorrow's elections, tonight reiterated his charge that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic Presidential nominee, was hopelessly enmeshed in an intrigue to deliver the United States to the control of a Kremlin-directed Communist conspiracy.

Dr. Gabriel R. Mason, principal of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn, believes that the Halloween custom of begging for pennies and cookies is not conducive to building character in children. The "trick or treat" challenge of young doorbell-ringers is, in the opinion of the 66-year-old educator, a form of extortion that sometimes borders on juvenile gangsterism.

Three men who had been indicted for the burglary in the Brevoort Post Office Station, 1205 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Leo F. Rayfiel in the Brooklyn Federal Court. They had been accused of breaking open a safe on April 29, 1951, and taking $15,083 in cash and $14,000 in traveler's checks.

It seems that in New York State if you make or take a bet on an election, you can be stripped of your right to vote -- that is, if someone happens to betray you to the Attorney General's Election Frauds Bureau.

For the third offering of its limited engagement at the Mark Hellinger Theatre, the S. M. Chartock Gilbert and Sullivan Company is doing the double program of "Trial by Jury" and "H. M. S. Pinafore." And, whatever the cause -- the martial beat of the "Pinafore" score or simply the tonic of passing time -- the fact is that last night's performance was the best yet achieved by the newly organized congregation.

DECATUR, Ill., Nov. 3 (UP) -- John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy adviser, said today that Joseph Stalin hoped for a Democratic victory in tomorrow's election so that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois could continue Administration policies "that let the Communists win" in Asia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- Danny Kaye's next picture will be made in association with the writing-directing-producing team of Norman Panama and Melvin Frank. "Knock on Wood" is the title of the musical comedy project, for which Sylvia Fine (Mrs. Kaye) already has written the music and lyrics for a group of songs to be done by Mr. Kaye.

IN 1912, when Edna St. Vincent Millay was a rather naive girl of 20 but already the author of one of the finest poems of this century, "Renascence," she wrote in a letter to another poet whom she had not yet met, Arthur Davison Ficke: "As to the line you speak of -- 'Did you get it from a book?' Indeed! I'll slap your face. I never get anything from a book.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 3 -- President Truman said today that he had no detailed election prediction of his own but that prophets of a Democratic victory were on the right track. He referred newspaper men to two former Democratic National Chairmen who predicted a triumph by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential candidate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Mickey Mantle, the Yankees' young switch-hitter, today again was declared physically unfit for military service.

Senders of Christmas parcels to Europe and South and Central America were warned yesterday by George M. Bragalini, acting postmaster, that the deadlines for mailing holiday parcel post so as to be assured of delivery by Christmas Eve were approaching rapidly.

A new merchant marine has been born, with scarcely anyone noticing it, according to Naess, Mejlaender Co., shipping agents, who report that the flag of Morocco has been raised over the tanker Meanara, belonging to a French concern.

TRIESTE, Nov. 3 -- The chances of finding a solution for the complicated Trieste problem are about as poor now as they ever have been. One may conjecture that one reason for this may be that neither Italy nor Yugoslavia completely wishes to end the impasse now.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Members of the Asian-Arab bloc called today for the establishment of a commission under United Nations aegis to try anew to settle a six-year-old dispute concerning South Africa's treatment of its Indian minority.
BOSTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's speech here tonight:

Making a compelling closing drive, the Saxon Stable's Dark Count won the feature event at the Empire City Racing Association's meeting at Jamaica yesterday. The race, called the Charentus, was at a mile and a sixteenth, and attracted seven starters, with F. H. Stark's Assignment and the Cockfield Stable's Arcave the most heavily played by the crowd of 19,835.

The members of the New York Times Chapel of Typographical Union 6 held a special meeting yesterday afternoon in the Times Building, 229 West Forty-third Street, to honor forty-three of their associates whose service on this newspaper totaled 1,200 years.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Following the recommendations of the N. C. A. A. council, Kentucky today said it would cancel its twenty-one game basketball schedule this season.

Sebastiano Nani, 46-year-old olive oil distributor, of 1888 Troy Avenue, Brooklyn, was held in $25,000 bail yesterday by United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn on a charge of seeking to bribe a Treasury Department agent with $2,500 to change his testimony in a California narcotics case.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Despite a small turnover and some weakening of British Government securities, most sections of the London stock market were fairly firm today.
HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The French Air Force hit hard today at Vietminh troop columns on the move north and south of the Black River.

Weaving would seem to be one of the most popular of the international handcrafts, judging from the exhibits at the Women's International Exposition at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street.

GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- After its staff had been fed copious quantities of thirteen unidentified kinds of "sardines" to test their ability to distinguish them, the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade decided in effect that one sardine ought to be treated very much like another from a tariff point of view.

In a reversal of policy the Soviet government has decided to permit next year the free export of more than 100 additional newspapers and magazines, including important scientific, military and economic publications formerly denied to the outside world.

City employes responded yesterday morning in such numbers at a special bloodmobile unit at 63 Park Row that many were sent to the Red Cross Blood Donor Center, 70 West Fortieth Street, for the donations.
CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 3 -- City police have decided to end the monkey business going on in suburban Hastings.

Many dinner parties will be given before and suppers after the opening of the sixty-fourth National Horse Show tonight in Madison Square Garden. Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman is president of the National Horse Show Association, and Frederick F. Alexandre is general chairman of the entertainment committee.

The block in which I live is visited by about three trucks of the Sanitation Department each day. Each truck proceeds the length of the block, collecting the trash which has been put out, the job requiring about ten or fifteen minutes for each truck. Cars are parked all along either side of the street, and in what is left of the roadway it is impossible for a moving car to pass the sanitation truck.

The City Planning Commission's recommendation for a Transit Authority could be a good step toward tackling the problem only if such an authority will have over-all jurisdiction on all means of transportation to and from the city. There is no escape from the fact that subways, buses, private cars, trucking and commuting facilities are all tied in to the same problem.

The start of the Big Three series marks the week in intercollegiate football on a program that provides few outstanding pairings other than Oklahoma and Notre Dame at South Bend and Southern California and Stanford at Palo Alto.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Leon Jouhaux, French labor leader and president of the new peace organization, Fighting Democracy, said today that he had received assurances of support from William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

In the United Nations various efforts are being made to find a formula for dealing with what is ostensibly the last issue holding up an armistice in Korea. That issue is whether 87,000 North Korean and Chinese prisoners who have sworn to resist repatriation shall be permitted to go free or whether they shall be driven back to Communist slavery, and possibly death, at the point of United Nations bayonets.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Y. T. Pyun, Foreign Minister of the Republic of Korea, said today that his Government would never give up its "perfectly legitimate intentions" of reco vering "our lost territory" so long as "one inch of North Korea remains in the hands of the Communist traitors and the Chinese Communist invaders."

Favored by generally fair weather throughout most of the nation, 55,000,000 to 60,000,000 voters are expected to go to the polls today to participate in the election of a new President and Vice President. The existing record of 49,815,000 ballots cast in a Presidential election was set in 1940.

A threatened strike of 500 editorial and commercial employes of The New York Daily Mirror, which had been scheduled for today, has been called off, Federal Mediation Commissioner J. R. Mandelbaum announced at 12:40 o'clock this morning.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3 -- Some of 1,632 rioting prisoners at the Ohio Penitentiary here offered to surrender tonight, eight hours after one convict had been shot dead and three had been wounded, with National Guardsmen called in to help quell the new outbreak in the four-day uprising at the prison.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Edward P. Taylor's Canadian filly, Canadiana, proved capable of defeating first-class American 2-year-olds by winning the $5,000 No Score Purse at Pimlico today before 11,563 fans.

Voters were advised to make their choices freely, without "hysteria" or "fear" by the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, presiding Protestant Episcopal Bishop, at a special pre-Election Day Service yesterday at Trinity Church.

The names of those appointed to the three boards of judges for the 1953 National Book Awards were made public yesterday by the National Book Award Committee. The awards, which encompass fiction, non-fiction and poetry, will be made Jan. 27, 1953, at the Commodore Hotel.

The concert given last night in Town Hall by the enterprising Little Orchestra Society was a curious compound. It began badly and rather dully; it ended with one of the most brilliant of the Hindemith chamber concertos and with some of the finest violin playing heard in seasons in this city by William Kroll, the soloist of the evening.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 4 -- South Korean infantrymen stormed up "Triangle Hill" three times yesterday, but were turned back each time by deadly Chinese mortar fire when they were within a few yards of the crest.

Dr. Harry J. Carman, nationally known educator and historian and dean emeritus of Columbia College, has been unceremoniously dropped from the city's Board of Higher Education, of which he had been perhaps the most distinguished and valuable member since 1938.

The City College of New York basketball candidates yesterday turned out for the first practice session of the season under new coach Dave Polansky. Polansky's debut marked the first time in thirty-four years that Nat Holman wasn't around for the start of a court campaign.
OTTAWA, Nov. 3 (UP) -- The hard-hit Canadian gold mining industry, caught in a squeeze between mounting costs and falling revenue, called on the Government for help today.
DALLAS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The financially harassed Dallas professional football team failed today to get aid from Dallas civic leaders and the future of the National League franchise was up in the air.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Of those within the purview of this department who undertake to predict the outcome of Presidential elections only Mr. David Lawrence has ventured this year on an unreserved prophecy. The professional vote-statisticians, who fear they can never again sell their wares if they go wrong again, as in 1948, generally have taken cover behind this shield produced by Dr. Gallup:

Recent reports of numerous and widespread forest fires throughout much of the country emphasize the imperative necessity of conserving one of our most valuable resources -- the woods and forests of America.
A fresh northwesterly breeze late yesterday afternoon dissipated the haze from southern forest fires that had veiled the metropolitan area Sunday and yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Jerry Anderson, a member of the Indiana University football squad, has been stricken by polio and is under treatment in Pittsburgh Municipal Hospital today.

Eighteen thousand telephone maintenance and repair employes in the metropolitan district will receive wage increases ranging from $2 to $5 a week under the terms of an agreement reached yesterday by union and company representatives.
Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres this morning.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 (UP) -- A funeral service was held today for Dixie Lee Crosby, wife of Bing Crosby. Some 600 members of the film colony attended the service in the Roman Catholic Church of the Good Shepherd in Beverly Hills.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee approved today without a dissenting vote a draft resolution intended to help end race discrimination in dependent territories.

Textile fiber blends, once viewed as hybrid upstarts in an industry where "pure" fibers held sway, are bringing new styling and wearing qualities to many segments of the trade. Silk has now joined the parade of natural fibers that find an affinity with new man-made and natural fibers, both for apparel and drapery and upholstery fabrics.

ATHENS, Oct. 28 (By Air Mail) -- A joint announcement by the Greek Government and the Mutual Security Agency, which distributes United States aid funds, said today that agreement had been reached on balance-of-payments estimates for the current fiscal year, and also on the level and composition of an import program.

Loomis Grossman, real estate operator, has purchased the two-story taxpayer building at 1128 Madison Avenue from S. Albert Horrwitt. The building, which has four stores on the ground floor and two stores on the second floor, was constructed by the seller in 1949 on the site of the home of Admiral John Ide.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- The High Commissioners of the United States, Britain and France in Bonn sent parallel notes today to their Soviet counterpart here denying that anti-Communist groups with headquarters in West Berlin were committing crimes in the Soviet zone.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -The Defense Department today identified 258 casualties of the Korean war. The new list included 20 killed in action, 197 wounded, 15 injured in accidents and 26 missing. The following casualties were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

Operations of Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 resulted in a net profit of $86,794,000, it was announced yesterday. This represents a drop of 18 per cent below the $105,404,000 reported for the first nine months of 1951.

Police records showed yesterday that Nick Peratto, who died on Sunday night with bullet wounds in the back in a tenement hallway at 2129 First Avenue, between 109th and 110th Streets, was an ex-convict.
Federal, state and city law-enforcement officials outlined plans yesterday for combating voting irregularities at the polls here today.

Plans to use eighteen musicians on last night's final campaign broadcast by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, were dropped late yesterday when the musicians' union demanded payment for each network carrying the program. Recorded music was substituted.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Nov. 3 -- The Independent Committee Against Communism in Government, which put full-page advertisements in three Connecticut newspapers on Sunday, attacking the record of Senator William Benton, Connecticut Democrat, called upon the Senator today to bring legal action against it, instead of demanding retraction from the newspapers.
PARIS, Nov. 3 (UP) -- Louis Verneuil, French playwright, was found dead today in his apartment. The police said the circumstances pointed to suicide. He was 59 years old.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov, 3 -- A series of crashes involving seven vehicles killed a sailor and injured three others and a civilian on the New Jersey Turnpike here early this morning. The police said that the first collision occurred after an unidentified driver had stopped his car because of heavy fog.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Delegates to the United Nations who have spent the last few Weeks parrying questions about their favorite Presidential candidate, made it apparent tonight that election day would come as a welcome relief.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson told the American people tonight in the final appeal of his Democratic campaign for President, that communism was being beaten back and that a solution, settlement and armistice in Korea would be "the first order of public business" if he were elected.
Jackson, Miss., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Nov. 12 on $2,253,000 of street improvement bonds due from 1954 to 1963.

Sales of Manhattan and Brooklyn department stores increased 3 per cent in October, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. This figure covers the sales of twelve stores against the same number a year ago and does not include on a comparative basis the sales of Frederick Loeser Co., which closed early this year.

Chile inaugurated a new President yesterday just as we were about to choose a new one ourselves. Gen. Carlos Ibanez was elected on Sept. 4 -- fairly, squarely and democratically. He is therefore entitled to the support and the best wishes of the whole hemisphere as well as of his own people.

FORT WORTH, Text., Nov. 3 (AP) -- The police and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents seized a former convict early today as he arrived at a vacant field to dig up loot taken in a $248,000 robbery of two exiled Cubans.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 3 -- The Israeli Government has instructed Abba S. Eban, its Ambassador in Washington, to approach the State Department with a series of proposals in an urgent effort to overcome the conflict between the Israeli military service law and the McCarran Act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that 61,862,000 Americans were working at regular jobs at mid-October -- about the same comparative number as last year -- and the total of unemployed was 1,284,000, the lowest since World War II years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The representatives of three less developed nations, the Philippines, Cuba and the Dominican Republic, emphasized today before the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee that foreign private capital was indispensable for the growth of underdeveloped countries.

SIMSBURY, Conn., Nov. 3 -- Despite the fact that Ron Michelini has only two letter men from the 1951 team that won five and lost one, Westminster School's head coach has an alert "bunch of lads who are determined and can follow directions."

There are only three books published today, of which one is a novel dealing with life in the African jungle. Entitled "10,000 Tom-Toms," the story was written by Jens Larsen, whose research for the book began thirty-two years ago, when he and his wife went to Liberia as missionaries.

Two companies whose tin mines were nationalized by the Bolivian Government in a decree Saturday declared yesterday that the action was "contrary to the Bolivian constitution and the most elementary principles of justice and equity recognized internationally."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- Chin Bok Hing, an Oakland lottery operator, was threatened with deportation to Communist China today by Federal Judge Edward P. Murphy on being sentenced to serve ten years in prison and pay a fine of $10,000 for evading income taxes.

Sharp criticism of President Truman and his Administration high-lighted an eighteen-hour television stint conducted yesterday by Governor Dewey as he ended his air campaigning in behalf of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Maryland's head coach, Jim Tatum, is wholeheartedly in favor of bowl games when undefeated football teams are involved. In this stand he is backed by the university president, Dr. H. C. Byrd. But the Southern Conference, of which Maryland is a member, frowns on post-season games and, Tatum told the Football Writers Association at its weekly luncheon-meeting at Toots Shor's yesterday, "Maryland never has knowingly broken a conference rule."
Mme. Colette Hebert, whose rich and unusual chocolate cake was described here last August, is offering a second dessert baked in her home kitchen.

All major financial and commodity markets in the United States will be closed today for Election Day. Chicago and some other livestock markets will operate as usual and Canadian stock and grain exchanges as well as the London stock market will be open.

Two new one-story factory buildings in Hempstead, L. I., have been leased from the Edbar Realty Corporation, owner. One at 56 Newman Court, containing 15,000 square feet of space, was taken by the Norich Manufacturing Company, maker of women's handbags and metal and plastic frames.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Washington, the goal of it all, was astir with partisan charges today as the 1952 Presidential campaign drew to a bitter close.
Confidence in the Canadian economy has been greatly strengthened by the general success of the Dominion Government's fiscal and monetary policies, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

If buses, instead of trains, were to provide commuter service for fifteen Long Island communities from Patchogue east to Montauk, the Long Island Rail Road still would lose money on the sixty-two-mile line, but the net operating loss would be cut to $48,610 a year from the present $500,000, the road said yesterday.

MADRID, Nov. 3 -- Spanish sources said today that the United States Government had reached military and economic agreements with the Government of Generalissimo Francisco Franco calling for the creation of three major and several secondary air bases, the conversion of the port of Cadiz, in the Atlantic, into a first-class naval base, and extensive improvements designed to enlarge the existing harbor facilities of Cartagena, in the Mediterranean.

Several hundred hunters examined yesterday 308 Winchester rifles discarded by the Police Department and offered for sale at the Police Academy. 7 Hubert Street. At the end of the day it was announced that forty-six of the weapons had been sold for a total of $1,840.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Said one American to another in London today, "Will you come to my house to a cocktail party at 5 o'clock Wednesday morning?"
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3 -- What do inmates of the Ohio Penitentiary get to eat under normal circumstances?
A statement that the country's chemical industry stands ready for any national emergency was made last night by three leaders in the industry.

The Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice yesterday ended the presentation of evidence supporting its civil action charging seventeen major investment banking houses with conspiracy to restrain the securities business in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Britain's gold reserve is continuing to rise slowly despite a fall in exports and production. The improvement is a result of curtailed imports, United States military aid and a surplus earned with the European Payments Union.
Commodities were generally higher in trading on the New York exchanges yesterday. Activity was slow. Cocoa registered the only decline and potatoes, rubber and wool closed mixed.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Nov. 3 -- Premier Tito recommended today that the sixth congress of the Communist party of Yugoslavia broaden the political and ideological struggle against the Soviet Union and Cominform by establishing the closest cooperation short of union with the Socialist parties, trade unions and liberal groups in the West.

PARIS, Nov. 3 (UP) -- Charles Humez of France, seeking to establish himself as the No. 1 challenger for the world middleweight championship, outpointed Eugene Hairston of New York tonight in a dull ten-round bout that was booed by a crowd of 16,000 at Palais des Sports.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- A representative of a small area of Indonesia calling itself the South Moluccan Republic requested the United Nations today to place on the General Assembly agenda a "flagrant" case of human rights violation by Indonesia.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Cudahy Packing Company, and the United Packinghouse Workers, C. I. O., reached agreement today on a new contract giving a 4-cent-an-hour wage increase to 10,000 workers in nine Cudahy plants. The increase is retroactive to Oct. 27. The current average hourly
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Organized labor was poised today for its greatest political effort and, therefore, for the greatest test of its political prestige.

Two former Army comrades of John David Provoo and a former Japanese Army lieutenant testified for the Government in Federal Court yesterday at the fifth session of Provoo's trial on a charge of war-time treason.

The anthracite coal operators, like the majority of operators in the bituminous coal industry, seem to be proceeding on the theory that it is all right to give John L. Lewis anything and everything he wants, regardless of price-wage stabilization.

BOSTON, Nov. 3 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower put away all the angry partisan rancor of the political struggle tonight and ended his campaign for the Presidency with an appeal for unity and faith in the republic.

Eleven o'clock Sunday morning -- when most Protestant churches are holding worship services -- was designated yesterday as the "most segregated time" in America by Dr. Helen Kenyon, former moderator of the Congregational-Christian Churches.

Complete radio coverage of the election will be provided by THE NEW YORK TIMES tonight through the facilities of Stations WQXR and WQXR-FM and twenty-one frequency modulation stations extending from Washington to the Canadian border.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The area that includes "voteless Washington" is expected to produce approximately 300,000 ballots in tomorrow's election. This, it was said, would set a record for voting from and in the vicinity of the capital.

The Giants from Chicago yesterday, elated over their convincing 28 -- 6 victory over the Cardinals. With that triumph, Steve Owen's club joined the Cleveland Browns in a first-place tie in the American Conference of the National Football League.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Federal price stabilizer, Tighe E. Woods, said today he had told President Truman the country should have stronger price controls.

With retailing undergoing a change that can only be described as a revolution, there is urgent need for a drastic overhauling of promotion concepts, Joseph Lorin, president of Grey Advertising Agency, Inc., asserted last night.

Mollie Parnis knows all the ingredients it takes to flatter a woman's figure. She used them unstintingly in her collection of holiday and resort fashions, shown yesterday by Saks Fifth Avenue at the Plaza Hotel.

After the wearying procession of Communists and fellow-travelers who have visited Russia these past few years and come back to tell of seeing Utopia on earth it is refreshing to have the candid account of the eminent Indian scientist Dr. S. S. Bhatnagar, a man who apparently kept his eyes open in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Charges of contempt of Congress against Joseph Baldassari of Scranton, Pa., were canceled by the Federal Government today because he had pleaded possible self-incrimination in refusing to answer questions of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 3 -- Gen. Carlos Ibanez del Campo, once dictator of Chile, was inaugurated this morning as her constitutional President, completing a political comeback that has taken twenty-one years.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady and closing prices were 3 to 19 points higher than on last Friday, excepting the March, 1954, contract which was off 10 points.
Winding up a one-man campaign for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, a 71-year-old voteless citizen came into town yesterday from Shishmaref, Alaska, to help his World War I captain "celebrate the victory."

George C. Sherman Jr. has been re-elected president for a seventh term at the annual meeting of the Indoor Polo Association of America. Representatives from clubs in Chicago, Detroit, New England, the West Coast and the metropolitan area attended the session at the Racquet and Tennis Club here.

Nobody can deny that the gas buggy -- to give it the name used by doubting Thomases half a century ago -- has taken over the business which once relied on four-footed horsepower. The clatter of hoofs has gone from our city streets.

Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal party candidate for the United States Senate, declared last night that the Republican Presidential campaign had produced "enough careless, impulsive and reckless statements to shake the foundations of the free world, in the present struggle against Communist aggression."

A total vote of 7,000,000 in New York State is expected in today's Presidential election on the basis of the registration that took place last month. In New York City, a turn-out of 3,400,000 is indicated. The vote outside the city, including the suburbs, is expected to reach 3,600,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- All grain futures as well as soybeans made a good show of strength in the early part of the session, but the buying followed about the same pattern as in many recent days, the demand fading out as prices registered moderate advances.
The manpower pinch in the metropolitan area is making the regional Wage Satbilization Board into a nursery sponsor.

To bring the dramatic story of the election to the thousands of visitors that are expected to be in Times Square tonight, THE NEW YORK TIMES will operate an electric election indicator eighty-five feet high on the north side of the Times Tower.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 4 -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1,423, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korea time:
Lou Little, Columbia's football coach, directed his squad through a light workout yesterday. He excused his regulars from contact work as the Lions began preparing for Saturday's game at Dartmouth.

All the action of a suspense thriller -- a chase and gunshots in a crowded street, passersby cringing in doorways, the quick-thinking fearlessness of a hero -- and the hero, too, of course -- was packed yesterday into an attempted hold-up of a Times Square area bowling alley.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 3 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois answered today the request made by the American Veterans of World War II (AMVETS) for a pre-election statement on the Veterans' Administration's medical care program.

THE closing of the New York forests, pending sufficient rainfall to eliminate the serious fire hazard, has disrupted the plans of a small army of hunters who had set the first week in November for their hunting holiday. Many had planned to leave for the Adirondacks immediately after casting their vote this morning.

Pre-election enthusiasm continued yesterday to dominate the stock market's action and a furtherance of last Friday's recovery added an average of a point to values. Profit-taking was encountered at intervals during the session and acted as a brake on extensions as wide as those enjoyed in the upturn late last week.

Irving Ravetch's latest play, "Where Late the Sweet Birds Sang," which is one of a trio on the Broadway production schedule of Kermit Bloomgarden, is to be staged by Daniel Mann. The director was last represented locally by "Paint Your Wagon," which he also re-staged for the road.

Tomorrow, or as soon as the results are known, the most important person in the United States will be the newly designated President. Today the most important person is the voter who actually votes -- not the voter in the mass, for there is no such person; not the voter as a symbol, for no symbol can mark a ballot or pull a lever.
Al Conway of unbeaten William Jewell (Mo.) continues to top collegiate football's scoring parade with 96 points.
The Daily Compass, a left-wing newspaper, ceased publication yesterday. Lack of funds was the cause, according to Ted O. Thackrey, publisher.

The battle for the No. 1 spot in The United Press football ratings developed into a five-team race yesterday with Michigan State still first, closely pressed by Maryland, U. C. L, A., Georgia Tech and Oklahoma.

Mrs. Elizabeth Bykova of Moscow, after winning her seventh-round game with Miss Mona M. Karff of New York yesterday, also won in the eighth from Mme. Chaude de Silans of France, thereby taking the lead in the women's world championship challengers chess tournament, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.
Lead, which as been dropping steadily in price for some time, apparently reached bottom yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3 (AP) -- National Guardsmen in the Ohio prison were ready to use gas grenades.

I would be grateful if you would allow me space to correct certain statements made about my late husband, Sisley Huddleston, and his life and work in the obituary notice published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on July l8.

One of the biggest illegal liquor stills ever discovered in this country was raided yesterday afternoon two blocks east of Brooklyn Police Headquarters. It was running at full blast -- 1,000 gallons of 180-proof alcohol a day -- in preparation for the Christmas rush.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Nov. 3 -- The Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Powers of Europe -- which General Eisenhower conceived and then headed for its first seventeen months -- already is aglow with pre-election fever, but betting odds on the General's chances are about as even here as they are on Broadway.

CAIRO, Nov. 3 -- Egypt's proposal to Britain for a settlement of the issue of the Sudan indicates an Egyptian view that self-determination for the Sudan shall consist exclusively of a choice between complete independence and unity with Egypt.

Having been a former inmate of several German concentration camps during the war, I wish to make the following remarks relative to the news reported in the New York newspapers regarding the meeting of members of Hitler's S. S. Elite Troops in Verden, Germany.
CAIRO, Nov. 3 (Reuters) -- Egypt has proposed to Britain that the two countries should "begin forthwith" measures to give the Sudan self-government and eventual self-determination.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 (AP) -- In identical notes to Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, the United States, British and French High Commissioners rejected as "baseless" a Russian complaint against the Free Jurists League, the Fighting Group Against Inhumanity, the American-operated radio station RIAS and the Socialist East Bureau.

New Jersey leaders of both major parties were as far apart as usual in their predictions of victory yesterday but they were able to agree on one thing, and that was on a forecast that a record number of voters would appear at the polls today.
WITH THE FIRST CORPS, in Korea, Nov. 3 -- Soldiers of this United Nations corps have contributed $66,109.32 to their special charity, a fund to be used to aid Korean amputee children.

Probably the most annoyed man in all New York yesterday morning was Harry Scheurer, a guard on a crowded IND "F" train running between 179th Street, Jamaica, Queens, and Church Avenue, Brooklyn, via Manhattan.
CONCORD, N. H., Tuesday, Nov. 4 -- The first towns in the nation to cast ballots in today's Presidential election gave Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower an early lead.

Following are the prepared texts, as carried by The Associated Press, of addresses delivered in a nationwide radio and television broadcast winding up the Democratic campaign last night in Chicago by President Truman, speaking from Kansas City, and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson from Chicago:
DES MOINES, Iowa, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- General Eisenhower held a lead early today over Governor Stevenson in Iowa, which went to President Truman in 1948.

The New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Industrial and Labor Conditions will hold public hearings on a proposed statewide statutory minimum wage law Monday at 10 A. M. and 2 P. M. in Room 500, State Building, 80 Centre Street.

Sydney M. Siegel and Aaron Powsner have sold the taxpayer building at 210-01 to 210-25 Horace Harding Boulevard in the Cunningham Park area of Queens to Shaul S. Bahary. The property, on a plot 100 by 125 feet, occupies the blockfront on the north side of the boulevard between 210th and 211th Streets.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Poland, Mexico and Haiti supported today an Asian-Arab recommendation that the United Nations make another attempt, through a proposed good offices commission, to deal with six-year-old charges that South Africa has discriminated against her Indian minority.

HONOLULU, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A thundering thirteen-foot wall of water, powered by one of recorded history's mightiest earthquakes 3,500 miles away, struck the evacuated northwest shore of Oahu in the Hawaiian Islands today.

BOSTON, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower appeared today to have captured sixteen electoral votes in Massachusetts by a plurality that might be at least 100,000, returning the Commonwealth to the Republican Presidential column for the first time since 1928. President Truman's plurality in 1948 was 242,418.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Displeasure at the treatment given to spokesmen from underdeveloped lands who have appeared before the United Nations Trusteeship Council was expressed today in the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Republicans swept all five Rockland County towns today with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower getting 27,588 votes to 15,097 for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 4 -- An eight-state police alarm was sent out today for a recently hired chauffeur for the West Jersey Hospital here, who was accused of having stolen $4,500 of the hospital's funds and its station wagon yesterday.

DURBAN, South Africa, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Durban police refused last night -- for the second night -- to arrest curfew-breaking demonstrators who paraded through the city in defiance of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's white supremacy policy.

Against a Republican tidal wave on Long Island that stood out even amid the national deluge of votes that swept the. Republican party into power early this morning, only Ernest Greenwood, freshman Demcratic incumbent in the First Congressional District in Suffolk County made a passable showing as he went down to a three-to-two defeat by Stuyvasant Wainwright 2d.

Off the Broadway stage since her sensitive performance in "The Voice of the Turtle," Margaret Sullavan returns tonight in "The Deep Blue Sea." The premiere at the Morosco, where she acted in the "Turtle" (from Dec. 8, 1943 through Dec. 16, 1944), will commence at 8 P. M.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- After trailing for nearly four hours, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President, swept ahead to a commanding lead over his Democratic opponent, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, for Pennsylvania's thirty-two votes in the Electoral College.
LONDON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of Queen Elizabeth's address today to the new session of Parliament:

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -Republicans scored a landslide today in Westchester County, giving a 2-to-1 lead to other ticket in many communities. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower received a plurality of 123,456 in the Presidential race.
CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 4 -- Larry MacPhail's General Staff, one of the nation's leading handicap performers, probably has run his last race.

A number of fabrics made of synthetic materials, as well as some printed designs, appear in a new collection of Titus Blatter Co.'s decorative fabrics. The materials are comparatively inexpensive in price.
PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Alex Maguy designs spring topcoats with wide maringale belts that suggest a lowered waistline, and afternoon coats with low necklines.

President Truman, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson have joined in urging support of the Crusade for Freedom in its 1952 drive. Charles E. Wilson, national campaign chairman, reported yesterday.

Well, that is over now, and one of them is both right and is President, while the other is just right without the complications. It is over now, and there is a new Congress, a new board of assessors, a new justice of the peace and, in those places clinging to a traditionally important elective office, a new dog catcher.

Speaking about close races, as everyone appeared to be doing on Election Day, the feature on the Empire-at-Jamaica ticket yesterday looked like a final charge of Democrats and Republicans until Mrs. John W. Hanes' Devilkin emerged from the middle of the pack and gained a two-length victory in the Comely Handicap.

ST. LOUIS, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- The outcome of the Presidential election in Missouri was in doubt early today, as returns from the metropolitan precincts began to cut into Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's impressive outstate lead.

Ed O'Malley of Bishop du Bois was the individual winner and Fordham Prep the team victor yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Bronx Manhattan - Westchester cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park.

OTTAWA, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- The time to start worrying about the United Nations would be if and when the violence of its debates softened to "meaningless courtesies," in the opinion of Lester B. Pearson, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs.

HARTFORD, Conn., Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower swept to an amazing landslide victory in Connecticut yesterday, winning by a margin of nearly 130,000 votes over Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson in final returns from the 169 cities and towns in the state.

The sixty-fourth National Horse Show had its formal opening in Madison Square Garden last night in the traditional parade of international jumping teams from Canada, France, Ireland, Mexico and the United States, and their impressive center-of-the-ring salutes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Delegates to the United Nations General Assembly, who in the last few days had begun to share the excitement of the American electorate over the Presidential outcome, left committee sessions early this afternoon to listen to returns on television and over the radio.

OTTAWA, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Canada informed the United States Government today she considered the 1941 agreement for joint Canada-United States construction of the St. Lawrence seaway-power projecct had been superseded by last week's International Joint Commission approval of a joint power project.

The Republican party re-elected three of its four Representatives from this city yesterday and captured four other seats in Congress -- one in the Bronx, one in Brooklyn, one in Queens, and the seat from the newly laid-out Brooklyn-Staten Island district.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 4 -- John M. Allison, Assistant Secretary of state for Far Eastern affairs, expressed the conviction here today that the United States would continue to give military and economic assistance to the Chinese Nationalists no matter what the result of the American Presidential election.
REDIPUGLIA, Italy, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi asked Yugoslavia today for "an act of goodwill" as the first step toward solving the dispute over Trieste.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today blamed the carelessness of the pilot and crew for an accident in which a woman passenger had been pulled through the suddenly-opened door of a pressurized-cabin airplane last July 27 and lost in the Atlantic Ocean off South America.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Verne Tindall, Republican campaign director, conceded an Arkansas victory for Gov-Adlai E. Stevenson last night. The state's eight electoral votes last went to a Republican Presidential candidate in 1872 when U. S. Grant carried Arkansas.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Toward the end of last January, King George VI sat in his study at Sandringham examining the proofs of a book.

SAN FRANCISCO, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has led California back to Republicanism in a Presidential election for the first time since Franklin D. Roosevelt cut it from twenty years ago.
TORONTO, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Mexico Tramways Company announced today that a final agreement has been signed in connection with its tramways interests in and around Mexico City.
The Eisenhower tide tightened yesterday the Republican party's grip on the New York State Legislature, which it has controlled since 1939.

Sunray Oil Corporation yesterday reported net income for the first nine months of the year of $17,265,000, or $1.73 a common share, compared with $16,399,000, or $1.65, earned last year. A joint statement by C. H. Wright, chairman, and W. C. Whaley, president, listed gross income at $96,600,000, against $94,500,000 for the same period last year.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential candidate, has smashed the traditionally Democratic Solid South in his national victory over Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson. He has carried outright Florida and Virginia, with their twenty-two electoral votes. This morning unofficial observers gave him the greatest Southern prize of all -- Texas and its twenty-four electoral votes, the sixth biggest bloc in the United States.

Senator Irving M. Ives won re-election in a three-cornered race yesterday by the largest plurality ever obtained by a Republican candidate in New York State, topping President Warren G. Harding's record-setting margin of 1,089,929 in 1920 by more than 200,000 votes.

MONTREAL, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Maurice Richard of the Montreal Canadiens, still looking for his record-shattering 325th goal, and Ted Kennedy, smooth skating center of the Toronto Maple Leafs, shared the lead in the National Hockey League's scoring race today.
WASHINGTON, Conn., Nov. 4 -Although his Gunnery School eleven lost its first game last Saturday in five starts, Coach Roderick Beebe Jr. casts a solid vote for his far from disheartened outfit.

ABOARD TRUMAN TRAIN, en route to Washington, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- President Truman went to bed at 9:30 o'clock last night, according to a White House spokesman, without having seen any election returns or listening to broadcasts on the voting.

The decline of American Labor Party strength in the old Marcantonio Congressional District was dramatically demonstrated in yesterday's election. James G. Donovan was returned to his seat in the House, as expected, since he had Democratic, Republican and Liberal endorsement.
Troops were ordered out to fight the blazes in two areas as fires crackled through woodlands in five states, The United Press reported yesterday.
A jet airliner able to take 150 persons between London and New York on a "three-hops-a-day" schedule has been reported on the drawing boards of Handley Page, a British aircraft manufacturer.

The New York City Ballet last night returned to the City Center for its fall season, after having covered itself with glory in a five-month tour of Europe. That it could not possibly have done less than that abroad was made more than clear on this occasion, for it is a stunning company, graced with leading dancers of highly individual excellence, an exemplary corps de ballet and a style all its own.

RICHMOND, Va., Wednesday, Nov. 5 -Traditionally Democratic Virginia voted Republican in a Presidential election yesterday for the first time since 1928 and gave its twelve electoral votes to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- It became known here today that the selection committee had decided to award the Nobel prize for chemistry to Dr. Archer J. P. Martin and Dr. R. Millington Synge, British biochemists who performed much of the basic research on the relatively new science of chromatography. This is a method of separating subtle mixtures such as vitamin-containing compounds and plant pigments.

THE waterfowl build-up is progressing rapidly on the Long Island Bays and on the Sound, and with the opening of the New Jersey and Connecticut seasons on Friday, the local wildfowlers will have a choice of locale and some choice in species.

No sudden or drastic change in the policies and practices of American President Lines is contemplated, but much of its future will depend upon the company's new stockholders and the Government's maritime policy, George Killion, president of the steamship concern, asserted yesterday.

Unbeaten Michigan State leads the nation's major college football teams in offense with 435.2 yards per game, National Collegiate Athletic Association figures disclosed today. Oklahoma is second with 430.8 and Maryland third with 423.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Nov. 4 -- They went wild at the Ambassador Hotel tonight when Richard M. Nixon came down from his second floor suite to tell the world of his gratitude for victory.

WASHINGTON (Science Service) -- Solution to medical who-dunnit story, the mystery of the seven sick race horses, has just been reported to the Army Medical Service Graduate School here. The solution brought the discovery that Japanese encephalitis, a brain inflammation, exists in Malaya where it had never before been even suspected.

Times Square last night had the smallest Election Night turnout in its long existence. It was the least demonstrative crowd, too -- without voice, without the traditional horns and bells, and utterly without enthusiasm.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- John B. Dunlap, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, intends to resign soon to become commissioner of the reorganized Federal tax district comprising Texas and Oklahoma.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower carried Oklahoma by an indicated majority of more than 60,000 votes, nearly complete unofficial returns showed early today.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was elected President of the United States yesterday in an electoral vote landslide and with an emphatic popular majority that probably will give his party a small margin of control in the House of Representatives but may leave the Senate as it is -- forty-nine Democrats, forty-seven Republicans and one independent.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 4 -- Three men set out from this port on Manhasset Bay at 8:30 A. M. today in a small boat with an outboard motor, and by the end of the day they had not returned, the North Hempstead Harbor patrol reported.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -- Jules Buck, former Twentieth Century-Fox producer, has organized his own producing company in Paris and will begin filming operations in January.
It appeared at 4:30 this morning that control of the United States Senate could be determined by the outcome of the Senatorial races in Michigan and Massachusetts.

VANCOUVER, B. C. (Canadian Press) -- Canadian Pacific's new cargo ships have already taken over part of the role left by the pre-war "empress fleet" on the Vancouver-to-Orient service and now they will take over another.

Four of the five Russian competitors in the women's world chess championship challengers' tournament in Moscow were among the six leaders at the close of yesterday's session of play in the ninth round, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The underdeveloped countries are seizing the occasion of the general debate of the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee to air their complaints about the downward trend in world prices of basic commodities such as cotton and wool.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The University of Kentucky has no intention of firing Coach Adolph Rupp over disclosures that he knowingly used ineligible players.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 4 -- French troops forged ahead against stiffening resistance in their counter-attack against Communist-led Vietminh forces in the hill country of north Tonkin yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- All was quiet -- very, very quiet -- in this capital city on this 1952 Presidential Election Day.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 5 (AP) -- United Nation Command communique 1,424 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Wednesday, Korea time:

MANCHESTER, England, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- Japanese plans for expanding world production of cotton textiles met head-on opposition from Britain at the recent Buxton International Cotton Conference, it was revealed here today.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Parliamentary democracy was hard at work on both sides of the Atlantic today. While the United States voters were busy electing a new President, their British cousins were grandly opening a new session of Parliament.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Goena Moberg, Swedish explorer, has returned to Europe after an exploration in the central Saraha of many months that took him into the little known area of the Tibesti Mountains, which lie in French Equatorial Africa.

De Witt Clinton tumbled Stuyvesant High from the ranks of the unbeaten teams in the feature of a double-header at Triborough Stadium at Randalls Island yesterday. Monroe and Evander battled to a 12-12 tie in the first contest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Civilian morale in North Korea is so poor that the majority of the population would welcome a United Nations offensive to end the war, a Defense Department analysis said today.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower touched off a tunultuous celebration at 2 o'clock this morning among 2,000 of his supporters and party workers in the grand ballroom of the Commodore Hotel.
MONTREAL, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Prices on the Stock Exchange and Curb Market were slightly higher today in quiet trading.

The golden nematode, which last spring hampered the importation into this country of thousands of bags of Spanish potatoes and earlier seriously impaired a Long Island potato crop, is once again affecting the economy of the Port of New York.

A driver who paused at the scene of an accident long enough to load his fatally injured victim into his car and then drive her twenty miles was arrested yesterday after police chased him seventy blocks up the West Side Highway.

There will be more toys around the Christmas tree this year. The Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., estimates that approximately $600,000,000 worth will be sold this year, an increase of 10 per cent from 1951. The trade association points out further that toy prices average 5 per cent less than last year and the 10 per cent gain in dollar volume means only one thing -- more toys.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Traditional cooking of twenty-two countries was demonstrated here today at the International Kitchen exhibition in the Royal Festival Hall before a distinguished audience that included Queen Mother Elizabeth.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower beat his Democratic opponent, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, by 60,303 votes in Fairfield County, Conn., according to a tabulation of returns early today.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Two United States Thunderjets yesterday chased a Soviet-designed fighter bearing the markings of the Soviet Air Force over northeastern Hokkaido and watched the plane cross the international boundary into Soviet territory.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Samuel M. Pistorio's Devils Verse, a 3-1 shot, outran eight other Maryland-bred juvelines to win the $7,500 added Pimlico Breeders' Stakes today at Pimlico.

Mayor Impellitteri had called upon citizens and organized groups in the metropolitan area to swell the ranks of civil defense workers. He issued yesterday a proclamation in support of the nation-wide campaign of the Federal Civil Defense Administration for workers from Armistice Day, Nov. 11, to Thanksgiving Day, Nov. 27.

State and local law-enforcement officials, whose investigators kept an eye on polling places here yesterday, agreed that the election went off like clockwork, with voting irregularities held to a minimum.

Dwight Eisenhower has been elected President of the United States, and for the first time since 1928 the Republican party has been returned to power. The contrast between the world in which that last previous Republican victory was won and the world in which we live today is stark enough to give the victors in this election a sobering sense of responsibility, even in this hour of triumph.

Four men who allegedly operated one of the largest illicit liquor stills ever seized in the metropolitan area were ordered held in bail for Federal grand jury action when arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Slingin' Sam Baugh, football's Mr. Forward Pass, said today he may have to retire as an active player before the season ends if his injured hand fails to improve.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Dalray, the New Zealand champion and 5-to-1 favorite, carried top weight of 134 pounds to a brilliant, half-length triumph today in the Melbourne Cup -- Australia's top horse race -- when he passed more than twenty of his twenty-nine rivals in the last half-mile.

Senator Irving M. Ives has produced a legislative and political record that has lodged him firmly in the liberal wing of the Republican party.

The Allied Artists of America have announced prizes and awards for their annual exhibition that opens to the public tomorrow in the galleries of the National Academy. The show, slightly smaller than in the preceding exhibitions, includes 237 examples of work in oil, water-color, casein and sculpture, 135 of which are by members and 102 by nonmembers
