WILMINGTON, Del., Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- The Republicans apparently swept all major offices in Delaware at yesterday's election as heavy G. O. P. returns from the rural sections wiped out the Democratic majority in the City of Wilmington and piled UP steadily increasing totals for the Republicans.
Connecticut and New Jersey were assured, by the generally high quality of candidates on both major party tickets, of being well represented in the Senate after yesterday's election.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Blown along by a dry nor'wester over smooth water that rose to twenty miles an hour at times (some skippers calculated much more), the sailing dinghies had real racing today off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, told a small and weary election party group early this morning that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, even in defeat, had become a national leader, and "we shall hear more of him."

CHICAGO, Wednesday, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Jacob Arvey, Illinois Democratic National Committeeman, conceded a Democratic defeat in Illinois, last night shortly after Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, swept out in front of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson on the Democratic Governor's home grounds.
Former Representative Christopher C. McGrath was elected Surrogate of Bronx County last night in a bitterly-contested, three-cornered race.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Nov. 4 -- Foreign Minister Edward Kardelj informed the sixth Yugoslav Communist party congress today that the Government would have to re-examine its position against joining regional defense pacts if the world situation continued to deteriorate and the idea of war approached.

THE press notice announced that wrestling would return to Madison Square Garden in another fortnight. No apologies were made for the intrusion. It was announced in straight-faced fashion as if this once noble athletic activity was deserving of patronage. It isn't, though. The grappling art has gone from worse to worser to worsest, even bridging the grammatical impossibility thereof.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- France notified the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today that the French defense promises for 1952 made in Lisbon early this year would be kept but that in 1953 the French Government could not increase its arming effort.

There was a large gathering of prominent persons in social, civic and business circles, and ranking officers of the Armed Forces of the United States and other nations and their wives last night at the first evening performance of the sixty-fourth National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower entered politics for the first time this year at the age of 61, after having gained world-wide renown as a military leader.

The successful cooperation of governmental health agencies and private organizations in the last half century is credited in a report made public yesterday for the progress achieved in the fields of public health and welfare in New York State.
Quarterback Mitch Price led the Columbia football team in a two-hour light contact scrimmage yesterday as Lion coach Lou Little continued to prepare his squad for Saturday's game at Dartmouth.
NEWBURG, N, Y., Nov 5 -- Four predominantly Republican counties in the mid-Hudson Valley today gave thumping pluralities to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in his bid for the Presidency.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 4 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion introduced a bill in the Knesset (Parliament) today recognizing the World Zionist Organization as the agency authorized to coordinate the activities of all Jewish bodies engaged in the development of Israel and in the integration of immigrants.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Asian and Arab members of the United Nations met today to hear Indonesia suggest that the deadlocked issue of the repatriation of prisoners of the Korean war be turned over to a neutral commission.

You call the forces which are being unleashed in British East Africa, by a "society only a few generations removed from savagery," satanic."

YONKERS, Nov. 4 -- No motive was immediately apparent to the police or to relatives this evening in the fatal shooting of Emil Meissmer, 45 years old, a mechanic, in front of his house at 26 Longmeadow Road.
WINNIPEG, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Prices closed irregularly in dull trade today on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange. Outside interest was light dut to the United States holiday for the elections.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The next President of the United States actually will be elected Dec. 15.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Ohio's twenty-five electoral votes were conceded to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican, this morning by Eugene H. Hanhart, Ohio's Democratic Chairman.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 4 (Reuters)--The Governor of Ja-t maica, Sir Hugh Mackintosh Foot, I will visit London this month forl consultations with Colonial Sec-/ retary Oliver Lyttelton on consti-I tutional and economic questions,! it was announced today. I

Gloves in novelty designs and fabrics have been playing an increasingly important role in the fashion picture, and for the holiday season and winter many innovations will be offered both for daytime and evening wear.
Yoko Matsuo, violinist, a winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Award, made her recital debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

" The World of Eli Whitney," by Jeannette Mirsky and Allan Nevins, will be published by Macmillan on Nov. 18. It is a biography of the inventor of the cotton gin as well as an account of how Whitney started America on its road to world leadership in industry and mass production.

Max Zaslofsky and Dick McGuire, Knickerbocker holdouts, will try to straighten out their contractual differences this afternoon in a meeting with Ned Irish, executive vice president of Madison Square Garden, it was learned yesterday.

Local service northbound on the East Side I. R. T. subway between Brooklyn Bridge and Grand Central Terminal was suspended, between 10:38 and 11:14 A. M. yesterday when power was turned off so firemen could fight a blaze caused by a short-circuited motor in a car at the Fourteenth Street station, the Board of Transportation reported.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, took the lead over Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, as late rural returns in yesterday's election began coming in early today, and the Republicans seemed fairly sure of winning Minnesota's eleven electoral votes for the first time since 1928.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- The hard-fighting South Korean infantry, driving for the third time in three days up the slopes of the central Korean ridges, drove a penetration today into the Communist lines on the western flank of "Triangle Hill," a strategic position north of Kumhwa.

With the creation in Munich, Germany, recently of a Coordinating Center of Anti-Bolshevik Struggle, two years of intense effort aimed at unifying anti-Soviet emigres from the Soviet Union for a joint struggle against Premier Stalin have ended in final success.

Two new films will open today at first-run theatres. "The Brave Don't Cry," a British-made drama about Scottish miners, with John Gregson, is at the Guild Theatre. Philip Leacock directed and John Grierson produced the Group 3 Production from an original screen play by Montagu Slater . . . "Operation Secret," a Warner Brothers action drama, with Cornel Wilde, Steve Cochran, Phyllis Thaxter and Karl Malden, is at the Paramount.

BALTIMORE, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Normally Democratic Maryland went Republican for the third consecutive election in the Presidential race, and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the G. O. P. nominee, piled up a lead of 82,000 over his Democratic opponent, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, in early returns today from all but 200 of the state's 1,428 polling places.

Your editorial on reciprocal trade in your issue of Oct. 31 brings to the fore again the peculiar bias which your otherwise great paper almost invariably brings to the discussion of agricultural subjects.

Like most other countries, Canada experienced an inflationary expansion following the outbreak of hostilities in Korea. In consequence, wholesale prices rose from 206.6 per cent of the 1935-39 average to 242.3, or by about 17 per cent, while the cost of living climbed from 164.5 to 190.9, or only 16 per cent.
TOPEKA, Kan., Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Voters of Kansas, where Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican nominee, spent his boyhood, backed him by landslide proportions in yesterday's election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A sharp decline in deliveries of Bolivian tin concentrates to the United States is expected by Federal officials to result from that country's nationalization of its mines. An unofficial estimate of 1953 deliveries already has been reduced from about 15,000 to 10,000 tons and there is some opinion that Bolivia may have to be written off as a source of the metal.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4 (UP) -- Yale indignantly denied today a charge it had "stolen" a football player from Louisiana State.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, had a slender lead in Tennessee early today as returns piled up from yesterday's election.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Wednesday. Nov 5 (AP) -- West Virginia Democrats stood in front, but on shakier ground than at any time in twenty years, as returns slowly mounted today from yesterday's election.

Women headed by Mrs. John C. Hughes and Mrs. T. F. Davies Haines, chairman and co-chairman, respectively, and including Countess Bernard d'Escayrac and Mrs. Pierre Bedard, are advancing the sale of tickets for the performance of Moliere's "Amphitryon" and "Les Fourberies de Scapin" on the night of Nov. 20 at the Ziegfeld Theatre for the benefit of the Library Fund of the French Institute.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The four-day uprising at the Ohio Penitentiary here appeared to be at an end tonight. Convicts in four cell blocks who had been out of control from Friday night yielded late this afternoon to a surrender ultimatum delivered by Warden Ralph W. Alvis.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Julius Boros, a play-for-pay shooter only three years, today was acclaimed the "Professional Golfer of the Year."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration (D. P. A.) today boosted its defense expansion goals for zinc, mercury, synthetic cryolite, machine tools and special industrial services.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Wednesday, Nov. 5 -Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, running far ahead of the state Republican ticket, apparently scored an amazing victory in this strong Democratic state. With all 284 districts reporting, he held a 6,142-vote edge over Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, but he cannot claim victory until the state's 10,790 absentee ballots are counted.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson conceded defeat early today to his Republican opponent. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, and pledged the support "he will need to carry out the great tasks that lie before him."

TORONTO, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Stock market prices today continued recent advances and all sections gained moderately. Trading was slow as investors awaited the outcome of the United States election.
PIERRE, S. D., Wednesday Nov. 5 -- General Eisenhower early today held a lead of more than 2 to 1 over Governor Stevenson.

INDIANAPOLIS, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, was assured of Indiana's thirteen electoral votes and the entire state ticket appeared certain to be carried into office early today.

With more than three-quarters of New Jersey's vote counted early this morning, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower appeared headed toward a plurality of close to 300,000 in the state over Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson. This far exceeded Governor Dewey's 1948 plurality of 85,669 over President Truman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration announced today that eighty-two new or expanded facilities costing a total of $31,291,345 are eligible for accelerated tax amortization under the Defense Production Act.
Two disparate items are on this morning's agenda: hillbilly comedy and the brand of hockey played by the Rangers. It's a little hard to get excited about either.

AUGUSTA, Me. Wednesday, Nov. 5. -Maine has given its five electoral votes to General Eisenhower as returns from 617 of the state's 625 voting precincts gave him 232,622 votes to Governor Stevenson's 118,545.

MIAMI, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Returns early today indicated that Florida, traditionally Democratic; had given Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower a winning lead over Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois for the state's ten electoral votes.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Under the "surrender or starve" ultimatum accepted today by the convicts the surrender will go into effect tomorrow morning.

New cooking times for dried legumes, much shorter than the old-fashioned long simmering, have resulted from recent research by the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics of the United States Department of Agriculture. It is now suggested, for example, that lentils require only thirty, not ninety, minutes over the burner.

Next time your friend of unlikely name, Balboa Prawn, drops in, I shall be surprised if he is not upset by the Empire State's adoption of the single license plate. It will take all of one corncob full, firmly packed, I predict, to describe his concern, which will be punctuated by such over-agitated puffs as may sear dangerously his none too youthful pipe.

DALLAS, Tex., Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- In a historic turn of political events, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower appeared early today to have gained a decisive edge over Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois in the electoral battle for Texas, scene of one of the hottest election fights and possible key to the Democratic party's future in the once-solid South.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, carried New York State with its forty-five electoral votes with a plurality of landslide proportions that will reach nearly 850,000.
The city's merchants may have been divided yesterday on the Presidential candidates, but they agreed almost unanimously on another issue. Election Day store sales were uniformly satisfactory.

Following the Election Day lull, blood donors will renew their contributions today on a large scale, over a wide area, under the direction of the mobile units sent out from the Red Cross Donor Center, 70 West Fortieth Street.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 4 (AP) -- British Colonial Secretary Oliver Lyttleton promised tonight to "deliver the people of Kenya from fear" of the terrorist anti-white Mau Mau secret society. He made the pledge after two more Africans had been slain in ambush in the Nyeri district, forty-five miles north of Nairobi.
MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Wisconsin went to the Republicans today for the third time in a national election since 1920.

Louis G. Raiche, formerly with the Boeing Aircraft Company, has been named works manager for the St. Charles, Mo., plant of the American Car and Foundry Company.
Mitchell Price, Columbia's outstanding passer, added a sixth Ivy League record to his collection last Saturday as the Lions lost another football game, this one to Cornell, 21 to 14.

Republicans appeared to have picked up at least ten seats in the House of Representatives early today, while the Democrats picked up one. Fifty-three districts remained doubtful -- the Democrats had erected 191 members, the Republicans 190.

Several hundred proud and stately chrysanthemums languished like so many wallflowers yesterday at the Prospect Park Greenhouse while their admirers were wooed by a couple of mere men. Only a few hardy regulars attended the opening of the annual show as Brooklynites flocked to the polls.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 4 -- The Garden State Stakes, $20,000 added six-furlong feature today, was won by the Trio Stable's Laffango, who was the 3-5 favorite with the crowd of 28,160 at Garden State Park.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee approved today items totaling $4,306,800 for the 1953 operation of United Nations headquarters at Geneva, which were recommended by an advisory committee.

A residence in Hato Rey, Puerto Rico, will contain New York diplomas representing Doctor of Education, Master of Public Service and Bachelor of Arts after Emilio A. Davila-Rivera, his wife, Cecilia Gonzalez, and 16-year-old Emilio Jr. complete the course of studies for which each is enrolled at New York University.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Announcement here today of a new 120,000,000 loan for the nationalized transport industry offset the influence of the rise in Britain's gold and dollar reserves. Early business was cautious but both British Government securities and industrial leaders improved in the afternoon. Gilt-edged issues were one-eighth of 1 per cent higher and miscellaneous industrial leaders rose sharply. Other industrial shares also were firm.

Monte Irvin, slugging outfielder who missed all but about the final month and a half of the 1952 season because of a fractured ankle, incurred in the spring, has the best lifetime batting average of all the active Giant players, according to figures compiled by the New York club's statistician, Willie Goodrich.
Luminous bridges of stars more than 10,000 trillion miles long have been discovered to link island universes that float by the million in the boundless ocean of space.

FEW writers could be called cosmopolitan more fittingly than May Sarton, whose father was Belgian, whose mother was English, who is an American citizen with an international background and international habits of living. A poet and a novelist of authentic distinction, Miss Sarton has not yet won the popular following in this country that she deserves.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 4 -- Union County Prosecutor Edward Cohn charged today that the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee, which operates a "clearing house" for complaints of low-flying planes, had only the representative of a telephone answering exchange available to receive a protest yesterday after noon.

Strong support in Congress for the private American merchant marine was pledged to the industry yesterday by Representative Alvin F. Weichel of Ohio, who, as ranking Republican member of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries, is expected to be chairman of the important committee in the next session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- A political era of twenty years marked by government experimentation ended today as decisively as it began twenty years ago with the mandatory closing of all banks, the discovery of the "forgotten man" and the glorification of the Constitution's "welfare clause."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, awaited word tonight from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower whether he intends to appoint soon a successor to tkae over the administration of the nation's defense program.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- All three West Coast states not only landed in the Eisenhower-Nixon column in yesterday's Presidential election but they gave the Republicans a net gain of nine to twelve members of the national House of Representatives.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 5 -- Ruddy-faced and still beaming, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived here at 5:22 o'clock this evening by airplane from New York for a ten-day vacation with a small party of relatives and friends.

HONOLULU, Nov. 5 -- The Hawaiian Islands counted approximately $150,000 damage today from the series of seismic waves that swept windward beaches late yesterday as an aftermath to heavy earthquakes off the Siberian peninsula of Kamchatka.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 5 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson today viewed his defeat for the Presidency by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower without rancor or misgivings and apparently felt the loss of Illinois to the Republicans as keenly as his failure to win the Presidency.

LISBON, Nov. 1 -- The tiny Portuguese possession of Goa, on the west coast of India, will be the scene on Dec. 2 of ceremonies to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the death of St. Francis Xavier, a Spanish-born nobleman, who, working for the Roman Catholic Church, went to India and the Far East as a missionary with the Portuguese navigators of four centuries ago.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5 -- Portraits of ten leading members of the Soviet Government headed by Premier Stalin were mounted on walls and buildings throughout Moscow today as decorations for the thirty-fifth anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, which will be celebrated Nov. 7 -- Friday.

The outcome of referendums affecting the issuance of $1,400,000,000 of new state and municipal bonds was not fully known yesterday because of incomplete counts, especially in California, where the heaviest borrowings were being passed upon.

TORONTO, Nov. 5 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs peppered Chuck Rayner, the Rangers' returning goalie, with a barrage of shots tonight as they skated into a first-place tie in the National Hockey League by defeating the New Yorkers, 4 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 29:

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Nov. 5 -- United States and Allied officers at Supreme Allied Headquarters here -- which Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower created and directed for seventeen months until last June -- expressed general gratification today at the news of their former commander's election victory.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Removal of limitations on the use of sulphur and the elimination of inventory controls on that product were ordered today by the National Production Authority.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 5 -- Republican politicians in Nassau County were celebrating today their triumph as the party's No. 1 vote-getting apparatus in the state.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5 (UP) -- The Soviet Union tonight gave notice that it refused to recognize as legal a United States naval defensive zone in Korean waters. The Russians said the United States naval order of Sept 27 was an extension of 1950 blockade that violated freedom of the seas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Instructions have been sent to all United States missions abroad, the State Department announced today, to encourage the participation of private capital in developments started under the Technical Cooperation (Point Four) Program.

FORT DIX, N. J., Nov. 5 -- A thinly clothed 20-year-old soldier with disordered nerves climbed to the top of a 125-foot water tower here today carrying an empty rifle. Seven hours later he was brought down under searchlights, so terrified that he could hardly move.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The French Cabinet reaffirmed today its determination to resist what is described here as United Nations interference in France's North African territories. Foreign Office sources cautiously suggested the possibility that the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to the Presidency might produce stronger United States support for the French position there.

THE National Collegiate Athletic Association would have had no excuse for its existence if it had not snapped the whip on Kentucky and forced the Wildcats to cancel their entire intercollegiate basketball schedule. Unless disciplinary action had been taken in so flagrant a case, further abuses would have reached the uncontrollable stage. A crack-down was an absolute necessity and Kentucky would appear to need the jolt it received.

On the heels of their worst defeat in New York State since 1920, Democrats were faced yesterday with a series of internal battles involving the party leadership in the state, next year's Mayoralty campaign, the minority leadership of the State Assembly and the county leadership in Brooklyn.
HELENA, Mont., Nov. 5 -- Montana, an election weathervane state since 1904, voted heavily for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower this year and selected a Republican Governor.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Premier Antoine Pinay was forced tonight to go before a refractory National Assembly to insist upon a balanced 1953 budget and to defend his policy of opposing any tax increases.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Senator Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin, ranking Republican member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, predicted today that under the Eisenhower Administration the United States would continue to oppose the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war against their will.
Paul Cameron, the sharp-shooting passer of U. C. L. A.'s unbeaten and untied Bruins, yesterday was named the Associated Press' back of the week.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Horinoshin Fma2hashi, Japan's famed Flying Fish of Fujiyama, i announced his retirement from the sport yesterday after seven years of swimming competition. WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, pledged his party today to the role of "a loyal, honest and patriotic opposition."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower's personal security is now in the hands of Secret Service agents, who will go with him wherever he goes, even to Korea, until the hour he leaves the office of President.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Georgia Tech, unbeaten and united football giant of the Southeastern Conference, agreed today to play in the 1953 Sugar Bowl classic. Its opponent has not yet been chosen.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- One of the first acts of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President-elect was to transmit a message to France via the French broadcasting system at 7 A. M. today, New York time. In it he said he had been brought up to believe French-American friendship was "an axiom of history" and that he found comfort in this fact amid the difficulties of today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Intrigued by America's super markets as well as the self-service features of other than food stores, a group of British retailers today urged that storekeepers in the United Kingdom consider adoption of American self-service merchandising.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- The Republican landslide yesterday stirred apprehension as to what the result would be in regard to Korea, and as to whether the new Administration would make any material change in farm policies. TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 6 -- The Chinese Communist and the South Korean troops fought savagely throughout yesterday in the battle for the central Korean ridges north of Kumhwa; but neither dented the opposing line.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- Republican candidates threw Democrats out of four state houses today and captured nineteen Governorships, while the G. O. P. challenger in Michigan fought a seesaw battle to oust Gov. G. Mennen Williams.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Even the most optimistic Republicans had underestimated the size of the landslide that was to sweep across Westchester County yesterday, but they began training their sights today on a new height in plurality for the future, such as the 123,308 reached by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's sweeping victory in Pennsylvania, an analysis of the Presidential election returns showed today.
Your very interesting editorial "Proposals for Korea" gives me the opportunity to make some observations which I hope will be graciously received in the columns of your distinguished paper.

BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- One of Berlin's most active anti-Communist organizations has reorganized itself, possibly to conform more closely to the spirit of notes sent to Soviet authorities yesterday by the three Western High Commissioners.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Dwight D. Eisenhower will be the twelfth general to serve as President of the United States.
MADISON TOWNSHIP, N. J., Nov. 5 -- James J. Tortorice, unsuccessful Republican candidate for Middlesex County Freeholder, lost not only his campaign yesterday but most of a case of liquor as well.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 6 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,425, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President Truman invited Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today to have a representative confer with Budget Director Frederick J. Lawton "so that he will be fully informed as to the items of the budget" for the 1954 fiscal year, which starts next July 1.

American diplomatic relations during the Civil War, particularly with England and Russia, are discussed in two books to be published three days apart. Putnam will issue on Nov. 14, "Atlantic Impact, 1861," by Evan John, which describes the reactions in America and Britain to the removal of the two Confederate commissioners from the S. S. Trent in 1861.
What is a "voluntary" hospital? It is a non-profit hospital organized by civic-minded men and women who believe that a community should meet its health needs by its own efforts and in its own way.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 5 -- Farley Granger is out of the cast of "The Golden Blade" and Rock Hudson will take his place as co-star with Piper Laurie in this swashbuckling romantic adventure which will go before the Technicolor cameras at Universal-International on Nov. 14.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Fairfield County, traditionally Republican, wrote a new chapter in its political history in yesterday's election when every town in the county went Republican and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower tripled his expected plurality.

Eight teachers dismissed last month by the Board of Education because of their refusal to answer questions before the Senate subcommittee investigating communism on grounds of self-incrimination filed a petition yesterday for an appeal of the action by the State Supreme Court.

A fist fight between two Bronx teenagers a week ago grew into a grievance between the rival street-gangs of which they were members and culminated yesterday in the mistaken-identity shooting of William Nalbach, 17 years old, of 2688 Third Avenue, the Bronx, by a 15-year-old rifleman, the police said last night.

A new issue of $2,600,000 of school building bonds of Monongalia County, W. Va., has been sold to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.10 for 2 1/2s. Only one bid was submitted.

Another highly rewarding evening was provided by the New York City Ballet in its second performance of the season at the City Center last night. That there were again no novelties on the schedule was beside the point, for a company of such artistry as this makes all the old works seem new.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The farm vote was not a decisive factor in yesterday's general election, as it was in the Presidential campaign of 1948, in the opinion of observers here. Farmers voted on general issues rather than on purely agricultural ones, these observers believe, and resumed a tendency to support Republican candidates.

Today's new film is "Breaking Through the Sound Barrier," a British-made aeronautical drama, with Ralph Richardson, Ann Todd, Nigel Patrick and John Justin, at the Victoria. David Lean directed and produced the London Films presentation from a story and script by Terence Rattigan. The Lopert Films release is being distributed by United Artists.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5 -- Whitaker Chambers, confessed Commutaker Chambers, accuser of Alger Hiss and author of the best seller "Witness" detailing Chambers' conversion to and from communism and his part in the Hiss case, is seriously ill in St. Agnes Hospital with a heart condition.

TRENTON, Nov. 5 -- Dr. Lewis Webster Jones, president of Rutgers University, asked the state today to increase its grant next year for university support by $3,735,237 "to attract and hold the best men" for the faculty and to bring facilities to "minimum standards."

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 5 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's sweep of this state by a margin of more than 125,000 votes in yesterday's election represented, uniquely among the forty-eight states, a victory for both the regular Republican and Democratic organizations, which, after a Democratic revolt, had collaborated in espousing his candidacy.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 5 -- Indian feelings on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's victory were mixed with some misgiving that a Republican regime would reduce American aid to this country. Other officials thought the new President would avoid radical changes in Washington's foreign policy.

Burlington Mills Corporation has acquired its first woolen and worsted manufacturing division, it was announced yesterday by J. C. Cowan Jr., president. The company, he revealed, has acquired the stock of Peerless Woolen Mills, one of the largest single units of its kind in the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Post-election speculation in the Capital today centered on the Cabinet Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will appoint. Most guessers agreed on John Foster Dulles as Secretary of State and Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., or Governor Dewey as Secretary of Defense.

Manufacturers of television receivers are running a production race to meet continued high demand for virtually all models, producers reported yesterday. Retailers said increased output is fore-stalling shortages except in isolated units priced at rock bottom.

After an ownership of six months, W. Bruce Brown has resold the three-story and basement dwelling on lot 19.2 by 100 feet at 252 East Forty-eighth Street, near Second Avenue, to Antoine Dadone, caterer and president of Vendome Table Delicacies, Inc.

TOKYO, Nov. 5 -- A stiffer attitude by the United States toward the Soviet Union may be expected as a result of the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Japanese press and political circles speculated today.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public land private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

Events tonight: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 o'clock: Gerhard Kander, violinist, Town Hall, 8:30; Norman Clayton, baritone, Carnegie Hall Recital, 8:30; Richard Dyer-Bennet, folk-singer, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30; Linda Babbitt, soprano, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30.

President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower was urged yesterday to develop a program to guide the nation in "its probable forthcoming change from an economy based on defense production to one finding its prosperity in normal peacetime pursuits."

The New York commodity exchanges opened strong yesterday following the Presidential election but domestic items generally fell off before the close. Dealers attributed the declines, though not extremely below Monday's closings but sharp compared with the day's highs, to a long-range view of the Republican victory.
Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Associated Press on the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower :

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 5 -- The largest crowd to watch a Harvard-Princeton game since 1946 is expected in Palmer Stadium on Saturday when the Tiger will open its quest for its sixth successive Big Three championship. The game will mark the seventy-fifth anniversary of the rivalry between the two schools and the start of the triangular competition for football's oldest title.

Paying large sums of cash to untried youngsters for signing baseball contracts will become a highly risky proposition if the major and minor leagues adopt the stringent new bonus rule that will be proposed at their annual meetings in Phoenix, Ariz., next month.

The Republicans, following the sweep of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's Presidential victory, have wrested numerical control of the House of Representatives from the Democrats. They had achieved such control in the off-year elections of 1946 only to lose it in 1948 when President Truman led the victorious ticket.
Columbia University extended congratulations yesterday to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, its president on leave of absence, on his successful campaign for the Presidency.

Carrying New York State outside of New York City by the greatest plurality ever obtained by a Presidential candidate, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican, won this state's forty-five electoral votes by a plurality of 863,447 over Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, his Democratic opponent.

SEWANEE, Tenn., Nov. 5 -- Eight leading figures in religious instruction at the University of the South have resigned their academic positions, effective next June, in protest of a ban on the admission of Negro students to the University's School of Theology.
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 5 -- While the peopel back in the United States were fighting to stay awake to hear the election returns, American soldiers here heard them throughout a pleasant sunlit day.

Harold C. Whittemore Jr. has been made a vice president of the Warwick Chemical Company division of Sun Chemical Corporation at Wood River Junction, R.I. He had been assistant to the president in Sun's New York offices.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Senator Wayne Morse, who bolted the Republican party to support Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, today sent telegrams of praise to the defeated Democratic candidate and President Truman.

A police guard was placed yesterday over election machines in the Sixth Congressional District in North Queens, where Representative Robert Tripp Ross was the only Republican member of Congress in the city to lose his seat in last Tuesday's election.

Improved conditions in the textile market as well as the pick-up in its plastics business are reflected in the increased sales for the third-quarter of the Celanese Corporation of America. Earnings for the quarter were little changed, but operating results for the nine months suffered a decline of $16,724,687 from a year ago.

The most beautiful ships in the world pass between the Battery and Fifty-ninth Street in the Hudson River. But the "ugly ducklings" of commerce, for the most part ply the backwashes of the harbor from Newtown Creek and the Gowanus Canal across the East River, Buttermilk Channel and Red Hook Flats to the low marshes of the Jersey Shore.

Coach Lou Little sent the Columbia football squad through long offensive and defensive drills yesterday at Baker Field as the Lions continued to prepare for Saturday's Ivy League contest at Dartmouth.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, acclaimed the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in a statement today.

MADRID, Nov. 5 -- In line with official instructions, the Government-controlled press continued today to show the same editorial aloofness after the United States election as it had during the last few weeks.

Rodman Gilder, whose watchful eye for changes in our city always takes note of links with the past, reminds this corner that too little attention has been paid to the transfer to the United States Government of the building which for half a century has been Wanamaker's store and was so often the scene of concerts and Christmas shows for children.

On the day when the dimensions of the Eisenhower victory are being finally established the thoughts of many American voters turn to the man from Springfield who was defeated. It is no surprise to any of us, including those who supported the Republican cause, that Gov. Adlai Stevenson proved to be a good loser.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 5 -- Passionate interest in Israel in the United States elections gave way to expressions of dull disappointment today as Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower swept to victory.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 5 -- Hope that even before his inauguration Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will induce France and Italy to speed ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty is the basis for the unbridled elation of the Federal Government over the Republican victory in the United States Presidential election.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 124,569 today, an increase of 1,174 since last week.
Moss Hart's latest play, "The Climate of Eden," opens at the Martin Beck Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock under the auspices of Joseph M. Hyman and Bernard Hart.

Among the many momentous tasks facing President-elect Eisenhower the most urgent in his own estimation is "to bring the Korean war to an early and honorable end." With this purpose in view he pledged himself to go to Korea personally in order to study the military and political problems involved and to re-examine and re-appraise the methods and courses of action open to us.

Advertising-wise, the election assumed a number of novel aspects this year, a check-up revealed yesterday. In this area there was no question that television had become a prime medium, equaling or surpassing even radio, while newspapers received more copy than in many years, according to veteran time and space men.

Dick McGuire and Max Zaslofsky, two of the standout members of the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association, ended their holdouts yesterday following a conference with Ned Irish, executive director of Madison Square Garden.
SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, Nov. 5 (AP) -- "Well, I'm damned! . . . Every now and then something clicks -- and evidently this one did."

In the deeply troubled times in which we live it is a fact of supreme good fortune that the next President of the United States will have, to a degree seldom matched in the history of this country, the endorsement of the American electorate on a truly national basis. It is no sectional victory that General Eisenhower has won.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 5 (UP) -Bookmakers paid off with bundles of 10 notes today to Cyril Neville, who won an estimated 63,000 ($141,120) when his New Zealand champion, Dalray, won the Melbourne Cup yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The stock markets declined generally today to evaluate the effect of General Eisenhower's victory. While weighing probable business trends under the Republican Administration, there was only a cautious response in prices.

A program for spurring action toward solution of problems of United States exporters arising from the heavy backlog of delayed commercial payments due from Brazilian importers was initiated yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau in the Statler Hotel.

Trans-Atlantic steamship operators asked the Government yesterday for time to consider a proposal under which immigration inspectors would ferry back and forth across the Atlantic for the examination of liner passengers and crews.

DETROIT, Nov. 5 (AP) -- In setting new high production marks for the current year the auto factories have been using up a lot of steel -- so much that shortages threaten to interfere with continued high volume output during November and December.

Based on the production of 9,254,300 dozen shirts during the first six months of 1952, a new high may be established for the year, topping the 1950 total of 18,099,300 dozen, it was predicted yesterday by the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers. The figure for 1952 is 1.5 per cent behind 1951, but production dropped during the second half of last year because of oversupply.
Some good cookbooks have appeared, it is pleasant to report.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder announced today the Treasury will accept bids on Nov. 13 for $2,000,000,000 worth of tax anticipation bills.

City Hall was immersed in post-election quiet all day yesterday as Democratic city officials, who usually are constantly coming and going, remained away in large numbers from the nerve-center of municipal business.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Without any opposition from the left, former Prime Minister Clement Attlee, who has been leader of the British Labor party for seventeen years, was re-elected today at a meeting of the party's representatives in Parliament.

Although John Rapacz suffered a recurrence of an old knee injury against the Chicago Cardinals, the New York Football Giants are hopeful that they will be able to get some service from their 260-pound center in Sunday's contest with the San Francisco Forty-Niners at the Polo Grounds.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 5 -- R. Ford Hughes, Suffolk County Republican leader, was jubilant today over the 76,772 plurality this farming and resort county rolled up for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower. He said it exceeded even his pre-election boasts.
CAIRO, Nov. 5 -- An extreme Nationalist, Fathi Radwan, was made head of the new Ministry of National Instruction tonight. He will disperse information and what would be called propaganda elsewhere.

OTTAWA, Nov. 5 -- Genuine pleasure has been widely expressed in the Canadian national capital and in the nation's press at the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to the United States Presidency. No American is more highly regarded and better liked here than the former Commander in Chief of the Allied Armies.

The third winner of the afternoon for Ted Atkinson at Jamaica yesterday was Mrs. Wallace Gilroy's 4-year-old colt Timely Reward, who took the lead from William Ziegler Jr.'s Requisition high in the stretch and then, under the whip, held on for a length decision at the end of the mile-and-a-six-teenth run.

An indeterminate penitentiary term of up to three years was imposed yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court on William A. Daab, 45-year-old former plainsclothes man, on his plea of guilty to three counts of perjury in the second degree, misdemeanors.

The veteran passenger liner De Grasse, which was withdrawn from the New York run last year to make way for the new liner Flandre, will probably be brought back in April for the spring-summer travel rush, Henri Chardon, director of passenger and freight traffic for the French Line, said yesterday.

Although over the last quarter of a century many strides forward have been made to strengthen family health and welfare there have been, too, changes that have meant confusion, anxiety and even fears on the part of parents, Dr. John A. Rose said last night.

Six Red Cross bloodmobile units operated yesterday and will again be out today receiving blood donations throughout the metropolitan area. Today in Manhattan the units will visit the Bell Telephone Laboratories, 463 West Street; the Union Managament Blood Bank of the New York Telephone Company at 125 West Seventy-third Street; St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, and the Downtown Center of City College, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 5 -- In an attempt to prevent the revival of Prussian militarism in the new German army, the West German Cabinet will appoint all officers of the rank of colonel and above in the German armed forces participating in the European Defense Community.
Armed robbers and muggers attacked in three sections of Brooklyn yesterday and, after obtaining $1,405 in cash, beat and tied up their victims in two instances.
ROME, Nov. 5 -- The landslide proportions of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's victory surprised most Italians.

Jean Graham, young American pianist, gave her second Town Hall recital last night. Her playing had some decided attributes. It was assured, it was competent, it also was frequently spirited. In such works as Bach's Italian Concerto, Beethoven's Sonata in D, Op. 10,

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Governor Lausche, the immigrant's son who campaigns in whispers where many shout, became the first four-time Ohio Governor today -- only Democrat to stem the tide of state-wide Republican victory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Labor leaders, their political prestige at a new low, today ascribed their rout at the polls yesterday mainly to the personal popularity and war record of President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- The United States, Ethiopia, Brazil and Yugoslavia endorsed today the Arab-Asian bloc's proposal that a new United Nations good offices commission try to revive stalled negotiation on South Africa's treatment of her Indian minority.

" How in the world does whisky ever get sold?" This seemed to be the question among members of the Merchandising Executives' Club of New York as they came from a luncheon meeting at the Shelton Hotel yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- Republican jubilation over the sweep by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower of New England's forty electoral votes was tempered today by the confirmation of defeat for one of the men chiefly responsible for his nomination, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Bonfires were burning and firecrackers were popping all over London tonight. But they were lighted and set off, not to celebrate General Dwight D. Eisenhower's victory; they were in commemoration of Guy Fawkes who, 347 years ago, tried unsuccessfully to blow up Parliament.

In an open letter to the "people of the City of New York," Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, invited all persons yesterday to visit the schools next week during Open School Week. The observance here will coincide with American Education Week, which will be held throughout the nation.

Final results from New Jersey yesterday showed that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican President-elect, had carried the state by a plurality of 356,048 over Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson. Senator H. Alexander Smith was reelected by 256.101 over Archibald S. Alexander. The Republicans also retained their 9-to-5 majority in the House of Representatives.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Nov. 5 -- The sixth congress of the Yugoslav Communist party was thrown into a turmoil this morning when Ljubodrag Djurich, secretary general of the Federal Government, accused Petar Stambolich, Serbian Premier, of having stolen his wife.
LONDON; Nov. 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Soviet note to the United States on the blockade around Korea, as broadcast from Moscow today:
A surprise strike of 290 flight engineers forced the grounding last night of all United Air Lines flights by DC-6 and Stratocruiser planes.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 5 -The student body started working on an important item of business today. On Saturday, Blair Academy entertains Peddie in the forty-ninth annual meeting between the schools and this afternoon the students were collecting paper, wooden boxes, branches and other inflammable material for the big barn fire at Friday night's traditional rally.

The results of eight adjourned games in the women's world chess championship challengers' tournament in Moscow were recorded yesterday, leaving Mrs. Elizabeth Bykova of Russia leading with a score of 7 1/2 -- 1 1/2, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.

The 1952 Whitney Museum annual of contemporary American painting, which opens to the public today, is one of the best balanced shows in the long series. It includes work by 154 artists from twenty-four states, forty-three names appearing in a Whitney annual for the first time, and 117 of those represented were not in last year's show.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Debate on Korea continued in the United Nations General Assembly today without mention of the election and without any sign that the Soviet bloc was coming closer to the principle of nonforcible repatriation of war prisoners.

OMAHA, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Northern Natural Gas Company announced today it would start work at once on new pipeline facilities which it hopes will increase its capacity 20,000,000 cubic feet a day by the first of the year.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 5 -- Edmund Cunningham is a patient man, but he called the police today after he had decided that his competitors had executed for three and a half hours an organized scheme to shunt customers past the driveways of his automobile service station.
SEATTLE, Nov. 5 -- Absentee ballots -- nearly 100,000 of them -- may decide whether the State of Washington sends two instead of three additional Republicans to Congress.

" You could not expect me to forget NATO," said General Eisenhower last week in reaffirming his full support of our commitments and obligations to the Atlantic community. Nor could any one else, in forecasting the President-elect's foreign policy, be expected to forget the great part he played as organizer of the Atlantic defense system and fervent apostle of European unity.

The overwhelming choice of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for President and Senator Richard M. Nixon for Vice President on Tuesday by the largest outpouring of voters in American history was emphasized by late returns yesterday that accounted for all forty-eight states as the triumph of a person as contrasted with that of a political party. The verdict was clearly for a change, but primarily, of national leaders.

DETROIT, Nov. 5 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower carried Republican Senators to victory today in Indiana, Ohio and Michigan. With the re-election of Senators John W. Bricker of Ohio and William E. Jenner of Indiana assured early this morning, a flood of tardy Republican ballots from rural Michigan unseated Senator Blair Moody, Democrat.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- An important by-election in the Parliamentary constituency of High Wycombe resulted in the Conservative party's retention of the seat, with a slightly increased majority over that in last year's general election.

Capt. Victor M. Carillo and Acapulco formed the combination that sent the Royce A. Drake Memorial Challenge Trophy to Mexico in the international jumping competition at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

Thanks to Terence Rattigan, Margaret Sullavan has an eminently actable part in "The Deep Blue Sea," which opened at the Morosco last evening. She gives the performance of her career. Something of the same sort could be said for all the parts, and perhaps for the other actors, too.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 6 -- New details of the use of a new compound extracted from citrus fruit that heightens the effectiveness of some cancer treatments, were reported today by Dr. Isidore Arons of Harlem Hospital, New York. Dr. Arons delivered his report on evidence gathered from 400 cases to the Inter-American Congress of Radiology meeting here.
CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 6 (UP) -- Glen Lasswell rode three straight winners today at Garden State Park, including Jungle Jag in the featured Senate Purse.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The only income besides savings that President Truman will have after he leaves office Jan. 20 is a military pension of $95.66 a month. But he has a fat portfolio of job offers.
Britons and Americans should bolster each other first, even though they pursue their own interests in other areas, Dean Rusk, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, said last night.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 6 -- The Ambassador to the United States, Felix Nieto, and the chief Chilean delegate to the United Nations, Dr. Hernan Santa Cruz are among twenty-three leading Chilean diplomats whose resignations have been accepted by the Ibanez Government as it began carrying out its promised "new broom" policy.

Taking leave at least for the moment from boisterous comedy, Moss Hart has written a serious play with a mystic mood, "The Climate of Eden," which opened at the Martin Beck last evening. It is dramatized from Edgar Mittelhozer's "Shadows Move Among Them," an exotic novel about British Guiana.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Nov. 6 (AP) -- America's record-breaking liner, the United States, quietly took possession of the trans-Atlantic speed trophy today and sailed for New York with the relic locked in a strong room.

Indictments against four longshoremen, including two widely known officials of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., were handed up yesterday by the special Federal grand jury investigating racketeering.

ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- Governor Dewey attempted today to spike rumors that he might be appointed to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's Cabinet with the statement that "my only intention is serving out my term as Governor."

Two hundred masterpieces from the huge collections of the Metropolitan Museum have been put on exhibition in ten galleries, surveying more than 5,000 years of art in East and West. The show, celebrating the museum's eightieth birthday, also honors the publication of a new book, "Art Treasures of the Metropolitan" (Abrams, Inc., New York).
The future of passenger service on the Staten Island Rapid Railway Company became further complicated yesterday in legal entanglements.

For the tenth year in a row, dividends on common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange in nine months have a new record. The figure this year was $3,904,487,000, a gain of 4.1 per cent, compared with the first three quarters of 1951.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 6 -- Beginning Nov. 15, 1,100 Korean males between the ages of 17 and 31 inclusive will be drafted for military service daily. That will be an increase of 400 over the present rate, which has been in force many months.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6 -- A new series of stop-work meetings for members of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., set for 10 A. M. tomorrow in the principal West Coast ports, was announced tonight by Harry Johnson, assistant secretary of the union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, is expected to have a decisive voice in the choice of a Senate majority leader, to be installed when the Republicans take control of Congress next January. This post is second in importance in the organizational structure of the Senate.

All-Sil Welding Metals Inc., offices in 1819 Broadway; Douglas Lee Inc, through Cross Brown Co, in 1860 Broadway; History Book Club Inc, Sky Cove Salon Inc in 45-47 W 57th St -- Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

The National Dairy Products Corporation achieved a new high record in sales for the nine months ended with September, and earnings before taxes indicate a peak of $60,123,206 was reached during the period.

Designed to reduce Treasury balances in the large banks of the nation to a more normal level, a call has been issued by the Treasury on the "B" banks for 3 per cent of their tax deposits as of Nov. 5, payable on Nov. 12. Banks in the New York area will be called on to supply $34,595,000 of the national total of $99,281,000.
Replacing aid by trade among nations of the free world was proposed yesterday by the international relations committee of the National Association of Manufacturers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Weather and crop developments, showing an increasingly critical situation in regard to the winter wheat crop, inspired more active buying of wheat futures today. The drought also was a factor in the corn situation because of the drying up of pastures in such a large part of the country.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Deputy Soviet Foreign Minister, made his long-awaited bid today for the raw materials trade of the underdeveloped countries. However, he buried a matter-of-fact statement about it in such a welter of propaganda that he left some delegates wondering if he were afraid of being taken up on his proposal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, chairman of the Republican National Committee, indicated at a news conference today that the outpouring of Republican votes in the Southern States in Tuesday's election might be rewarded by a share of patronage in the Eisenhower Administration.

PAWLING, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Nearly 100 specialists in parent education, drawn from such fields as teaching, public health and social work, are attending the eighteenth annual New York State Conference on Parent and Family Life Education here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Illinois gained five key Congressional posts in Tuesday's election, although its Governor lost the Presidency.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 6 -- In a move to increase annual revenue by an estimated $3,000,000 to $4,000,000, members of the City Commission today introduced an ordinance to license all retail and wholesale business establishments and industries in Jersey City.

Chrysanthemums by the thousands provided a brilliant background for indoor garden displays at the opening yesterday of the autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York in the Colonnades Ballroom of the Essex House, 157 West Fifty-eighth Street.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 6 -- Efforts of New York savings bankers to establish additional branch offices have been stymied by the opposition of their "friends" the commercial bankers, it was charged here today.

The leaders of the Soviet Union celebrate today the thirty-fifth anniversary of their seizure of power. There will be speeches, parades of Soviet armed might, and millions of regimented citizens will march through the streets. That Stalin, Molotov, Malenkov and Company should rejoice today is not surprising.

Girls of today need to learn new "survival skills" in addition to such things as swimming and first aid. Miss Dorothy E. Stratton, national executive director of the Girl Scouts, told 1,500 volunteer and professional Scout leaders yesterday.

The New York Public Library announced yesterday the appointment of Amelia H. Munson to head its Municipal Reference Library in the Municipal Building. Miss Munson, who has been with the library for twenty-eight years, succeeds Miss Rebecca B. Rankin, retired.
Little Phil Rizzuto, Yankee shortstop, checked out of the Lenox Hill Hospital a couple of days ago and has returned to his Hillside, N. J., home.

The 23,000-ton liner Washington, in service for a year on the trans-Atlantic "diaper" run for the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service, will be withdrawn temporarily at the end of the month, the service announced here yesterday.

The board of governors of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers presented a testimonial scroll to Samuel L. Deitsch last night for his service to the association and the garment industry. The presentation was made at a dinner in the Astor Hotel attended by members of the board and of the industry.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 6 -- The Silvermine Tavern, on the banks of the Silvermine River, is once again filling a dual role as country inn and meeting ground for New England antiques dealers who gathered there today for the tavern's sixth antiques show, a four-day affair.

The development of the art of glassmaking in the United States is defined nicely in a display opening today in the new Exhibition Gallery at Steuben Glass, 718 Fifth Avenue. The exhibit, which will be open to the public through Dec. 27, is composed of about 100 pieces and is the first of a series of projected traveling shows organized by the Coming Museum of Glass.

Futures were generally quiet on the New York exchanges yesterday, with most items closing slightly lower. Rubber, zinc, tin, cocoa, coffee and wool eased and hides, sugar and vegetable oils were mixed. Lead and potatoes closed higher.

A campaign for funds to save the City Center of Music and Drama from closing was decided upon yesterday at a City Hall meeting after Mayor Impellitteri announced that the nine-year-old organization was in "financial distress" and needed between $75,000 and $100,000 to keep going.
A majority of some thirty or forty children who attended the nature classes at the Hudson Guild, 436 West Twenty-seventh Street, had never seen a skunk before yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 6 -- Sixty of 140 Indian Jews who were sent back by air to India by the Jewish Agency last spring after they had staged two sit-down strikes outside the Agency's offices, today cabled Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion petitioning for permission to return.

The tremendous vote for General Eisenhower in New York State, the pathetically bad showing made by the Democratic candidate for the Senate, John Cashmore, the damaging losses of Democratic seats in the Legislature and a whole series of previous setbacks must combine to convince the Democratic organization, in state and city, that it is time for a change within its own ranks and policies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Five requests from African native leaders for permission to appear personally with grievances were approved today by the Trusteeship Committee of the General Assembly. Some delegates were worried lest the committee be flooded by similar requests.

Billy Steinkraus, 27-year-old Westport, Conn., rider, and Democrat, 19-year-old patriarch of the rings, came through in the pinches twice yesterday to give the United States dominance of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.
LONDON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Prime Minster Churchill saw a glowing photograph of Queen Elizabeth II in newspapers yesterday and said in a telephone message to a news agency's photographic department here:

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy accused New York State yesterday of failing to pass on to New York City and other localities anything but a minute share of a "Federal windfall" of some $45,000,000 in welfare funds that have accrued annually to the state through recent amendments to the Social Security law.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Replacement of 50 per cent or more of this country's top-ranking diplomats abroad after the new Administration takes office in January was regarded as a virtual certainty here today.

Formal affiliation of the congregations of Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, and the Judson Memorial Baptist Church on Washington Square with the New York City Congregational Church Association of the New York Congregational Christian Conference was carried out last night at Broadway Tabernacle, Congregational Church, at Fifty-sixth Street.

Denying that American educational institutions were "hotbeds of communism," Dr. Henry T. Heald, chancellor of New York University, declared yesterday that nevertheless they should be "seriously concerned about the alleged affiliations" of teachers who failed to cooperate with legal bodies investigating communism.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Britain and the United States proposed formally today that India and Pakistan start immediate face-to-face negotiations in New York toward settling the long dispute over Kashmir.

MUTTONTOWN, L. I., Nov. 6 -- The handsome estate of Knollwood, which ex-King Zog of Albania bought a year ago, will be sold for tax arrears and penalty on Dec. 1 at the opening of the annual Nassau County tax sale.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The House of Commons was touchy today on the subject of the Korean war. On the eve of his departure for the United States to attend the United Nations General Assembly Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden assured the members of the House that he would make every effort to find a formula for bringing hostilities in Korea to a close.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Nov. 6 -- Scott Tuttle, captain of Haverford School's football squad, has been wearing a red flannel shirt with tails hanging out all week. He didn't lose an election bet. It's merely a custom that has grown with the Penn Charter football rivalry, and since the Maroon and Gold meets the P. C. eleven tomorrow afternoon, Turtle has been carrying out a tradition that is part of the captain's job.
The signing of an agreement between the Japan Commercial Arbitration Association and the American Arbitration Association was celebrated last night at a dinner in the Union Club.

New custom weaves in hand-woven and power-loomed fabrics by Jack Lenor Larsen are now available through decorators at the designer's new studio, 32 East Twenty-second Street and at Waldron Associates, 1230 Second Avenue.
Three former University of Kentucky basketball stars were directed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit not to engage in sports for the duration of their three-year probation periods.

Paul Crowell, City Hall reporter for this newspaper, has covered the administrations of James J. Walker, Joseph V. McKee, John P. O'Brien, Fiorello H. La Guardia, William O'Dwyer and Vincent Impellitteri. Mayors have freely confided in him, received in confidence his occasionally unflattering opinions, sought his counsel and -- to their disadvantage -- not always followed it.

Women headed by Mrs. Charles E. Saltzman and including Mrs. William Thompson Baker and Mrs. Joseph W. Dorland are aiding in the plans for the seventeenth annual entertainment, known as the Tip Top Ball, to be held tonight in the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of Stony Wold Sanatorium.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Second thoughts on implications of General Eisenhower's election brought a long list of declines on the stock markets today. British Government securities were a steady exception, and they too weakened slightly toward the end.

President Truman set up an emergency fact-finding board yesterday in the hope of bringing about a quick end of the strike of 290 flight engineers that has grounded all United Air Lines flights of DC-6 and Stratocruiser planes.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- Walter J. Donnelly, United States High Commissioner, sent a protest today to his Soviet counterpart that heaped ridicule on the Soviet security system for its six-day detention and interrogation of a United States Army officer who had lost his way crossing East Germany.

NO matter what business a man may be in, he usually can learn something by studying the opposition. Yet a fellow who tries to follow that practice in the business of forecasting football results immediately encounters obstacles. The two most successful pickers during the past fortnight in one of the biggest of all newspaper polls have been an 18-month-old baby and a 77-year-old grandmother.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and closing prices on active months were steady and 17 to 34 points net higher than on Wednesday.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick announced yesterday his resignation as Democratic State Chairman, to take effect not later than Dec. 1, when he will call a meeting of the Democratic State Committee to elect his successor. The announcement followed Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's sweeping victory, in which he carried New York State by a plurality of 851,032, and opened the way for a fight for control of the Democratic state organization.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- The Social Democrats today for the first time openly attacked the Fighting Group Against Inhumanity, an anti-Communist organization in West Berlin supported by private American funds and by the city and West German governments.

A plot 100 by 200 feet at the northeast corner of Lincoln Avenue and Hutchinson Parkway in North Pelham, N. Y., has been purchased by S. Solon Cohen, builder, for improvement with a structure containing a super market and three other stores. Mr. Cohen at present is building the 150-family Monterey Homes colony in the northern section of New Rochelle.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6 -- Bernard Girard, former Monogram producer, and Richard Dorso have announced the formation of an independent producing company that plans to make six pictures during the next two years. The company, incorporated as Girard-Dorso Productions, will co-star Ida Lupino and her husband. Howard Duff, in its first picture, "Jennifer."

A tract containing 9,000,000 square feet near the Deer Park Airport in Babylon, L. I., has been acquired for improvement with an industrial terminal by a group of investors headed by Joseph F. Mittelman, president of the Mittelman-Spies Organization of Jamaica, Queens. Snover Co. and Samuel H. Shieber were brokers in the transaction.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Russia is flying experimental rocket fighter airplanes at speeds up to 1,700 miles an hour and altitudes upward of 100,000 feet, American Aviation Magazine said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A bill to abolish the National Labor Relations Board and set up a new board will be one of the first labor measures introduced in the new Congress. The objective would be to replace some or all of the present five members and the general counsel.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 6 -- Home affairs Minister Mohammed Rum announced today that government printing plants last Monday started printing 50,000,000 registration cards for Indonesia's forthcoming general elections. Mr. Rum said the printing would be completed by the end of November and distribution begin in December.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 6 -- All leading Indian newspapers, including important journals in the provincial capitals, devoted their leading editorials today to a somewhat bewildered analysis of the factors behind Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's victory in the United States election, which was a great surprise here.

Brisker weather brings the soup tureen to the table more often, and with that in mind THE NEW YORK TIMES' home economist, Mrs. Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, suggests today recipes for soup garnishes that vary the usual chopped parsley pattern.

Charges that the Shuberts, defendants in a pending Federal antitrust action, were allegedly intimidating managers to route shows to Washington's newly refurbished Sam S. Shubert Memorial Theatre (formerly the Gayety) are being studied by the Committee of Theatrical Producers.
The stock market returned to a more normal balance yesterday after its pre-election and post-election splurges.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (UP) -- An A. F. L. labor leader said today that American workers could be turned into the "most ardent of capitalists" and away from communism if given "greater share in the enormous profitability of American industry."

General Eisenhower's victory has been greeted abroad with mixed emotions. These emotions derive not only from the political coloration and national interests of those expressing them; they are also the result of some distortions of General Eisenhower's views, and even more of the uncertainty that must prevail during the interregnum decreed by the American political system between the election and the time when the new Administration takes office.

Abba S. Eban, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, voiced strong confidence last night that the new Administration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower would continue a close cooperation and friendship with his nation.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- In the presence of Premier Stalin a stern warning to "American aggressors" not to forget the might of the "unconquerable" Soviet Army was delivered tonight at a solemn meeting marking the thirty-fifth anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon indicated on his return to Washington today that his duties and responsibilities as Vice President might be expanded beyond the once traditional role of gavel-banging as President of the Senate.

It is probably too early for detailed conclusions on how organized labor's 15,000,000 to 16,000,000 members voted on Tuesday, but one general conclusion may be drawn. Trade unionists, like members of all other closely knit groups, vote according to what they consider their best interests, whether or not their leaders urge a particular choice.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Roger L. Putnam, former Mayor of Springfield, Mass., will step out of his present job as head of the nation's Economic Stabilization Agency on Nov. 14.

The police turned over to Board of Elections officials in Queens yesterday the voting machines they had impounded in districts where there were close contests. The final results are not expected to be known before Nov. 20

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is considering a revamping of United States foreign economic programs under an independent agency that would remove these activities from State Department control for the first time since Paul G. Hoffman quit as Economic Cooperation Administrator.

The Rev. Dr. Herbert Welch, retired Methodist Bishop in the Orient and senior Bishop of the Methodist denomination, received a check for $10,000 at a luncheon celebrating his ninetieth birthday yesterday.

Plans for altering the store in the four-story loft building at 53 Nassau Street and its occupancy as a stationery and greeting card shop were announced in connection with the sale of the property by Harold Lodon to Sarah Epstein Associates. Assessed at $80,000, the property is near the southwest corner of Maiden Lane and was sold in a deal negotiated by Raymond E. Ryan, Inc., broker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Mrs. Mary Jane Keeney of New York was ordered today to stand trial Jan. 26 for contempt of Congress for refusing to tell the Senate Internal Security subcommittee whether any person in the State Department had helped her to obtain employment with the United Nations.

Burglars made their way through the front door of a three-room apartment on the fifth floor at 44 East Sixty-seventh Street early yesterday morning and escaped with thirty-seven pieces of jewelry estimated to be worth $47,000 and a mink stole valued at $2,000. They were the property of Mrs. Marjorie Brenner, who occupies the apartment.

OTTAWA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Virtually the entire $50,000,000 fine paper industry in Canada was accused of operating an illegal price-fixing combine in a report made public today by Justice Minister Stuart Garson.
PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Premier Antoine Pinay intervened with the Cabinet tonight to obtain backing for his Minister for Overseas Territories, who had offered to resign.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 5 (AP) -- A constitutional clause is to give opposition parties some legislative seats they were unable to win in the landslide Tuesday that kept Gov. Luis Munoz Marin's Popular party in control of Puerto Rico's government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 1 were 5 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1951:
DIDYMOTEIKHON, Greek-Turkish Frontier, Nov. 5 -- Today this Thracian plain became a token meeting ground of this free world's military forces.
CHICAGO, Nov, 6 (AP) -- A credit official contended today that too many people are trying to buy eight-cylinder automobiles on four- cylinder incomes.

The entry of Lone Eagle and Mandingo, well-liked by the 16,872 spectators, justified its popularity by finishing one, two in the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. Competing in the Resolute II, a classified handicap over a distance of a mile and a half, Lone Eagle and Mandingo had things their own way against the four others that made up the opposition.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Nov. 6 -- Dr. Philip C. Jessup, who as United States Ambassador at large has been one of the closest advisers of Secretary of State Dean Acheson, will resume his duties as professor of international law at Columbia University, when the winter term begins next February.

Despite taxes which more than doubled those of the prior year, net earnings of the Chrysler Corporation and its wholly owned United States subsidiaries increased to $59,661,657 in the first nine months this year from $50,108,179 a year ago, the report disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- British Actors Equity still is making no statement on ban of Jose Ferrer, but the best guess is that it will stand.

Elegant fabrics have been used in two new groups of furnishings on view at Lord Taylor. One collection, called the Ottavia group, is composed of sixty designs of embroidered white window curtains made in Switzerland. Fabrics of the Siamese silk type appear in a collection of Craig bedspreads.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A hopeless last-ditch effort to elect General of the Army Douglas MacArthur President fizzled in the boom of the Eisenhower victory.
