Television's coverage of the election returns on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning resulted in a landslide victory for the Columbia Broadcasting System. Both in the complex task of tabulation and the incidental commentary, the network left its rivals far behind.

A letter to THE TIMES by Jane Quinby describes the unholy power of Philip Murray, William Green and especially, of course, John L. Lewis. This emotional outburst is a reflection of an editorial in the same issue in which THE TIMES declares that Mr. Lewis is not "bigger than the Government and the people of the United States."

Most of the gift catalogues are out now, so this obviously is the time to begin thinking serious thoughts about Christmas. These gay documents, sent by the stores and the mail - order houses, do not mean that the day after tomorrow will see the tree and the holly, the red ribbons and bright wrappings, for Christmas itself must wait a time for its usual date.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 862,012 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 101,271 cars, or 13.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 24,395 cars, or 2.9 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 1,137 cars, or 0.1 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 7 -- Chinese Communist infantry renewed last night the attack on "Sniper Ridge," north of Kumhwa on the central Korean front. But the Reds were thrown back from the South Korean lines on the long-contested hilltop, taking a heavy loss.

A BRIGHT sun and a gentle wind, weather conditions which would have been a welcome gift of nature to trout fishermen six months ago, are doing nothing to improve forest conditions right now, and unless heavy rains arrive along the coastal states very shortly even more areas will be closed to hunting.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6 (AP) -- H. B. Delman's Off The Record and Jaclyn Stable's Main Bout shared honors on the Pimlico racing program today; the two juveniles scoring in the co-featured Plucky Liege and Belvedere purses.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Senator Wiley is expected to take the chairmanship of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee when the Republicans organize the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Five House contests remained in the undecided column tonight. Some may not be decided for days until absentee ballots are counted or an official canvass of the vote is completed.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (Reuters) -- The British must suppress Mau Mau, a secret witchcraft society campaigning against them in Kenya, East Africa, Oliver Lyttelton, colonial secretary, said here today after an on-the-spot inspection trip.

MONTREAL, Nov. 6 (UP) -- The Canadiens moved into a three-way tie for first place in the National Hockey League tonight with a 3-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs. Maurice Richard, Montreal wing, failed for the third straight time in his attempt to crack the N. H. L. scoring record.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The United States Navy is "already the largest peacetime fleet ever maintained by any country and is as large as all the other navies of the world put together," according to the 1952-53 edition of Jane's Fighting Ships.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 6 -- The states of Tennessee and Kentucky, on the basis of almost complete returns, seemed virtually certain today to have gone in the opposite directions in the Presidential election by extremely narrow vote margins.
PARIS, No. 6 -- Fantasy, fun and new details stamp Schiaparelli's small mid-season collection with a gay holiday atmosphere.

DETROIT, Nov. 6 -- Michigan's Democratic Governor, G. Mennen Williams, today faced the prospect of a recount of ballots -- the second in two years -- to determine whether he had won a third term in Tuesday's general election.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- During the week ended Nov. 5, member bank reserves decreased $115,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Advice to Americans who plan Mediterranean tours next year to book hotel reservations as far in advance as possible was issued yesterday by William H. McConnell, American Export Lines vice president, for passenger traffic.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Senator Morse got out a statement today and signed it as an pendent" from egon instead of an "independent Republican." His office staff said he had ordered it that way in dictating the statement by telephone from a point outside of the city.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 6 -- In a cable congratulating General Dwight D. Eisenhower on his election, Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion today recalled the General's war-time crusade against the "most foul and criminal tyranny that ever darkened the annals of mankind" and recalled their meeting in Frankfurt.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 6 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, proposed today to meet President Truman during the week beginning Nov. 17, and said he would like to send key representatives to Washington for indoctrination in several Federal departments.

An explanation of how and why a business enterprise with its headquarters abroad may be taxed on profits obtained here was offered yesterday by Eldon P. King, officer in charge of the United States Office of International Tax Relations of the Internal Revenue Bureau.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations, declared today that it was essential for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to state his views in the next few days on Korea and other issues outstanding before the United Nations General Assembly.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- The death of Representative Adolph J. Sabath, Democrat of Illinois, has created a vacancy in Congress that cannot be filled for several months, election law experts indicated today.

The sixty-fourth National Horse Show continued to attract a representative gathering of prominent persons in the social, civic and financial worlds as well as many ranking officers of the armed forces last night at the Madison Square Garden.

The heads of all city departments and agencies whose activities are financed wholly or in part with city funds were told yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri that "necessity and economy" must be their watchwords in submitting requests for 1953-54 budget appropriations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Counsel for Col. Lawrence Westbrook, ousted Democratic National Committee official, denied today that Colonel Westbrook was a "five per center" or that the concern he represented had violated its contract with the United States Government.

Your article of Oct. 31 about U. N. cars parked illegally is good. There are so many favorites played in New York City that there is no traffic law necessary. I have seen signs "No Parking at Any Time" over which the police had hung another sign for the day, "No Parking Today," with cars still parked in that area.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 6 -- The West German Government is standing firm in face of threats by the states of the Arab League to cut their trade with West Germany as a consequence of its restitution treaty with Israel.

Lester T. Doyle, trustee of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation, offered a reorganization plan yesterday under which first-mortgage bondholders would receive 74 per cent of the new common stock issue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The State Department called on the Soviet Union again today for the return of 186 naval vessels of various categories supplied for use in World War II. Its note to Ambassador Georgi N. Zarubin, delivered to the Soviet Embassy here, was the latest in a long series of communications seeking from Moscow some kind of settlement of the wartime Lend-Lease account.
Framed wall decorations and lamps make up the two major collections of accessories on view in the new Marian Gibney decorators' showroom at 50 East Fifty-third Street.

THERE is something about the great gray bulk of an elephant that appeals to the imaginations of many men. Even if he is seen under humiliating circumstances, meekly accepting peanuts from children in a circus, an elephant is impressive, the little eyes, the versatile trunk, the appearance and reputation of wisdom and all the historical and literary associations: Pyrrhus, Hannibal, Indian royalty and Siamese sacred symbol, Kipling's Toomai and Kipling's insatiably curious elephant child.

The underworld, with billions of dollars invested in legitimate businesses, has raised a threat against the national economy that cannot be overcome by official law enforcement agencies alone, a national conference of privately-financed crime fighters was told here yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 6 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, will confer with General Eisenhower on matters confronting the new Administration, the Senator said today.

Subway workers and some other witnesses were questioned yesterday by Board of Transportation officials seeking the cause of a mishap that brought minor injuries to forty-six persons early yesterday on the Fourteenth Street-Canarsie line of the B. M. T. subway division.

The Bronx Zoo received by air mail from New Zealand Monday morning a medium-sized wooden box labeled "tuatara." Quite a few persons had to look in the dictionary, before they opened the box, to figure out what was inside.

Columbia, flying its squad to a football game for the first time, will take off this morning for Hanover and its contest with Dartmouth tomorrow in a state of mind equally compounded of hope and fear.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Alger Hiss, former State Department official serving a five-year prison term for perjury, applied for a parole today.
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 7 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,426, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

The defense in the departmental trial of thirty policemen charged with having protected the multimillion-dollar gambling combine of Harry Gross continued to hammer away yesterday at discrepancies between the former bookmaker's testimony at this trial and that given on earlier occasions.

Dr. Wallace E. Howell, the rainmaker, passed through New York yesterday on his way home to Lexington, Mass., from Peru, where he has been practicing his profession on the glaciers three miles high in the Andes.

" The White Rabbit," a work of non-fiction by Bruce Marshall, has been scheduled for Nov. 24 publication by Houghton Mifflin. It is an account of Wing Commander Yeo-Thomas' work in World War II behind German lines. He organized French Resistance, was captured and escaped. Mr. Marshall's earlier books include "Father Malachy's Miracle" and "Vespers in Vienna."
A broader basis of fiscal support for the city's four municipal colleges, with continued aid from the state and Federal Governments, was forecast yesterday by the Board of Higher Education.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 6 -- Dr. Edward Mills Purcell has been associated with the Physics Department of Harvard University since 1936, two years before receiving the degree of Doctor of Philosophy there. During World War II, he was on leave of absence to head the fundamental development group at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology radiation laboratory.

Five thousand members of Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., voted last night to strike Dec. 1 on nine privately operated bus lines that normally carry 3,000,000 riders a day in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.
PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Francois Mauriac said today that the Nobel prize for literature was "the greatest honor I have ever received."

The Philadelphia Orchestra, under the direction of Eugene Ormandy, will open the 1952-53 Jubilee Concert Series next Sunday evening at 8:30 in the Hunter College Assembly Hall, Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street.

A first impulse after a first hearing of Darius Milhaud's opera, "Christophe Colomb," given its first performance in New York in concert form last night by Dimitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, is to applaud Mr. Mitropoulos for his intrepidity and sovereign ability in venturing to give this immense and astonishing work at all.

Gerhard Kander, in his Town Hall violin recital, followed the pattern he had set in his previous appearances. His playing had honesty and the highest of intentions. Within its rather small emotional scope, it was faithful to the music, and there often was a reflective turn of phrase, especially where the violinist's technique was not taxed, indicative of real sensitivity.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- President Truman said today the country "has lost a public servant of rare distinction" with the death of Representative Sabbath.

The American Trust Company, of which Harvey M. Schwamm is president, has sold its new two-story banking quarters at 301-303 East Fordham Road, the Bronx, to a client of John T. McCormick Jr., attorney, and has taken back a lease on the property for thirty years. John J. Reynolds, Inc., was the broker and Garey Garey were attorneys for the seller.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Wide changes in the immigration policy of the United States and establishment of a new, independent government agency to administer laws regarding entrants were urged today by the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society.

TRENTON, N. J. Nov. 6 (AP) -- State Treasurer Walter T. Margetts Jr. announced today that New Jersey would advertise for bids on Dec. 9 on a $25,000,000 bond issue to improve state institutional facilities.

Consideration by the United States of a more liberal policy of importing goods from Western Europe was proposed yesterday by Sir Archibald Forbes, president of the Federation of British Industries. He spoke at a luncheon given in his honor by the British Commonwealth Chamber of Commerce in the United States of America at the Plaza Hotel.

Wide and diversified segments of business and industry have called upon banks for ready cash during the last week. New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System reported a rise of $101,000,000 in commercial loans during the week ended on Wednesday, to set the fifth successive new high in nine weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Western Union Telegraph Company today asked for the right to continue its international service. It urged a merger of companies now operating in the overseas radiotelegraph and cable field.
Two retired Army colonels, both 30-year men, were witnesses yesterday at John David Provoo's trial in Federal Court on charges of wartime treason.

George E. Roosevelt, chairman of the Long Island Transit Authority, charged yesterday in an affidavit filed in Brooklyn Federal Court that the proposal of William Wyer, trustee of the Long Island Rail Road, to make six surveys to improve operation and cut expenses on the bankrupt railroad offered "nothing but a waste of time and money."

Brooklynites must contribute more blood in the months ahead if they are to keep pace with the growing Korean casualty lists, Hugh H. Cuthrell, chairman of donor recruitment of the Brooklyn Red Cross Chapter, declared yesterday.

Freedom of teaching and learning must include the right to criticize the policies and conduct of the Government and of all groups or individuals, Dr. R. Freeman Butts of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday. However, he emphasized, educators must exercise "respect for truth, scholarship and fair play and for the freedoms of those criticized."
The Public Education Association has charged Mayor Impellitteri with "profoundly shocking" conduct in his recent appointments of six members to the Board of Higher Education.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 6 -- Francois Mauriac, French novelist and journalist, won this year's Nobel Prize in literature today. He was selected for the award by the Swedish Academy of Literature.

Rabbi Irving Miller, president of the Zionist Organization of America, sharply rejected yesterday the assertion by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion of Israel that elements in the Zionist Organization "have tried to smear the State of Israel."

Second only to the Presidency, the great contest in this election was for control of Congress, particularly of the Senate. Despite the magnitude of General Eisenhower's personal victory, the Republicans were barely able to win enough new seats in both bodies to be able to organize them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Defense Production Administration today made official the additional allotment of 1,480,000 tons of carbon steel to original civilian industry allocations of 9,700,000 tons for the first quarter of the coming year.

Many persons hold the erroneous belief that newspaper reading has been reduced by such diversions as the automobile, jazz, radio and television. Studies have shown, however, that the opposite is true and the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, Inc., is embarking on a campaign to let the world know the facts.

It really was heart-warming to read your editorial on chess, the second editorial in a short time (Bravo, Byrne!). If your sports editors would allot two columns in their domain to chess every day -- and there's lots to report on goings-on in the chess world -- and if other newspapers would do the same, then we too could develop a chess-loving audience and chess-playing youngsters.

Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club was elected president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the group's annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Shelton. Mrs. Nesbitt succeeds Mrs. Caryl H. Sayre of The Creek Club, who held the office the last two years.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The sixth congress of the Yugoslav Communist party, on the eve of the celebration in Moscow of the thirty-fifth anniversary of the 1917 Bolshevik revolution, heard a prediction tonight that Soviet peasants and workers again would rise and overthrow "the bureaucratic rule of Moscow."

Last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center dealt once again in familiar works, with at least one major casting change. This was the first appearance here of Melissa Hayden in Jerome Robbins' "The Cage," in the role hitherto performed exclusively by Nora Kaye.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Bob Evans, the University of Pennsylvania football captain who was declared ineligible yesterday, was admitted to the University hospital today for "a rest and a complete physical check-up."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- A United Nations relief program to assist 850,000 Arab refugees in the Middle East was approved today by the General Assembly, 48 to 0, in its first major decision taken at this seventh session.

TOKYO, Nov. 6 -- Assistant Secretary of State John M. Allison assured the Japanese today that fears of a possible drastic change in United States policy toward Japan as a result of the sweeping Republican victory Tuesday were groundless.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Stuart Chase said today the world could achieve greater harmony by borrowing principles used for centuries by Quakers in their business meetings. In an address delivered at the eighteenth biennial congress of the Cooperative League of the U. S. A., the economist said of the Quakers:
" I don't know whether or not we've got the speed to beat 'em," said Coach Steve Owen yesterday after running his Football Giants through a two-hour workout at the Polo Grounds.

A decline last week of 204,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 120,563,000 barrels compared with 120,767,000 a week earlier and 119,563,000 a year ago.
HANOI, Indo-China, Nov. 6 -- Two French columns today cut deeply into Colonial Route No. 2, one of the Vietminh's best supply lines from China.

Department of Health inspectors, dusting off a seldom-invoked law for the second time in eight days, yesterday ordered another dilapidated rooming house in Brooklyn vacated within forty-eight hours. The five families in the building, at 224 South Ninth Street, pay rentals of $6 to $15 a week.

The two principal managers of Governor Stevenson's campaign for the Presidency have made statements about the future of the Democratic party that, because of what happened at Tuesday's election, will have no determining effect on the shape of that future.

Congratulations are pouring in today from all over the world to Bishop Herbert Welch, who is celebrating his ninetieth birthday. Yesterday a large group of his former students and associates met him at a testimonial luncheon and presented a fund that is to be used at his discretion, probably in the form of scholarships.

Reynolds Metals Company has arranged for the private financing of plant expansion now going on at plants in Texas and Arkansas. The details of the transaction have not been announced in full, but it was learned that the borrowing runs to about $75,000,000 and consists of a "V" loan negotiated privately with about sixty commercial banks and insurance companies in behalf of Reynolds Reduction Company, a subsidiary enterprise.

On Nov. 3 a five-alarm fire broke out in an abandoned warehouse on 100th Street, between Third and Second Avenues. Fortunately, no lives were lost and the fire did not spread to the adjoining buildings, which had to be vacated of their tenants.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 6 -- Dr. Felix Bloch is a Swiss-born physicist whose family picked out an engineering career for him. He switched to physics while at the Federal Institute of Technology of Switzerland, got his degree of Doctor of Philosophy at the University of Leipzig and joined the list of scholars that left Germany after Hitler had come into power.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President Truman has been telling his intimates in the wake of the election that he recognizes Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois as the leader of the Democratic party and will support him all the way.

A "thanksgiving" appeal for 500,000 pounds of wearable clothing and shoes for war victims in Korea, Hong Kong, Formosa, Europe, and the Near East, will be conducted in the 389 parishes of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York for a week beginning Nov. 23.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- William Benton, who has been Senator from Connecticut for two years but who was defeated last Tuesday, urged President Truman today to concern himself especially with the role of the "world's most distinguished private citizen."

CAIRO, Nov. 7 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Egyptian Premier, on leaving a two-and-one-half-hour meeting of the Arab League Political Committee today, suggested the possibility that the committee might ask for a general Arab breach of commercial relations with West Germany.

Edward J. Nelson has been named vice president of Modern Globe, Inc. (formerly Globe Knitting Works) Grand Rapids, Mich., manufacturer of underwear, and will be in charge of all New York operations. He has been with the concern twenty-four years as a sales executive. Globe was recently acquired by the Aetna Industrial Corporation.

The State Crime Commission will hold public hearings beginning next Thursday on the relationship between organized crime and "units of government," it was announced yesterday by former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, commission chairman.

Revision of the "retailer's bible" -the annual report on departmental, merchandising and operating results of dry goods and specialty stores -- is planned by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Business inventories built up about 1 per cent during September, compared with August, the Department of Commerce reported today in a survey conducted on the basis of seasonal adjustments. This brought inventory values in September back to about the June level.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 7 (UP) -- Former Gov. Alf M. Landon, the 1936 Republican Presidential nominee, and former Secretary of War Harry H. Woodring issued a joint statement today opposing General Eisenhower's plan to go to Korea.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Wage Stabilization Board agreed in effect today to approve a part, but not all, of the terms of a contract reached last summer by the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., and the Pacific Maritime Association.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Uncertainty about the future policy of the new United States Government continued to keep business quiet on the stock markets today. Slight selling drove prices lower in most sections.
YONKERS, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Volto Man, driven by Paul Vineyard scored a head triumph over Dr. Stanton in a Class AA pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight before a chilled crowd of 14,838.

Pat Marcune, 130 1/2, Coney Island, defeated Eddie Compo, 131 1/2, New Haven, Conn., in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 3,472 fans, one of the largest in several seasons, paid a total of $8,497 to witness the fight, which headed a program for the benefit of the Building Fund of the Brownsville Boys' Club.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- Officials in close touch with the preparatory work being done here for the meeting of the North Atlantic Council scheduled here Dec. 15 expressed doubt today that the council would be able to fix definite defense goals for 1953 by that time.

Students and faculty at the City College School of Business and Civic Administration contributed 236 pints to the blood bank conducted by the Manhattan Center of the American Red Cross by means of its bloodmobile units.

Like the trumpets' blare that leveled the walls of Jericho, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's election as President is expected to remove speedily all remaining obstacles to New York State's development of the St. Lawrence River's hydro-electric potential in cooperation with Canada, according to members of the State Power Authority.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Army began inquiry today into the public issuance of a book by a District Engineer office containing material on projects the Army still rates project.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 7 -- The seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Princeton-Harvard-Yale Big Three football series will be marked tomorrow afternoon when Princeton meets Harvard in Palmer Stadium starting at 1:30 o'clock.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- A camera that could take pictures at the rate of 100,000 of a second, with an exposure time of one ten-millionth of a second for each picture, was used to photograph the fireball of the British atomic bomb exploded last month in the Monte Bello Islands, northwest of Australia.

WESTBROOK, Conn., Nov. 7 -- Dull skies and a strong wind, a combination that usually brings a happy smile to the wildfowler, marked the opening of the Connecticut waterfowl season today. But the bags were not as heavy as the weather warranted.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 7 -Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson worked in his office in the Illinois Executive Mansion today, conferred with several staff members and talked briefly with a visitor, Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma.

Lewis Olive, a powerfully built third-classman from Louisville, Ky., by way of the University of California, yesterday led Army's harriers to their sixth straight team victory in the Heptagonal cross-country championships.

The one-story building 50 by 97 feet at 37-13 to 37-15 Thirty-first Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, formerly occupied as an H. C. Bohack Company market, has been sold by the Church of the Holy Communion to Philip and Carmela Giunta. The Edward A. Dangler Company and Anthony Di Paola were the brokers. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title to the property, which is assessed at $34,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today denied applications by Texas-Ohio Gas Company, Houston, for authority to construct a 1,406-mile pipeline from Texas to Ohio and to import natural gas from Mexico.

GENEVA, Nov. 7 -- An arrangement that appears to be satisfactory to all concerned has been worked out to govern the relationship between the European Coal and Steel Community established under the Schuman plan and the larger community of nations adhering to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
TOKYO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Bank of Japan has asked two British and four United States financial houses to handle details of Japan's repayment of pre-war debts slated to start on Dec. 22.

The annual meeting of the Friends of the World Council of Churches will be held Nov. 21 at Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, at Fifty-sixth Street. It will start with a luncheon at 1 P. M. planned as a special tribute to the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, who recently resigned as the council's associate general secretary.

The Department of Health paused briefly yesterday in its drive against slum housing conditions here to lend a hand to Puerto Rico's Health Department, also campaigning against unsanitary living conditions.

The Lafayette High School football team, paced by Ralph Fasano and Lowell Chereskin, overwhelmed Midwood, 35 to 0, at Lincoln Field in Brooklyn yesterday. It was the fifth consecutive victory for the Frenchies, the only unbeaten and untied P. S. A. L. eleven.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 6 to 13 points net higher than on Thursday.

As the horses headed into the windswept stretch at Jamaica in the feature race yesterday, Maj. Francis W. Sutherland and his band prepared to play "Wait Till the Sun Shines, Nellie." A filly named Sunshine Nell was about to go to the front, and it has become the custom to play the old song after each of Sunshine Nell's triumphs.
The D'Oyly Carte Opera Company of London will be visiting these parts next fall, according to Frederick Lloyd, for the last eighteen months general manager of the troupe.

For its casting novelty of the evening, the New York City Ballet, which is specializing in such things in its season at the City Center, last night put Janet Reed into the role of the Joker in the Balanchine-Stravinsky "Card Game" for the first time, replacing Todd Bolender, who has previously done the role.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Although a new Constitution providing for elections and internal self-government in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan could legally take effect tomorrow, the promulgation of the Constitution will be delayed to allow for negotiations among Britain, Egypt and the Sudanese Administration.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 7 (AP) -- The eleventh running of New Jersey's richest horse race, the $50,000-added Trenton Handicap, will be staged at Garden State Park tomorrow with Alerted from the Hampton Stables and Greek Ship, Brookmeade Stable star, looming as the public choices.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture in the Cabinet to be appointed by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will find that he can make few important changes in the department's 1953 programs.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 7 -- Lois Curtiss, 33 years old, of Norwalk was convicted today by Su-period Court Judge James E. Murphy in the death by carbon-monoxide poisoning of her father, John W. Curtiss, 73. She was immediately sentenced to an indefinite term at the State Farm for Women at Niantic.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Abram Flaxer, leader of a left-wing union of Government workers, won today what appeared to be a major round in his court fight against contempt - of - Congress charges.

Harry Shub, an uncommonly equipped musician, gave a violin recital last night in Carnegie Hall, when he made his program of just four compositions that traversed the period from Brahms of the nineteenth century with his A Major sonata to Albert Roussel with his first violin and piano sonata of the twentieth, vintage of 1911.

As every suburbanite knows, the leaves now may be considered gone from the trees. The red of the dogwood and the yellow of the maple have drifted down to mingle with the yellow of the spice bush and the red of that ivy which is dangerous to the casual touch.

It was said in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday morning that it was doubtful if a poem praising the tuatara would ever be written. This proved to be in error. The Bronx Zoo had received a tuatara from New Zealand on Monday. A tuatara is a lizard-like living fossil, the sole survivor of an order of reptiles known as the rhynchocephalia.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 7 -- Details of the magnificent palace of King Nestor, famed elder statesman of the Trojan War and ruler, more than 3,000 years ago, during Greece's Heroic Age, were described today by Carl W. Blegen, Professor of Classical Archaeology at the University of Cincinnati. He extended excavations last summer at the site on the promontory of Pylos, near the Ionian Sea.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 -- Women should persevere in their efforts to break into traditionally masculine fields, Miss Sarah Gibson Blanding, president of Vassar College, said today at a conference on professional opportunities for women.

GENEVA, Nov. 7 -- A United States citizen testified before the United Nations Forced Labor Committee here today that there were 5,388,000 persons in the United States working under conditions of involuntary servitude.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President Truman sent a telegram to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today suggesting Nov. 17 as the date of their proposed meeting, and disclosed that yesterday he had sent a secret message to the President-elect by courier.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7 -Wilmartha S. Lewis of Farmington, author and editor, said today that the new Yale Art Gallery and Design Center would provide the community with a building in which to "study the enduring works of man's hands."

Action in behalf of the thousands of litigants, jurors, witnesses and others who must elbow their way through Manhattan's busy City and Municipal courts each year will be taken Nov. 17 by the chief justices of the two courts and a group of leading lawyers.
HUDSON, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- A man and a woman were killed today in a two-car crash near here, and Governor Dewey personally took charge after the accident.

George F. Kennan, former United States Ambassador to Moscow, speaks out vigorously in defense of the bravery and accomplishments of United States troops and against Soviet slanders on the subject in an open letter to the Soviet people that will be broadcast to the Soviet Union today by the Voice of America.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 7 (AP) -- The State Toll Bridge Authority today authorized the sale of up to $72,000,000 in bonds to finance construction of a bridge from San Rafael to Richmond across northern San Francisco Bay.

A proposal by the city's realty interests for modifications of the existing zoning law, enacted in 1916, instead of an over-all rezoning such as that recommended by Harrison, Ballard Allen, planning consultants, was attacked as impractical yesterday by City Planning Commissioner Lawrence M. Orton.

Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday that he acted non-politically and "in the best interests of our city" in his Oct. 31 appointment of five new members of the Board of Higher Education and the reappointment of a sitting member.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 7 -- More coals were heaped on the fires of the traditional Princeton-Harvard undergraduate rivalry here this morning when an enterprising group of Harvard students replaced an edition of The Daily Princetonian, campus newspaper, with a mock Princetonian.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Colonial Secretary Oliver Lyttelton cautioned today in the House of Commons that Kenya might have to undergo several more months of unrest because of the activities of the Mau Mau secret society. He described the group as "the unholy union of dark and ancient superstition with the apparatus of modern gangsterism."
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 7 -- Merchants, business men, wholesalers and industrialists moved today for an all-out fight against a proposed ordinance to license all business and industry in the city.

The granting of a license to an Israel manufacturer to produce Saran, a plastic material, was announced yesterday in Midland, Mich., by Dow Chemical International, Ltd. The announcement was described as marking the beginning of a new basic idustry for Israel.
MIAMI, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Vanderbilt's offense choked and sputtered tonight, but the Commodores had all the attack they needed to run down the inept Miami Hurricanes, 9 -- 0, in the Orange Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -The Department of Defense today identified 156 casualties of the Korean war. The new list included 18 killed in action, 133 wounded, three injured in accidents, and two missing. The following casualties were reported from New York and New Jersey. None were reported from Connecticut.

WABD, the Du Mont television station, will join WNBT, the National Broadcasting Company's local outlet, in televising today's football game between Notre Dame and Oklahoma at South Bend, Ind., beginning at 2:15 P. M.
DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP) -- All Michigan's ballot boxes of Tuesday's election were placed under the specific protection of the State Police today.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 7 -- The reunification of Germany, the most durable of all German political issues, is arising again to plague the West German Government just as Chancellor Konrad Adenauer prepares to guide the treaties completing his policy of integration with Western Europe through the Bundestag.

MADRID, Nov. 7 -- Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, Archbishop of Seville, today warned Spanish youths who are studying for Roman Catholic priesthood that the custom of spending part of their summer vacation in camps of the Falange youth front was "gravely harmful" to the interests of the Catholic Church. It was the second time this week that the Cardinal had made the Falange a target of his criticism.
Modest post-election enthusiasm again moved prices on the stock market to a higher level yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 7 -Because of a "stay at home and pray" strike, called for Monday by Negroes in eastern Cape Province, the Port Elizabeth City Council has asked the South African Defense Department to take control of the city. The Government has banned all meetings in the city from today for all races for one month and the police have been instructed to disband any meetings held in defiance of the ban.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 7 -- In replies to two new messages from President Truman, one classified as "top secret," Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower continued to develop plans today for an orderly transfer of government from Democratic to Republican control.
Your fine editorial entitled "Silence on Mount Scopus" reminds one of all that has been accomplished over the years by the Hebrew University of Jerusalem.

FORT DIX, N. J., Nov. 7 -- An Army lieutenant was killed and three enlisted men were wounded tonight when they stepped on and exploded rifle grenades on a range here. The men were on their way to fight a brush fire.
For the first time in recent years a Big Three game commands paramount interest on a football program in the East as Princeton and Harvard open the triangular rivalry today in Palmer Stadium.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- Pennsylvania and Georgia collide in football for the first time tomorrow at Franklin Field and a crowd of 45,000 is expected to be on hand for the intersectional contest.

On Nov. 3 an article appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES entitled "Who Takes Office if the Victor Dies?" in which reference was made to the requirement "of native birth" as a qualification for President of the United States.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Nov. 7 -Despite the Government's expressed desire for speedy ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty, the Dutch Parliament is shifting into slow gear to keep pace with lagging action in France and West Germany.

An officer of the Irish Army, Capt. Colm O'Shea, made a successful defense of the West Point Challenge Trophy for his nation last night by riding Ballyneety faultlessly and fast in the international jumping competition of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko delivered a warning today from the podium of Lenin's tomb in Red Square that the "warmongers" now waging a "barbaric war in Korea" were seeking to incite other nations against the Soviet Union.

Fritz Kaufmann, who retired last December as administrative assistant to the executive director of the New York State Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance, died on Thursday at his home, 333 Central Park West. His age was 65.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A license plate enabling a hunter to be traced by his footprints is among the 1,014 inventions patented this week. The inventor is William F. Smith of Minneapolis, a retired locomotive engineer and an active deer hunter.

Robert Frost, in his letter criticizing Veterans Administration policy, is right when he states: "The men in these hospitals, who have returned from the battlefields of Korea and Europe, deserve more consideration than they are getting from this unbalanced medical program."

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 7 -- Dartmouth faces Columbia tomorrow at Hanover in the final home appearance of the Indians. Both teams are looking for their second victory of the season, with Columbia favored to come out on top.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Bullish drought reports, along with the five-day forecast for little if any precipitation, gave wheat a firm tone today. But buyers generally are still unwilling to follow rallies, so price changes were insignificant. News from the Southwest is becoming increasingly pessimistic.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Democrats still led tonight in four of the five undecided contests for election to the House of Representatives.

Opposition to the release of consultants' reports on city departments before the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey can take action on them was voiced yesterday by Abraham D. Beame, City Budget Director.
The strike of 290 flight engineers that grounded all United Air Lines DC-6 and Stratocruiser planes Wednesday was ended yesterday.

Is the rearmament of Japan as recommended in your editorial of Nov. 3 "Japan's Big Problem" really the right answer? Mrs. Elkinton and I have just returned from a six months' visit to Japan and are deeply disturbed by both the presence of American troops in Japan and pressures upon Japan by the United States to rearm.

The need for building a long-blueprinted extension of the New Jersey Turnpike to link the Newark Airport with the Holland Tunnel was stressed here yesterday by Paul L. Troast, chairman of the authority, in an address before the Municipal Forum following a luncheon meeting at the Lawyers Club.

The experience of the pollsters in this year's election seems to make it abundantly clear that the popular sampling research method cannot be used too successfully in measuring something that people regard as confidential and an integral part of their rights as citizens.

Six exhibitions, greatly varying in character, make up events of interest in this busy week in the art world. At the Sculpture Center, Leo Amino is showing new work, fragile and highly finished semi-to-total abstracts in plastic, wood and in combinations of the two mediums.
TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 8 (AP) -United Nations Command Communique 1,427, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President Truman was notified today that initial hearings in an exhaustive analysis on the disposition of the consumer's dollar in various commodities will begin either late next month or early in January.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- United Nations delegates made a revised effort today to find a formula that might bring India and Pakistan together with South Africa to discuss their six-year-old quarrel over the treatment of South Africa's Indian minority.

Organized crime along the waterfront costs at least $350,000,000 a year in "hidden taxes" in the Port of New York alone, Spruille Braden, chairman of the New York City Anti-Crime Committee, declared yesterday.

The Juilliard Orchestra, under the direction of Jean Morel, played the first performance here last night of Peter Mennin's Concertato for Orchestra at the Juilliard School. The new work was commissioned by the Erie Philharmonic Orchestra and had its first performance by that orchestra, with Fritz Mahler conducting, on Oct. 21.

Dan Bucceroni, Philadelphia heavyweight, was signed yesterday to oppose Danny Nardico of Tampa, Fla., in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. Bucceroni was called in as a replacement for Jake La Motta of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- New teams of subversive activities investigators will take over when the Republicans organize the new Congress next January, with a revitalized House Committee on Un-American Activities likely to take the spotlight once again.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 -- In an unusual peacetime procedure, the Bethlehem Steel Company's Sparrows Point Shipyard launched one tanker today and a few minutes later laid the keel for a duplicate on the same ways. Both tankers are for the Sinclair Oil Corporation.

The responsibility of women to become vocal in making their wishes known to the Congress, as well as to work on problems confronting the United Nations, was emphasized yesterday afternoon by Miss Luella Reckmeyer, director of Christian world relations, at a meeting of the Manhattan Council of Church Women at Marble Collegiate Church, Twentyninth Street and Fifth Avenue.
A productivity team representing French makers of ready-made women's apparel yesterday began a study of manufacturing techniques in the New York fashion apparel markets.

Julius A. Archibald, the first Negro to be elected to the State Senate, expressed his determination yesterday to represent all his constituents in the Twenty-first Senatorial District by getting his "cues from the people."

For more than an hour yesterday a 3-year-old girl with a tremendous smile posed for photographers. She posed eagerly on a bicycle, standing against a large picture of herself on a poster, and sitting on a chair.
Armed thugs preyed on small shopkeepers in Manhattan and Brooklyn last night, escaping with sums ranging from $45 to $400.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 7 -- Nearly complete returns from Tuesday's election in South Carolina show that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, received a total popular vote that narrowed his opponent's margin of victory to about seven-tenths of 1 per cent of the ballots cast.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A credit of $5,000,000 was established by the Export-Import Bank today for the Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., of Toronto, Canada, to finance expansion of its nickel, copper and cobalt production. The Canadian concern is the world's second largest nickel producer.

The city's drive against firetrap tenements in Harlem has turned up 2,424 violations in 177 buildings in the three weeks the campaign has been under way, Deputy Commissioner of Housing Frederick S. Weaver announced last night.

WITH FRENCH UNION FORCES, Northwest of Viettri, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 7 -- French Union forces, in a double-barreled offensive, clipped off the tail-end of one of the Commu nist-led Vietminh's main supply routes with China today. This put them in a strong position to drive deep into the heart of enemy-held territory.

Events today: Father Flanagan's Boys Town Choir, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Guiomar Novaes, pianist, Town Hall, 3; Ethel Colt, songs of the theatre, Town Hall, 5:30; Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Yvonne Balbous, soprano, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30; Frances Magnes, violinist, Washington Irving High School, 8:30; Carib Singers, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., $:40; "La Boheme," Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to the homemaker.

PAWLING, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- Too many individuals and agencies responsible for the welfare of children are continuing to follow methods that research in child development has proved unsound, Dr. L. Joseph Stone, Professor of Child Study, Vassar College, said last night.

The dual problem of larger numbers of girls reaching Girl Scout age and fewer women in the age group from which troop leaders are normally drawn was discussed yesterday by national and regional officials at the closing session of the two-day biennial conference of Region II attended by more than 1,600 representatives of Girl Scouts in New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico, Canal Zone and Virgin Islands.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Four of President Truman's Cabinet members, soon to be unemployed, paused outside the White House today to comment on their plans. Following is what they said:

Major financial and commodity exchanges throughout the United States will be closed on Tuesday, Nov. 11, Armistice Day. Livestock market will be reported as usual by the Department of Agriculture. Canadian securities markets and the Winnipeg grain exchange will also be closed to mark Remembrance Day.

One of the last of the nation's large complex public utility holding companies is going out of business. The United States District Court in Delaware approved yesterday the initial and most important step in the complete liquidation of the Standard Gas and Electric Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- George Washington University's alert football team turned a blocked punt, a pass interception and a recovered fumble into a 21-7 victor over Bucknell tonight. It was Bucknell's second loss in its last twenty games.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7 -- Bette Davis will make a second picture next summer for Bert Friedlob, the independent producer for whom she played the lead in "The Star" before joining the stage revue, "Two's Company," which is heading for a Broadway opening.

The United States should make one last attempt to achieve a united Germany through four-power talks with the Soviet Union, before accepting the divided Europe implicit in the terms of the European Defense Community Treaty.

Eleven nominations to the 1952-53 board of governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms were announced yesterday by the nominating committee headed by Henry Upham Harris of Harris, Upham Co. The elections will be held following the close of the market on Nov. 19 in the board of governors' room of the New York Stock Exchange.

Women guests wearing brilliantly hued gowns and jewels, members of the hunt clubs in evening "pinks," and officers of the United States Armed Forces and foreign nations wearing their dress uniforms made the annual Horse Show Ball, held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, the most colorful event of the week's festivities in connection with the sixty-fourth annual Horse Show.

The leaders of organized labor sought to make repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act the touchstone of their campaign on behalf of the candidacy of Governor Stevenson, but, by their own count, one result of the election has been to diminish the number of members of Congress regarded by organized labor as "friendly."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved proposals by the Ohio Valley Electric Corporation and its subsidiary, the Indiana-Kentucky Electric Corporation, for financing the construction of two electric generating stations for the gaseous diffusion plant of the Atomic Energy Commission near Portsmouth, Ohio.

Abroad as at home General Eisenhower's triumph is interpreted as a personal more than a party victory. The size of the vote encourages nervous overseas observers to share the American view that since he obviously won support from independents and Democrats he is now free to carry out his own ideas and initiate his own program.

The one-story industrial building at 93 Meserole Street, Brooklyn, containing about 5,000 square feet of space, has been leased by the R Wags Quilting Corporation from Damon Creations, Inc. The Kalmon Dolgin Company was the broker. The lessee will use the property for the quilting of textiles for the general textile trade.

A representative of Lines Brothers, Ltd., London, met yesterday with members of Ideal Toy Corporation to plan spring lines. The companies have an oral agreement to share blueprints of toys that are adaptable in either country.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 7 -Representative John M. Vorys, Republican of Ohio, a ranking member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, advocated today that the United States make long-term loans to finance economic aid to foreign countries instead of continuing "an indefinite program of gifts all over the world."

The Borg-Warner Corporation, manufacturer of mechanisms and parts used in the automotive, aircraft, farm equipment and machinery fields, reported declines of 14 per cent in sales and 11 per cent in earnings in the first nine months of this year.

The wages of coal miners have increased by so much since 1920 that it now costs from $6 to $8 a ton of annual capacity to develop a good coal mine, compared with not over $2 in 1920. Inventors have made the most of the opportunity. Underground machines are doing more and more of the dirty work in coal mining.

In general the voters used good judgment in returning able members to the New York Legislature in Tuesday's election, although they undoubtedly returned many mediocre members and some poor ones also, perhaps for want of a better alternative. At least four useful legislators went down to defeat in the Eisenhower landslide, however: Senators Braisted of Staten Island and O'Connor of Queens, and Assemblymen Bowe of Queens and Mauhs of Schoharie County. All four are Democrats.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A big Air Force plans, one of sorts that flew to Alaska last week for Exercise Warmwind Arctic maneuvers, disappeared early today with nineteen men aboard.
A voluble Army male nurse poured out a stream of startling charges in Federal Court yesterday against John David Provoo, who is on trial for alleged wartime treason.

The transparent effrontery of the Soviet Union's protest against the establishment of a defensive sea zone around Korea is so flagrant that no reply could possibly be expected other than that indicated by the State Department's press officer. Mr. McDermott observed that this protest was "another in a seemingly endless series of messages designed to deceive the people into believing that legitimate counter-measures to acts of aggression are new acts of aggression."

North American Constructors, a joint venture on behalf of four engineering and construction concerns, has leased four floors comprising about 45,000 square feet of space in the building at 80-92 Varick Street through the Charles F. Noyes Company and Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers. The building is owned by the Twin Coast Newspapers, Inc., a holding company for The Journal of Commerce, which recently acquired the ten-story structure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- A special Federal grand jury has resumed its investigation of tax scandal leads uncovered by a House Ways and Means subcommittee, headed by Representative Cecil R. King, Democrat of California.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 7 -- A discrepancy between an estimated income of $54,000,000 for the United Israel campaign published in the United States by the United Jewish Appeal and the $41,000,000 included in the foreign currency budget by the government here was explained today by a Finance Ministry spokesman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Mrs. Ivy B. Priest, director of women's activities for the Republican National Committee, declared today that as a result of the successful showing made by women in the campaign and election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, she was confidently expecting high appointments in the Administration for "capable and qualified women."

As two additional candidates for Democratic State Chairman sought support from state committee members for election to succeed Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, called yesterday for the election of a new chairman who would furnish a "fighting, liberal leadership."

A 49-year-old luncheonette owner, who had stopped his car to fix a defective tail light, was injured critically on the Gowanus Parkway in Brooklyn last night. Struck by another automobile, he was carried 100 feet with his legs crushed between the two vehicles.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP) -- John McKinnon, a substitute quarterback, stepped off the bench tonight to score two touchdowns and set up another with his field direction as Boston College defeated the University of Detroit, 23-20. Boston stopped Detroit on the 1-yard line on the final play of the game.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Mayor Martin H. Kennelly refused today to overrule the decision of Police Commissioner Timothy J. O'Connor and the Chicago Police Department Censorship Board that banned the showing of the film "The Miracle."

When a previously more or less private citizen is elected President of the United States a little group of serious-looking men appear in front of his house or even, after knocking at the door, go inside. These gentlemen are employes of the Secret Service. Their function is to see that the person of the President-elect is protected.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- In July, 1945, Prime Minister Churchill hurried back to London from the Potsdam Conference to receive the stunning news that his Government had been overthrown in the British general election.

Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, reported yesterday that the Committee on Slum Clearance Plans, of which he is chairman, had obtained preliminary sponsorship for a new three-block slum-clearance project in the area between Thirtieth and Thirty-third Streets and First and Second Avenues.
A football newcomer to New York, Clemson College, will oppose Fordham at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, today. The kickoff is scheduled for 1:30 P. M.

Futures trading was generally quiet on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday with the outstanding feature a sharp drop in cocoa as the spot price fell. Rubber, potato, wool and vegetable oil futures were up, hides, zinc and sugar were mixed and lead, coffee and cocoa were down.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Millard Caldwell, Federal Civil Defense Administrator since Dec. 6, 1950, resigned today effective on Nov. 15. He was the first member of President Truman's official family to leave the Government following the Democratic Administration's defeat at the polls on Tuesday.

Young Lilian Kallir, in her Town Hall recital last night, showed a nice set of external pianistic specifications. Her fingers were well drilled, she produced a resonant tone, and her brand of playing was very reliable. She gave a sprightly performance, albeit one a little too fast, of the Bach Fugue, and a neat one of the Beethoven Sonata.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Alarmed at the threat to aluminum supplies arising from power shortages in the Northwest and the Tennessee Valley, aluminum producers today urged that the Government not only suspend stockpiling of the metal, but consider withdrawing some of the existing supplies from that source to help tide consumers and fabricators over a temporary shortage.

Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick last night ruled there was no tampering involved when the Browns signed Harry (the Cat) Brecheen last week after the Cardinals had asked and received waivers on the southpaw pitcher.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 7 -- Six new scholarships of $1,400 which are named in honor of Emily Dickinson, famous American poet, will be offered annually Mount Holyoke College. President Roswell Gray Ham made the anouncement today at Founder Day ceremonies observed annual since the opening of the institution Nov. 8, 1837.

The homemaker busy with the dishes and the baby might have been a bit amused yesterday if she could have peeked at a couple of hundred food experts gathered at the Pierre Hotel deep in discussion of the question, "Who is the American housewife and what is she like?"

The taxpayer and garages at 281 East 140th Street, also known as 287-301 Bruckner Boulevard, the Bronx, have been sold by Paul Maslin Co. to the Gaulang Realty Company. The property has ten tenants and was sold for cash above mortgages of $101,675. The sellers were represented by Gerard M. Bloomfield, attorney, and William Seligson, attorney, acted for the buyers. Title was insured by the Home Title Gueranty and Trust Company.
The Bull Lines passenger vessel Puerto Rico will begin service on Thursday on her new route to the Virgin Islands after a two-month overhaul at a Brooklyn shipyard.
HAMBURG, Germany, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Western Europe counted eighteen dead tonight in the wake of a storm that raged from Britain to Greece.

The difficult tasks faced by Exeter, at Andover, and The Hill School, host to Lawrenceville at Pottstown, Pa., hold the center of attention today as the prep school football season for most teams heads for a stirring finish. It is a day filled with traditional rivalries.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 8 -- Chinese Communist troops failed yesterday in a renewed effort to wrest "Pinpoint Hill" from the Republic of Korea forces defending that dominating rise of "Sniper Ridge" on the central front.

ALPINE, N. J., Nov. 7 -- Forest fires, feeding on parched autumn leaves and dry brush and driven by gusty winds, have burned up thousands of acres of woodland in the last two days in northern New Jersey and neighboring Rockland County, N. Y.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- De Givenchy's mid-season collection brought forth deserved applause for his balance of the simple and the sumptuous, the chic simplicity of jersey frocks with low necklines and long tight sleeves as against the magnificence of coats and furs, the latter executed by Aronowitz of New York and Paris.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations said today that it was carrying on its negotiations on the Korean case on the assumption that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, would support the "basic goal" of an honorable armistice based on the non-forcible repatriation of prisoners.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- Debate on the creation of a proposed international criminal court got swiftly under way in the United Nations today with France supporting and Britain opposing a tribunal or handling such crimes as genocide and wars of aggression.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 7 -The Communist Party of Yugoslavia, ended its sixth congress today in Zagreb having adopted a policy of intensifying the ideological struggle against the Soviet Cominform. The congress also approved moves for the political and economic structure of Yugoslavia to a point where the greater percentage of people could be induced to abandon their passivity and support the regime.

A chemist's report on a sample of hair taken from one of the thirty policemen identified by Harry Gross as recipients of his graft was introduced yesterday into the departmental trial being conducted before Third Deputy Commissioner James A. Delehanty in the Criminal Courts Building.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 7 (AP) -- A petition said to have about 50,000 signatures and asking a new trial for Mr. and Mrs. Julius Rosenberg, condemned as atomic bomb spies, was left in the office of the Supreme Court Clerk today.

A syndicate headed by Philip Edwards has purchased the eight-story and penthouse building at 340 West Eighty-fifth Street from the Three Arts Club, Mrs. John Henry Hammond, president for cash over a mortgage of $161,675. Assessed at $400,000, the building was erected by the seller in 1927 and was used as a nonprofit residence for women students of the drama, music and fine arts. Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., was the broker.

Many Southern factories making low and medium price bedroom and dining room furniture are sold up through February. Buyers just returned from the annual fall unofficial market in the Lenoir-High Point, N. C., area reported yesterday that business at the event was the heaviest in several years.

The Nobel Prize in Literature has once again been given to an eloquent spokesman for human values. Francois Mauriac's impassioned voice has for several decades -- and to this very moment -- given the lie to those critics of France who have been overimpressed by her moods of cynicism.

BELLINGHAM, Wash., Nov. 7 -- A crude oil pipeline under construction from the Edmonton, Alberta, oil fields to Vancouver, B. C., will be extended across the Canada-United States border and a $35,000,000 refinery with a capacity of 35,000 barrels a day will be built at Ferndale, near this city, under a program announced here today.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- European officials charged with framing defense and economic policies are asking themselves how long the paralysis of Western diplomacy occasioned by the United States election must continue.

THIS afternoon at 4:30 o'clock, when the new series of ninety-minute television programs called "Omnibus" makes its first appearance over the C. B. S. video network, the Ford Foundation's TV-Radio Workshop will have launched an undertaking aimed at affecting American television on a broad and practical scale.
NEWPORT, R. I., Nov. 8 -- Scoring three touchdowns in the second quarter, Middlesex School overpowered St. George's School at Crocker Field today, 41 to 12.

GRAPE arbors are not a thing of the past, for they are still to be seen in back yards in towns or the country. They are no longer erected and planted as a matter of course because of the limited property area around modern homes.
TORONTO, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Detroit and Toronto battled to a 3-3 tie in a rough National Hockey League game at Maple Leafs Gardens tonight as the Red Wings continued to be haunted by their "road jinx."

My "Evening with Beatrice Lillie" was a disappointment. I felt like an outsider. Oh, it wasn't Miss Lillie's fault, or Reginald Gardiner's. It was the fault of the audience. Perhaps once each week, in order to remedy this situation, Miss Lillie might arrange for an "Introductory Evening with Beatrice Lillie" for newcomers to her art.

Warnings against the misuse of lie detector machines as they are now constituted were voiced yesterday by criminologists, law enforcement officers and intelligence agency personnel at a conference on lie detection and interrogation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- At 6:15 o'clock on any workday evening the towering secretariat building at United Nations headquarters undergoes a shift from a hive of activity to a campus of sorts.

LOCAL Girl: "Only Tallulah would have * * * quoted from so many of her best press notices," writes the book reviewer of a Jasper (Ala.) newspaper, giving a we-remember-her-when imprimatur to Tallulah Bankhead's autobiography the other day.

IT'S a hard job to focus a clear and direct light on the many-faceted Roosevelt. There is a pro and contra view as to every quality the man possessed -- or lacked. There are many who think him great; there are many others who think him tawdry.
A BRITISH novelist of considerable literary skill and humor, Norman Lewis was stricken about three years ago with a desire to go to Asia, as he says in the foreword of this book, "before I died."

A LITTLE more than ten years ago Kierkegaard was virtually unknown in this country, and now, after having become a household word in some circles, he seems at last to have arrived, for he has reached the anthology stage. "The Living Thoughts of Kierkegaard" seems to me the best introduction to the work of this great and difficult thinker.

ANOTHEH cavvy of all-Western calicos and buckskins, fresh from the high-grass country in the Wood-Pulp Range, reminds this reader that the supply of Westerns never varies, regardless of season. All the brands seem in order in this autumn's corral -- and the cavvy, on the whole, deserves a good rating, with exceptions noted below.

WITH her particular blend of passion, wit and rueful restraint, Mary Jane Ward writes about Everywoman up against it. Her last three novels have dealt with courage against odds, women in conflict with environment, violent and obvious conflict in "The Snake Pit"; not so violent, but still obvious in "A Little Night Music"; more confused and diffused in "It's Different for a Woman."

BAYONNE, N. J., Nov. 8 -- Three Hudson County fires today left a Jersey City woman dead, a Hoboken church badly damaged and a Bayonne theatre and four stores in ruins. The local fire was reported to be the most serious in the business section here in the last decade.
LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A private British-American group said today that there was serious "bad feeling" between American G. I.'s in Britain and the British public.

JOE E. BROWN, who left home at the age of 9 to become an acrobat in vaudeville, is currently trying to adjust himself to television after more than fifty years in show business. This new phase of his career is looked upon with mild trepidation by the comedian, who plays a circus clown in the "Circus Hour," presented once a month on Tuesday at 8 P. M. over Channel 4.

ALBANY, Nov. 8 -- Charles H. Diefendorf of Buffalo, president of the Marine Trust Company of Western New York and of the Marine Midland Corporation, was appointed by Governor Dewey today chairman of the State Temporary Highway Finance Planning Commission.

Few, if any, American factories have become so mechanized that they can eliminate the necessity of manual handling of materials. It is this point in the manufacturing process -- where employes handle materials -- that industry's most pressing safety problem lies.

THE French will be the objects of much criticism and controversy in the coming weeks and months. It will be provoked by their unsettled relations, both with the North Atlantic Treaty group of nations and with the smaller group that seek to create a Western European Community closely linked for defense with the Atlantic alliance.

In several situations of tension and difficulty the United Nations can be of service even if it does not take specific and definitive action. It can recommend, it can discuss, it can bring about the exchange of opinion, and it can supply the "good offices" that are sometimes needed to resolve a conflict.
WHICHEVER Republican succeeds Jesse M. Donaldson as Postmaster General could conceivably enter office with only a vague notion of stamp collecting as a hobby, but before he leaves he will learn.

Order-hungry textile exporters are looking with misgiving on efforts of Canadian manufacturers to obtain higher tariffs for protection of home industries. The Canadian business, it was pointed out last week, is about the only bright spot in the entire textile export picture.
There was further reiteration last week that there will be no drastic change in United States foreign economic and military aid policy under the new Administration.

Cheap journalism (upon which the public feeds its lowest instincts) is primarily responsible for the incredible snub given Chaplin's major film, "Limelight." It was encouraging to read your fine article on this film, published in last Sunday's TIMES, a newspaper that merits the admiration of its readers.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Mrs. B. F. Whitaker's Grecian Queen came on the last sixteenth af a mile to win the first division of the Marguerite Stakes against eight other 2-year-old fillies by a neck at Pimlico today.

TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 9 -- The Chinese Communists struck lightly last night and early today in probing attacks all along the western and central Korean fronts. They were turned back without penetration of the United Nations lines.

THE Broadway impresarios who ten weeks ago made a wistful stab at increasing box-office revenue by launching the Monday night 7 o'clock curtain are looking as pleased with themselves these days as a groping youngster who has pinned the donkey's tail in the right place.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation today was still looking into the accounts of a 45-year-old woman bank teller charged with embezzling $35,338 so she could live extravagantly in the suburban community of Swarthmore, Pa.

THE idea of an innocent person -- such as one's self -- going to prison is so repugnant that there is a general inclination to assume that anyone duly convicted and incarcerated must be guilty. But even the American system of jurisprudence, with its layers of safeguards, is subject to occasional combinations of human fallibility resulting in miscarriages of justice.

SEATTLE, Nov. 8 (AP) -- An alert defense and the daring, mix-'em-up quarterbacking of Don Heinrich earned the Huskies of Washington a surprise 22-7 triumph today over California's fumble-plagued Bears in a Pacific Coast Conference football game.

Starting tomorrow morning and continuing through Friday, millions of parents and interested citizens will make their annual pilgrimage to the nation's schools for the thirty-second annual observance of American Education Week. Many public schools will hold "open house" and will put children, teachers and modern education on display.
