THE search for desirable living quarters at sensible prices has bedeviled many of us during the past ten years. But in the case of older Americans, the dilemma has been, and still is, even more acute. There are now more persons past 65 than ever before -- and the proportion is growing.

ALTHOUGH "Bernardine" is not very well written nor very well staged, no one seems to be pedantically distressed. For Mary Chase has a knowledge of adolescent boys that is sound and a humorously compassionate point of view that is winning. You know that you are in good hands when she presides over an evening in the theatre.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 8 -- A letter, postmarked New York, arrived at the Illinois Executive Mansion here this week, addressed only to "The man who would rather be right than President."

The annual card party of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service will be held tomorrow in the ballroom of the Colony Club. The beneficiaries of the event will be St. Barnabas House, the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, the Hospital Reading Society and the San Salvatore Mission.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Charlie Harding, goat of last week's last minute defeat by South Carolina, more than made amends today by throwing three touchdown passes and scoring once himself as Virginia scored a convincing 34-7 football triumph over North Carolina.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Trailing, 14 -- 7, after three periods, the Temple University Owls today fashioned an 88-yard drive for a touchdown early in the final period to gain a 14-14 tie with Boston University.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 8 -- Hofstra scored four times in the second quarter today and routed the United States Merchant Marine Academy, 44-20, for its third victory in the traditional Long Island collegiate series.

Despite the growing number of trade shows, traveling salesmen still conduct their own one-man exhibits while on the road. In sharp contrast to the displays at the trade events, usually held in luxurious surroundings, most of the one-man affairs must, of necessity, be conducted in comparatively unattractive or, in too numerous instances, in dingy hotel rooms.

The reaction abroad to the Eisenhower victory was one of uncertainty, mixed with some searching for a silver lining. Foreign peoples, particularly European, have held Eisenhower in warm esteem since the war years. When he was nominated at Chicago, many foreign statesmen were relieved. They were confident of his sympathy and understanding. As one NATO official put it, "No matter what happens, we can't lose."

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (UP) -- The Missouri Basin Inter-Agency Committee revealed today detailed, long-range plans for harnessing the Missouri River and controlling its destructive floods at an estimated total cost of $9,400,000,000.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Former Lieut. Gov. Sam Lumpkin quit his $9,350-a-year appointive state job today and asserted that Gov. Hugh White had forced his resignation because he had supported Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for President.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 8 -- President Carlos Ibanez del Campo appeared today to have come out victorious from his first contest of wills with some of the political elements that backed him for the Presidency and that some observers had feared would dominate him.

LITERARY controls in postwar Russia have compelled Soviet writers, poets and dramatists to concentrate on devising ways for depicting life in the U. S. S. R. without arousing the ire of the mighty, or the fears of officials responsible for permission to print or produce works of art.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 8 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson took hold of the Democratic party as its titular leader today and expressed the hope and expectation that the party "will serve the nation as a vigorous and constructive force in the Congress and in our national political life."

ONE of the more interesting mysteries of modern letters, to me, is how S. J. Perelman keeps it up. It was quite a number of years ago that he began writing humor, writing it keyed up very high every sentence of the way, and here he is, still sitting on the edge of his chair constantly writing for all he is worth and still being funny a large part of the time.

THROUGHOUT this long and somber novel the reader senses an unmistakable ambivalence on the part of the author. Mark Aldanov has not written an American novel but has made a kind of crabwise approach to one.

FIVE years ago Ben Thomas wrote a good book called "Portrait for Posterity," a study of the biographers of Lincoln. He divided these writers into two schools, the realists and the idealists. At the end of his survey Mr. Thomas posed the question: which group has portrayed Lincoln most successfully?

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- F. E. Bellows High, scoring its sixth straight victory, toppled another previously unbeaten and untied eleven, Blessed Sacrament High of New Rochelle, 14 to 13, at Daniel Warren Field today. The loss ended a Blessed Sacrament string of ten triumphs, five of them this season.

DESPITE the dates in its title, William Appleman Williams' book deals chiefly with the period between 1900 and 1939. This is readily understandable. Early relations with the empire of the czars are, broadly speaking, of limited importance in comparison with the relations of the twentieth century.

OF all the lunacies, the professional abnormalities, which flowered or festered on Manhattan Island in the frenetic Twenties, but a single one has survived -- the Broadway columnist. Among the first and foremost of the breed was Mark Hellinger.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Patricia McMahon, 12-year-old daughter of the late Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, who died last July, tonight accepted on behalf of her father the first Peace Award to be granted by the Catholic Association for International Peace. The award, inaugurated this year, will be made annually to an American whose outstanding achievements have helped further the Christian principles of justice and charity in international life.
DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 8 (UP) -- A burning drought, coupled with forest and grass fires, threatened today to ruin the cattle and farming economy in ten states of the South and Southwest.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 8 -- Business and industry will have an early opportunity to tell Congress if they feel they have been, as many allege, "over-regulated by the Democrats for the last twenty years."

TOKYO, Nov. 8 -- Political circles said today that Japanese foreign policy was likely to be overhauled as a result of the statement here this week by John M. Allison, the United States' Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, that the newly independent nation had been dilatory in approaching the question of reparations, on which her relations with her Asian neighbors depend.

The immigration policy of the United States should be reviewed and reformed on a bipartisan basis, Rabbi Manuel Saltzman said in his sermon yesterday morning at Temple Ansche Chesed, 100th Street and West End Avenue.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 8 -- Lawrenceville School's unbeaten football squad lived up to its reputation today with a 32-0 triumph over the Hill School in the forty-sixth meeting of the series. Sparked by the sterling T-quarterbacking of Joe Mark, the winners tallied in every period.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 8 -- Snow, mud and Penn State failed to stay the "Bill Orange" boys from Syracuse from their appointed rounds today as they romped over the vaunted Nittany Lions by a score of 25 to 7 before 15,000 fans at Archbold Stadium.

IN the wave of recent books written by the many who have escaped from imprisonment and death in the U. S. S. R., Tadeusz Wittlin's "A Reluctant Traveler in Russia" belongs among the most literary. A writer in pre-war Poland, Mr. Wittlin left Warsaw during the German occupation on a round-about journey -- via the Soviet-occupied Eastern territories -- to France.

WHEN, in late December, 1950, the expressman delivered to my New York City apartment a miniature greenhouse, I soon realized that it was quite a challenge to an amateur horticulturist -- and mechanic.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- Alarmed by increases in traffic casualty rates, a number of governments have joined forces, under United Nations auspices, to seek ways of reducing highway accident tolls. This safety drive has been tackled by two separate groups, one meeting in Geneva and the other at the new glass-and-marble world capitol on the East River.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A two-year limit on the White House term of any Vice President who becomes President on the President's death was proposed today by Senator George Smathers, Democrat of Florida.

The supporters of Ireland had something to cheer about last night when Lieut. Col. Daniel J. Corry rode Kilkarne to victory in the International Special Challenge Trophy event that was the feature of the international jumping competition of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.
Totten P. Heffelfinger of Minneapolis has been nominated for re-election as president of the United States Golf Association.

EVEN though Election Day has come and gone, there is still time to plant tulip bulbs this fall. They can go into the ground up to the time it is frozen hard. Since the bulbs produce their root systems in the fall of the year, however, they should be planted as soon as possible to give them a chance to build up a strong root system.

NEWARK AIRPORT will be opened for full-scale, around-the-clock commercial airline traffic on Saturday when the new $9,000,000 runway that will make it possible to eliminate all landings and takeoffs over the center of Elizabeth, N. J., will be put into service.

Editorial work, education and science provide careers most attractive to Barnard College graduates, class, of '52. A survey of the class shows that more than 50 per cent of those now working are employed in these fields.
SEVERAL interesting casting items will be found in the New York City Ballet's schedule at the City Center, along with a postponement or two.

CAMERA clubs and members will share alike in the $3,000 Osborne Color Transparency Contest for camera club members sponsored by the Osborne Company of Clifton, N. J., sixty-five-year-old calendar company.

NEWARK, Nov. 8 -- Reorganization of the Democratic party in New Jersey, with a state leader replacing the regional coalition that has functioned since the defeat of Mayor Frank Hague in 1949, is planned by party leaders to coincide with the primary election next May for a candidate for Governor.

SYDNEY, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The favorable price trend so far at Australian wool auctions of the 1952-53 wool-selling season indicates that Australian wool growers will make at least 10 per cent more money than they did last season.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- The British freed two of the smaller fry war criminals today, Herbert Koestlin and Hans Horstmann, from the Werl, Westphalia, jail.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Prospects of a five-way fight for the post of Republican floor leader in the new Senate developed today, raising the possibility that Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire would reluctantly remain in the position in the interest of party harmony.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the preview performance of "The Seven Year Itch" on the night of Nov. 19 at the Fulton Theatre for the benefit of the New York City Mission Society. Mrs. Stanley M. Rumbough Jr. and Mrs. R. Clifton Wilson are co-chairmen of the arrangements committee for the benefit.

J., next year will be in the medium to high price range and this will keep sale. dollar volume at current levels although the number of houses t6 he started may decline, in the opinion of B. J. Bergton of Teaneek, agent for housing developments in northern New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- For President-elect Eisenhower, one of the more gratifying results of Tuesday's landslide victory was that it applied the final binding of cement to the structure of Republican party unity for which Candidate Eisenhower had labored so hard, often under discouraging, and difficult circumstances.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 8 -- A United States professional golf team retained the Lakes International Cup today with a 7-5 victory over Australia by winning two of four final singles matches.

FIFTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, in Korea, Nov. 8 -- Enemy artillery, mortar and rocket fire, which, since last August, had been a volcano of flames and thunder, has passed its peak and will diminish, a United Nations commanding general predicted here today.

After the end of World War II in 1946 observers on aerial flights over the Arctic Ocean saw large bodies of floating ice that differed from those of surrounding pack ice. Ice in the polar region is seldom thicker than ten to fifteen feet. It is subject to fracture as the result of the disruptive action of wind and tide.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- San Francisco's new $500,000 Morrison Planetarium, billed as "the best in the world," was opened today to the public as an addition to the California Academy of Sciences in Golden Gate Park.

Prices of foreign steels, which were heavily cut in July, are likely to be reduced again by the year-end, in the opinion of importers questioned last week. The big reason advanced is that buying, which turned upward during the mid-summer steel strike here, has dropped off to about half that of the high levels of 1951.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Y. T. Pyun of South Korea said today the Japanese Communists were smuggling small arms to guerrillas in South Korea.
HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 8 -- An aroused Dartmouth team rolled up its highest score since 1943 in thwarting the favored Columbia football squad by 38 to 14 today.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 8 -- Rolling up a total of 453 yards along the ground, Coach Steve Sorota's powerful Andover eleven finished its season undefeated today by routing a game Exeter team, 59 to 0, before 6,000 fans on Brothers Field today.

IF one undertook to describe a great city such as New York in a romantic way he would try to catch the whir and the roar of the avenues, the noises and smells, the flow of the human tide at morning and at night, the laughter and the sadness in the faces of the crowds, Central Park romances, the music of church towers, the low ebb before dawn.

An elderly gentleman was scurrying through the hallway on the eighth floor of the Mary Manning Walsh Home for the Aged at 420 East Fifty-ninth Street last week briskly lining up talent for the institution's first Christmas play.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- The University of Rochester turned back the Hamilton College eleven, 33 -- 6, today to score its seventh straight victory of an unbeaten season, Dick Gumerlock, brilliant left halfback and co-captain for the visitors, shook loose early in the fourth period to race sixty yards for a touchdown.

Since last Tuesday Americans have been appraising and analyzing the election result. We have a new President-elect. We are concerned, and rightly so, with what this means in terms of national courses of action, of high policy and its implementation, of relationships both among the different communities within our own commonwealth and throughout the world. Sober judgment in the wake of election passions is a good thing.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 8 -- Trinity defeated Amherst, 7 to 0, in a thriller today on an 84-yard return of a punt in the closing minutes of the game.

Unusual weather conditions interfered with retail trade in the week. Temperatures were well above those of a year ago on the important shopping days, especiall yElection Day, and seasonal apparel volume was slowed as a result. Department store sales, without including the Loeser sale figures, were estimated by trade observers at about 7 per cent below those of a year before.

ATHENS -- A trip to the blossoming island of Corfu, set like a boutonniere on the Ionian Sea, holds some of the thrill of a voyage of discovery. The reasons are threefold: the loveliness of the island, the moderation of its prices and the fact that to travelers from the Western Hemisphere it is comparatively unknown.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin and a delegate to the United Nations General Assembly, has called on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, to give the green light to proceeding with the United States-backed resolution on a Korean truce.

ATLANTA, Nov. 8 -- Sugar Bowl-bound Georgia Tech rode its vaunted running attack and an improved passing game to a 45-6 victory over Army today despite the loss of All-America hopeful, Leon Hardeman, in the first quarter.

AMONG the great throng of spectators from all parts of the world on hand to witness the pageantry of the Coronation procession that will wind through the streets of London next June 2, will be more than 2,000 American tourists who will converge on the British capital on five cruise liner.

One of the stumbling blocks in evaluating the economic health of the nation -- uncertainty -- was removed by General Eisenhower's sweeping victory at the polls last Tuesday. No longer will business be made a whipping boy for politicians, as it has been for many years. Government interference with business should lessen considerably and industry may look forward to a more sympathetic administration in Washington.

THE President-elect will enter the White House next January with the echoes of the voice of the American people ringing in his ears. Stored in his mind, against a blurred background of high mountains and endless plains, braggart cities and nameless little towns, is a moving picture of upturned and questioning faces, millions of faces that merge at last into one face -- the broad-stroked, strong-colored, forever unfinished self-portrait of America.
I READ with interest and surprise the letter of Rev. Clyde D. Williams in last Sunday's TIMES expressing his views on the commercial sponsorship of religious programs.

THE literate movie-goer today, if he were playing the game of word-association, would most likely respond to the given word "movies" with the word "Italian." There was a time when he might have said "Russian" (for its documentaries), or "French" (for its psychological dimension), or "British" (for its thrillers).
During the last sixteen months the Fund for Adult Education has appropriated nearly $4,000,000 to "encourage the discussion by American citizens of vital issues," it was announced yesterday.

Mayor Impellitteri will proclaim next week as Diabetes Detection and Education Week and will request the public to cooperate with physicians and health authorities in finding diabetics. The American Diabetes Association estimates that one of every five Americans has the ailment without knowing it.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 8 -- A gathering of 4,000 looked on as Rutgers scored an unimpressive football victory over Lafayette, 21 -- 6, today. The onetime bitter Middle Three rivalry lost part of its significance since Lehigh, the possessor of the Little Cannon symbol of championship, will not face the Scarlet this season.

FORT DIX, N. J., Nov. 8 -- An Army board of inquiry began today an investigation into the circumstances that resulted in the death here last night to a 30-year-old Army lieutenant and injury to three enlisted men.

Two men were taken into custody late yesterday by the Queens police as a result of a raid on a dwelling near Jamaica race track allegedly used for the illegal transmission of race results to a national gambling syndicate.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 8 (UP) -- James Mitchell, Civil Service Commissioner, proposed today putting United States overseas employes under the Federal merit system as a means of getting better public service at a lower cost.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 8 -- Mrs. Mamie Geneva Doud Eisenhower, the country's First Lady after Jan. 20, will celebrate her fifty-sixth birthday here next Friday as part of the ten-day vacation she is spending with the husband she married on July 1, 1916, in Denver, Colo.

The results of the election had little effect on the retail outlook with high employment and large Government expenditures expected to continue. Buyers of spring goods who are expected to arrive in the wholesale markets here next week will look for a good season, Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office, stated.

NOT long ago a branch of the Census Bureau issued a bulletin, available on application, explaining to counties and communities of this nation how, even without a crystal ball, they can estimate and forecast their own population some years hence.

A METROPOLITAN OPERA announcement informs us, apropos of tomorrow night's opening of its 1952-53 season with a revival of Verdi's "Forza del Destino," that composers have "book trouble," and that this fact is responsible for the specially cut and historically transposed version of the work which is to be seen.

WITH a career in mind, young Steve Brandon makes a summer trip to Alaska to visit his uncle and learn about commercial fisheries. When the boy's uncle is suddenly stricken, Steve becomes watchman of a big fish trap during the annual salmon run.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Rate decreases in areas of large population have offset increases for residential electric service through the country this year, the Federal Power Commission reported today. Rates today, in general, are lower than they were in 1940 and in 1935, according to the report "Typical Residential Electric Bolls -- Cities of 2,500 Population and More."

According to the most generally accepted theory, arteriosclerosis (hardening of the arteries) begins with faulty fat metabolism and deposition of fatty chemical substances, principally cholesterol, in the inner lining of the walls of the blood vessels, especially the coronary arteries.

A BORDER of flowering shrubs is an excellent stand-in for a bed of perennials. It can be just as colorful during most seasons, and is far more practical for the property owner who has to limit his gardening activities. Now that they've lost their leaves, most shrubs can be moved easily with good chance of success.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Republican margin of control in the Eighty-third Congress is so slim that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, will have to look beyond his own party for votes to put across his program.

Mrs. George Hamlin Shaw is chairman of the committee for the Philharmonic-Symphony "Friends' Fund" luncheon to be held on Thursday in the grand ballroom of the Plaza. The luncheon will mark the opening of the 1952 fund-raising campaign of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York and David M. Keiser, chairman of the campaign will preside.
KIMBERLEY, South Africa, Nov. 8 -- The police opened fire today on rioters in a Negro suburb of this diamond city, killing fourteen Negroes and wounding thirty-nine.

A set of new flight procedures aimed at increasing the safety factor and reducing the noise nuisance of aircraft that will use Newark Airport when it is reopened for full scale operations on Nov. 15 was announced here yesterday by the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee.

The major metal industries, particularly steel and aluminum, are becoming restive under Government controls. Industry officials would like to see these distribution regulations removed forthwith. There is still no overall balance between supply and demand in either metal, but the tight supply situation is easing in more and more products all the time as new productive capacity is brought into operation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, chief Indian delegate, attacked today the suggestion made by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, during his campaign, that the war in Korea should be fought primarily by Asians against Asians.

IN this city, probably more than anywhere else in the world today, the forces of Orient and Occident are in constant collision, pitting young against old, past against future, hand against machine, war against peace. Here, also, Americans are making their strongest bid for friendship as well as cooperation from Koreans.
OTTAWA, Nov. 8 -- Last Tuesday's election in the United States has provoked much serious thinking in this neighbor nation and a considerable revision of first reactions seems to have resulted.

Richard L. Neuberger's "Toward Restoring States' Rights" (Oct. 26) delineates a constructive program. * * * States' rights is not the antithesis of strong Federal Government. It is the foundation of our political system.

The sun, stars, galaxies and other celestial bodies emit not only light but radio waves which can be converted into sound by a loudspeaker and heard as hisses and which are picked up by large receivers parabolic in shape. The British have been leaders in developing this new technique.
ALBANY, Nov. 8 -- Champion Ensarr Glace, the nation's outstanding standard poodle for the past two years, won best-in-show at the ninth annual event of the Albany Kennel Club today.

MANY years ago the Giants upset the favored Washington Redskins, 14 to 7. The Giants didn't make a first down and they gained precisely one yard rushing all afternoon. It was that last item that cut deepest into the sensitive soul of George Preston Marshall, the owner of the 'Skins.

A FORMER F. B. I. counterintelligence and McCarran committee investigator, Guenther Reinhardt, has added a collection of Soviet terror acts against the United States to communism's ever - growing blood register of means toward its end.

ANTOINE LAURENT LAVOISIER goes down in history as the founder of modern chemistry who was guillotined during the French Revolution. "Only a moment to chop off that head," said Lagrange the mathematician to Delambre, one of the inventors of the metric system, "and a hundred years may not give us another like it."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Asking that the American people "offer a prayer of gratitude for the spirit of unity which binds together all parts of our country," President Truman issued a proclamation today officially setting Thursday, Nov. 27, for the observance of Thanksgiving Day.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 8 -- Notre Dame's inspired Fighting Irish pummeled unbeaten Oklahoma, the nation's No. 4 team, into a fumbling, sputtering victim of a resounding 27-21 upset in a nationally televised football thriller today.
Plans are going forward rapidly for the Thanksgiving tea dance for the benefit of the Judson Health Center to be held on the afternoon of Nov. 20 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

HUGH and his younger sister, Gertrude, lived at Pennsbury, where their cousin, James Harrison, was the manager. So much did they love the property that they too felt as if they were stewards of the place. When the horses had to be sold to meet Penn's debts, it was they who managed to save and hide the valuable Dutch colt, Dapple.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- To a political party that has been out of power for twenty years, anytime is a good time to get back in. But in some ways the Republicans couldn't possibly have picked a more unfortunate moment of history to assume responsibility.

At 1:40 A. M. last Wednesday morning Adlai E. Stevenson went before the television camera in Springfield, Ill., and conceded his defeat in the Presidential election. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had been elected the thirty-fourth President of the United States in a landslide victory.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Wisconsin rolled freely in the first half today but wilted in the second and, aided by a fourth-quarter field goal, nipped Northwestern, 24 -- 20, to remain in contention for the Big Ten football title.

AN ancient entry in the records of the town of Cape Elizabeth, Me., for 1785 sets this novel going, and the pioneer belief in the Calvinistic doctrine of universal damnation keeps it going. The pawn in the church-and-state drama is Dorcas, an old maid in her twenties, who can't seem to get things to add up for her.

Ethel Colt, soprano, appeared at Town Hall yesterday afternoon in a program of "Songs of the Theatre." The program, which was of unusual interest, was made up of operatic and operetta numbers, not often heard in the recital hall.

The auction galleries will strike a high average this week in the quality and quantity of merchandise scheduled for sale. Much period furniture will be on the market, and so will many decorative adjuncts for the home and paintings and prints.

TO open this book is to savor the lovely maudlin joy of sentimental recollection. I see my mother cross and recross her hands to play "I've Waited, Honey. Waited Long for You" on our Circassian walnut Kranach and Bach piano, while the lachrymose melody flows like soothing syrup through my consciousness.

The annual bridge and fashion show of the alumnae of the Academy of Mount St. Vincent, Tuxedo Park, N. Y., will be held next Saturday in the Biltmore. Proceeds will be donated to the scholarship fund of the academy.

MOST historical novels nowadays are "novels" only by courtesy. Historical "entertainments" (to borrow Graham Greene's designation) would be a better name for the majority, which are to the genuine article as a garish cardboard cutout is to a portrait photo by Karsh.

AN annual highpoint for both the editor and the readers of this column is always the volume of prize-winning stories from the contest conducted by Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine. But year by year I get a stronger feeling that, much though I love the collection, this column is not precisely the place to review it.

The fifty-sixth anniversary luncheon of the Mary Washington Colonial Chapter of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution will be held on Nov. 24 in the Tapestry Room of the Park Lane. Mrs. Joseph Madison Carlisle is chairman of the luncheon committee and Mrs. Beekman Aitken is vice chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (AP) -- George H. Earle 3d, former United States Ambassador to Bulgaria, was quoted by The Philadelphia Inquirer tonight as stating he personally handed affidavits to the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1944 signed by high Rumanian and Bulgarian Red Cross officials accusing the Russians of the Katyn Forest massacre.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: The long dry spell this fall endangers not only this season's planting, except for bulbs, but any trees, perennials or shrubs set out during the last year. Thorough watering of the soil is necessary not once but several times before the ground freezes. Light rains are not sufficient. Soak the ground, even under leafless shrubs and trees.

TO children who grow up in a college town the autumn brings a special excitement. Regardless of the calendar, it is the beginning of a new year -- and of the football season. If, like the three Ridgeway children, they live in a house with a tower overlooking the stadium and also have a university quarterback to mow their lawn, they are thrice-blessed.
DOWN here at Cooper Union we were somewhat dismayed to read that "The Best Friend of Charleston" was given credit in "Hear the Train Blow" for making the first successful steam run in America.

THEIR recent annual conference was almost ended when about a hundred and fifty newspaper food editors, who had eaten for five days at a rate that would have finished off lesser gastronomes, filed into the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria's Serf Room to sit down at a luncheon at which the Danish Office of Information was the host.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 2 -- A reorganized Chinese Youth Anti-Communist National Salvation Corps, with membership open to young Chinese men and women from 15 to 30 years of age, has been established here under the joint auspices of the Kuomintang (National party) and the Ministry of National Defense.

I read with interest Arthur Krock's "Is Honesty the Best Political Policy?" (Oct. 5). Surely the best comment on this subject is the advice that your poet, James Russell Lowell, put into the mouth of Homer Biglow:

FORTY-SEVEN years ago, when James M. Barrie's beguiling fantasy. "Peter Pan," was drawing capacity audiences to the Empire Theatre, clusters of women and girls used to wait outside the stage entrance after matinees for a glimpse at Maude Adams, the winsome star of the play.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Solid voting in the United Nations today by the Latin-American and Asian-Arab delegations, working in agreement and helped by the Soviet bloc, defeated the colonial powers, supported by the United States and a few scattered allies, on the issue of supervision of non-self-governing territories.

WHAT was television's role in the landslide victory of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower? No doubt the politicians, professors and researchers will be studying and analyzing the tabulations for months to come with a view to determining video's influence on the final choice.

FOR guidance through life modern man relies mostly on reason. In the Middle Ages, when most men were moved by an unreasoning faith. Maimonides set out to show the compatibility of religion with reason.

THE recently opened 1952 annual of contemporary American painting at the Whitney Museum has stressed the system of rotation of artists to good effect. The number of artists who exhibited the year before is smaller; more than forty have not previously appeared in the annuals, and a number of these give a very good account of themselves.

OBVIOUSLY a mere Easterner cannot hope to understand Texas. He will accept as fact that the state has the largest area and ranches and the largest steaks, and perhaps some of the tallest stories. He also will accept as fact that a Texan has just written, in "Sironia, Texas," a 1,731-page novel that is as long as all modern times.

NOVELS by Oriel Malet have the delicate enchantment of youth on their side. In the case of her latest, an unwanted child moves through adolescent heartbreak to maturity with an unfaltering grace of spirit which transcends the outlines of a familiar divorce problem.

LINDEN, N. J., Nov. 8 -- After two years of surveys and an educational campaign, the Exchange Club has announced plans to purchase a house for the establishment of a mental hygiene clinic. It would begin operation by next Jan. 15.

I SUGGEST that you remove your self-hypnotizing apparatus and see "Limelight" again. The movie is the dullest trash that was ever foisted on the movie-going public, filled with Chaplin's teen-age attempts to be a profound mind, interpreting life with a series of cliches, such as "God helps those who help themselves."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko heard himself criticized today on the ground that he had attempted to disrupt the work of the General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee on economic development of the under-developed countries.

New York today will have its biggest attraction of the professional football season to date. In one of the key games of the National Football League campaign, the New York Giants, tied for first place in the American Conference, will oppose the San Francisco Forty-Niners, National Conference leaders.

KENT, Conn., Nov. 8 -- Scoring once in every period but the third, the Taft School eleven defeated Kent, 20 to 7, before 1,200 fans today. The game was the season's finale for both teams, Taft concluding with a 2-3-1 record and Kent with two victories in six starts.

An unusual benefit, known as a tour of "Private Homes of Public Figures," will be held on Tuesday and Wednesday for the Wellesley College Development Fund. The event has been arranged under the auspices of the New York Wellesley College Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania long a foe of restricted television of college football games, urged today that the program be revised in 1953 with each institution permitted to make its own television arrangements. One-third of all the TV proceeds would go into a special trust fund.
Enrollments for the current academic year at Columbia University have dropped to 25,120, 9 per cent under last year's 27,645, according to official figures released yesterday.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 8 -- Nearly one-half of this city's population of 85,000 turned out today to honor Mayor Charles H. Martens, the nation's longest-term mayor of cities over 50,000.

KINGSTON, R. I., Nov. 8 -- Hard-hitting Abbruzzi scored two touchdowns and pushed his season's ground-gaining total over the 1,000-yard mark as the University of Rhode Island scored a 55-to-7 triumph over a weak Brooklyn College team today.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Pat Oleksiak, third string halfback, sparked a sluggish Tennessee offense with two second-half touchdown passes to give the Volunteers a 22-3 victory over Louisiana State today.
There was a superior item of Tomfoolery at the Jamaica Race Track yesterday.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 8 -- Reports from Spain last week indicated that another strange bedfellow was about to enter the growing world-wide alliance against communism.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Brown broke out of an eleven-game losing streak today with a 21-13 football victory over the University of Connecticut before a 4,500 crowd.

IT has been suggested that in the Ideal Museum, the masterpieces would be exhibited in a few easily accessible galleries from which other galleries containing secondary material would fan out. In Malraux's Imaginary Museum -- which is a museum of reproductions -- objects from cultures remote in time and space are intended to be seen in juxtaposition.

FREEPORT, L. I., Nov. 8 -- The Mepham High School Pirates rallied in the second half to score a 19 -- 7 victory over the Freeport Red Devils in the stadium today for their seventh straight triumph and twelfth in a row over a two-year period.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Tribute to the sisters who dedicate their lives to humanity was paid today by Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, at an open house marking the completion of a $250,000 modernization program at St. Joseph's Home.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 8 -- The Nazi warning, "We shall return," overshadows tomorrow's communal elections, for which almost half the electorate of Federal Germany is eligible. The poll is regarded as the first indication of popular preferences for next year's general election.

IF we accept nature as the sum of all things in the universe which are not human or of man's contriving, it becomes an inexhaustible add nourishing field. To the average man nature cannot fail to be a source of wonder and delight -- fosterer of his thought, instigator and abettor of his joy, sharpener of his consciousness.

THE most beloved of American primitive painters, Edward Hicks, dedicated his life to religious beliefs which convinced him that his gift for art was evil "If the Christian world," he wrote, "were in the real spirit of Christ, I do not believe there would be such a thing as a fine painter in Christendom."

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 8 -- This port, the world's third busiest after New York and London, was completely cut off from the sea for eighteen hours when a freighter crashed through a concrete pier in a gale last night and sank at the entrance to the New Waterway, the channel to this inland harbor.
GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- Turkey has joined the Netherlands in imposing special burdens on United States trade in retaliation for restrictions by the United States on imports of agricultural products.
THE late autumn term is coming up for garden courses. Emphasis is switching from outdoor garden practice to plants and flowers indoors and plans for next season's displays.

OF all the elements present in the sea, probably none has stirred men's dreams more than gold. It is there -- in all the waters covering the greater part of the earth's surface -- enough in total quantity to make every person in the world a millionaire.

BECAUSE limestone is slowly soluble in trickling water, there is a chain of majestic caverns, lost rivers, flowing springs and crater-like sinkholes all the way from Albany to Atlanta. The caves of Virginia, Pennsylvania and New York, Natural Bridge and the great spring that gives Bellefonte, Pa., its name are examples.

BONN, Nov. 8 -- Progress toward European unity in defense, in economics and in political cooperation, which President-elect Eisenhower did so much to foster during his year and a half at SHAPE, has come almost to a stop.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN George Jessel asked cinematographer Charles Clarke to accompany him on a date with a beautiful woman "to light me and make me look good," the gag was a compliment to the globe-trotting workhorse of the Twentieth Century-Fox photographers' stable second only to the thirty-two years of silence generally accorded his nigh-heroic efforts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- The 158-man police force that guards your Congress and the Capitol expects to be dismissed and replaced almost en masse soon after Jan. 3, and Capt. Olin Cavness, the chief, thinks you should know about it.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Samuel D. Sturgis Jr., has been appointed Chief of Army Engineers to succeed Lieut. Gen. Lewis A. Pick, who has been under Congressional criticism recently.

Arturo Toscanini led the N. B. C. Symphony through three works in yesterday's concert broadcast from Carnegie Hall. One of the three was a slight preview of tomorrow night's opening at the Metropolitan Opera. With perhaps a gesture at that august institution, Mr. Toscanini conducted the Overture to Verdi's "La Forza del Destino."

Father Flanagan's Boys Town Choir gave its annual New York concert yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. As on the group's four previous visits, the program was divided, into serious-secular, liturgical and semi-popular secular music, with the fifty boys wearing appropriate costumes for each grouping.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, said on his arrival today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, "is a very old friend of ours" who is known to the British people for his leadership in peace as well as in war.
Thomas J. Hamilton, in "Challenge to the U.N. -- And the U. S." (Oct. 26) states that giving independence to Libya was premature. He should have included Indonesia.
TULSA, Okla., Nov 8 (AP) -- Villanova's hopes of an unbeaten season and a possible football bowl bid were shattered tonight as Tulsa's Hurricanes struck for a 42-6 victory on Skelly Field.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Quarterback Tommy O'Connell shattered three Big Ten passing records today to lead Illinois to a 33-to-13 victory over Iowa before 44,855 fans in Iowa Stadium.
NOW that the egg-heads and the pin-heads, the round-heads and the square-heads have had their say, somebody ought to go to work on the problem of how to elect a President of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Labor Department estimated today that 200,000 Korean veterans would collect unemployment pay under the new G. I. bill between now and July 1.
LONDON, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers crushed Manchester City, 7 -- 3, today to take a clear lead in the first division of English soccer.
The bartender of kings, and therefore perhaps the king of bartenders, arrived in New York yesterday for a two-week visit to the plush hotels of the New World.

ALTHOUGH "In an Age of Revolution," written by the Archbishop of York, deals primarily with the British scene and is principally intended for British readers, it is of acute interest and importance to Americans. The author surveys over seventy years of revolutionary change which he himself has seen, culminating now in "one of the greatest crises in history."

SOUTHERN historians in their concentration upon the antebellum and reconstruction eras "have unwittingly left their history open at both ends, with neither a beginning nor a conclusion." So writes Carl Bridenbaugh in the preface to this volume of lectures in Southern history which he delivered last year at Louisiana State University.

KATHARINE HEPBURN is a millionairess. Shrewdness, insight, intelligence and an abundant talent made her a millionairess. The movies she made in Hollywood have hit the million mark many times. Miss Hepburn has earned leisure but she has forsaken the rocking chair to dive energetically and head-long into the difficult role of a rarely performed play, "The Millionairess," now at the Shubert Theatre.

A QUARTER-CENTURY ago Margaret Kennedy enchanted the reading world with "The Constant Nymph," a first novel with the morning freshness, the poignance and immediacy, and the verbal spell of poetry. It is a pleasure to report that the magic has not departed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Possibly as many as 12,000 Federal officeholders are either in the market for new jobs today or wondering and worrying about what the voters' decision at the polls last Tuesday will mean to them and their families.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Presidential election has broken not only the Solid South but also the whole unlikely coalition of right-wing Southerners and left-wing Northerners formed by President Franklin D. Roosevelt and continued through the Truman Administration.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- The seventh general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization will open here on Wednesday with major emphasis on the extension and improvement of education, particularly in the world's backward areas.
ON THE CENTRAL FRONT, Korea, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Just how good is the Republic of Korea's Army?

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 8 -- After years of discussion, efforts of New York savings bankers to solve their "biggest real problem," the establishment of additional branch offices, is no nearer to peaceful solution.

Spring is a time of looking forward, autumn a time of looking back. Perhaps that is why the poets write cheerful verses about spring and the pleasures of summer to come, but tend to grow melancholy when they consider what someone has called "the Sabbath of the year."
The South is emerging rapidly as a furniture distribution center on a par with the industry kingpin -- Chicago.

The education of free men for the responsibilities of a democratic society is a fundamental purpose of church-supported colleges, Dr. David Marion Delo asserted yesterday after being installed as the twelfth president of Wagner College.

Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 2 in C minor, one of the composer's earliest symphonies, will be the highlight of the Wednesday noon to 2 P. M. recorded concert at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The work, which will be played in its entirety, was recorded by the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos.

Many persons in society have subscribed to the Friday night performance of Shaw's comedy, "The Millionairess," with Katharine Hepburn, at the Shubert Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Child Study Association. Heading the executive committee for the benefit as co-chairmen are Mrs. Nelson Doubleday, Mrs. Frank J. Karelsen Jr. and Mrs. Jacques C. Nordeman.

WRITING once more of Carolina's early growth and struggle, Miss Fletcher sets her new novel in the month of June, 1788. The debate about the newly framed Constitution is stirring up anger and bitterness among the thirteen states.

A young pharmacist admitted yesterday that he had set fire to a laboratory on the third floor of the School of pharmacy at Fordham University in the Bronx on the night of Jan. 1, 1949, to destroy traces of his search for narcotics.

TO ONE who has grown up with "Aida" in the opera house it was hard to believe that any one would attempt to give the piece another home. For "Aida" is one of the grandest of grand operas, made for the vast spaces of theatres like the Metropolitan, the Scala and the other lyric theatres of the world.

A LOOK often gives lie to a label. So it is with Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres, one of the most individual and greatest of French nineteenth - century painters, whose textbook designation as a "Classicist" has turned many modern eyes from full appreciation of his genius.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 8 -- Senator Eugene D. Millikin of Colorado, a financial expert and powerful pre-convention supporter of Senator Robert A. Taft, became the first person on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's calling list when he arrived here at 11:11 o'clock tonight by plane from Denver. He expects to see General Eisenhower tomorrow.

The Ladies' Aid Society of the Lenox Hill Hospital will hold annual card party for the benefit of the hospital on Nov. 25 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf- Astoria. Miss Carrie L. Seeger is chairman of the benefit. Mrs. Carl Eggers is president of the society.

Representatives of American newspapers will join with city officials and members of the Board of Education Thursday night in dedication ceremonies for new Public School 18, the Bronx, named for John Peter Zenger, pre-Revolutionary publisher who was responsible for establishing freedom of the press in this country.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 8 -- Two accidents in which three men were killed at the recently rebuilt Burnet Street traffic circle here were the result of negligence on the part of the drivers and not owing to faulty construction, Edward Kilpatrick, State Highway Engineer, said yesterday in answer to widespread criticism brought about by the fatalities.

More than three years after the armistice between the State of Israel and the Arab states there are 850,000 Arab refugees who once lived in the territory that is now Israel. As long as these unfortunates are unsettled and unhappy the peace of the Middle East is that much less secure.

MOSCOW, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, published today the text of a message of "good wishes" to the Soviet people sent by the United States State Department on the thirty-fifth anniversary of the 1917 revolution.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 8 -- Aids to navigation will be maintained until the first of the year and the United States Coast Guard will provide icebreakers in an effort to lengthen the Great Lakes shipping season, it was reported today.

ALTHOUGH the spring snowflake (Leucojum vernum) is a dainty-looking flower, it is quite capable of taking care of itself in competition with weeds and grass. It is only when man intercedes and moves it to an unfavorable site that difficulty is encountered.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 8 -- Bolivia's nationalization of the country's bigger tin mines is the most recent demonstration of a strictly emotional -- non-logical -- wave of national feeling that is sweeping South America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- From 60 to 80 per cent of all workers and shoppers look to city street car and bus systems for transportation, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States said today in urging business men to help solve some of the problems driving many transit companies into municipal ownership.

Exchange-of-persons programs, now involving nearly 35,000 persons from abroad studying or training in the United States, and another 15,000 Americans studying abroad, are now being built on a foundation of basic and intensive research.

The Christmas Fair, sponsored by the Women's Association of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street, will be held on Thursday and Friday at the church. Proceeds will aid local relief work and mission projects at home and abroad.

WITH nonfigurative painters in general, and certainly with four of them exhibiting this week, the spectator will doubtless conclude that a preoccupation with matters of style supersedes all others. The artist, however, is quick to resent such observations, as if style, that is a pictorial vocabulary, feeling for color, etc., were no more than a handmaiden to the emotional and intellectual impulses that lie behind it.

LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Franklin and Marshall's unbeaten Diplomats overwhelmed a tired Ursinus eleven in the fourth period today to rack up a 68-19 victory after the scrappy losers had scared the Parents Day crowd of 5,000 by holding the favorite hometowners to a half-time tie.
PARIS, Nov. 8 -- By a vote of 324 to 128 the French National Assembly tonight reversed its decision to cut down by one-third the amount allotted to the Ministry for Overseas Territories.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 8 (UP) -- The Southern California Trojans put on a brilliant aerial circus today that led them to a 54-to-7 slaughter of the Stanford Indians before a crowd of 50,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- The spectacular and often stormy career of Dr. Painless Parker, nationally known San Francisco dentist, came to a close today. Dr. Parker died of a heart ailment in Permanente Hospital here at the age of 80.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Police Lieut. C. H. Knight reported today the capture and confession of 16-year-old Claus J. Eischen on a charge of slaying his parents in Kearny, N. J., on Oct. 23. Lieutenant Knight said the youth quickly admitted he had shot his father and mother, because "I had a part-time job and my family wanted me to quit school and take a full-time job."

FROM out of the Hollywood lots last week came word, more authentic than usually is the case, that George Tabori, the Hungarian journalist, novelist, film writer and playwright, is ready for another tussle with the Broadway theatre critics.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- The second United Nations commemorative stamp will be issued on Human Rights Day, Dec. 10.

One of the current, top-drawer union goals is to see that all pension agreements allow wage-earners to change jobs without losing the amount stashed away for them in the company's retirement fund. At first glance this seems to be an uncommonly reasonable demand.

A formal preview of one hundred prize-winning paintings of Christmas will be held on Dec. 10 at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, for the benefit of the United States National Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

THE first day of his vacation, Jamie Bassett, a salty young Cape Codder, tangled with a couple of new kids, mislaid the family dinghy and justified once again his absentminded reputation. The next day he discovered a retired British naval officer camping on a deserted island, in company with an individualistic donkey, and there began one of those friendships which mean so much to both adult and boy.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 8 -- Pittsburgh unleashed a surprising aerial attack here today to upset Ohio State, 21 -- 14, before 75,120 fans.

Plans are being advanced by frequent meetings for the annual Bachelors' Ball which will take place on the night of Dec. 13 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza. The event, a subscription dance, has been arranged under the direction of Mrs. W. Montgomery Wilcox for young women who made their debuts in recent seasons and for bachelors between the ages of twenty-two and thirty-five years.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- A political feud between President Truman and Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, that has delayed for more than two years the appointment of two judges for the Northern District of Illinois puts these appointments on the list to be made by the new Republican Administration.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 8 -- Political analysts see in the results of Tuesday's voting in Hudson County, where Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson received a slim plurality of 7,500 votes, a definite weakness in the Democratic forces of Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City.
DENVER, Colo. -- The term "suspension bridge" has come to mean such mammoths of modern engineering as the George Washington or Golden Gate spans, but Colorado has another and very different kind.

BEFORE the New York City Ballet gets at its season's novelties, there is still time to slip in a few observations on stage and film activities in which dancing is a contributory, though by no means a major, element.

The majority of our parks, national, state and local, have been almost overwhelmed by a wave of vandalism in the last few years. This is deplorable. It seems especially tragic in Yellowstone National Park, where the great geyser basins are located. These rare mani festations of nature are at once unique and vulnerable to vandalism.

Standing on line outside the Metropolitan Opera House for the right to buy standing room to the opening performance, once was a project for only the most rugged of individualists. It has now been collectivized, without benefit of commisars.

Brooklyn Prep swept honors yesterday in the cross-country championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at Van Cortlandt Park. Nineteen teams from all boroughs participated in the event.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Charges that Tobias E. Diamond, United States Attorney for the Northern District of Iowa, used his official position to attempt to force a settlement of an $8,000 claim for a civil client will be inquired into by the judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives investigating the Department of Justice.

" The nuclear physicist has opened to us a new world -- like Columbus on the shore of a continent without an airplane to cross it -- but the civil engineer will be called on to build its foundations, its containers."

BETTY FURNESS, who leaped into national prominence on TV as a demonstrator of home appliances, is going to get a program of her own.

IF you want a Kodiak bearskin to keep you warm, shoot the one-ton critter at a high elevation in the mountains of the north. The pelt will be much furrier and thicker than that on a bear which makes its habitat at sea level.
ALBANY, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A. F. L. truck drivers in eastern New York had started a strike today as the result of the breakdown of negotiations for a new contract.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Business activity in the Chicago area continued to move ahead, paced by heavy industries and the big electronics firms. Retail trade, however, after a marked upturn in the first few weeks of October, settled back under the impact of pre-election week dullness and moderate temperatures.

BUSINESS has much to hope for in the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President of the United States. For the first time in twenty years there is reason to believe that cordial relations will exist between Government and business, instead of the mutual suspicion and distrust which generally marked the last two decades.

THE recent announcement of Pan American World Airways that it would buy British commercial jet airliners has led some Americans to wonder why jet transports are not ready in this country. DESPITE protests from labor unions, Hollywood's movie makers will continue to operate on a world-wide scale in 1953. At present seventeen pictures are scheduled to be made during the coming year on locations ranging from neighboring Mexico to remote Ceylon.
Former Postmaster General James A. Farley said yesterday that the loss of the Catholic vote was an important cause of the Democratic defeat at the polls last Tuesday.

The performances of two plays during the first week in December have been taken over by the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, 331 East Seventieth Street. MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 8 -- An Minnesota outplayed favored Purdue today, but had to be content with a 14-14 tie when a pass interference call set up a Boilermaker touchdown in the final two minutes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, a leading advocate of governmental economy, thinks the Eisenhower Administration can give a tax cut to the American people within two years.

IN his reply to ray review of his book "The Skin" (Sept. 21) Curzio Malaparte has put forward a brief account of his record as an anti-Fascist. Several hundred merchants and employes of the textile industry in lower Broadway will assemble at 81 Worth Street tomorrow morning to donate blood to the Red Cross mobile unit there.

The thirty-seventh National Hotel Exposition will open at Grand Central Palace for a five-day run at 3 P. M. tomorrow. About 500 exhibits will cover a wide range of products of interest to executives, purchasing agents, department heads and other officials of hotels, restaurants, clubs, schools, hospitals, institutions, motels, railroads, airlines, steamship lines and caterers, as well as decorators, builders and architects.
WACO, Tex., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Texas rolled 74 yards against the clock today to beat Baylor's Bears, 35 -- 33, in one of the wildest of Southwest Conference football games.

Her book presents a sincere, often penetrating and sometimes caustic picture of the doctor today and the public he serves.

The Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy and the Greek National Theatre will be the beneficiaries of a pre-opening performance of "Electra" by players of the Greek National Theatre on Nov. 18 at the Mark Hellinger Theatre.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- Industrial employment is continuing its upturn, despite lack of basic materials in some lines, partly as a lingering aftermath of the steel strike. In durable goods most of the larger manufacturers are seeking additional production and technological help.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 8 (UP) --Michigan combined a powerful offense and a rugged defense today to trounce Cornell, 49 to 7. The Big Red could cross the midfield stripe only twice.
A new community of small estates in Westchester County, with each home occupying a p/ot of at least an acre, has been started offl Palmer Lane near Bear Ridge Road in Pleasantville.

VIENNA, Nov. 8 -- Whether the Republican victory in the United States will mean the cessation of American aid to Austria has become the subject of lively discussion in political circles here.
The operations of the New York State Assembly were presented yesterday at the Staten Island Borough Hall in St. George by 100 high school students representing sixteen Hi-Y clubs throughout the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- The widest and wooliest scoring duel witnessed at Franklin Field in many a moon saw Georgia out-scramble favored Pennsylvania, 34 to 27, before 45,000 spectators today. Five of the contest's nine touchdowns came in a hectic third period, with the Dixie Bulldogs getting the odd one that represented their final margin of victory.

The United Israel Appeal announced last night a budget of $102,200,000 for 1953 to carry out its resettlement, rehabilitation and productivity programs among the record influx of immigrants in Israel.

ON U. S. Highway 85, which winds through New Mexico, a hill called the Descent (La Bajada) becomes the scene of a chain smash-up of cars and the climax of Fritz Peters' latest novel. Here, with one dramatic punch, the author frees his characters from the psychological confusion which seems the one thing they have in common.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 8 -- A belief that it was easier to sleep off all-day drinking sprees at home than amid the gunfire from the sound track in all-night movies brought to an end today a week of high living on ill-gotten gains for a hospital chauffeur here.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- British politics have been simmering while the American political kettle boiled over. The most interesting fact about trends in this country is that, with the growth in the strength of Bevanism within the Labor party, the Conservatives have been gaining.

MONTREAL, Nov. 8 (UP) -- After being frustrated for three games, Maurice (Rocket) Richard finally established a new National Hockey League scoring record when he rapped in the 325th goal of his career tonight as the Montreal Canadiens whipped the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 to 4.

A directory containing information about all the existing psychiatric facilities in the state has been prepared under the auspices of the New York State Mental Health Commission, it was disclosed recently with the release of the commission's second annual report.

Four touchdowns, equally, divided, were scored in the Fordham-Clemson clash at Randalls Island yesterday, but neither side was able to convert and a 12-12 stalemate resulted. The Rams, still seeking their first victory of the campaign, were not overly elated with the deadlock because they had the last crack at an extra point and failed.

ZANE GREY, the one-time dentist who astounded literary critics by turning a mixture of hoofbeats and purple sage into a million dollars, loved to fish. Say what you will about the style or substance of his forty-nine Western novels, but when talk gets around to shark, swordfish, tuna and far-off fishing grounds few anglers have ever topped Grey's tales for sheer drama and wild, contagious excitement.

There is a large reservation list for the dinner dance and entertainment known as the Indian Summer Dinner Dance to be held on Friday night in the Embassy Room and Garden of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association.

IN the Sunday papers of Nov. 11, 1923, there were advertisements of forthcoming recitals by Emma Calve, Paderewski, Rachmaninoff and De Pachmann, all of whom have since gone to their rest. But a new organization that advertised its "opening concert" for that night is still very much part of the local scene.

THE fourteen essays in this volume span two centuries of our history. LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 8 (UP) -- Big Steve Mielinger, Kentucky's candidate for all-America, personally battered Tulane into submission from three different positions today as Kentucky won a 27-6 Southeastern Conference victory before 31,000 fans.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. G. Wright will give a dinner on Dec. 20 in their home at 1 West Seventy-second Street before the Junior Assembly at the Plaza, to introduce Mrs. Wright's daughter, Miss Pauline Hammond Rathbone. The debutante is the daughter also of the late John Rankin Rathbone, onetime member of the British Parliament who was killed while serving with the Royal Air Force during the second World War.

A rapid rate of increase of scientific personnel in the Soviet Union is reported in the current issue of Science, official publication of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. The report, based on an analysis of recent Soviet official publications, was presented by Demitri Shimkin of the Russian Research Center at Harvard University.

JUST a year ago, a unique traffic court was established here in Baltimore -- for teen-agers only. Its sponsor was Chief Traffic Magistrate Stanley Scherr. Its basis was the fact that teen-agers are the most numerous offenders among any age groups in breaking traffic laws and causing highway accidents.

CAVOUR, Wis., Nov. 8 (AP) -- One trainman was killed and four injured early today when a Soo Line fast freight, west-bound for Minneapolis, smashed into a similar twin-unit Diesel freight standing at a station in this northern Wisconsin village.

THE impact of automobiles and motoring on the face of America during the past half-century now is slated as a subject for the screen. The news is that Richard deRochemont has acquired movie rights to "Fill 'Er Up," the book by Bellamy Partridge published last month under the aegis of McGraw-Hill.

Watch bracelets will be offered as Christmas gifts for the first time this year, manufacturers said last week. Generally considered a necessity to be replaced only when worn out, the item now is expected to be an important factor in jewelry store holiday sales.

The annual card party for the benefit of the American Women's Unit for War Relief, Inc., will be held tomorrow afternoon at the Duchesne Residence, 7 East Ninety-first Street. Miss Frances Coleman, president of the beneficiary, heads the committee to charge of the arrangements for the benefit and assisting her are officer and members of the organization's board of directors.

Mrs. Amelia Marie Propper, a Protestant Episcopal deaconess obligingly celebrated her birthday two days early yesterday to allow her friends and relatives, who are not so casual as the venerable lady is about 104th birthdays, to come to town for the occasion.

THE admirable survey of the first six years of the United Nations by A. H. Feller could not have come at a better time. WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- The Army, now building heavy tanks, may have enough ready for field tests by next spring.

A long voyage -- almost ten and a half months from port to port -- will come to an end today when the Prudential Steamship Line's Newberry Victory arrives in port under tow of the powerful Dutch tug Zwarte Zee.

The Conservative party has won a neat little victory in England which seems to show that the political wind has shifted again. The by-election at High Wycombe on Wednesday was only a straw in that wind, but there have been others during the last three months, and notably a short swing of the pendulum away from the Labor party at a previous by-election in the Cleveland division of Yorkshire.

THE great majority of those who take to the deer woods during the next four weeks, which constitute the height of the Eastern season, will return home without venison. Many of them will not so much as see a deer, and an even larger number will not get a shot at one.

On the day following the grand finale of one of the most important and decisive political campaigns in history I think a chorus of praise and gratitude should go to our major radio, television and press associations for their magnificent coverage of the entire campaign and especially for the brilliant manner in which they brought the climax to a vast audience.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Representative John Taber, Republican of New York, who is slated to head the Appropriations Committee in the new House of Representatives said today that he would set up a staff of "minute men" to keep a close check on "loafer" Federal employes and government extravagance.

HERE is a new story about the same little girl first met in "A Pony for Linda." Linda likes to read about Indians and it is easy to imagine, riding her pony along an old trail, that Indians are all about her. Seeing smoke rising, Linda rides on the source of this "signal fire" and into a real adventure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Republican National Committee appointed today Joseph C. McGarraghy, chairman of the Republican State Committee for the District of Columbia, as chairman of the Citizens Inaugural Committee, that will make plans for the inauguration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, on Jan. 20.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 8 -- A radio telescope is being constructed at the Agassiz station of the Harvard College Observatory at Harvard, Mass., in preparation for a program of research in radio astronomy, Provost Paul H. Buck announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- About all that can be said with certainty at this time about the legislative program of the Republican Administration that will come into power next Jan. 20 is that it will fall somewhere between the glowing Utopian promises of its advocates and the calamitous predictions of its detractors.

JAYWALKERS will see themselves as others see them in a new booklet, entitled "Wacky Walkers," sponsored as part of a national campaign by the Inter-Industry Highway Safety Committee to reform the more careless pedestrians.

The exhibition of paintings and drawings by Ingres, lent by the Museum of Montauban in France, will open with a preview on Tuesday night at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, and will continue there through Nov. 29.

The election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President of the United States has created within the shipping industry an atmosphere of confidence and expectation unsurpassed since the days immediately following the passage of the Merchant Marine Act of 1936.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, today voiced confidence that Congressional investigators would get access under the incoming Eisenhower Administration to many documents denied them during twenty years of Democratic sway.

NORTH PLATTE, Neb., Nov. 8 -- Nebraska's Republican Governor-elect said today he favored moving the statue of William Jennings Bryan from its position of prominence on the steps of the Statehouse.
ALBANY, Nov. 8 (UP) -- George O. Williams, managing editor of The Albany Times-Union, collapsed and died tonight while dining at a restaurant here. He was 62 years old.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Nov. 8 (AP) -- The president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association said today that the American press had exerted great influence in the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for President.

The laying of cornerstones for three new buildings, several educational conferences, an academic convocation and jubilee banquet marked the celebration last week of the fiftieth anniversary of Simmons College (Boston). The theme of the two-day program, which attracted several thousand visitors and alumnae from all over the country, was "A Mid-Century Review of the Place of Women in Society."
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 8 (UP) -- Holy Cross capitalized on a pair of fumbles today as Charlie Maloy tossed two touchdown passes for a 13-7 victory over Colgate before 10,000 snow-swept fans.
GROTON, Mass., Nov. 8 -- St. Mark's School upset Groton School, 27 to 12, in the sixty-sixth renewal of their series before 2,000 fans who sat out a blizzard today.

The problems raised by Marshall Plan economic aid to Europe have recently received increasing attention both here and abroad. Perhaps regrettably the discussion thus far appears to indicate agreement on the premise that economic aid of the Marshall Plan type has been appropriate in the past.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Nov. 8 -- A top-ranking Communist leader said today that the Red guerrillas in the Malayan jungle were facing starvation, that there was a shortage of manpower, and that the rebellion was doomed to failure.

AN Irishman belonging to the English Province of the Jesuits, Father Brodrick has long enjoyed a high reputation as a historian. Now he has added to his laurels with what is certainly the best book on Francis Xavier in any language.

LIONEL BARRYMORE, a man of many talents, disclosed in his sixties that in addition to being an actor, both screen and legit, a scenario writer, film director, painter and watercolorist, he was also a composer.
LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- British Communists and members of the British Union Movement clashed tonight in an ugly street brawl touched off by a Red-led rally attended by the "Red Dean" of Canterbury.

A SMALL man sat at a table in the oldest club in the United States. The waiter brought lettuce and the ingredients for a salad dressing, which the diner insisted on making himself. Pointing to the lettuce, he said: "It's all wet. Bring me a napkin."

THE history of the short biographical-critical study of modern and classical writers has not been a particularly happy one. Excepting the older English Men of Letters Series and the recent Makers of Modern Literature and Modern European Novelists Series, no planned group of brief studies has escaped the danger of dullness and the danger of superficiality.
Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, ruled himself out of consideration yesterday for appointment to the Cabinet or Supreme Court.

In his reply to the letter of Philip Pearl of the A. F. L. (Oct. 26) Arthur Krock seems to have lost sight of the fact that this country has had nation-wide strikes both before and after the enactment of Taft-Hartley without coming apart at the seams.

VICTORIAN in setting, whimsical in approach, "Mouse Manor," says its author, was inspired (like a great many other books) by Beatrix Potter. Such a statement, even by its creator, invites an unfair comparison.

A 19-yard pass from Quarterback Mike Green to Nat Diamond, substitute end, in the end zone on the last play of the game enabled Abraham Lincoln High's football team to upset James Madison, 13 to 7, in their game at Lincoln Field in Brooklyn yesterday.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 8 -- Lehigh University spotted Muhlenberg College two touchdowns in the first quarter and then took charge to roll up a 26-13 victory before 7,500 fans today.
ATHENS, Nov. 8 -- About 1,000 candidates will compete for 300 seats in Greece's single-chamber Parliament on Election Day, Nov. 16.
SOME like their science hot. Some like it cold. The readers of the second group will probably find Denning Miller's explanation of the mysteries of modern meteorology the most attractive.

LOS ANGELES -- While most of the rest of the nation is thinking in terms of overcoats and antifreeze, California is just teeing up for the final month of fall its three-month winter season not officially beginning until December.

A FESTIVAL OF FREEDOM to be held in Switzerland some time in 1954 was proposed here last week by Florian Niederer, assistant general manager of the Swiss National Tourist Office, in a talk before the New York Travel Writers Association.

By the end of the year, the huge modern apartment building in Marseille, designed by the architect Le Corbusier, will be fully occupied. It took five years to build and cost $6,000,000. It contains 337 living units that will house approximately 1,500 people; an interior street, a stadium, swimming pool, bar, kindergarten and playground, restaurant, hotel and post office.
Re: "Toward States' Rights," I would add that we want programs and funds by the Federal Government and administration of them by the states because:
The American Management Association will begin tomorrow a new program designed to alleviate the shortage of qualified top executives.

The Republican victory at the polls last week generally is considered to have removed much of the uncertainty that has enveloped the oil industry at home and abroad. Under the new Administration to be headed by General Eisenhower some of the stumbling blocks to a further great expansion of the industry are expected to be removed.
Many United States exporters have run out of patience over the delay in payments of debts owed them by Brazilian importers, it was evident last week.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 8 -- Princeton scored its sixth successive victory over Harvard today, the longest sequence of success for either team in the history of their football rivalry, which dates back seventy-five years to 1877.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sunday, Nov. 9 -- President Chaim Weizmann of Israel died at 6:30 this morning in his home in Rehovot, near here, after a long illness. He would have been 78 years old on Nov. 27.

IN "The Taming of the Nations'' F. S. C. Northrop has again written a profound tract for the times, times grown more perilous since he published "The Meeting of East and West." This effort, like his others, is perhaps too intellectual to be read by those who run from crisis to crisis.

BILLED as "the inside story of Voodoo as practiced on the island of Haiti" (and its author as "America's foremost religious researcher") "Strange Altars" turns out to be a lot less sensational and considerably more informative than it looks. Marcus Bach's mind was so open when he came to Haiti that he appears not to have read any of the reliable books dealing with his subject.

Out of the mists of history and legend there emerges the character of an ancient Greek king, Nestor of Pylos. Nestor, according to Homer and Greek tradition, had had a stormy youth. His brothers had been butchered by Heracles, but this episode did not seem to dampen his spirits too much, for we find him in the Iliad, a man of 70, boasting of the athletic exploits of his younger days.
