A number of steamship lines transporting cargo from Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay to New York have instituted a new schedule of terminal charges here, effective Dec. 1. The companies are subscribers to what is known as the East Coast South America/New York Free Time Agreement.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- A letter written by Abraham Lincoln to his physician, Dr. Anson, G. Henry, July 4, 1860, has been given to the Illinois State Historical Society by Dr. Karl A. Meyer, superintendent of the Cook County Hospital and a collector of Lincolniana, it was revealed today.

Your editorial "For Korea's Children" was of special interest to me since I have just returned from a brief but intensive visit to the enormous, swarming refugee centers of South Korea. People in these centers -- from the embattled areas around Seoul down to the squatter-cities near Pusan -- face tragic suffering during the next months.

Although countless children may try to hide the fact from unsuspecting parents, and an equal number of teachers may dread meeting Junior's Mom and Dad, Open School Week is upon us. This phenomenon of education -parent watching teacher instruct offspring -- is a yearly occurrence in these parts, and while to some it may appear a time of dread, to most Open School Week is an opportunity.

Philip Murray hadn't been a well man for several years, but when he died suddenly yesterday, in San Francisco, he had just addressed a conference of steelworkers and was about to go to Los Angeles for a meeting of the C. I. O. executive board. He was tired but he hadn't let down.

A courageous cab driver yesterday took a loaded automatic from a man he accuses of having held him up earlier. He then kept the man subdued in a tavern at Thirtieth Street and Ninth Avenue until police arrived. The accused man allegedly had held up and robbed another taxi driver an hour earlier.

As the agency that translates the ideas and instructions of city, state and Federal legislators into brick-and-concrete dwellings for thousands of men, women and children, the New York City Housing Authority has wrought many changes in this city's appearance in the last few years.

A two-story dwelling on lot 89 by 90 feet at 104-25 Farmers Boulevard, St. Albans, Queens, was sold by Frank M. Powell to Ralph Cennamo, who insured title with the Security Title and Guaranty Company.

A conclusive 23 -- 14 upset victory over the San Francisco Forty-Niners before 50,880 fans at the Polo Grounds yesterday kept the New York Giants deadlocked with the Cleveland Browns for the American Conference lead in the National Football League.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 4 -- Five young United States farmers representing the 4-H Club who last week finished a four-month program of living and working with Israeli farmers not only learned a lot about Israel but also taught their hosts a thing or two about the United States.

MADRID, Nov. 1 -- Egiz, a clandestine anti-Government periodical published by Basque nationalist priests, which was suppressed last month under a decree issued by the Roman Catholic bishops of the San Sebastian, Vitoria and Bilbao dioceses in northern Spain, will resume publication shortly.

The observance of the thirty-fourth anniversary of the armistice ending hostilities in World War I began yesterday with memorial services and reunions of veterans' organizations and will reach a climax tomorrow with traditional parades in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

One of the strange things about Michael Field's piano playing last night in Town Hall was the fact that the easiest piece, technically speaking, gave him the most trouble. That was Beethoven's D minor Sonata, Schoenberg's Op. 23 pieces and Schumann's "Carnaval" went better, though the finger work was far from impeccable.
A third Israeli flag line has been organized for service between the United States and the Mediterranean.

DURBAN, South Africa, Nov. 9 -- Gun-wielding South African policemen tonight still battled rioting Negroes who put the torch to at least five municipal and Government buildings in a Negro settlement in suburban East London.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Robert Hall, chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's television committee, warned today that unrestricted television of college football games would "create a football aristocracy of fifteen or twenty colleges which would mean the death of the sport."

NEWARK, Nov. 9 -- A sealed lead box, discovered in August in the demolition of the old Halsey Street Methodist Church, which had been built in 1809 and reconstructed in 1851, was opened today in the First Methodist Church, 227 Market Street, at vesper services attended by 200 members of the congregation.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 9 (UP) -West Germany rejected today an Arab League demand that it cancel its agreement to pay Israel $715,000,000 in goods as restitution for Nazi war crimes against the Jews.

The sixty-eighth season of the Metropolitan Opera will be opened tonight with a completely new production of Verdi's "La Forza del Destino." It will be the first time that this opera has been the inaugural.

After a rest of three days, the competitors in the women's world tournament resumed play, yesterday, in the tenth round in Moscow, but only one decision, affecting the leadership, was recorded, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.

A dessert suitably festive to be the climax at a dinner party often poses a problem for the hostess, especially if she does not have time to prepare it herself. Fortunately, there are obliging individuals who, for a fee, will concoct in their home or bakery delicacies unusual and delectable.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 9 -- A tradition of more than two and a half centuries ended today with the War Office announcement here and in London that it was obliged to withdraw the British garrison. British troops have been stationed here for 251 years, but the closing down of the garrison has long been expected.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Britain will withdraw her garrison of troops from Bermuda beginning this month, the War Office announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Members of the Catholic Association for International Peace were told at their silver jubilee conference today that they would "prove faithless" to their tradition if they ignored the teachings of Pope Pius XII looking toward world peace.

Raising of the world's standard of living would result in record peacetime prosperity, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, former rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, declared in a sermon yesterday morning.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 9 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower notified President Truman by wire this evening that he had named Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts as his primary liaison representative in Washington on all matters except the Federal budget and Joseph M. Dodge of Detroit as his personal representative on budgetary affairs.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (AP) -The Philadelphia Eagles found their running shoes for the first time this season and combined their running with the effective passing of Bobby Thomason to rout the Washington Redskins, 38-20, before 16,932 at Shibe Park today.

In "a time of confusion and crisis," the Rev. Dr. John Paul Jones said in a sermon yesterday morning at Union Church (Presbyterian), Ridge Boulevard and Eightieth Street, Brooklyn, "religion must be loyal to basic truth and heavily supported by common sense."

Twelve hundred delegates representing various sections of the country, attending the final session of the sixteenth annual convention of the United Israel Appeal at the Commodore Hotel, paid solemn tribute yesterday at a special memorial session to Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Israel's first President, distinguished scientist and statesman.
ALBANY, Nov. 9 -- Publication of a book to assist school personnel in reducing juvenile delinquency was announced today by Lee C. Dowling, executive director of the New York State Youth Commission.
PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Real effort is being made by the French Government and business circles to increase financial and trade transactions between France and Spain.

BONN, Germany. Nov. 9 -- A new report on the situation of the Jewish communities in Western Germany, prepared in terms of relief needs but covering the general aspects of community life, stresses the continued deterioration of opportunities for Jewish integration in the country.

A drastic reorganization to permit nation-wide representation on the board of the American National Theatre and Academy, which operates under a Congressional charter, is about to be realized. The change originally was advocated at the National Theatre Assembly held here in January, 1951.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Trade activity in grain and soybean futures was comparatively slow last week. Average purchases were 42,000,000 bushels for the four-day week, compared with 45,000,000 the week before and 66,000,000 for the corresponding 1951 week.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- The Screen Actors Guild tonight called on motion-picture producers and the entertainment industry in general to provide greater employment opportunities for Negro artists, who, it was asserted, have suffered "inadvertent harm" because of a "well-intentioned but ill-directed" effort to avoid wounding racial sensibilities that has resulted in loss of work for Negroes in the movies.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 9 -- Yet another promise that the "European soldiers of German nationality" will be free of Prussian militarism was offered to the German nation tonight by Theodor Blank, adviser to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer on defense problems.

The financing of New Jersey's Garden State Parkway, a project just authorized by referendum to be backed by the state's taxing power, will take the form of a "well-spaced" public sale of bonds in blocks of from $50,000,000 to $60,000,000 over two or three years, Bayard L. England, vice chairman and treasurer of the New Jersey Highway Authority, announced yesterday.

A memorial service for members of the city's Police Department was held yesterday afternoon at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street, under the auspices of the Shomrim Society, the organization of Jewish members of the department.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 -- Philip Murray, who made his way from the coal pits of Scotland into one of the most powerful jobs in organized labor, the presidency of the 4,000,000-member Congress of Industrial Organizations, died of a heart attack today in his room at the Mark Hopkins Hotel here.

GROSTENQUIN, France, Nov. 8 -- Quietly and efficiently the Canadians have developed a jet fighter base here in the last four months that will compare -- in speed of construction, operational efficiency and living conditions for officers and men -- with any of the twenty-one other North Atlantic Treaty Organization air bases already built in France.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 9 -- Terming the McCarran Immigration Act "dangerous to our American tradition," Senator Hubert Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said here tonight that the Eisenhower Administration should amend the new law, which will become effective next month.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman was honored last night by Yeshiva University for his services as a defender of freedom and human rights.

As the weather grows colder one begins to pay more attention in these latitudes to advertisements prepared, with dash and imagination, by winter resorts where it never rains and all women are beautiful as they run laughing, and with their hair flying in the sea air, from the gentle surf.
Attractive aprons for mothers and little girls are brought to you today by Patterns of The Times. There are four patterns in all, each by Advance.

Because of a lack of public information "linking people to the services they need," only one out of four unmarried women awaiting the birth of their children here are assisted by the city's public and privately operated agencies, Raymond M. Hilliard, executive director of the Welfare and Health Council said yesterday.
Benjamin Lees and Charles Jones were the composers represented on the Saturday evening Composers Forum at the McMillin Theatre, Columbia University.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 11 -- Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg Assistant Secretary of State, said today following a tour of the Korean front that she was impressed by the "remarkable progress" of the South Korean Army under the training program started last year by Gen. James A. Van Fleet, commander of the United States Eighth Army.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 (UP) -- Center Fleming Mackell scored the "hat trick" tonight as the Boston Bruins downed the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 1, in a blazing National Hockey League game before 7,811 fans at the Garden.

A panel of six high school students, discussing the question of "What Do We Mean by Good Citizenship" on the New York Times Youth Forum television program, disagreed last night on whether an 18-year-old boy was old enough to vote even if he was drafted into the armed forces.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 9 -After six sailing dinghy races today off the Larchmont Yacht Club, Arthur Knapp and Jack Sutphen were tied in the scoring. The position of a boat ahead of another is a point.

The Bendix Home Appliances division of Avco Manufacturing Corporation confirmed reports yesterday that it plans to market a full line of electric refrigerators, home freezers and ranges. Judson S. Sayre, Avco vice president and Bendix division general manager, said his organization expects to have full national distribution in the last half of 1954.

The Christian impact upon the world today largely depends upon the strength of each congregation and the fidelity of its individual members, the Rev. Dr. O. Frederick Nolde asserted in a guest sermon yesterday morning at the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street.

The season's second performance of Frederick Ashton's "Picnic at Tintagel" by the New York City Ballet yesterday afternoon at the City Center revealed a substantially new cast at work. Melissa Hayden, who has danced the central role of Iseult only once before, was joined by Stanley Zompakos for the first time as King Mark and Irene Larsson for the first time as Brangaene.

A memorial service for members of the Seventh Regiment was held yesterday at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifty-third Street and Fifth Avenue. Six hundred persons attended the service, which was preceded by a parade of 200 men from the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street, to the church.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 8 -Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion declined today to enter a discussion with Rabbi Irving Miller, president of the Zionist Organization of America, on the latter's complaint that the Israeli leader had censured American Zionist leaders for "smearing" the Israeli Government.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The stock market and the financial and business world generally were so overwhelmed by the rush of events last week that they have been left in a bewildered condition and unable adequately to reflect the effect of any of them.

HOOK OF HOLLAND, the Netherlands, Nov. 9 -- Limited navigation through Rotterdam's waterway was resumed today while the Dutch Navy made plans to remove the wreckage of a Panamanian freighter that sank in the channel mouth Friday night, blocking the world's third busiest port for eighteen hours.

Leaders of the steel industry, whom he had fought so often at the bargaining table and on the picket line, joined high Government and union officials yesterday in expressing regret at the death of Philip Murray.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The average American household was paying $3.76 a month for electricity last Jan. 1 -- two cents more than a year earlier -- the Federal Power Commission reported today.

KAOHSIUNG, Formosa, Nov. 3 -- One of the most promising Nationalist military outfits in Formosa is a new marine division that is being whipped into shape at the Tsoying naval base here under the guidance of a small group of energetic United States marines.

The death of Philip Murray and the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower have created the strongest likelihood for labor unity in the seventeen years since the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations parted company.

Production in the men's clothing industry was at 68 per cent of capacity for the first nine months of the year, a decrease from the 77 per cent in 1951 and 83 per cent in the 1950 period, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. All segments of the industry registered declines except production of separate pants.

Strong books can make an indelible impression on the child reader as well as re-create and refreshen human spirits. This statement was made by May Hill Arbuthnot, who was guest speaker on Saturday at the third annual parent conference on reading at the University of Delaware.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 -- Election Day came and went with no effect on steel output. There was in the steel trade last week an intangible feeling of buoyancy. Whether this will change the view that steel demand will level off by mid-1953 remains to be seen.

A dispatch to this newspaper from Tokyo indicates that Japan may come more sharply to grips with the problem of reparation to smaller East Asian states. A fresh approach to the question by the Japanese and some tangible proposals could effect a considerable improvement in the all-over climate in the Far East.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel L. Hamilton, Professor Emeritus of Religious Education at New York University and a Methodist minister, paid tribute to the Moravian Church yesterday for its contributions to Protestantism.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A plea to the American people to break down the barriers of "ancestral suspicions" that have been built up through the years among those of differing faiths, was voiced here tonight by the Most Rev. Mark K. Carroll, Roman Catholic Bishop of Wichita, Kan.

One of the most crowded weeks of the art season opens with more than twenty exhibiteons on the calendar today and nearly as many more to round out the week. Of outstanding interest is the exhibition arranged by the Knoedler Galleries for the Ingres Museum at Montauban, France, which is lending fourteen paintings and a score of drawings not shown in this country before.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- A sharp setback in grain and soybean futures followed the Republican landslide last Tuesday. The trade feared the Republican farm program might be changed from the present set-up, the Korean war might be ended, and that retrenchment in Government spending would affect the over-all inflation picture.

BEDMINSTER, N. J., Nov. 9 -State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes, Republican of Somerset, today pledged himself to "fight" any proposal by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to shift the 1953 state primary to next September.

Secretary of State Dean Acheson, French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman and British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden conferred yesterday in the Riverdale home of Sir Gladwyn Jebb, permanent British representative at the United Nations.
The stabilization regulations are holding the ceiling on salaries paid to white collar workers in this city fairly firmly, but "the floor is moving up."

Dan A. Kimball, Secretary of the Navy, will be the principal, speaker tomorrow at the Armistice Day services in Arlington National Cemetery, instead of President Truman, who had been previously announced as speaker. The N.B.C.-TV network will carry the ceremonies from 10:58 A. M. to 12:30 P. M., EST.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 10 -- The Eastern Korean front, manned on the enemy's side by North Korean Communists and generally quiet for several months, exploded into action yesterday and early today.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 9 -- A continued high level of realty activity and a busy period for builders may be anticipated under the new national political line-up, according to Joseph W. Lund of Boston, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

A two-family dwelling on the east side of Pine Street, 237 feet south of Fulton Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Joseph Adamo to Frances J. Barr, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, which also insured title in the sale of the one-family home at 315 Park Place by Emma Moller to Vincent Gironda in a deal negotiated by A. Peace Son, brokers.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 9 (UP) -- The Cleveland Browns, with Marion Motley once again adding his brilliant running power to the passing ability of Otto Graham, regained their offensive punch today and smashed the Chicago Cardinals, 28 to 13, before 34,097 at Municipal Stadium.

Three men and three women arrested for complicity in obtaining horse race results from local tracks and transmitting them to a Delaware wire service, which sold the information to bookmakers, were arraigned yesterday in Queens Felony Court, Ridgewood, Queens, on charges of having violated gambling statutes.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 10 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,429, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

TOKYO, Nov. 3 -- Mrs. Margaret Sanger, barred from Japan during the occupation, has attracted considerable interest during a visit here under the auspices of the Tokyo newspaper Mainichi and Japanese birth-control groups.

William Steinkraus of the United States equestrian team, riding Democrat, won the $1,000 international stake, the jumping event that served as the feature competition on the program of the National Horse Show last night. Steinkraus gained the premier award in a jump-off with Lieut. Bertrand duBreuil of the French Army team aboard Tourbillon, before a crowd of 9,000 at Madison Square Garden.
BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- Five thousandl Masons braved snow and rainl today during a colorful p'arade toI I

British sterling and the Canadian dollar turned sharply lower last week. After a good start on Monday on a carry-over of the rising trend of the preceding week, rates ebbed steadily when trading was resumed on Wednesday following Tuesday's elections. Markets were extremely active, especially as the week worked toward its close.

The death of Chaim Weizmann, President of Israel, has removed from our midst one of the titans of this century. During his lifetime of 77 years he combined the three careers of scientist, statesman and teacher, any one of which would have been sufficient for world-wide renown.

Like leaves fluttering from the trees as the frost gets heavy on the pumpkin and the corn is not alone in shock, the giants of the gridiron wither and fall out of the parade with each succeeding week.
CLIFTON, N. J., Nov. 9 (AP) -An automobile plunged into a deep pond alongside Route 6 early today. The driver was trapped and drowned in the submerged car, but three companions managed to get out.
The Federal Government encourages contributions to the United Hospital Fund of New York by granting income tax relief to those who support the Fund.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 8 -An opportunity to reappraise the contemporary design movement of Sweden was offered by an exhibition that opened here today. The exhibition, installed in the Busch-Reisinger Museum of Harvard University, is composed of selected examples of the best of the decorative arts of Sweden.

President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower has accepted "with gratification" President Truman's friendly offer of cooperation during the interregnum between the election and Inauguration Day, next Jan. 20. In particular, he wired Mr. Truman, "I shall try to take immediate advantage of your suggestion concerning a budgetary representative."

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Aneurin Bevan, who is challenging Herbert Morrison for the deputy leadership of the Parliamentary Labor party, said tonight that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect of the United States, would not have "the support of the British people" if he tried to end the war in Korea by extending the conflict to other areas.
GENEVA, Nov. 9 -- The United States has submitted to the United Nations Committee on Forced Labor new data bringing the record on the Russian forced labor system up to May, 1952.

The Hunter College concerts generally consist of recitals by famous soloists, but last night, to launch the tenth anniversary series, Dr. Benno Lee, the impresario, offered the subscribers something special -- a concert by the Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UP) -Four leading soap manufacturers have agreed to stop claiming that their laundry detergents wash clothes "just as clean" without rinsing.
The TV-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation made its debut on television yesterday afternoon with a program called "Omnibus." There is only one word that fits the occasion: bravo!

Mr. Truman and his family will not suffer want after they leave the White House. For one thing, the President has a military pension of $95.66 a month, an amount derived from his service in the First World War and his further service in the Army Reserve, in which he is a colonel.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers, led by Fullback Fred Cone's 20 points, scored a 41-28 upset over the Chicago Bears before 41,751 at Wrigley Field today.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday the creation of an Interdepartmental Health Council to coordinate the jurisdictions, policies and programs of the Health, Hospitals and Welfare Departments in the general field of city health services.

Tony Vittiburga, 19 years old, on parole from the New York City Reformatory at New Hampton, N. Y., was held in $5,000 bail by Magistrate John R. Starkey in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday on a charge of grand larceny for a hearing Friday.

Six women leaders in public life left here yesterday by plane for a month's tour of West Germany as guests of the Bonn Government. They will meet with German women leaders and study conditions in their particular fields of interest.

BONN, Germany, Monday, Nov. 10 -- Wilhelm Schepmann, the last leader of Hitler's brown-shirted Storm Troopers, became yesterday the first prominent ex-Nazi to win an elective office in Federal Germany.
DETROIT, Nov. 9 (UP) -- Rookie Lou Jankowski scored his first National Hockey League goal tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the New York Rangers, 3-1, before 10,771 fans at Olympia.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 9 (UP) -Rain and a stubborn Dallas Texan defense stifled the touted Los Angeles Rams' offense today, but the Rams' defensive unit came to the rescue late in the day to lead the world champions to a 27-to-6 victory.

ALTON, Ill., Nov. 9 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, in his first public address since his defeat in the Presidential election, said today that it was "the right -- and the duty -- of the individual to speak out for the truth."

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 9 (UP) -- Three Kearny, N. J., police officers arrived here today to request the custody of a bespectacled 16-year-old youth who, the police said, admitted killing his sleeping parents.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh marked Remembrance Sunday today by laying wreaths at the Cenotaph in Whitehall, the memorial to Britain's war dead. Since World War II, the nearest Sunday to Nov. 11 has replaced Armistice Day of World War I as the day dedicated to the men who fell in both wars.

Lom Ching, a 48-year-old waiter, described in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday the violence occasioned by his refusal to serve crackers with won ton soup to a customer in the Great World Restaurant, 4320 Eighteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, Saturday night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -The Chemical Bank and Trust Company of New York has agreed to lend to United Artists for use as "primary financing" a sum of money sufficient to cover the production of a program of ten pictures.

General rains and some snow flurries brought an end yesterday to forest fires in sections of the hard-hit South, East and Ohio Valley, The Associated Press reported. For much of the timberland, it was the first important precipitation in more than two months.

The annual fair for the benefit of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, 209 Madison Avenue, will be held Wednesday and Thursday in the parish house. Mrs. Lyman Delano is chairman of the committee, which consists of members of the church's women's auxiliary and other interested women in the parish.

In a "mass crackdown" on barber shops and beauty parlors violating the sanitary code, the Division of Licenses of the New York State Department announced yesterday that fifteen shops had been ordered closed for at least two weeks and sixteen operators had been suspended.

Since Greece is such a vital spot in the cold war between communism and democracy, we should know more about the man who, according to all indications, will be at that country's helm after the elections of Nov. 16.
Pete McNab, outside right for the Hispano eleven, stole the show in the final double-header of the American Soccer League series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

The affinity of barnacles, mussels, tube worms and other seagoing organisms for ships' hulls is costing the shipping industry $100,000,000 a year, according to the United States Naval Institute's new book, "Marine Fouling and Its Prevention."

The end of the "age of colonialism" has been pronounced with vigor and conviction at irregular intervals since the close of the First World War. However, there is life in the old system still, as the United Nations debates in the Trusteeship Council, not to mention Tunisia, Morocco and many other dependent territories, are demonstrating.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 9 -- The French staged the biggest airborne operation in the Indo-China war today in striking deep into the heart of the Vietminh rebels' territory in the mountains of North Tonkin.

The arrival of the Foreign Ministers of Great Britain and France to take part in United Nations discussions is expected to mark the beginning of a more active phase of the General Assembly. Heretofore the delegates have been marking time. The debate on Korea, the crucial issue of this session, has not advanced beyond the preliminary stage.
Six new films, including an importation from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- A Pan American World Airways passenger plane heading west across the Soviet zone of Germany last night was turned back by the appearance of a lion in the cockpit.

The disastrous effect of the communization of a country upon the life of the Jewish community was detailed yesterday in the second of a series of reports by the Institute of Jewish Affairs of the World Jewish Congress. The report treats the plight of the Jews of Hungary in terms similar to those evoked by the situation in Rumania a year ago.
When the Fourth Field Army of General Lin Piao swept over China's Kiangsi and Kwangtung Provinces in late 1949 one-third of world tungsten ore production went into Communist hands.
Following are tributes to Dr. Chaim Weizmann, scientist, statesman and Israel's first President, who died yesterday, as received by The New York Times and press agencies:

A new hold-up technique was reported by the police last night after three men, one of them "tall, blond and very good looking," escaped with at least $3,269 at a wholesale drygoods house at 22 Orchard Street.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 10 -Crown Prince Akihito was proclaimed officially today a man and the heir apparent to the Japanese throne of his father, Emperor Hirohito.
WEST ADEN PROTECTORATE (Reuters) -- Cotton growing is bringing wealth and prosperity to a desolate section of Arabia which for centuries has been a desert battlefield for tribal feuds.

Now is the time for the United States to get tough and forget its democratic ideals if it wishes to survive. It must stop preaching and practicing equal rights, stop being overly sentimental and fight for its existence by making "an extreme application of organizational methods."

Ceramics that won $2,600 in prizes went on view yesterday when the seventeenth Ceramic National Exhibition opened at the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts. The exhibition arranged by the museum, the Onondaga Pottery Company and the Ferro Corporation, comprises 405 ceramic works and fifty-nine dinnerware designs.

Steve Kuk, a former backfield star at Colgate and the head coach at Blair Academy, has to be a perfectionist. The reason is Fred (Scrap) Johnson, a top lineman at Lehigh fifty years ago, who retired as a member of Blair's faculty in 1947.
Any chance that the city might, in the foreseeable future, consider the Hudson River as a permanent source of water supply was dispelled yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Even as first steps were taken to smooth the change-over in Administrations, further problems were added today to those already awaiting the incoming President, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

The philosophy of materialism is the greatest threat to freedom in America today, the Very Rev. Christopher J. O'Toole, former head of the University of Notre Dame philosophy department, declared here yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 9 -- "We may be nearer to general convertibility than we had until recently believed," Dr. Marius W. Holthrop, president of the Netherlands Bank said in a speech before the Netherlands Chamber of Commerce for America at Amsterdam this week.

TRENTON, Nov. 9 -- The State Highway Authority, announcing a financing program for the construction of the Garden State Parkway, said today that state-guaranteed bonds in issues of $50,000,000 to $60,000,000 would be sold as funds were required.

The Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of Fordham University, told 500 faculty members yesterday that the university had not yet reached the proper level of achievement in its teaching and research. He urged them to "achieve such excellence that our standing in the intellectual world will be beyond question."
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 9 -- The State of Israel mourned today the death of Dr. Chaim Weizmann, its first President, who succumbed to a heart attack at 5:55 A. M. He was 77 yeas old.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 9 -- One of the first of the Government's regulatory bodies to be called before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee under the new Republican Administration will be the Federal Communications Commission.

Although the trend of cotton prices in the domestic market was generally upward last week, a rather sharp reversal on Wednesday kept net changes as a whole to small, irregular proportions. At the close of trading on Friday active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 5 points higher to 16 points below the levels of the previous week.

Subcontracting offers the best method for taking part in defense orders for many small plants in this area, it was noted yesterday by Casper H. Citron, regional director of the Small Defense Plants Administration, in announcing a new leaflet designed to assist small business men in obtaining defense subcontracts.

As a former member of the Board of Higher Education I am in thorough agreement with the main theme of your editorial "Dr. Carman Dumped." The failure of Mayor Impellitteri to reappoint this most distinguished educator is, to say the least, reprehensible and downright silly.

The twenty-first anniversary of the Theatre Collection of the New York Public Library and the Astor, Lenox and Tilden Trust will be observed on Thursday. The collection actually came into existence on Sept. 1, 1931, and almost continuously since then has served as a valuable source of information, covering every sector of the amusement industry. It is supervised by George Freedley, founder.

This country has the economic and industrial establishment to continue the cold war but there is a question whether the people "will stand what ten more years of this kind of cold war involves," Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, declared last night.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 (AP) -Detroit's Lions moved into a tie for the National Conference lead of the National Football League today by swamping the Pittsburgh Steelers, 31 -- 6, while the San Francisco Forty-Niners lost to the New York Giants, 23 -- 14.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 9 -The winter championship season opened at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today and Walt Pierson Jr., with his Sphinx, romped home first in all four races for a perfect score of 32 points.

Six national leaders of the three major religious faiths in the United States issued yesterday a statement that in the recent Presidential campaign the major candidates, meaning Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, had "scrupulously avoided appealing to the intolerance of the prejudiced."

If it isn't apparent that television has not destroyed all the things it was supposed to destroy when it first took hold of the popular imagination, figures gathered by Clarence L. Jordan, executive vice president of N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., should set the mind of the advertising executive at rest.

" General Billy Mitchell: Champion of Air Defense," a new work by Roger Burlingame, will be published on Wednesday by McGraw-Hill. This biography of the controversial figure of two decades ago examines his ideas about military aviation and shows how time has proved them correct.

ZURICH, Nov. 9 -- "Visible exports from Austria in 1951 aggregated in value about $450,000,000 and visible imports, inclusive of those under the European Recovery program of about $655,000,000, leaving a deficit in the Austrian balance of trade of about $200,000,000 which could be closed only by increasing sufficiently our invisible exports such as hydroelectric power," Dr. Rudolf Stahl, general manager of the Austrian Electric Power Corporation, explained last week in Vienna.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, in the first nine months this year, had sales of $133,778,460, highest in its fifty-year history, R. P. Carlton, president, reported in the statement mailed to stockholders today. Sales for the similar period last year were $126,810,666.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- Cardinal Hayes High School of New York defeated Archbishop Stepinac High of White Plains, 12 to 6, today with a touchdown in the final moments of a stirring clash before 7,000 fans at Memorial Field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, urged a full Senate investigation tonight of what he called excessively costly Air Force contracts held by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation for building cargo planes.

ON THE WESTERN FRONT, Korea, Nov. 9 -- The farm boy from Iowa who did not think any more of the United Nations than he did of a sick ear of corn when he left the United States, is apt to go home from the battlefield here with affection and admiration for the soldiers of his allies and with respect for the world body.

The Church must recapture its social responsibilities from politicians, the Rev. Dr. Adam Clayton Powell Jr. declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 235 battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 61 killed, 162 wounded, 3 missing and 9 injured. The following casualties were from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Terry Moore, a member of the St. Louis Cardinals since 1935, said tonight he was through as a coach with the club.

ALL over town yesterday the well-upholstered football folks were talking in awed but excited tones about the magnificent and violent Giant-Forty-Niner game of the day before. The Giants, in case you didn't notice, upset the San Francisco powerhouse, 23 to 14, while holding to a paltry 35 yards rushing gain a team that had been the strongest offensive unit in the league.

A special Trans World Airlines Constellation is scheduled to leave New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 9:40 A. M. today, carrying fourteen airline officials on an extensive survey flight around the Far East.

DETROIT, Nov. 10 -- To stimulate fresh thinking on the problem of America's highway system, the General Moters Corporation offered today $194,000 in cash prizes for essays on the topic: "How to Plan and Pay for the Safe and Adequate Roads We Need."

The W. T. Grant Company, operator of 492 variety stores in thirty-nine states, has reached an agreement looking toward an affiliation with Zeller's, Ltd., largest Canadian company in a similar variety store field. It marks the first investment by W. T. Grant in Canada.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has decided not to appoint a representative to serve with the United States delegation to the General Assembly, a reliable source reported today.

Schenley Industries, Inc., suffered a drop in sales and a sharp decline in earnings in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31. The annual report yesterday of Lewis S. Rosensteil, chairman, showed sales of all products, including alcoholic beverages, pharmaceuticals, cooperage and farm feed supplements, totaled $426,483,232, against $450,576,264 in the previous fiscal year.

BARTON, Vt., Nov. 10 (AP) -- The eligible voters of the 1,267 residents of this dairy village will decide by secret ballot tonight whether they want to sell their publicly-owned power system to a private concern for "about $200,000."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- William C. Foster, Deputy Secretary of Defense, said at a Pentagon press conference today that the United Nations commanders in Korea despaired of attaining a negotiated peace. He said the military leaders were pressing to make the aggression as costly as possible and in this way convince the Chinese Communists of the desirability of peace.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 10 -- The Government revealed today that it would reduce by half the civil and military expenditures scheduled for the period from November 1, 1952, to March 31, 1953.

Competition for players in post-season football games has become so keen, scouts are reluctant to identify the athletes in whom they are interested. Andy Kerr, who has been searching for players to man the East against the West in the annual charity game at San Francisco on Dec. 27, declined to name names yesterday at the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's.

In the fourth week of its Gotham incarnation Mr. Chartock's Gilbert and Sullivan troupe is in excellent form. It is bringing us an enchanting performance of "Iolanthe," which opened at the Mark Hellinger last evening. After having the same musicians under his baton for three weeks, Lehman Engel, the Mississippi maestro, has developed a responsive orchestra that fills a large theatre with the mellow tone and the decorous harmonies of Sullivan's most captivating score.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 (AP) -- In his first start since being purchased by Jerry Lynch, Inc., Sonic ran off with the $5,000 Hayward Purse at Pimlico today, easily scoring over G. R. Petersen and Prop in the mile-and-a-sixteenth feature.

The closing of "In Any Language," starring Uta Hagen, after Saturday night's performance was announced yesterday by Jule Styne and George Abbott, producers of the attraction. Written by Edmund Beloin and Henry Garson, the comedy began its local career on Oct. 8 and will depart after a total of forty-five showings at the Cort Theatre.
Trading on the New York commodity exchanges was light yesterday. Hides, lead, zinc, rubber and wool were higher, while sugar, potatoes, cocoa, coffee and vegetable oils eased.

Americans were urged yesterday to make Armistice Day donations of blood, or arrange today for future donations, not only as tributes to men who have died in wartime but as a means of saving lives in Korea.

The Federal Maritime Board resumed yesterday, after a ten-day recess, its hearing into the dual-rate system proposed by the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference. The sessions, which are being held in the Department of Commerce offices, 2 West Forty-third Street, are inquiring into the reasonableness of a 10 per cent differential proposed by the conference for its exclusive shippers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The first Negro to be appointed an assistant attorney general of Maryland will be named next week, Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin said here today.

Up to this time the many reports to the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey have dealt with problems that the city government could solve on its own motion, assuming the desire and the determination were there. The five-team, five-volume study of the city's Welfare Department, however, is a different matter.
Governor Dewey yesterday reopened the forest lands of fifteen Hudson Valley counties because extensive rains and snow during the last two days had diminished the danger of forest fires.

A change in leadership took place yesterday in the women's world chess championship challengers tournament in Moscow, according to a report received through Soviet news sources. Mrs. Elizabeth Bykova of Russia won in the eleventh round from Salome Reischer of Austria to take first place with a score of 8 1/2-1 1/2.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Following is the text of the statement to the General Assembly by Trygve Lie in which he made known his resignation as Secretary General of the United Nations:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Robert Schuman, Foreign Minister of France, declared today that interference by the United Nations in the Tunisian and Moroccan disputes would violate the United Nations Charter and possibly do irreparable harm to the organization itself.

In fashion, the opening was an evening of great splendor, of opulent furs, magnificent gowns and even of glittering cosmetics -- eye shadow and streaks in the coiffures vying with the flashing jewels.
Gifts for the home, selected by a decorator, make up the Christmas wares now on view in the Pahlmann Previews shop at 231 East Fifty-first Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- New principles of law developed at the post - war trials of major war criminals at Nuremberg and Tokyo must be promulgated regardless of the criticisms that the two events stimulated, Dr. B. V. A. Roling of the Netherlands asserted today in the Legal Committee of the General Assembly.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Marshal Tito has accepted the British Govern ment's invitation to visit this country, the House of Commons was told today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Ambassador Frederick L. Anderson, deputy special representative in Europe for the Mutual Assistance Program, assessed today the future problems of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as political, moral and economic, rather than military.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The smashing of a juvenile "Nazi storm troopers club" was announced here today and the defiant head of the organization told the police:

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Duncan Sandys, Minister of Supply, revealed in the House of Commons today that although the shortage of steel in Britain had eased slightly, it would be necessary to import another 2,000,000 tons next year.

Despite an ominous recrudescence of Nazi elements, the coalition Government of Chancellor Adenauer appears to have emerged with unimpaired and possibly even increased strength as a result of local elections involving half the German electorate. The Chancellor's own party, the Christian Democrats, continued to lose ground through attrition from the Left and Right, and the Socialists, who demand German unification before German rearmament, scored some gains.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 10 -- The Thai military were alerted Sunday night while the police rounded up about 100 persons suspected of planning to overthrow the Government. Those arrested included some army and navy officers and many prominent members many of the Thailand Peace Committee -- which recently was able to send delegates to the Peiping peace conference although passports were denied -- and the complete staff of the pro-Communist Chinese daily Chuan Min Poa.

The stock market put on a little burst of speed late yesterday as strength in the railroad section invited some buying in other groups. Earlier, the list had staged an indifferent performance with prices scrambled and variations in quotations narrow.

We believe there is public prejudice, rightly or wrongly, against adding any considerable amount of Hudson River water to New York City's water supply and that Mayor Impellitteri has probably made the right decision in calling off any further consideration of it for the time being.
Approaching the homestretch, intercollegiate football this week goes over the top with a wealth of glittering attractions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and four other Republican leaders were on record today as saying President Truman's tactics "hurt" Governor Stevenson's bid for the Presidency.

Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Brooklyn held yesterday that an applicant for Social Security benefits between 65 and 75 years old must inform the Social Security Administrator of personal earnings if the applicant were to get old-age insurance checks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Federal District Judge James R. Kirkland refused today to set aside subpoenas by which the Government was requiring seven major oil companies to produce records at a grand jury investigation.

The first successful prevention of paralytic poliomyelitis was hailed last night by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, as the scientific highlight of 1952 and the greatest step yet taken toward ultimate control of the disease.
Mrs. F. Richard Smith of Woodway was re-elected president of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the annual meeting held yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.
Thousands of parents here became "students" again yesterday, as the annual Open School Week got under way.

The case of the Halloween treat-seeker who got slapped was settled in a sort of way yesterday in Flatbush Magistrates Court, Brooklyn. Ten-year-old Richard Wanderman shook hands with his neighbor from across the street, 66-year-old Dr. Gabriel R. Mason, principal of Abraham Lincoln High School, and everybody was sorry about something or other.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

President-elect Eisenhower and President Truman are doing their level best to bridge the gap of power and responsibility between Election Day and Inauguration Day. We have no doubt that Senator Lodge and Mr. Dodge, watching the operations of Government during the next two months and nine days, will learn much that will be of use to General Eisenhower later on.

That salesman have a good friend in the court of management was demonstrated yesterday when one of the leading sales officials of the country went to bat for them at a luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Abraham Teitelbaum, Chicago lawyer, appeared before a Federal grand jury today to tell again his story that two men claiming high Washington connections tried to get $500,000 from him two years ago in a "shakedown." He first told the story to a subcommittee of the House of Representatives investigating alleged tax scandals last December.

At his first local recital last night, Maryan Filar, Polish pianist, confirmed what seemed to be true when he made his New York debut last season as soloist with the Philadelphia Orchestra -- namely, that he is a greatly gifted interpreter of Romantic music.

The American Baseball Academy, founded to combat juvenile delinquency and, at the same time, teach youngsters the right way to play baseball, started its second season yesterday at an indoctrination session at the 165th Infantry Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street.
Canada came through in the international jumping competition of the National Horse Show for the first time in Madison Square Garden last night, but made its triumph a major one.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today made a surprise increase of 492,000 bales in estimating the size of this year's cotton crop, putting indicated production at 14,905,000 bales.

A singer's opera with some of the finest singers in the world graced the opening of the Metropolitan Opera's sixty-eighth season last night. Starting his third year as general manager, Rudolf Bing led off with another of his rehabilitations of an old work relatively neglected in recent years.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 10 -- Commercial production of electric power from atomic reactors may be "no more than four or five years away," it was declared here tonight by Dr. Charles Allen Thomas, president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, which played a major role in the development of the atomic bomb.

Although unemployment insurance taxes soon will be substantially reduced, the state's Unemployment Trust Fund will reach $1,200,000,000 by the end of this year, Milton O. Loysen, director of the State Labor Department's Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance, reported yesterday.
This is a chip-off-the-old-block item that is guaranteed to stir up some memories.
United States steel mills operated at a record level in October as producers sought to satisfy peak demand.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 26 to 72 points net lower, than on last Friday, with old crop months showing the most weakness.

Widening and deepening of the Hudson River channel between here and Albany and extensive improvements to the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal at a combined cost of $126,700,000 were recommended yesterday by the Army Board of Engineers for Rivers and Harbors.

The nation's steel mills are maintaining operations at record levels. Steel operations this week are scheduled at 106.4 per cent of capacity, with production of 2,209,000 tons of iron and steel for castings, according to yesterday's report of the American Iron Steel Institute.

GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- The High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, or Schuman plan, gave an undertaking today to act in matters of commercial policy so far as its authority extended as if it were a single country.

Customs receipts from shipping in the Port of New York reached last month a high for the year of $30,813,114, and an additional $1,907,332 was collected from airport activities in the metropolitan area. Disclosing this yesterday, Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs, noted that total receipts were more than $4,000,000 above those reported for September and nearly $6,000,000 greater than in October, 1951.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 10 -- Heavy destruction of Vietminh supplies today followed yesterday's parachute and overland occupations of Phudoan by French Union forces. French aircraft blasted convoys on the roads and hit a big storage depot at Yenbay while French and Vietnamese troops at Phudoan took over a large munitions dump.

FORT DIX, N. J., Nov. 11 -- Four soldier-prisoners who overpowered and bound their guard and escaped from the stockade here at 1 P. M. yesterday were back in Army custody early this morning, less than twelve hours after their break.

Governor Dewey joined yesterday with the staff of the State Labor Relations Board in paying tribute to the memory of Keith Lorenz, chairman of the board, who died last July. The Governor unveiled a bronze plaque, purchased by the staff, which hangs in the waiting room at the board's offices, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street.

New efforts to prevent juvenile delinquency and crime among youth will be discussed at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Friday morning as 250 members of the Community Service Society meet to consider plans for strengthening welfare programs in this area.

All Manhattan-bound traffic on Williamsburg Bridge was barred for twenty minutes yesterday because of a snarl caused by a fatal accident involving a laborer on the bridge at 9:12 A. M. The victim was Joseph Perkowski, 43 years old, of 61-24 Fifty-sixth Street, Maspeth, Queens, an employe of the Department of Public Works, who was killed as he sought to put out a truck fire.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Supreme Court today denied to Frank Costello, New York gambler, a review of his conviction on charges of contempt of the Senate.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 10 (UP) -- Wilson Wyatt, Governor Stevenson's personal campaign manager, returned to his law practice here today.

Paul Crowell, City Hall reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES, received the annual award of the Society of the Silurians last night at its fall dinner at the New York Athletic Club. The organization is composed of men employed on New York newspapers twenty-five or more years ago.

ROCHELLE PARK, N. J., Nov. 10 -- Laurence F. Lee, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said tonight the chamber was starting an investigation to determine whether strikes in defense plants were being fomented by Communist agents.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 -- The elongated torso line with hipline interest makes news in swimsuits for resort-into-spring-into-summer, and a flattering, slimming line it is, as interpreted by such nationally known firms as Caltex of California; Catalina, Inc.; Cole of California; Gantner of California, and Rose Marie Reid.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A Senate-House Committee staff estimated today that reductions in Federal taxes scheduled to take place in the next eighteen months would mean a revenue loss of $8,500,000,000 a year unless Congress changes the law.

Supreme Court Justice Felix Frankfurter, saying that he wished Mayor Impellitteri were present to hear him, called last night for "continuity" in the administration of public education, and cautioned against subjecting it to "political" changes.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Labor party members of Parliament expressed the view today that Aneurin Bevan's bid to replace Herbert Morrison as deputy leader of the Opposition in the House of Commons had been rejected by his colleagues by a vote of at least two to one.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- The Government of West Germany, wrestling with the problem of fulfilling its restitution treaty with Israel while retaining its expanding trade with the states of the Arab League, has decided to ask the United Nations for help.

The State of Louisiana borrowed $46,500,000 yesterday in the public market to refund veterans' bonus bonds. The issue was bought at competitive bidding by a banking syndicate headed by C. J. Devine Co. at an interest cost of 2.075 per cent.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 10 -- Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia disclosed today that mutual defense talks between this country, Greece and Turkey would begin in the near future with the objective of an agreement to act jointly against aggression menacing any of them.

After a five-year struggle by a group of unpaid lawyers Queens County Judge Peter T. Farrell yesterday set aside the first-degree murder conviction of Louis Hoffner, who has served nearly twelve years in prison on a life sentence for a slaying the law now seems to think he did not commit. The decision brought the likelihood that Hoffner would go free.

The same October drought that brought danger to the tinder-dry forests in this part of the country reduced New York City's water in storage by 10 per cent of the reservoirs' capacity, according to figures made public yesterday by the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The following are excerpts from the unofficial English translation of an address on Tunisia and Morocco delivered in French today in the United Nations General Assembly by Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister:

Although New Yorkers are frequently asked to make monetary contributions to charities there is a continual demand for a substance that is not only more valuable than money but comes from our own life streams. As never before, America needs plasma. The Red Cross in New York has collected over 55,000 pints of blood toward this year's quota of 200,000 pints.

A FRIEND of mine, a European widely read in world literature but not well acquainted with American history, asked me last year to recommend a biography of Lincoln. Since there are hundreds of books about Lincoln the answer should have been easy. Sandburg's is magnificent, but six volumes were more than my friend could tackle.

The directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People told Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, and the Republican party yesterday that their responsibilities involved not only securing of peace but also the effectuation of pledges regarding civil rights.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- As long as Britain is subject to the buffetings of economic winds that start blowing outside these islands, Herbert Morrison told the House of Commons today, she must rely on planning and internal controls to protect herself against unemployment and the hardships of the interwar years.

Increased demand for frozen citrus juice concentrate during the new crop season will meet with a tight fruit supply, tending to firm prices, members of the Eastern Frosted Foods Association heard yesterday at a meeting in the Advertising Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A 24 per cent rise in wholesale natural gas rates of Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation of Shreveport, La., was approved by the Federal Power Commission today, effective Dec. 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Paul Van Zeeland, Foreign Minister of Belgium, told the United Nations General Assembly today that collective security was now "more right and more necessary than ever."

The Federal Government dismissed yesterday a charge against William Brinckerhoff Brown, a 61-year-old Queens grave digger, for sending a threatening letter to Arnold Schuster, a Brooklyn clothing salesman, after he had given the tip that led to the arrest of William F. Sutton, convicted bank robber.

The Presbytery of New York, representing sixty-three Presbyterian churches with more than 33,000 members in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island, voted unanimously last night to alter its basic organization for greater efficiency in the work of the churches concerned.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov 10 -- The movie makers are giving attention once again to the writings of Herman Melville.

Acquisition of Milk's, Inc., retail apparel department store in Woodmere, L. I., by Namm Loeser's, Inc., Brooklyn department store, was announced yesterday by Maj. Benjamin H. Namm, president of Namm Loeser's.

Attempts to recover for shareholders the costs of a 1949 battle for control of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation failed yesterday. Justice Meier Steinbrink of the Supreme Court in Kings County found against William Rosenfeld and others, the plaintiffs, but did not assess costs.

New York's citizens have traditionally been men and women who wished to provide for them selves in their own way to meet their own needs. It was thus understandable that they chose voluntarily to create the great system of non profit hospitals that now stand ready to serve us all. The fund is a channel through which the citizens of the city contribute to all the voluntary hospitals on which they depend.

" Tugboat Alley," the slip off Battery Place between Piers 1 and 2, where the harbor and ocean-going workhorses puff placidly between jobs, was host yesterday to the Zwarte Zee, said by her owners, L. Smit Co. of Rotterdam, to be the most powerful tug in the world.

REHOVOT, Israel, Nov. 10 -- More than 200,000 persons had paid their silent last respects to President Chaim Weizmann lying in state on a black-draped catafalque in front of his home up to 11 o'clock tonight, according to Israeli army officers in charge of funeral arrangements here.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 10 -- President Otilio Ulate today laud the example set by messages exchanged last week between the Presidential winner and loser in the United States and he said, "I hope Costa Rica will profit by the example."

The Du Mont television network sought permission yesterday to televise locally six college football games in the next two weeks but received a virtual "no" from the men who run the restricted college program.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 10 -- Indonesia's leaders issued an appeal for national unity today against a backdrop of an internal political crisis over the future of the Indonesian Parliament, which went into indefinite recess Oct. 17 following demonstrations demanding its dissolution.
WITH THE FIRST MARINE DIVISION, in Korea, Nov. 10 -- A newly adopted member of the corps took an enthusiastic part in celebrating the 177th anniversary of the United States Marines here today.

A record number of buyers registered in the first two days of the market week sponsored by the Boys Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association, it was reported yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel. Registration began Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a lower court ruling that held unlawful the segregation of white and Negro passengers on day coaches of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Coach Pete Slader's Hackley School football team has an off-day Saturday, but the Black and Gray players will be called upon to go all-out in practice from now until a week from Friday. The reason? Hackley faces its traditional foe, Riverdale, undefeated last year and unbeaten thus far this season, on Nov. 22.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 10 -- Jacobus Strauss, Opposition leader, called today on the Administration of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan for an immediate impartial inquiry into "repeated Negro riots" or, failing that, a special session of Parliament to consider "this new phenomenon of current bloodshed in South Africa."

As detectives and Federal agents burst into a flat at 2321 First Avenue yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Marie Donato, 28 years old, dashed for a bedroom and swallowed half a dozen sleeping pills, the police reported. In a valise under a bed, hidden beneath bathing suits and clothing, the raiders found thirty-two ounces of pure heroin, they charged.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle was urged at the Congress of his party, Reunion of the French People, today to become a candidate in the byelection in a Paris district for the National Assembly. The election is to be held shortly to choose a successor to Louis Rollin, a deputy and a pro-war Cabinet minister who recently died.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A boom was started today by Southern and border state Senators to elect Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas as Democratic minority leader of the Senate in the Eighty-third Congress.

The scheduled airlines, according to figures released yesterday, had a safety record surpassing those of both automobiles and railroads in the twelve-month period that ended last Sept. 30. The statistics appeared in the current issue of Planes, the official publication of the Aircraft Industries Association.

What has happened to all of the New York City street cleaners and their fine apparatus? The simple suburbanite or other out-of-town visitor used to be able to gape at the Empire State Building or yearn nostalgically toward the once shiny Chrysler Building without fear of slipping on an antique orange peel or finding his legs wrapped securely in blowing newspaper, but now it is different.

Every Armistice Day in the Nineteen Thirties at 11 o'clock the teacher would tell the class to stand in silence for two minutes and think of all the American soldiers who had died in battle during the World War.

Trygve Halvdan Lie was Norway's Minister of Foreign Affairs and delegate to the first session of the General Assembly of the United Nations when he was elected, on Feb. 1, 1946, Secretary General, the office from which he resigned yesterday.

I wonder if I could enlist the aid of you and your newspaper in the fight against the narcotic situation in our country. This is something that is eating at the very heart of our country -- our youth -- both boys and girls.

Continuance of food prices at present levels, with possibility of a further downtrend, was forecast for the year ahead as the Grocery Manufacturers of America opened a three-day forty-fourth annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

During his campaign General Eisenhower referred to the importance of establishing at the highest level a group of counselors who would advise the next President, especially on foreign affairs. This idea was put forward early in the year by Bernard Baruch in an article in Look magazine, and was repeated by John Foster Dulles at a recent dinner of the New York Board of Trade.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo, Nov. 10 -- The 1952 Borden Award in Medical Sciences was presented tonight to Dr. William S. Tillett, Professor of Medicine at New York University-Bellevue Medical Center. The award consisted of a gold medal and $1,000.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- The Social Democratic party emerged today at the strongest in North Rhine-Westphalia, the most populous state of West Germany, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democrats lost ground there, in Lower Saxony and in Rhineland Pfalz, and the right-wing Free Democrats made sizable gains in all three states.
It may be said without overstatement that the performance last night of Verdi's "La Forza del Destino" as the opening event of the Metropolitan Opera's 1952-53 season went off with a Bing!

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- A British-United States effort to bring about a speedy solution for the stalemate between India and Pakistan on the status of Kashmir appeared today to be headed for failure as Indian delegates declared that their Government would refuse the terms proposed.

An 18-year-old youth was booked for homicide yesterday at the Bath Beach police station in Brooklyn after allegedly admitting he had struck an infant while serving as a baby sitter on Friday night. The child died of a ruptured liver.
Three of the eleven counties in the nation that had voted for every victorious Presidential candidate since 1896 lost their political preeminence at the last election.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 11 -- Heavy fighting in October halved the combat efficiency of at least two Communist Armies, Gen. James A. Van Fleet, United Nations ground forces commander in Korea, said today. He added that the United Nations limited objective offensive on the central front had diverted Communist plans to attack elsewhere.

Increased use of bus transport to aid in solving traffic congestion and to reduce private car operation was outlined yesterday at the eighteenth annual meeting of the New York State Motorbus Association at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Department store sales are likely to show an increase of 5 per cent in the first quarter of 1953, which would be reduced to 1 per cent in the second quarter, it was predicted yesterday by Charles F. Roos, president of the Econometric Institute.

Even if the Giants -- baseball, that is -- fail to win the pennant, a great financial year is in prospect. In disclosing their advance ticket plan for 1953 yesterday, the Giants listed sixteen night games, four against the Dodgers, at the Polo Grounds. In addition, the inter-borough rivals have drawn the opening day assignment and two Sundays under Coogan's Bluff.

What started out as a sharp French Union counter-attack in northern Vietnam is beginning to take a significant strategic pattern. The French and Vietnamese troops do not appear, at this time, to be striking frontally at the Communist Vietminh forces but rather to have initiated a series of pincer movements aimed at the foe's flanks and rear areas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- For the first time in American history, according to those familiar with events between Election and Inaugural Days when one political party has displaced the other, specific arrangements for an orderly and informed transition have been made.

ST. BONAVENTURE, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The chapel of the new $2,500,000 Christ the King Seminary at St. Bonaventure University was dedicated today by the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States.

Toting French horns, violins, trombones and other musical instruments, two dozen children, 8 to 14 years old, from private schools in this area met at the close of school on Friday at 45 East Seventy-fifth Street to combine their talents in a new orchestral group to be known as the Young Players Orchestra.

Walter Cartier, 162 pounds, Greenwich Village, scored a technical knockout over Otis Graham, 157 1/2, Philadelphia, last night in the feature bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn before 2,500 fans. Referee Mark Conn stopped the battle, listed for ten rounds, at 1:31 of the sixth after Graham had suffered his third knockdown in the session.

NORTH HILLS, L. I., Nov. 10 -- In the final Long Island Professional Golfers' Association tournament at the Links Club, Ferdie Catropa of Peninsula teamed with Chet Munson of Wheatley Hills to win the pro-pro best-ball team event, played in the rain this morning. The victors combined for a round of 33, 34 -- 67.

PARMELE, N. C., Nov. 10 (UP) -- William C. Chance, 65 years old, a school principal, viewed as a "matter of right" today court decisions upholding his stand that Negroes should not be required to travel in separate train coaches. He said that his legal action stemmed from a belief that segregation of train passengers in the South was "an injustice."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, announced today that the Soviet Union "will not budge" from its position that all Communist prisoners of war in Korea must be returned, whether they choose to be or not.

The memory of an outstanding surgeon, who also pioneered in organizing the Blue Shield movement in New York and the Blood Transfusion Association, was honored yesterday at ceremonies dedicating the new DeWitt Stetten Pathology Laboratory at Lenox Hill Hospital, Park Avenue and Seventy-six Street.

Governor Dewey strongly defended last night the state welfare system in relation to New York City, indirectly replying to charges by city Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy that the state had failed to pass on more than a minute share of a Federal welfare "windfall."

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Light to heavy rains in the Southwest caused free selling of wheat at the start of the Board of Trade session today, and later corn and soybeans were adversely affected by the cotton report for November which was much more bearish than expected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Senator-elect Prescott Sheldon Bush, Republican of Connecticut, declared today he did "not see why we can't bring home a couple of hundred thousand American boys" if trained Chinese Nationalist troops, now stationed in Formosa, were thrown into the fighting in Korea.

The solution to the city's transportation problem does not lie in the establishment of a transit authority, Warren Moscow, Manhattan Commissioner of Borough Works, told the Women's City Club of New York yesterday.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 10 -- William H. Abel, president of the Central National Bank of Mineola, and three other persons were indicted tonight by the Nassau County grand jury on charges resulting from an alleged $475,000 swindle of the bank.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- The demand for petroleum products in the United States will increase almost 50 per cent in the next fifteen years, but expanding production will more than meet requirements, two oil men said today.

The hotel industry has reached a refurbishing cycle that spells good business for suppliers of equipment and furnishings, it was pointed out yesterday at the opening of the five-day National Hotel Exposition in Grand Central Palace.

HONG KONG, Nov. 10 -- Thousands of Chinese troops and workers are building a highway across "the roof of the world" to link the Tibetan capital of Lhasa with Communist China, the New China News Agegncy reported today.

The city will pause in silent tribute as the clock strikes 11 A. M. today, the thirty-fourth anniversary of the ending of World War I. Indoors and in the streets, the period of silence will be observed. Subways and buses of the municipal transit system have been ordered to stop for two minutes as part oft he memorial.

A posthumous edition of the third and final volume of George Santayana's autobiography, "Persons and Places," will be issued in the spring by Scribners. Entitled "My Host the World," the volume will cover the period from 1912 to the last years of his life, which he spent as a recluse in a Roman convent.

Women headed by Mrs. Peter I. B. Havan, chairman, and Mrs. James J. Lee, vice chairman, are furthering the sale of tickets for the play "The Climate of Eden" on the night of Nov. 20 at the Martin Beck Theatre. The performance has been taken over to raise funds for the Turtle Bay Music School.

To those trusting souls who believe that democracy of the American type will be dominant in Germany the recent reports of the revival of nazism in Western Germany should provide plenty of food for serious thought.

Recent queries and comments received by this department from readers have covered a wide range of subjects. One writer has asked how to make a tender, flaky pastry. Another provided an intresting explanation for the origin of Welsh rabbit. Today we present some of this correspondence.

Willie Lester, the 20-year-old apprentice jockey from Cass, W. Va., made the fans forget the unpleasant weather at Jamaica yesterday. The "hot" rider just about tamped a path to the winner's circle as he made his way to that enclosure four times through the afternoon.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Organization of a committee to provide Governor Stevenson with funds for regular radio and television appearances to continue to "talk sense" to the American people was announced today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Trygve Lie, whose term as Secretary General of the United Nations does not expire until Feb. 1, 1954, announced his resignation today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- The National Production Authority today barred five firms -- including two accused of black marketing -- from receiving any more controlled materials. It said they "will find it necessary to cease operations."
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 -- The Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., agreed today to end its week-old coastwise walkout.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- The Daily Mirror, Great Britain's largest newspaper, suggested today that Governor Stevenson be appointed ambassador to this country when his term as Governor of Illinois expires.

ROME, Nov. 10 -- Two pilasters covered with brightly colored frescoes have been discovered in the famed Loggias of Raphael in the Vatican at the extremity nearest to St. Peter's Square. The frescoes are the work of Raphael's pupils on cartoons by the great master himself.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 10 -- A charge that a bribe fund of $228,000 had been raised by racketeers to induce state and local officials to cripple an investigation into gambling in 1950 was disclosed today. The allegation was made by the Bergen County grand jury in a sealed indictment that was opened here.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 -- The body of Philip Murray was on its way home to this steel city for burial today as President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower joined industry and union leaders in paying tribute to the dead president of the Congress of Industrial Organ izations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today upheld the right of the Federal Government to use two power lines of the Idaho Power Company in southern Idaho.
