TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 11 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,430, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

OTTAWA, Nov. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's gold mining communities appealed to the Federal Government today for larger gold-mining subsidies to avert what they called a "perilous" economic situation threatening the future of 132.000 Canadians in mining areas.

The nation's savings and loan association executives were urged to undertake "concerted activity" in opposition to new Government housing proposals at their annual convention yesterday. Approximately 2,000 executives are scheduled to attend the sessions of the United States Savings and Loan League which will continue through Friday at the Statler Hotel.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 10 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower received some assurance today of substantial Southern Democratic support in the new Congress when Senator Burnet R. Maybank of South Carolina, chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, said he would support all "sound" proposals by the President-elect.

Miles Leslie, 43 years old, a self-styled artist, pleaded guilty yesterday to eight counts of an indictment charging him with compulsory prostitution and living off the earnings of a prostitute. When he appears for sentencing Dec. 16 before General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein, Leslie faces a possible maximum jail term of 160 years.

Cpl. Robert Morris Brown, Government witness against former Sgt. John David Provoo, treason trial defendant, left the stand in Federal Court yesterday with his story apparently unshaken by lengthy cross-examination.

With the Congress of Industrial Organizations torn over the choice of a successor to Philip Murray, strong sentiment developed yesterday for postponing the C. I. O. convention, scheduled to open in Los Angeles Monday.

ATLANTIC City, Nov. 10 -- A vast increase in the number of farms in this country connected to electric power was reported here today at the twenty-sixth annual conference of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association at the Haddon Hall Hotel.

The Taurid meteor shower, so called because the meteors appear to come from a point in the constellation of Taurus, the Bull, was visible at its relatively meagre best last night to those in the metropolitan area who stayed up late enough and looked hard enough to see it.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The approaching end of the bookkeeping account contributed to the idle conditions in most sections of the London stock market today. With buyers holding off, small routine selling was sufficient to account for the general dullness.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Truman today accepted the resignation of Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, who, last June, accepted the positions of director of the Merrill School of Economics and professor of economics at Amherst College.

The Giants' Bob Wilkinson and John Amberg, both injured in Sunday's game against the San Francisco Forty-Niners, were still at St. Elizabeth's Hospital yesterday. Wilkinson, with a fractured nose, may be available against the Packers Sunday at the Polo Grounds.

The pre-offering market screening document just authorized by the Securities and Exchange Commission is being used in newspaper advertisement form for the first time here today in connection with the pending issue of 70,000 shares of convertible preferred stock of Suburban Propane Gas Corporation.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Striking technicians removed picket lines from the site of the Atomic Energy Commission's huge hydrogen bomb plant tonight and radio appeals were broadcast for workers to return to their jobs.

" Bloodhounds of Broadway," Twentieth Century-Fox Technicolor adaptation of the Damon Runyon story, originally announced to open at the Roxy on Tuesday, instead will arrive at that house this Friday, the company announced yesterday.

DANFORTH, Me., Nov. 10 -- The first real tracking snow of the season began falling at dusk, shortly after our arrival at Rideout's Camps, bringing joy to the hearts of the assembled hunters who had been bemoaning the warm weather that kept the deer in the sanctuary of the swamps.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 10 -- The pressing problem of keeping American agricultural production abreast of the demand for food for a growing population was emphasized by farm realty experts here today in connection with the forty-fifth annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

One of Alfred E. Smith's dreams came true yesterday. From cold, damp tenements on the lower East Side where he had grown up, families began moving into the second and final section of the largest public housing project built so far in Manhattan -- the Gov. Alfred E. Smith Houses.

Reproductions of early American furnishings, handmade like the pieces from which they were copied, are on display at Honeymoon House, a new shop at 1127 Broadway, Hewlett, L. I. The five-room house is accessorized throughout with fabrics, lamps and rugs of the same period.
HARTFORD, Nov. 10 -- A scheduled recital by Paul Robeson at a People's party rally in a local high school auditorium next Saturday night has caused a major controversy in the city.
HAVANA, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A sugar crop of 5,000,000 long tons for the coming year has been recommended by a commission appointed by the Government to fix the size of the crop.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,500,000,000 of 92-day Treasury bills to be dated Nov. 13 and to mature on Feb. 13 were opened to the Federal Reserve Banks today.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 10 -- J. Russel Sprague, retiring as Nassau County executive after sixteen years in office, filed today his final proposed annual budget, which calls for an increased tax levy of $1,794,084 over the current year's $20,840,747.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Londoners quickly took to Julie Wilson, who appeared tonight at the Drury Lane Theatre in her first performance as Ensign Nellie Forbush, star of "South Pacific." The show has been running here for a year with Mary Martin in the leading role.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Prime Minister Churchill, touching on a variety of issues being considered by world powers, said tonight it would be dishonorable to end the Korean war at the cost of sending back Chinese prisoners to be slaughtered by the Communists.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 11 -- Hundreds of thousands of Swedes stood patiently in the pouring rain for hours today to congratulate King Gustaf Adolf on his seventieth birthday. Despite the heavy downpour, the King and Queen Louise rode in an open, horse-drawn carriage in a parade through the city.

The most recent of the many innovations in preparing turkey since the Pilgrims served it at the first Thanksgiving dinner is the frozen, completely boned bird that the Maison Glass is introducing. This shop, at 15 East Forty-seventh Street, has exclusive rights in this country to sell the boneless turkeys, which come from the White Holland Farm, Whitman Mass.

A sizzling 1:11 for the six furlongs brought Mrs. Jan Burke's Squared Away top money in the $20,000 added Autumn Day Handicap, which featured yesterday's Empire-at-Jamaica racing before a crowd of 31,372. Except for the first few strides, Cowboy Jim Nichols had the 5-year-old bay gelding in front all the way.

Ed McGuirk of Brooklyn Prep captured individual honors and Fordham Prep took the team crown in the Class 1 Division of the Private Schools Athletic League cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

GEORGE SCHOOL, Pa., Nov. 11 -- When Bob Geissinger, former Springfield player, took over as head coach at George School last September he found he had only two letter men, the co-captains, around which to mold the current football team.

Mrs. Kingsley Kunhardt heads the committee in charge of the plans for the annual bazaar and tea in behalf of the Peabody Home, to be held tomorrow afternoon at the headquarters of the home, 1000 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx. A wide variety of useful and decorative articles made by the residents of the home will be offered for sale.

DANFORTH, Me., Nov. 11 -- The hunter who just wants to get a deer does not have too much of a problem here. The man who insists upon waiting for one with a really large rack of antlers, however, must be selective in spite of what, at the time, comes under the heading of "better judgment."

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Union printers left their jobs at The Montgomery Advertiser tonight, and R. F. Hudson Jr., assistant publisher, called it an "illegal strike" and said the men had been discharged.
Stuyvesant's football team completed its most successful season in many years with a 20-14 triumph over Monroe yesterday at Monroe Field, the Bronx.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon said today he has submitted his formal resignation as a Senator to Gov. Earl Warren of California.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Two men of the large Conklin clan, "hill people" who have lived and hunted in the Ramapo woods since Revolutionary days, were locked up here today as material witnesses in the unsolved murder of two squirrel hunters in the forest on Oct. 26.

The Post Office Department was accused yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union of "setting itself up as a judge of academic standards" by a policy of letting some subscribers here receive Soviet publications, whereas other persons may not.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Truman will hand the economy-bent Eighty-third Congress a budget of about $85,000,000,000 for the 1954 fiscal year, with roughly 75 per cent of the funds earmarked for defense and related programs, it was estimated today.

City College's cross-country team yesterday defeated New York University, 27 -- 30, for the first time since 1921, over the Van Cortlandt Park five-mile course. City scored a 27-to-28 victory in 1921.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 -- Accent on clean-cut silhouettes, on the costume look, on complete coordination, with dyed-to-match themes, sometimes using as many as three fabrics in one costume -- these are characteristics of fashion collections shown today at National Press Week sponsored by California apparel creators.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 -- Vice presidents of the Congress of Industrial Organizations began gathering here tonight for the mournful task of burying their leader, Philip Murray.

The pupils of St. Hilda's School at 621 West 113th Street, their parents and members of the religious order of the Community of the Holy Spirit will participate on Saturday in the celebration of the patronal feast of the school at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
The gaiety and glitter that go with the holiday season are reflected in the junior fashions to be found now in New York department store styles.
Nineteen poems lauding the tuatara, a New Zealand reptile that was only a biological curiosity last Thursday, were received by THE NEW YORK TIMES up to last night.

SALTON SEA, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Bob Sykes, Long Beach, Calif., cracked the world record for the 266-cubic-inch hydroplane class aboard the Guess Who today at the American Power Boat Association's desert regatta.

Today when we see a red and white barber pole it is difficult to imagine that a hundred years ago this innocent-looking post was the barber's announcement that surgical operations were also performed on his premises. Yet the old-fashioned barber shop of 1852 can still be seen.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, gave one of his rare press interviews today to a student at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, who spoke to him in Russian.

HARTFORD, Conn.,. Nov. 11 -- The controversy over whether Paul Robeson should be permitted to sing in a local high school auditorium Saturday night widened today when the City Council voted, 6 to 3, to ask the Board of Education to deny Mr. Robeson use of the school hall.
TYLER, Tex., Nov. 11 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle, retired, held hope tonight that "with resolution, we can develop the strength that may enable us to end the Korean war."

The 154 officers and men who have been garrisoning Bermuda for the London Government were not there to hold the island in subjection. But their imminent recall, now announced by the British War Office, is the end of a great tradition. For two centuries and a half there had been British troops on Bermuda.

For the first time since 1947, when the two teams played a 24-24 tie, the Green Bay Packers will be seen at the Polo Grounds on Sunday when they tangle with the Giants in a game that must be rated as "crucial."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- During the last two weeks approximately $18,000,000 worth of defense work was earmarked for small plants, the Small Defense Plants Administration reported today. With the latest additions to its total the S. D. P. A. said that approximately $160,000,000 of defense work has been marked for small business, John E. Horne, head of the Agency said.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 11 -- The $15,000,000 Savannah State Docks and Warehouse System of the Georgia Port Authority was formally dedicated before 5,000 persons here today.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Trouble in No. 2 engine might have caused the crash of a Pan American World Airways Stratocruiser over the Brazilian jungle last April, witnesses said today at a Civil Aeronautics Board hearing.

The presentation of the French case on Tunisia and Morocco at the United Nations General Assembly by Foreign Minister Schuman was cogent and impressive. The French have a good case and have always had one, although it is not impeccable and is certainly open to criticism and argument in some of its details.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 11 -- Realty men who have watched vast new retail shopping centers spring up on the fringes of cities throughout the country were warned today that there was grave danger this new type of commercial project would be overdone, with consequent adverse effect on business and property values.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower plans to discuss the major issues before the United Nations with Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, after his meeting with President Truman next week.

Dr. Hans Simons, president of the New School for Social Research, declared yesterday that "the most disturbing aspect" of the Presidential election was the attempt of the American electorate "to vote itself out of trouble." He also attributed the results to "the fact that the Republicans regrettably took a more nationalistic line than the Administration."

Oscar Gacitua, 26 - year - old Chilean pianist, made his first New York recital appearance last evening in Town Hall. Senor Gacitua is a graduate of the National Conservatory of Music in Santiago, where he studied with Alberto Spikin-Howard. In 1950 he received the Henry Doherty Foundation Fellowship for further study in this country.
Michigan State, ranked first by the United Press board of coaches yesterday for the eighth straight week, can just about clinch the 1952 college football honors by beating Notre Dame this Saturday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 11 -- All Negro attacks at Port Elizabeth, East London, Kimberley and other places followed the same pattern, Minister of Justice C. R. Swart said today.

CAIRO, Nov. 11 -- The Arab League Political Committee meeting here since last Wednesday postponed again today its decision on measures taken to support its protest against West Germany's paying reparations to Israel for crimes committeed against the Jews under the Nazi regime.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Nov. 11 -- The leaders of the National Grange assembled here today, determined to develop a long-range program that would serve farmers and yet assure them of freedom from Federal interference.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- An employes' pension fund bought out the company that set it up, the owner reported today.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 12 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Wednesday, Korea time:

The ninth annual national traffic safety poster contest conducted by the American Automobile Association was announced yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York. Sixty-one awards will be made to students who submit the best designs, according to Edward J. Rieger, the club's director of traffic engineering and safety.

Seven critics, editors and reporters who cover the theatre for New York newspapers and trade publications participated yesterday in a symposium on "The Current Theatre" at the American Theatre Wing, 351 West Forty-eighth Street. The panel answered questions asked by students of the Wing's professional training program.

The overwhelming response of volunteer workers to assist in the gamma globulin fields trials last summer in the hard-hit polio epidemic areas of Houston, Tex., and Sioux City, Iowa, was described yesterday by Mrs. R. O. Pearson of Abilene, Tex., who was the only volunteer actually on a research team staff.

Jack Brause, real estate operator, has contracted to purchase the three-story commercial building at 1166-1184 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, from the 1174 Bedford Avenue Corporation, which has owned it for more than twenty years.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Business will remain at a high level for the next six to nine months and then drop, a New York University professor of finance predicted today.

A pacing horse called Good Time -- presumably named for a venerable race track at Goshen, New York -- was guest of honor at a lunch the other day in Yonkers. He ate carrots and apples and licked a brick of sugar while other guests, members of the United States Harness Writers Association, ate roast beef.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A brief outlining the ground on which the American Newspaper Publishers Association bases its appeal from union printers' demands to be paid for setting "bogus" type, was filed with the United States Supreme Court yesterday by Elisha Hanson, general counsel of the association.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 11 -- In the name of the "oppressed German Opposition" of the Saar, the pro-German political parties of that state called on the electorate today not to vote in the state elections Nov. 30, or, if they did vote, to cast invalid ballots protesting against "separatist" rule.
LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Assembly of the Church of England declined today to consider a motion for the resignation of the "Red Dean" of Canterbury, Dr. Hewlett Johnson.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association today approved eight post-season football bowl games.
Sol Hurok is one impresario who isn't awed by the format of artistic ventures. Anything that bids fair to bring out the cash customers in droves, he is only too eager to tackle.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net income after depletion of $25,643,671, equal to $2.53 a share in the first nine months this year, according to the report to be mailed to stockholders today.

Five hundred mothers and fathers visited the Barnard College campus yesterday as guests at the fourth annual Parents' Day. They went through a "typically routine" day with their daughters, sitting in on classes, attending an afternoon assembly, and chatting with faculty members.

Officers of the Mexican Army, riding green horses that had prevented them from making their customary tremendous showing, nevertheless rode off with the International Perpetual Challenge Trophy team competition that brought the sixty-fourth National Horse Show to an end in Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Department of Agriculture today displayed at its Beltsville, Md., experiment station the first of a series of small but "expansible" farmhouses to be furnished and tested for livability.

One of the numerous apparitions used to confuse voters during the recent election campaign was the prediction that if General Eisenhower should be elected it would mean the scrapping of the Hull Trade Agreements policy and a return to the protectionist philosophy of the Smoot-Hawley days. General Eisenhower's own comment on this question was instinctively sound.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 11 -- St. Peter's High scored Hudson County's biggest upset of the football season by halting Memorial High of West New York, 13--7, today. The defeat ended the thirty-one game streak of the Orange and Black, which had gone unbeaten and untied since bowing to Camden Catholic in a postseason clash in 1948.

HANOI, Vietnan, Indo-China, Nov. 11 -- French and Vietnamese troops fanned out today from Phudoan in the new French drive into territory held by the pro-Communist Vietminh forces seventy-five miles northwest of Hanoi. They are making a methodical, large-scale search for Vietminh supply dumps.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11 -- The resignation of Edward G. Miller, Jr., as Assistant Secretary of State for Inter - American Affairs was welcomed by the Peronista newspapers today as an indication of a forthcoming change in foreign policy toward Latin America under the Eisenhower Administration.

C. B. S. television's coverage of the Presidential inauguration ceremonies on Jan. 20 will be sponsored by the Packard Motor Car Company. The sponsored portion of the telecast will present the procession from the White House to the Capitol, beginning at 11:30 A. M.; the parade back to the White House Reviewing Stand, at 1 P. M. and the review of the parade.

UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Delegates to the convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs approved, at their opening session today, the further development by private enterprise of hydroelectric power from the Niagara River.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Assistant Defense Secretary Anna Rosenberg and Gen. James A. Van Fleet are agreed that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's forthcoming visit to Korea will be profitable.
SACRAMENTO, Nov. 11 -- Governor Warren has not yet received the resignation of Senator Nixon, his office said today, nor decided who his successor would be.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio believes it was a "negative enthusiasm against what had been going on in Washington in the Executive Administration" that swept Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to victory in the Presidential election.

Deprecation of the Police Athletic League that was included in recommendations made recently by the Institute of Public Administration for the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey was deplored yesterday by the league's board of directors.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, in a radio broadcast last night, declared it "essential to each free nation that it support freedom in others where freedom still lives." In his election campaign he had been accused of surrendering to isolationists, but last night he displayed his continued support of international cooperation.

An arbitration award in the wage dispute between the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and the New York Shipping Association is expected to be made before the end of the week by Paul R. Hays, arbiter. The decision will affect 42,000 regularly employed dockmen and 20,000 occasional workers in ports from Maine to Virginia.
Our great voluntary hospitals were organized to provide care for the sick, regardless of their ability to pay. Thousands every year are admitted on a free or belowcost basis.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Major officers of the Professional Golfers Association were re-elected at the annual convention today.
YANCEYVILLE, N. C., Nov. 11 -- An all-white jury today convicted Mack Ingram, a Negro sharecropper, of assault by "leering" at a white girl at a distance of sixty feet.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- While Soviet Stakhanovites and East German officials were honoring him last month as one of fifty-seven "Heroes of Labor, 1952," Willy Knoblauch was at a West Berlin refugee center.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UP) -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue said today that most Americans paid up without protesting when the tax collector pointed out "deficiencies" in their returns.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 11 -- A public meeting for discussion of conditions at Danbury Hospital, scene of a controversy between the board of managers and medical staff members, will be held Thursday at 8 P. M. in Elks Auditorium.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 11 -- Elaborate security precautions will surround Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower when he makes his forthcoming trip to Korea.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, announced yesterday that a contract had been entered into between Atlas and the Italian Superpower Corporation covering a recapitalization of the latter company, subject to any necessary approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of the Association of Land-Grant Colleges and brother of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, gave his organization today a nostalgic picture of their boyhood home at Abilene, Kan. This was his way of pointing up his theme that American youth must be educated in global problems to obtain peace.

George F. Kennan, who was declared persona non grata as United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union after likening present Russian restrictions on diplomats to those in Nazi Germany in 1941, returned home yesterday on the United States liner America for consultations with Secretary of State Dean Acheson.

ATHENS, Nov. 11 -- Fourteen representatives of North Atlantic Treaty nations arrived here today to board the United Stares Sixth Task Fleet's flagship Columbus, from which they will view Exercise Longstep, the current NATO naval exercises in the eastern Mediterranean.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Nov. 11 (AP) -- More than 4,000 Germans, barred from emigrating to the United States because of their Nazi past, will get a new chance next month.

CAIRO, Nov. 11 -- The State Department has begun recruiting in the United States a group of Americans to join an Egyptian group appointed by the Government of Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib to make a survey of the possibilities of a rapid development of Egypt's resources, chiefly her industry.

The "challenge" of the immediate future, specifically the need of business for stronger advertising programs to sell the products of the nation's increased industrial capacity, provided the theme yesterday for advertising meetings in two widely separated sections.

Samuel Leppo and Jack Hoffman have sold the four-story building at 83-22 Northern Boulevard in Jackson Heights, Queens, containing nine stores and thirty-nine apartments, to Abraham Goldstein Lawrence Smirbauch was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

Officials of the United States Lines, at a dinner tonight aboard the superliner United States, will accept in behalf of the ship the Hales Blue Ribbon Trophy for record Atlantic crossings by passenger liners. The four-foot-high silver and gilt symbol arrived here yesterday aboard the superliner in the custody of the Duke of Sutherland.
WHEN the Football Giants returned from pre-season training in Minnesota, they brought back a message for this reporter. "I have greetings," drawled Steve Owen, "from an old friend of yours."
Steady improvement is expected in the safety record of New York's waterfront, according to a report made public yesterday by John V. Lyon, chairman of the New York Shipping Association.

An assurance that American business can maintain prosperity despite a leveling-off in defense spending and a prediction that 1953 will see a buyers' market in new housing were issued here yesterday by the committee on economic trends and policies of the United States Savings and Loan League, which is holding its sixtieth annual convention at the Statler Hotel.
VERBANIA, Italy, Nov. 11 (UP) -- A court in near-by Novara will try two former United States secret agents early next year for the wartime murder of Maj. William V. Holohan of New York.

Fitting motor vehicles into the established pattern of city life and eliminating bottlenecks would resolve traffic difficulties here, William H. Holmes, president of the New York Board of Trade, said yesterday. He agreed with Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, that the congestion problem was confined to midtown Manhattan. Mr. Holmes decried off-street parking as a relief measure in that area.

TOKYO, Nov. 11 -- Political circles here now expect quick resumption of suspended negotiations with the Philippines and an offer by Japan for payment at least of token reparations in terms of services -- largely technical assistance in the development of Philippine natural resources.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Gloves designed for real jewels are Lionel Legrand's contribution to the spring. He suggests a new way to wear diamond earrings: Just clip them into the buttonholes on the little band cuffs that finish off his above-elbow white kid gloves. Short gloves have a vent on the back of the hand spanned by cuff links -- of diamonds on powder blue kid, of paved sapphires on garnet red suede gloves.

The attempt of the Arab League to sabotage the reparations agreement between Western Germany and Israel is the sort of thing that leaves a bad taste in the mouth. The Arabs are trying to prevent the Israelis from getting $775,000,000 worth of German goods, which would be a token payment for the horrors that the Nazi regime perpetrated on the Jews of Germany and Central Europe.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- A better financial tone developed on the stock markets today, although business continued small. British Government securities improved slightly. Their firmness, coupled with some encouraging profit and dividend statements and news of record steel output in October, helped industrial shares to rise.

The Yonkers ship's chandler who opened a private war on the Communists a year ago with a campaign in Italy based on a quiz contest has started another attack, this time in the United States and with record albums of informational lectures on communism.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 11 -- Representative Clifford R. Hope, Republican of Kansas, declared here today that Republican leaders in the new Congress want agricultural programs administered "from the farmer up, rather than from the Department of Agriculture down."

The Fourth Presbyterian Church, founded in 1785, which has been at Ninety-first Street and West End Avenue since 1893, will sell its property and merge with the Olmstead Avenue Presby terian Church, Olmstead and Newbold Avenues, the Bronx, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Moscow radio said tonight Trygve Lie's resignation was a revelation of "his complete political bankruptcy."
Eighty-nine young men and women, representing rural areas in the United States and Alaska, debarked here yesterday from the liners United States and Queen Elizabeth with accounts of farm life abroad.

The sixty-six-family apartment house at 19-25 East 213th Street, bought recently by the Mace Realty Corporation, has been resold to Katz Brothers, investors. It is assessed at $190,000. Mrs. Anne Inselstein was the broker in the sale and Bernard Friedman represented the seller.

BOMBAY, India, Nov. 11 -- The two Bombay editors invovled in the forgery case arising out of the publication of a letter purported to have been written by United States Ambassador Chester Bowles were discharged by the court today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The achievement of world peace and universal brotherhood can become a practical reality through a working partnership between religion and science, "two of the most potent forces in civilization," David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, declared today.

A new work by Carl Sandburg, "Always the Young Strangers," will be published on Jan. 6 by Harcourt, Brace to commemorate the poet-historian's seventy-fifth birthday. It is an account of his life in Galesburg, Ill., in which he was born, of his family and of his friends and neighbors, and of the change and growth of this country.

A demand that the Board of Estimate be supplied with "specific, first-hand" information on the $25,000,000 in Federal welfare funds allegedly withheld from the city by the Republican state administration was made yesterday by Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower's forthcoming trip to Korea can achieve no miracles. But as seen from Europe it has considerably more importance than the mere fulfillment of a campaign promise.

A family ownership of more than sixty years has been terminated in the sale of the Hughes Building at 515 Bloomfield Avenue in Montclair, N. J. The three-story structure containing three stores and nine apartments was conveyed by the 515 Bloomfield Avenue Corporation, represented by John E. Hughes, attorney, to Lena Price, represented by Chazin Chazin, attorneys. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

As far as preparations go, the stateside Christmas Eve for the men in Korea ends when the post offices close this Saturday. Any relatives or friends of soldiers and sailors in Asia who wish to get presents to the battlefront, the rear areas or the ships by Dec. 25 should mail them on or before Nov. 15.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 11 (UP) -- Authorities cabled European police today asking for the arrest of a former New Jersey State official who is charged with bilking a gangster of $228,000 in protection money.
DETROIT, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Three makes of cars in the General Motors 1953 lines will offer refrigerated air conditioning as optional equipment.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- As a follow-up to the speech on Tunisia delivered yesterday by Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister to the United Nations General Assembly, Mohammed Sidi el Amin, Bey of Tunis, released today extracts of a two-month-old report by a special council of advisers, urging rejection of the French plan for reforms.

ON THE KOREAN FRONT, Nov. 11 -- While war at best is a dirty business, the United States Army here has civilized life for the fighting man to a degree that would not have seemed believable to the American G. I. who landed in Africa ten years ago.

Armistice Day sales by major department stores were reported excellent, although there was a belief expressed by merchants that combined volume for yesterday and the preceding Monday would not more than equal that for the comparable two-day period last year.

MALIBU, Calif., Nov. 11 (UP) -- Anna Roosevelt Boettiger, only daughter of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, was married today to Dr. James A. Halsted at the physician's ranch in the near-by Malibu Mountains.
In Times Square yesterday morning, a 12-year-old Boy Scout sounded Taps, and then a crowd -- rather small for the "crossroads of the world" -- pledged allegiance to the flag of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Reconstruction Finance Corporation Chief Harry A. McDonald said today industries are showing "growing preference" for the R.F.C.'s newly-developed synthetic "cold" rubber.
The text of the radio speech of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Crusade for Freedom last night follows:

YONKERS, Nov. 11 -- The Pe-Ku-Pheasant Farm's Prince Eton from Tamaqua, Pa., with Johnny Bedell in the sulky, challenged from second place at the three quarter pole to win the $3,500 Greenwich pacing feature by three quarters of a length from Noble Dean in 2:06 4-5 before 14,003 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Four trustees of the George Washington University received honorary degrees tonight at the Fall Convocation of the University. The degrees were conferred by Dr. Cloyd H. Marvin, university president, for notable contributions made by the four to the life of the Washington community and to the nation.

General Eisenhower will be President of the nation to which we all belong. He will face numerous and demanding problems which cannot be solved without the goodwill of his countrymen. A great leader is worthy of magnanimous followers.

Lot No. 17 in Block 279 on the municipal land map, and the names of 153 New York settlers who sleep in it, were discussed yesterday at an unusual meeting at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- By more than 2 to 1 the parliamentary Labor party has chosen Herbert Morrison as deputy leader in preference to Aneurin Bevan, left-wing leader, it was announced today. The vote was 194 to 82 -- a majority of 112 for Mr. Morrison -- but Mr. Bevan's strength surprised his followers as well as his opponents.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 11 -- Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, said today the United States stood ready to pour atomic bombs on Soviet targets in the event of an attack "that might come at any minute."

BONN, Germany, Nov. 11 -- Fascist activity by former members of the waffen S. S., the armed branch of Hitler's Elite Guard, has penetrated into North Rhine-Westphalia, the most populous of the West German states.

REHOVOT, Israel, Nov 11 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, first President of the State of Israel, who died Sunday, was buried this afternoon in an olive grove on the side of a hill sloping eastward from his home toward Jerusalem.

DETROIT, Nov. 11 -- The United Automobile Workers Union moved today to put off the choice of a new president for the Congress of Industrial Organizations by urging postponement of the C. I. O. convention, which was scheduled to open in Los Angeles on Monday.

Many prominent persons in the social, civic and financial worlds, as well as high-ranking officers of the United States Armed Forces and foreign countries, attended the final performance of the sixty-fourth National Horse Show last night at Madison Square Garden. Many of the officers, who had attended Armistice Day observances during the day, remained in uniform for the show's final session.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Edward C. Dougherty will head the new Internal Revenue district comprising Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware, Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder announced today.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Officials of the Augustana Lutheran Church have withdrawn from a proposed merger of the five bodies of the American Lutheran Conference.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Goalie Jim Henry registered his third shutout as the Boston Bruins beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 0, in a National Hockey League matinee before 7,861 at the Garden today. Boston scored four times in the first period with Joe Klukay, Real Chevrefils, Hal Laycoe and Fleming Mackell registering.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- Pennsylvania, which has been specializing in close football games this season, is braced for another tight battle this Saturday, when Army pays its annual visit to Franklin Field.

Ballet Theatre, now on a coast-to-coast tour, will go to Europe next spring to make an extended tour of seven months. The company will sail on April 23 for Naples, where it will open at the San Carlo Opera House on May 4.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Following is the text of the address delivered today by Anthony Eden. British Foreign Secretary, at the United Nations General Assembly session:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11(AP) -- A Negro leader today interpreted a Supreme Court action of yesterday as "a beautiful step" toward the elimination of all segregation in railroad travel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Dr. Isador Lubin, United States representative in the United Nations Economic and Financial Committee, pressed Poland and Czechoslovakia today to reveal some of the "mysteries" about the "selfless generosity" of the Soviet Union in its trading with those members of its bloc.

The shrill wail of a siren piercing the noon hour at various times during the week should serve as a vivid reminder to all that our Civil Defense program is a necessary and vital force for the protection of our city. Preparedness is the first line of any defense and to prepare New York against a possible air raid is a purposeful operation.

Timothy N. Pfeiffer, president of the Legal Aid Society, announced yesterday that Eustace Seligman of the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell had been named general chairman of the society's 1953 fund raising campaign. Mr. Seligman is treasurer of the society.

Two members of the Senate Judiciary Committee suggested yesterday that the United Nations be ousted from its New York headquarters unless the international organization rid itself of "spies and saboteurs."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 -- A jurisdictional conflict over jobs in the Los Angeles television field that threatens to have national repercussions, and involve as well the motion-picture studios, faded yesterday when the International Brotherhood of Electric Workers backed down under pressure of an all-out fight warning by the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, the dominant union in the entertainment industry.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 11 (AP) -- The deportation of three Roman Catholic nuns will be recommended, L. C. Hafferman, Hearings Commissioner for the United States Immigration Service, reported today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The first running of the $25,000 added Gallorette Stakes was won by Mrs. Marian W. O'Connor's La Corredora, a 3-year-old Maryland-bred filly at Pimlico today. She returned $33.20 for $2 before a crowd of 16,748.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Britain urged Trygve Lie today to reconsider his resignation as Secretary General of the United Nations, but the halls were full of speculation about a successor and the corridors were full of candidates.

WHEN Avery Bullard dropped dead as he was about to get into a taxi in front of the Chippindale Building on Fifth Avenue he left behind him an important piece of unfinished business. And this was unlike him, but, as president and guiding genius of the Treadway Corporation, he had failed to fill the vacancy in the office of executive vice president.

The assessment of Chaim Weismann's share in the turbulent process which has transformed world affairs since the First World War must be left to the slow-maturing verdict of history. A fluctuating reputation is the common fate of statesmen, and Dr. Weizmann will not escape it.

Business executives believe that the current high level of business activity will be maintained and even increased in the first quarter of 1953, it was reported yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., on the basis of a national survey.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- This country's soil, water and fertilizer resources, if intelligently used, are sufficient to meet all foreseeable requirements of the fast-growing population, Dr. Robert M. Salter, chief of the Agriculture Department's Soil Conservation Service, asserted today.

For his third New York recital at Carnegie Hall, Fredrick Marvin, pianist, tried something different last night. For his final selection he assembled a flutist, an oboist, a clarinetist, a violinist and a cellist and played with them the concerto that de Falla wrote for those instruments with a harpsichord or a piano as the interchangeable solo instrument.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Department of Justice has stopped trying to send Paul (The Waiter) Ricca, former Capone henchman, back to prison to complete an extortion sentence, United States Attorney Otto Kerner Jr. reported today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 11 -- The "New Broom" Cabinet of President Carlos Ibanez del Campo held its first regular meeting today and decided to summon Congress in special session next Tuesday to consider quick action on bills to give the Government special economic powers, repeal the anti-Communist Law and investigate the last Administration.
SEA ISLAND, Ga., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Directors of the Bureau of Advertising, a national newspaper promotional group, said today the business outlook for 1953 is "surprisingly favorable."
TUCSON, Nov. 11 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson was expected to arrive at Municipal Airport "sometime tomorrow" for five days of relaxation on a ranch at Sasabe, Ariz., about sixty miles north of here.

For its premiere of the season, the New York City Ballet presented last night at the City Center George Balanchine's choreographic setting of Mendelssohn's "Scotch Symphony," or at least the last three movements of it.
The teleflop, most easily identified as imitation in a setting of hysteria, is ever with us.
Members of the American Veterans Committee donated blood to the American Red Cross blood bank at 70 West Fortieth Street yesterday in their fourth annual contribution to mark Armistice Day.

Michigan State, Georgia Tech and Maryland, all by themselves as the 1, 2, 3 teams in this week's Associated Press poll, face assignments Saturday that will either keep them far out ahead or drop them down into the pack.
A little girl in the Bronx decided to "play mother" yesterday and as a result, there was a hectic hour around East 146th Street and Willis Avenue.
GENEVA, Nov. 11 -- The removal of quantitative controls on imports by members of the Western community of trading nations seems to be about as distant an objective as at any time since World War II.

TUPELO, Miss., Nov. 11 (AP) -- The circulation manager of The Tupelo Journal told the police today that two hooded men had taken him on a wild ride last night, menacing him with a razor because he was a "Yankee," and had threatened him with worse if he and his wife did not leave town by 6 P. M. tomorrow.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- France's task today is to regain her place in the world as a first-class power, Premier Antoine Pinay said in a speech at ceremonies in the forest of Compiegne where the armistice in World War I was signed thirty-four years ago.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The first attempt by the Labor Opposition to defeat Prime Minister Churchill's Conservative Government in this new session of Parliament was defeated tonight in the House of Commons by 313 votes to 279. This gave the Government a margin of 34.

The resignation of Mr. Trygve Lie as Secretary General was received with dismay in the United Nations. The President of the General Assembly, Mr. Lester Pearson, had been informed of Mr. Lie's intention last September, but most of the delegations had no inkling of it an hour before it was announced.

Despite the loss of production due to power shortages, the nation's output of primary aluminum in the third quarter of 1952 will exceed that of the preceding quarter by 2.2 per cent, Donald M. White, secretary of the Aluminum Association, reported yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11 -- The discovery of the location within the living cell of the "power-plant of life," where the energy to keep life going is generated, was reported here today at the annual autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences, held at Washington University.

Today's new film is "The Steel Trap," a melodrama written and directed by Andrew Stone and starring Joseph Cotten and Teresa Wright, at Loew's State. The Thor Productions presentation was produced by Bert E. Friedlob and is being released by Twentieth Century-Fox.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 12 -- Reinforced South Korean troops, in a savage five-hour battle today, recaptured "Pinpoint Hill," a key position on the ridges south of Kumhwa, on the central Korean front. The hill had been lost last night to a powerful Chinese assault, backed by heavy artillery and mortar barrages.

Mrs. Elizabeth Bykova of Russia, winning her adjourned tenth-round game from Mrs. Rowena Bruce of England yesterday, increased her lead in the women's world chess championship challengers' tournament in Moscow, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.

ILION, N. Y., Nov. 11 (UP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur made his first official visit tonight to the Remington Rand Corporation here and read a poem that he said he had carried with him for years to the company's Twenty-Five-Year Club.
The New York Chamber of Commerce warned yesterday that city fiscal officers were spending too much time searching for new sources of revenue and not enough time developing programs of economy.

The Museum of Modern Art is keeping to its laudable policy of encouraging new talent by showing, in its Penthouse Gallery, work by three young American artists, two painters and a sculptor, whose work is unfamiliar to New York.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 11 -- A definite trend in 1953 toward increased electric company sales and advertising budgets together with larger selling organizations was noted here today by Bayard L. England, president of the Edison Electric Institute.

In a letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Nov. 7 the writer, Martha A. Zalles, secretary, East Harlem Health Council, called attention to a fire in an empty warehouse on the site of Washington Houses, and drew conclusions based on the false assumption that the building was allowed to stand empty through indifference on the part of the Housing Authority.
Salaries for probation officers in the city's courts are "simply terrible," Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, chairman of the executive committee of the Jewish Big Sisters, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Robert H. Jackson, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, denied before a Congressional investigating committee today that the Administration in Washington had attempted to influence the International Military Tribunal, which tried Nazis in 1945-46, to the advantage of the Soviet Union.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- The Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today a resolution to establish a good offices commission to arrange and assist in negotiations between the Union of South Africa on the one hand and India and Pakistan on the other regarding the treatment of people of Indian origin in South Africa.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, appealed today to the Soviet Union, Communist China and North Korea to accept the principle that "after an armistice [in Korea] a prisoner of war may not be either forcibly detained or forcibly repatriated."

DENVER, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Senator Eugene D. Millikin of Colorado, who is expected to have a lot of influence on the handling of finances by the incoming Republican-controlled Congress, indicated today that defense plans would control tax reductions.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 11 -- The affair of the goats has become one of the season's major biological disappointments of this northern territory.

Americans today face "the greatest opportunity in history to make a lasting reality of our traditions of economic and individual freedom, of progress and prosperity, and the conquest of fear," according to Clarence Francis, chairman of the board of General Foods Corporation.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- Representatives of the State Civil Service Employes Association met today with Governor Dewey to urge his support for their program for "a substantial increase" in all state workers' salaries for the 1953-54 fiscal year.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 -- The vice presidents and executive officers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, gathered here for the funeral tomorrow of Philip Murray, C. I. O. president, agreed today to postpone the organization's annual convention for two weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Democrats supporting Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas for the post of minority leader in the new Senate tonight asserted his election was cinched as Northern support for him developed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- India will put her own formula for a Korean armistice before the United Nations. It will center on a proposal to send prisoners of war to islands off the Korean Peninsula where they would be declared to be free.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 13 -- Hard-fighting South Koeran troops recaptured yesterday all positions lost in the earlier Chinese Communist night attacks on the ridges north of Kumhwa on the central Korean front. Last night the South Koreans beat off new Communist advances.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The president of The Associated Press Managing Editors Association called on the incoming national Administration today to lift an Executive Order restricting news of Government agencies.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 -- A new approach to the alleviation of high blood pressure, already tried "with benefit" on 200 patients, was described here today at the closing sessions of the autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, defended today this country's military policy in Korea and recommended its firm continuance.

The scope of the present inquiry of the Federal Maritime Board into the dual-rate practices of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference was broadened yesterday to similar rate structures of all such steamship line organizations.
Rugs that are all-paper or of synthetic fibers and a yard or more wide make up a new group of carpets made by the Waite Carpet Company. John Gerald and Miss Katharine Kinnane designed the collection.

ON THE KOREAN FRONT, Nov. 6 -- The young American lieutenant was dead when they brought his body down from the nameless hill just west of "Old Baldy." Three other soldiers had been killed in the same patrol action. When the battalion commander heard of the deaths he sat on the edge of his cot and began to cry.

The article by the auto association and your editorial relative to so-called jaywalking were read with interest, but I failed to find any mention in them of the real danger to pedestrians -- namely, those drivers who turn corners recklessly and without regard for the rights of others.

ATLANTA, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The State Court of Appeals deadlocked 3 to 3 today over a contempt of court citation against Ralph McGill, editor, and William Fields, managing editor of The Atlanta Constitution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The fact that those burnt children of 1948 -- Gallup, Roper and Crossley -- shrank in 1952 from the possibility of getting singed again in the fires of political prophecy has led to widely expressed hopes that not much attention will be paid hereafter to the national pollster syndicateers.

CORNWALL - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- There was plenty of activity at the New York Military Academy today. The jayvees were playing against Storm King, the soccer squad was meeting Peekskill Military Academy and the varsity, stripped of its reserves because of the jayvee test, was going through a signal drill at the Parade Field.
A signal victory in the merchant marine industry campaign to eliminate Government competition in the field of ocean transport was seen in a Federal Maritime Board decision issued yesterday.

Two 92-year-old Hunter College graduates proved yesterday that good old-fashioned vocal cords are just as dependable as some modern mechanical inventions. Rejecting the aid of microphones, the nonagenarians from the class of 1878 greeted 2,000 alumnae and undergraduates at the college's annual Alumnae Day Assembly.

Puccini's "La Tosca," which was the second production of the Metropolitan Opera's new season last night, is an opera not only for singers but also for actors. There is a further problem; theatrics really suited to the melodramatics of the story will not go down with audiences today, and the singer must find somehow, somewhere an acting technique compounded of restraint and intensity.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Professional Golfers Association today rejected, by a 46-to-7 vote, a proposal to modify the match-play system of the National P. G. A. tourney.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 12 -- A bill reorganizing the political structure of Yugoslavia to conform with the decentralization of the economic system will be submitted to the National Assembly at the end of this month.

The Hales Blue Ribbon Trophy, awarded in the last seventeen years for the fastest Atlantic crossing by a passenger liner, was presented last night for the first time to an American ship. The recipient was the superliner United States, which last summer made new records.
The Barium Steel Corporation announced yesterday the purchase from the Pittsburgh Steel Company of a rotary forging seamless tube mill. The price paid for the mill was not disclosed.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 12 -- Benjamin F. Feinberg, chairman of the New York Public Service Commission, declared today that the economic plight of privately owned city bus companies is an "extraordinary phenomenon" amid the great expansion of other utilities -- "a situation full of contradictions."

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 12 -- An Air Force spokesman said today that two veterans had been "fixed up" by Washington officials so they could "hitch-hike" free rides to and from Europe on military aircraft.

Young women are aiding in the plans for the third annual Le Bal Blanc for the benefit of the House of Free Russia, Inc., to be held tonight in the Carnaval Room of the Sherry-Netherland. Prince Serge Belosselsky heads the executive committee for the fete.
The Holland Tunnel, first underwater vehicular crossing with "lungs," will be twenty-five years old today.

On the field and in the dressing room, the New York Football Giants yesterday buckled down to the formidable job of preparing an effective defense against the passing attack of the Green Bay Packers, whom they will meet at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.
Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad authorized yesterday a three-year $47,000,000 program of freight service improvements, one of the largest of its kind ever undertaken by the road.

The rise in the average discount at which the Treasury sold its last weekly issue of discount bills indicates that the sale of the 210-day tax anticipation bill issue today will be at a rate of discount measurably higher than the average cost of 1.72 per cent waived by the $2,500,000,000 issue of 161-day bills sold in October.

Mayor Impellitteri has done a double disservice in directing the Board of Water Supply to refrain from conducting an objective engineering study of the upper Hudson River as a future auxiliary source of water for this city. Such a study was recommended by the nation's foremost water supply experts.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 -- The treaty system that will bind an armed and equal West Germany to Western Europe moved a short but important step toward ratification today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that favorable harvesting weather has assured the nation its second largest crop output on record, but added that prospects for some 1953 crops are disturbing.

An Iowa housewife who fell victim to poliomyelitis a year ago told here yesterday the story of her fight back from a half-life of physical helplessness to a useful and happy place as the mother of two children.

TUPELO, Miss., Nov. 12 (AP) -- A young North Dakota newspaper man and his 21-year-old pregnant wife started homeward to Fargo today one hour before a deadline he said was set by hooded men for him to get out of town because he was a Yankee.

Ambassador Ernest A. Gross, deputy head of the United States delegation to the United Nations, last night gave assurances that the delegation would not abandon its position against the forcible repatriation of Communist prisoners of war in Korea.

Newly arrived from France, just in time for holiday entertaining, are collections of glass and linens at Baccarat Porthault, 55 East Fifty-seventh Street. A peculiarly Parisian elegance and formality characterize both, although several of the designs have been slanted to American taste.
TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 12 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, en route to southern Arizona for a rest at a ranch on the Mexican border, reached Tucson municipal airport at 9:20 tonight, Eastern standard time.

Appointment of a new top management team for L. E. Waterman Company, manufacturer of writing equipment, has been announced by Frank D. Waterman, president. Robert D. Howse, formerly president of Argus Cameras, Ann Arbor, Mich., becomes executive vice president.

Baseball Commissioner Ford C. Frick yesterday made a decision unprecedented in the history of the office he holds by placing Jim Rivera, White Sox outfielder, on probation and prohibiting the Chicago American League club from disposing of Rivera's contract by trade or waiver "for the period of one year."
Hector Chevigny, newly elected president of the Radio Writers Guild, has filed a complaint in State Supreme Court against thirty-one guild members.

Commodities closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges with potatoes and rubber most active. Prices of rubber, zinc, cocoa and vegetable oils were higher, and hides, tin, potatoes and coffee closed lower. Lead, wool and sugar were mixed.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 -- Pretty and feminine continue to be words that come to mind at the California designers' showings for National Press Week, under the sponsorship of California Fashion Creators. Coats and suits were presented today for the first time; play and sun togs were important and mother and daughter dresses added lively interest.

The Grenfell Association of America elected Arthur W. Bingham Jr. president of the board of directors, succeeding William L. Savage, at its annual meeting in the Hanover Bank, 40 East Forty-second Street, yesterday. Other officers elected were William Adams Delano, Dr. Beeckman J. Delatour and J. Minturn LeRoy, vice presidents; Edwin K. Merrill, treasurer, and Miss Eleanor J. Cushman, secretary.

Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York was the guest of honor last night at a dinner commemorating the 125th anniversary of the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street.

Madeleine Renaud, Jean-Louis Barrault and their Theatre Marigny company have arrived in New York, and they are most welcome. After suitable patriotic exercises, which were also most welcome, the Barraults raised the curtain on Marivaux' "Les Fausses Confidences" (The False Secrets) at the Ziegfeld last evening, and inaugurated a month of repertory in French.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Norman Hayes, 160 1/2, scored a technical knockout over Joey De John, 165, in the third round of their nationally televised fight tonight by sending De John to the canvas three times moments after Joey thought he was on the verge of whipping Hayes with a technical knockout.

The installation of safety devices without "selling" employes on using them properly is almost totally wasted effort, a group of Government employes were told yesterday by Capt. Vernon E. Day, Engineering and Safety Officer of the Third Coast Guard District.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Police authorities asserted today they had unearthed a plot for a Communist revolution in Thailand involving members of the armed forces, the National Assembly and a former Premier.
Voluntary hospitals in New York City are in the forefront in matters of research, one rea son why the system of this city has been called the finest in the world.

Big Labor, like Big Business, is affected with a public interest. We are reminded of this by the death of Philip Murray and the tasks he bequeaths to the men who will head the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the United Steelworkers of America. Virtually every major problem of a large labor organization has a facet that impinges on the public in one way or another.

Elia Kazan is back from-Europe and things are expected to start happening soon on "Camino Real," the Tennessee Williams play that will have such diverse characters as Casanova, Don Quixote, Sancho Panza and Dumas' Marguerite Gautier.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 12 -- New highs in system capacity and average daily deliveries of gas to customers, and increased net income of $4,526,448 for the third quarter of 1952, were reported by the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company in its quarterly report mailed to stockholders today.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 12 -- The United States mail and its carriers were temporarily stayed from completion of their appointed rounds here today -- because of a one-man noise abatement campaign pressed by a harassed Federal judge.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Acting City Judge Edward K. Kennedy today asked state officials to provide a stiffer penalty than the present $10 maximum fine for a motorist who leaves the scene without reporting after killing a dog or other domestic pet on the highway.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Westchester County's conservative citizens looking out from their Old English-style leaded casements may suck in their breath sharply when they see the interior of the new $700,000 Student Arts Center that Sarah Lawrence College will formally unveil here Friday morning.

International Harvester Company announced yesterday the appointment of Motorola-New York, Inc., as distributor for International Harvester refrigerators, home freezers, room air conditioners and dehumidifiers in New York City, Long Island and Westchester County.
The Denver, Colo., City and County School District No. 1 borrowed $30,000,000 yesterday on serial bonds maturing from 1953 to 1971 at an interest cost of 1.8905 per cent.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Spurred by what he said were the feelings of the United States public and Congress, Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, made an impassioned plea today for a further reduction in the United States contribution to the cost of the United Nations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- The General Assembly's Special Political Committee opened debate today on the issue of racial discrimination in South Africa, with discussion limited to the competence of the United Nations to deal with the matter under the provisions of its Charter.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Farewell parties are starting at the White House, Mrs. James M. Helm, social secretary, said today.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries increased sales in the first nine months this year, but earnings were little changed from a year ago, the report revealed yesterday.

TOKYO, Nov. 12 -- The United States signed an agreement today to lend Japan a fleet of eighteen frigates and fifty landing craft as the first formal step toward the underwriting of Jap anese rearmament for defense.

A warning against attempts by advertising agencies to "wash away the uncertainties" about many phases of international advertising with a "flood of words" was issued yesterday by George Barnes, export advertising manager of the Bristol-Myers Company.

A magnificent emerald and diamond necklace, which the late Henry Ford gave his wife for Christmas twenty years ago, will be auctioned here next week. The jewel, together with fourteen other precious ornaments that Mrs. Ford, who died in 1950, had acquired, will be on exhibition today at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 12 -William H. Abel, former president of the Central National Bank of Mineola, and Mrs. Lillian B. Robinson, the Roslyn business executive accused of swindling $475,000 from the bank through forged loan applications, were released today under $40,000 bail each to await trial in Nassau County Court on a conspiracy charge and fifty counts of second-degree forgery.
Improved sales and earnings for the first quarter of its fiscal year and the possible undertaking of additional financing next year were reported by R. H. Macy Co., Inc.

George B. Wellbaum, retired assistant vice president in charge of public relations for the New York Telephone Company, was honored last evening at a reception and cocktail party in the Biltmore Hotel by 150 of the many friends he has made in his twenty-four years with that company. His retirement was effective on Nov. 1.

An investment banking syndicate headed by White Weld Co., will offer to investors today $20,000,000 of new 3.65 per cent subordinated convertible debentures of International Minerals and Chemical Corporation due July 1, 1977. The securities are priced at 100.

SHELTON, Wash., Nov. 12 (AP) -- A Navy patrol plane with eleven men aboard crashed in flames near here tonight and state patrolmen said it was unlikely there were any survivors. The Navy said the plane was a four-engined Privateer from its Sand Point Naval Air Station at Seattle.

DANFORTH, Me., Nov. 12 -- Deer hunting, like roulette, is cluttered up with theories. As a result of violating one of those tenets today we are back in Rideout's Camp wet, weary and without that big ten-pointer we are seeking.

Mrs. Bessie Honig of 120 South Elliot Place, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday before Special Sessions Justice Bernard A. Kozicke to a violation of the multiple dwelling law as the owner of a house at 10 Stuyvesant Avenue, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Queen Elizabeth showed her great interest in the work of the Incorporated Society of London Fashion Designers when she visited the Hotel Claridge with Princess Margaret this afternoon to see sixty-six designs selected from the collections. Crowds cheered their arrival.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- Enrollment in the state's public schools this year increased 92,225, about 4.6 per cent, over the opening figures for the 1951-52 academic year, the State Education Department reported today.

LARRY GOETZ is an excellent umpire, one of the very best in either league. So deep is his devotion to the game that he attends world series, All-Star games or any gathering of the baseball clans, even when he has to pay his own way. Not many in the sport are as singularly loyal, their ardor cooling as soon as they have to reach for their wallets.

Some 10,000 to 15,000 Soviet bloc books, pamphlets, newspapers and other writings come each month through the port of New York, handling about half the nation's imports, it was estimated at the Custom House yesterday.

The sound trucks are banished, the sale of campaign furniture is in progress. It is a lull that is perfect for a little reflection on the merits and demerits, the why and the wherefore. It is also a good time to stop and think of a great gap in our system of governmental management.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Iran made a new offer to Britain today to settle the dispute between the two countries over the nationalization of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Nov. 12 -- Southern California's most prolonged siege of smog -- five straight weeks -- has cost farmers from San Diego to Ventura a half million dollars in crop damage, a plant pathologist reported today.

May I sign at the foot of your editorial hailing Paul R. Crowell of THE TIMES upon his receipt of the Silurian Society's award for his "integrity as a newspaper man"? You state that through the years he has been unique as a specialist in rapid transit matter; truer words could not be spoken.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Nov. 12 -- Herschel D. Newsom, master of the National Grange, called today for a review of the nation's anti-trust and industry-wide collective bargaining laws to determine if they restrained or promoted monopoly.

Today's new film is "Plymouth Adventure," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's Technicolor drama about the Pilgrims and the Mayflower voyage, at the Radio City Music Hall. Spencer Tracy, Gene Tierney, Van Johnson, Leo Genn, Dawn Addams, Lloyd Bridges and Barry Jones are among the principals.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Dr. Arthur J. Leonard, Democratic leader of Saratoga County, was named in a second bribery indictment today as he awaited trial on a first involving gambling operations in the county.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Yale University's football committee will meet in New York City tomorrow to consider a new three-year contract for Head Coach Jordan Olivar, the New Haven Register reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -- David L. Cole, Director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, suggested to labor relations experts here today that their interest would be better served if they stopped bringing their bargaining problems to the Government.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 -- An American film about Marshal Erwin Rommel, German commander m North Africa, has fanned a struggle between neo-Nazi and anti-Nazi groups in the German colony in Argentina.

The spotlight will be focused again today on the links between politics and the underworld when the State Crime Commission opens its long-awaited hearings into alleged abuses in connection with local judicial appointments and the corrupt bestowing of political favors.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 12 -- Dr. Pinkos Churgin of New York, retiring president of the Mizrachi Organization of America, pleaded tonight for unity in the development of Israel and emphasized that the need "was no less urgent in Israel than among its non-Israeli supporters."
TOKYO, Nov. 12 -- Japan's Foreign Office revealed today it had asked ten World War II Allied nations to parole the twelve remaining Japanese major war criminals this month.
Another big return on a $1 investment was obtained by Mrs. Kay Erik Jensen, wife of the former jockey who has become a highly successful trainer, at the Jamaica track yesterday.

Scenes that reflect the leisure of summertime and holidays are depicted in a series of wallpapers designed by James Seeman. The papers are machine-made but in appearance and design give the impression of hand-prints. They will be available at Gimbels and Bloomingdale's tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Abe Burrows, television and stage writer and comedian, conceded today that to all appearances he was a Communist in the Nineteen Forties, but, he declared, "in my heart of hearts I never believed in it."

TORONTO, Nov. 12 -- The organizational setup in one of the biggest merchandising mergers ever to take place in Canada was announced today by Simpsons-Sears, Ltd. The new company will introduce Sears techniques and products to Canadians in an effort to corral a greater share of the nation's $10,000,000 annual retail trading.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 12 -- "Isn't father coming soon?" 8-year-old Princess Benedict of Denmark asked in a loud voice as the royal families of Sweden, Norway and Denmark met tonight at the opera for a concert celebrating the seventieth birthday of King Gustaf Adolf.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer asserted tonight that West Germany would stand by its restitution agreement with Israel and would not yield to the threats of an economic boycott advanced by the Arab League.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Mrs. Emanuel Siner of Long Island today was re-elected to a second two-year term as president of the National Women's League of the United Synagogue.
The post-holiday session brought little change yesterday in the cautious, approach to the stock market. Price changes throughout the day were narrow and quotations generally leaned to the lower side.

That headline in this newspaper the other day -- "New Gadgets Lend Order to Closets" -- no doubt was eyed hopefully in households where, concerning the use of closet space, the distaff side's theories and masculine views collide head-on.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady, yesterday, 7 to 17 points higher than on Tuesday with a moderate volume of business.
A brief visit to New York has given me the opportunity to read the letter headed "Incidents in Kenya" in your issue of Nov. 5.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Egypt called upon the United Nations today to give its full support to the aspirations for freedom and self-government of the peoples of Tunisia and Morocco.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, playing superbly, gave its first New York concert of the season last night at Carnegie Hall. In all respects of performance, in quality of tone, sensitiveness of phrase, glow of color, this was the Boston Orchestra at its finest, as Mr. Munch's conducting was of a perceptiveness and authority that made the evening one of rare satisfactions.

The National Horse Show that ended Tuesday night in Madison Square Garden was too big, Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman, the show's president, said yesterday. He will propose to the board of directors that some form of qualifying system for entries, particularly in the hunter and jumper divisions, be adopted for next year.

An orthodox program of songs was presented last night in Town Tall, where Gerald Smith, baritone, made his New York debut. Durante, Beethoven, Wolf, Brahms and John Duke were the composers chiefly represented. Harold Eisenberg was at the piano.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 12 -- A new "philosophy" of baby feeding, including early introduction of solid foods and only three meals a day, was outlined by a Miami physician today at the convention of the Southern Medical Association.

A former Army surgeon who spent an average of fifteen hours a day for five weeks on Corregidor with John David Provoo, who is on trial in Federal court on treason charges, added further weight yesterday to the Government's case.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Secretary of the Interior Oscar Chapman warned today that the United States still is teetering on the edge of a grave shortage of aviation gasoline in grades required by the armed forces. At the American Petroleum Institute's annual meeting in the Conrad Hilton Hotel he said prospects are for increasing shortages unless something is done quickly.

A Senate internal security subcommittee called a sudden halt yesterday to its open hearings on subversion among United Nations employes but promised to bring into the open "very important matters" after Jan. 1.

The Yankees and Dodgers, who met seven times in the 1952 World Series, will tangle eight times next spring, according to the world champions' spring training exhibition schedule released yesterday by General Manager George Weiss.
Methods have been considerably improved by the laboratories of the United States Bureau of Customs, it was reported yesterday by John F. Williams, chief of the bureau's division of laboratories.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 -- Permission to borrow $2,400,000 to meet the first payments of Federal estate and state inheritance taxes was granted today to executors of the William Randolph Hearst estate by Superior Judge Newcomb Condee.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Government moved today to bar the possibility of any general advance in natural gas prices at the production level.

YANCEYVILLE, N. C., Nov. 12 (AP) -- A Negro tenant farmer, convicted of assaulting a white girl by "leering" at her, escaped a jail term today, but he will appeal his conviction to the State Supreme Court.

A one-piece molded plastic television cabinet, introduced in 1948 by Admiral Corporation, enabled that company to make an immediate price reduction of $100 on its seven-inch set. That year 10,000 such cabinets were molded. Since then technical progress has been steady and large plastic cabinets are being turned out at the rate of 160,000 a month.

The Board of Transportation came up with a new twist yesterday in its defense against the perennial complaint of the subway straphanger. "Too many trains," the board said, rather than too few, caused yesterday's delay, which made thousands of morning rush-hour travelers in Brooklyn ten minutes late.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 (AP) -- H. B. Delman's Roaming gained his second straight victory of the Pimlico meeting today, scoring by a length and a half over Mrs. Robert H. Heighe's Seer in the $4,500 Mount Washington purse.
