LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The stock markets were heartened today by Chancellor of the Exchequer Butler's statement in the House of Commons yesterday that Britain was making economic progress and the announcement today that exports increased during October.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Joseph M. Dodge arrived today to carry out his assignment as budget liaison officer for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, and emphasized at once that he was here strictly as an observer.

The protracted efforts of Peter Harisiades, textile union organizer who was held to be a member of the Communist party by the United States Supreme Court, to avoid deportation, ended yesterday at 11:35 A. M. with his departure on the Norwegian liner Oslofjord, for Scandinavian ports.

The first of a series of Supreme Court actions resulting from a five-month investigation by the state into allegedly illegal tie-ups among certain pharmaceutical corporations, physicians and druggists was instituted yesterday by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

Wally Hergesheimer personally conducted the New York Rangers to their second victory of the National Hockey League season at Madison Square Garden last night. The diminutive right wing came through with a high-hat trick of four goals as the Broadway Blues skated to a 5-to-2 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks before a crowd of 5,130.

We may think of ourselves as beef eaters but actually, on a per capita basis, we consume more pork than any other meat. Fall is the season when supplies rise; it also is the time when pork becomes more pleasing to the palate. We suspect this is an "inherited" appetite of the brisker weather, coming down to us from the days when pork was taboo in the summer and considered wholesome only in cool temperatures.

The young instrumentalists who will play in the series of WQXP broadcasts called "Musical Talent in Our Schools," in addition to being considered for solo engagements for the young people's concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony next season, will also be considered for solo opportunities in the children's concerts of the Little Orchestra Society.
BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- Wilhelm Pieck, President of the East Ger man Government pledged today that his regime would "never permit" that Germans again wage war against France.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 -- Clair Bee, former basketball coach at Long Island University, was named coach of the Baltimore Bullets of the National Basketball Association tonight.

The press, education and religion will be represented at the dedication this evening of the new Public School 18 in the Bronx which is named for John Peter Zenger, whose courage in standing up for freedom of the press in colonial days is remembered with inspiration to this day.

An international standard for color fastness in textiles is close to realization. The project, worked on for the last four years by the International Organization for Standardization, should be completed within a year, according to textile technicians who attended a three-day meeting in New York at the offices of the American Standards Association.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of New York City's public school system, called upon educators tonight to fight any attempt by the Federal Communications Commission to give to commercial interests the television channels reserved for educational use.

Campaign committees of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York have amassed $71,660 toward the $285,000 that is needed to operate thirteen "Y" centers in Manhattan and the Bronx in 1953.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12 -- Columbia Pictures plans to make early next year a romantic adventure drama based on the life of Casanova, the eighteenth century Italian nobleman. The screen play will be drawn from the fourteen-volume memoirs of Casanova de Seingalt.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- United Nations technical assistance programs list 956 experts at work in more than sixty countries, David Owen, executive chairman of the technical assistance board, reported today.
Stan Musial of the Cardinals and six members of the pennant-winning Dodgers were named to the United Press' National League All-Star team yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Farm lands in New York State have declined by more than 4,600,000 acres in thirty years, and there are 68,218 fewer farms than there were in 1920.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Sir Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan, Vice President of India and a noted philosopher and theologian, was elected president of the seventh general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization which opened its sessions here today.

State officials from Governor Dewey down, city officials from Mayor Impellitteri down and leaders of private social agencies turned out en masse for the fifth anniversary conference of the New York City Youth Board this week. This was, indeed, testimony that the Youth Board has won the widespread admiration for the way it is combating juvenile delinquency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- For the first ten months of this year dividends of corporations issuing monthly reports showed a gain of 3 per cent over 1951, the Office of Business Economics of the United States Department of Commerce reported today.

The Pennsylvania Railroad was accused yesterday of deliberately forcing its subsidiary, the Long Island Rail Road, into receivership so it could sell the passenger facilities of the bankrupt railroad to a state authority for $75,000,000.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Grain trade sentiment switched quite decisively to the bull side today, substantial gains being registered as buying assumed more aggressive proportions.

An operating deficit of $11,885,335 on the municipal transit system for the three months ended Sept. 30 was reported yesterday by the Board of Transportation. This operating loss for the first quarter of the current fiscal year was $6,271,794 larger than the deficit for the same period in 1951-52.

HARRISON, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Fearful that this town may become "a center of ignorance or an object of ridicule," a committee of prominent residents announced today it would protest tomorrow the Harrison Board of Education's recent order that oficers of any community organization wishing to use Harrison school facilities must sign a "loyalty" oath before meeting and that guest speakers must do likewise before speaking.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 5, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

The American Cancer Society presented yesterday its 1952 Distinguished Service Award posthumously to Howard W. Blakeslee, science editor of The Associated Press. Mr. Blakeslee's widow, Rosamond, received the award at ceremonies at the 21 Club, 21 West Fifty-second Street.

CAIRO, Nov. 12 -- The Wafd party intends to challenge before the State Council the constitutionality of the law for purging and reorganizing political parties. The State Council acts as the supreme court of Egypt.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12 (UP) -- There were no tickets sold and no ticket takers at the door of a Columbus neighborhood theatre tonight, but the house was packed.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 12 -- The American Association of Port Authorities, comprising port managers and officials from the leading harbors in this country and twenty-five foreign countries, is holding its forty-first annual convention in this port city.

Homer Smith, Princeton's power-plunging fullback, was named The Associated Press back of the week yesterday. Smith last Saturday overpowered Harvard defenses in a display of slam-bang football -- a contrast to the slick T formation quarterbacks and speedy, clever halfbacks who often gain the headlines.

Morton Bloom is a bathroom tenor whose singing -- to hear his neighbors tell it -- has frequently driven them out of their homes and their minds. All protests to 17-year-old Morton and his parents having failed, the neighbors appealed yesterday to Magistrate Charles F. Murphy in Long Island City Court, Queens, to silence the boy.

Under the new national Administration the cost of money will be based more on factors of supply and demand, and less on "government edict and political motivation," a spokesman for the savings and loan industry declared last night.

GENEVA, Nov. 12 -- The first projects for utilizing the Ford Foundation's $2,900,000 grant designed to assist the integration of European refugees in countries where they now reside have been announced by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12 -- After taking five successive lickings from Princeton, Yale is strongly of the mind that it is time to win a game from its Big Three rival, and Coach Jordan Olivar thinks it can he done. The Bulldog and the Tiger meet here in the Bowl Saturday for the seventy-fifth time since 1873 before a crowd that is expected to reach 60,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Soviet bloc diplomats have been dropping hints that they believe agreement can be reached on a successor to Trygve Lie as Secretary General of the United Nations.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Premier Antoine Pinay told the National Assembly's Finance Committee today that France was keeping her arming pledges to the North Atlantic Council made in Lisbon, Portugal, this spring.
Your paper has championed the cause of city employes on many occasions in the past. I wonder if you could do something to shorten the delay in the city's initial payment to retired employes?

DALLAS, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Dallas franchise in professional football folded today after incurring losses that reached nearly a quarter of a million dollars, with the season a little more than half finished.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Defense Department reported today 1,318 Korean battle casualties in a week's fighting -- the largest weekly increase in a year.
Gains in Christmas trade ranging up to 10 per cent over last year are likely for jewelry, variety, department, clothing, electric appliance and radio-TV stores.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Previously secret 1943 correspondence between President Roosevelt and Premier Joseph Stalin, in which Mr. Roosevelt tried unsuccessfully to prevent a complete break between the Soviet Union and the Polish Government in Exile, was read into the public record today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire said today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower would conduct a bipartisan administration, appointing qualified Democrats to Federal posts as well as Republicans.

When does an internal dispute cross the borderline into the international field? This is the great problem with which the United Nations is grappling now, and not for the first time. What gives it special emphasis at this session of the General Assembly is the issues of Tunisia, Morocco and South Africa.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Ever since Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower became President-elect the left-wing press of Britain, led by the Bevanites, has been conducting a campaign to convince the people of this country that his efforts to bring peace in Korea may drag them and the rest of the allies of the United States into an unwanted world war.

" A Many-Splendored Thing," a new book by Han Suyin, will be published next Thursday by Atlantic-Little, Brown. Set in Hong Kong, the book gives a first-hand account of life in the refugee-crowded city and tells a love story that involves the author and an English correspondent who was killed in Korea.

COMMERCE, Tex., Nov. 12 (UP) -- East Texas State College, the highest scoring, unbeaten college football team in the nation, will play in the Tangerine Bowl at Orlando, Fla., New Year's Day, Lloyd Russell, East Texas Athletic Director, said today. The Lions, the only unbeaten college team in Texas, have scored 345 points this season, while allow-I lng their opponents 74 in seven games. I

SAIGON, Indo-China, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Vietnam's Chief of State, Bao Dai, dismissed the Governor of North Vietnam today and replaced him with an ultra-nationalist whose party refused earlier to give the French full support in their fight against the Communist-led Vietminh.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Sweden has asked Russia to free a Swedish diplomat taken prisoner by the Russian Army when it moved into Budapest in 1945.

Two more arrests in District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's continuing investigation of waterfront crimes were made yesterday as the prosecutor reiterated his criticism of the "unwillingness" of business men to come forward with evidence of crime.

UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Ultra modern art forms were roundly criticized by delegates to the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs convention today. The discussions led to a resolution protesting the awards given in the Metropolitan Museum of Art exhibit last December of "Sculpture 1951."

Officials of the State Department of Commerce declared yesterday that the present high level of employment and business activity in New York was not built on "solid rock" and was being threatened by the raiding activities of other states.

Ira S. Robbins, executive vice president of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York, yesterday criticized Mayor Impellitteri and Bernard J. Gillroy, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, for "failure" to catch up with building code violators.

The two American representatives in the women's world chess championship challengers' tournament, Mrs. Mary Bain and Mona M. Karff, successfully weathered the twelfth round in Moscow yesterday when the former drew with Senora de Montero of Argentina and the latter won from Mrs. Rowena Bruce of England, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.
The Grocery Manufacturers of America announced yesterday a pledge of cooperation with the new Administration as the group concluded its forty-ninth annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Appellate Division, Fourth Department, today reversed an order fixing a fee of $175,000 plus expenses for a referee in litigation between the New York Central Railroad and the City of New York over franchise and property assessments involving hundreds of millions of dollars.
Irving Raincoat Co, store, basement and second floor, Lovisi Brothers, uniforms, through Robert Joseph Co, fourth floor, in 657 Broadway -- Tankoos Co, brokers.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 12 -- Governor Dewey will come here Friday afternoon at the invitation of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to discuss the President-elect's trip to Korea and other high-level policy matters.

The New York Knickerbockers will have Max Zaslofsky in their starting line-up tonight when they face the Minneapolis Lakers at Madison Square Garden in the featured contest of a National Basketball Association double-header. The program will open at 7:30 P. M. with a game between the Rochester Royals and the Milwaukee Hawks.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,432, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

In a centennial publication four years ago the New York Public Library remarked that "the full roster of those who since 1948 have contributed financially to Library endowment runs into the thousands." These "hundreds upon hundreds of smaller donations" have come from persons appreciating assistance the Library has given them in earning a living, writing a book, perfecting an invention, or "merely adding to the pleasure and dignity of daily life."

If changing a lonely and unsmiling blind baby into a chortling young member of the crowd involves "putting the cart before the horse," then let the horse stand back -- the cart is moving up. That sentiment was expressed yesterday by Mrs. Howard S. Cullman as she explained to 300 business and social leaders why the Lighthouse first expanded its facilities and now sought the money to pay for the expansion.

A favorable outlook for women's spring apparel was reported last night at the "selling fashion clinic," held by Felix Lilienthal Co., resident buyers at the McAlpin Hotel. The clinic was designed to illustrate the selling points important for retailers for the coming spring season and to stress basic style points found in all price levels.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov 12 -- The National Electrical Manufacturers Association has set up a tax policy committee to study the Federal excise tax structure and cooperate with other national organizations on other tax matters, it was announced here today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were 5 points lower to 10 points higher than on Wednesday.

Progressive decontrol for machine tools was recommended yesterday as the surest way to strengthen the industry for the future defense of the country and for its vital role as the basis for all industrial production.

The New York City government is digging itself deeper and deeper into a financial hole. The transit deficit figures for the first three months of the fiscal year are only one, though an important, element in the picture. The city's net debt is rising, the future ever more heavily mortgaged.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 -The first unit of Television City, a huge TV production center being developed here by the Columbia Broadcasting System, will begin full scale operations on Saturday coincident with a day-long program of dedication ceremonies, to be topped off by a special hour-long show featuring most of the network's leading entertainers.
Yesterday's Fashion Group luncheon, directed by the ready-to-wear division and held at the Biltmore Hotel, concentrated on resort styles as created by American designers.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Iran's offer to pay compensation for the nationalization of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company's concession in Iran on the basis used in Britain when industries were nationalized is not a new idea and consequently it has aroused little interest here.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 13 -Officials of Danbury Hospital, scene of a bitter controversy over the suspension of two staff physicians, boycotted tonight a mass meeting of townspeople at which resolutions were adopted urging that the dispute be settled by mediation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The proposed merger of the United Paramount Theatres, Inc., and the American Broadcasting Company was urged upon the Federal Communications Commission by one of its examiners today.
A wide variety of business enterprises participated in the $87,000,000 expansion in commercial loans from banks in this area last week.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet, director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, told delegates attending the organization's seventh general conference today that never before had so much doubt been cast upon UNESCO ideals as this year "by so many and such important sections of public opinion in our member states."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 829,198 cars, the Association of American Rairoads announced today. This was 32,184 cars, or 3.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 37,795 cars, or 4.8 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 10,682 cars, or 1.3 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today it has made a loan to Finland in Swedish currency. The loan, of 18,000,000 Swedish kroner -- approximately $3,500,000 -- was the first World Bank loan in Swedish money.
LONDON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Prince Charles will be 4 years old tomorrow, and there are indications that the heir apparent to the British throne will be entering the most eventful year of his young life.

Six politicians and three racketeers sat for their portraits yesterday at the State Crime Commission public hearing while spectators in Room 408 of the New York County Courthouse were conducted on a guided tour of the lower depths of local politics.

Small things assumed vast proportions yesterday when the Port of New York Authority awarded a contract for 1,192,000 nuts, bolts and washers to fasten the 2,023 cast iron rings that will form the outer shell of the under-river segment of the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- The following tributes to Abraham H. Feller, general counsel to the United Nations, were issued today:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie declared today that the suicide of Abraham H. Feller, General Counsel of the United Nations, resulted from overwork in defending United States members of the Secretariat "against indiscriminate smears and exaggerated charges."

One of the more encouraging aspects of the United Nations debate on Korea is that it has enlisted India in a new effort to end the Korean war by facilitating a solution of the prisoner-of-war issue that is ostensibly the last obstacle to an armistice. The precise nature of the Indian plan is still vague and subject to further consideration as to details.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- During the .week ended Nov. 12, member bank reserves increased $113,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Abraham H. Feller, $18,000-a-year General Counsel to the United Nations, plunged to his death yesterday afternoon from a rear window of his twelfth-floor apartment at 50 Central Park West, at Sixty-fifth Street. His wife, Alice, said he had declared his intention to kill himself, had run frenziedly through the eight-room apartment, broken away when she tried to hold him back, opened the window, and jumped.

It costs $5 to park overtime on top of one of the street corner wire trash baskets of the Department of Sanitation -- providing you weigh ever 285 pounds. At least that was the ruling of Magistrate Abner C. Surpless in Flatbush Magistrates Court yesterday morning.

ATLANTA, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Thirteen Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church today requested a special meeting of trustees of the University of the South at Sewanee, Tenn., to discuss the question of admitting Negroes to the university's Theological School.

The U. S. S. Bennington rejoined the United States fleet yesterday after four years in moth balls and a two-year reconstruction job which, Secretary of the Navy Dan A. Kimball said, has made her "the most modern carrier in our fleet."

Fifty - seven names recently carved on the marble walls of the New York Public Library's main entrance hall in the building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street were unveiled yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet yesterday filed charges against four fire officers and three firemen as an aftermath of his disclosure Sept. 9 that twenty-one officers and men of his department held outside jobs as pier guards.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks thrashed the New York Rangers, 6 to 2, tonight to break a three-game losing streak and move into a tie for second place in the National Hockey League.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 -- The musical show, "High Button Shoes," which starred Phil Silvers and was a hit Broadway attraction in 1947, has been bought by Warner Brothers. Jack L. Warner, studio head who is in New York, closed the deal for the property that was produced by Monte Prosser and Joseph Kipness.

MONTREAL, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs took over first place in the National Hockey League tonight, checking the Montreal Canadiens to a standstill as they skated to a 3 -- 1 victory before 14,495 fans at the Forum.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Iraq returned to the general debate in the United Nations today to attack French control over Tunisia and Morocco and demand full independence for the two North African territories.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 13 -- Dr. Walter Linse, the West Berlin lawyer kidnapped by agents of the Communist East German Government, was alive in a Soviet zone prison in September when Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, chairman of the Soviet Control Commission in Germany, denied all knowledge of the case, a reliable source revealed today.

Three new films will open at first - run theatres this morning. "Bloodhounds of Broadway," Twentieth Century-Fox's Technicolor adaptation of the Damon Runyon story, with Mitzi Gaynor, Scott Brady, Mitzi Green, Marguerite Chapman and Michael O'Shea, is at the Roxy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board today denied that "bogus" typesetting in the newspaper industry violated the Taft-Hartley Labor Act. The Board gave its view in a brief filed with the Supreme Court answering charges by the American Newspaper Publishers Association that "bogus" typesetting is a device to circumvent the labor act.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- A state-wide gathering of education officials urged in a resolution here tonight that the 242 television channels reserved for noncommercial educational use be "vested permanently in the public domain."

A clear pattern of close relationships between Tammany district leaders and underworld figures in the city was drawn yesterday from witnesses at the first open hearing conducted by the New York State Crime Commission in New York County.

The trial of James J. Breslin, charged with criminal contempt, was postponed indefinitely yesterday by Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz after he had learned that Supreme Court Justice Alfred V. Norton had "disqualified" him from sitting as the trial judge.

Proposed local legislation that would hold parents responsible for the willful destruction of city property by children under 16 years old was approved yesterday by the City Council's Committee on General Welfare. Action came in executive session after an open meeting and discussion.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- State Conservation Commissioner Perry B. Duryea announced today the extension of hunting seasons in areas where Governor Dewey closed the forests during the recent forest fire emergency.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 13 -- The American Association of Port Authorities reported today that it "views with alarm" the absence of any program to keep small ports active and available as alternate emergency terminals in the event an enemy attack crippled large harbor facilities.
A new drive to purge Soviet science of "reactionary" theries has been announced by the head of the Soviet Union's Academy of Sciences, Academician A. Topchiev.
The Albeneri Trio, Erich Itor Kahn, pianist, Giorgio Ciompi, violinist, and Benar Heifetz, 'cellist, played a concern last evening in Town Hall.

Satin shimmered, jewels flashed and gowns of layer upon layer of frothy net glowed in palest pink tones in Russek's showing yesterday at the Plaza Hotel of cocktail and evening gowns for the holidays.
The right to know the truth is the foundation of the freedoms guaranteed by the Bill of Rights, James Wright Brown, president of the Zenger Memorial Fund, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Paul A. Walker, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, today urged the members of the Association of Land Grant Colleges to organize forty-eight state educational television networks now.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -Thirty-two packing cases of documents Gen. Douglas MacArthur had brought from Japan have been transferred to Army custody in New York.

Improved packaging and better storage facilities for dried fruits have helped, it is true, in extending their consumption throughout the whole year. Nevertheless, those old-fashioned cooks who like to change their menus with the seasons, and thereby preserve what is to us a welcome variety and rhythm, associate raisins, figs, dates and similar products with the fall, when the new packs arrive in the stores.

PINE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The body of Abe M. Luban, 45 years old, $25,000-a-year textile company executive missing since last Thursday, was found today in his automobile parked near Stissing Lake.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Two likely Republican leaders of the House and Senate in the new Congress disagreed today on whether a tax cut was possible next year or must await balancing of the budget.

The stock market experienced considerable difficulty yesterday in charting a course and, after following contrary patterns, finally ended up almost at dead center. Price changes were generally in fractions, only a few of the higher priced issues managing to break out of the day's limited range.

Only one witness was heard at yesterday's session of the Federal Maritime Board inquiry into the reasonableness of the proposed dual rate structure of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference. The hearing is being held before Board Examiner C. W. Robinson, in the Department of Commerce offices at 2 West Forty-third Street.

The Federal prosecutor's office here has marked off the trial calendar nineteen pending cases involving alleged violators of the Selective Service Act as the result of a United States Court of Appeals decision that a defendant is entitle to inspect Federal Bureau of Investigation reports involving his case.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Eighteen nations submitted to the Special Political Committee of he General Assembly today a joint resolution proposing the creation of a commission to examine the international aspects of the racial situation in South Africa, now under debate.

Three things the textile industry should do to make the work of the retailer easier are to use better labeling, standardize prices and inaugurate an advertising program to educate the consumer to use the new fibers to the best of their advantage.

DETROIT, Nov. 13 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay rapped home two third-period goals tonight and Goalie Terry Sawchuk turned in his second shutout of the season as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 0, before 10,173 fans at Olympia.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 13 -- A new Vietminh threat to Laichau, 200 miles northwest of Hanoi, was repulsed last night when a small French-Thai garrison beat off an assault by a larger enemy force at Pousamkap, thirty miles east of the Thai area's capital.
A new stainless steel flatware pattern, distinguished by a molded, fluid look, is included in a collection of coordinated tableware designed by Russel Wright. Macy's has the group.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 13 (AP) -In an effort to avert any break in German-Arab trade relations, a Right Wing Bonn Government party suggested tonight that the United Nations take over distribution of the $775,000,000 of reparations West Germany has agreed to pay Israel.

SHEFFIELD, Mass., Nov. 13 -For two seasons George Menard, a former three-letter athlete at Brown and now the football coach at the Berkshire School, tried his hand at professional baseball in the New York Yankee chain. He caught for Norfolk of the Piedmont League in 1951 and last summer was a member of the West Palm Beach Indians of the Florida International League.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The General Services Administration announced today that the giant basic magnesium plant at Henderson, Nev., has been sold to a private corporation.

Samuel Chapman, 56-year-old dress distributor and former husband of Ceil Chapman, the designer, was acquitted yesterday by a three-man bench in Special Sessions of possession of pornographic pictures and other articles.

SADDLE ROCK, L. I., Nov. 13 -A meeting called last night by the trustees of the $4,000,000 North Shore Hospital in an effort to reach an agreement with 200 doctors in the area on policy matters ended early today, after a stormy four-hour session, in a complete deadlock.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The "complete refusal of the White House to hear anything against the Russians" was blamed today for the United States Government's failure during World War II to accept evidence of Soviet responsibility for the Katyn Forest massacre.
Excerpts from testimony given yesterday before the State Crime Commission investigating links between politics and the underworld follow:

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 13 -- The courtroom of Federal Judge Willis W. Ritter resounded again today as postal workers on the floor below strove to move a backlog of 18,000 first-class letters and uncounted thousands of parcels that pried up yesterday during an imbroglio between the judiciary and the post office.
Governor Dewey asserted last night that the secret of the quality and availability of medical and hospital care was to be found in the free, voluntary system.
Racial discrimination is more repugnant to the people of the Union of South Africa than to almost any other population in the world, Gerhardus P. Jooste, South African Ambassador, said yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 13 -- The German Social Democrats, encouraged by their gains in Sunday's communal elections, will strive for the postponement of the Bundestag debate on ratification of the treaty system binding an armed and equal West Germany to Western Europe.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 13 (UP) -A union officer gave the word today for a new strike Monday at the Savannah River atomic energy plant -- a key production point for hydrogen bomb tests.

The moves in the Anglo-Iranian oil dispute are getting so subtle and devious that it is almost impossible to follow them. To be on the safe side one should take it for granted that nothing significant is happening, and then by chance if something does it will prove a surprise -- pleasant or unpleasant, as the case may be.
The Girl Scouts of Greater New York gave a total of 23,073 hours of service to hospitals, nurseries and old-age homes in the last year, according to the annuax service report released yesterday.

BOSTON -- Nov. 13 -- The award of a forty-loom work schedule that will double the individual production of weavers at the Pequot sheeting mill at Salem, Mass., was seen today as a step toward halting further losses of the New England cotton textile industry to the South.

MANILA, Nov. 13 -- The fierce little Moro war, stalemated since early August, was nearing an end today with its instigator and leader, Hadji Kamlon, behind bars in a Government penitentiary. He was brought peacefully to Manila to surrender personally to President Elpidio Quirino.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- State tax collections for the first seven months of the current fiscal year that started April 1 are running 2 per cent above Governor Dewey's estimates of last winter. This was disclosed today as T. Norman Hurd, Budget Director, began formal hearings on departmental requests for funds for the next fiscal year.

The "lend-lease" transfer of sixty-eight naval craft to Japan has an aspect even more important than its military significance. It is true that this represents the token building of a new Japanese navy and as such it is a significant act of policy. We are helping Japan to become stronger.

The jury at the treason trial of John David Provoo was told yesterday that the defendant and former Army sergeant "even bragged" about having turned in to the Japanese for disciplinary action a United States Army captain who subsequently was executed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Attorney General James P. McGranery today ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate a Justice Department telegram directing abandonment of further proceedings against Paul (The Waiter) Ricca, former Capone gangster.

Adrian Fisher, Assistant Secretary of State and legal adviser to the State Department, was taken before Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld yesterday when he refused to answer a question before a grand jury investigating employment of American Communists at the United Nations.

The Norge division of Borg-Warner Corporation is budgeting manufacture and sales of its household appliances in the first quarter of .1953 for a 100 per cent dollar volume increase compared with 1952. This was revealed yesterday by P. F. Smith, Norge president, prior to introduction of the organization's 1953 line in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The U. S. Chamber of Commerce will be doing the nation a service if its announced intention of investigating Communist influence on strikes in defense plants makes substantial progress.
PARIS, Nov. 13 -- The National Assembly's Finance Committee rejected today for the second time the proposal submitted by the Government for tax reform. The vote was 24 to 18 with two abstentions.

Any number under 100 would have let down the 11,213 fans, who stayed for the finish only to see the New York Knickerbockers hit the century mark against the Minneapolis Lakers last night at Madison Square Garden. With two seconds remaining, Dick McGuire caged the foul that satisfied the customers and completed a 100-91 triumph for the local quintet.

The American public must be "sold" on spending more time and money in restaurants and hotels if these industries are to prosper and overcome tight profit conditions, leaders of the two fields declared yesterday.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 13 -The National Assembly today gave all three readings to the anti-Communist bill providing sentences of from ten years to life for party members. The bill also provides prison terms for those joining in Communist discussions without reporting to the authorities and those aiding the Communists by funds or providing dwelling or meeting places. Presses producing Communist propaganda are rendered liable to seizure.

Futures closed irregular yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with potatoes, lead, coffee, vegetable oils and hides increasing. Rubber, cocoa and tin declined and zinc, sugar and wool were mixed. Almost all markets were less active than on Wednesday.

LINCOLN, R. I., Nov. 13 (AP) -Tony DeSpirito, 17-year-old Lawrence, Mass., apprentice who is leading the nation's jockeys, won four consecutive races in eight tries at Lincoln Downs today to lift his season's total to 346 victories.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- High-level diplomatic talks were held here and elsewhere in New York today as part of the delicate task of trying to work out a formula that might bring a cease-fire in Korea.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Prices and volume of business continued to rise slightly on stock markets today largely on the strength of better trade figures for October and Chancellor of the Exchequer Butler's recent statement on the country's economic progress.

HARRISON, N. Y., Nov. 13 -Three hundred fifty residents of this town attended tonight a meeting in the high school here that was called to protest the Board of Education's recent order that officers of any community organization wishing to use Harrison school facilities must sign a "loyalty" oath before the meeting and that guest speakers must do the same.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Top civilian military officials and the Joint Chiefs of Staff replied forcefully today in a documented statement to a Senate Preparedness subcommittee attack on Pentagon planning and performance during the emergency.

Wage increases of 5 to 15 per cent and overtime benefits were won yesterday by East and Gulf Coast unlicensed seamen, and rises of slightly more than 15 per cent by engineer officers on all coasts, in an arbitration award handed down by Aaron Horvitz of 285 Madison Avenue.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -The J. Arthur Rank motion picture organization announced tonight that, starting in the new year, it would begin producing a program of British films entirely with its own resources.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) --- Julius (Blinky) Fink, reputed Baltimore gambling figure, was acquitted today of a contempt of Congress charge. The Government promptly dismissed similar charges against three Reading, Pa., men.

SASABE, Ariz., Nov. 13 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois today spent the first day of his five-day southern Arizona vacation in the bright sun at a guest ranch in this tiny, ancient hamlet on the Mexican boundary. He flew in a private plane from Springfield, Ill., to Tucson, Ariz., yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -Senator Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat of Maryland, said today the Army gave a medical officer a commission and assigned him to a "sensitive spot" in Korea although he refused to say whether he was a Communist.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos, conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Aldo Parisot, 'cellist, Town Hall, 8:30; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch conducting, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30; Duke Ellington and his Band, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 and midnight; "La Traviata," Joan of Arc Auditorium, 154 West Ninety-third Street, 8:30.

Herman T. Stichman, State Commissioner of Housing, advised Negroes yesterday not to be hesitant about applying for apartments in state-controlled housing developments, "as we want you as part of the projects."

Two new steps taken by the Metropolitan Opera to expand its activities and influence on a national scale were announced yesterday. It has agreed to televise to theatres across the country a performance of "Carmen" directly from the New York stage the night of Dec. 11. It also has organized a national council, which will hold its first meeting at the Opera House this afternoon.

The nation's 529 mutual savings banks will send out Christmas Club checks totaling $187,624,504, a new high record, to 2,178,857 depositors during the next few weeks, according to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, and other Cabinet members and officials probably will participate in Tuesday's White House conference between President Truman and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Those who desire to continue at at work after reaching retirement age, and have the ability to do so, are being subjected to "unwarranted, prejudicial and unjust treatment" when employment is refused them, Elizabeth Hatch, personnel director for Carson Pirie Scott, Chicago department store, told the National Social Welfare Assembly, here yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Norway offered today to increase her contribution to the United Nations if such action would help Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, "convince his compatriots" of the sense of obligation other governments felt for the world organization.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 10 -- The Netherlands, a small nation with a great past, is in the midst of a difficult adjustment from neutralism to activism and from a great colonial power to continental self-sufficiency.

A further advance in the women's world chess championship challengers' tournament in Moscow was made by Mona M. Karff of New York, yesterday, when she won in 34 moves from Salome Reischer of Austria in the thirteenth round, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.

BUFFALO, Nov. 13 -- The Nation has an annual total of 1,000,000 juvenile delinquents and the number can be expected to increase to 1,500,000 annually within the next eight years, Dr. Martha M. Eliot, chief of the United States Children's Bureau, said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -The Government today issued an order giving milk boards and commissions in twelve states full control over prices of products covered by their regulations.

Gasoline stocks in the nation were 121,374,000 barrels at the close of last week, it was announced yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. This was 811,000 barrels more than a week earlier and compared with 119,559,000 barrels a year earlier.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Nov. 13 -- Management has been leaning too much upon legislation to solve its labor problems, according to top business executives gathered here today for the annual fall meeting of the Business Advisory Council. Members of the group, which advises the Secretary of Commerce upon economic problems affecting the nation, devoted today's gathering to a discussion of labor relations.

The city of Mobile, Ala., yesterday posted for public offering on Nov. 25 two issues of bonds totaling $10,490,000. Of the total, $6,790,000 are refunding general obligations due on Oct. 1 from 1953 to 1970. The $3,700,000 balance will be water revenue bonds due on Oct. 1 from 1957 to 1980.

Many parties will be given at the Indian Summer Dinner Dance to be held tonight in the Garden and Embassy Room of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association. The fete will be preceded by several cocktail parties at the hotel and in private homes. Mrs. Ruth McCullough Young and Mrs. Charles A. Gristede are co-chairman of the executive committee.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 14 -- South Korean troops early today lost, then recaptured "Pinpoint Hill," the much-contested rocky knob that dominates "Sniper Ridge," north of Kumhwa on the central Korean front.

BASKEHEGAN, Me., Nov. 13 -- Abelard Le Bono, from "on top Canada," is a successful deer hunter, and has a nine-point buck to prove it, but there is a large and very obvious flaw in the tradition which specifies that the first successful member of the hunting party automatically becomes the camp cook until another deer is killed.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Twenty-nine amendments to the major-minor rules, eighteen amendments to the minor league agreement, and two resolutions will be considered Dec. 4 when the minors' National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues meets at Phoenix, Ariz.

Food shoppers will have to pay from 4 to 6 cents a pound more for pork loins, veal cutlets and frankfurters than last Friday. Roasting chickens and broilers also are costlier and large grade A eggs edged up a couple of cents a dozen, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

A suit seeking a temporary receivership for the $50,000,000 R. K. O. Pictures Corporation and its subsidiary, R. K. O. Radio Pictures, Inc., was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by three minority stockholders.

Floyd G. Blair, president of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, paid tribute yesterday to "The Six Great Ladies of Music," each of whom has served on the board of directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony for twenty-five years or more.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 13 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will end his golfing vacation here early Tuesday morning and fly to Washington for his White House conference with President Truman. High on the agenda of this conference are the proposed trip of the President-elect to Korea and steps to be taken toward the "orderly" transition of the Government from the old to the new Administration.

SASKATOON, Sask., Nov. 13 (AP) -- A new phase in prairie agriculture has been recorded with the discovery and development of valuable potash deposits near the Saskatchewan centers of Vera and Unity, about 150 miles northwest of here.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- Pressures put upon the United Nations by Americans who are unable to understand that such an international body cannot serve the exclusively national interests of any member state were denounced tonight by Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the Department of Trusteeship of the United Nations.

Circuit Judge Harold R. Medina said yesterday that it was "a mystery to me" why Kidder, Peabody Co. was included in the list of seventeen investment banking defendants accused of anti-trust violations in a trial now proceeding at the Federal Court House here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A college professor served notice on the American housewife and the African Zulu today that he was determined to help them save themselves work.

Many of their valuable facilities, all coming under the heading "service." have not been adequately advertised or merchandized by banks, according to Mortimer J. Davis, executive vice president of the New York Credit and Financial Management Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -The Defense Department today identified 157 battle casualies in Korea in a new list that reported 66 killed, 87 wounded, 3 missing and 1 injured. The following casualties were listed for New York and New Jersey (none for Connecticut):

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Britain's economic progress as measured by the drop in her adverse balance of trade -- the excess of imports over exports -- was described by the Board of Trade today in an analysis of the distribution of the country's trade.

NEWARK, Nov. 12 -- Plans to consolidate the National Newark an Essex Banking Company of this city with the Savings Investment and Trust Company of East Orange were announced today by officials of the two banking institutions.

All the talk was of Navy at Columbia's weekly football luncheon yesterday. None of it cast a happy light on the chances of Lou Little's battered Light Blue squad in its game with the midshipmen at Annapolis tomorrow.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 13 -- The Appeal Court, South Africa's highest tribunal, ruled unanimously today that the High Court of Parliament set up by the Malan Government was illegal.

Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, testifying yesterday at the departmental trial of thirty policemen accused of having accepted his graft, said under cross-examination that certain testimony he gave against a defendant at the trial and to a grand jury could be construed as "inaccurate."

Henry Morgan, who of late years has floundered around rather badly in both radio and television, may be on the road to finding himself again. Over the facilities of WMGM the humorist has taken on one of those backbreaking assignments -- talking from midnight to 3 A. M. seven nights a week -and more often than not he is very amusing.
A community hospital with accommodations for more than 23,000 patients would approximate
I wonder if I may be permitted to ask, through you, what the public, or more importantly, what editors of newspapers, believe to be the essential purpose of pre-election public opinion polls.

UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- The New York State Federation of Women's Clubs voted its approval today of lowering from 65 to 60 the age at which a woman may receive Social Security benefits and of removing from the law all restrictions penalizing persons over 65 who wish to work.

The voluntary hospitals of New York resulted from the recognition by community-minded citizens that medical care should be provided for those who could not afford to pay for it. Today these voluntary institutions are recognized as centers of medical care, research and education for the entire city.
There has occurred to me a plan for the treatment of the prisoner question, which it is said has been the obstacle toward effecting an armistice in the Korean conflict.

A new quirk has been found in that misbegotten piece of legislation known as the McCarran Act. This new law, which goes into effect on Christmas Eve, contains a provision against Communists and former Communists entering the United States as immigrants. We certainly do not wish to admit anyone who has the faintest shred of sympathy with communism.
Bright colors and simple shapes are combined in a new collection of ceramic and enameled metal accessories, now on view at the Willow, 184 West Fourth Street.

A lack of adequate medical services in Israel, particularly a comprehensive program in the field of preventive medicine, was described yesterday by Dr. Morris Fishbein, chairman of the medical advisory committee of the Care-World Health Organization.
DUNELLEN, N. J., Nov. 13 -- Fire and death finally opened here today the barricaded doors of a junk-crammed house upon the strange life of its aged, eccentric and apparenty wealthy inhabitant.
Lever Brothers Company yesterday announced it will dedicate on next Tuesday its new integrated Research Center at Edgewater, N. J., marking its golden anniversary in research.

Fred Allen will be the master of ceremonies for a special radio broadcast to be presented by the National Broadcasting Company network tomorrow evening at 8:30 in connection with the annual detection drive of the American Diabetes Association.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Karen Morley, motion picture and stage actress, declined to tell a subcommittee of the House Un-American Activities Committee today whether she was or had been a Communist.

Carl W. Ackerman, Dean of the Columbia University School of Journalism, and Elliott M. Sanger, vice president and general manager of radio station WQXR, were honored last night at the fortieth anniversary observance of the founding of the school under the will of Joseph Pulitzer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Pentagon called a news conference today to "get over to the public" the thought that eighty-five of every 100 soldiers wounded in Korea recover sufficiently to return to some form of duty.

Public offering of $10,000,000 of Pacific Finance Corporation 5 1/2 per cent capital subordinated debentures due in 1973 will be made today by an investment banking group consisting of Blyth Co., Inc.; Hornblower Weeks, and Harris, Hall Co., Inc.

The writer has recently returned from the Far East, where for eighteen months he was assigned to an American Strategic Intelligence Organization. With regard to the letter from J. Passmore Elkington, published Nov. 8, I was astonished by misconceptions or inaccuracies which are, in the opinions of those who are studying Japan's economic and political problems in minute detail, without firm basis. To enumerate:

Dr. Harold C. Urey, Nobel-prize-winning atomic scientist of the Institute for Nuclear Studies of the University of Chicago, estimated here last night that there are 1,000,000,000,000,000 worlds in the known universe on which it is possible that life might have originated and survived.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- If the arts are to survive in Britain, the state and local authorities must take the place of private benefactors, the National Arts Council said in its seventh annual report, published this week. Wealthy patrons of the arts are dying out and, while there still remain some private donors, present-day economics are forcing them to retrench more and more, the group said.

MUNSAN, Korea, Friday, Nov. 14 (UP) -- The United Nations Command reported today that an Allied medical aid man was shot and killed by a Communist rifle bullet inside the neutral corridor between Munsan and Panmunjom on Wednesday.

Another chapter was added yesterday to the woeful story of the fifty-million-dollar R. K. O. Radio Pictures Corporation and its top subsidiary, R. K. O. Radio Pictures, Inc. Arnold M. Grant turned in his resignation as chairman and an executive officer of the corporation and its subsidiaries at a directors' meeting.

Striving to match the popularity of such recent Palace headliners as Judy Garland and Betty Hutton, the former citadel of vaudeville finally has obtained an entertainer to fit into its scheme of things. Signed to appear there, beginning Jan. 19, is Danny Kaye in what is dubbed his "All-Star International Variety Show."
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 14 (AP) -Unite Nations Command communique 1,433, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Friday, Korean time:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The large majority of those who voted on Nov. 4 seemed to agree with General Eisenhower that a "change" of officials was needed to clean up the "mess in Washington." There will be plenty of hands in the policy-making echelons of the executive department, in the membership of the federal agencies and commissions and in both branches of Congress.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- Ceylon announced today she was stepping up her shipments to Communist China of rubber and certain other undesignated commodities.
The executive director of the American Heritage Foundation literally ate crow yesterday to fulfill an election bet.

Bobby Shantz, one of the smallest performers in the major leagues, yesterday carried off one of baseball's biggest individual prizes with the announcement that he had been voted the American League's most valuable player for 1952.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Two Left-Wing Labor Members of Parliament who returned from Kenya today expressed disagreement with the British Government's views on the causes of Mau Mau terrorism in the British East African colony.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation has been investigating the affairs of Armand Chankalian, administrative assistant to the United States Attorney, who will appear today before the State Crime Commission to discuss his relations with racketeer Thomas Luchese, widely wnown as Three-Finger Brown.
BOSTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The teletypesetter was examined by a group of managing editors today and the findings were generally good.
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 13 -- Formally charged with the murder of his parents, Hans G. and Clara Eischen, 16-year-old Klaus Eischen of Kearny was arraigned today before Hudson County Judge August Ziegener.
In offensive drills yesterday for Sunday's meeting with the Green Bay Packers, Coach Steve Owen sent the Giants through some spread plays, which have not been seen in a Giant game this season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -The Defense Department issued a call today for 945 medical men in January, and Pentagon experts indicated that heavy casualties in Korea might force the Army to keep its over-all draft sights high.

Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of directors of the City Center of Music and Drama, announced yesterday that the civic playhouse had canceled its drama activities for this winter because of its "present financial situation."

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Corn, oats and soybean futures took the lead in the pit activities on the Board of Trade today, while wheat was mildly reactionary, traders fearing that possible rains might take the edge off the market. Buying of corn appeared to be based largely on the fact that the increase in the Government's corn estimate compared to last month was much less than expected.

Three thousand spectators crowded around the skating rink at Rockefeller Plaza at noon yesterday to watch a skillful 6-year-old figure skater and a frisky French poodle join with screen and television stars in staging a colorful rally that marked the opening of the United Hospital Fund's annual Hospital Week appeal.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, was buried today with solemn Roman Catholic rites and a prelate's eulogy of "this great, good man."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Most Rev. Michael J. Ready, Bishop of Columbus, Ohio, noted an increase in wholesome and moral themes in Hollywood-produced motion pictures in his report today to the annual meeting of the Catholic Bishops of the United States.

A biography of Richard Rogers Bowker, whose name is inseparable from book publishing in the United States, is published today by the University of Oklahoma. Written by E. McClung Fleming, "R. R. Bowker: Militant Liberal" portrays the man who for fifty years directed Publishers' Weekly, was a founder of the American Library Association and of The Library Journal.

MADRID, Nov. 13 -- The Madrid newspaper Pueblo said editorially today that the "Spanish man in the street" agreed with Generalissimo Francisco Franco's policy of collaboration with the United States because he knew that Spain could not remain neutral in the event of a third World War caused by Soviet aggression.

Market professionals who marched the prices of Government securities up the hill a fortnight ago marked them down yesterday in a trading session virtually devoid of meaningful transactions affecting the cash of investors. Traders exchanging quotations among themselves backed away at the opening of the market.

An increasingly "stiff" attitude by management toward the demands of organized labor has been noted recently, Merlyn S. Pitzele, chairman of the State Board of Mediation, reported yesterday to the Joint Legislative Committee on Industrial and Labor Conditions.

There is something to be said for a primitive state of trade, involving the barter of goods, such as existed before the general use of money in the form of beads, dog teeth, elephant tails, coins and other articles of currency.

When children sing the songs of other lands, lift their voices in chorus to international understanding, or join in jingles about politeness or caring for their belongings, does the musical experience actually affect their attitudes?

Higher minimum reserve requirements against losses was proposed for savings and loan associations yesterday by William K. Divers, chairman of the Home Loan Bank Board. Mr. Divers, head of the Government agency which supervises the Federally-chartered asso iations, spoke at the annual convention of the U. S. Savings and Loan League at the Statler Hotel.
The low temperatures prevailing in the New York Butchers pressed Meat Company storage plant at 600 west Fortieth Street caused three would-be hold-up men to miss an $8,000 payroll last night.

Harlem Maid, under the persistent guiding of Willie Lester, administered a decisive beating to the odds-on favorite in winning the Heather Broom, the feature race of the program at Jamaica yesterday. The crowd of 18,933 liked Ceremonious so much that he went off at 7-10, but at the wire he was the runner-up by a length and a half to Harlem Maid.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Nationalist China charged before the United Nations today that "Stalin and his Communist stooges" did not want a truce in Korea.

Dan Bucceroni, 24-year-old Philadelphia heavyweight, will enter the Madison Square Garden ring tonight a 7 1/2-to-5 favorite over Danny Nardico, ex-Marine from Tampa, also 24, in the 10-round main event.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- A new method for keeping human hearts beating, by means of a standard laboratory machine about the size of a table model radio set, was described today by Dr. Paul M. Zoll of Beth Israel Hospital in the New England Journal of Medicine.
OTTAWA, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The governors of the Banks of England and Canada will meet here next week to discuss, among other things, the repayment of the 1946 Anglo-Canadian loan.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13 -Four major developments in recent months give high promise of aiding materially in assuring a sound economic future for Israel, the Mizrachi Organization of America was told here tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13 -- Although polite diplomatic notes are being exchanged between Argentina and Uruguay, an undeclared economic boycott by the Peron Government is harassing almost all international airlines and steamship companies as well as causing untold difficulties for tourists and foreign business men residing here.

Aluminium, Ltd., of Montreal reported yesterday consolidated net income of $15,883,109 for the nine months ended Sept. 30 after providing $26,923,198 for depreciation and depletion and $28,033,688 for income taxes. All figures are in Canadian dollars.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- Governor Dewey today appointed former United States Attorney Charles H. Tuttle of New York as chairman of the temporary state commission created to study present and prospective rapid-transit needs of the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area and to make recommendations for improving commuter facilities there.

That the development of good design today is inhibited by a dogmatic attitude toward the nature of its characteristics was contended at a symposium at the Museum of Modern Art this week. The theme was "Good Design Could Be Better."

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Plans of the National Collegiate Athletic Association to make major changes in its annual basketball tournament would not affect regularly scheduled competition such as the Southern Conference tournament and the Pacific Coast North-South play-offs.
The American Professional Basketball League was reorganized last night by six members and a seventh city likely to meet franchise requirements within the next week.

WHEN the Chinese Communists overran Tibet two years ago that ancient and mysterious country, traditionally "forbidden" to foreigners, became in fact more forbidden than ever before. But before that unhappy event a substantial number of Europeans did succeed in penetrating the land of Lamaism. Of these one of the most successful was Prof. Giuseppe Tucci, an Italian explorer, Orientalist and Buddhist convert.
Federal tax reductions must await balancing of the budget, Dr. Jules Backman, economics professor, New York University, warned yesterday.

Treatment of their "deep-seated" emotional disturbances must be a part of any lasting cure of narcotics addiction in teen-agers, Dr. Jerome L. Leon, medical superintendent of Riverside Hospital, declared yesterday. He spoke at the annual institute of the New York City Hospital Visiting Committee.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Nov. 13 -- Senator John Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, defeated Vice Presidential candidate, called today for the Democrats to present what he termed a "constructive" opposition in the new Congress.

Dan Bucceroni, Philadelphia heavyweight, applied a weight margin to good advantage in defeating Danny Nardico of Tampa, Fla., in the main bout of 10 rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. Scaling 185 pounds to 175 1/4 for his opponent, Bucceroni punched his way to a unanimous decision.

A "family gathering" of 800 friends was held last night in the auditorium of St. Jean Baptists Roman Catholic Church, 167 East Seventy-fifth Street, to bid farewell to the Rev. Francis T. Brennan, who had completed thirty-three years of youth work in the parish.

Social welfare agencies should stop distinguishing between regular and national emergency services and accept as a fact that "the so-called emergency has become a part of our present way of life," Leonard W. Mayo, an authority in the field, declared yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- Three well-known lawyers, one of them William DeWitt Mitchell, who was Attorney General in the Hoover Administration, held their first meeting here today to examine the problem created by the current attacks in the United States on certain United States employes of the United Nations.

HARRISBURG, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The State Game Commission today set a special six-day small-game hunting season for Dec. 22-27 to make up for days lost by a suspension of the opening of the regular season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged at 110 per cent of the 1947-49 average for the week ended Nov. 11, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum of Niles, Ill., fell two strokes back of a pair of pace-setting Australians today as a flare-up enlivened the third round of the Melbourne section of the Ampol golf tournament.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 14 (AP) -- United States authorities in Germany made tonight the red-faced admission that they had spent more than 200,000 Deutsche marks ($47,600) financing the publication of world history textbook written by a Communist and heavily loaded with Red-propaganda.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Following a dinner last night at which Premier Antoine Pinay was the guest of Rene Mayer, former Radical minister, reports were circulated here of a possible reshuffle of the French Cabinet. 8he latest rumor in the press was that M. Mayer might possibly become Foreign Minister while Robert Schuman, the present Foreign Minister, now in New York, would become Minister for European Affairs.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Dallas Texans were taken over by the National Football League today and will play the rest of the 1952 season on the road.
BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Geological Society of America awarded medals to four scientists today at its sixty-fifth annual meeting
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth of England will be named co-defendant with Canada in an amended suit for damages to Lake Ontario property here because of high water.

Minor price fluctuations were the general rule in the New York commodity exchanges yesterday with rubber showing the only sizable movement. The closings were irregular. Rubber, tin, sugar and coffee were up; lead, zinc and potatoes eased, and wool, cocoa, hides and vegetable oils were mixed.
PARIS, Nov. 14 (UP) -- The three-month deadlock over the import of Hollywood films with dubbed - in French dialogue has been broken and a new agreement signed, informed sources said today.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Prof. Zechariah Chafee Jr. of the Harvard Law School criticized the American press today for publishing what he called "defamatory" statements, made under Congressional immunity, without additional information to aid readers in evaluating the charges.

VIENNA, Nov. 14 -- Lieut. Gen. Vadim P. Sviridov, Soviet High Commissioner in Austria, announced at today's meeting of the Allied Council that he would not permit the Austrian police to check on or keep order at political meetings in the Soviet zone during the forthcoming general election campaign.
ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 14 (UP) -- Cornell will meet defeat - ridden Dartmouth tomorrow when both teams seek to salvage some late-season pride.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 14 -- French forces raced twenty more miles into Vietminh territory in the Red River Valley northwest of Hanoi yesterday and today. The new advance was made at the same time French Union and Vietnamese troops were beating off a powerful Communist-led Vietminh attempt to capture Phatdiem in the extreme south of the Tonkin delta.

Mayor Impellitteri must find $100,000,000 to $125,000,000 in new revenue to balance next year's city budget, even if some means are found for overcoming the transit operating deficit, now estimated at $40,000,000 to $50,000,000 for the present fiscal year that ends on June 30.

HAIFA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Anglo-Iranian Oil Company and the Israeli Government will shortly sign an agreement on the working of the Haifa oil refineries, an Israeli petroleum official disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -- Tuna fishing and its problems, foreign and domestic, will get another going-over next week from the United States Tariff Commission. Hearings will start Monday and are expected to last two or three days. A dozen or more representatives of American fishermen, packers and importers are to tell what has happened to their industry lately.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- A county budget providing for tax levies of $17,660,968 and a tax rate of $8.52 for each $1,000 of valuation was proposed to the Westchester County Board of Supervisors today by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach.

HANOI, Nov. 14 (AP) -- French garrisons, warplanes and naval assault craft joined in beating down the thrust by perhaps 3,000 rebels at Phatdiem, near the Gulf of Tonkin, seventy-five miles southeast of Hanoi.

State Supreme Court Justice Matthew Levy reserved decision yesterday after an all-day hearing on a complaint alleging unethical practices by the Colin Pharmacal Co., Inc., of Long Island City, Queens, after its counsel had agreed to a temporary injunction on dealing in stock provided that an early trial date be set.

Between 80 and 90 per cent of the foreign mining engineers and other technicians in Bolivia will decline to work for her nationalized tin industry and that country's economy will go into an early tailspin, according to six engineers recently employed by the Compagnie Aramayo de Mines en Bolivie, of Geneva.

WESTPORT, Mass., Nov. 14 -- Mrs. Mary T. Audette, 44 years old, and eight of her ten children suffocated early today in a fire that was confined to the kitchen and pantry of their two-and-a-half-story home. The bodies of the victims were found in upstairs bedrooms. None had been burned.

ATHENS, Nov. 14 -- In a forty-minute broadcast from behind the Iron Curtain today, Nicolas Zachariades, secretary general of the outlawed Greek Communist party, urged listeners to support EDA (the Union of Democratic Leftists) in Sunday's elections and in no circumstances to split the ticket.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Harry Agganis, one of the outstanding stars in Boston University's football history, and nine other seniors will be making their final home appearances tomorrow when the Terriers engage New York University's improving forces at Fenway Park.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 14 -- The Kashmir Constituent Assembly elected 21-year-old Prince Karan Singh, who would have been Maharajah of the former princely state, as the first Sadar I Riyasat, or Chief of State, today, ending the territory's ancient monarchy. He was unopposed.

Bishop James P. De Wolfe of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will install the Rev. Melville Harcourt as canon pastor of St. Ann's Church, 131 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, at 8 P. M. tomorrow. The church became the "Diocesan Church" in the fall of 1950.

Our growing economy, its inflationary bias and the retained earnings of most corporations give almost all stocks "a built-in growth factor," Walter Maynard, retiring president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, told the Federation of Women Shareholders in American Business, Inc., in a lecture at Town Hall yesterday.
SOUTH AMBOY, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Tension gripped the 8,000 residents of this town tonight as news spread that the police had found fifteen half-pound packets of high explosives.

As the first of the Harlem firetrap cases resulting from the current Housing and Buildings survey came before Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh in Municipal Term court yesterday, the jurist attacked provisions of the Multiple Dwelling Law that permit an accused landlord to waive a hearing for trial in Special Sessions.

Bus management reminded Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private transit industry, yesterday that a walkout threatened for Dec. 1 by Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., would violate the no-strike clause of the existing contract.

Figuring a personal output of 751,557 automobile tires in thirty-four years, Mrs. Stanley Bargiel said yesterday that she would never get tired of making them with prayers for their long and faithful service. She firmly believes that no highway accident could be attributed to a tire of her handiwork.

A young Philippine soldier was summarily executed by a Japanese guard on Corregidor after John David Provoo, former Army sergeant, had talked with the guard in Japanese, a witness testified yesterday at Provoo's treason trial in Federal Court here.

Lumber production for the week ended Nov. 8 was 2.5 per cent above the comparable week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were up 6.3 per cent and orders 11.3 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet;

The United States is the equal of any other nation in the field of science, but is "not even close to having a scientific monopoly," Dr. Karl T. Compton, former president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, declared last night in an address prepared for delivery at the dinner of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The State of Iowa produced the two individual champions in today's Big Ten and Central Collegiate conference cross-country double-header at Washington Park.

NEWARK, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Superior Court Judge Walter J. Freund has approved a stock option plan of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) which the company said was aimed at giving an incentive to keymen.

CAIRO, Nov. 14 -- The Wafd party's challenge to the Egyptian Government collapsed today after the publication this morning of a decree withdrawing from the courts the right to review ordinances issued by Premier Mohammed Naguib during the first six months of his regime, which began July 23.

Net earnings of the Pure Oil Company and its subsidiaries for the first nine months this year totaled $20,195,000, equal to $4.56 a share on 4,067,719 common shares, the report disclosed yesterday. For the corresponding 1951 period the net was $24,375,000 or $5.70 each on 3,982,031 common shares, and included $3,000,000 non-operating earnings from capital gains.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 14 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's sixty-third birthday today apparently broke the Communist party line here, which normally follows Kremlin policy closely. The Prime Minister received a message of congratulations from Premier Stalin but the Communist members of Parliament remained aloof from the cheering that greeted Mr. Nehru as he entered the House this morning.

William Conant Church, founder and owner of The Army and Navy Journal, is the subject of one of the two books published today. Written by Donald Nevius Bigelow, "William Conant Church and The Army and Navy Journal" describes Mr. Church's background, tells why The Journal was first published in the middle of the Civil War and surveys his fifty-four years as editor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 14 -- Princeton's powerful football team rules a two-touchdown favorite to clinch its sixth successive Big Three title by defeating Yale in the Bowl tomorrow. The kick-off is scheduled for 1:30 P. M. and a crowd of 60,000 is expected.

Dr. Fredrick J. Stare, chairman of the Department of Nutrition of Harvard University's School of Public Health, talked the other day in down-to-earth terms on how nutrition can improve the health of Americans -- "Americans," he said, "such as you and me."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission acted today to insure an adequate power supply for an atomic energy project in the Portsmouth, Ohio, area.

One of the earliest harbingers of the Yuletide season is the annual sale of Tuberculosis Christmas Seals beginning in mid-November. Next Monday thousands of letters carrying sheets of the gaily colored stickers will go out to New Yorkers throughout the city. In Manhattan and the Bronx alone 900,000 of these Christmas Seal letters will be delivered.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 14 -- Stage and motion picture leaders will meet next month in New York to work out plans for the observance of National Theatre Week, to be held next spring in conjunction with the release of the feature film, "Main Street to Broadway."

Peter Salmore, who described himself as "retired," filed suit yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court against the Empire City Racing Association, operator of the Jamaica track, and the State Racing Commission because, he said, he had been cheated on the pay-off on a deadheat winner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Plans to build angled or canted flight decks on United States and possibly British aircraft carriers were announced jointly today by United States and British naval officers.

WOONSOCKET, R. I., Nov. 14 Seventeen-year-old Tony DeSpirito, the nation's leading jockey, was hospitalized with a "slight" concussion and bruises today after being thrown twice from a horse at Lincoln Downs, Lincoln, R. I.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- Governor Dewey set up today an interdepartmental committee on Indian services to coordinate and improve existing services and "provide the Indians with opportunity to participate in all of the activities of our society as expeditiously as possible."
LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Anglo-Iranian Oil Company is constructing a big new oil refinery in the Red Sea port of Aden to help offset Iran's nationalization of the company's Abadan plant.
In the Topics of The Times I was pleased to note that Rodman Gilder was "keeping a watchful eye for changes" (in New York City).

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 -- The Mizrachi Organization of America adopted today a 1953 budget of $2,750,000, the largest in its history, to carry out its many programs in Israel and in this country. In addition, delegates to the organization's thirty-second annual convention pledged it to sell $10, 000,000 in Israel bonds during the coming year.

The Brooklyn Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on a motion to confirm Supreme Court Referee Peter P. Smith's recommendation to clear Herman Methfessel, former Richmond County District Attorney, and his assistant, Irving Rivkin, of charges of professional misconduct.
