A special workshop conference for adult and teen-age volunteers who work with youngsters in the Yorkville Youth Council's after-school play programs was presented for the first time yesterday at Public School 151, First Avenue at Ninety-first Street.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14 -- Police here were told today that they must adopt some of the super-sleuthing methods used on television and radio crime shows if they wanted to please the modern juror.

An industrial property occupying a plot of nearly seven acres at 134 Garfield Avenue, corner of Gates Avenue, in Jersey City, N. J., has been leased from the Atlantis Corporation by the Owens - Illinois Glass Company which will use it as a warehouse and a distribution center for the metropolitan area.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 14 -- Federal Judge Willis W. Ritter, maintaining a stony silence, heard a case in his noisy courtroom today. While Wilbur Lee Judd of Calexico, Calif., pleaded guilty to two narcotics counts, the Federal Building courtroom again rumbled as postal workers hauled mail one story below in steel-wheeled carts and operated a clattering freight elevator.

Despite the constitutional date for an inauguration of the new President-elect and the immediate post-election agreements on meetings to be held between General Eisenhower and President Truman, it is important, I believe, to underline emphatically Senator Wiley's desire for a word from the President-elect with respect to his attitude toward the Korean truce negotiations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Swift Co. and the National Brotherhood of Packinghouse Workers signed a new wage agreement today, calling for a general increase of 4 cents an hour. The contract covers 5,000 Swift employes in eight plants. The old wage rate was $1.41 an hour for common labor in large cities.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -- The Federal Government's farm price support program will be operating at high speed when the new Republican Administration takes over on Jan. 20, a survey showed today.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- With the arrival today of Britain's reply to the questionnaire on defense efforts sent out last July by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, it became probable, in the opinion of officials here, that the Council of the organization would meet in Paris Dec. 15 as scheduled but would leave decisions to a later meeting.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- The United States rejected today a Pakistani suggestion for an immediate cease-fire in Korea.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- A homecoming day crowd of more than 55,000 is expected to watch Pennsylvania attempt to halt its two-game losing streak tomorrow when the Red and Blue takes on thrice-beaten, once-tied Army at Franklin Field.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 14 (AP) -- The San Antonio police were asked today to hunt for a 28-year-old United States Navy ensign who was charged in Federal court in Portsmouth, Va., with embezzling $38,000 of a payroll of the Portsmouth Navy Yard.

The post-war decentralization of industry and management from overcrowded New York to the suburbs continued yesterday with the announcement by the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company of plans to move its headquarters and staff of 700 persons to Westchester County.

HACKENSACK, N, J., Nov. 14 -- Frank Erickson, the former bookmaking and policy ring czar who recently finished a sixteen-month jail term at Rikers Island in New York, today was sentenced to twelve to fourteen months in New Jersey State's Prison on charges growing out of his New Jersey operations.

The American Red Cross re-976 pints of blood on Thursday. The donations were made at two Red Cross centers and five mobile ported yesterday the collection of units. Winding up two days of contributing blood, soldiers at Fort Monmouth, N. J., gave 347 pints.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- The Soviet Union "sells" technical assistance to its satellites at a price fixed in United States dollars and does not provide it "free," Leo Mates, Assistant Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia, charged today in the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee.

HO-HO-KUS, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Two young men who stole two cars, shot at a policeman, held a family hostage in its own home, and robbed a drug store and a gasoline station during the night and early morning hours have eluded state, county and local police searches today.

Parents who have been trying ever since Sept. 8 to get something more than a two - word reply ("Nothing much") to the time-honored question, "What did you do in school today?", had an opportunity to discover their own answers during Open School Week just ended.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The stock markets here were stimulated into greater activity and higher prices today by news that Australia intended to relax some of her import restrictions. Best rises were shown by industrials, particularly by textiles and motors, which would be chief gainers from the Australian move.
Plans for two new public schools, one on the west side of Manhattan and the other in Forest Hills, Queens, have been filed by the Board of Education with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

ODENDAALSRUST, South Africa, Nov. 14 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan said here tonight that he would appeal to the electorate against the Appeal Court's invalidation of his attempt to make Parliament the highest constitutional court in the land.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 14 -- Michael Straus, Reclamation Commissioner, announced today that a new $2,100,000,000 six-year reclamation construction program would be given to Congress in January. He also told the National Reclamation Association convention that there would have to be more local and state control of reclamation development in the West.
The following is a round-up of hints on housekeeping that may be of use to the homemaker.

Walter Maynard, president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, drew heavily on Shakespeare yesterday in his address before the Federation of Women Shareholders in American Business, Inc. Paraphrasing one of Hamlet's soliloquies, he called his speech, "To Hold or Not to Hold."

NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 14 -- Thirty-four independent native schools in Kenya were closed this morning because of their connection with the Mau Mau terrorist society. Warnings were given to 150 other schools.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Notre Dame's tricky shift brewed a controversy today and helped rocket ticket prices for tomorrow's Michigan State game to a reported high of $70 a pair.

The National Council of the Metropolitan Opera Association was formally inaugurated at a meeting yesterday afternoon in the Opera Club room at the opera house. Fifty of the eighty-five members attended to listen to an address by Rudolf Bing, general manager, and to elect a steering committee.

The Department of Army announced yesterday through First Army headquarters on Governors Island that five camps would be closed in the near future and the men at these posts shipped to other installations.

Total volume of business in 1953, both in dollars and units, will average slightly higher than in 1952, it was predicted last night by A. W. Zelomek, president and economist of the International Statistical Bureau, in addressing the local chapter of the American Statistical Association at Remington Rand Hall.

A New York theatre and an opening date have been decided on for the new and as yet untitled Arthur Miller play. It will post its banner at the Martin Beck Theatre on Jan. 7. Before arriving here, the Kermit Bloomgarden production will be tested for two weeks in Philadelphia commencing Dec. 22.

Explanations, denials and a reversal of position on the part of a prison warden yesterday marked public statements of officials whose words and actions were the subjects of the hearings of the State Crime Commission.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 15 -- South Korean troops this morning cleared the foe from the crest of "Pinpoint Hill," dominating height of "Sniper Ridge" on the central front north of Kumwha, and then swarmed toward the Chinese Communists entrenched positions to the north.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- Temple University will close the home portion of its football schedule tomorrow when it takes on Fordham at Temple Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Justice Department is trying to find out if some public officials have been reporting graft receipts in their income tax returns, although the department is aware that such information is regarded as confidential.

The first of several young stars the Yankees are expecting to return from military service before the 1953 campaign was discharged from the Army yesterday, according to General Manager George M. Weiss of the world champions.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14 (AP) -- J. F. McHugh's River Jordan accounted for Pimlico's Clifton Park Purse at $36.80 for $2 today, but his price was overshadowed by the $185 return on Dolly's Rocket, winner of the second race.

Six of the current art exhibitions cover completely the territory between abstract and representational, and demonstrate once again that the modern artist's freedom to choose any manner that he fancies is unchallenged.

KEARNY, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Two men were killed, seven persons were injured and twenty-seven vehicles, including a bus and three trucks, were damaged today in four accidents on a fog-shrouded, half-mile section of the New Jersey Turnpike. The four accidents occurred within twenty minutes.

The nation is "very near" the end of the sellers' market in all lines and competition will force prices down during the coming months if normal factors are permitted to operate, Prof. Raymond Rodgers of the Graduate School of Banking, New York University, declared yesterday.
TORONTO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- France took an early lead tonight in a three-event international jumping competition at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Predictions for scattered showers in parts of the Southwest and in some corn belt areas took the edge off demand for grains, although the five-day forecast gave no assurance of general or heavy rainfall. Traders are cautious in buying despite the critical drought conditions which have embraced most of the country since early September, and the Southwest since last June.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 14 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, deferred today to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's disinclination to accept a post in his Cabinet at the present time, but left the door open on the possibility of a high-level appointment for the New York Governor on a temporary or emergency mission.

We were so busy talking to ourselves during the late and unlamented Presidential contest that we hardly noticed what other people were saying. Now we wake up to hear the record we made in the fine abandon of partisan debate played back to us with variations in many languages.

Two multiple-traffic offenders, one a 24-year-old former sailor who said he had flown twenty-five missions for the Israeli Air Force, were sent to the workhouse yesterday after they had been picked up for having failed to answer summonses.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Harvard's steadily improving football team, which has suddenly become extremely air-minded, will attempt to rebound from its 41-21 Princeton setback here tomorrow against Brown's luckless Bears.

An 11-year-old daughter of a Manhattan construction engineer was shot and killed in her Bronx home last night while her parents were away at the movies. The girl's two brothers, who had been "playing soldier," subsequently were missing.
A strange story of a 44-year-old legacy of $250,000 and its eventual shrinkage to $100 was related yesterday at the second day of open hearings by the State Crime Commission.

One of the pleasant things about being a grandparent is the legitimate excuse it provides for visiting the fabulous wonder world of toyland exhibited in the store and making extravagant purchases without feeling a twinge of guilt.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- The incoming Republican Administration will not "turn back the clock" on the social welfare advances of the last twenty years, Brooks Potter, president of the Family Service Association of America, declared here today.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 14 (UP) -- Over-confidence and a historic jinx are the chief enemies when Syracuse plays Colgate tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Treasury Department announced today an offering of an additional amount of certificates of indebtedness bearing 2 per cent interest in exchange for an issue of $1,062,634,000 of similar securities bearing 1 7/8 percent interest and maturing on Dec. 1.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 14 -- The Texas Company tanker Washington, loaded with oil, knifed into a small Navy transport sixty miles east of Cape Henry early today, killing five sleeping soldiers, injuring thirty-three other men and forcing postponement of a mock amphibious assault scheduled several hours later just south of Virginia Beach.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The United States continued to sell more goods abroad than it bought during September, thus further draining the dollar and gold reserves of foreign countries, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

In a statement presented at St. Louis on his behalf Dr. Charles A. Thomas, president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, a chemist who has had much to do with the management of plants in which uranium is split, assured an audience of scientists that atomic power will be a reality in four or five years.

YONKERS, Nov. 14 -- A new handle record for harness racing, $1,543,642, was set tonight by 23,520 fans at Yonkers Raceway, exceeding by $19,045 the former mark, established at Yonkers on Nov. 15, 1951, the closing night of that year.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- The West Berlin police said today they had arrested the sister of one of the seventeen members of the team of kidnappers alleged to have spirited Dr. Walter Linse, anti-Communist functionary, from West Berlin into East Germany last July 8.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Two news reports -- the special message to France from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower broadcast on the French radio the day after the Presidential elections and a recent interview with the Sultan of Morocco by an American broadcaster -- are causing ink to flow in Paris.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 14 (AP) -- A $3,000,000 expansion program for the General Electric Company's plant here to begin in the early spring was announced today by C. C. Walker, vice president and general manager of the G. E. construction materials division.
ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- A man convicted as a forger and imposter seven times since 1941 was back in jail today after a year of posing as a retired brigadier general.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 14 -- Although large-scale use of radio-isotopes already has arrived in manufacturing, research and medicine, it will be many years before the full revolutionary effect of atomic energy will be felt in the factories and homes of America, an expert in this field advised the realtors of the nation today.
DALLAS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Cotton Bowl picked Tennessee today and paved the way for a probable repeat of 1951 when the Volunteers played Texas in the Dallas New Year's Day football game.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 -- The strictly "put - together - made - for- each-other" look continues strong in the California National Press Week showings of fashions. There are full-length coats over dresses or suits, jackets that range from no more than shoulder depth to waist length and mid-hip boxy or slightly longer styles with a hint of middy influence.

New York's horse-racing wheel will have its last eight spins of the year, under Empire City Racing Association auspices, at the Jamaica track today. The wheel has been spinning, eight times a day, six days a week, since April 1, and some of the horses -- and most of the horse players -- are a bit the worse for wear.

ARLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 14 -- The deer hunters in this hilly, wooded corner of Vermont opened the season today with a very literal "bang!" and although the weather was unseasonably warm and the woods rather noisy as a result of the dry leaves underfoot, at least a half-dozen bucks were taken on Buck and Checkerberry Hills.

In the neighborhood of 150,000 persons are expected to attend the three football games of major interest in the East today and big crowds will gather in every section for one of the most attractive programs of the season drawing toward a close.

THE TIMES of Nov. 8 brings the letter of J. R. D. C. with regard to a story in which reference is made to the requirement "of native birth" as a qualification for the Presidency. Your correspondent bases his objection on the ground that the Constitution uses instead the words "natural-born citizen."
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The sordid story being sketched before the State Crime Commission, by the witnesses' testimony and by their silences, can lead to only one logical conclusion. New York City will be governed well and cleanly only when Tammany Hall is ground under the voter's heel.

SOUTH OF PANMUNJOM, Korea, Nov. 14 -- The United Nations Command today accused the Communists of killing a United States Navy hospital corpsman Wednesday in a security zone near the Panmunjom truce negotiations site.

Dimitri Mitropoulos yesterday afternoon led the Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall in a new violin concerto by the Swiss composer Frank Martin, with Joseph Szigeti as soloist. The performances of the concerto at this week's concerts were announced as being the first in America.

RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 14 -- The record vote in the Presidential campaign was "wholesome for America," Ellis Arnall said in an address at North Carolina State College here tonight. The former Georgia Governor and Director of the Office of Price Stabilization, urged both Democrats and Republicans to "close ranks and march forward unitedly behind the President the people have chosen."
Following are excerpts from the testimony of Thomas Luchese (given at previous private hearings and read into the record yesterday) and Armand Chankalian before the State Crime Commission:

Behor Sitreet, Israel's Minister of Police, who arrived here recently to study American police methods and to speak in behalf of the State of Israel bond drive, underscored yesterday the economic and industrial progress of his nation.
I am writing in reference to the article by Drew Middleton published Nov. 10.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 14 -- The American Association of Port Authorities closed its forty-first annual convention today with the election of Dr. M. D. Kinsella of Toronto as president for the ensuing year.
HONOLULU, Nov. 14 -- The Government continued to put Communist publications in evidence today in the face of continuing defense objections in the trial of seven alleged Communist leaders in Hawaii.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Tennessee, selected to compete in the Cotton Bowl football game at Dallas, has appeared in eight post-season contests, winning three and losing five. The Vols lost two Rose Bowl games, broke even in two Orange Bowl tests, have a 1-2 Sugar Bowl record and won in their lone Cotton Bowl appearance.

DETROIT, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Ron Morris outpassed Detroit's Ted Marchibroda, four touchdowns to two, in one of college football's greatest aerial shows tonight and bowl-conscious Tulsa rolled to a 62 -- 21 victory.

SASABE, Ariz., Nov. 14 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois said today that the best course for the Democratic party to follow to get back into power was to earn the respect and esteem of the people.

The Metropolitan Opera, ever alert for new fields to conquer under the generalship of Rudolf Bing, is to send its performance of "Carmen" to some thirty-five theatres across the nation in a single night. This jet-propelled miracle will be accomplished through the medium of television.

A taxpayer building containing fifteen stores at 24-02 to 24-30 Thirty-fourth Avenue in Astoria, Queens, has been sold by the H. N. S. Realty Corporation to clients of William Alpern and Edward Tykets, attorneys. Louis Dandsman was the broker and Samuel R. Buxbaum was attorney for the seller.

TANGIER, Nov. 14 (AP) -- It looks as if pirates are again sailing the Moroccan Main. Police in the international zone here will not give any details, but they are holding nine crewmen -- American, British, French and Dutch -- of a landing barge, and a former British mine-layer has been found beached and abandoned on the Algerian coast.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 15 -- A United States Air Force transport plane crashed into a 2,000-foot mountain twenty miles east of Seoul yesterday, killing forty-four passengers and crewmen. Headquarters here of the Far East Air Forces said the plane was a C-119 Flying Box-car.
CAMBRIDGE, N. Y., Nov. 14 (AP) -- A General Electric Company official predicted tonight that American farms would be using 70 billion kilowatt hours of electricity annually by 1970.
The machine-tool industry faces in 1953 a probability of greatly reduced shipments, an influx of foreign tools and a prospect of a saturated market.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was again active yesterday and active months dipped 7 to 44 points net.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Clayton Bissell, retired, testified today that he had put a "top secret" label on a report of the Katyn Forest massacre because of its "political implications" in light of the Yalta agreement. He made the statement before a House subcommittee that is investigating the massacre.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- With two opposing resolutions before it, the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly continued in spirited debate today on the racial policies of the Union of South Africa.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Nov. 14 -- A high level of business activity, buttressed by stable prices and a firm base of income, is in prospect for the country during the first part of next year and probably longer, the Business Advisory Council, composed of the nation's top industrialists predicted here today.
OTTAWA, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian farms have broken all records, harvesting an unprecedented 688,000,000-bushel wheat crop this year, exceeding all official forecasts.

The National Rubber Machinery Company increased its quarterly dividend to 30 cents a share yesterday and also voted an extra of 15 cents, both for payment on Dec. 18. This will bring 1952 payments to $1.20, or 20 cents more than last year's disbursements.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Prince Charles, the Duke of Cornwall and heir apparent to the British throne, celebrated his fourth birthday today by playing host to a dozen young friends at a tea party in Buckingham Palac .

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- The Public Service Commission promulgated today the state's first comprehensive gas service safety code and ordered gas service companies of the state and all interstate companies having pipelines in the state sive gas safety code and ordered all gas service companies of the state and all interstate companies having gas pipelines in the state to undertake immediate programs for compliance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Jack Baumgartner, a fourth-string quarterback for George Washington University, scored a touchdown and passed to two others tonight to lead his team to a 40-13 victory over Davidson.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Members of Parliament, like American members of Congress, can hurl charges of communism with impunity within the precincts of their own chamber, Sir Charles MacAndrew, the Deputy Speaker of the House of Commons ruled today.
Newark Airport, which was closed to all flights on Feb. 11 and reopened with severe restrictions on June 16, became available to all operations at 12:01 A. M. today.
Government shipping authorities are seriously considering dropping plans to build additional fast freighters of the Mariner class, it was reliably reported yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 14 -- The Chairman of the Indonesian Parliament, Sartono, announced yesterday that Parliament would re-convene Nov. 27 and that the Government would take strict security measures to prevent threatened disturbances when the representatives reassemble for their third session this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Federal Government today authorized ceiling price increases ranging as high as 75 cents a ton on bituminous (soft) coal and $1.35 a ton on Pennsylvania anthracite (hard coal) to cover increased labor costs.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 14 (UP) -- Alger Hiss pleaded in person today for a parole from prison. The former State Department official asked that he be freed after serving twenty months of a five-year sentence imposed for perjury in testimony to a Federal grand jury about his connections with Communist spies.

Additional offensive strength was given to the Football Giants yesterday when Joe Scott, right halfback in both the A and T formations, was returned to the active list. Scott will be in the backfield in tomorrow's important clash with the Green Bay Packers at the Polo Grounds.

The struggle of Christians to improve living conditions and halt the spread of totalitarian concepts in secular government will be among the topics of discussion when official representatives of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. meet next month in Denver for the council's second general assembly.

DUNELLEN, N. J., Nov. 14 -- The police of this small Middlesex County borough continued their search today in the junk-littered house of an aged eccentric, whose death on Wednesday revealed that he left a fortune that may run into thousands of dollars.

Woods with colors as unusual as their names have been utilized by Edgar Johnson to fashion handmade trays and bowls that will go on view at Wor-de-Klee, Inc., and the Mortimer Levitt Gallery, 35 East Forty-ninth Street.

" SNIPER RIDGE," on the Korean Front, Nov. 14 -- As darkness fell across the cheerless mountains of central Korea tonight a new epic in bravery had been written by the infantrymen of the South Korean division holding this sector.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The members of Prime Minister Churchill's government have expressed the hope privately that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's inauguration next January will not be followed immediately by a change in Ambassadors to the Court of St. James.

A jazz concert was presented at Carnegie Hall last evening under the auspices of Patrica Music, Inc., featuring Duke Ellington and his Orchestra, Sten Getz, tenor saxophonist; Ahmad Jamal and his Three Strings, Dizzy Gillespie, trumpeter; Charlie Parker, alto saxophonist, and Billie Holiday, vocalist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 - President Truman today gave Washington's 250,000 Federal employes permission to take time off from their jobs Tuesday to participate in a civic welcome for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect.

Thunderclap testimony disclosing warm social relationships between Thomas (Three Finger Brown) Luchese, underworld chief, and high Government officials was introduced yesterday at the State Crime Commission's public hearing into gangster - politician tie-ups.

Philip Murray probably died of a broken heart. The overwhelming defeat of Adlai Stevenson undoubtedly meant to him the repudiation of all he had helped to build, a better world and a finer America. He came as close to being the indispensable man in the labor movement as we shall ever see.

Last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center included the season's first presentation of "Age of Anxiety," choreographed by Jerome Robbins to music of Leonard Bernstein. Heading its cast, as in other seasons, were Melissa Hayden, Francisco Moncion, Todd Bolender and Roy Tobias.
TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,434, for Friday:

The most prosperous and able-to-buy group in the country today consists of the wage-earner families, who comprise 52.3 per cent of all United States families and more than 60 per cent of urban families. This is shown in a survey, "America's New Buying Power," by Macfadden Publications.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Speakers at the plenary session of the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization appeared today to be going off in several different directions on the organization's budget and program.

TWO challenging studies in the creeping pathology of totalitarianism are on our table this morning. One is "Report on the American Communist,"* by Morris L. Ernst and David Loth, a briskly Kinseyan investigation of slavery in red. The other is "Anatomy of a Satellite," by Dana Adams Schmidt, who shows in precise, dramatic detail what happens to everybody, high and low, when the Kremlin gremlins take over a democracy.

Situated within a stone's throw of the "Great White Way," the sixteen-block area from Fiftieth to Fifty-eighth Streets between Eight and Tenth Avenues was singled out yesterday as having "just about the city's worst recreational facilities."

Edith Keller of East Germany and Eileen Tranmer of England were credited with victories yesterday in adjourned games in the women's world chess championship challengers tournament in Moscow, according to a report received from Soviet news sources.

The stock market exhibited a fair measure of strength in late trading yesterday but the improvement was highly selective and permitted a rise of only 0.42 point in the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- The budget committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted today to place, effective in 1954, a ceiling on the contributions of each United Nations member. The ceiling was fixed at 32 1-3 per cent of total assessments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A Navy patent (2,617,703) issued this week for a torpedo recording mechanism is notable chiefly for its age -- the application had been pending more than nineteen years. The inventor, Chester T. Minkler, who in 1933 was employed at the Naval Torpedo Station, Newport, R. I., designed it to test the exploding mechanisms of torpedoes.

Linden, N. J., borrowed $1,248,000 yesterday on general and local improvement bonds due from 1953 to 1971. The issue was bought at public sealed bidding by a banking syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank at a bid of 100.1992 for interest of 2.1 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields ranging from 1.1 per cent to 2.25 per cent.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 -- The Executive Board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations met and recessed today without making any move toward the designation of a president to succeed Philip Murray, who died last Sunday in San Francisco, where he had stopped on the way to the C. I. O.'s annual convention in Los Angeles.

A Christmas gift of thousands of shiny new toys from the people of West Germany to orphans and underprivileged children in this country was made available by the Army yesterday for distribution in time for the holiday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -- Spokesmen for the lumber industry urged the Government today to spend $150,000,000 in the next five years for access roads to speed the harvesting of over-age and damaged timber on Federal lands.

The Bureau of Education of Fair Trade will issue today a newsletter accusing the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission of seeking to "repeal by indirection" the McGuire (fair trade) Act passed by Congress at its last session.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- John Paton Davies Jr., Deputy Director of Political Affairs in the Office of the United States High Commissioner in Germany, is undergoing a hearing by the Loyalty Review Board.
You are going to be approached, perhaps today, by a cheerful lady wearing a "United Hospital Fund" sash and bearing a blue collection box.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 14 -- A surprise Navy eleven, boasting its best record since 1945, goes after its fifth triumph in eight starts tomorrow at Thompson Stadium. The Middies rule two-touchdown favorites over the Columbia Lions of Lou Little.

HAVANA, Nov. 14 -- President Fulgencio Batista tonight declared he had saved the national economy from collapse and blamed the regime of his predecessor, Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, for the difficulties now being faced by his Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -- Rear Admiral Thomas S. Combs said at his press conference today that modern high speed aircraft had been encountering difficulty in snagging the arresting gear at the stern of a carrier. Sometimes they careen through barriers and over a twelve and one-half foot nylon net barricade and crash into planes parked forward for storage or take off, he added.

The battlefields of Korea are strewn with the bodies of men who have given their lives for the United Nations ideal. The dream of world peace inexorably demands its sacrifices, but they are not limited to the victims of shot and shell. Sometimes the toll is taken in this mortal struggle far behind the lines of combat.

Exultant over their impressive victory over the Minneapolis Lakers, the New York Knickerbockers will face the Boston Celtics, another keen rival, at Madison Square Garden tonight. The opening contest of a National Basketball Association double-header, starting at 7:30, pairs the Indianapolis Olympians and the Philadelphia Warriors.

Sales in October of leading chain and mail order companies showed an increase of 10.1 per cent over the same month last year, according to a compilation of forty-two companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The increase compares with a rise of 7.5 per cent in September.

MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Engelbert Beham, procurement officer of the Bavarian State Police, was formally charged by a United States prosecutor today with illegal possession and transportation of stolen United States Army ammunition.
Kitchen employes of the Toots Shor restaurant, 51 West Fifty-first Street, struck last night at the height of the dinner hour, charging that management had refused to bargain in good faith.

It was a musical program, played in a musical manner, that Aldo Parisot presented last night in Town Hall. The Mozart Divertimento is a lovely piece, the Sammartini Sonata (a novelty to this listener) perfectly charming, and the Schubert "Arpeggione" Sonata, long a favorite of 'cellists, is one of the composer's most pleasing lightweight works.

Among the many big problems with which the Eisenhower Administration will have to struggle there will be a number of minor ones -- minor in a relative sense and decidedly major for the countries concerned. Trieste is one of these problems, but all of them are like running sores, intensely irritating and capable of spreading to serious proportions if they are left to fester.

The John and Mary R. Markle Foundation, which marked its twenty-fifth anniversary at the close of 1951, appropriated $13,700,000 in the quarter-century period in support of charitable and medical research projects. John M. Russell, executive director, reported yesterday.

STEVE POTTER, star 220-yard runner for Hillchuck High, has trouble. Worried over his father's illness and over the lack of money which may prevent him from getting to college, Steve has to fight against the temptation of easy money in college athletics.

Trade here was off in the week, and merchandisers frankly conceded their puzzlement as to the cause. The weather was a couple of degrees below normal, whereas in the corresponding 1951 week it was 11 degrees above normal. The should have helped the year-to-year comparative figure.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- This northern Westchester community plans a formal opening soon of the Underhill Road Overpass, which it has sought since 1931 when the Taconic State Parkway was opened and cut this town in half.

Plans are being advanced for the fourth annual dinner dance of Ballet Associates in America, Inc., to be given on Nov. 28 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the New York City Ballet. The sponsor of the fete is Smoke Rise, the suburban residential community project in Kinnelon Borough, near Butler, N. J., of which J. Alden Talbot, president of Ballet Associates, also is president.

A BIOGRAPHY of a President needs no excuse. This book is the first half of a full-length portrait of Benjamin Harrison -- a prologue, in a way, to a study of mediocrity in high office. Father Harry Sievers has painstakingly culled extensive materials on a very limited man.

HAS your dog been having any trouble with you lately? Do you act dopey while he is taking you for a walk, spurn his left-over hamburger, at the table, dawdle over answering his commands? While the regrettable truth may be that your true nature is revealed in these shortcomings there is reason to hope that you simply are a little thick, that you don't understand your place in your dog's home.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 15 -- The totalitarian menace that confronts the United States is constant and as a result this country must maintain a steady defense effort that avoids extremes but keeps us at all times at cruising speed, Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, said here today.

PRESIDENT Edward T. McCormick, when he persuaded his associates recently to vote a new name for the New York Curb Exchange, was thinking in three tenses. The Curb's handsomely housed present is greatly different from its blustery outdoor past. And Mr. McCormick has ambitious plans for its future.

MANY long hard roads with sagging surfaces and dangerous curves lie ahead of the State Temporary Highway Finance Planning Commission recently appointed by Governor Dewey. To this board is allotted the task of finding the money to bring the highways of the state back to a degree of adequacy.

ANYONE in Asia who watches Point Four in action soon comes to a challenging realization. Point Four is no mere program, however bold and new. Potentially, it is a revolutionary concept. If we understand it, and nourish it. Point Four may go down in history as the most important single idea of our generation, the counter-revolutionary movement with which world communism could not cope.

TOKYO, Nov. 15 -- Crown Prince Akihito, heir to the oldest throne on earth appeared in the Imperial Plaza in downtown Tokyo this afternoon before 75,000 cheering Japanese to thank them and his 84,000,000 other future subjects for their good wishes.

THIS small land-dot in mid-Atlantic is enjoying something new in the way of entertainment. The Bermuda Festival, in progress since September, is a cultural venture with the professional touch and, its ardent sponsors believe, wide possibilities.

IN the political campaign just past, we have heard considerably about a "one-party" press. Because of this charge, it is good to have this review of the news scene by the leading historian of the American newspaper.

Peattie is not among the paradoxical sportsmen who best express their love for the great outdoors by slaughtering in safety its more defenseless creatures. His book concerns itself with America and its so-called lesser beings and incidentally with what man has done to them.

In fact, John Gielgud, the Cassius of Metro's now completed "Julius Caesar," was not above an implication or two that the international Shakespearean stage, which he exemplifies, might soon be contemplating its laurels.

TOKYO Sunday, Nov. 16 -- Chinese Communist troops made sporadic attacks last night and early today against United Nations positions atop "Sniper Ridge," north of Kumhwa on the central Korean front but failed to break into the Allied lines.

THE recent admission of Mamie Eisenhower that her husband is a better cook than she spotlights the widespread and victorious post-war male invasion of woman's traditionally impregnable redoubt -- the kitchen The growing popularity of cooking articles in men's magazines, the increase in the purchase of cookbooks by men and the sales of charcoal broilers and barbecue tools all underline the fact that more men are interested in cooking than ever before.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Frank Milostan and two platoons of hard - charging linemen carried Xavier University to a 6-0 victory over favored Boston College today in the Cincinnati Musketeers first visit to the East in fifteen years.

ONE of the greatest advantages of science fiction is the ease with which the reader can roll back the boundaries of time and space. In this second quintet in the Winston Science Fiction Series he can, as he chooses, go forward into space, backward into pre-history, or down, down into the depths of the ocean.
THE greatest document for human service is here interpreted at a young level, with the apparently effortless human quality which is characteristic of this distinguished author.

A joint celebration marking the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the Altro Health and Rehabilitation Services and the completion of the organization's new $300,000 Bronx workshop for persons recovering from tuberculosis and heart diseases was announced yesterday by Edward Hochhauser, president of the Altro Work Shops, Inc.
The National Association for American Composers and Conductors began its twentieth season with a concert at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

THE season for looking into the theory behind garden practices is in full swing. The various horticultural groups around New York City are offering a selection of lectures, many of which are open to the public without charge, on topics ranging from insect control to flower arrangement.

LATE fall. after the leaves have fallen, and early spring, before the leaf buds open, are the best periods for planting deciduous trees. Fall planting gives most kinds added time to readjust to their new environment but, in spite of this, certain trees with spongy roots and paper-thin bark should be moved only in the spring.

"DING DONG SCHOOL-HOUSE," a program for very young children which made its debut over WNBQ in Chicago early in October and promptly became a phenomenal local success, will become a network feature over the N. B. C. television chain beginning Monday, Nov. 24, from 10 to 10:30 A. M., on a five-morning-a-week schedule.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., Nov. 15 -- Federal state and local enforcement officers rounded up twenty-five persons today in a series of raids that climaxed a four-month narcotics investigation.

IN an election year made memorable not only by the vigorous battle between the parties and the candidates but also by some unexpectedly brilliant speechmaking, the publication of a new biography of Robert G. Ingersoll (1833-99) is especially timely.

TO many sociologists and psychologists, modern women represent the lost sex: to others, they seem actually to have found their place in that sun which man works from and to. Others hold that women have been educated beyond their opportunities, have confused feminism with femininity and have abandoned wiles for Wylie.

"A MINUTE or two before or after two-thirty on the afternoon of the twenty-second of June. Avery Bullard suffered what was later diagnosed as a cerebral hemorrhage. After fifty-six years, somewhere deep within the convoluted recesses of his brain, a tiny artery finally yielded to the insistent pounding of his hard-driven bloodstream.

While it is essential to keep sectarian religious influences out of the public schools, it is neither possible nor desirable to maintain a separation of religion from education, 1,250 members of the Protestant Teachers Association of New York were told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The American working population has a tradition of mobility and flexibility to meet the Nation's changing manpower requirements, such as in the current semi-mobilization economy, but it has a large degree of stick-to-itiveness as well.

With great interest I read Harry Schwartz' homage to Mr. Kerensky in "Then and Now" (Nov. 2). Mr. Kerensky is undoubtedly a great orator, but foreign observers agree on his being but a poor statesman.

THE first scheduled helicopter passenger and freight service in the United States will be started sometime next year in New York and Los Angeles, L. Welch Pogue, former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, forecast last week.

This week will be one of the busiest of the season at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. A quantity and variety of merchandise will be auctioned each afternoon, except today and tomorrow, and on two evenings.

LANGSTON HUGHES, the famous Negro poet, has written an introductory account of the Negro people which describes their life and culture in Africa as well as on this continent. It is told in semi-fictional form, chiefly through the experiences of Terry a little Negro boy who lives in New York.

A SPIRITED story, this one, of the old fur-trading days in Canada, woven around the adventures of a 14-year-old Scottish boy, Alex McAndrews. Enticed away from the Hudson's Bay Company by the promise of quick promotion, young Alex joins an expedition going west to meet the famed head of the company, Alexander Mackenzie.

A COLLECTION of thirty-five long and short documents from American history, back-stopped by introductory chapters written by Richard D. Heffner, "A Documentary History of the United States" is a fine contribution to popular education.

TWELVE stories, one for each month of the year, tell of the experiences of small Timothy. In February a valentine snowman was a pleasant surprise for a little boy who had the mumps; during the spring months there were a shopping tour, a walk in the rain and a train ride; summer brought a new neighbor and the important fifth birthday; and in the fall the great event: Timothy's first day in kindergarten.

VARIETY is, of course, the bible of show business, each week writing a pungent chapter on bookings, grosses, gossip and similar trade matters, and then, on occasion, coming out with special numbers which are bible in the super colossal.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 15 -Hofstra lived up to its notice as one of the east's better small college elevens today by downing Upsala, 25 to 7, on the slippery turf of Hofstra Field.

THIS tale of two feuding towns and their peacemaker is created for the child who, even in his early reading, has learned to take more from a book than just its plot, suspense or humor. He will easily find all three here, used to the fullest advantage.

IT is not quite true that during the autumn months there is no one in Europe hut the Europeans. There are some American tourists, but nowhere near the great masses of them that clutter up the place in the summertime, and one does not have the feeling that Piccadilly Circus and the Champs-Elysees are merely extensions, respectively, of Times Square and Fifth Avenue.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 15 -Thick fog brought another disastrous day to motorists on the New Jersey Turnpike today. Within three hours early this morning, six crashes occurred in the ElizabethNewark area of the high-speed highway, resulting in the death of two young sailors on leave and injuring thirty-three other persons.
The arbitration award of last week which increased seamen's wages by as much as 15 per cent was viewed with disappointment yesterday by East and Gulf Coast steamship operators.

The United Nations has lost ground in the past two years because of the Korean conflict and the attendent loss of goodwill in the United States, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the Trusteeship Department of the United Nations, conceded here yesterday.

MOVIEGOERS who enjoyed this Academy Award winner on their neighborhood screen should get many a retrospective chuckle from its adaptation in book form -- though it must be admitted at the outset that some of the antic humor is lost in the silent treatment.

EVER since Joseph received his coat of many colors, big brothers have been complaining about little brothers. In the case of Buzz it's not very serious, but he is annoyed by his little brother Frankie, who tags along and spoils his fun. This is the unfortunate but typical state of affairs when the school puts on its Spring Festival.

The police began a new crackdown on persistent violators of traffic and motor vehicle laws at 12:01 o'clock this morning by rounding up and towing away automobiles with out-of-state registrations whose owners have ignored parking summonses.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15 -- Pravda declared today that the elections in the United States constituted a repudiation of the Truman-Acheson foreign policy and reflected a wide demand by the American people for an end of the war in Korea.

THERE'S scarcely anything about telephones and how they work that doesn't come in for some consideration in this book -- whether it is how a plucked rubber-band makes sound to how you can telephone to your grandmother from mid-ocean. Between these extremes the reader learns what happens in the receiver at your ear.

ATHENS. RICHLY rewarding vestiges of a Greek civilization as early as 2000 B. C. are currently being excavated at Mycenae. Homeric royal capital in the Peloponnesus. Within a few hundred yards of the Lions' Gate where the famous German-American archaeologist Heinrich Schliemann made important discoveries seventy-six years ago -- thus piecing together much history of Greece's ancient past -- new scholars are at work.

The Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers bestowed honors and awards upon several members and visitors for outstanding and notable accomplishments in the maritime industry at the group's sixtieth annual conference last week.

WHEN the War of 1812 cut off imported goods daring men risked their reputation and fortune by setting up mills to manufacture thread. A few even thought of power looms, but found themselves opposed by a vain preference for imported fabrics and by Congressmen who said America was still too young for such enterprise.

THIS modest little book by a distinguished Massachusetts business man belongs in the field of pure polemics. It is a compact and savage indictment of most of our policies and actions of the past decade with especial emphasis on the loss of China, the dismissal of General MacArthur and the acquiescence in the Soviet seizure of Poland. It is in the form of two letters, one to a friend and the other to the publisher.

THESE "young pages from American autobiography" offer older boys and girls a stimulating group of personal histories. Touching on widely varied aspects of life in this country, it is an original collection that ranges far afield in time and place, and includes personalities as diverse as Walter White, P T. Barnum, Bob Feller and Emily Kimbrough.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 15 -- Peter Poth, 35-year-old ex-convict, of 149 Carroll Street, and Robert Calabrese, 17, of 166 Union Avenue, Bloomingdale, N. J., were identified today as the bandits who forced their way into the home of James J. Wall of 11 Carlton Avenue, Ho-Ho-Kus, and held him prisoner for three hours Thursday night.

IN the last year or two we have all become more aware of a diversified opinion among critics, announcers, TV production and technical personnel, and viewers, as to the degree of talk that should be employed in the description of sports events.

One of the more unusual devices used by industry to build good-will and at the same time promote sales, is the collecting and exhibiting of ancient or odd items depicting the evolution of a particular type of product. Most such collections, particularly if they are portable, are effective in stirring up public interest in a product while enhancing the reputation of the exhibitor, it has been found.
GENEVA, Nov. 15 -- In several European parliaments, Government leaders found it necessary this week to affirm that Western economy is not in a depression.

Y., is one of the few progressive-education colleges in the country. It has become known for a highly individualized plan of study under which each student follows a program designed for his own needs.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Kentucky unleashed a ground attack today that gained a total of 284 yards to defeat Clemson, 27-14.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Delegates dealing with the Korean negotiations were urged by their committee chairman today to set a faster pace and move from general debate to detailed consideration of specific proposals for an armistice.

IN these days when a necessary effort is made to lure unwilling readers into literature with brief and easy stories, a juvenile book of near 600 pages seems almost an anachronism. There are still, however, avid readers who really enjoy the substance and the continuity which a three-decker novel offers. For them this picaresque tale should be a major experience.

PROTECTING her three kittens, Percy, Polly and Pete, from the affectionate but smothering embraces of the baby, Shasha, aged 2, proved a trying chore for Millie, the mother cat. DURING the next two weeks, with the deer season open in several Eastern states, there are certain to be a number of fatal accidents which will be emphasized, for the benefit of the reading public, in large, bold headlines.

A new program of graduate studies for full-time resident students in the field of professional education goes into effect this fall at the University of Connecticut. The number of students earning degrees has increased so rapidly that a campus program for full-time resident students became necessary.

The controversy between New York savings banks and commercial banks over establishment of branch offices "points up the close identification of interests between savings banks and savings and loan associations."

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Premier Antoine Pinay decided today to ask the National Assembly next week to give him a vote of confidence on his financial program, over which there has been considerable disagreement in the last few weeks' discussions.

GENEVA, Nov. 14 -- News is beginning to trickle into Europe of powerful business support for re-examination from the ground up of United States commercial and monetary policies where these have impact on the world economy. This is news Europeans like to hear.

FREEVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Gerald Morrison of Rochester took office today as president of the world's smallest republic with the good wishes of the President-elect of the world's largest republic, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

CEDRIC ADAMS is a newspaper columnist out Minneapolis-St. Paul way. Primarily he is a personality, a natural, as they say, for radio and television, with a large following throughout the Midwest. This book shows why.
A sporting goods store in Cheyenne, Wyo., announced the winner of its trout fishing contest--Harland Troudt.

THE heat's on. As millions of radiators hissed and banged their way back into action last month, house plants and city gardeners found themselves under a terrific strain. Plants showed the effects in wilting and yellowing of foliage; gardeners in a general morbidness which increased with each faded leaf they removed. There were moments when, like others, I was all for trying something simple -- polar bears, for instance.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Andy Kozar, a Pennsylvania coal miner's son who, doctors once said would never be able to play football, ripped Florida's line to shreds today to lead Cotton-Bowl-bound Tennessee to a 26-12 homecoming victory.

THE "Bantam 8," a new flash lamp less than half the size of the popular midget, was announced last week by Sylvania Electric Products, Inc. The tiny lamp, which has the same bayonet base as the midget and is the same length but slimmer, fits regular bayonet sockets and standard reflectors without adaptors.

AS the climax of this year's Stamp Collecting Week, beginning today, the fourth annual National Postage Stamp Show, with "The Story of the Red Cross in Postage Stamps" as the theme, will be held Friday through Sunday in the 71st Infantry Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

Development of electrical methods for machining and grinding may lessen this country's dependence on industrial diamonds, a critical item, for machine tool work, Kenneth R. Beardslee, general manager of the carboloy department of the General Electric Company, said last week in Detroit.

Riverdale captured the local Ivy prep school championship for the third successive year, crushing Stony Brook of Long Island, 33 -- 13, yesterday on the winner's gridiron in the Bronx. The triumph wag Riverdale's thirteenth straight, six of which were recorded this campaign.

FIRST published in England in 1940, "A Chinese Childhood" will be welcomed by all Americans who have enjoyed "The Silent Traveler in New York," "The Silent Traveler in Edinburgh," and "The Silent Traveler in the Yorkshire Dales."

Y.

THE man at the baby grand was Frank Loesser, the country's hottest tunesmith. He was playing like anything, singing puckishly, and talking all the while, with the opulence of prosperity in his voice, about "Hans Christian Andersen," the new Goldwyn musical opening Nov. 25 in New York.

THE recent rise of interest in Portugal has been accompanied by considerable frustration on the part of people looking for a good book to explain its past and analyze its present. Charles Howell, Professor of History at the University of Illinois, has now provided the much needed layman's history.

SOUTH AMBOY, N. J., Nov. 15 -- Hampered by cold rain throughout the day, searching parties today called off their hunt for any additions to the cache of fifteen high-explosive packages found by the police in a deserted area of this town two days ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 15 -- The weather, unmindful of civic pride, put a damper this morning on the public ceremonies arranged for the formal opening of Television City and prevented two of the Columbia Broadcasting System's top executives from being present at the ribbon-cutting ceremony.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 (AP) -Unbeaten Southern California drove through rain, mud and the University of Washington football team today for a 33-0 victory to set the stage for next week's Rose Bowl-deciding battle with undefeated U. C. L. A.

THE difference between college and professional hockey is pointed up in this fast paced story for teen-agers. When Pete Grenville, Dartmouth's star center and highest scorer in the East, is tapped by a scout for the professional New York Rangers he feels that his future is set.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -- President Truman opened Federal tax returns today to a Senate Judiciary subcommittee for its investigation of the Office of Alien Property, denounced by some Republicans as "a super gravy train" for Administration friends.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Wisconsin rode into a tie for the Big Ten lead today on the broad back of Alan (The Horse) Ameche, who scored three touchdowns in a 37 -- 14 victory over Indiana.

JOHANNA, 17 and just out of finishing school, had come back to her father's home for what promised to be a rather uneventful year. An unusual legacy -- two horses, one of them a killer -- brought excitement and danger, work and a chance to grow up.

YEARS ago when Indian camps dotted the Great Plains, the movements of vast buffalo herds marked the real calendar of the seasons. Spring saw the animals surging north for rich grazing. They were tough and lean, not yet tempting to hunters.

FROM the moment he climbs out of a cab in front of a Florida hotel until his final acceptance by Mike and the regulars, Marty Ferris finds his life with the New York Yankees thrilling experience. He wins a place in the Yankee outfield by opening day and plays spectacularly, but in early summer he is sent back to Kansas City for more seasoning.

STARTING out with a real, everyday little girl in a small shipbuilding village in nineteenth - century England, this story soon leaves ordinary matters behind and leads fanciful readers to a valley where only the young of heart can follow.

The selection in Santa's pack may not be as complete this year as the public would like. St. Nick has been relaxing the past few weeks, what with early Christmas buying slower than last year. Retailers note that they have not put through many reorders but manufacturers say their shelves are nearly empty, especially on the most popular items.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -- The Defense Department released today plans for holiday leave in the military establishment. They vary from service to service. On paper, the Army's plans seem most liberal.
CAIRO, Nov. 15 -- Husbands should try to reform their wives before thinking of divorce, a leading Moslem authority in Egypt, Sheikh Mohammed el Khadr, rector of Al Azhar University, has declared.

THE Tidewater region of North Carolina can seem a very dull and uninteresting place to the southbound tourist who hurries through it on U. S. 17. It is a flat land, with broad stretches of pine forests and gloomy swamps.

IT is a real pleasure to find a novel which presents young people of pioneer days as sensitive human beings with problems beyond those of wresting a living from a new land. Such a person is Jim Keath who has been brought up by the Crow Indians.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- White Plains High routed DeWitt Clinton High of New York, 55 to 0, today to extend its football string to twenty-eight games without defeat since 1949, including twenty-seven straight victories, seven this fall. The Governors dropped their fourth of seven games.
If Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower really wants lower Government spending, a balanced budget and an end to inflation, he has picked a man who knows how to give him all three in overflowing measure.

THE fact that George Jessel is making television appearances these days does not mean that the comedian-producer has turned his back on the movies. The reverse is true, as the self-styled "toastmaster general" made plain last week.

THE main characters of this exceptionally good historical novel are Margaret Plantagenet and her small brother Neddie, orphaned children of the Duke of Clarence and cousins of the two little princes who were murdered in the Tower of London.

Moving to the front in great style in the second half, the New York Knickerbockers remained unbeaten at home and stayed in first place in the Eastern division by halting the Boston Celtics, 79 to 68, in the feature clash of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Watertown High School today won the State Public High School Athletic Association cross-country championship for Class A schools with enrollments over 1,000.

Drs. L. Jennings Hampton, associate professor, and David M. Little Jr., assistant clinical professor of anesthesiology of Yale's School of Medicine, come forth with succinylcholine, a synthetic drug that shortens the preparation of patients for certain surgical operations.

THIS collection of Norse myths provides a much-needed and vigorous interpretation for children of the tales the North men told about the high deeds of their gods. Miss Hosford has used Snorri Sturluson's compilation of the Icelandic Prose Edda for her source, bearing in mind his advice to Young Skalds to handle the tales "with affection and respect and understanding."
COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 15 (AP) -Jimmy Campagna, who runs like a streak, and Bob Clemens, who charges like a maddened bull, sparked Georgia to a 13-to-7 triumph over Auburn today.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Although the number of hunting licenses issued in the state this year reached a new high, fewer sportsmen appeared in the woods of Rockland and southern Orange counties for today's opening of the deer season than at any time since deer hunting was legalized.

ATHENS, Nov. 15 -- The process of constructing a deterrent wall against any potential Soviet aggression in Europe was materially advanced this week when Marshal Tito disclosed that Yugoslavia would shortly begin mutual defense talks with Greece and Turkey, the two easternmost members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

IT would be hard to imagine a better introduction to seamanship than this comprehensive little book. Here the fledgling mariner will find all he needs to know about all types of boats; their construction, use, maintenance and even their historical background.

CERTAIN forces in Hollywood have been trying in recent weeks to kick up a first class row over the refusal of the British to grant work permits to some American actors hired to play in American-sponsored pictures made in England.

Financial markets gave a comparatively dull performance last week, with business restricted to four trading days because of the Armistice Day holiday. There was no disposition shown to extend the recent improvement in the stock market. Stocks moved narrowly in quiet trading, and prices showed little change in the week as traders awaited the decision on the soft coal miners' wage dispute.
LONDON, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- Billy Elliott, outside left for Burnley, slammed home a goal on a solo run which carried his team to second place in the first division of English soccer today.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 15 (AP) - Oil men received this week a prediction that United States demand for petroleum products will increase 46 per cent in the next fifteen years.

Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett is among the least loquacious and least contentious of our department heads in Washington, but when aroused he is also easily one of the most articulate. This characteristic is well exemplified in Mr. Lovett's reply to the Senate "watchdog committee" on rearmament, which had charged that "blundering" by the Pentagon had slowed the nation's rearmament build-up.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 15 -- In another of those tense struggles sprinkled liberally through the 53-game series begun in 1891, favored Syracuse posted a 20-to-14 triumph over Colgate's eleven today. The contest was a battle until the very end with the winners staving off a Red Raider last-period surge to triumph.

THE cheerful colors on these pages match not only the sunrise but the joyful welcome of the small child, eager to begin the new day. "What will you think? What will you play? Wake up, everyone! This is your day." The birds, horses, sheep, flowers, bees all awaken to a bright new world.

One of the first large post-election gatherings of business leaders and representatives of major concerns in the international trade and investment fields gets under way tomorrow with the opening of the thirty-ninth National Foreign Trade Convention. It is expected to serve as a "direction finder" for future national foreign economic policy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The headaches that the new Administration will inherit in January will almost certainly include the knotty question of what to do about Judith Coplon, twice convicted of spying for Russia.

RICK dreads leaving his friends in Ohio to homestead in Alaska's Matanuska Valley until his father promises to let him return "outside" in the fall. The trip over the Alaska Highway, and homesteading on Hard Luck Land are experiences that will fill city boys with yearning for the far north.

At the meeting of the Grocery Manufacturers Association here last week, Austin Igleheart, president of General Foods Corporation, produced figures to show that, in terms of average earnings, the cost of food, though high, is not as high as it used to be.

THE regret with which Lippincott announces that "Doctor Dolittle's Puddleby Adventures" will be the last of the series is an emotion that will be shared by many of us. Since 1920 almost every childhood has been enriched by the stories of the kind, animal-loving doctor and his friends.

LIVING in a beach community this summer brought home sharply to me the constant observation and criticism to which parents are exposed in living with their children. One afternoon I sat by as two other mothers seated on the sand discussed the difficulties of a mutual friend and her children.
ATHENS, Nov. 15 -- Nearly 1,500,000 voters will go to the polls tomorrow in a national election. the outcome of which may prove fateful in Greece's history.

IN 1924 against a powerful Michigan eleven, to cite an outstanding for-instance, Illinois' Red Grange scored four touchdowns in the first ten minutes of play, returned in the third quarter to go over for a fifth time and later passed for a sixth score. Surely, few will quarrel with the choice of subtitle for this latest biography from the Schoor production line.

The New York Football Giants, who looked so well in downing the San Francisco Forty-Niners last Sunday, will tackle another tough foe at the Polo Grounds today. Their rivals, in the twenty-ninth game of a series dating back to 1928, are the Green Bay Packers, who come to town with a winning record and the National League's two top passers.

OCALA, Fla. -- This Florida city of 10,000 in the north-central part of the state 102 miles from Jacksonville and 171 miles from Tallahassee is a highway junction point of three U. S. and four state roads, and probably serves more overnight visitors in its many motels than any other city in the state.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Managing editors of the country said today that secrecy was the "refuge of corrupt, wicked and reactionary government" and urged complete freedom of information concerning Government agencies.

Mrs. Rodman B. Montgomery heads the committee for the annual Mayfair Assemblies to be held on Thanksgiving Night and on Dec. 19 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza. The events are arranged for debutantes and their escorts, under the direction of Miss Clementine Miller.

Football had been foreign to this second classman, whose father, Brig. Gen. Branner P. Purdue, had been stationed at Anchorage, Alaska, and from which point the young man had received his appointment to the Military Academy.

FLYBALL, the kitten, was so named by Captain Stone, on whose plane he stowed away. Captain Stone, as adventurous a type as Flyball, let the kitten stay at the experimental station in the desert. In no time at all Flyball felt that he was in charge of the whole shooting match, including a mysterious huge rocket. His first flight on the rocket v,as unauthonTJed.
Accidents to American shipping in the year ended June 30 led to the loss of 330 lives and involved 2,048 ships, according to a report by the Coast Guard's Merchant Marine Council.

BUFFALO, Nov. 15 -- A guide for national and local action on matters affecting "the security and stability" of the American family was adopted today at the final session of the 1952 biennial meeting of the Family Service Association of America.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Finish the season's planting. Spring-flowering bulbs and lilies should go in the ground outdoors as soon as possible, and bulbs for forcing in pots indoors. Roses, deciduous shrubs and vines, rhubarb and asparagus may be planted this month but require ample water when set out and each week until the ground freezes this year.

WRITERS of teen-age historical fiction have not been quite so zealous in seeking out obscure corners of history for story material as have writers for adults. This fact alone gives a certain novelty and interest to Maxine Shore's "The Captive Princess." a story of the early Britons and their struggles against the legions of Imperial Rome.
Bolivia's ability to run her three recently nationalized tin mines was defended here yesterday by Dr. Victor Andrade, Bolivian Ambassador to the United States.

I SHOULD like to answer Mr. Emil Kun's letter about the Philharmonic - Symphony concerts in THE TIMES of Nov. 2. First of all, there has been no decline in the number of our subscribers. Rather, this season has shown an increase in subscriptions as well as in the sale of single tickets for the first three weeks.

WHEN the small, earnest brown bear, J. Walter Duffle Duff, came down off the top branch of the Christmas tree, Richard, after polite introductions, asked if he could do any tricks. Of course, Walt could.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 15 (UP) -Michigan marched from behind with a three-touchdown outburst today to knock Purdue out of the Big Ten lead with a 21-to-10 victory before 54,376 fans at Michigan Stadium.

If the bluejay were one of those migrants who stop in for only a few days each season, he probably would be known as an exotic bird of unusual beauty. Some jays do migrate a little way, but few places in their range are ever without them. The jays and the crows keep the winter landscape alive and lively.
A joining of the forces of nazism and communism in Germany in a move against democracy was foreseen yesterday by Rabbi Zev Zahavy of Congregation Zichron Ephraim, 163 East Sixty-seventh Street.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 15 -- The period of thirty days following the death of Israel's first President, Dr. Chaim Weizmann, during which the Knesset (Parliament) must select his successor is a time for taking stock of the situation of this four-and-a-half-year old country.

If Prof. Ambrose M. Richardson, an architect on the faculty of the University of Illinois, has his way the city of the future will be roofed by domes formed of plastic "pillows." Nobody will have to carry an umbrella, wear overshoes or shovel snow. When some adventurer returns from hiking in the open country he will boast of the brooks through which he splashed or the wind and slanting rain that buffeted him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -The Army under a new agreement with the Air Force, is beginning to build up its own specialized aviation unit to a total strength of about 2,200 helicopters and light planes.

HERE is an amiable little spoof that belongs high up on your shelf of children's ghost stories (friendly division). It all begins when the shade of Captain Apple has his nap interrupted as he sails through interstellar space on a friendly cloud.

THE annals of Narnia, which began with "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" and were continued in "Prince Caspian," have seemingly reached their conclusion in this Odyssey-like tale of a voyage to "the end of the world."

HARDY chrysanthemums aren't what they used to be -- they are remarkably better. Thousands of visitors who throng the chrysanthemum shows and exhibits each year must feel like tossing out all remaining thin - sprayed, old - fashioned varieties in favor of the strong - branching modern creations.

I SEE no reason to apologize for science fiction, whether intended for juvenile or adult readers. Stories of fantastic adventures in real or imaginary worlds have always been popular among all age groups and at all periods of time: the explorers of peculiar planets at the edge of the Galaxy are direct descendants of Odysseus and Sinbad.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 15 -- Wesleyan's eleven toppled Trinity College, 7 -- 6, today before 4,500 on rain-soaked Andrus Field.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States expressed deep concern today over what they viewed as a movement to divorce religion from education in the nation's schools.
LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The United States Air Force is taking direct action to combat reported bad feeling between some British civilians and United States airmen in Britain.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A substantial volume of military materiel is moving out of the nation's automobile factories, but few persons connected with the industry are prepared to say when defense output will reach its peak.
HOUSTON, Nov. 15 -- Halfback Ken Pridgeon scored two touch-downs and set up a third with his running and passing today as Houston throttled Baylor's high powered offense for a 28-to-6 upset victory.

NOT that most of our very young ones don't know this already, but Marc Simont makes it undeniably and delightfully clear that rabbits are more fun than people. "The Lovely Summer" is a rabbit's-eye view of a couple of city folk who move out to the woods and plant a vegetable patch, and a people's-eye view of a couple of rabbits who ought to know better than to plunder a garden.

Women who have long taken an active interest in the work of the Committee for the Rehabilitation of Crippled Children have arranged the annual card party in behalf of the organization for Tuesday in the main ballroom of the Pierre. Mrs. Anton L. Trunk, president of the beneficiary, heads the committee in charge of plans for the benefit and among her aides are Mrs. George W. Williams Jr. and Mrs. Gordon C. Forbes.
Six hold-ups, three of them in liquor stores, were staged in Brooklyn in a four-hour period last night. The total loot was $1,338.

FOR Ted and Sue, 10-year-old twins who lived on a farm, the Great American Dream (junior division) had come true. They now had a pony of their own -- and he was proving even more useful than their enterprising little brother Robby or Jemima, the ever-complaining duck.

A FRONTIER boy like Bill Cody learned to look after himself, and little Bill could aim and shoot his father's big gun very, very early. Living beside the Oregon Trail, he frolicked and hunted with friendly Kickapoo Indian children, and he watched the traders, and the covered wagon families, and the ox-wagon strings rolling past toward the setting sun.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -Veterans of the armed orees who have served since the outbreak of the Korean war are eligible for a second guaranteed, loan to buy homes and farms, the Veterans Administration sid today.

Goodwill tokens and amulets by the hundreds have been pouring into Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's temporary headquarters at the Commodore Hotel and his official residence as president of Columbia University at 60 Morningside Drive since the election.

SEVERAL months ago, a national magazine ran a story under the heading "Youth" and the subhead "Mother Is Bugged at Me." It concerned an 18-year-old California girl who had been picked up for smoking marijuana and wanted to talk about it. While a reporter took down her ideas in the uptempo language of "tea," someone snapped a picture.
TORONTO, Nov. 15 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks regained a tie for first place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 1, before 13,743 fans.

IT is always a pleasant surprise to find a sequel to a good story which doesn't copy the original pattern. This second story about Ronnie, Jill and the wonder-working black cat, Merlin, is more leisurely in tempo than "The 13th Is Magic," and where that was episodic, this is the single story of a search.

THE popular author of "Flamingo Road" and "Written on the Wind" has attempted a study of a subsidized All-American football player, both during and after his hour of glory. The theme is obscured by neither the glamour and suspense of actual gridiron scenes nor a tendency to expose college athletic professionalism.
The New York City Omnibus Corporation, operator of most of the bus lines in Manhattan, announced yesterday that it had filed with the Board of Estimate an application for a 15-cent fare.

DESPITE a certain rather cavalier attitude on the part of educators toward the alphabet, children still enjoy an ABC book if it is bright, amusing and rhythmic. It is a long time since we have had two such original examples as these.
NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 15 (AP) -Oklahoma chopped up Missouri's hopes for the Big Seven Conference football crown today, mixing wide-awake defensive play with a driving ground game for a 47-7 triumph.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -- With President Truman headed for retirement, Democratic Senators have devised a united "battle plan" that they said today should regain their Congressional majority in 1954 and recapture the White House in 1956.
