PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Further demands for economy in planning and executing the program of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization were heard today at the organization's general conference. They were made by Belgium and New Zealand, which warned that they could not contribute more than they were now.

An advertisement affecting a pending offering of industrial securities just published in THE NEW YORK TIMES and other Eastern newspapers may mark the introduction of significant new practices in the distribution of common stock.

Young women, including Mrs. Basil Goulandris and Mrs. Wing Williams, will participate in three tableaux of the pageant, "Fans and Fantasy," which will be a feature of the third annual Fan Ball for the benefit of the Children's Memorial Cancer Fund, Inc., to be held on Friday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

NONE of the many lost causes in the long course of English history is more unfortunate and pathetic than that of Lady Jane Grey, nine days a Queen. This pretty 16-year-old girl was the victim of political and religious forces and parental ambition.

Since I like to do justice to foreign languages, I write with reference, in Harry Gilroy's "Waksman and 10,000 Microbes" (Nov. 2), to the name of Dr. Waksman's house, "Villa Bobili" and the scientist's translation of the word "bobili" as grandmother in Russian. This is incorrect.

TWELVE - YEAR - OLD Pete Tillotson's home was 'way up at the end of rough Tug Hill Road, on the border of the Adirondacks, where even the school bus didn't climb. Pete was pretty lonesome sometimes until his father brought home the English setter pup, Corporal Bess.

ANY collection of medical writing that attempts to cover the dramatic events in medical science from the Hippocratic oath to the development of cortisone is subject to the personal tastes and preferences of the editor. Samuel Rapport and Helen Wright declare that after five years of preparation their manuscript was three times as long as the present book.

YEARS ago the Belgian-born French novelist Joseph-Henry coined the word "astronautics" to designate the science and art of voyaging from star to star. There was no such science or art even though, in imagination, Jules Verne had shot a luxuriously furnished, manned projectile to the moon and other fictitious travelers had visited distant stars and planets.
Clear, bright performances, with the maturity and experience that only years before the public can give, prevailed yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, where Jan Smeterlin gave a piano recital.

THE whole world seemed to explode on an April morning in 1906. The earthquake which started the Great Fire in San Francisco set atremble cities and towns for miles around. For Megan Dyke, who had just had a bad first day in a new city school, the disaster was a climax to a series of events which had recently shaken her little-girl's world.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Iowa's "injured" quarterback, Burt Britzmann, scored one touchdown and flipped two touchdown passes in a blistering second half attack which jolted favored Northwestern into the Big Ten cellar under a 39 -- 14 defeat, today.

THE author of "First Woman Doctor" has written with insight and sensitivity the biography of one of the important figures of the twentieth century -- Sigmund Freud. Her portrayal of Freud's lifelong struggles to bring to fruition and acceptance a new therapy, psychoanalysis, will stir the imagination and the hearts of young adult readers.
Ed McGuirk took his fourth straight title of the season when he paced his Brooklyn Prep teammates to victory yesterday in the Jesuit High Schools cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park.

THIS is a description of a storm in the country, in the city and at the seashore. A little boy first sees dark clouds approaching as he is lying in a field on a hot summer afternoon. When the lightning and thunder come he hurries to his mother to ask, "What's that?" Her answers allay his concern and together they watch the progress of the storm.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Freshman Fred Wyant threw touchdown passes to Dick Nicholson and Paul Bischoff in the final period today to lock up a 27-7 victory for West Virginia over Virginia Tech.

Fashion apparel buying for spring 1953 got off to a fast start in New York's wholesale markets last week. With Election Day behind them, retailers are concentrating on keeping current sales in line with the high level of consumer income to increase their volume, if possible, in the first quarter of 1953.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 15 -- City officials and representatives of the Norwalk Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution will meet Monday to try to resolve the controversy over the city's historic Town House on Mill Hill.
RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 15 -- The cost of avoiding school consolidation is high, a small North Carolina town has discovered.
UNTIL somebody comes back from a real trip to the Moon, or Mars -- or at least a space station -- about the best we space addicts can hope for is more books such as these two.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Most of Britain's sugar-bearing West Indian possessions scattered across the Caribbean Sea have agreed to federate, the Colonial Office announced here today.

ATHENS, Nov. 15 -- Washington is understood to feel, on the basis of official information it has been receiving, that internal security in volatile Greece and her political stability and economic prospects will be improved if the right-wing coalition of Field Marshal Alexander Papagos wins tomorrow's elections, above all if it gains a true parliamentary majority.

TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 16 (UP) -- A United States Air Force C-46 transport with sixteen passengers and four crew members aboard crashed off Korea's east coast last night, the Far East Air Forces reported today. It was the second Far East air disaster in two days.

IF you think Patience Little and Cleon Cottle had improbable adventures and if you imagine they could not have stowed away on a sailing ship, back in the Eighteen Eighties, it shows you don't know the State of Maine.

SAMUEL JOHNSON once explained why great men are often disappointing to meet "Uncommon parts," he said, "require uncommon opportunities for their exertion." Yet The Club to which he himself belonged was great just because its most distinguished members were exceptions to the rule and needed no special opportunities.

NAIVASHA, Rift Valley, Kenya, Nov. 13 -- An eminent witch doctor, known locally as the "Wizard of Oz," arrived today from the Kikuyu reservations to conduct cleansing ceremonies among Kikuyu workers on farms here owned by Europeans. It is expected that many who have unwillingly taken the oath of the terrorist Mau Mau society will require his services.

HOW does American cooking appear to the non-Americans in our midst? New York was the obvious place to pose this interesting question, especially when the General Assembly of the United Nations was in session.

MOVING back to her ancestral home after five years in Europe, Callie Prichard longs to be accepted by the group of teen-agers whose summer obsession is sailing. Her unusual experiences and luxurious surroundings set her apart.

The gas utility industry, with annual revenues of well over $2,000,000,000 is deriving great satisfaction from the sales this year of gas household appliances. Gas utilities, in their unceasing struggle to overhaul the $6,000,000,000-a-year electrical utility industry, look back with restrained satisfaction on the almost incredible recovery of gas appliances from the depths of the slump at the beginning of this year.

FROM Lisbon comes official word that Portugal is issuing 1-escudo red and 2.30e blue stamps for approximately the centenary of the birth of Francisco Gomes Teixeira (1851-1932), mathematician and astronomer, and four pictorial commemoratives for the centenary of the Ministry of Public Works.

THIS is the ever-popular story of the wild beast that likes people only to find that once he is outside the zoo his mere presence is enough to make people shinny trees, shriek in terror or run every which way. Friendly Homer never does find out what is wrong with people a problem much bigger than a tiger, obviously but he does solve his own dilemma with quick decision.

A QUIET story, full of wisdom and faith in the goodness of living, "A Place for Peter" continues the chronicle of farm life begun in "Mountain Born." Peter, now reaching adolescence and striving for independence, bitterly resents his father's refusal to grant him responsibilities worthy of his age and size.
Many young women are aiding in the arrangements for the dinner dance in behalf of the Big Brother Movement to be held on Thursday night in the St. Regis Roof.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 15 -- The Amherst College football team captured its first Little Three gold medal in ten years and scored its first victory over Williams since 1948 today on the strength of senior end Dick Catlett's educated toe. The score was 21 -- 19.
NOW available from Westminster is a work one is not likely to hear in a lifetime of operagoing, Berlioz' Les Troyens a Carthage (three disks).
Plastics officially have come of age, and the American consumer can expect a host of new products and improved versions of old ones.

AS a people accustomed to cutting our literary eye teeth on classics that have first been strained through the sieve of censorship, we develop affections that a whole lifetime of disillusionments cannot alter. What matter that the original "One Thousand and One Nights" is, practically speaking, unprintable?

KARELIA and the Ukraine, Siberia and the Altai of Central Asia are among the regions represented in this collection of little-known folktales. Although fragmentary, the stories have the robust humor and the repetitive pattern characteristic of folktales all over the world.

THE efforts of Northfield citizens to capture Joanna, a pet monkey, made the town the laughing stock of the county. The kids, notably Sleepy and Lover, set out to redeem the local reputation by winning the Little League championship with Joanna as mascot.

THE TIMES Magazine of Nov. 9 with its first Christmas gift advertisements reminded me again of the real meaning of Christmas. With so much suffering in the world, it seems that a better service to Christ's memory could be done than exchanging gifts among people who can get along perfectly well without them.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 15 -- German aspirations to independence and sovereignty have been wounded by a frontier incident involving French gendarmes and relations between the West German Federal Republic and France have deteriorated further.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 15 -- United States, British and French diplomats in both Israel and the Arab countries are now more hopeful regarding the prospects for an Israeli-Arab peace than they have been at any time since the hostilities of 1948-49.

New discoveries in the area of the mystery sanctuary of the "Great Gods" on the Greek Island of Samothrace were reported yesterday by Prof. Karl Lehmann of the New York University Institute of Fine Arts, director of the university's annual summer archaeological expedition to Samothrace. The island was colonized by Greece about 700 B. C.

The South African Appeals Court has rightly and wisely overruled Premier Malan's attempt to make a mere Parliamentary majority superior to the South African Constitution. The whole place of law in South Africa is at stake in this case and not merely, as might be supposed from some of the discussion in this country, the issue of racial segregation.

ATLANTA, Nov. 15 -- Two second-string backs, Pepper Rodgers and Dick Oretz, paired with regulars Billy Teas and Glenn Turner and a brilliant defense today to give Georgia Tech a squeaky 7-to-3 victory over unexpectedly strong Alabama.
WHAT is the greatest weakness of the "good" bridge player -- the player who knows what it is all about, but still does not aspire to a place among the top experts?

PROGRESS in the improvement of furnishings in hotels and motels was demonstrated last week at the Thirty-seventh National Hotel Exposition in Grand. Central Palace, attended by more than 100,000 executives of hotels and other institutions interested in the comfort of the transient wayfarer.

THESE six tales, beautifully retold by an American who lived in Norway as a child, are similar to stories we know already, but it is such fun to have white bears as pets and trolls where we used to have giants. "The Bewitched" is a perfectly charming "Puss in Boots"; "The Hen That Saved the World" is our old friend "Henny Penny"; "Why the Bear's Tail Is So Short," is well known.

CLAUDE, one of eighteen mice children, ignored his mother's warnings and came down from the attic to look for Switzerland. He found Swiss cheese, but that was in a trap. A second later Claude's tail was in the trap too, and his mother rescued him just in time.

James Mahoney paced his Iona College team-mates to the title in the third annual Small Metropolitan Colleges League cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. A record entry of fourteen teams and 103 competitors competed in the meet.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 -- Greek Lakes vessel operators are taking steps to eliminate the possibility of a manpower shortage next spring when shipping is resumed on the inland waters.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 15 -- Our government of the people has become one of government officials, a subcommittee of the House of Representatives charged today in a report that was particularly pointed in its criticism of certain Department of Justice procedures and the actions of one of its attorneys.

SPARKY is a lively little trolley car who is never quite content just whizzing back and forth along his daily route. His vivid imagination plus his love for adventure help make all sorts of exciting things happen. As a result, Sparky gets involved in trouble with the very excitable Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Notwithstanding the Election Day defeats and meager victories of the Democratic Presidential ticket in the South, the Southern Democrats are still a monolith of power in Congress and a measurable, if profoundly irritating, force even in the national Democratic party.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 15 -- Members of the Junior Auxiliary of the Paterson General Hospital will hold their annual luncheon and card party on Tuesday at the Alexander Hamilton Hotel here. Proceeds from the event will be used to purchase special equipment and supplementary comforts for patients of the hospital.

IT is seventy years or so since a stepfather decided to amuse his precocious stepson (an American child need I say?) by writing for him an adventure story. He also hoped to make a little money and his hopes have been justified. But as some preliminary verses make plain, Robert Louis Stevenson was not at all certain, even in that remote day, that the old magic would work: pirates, buried gold, castaways.

Judged by its natural advantages the Union of South Africa should be an Eden on earth. Its climate is pleasant. It has fertile fields and rich mineral and power resources. Its great coastal cities are thriving entrepots of world trade. Its borders are remote from potential aggressors.

FORT WORTH, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A partially blocked punt and an intercepted pass set up two Texas touchdowns in the last period and Billy Quinn and Dick Ochoa paced the Longhorns to a 14-7 victory over Texas Christian today. The victory gained for Texas the host spot in the Cotton Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The concern or disgruntlement on the faces of employes at the Capitol bears mute evidence of the change-over in control of Congress. In all, about 1,500 employes, all of them originally named through patronage, will be job-hunting after Jan. 3.

THIS absorbing British import tells the stories of a dozen inventors. The setbacks of Bell and Edison are made engagingly laughable; their achievements and those of Marconi and the Wright brothers are both human and dramatic.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- In an oak-paneled office with thick carpets and sound-proofed ceilings not far from Paris, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway likes occasionally to rise from his desk, stand before a huge rubber terrain map on a wall and tell selected visitors how strong the North Atlantic Treaty forces are -- and are not.

After an absence of two seasons from the repertoire, Wagner's "Lohengrin" was revived yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan, where it received its three-hundredth performance in that auditorium. The production was practically new in all of its aspects, and, with one exception, the principal roles were allotted to artists who had not sung them before with the company.

MARGARET E. BELL'S biography of Kit Carson, the celebrated guide and trapper, mercilessly reveals the gap between the generations. It is badly written, and to the average business man, or housewife, it is pretty dull. Kit Carson was a fast man with the beaver traps and the Apaches but Miss Bell's book does not amuse the adult who reads it aloud.

A further week of discussion in the General Assembly of the United Nations on the Korean truce proposals has not brought any sign of a change in fundamental positions. The issue that still represents an outright deadlock is that of the involuntary repatriation of prisoners.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 15 -- An uneasy quiet prevails in the recent riot areas -- Kimberley, East London and Port Elizabeth -- which are still heavily patrolled by armed police. The Minister of Justice, C. R. Swart, said last night that he had instructed the police not to wait until their men were killed or injured in riots before they fired.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., NOV. 15 -Long Island's No. 1 eleven defeated the New York Firsts, 2 to 0, in the feature contest of the New Atlantic sectional women's field hockey tournament which started at Adelphi College today with a dozen games.

Herb Hinman, Roosevelt harrier, scored an upset victory over Bob Lippemeier of Forest Hills yesterday and thereby captured the individual title in the Public Schools Athletic League city-wide cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park.

AS the father of three energetic, semi-literate children ranging in age from 8 to 13. I have gradually become aware of an accelerating trend in American children's book publishing. Mixed in with the trash from the comic-book stands that they bring home are a quantity of admirably written biographies of American statesmen, soldiers, explorers and scientists.

AN animal picture-rhyme-book, "Look!" uses the sure-fire turn-the-page-and-look technique so intriguing to tiny book-lovers. Though the rhymes are simple and ear-catching, the charm of the book lies in the yellow, brown and black animal drawings, which one 2-year-old at my side found lovable and realistic enough to stroke.

TURNING marsupial this month, the Book-of-the-Month Club has launched The Young Readers of America, a book club for boys and girls from, say, 7 or 8 up into the early teens. The way it works, the child subscribes in his own name, gets a sturdy bookshelf and fifty bookplates for joining, and turns the monthly dun ($1.50) over to papa.

SINCLAIR LEWIS was the Edith Wharton of the provincial American middle class not simply because he wrote about such people but because he was one of them, and Lewis' books, for all the satire, are most alive when he is representing them in their native habitat.

DURING the last twenty years Washington has supplanted New York as the real center of the nation. During the last decade it has also become the capital of the Free World. Soon a change of administration will take place here, and, since the decisions made in Washington are crucial it is worthwhile to consider the kind of city it is.

After years of planning, all the activities of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University will be concentrated this fall for the first time in a new building designed for that purpose. Administered as a cooperative enterprise by the Departments of History, Politics, Economics and Social Institutions, the school acts as a separate department of social studies for purposes of upper class concentration.

BEFORE the end of this week, Elliott Nugent will be represented simultaneously in two Broadway playhouses. On the stage of the Music Box he will, of course, be playing in the unusually successful revival of "The Male Animal," which he wrote with James Thurber.

BILL GORDON, who did so well for himself in "Start of the Trail," is back. Going home from college for the Christmas vacation Bill becomes involved with a stranger who is searching for a brother lost in the lumber camps of northern Maine.

PENNY ROSE WILDER is torn between love of her father and resentment at the ruin his neglect has wrought upon the fine farm and house he inherited from his grandfather. She longs for social acceptance, and is secretly in love with the young medical student who represents that acceptance.

"A HOG," as those famous advertisements said a few years ago, "can cross the country without changing trains, but you can't." Vacationists headed for the Southwest this winter will find, as we did, that there is almost inevitably a layover in Chicago, despite the few through coast-to-coast cars carried by some name trains.

FOR the hard-pressed parents who currently may be enduring the "why'' period in the lives of their children, Herman and Nina Schneider offer a lively bit of relief. The authors explore the puzzle: "What makes the new day come after the night?

IN this fourth of her "Play With - -" botanical series Millicent Selsam explores plant movements and suggests ways in which youngsters may observe certain easy-to-find examples. Miss Selsam is a sound naturalist, whether she is explaining how clover leaves fold up at night or how to tell time by flowers that open and close each day as regularly as the sun rises and sets.

THERE are many reasons why an intelligent man should never ever write for children. Of all professions for a man, it is socially the most awkward. You go to a party, and how do they introduce you? The hostess says, "Dr. Seuss, meet Henry J. Bronkman, Mr Bronkman manufactures automobiles, jet planes, battleships and bridges. Dr. Seuss * * * well, he writes the sweetest, dear, darlingest little whimsies for wee kiddies!"

An intended demonstration by irate automobile owners from the Sheepshead Bay-Nostrand limited-income housing projects in Brooklyn got a cool reception at Gracie Mansion yesterday from the Mayor, the police and the weather.

Saint-Saens' Symphony No. 3 for Organ and Piano was the major work of Arturo Toscanini's third program of the season with the N. B. C. Symphony late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. His reading of the thirty-five-minute work won him an ovation.

In the corridors of the United Nations last week, delegates conferred in sober, anxious groups. In the General Assembly auditorium, the speeches were studded with pleas against abandoning hope in the U. N. Throughout the gleaming new headquarters on New York's East River, the feeling was that the U. N. had reached one of the most critical junctures in its history.

LITTLE girls will be delighted to see a new book about charming Jennifer. At 11 she solves a major problem in her life and develops a sense of responsibility. The problem roughly was what to do with the bull calf she won in the previous book. The neighbors are aghast at a little girl having a bull for a pet, but not Jennifer; she loves Sir Prize dearly.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Nov. 15 (UP) -- Southern Methodist University overcame a 17-point deficit today to beat Arkansas, 27 to 17, with an aerial attack led by a substitute tailback before a homecoming crowd of 20,000.

FREIGHTERS to Miami and New Orleans via the Pan-Atlantic Steamship Corporation, a subsidiary of the Waterman Steamship Company, will be a solution this winter for many travelers who prefer ships to trains and planes.

CHURCHMAN, traveler, novelist and historian, Archbishop Mathew here turns his attention to those characteristics which set off the reign of the first Charles as a distinct "age" in English history. It is the period of the king's personal government which seems to him typically Caroline, and in a series of penetrating essays he explores various aspects of English life during the years 1629-1640.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 -- Francis W. White, president of the American Woolen Company, paid tribute today to New England textile workers for their cooperation during the year in accepting new work assignments in the struggle to meet outside competition. He warned management leaders, however, that they were "not moving fast enough" in reducing competitive cost differentials.

"THE story of the earth is everywhere, and everything tells its past." So write Herman and Nina Schneider in another of their clearly and accurately written science books for children. Each page of text, each easy experiment as well as each illustration helps the reader to understand the forces at work on earth -- forces that build up mountains, wear away valleys, build up the ocean floor, and carve out caves underground.

MARC BLITZSTEIN'S "Regina'' will be presented by the New York City Opera Company next spring. Robert Lewis, who directed the work when it was introduced on Broadway three years ago, will also be the stage director for the City Center production.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 15 -- Lehigh triumphed over Carnegie Tech, 26 -- 6, today in Taylor Stadium.

WITH a deceptively light touch Miriam Schlein sets young children to thinking about the nature of shapes. She explains the roundness of a wheel: "It can never be square or you will never be able to get anywhere!"

The judges officiating at the women's world chess championship challengers tournament, in progress at the Soviet Army Clubhouse in Moscow, faced a problem yesterday because of the continued illness of Fannie Heemskerk of The Netherlands. Four of Miss Heemskerk's games scheduled with Russian opponent, remain undecided, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.

THROUGHOUT their high school years, Cliff Gear and Bill Devlin had been friends and football team-mates. Bill, brilliant and self-assured, has come to dominate Cliff's life. make his decisions, protect his interests. The latter becomes increasingly disturbed at Bill's attitude.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 15 (UP) -Ohio State romped to a one-sided 27 to 7 victory over Illinois before 60,077 fans today, but the brightest star was Illini quarterback Tommy O'Connell, who set new Big Ten records in total offense and passing.

THIS is a blessed event. At last the United States Army has given birth to a top-grade writer. From the Korean war has come finally one thin volume of prose which is apt to be remembered long after we have forgotten the heroisms of Heartbreak Ridge and the frustrations of Panmunjom.

IN relentless narrative with no pause for exposition or mood-building, this first novel unfolds a tale of violent action and lustful activity against a background of New York in the early Nineteen Hundreds. Book One traces the down-hill career of Rocky Manera, gambler, tough guy, despoiler of women.

A LITTLE-KNOWN woman comes to life in this biography of Betsy Schuyler Hamilton, the quiet but powerful influence behind many of her famous husband's achievements. Daughter of the powerful Philip Schuyler and the equally prominent Catherine Van Rensselaer.

The search for two brothers, 13 and 9 years old, who fled their Bronx home Friday night after what is believed to have been the accidental killing of their 11-year-old sister, swung to New Jersey last night when a bicycle found near Fort Lee area was identified as the one the boys rode away on.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15 -- Rabbi Max Kirshblum of Brooklyn, newly-elected president of the Mizrachi Organization of America, tonight called upon Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion of Israel "to stop his cold war against American Zionism."

In Korea, where most things are either luxuries or ordeals, the Korean Naval Symphony Orchestra has aspects of both. Troops and civilians get so much pleasure out of the music of the sixty-piece group that it has been kept together with help and encouragement from the Korean Government and the United Nations.

WITH the same wistful affection for days-gone-by expressed in "The Little House." Miss Burton tells the story of a proud little cable car in San Francisco. For almost eighty years Maybelle and her sister cars have carried their passengers up and down the city's hilly streets.

The New York Rangers will oppose the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The contest will mark the first local appearance of the current season for the Canadian skaters.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 15 -- Brown University made its season a success by downing Harvard, 28 to 21, before a homecoming crowd of 12,000 at Brown Field today. The victory was the first football triumph by the Bruins over the Crimson since 1949.

THE present paucity of popular bands which record material of more than ephemeral musical interest has left such a vacuum in this area that even the industrious reissuing of recordings by bands of the Thirties and early Forties apparently can't fill it: The record companies are now looking beyond their own catalogues and digging up air checks of late evening broadcasts made by these bands a decade or so ago.

In her letter published in THE TIMES of Nov. 2 Mrs. Besse Howard rightly stressed the vital importance of achieving a Franco-German agreement on the Saar, lest this dispute wreck the hope of European unity. Her letter warns that it would be impossible for any French Government to either ratify the European army agreements or carry out the Sehuman plan "so long as there exists the possibility of the Scar's reannexation to Germany."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- The United States recommended today that the question of racial discrimination in South Africa be left to the "lively conscience" of the people there on the theory that the "power of world opinion" would accomplish "far more than abrupt and direct action" against the Government of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan.

OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 15 -- Mississippi's quarterback, Jimmy Lear, pitched a magnificent 42-yard fourth-period pass to upset mighty Maryland, 21 -- 14, and raise the Ole Miss Rebels into the national football limelight.

Development of a plastic dental filling material that does not need heat to harden and does not dissolve or waste away was described last week by Dr. George C. Paffenbarger, chief of the American Dental Association research staff at the National Bureau of Standards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- With twenty years of Democratic rule at an end, the opportunities for investigation are virtually unbounded as the Republicans take over in January, both in Congress and at the White House.

THE familiar ingredients are here: A short man fighting to make good at a tall man's game; a new college coach handicapped by a hostile athletic director and renegade son; a snob fraternity with tentacles that reach to the basketball court; and, to keep things abreast of the news, gamblers looking for a fix.

WHEN the Metropolitan Opera House opened for its first first-night in 1883, there was, by all contemporary accounts, quite a do. After all, the theatre had been built more for social than artistic reasons.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Hermond Lannung of Denmark told the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee today that a constitutional revision giving Greenland self-government was nearing completion. He spoke during a debate on factors that determine whether a country is or is not self-governing.

WHEN it's Today, Joan and Jackie yawn and stretch, and bounce right off on a string of imaginary adventures ranging from Punch and Judy to Captain Zizz's rocket trip to the moon. A double-decker bed can be just almost anything at all, and these lusty adventurers exploit it, too, for a stagecoach (the Indians lose and "are ashamed") and a pirate ship.

CAIRO, Nov. 15 -- The Arab States' note to the Bonn Government stating that they might be compelled to break off economic relations with the West if the German Parliament ratified the agreement to pay reparations to Israel for the Hitler regime's crimes against the Jews was published here tonight.

IT can be a problem for a little boy to be in an all-girl class. With perceptive understanding Charlotte Steiner turns this problem situation into a stimulating and suspenseful story. When the kindergarten girls plan a Doll Show, Pete solves his dilemma by turning up with his home-made egg-and-vegetable-head puppets.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 15 (UP) -- A hometown boy named Bill Leonard kept Penn State from being upset two weeks in a row today as the Nittany Lions squeaked past Rutgers, 7 -- 6.

THE autobiography of Joseph C. Grew is the story of four tumultuous decades in the foreign service of the United States. It is also a self-portrait of a man of warm loyalties, wide tolerance, great intellectual integrity and with profound respect for his task.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Seven players had a hand in the touchdown making here today as Virginia's Cavaliers crushed the University of Richmond Spiders, 49 to 0.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 15 -- Lloyd Mangrum of Niles, Ill., fired a sparkling 69 today to win the Melbourne division of the Ampol golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 281.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -- A House of Representatives committee announced today that it would start an investigation Tuesday of whether tax-exempt educational foundations had exerted "un-American and subversive" influences on public opinion.

EXPANSION of fall retail trade has not developed as expected, with erratic weather conditions chiefly blamed. Nation-wide sales decrease compared with a year ago have been reported by department stores the last two weeks, with only a few of the Federal Reserve districts showing increases.

At a recent meeting of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. speakers from all segments of the industry called for a promotional campaign to increase the sale of men suits. Various methods to stir the interest of the consumer were proposed and several speakers suggested that $1,000,000 be raised for the campaign.

THEATREGOERS who remember the hilarity and showmanship of "Light Up The Sky" and "Lady In The Dark" will not be prepared for the new look in Moss Hart's workmanship. For "The Climate of Eden," based on Edgar Mittelholzer's novel, "Shadows Move Among Them," is a serious drama with wistful overtones.

THIS outsize book ought to provide members of the nursery set with many happy moments. It is an olla podrida of stories, verses, a playlet, cartoons, a guessing game all concerned with animals, both wild and tame.

FEW organized sport groups have ever snowballed into national recognition as quickly as Little League Baseball. The league was organized by Carl Stotz in 1939 at Williamsport, Pa., with three teams. By 1951, the league had 3,333 teams from thirty-eight states and six foreign countries.

BILL BERGSON and his two best friends, Anders and Eva-Lotta, play out this story during a wonderful summer, in which they give an amateur circus, invent war games and chase three jewel thieves. Bill had often thought and dreamed of himself as Master Detective Bergson, but when he actually discovered stolen jewels it was the surprise and shock of his 13-year-old life.
LOUDONVILLE, Ohio., Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad's speedy Manhattan Limited and a ninety-seven-car freight train collided west of here today and five persons were hurt.

THE Florida jungle is full of weird sights and sounds, and full, too, of traps for the unwary and inexperienced. A little box of a boat steamed up one of her tropical rivers in the Eighteen Seventies with an odd assortment of crew and passengers, and floated right into one of the jungle's natural traps, and sprung it.

ONE can scarcely blame a circus baby like the littlest seal for being stage-struck. Naturally he was bored backstage and wanted to get in the act. Fie did, too, quite unannounced, and thereby created a furor -- but not exactly in the way which he had anticipated.

RAGS is more than a dog; in Philadelphia she is an institution. Seconds after the alarm bell rings for Engine Company 20, Rags can be seen riding right up front on the pumper. When dog-lover Elizabeth Morton first saw Rags in action she was intrigued, "interviewed" the shaggy brown and white mutt, and finally wrote this heart-warming story.

GENOA, Italy, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- Last-minute delays have held up the maiden voyage to New York of the new 30,000-ton Italian liner Andrea Doria. The vessel originally was to sail from Genoa for New York Dec. 14. She will not leave now till Jan. 14. Instead she will make a ten-day Mediterranean cruise.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 15 -- All but a handful of the nation's smaller colleges will finish the football season in the red -- because of television.

J. N. Breston, Robert Macfarlane, Willard Johnson and Donald Neil rose before oil men at Pennsylvania State College to describe laboratory experiments which they have been making for the last two years for the purpose of getting more oil from fields that have ceased to produce.

JOSE LIMON and his company will give their first New York season in several years next month when they will be presented in a series of six performances in the Juilliard Concert Hall, 120 Claremont Avenue, by the Juilliard School of Music for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the school's dance department.

DUTCH iris are rapidly becoming one of the Southwest's most important bulbs for fall planting. Garden supply dealers offer the bulbs from the first of September through the middle of December. Amateur gardeners find Dutch iris especially appealing, for their outstanding characteristics are ease of culture and a supply of delicately tinted flowers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15 -- Under a bleak, murky canopy that contrasted with the brilliant action of one of the most exciting of all Yale-Princeton football games, the Tiger defeated the Bulldog, 27 -- 21, today to win the Big Three championship for a record-breaking sixth successive time.

AMONG the growing company of Americans who have seen that the United States cannot survive on tolerable terms in a world whose majorities are half-starved and dispossessed, Stringfellow Barr has a leading place. Mr. Barr is president of the Foundation for World Government and author, among other books, of "Let's Join the Human Race." Few present the facts and challenge of inequality so well as he.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 -- The death of Philip Murray leaves the C. I. O. in a vulnerable position. Internal rivalries and the scarcity of fully developed talent make it the prey of all opposing forces, including the rival labor organizations.

The Brooklyn College soccer team won its fourth Metropolitan Conference championship in five years by holding City College, the defending champion, to a scoreless tie at Brooklyn College Field yesterday. The Kingsmen, undefeated and untied in four Conference games up to yesterday, won the title by virtue of City's early season tie with Queens College.

ACURSORY reading of Henry Simon's article "Records vs. Books," in your record supplement of Nov. 2, would seem to indicate that book publishers indeed lead a harried existence in contrast to the "unexciting," "safe," "boring," "sheltered" lives of record producers.

Assertions that this country is heading for a recession when the preparedness program is completed are challenged by Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly business review, released for publication today.

W. Paul Jones started out as an economist but ended up as one of the leaders in the air conditioning and refrigeration industry. Probably his very name, which carries back to early American history, impelled him to drive ahead in a field that grew up after World War I to take its place among the mature industries of the country.

TUBERCULOSIS one of the most important diseases that afflict the human race is primarily a social disease. The economic and social factors of the individual must be given as much consideration as his actual infection by tuberculosis.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 15 -- The signal along the banks of the Severn tonight was full steam ahead for Army, as Navy's football team swamped Columbia this afternoon, 28 to 0, on the mud-caked field of Thompson Stadium.

BEN PORTER, a fictional version of Dizzy Dean, has a white-hot fast ball, a playing brother, a bragging mouth and a sense of humor of the Gashouse Gang genre. In this story the Dodgers own Diz -- hat is, Ben -- and they put up with the jokes to get the fast ball.

THE bedding style of gardens -- low-growing flowering or colored-leaved plants set out to form a design -- has been displaced largely by more casual naturalistic plantings. A modest offshoot is still seen once in a while in the nasturtiums that ring a tree stump and the sedum at the base of a flagpole.

WAPITI -- an Indian name meaning "monarch of the high country" -- is a helpless baby elk, less than one hour old, when this story opens. Hiding in a thicket, he is found by a ravenous she-bear, and his story almost ends in chapter one.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Paul Giel tossed a 50-yard scoring pass and ran and passed to 57 yards of a 60-yard drive to the goal line today as Minnesota defeated Nebraska, 13 to 7, in a Big Seven - Big Ten interconference game.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 15 -- Maureen Connolly, the 18-year-old tennis queen from San Diego, Calif., found her game after photographers had been banished from the center court of the White City Stadium today and made her Australian tennis debut a successful one.

Several dinner parties will be given before the performance of "Dial M. for Murder," with Maurice Evans in the leading role, Thursday night at the Plymouth Theatre for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club. Mrs. Colley E. Williams heads the committee in charge of the arrangements, with Mrs. Donald Perkins and Mrs. James Butler as co-chairmen.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 15 -- Soviet opposition to Premier Stalin is more complex than most Americans realize and it will not displace the present Soviet regime in time of peace, an expert at the Russian Research Center of Harvard University declared today in a newly published book.

After Igor Buketoff finished his Carnegie Hall chores yesterday morning as conductor of the Young People's Concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony, he faced a much more arduous task in the form of an interview with a group of persistent, gimlet-eyed student editors from junior high schools here.

A rare Bloor Derby porcelain punch bowl, painted with hunting scenes and attributed to Cuthbert Lowton, about 1840, was sold to a private collector for $900 yesterday at an auction of art objects and furniture from Mrs. Joseph E. Davis of this city, Mrs. Herbert T. B. Jacquelin of Wilton, Conn., and Mrs. A. L. Zent.

THIS is an affectionately written yet frank biography of probably one of the most interesting men of the many unusual leaders who have come out of the British Labor party and the labor movement. It is a lively and absorbing narrative by Raymond Postgate, Mr. Lansbury's son-in-law, and for a long time his associate and co-worker.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 15 -- Jimmy Carruthers of Australia knocked out Vic Toweel of South Africa in 2 minutes 19 seconds of the first round tonight to win the world bantamweight championship.

OBVIOUSLY an old-fashioned character, the little cat in this story prefers a balloon to more modern ways of flight when he is trying to get away from a menacing horde of mice. His choice, however, gives him a chance to enjoy at his leisure the landscape beneath hin the smells and sounds that float up, the feel of the air.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 15 (UP) -- An Oregon University football team that had previously won only one game this year rose today to whip the crippled Stanford Indians, 21 -- 20.

ALICE and Albert, driven frantic by city noises, look for a peaceful place in the country, but finding peace and quiet even there wasn't as easy as they had thought. The birds and other little animals that were on the place before the city couple came resented their coming and let them know in appropriate language -- all loud.

HERE is another "First Book" that promises to be as instructive as previous titles in the series have been. The text deals with the importance of water: as a solvent, a traveler, and a regulator of temperature, as well as a source of power.

Fourteen business and financial executives have joined with Columbia University to form a council to develop company-supported employe education programs, Dr. Grayson Kirk, acting head of the university, announced yesterday.

AT 55 Lester Bowles Pearson, a mild-talking man who wears shell-rimmed glasses, bow ties and a rumpled look, has become President of the United Nations General Assembly, the Canadian best known to the rest of the world and the victim of a pleasantly intentioned but quite misleading caricature.

IT was almost a generation ago that Mary Poppins, that mysterious, tart-spoken English nanny first made an appearance. By this time she has taken on some of the aura of a classic figure, but she is essentially unchanged, even though she wears a new and almost stylish hat.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 15 -- Combat activity declined today in all sectors of the Tonkin war area. In the delta, to the south, rebel Vietminh forces did not renew their attacks against Phatdiem after having been repulsed yesterday in a major assault on the town.

Occasionally it happens that the familiar tourniquet is used to stop excessive bleeding when a leg or an arm is injured. When the tourniquet is used for a protracted period and when it is too tight, it can cut tissues, skin, muscles, blood vessels and nerves. The rare cases of paralysis that resulted have been attributed to the arrest of blood flow.

POOR Papa Pifflesniff. He had such trouble catering to the contrary whims of his seven little Pifflesniffs: Patsy, Peggy. Pam, Patrick, Percy, Paul and little Pim. Not to mention seven assorted pets, including Tired-out, the turtle. But if Papa Pifflesniff was too indulgent with his energetic family -- well, there was Mama Pifflesniff, who kept a stern lookout for health care and daily chore-doing.

Memories of the indispensable role of the Home Guard in the defense of the British islands give an emotional overtone to the current debate in the House of Commons on the scaling down of the new Home Guard. A plan to recruit 170,000 men for civilian defense, announced last February, has fallen down for lack of volunteers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- Fordham finally made it. Smashing away with a strong second-half attack, the Rams subdued Temple today by 33 to 6 and in so doing registered their first victory of the season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Following is the text of a statement, issued today by the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States at the close of their annual meeting here, signed in their names by the Administrative Board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference:

SOME fifty persons connected with the Greek National Theatre, mostly players, arrived in New York from Athens on Friday to keep a two-week engagement at the Mark Hellinger Theatre in New York. Their two plays, "Electra" and "Oedipus Tyrannus," both by the fifth century B. C. Greek general, playwright, and poet, Sophocles, are to be produced in the United States by Guthrie McClintic in association with the American National Theatre and Academy.
The voluntary hospitals in this city are preparing for their role in civil defense in the event that hostilities touch this major defense area. In attitude, they are gearing for possible emergencies.

WHAT child wouldn't adore a woman who hangs swings and trapezes from her living room ceiling and always wears overalls? The unusual Mrs. Pennywhistle proves as capricious as her kittens, Nibs and Nobs.

THERE is plenty of horse talk in this excellent story, and since it has obviously been written by one who understands horses, it will interest even the most knowing enthusiasts. A young South Dakota ranch girl saves the life of a half-starved 2-year-old, the orphaned colt of a splendid mare.

Lafayette High, the only unbeaten P. S. A. L. team in the city, ran its winning streak to six by defeating Brooklyn Tech, 26 -- 12, at Lincoln Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. The score was the lowest Lafayette has made this season. Tech was the first school to score more than one touchdown against Lafayette this season.

AS the successive volumes of Theodore Roosevelt's letters appear, it becomes increasingly evident that he belongs among the most readable of letter writers. His are, as all good letters must be, the spontaneous reflection of a personality.

Most of the nation's mentally ill are surrounded by "an invisible wall of isolation" that shuts them off from adequate treatment and conceals true conditions from an uninformed public, Dr. George S. Stevenson, medical director of the National Association for Mental Health, declared last week.

MONTREAL, Nov. 15 (UP) -Elmer Lach tipped in two deflection goals tonight and Gerry McNeil turned in his second shut-out of the season as the Montreal Canadiens downed the Boston Bruins, 2 -- 0, before 14,475 fans at the Forum.

JACK LAVELLE, the stylish-stout scout of the Football Giants and free-for-all raconteur, likes to tell the tale of the gridiron recruiting agent who returned from a long trip and reported to his boss.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 15 -The United States Merchant Marine Academy and Adelphi College battled to a scoreless tie today in the fifth renewal of their series. It was their first meeting since 1950 and the first deadlock.

WITH his usual lively style Geoffrey Trease brings Athens alive for young people much as he did the Elizabethan era in "Cue for Treason." In this tale young Alexis' thirst for knowledge brings him to Socrates and his circle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Representatives of both the Bituminous Coal Operators Association and the United Mine Workers of America were reported today to be prepared, reluctantly, to appear Monday at an open hearing of the Economic Stabilization Agency.
Another foreign source of iron ore for the expanding steel industry of the United States has just been opened in the Dominican Republic.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Nov. 15 -- French-led forces this week took a giant stride forward in their counter-offensive against the Communist Vietminh troops in the main Tonkin theatre of the Indo-China war.

Dr. Bela Schick, world-renowned pediatrician, discoverer of the Schick test for diphtheria and a pioneer in the movement for universal immunization, will be honored next Sunday night at a dinner to be given by the Yeshiva University medical college campaign committee.

TRENCHERMEN of the New York region have been hearing reports of late that there is an oyster shortage. Where the Long Island and Connecticut littoral once teemed with these lethargic beasts -- which, however, according to the great scientist Huxley are actually "more complicated than a watch" -- this is no longer so true.

THE steady improvement of Mexican highways is bringing into that country an increasing number of American motorists, who busily tour Mexico and then drive home again. Not many of them realize that they can press on to the south, exploring the lands below Mexico along the Pan American Highway.

In "Challenge to the U. N.-and the U. S." (Oct. 26) Thomas J. Hamilton states that the first session of the General Assembly found U. N. delegates in low spirits. He adds, "They were worried about the obvious decline in the prestige of the organization in the United States.

Ten-years ago any serious study of contemporary writing would have had to consider James T. Farrell as a novelist, although his talent is that of the great dissenters and it is as a dissenter that his name will live. When he was still a young man he took on and overcame the opposition of the most powerful organizations of the Right and Left extremes.

BY taking a little boy with a juicy mud pie and a mischievous dog and cat and setting them loose on the road to a fair, Margot Austin again comes up with a combination of fun and fantasy that can't miss.

THE romance, excitement and rigors of Pacific whaling days are vividly portrayed in this fast-moving tale of adventure in the Far North. Cody Dawson, shipping as cabin boy on the motor whaler Balena, soon discovers that life in the Arctic can present problems with which the average young Californian landlubber has never had to cope.

TOKYO, Nov. 15 -- Long-armed, hard-hitting Yoshio Shirai, Japan's first world boxing champion, battered aging Dado Marino into retirement tonight in a successful fifteen-round defense of the flyweight crown he won from Marino last May.

United Cerebral Palsy and its affiliates raised $4,062,143 in the last fiscal year, nearly twice as much as the previous high of $2,133,000 set a year ago, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, announced today that he would discuss budget-cutting and inauguration plans in New York Wednesday with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect.

MUCH has been written about the War of the Theatres and, recently, about the changes in manner and matter of Shakespeare's plays after he began to write for the fashionable audiences of the private house in Blackfriars as well as for the popular audiences of the Globe.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 15 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru took a significantly conciliatory tone toward Pakistan today in a spirited debate in the House of the People, the lower chamber of the Indian Parliament, on recent migrations between the two countries.
Transportation, like food, is a vital link in the economic lifeline of any nation.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 (AP) -Gaining his second stakes victory in eight days, Mrs. E. K. Weil's Ken won the $20,00O-added Exterminator at Pimlico today as the Maryland Jockey Club track concluded its highly successful meeting.

THE Woover, an animal with fur like a cat's, striped lemon and cinnamon and whiskers two feet long which express his every mood, shows up in the backyard of a family where the three children are always two against one. The Woover, a tactful animal, always makes it two against two, thus eliminating many rows.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 15 -- Officials of Danbury Hospital took the offensive today in the fight over the suspension of two physicians by accusing the medical staff of refusing to cooperate in efforts to settle the controversy.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- The six Swiss mountain-climbers who set out nine weeks ago to be the first to conquer Mount Everest were reported on their way back from the world's highest mountain today, but sources in touch with the expedition were unable to say whether any had reached the top.

WHEN Hobie Yates was old enough to have his own horse it didn't take him long to make up his mind. The little white horse of his choice was small, but "smart as a spur." When the ranch hands teased the runt because of his size the yearling managed to get even in the most ingenious and surprising ways, thus earning the name of "Even Steven."

New processes and materials and ways of using them are reducing the cost of military aircraft despite fantastic increases in their weight and complexity and almost equal increases in the cost of labor and materials.
ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Without completing a single forward pass, Cornell's football team defeated Dartmouth, 13 -- 7, before 14,000 as it closed its home season on Schoellkopf Field today.

HARTFORD, Nov. 15 -- A contest has begun among leading Republican legislators in Connecticut over party leadership in the General Assembly, which opens a five-month session in January under complete control of the Republicans for the first time since 1947.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Before the astonished eyes of visitors, crush barriers and grandstands for the coronation next June are beginning to appear in London's thoroughfares.

Ten additions to the list of scientific areas in Wisconsin have been announced by Prof John T. Curtis of the University of Wisconsin, chairman of the State Board for Preservation of Scientific Areas. A scientific area is one which is about what it was before the coming of the white man.

MOST of the large record manufacturers, it seems, have recognized that the standard Christmas carols have been recorded almost to death. Thus in their new releases for the Christmas trade one finds that, besides being far-sighted enough to get their records out early, they have been perspicacious enough to work for novelty.

WASHINGTON -- The Republican march on Washington has already begun, at least as far as this city's hotel managers are concerned. They are being flooded by requests from all over the United States for reservations for accommodations during inaugural week, which begins Jan. 18.

Although its political activity gets more publicity, the United Nations' larger, basic interest is human welfare, Dr. Benjamin Cohen, Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations, told 250 settlement workers yesterday at the Henry Street Settlement auditorium, 301 Henry Street.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 15 -- Congressman Robert Crosser's political obituary is back in the "hold" file.
DETROIT, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Americans probably lose enough time because of poor traffic conditions to provide an extra two weeks' vacation each year.

TOKYO, Nov. 15 -- Foreign and domestic issues are now solidifying in the path of the conservative Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida, re-elected by a narrow margin last month, and promise it rough sledding when the Diet resumes its session next week.

For some time educators have been concerned at the growing emphasis placed on research in the physical sciences at the expense of the humanities or liberal arts. Millions of dollars are allocated annually for practical research projects but comparatively little for "general education" purposes.

THE "independent" in Claude Fuess' title is something of a pun. He prefers to call such schools as Andover -- which he stoutly served for the forty years of 1908 to 1948, the last fifteen as headmaster -- "independent" rather than to use the more common word "private."

Traditionally, the Boston Symphony Orchestra has been a masculine stronghold. But this season, for the first time, it has a woman in a first desk position. Her name is Doriot Anthony. She's the first flutist and yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall Charles Munch saw that she had a good introduction to the New York subscribers.
LONG BEACH, L. I., Nov. 15 -- Long Beach announced plans this week to make itself a year-round convention city. Two committees have been formed to advance the program.

The fashion openings in the wholesale market here last week attracted many buyers and an increase of 5 per cent in sales over last spring is expected on ready-to-wear items, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

JANET LEE arrived at Green Valley, N. H., all set to spend a miserable summer. The prospect of working as a waitress in a guest house was bad enough for 16-year-old Janet, whose every summer had been spent lazying on a Cape Cod beach.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 15 -- Though crossing midfield only twice under its own power, Michigan State made good on three of seven scoring opportunities presented by the ball-hawking alertness of its hard-hitting defensive platoon to defeat Notre Dame. 21 -- 3, before a record Mackin Field crowd of 52,472 today.

WHILE waiting with his family on the Kansas-Oklahoma border for the Cherokee Strip run, young David made a friend -- a stray horse. When the eventful day came it was David who made the run on Cherokee Bill and staked the claim.

United States Attorney Myles J. Lane, who was mentioned in testimony before the State Crime Commission as having met Thomas (Three Finger Brown) Luchese socially, announced last night that any evidence of Federal law violation by Luchese would be presented to a special rackets grand jury.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The National Council for Historic Sites and Buildings, a private, nonprofit organization formed in 1947, voted yesterday to merge into the National Trust for Historic Preservation, a government agency having similar objectives.

NEWARK, Nov. 15 -- Operations today at the airport here, which was reopened for full-scale activity one minute after midnight, with the new $9,000,000 instrument-landing runway in use, moved slowly toward normal.

WAKE FOREST, N. C., Nov. 15 (AP) -Duke stormed for two first half touchdowns and fought off a desperate last-half attack to defeat Wake Forest, 14 -- 7, today and take over the Southern Conference leadership.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -San Francisco became aware this week that a local concern, virtually unknown in its home town, has achieved international repute.

New York's 197-day horse-racing season ended yesterday at Jamaica, where 40,602 still hopeful winner seekers gathered on a gray, misty, drizzly afternoon for their final fling at legal betting until next April. The last fling was a big one. When the final $2 flip had been recorded on the tote board, on the 1,576th race of the year, it brought the total betting for the day to $3,537,177.
NEWARK, Del., Nov. 15 -Delaware eked out a 13-to-12 victory over Lafayette today as Capt. Paul Mueller's educated toe spelled the difference between victory and defeat.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 15 -- W. H. Gibson Bradfield of Barnesville, Ohio. who over the past score of years has whizzed around race ovals in every kind of a speed boat, has been re-elected for a second term as president of the American Power Boat Association.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Millionairess," with Katharine Hepburn in the leading role, tomorow night at the Shubert Theatre. Mrs. Clifford D. Mallory Jr. heads the patroness committee for the event, and Miss Augusta de Peyster is co-chairman.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Tulane's Green Wave, using the talents of Pete Clement, Max McGee and Roy Bailey, battled from behind in the last half today for a 16-7 homecoming victory over Vanderbilt.

IF Homer makes the Trojan Expedition the greatest and most heroic war of history, Eyvind Johnson makes the decade following, when Odysseus was wandering home, an almost proportionate post-war depression.

CALAMITY struck in triplicate for Penny. Her family's seashore vacation was postponed when her brother Peter caught the measles, she was sent to stern-faced Great-Aunt Amelia's during the quarantine, and her dog Ginger was not permitted to accompany her.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Visions of a bowl invitation glowed brighter for the Pittsburgh Panthers today when they routed North Carolina State, 48 -- 6, with sheer ground power and "economy'' passing for their sixth victory.

The New York Public Library's weekly art lecture on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. in the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building will be on "Stage Design Today." Howard Bay, designer for stage and films, will be the lecturer.

A PROFESSOR who lectures on a natural science, such as chemistry or physics, is concerned with the universe, though you would never know it to listen to him. He tears pieces of the universe apart if he is a chemist, explains that the bits are composed of atoms and how the atoms are combined into molecules that we call water or sulphuric acid.

The last time Harry S. Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower met was Jun 2, in the Rose Garden of the White House. Cabinet officers, NATO representatives and Mrs. Eisenhower stood by Mr. Truman pinned on the General a fourth oak leaf cluster for his Distinguished Service Medal.
ESTABLISHMENT of the TV-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation may prove to be one of television's most exciting and important events since the introduction of commercial video.

BRITISH studios have just emerged from one of the most fantastic episodes this industry of fantasy has ever known. Curiously unpublicized here, a rash of "token strikes" broke out, disrupting (to say nothing of adding to the cost of) every film in the making and pushing producers, directors, cameramen and players to the never-far-off edge of nervous distraction.

TOMORROW begins "New York Philharmonic-Symphony Week," according to the edict of Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri. Every New Yorker, the Mayor has announced, should "be aware of the part the Philharmonic has played in the musical life and history of this city." The week, it is hoped, will also help raise $150,000 for the Philharmonic's annual deficit.

The annual Parish fair of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Resurrection will be held at the church, 115 East Seventy-fourth Street, on Saturday afternoon. Mrs. K. George Faulk, general chairman of the committee, will have charge of the various divertisements.

The death of Abe Feller, General Counsel of the United Nations, is far more than a shattering wrench to his friends and those who shared the goals to which he dedicated his formidable energies and talents.

Construction in atomic-powered merchant ship in about ten years in radical changes in ship design within twenty-five years were predicted last week by William E. Blewett Jr., executive vice president of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock company.

RALPH J. BUNCHE'S life is the kind of success story Americans like. To the childhood hardships of hand-to-mouth poverty and the shadows of back streets was added the early sorrow of his parents' deaths Yet even as a young boy his brilliance was recognized.

IN 1654 about twenty-three Sephardic Jews "reached the end of the inhabited earth called New Holland" and the following year petitioned for permission to purchase a burying ground, thus showing that "they intended to remain in this part of the New World and throw in their lot with the new Colony."

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 15(AP) -- Dr. George D. Stoddard, president of the University of Illinois, today ordered the university staff to drop all studies and use of Krebiozen, the controversial cancer drug.

FORT BELVOIR, Va., Nov. 15 -- Fifty South Korean Army officers, enthusiastic and eager to learn, completed yesterday the second week of a combat engineers' course. If the Army Engineer Corps instructors stand up under the pace set by their students, the Republic of Korea officers will be back home pitting their new-found skills against the Communists in about five months.

As a writer and producer of children's records for the last fourteen years, and as director of Columbia Records Children's Department, I take issue with Maria. Cimino's comments in "Children's Disks -- What's Wrong," an article that appeared in your recent record supplement.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 14 -- Hasso yon Manteuffel, one of Wehrmacht's crack Panzer generals in World War II and a recent arrival in German politics, criticized the United States strategic plans for Europe today and suggested that the twelve divisions West Germany would contribute to the European army might not be sufficient for defense.

THOUGH the City Ballet has postponed its originally scheduled premiere of the Balanchine-Hindemith "Metamorphoses" until next week, it has several compensations to offer in the way of returning personnel.

THE TIMES recently carried an account of Mr. Stokowski's effort to bring about a better hearing for the contemporary American composer. Mr. Stokowski has been asking himself certain questions as to why the programs of American symphony orchestras devote so little attention to new American music, why conductors don't play it, and why the general public shows so little interest in contemporary symphonic music.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 15 -- A problem that by now should be familiar, although it is patently unwelcome, presented itself for the consideration of the Government of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer this week. It is the German neo-Nazis, their present and future strength in the political life of West Germany and their relationship with the Government of a democratic Germany.

With the country's population aging to the extent that it may include 63,000,000 persons over 45 years old within the next quarter of a century, drastic revisions in planning employment for the older worker, as well as in caring for his infirmities, are under way.

TOKYO. INFANTRYMEN of the Republic of Korea, charging again and again into some of the heaviest Chinese artillery fire of the war, are winning a new reputation for physical toughness and moral courage. From White Horse Mountain, Triangle Hill and Sniper Ridge, the reports of United Nations officers are that the ROKs are fighting most creditably, even though they may lack some of the polish of Western troops.

BOYS who will be carrying draft cards in another few years will find in these four little books a grim but informative catalogue of the deadly machines they will soon be using -- and facing. Parents, and all the rest of us, may look upon these things with dismay, but they are very real here in 1952.

EVELYN WAUGH has blandly suggested that the literature most typical of present-day culture in the United States is the detective story. Others feel it is the Western. Our abiding devotion to the latter seems to stem from drives nearer the surface and a good deal healthier than those of the devotees of Mickey Spillane and such.
BABAR will be 21 this Christmas, and I would like to tell you his story.
The fifth annual benefit concert for the Manhattanville Neighborhood Center will be held in Town Hall on Thursday under the sponsorship of eleven institutions located in the Morningside Heights area.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra, which gives its second concert next Tuesday night in this city, does so in the year which is the fiftieth of its incorporation as the orchestral society that it is today and fifty-two years and two days from the time of its first concert on Nov. 16, 1900.

Capt. Harry J. Parker, chief surveyor of the New York Board of Underwriters, was elected commodore of the Rudder Club for 1953 at a dinner meeting in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, last week. He succeeds Capt. Walter Herzer, vice president of the National Association of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., who was named to the board of governors.

IT would be interesting to find out what the Comrades will make of "The Lumberyard and Mrs. Barrie," Jane Barrie's account of her experiences in her husband's lumber business. Will they decide that American capitalism is on its last, tottering legs?

A LIKE in style and format, these books are planned for parents and children to read together. They are set in two sizes of type. The publishers indicate that: "The large type pages can be read by children as young as 7 or 8 years; the more detailed text, in smaller type, is for adults who are using the book with children and for young people who are better readers."

WHILE one misanthropic press agent goes around these days threatening to expose some of his experiences in a book called "Press Agents Are Nicer Than People," two other members of the clan this week were preparing to fatten the Broadway list of producers and thereby become employers of press agents.

GIAN-CARLO MENOTTI'S opera has won acclaim and awards; there will be productions this year, and, no doubt, for many years to come. Frances Frost, using the dialogue by Menotti, has told the narrative simply and unobtrusively.

ALL the holidays essential to the school program are represented by stories or poems in this collection, not excluding that popular newcomer. United Nations Day The inclusion of religious festivals, particularly those celebrated in the Jewish faith, widens the book's scope and usefulness.

THIS remarkably convincing story of the South African veld is by a woman who has never been to Africa. Mrs. Mirsky's interest in primitive societies led her to make friends with Zulu students and teachers whom she met in her travels and from whom she gathered material for this book.

STARTLED by the spectacle of grown people looking for birds in trees, the editor of this analytical journal requires an explanation. Why do people, who are otherwise blameless, inconvenience themselves by searching the beaches and countryside for birds? What the editor probably is asking is.

WHILE both of these books deal with the origin of life. the emphasis in one is on the origin of animal life and in the other on the origin and growth of the human being. "All About Eggs" provides excellent natural-science material to use with children from nursery school through the elementary grades.

Seeing stars is all in a night's work for five amateur astronomers at Hunter College. The one man and four women students, all preparing to teach in high school, are studying astronomy as part of the Fifth Year Teacher Training Program.

WHAT John Dickson Carr calls the "fair-play duel of wits between reader and writer" is -- to my mind at least, -- one of the noblest and most enjoyable pursuits in which either reader or writer can indulge; and it's doubtful that even Ellery Queen or Agatha Christie h ever excelled Mr. Carr's virtuosity in that pursuit.

MARIO PEI, associate professor of romance philology at Columbia, has written another brilliant popular book on language. His "Story of English," like his "Story of Language" before it, is an engrossing narrative -- a clear, interesting account of the development of a great language, from small, tribal Anglo-Saxon to large, cosmopolitan English.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 -- The executive board of the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., designated David J. McDonald today "to assume the duties and powers of acting president" until the regular election of officers by referendum on Feb. 10.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Four Cabinet Minister belonging to the Hungarian Workers (Communist) party and one member of the party's Central Committee were advanced today to Vice Premierships in a shake-up of Premier Matyas Rakosi's Government.

YONKERS, Nov. 15 -- Paige H. West's Paige Direct, a 5-year-old horse by Billy Direct, handled by Alan Myer, staged a stretch drive to win the $4,000 Bear Mountain pacing feature before 15,055 fans as the 1952 metropolitan harness racing season closed at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 16 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,453, for Saturday's activities:

THOUGH it can no longer be labeled the Dark Continent, Africa remains a mystery for many readers today, regardless of age groups. This picture-geography will do a great deal to dispel that mystery -- and, though the emphasis is on the maps rather than the people who populate them, the basic facts are there.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel A. B. Mercer, an Episcopal minister, retired college professor, and authority on hieroglyphics and cuneiform languages, sailed last week from New York on the Cunard liner Media for his twelfth visit to Egypt's ancient pyramids, temples and tombs.

VIENNA, Nov. 15 -- The Austrian Government soon will invite a committee of banking experts, headed by an American, to investigate the Austrian banking system, with particular reference to the Creditanstalt and the Laenderbank, its two big nationalized commercial banks.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 15 -- Walter Williams mentioned as a candidate for Secretary of Commerce in the Cabinet of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, gave the Presidentelect a hopeful picture today of a peacetime economy that would bring prosperity and a higher standard of living.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Nov. 15 -- As part of its duty to plan the complete defense of Western Europe, Supreme Allied Headquarters is preparing a medical training program weighed against the possibility that some day the Russians might resort to atomic, bacteriological or chemical warfare.

Blood instead of money was deposited yesterday at the Brevoort Savings Bank, 1281 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, as residents of .the borouffh'g edford-Stuyvesant section contributed 273 pints of the lifesaving fluid to the Red Cross Blood Program. Rainy weather slowed up the eollectlon, to the disappointment of Richard A, Brennan, president 0i the bank, and other religious and community leaders who were interested in the program.

Advocates of the proposal that self-employed persons be granted tax exemption by the Government on contributions made by them into pension funds feel confident Congress will act more favorably on their program next year than it has previously.

At last week's meeting of the Southern Medical Association in Miami, Fla., Dr. Tom Spies of the University of Cincinnati pleaded for a new concept of medicine. Like others before him, he made the point that "we are what we eat," which means that more attention ought to be paid to the chemistry of disease.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The most significant thing about this post-election season is that after nearly half a century of talk -much of it abstract and without much relevance to the American system -- about how to effect an "orderly transfer of the public business" from an outgoing to an incoming Administration, Mr. Truman and General Eisenhower are doing something about it.

WINTER winds blow, the world has snow, and what animals and children do then concerns the little boys of these two books. The same answers are provided in quite different spirits. Grandfather, in "Go With the Sun." shows Peter the birds and fish and butterflies that follow the sun, the creatures that find warm, safe places, and the snowshoe rabbit who puts on a white coat.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 15 -- The Gregory Club of New Jersey will hold its Chrysanthemum Ball next Saturday evening at the Montclair Golf Club.

"I AM only one mother among the mothers from all over the world who feel the remoteness of our children from our past," writes Olga Zhigalova. From earliest years she had wanted to write a novel of her life, but she wrote it only in her dreams.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 -- Even without the services of their ace, Harry Agganis, the Boston University Terriers were too much for N. Y. U. on this unusually mild afternoon at Fenway Park. The home team defeated the Violet, 14 -- 7, before 5,063 fans.

THIS story from Russia is set in a country village immediately after World War II. It focuses on two orphaned children, 10 and 12, who live by themselves on the edge of a great swamp. Anna and Peterkin go in search of wild cranberries and find not only the fruit they are seeking but adventure and even the path to wisdom. book are pleasantly reminiscent of Selma Lagerlof.

The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., and the Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., yesterday announced the end of a six-week strike at six Sylvania plants. A 5 per cent pay rise was granted.

TENAFLY, N. J. -- Motorists whizzing along the highway between Tenafly and Tappan, N. Y., last Sunday in their modern automobiles were convinced the good old days had already come back. For there were nine vintage automobiles -- including a 1910 Cadillac, a 1913 Renault, a Locomobile and an old Pierce Arrow -- chugging along in procession.
