The following is with reference to the excellent column by C. L. Sulzberger appearing Nov. 2. Mr. Sulzberger mentions the problems of foreign aid facing the new President. He mentions two studies being prepared by the Mutual Security Administration and another by O. E. E. C.

AN intemperate, sometimes wrong-headed but always fascinating book is this new study of the perennially absorbing Irish writer. St. John Ervine, known to America for his play, "John Ferguson," qualifies his "Oscar Wilde" as a present-day appraisal.

WHEN he comes to New York City where his father has a new job, Tom Briggs misses the friendliness of his little midwestern smalltown high school circle. His home is a tenement in a poverty - stricken neighborhood; school is big, noisy and impersonal.

FEW artists have elicited more diverse and even contradictory appraisals of their work than Ingres. In his own time he was labeled classicist, romanticist and realist by turns. A century later one American writer whose opinions are perhaps more violent than subtle dismisses Ingres cavalierly and talks of his senile sensuality, while another stresses the purity of the artist's absorption in his drawing of the nude and gives him high rank.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Leonard Greenburg, executive director of the Division of Industrial Hygiene and Safety Standards of the New York State Department of Labor, as the first Commissioner of the city's new Department of Air Pollution Control at an annual salary of $17,500.

The successful Presidential candidate and his worthy opponent, recuperating last week from the effects of the most arduous campaign in American annals, may have found occasion to regret our changing political folkways which once forbade Presidential candidates to appeal directly to the people.

DESCRIBING the picture story as "good discipline photography" because it calls for careful planning and execution of a specific idea, Arthur Rothstein, chief photographer for Look Magazine, last week gave the Village Camera Club a few practical pointers on how to shoot a picture series to tell a story.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 15 -- The smaller countries of Western Europe, still short of many vitally needed items of modern military equipment, have established an informal barter and borrow system to provide temporary relief for their deficiencies.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 15 (UP) -- Electronics engineers today called off a strike scheduled for Monday at the Savannah River hydrogen bomb plant after the National Labor Relations Board promised to investigate the dismissal of six men.

Some of New York University's students who are preparing for mid-semester examinations this week are wishing they had paid more attention to the advice offered in a pocket-size booklet handed to them at freshman orientation.

ONE of television's dramatic shows has worked out a way of being unique and different from its legion of video counterparts: it does not present crime or mystery plays. Neither does it use scripts adapted from other works, depending on original plays only.

FREDDY the pig, most distinguished of the talking animals on Mr. Bean's New England farm, has added a new talent to his repertoire. Already accomplished as a magician, detective, versifier, cowboy and banker, Freddy has now learned to fly a plane.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Britain's reply to the questionnaire of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization regarding defense efforts for next year is understood to adopt the thesis that a stretch-out is necessary, and that the 1953 program should be much less than that tentatively foreseen when the 1952 program was fixed.

A panel of six school youngsters appearing on the New York Times Youth Forum agreed unanimously yesterday that regular allowances were the best way to provide children with spending money and to create good habits such as thrift.

The Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton conducted the first service in the complete edifice of the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway, yesterday morning. Six hundred persons were present.
